column2: RIO DE JANEIRO -- Congress is now engaged in creating the Brazilian Petroleum Corporation, better known as the Petrobraz, whose purpose is to trade in national oil that is still in the earth.

An agreement to end the six-day strike of three small International Longshoremen Association locals against the American Weightmasters Association was reached early this morning, it was announced by John A. Burke, Commissioner of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service.

The Heyden Chemical Corporation and the Monsanto Chemical Company have entered into an agreement to build a methanol plant adjoining Monsanto's new acetylene facilities in Texas City, Tex., it was revealed yesterday by Simon Askin, president of Heyden, and Joseph R. Mares, general manager of Monsanto's Texas operations.

BALBOA HEIGHTS, C. Z. -- All records for traffic through the Panama Canal were broken in 1952. The total number of seagoing merchant ships passing through the Canal for the first eleven months exceeded by 562 ships the total for the full 1951 calendar year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- President Truman lifted two small blond sisters to his desk today and held hands with them while they enlisted him in the 1953 March of Dimes campaign against infantile paralysis.

SAN JUAN, P. R. -- Total bank deposits in Puerto Rico, including those of the Government Development Bank, rose from $291,739,000 on June 30, 1951, to $292,448,831 on June 30, 1952, according to a report by Milton C. Taylor, Assistant Director, Office of Research and Statistics of the Treasury Department.

The days when lion-maned piano virtuosos came storming out of Europe with flowing black ties, prodigious techniques and temperaments to match are over. Today the virtuoso is practically indistinguishable from the vice president of any going industrial concern -- and, for all we know, may even be one.

BOGOTA, Colombia -- Business in Colombia was as good or better in 1952 than it was in 1951. Although the volume was larger than in 1951, trade was more competitive, with indicated lower profit margins. The prospects for 1953 are considered satisfactory.

Capt. Harry J. Parker, chief surveyor of the National Cargo Bureau, Inc., will take over as commodore of the Rudder Club tomorrow evening at the monthly dinner in the St. George Hotel, Brooklyn. Captain Parker succeeds Walter Herzer, vice president of Local 88, National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots.

Joe Adonis, gambler and racketeer who had been brought up from the New Jersey State Prison in Trenton but still was the best-dressed man in the courtroom, went on trial in Federal Court here yesterday on a contempt charge.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- The Government said today that four cotton gin machinery manufacturers have paid $496,000 in settlement of claims for alleged overcharges in violation of price orders.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- A recommendation that the United States, Britain, Canada, France and other Western nations "review and then tighten their present statutes against the high crimes of treason, espionage and subversion in high places" was issued today
ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- Governor Dewey today appointed D. Mallory Stephens of Brewster, former chairman of the Assembly Ways and Means Committee, as a member of the temporary State Commission on Rents.

The one-story taxpayer at 81-14 to 81-20 Northern Boulevard in Jackson Heights, Queens, has been sold by Hugh K. McGovern, real estate operator, to L. Silverstein in a transaction negotiated by M. S. Gaumont as brokers. Irving L. Levitt was attorney for the seller and Joseph S. Schwartz acted for the buyer.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Senator H. Alexander Smith of New Jersey accepted chairmanship of the important Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee today, after Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio yielded his seniority because of the press of duties as Senate Majority Leader.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Jan. 7 -- South Korean President Syngman Rhee departed for Korea today after a two-day unofficial visit to Japan in which he apparently laid the groundwork for a resumption of talks to settle the multifold problems between the two nations.

When Prime Minister Churchill spoke to newspaper men on his arrival here this week he remarked that he and President-elect Eisenhower had "met at least 100 times to deal with business of one kind or another."

CHICAGO, Jan. 6 -- How the late Lammot du Pont rejected the selection of General George C. Marshall as a director of General Motors Corporation was told today as page after page of "big business" secrets unfolded in the du Pont anti-trust trial here.

Prime Minister Winston Churchill pressed his informal exploration of future British-American relations and world affairs last night by conferring with two key aides of the incoming Administration of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President elect.

LONDON, Jan. 6 -- The British Foreign Office "had another think" last night about its invitation to a leading British authority on cosmic radiation to lecture in West Germany and called off his sheduled tour of six universities there for political reasons.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Salvage workers recovered potentially dangerous radioactive material today from the debris of a British transport plane that carried twenty-seven persons to death.
The Radio Corporation of America announced plans yesterday for construction of a factory in Spain for production of television home receivers, phonograph records and record players.

LONDON, Jan. 6 -- The Prague hangings of fallen Communist heroes were a consequence of the failure by Czechoslovakia to manufacture and deliver to the Soviet Union the products "commanded by the Russian exploiters," Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden said in a broadcast tonight.
MEXICO CITY -- Expanding even slightly more rapidly than had been expected, tourism was once again Mexico's biggest single dollar earner in 1952.

BOGOTA, Colombia -- The petroleum industry in Colombia and the official attitude toward it, have come of age. In fact, last year the Government itself entered the field through the reversion of the De Mares concession, which had been operated by a subsidiary of International Petroleum Company for thirty years.

A syndicate of investors headed by Irving Schwartz of Stein Schwartz, attorneys, bought the sixteen-story and penthouse apartment building on plot 93 by 100 feet at 710 West End Avenue, adjoining the southeast corner of Ninety-fifth Street, from a group headed by Knepper Levin.

STRASBOURG, France, Jan. 6 -- The fear that Communists might be elected to the projected European Parliament and sabotage its operations worries some of those engaged in drafting a constitution for such a Parliament. Plans for this constitution will he discussed here tomorrow at meetings of the Special Assembly formed for this purpose from the Assembly of the European Coal and Steel Community.

SAO PAULO, Brazil -- Not long ago, when you asked a Brazilian abroad, who happened to be from Sao Paulo, where his home was, his ready answer was, "I am a Paulista." That did not mean that he was relinquishing his Brazilian citizenship. He was proud to be a Brazilian, but he felt that Sao Paulo was Brazil.

ALBANY, Jan. 6 (AP) -- State tax revenues are running less than one per cent above Governor Dewey's estimate for the current fiscal year. Tax collections for the first eight months of the fiscal year that began last April 1 were $49,679,997.52 higher than in the comparative period a year ago -- a gain of 7.7 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Members of Congress who can't make ends meet on a $15,000 annual salary ought to cut their living standards or quit Congress, Representative Usher L. Burdick, Republican of North Dakota, said today.

The State of Oregon borrowed $10,000,000 in the public market yesterday to finance highway construction by the sale of an issue of bonds maturing serially from March 1, 1954 to 1973 to a banking syndicate headed by First National Bank of Chicago.
The merchant fleets of Canada and Latin America suffered for the most part from the same general decline in shipping that affected the United States and the rest of the world in 1952.

Although defeated in the seventh round yesterday, Jonathan Penrose of London retained his lead in the international chess masters tournament at Hastings, England, with a score of 4 1/2 -- 2 1/2, according to a report from London.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 6 -- The ordinary budget shows a deficit of 12,500,000 (Israeli) at the end of the third quarter of the fiscal year, it was disclosed in Jerusalem today by Finance Minister Levi Eshkol.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Joseph M. Dodge, the incoming Budget Director, cautioned the country today against looking for "any sixty-day miracle" in the way of budget cuts under the Administration of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect.
Nearly 200,000 victims of pernicious anemia may now be able to take their medication by mouth instead of by injection as the result of a new process announced yesterday.

VANCOUVER, B. C. (Canadian Press) -- British Columbia's industrial forces paused to regroup during 1952. That is, generally speaking. A few spearheads, notably oil and electric power, kept thrusting ahead. There were also some retreats.

WASHINGTON -- Prospects of Hawaii's becoming the forty-ninth state of the union appeared somewhat brighter as the Republicans took control of Congress, but the continued threat of a successful filibuster by Southern Senators made the outcome still far from certain.
TORONTO -- The Canadian steel industry, now in the midst of a large expansion program, expects to push production over the 5,000,000-ton mark in 1953.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 6 -- David Weintraub, who has been one of the principal targets of Congressional committees investigating alleged Communists among American employes of the United Nations, resigned today as director of the organization's Division of Economic Stability and Development.

Contract negotiations covering the 3,500 workers aboard tugs, self-propelled oil tankers and non-self-propelled oil barges in this port were opened formally yesterday in what was described as a "preliminary" meeting.
KINGSTON, Jamaica, B. W. I. -- The pace of industrial development in this British colony with a population of 1,400,000 quickened perceptibly last year. Bauxite mining set the pace.

WASHINGTON -- All that is needed to breathe life into the half-century-old dream of developing the St. Lawrence fully for power and commerce is the designation, expected any day now, of the New York State Power Authority as this country's agent in tapping the river's hoydroelectric potential.
Dominant factor in the 1952 sugar market was the effort of the United States Department of Agriculture to force prices higher by allowing less sugar to enter the country than was needed.

GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador -- Production of refined sulphur by the Ecuadorean Mining Company, a subsidiary of Chemical Plants Corporation, at the Tixan mines passed the mark of 1,000 tons a month in 1952. The capacity of 7,000 tons a month will be reached in 1953, according to company officials.
RIO DE JANEIRO -- Coffee occupied a major share of Brazilian attention during 1952, as always, because if she is not quite a one-commodity country, Brazil is perilously near it today.
TORONTO (Canadian Press) -- Contradictory trends marked activity on the Toronto Stock Exchange in the year just ended. But the exchange figures show 1952 was a big year for stock trading.

CHATTANOOGA, Jan. 6 -- Laboratory research was the main factor in spurring the South's economic and industrial progress in the last decade, the Southern Association of Science and Industry reported today.

Judging by the number of new cook books that have appeared in recent weeks, the field continues to be a fertile one for publishers. But how valuable the ever-expanding list of recipe books is to the home cook is questionable. After surveying eight of the latest works, this department concluded that it still is a good idea to "examine carefully before buying."

Yields on Treasury discount bills crept back toward a 2 per cent basis yesterday as the market for Government securities put behind it an uneven day in which all parts of the list, and particularly the long-term obligations, lost a sizable part of recent price gains.

Operations of the Detroit Harvester Company for the year ended last Sept. 30 resulted in a net income of $1,070,606, it was announced yesterday. This represents a drop of 31 per cent below the $1,554,224 recorded in the previous fiscal year.

SANTIAGO, Chile -- "Never before has Chile been confronted with a so disquieting, obscure and difficult a financial situation," according to the statement made to Congress by Juan Bautista Rossetti, Minister of Finance, on Nov. 8, four days after the inauguration of President Carlos Ibanez.
BUENOS AIRES -- President Juan Peron's most ambitious undertaking, a five-year plan calling for the investment of 33,500,000,000 pesos ($2,360,000,000) by 1957 began the first of this year.

HAVANA -- The prospects for further industrialization of Cuba are not considered too bright because of the intransigent attitude of labor and the Government's failure to do anything about it, new and heavier taxes, and the trend toward the establishment of more artificial industries.

LIMA, Peru -- Peru continued in 1952 to be a bright spot on the economic map of South American. Foreign trade held up during the year, domestic commerce maintained its satisfactory level and inflationary tendencies were kept well under control.

The New York City Ballet, which seems to be devoting itself single-mindedly to the production of divertissements this season, presented the premiere of another one at the City Center last night, and a lovely little one it proved to be.
MEXICO CITY -- Rapid economic expansion with the Government's blessing and a free, stable peso have made Mexico an attractive field for foreign investment, both for public and private capital.
RIO DE JANEIRO -- Immigration is generaly agreed to be one of the great needs for developing Brazil's potentially huge natural wealth. Like the United States, Brazil has been built on immigration.

With North America accounting for about 60 per cent of production, total world supply of newsprint last year came close to filling actual demand for the first time since the end of economic dislocations caused by total war.

ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- Richard H. Balch, State Democratic Chairman, met today with the men chosen to head his party's delegation in the Legislature this year and promised afterward that the Democrats would present a more aggressive united program in 1953 than in past years.

RIO DE JANEIRO -- Continued and expanding cooperation with the United States on the good side and general inflation and money troubles on the bad were outstanding in the picture of Latin America in 1952. Conditions varied, with some countries escaping the worst worries, but on the whole it was a hard year.

Gil Hodges, the slugging first baseman, yesterday signed his 1953 Dodger contract for a salary estimated at $22,000. Hodges was the second Dodger to sign, Joe Black, the top-flight relief pitcher, having come to terms during the winter meetings at Phoenix, Ariz.

Prospects are bright that Latin America will remain Uncle Sam's best customer in 1953, with private trade continuing to exceed that between the United States and Europe, according to William E. Barlow, president and publisher of two news magazines, Vision and Visao, which circulate south of the border, but are published in New York.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Recommendations by the Rules Committee of the American Football Coaches Association for a change in the playing code that would eliminate certain types of so-called "sucker" shifts and for the retention of the liberal substitution rule that makes the two-platoon system possible were announced tonight by Chairman Lou Little of Columbia University.

Howard S. Butterweck and Howard B. Mac Adams have been appointed vice presidents of the City Bank Farmers Trust Company, it was announced yesterday. The appointments of James W. Carmelich and Robert T. Luginbuhl as an assistant vice president and an assistant secretary, respectively, were also announced.
Brazil currently is engaged in trying to extricate herself from ill-advised governmental efforts to control the price movements of the world.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The House Armed Services Committee was told today that the Air Force had found "no tangible evidence that sabotage was a factor" in any of the major aircraft disasters that plagued it last fall.

ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- The 176th regular session of the State Legislature gets under way here tomorrow with New York City's budgetary and financial troubles expected to provide the knottiest political and governmental problem the state will be called upon to handle.

The city's Sanitary Code, which still requires that beauty parlors and barber shops provide a "sufficient" number of spittoons but prohibits spitting in them, is scheduled for a piecemeal streamlining.

Former New Yorkers now living in other places have not forgotten the annual appeal of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. Correspondence received yesterday with 112 donations totaling $2,139.50 made it clear also that it was better to contribute "late than never."

The Chase National Bank's loans, deposits and total resources on Dec. 31, last year, were higher than at the close of the previous year and at the end of the preceding quarter, according to the bank's latest condition statement published today.

The sulphur supply should be sufficient this year to meet the needs of United States industry. For the last two years there has been a world shortage that has restricted consumption and caused the precious yellow mineral to be allocated on an international basis.
Fluid curves and delicate glitter are the outstanding features of the I. Miller spring shoe collection shown to the press last evening in the company's showrooms in the Empire State Building.

Branch stores which are not truly representative of their parent establishments are a "mistake," the National Retail Dry Goods Association warned yesterday in a new book, "The Organization and Operation of Branch Stores."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The election on Nov. 4 of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower as President, and of Senator Richard M. Nixon of California as Vice President was made official in Congress today.

HELEN COOKE, white-haired, 57-year-old sub-postmistress of the village of Baltinglass, is one of the most celebrated women in Ireland. In more cynical nations, France, say, or the United States, where corruption in politics is taken for granted and public indignation is aroused only when abuses far exceed the norm in shamelessness, Miss Cooke could never become a national heroine.

Many new fabrics are being introduced in the apparel field which are put to end-uses that are "treacherous in their unsuitability," according to John M. Reeves, president of Reeves Brothers, Inc., manufacturer of textiles. He spoke yesterday at a luncheon opening the two-day meeting of the Boys Apparel Buyers Association at the Astor Hotel.

Exports of wool by Argentina for the season ended Sept. 30, 1952, amounted to 116,600,000 pounds, the smallest in a great many years and only about half as large as those of the previous season, according to a study of the First National Bank of Boston.
KHARTUM, the Sudan, Jan. 6 -- The sentiment here for maintaining ties to the British Commonwealth appears to be considerable.

Ruben Varga, violinist, who has given two recitals at Town Hall, last night moved up to Carnegie Hall for his third New York recital. Brooks Smith was his accompanist and the program consisted of Beethoven's "Kreutzer," Bach's unaccompanied Sonata in G minor, Debussy's Sonata, four Paganini Capriccios and Sarasate's Zigeunerweisen.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Two Republican Congressmen proposed today establishment of a commission to recommend areas of government activity that could be discontinued on the grounds that they were nonessential, more properly within state or local jurisdiction or competitive with private enterprise.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 6 -- Stricken with a virus infection while entertaining troops back of the Korean battle hills, three members of a Hollywood show unit were unable to fly home with their companions, who arrived tonight at Los Angeles Airport.

Cotton, the nation's most important export crop, heads into a rather uncertain future as the new year opens. With exports showing rate of about one-half of that of a year ago and the domestic demand indicating virtually no signs of a pick-up, the industry is facing another surplus problem, such as it has confronted at intervals for the last quarter of a century.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic -- According to preliminary reports from its division of statistics for the first ten months, 1952 was the most prosperous year in the Dominican Republic's history, with numerous indications that 1953 will be equally good. Exports for 1953 are expected to exceed $100,000,000 for the second year and again a record.
Corrugated plywood, made with a newly patented press and suitable for industrial and construction uses, may soon be shipped to the United States from Brazil.

ST. JOHN'S, Nfld. (Canadian Press) -- Premier Joseph Smallwood predicted fifteen years ago that Newfoundland would "blossom forth as a mining country whose importance will challenge the attention of the world."

LONDON, Jan. 6 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill's warm and cordial reception in New York caused considerable gratification here today and relieved some misgivings about the wisdom of his bold decision to talk with Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, before his inauguration.
MEXICO CITY -- Though there was a considerable increase in the acreage planted, drought, floods, frost and pests gave Mexican agriculture a poor year.

A highly novel theatrical experiment -- one actor doing a serialized version of "Hamlet" in modern dress -- is now being presented at 11:45 A. M. weekdays over the Du Mont outlet, WABD, on Channel 5. It's well worth tuning in; it's an immensely interesting show.

SAN JUAN, P. R. -- Puerto Rican rum has been priced out of the markets in both the United States and the island by the higher Federal and insular taxation, according to Jose Miguel Garcia, executive secretary of the Puerto Rican Rum Institute.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, B. W. I. -- One of thte world's largest sources of bauxite, the raw material from which the metal aluminum is derived, was activated in 1952 when two large aluminum companies started initial production at their mines on this Caribbean island.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Representative Robert L. F. Sikes, Democrat of Florida, said today the Army recently increased the fire power of United States infantry divisions 6 per cent and that each one now could "plaster the enemy with over 11,000 pounds of steel a minute."
ALBANY, Jan. 6 (UP) -- The State Commerce Department today reported the following winter sports conditions at New York resorts:

BERLIN, Jan. 6 (UP) -- Dr. Leo Zuckermann, former assistant to East German President Wilhelm Pieck, fled to West Berlin three weeks ago with his wife and two children to escape being purged as a Zionist spy," it was disclosed today.
The President-elect of the United States paid a friendly call yesterday morning on the man who will succeed him as president of Columbia University on Jan. 19.

WIESBADEN, Germany, Jan. 6 (AP) -- The Air Force announced today that Maj. William G. Draper had been sent home for a new assignment. It may be the best in the business, that of personal pilot for Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower after he moves into the White House.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Jan. 6 -- The designation of John A. Hannah, President of Michigan State College, as Assistant Secretary of Defense in the Administration of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, was foreshadowed here today.

City department heads have given assurances of cooperation in a new drive to conserve municipal water, light and power, Dominick F. Paduano, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, has reported.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay -- Under the pretext that Uruguay had impinged upon the sovereignty of Argentina by maintaining for more than twenty years a consul in the Falkland (Malvinas) Islands, the Argentine Government brought tourist traffic with this country to a halt last year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (UP) -- Representative Kenneth B. Keating said today that House investigators in the Republican-controlled Eighty-third Congress would ask Justice Tom C. Clark of the Supreme Court to testify on his administration of the Justice Department. Mr. Clark was Attorney General from 1945 until President Truman named him to the high bench in 1949.

" La Ronde," the French-made adaptation of the controversial Arthur Schnitzler play, "Reigen," which has been banned from New York State motion picture houses, will be brought before the Court of Appeals of the State of New York in Albany today by the distributor, Commercial Pictures, Inc.

OTTAWA -- Every Canadian earning $10,000 a year pays more than two months' salary to the Government in direct taxation and when indirect taxation is added his total tax payment amounts to nearly a quarter of his earnings.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay -- As in the case of almost all other South American countries, Uruguay is hoping that the United States will become a better customer for her products. Statistics covering this country's foreign trade for the first six months of 1952 disclosed an unfavorable balance of trade amounting to $51,348,415.

DURING the late but not universally lamented big game season a crop of interesting, time-tested alibis were produced by those who had an opportunity to get some venison but not one of them took advantage of the "temperature-change" alibi, which ballisticians consider one of the best in the book.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- President Truman, according to high Administration sources, is planning to issue an Executive Order proclaiming that all the vast offshore oil deposits are naval oil reserves.
BOGOTA, Colombia -- Coffee has risen to 78 per cent of Colombia's exports. Colombia's soil and climate are excellent for the type of mild coffee produced here, and production has increased steadily.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Two big Dutch passenger ships with a total of 1,750 persons aboard collided today in the Red Sea near Port Sudan. The ships' owners here said no casualties occurred but the ships were seriously damaged.

Productivity increases of 3 per cent annually, or 6 cents an hour, to be retroactive three years, were asked for 1,250,000 operating and non-operating employes of the nation's railroads at the opening of public hearings here yesterday. The roads said that this would cost approximately $500,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The Daughters of the American Revolution finally got some official support today for their demand that the gold buried at Fort Knox, Ky., be checked.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Loyal troops today foiled an attempted revolt that President Victor Paz Estenssoro said was planned by traitors within his own ruling party.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Australia's two Davis Cup heroes broke even in their American debut as professional tennis players tonight, with Frank Sedgman, the No. 1 man, defeating the reigning pro king, Jack Kramer, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4.

Even Senator McCarran will probably not level charges of pro-communism against the committee Secretary Acheson has proposed to review the case of John Carter Vincent. Headed by Learned Hand, who is probably the most distinguished American jurist alive today, the committee is to include John J. McCloy, two former Assistant Secretaries of State (one who served under Stimson and the other under Hull) and a retired Ambassador.

PANAMA -- The Central American countries are frequently and incorrectly called "banana republics," whereas coffee is the chief export crop. Since the prices of both coffee and bananas remained high and the demand constant, 1952 was a prosperous year.

ASUNCION, Paraguay -- Galloping inflation, declining foreign trade and general hard times have been the distinctive features of 1952 in Paraguay. Argentina's economic difficulties have been reflected here in two ways -- through loss of markets and through the need to buy elsewhere wheat that Argentina could not provide.

OTTAWA -- Between the end of 1949 and the end of 1951 United States investment in Canada increased from $5,909,000,000 to $7,235,000,000, and, although there has been a disposition among United States investors to dispose of their marketable holdings of Canadian securities and take a profit on the dollar difference, it is expected that this year will see no appreciable change in the situation.

MONTREAL (Canadian Press) -- Alternate flurries of buying and selling buffeted the Montreal Stock Exchange in 1952 and prices generally spent more time in lower levels than on higher ground. As 1952 was closing the price indexes of four groups traded on the Stock Exchange and Curb Market were lower than in 1951. Only two were higher.
MEXICO CITY -- Low demand in the United States resulted in a far smaller movement of Mexican cattle across the border in the closing months of 1952 than had been expected.

Future contract prices were generally lower in trading yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges. Sugar trading was particularly active, reaching higher totals than in several months, and potatoes showed more volume than at any time in a week. Cocoa, potatoes, soybean oil, wool, lead and zinc closed lower. Coffee and rubber were higher. Sugar, cottonseed oil and hides ended irregular.

WASHINGTON -- Cooperation of Canadian officials with United States authorities broke the back last year of an investment racket which had been siphoning millions of dollars annually from United States investors. The racket had caused concern to officials on both sides of the border for more than fifteen years.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 6 (UP) -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh rode out a threatening upsurge of opposition today and won a near unanimous vote of confidence after whipping Parliament into line with a bristling speech.

OTTAWA -- Canadian labor income has during the past year reached a record peak, the monthly level on different occasions exceeding $900,000,000. Spread over a labor force estimated at 5,500,000 skilled and unskilled men and women, including teen - agers, this amounts to an average of $164 a month.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica -- Business in Costa Rica expanded in 1952 and may be expected to make further progress in 1953, unless disturbed by the Presidential election scheduled for next July. The soundness of the economic and financial policies of the present Government have restored the confidence of business.

With the present deterioration of our city as a safe and law-abiding community, as is evidenced by the increase in violence and crime -- particularly the hold-ups and muggings -- it is time to re-examine all possible measures available to cope with the situation and to correct it.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 6 -- The Federal Government founded in Cologne today an aviation equipment company that is to prepare the way for the rebirth of the German civil airline after the ratification of the peace contract with the Western Allies.

SANTIAGO, Chile -- Huachipato, Chile's steel mill built three years ago with close to $100,000,000 lent by the Export-Import Bank apart from local support in smaller brackets, has proved to be a satisfactory project.

A middle-aged public school teacher was called out of her third grade classroom in Brooklyn yesterday by an unidentified youth who then robbed her of $60 in lunch money that she had collected from her pupils.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Commissioner Bert Bell of the National Football League said tonight that Baltimore fans had "lived up to their end of the bargain" by buying 15,000 season tickets for 1953 and "I'm ready to live up to mine" by approving a franchise for the Maryland city.
OTTAWA -- Out of the 1952 Canadian budget of about $4,500,000,000 better than 45 cents out of every dollar of taxes was earmarked for defense.

Mr. and Mrs. Allen Murray Myers of 451 East Fourteenth Street will appear in Domestic Relations Court this morning to admit that they have deliberately kept their 9-year-old daughter, Shelley, out of school since the term opened last September.

Counsel for Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, wartime atom spies, signed yesterday a court order agreeing to make an executive clemency plea by Saturday, thus assuring the couple a stay of execution until five days after the President has acted on their petition. The Rosenbergs were scheduled to be put to death on Jan. 14.

LA PAZ, Bolivia -- The biggest event of Bolivia's year was undoubtedly the nationalization of the $60,000,000 properties of the three great tin companies that have dominated the country for the last half-century: Patino, Aramayo and Hochschild. After six months of preparatory discussion, the three companies were formally taken over on Oct. 31.
Following is the general outline of the city's long-range fiscal program embodied in the memorandum submitted yesterday by Mayor Impellitteri to the Legislature:

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 6 -- An ancient tree, brought from the Orient, may work a modern miracle for Mexico, providing, in a virtual grab-bag of benefits, fodder, paper, fertilizer, silk and, most important of all, water and soil.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, suggested today to the incoming Senate Rules subcommittee on Privileges and Elections that it investigate one of the men who, as a member of the outgoing Rules subcommitte, recently helped investigate him.

A new version of the Elna portable sewing machine, equipped with a device that makes possible the automatic sewing of ornamental stitches, is available at the Necchi-Elna Sewing Circle shops, one of which is at 379 Fifth Avenue.

ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- Democratic members of the Legislature tonight confirmed agreements reached at conferences in New York yesterday by choosing Assemblyman Eugene F. Bannigan of Brooklyn as the party leader in the Assembly and by re-electing Senator Francis J. Mahoney of Manhattan as the Minority Leader in the Senate.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska -- With $240,000,000 worth of defense construction contracts scheduled to be awarded by April, and private industry mapping plans to build a $400,000,000 aluminum smelting plant and a $46,000,000 pulp mill, the outlook in Alaska is for a continued high level of prosperity.

LIMA, Peru -- A big and growing business, peculiar to Peru, with a turnover that already is more than $250,000 a week, is La Polla, similar to British football pools but based on the weekly horse races. Illegal until 1948, it is conducted now by the Jockey Club and, with a population of 650,000 in Lima, the sale of cards on many Saturdays passes 200,000 and the prize money sometimes is more than $100,000.

The nearly complete breakdown of Communist Poland's rationing system was a prime factor behind the decision, announced Sunday, to abolish rationing and to raise prices substantially more than incomes, close observers of the Polish scene said yesterday.

The world's contract bridge championship seems likely to remain with the United States team of John R. Crawford, Philadelphia; and Howard Schenken, Samuel Stayman, B. Jay Becker, Theodore Lightner and George Rapee, all of New York.

MEXICO CITY -- The United States remained by far Mexico's largest customer and supplier last year, although the growth in the total volume of Mexican trade allowed for an increase in sales to Europe as well.

In your Topics of The Times column for Jan. 2 your observations concerning the mockingbird which was seen in New Jersey brought both delight and interest to this reader. I noted that you warned the bird lovers of this area that should this melodic fellow from the Southland see fit to take up permanent residence in these parts he will be found to be a rather noisy neighbor.

Giulio Gari, who has been a member of the New York City Opera Company at the City Center for a number of seasons, made the transition to the Metropolitan Opera in fine style last night. The tenor made his debut at the senior opera house as Pinkerton in "Madama Butterfly" and sang with the skill and polish of a veteran.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Jan. 7 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,487, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M. Wednesday, Korea time:

EDMONTON, Alberta -- Growth in the exploration and distribution of oil from the Alberta oil fields has continued vigorously throughout the last year. There are now more than 3,300 wells in the single province of Alberta, with a potential production in excess of 250,000 barrels daily.

Stockholders of Foremost Dairies, Inc., at a special meeting called for Jan. 28, will vote on amending the company's charter in order to increase the authorized cumulative preferred stock from the present 100,000 shares ($5,000,000) to 160,000 shares ($8,000,000) and the authorized common stock from 1,000,000 to 1,950,000 shares.

RIO DE JANEIRO -- President Getulio Vargas, in his inaugural address in 1951, said he would strive to lower living costs, but prices have continued to soar despite the measures taken by the administration.
LONDON, Jan. 6 -- In Norman Hartnell's Bruton Street salon, peeresses and other coronation guests viewed the official fashion parade of robes and caps of state today.

Francis J. Sinnott, former Kings County Democratic leader, announced yesterday that he would abandon his legal action challenging the election of Kenneth F. Sutherland, Coney Island district leader chosen to succeed him on Dec. 29.

Seventy per cent of United States direct foreign investments, having a book value of $8,200,000,000, are in the Western Hemisphere, according to first results of a new census of American Direct Investment in Foreign Countries just released by the Office of Business Economics, Department of Commerce.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- The State Department is recalling the passports of Americans who attended the Communist-run "peace" conferences at Peiping and Vienna last year.

Overtime decided the battle, as Notre Dame conquered New York University, 78 -- 77, before 6,694 court fans at Madison Square Garden last night. It was the second straight year that the Fighting Irish from South Bend had to go into an extra five-minute period to take the measure of the Violets.

Chlorophyll, which hit the merchandising field at the start of 1952, grew into a vast business by the year's end, a check-up revealed yesterday Before the year was over, manufacturers utilizing the element in their products had made such heavy inroads in their respective markets that many competitors were forced to follow suit. This was particularly true in the dentifrice and deodorant fields.

CANTON, N. Y., Jan. 6 -- The United States Steel Corporation has purchased a parcel of land near here bearing iron and copper pyrites, it was learned today from a deed filed at the St. Lawrence County clerk's office.

Negotiations were broken off last night between a union of cemetery workers and representatives of eighteen cemeteries in Brooklyn, Queens and Westchester, and the union prepared to strike at 8 o'clock this morning.

NEWARK, Jan. 6 -- Mayor John V. Kenny of Jersey City insisted today that five of his former associates had testified untruthfully in New York about his alleged dealings with waterfront racketeers, but he admitted that he himself had lied to a grand jury about his midnight meeting with the notorious Anthony Strollo (Tony Bender) last March.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 6 -- An expanded floating drydock at the Key Highway yard of the Bethlelem Steel Company's shipbuilding division is ready for use, and the super-tanker, Las Piedras, the largest ever built in Baltimore, has been moved in for painting.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat of Nevada, and all the other members of the Senate Internal Security subcommittee submitted a series of questions today to Dean Acheson, the Secretary of State, asking him to clarify the status of the new board that will review the suspension of John Carter Vincent.

The striking bus workers are seeking a forty-hour week with no cut in the pay they used to get for working forty-four to forty-eight hours, with five to nine hours of guaranteed overtime. The old basic wage ranged from $1.66 to $1.73 1/2 an hour.
SAN JUAN, P. R. -- Ramon Colon Torres, Secretary of Agriculture and Commerce, authorized release of the following figures on exports and imports.

BUENOS AIRES -- In 1952 Argentina began to make her way out of the seemingly bottomless economic pit into which she had been plunged by two consecutive years of drought and an apparently ill-advised policy of speculative stockpiling and all-out industrialization.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 6 (AP) -- First Refusal, showing excellent speed, flashed to his third victory of the winter today as he drubbed eight rivals in the $3,500 Gardenia Purse at Tropical Park.

The major features of the foreign exchange market during 1952 were the firmness of the pound sterling and the strength of the Canadian dollar, which reached its highest level in nearly twenty years. There were no important developments in other currencies, which generally remained at their official rates.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The Senate's most powerful voices were raised today against an effort to vacate and supplant the present rules so as to make it easier to halt filibusters and thus forward the civil rights program.

Marcella Ayer, Ohio-born soprano, made her first appearance last evening at Town Hall. Miss Ayer opened the program with Beethoven's "Ah, perfido!," revealing a voice of fundamentally good quality, which was not always skillfully used.

MONTE IRVIN slid into third base in Denver on April 2 last year. His spikes caught in the ground and his right ankle crumpled. So did Giant pennant hopes. Maybe the Polo Grounds tenants never could have retained their championship anyway. But they didn't have a ghost of a chance once their biggest gun was silenced.

Extending from several gateways on the southern frontier of the United States are the mighty approaches of the Pan-American Highway. Foremost in the development of this broad thoroughfare is the construction in Mexico. Hundreds of miles have been built over difficult terrain and engineering skill has overcome the obstacles offered by rugged mountains and deep ravines.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The Army disclosed today that 46,000 soldiers had deserted from its ranks since the start of the Korean war and that about 11,000 of them had not been apprehended.

The Citizens' Committee on Children of New York asked Governor Dewey yesterday to provide state help for several hundred disturbed children described by the committee as "too well for mental hospitals but too sick to remain in their own homes or be cared for in foster homes or institutions."

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 6 -- Brazilian authorities are reported planning a strong drive against Communists as a new security law covering all forms of crimes against the state went into effect upon its official publication today. It was signed yesterday by President Getulio Vargas.

At the outbreak of World War II seven Canadian concerns shared a backlog of orders for 200 military aircraft, J. Geoffrey Notman recalled in Montreal this week. Now, he said, his own company alone, Canadair, Ltd., turns out that many F-86 Sabres every six months and employs eleven times the thousand workers on all aircraft in Canada in 1940.

In a deal involving close to $1,000,000, the property at 323-27 Fifth Avenue and 4-8 East Thirty-third Street with an interest in a right-of-way to East Thirty-second Street has been purchased by Abraham W. Scheffres, textile merchant, who plans to alter and occupy a large part of the premises. J. Brion Foulke Jr. was the broker in the sale.
A sales goal of at least $435,000,000, 20 per cent above 1952, has been set for 1953 by the Philco Corporation, it was announced yesterday at the annual convention of the company in Boca Raton, Fla.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 6 -- Because of serious financial pressures, many independent colleges and universities are in danger of weakening and going under, Dr. M. E. Sadler, president of Texas Christian University, warned today. A definite trend is taking place, he said, toward the growth of government-supported colleges at the expense of the private institutions.
SAN JUAN, P. R. -- A total of 6,530 building permits, at a cost of $97,488, was granted in Puerto Rico in the 1951-52 fiscal year, compared with 6,155 valued at $83,134 in the previous year.
OTTAWA (Canadian Press) -- Canada, building electrical power capacity to meet increasing demands of expanding industries, added a record total of 1,064,600 horsepower during 1952.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Jan. 7 -- B-29 Superforts raided enemy troop and supply centers in northwest Korea within seventy miles of the Manchurian border last night and early today, following up daylight attacks yesterday by fighter-bombers deep in Communist territory.

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti -- Despite lower prices for sisal, the white fiber that is her second most important crop, Haiti has been making long economic gains. Confidence has returned. The flight from the gourde has ended and bank deposits have risen sharply, advancing more notably each year since 1950, when Gen. Paul E. Magliore became President.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The bankrupt Long Island Rail Road has spent $4,522,706 on the safety program it began after two collisions in 1950 in which 112 persons were killed and hundreds injured.
CHICAGO, Jan. 6 -- The city that he immortalized as "hog butcher for the world, tool maker, stacker of wheat" tonight paid tribute to Carl Sandburg.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- At her final meeting with women reporters today, Mrs. James M. Helm, retiring White House social secretary, said that Mrs. Harry S. Truman's contribution to the archives of this Administration would be seventy-five standard size file drawers of personal and social correspondence and records.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 6 -- The danger of oversimplifying the complex and seemingly conflicting views of Mohandas K. Gandhi on international affairs was emphasized today at the first meeting of the peace seminar in which eminent thinkers from nine countries are participating.
BUENOS AIRES -- Argentina's current capital investment needs are between $4,000,000,000 and $5,000,000,000, according to one of the country's leading economists.

Hopefully interpreting last Sunday's decisive triumph over the Boston Bruins as a portent of better things over the second half of the National Hockey League campaign, the New York Rangers will face the Chicago Black Hawks tonight at Madison Square Garden.

Raymond Revit has been promoted to regional vice president of Hiram Walker, Inc., in charge of sales in all Eastern open states including operations of Hiram Walker Distributors, Inc., in metropolitan New York. William C. Mechanic has been made vice president and sales manager of the latter concern.

WINNIPEG, Canada -- Aided by favorable weather conditions throughout the growing and harvesting seasons, grain production in Canada last year was at a record level of 1,500,000,000 bushels. This was an increase of nearly 400,000,000 bushels over the 1,116,480,000 bushels in 1951. In the ten years, 1941 through 1950, the average yield was 817,247,000 bushels annually.

" Man's Opportunities and Responsibilities Under Freedom" will be the central theme of the 300th anniversary celebration of Jewish settlement in the United States. The celebration will begin in September, 1954, and continue until April, 1955.

Wars and global aid programs have resulted in creation of an industry dealing solely in surplus materials, ranging from clothing of all types to tools and equipment. Manufacturers of this type of goods -- some of it said to have been made to be sold as surplus -- gathered yesterday at the Statler Hotel for a convention and trade show at which their wares were offered to buyers.

BOGOTA, Colombia -- South America's third integrated steel plant is currently under construction at Belencito, 160 miles northeast of here. Empresa Siderurgica Nacional de Paz de Rio, S. A., is building the plant and developing raw material deposits, situated within twenty-two miles of the main site.
IGNACIO, Colo., Jan. 6 (AP) -- A 50,000-acre parcel of southern Ute Indian land in and near the Ignacio pool will be advertised for oil and gas leasing within three weeks.

Filmed highlights of last October's world series will be televised over Channel 11 Saturday night from 9 to 9:30 o'clock. The film was produced by the American and National Leagues under the direction of Lou Fonseca.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6 (AP) -- James D. Norris, president of the International Boxing Club, is planning to make a formal offer to J. Edgar Hoover, Federal Bureau of Investigation chief, within the next two days to serve as the club's board chairman at an annual salary of $100,000.

PONTIAC, Mich., Jan. 6 -- Elimination of Federal controls on automotive construction materials and business restrictions by the end of this month was forecast hare today. The indicated result was described as an acceleration of production throughout the automotive industry which has a backlog of thosuands of orders for 1953 products.

Mayor Impellitteri, irked by reports that his efforts to settle the six-day-old bus strike were being undercut by other high city officials, called a special meeting of the Board of Estimate yesterday to read the riot act to his colleagues.

One day last fall this column was devoted to the trials and tortures of writing a book. The article gave the impression that the trouble ended at the delivery of the finished, bound product, or possibly with reading the reviews the book might receive.

LONDON, Jan. 6 -- Members of the British Government and the three highest ranking United States diplomats in London met at the Foreign Office today to consider the results to date of the American effort to resolve the oil dispute between Britain and Iran. Negotiations with Iranian Premier Mossadegh are being conducted by United States Ambassador Henderson in Teheran.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (UP) -- The Federal Trade Commission has ordered Philip Morris, Inc., to stop "misleading" advertising that its cigarettes are less "irritating" than other brands.

ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- The Republican State Executive Committee decided at a meeting here this afternoon to sponsor legislation providing for a September instead of an August primary this year. The bill will be part of a Republican electoral reform program that will make provision for absentee registration as well as voting and for purging "dead wood" from registry lists in nonpersonal registration districts.

LA PAZ, Bolivia -- Almost unnoticed in the excitement over Bolivia's nationalization of the three big tin companies there, the concession obtained in La Paz by the Chacur group of Buenos Aires is just about as sensational in its way.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 6 -- President-elect Dwight D. Eisenhower intervened forcefully today to halt the delay of progress toward a German army with a message to Chancellor Konrad Adenauer endorsing the European Defense Community in which the forces of the Federal Republic will play a major role.

LA PAZ, Bolivia -- To the outside world Bolivia generally just means tin, and that is part of the National Revolutionary Government's excuse for seizing the big tin companies. They said the companies were smothering the development of Bolivia's economy outside of tin mining.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6 -- Business picked up here on the second day of the Winter International Home Furnishings Market in the American Furniture and Merchandise Marts. Orders were placed freely in all categories.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 6 (AP) -- Yale, playing possessive basketball and backing it up with accurate shooting, upset favored Pennsylvania, 76 -- 64, tonight in their opening Eastern Intercollegiate League contest.

Influenced by continued liquidation in March, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned barely steady yesterday and closed not far from the lows of the day, 24 to 37 points net lower than on Monday.

The delicacy and perfection of Braagaard's designs are the two most lasting impressions of this milliner's spring collection. Shown yesterday at 10 East Fifty-sixth Street, the hats combined a Renoir-like prettiness with a contemporary flawless chic that one of the audience likened to "that never-a-hair-out-of-place" look.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6 -- Bulls were again on the defensive in the grain market today, with new low prices for the season registered in all pits. All the active cereal futures except March corn reached new lows, while the deferred soybean deliveries also registered new low spots.

John Charles Thomas, baritone, who has been absent from the Broadway stage since 1921, yesterday confirmed from Baltimore the report that he will appear as Franz Schubert in a revival of "Blossom Time."

ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- The Republican State Executive Committee decided at a meeting here this afternoon to sponsor legislation providing for a September instead of an August primary this year. The bill will be part of a Republican electoral reform program that will make provision for absentee registration as well as voting and for purging "dead wood" from registry lists in nonpersonal registration districts.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Californa Eastern Airways, Inc., Burbank, Calif., asserted today that it planned to start airline service in the spring between Tokyo and Sao Paulo, Brazil, for Japan International World Airways.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 7 -- Two years ago today General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower arrived in Paris and began to organize the defenses of the West. Although these are still incomplete they are vastly more powerful than even the General's warmest admirers could have hoped for twenty-four months ago.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill of Britain will arrive here at 12:30 P. M. tomorrow and three-and-one half hours later will confer with President Truman, John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, and Dean Acheson, Secretary of State.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 7 -- Adolph Zukor, who fifty years ago on March 3 opened a penny arcade on Fourteenth Street in New York and thus started on a career in the motion picture business, today celebrated his eightieth birthday.

A new work by Bertrand Russell, winner of the 1950 Nobel Prize for Literature, will be issued Jan. 26 by Simon Schuster under the title "The Impact of Science on Society." It is Lord Russell's affirmative answer to the question: "Can a scientific society be stable?"

ALL who have, during their formative or formed years, searched assiduously for a left-handed monkey wrench, tried to comply with a request for a pail of steam, or who have "played" a bucket from the cockpit of a fishing cruiser, will feel a pang of sympathy for a member of this organization who recently returned from his first snipe hunt.

I think that Prof. Clinton Rossiter in his recent letter is mistaken in giving the verdict to President Truman in the argument on the counting of Presidents. In fact, President Truman himself has already taken the opposite position more than once. In a proclamation on the death of Franklin D. Roosevelt President Truman referred to him as the thirty-second President (10 Federal Register 4009).

Armour Co. and its domestic subsidiaries had net earnings of $7,140,485 in the fifty-three weeks ended on Nov. 1, according to the annual report issued to stockholders yesterday by Frederick W. Specht, president and chairman.

Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt, still recognized as the leader of New York and Newport society although inactive in recent years, died of pneumonia last night at her home, 1048 Fifth Avenue. She was believed to have been in her eighty-third year.

Taking the lead for the first time with fewer than four minutes to go and scoring 15 points within the final two minutes, St. John's basketball team upset St. Francis, 68 --54, at the II Corps Artillery Regiment Armory, Brooklyn, last night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Donold B. Lourie, Under Secretary of State-designate, said today he would begin as soon as possible the elimination of "overlapping and duplication" between the State Department and other Government agencies.

Dissension broke out in the Fire Department yesterday as Commissioner Jacob Grumet criticized Howard P. Barry, a fireman and president of the powerful Uniformed Firemen's Association, for charging that the department, under Mr. Grumet and Chief of Department Peter Loftus, was "rapidly developing into one of the most viciously anti-labor administrations the Fire Department has ever had."

California Eastern Airways, Inc., has acquired an 80 per cent interest in the Air Carrier Service Corporation, according to an announcement yesterday by S. J. Solomon and Wm. W. Brinkerhoff, presidents of the companies. Mr. Solomon said in Washington it would make the combined organization one of the largest of its kind in the world.

PARIS, Jan. 7 -- It appeared probable tonight that Robert Schuman would cease to be French Foreign Minister if Rene Mayer, accepted as Premier today, succeeded in forming a Cabinet. Georges Bidault, former Foreign Minister and Premier, seemed likely to replace M. Schuman.

Three Englishmen occupied the top places in the international masters tournament after the eighth round at the Hastings Chess Club in England yesterday. Henry Golombek, former British champion, defeated Dr. Edward Lasker of New York and tied for first place at 5 -- 3 with Jonathan Penrose, according to a report from London.

LONDON, Jan. 7 (Reuters) -- The British Seamen's Union has protested to Polish Ambassador Jerzy Michalowski against "uncivil and irksome" treatment of British seamen when their ships call at ports behind the Iron Curtain.

More than $650,000,000 was spent for industrial advertising during 1952 and indications are that this sum will be surpassed this year, according to Blaine G. Wiley, executive secretary of the National Industrial Advertisers Association.

STRASBOURG, France, Jan. 7 -- Members of the constitutional committee of the European Coal and Steel Community's Special Assembly submitted today a report advising the creation of a supranational political authority for Europe on the basis of a compromise between those seeking Europe's federation and those preferring an association of independent national states.

VIENNA, Jan. 7 -- Dr. Karl Gruber. Austria's Foreign Minister, declared in a speech here tonight that the recent United Nations debate might prove the point of departure for a new high-level meting of the Great Powers to discuss the Austrian question in broad terms divorced from actual treaty negotiations.

FLINT, Mich., Jan. 7 (AP) -- Buick will have a new high-compression, valve-in-head, V-8 engine in its Roadmaster and Super series automobiles for 1953. A twelve-volt electrical system will be used in these two lines.

CHICAGO, Jan. 7 -- Increased concern for the consumer's needs and desires appeared to be a newly important consideration on the part of designers, manufacturers and merchants attending the wholesale International Home Furnishings Markets in progress here.

ALBANY, Jan. 7 -- The constitutionality of the state statute permitting banning of motion pictures because of immorality was challenged before the Court of Appeals today in an attempt by the Commercial Pictures Corporation to obtain a New York license for commercial exhibition of the French film "La Ronde," an adaptation of the Arthur Schnitzler play, "Reigen."

Speculation on evidence indicating that L. P. Beria has been demoted two places in the Soviet hierarchy suggests all sorts of questions that cannot at present be answered, Mr. Beria and Russia being what they are.

CHICAGO, Jan. 7 -- Buying on the third day of the international winter home furnishings market in the American Furniture and Merchandise Marts here increased substantially today. Failing to get satisfactory delivery of bedroom and dining room sets from first-line furniture manufacturers, retailers placed orders in droves with secondary suppliers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The Government and the Communist party in the United States completed final arguments today before the Subversive Activities Control Board. The board now must decide whether Communists and members of Communist-front organizations in this country will be required to register annually under the Internal Security Act.

OTTAWA, Jan. 7 -- For the second time in two years newspaper correspondents accredited to the Canadian Parliament were admitted to the Canada atomic energy project at Chalk River Tuesday and permitted to inspect the heavy water reactors, laboratories and workshops under guidance but without restrictions.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- President Truman's eighth and final message on the State of the Union today left usually highly vocal segments of the Congress either quieter or wholly silent.

HONG KONG, Jan. 7 -- The Chinese Communists were reported today to have intensified their indoctrination work among fishermen operating along the Kwangtung coast following a mass flight from Chungshan of more than 400 fishing junks with at least 3,000 persons aboard.

MANHASSET, L. I., Jan. 7 -- A great blue heron, rescued here last night by policemen from pedestrian hazards posed by heavy Northern Boulevard traffic, was repatriated early this morning to obscurity in marshlands at the head of Manhasset Bay.

An official United States contract bridge team last night increased its lead to 4,690 points over the Swedish bridge champions of Europe. Four sessions out of a scheduled eight remain to be played in the week-long two-team contest held at the Sherry-Netherland Hotel for the 1953 official World's Team of Four Championship.
TOKYO, Thursday, Jan. 8 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,488, for the twenty-four hours ended at 6 A. M. Thursday, Korean time:

Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, now serving as Director of the Central Intelligence Agency under President Truman, is slated for appointment as Under Secretary of State by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, it was reported on good authority yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 7 -- Forty-eight of the du Pont minors will be dismissed as defendants in an anti-trust suit under an agreement reached today by Government and defense attorneys in Federal District Court here.

TOKYO, Thursday, Jan. 8 (UP) -- Mrs. Dorothy Krueger Smith broke into loud sobs at her court martial today as a neighbor directly contradicted prosecution testimony that Mrs. Smith killed her husband because of his impending transfer back to the United States.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 7 -- This city of nearly a million inhabitants ended its seventh day today without regular garbage removal. More than 3,000 garbage collectors, school janitors and other municipal laborers remained on strike, while refuse gathered in the streets, alleys and emergency dump points at an estimated rate of 1,000 tons a day.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 7 -- Charges that "coercive" tactics had been used by the Ford Motor Company against a former sales agency were aired today in a $1,650,000 suit filed in Federal court here.

ALBANY, Jan. 7 -- A proposal today by Governor Dewey to raise parking fees at state parks, coupled with the recent plan to place a 10-cent toll on the Southern State Parkway, would increase by 35 cents the fees required of many visitors to Jones Beach. The present fees total 60 cents.

The City Council adopted unanimously yesterday a resolution imploring the Police Department to ease parking restrictions during the bus strike. It requested the police to permit parking in unused bus stops.
The registration of trucks continued to lag here yesterday as legislative and court tests of new regulations governing registration fees were being pushed in Albany.

The texts of statements on the bus strike issued yesterday by Mayor Impellitteri, Council President Rudolph Halley, Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union and labor member of the Mayor's mediation committee, and Victor S. Riesenfeld, chairman of the mediation committee, follow:
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Jan. 7 (AP) -- Newspapers were warned today they would lose "in spirit, in strength and influence" if they failed to uphold man's right to dissenting view.

An increase last week of 2,591,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, total supplies were 137,016,000 barrels, compared with 134,425,000 a week earlier and 135,344,000 a year ago.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Jan. 7 -- The Belgian Government will stand or fall by the six-nation European Defense Community Treaty signed in Paris last May, a well-informed spokesman said today. He was commenting on reports that Belgium's State Council was against ratification of the treaty.

The personnel and civilian employes at Mitchel Air Force Base will receive an engraved plaque Jan. 16 commending them for donating 5,900 pints of blood to the Red Cross since the beginning of hostilities in Korea, it was announced yesterday.
MADRID. Jan. 7 -- Anti-Communist opposition in Spain to the Franco regime was said today to have been considerably weakened by the recent arrest in Barcelona of a group of Anarchist leaders.

Mayor Impellitteri's program for immediate and long range relief for the city's financial plight was attributed yesterday to "political myopia which limits his vision into the future needs of the city to Election Day, 1953."

ALBANY, Jan. 7 -- Kenneth F. Sutherland, the new Brooklyn Democratic leader, threatened to seize the Senate Minority Leadership in an initial skirmish with Carmine G. DeSapio, leader of Tammany Hall, and Edward J. Flynn, Bronx Democratic leader, as the Legislature met today.
ALBANY, Jan. 7 -- Governor Dewey slammed the door today on Mayor Impellitteri's request for $62,700,000 more in state aid for New York City.
ALBANY, Jan. 7 -- Following is the text of Governor Dewey's annual Message to the Legislature delivered at a joint session here today:

CHICAGO, Jan. 7 -- The grain market showed signs today of reversing the long-drawn-out bear trend, heavy short profit-taking in cereal futures being in evidence. Shorts took advantage of the weakness in soybean futures to buy the cereals, while there was some evidence of returning confidence on the part of investors in wheat and corn.

Archbishop James Francis A. McIntyre of Los Angeles arrived at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, at 9:50 o'clock last night on his way to Rome, where he will be consecrated a prince of the Roman Catholic Church next Monday.

The eighth international cruise-congress of the Pan American Medical Association left here for the Caribbean yesterday aboard the Holland-America Line's Nieuw Amsterdam with the blessing of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, President-elect.

ALBANY, Jan. 7 -- In delivering his eleventh annual message to the Legislature today, Governor Dewey observed that he had now served longer than any other Governor since the first one, George Clinton. Mr. Dewey was elected in 1950 to serve his third four-year term.

TOPEKA, Kan., Jan. 7 (UP) -- Alf M. Landon, 1936 Republican Presidential nominee, said today that Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois since the November elections had taken part in "misrepresentation of the fairness and truthfulness of American newspapers" in political reporting.

President Truman's final message to Congress on the State of the Union will be remembered for its warning to potential warmakers that the world has entered an era in which "war has changed its shape and its dimensions." The A-bomb has been followed by experimentation with the H-bomb, and even more terrible weapons may well be perfected.

ALBANY, Jan. 7 -- Governor Dewey reported in his message to the Legislature today that a 150-mile section of the New York State Thruway would be open to traffic between Utica and Batavia by next January and that tolls would be charged on that stretch as soon as it was completed.

Investment banking syndicates competed yesterday for the purchase of major local government bond issues totaling more than $35,700,000. The borrowers included the state of South Carolina, the Detroit-Wayne Joint Building Authority of Michigan, the St. Louis Board of Education and the Salt River Project Agricultural Improvement and Power District, Arizona.

The regional Wage Stabilization Board announced approval yesterday of all but one of the terms of a new contract negotiated last November between THE NEW YORK TIMES and the Newspaper Guild of New York, C. I. O.
LONDON, Jan. 7 -- Polish Catholics have rioted at Cracow in protest against the arrest of Archbishop Eugene Baziak, it was reported here.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 7 (AP) -- Corfel, a 4-year-old son of Buster who compiled a creditable record during the New Jersey racing season, opened his winter schedule with a rousing triumph in the feature race at Tropical Park today.

Fordham's spotless basketball record was never jeopardized by Brooklyn College and Johnny Bach's Rams romped to an 81-56 victory over the Kingsmen from Flatbush last night on the Rose Hill gymnasium floor. It was the tenth straight triumph of the season for Fordham.

A Ford Foundation scholar from India, who is enrolled in American Studies at Yale University for Foreign Students, expressed his good will and sympathy for the New York Times Neediest Cases in a letter received yesterday with his $2 donation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Taking a position contrary to the overwhelming sentiment among football coaches, the Council of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, in forty-seventh annual session here, has turned thumbs down on the liberal substitution rule in the football codes that permits the use of the two-platoon system.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (UP) -- Representative Jesse Wolcott, incoming chairman of the House Banking Committee, said tonight that Congress definitely would scuttle direct economic controls and would not replace them with stand-by "emergency" controls.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Eisenhower-Nixon well-wishers who attend either section of the Inaugural Ball on Jan. 20 were promised today that they would hear plenty of music.

The Neighborhood Children's Center will be the beneficiary of a pre-opening performance of "The Love of Four Colonels," with Rex Harrison and Lilli Palmer in the leading roles, Wednesday night at the Shubert Theatre. Mrs. Vincent Astor and Mrs. George Cannon are co-chairmen of the benefit committee.

I thoroughly endorse the suggestion made by Edward Early in the letter you published Jan. 4. What this country needs, he says, is a "Keep-in-touch-with-your-Congressman" drive. It is the duty of every citizen, he adds, to contribute his opinion. Of course this is true.
After reading the testimony of the Rosenberg case I find that I cannot put to rest my doubts about the verdict and wish to cite the following points:

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 7 -- The United Nations announced today the resignation of David Zablodowsky, a high-ranking official who had been identified as part of a Communist undercover operation in the United States in 1936.

Shipments of the new twelve-denier nylon yarn will begin next month to manufacturers of women's hosiery and the new "ultra sheer" stockings will be available to consumers in March, it was announced yesterday by E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc.

A two-year study of savings facilities in New York State indicates there is no need for additional savings bank branch offices, Ernest H. Watson, president of the New York State Bankers Association, said today in issuing the results of the study.

NEWBURGH, N. Y., Jan. 7 -- The activation of a new jet fighter squadron, the first fighter group to be stationed at near-by Stewart Air Force Base, was announced today by the Eastern Air Defense Force Headquarters here. The unit is the 330th Fighter-Interceptor Squadron, attached to the 4709th Defense Wing, with headquarters at McGuire Air Force Base, near Trenton, N. J.

Columbia successfully launched its forty-ninth Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League campaign by routing Harvard, 82 -- 57, before 1,500 spectators at University Hall last night. It was the sixth straight triumph for the Lions, who have not been beaten since their opening-game loss to powerful Fordham.
Hoyt Wilhelm, North Carolina's second gift to the Giants in recent years -- the first was Whitey Lockman -- yesterday became the third member of the Polo Grounders to accept terms for 1953.

TROY, N. Y., Jan. 7 (UP) -- Dr. Livingston Houston, president of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, said today that Dr. Jerome M. Greenberg, Assistant Professor of Physics, indicted on charges of falsely denying he had ever been a member of the Communist party, was on a leave of absence.

" La Boheme," given its first performance in the new English version of Howard Dietz eleven days ago at the Metropolitan, was presented there for the first performance in the original Italian last night. The cast was almost a new one, different in nearly all the leading parts from the one of the English version.

PEARL RIVER, N. Y., Jan. 7 -- The century-old cemetery of this village has been invaded by teen-age hoodlums who smashed thirty-eight headstones and overturend a dozen more, thereby arousing the indignation of a community of about 4,000 inhabitants.

NEWARK, Jan. 7 -- Public Safety Director John B. Keenan tonight ordered Acting Fire Capt. John T. Fischer of the theatre detail to insist on the immediate removal of a lion from the lobby of the Paramount-Newark Theatre, 195 Market Street.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's State of the Union Message to Congress today:

Net asset value of the Lehman Corporation, one of the country's largest specialized or closed-end investment concerns, continued upward last year. At the end of 1952, according to the company's report issued yesterday, asset value was $73.22 a share on 2,076,562 shares of capital outstanding, compared with $69.83 a share three months earlier.
LONDON, Jan. 7 -- Opinion was divided here tonight on President Truman's State of the Union message to Congress.

ALBANY, Jan. 7 -- Eighteen bills incorporating legislative proposals by Governor Dewey in his annual message to the Legislature were among more than 200 measures introduced today as the state lawmakers convened for their 1953 regular session.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- A broad new study of the education of women, made possible by a three-year grant totaling $50,000 from the Ellis L. Phillips Foundation of New York, was announced today by the American Council on Education.

The stock market pulled out of a decided slump yesterday and in late trading managed to recoup a large part of its loss. Rallying powers exhibited first by the oils and rails, later supported by the automotives and airlines, gave the list the drive needed to emerge from a course which at one time clipped 1 to 2 points off prices.
An unusual alliance between Peru and New York was established yesterday when Fred of John Frederics presented his millinery collection for spring and summer.

Acquisition of the plants, inventories and business of John A. Roebling's Sons Company, Trenton, N. J., was announced yesterday by the Colorado Fuel and Iron Corporation. The Roebling organization, builders of the Brooklyn Bridge, will be operated as a newly formed and wholly owned subsidiary of Colorado Fuel and Iron, according to Charles Allen Jr., chairman.

Sticking close to home base, Paul Vroom will sponsor next fall a recently completed comedy, "The Guests," written by his producing colleague, Robert L. Joseph. The latter is producer of the current "My Darlin' Aida," of which Mr. Vroom is general manager and associate producer. Mr. Joseph has been represented before on the local stage as an author.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Manufacturers of machine-made glass ware for both household and commercial use were authorized by the Office of Price Stabilization today to increase their selling prices a maximum of 7 per cent above the highest levels prevailing since July 1.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The Senate smashed today by a roll-call vote of seventy to twenty-one an effort by a bipartisan bloc of declared liberals to change its closure, or debate limitation, rule so filibusters might be curbed.

Government will be less paternalistic under the new administration so that the responsibility "for economic stability, for caution and sanity of economic behavior falls more largely on individuals and business," according to the annual report of The National City Bank of New York.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 7 -- President Getulio Vargas signed the law today establishing a "free market" in foreign exchange parallel with the rigidly-fixed official rates.

ROME, Jan. 7 -- Premier Alcide De Gasperi will arrive in Athens by air tomorrow on a four-day official visit designed to seal Italo-Greek friendship after the aggression that Greece suffered at Italian hands in 1940. The visit assumes particular interest at the present moment in view of the negotiations under way for a defensive pact between Yugoslavia, Greece and Turkey.

Commodity futures closed irregularly lower yesterday on the New York exchanges. The domestic sugar contracts and potato options were fairly active. Rubber, soybean oil, potatoes, zinc, lead and tin closed lower. Cocoa and coffee were higher and hides, sugar, wool and cottonseed oil were mixed.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- The nation conferred its highest award -- the Medal of Honor -- on six dead heroes of the Korean war today, four soldiers and two Marines.

Pream, a powdered light cream that stays fresh for weeks at room temperature, was introduced to food writers and the trade last night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Retail distribution is to begin immediately; it is expected that consumers will find the new product in the stores by the first of next week.

Mrs. Rose Russell, legislative representative of the Teachers Union, said yesterday that Governor Dewey's message to the Legislature "ignores but cannot obscure the dire need for a substantial increase in state aid for our public schools to help overcome the catastrophic school building shortage, to wipe out the double and triple sessions that cheat our children of a full day's schooling and bolster the vanishing morale of the overburdened, underpaid and perpetually harassed teaching staff."

The long list of new textile fibers, yarns, fabrics and finishes refutes the oft-repeated charge that the textile industries are lacking in research, it was pointed out last night by Julius B. Goldberg, research director of J. P. Stevens Co., Inc., textile manufacturers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The first tangible political effect of the choices by President-elect Eisenhower of many big business men for his Cabinet, near-Cabinet and sub-Cabinet appeared today when bipartisan Senate objections developed to the General's suggestion that his Cabinet be confirmed on Inauguration Day.
