Public School 19 at First Avenue and Fourteenth Street, which was built ninety-four years ago, has not had a general inspection by the city Fire Department since 1937, it was disclosed yesterday.

A fourteen-point program to develop a physical and financial method of road improvement in the state for the next five to fifteen years was submitted to the Legislature yesterday by the New York State Automobile Association.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The Democratic Senate minority halted a Republican effort late today to whisk through a change in rules that would enable the majority to control all fifteen standing committees of the Senate without having to depend on the vote of Senator Wayne Morse of Oregon, who bolted the Republican party in the last election.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (UP) -- The Federal Housing Administration, long under heavy pressure to increase interest rates, has finally approved a one-half per cent "service charge" for mortgage loans on the lowest cost homes.

Governor Dewey's eleventh annual message to the Legislature notes with pride that his length of service, since 1943, has been exceeded by only one previous Governor. The Dewey years have been good years for New York State, and the current message is typical of the firm but measured advance toward limited objectives.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat of Nevada, called on the Senate today to claim the right to jail without a court trial any Government official who refused to surrender subpoenaed documents to any Senate investigating group.

Wholesale food prices advanced during the week ended on Tuesday, marking the third successive weekly rise, according to the Dun Bradstreet food index. It now stands at $6.23, compared with $6.16 in the previous week and $6.61 a year ago.

Singers, dancers, comedians and other types of performers serving in the armed forces will be featured in a new television variety program, to be presented over the American Broadcasting Company network beginning Monday, Jan. 19, from 9:30 to 10 P. M.
The International Longshoremen's Association accused the New York State Crime Commission yesterday of acting as a "sounding board" for Communist propaganda.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Republican Senators, anxious to find Government jobs for deserving party members, decided today to ask the Civil Service Commission for a complete list of all jobs available for political appointment.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 7 -- The Association of American Colleges, representing nearly 800 of the foremost colleges and universities in the country, adopted a report today pledging its support to the forthcoming House Un-American Committee's investigation of higher education.
The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad sold an issue of $14,000,000 of first mortgage bonds yesterday to investment bankers at an interest cost of 4.48 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- While preserving official secrecy about hydrogen weapons, President Truman left no doubt today that the United States had reached a new momentous stage in the development of atomic power.

The Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago, reported as of Dec. 31, 1952, total deposits of $2,568,797,375 and total assets of $2,800,500,848, compared, respectively, with $2,331,275,571 and $2,555,397,000 on June 30.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 7 -- Dry cargo facilities in the Port of Philadelphia were paralyzed today by a contract dispute between 350 waterfront railroad carloaders and their employers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Increased supplies of manganese, alloy vital to the production of steel were assured the Government today. In a deal with Brazilian interests the Government combined a loan of $67,500,000 with a long-time purchase contract to assure the development of newly discovered manganese ore deposits here.

New York's "phantom" port strike of longshore weighers, scalemen and samplers ended officially yesterday afternoon when three locals of the International Longshoremen's Association voted to ratify a new agreement bringing higher wages.

Senator H. Alexander Smith of New Jersey, who now succeeds Mr. Taft as chairman of the Labor and Public Welfare Committee, voted for the Taft-Hartley Act in 1947. But while he followed the leadership of Mr. Taft on this occasion he also went along with Senator Ives, who succeeded in softening some of the act's provisions.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Senator John W. Bricker. Republican of Ohio, said in the Senate today that unless the present Congress defined the exact relationship between the United States and the United Nations and unless it assured high quality of United States representation in the world body, a future Congress would be forced by public opinion to sever that relationship.
LONDON, Jan. 7 -- Although the stock markets remained quiet today, most markets continued their slight rise. British funds in particular were stronger. Industrial prices also tended to improve.

Directors of Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation yesterday authorized expansion of the company's working capital by extension to shareholders of record of March 27, 1953, primary rights to subscribe to authorized bug unissued common stock on the basis of one share for each five held.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 7 -- The new road from Beersheba to Sodom, the biggest and most difficult engineering feat to be carried out in this country, which gives Israel access to the southern end of the Dead Sea, was opened today.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 7 -- A proposal that the United Nations enforce and supervise the West German-Israeli restitution agreement is being examined as a possible way to end the threat of the Arab Governments to invoke a boycott against the Federal Republic.

A taxpayer's suit seeking to enjoin the city from proceeding with its Fort Greene slum clearance project in Brooklyn is scheduled to be argued this morning in Special Term, Part I, of the Supreme Court in Brooklyn.

True to her usual traditions, Irene of New York dipped into color lavishly for her spring hat collection, turning out a whole crop of her favorite pert young bretons and brims gay with bright velvet ribbons. Shown yesterday at the designer's salon at 16 East Fifty-second Street, the presentation re-emphasized her belief in simple casual shapes enhanced with vibrant colored velvet trim and flowers as well as flattering brims.
One of thirty suspended policemen was questioned yesterday in the Criminal Courts Building about apparent increased income and assets over a three-year period in plainclothes duty.

HARTFORD, Jan. 7 -- In a plea for economy in state government, Gov. John Davis Lodge urged the opening session of the biennial Connecticut General Assembly today not to consider any requests for new appropriations "until we have cut to the lowest practicable minimum the cost of existing services and facilities."

The doom of the historic World Building at 63 Park Row was forecast yesterday as the City Planning Commission approved a $5,266,000 plan drafted by Manhattan Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr. for rearrangement and reconstruction of the street system at the Manhattan plaza of the Brooklyn Bridge.
BERLIN, Jan. 7 (AP) -- A wide purge is now under way against the 2,700 ews remaining in Communist-ruled East Germany, West Berlin Jews said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- President Truman proclaimed today the dawn of the age of hydrogen power and warned Premier Stalin that a war provoked by Russia now would mean the ruin of the Soviet regime and homeland.

Pan-American unity is right now 'more operative than that of the United Nations" despite the differences in Spanish and Anglo-Saxon cultures, Dr. Gesar Gonzalez, Ambassador of Venezuela to the United States, declared yesterday.

A defense lawyer charged yesterday that the thirteen secondary Communist leaders on trial in Federal Court were the victims of "a frame-up and a fraud," in which they were being made accountable for what they or their descendants might do at some far distant time.

A ticket-selling drive for Fordham's 1953 home football games has been launched by Fordham's Alumni Football Committee. The object of the campaign is to rally sufficient support by graduates and friends to assure the continuance of football and reestablish the sport on a major scale at Rose Hill.

If President Truman carries out his reported intention of declaring by executive order that the offshore oil deposits are naval reserves he will be responsible for a political coup that will throw an unnecessary cloud of controversy over the last days of his Administration.

The first and the natural reaction here to the solution of the French political crisis by Rene Mayer will be one of shock. The new Premier's program is based on a measure of compromise and concession to the Gaullists. This will result in a delay in putting through the European Army Treaty.

THE world in this new year of grace needs many things, many books. It needs good books particularly, for our instruction and our delight. It needs volumes on world affairs so wisely and brilliantly written that they do not go hopelessly out of date before they even start competing with the morning papers. It needs two or three new supplements to the indispensable Dictionary of American Biography.

The Humane Society of New York issued a statement yesterday clarifying its opposition to the Metcalf-Hatch Act, which permits the state and city health departments to requisition animals from public-aided pounds for medical experimentation in approved research laboratories.

Plans for the first Protestant church to be constructed within the boundaries of a New York City public housing project were announced yesterday by Dr. Kenneth D. Miller, executive director of the New York City Mission Society.

CAMDEN, N. J., Jan. 7 -- Three days of balloting for new officers of a 5,000-member union local covering membership in five plants, including the Campbell Soup Company, ended today with a Roman Catholic priest agreeing to charges by the union local president that he was attempting to influence the election.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 7 -- In a startling shift in Government policy, Chancellor Konrad Adenauer of the German Federal Republic tonight asked for wholesale changes in the European Army Treaty that would add German divisions to the defense of Europe.

Your editorial comment on the need for more adequate maintenance and repair of school buildings is one that could be echoed, I am sure, for city hospitals, colleges and many other public buildings. And the need is one about which citizens and many city officials would agree, though perhaps with differing degrees of vehemence.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower held his third meeting as President-elect yesterday with Prime Minister Winston Churchill of Great Britain, a ninety-five-minute session during most of which the two men were alone in a room of the fourth-floor apartment of Bernard M. Baruch, 4 East Sixty-sixth Street.

The eightieth anniversary of American Reform Judaism, founded in Cincinnati by the late Rabbi Isaac Mayer Wise "to adapt Judaism to the American way of life," was marked last night with special ceremonies and a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. More than 300 American Jewish leaders from various sections of the country attended.
City College rolled to its sixtht victory in eight starts last night[ as Wagner College bowed to theI [Beavers, 73--60, at the losers'I gynmasium on Grymes Hill, Staten! Island.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., Jan. 7 -- The Federal Government joined Westchester County and Mamaroneck today in prosecuting three of the defendants accused of storing munitions in a closed gasoline station here for a revolution in Cuba against the regime there of President Fulgencio Batista.

The twelfth annual "dawn patrol breakfast" of the Greater New York Councils of the Boy Scouts of America was held yesterday morning in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. It opened officially the organization's 1953 campaign, which has a goal of $2,000,000 for maintaining and increasing Scout activities and camps in the metropolitan area.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Northern Natural Gas Company of Omaha contended today that it had not violated Federal Power Commission orders in selling its gas wells and leases to a subsidiary.

SEATTLE, Jan. 7 -- A chartered C-46 transport plane carrying thirty-seven soldiers on the last long leg of their homeward trip from the Far East was missing today over mountainous country of southeast Idaho or Wyoming.

Midtown has taken on a nautical look this week with traffic on parts of East Forty-sixth and East Forty-seventh Streets and Depew Place clogged by boats headed into Grand Central Palace where the annual National Motor Boat Show will start its eight-day run tomorrow night.

A second-period outburst that netted them four goals enabled the Chicago Black Hawks to beat the New York Rangers in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. On the over-all, the Blues outskated their foes, but they could not match their rivals' middle-period surge, and had to leave the ice on the short end of the 6-to-4 count.

LONDON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- A 13-year-old American boy who ran away from his new home in London because he was homesick for his old neighborhood in New York, was found in France today after a three-day search.

The city's efforts to settle the week-old bus strike bogged down in "hopeless deadlock" yesterday, and union and company officials predicted that it would be at least another week before buses that normally carry 3,500,000 daily riders started running again.

Burials were halted yesterday at six cemeteries in the metropolitan area by a strike of about 200 gravediggers and other workers that began at 8 A. M. Originally the union, Local 365 of the Building Service Employes International Union, A. F. L., threatened to stop work at eighteen cemeteries in Brooklyn, Westchester and Queens.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between 8 and 14 years of age a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified. The programs follow:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin informed the Republican Senate leadership today that the Senate Permanent Investigating subcommittee, which he will head, would not press a demand for exclusive jurisdiction over communism as a field of inquiry.

The Bach Aria Group, William H. Scheide, director, presented the second concert of its 1952-53 subscription series at Town Hall last evening. Major works on the program were the Cantata No. 100, "Was Gott tut, das ist wohlgetan," and the Cantata No. 60, "O Ewigkeit, du Donnerwort." A group of arias for soprano, alto, tenor and bass completed the program.

TOKYO, Thursday, Jan. 8 -- The Chinese Communists resumed their attacks yesterday against the ridges north of Kumhwa on the central front in Korea, and again sent their Russian-designed MIG fighters into the air over northwest Korea to clash with American Sabre jets of the Fifth Air Force.

James P. Warburg, author and financier, said last night that the incoming administration of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, was confronted with the choice of seeking peace through restoring the unity of Germany or through "a precarious balance" of military power in a permanently divided Europe.

NEWARK, Jan. 7 -- The power of politics over the waterfront was demonstrated today to the New Jersey Law Enforcement Council when Mayor John V. Kenny of Jersey City divulged that he was canceling the municipal pier lease of a stevedore corporation whose vice president had given testimony unfavorable to Mr. Kenny before the New York State Crime Commission.

With four or five of its members reputedly willing to be tapped for Mayor in next November's election, the Board of Estimate naturally insisted that any long-range fiscal plan for submission to the state be as inoffensive as possible to the largest number of voters.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Big Jack Kramer of the United States squared his professional series at a match apiece tonight with Frank Sedgman of Australia, defeating the Aussie decisively, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 4.

Stuard Hirschman, 91-year-old real estate leader who died last Dec. 16, disposed of his estate, estimated at $6,000,000, in a will and nineteen codicils drawn within about two and one-half years of his death. This was disclosed yesterday in Surrogate's Court, where the documents were offered for probate. Mr. Hirschman lived at 225 West Eighty-sixth Street.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 8 -- Premier Marshal Tito and seven of the highest ranking Roman Catholic Bishops exercising their functions in Yugoslavia agreed in a conference today to seek a "settlement" of church-state differences.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Jack Kramer, king of the professional tennis players, isn't abdicating just yet.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 563,085 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 42,414 cars, or 8.1 per cent, above the preceding week, 47.031 cars, or 7.7 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 99,342 cars, or 15.0 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.
Brooklyn Borough President John Cashmore sought last night to rally educational leaders, parents and political forces in Brooklyn to fight for increased state aid for education.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8 -- Grain future prices were irregular today, with more confidence evident and the market showing greater rallying capacity than in some time. Bulges still ran into heavy selling, but the general opinion seems to be that the liquidating pressure has tapered off.
Two residents of Massachusetts and a woman who lives in Westhampton Beach, L. I., topped the roll of fifty-three contributors who added $1,102.65 yesterday to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Representative Clarence E. Kilburn, Republican of New York, said today he had been promised that the Armed Services Committee of the House of Representatives would review his plan to choose an alternative site for the proposed Plattsburg, N. Y., Air Force Base.

A committee to bring about closer cooperation between the American Horse Shows Association, the national authority, and the United States Equestrian Team, Inc., whose main concern lies in international horse show competition, has been formed.

DENVER, Colo., Jan. 8 (UP) -- Lewis W. Douglas, former United States Ambassador to Britain, said today it was essential to peace that the United States "re-establish communications" with the Soviet Union.

JERSEY CITY, Jan. 8 -- An autopsy will be performed here tomorrow morning upon the body of Frank (Biffo) De Lorenzo, former waterfront boss in Jersey City and Bayonne, it was decided this afternoon by Hudson County Prosecutor Horace K. Roberson and Chief Medical Examiner Vincent Butler.

The Rev. Dr. J. Henry Carpenter, executive secretary of the Brooklyn Division of the Protestant Council of the City of New York, whose original passport application for a trip to Japan was rejected because of alleged "political activities" last spring, announced receipt of it yesterday.

The Federation of Jewish Philanthropies, which maintains 116 affiliated hospitals and social service agencies, will conduct a "Jewish Community Roll Call" for the remainder of this month to enlist widespread support in the city toward the Federation's campaign for $20,000,000.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 8 -- President Sukarno in a twenty-five minute speech reviewing achievements in the past year, reopened the Indonesian Parliament today. He urged Indonesians to make continued sacrifices in the development of their country because "a state does not come into existence merely by being proclaimed.

At a special meeting marked by exchanges of bitter charges, the Board of Education last night dismissed seven teachers who had refused to answer school officials questions dealing with alleged membership in the Communist party.

The coming coronation of Queen Elizabeth II of England sprinkled a light touch over the collection that Mr. John presented yesterday morning. There is almost a fairy princess aura about the hats this milliner dedicates to spring, 1953.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Jan. 8 -- Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery, Deputy Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, urged here today that the British Government formally join the European Defense Community.

The Sydenham Society, Inc., 565 Manhattan Avenue has established in the New York Community Trust an initial fund of $100,000 for use at Sydenham Hospital, Harry C. Oppenheimer, president of the society, announced yesterday.
ALBANY, Jan. 8 -- Democratic lawmakers said today they would give top priority this year to enactment by the Legislature of a bill authorizing state-wide permanent personal registration.

ALBANY, Jan. 8 -- Senator Francis J. Mahoney of Manhattan and Assemblyman Eugene F. Bannigan, new Democratic minority leaders of the Legislature, agreed today to meet with Mayor Impellitteri and other city officials in New York on Sunday for a discussion of the city's finances.

Plans for a one-story garage- type building to replace a similar one-story structure at 618 West Forty-seventh Street have been announced in connection with the purchase of the property by Henry Lichtig from G. Crawford Eadie The buyer was represented by Irving Abraham, attorney.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The Senate Armed Services Committee was understood here tonight to have made plans to meet next Thursday to interrogate Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense-designate, and the three service secretaries preparatory to "clearing" them for approval as members of the Eisenhower Cabinet.

Twenty-five-year leases for the use of facilities at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, were signed yesterday at the Hotel Roosevelt by the domestic and international airlines using the 4,900-acre field and the Port of New York Authority.

The Rev. Dr. William J. Villaume, executive director of the Department of the Urban Church of the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A., called last night for "a new kind of churchmanship" to cope with conditions brought about by population shifts.

As in her previous recital, Shirley Aronoff, who presented a program of piano music last night in Town Hall, showed considerable natural aptitude for the keyboard. But again the same faults were present -- a tendency to slow up and sentimentalize over lyric sections, thereby throwing the entire musical architecture out of plumb.

The national election was not only the most important economic event of last year but "also may well prove to have been a major turning point in our national history," the Guaranty Trust Company of New York says in its annual report.

Fish prices are sharply higher this week-end. Most of the popular species were marked up 5 to 10 cents a pound. Unfavorable fishing weather and the mooring of boats by many fishermen over the holidays had reduced receipts, the City Department of Markets reported yesterday.

Ralph (Tiger) Jones, popular middleweight from Yonkers, will face Rocky Castellani of Luzerne, Pa., in the main attraction of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight. The fight has attracted considerable interest around town, and is likely to draw better than most of the Garden shows have this season.
TOKYO, Friday, Jan. 9 (AP) -- The Japanese Maritime Safety Board said today that eight crew members were dead and twelve missing in the break-up of the Swedish tanker Avanti in a Pacific gale.

The striking bus workers are seeking a forty-hour week with no cut in the pay they used to get for working forty-four to forty-eight hours, with five to nine hours of guaranteed overtime. The old basic wage ranged from $1.66 to $1.73 1/2 an hour.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Basil O'Connor of New York, chairman of the Executive Committee of the Harry S. Truman Library. Inc., said tonight that contributions large and small would be welcomed for the institution that will house the President's papers at Grandview, Mo.

PARIS, Jan. 8 -- Jean-Louis Barrault, French actor-producer-director, said today that the Egyptian Government had canceled his projected series of performances in Cairo and Alexandria for "political reasons."

WITH the possible exception of the dove shooter, the duck hunter probably expends more ammunition with less return in game than any other shooter. In both instances the high ratio of misses usually is attributed to faulty range estimation rather than bad shooting.

Tonight at 7 o'clock the wonders of another National Motor Boat Show will be unveiled in Grand Central Palace on Lexington Avenue to thousands of skippers of yachting experience and even more thousands of landlubbers with ambitions to spend vacations afloat.

Walter Florell is celebrating the spring season by producing one of the best millinery collections yet to come out of this salon. Shown yesterday at 29 East Fifty-third Street, the hats were filled with imaginative ideas, severely simple or gay and merry but always essentially wearable and smart. Shown in conjunction with the millinery were this designer's custom clothes.

The Forty Bay street Corporation, has sold the storage yards on the west side of Columbia Street, between Sigourney and Bay Streets, in Brooklyn, to the Mae Realty Company, represented by Philip Silver, attorney. James B. Fisher was the broker and the Title Guarantee and Trust Company insured title.

The National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis announced yesterday that it was ready to purchase all commercial gamma globulin now on hand or to be produced before next June 30 for inclusion in a national pool to be used in the fight against polio.

JOLIET, Ill., Jan. 8 (UP) -- Nathan Leopold, "thrill" slayer with Richard Loeb of kidnapped Bobby Franks in the Nineteen Twenties, pleaded for parole today on the ground that "I have changed completely."
KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 8 (UP) -- Armed troops sped into Karachi today to break up Communist-led rioting that killed at least nine persons and injured more than sixty in two days.

A freezing rain that formed a treacherous coat of ice fell yesterday over a wide section of the Midwest and the East. It created hazardous road conditions, snapped power lines and forced the cancellation of many airplane flights.

With the departure from the French Cabinet of Foreign Minister Robert Schuman a great Frenchman and a great European walks off the stage of Western affairs. For four and a half years he has been the champion and the symbol of European unity, and he played his part so well that the work he did cannot and will not be undone.

! Members 'of the women's comJ mittee of the American Museum of Natural History gave their first Portrait Room luncheon for this yea' yesterday at the rAuseurn, Central Park West and Seventy-I ninih Street. The guests of honor !were Alexander M. White, president of the museum, and Dr. Alr 'bert E. Parr, director.
RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 8 -- Rejection by Asian Socialists of a formal merger with the Socialist International appeared certain here today.

Jerry Finkelstein testified for more than an hour yesterday before a grand jury investigating a $10,000 "campaign contribution" in 1949 to former Mayor William O'Dwyer, but the former City Planning Commissioner still found himself facing a possible citation for contempt.

The State of Rhode Island sold yesterday $2,500,000 of Blackstone Valley Sewer Distinct bonds due from 1966 to 1983 to a banking syndicate headed by Chemical Bank and Trust Company at a bid of 101.05 for an interest cost of 2 1/2 per cent. The bonds were re-offered at yields ranging from 2 per cent to 2 1/2 per cent. The balance in syndicate account at the close was reported $1,888,000.
The Army has chosen tentatively a rousing march, "The Army's Always There," by Sam H. Stept, a professional song writer, as the new all-Army theme song.
New sensations in the waterfront crime investigation were shaping up yesterday on both sides of the Hudson River.

Mr. Churchill departed at 10:30 o'clock yesterday morning from the home of his old friend, Bernard M. Baruch, 4 East Sixty-sixth Street, where he had stayed since arriving from England Monday on the Cunard liner Queen Mary.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Carl Snavely, president of the American Football Coaches Association, criticized college leaders tonight for making the coach the scapegoat of the game's abuses.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Jan. 8 -- Atomic power for private industry is feasible within five years unless policy changes in Government control slows or halts current development projects, according to Dr. Karl P. Cohen, vice president of the Walter Kidde Nuclear Laboratories, Inc.
The egg was, as it were, the guest of honor at a luncheon earlier this week at the Statler Hotel for the press and trade.

Coffee consumption remained at high levels in 1952 in contrast with expectations to the contrary, Frederick H. Silence, president of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, Inc., said yesterday at the group's annual meeting.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- A supervised national program of intercollegiate football telecasts such as was carried out in 1952, but more elastic in recognizing regional problems and time differentials, was recommended today to the National Collegiate Athletic Association for 1953 by its television committee.

Fifty-eight city and other local governments adopted last year the council-manager form of government, bringing to 1,141 the number in the United States and Canada now under this plan, the National Municipal League reported yesterday.

Worried by union efforts to capitalize on splits among top city officials, the Board of Estimate sought yesterday to present the appearance of a united front in the city's attempts to settle the eight-day-old strike of 8,000 members of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., on eight privately owned bus lines.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Retail food prices decreased 1.1 per cent in the period from Nov. 24 to Dec. 15, the Bureau of Labor Statistic estimated today.

LONDON, Jan. 8 -- The Dutch liner Klipfontein sank today off the coast o Mozambique in East Africa. A radio message from the British Union Castle liner Bloemfontein Castle said she had rescued all passengers and members of the crew.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 8 -- Radio and television are to be allowed to poke fun at or criticize the Government and the conduct of Mexican politics. Legislation is being prepared to extend the Constitutional guarantees of press freedom to the two media that have been barred by law from discussing politics or criticizing the actions of the Government.

Two million New Yorkers who normally drop 3,500,000 fares daily into the coin boxes of the eight struck bus lines ended their eighth day without bus transportation yesterday, and apparently were learning to live without it.

MONTREAL, Jan. 8 (UP) -- Maurice (Rocket) Richard broke a National Hockey League point-scoring record tonight as the Montreal Canadiens and the New York Rangers staged a lively 4-4 draw before 14,110 fans in the Forum.

Seasonal influences cut New York bank loans to business $114,000,000 last week in the second successive weekly decline. The reduction, which compares with one of $71,000,000 in the corresponding week of last year, was the largest since July 2, when business loans were off $162,000,000.

STRASBOURG, France, Jan. 8 -- Uncertainty regarding the fate of the European defense treaty in the National Assembly in France and in other member countries impeded the work of the drafters of a European constitution, which was under discussion here today in a special assembly of the European Coal and Steel Community.

" My Darlin' Aida," sumptuously produced by Robert L. Joseph with Dorothy Sarnoff and Elaine Malbin starred, will quit the Winter Garden after Sunday night's benefit for the Equity Welfare Fund. On Dec. 23, Mr. Joseph expressed the hope that if sufficient box-office strength developed after the customary pre-holiday recession, the musical would stay right where it was.
ROME, Jan. 8 (AP) -- An Italian Protestant evangelist was convicted at Alessandria today on a charge of holding a religious meeting that had not been authorized by the police.

We are indebted to Mayor John V. Kenny of Jersey City for lifting a corner of the veil that has hitherto largely obscured the relations between politics and the waterfront, the incubating ground of many evils.

MOSCOW, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Nearly a thousand Soviet economists and scientists gathered here today to admit publicly their errors in once praising the wartime economic views of former Politburo member Nikolai A. Voznesensky.
SAVANNAH, Ga., Jan. 8 (AP) -- Two giant B-50 Air Force bombers collided in flight tonight and at least six airmen died when one of the four-engine planes crashed into marshland near Savannah.

It begins to look as though we might be nearing the legislative stage of the years-long agitation for modernization of the building code as it affects legitimate theatre houses. Nearly three years have passed since Councilman Hugh Quinn introduced his bills to stimulate new theatre construction and give audiences more comforts.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The 70-21 defeat by the Senate yesterday of an attempt by liberals to break the backs of filibusters has not discouraged a new move in the House of Representatives to soften similar rules there.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8 -- Lawrence F. Fisher, of "Body by Fisher" fame, appeared at the du Pont anti-trust trial in Federal District Court today as the Government's case moved to the charge that the six Fisher Brothers were a stumbling block to the alleged du Pont domination of General Motors Corporation.

PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 8 -- The adoption of a plan, under which the Ivy League, will be greatly strengthened and members will play at least five league football games annually, will be urged by six undergraduate newspapers tomorrow.

Net operating earnings of the Manufacturers Trust Company last year were $13,366,183, equal to $5.31 a share, against $12,485,737, or $4.96 in 1951, according to the bank's annual report issued yesterday.

RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 7 -- A British Embassy spokesman said here today that the Burmese Government had given no indication of a desire to dispense with the services of the British military mission. The spokesman stated that, on the contrary, Burma had expressed satisfaction with the work of the mission and wished to continue its services.

Bernard M. Baruch, 82-year-old adviser to Presidents since the days of Woodrow Wilson, signified yesterday his availability as an adviser when needed by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, but he said he expected to remain a private citizen.

Five members of the champion Detroit Lions have been selected for The Associated Press All-Pro two-platoon football team. Chosen for the offensive array were End Cloyce Box, Guard Lou Creekmur and Quarterback Bobby Layne. On the defensive squad are Tackle Thurman McGraw and Halfback Jack Christiansen.

" You Are There," a former radio series presenting the re-enactment of great events, will make its television debut over the Columbia Broadcasting System network on Sunday, Feb. 1, from 6 to 6:30 P. M.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- A fourteen-page brochure on the national blood program, issued today by the Office of Defense Mobilization, told how blood collected by the American Red Cross was a life-saving national resource both for the armed forces and for the civilian population.

WHEN Charles Dickens died in 1870 at the age of 58 he left an estate equivalent to more than one million dollars today. The unhappy child who was put to work at 12 pasting labels on bottles in a shoe-blacking factory had come a long way. He was the most popular novelist in the world, a celebrity accustomed to unceasing adulation since his twenty-fifth year, the friend of the great of two continents.

TRENTON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Judge Thomas J. Stanton of the New Jersey Superior Court's chancery division has signed a temporary order forbidding the sale of price-fixed "Presto" appliances at cut-rate prices by a Harrison chain store.
TOKYO, Friday, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Eighth Army tactical summary 288, to 6 P. M., Thursday:

Harold H. Dice has been made assistant general manager of the Allison division of General Motors Corporation of Indianapolis, succeeding Paul W. Rhame, who has been made general manager of the New Departure division in Bristol, Conn.

Arguments for wage increases for 1,500,000 unionized railroad workers were completed yesterday at a closed meeting of representatives of twenty-one union and 132 Class One railroads and a Government referee. A railroad spokesman, who made the announcement, said the carriers would begin presenting their arguments Monday at 9:30 A. M. in the New York Central Building, 230 Park Avenue, where yesterday's session was held.

ALBANY, Jan. 8 -- Dr. Herman E. Hilleboe, State Health Commissioner, announced today that about 12,000 state employes in the Metropolitan New York and Long Island area would receive free chest X-ray examinations starting Jan. 12 under a program sponsored by the State Health Department and the State Civil Service Department's Personnel Council.

An official program will be published by the Presidential Inaugural Committee, but it will carry no advertising, the National Better Business Bureau, Inc., has been advised by Joseph G. McGarraghy, chairman of the committee. The latter's statement was made in reply to a query by the N. B. B. B. as to the status of a "Special Souvenir Inaugural Edition" of The Diplomat, a monthly magazine published in Washington, D. C.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 8 -- The Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service stepped into the strike of 450 waterfront railroad carloaders today. The dispute has tied up dry cargo facilities in the port of Philadelphia for two days.

The overwhelming defeat of the first effort this session to alter the Senate rule under which filibusters are made easy was hardly unexpected. The particular means of tightening the closure procedure proposed by the Anderson resolution flew in the face of a tradition of more than a century and a half by implying that the Senate was not a continuing body but one, like the House, which had to reconstitute itself at each session.

ROME, Jan. 8 -- Italian authorities seized the Yugoslav consulate in Milan as security for a sum of money that an Italian citizen asserts is owed him by the Yugoslav Government. Although the seizure resulted from a civil suit in which the Government is in no way concerned, it is not likely to improve relations between Italy and Yugoslavia.

The stock market went through a series of contradictions yesterday, but despite an easier tone in the afternoon after a morning of strength, the general price structure managed to show more gains than losses. However, the composite averages of THE NEW YORK TIMES went into lower ground because of a drop in two of the principal industrial components.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8 -- Many furniture factories will leave the International Winter Home Furnishings market here with enough orders to maintain production for four months, it was reported today by three furniture men in the American Furniture Mart.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 8 -- The Indian Government is to nationalize the country's civil aviation industry and run it as a state-owned enterprise, authoritative sources reported today.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 8 -- Leading college officials, who said they had no confidence in proposed investigations of colleges and universities by existing House or Senate committees, urged the President-elect, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, today to appoint an impartial commission of responsible citizens to make a study of the charges against higher education.

Physicians should realize that they must respond to public demands for plans to help people pay their medical bills, the incoming president of the New York Academy of Medicine warned here last night at the academy building, 2 East 103d Street.

MANILA, Jan. 8 -- United States Ambassador Raymond A. Spruance and President Elpidio Quirino conferred with heads of the Mutual Security Agency's technical mission and Philippine Government officials in an effort to iron out differences over implementation of the American assistance program.

For the first time since the start of the international tournament at the Hastings Chess Club in England, all five games, scheduled for the ninth round, were drawn, yesterday, according to a report from London.

ALBANY, Jan. 8 (UP) -- A bill that would outlaw shape-ups in hiring longshoremen on the New York waterfront was under consideration today. Introduced yesterday by Assemblyman John R. Brook, Republican of Manhattan, the bill would make it a misdemeanor to hold shape-ups on "docks, piers, wharves, streets or waterfront property or in waterfront warehouses of New York."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Jamaica needs an "imaginative, farsighted development program" prosecuted with vigor if it is to achieve economic and political stability, a mission sent to the British island in the Caribbean by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development has concluded.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- A special committee of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tonight recommended a limitation on the number of football and basketball games a college can play. It also suggested a rule stating when practice sessions should start.

LONDON, Jan. 8 -- Three African chiefs from Nyasaland protested here today against the plan to federate three British territories in Central Africa, now under discussion at a governmental conference here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Robert A. Lovett, retiring Secretary of Defense, in a "briefing" of the House Armed Services Committee today, failed to confirm estimates by President Truman and Prime Minister Churchill that the threat of war was less imminent now than it had been in recent years.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., Jan. 8 -- The position of the United States in the international wheat agreement will get top priority by the Department of Agriculture, Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary-designate, said today.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 8 (UP) -- Vic Seixas and Maureen (Little Mo) Connolly led America's five entries into the second round of the Australian tennis championships today as this country's players made their first post World War II start without Frank Sedgman and Ken McGregor.

A blockfront taxpayer on Westbury Avenue, between Cherry and Stonahinge Lanes in Carle Place, L. I., has been purchased by Jack Brause, real estate operator. The building was erected in 1946 by Levitt Sons for their Old Westbury development.
PALO ALTO, Calif., Jan. 8 (AP) -- Bob Mathias received The Associated Press 1952 male "athlete of the year" award today, but declared he wished an Olympic teammate had won it.

The eleventh annual Carey-Thomas Award for distinguished creative book publishing was presented yesterday to the Macmillan Company. The award was made for the editorial planning, production and publishing of "The Diary of George Templeton Strong, 1835-1875," edited in four volumes by Allen Nevins and Milton Halsey.
The International Longshoremen's Association has been collecting contributions from business concerns for eighteen years for a confidential fund used to fight communism on the waterfront.

The Manufacturers National Bank of Detroit, Mich., reported as of Dec. 31, 1952, total deposits of $598,563,586 and total assets of $622,467,872, compared, respectively, with $564,267,387 and $588,259,520 on June 30. Cash on hand and due from banks amounted to $143,331,278 against $136,542,985 holdings of United States Government securities to $306,032,792 against $260,794,394 and loans and discounts to $155,963,979 against $147,055,883.
Incorporating many styling and mechanical advances, the Chevrolet and Oldsmobile divisions of the General Motors Corporation announced yesterday their 1953 automobile lines.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Jan. 8 -- The Algonquin Gas Transmission Company was ordered by Supreme Court Justice Elbert T. Gallagher today to remove within forty-five days two and one-half miles of natural gas pipeline from private lands in northern Westchester County, and to reimburse the property owners for all damages to the land.
PARIS, Jan. 8 -- President Truman's final State of the Union message won editorial praise here today as a record of courageous action by the outgoing President.

Extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act for a minimum of three years was advocated yesterday by the National Council of American Importers. The act, extended by Congress for two years in 1951, expires next June 11.

Norman Thomas, chairman of the Tresca Memorial Committee, in a letter to Joseph M. Proskauer, chairman of the State Crime Commission, made public yesterday, urged that the commission investigate the ten-year-old murder of Carlo Tresca, anti-totalitarian editor.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Selective Service officials called today for sweeping revision of draft legislation and regulation to plug wide "leakages" in the nation's rapidly diminishing manpower pool.
Twenty-eight building service employes and waitresses to whom the late Stuard Hirschman, multi-millionaire real estate operator, bequeathed $500 each, are, for the most part, happy about it.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 8 -- There appears to be a growing acceptance here of the belief that the motion picture industry soon will enter upon a new era of startling technical innovations in photography, projection and sound recording that will make present-day pictures almost as outmoded as the silent films.

Commodity futures closed irregularly yesterday on the New York exchanges. Volume increased in most lines, particularly in coffee. Cottonseed and soybean oils, sugar, cocoa, rubber and tin closed lower. Coffee, zinc, lead and wool were higher and potatoes and hides ended mixed.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Prime Minister Churchill of Britain came to the capital today to say good-by to President Truman. He will leave here for a vacation in Jamaica tomorrow.

The years just ahead must be an era of good feeling between Government and business, Benjamin Strong, president of the United States Trust Company of New York, declared at the annual meeting yesterday. Those years, said, "may well involve adjustments of great magnitude in our national economy, as defense needs change and the impact of our vast productive capacity is fully felt."

The United States contract bridge team of John R. Crawford of Philadelphia and Howard Schenken, Samuel Stayman, B. J. Becker, Theodore Lightner and George Rapee. all of New York. dampened Europe's hopes last night for the 1953 Team-of-Four world championship.

The 1953 fund campaign of the Protestant Council, which provides welfare services to young and hospitalized New Yorkers, has set a goal of $315,230 needed in contributions to carry out its program. This was announced yesterday at a meeting of the campaign's special gifts committee at the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway.

BERLIN, Jan. 8 -- East Germany's Liberal Democratic party appeared tonight to be combing from its ranks all officials who have resisted Communist plans for rearmament and "building the basis of socialism."

CHICAGO, Jan. 8 -- Restraint rather than revolution appears to characterize the latest edition of the Good Design Show which opened here today. This is the seventh time that new selections have been made for this continuing exhibit, jointly sponsored by the Merchandise Mart of this city and the Museum of Modern Art of New York.

Skiing prospects for the weekend continue to be bright with even the Berkshires of western Massachusetts and the Poconos of Pennsylvania finally coming through with satisfactory reports, according to observation yesterday.
TOKYO, Friday, Jan. 9 -- Raiding parties of the United Nations Command struck boldly into enemy lines on the western and eastern fronts in Korea over Wednesday night and through yesterday.

No one will discount the strong following of the New York Knickerbockers, but Joe Lapchick's lads had to take the back seat last night at Madison Square Garden, where they conquered the Milwaukee Hawks, 81 -- 68. The bigger attraction was the curtain-raiser, in which the Boston Celtics, with Bob Cousy excelling again, overcame the Rochester Royals, 88 -- 85, in overtime.
The tea industry in this country is about to embark on an unusual venture in international business relations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The overwhelming defeat yesterday of the effort to get the Senate to agree that it is not a "continuing body" and therefore must adopt rules at the opening of each new Congress, and the few hours that both sides were content to assign to the debate, make it clear that the advocates of the change were engaged in merely a "token" demonstration.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 8 (AP) -- With a snub for Bill Veeck's Browns, the Indians today listed a twenty-nine-game home night schedule for 1953.

HONG KONG, Jan. 8 -- Cardinal Spellman of New York, who arrived here today from the Philippines, is scheduled to celebrate a mass tomorrow at a new Catholic refugee center established in Kowloon to honor the memory of the late Bishop Francis X. Ford.

ATHENS, Jan. 8 -- Italy's Premier, Alcide De Gasperi, accompanied by three important aides, arrived in Athens today. The Greek Premier, Field Marshal Alexander Papagos, and Foreign Minister Stephen Stephanopoulos greeted him at the airport.

The orchestral works of the program given by George Szell and the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall with Clifford Curzon as solo pianist, were all of the sure-fire quality. And all were given authoritative performances.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 8 -- Fears that the new French Government intended to withdraw still farther from support of the European Defense Community Treaty pervaded private comment by Government officials and newspaper speculation here today.

The health of the fabulous invalid, the American legitimate theatre, was closely examined yesterday, and despite the discovery of minor afflictions, was conceded generally to have a fine chance of indefinite survival.
As a private citizen having no axe to grind I note the following effects of the bus strike:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The 10,000th registration statement filed under the Securities Act of 1933 reached the Securities and Exchange Commission here today. The registration came from the Louisville Gas and Electric Company and was for 200,000 shares of no par common stock. Lehman Brothers and Blyth Co., Inc. were named as the principal underwriters.

Ray M. Evans and William B. Anderson have been elected directors of the Columbia Gas System, it was announced yesterday by Stuart M. Crocker, chairman. Mr. Evans is president of the Evans Lead Company, Charleston, W. Va., and Mr. Anderson is president of the Anderson-Newcomb Company, Huntington, W. Va.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (UP) -- The Senate Republican Policy Committee assigned its three top members today to seek a showdown with Eisenhower headquarters on the control of Federal patronage.

A Braille telephone switchboard, on which aluminum pegs pop out to enable blind operators to identify calls, was installed yesterday at the Queens Industrial Diivsion of the Lighthouse, 36-20 Northern Boulevard, Long Island City, Queens.

National Distillers Products Corporation cut the price on its Old Grand-dad and Old Taylor bonded bourbons by $6.25 a case yesterday, which will result in a reduction in the New York market of 76 cents a fifth. Both brands will sell here for $6.59 instead of $7.35.

The solution to the current profit squeeze induced by declining margins and increased operating costs is related selling, William J. Pilat, president of the Russell W. Allen Company, Inc., market researchers, said yesterday, Mr. Pilat discussed a study on related selling in boys' departments at a dinner meeting of the Boys Apparel Buyers Association and the Astor Hotel.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange again turned barely steady and declined 13 to 39 points net yesterday with the weakness most pronounced in the old crop months.
Metropolitan art events have picked up in interest and variety during the first days of the new year, and this week offers several thoughtfully prepared exhibitions.

BOSTON, Jan. 8 -- Former Representative Christian A. Herter began his administration as the fifty-ninth Governor of Massachusetts today by recommending a sweeping reorganization of seven agencies of the commonwealth.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 8 -- The first break in Baltimore's strike of city laborers came today when janitors returned to work in nine additional school buildings, permitting 15,000 additional children to return to school.

Ohio Edison Company's offering of 479,846 shares of new common stock to the company's stockholders for subscription at $35.25 a share on a one-for-ten basis until Jan. 21 went into effect yesterday, with a banking syndicate headed by Morgan Stanley Co. handling the underwriting.
A conference called by the American Standards Association voted yesterday to establish tests and performance specifications for textiles used in the hotel, restaurant and institutional fields.

PARIS, Jan. 8 -- Rene Mayer, the new French Premier, in forming his Cabinet today, removed Robert Schuman from the post of Foreign Minister, thus increasing the doubts about the future French foreign policy that had been caused by M. Mayer's speech to the National Assembly last Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- During the week ended Jan. 7, member bank reserves increased $952,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

ALBANY, Jan. 8 -- Governor Dewey's highway-safety program, particularly his proposals for twice a year state inspection of all-vehicles and compulsory automobile liability insurance, as well as his judicial - reform recommendations, appeared today to be facing heavy Republican opposition in the Legislature.

I have read with interest your comments on the recent strikes and am in accord with everything you say. The bus drivers are certainly entitled to an increase, for they are virtually doing the job of two men, but I regret to be obliged to say I do not like the arrogant attitude of some of their leaders.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (UP) -- Walter S. Franklin, president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, said today that the road advanced $13,500,000 to the Long Island Rail Road in the fourteen years before the Long Island went bankrupt in 1949.

A program that assertedly contained the true aims of the Communist party in the United States was outlined yesterday by a defense attorney at the trial of thirteen secondary Communist leaders accused of conspiring to teach and advocate overthrow of the Government by force and violence.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Small business production pools have obtained more than $4,000,000 worth of defense contracts since last August when the program was started, the Small Defense Plants Administration disclosed today. In addition, the agency said, more than $113,000,000 in proposed defense contracts have been selected as suitable for pool production.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that department store sales in the week ended last Saturday were 5 per cent above sales in the corresponding week a year ago. The report also showed that sales for 1952 were 1 per cent above sales for 1951.

Douglas Fairbanks Jr., the motion-picture actor and a debonair figure in society on both sides of the Atlantic, made his debut on Wednesday evening as a producer of films for television. But this morning the play, seen over N. B. C., must wait. The commercial is the thing.

James (Dinty) Moore, owner and operator of Dinty Moore's Restaurant, 216 West Forty-sixth Street, who died Christmas Day at the age of 83, left the bulk of his estate to his daughter, Anna Moore, cut off two children with $1 each, and left his widow the minimum required by law.
Hiram Walker - Gooderham Worts, Ltd., and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the quarter ended Nov. 30, net profit of $5,779,578 after all charges including $7,307,400 in taxes.

The generous grants left to seven women's colleges by the late Mrs. Thomas Lamont are gratifying recognition of the increasing appreciation of the importance of higher education for women. Of the more than 1,300,000 students enrolled in colleges this year about 35 per cent are women.

The American Fund for Israel Institutions, which supports and maintains a network of fifty-two cultural, educational and social welfare institutions in Israel, held its annual $100-a-plate dinner-concert last night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
EAST LANSING, Mich., Jan. 8 (AP) -- John A. Hannah, president of Michigan State College, today termed his selection as Assistant Secretary of Defense "akin to a call to military service."

Capt. E. V. Rickenbacker, president and general manager of Eastern Air Lines, took a look last night at the till for the first week's operations of 1953. A quick totting up showed that passenger, freight, mail and other revenues came to $3,545,990.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Government officials expressed concern tonight over developments from France and West Germany that might delay the formation of a European Army, already behind schedule.

ALBANY, Jan. 8 -- Bills to carry out a proposal of the state Republican organization that absentee ballots be available to physically disabled persons unable to go to the polls were introduced in the Legislature today. Adoption of the plan would provide votes for thousands.

DETROIT, Jan. 8 (UP) -- Rookie Glen Hall, substituting for injured Goalie Terry Sawchuck, turned in a shut-out tonight as the Detroit Red Wings defeated the Boston Bruins, 4 to 0, before 9,697 fans at Olympia.

The generous grants left to seven women's colleges by the late Mrs. Thomas Lamont are gratifying recognition of the increasing appreciation of the importance of higher education for women. Of the more than 1,300,000 students enrolled in colleges this year about 35 per cent are women.

The American Fund for Israel Institutions, which supports and maintains a network of fifty-two cultural, educational and social welfare institutions in Israel, held its annual $100-a-plate dinner-concert last night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

ALBANY, Jan. 8 -- Bills to carry out a proposal of the state Republican organization that absentee ballots be available to physically disabled persons unable to go to the polls were introduced in the Legislature today. Adoption of the plan would provide votes for thousands.

DETROIT, Jan. 8 (UP) -- Rookie Glen Hall, substituting for injured Goalie Terry Sawchuck, turned in a shut-out tonight as the Detroit Red Wings defeated the Boston Bruins, 4 to 0, before 9,697 fans at Olympia.
There is only one book published today. It is "Sulphur and Molasses," by Nell Waddell, an account of one year in the author's childhood. It is issued by Vantage Press at $2.75.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- President Truman has long prided himself on his prowess as a budget maker and his familiarity with details of budgets he has submitted to Congress, the present one being his eighth.
ADEN, Jan. 9 (UP) -- The Rose Mary, 632-ton Honduras-registered tanker, has been held here under British injunctions since June 17.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 9 -- The motion-picture industry will wrap up its campaign for repeal of the 20 per cent Federal tax on theatre admissions with a special film short subject, which will be shown to the House Ways and Means Committee.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- President Truman estimated at $7,600,000,000 today the cost of military, economic and technical foreign aid during the 1954 fiscal year. This would be an increase of $1,100,000,000 over the amount appropriated by Congress for similar purposes this year, but the President said it was about $1,000,000,000 less than requested by the Mutual Security Director.

Price movements were irregular yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges. Volume fell off with only coffee and soybean oil showing more activity than during the previous day. Cocoa, lead, tin, potatoes and wool closed higher. Sugar and coffee were lower. Hides, rubber, cottonseed oil, soybean oil and zinc ended mixed.

Delivery and installation of the city's 13,000 new parking meters will get under way about Jan. 20, with the first meters going to some of the city's "busiest sections," Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley announced yesterday.

The farce that is Soviet "scholarship" in the social sciences has rarely been revealed so clearly as in the meeting of economists in Moscow. Almost a thousand scholars gathered there to make cringing apology and abject recantation of the "crime" of having once approved a book by Nikolai A. Voznesensky, a Politburo member who disappeared four years ago.

The Chicago Great Western Railway is contemplating the sale of a $6,000,000 collateral trust bond issue. William N. Deramus 3d, president, told a meeting of the New York Society of Security Analysts yesterday that the proposed financing is to take care of the $3,000,000 of short-term notes outstanding and that the remaining $3,000,000 will be added to working capital.

A sign of hope that the city might not after all lose its $60,000,000-a-year exposition business was seen yesterday in the announcement that the Institute of Radio Engineers, one of the major users of Grand Central Palace in the past, has selected the Kingsbridge Armory in the Bronx for its March, 1954, exposition.

Combining a superb exhibition of boxing skill with flurries of savage fighting, Rocky Castellani, Luzerne, Pa., middleweight, last night shattered the title dreams of Ralph (Tiger) Jones of Yonkers in ten fast rounds at Madison Square Garden, but he had to be content with a split decision.

The same methods and media successfully used to spur more Americans to participate in the country's political freedoms should be utilized to help them participate in the fruits of the economic system. This was urged last night by Thomas d'Arcy Brophy, chairman of the board of the Kenyon Eckhardt advertising agency and president of the American Heritage Foundation.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 9 -- For the third consecutive day, acts of hooliganism, arson and looting continued in Karachi today, confirming the belief that some political organization is at the back of the organized and systematic attempts to defy law and order.

BERLIN, Jan. 9 -- Youth organizations in East Germany have come under the scrutiny of Communist leaders who are moving to break all resistance to transformation of their zone into a "people's democracy."

All was quiet on the bus strike front yesterday. Buses did not operate for the ninth straight day and neither did any of the city's machinery for settlement of the dispute between the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., and eight private transit lines.

Deputy Attorney General James Rosen of New Jersey began inquiry in Jersey City yesterday into the payment of $47,554 by Hudson County Prosecutor Horace K. Roberson to Frank Bielaski, a private investigator who heads the Research and Security Corporation here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The Treasury Department announced today that it has devised a means by which Chinese-type goods originating in Hong Kong can be allowed entry here without the danger of including Communist Chinese or North Korean products.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- President Truman has blamed politically inspired attacks on Korean war policy for the more than 49,000 military desertions since that war started, according to Doris Fleeson, Washington columnist for The Bell Syndicate.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9 -- Another wave of long liquidation and local selling overwhelmed buyers for a time today, with prices for all grains and soybeans dropping sharply, erasing much of the mid-week improvement.

It was disconcerting to read at the conclusion of your editorial "Mr. McCarran's Law," which commends the report of the President's Commission on Immigration and Naturalization, that you believe "abolition of the national origins quota system probably out of the range of practical politics at this time."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- President Truman asked Congress to authorize $41,535,000,000 to continue the build-up of the armed services to a state of constant readiness.

PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 9 -- Princeton's varsity basketball team overcame an eight-point deficit in the final period and then went on to defeat previously unbeaten Navy, 76 -- 75, in double overtime tonight.

The operators of the eight privately owned bus companies struck by the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., are ready and willing but not quite able to pay their 8,000 striking employes wages earned before the New Year's Day walkout, it developed yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 9 -- A proposed plan of union for the merger of the three major Presbyterian denominations in this country has been drawn up by a joint commission and will be mailed to pastors and leaders of the three church bodies tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Yugoslav Ambassador Vladimir Popovic disclosed tonight that his Government had asked the United States for increased military assistance because of the growing strength of Soviet forces on the borders of Yugoslavia.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) -- The Government today authorized the seven wholesale distributors of nickel in this country to raise their ceiling prices by 3 1/2 cents a pound for primary nickel.

The Park Terrace Apartments accommodating twelve families at 124-16 Rockaway Beach Boulevard in Rockaway Park, Queens, have been sold by Arthur Meyer to Moe Levine of Belle Harbor for cash above mortgages of $97,000. The sale was negotiated through E. Rae Robbins as broker. Elmer H. Settel was attorney for the seller and Maurice A. Taub acted for the buyer. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.
OTTAWA, Jan. 9 -- The Canadian Government announced tonight the floating of a $100,000,000 twenty-five-year bond issue to "feel out" the money market for a much bigger issue planned for 1954.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- President Truman changed his position today on compulsory health insurance.

Cruising along under the new and apt slogan "Boating's Fun," New York's annual January delight, the National Motor Boat Show, opened for the forty-third time in its history of forty-eight years last night in Grand Central Palace.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Jan. 9 (AP) -- President Victor Paz Estenssoro, whose government recently nationalized the tin industry, today proclaimed the need for private capital investments and said "we cannot be anti-capitalist."

The forty-five-family apartment house at 2807 Claflin Avenue, the Bronx, has been purchased by Geisinger Rau, operators, from David Cohen. The property is assessed at $170,000, Sokolow Co. were the brokers in the sale.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Following is the text of President Truman's Budget Message, transmitted to Congress today:

Results attained by the Advertising Council last year portend the beginning of a new and dynamic partnership between business and advertising on one hand and the public on the other, according to Howard J. Morgens, chairman of the council.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The Senate Republicans moved today to tighten their party organization and to make swift and easy the coming transfer of national power to the Eisenhower Administration.

Added incentives for tackling correspondence as well as budgets or income tax returns might be some of the new desk accessories. Handsome enough to appear permanently on the top of the desk, these practical objects are made of leather, metal, crystal and wood.
MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Prime Minister Churchill arrived here late today in President Truman's plane to spend a fortnight holidaying under the Jamaican sun.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- General of the Army Omar N. Bradley, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, told a closed meeting of the House Armed Services Committee today that the slowdown in Western European rearmament was due in large degree to a "dangerous hope" that a future world war could be won by the free countries through the use of atomic weapons alone.
Stock prices dropped yesterday to the lowest levels since mid-December. Losses were the widest in three months with trading crossing the 2,000,000-share mark.

Members of the world champion Yankees who have been wondering what 1953 has in store for them in the way of financial remuneration, will not be kept in suspense much longer. Contracts were sent out yesterday, according to Roy Hamey, assistant to General Manager George M. Weiss.

We do not believe that the officials of building-trades unions in New York and Essex County can take any satisfaction in the results of their ban against the erection of prefabricated huts by soldiers manning anti-aircraft defense batteries. Their threat to strike on first priority mess halls and other installations led the Army to back down in its attempt to provide the most comfortable quarters for our anti-aircraft guardians.

MADRID, Jan. 9 -- The bulk of the United States Sixth Fleet -- thirty-five fighting ships manned by 20,000 officers and men -- steamed quietly into eight Spanish ports this morning for a seven-day goodwill visit to Spain.

Governor Dewey's proposals for a state-wide uniform traffic summons to combat the "fixed ticket" and for compulsory automobile liability insurance won praise yesterday from Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh and Supreme Court Justice Samuel H. Hofstadter.

A field that includes six 1952 Olympic champions will help open the indoor track and field season here in the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union title games at the Third Engineers' Group Armory tonight.

Harry S. Radcliffe, executive vice president of the National Council of American Importers, has urged that a "new approach" be made to the Customs Simplification Bill, which has been stuck in the legislative mill in Washington now for more than two years. He proposed that the Secretary of the Treasury-designate, George M. Humphrey, submit a completely new bill to Congress.

HONOLULU, Jan. 9 -- A bitter dispute over the appointment of a Republican Governor of Hawaii may be resolved in New York next week when Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, holds pre-inauguration conferences.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 9 -- Federal Germany is ready to open bilateral negotiations with France on revision of the European Army Treaty, authoritative sources said today.

Senator McCarthy has attempted to undermine the Senate inquiry into his own integrity by assuming a personal offensive against the Senators who were on the investigating subcommittee. These are the tactics that have served Mr. McCarthy well in the past; it requires particular courage to stand up to him because of the unprecedented lows in vilification to which he seems willing to stoop.

ROME, Jan. 9 -- The Vatican was perplexed today by news from Belgrade that Premier Marshal Tito had summoned seven high Roman Catholic prelates in Yugoslavia and conferred with them for two hours. The Vatican's communications with Belgrade have never been good and have become worse now that the Papal Nunciature (office) is closed.

Lieut. Gen. Willis D. Crittenberger, who retired recently as Commanding General of the First Army with headquarters on Governors Island, was reported yesterday to be slated for an important diplomatic assignment, possibly as Ambassador to Brazil, in the new Eisenhower Administration.

STRASBOURG, France, Jan. 9 -- Rejecting a move to curtail the powers of national ministers by a revision of the European Defense Treaty, the European Constitutional Assembly approved late tonight a compromise proposal maintaining most of the authority the ministers would exert over the new European political authority.

The first agreement between the New York State Athletic Commission and the National Boxing Association for supervision of boxing on a nation-wide scale was forecast yesterday by Robert K. Christenberry, chairman of the Empire State board.

The first Latin American Congress on rural life problems will be held tomorrow through Jan. 18 in Manizales, Colombia, under auspices of the National Catholic Rural Life Conference of the United States of America.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 9 (AP) -- Pete Fleming, former professional boxer who turned to belting golf balls, scored a decision over a field of stars today with a 6-under-par 66 in the first round of the $10,000 Bing Crosby pro-amateur golf tournament.
ALBANY, Jan. 9 (AP) -- The State Commerce Department today reported the following winter sports conditions at New York resorts:
LONDON, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Britain's first coffee auction in eleven years was held today and merchants found the selling prices good.

A DUBLIN wit once said that the Irish Literary Renaissance was nothing but a crowd of writers who lived in the same town and hated one another enthusiastically. It might be a trifle pompous to say that was not quite so. And, anyway, the truth of the matter is that some of them managed to dislike one another cordially while living as far apart as Switzerland and Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- President Truman submitted to Congress his eighth and final budget today as a blueprint for bringing the country's defense build-up to a peak and carrying forward the Democratic Administration's other programs under the new Republican management.

PARIS, Jan. 9 -- The new French Government will soon submit to the five other signatories of the European Army Treaty draft protocols designed to allay concern for the security of French territories overseas and for a guaranteed link between the British forces on the Continent and those in the proposed European Army.

THE task of evaluating and recording world game fish records is not an easy one, and few who have had dealings with anglers individually or as a group would be willing to assume the problems of Francesca LaMonte, secretary of the International Game Fish Association.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 9 -- The strike of 450 waterfront railroad carloaders, which has tied up dry cargo facilities in the Port of Philadelphia for three days, spread to Chester arid Wilmington today as two sugar refineries here announced plans for shutting down for lack of raw sugar.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today the quantity of livestock feed grains on farms at the beginning of the year was smaller than on any Jan. 1 of the peak production years of 1949 through 1951.

TOKYO, Saturday, Jan. 10 (UP) -- An Army Court Martial today found Mrs. Dorothy Krueger Smith, daughter of a four-star general, guilty of premeditated murder in the stabbing of her colonel-husband and sentenced her to life imprisonment.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Mrs. Leon Keyserling, wife of the chairman of President Truman's Council of Economic Advisers, has been cleared of disloyalty charges and has been reinstated in her $10,000 a year job in the Department of Commerce, a reliable source said today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9 -- Railroads are losing freight traffic because slow methods and red tape of regulatory bodies limit freedom of competition with other types of carriers, J. P. Newell, vice president in charge of operations for the Pennsylvania Railroad, asserted today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Five Representatives asked the House today to begin steps toward bringing the Soviet Union to trial before the International Court of Justice at The Hague for the massacre of 15,000 Polish officers in World War II.
Deft and handmade details on classic, understated hats were the tenor of Gladys and Belle's millinery spring collection shown to the press yesterday at 20 West Fifty-seventh Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Representative Francis E. Walter, Democrat of Pennsylvania and co-author of the McCarran-Walter Alien-Entry Act of 1952, told the House of Representatives today that after studying the New Year's Eve report of President Truman's Commission on Immigration and Naturalization he had "laid that document aside with disgust."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) -- J. B. Hartranft Jr., president of the Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association, urged Federal authorities today to call off plans for some 400 jet planes to fly over the parade route during the inauguration ceremonies here on Jan. 20.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned weak again yesterday and closed 17 to 46 points net lower than on Thursday.
The signing of a five-year lease with the New York Dock Company of Brooklyn for the use of its piers was announced yesterday by Dr. Alvaro Diaz, general manager of Flora Mercante Grancolombiana.

LONDON, Jan. 9 -- Continued activity in some sections of the industrial market to some extent relieved quiet conditions on the stock exchange today. Shipping shares were again prominent with a large turnover and a rise by a majority of issues.
CHICAGO, Jan. 9 (UP) -- Substantial price declines in meat and other basic foods were reported today in a spot check of retail food stores across the nation.

For Europe the past year has been the first full year since the end of the Marshall Plan. During 1952 the United States extended further economic and military aid under the Mutual Security Program. The results are gratifying in one sense, inadequate in another.

Chain Belt Company had a net profit of $2,105,639, equal to $3.69 a share, for the year ended on Oct. 31, according to the report released yesterday by J. C. Merwin, president. This compares with $2,563,586, or $4.49 a share in the previous fiscal year.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The resignation of Chester Bowles as United States Ambassador to India has been accepted and he will be replaced in that post, it was reported on good authority today.

The purchase by Beth David Hospital of the property of the Hospital for Special Surgery on East Forty-second Street, between First and Second Avenues, was announced formally yesterday. The plant consists of four and five-story units on a plot fronting about 200 feet on Forty-second and running through the block for a depth of 200 feet to Forty-third Street. It formerly was called the Hospital for Ruptured and Crippled Children.

The Grandchile Realty Corporation, represented by A. Irving Isaacson, attorney, has purchased the four-story apartment house containing thirty-eight suites at 1209 Bushwick Avenue in Brooklyn. The property, assessed at $125,000, occupies a plot 100 by 100 feet at the corner of Hancock Street.

The season's first performance of Verdi's "Aida" took place last night at the Metropolitan Opera. The audience seemed happy to welcome it back. It was a receptive audience, lavish with its bravos, eager to respond to the action, thoroughly in sympathy with the production as a whole.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, made a surprise appearance at a medical-charity dinner here last night and completely backed up a speech by his brother, Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower, president of Pennsylvania State College, attacking socialized medicine, and avowing a "passionate" belief in private enterprise.

KHARTUM, the Sudan, Jan. 9 -- The Anglo-Egyptian Sudan's highly organized and increasingly self- conscious workers movement is entering, in a three-day general conference of the Confederation of Labor beginning tomorrow, into a full-dress battle to oust Communists from control of the Confederation.
