Thousands of homes in Connecticut, Westchester County and northern New Jersey were left without electricity last night as an ice storm, described as one of the worst in a generation, de scended on the suburban countryside.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 9 -- The Belgrade radio reported this afternoon that in the wake of Marshal Tito's meeting with Catholic Bishops, there was a great deal of public comment to the effect that the meeting proved the regime was not anti-religious but merely sought a settlement of religious problems.
President Truman sent to Congress yesterday his eighth budget as Chief Executive and the third of the series reflecting the post-Korea defense program.

T. Vincent Quinn, Queens County District Attorney, was named yesterday in two Federal indictments that charged him with illegally accepting attorney's fees while serving as a member of the House of Representatives. One indictment, in Manhattan, involved the sharing of $19,000 in fees; the other, in Brooklyn, $16,500.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- As a measure of the impact of Federal spending and taxes on the country's economy, there is, in the budget, the usual table estimating actual cash transactions between the Government and the public in the fiscal years 1953 and 1954.
The following is a list of recently published booklets that may be of interest to homemakers:

STRASBOURG, France, Jan. 9 -- A new stage in the preparation for a single market for coal and steel has been accomplished by the High Authority for the European Coal and Steel Community since it was set up in Luxembourg last August.

The basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden tonight will share local interest with a single game at the University Hall Gymnasium at Columbia. The top attraction at the Garden will pit Loyola of Chicago against St. John's, with the preliminary game bracketing St. Joseph's of Philadelphia against Manhattan.

CORAL CABLES, Fla., Jan. 9 (AP) -- Stormy weather, which brought squalls, high winds, thunder and lightning, marred the program today at Tropical Park as M. Pellicane's Patty's Day, a 24-to-1 shot, longest-priced horse in the field of eight, emerged winner of the featured Poinsettia Purse.
TOKYO, Saturday, Jan. 10 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,490, covering Friday's activities:

TORONTO, Jan. 9 (AP) -- A Toronto-born minister has been refused entry to the United States to return to his parish in Pittsburgh. Immigration authorities gave no reason for having refused entry to the Rev. R. H. Thomas, an Episcopalian minister, and his wife.

Exhibitors who wish to compete in classes from which professionals are barred will be required to display a card attesting their amatuer status, President Adrian Van Sinderen told the American Horse Shows Association's annual meeting at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- President Truman, in discussing his budget with reporters yesterday, called it an honest one and a very tight one.

TOKYO, Saturday, Jan. 10 -- South Korean infantrymen yesterday ambushed and cut up a North Korean attack group that was retreating northward after an unsuccessful assault on the Allied lines northwest of Kansong on the eastern Korean front.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- President Truman's budget message is heavily sprinkled, as usual, with budgetary terms that are unintelligble to many readers. They include "obligation authority," "reappropriations" and the like. Here is an abbreviated glossary of some of them:

A prototype of a new class of tanker, of a special design approved by the Navy, is to be constructed by the Maritime Administration as a national defense measure, the budget message of President Truman disclosed yesterday.

Five persons were injured and six families were made homeless yesterday in a fire that started in a basement apartment at 97 Macon Street, in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, and spread quickly through the three-story brownstone rooming house. The cause of the fire was not immediately determined.

Almost every general cook book, in English as well as in German, Hungarian, French and Austrian, includes a recipe for marrow balls or dumplings as a garnish for clear soup. Yet marrow, the soft, delicately flavored tissue from bone cavities, is used rarely today in homes and only occasionally in restaurants.

The New Year's resolution of the Borough Council of Pine Hill, N. J., in Camden County, to serve coffee and cake as a means of attracting more residents to its evening meetings and thus stimulating interest in municipal affairs is a sign of the times.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The televising of college football games will be tightly controlled again in 1953. The National Collegiate Athletic Association so decided today by the overwhelming vote of 172 to 13 at the first meeting of its forty-seventh annual convention.

Crosby L. Hull and Martin J. Chapman have joined Henry Waltemade, Inc. Mr. Hull, formerly with Ivor B. Clark, Inc., and Central Savings Bank, will arrange mortgage financing. Mr. Chapman specializes in industrial sales and leases.
As the forty-first annual appeal of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund neared the close of its fifth week, donors continued to push the campaign toward a possible record year.

Joseph Brun, the photographer of such offerings as "Walk East on Beacon" and "Savage Splendor," has been signed by Stirling Silliphant, independent producer, to supervise the camera work for the forthcoming "The Joe Louis Story."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Average primary market prices rose 0.1 per cent in the week ended Jan. 6, to 109.7 per cent of the 1947-49 average, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. This is the third consecutive advance and reflects chiefly higher prices for processed foods (0.8 per cent) mainly for meat.

Striking gravediggers at the Mount Hebron Cemetery in Flushing, Queens, went back to work without pay for a short time yesterday when they buried the body of Pvt. 1/c Fred Goldstein, United States Marine Corps, who was killed in action in Korea last November.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Jan. 9 -- The stormy course of this week's engagement of "Tobacco Road" here took a new turn today when police arrested the producer, Edward Gould, and charged him with producing an "indecent, immoral show."

The re-election of George D. Widener as chairman, Ogden Phipps as vice chairman and Joseph E. Davis as secretary, and the reappointment of Marshall Cassidy as executive secretary and assistant treasurer, was announced yesterday by the Jockey Club, which held its annual meeting on Thursday at its 250 Park Avenue offices.

Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman refused yesterday to reduce the thirty-year sentence of Morton Sobell, who was convicted with Ethel and Julius Rosenberg of conspiracy to transmit atomic secrets to the Soviet Union. He is now in Alcatraz Brison.

Massachusetts municipal housing authorities received bids yesterday on $33,411,000 of state-guaranteed notes due variously from July 28, 1953, to July 27, 1954. The best bids were at interest rates ranging from 0.74 per cent to 0.79 per cent, according to the term.

ADEN, Jan. 9 -- Judge Ralph Campbell, sitting in the Supreme Court, gave judgment today for the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company in its claim to a cargo of 900 tons of oil in the tanker Rose Mary, now in Aden Harbor.
MELBOURNE, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Two of America's three male tennis stars will be put to the test in the second round of the Australian championships tomorrow.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 9 (UP) -- Led by Jack Sheehy, Cornell staged a last-period drive tonight to defeat Harvard, 63 to 59, in an Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League contest.

Howard P. Barry, president of the Uniformed Firemen's Association, accused Fire Commissioner Jacob Grumet yesterday of having used 200 of the 381 new probationary firemen to fill vacancies in the uniformed ranks "without proper training."
There was a new honor yesterday for Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's gray 3-year-old colt Native Dancer.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- President Truman put out a special statement today in defense of his record on Federal spending and made it clear that he was opposed to tax reduction until the budget had been balanced.
A new policy in the promotion of policemen was announced yesterday by Commissioner George P. Monaghan as he promoted four men, one to lieutenant and three to sergeant.

John T. McTernan, continuing his summary in behalf of four of the thirteen secondary Communist leaders accused of conspiracy to teach and advocate the violent overthrow of the Government, asked their acquittal yesterday on the ground that the prosecution had failed to produce evidence of any act or intention of violence.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (UP) -- Walter S. Franklin, president of the Pennsylvania Rialroad, said today the Long Island Rail Road's losses were increasing despite the highest passenger revenues in its history.

ROME, Jan. 9 -- Msgr. James Francis McIntyre, the Archbishop of Los Angeles and the only American among the twenty-four prelates who will be raised to cardinals in a secret consistory that Pope Pius XII will hold on Monday, arrived in Rome by air late tonight.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Republicans greeted President Truman's budget proposals today with strong criticism, even derision in some cases. Cuts of more than 10 per cent were promised.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Don Faurot of the University of Missouri today was chosen president of the American Football Coaches Association to succeed Carl Snavely of North Carolina.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The Province of Ontario filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission today for the sale of $50,000,000 of twenty-two year debentures, due on Feb. 1, 1975. The securities are to be offered for public sale through an underwriting group headed by seven companies including Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., and Wood, Gundy Co., Inc.

The twenty-eighth annual international congress of the Hastings Chess Club was concluded yesterday at the White Rock Pavilion with a formal presentation of prizes by the Mayoress of Hastings, wife of Alderman H. W. Rymill, J. P., according to a report from London.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- President Truman today sent to President-elect Dwight D. Eisenhower the draft of a proposed Executive Order to establish a Civil Service Reserve and eliminate red tape.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Senator Spessard L. Holland, Democrat of Florida, for himself and thirty-nine other Senators, today moved to give clear title to offshore areas to the Seaboard and Great Lakes States.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 8 -- Three Argentine ports were at the point of being closed to further grain shipments today as a bumper wheat crop continued to pour in from the farms while export shipments were at a virtual standstill.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 9 (AP) -- The National Constituent Assembly confirmed Col. Marcos Perez Jimenez today as Venezuela's President to serve "until constitutional government is re-established."

CHICAGO, Jan. 9 -- A discussion of the woes of automobile manufacturers three decades ago before old-time paint methods were replaced by present fast-drying methods of finishing car bodies enlivened the du Pont anti-trust trial today in Federal District Court here.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9 -- Representatives of several large Eastern railroads will meet furniture industry leaders next month to hear and consider demands for furniture freight rate relief, R. F. Bohman, president of the National Furniture Traffic Conference, said here today.

Hosiery shipments in November, 1952, amounted to 14,982,238 dozen pairs, it has been announced by the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers. This compares with shipments of 13,924,279 dozen pairs in the corresponding month of 1951.

NEWARK, Jan. 9 -- Members of Congregation of B'nai Abraham began with services tonight the celebration of the 100th anniversary of the founding of the synagogue here. Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll was a speaker at the ceremonies.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The fly fisherman can now use bait that not only looks (to a fish) like an appetizing insect but sounds like one. Stanley A. Wehn of Santa Monica, Calif., received a patent (No. 2,624,145) this week for a fishing rod attachment that he says can cause an artificial fly to simulate "the drone or hum of the larger insects, or the singing quality of flies or mosquitoes."
SAIGON, Vietnam, Indo-China, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Nguyen Van Tam, the Premier of of Vietnam, said today his Government could spare nothing in a drive to step up the war against the Communist-led Vietminh.
NEWARK, Saturday, Jan. 10 -- A disgruntled painter staged shooting affrays in three sections of the downtown business area last night, killing a fellow union member and wounding three other men.

I am truly grateful to THE NEW YORK TIMES because it is the only newspaper in the United States which has given fair coverage in its news columns to an issue of ethics in government which I have been trying without too much success to raise for the past month or so.

LONDON, Jan. 9 -- The decision of the Aden Supreme Court, holding that the oil in the tanker Rosa Mary was the property of the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company, caused considerable satisfaction here today, both in Government and oil company circles.

The Striking bus Workers are seeking a forty-hour week with no cut in the pay they used to get for working forty-four to forty-eight hours, with five to nine hours of guaranteed overtime. The old basic wage ranged from $1.66 to $1.73 1/2 an hour.

Two young men posing as world tourists robbed the KLM Royal Dutch Airlines ticket offices at 572 Fifth Avenue yesterday afternoon of $2,600 in cash and $2,500 in checks. The robbery went unnoticed by eight other employes and ten customers.
Australia's winning Davis Cup team comes into Madison Square Garden this afternoon on one of the most attractive professional tennis shows offered there.

RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 9 -- The main committee on policies and objectives of the Asian Socialist conference here unanimously voted a resolution today against becoming a regional organization of the Western Socialist International. Adoption of the resolution by the full conference seems assured, since all the delegation leaders are represented on the main committee.

The de Gaullists are not in power in France. Their parliamentary leader, Jacques Soustelle, failed in his perfunctory effort to form a Government. They have no representative in the new Cabinet. Unquestionably, however, the de Gaullists wield more influence in this eighteenth post-war Administration than they have exercised since the General himself headed the first Government after the liberation.

PUSAN, Korea, Saturday, Jan. 10 -- Towering waves upset and foundered a 146-ton South Korean passenger ship ten miles west of here last night, drowning 233 persons, the South Korean Transportation Ministry announced today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 9 -- A nation-wide campaign with a probable goal of $1,500,000 will be put under way about mid-April to help thirty-one Negro colleges and universities meet their operating budgets for next year.

With the help of comrades in the Police Department, a detective obtained nine pints of blood from the police blood bank last night and rushed it to his critically burned 70-year-old mother in a New Jersey hospital less than an hour after an emergency call had been received at Police Headquarters.
MEMPHIS, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Representatives of cotton producers from six states urged yesterday that 1953 planting records for cotton be eliminated from the basis for future acreage allocations.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 9 -- President Getulio Vargas has summoned a Cabinet meeting for tomorrow afternoon, it was reported here tonight, and the rumor in political circles was that he was preparing to reorganize his Government.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- United States citizens holding or seeking positions in the United Nations will be investigated as thoroughly as are those holding or seeking sensitive Federal jobs under the terms of an executive order issued by President Truman today.

PEORIA, Ill., Jan. 10 (AP) -- A little railroad with big troubles is multiplying its capitalization 720 times.

VILLANOVA, Pa., Jan. 10 -- Bob Schafer, 19 years old, Villanova College basketball star, was kidnapped last Tuesday night by four men who urged him to be "less active" in future games, it was disclosed today.

ERNIE KOVACS, the zany gentleman from Philadelphia, apparently is to be the new workhorse on the C. B. S. television network. Every weekday morning he does an hour's stint from 8:30 to 9:30 and then on Tuesday evening he is before the cameras for another hour from 8 to 9. It's a little too much.

HANOVER, N. H., Jan. 10 -- Dartmouth's No. 1 team of Hullman, Stewart, Carry and Ashnault took first place in the I. S. E. A. S. A. cross-country relay with a 171.42 time. Near-by Labanon High School took second, followed by the Finnish Ski Club and Williams College's No. 2 team.

More buyers entered the wholesale market here last week than in some time, Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying offices, announced yesterday. Substantial orders were placed, and despite conservative budgets, buyers requested replacements because the holiday business cleared stocks.

Modern building design will be the topic of the free art lecture on Tuesday at 6:15 P. M. in Room 213 of the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. Martin Lowenfish, member of the American Institute of Architects and the New York Society of Architects, will be the speaker.

District Thousands of Americans this year, as in each year since the war, will experience the pleasure, for the first time, of owning their own boats. Some are attracted to the waterborne recreation by the respite it offers from the week-end congestion and danger of the highways. Others seek the variety of activities available on the water -- from canoeing on a quiet lake to the thrilling sport of deep sea fishing.

Consumers of Fanny Farmer candies may not have noticed it but there has been a gradual change in the packaging of those products. Gayer, more modern boxes are replacing the old type container featuring a somberly dressed woman and black and gold lettering.

Perhaps it was the cold, bleak day of drizzling rain outside Grand Central Palace on Lexington Avenue that chased unexpected thousands inside to the warmth, color and fascination of pleasure craft on the first full day's session yesterday of the newest edition of a National Motor Boat Show.

IN 1898, when William McKinley was President of the United States, a young Filipino named Emilio Aguinaldo had a conference with Admiral (then Commodore) George Dewey aboard the battle cruiser Olympia, anchored outside Manila Bay. The two men made a deal.

NEWARK, Jan. 10 -- Back in the year 1818 a 37-year-old astronomer, teacher and author, David Young of Pine Brook, in neighboring Morris County, laboriously prepared with crude, hand-set type the first edition of his Farmers Almanac, which, he announced, contained "the usual astronomical calculations and a greater variety of other matter than is common in an almanac."

I would like to express my complete disapproval of Mr. Moses' thesis. He states that "fully half of all our traffic deaths are due to speed." It may be true that "fatalities increase as speed increases," but it does not follow that speed per se causes fatalities.

TRAVELERS' tales are an art-form that should not be looked at too critically, just as we should not criticize the Egyptians because their silhouetted figures face one way below the waist and another way above.

The first published clues to the four-year-old mystery of Nikolai A. Voznesensky's disappearance from the Politburo and the highest level of Soviet officialdom point in the direction of a major dispute decided by Premier Stalin against Mr. Voznesensky on fundamental issues of economic theory having important practical consequences.
A plea for continuance of the nation's basic philosophy on social welfare was voiced yesterday by Kenneth D. Johnson, dean of the New York School of Social Work, Columbia University.

A Port Arthur, Texas, butcher, who was driven to New York last month by a woman customer for a critical heart operation, left Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospital yesterday afternoon after surgery that doctors said had saved his life.

Marked by an international flavor, the forty-second annual convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association will open tomorrow at the Statler Hotel. Close to 6,000 retail executives from stores all over the country -- a record high -- are expected to attend the conclave, which will continue through Thursday.

TRENTON, Jan. 10 -- The State's waterfront crime investigation and the election next fall of a new Governor will be major influences on the New Jersey Legislature as it opens its 1953 session Tuesday.
A PART from those who use artificial bidding systems, good bridge players all over the world bid much the same. This was borne out in the world championship play in New York this past week.
The business of the American Power Boat Association national council at the Hotel Belmont Plaza yesterday was mostly financial. No points of friction developed.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 10 -- Yale overcame Brown, 5 -- 1, in a last period onslaught to win a Pentagonal League hockey game before 2,300 tonight.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 10 -- The Charter of the United Nations provides that the paramount consideration in the selection of its employes shall be "the highest standards of efficiency, competence and integrity," with "due regard" for the principle of geographical representation -- in other words, spreading the jobs among citizens of the sixty member states.

A young fellow, upon being graduated from high school here, thought he had some liking for the electrical business. He first tried it out as a salesman in the sign industry and then got a foothold in what is today an unexplored field -- that of lighting.

The new 30,000-ton Italian luxury liner Andrea Doria, scheduled to leave on her westbound trans-Atlantic maiden voyage from Genoa, Italy, next Wednesday, incorporates a host of modern safety devices installed in accordance with the 1948 International Convention for the Safety of Life at Sea.

A BUSINESS executive and veteran reformer in politics, election law and government, Richard S. Childs gives us in "Civic Victories" the dividends of a busy lifetime devoted to producing better municipal, county and state government. New Yorkers know him well as a civic leader.

One man was burned to deathi and hree firemen were injured in a fire that destroyed the interior !of a three-story brick dwelling house at 386 Carlton Avenue, near Greene ,a-venue, in the Fort Greene district of Brooklyn, yesterday. Two alarms were sounded, the first at 2:30 P. iVL Firemen put out the blaze in about an hour.

VIGOROUS and crowded lives make for voluminous biographies, and Edgar Johnson's study of Dickens must be among the fullest that has yet appeared. In one respect its length is excessive There was surely no need to devote entire sections to a detailed recapitulation and analysis of the novelist's best-known works.

THE abundance of nuts in wintertime markets suggests to the culinary-minded a variety of luscious dishes, Three are pictured today -- the chestnut dessert known in France, where it originated, as Mont Blanc, a layer cake with a black walnut frosting, and butterscotch nut rolls.

TOKYO, Jan. 10 (UP) -- Defense attorneys for Mrs. Dorothy Krueger Smith, sentenced by a court-martial to life imprisonment at hard labor for murdering her husband, said today they would appeal the verdict "all the way to the President," if necessary.
HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 10 -- The Connecticut Supreme Court, which has had to settle two major state political problems in the last four years, may have another to resolve in the next few months.
STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 10 -- Observance of Freedom Week, a community-wide rededication to the Bill of Rights and responsible government, began here this afternoon.

It was with great dismay and not without real disappointment that I read Mr. Crowther's recent column on the best movies of 1952. My qualms were not so much with the list of "The Top Ten" but with the second list of "good movies" of the year -- pictures which Mr. Crowther cited as being somewhat less than the best but still very good.

GENEVA, Jan. 10 -- The recommendation of the Tariff Commission that United States import duties on briar pipes be increased, widely reported in the European press today, has already been selected by European trade officials, many of whom knew about it some time ago, as a test case for the intentions of the Eisenhower Administration in the foreign trade field.

Two principal facts stood out last week as the strike of 8,000 employes of New York's eight private bus lines went into its second week: First, the strike had disrupted the city far less than anticipated; and second, it had produced not even the barest minimum of real bargaining between the parties.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- President Truman accepted today the resignation of Mrs. Eugenie Anderson as United States Ambassador to Denmark, effective Jan. 19, the day before the inauguration of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower.

PARIS, Jan. 10 -- From the new Administration at Washington the French hope for a moderate and not too risky attitude toward the Korean war, greater aid in money and materials for their war in Indo-China, some arrangement through the North Atlantic Treaty Organization or through United States orders for defense goods from France that will permit the French to plan a defense production program over several years.

There were several Columbia heroes on University Hall Gymnasium floor last night as the Lions' basketball team defeated Navy, 77 -- 71, before 2,500 fans and ran the Light Blue winning streak to seven games. The setback was the second in a row for the middies, who had their seven-game string snapped by Princeton Friday.
BONN, Jan. 10 -- Probably no nation in Europe is more anxiously awaiting the inauguration of General Eisenhower as President than Federal Germany.

CHARLESTON, S. C., Jan. 10 (AP) -- A Marine sergeant was reported in good condition at the naval hospital here today after a dramatic transfer on the high seas. He had been stricken with appendicitis en route to Puerto Rico.

Organization of a new company, headed by Mrs. Millicent C. McIntosh, president of Barnard College, as chairman of the board, to build the 984-family $12,500,000 middle-income cooperative Morningside-Manhattanville housing development was announced yesterday by Morningside Heights, Inc.

THE name Winchester, like Colt and Deringer, has become a generic title in firearms history. Millions of rifles and shotguns have borne the name of the shirt manufacturer who bought a bankrupt firearms company and who never, so far as the record goes, shot one of the weapons he made.

A "new philosophy" of law enforcement obligates the public prosecutor to extend his duties to include participation in crime prevention and investigations, District Attorney Miles F. McDonald of Kings County noted last week in making public his report for 1950 and 1951.

SINCE the beginning of the Korean war two and a half years ago the cost of living in the United States has risen about 12.5 per cent. This is inflation -- the continuation of a process which, stemming in large part from the cost of World War II and the subsequent heavy defense burden, has halved the buying power of the dollar since 1939.
LONDON, Jan. 10 -- With some changes of emphasis Britain expects General Eisenhower as President to hold the United States to its present basic policies in foreign relations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The McCarran-Walter Immigration and Nationality Act, passed by Congress over the veto of President Truman, continues to be the center of a storm of controversy, now that it is in actual operation.

CONCORD, Calif., Jan. 10 -- In 1952 there were 136 American Power Boat Association-sanctioned regattas where events were scheduled for stock outboard boats and eighty-five regattas where racing outboards competed. The 2,037 outboard owners and drivers who attended these races had a total of 2,964 registered boats.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 10 -- Five hundred college presidents, deans and top-level administrators attending the thirty-ninth annual convention of the Association of American Colleges, composed of nearly 800 accredited liberal arts colleges and universities -- virtually every such institution in the United States -- considered various problems this week ranging from academic freedom to the inflationary costs of operating a college.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Jan. 10 -- Playing before a crowd of 2,000, St. Francis of Brooklyn defeated Le Moyne College of Syracuse tonight, 67 to 56. Trailing by 3 points at the end of the first quarter, the Terriers rallied and left the court at half-time leading, 36 to 31.

ROME, Jan. 10 -- Just two days before the secret consistory will meet to create twenty-four new Cardinals in an unusually austere ceremony, with the participants in severe vestments, the Pope issued an apostolic constitution introducing not greater strictness but a certain measure of relaxation in church rules concerning the eucharistic fast.

Your eminent financial writer, Edward H. Collins, analyzed in two recent articles the question of the price of gold in its relation to the quest for higher profits for the gold producers and the assumed desirability of a greater international liquidity.

PLAYWRITING, as any honest journeyman will tell you, is no longer a full-time job in the commercial sense -- and this is the theatre's real danger, no matter how lushly it may flourish outside the purlieus of Broadway.

BERLIN, Jan. 10 -- The Council of Ministers of East Germany has decided to complete the first part of its land-collectivization program by next autumn, according to what appears to be a well-documented report.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., Jan. 10 (AP) -- A widow was charged here today with murdering her seven-year-old son and the police said they were looking into the death of her husband and a younger son, as well as into three fires at her home, all in the last two years.

THE grim statistics of current publication of science-fiction anthologies demonstrates that any editor, even one so able as Groff Conklin, is licked long before he starts the job of assembling one more collection. Conklin's newest is the sixteenth anthology of science-fiction short stories to be published this year.
The travel movement into New York continued its upward spiral in 1952 when 931,508 passengers arrived by ship or plane from foreign countries with 3,029,329 pieces of baggage.

VIENNA, Jan. 10 -- The Truman Adminstration and its representatives in Vienna were charged today by Ferdinand Graf. State Secretary and People's party leader, with an attempt to further "Socialist collective tendencies" in Austria.

A MAN of profound thought and wide historical knowledge, Lord Acton -- who was Regius Professor of History at Cambridge University at his death in 1902 -- was neither a systematic thinker nor a historian in the orthodox sense.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 10 -- The Ohio penitentiary convict who copied an 8-year-old book and sold it to a Boston publisher has another manuscript on the market.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, has made a farewell statement to the alumni of Columbia University, from which he has resigned as president, effective Jan. 19, the day before his inauguration in Washington.

Predicted log races have provided for many years an outlet for the power cruiser owner's interest in competitive sport. At the same time these contests have been instrumental in educating a sizeable number of cruiser owners in the fine points of piloting and navigation

We have grown used to public expenditures in terms of many billions of dollars. Even so, it is somewhat startling to consider that the deficit which the Federal Government would incur if President Truman's final budget went through uncut and revenues ran at the estimated level would be greater than the total Federal expenditures in any peacetime year prior to 1941.

The Vocational Advisory Service will be the beneficiary of the performance of "John Brown's Body," a dramatic reading, with Judith Anderson, Raymond Massey, Tyrone Power and the Walter Schumann Chorus, on the evening of Feb. 17 in the Century Theatre. Co-chairmen of the benefit committee are Mrs. Walter E. Beer Jr. and Mrs. L. Emmett Holt Jr.

WASHINGTON'S rainy seacoast seems a propitious place for writing about the seamy side of quaint and humorous backwoods people who might authentically be called "characters." Betty MacDonald did it in "The Egg ad I." Now Norah Berg has described the experiences of herself and neighbors as beachcombers at a lonely salt-water hamlet, Ocean City.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 10 -- The Brazilian Cabinet met with President Getulio D. Vargas today in a session generally believed a prelude to changes in the ministries. One report was that the ministers, under instructions from their parties, were going to present their resignations to President Vargas to make it simpler for him to carry out the reorganization.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 10 -- One of the war criminals who escaped from a Netherlands jail last month has asked help of Dr. Erich Mende of the Bundestag in a secret meeting in the Bundeshaus, home of the Federal Parliament.

MEXICO means different things to different people -- to some, night life in Tijuana, the silver of Taxco, bathing at Acapulco or a quick divorce in Cuernavaca. What follow are the things one traveler remembers liking -- a town, an old pyramid, an island and a small hotel.

BARNESVILLE, Ohio, Jan. 10 -- During the last few years the American Power Boat Association has made progress in stimulating boat racing. Last year was the finest in the organization's history, both in number of events held and increase in membership.

The textile industry achieved a remarkable recovery in 1952. Whether it can sustain the comeback from the serious recession of a year ago depends on several factors, some of which are beyond the industry's control.

LONDON, Jan. 10 -- In London this week certain gentlemen in the diplomatic trade were showing signs of weariness. They were Henry A. Byroade, an Assistant Secretary of State of the United States, and Sir James Bowker of the British Foreign Office.

ONE of the largest rail movements of the year will get under way this week when special trains from many parts of the nation start rolling toward Washington, carrying visitors to the inauguration of General Eisenhower on Jan. 20.

INSPIRED and guided by his father, the late Prof. Robert Seton-Watson, an outstanding authority on East European affairs, Hugh Seton-Watson, Professor of Russian History at the University of London, wrote "The East European Revolution" in 1951.

ISLIP, L. I., Jan. 10 -- A campaign to save the Sunken Forest, a fifty-acre woodland on Fire Island, has only to next Thursday before an option, held by a group that desires to preserve the property, expires.

THERE is a fair sampling of American music on recent releases and the new disks give glimpses of some of the chief personalities and major tendencies that have figured in our music since the early years of the lest century.

General of the Army Douglas MacArthur said last night that any excessive desertions from the armed forces could be traced to "lack of faith in President Truman's policies of appeasement" in Korea and to "growing fear that such policies will inevitably plunge us into another world war."
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 10 -- Coolkenny, former $500,000 showplace in suburban Haverford, has gone the way of many other Main Line mansions.
CHICAGO, Jan. 10 -- Ezra Taft Benson, who will be Secretary of Agriculture in the Eisenhower cabinet, had his first meeting today with Republican farm leaders from the Middle West.

New York's ten-day-old bus strike, which continued yesterday without a sign of settlement, has cost the eight private bus lines about $2,000,000 in lost revenues. Their 8,000 striking employes have lost $1,000,000 in wages.
LONDON. SOME people -- intelligent people -- have labeled my play, "A Political Satire." It is nothing of the sort, although it contains elements both satirical and political.

INSTEAD of a retrospective exhibition of work by one American artist, the Whitney Museum this year has elected to put on two simultaneously and both are of work by women. Although both have been painting for more than twenty years they are still young and still developing and it is quite possible that their best and most significant work lies ahead of them.

VACATIONISTS who are in a hurry and who want to follow the sun south during the winter for a few days no longer need confine themselves to the beaten travel path. There are now few places in the Western Hemisphere that cannot be reached by regular scheduled airliners or by charter planes.

BELGRADE, Jan. 10 -- The Yugoslav Government appeared today to be starting an all-out campaign to establish the idea that a final settlement of differences with the Roman Catholic Church depended on success of a joint commission with leading Catholic Bishops.

ALBANY, Jan. 10 -- Senator Francis J. Mahoney of Manhattan and Assemblyman Eugene F. Bannigan of Brooklyn, the new Minority Leaders of the Legislature, are expected to try to reduce the number of duplicating bills introduced this year by Democratic members.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, announced formally today the selection of Gen. Walter Bedell Smith as Under Secretary of State and Lloyd A. Mashburn, California State Labor Commissioner, as Under Secretary of Labor.

Once again the New York financial community is looking over its shoulder, for once again New York City authorities have asked Albany for permission to boost taxes and make financial business here even less attractive.

IN an adjoining column last Sunday, William Saroyan (Wild Bill, to his friends) pointed out that there has not been a professional production of an O'Casey play in this town since 1934, although, to quote him precisely, "No O'Casey play can be bad in itself.'
Before the jointly convened houses of the Eighty-third Congress the electoral votes cast Nov. 4 were officially counted last Tuesday and this pronouncement was read into the record:

Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democrat of New York, asserted last night that the recent trials in Prague "serve notice that Israel and Zionism are to be made pawns in the internal and external power play of Communist imperialism."

THIS is a modest, almost an artless and very unsophisticated book, yet a strangely captivating one. The author is a Frenchwoman married to an Englishman. She is the mother of Bobby Henrey, the boy who gave such a remarkable performance in that remarkable British motion-picture, "The Fallen Idol."

BALBOA, C. Z., Jan. 10 -- The first year of the operation of the Panama Canal, ending June 30, 1952, by the new Panama Canal Company showed a tentative net income of $2,369,000, according to a preliminary financial statement released today by Gov. John S. Seybold, president of the company.

FRENCH political literature since the war has, like the National Assembly, mirrored the bitter divisions of opinion among Frenchmen. The most provocative (as distinguished from persuasive or pervasive) political ideas have been developed by Gaullist sympathizers.

Steel supplies, which had held up work on the Queens-Brooklyn Connecting Highway in Jackson Heights for two years, have become available again, so a section from the present Thirtieth Avenue terminus may be completed south to Northern Boulevard late this year.

SOME of the most prolific and successful mystery novelists in the English language -- men who make Gardner and Stein relatively sterile -- are almost unknown to the American reading public, a fact which is in some cases lamentable and in others a blessed relief.

Chunks of ice tumbling a thousand feet from the mist-shrouded tower of the Chrysler Building in midtown Manhattan made it necessary yesterday to rope off nearly the entire block bounded by Forty-second and Forty-third Streets, Third and Lexington Avenues.

Rudolph Halley, President of the City Council and a probable candidate in the Mayoralty contest next fall, declared yesterday that he would "campaign for the principle" of an independent Board of Education and Board of Higher Education.

BATON ROUGE, La., Jan. 10 -- Louisiana Republicans today cheered a cry of "jobs for Republicans" as the State Central Committee, in its first post-election meeting, launched a program for expanding the party in this State. D. Bigger Suarez of St. Bernard Parish, declared that "to build a party we must have patronage."

EDINBURGH, Jan. 10 (UP) -- The Earl of Dalkeith will inherit five stately homes and 500,000 acres. He was for a long time Princess Margaret's favorite escort and they were once reported to have reached an "understanding." Dalkeith loves his Scottish forests and Margaret the glitter of life in London and they drifted apart.

PRIMARILY, Cecil Smith's aim has been to give "some indication of the tremendous scope, variety and vitality of our American dealings with serious music." He has fulfilled that purpose and gone beyond it -- for his new book is a critique as well as a report. He has surveyed the American musical scene with balanced judgment.

California school children are learning how to meet everyday social problems by "acting them out" in the classroom. The new teaching method -- called "sociodrama" -- employs a storytelling technique. However, it may soon be implemented by the use of educational films to tell the story.

The Montreal Canadiens will engage the New York Rangers in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight. The clash will be the fourth of the season between the sexteto on the local ice surface.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Penn's 6-4 center, Ernie Beck, poured 25 points through the hoops tonight as the Quakers evened their Ivy League record at 1 -- 1 by defeating Yale, 63 -- 51, before 5,329 fans at the Palestra.

CAIRO, Jan. 10 -- British-Egyptian negotiations on problems of self-government and self-determination in the Sudan are entering their critical phase in an atmosphere of increasing asperity and bitterness. As a result the serenity that surrounded the talks when they opened Nov. 2 appears to have given way to a measure of tension if not of actual pessimism.

SALMON angling, considered by many to be a philosophical exercise as well as a sporting activity, normally is unmarked by the loud bickering that distinguishes some forms of fishing, but it provides many points of contention. The fact that soft tones are used by its devotees in presenting their arguments does not lessen the heat of the debate.

DAVID BAUMGARDT has given us the most important volume on Jeremy Bentham since Charles Warren Everett in 1945 identified and published what Bentham intended as the second volume of his "Introduction to the Principles of Morals and Legislation," namely, "The Limits of Jurisprudence Defined."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- A one-track rail line in Southern Rhodesia is the major bottleneck toward an adequate supply of metallurgical chrome essential to defense and civilian production needs here, the Defense Materials Procurement Agency has been advised.

THE ancient spectacle of the corrida being at an historic peak in popularity, United States publishers are bringing out a book on it every few months. Novels, memoirs, at least one doctor's thesis have been published or are about to be, but there has been no recent respectable attempt at explanation or exposition of the corrida.
TOKYO, Jan. 10 -- Watchers on the snow-covered hills of North Korea have seen some big Allied air fleets come over them recently

TAMPA -- There are, broadly speaking, two Floridas. There is the Florida publicized as a nation's playground ,with palm-lined beaches, midwinter golf courses and either organized entertainment or pleasing relaxation in the sunshine.

The fourth floor of the Palace is again the center for those organiations which, while concerned with life afloat, are not sellers of marine products but dispensers of education. These include the United States Coast Guard, the Seaman's Church Institute, the New York State Department of Public Works and the Marine Historical Association of Mystic, Conn.

Debutantes of recent seasons, headed by Miss Joan Pressprich and Miss Barbara Gile Lord and including the Misses Julia Beals and Mary H. Edson, are serving on the Junior committee for the dinner dance in behalf of the Yorkville Community Association, to be held Friday night in the main ballroom of the Plaza.

ALTHOUGH the subject of these books is the same, they have only music in common. The first is a high-pressure, you-too-can-do-it book about playing musical instruments; the second is a comprehensive, unhurried picture of musical life, past and present, as it relates to instruments of the band and orchestra.

MOBILE, Ala., Jan. 10 (AP) -- The Thomasville Bank case trial was called off last nighth after W. P. Stutts, lumberman of Thomasville, pleaded no contest to charges against him. The Government continued cases against his wife. The trial was scheduled to begin in the Federal Court here on Monday with five defendants. Three others pleaded earlier this week.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- President Truman's farewell budget was assigned to a Congressional pigeonhole today pending the inauguration of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, who plans to propose revisions after his inauguration on Jan. 20.

JOSE FERRER, who admittedly relished making "Moulin Rouge" in Paris, may return to the "City of Light" this summer to star in "The Poachers," the next project on Director Jean Renoir's agenda. This is the story now being written by Renoir in California dealing with the love of an American writer (Ferrer?) for a young French girl (Daniele Delorme).

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 10 -- The National Conference, scoring one first-period touchdown on a tremendous 74-yard pass play, and another on a little blooper of 12 yards, went on to defeat the American Conference, 27 -- 7, in the annual National Football League Pro Bawl game today.

ONE of the fascinating house plants of the winter is the Christmas cactus. It sometimes is called the crab cactus because of its clawlike, segmented leaves. Small, pointed pink buds, now showing at the tip of each branch, elongate slowly into stunning rosy red flowers.

BOTH of these books have grown out of the authors' and composers' years of close association with young children. In each the simplicity and directness of music and words will bring quick response from children.

LOS ANGELES -- Only twenty-five years ago Death Valley was practically unapproachable. Today it is served by a network of paved highways. Annually several hundred thousand visitors drive over them through the valley, discovering the vast, burned wastes and escarpments which are a desert spectacle surpassed in beauty and grandeur only by the Grand Canyon.

ATHENS, Jan. 10 -- Premier Alcide De Gasperi said today that Italy had "no objection in principle to any regional pact" so long as it conformed to the North Atlantic Treaty and hence contributed to international security.

FOLLOWING assorted delays since April, 1950, the proposed alterations in the building code, as it applies to the construction of theatres in this city, appear ready for final decision. With minor changes both the Fire Department and the Department of Housing and Buildings have given their approval to a list of bills prepared by Councilman Hugh Quinn, Queens Democrat, in association with the League of New York Theatres' codes committee.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 10 -- Army and Brown engaged in a close basketball game for more than three periods today, but the Cadets proved stronger in the stretch to win, 64 to 56, before 2,500 in the field house.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla. -- The questions that prospective visitors ask about Florida would fill a book every day in the year. With all that is published about the state there is still a surprising lack of information among those who plan a Florida vacation or want to come here to live. But not all are as ill-informed as the inquirer who asked, "Is it true nothing but cactus will grow in Florida?"

A six-man team of American bridge experts last night defeated their Swedish opponents by 8,260 points, bringing the world championship bridge title to the United States for the third successive year. The team was the same that had won the two previous titles.

IT was the curious fate of Napoleon Bonaparte (who in his heart really respected the English) that, born on an island, he was twice imprisoned on an island, each time with an English jailer whose tactlessness was only matched by his lack of common sense.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 10 -- A proposal to import thousands of Asians to work on California farms because of an asserted "labor shortage" brought to the fore this week one of the problems the Eisenhower Administration will inherit.

WHAT looks like a modified "Baltimore experiment" in salon judging by representatives of the art world is noted in the jury line-up announced for the Twentieth Detroit International Exhibition of Photography.

Ice can be an insidious thing. It has virtually paralyzed the most of the northeastern part of the country. Fortunately, the death toll is lower than might have been feared from so large and widespread a storm. Some of this saving of life must be attributed to the fact that the vast majority of persons in the area were unable or wisely unwilling to venture on the highways.

NEW DELHI, Jan. 10 -- New Delhi expects from the new Administration at Washington sympathetic appreciation of the gigantic efforts being made to raise the living standards of the masses. Without large-scale external aid, which can come only from the United States, the plan will fall far short of the targets.

THIS kaleidoscopic first novel, by a member of the Public Information Office of the United Nations Command in Korea, deals with the role of the U. S. A. F. Sixty-sixth Fighter Bomber Wing in the Korean war in May, 1951. Its best part is the account of the big airstrike on Tinju.

COLOR in photography can give mood or destroy it; it can be less realistic than black-and-white or it can intensify actuality. Attitudes of photographers toward color were given a fresh twist at the meeting of the Pictorial Photographers of America last week when Ben Rose, versatile and imaginative magazine photographer, discussed and illustrated the color medium as a constant challenge, rather than as a predictable finality.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 10 -- In a letter published this week in The Harvard Crimson, undergraduate daily newspaper, Professors Zechariah Chafee Jr. and Arthur E. Sutherland of the Law School asserted that cooperation with the Government was an "underlying principle" of adherence to the Fifth Amendment to the Constitution.

The horny tissues of the body, including hair, are among the least-known parts of the anatomy. No one knows why most men lose their hair and most women do not, why hair usually grays with age and grows in spurts.
THE event of the season in Switzerland has been the first Swiss production of Bizet's "Ivan IV," also referred to as "Ivan the Terrible," by the Stadttheater in Berne.

The rayon and acetate textile industry has exceptional resiliency and is conditioned for the tough competition among natural and man-made fibers in the years ahead, according to Clyde B. Morgan, president of Rayonier, Inc.
KARACHI, Jan. 10 -- Tension in Karachi, Pakistani capital, eased today after three days of rioting, in which at least sixteen persons died and 300 were injured.

Continuing improvement in foreign economic conditions was reflected in the moderate flow of gold to these shores during 1952. The United States, already the world's largest holder of monetary gold, with two-thirds of the known supply of approximately $36,000,000,000, took in an additional $1,000,000,000 worth last year.

A PICTURE window emphasizes the importance of having a well-designed outdoor planting. This is never more evident than in winter. And it is possible to design such a planting so the scene will be pleasant to look on even in the dead of winter.

I MUST take objection to your selection of "High Noon" as one of the best ten films of last year. Not that it was a bad picture or uninteresting. But it was so rigid and so well drawn out. There was no attempt to do something that hasn't been done before. I expected more from Stanley Kramer.

Two new marine Diesel engines and a Diesel-powered generator are introduced at the Palace by the Detroit Diesel Engine Division of General Motors. The smaller of the Diesels is a valveless engine designed for small pleasure craft, fishing and work boats.

BALTIMORE, Md., Jan. 10 -- Negotiations with the city's striking labor force of 3,000 were broken off today by the Board of Estimate until the strikers guaranteed an end of violence and consented to the making of emergency repairs to water, sewer and other installations.

MIAMI -- Villa Vizcaya, the fabulous estate of the late James Deering, which is within a stone's throw of downtown Miami, has been purchased by Dade County and will be opened about Feb. 1 as the Dade County Art Museum.

THIS is a story of World War II in Southeast Asia and of what one man learned about himself and others in the tight world behind the barbed wire. The author, a young Australian, was captured by the Japanese during the Malay campaign in the early Forties.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 10 -- Leroy (Satchel) Paige, who may be 45 and could be 50, signed his 1953 contract with the Browns today with a promise to "keep right on going until I'm 70."

With America's boating public growing by leaps and bounds every year, interest has focused on the kit boat, the "boat that comes in a box" for home assembly. Once looked upon as a tinker toy or a hobbyist's pastime, the kit boat has become an integral part of the boating industry and today tens of thousands of them are giving pleasure along the sea coasts, on lakes, bays and rivers.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The Senate Internal Security subcommittee accused the State Department today of having a "blind spot" toward the questions of subversion and disloyalty to the United States.

ALBANY, Jan. 10 -- The Legislature's top Republican fiscal officers today threw virtually all of Mayor Impellitteri's 1953 financial program on to the scrap heap and told the Mayor he would have to offer something better.
The part fishing plays in pleasure afloat is reflected in a number of craft designed specifically for that sport. They range from canoes to a 34-foot sport cruiser.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, who has twice just missed being the Republican Presidential nominee, within a week has settled with vigor into the high place that has come instead, the Republican leadership of the Senate.

SALMON P. CHASE'S pursuit of the Presidency of the United States from 1856 to 1872 was persistently thwarted. Across the years, however, he discharged his overweening ambition as successful Governor of Ohio, Lincoln's Secretary of the Treasury and finally as Chief Justice of the United States.

Three electronic devices for navigation and boat handling are displayed by Bendix. They are the Photo Electric Pilot for automatic steering, the Bendix Depth Recorder and the new Bendix Depth Indicator.

The New York Power Squadron's free piloting course begins on Jan. 19, at 7:30 P. M., at Julia Richman High School, Sixty-seventh Street and Second Avenue. Past Commander Otis G. Fales has his corps of instructors lined up to provide instruction in rules of the nautical road, seamanship, safety, aids to navigation, mariner's compass, charts and piloting. The course will run about ten weeks, and is open to boat owners and others.

A REVIVED respect for an age-old practice has become apparent in recent months, with the reappearance of a great variety of "art glass." These are pieces made by craftsmen who treat glass as an art material rather than simply making use of its purely functional properties. Vases and bowls so designed are conceived as objects of beauty in themselves and can exist as such without the addition of a bouquet of flowers.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 10 (AP) -- "I'd give anything to be in the Senate at the present time."

The McCarran-Walter Immigration and Nationality Act has been sharply criticized by Hoyt S. Haddock, executive secretary of the C. I. O. maritime committee, as a measure that sets this country up as the "world's district attorney, jury and judge" in its effort to screen foreign seamen entering United States ports and keep out subversive or dangerous aliens.
" A PIECE of history," says the author of this excellent book, "is a better story than any novel which can be written about it." I emphatically agree. The Overbury case is well chosen to prove it.

THE Metropolitan Opera's first contribution to "Omnibus" will be Johann Strauss' "Fledermaus," in the English translation by Garson Kanin and Howard Dietz. This also will be first production ever prepared by the "Met" especially for television.

WASHINGTON, D. C. THE most interesting aspect of modern Indian painting -- and one vividly demonstrated in the exhibition of contemporary Indian art and crafts which opens today at the Smithsonian Institution -- is its birth-pangs.

Members of the New York Committee of the Frontier Nursing Service, Inc., of which Mrs. Seymour Wadsworth is chairman, will give a reception and tea on Thursday afternoon in the ballroom of the Cosmopolitan Club for Mrs. Mary Breckinridge, founder and director of the service.

Inboard racing men, and officials who patrol the sport, are fervently harboring the most unusual wish that 1953 will fall far behind the 1952 season in one specific respect. They hope that the coming year will fail by a wide margin to produce the number of accidents which plagued inboarders last season.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. l0 -- Frank J. Lausche, the son of an immigrant Slovenian steel worker, will be sworn in Monday as Ohio's first fourth-term Governor.

New records were established again last year in virtually every phase of the oil industry. Production, consumption and drilling activity attained new peaks. The net earnings of the industry probably exceeded the former high level recorded in 1948, despite higher income tax rates now in effect.

TORONTO, Jan. l0 -- Canadian waterways are a playground in summer for one hundred thousand inboard motor boats and half a million outboards, according to a recent report of the Canadian Press. These figures indicate that Canadians are rapidly becoming aware of the pleasures of boat: ownership and more are taking advantage of their country's natural resources and pleasant lakes and rivers.

UNLIKE the majority of writers of juvenile biography Miss Ripley approaches her subject from the strictly factual angle eschewing fictional recreations of scenes and dialogue. Her life of Leonardo da Vinci is compact in form, spare in style, dignified in treatment and generously illustrated with reproductions of his drawings and paintings.
BOSTON, Jan. 10 -- Federal prosecutors were preparing today for the final week before the statute of limitations expired in the $1,219,000 Brink's, Inc., robbery.

A DECISION is now in the making in New York State which is destined to affect the education of our children for generations to come. This decision, which will have enormous implications for the adult population as well, is whether we shall have educational television in New York.

NORWALK, Conn., Jan. 10 -- Large strips of Fairfield County continued to be blacked out and without heat, water and other conveniences tonight after last night's ice storm, which glazed the countryside.

It must have been about this time of year that Benjamin Franklin first had his idea for a stove. He was about to begin his thirty-eighth year, an age when a man would have had enough of chill and scorch from a fireplace. Ingenious as he was, he knew that a fire in an iron box open to the room on all sides would radiate much more heat than a fire in a wall.

Retail trade was active in this area in the week, but not equal to the extensive gains reported for other sections of the country. Response to promotion of white goods was fair, and there was improvement in buying interest in home wares.

A SMARTLY dressed, jovial Negro left London Airport recently with a stuffed briefcase and a broad grin, saying, "My talks have been satisfactory." Back in Accra, capital of the Gold Coast, he reported to Prime Minister Kwame Nkrumah on his talks with Britain's Treasury and Board of Trade.

The Spanish soprano, Victoria de los Angeles, undertook her first German role at the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday afternoon when she sang Eva in the season's fourth performance of Wagner's "Die Meistersinger."

AN UNUSUAL sight-seeing dividend for visitors to Washington during General Eisenhower's inauguration next week has been arranged by a group of women who hope also, thereby, to benefit the National Symphony Orchestra.

TOKYO, Sunday, Jan. 11 -- Three hundred Allied planes, in one of the heaviest raids of recent months, plastered road and railroad bridges across the Chongchon and Taeryong Rivers near Sinanju, on the west coast of Korea, yesterday. The targets were an important link between enemy supply bases in Manchuria and the front lines.

Liberalization of the so-called "eight week" rule in tennis, in which amateur players are permitted to receive expenses, was indicated yesterday by delegates to the annual meeting of the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association.

During the last twelve months mutual funds, or open-end investment companies, attained new records. Sales of new shares in the business of investing other people's money are estimated at $760,000,000.

LET us suppose that Vladimir Horowitz' performance of the Tchaikovsky concerto with the Philharmonic tomorrow night, twenty-five years after his American debut, were available for telecasting. Would it make a newsworthy show? Would it be exciting musically? How many people would tune in on it?

CHARLESTON, S. C., Jan. 10 -- The News and Courier, whose editors through the years were said to be wrong sometimes but seldom neutral, observed its 150th anniversary today with a special sixty-four-page Sunday issue prepared for distribution tomorrow.

BESIDES the opening of Jose Greco and his company at the Century tomorrow (see adjoining column), the week will have several interesting contributions from the New York City Ballet. Tonight both Nora Kaye and Jerome Robbins will appear on the bill.

TWO weeks ago I made what some of you might consider as rather disparaging remarks about the novel as a conveyor of ideas. I had in mind the fact that the books which have most profoundly affected the course of human events, the books which have altered the attitudes of men in the mass, have not been fictional.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 10 -- The recreational boating industry, recovering from a material scarcity that threatened to put it out of business in 1951, has just concluded a very successful year and all indiations from national income and national spending figures forecast an even more successful year in 1953.

" MANY people are miserable when listening to, or talking about, music" observes Mr. Young, English conductor and musicologist. This is an attitude with which he has little patience and he does his best to counteract it.

HE was seeing more and more clearly that all civilization was an effort, and so far always an inadequate and very partially successful effort. Always it had been aristocratic, aristocratic in the sense that it was the work of minorities, who took power, who had a common resolution against the inertia, the indifference, the insubordination and instinctive hostility of the mass of mankind.

TRIESTE -- The skiing news from Middle Europe this early winter is the zooming popularity of Italian resorts, and the continued rise of small, little-known Austrian resorts in the esteem of foreign skiers. Advance bookings clearly indicate the trend, and although the deep snow has been too soft for good skiing, the more accessible of these resorts are fairly crowded over week-ends.

Among the new products at the show is a radio-telephone transmitter-receiver introduced by the Radiomarine Corporation of America. Called the ET-8050-HF, it comes in two models designed to comply with the latest and pending F. C. C. regulations.
The herculean task of fitting 248 exhibitors' elaborate and costly displays into 150,000 square feet of space on the four floors of Grand Central Palace is surrounded with hundreds of daily problems.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 10 -- The American Jewish Archives of the Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion has obtained, classified and field one of the world's largest collections of Americana about Jews in the five years of its existence.

Printing Week will open officially at noon tomorrow, when ceremonies commemorating the 247th anniversary of the birth of Benjamin Franklin will be held in the Board of Estimate chambers in City Hall. A wreath-laying ceremony at the Franklin statue in Printing House Square will follow.

ALBANY, Jan. 10 (UP) -- New York State has drafted 19-year-olds this month for the first time since the outbreak of the Korean conflict, it was disclosed today, and more will be taken from that age bracket next month.

The University of Wisconsin and Harvard University are sharing an experiment in the relative value of labor education techniques for foreign trade unionists. Nine unionists from such countries as Norway, Germany, France and Greece are currently studying at Wisconsin under a program that puts its strongest emphasis on field trips and talks with local labor representatives in the Wisconsin area.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Opening sessions of Congress are gala occasions for everybody at the Capitol except the bill clerks of the Senate and the House. These officials are literally snowed under, each time a session comes along, by legislative projects of dubious future.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 10 -- John J. McCloy, former United States High Commissioner to Germany, will deliver the annual Godkin Lectures at Harvard University Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday. The lectures were founded in 1903 in memory of Edwin L. Godkin, onetime editor of The New York Evening Post and The Nation.
I was deeply interested in the letter on Indo-China written by the President of the India League of America and published in your issue of Jan. 4.

SURELY everyone who has walked along an ocean beach has felt some sense of mystery and wondered about the vast world beneath the sea, remembering perhaps childhood tales of enchanted submarine palaces or sea monsters.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Jan. 10 -- A wayward woodcock, grounded by cold and hunger, was returned aloft in an airliner today on its long overdue trek to the South.

Manhattan College's quintet continued its impressive record at Madison Square Garden last night when it defeated St. Joseph's College of Philadelphia, 71 -- 55. Pressed in the early stages of the game, the Jaspers came on to chalk up their seventh victory in eight starts this season.

Increasingly diversified production is indicated for the United States drug industry in 1953 as a result of sharpening competition and price reduction in antibiotics, the so-called ."wonder drugs." Consequently, more attention will be given to other drug specialties.

" THE WHOLE WORL'," as the Paycock remarked in Sean O'Casey's play, "is in a state of chassis," a proposition that can be demonstrated, when it comes to the world of books, in the following manner: (a) Hungary has just banned Christopher Robin, the Little Women, Sherlock Holmes and Pinocchio --anyone caught enjoying them is subject to prosecution.

Tullio Serafin celebrated his fiftieth anniversary as a conductor last night by leading a concert at Carnegie Hall for the benefit of the Tullio Serafin Foundation fort the Promotion of American Conductors.

NEW England whaling captains are legendary figures. Their day is past, but for a hundred years and more they ranged the seas in their clumsy vessels, unwittingly writing a stirring chapter in maritime history.

Victims of anemia may soon be able to take their daily maintenance dose of vitamin B-12 by mouth instead of by injection, spokesmen for Organon, Inc., pharmaceutical manufacturers, reported here last week. The company has developed a process said to make it practical for the first time to produce on a large scale in concentrated form the elusive substance known as the gastric intrinsic factor.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 10 (UP) -- It stopped raining today at Tropical Park, but the flood of long-shot winners continued as Nimble Fox, a 6-to-1 shot, upset a good field in the $15,000 Straus Memorial Handicap and several other outsiders pranced to victory in earlier races.

Rabbi Norman Lamm, spiritual leader of Congregation Beth Israel, questioned yesterday the propriety of using religious hymns in connection with radio and television commercials and the broadcasting of religious programs under commercial sponsorship.

BONN, Jan. 10 -- The situation of the European Defense Community treaty went from bad to worse this week. In Germany and France, two nations which can make or break the Community, delay, irresolution and revision seemed to be replacing the purposeful urgency which wrote the treaty.

PRETORIA, Jan. 10 -- When Mr. Churchill visited with his old friends General Eisenhower and President Truman this week he came not only as the beloved and respected Prime Minister of America's ally, the United Kingdom. In the background of virtually every subject for possible review, from atomic energy to Pacific defense, lay the shadow of that amorphous, complex and unprecedented association of nations known as the British Commonwealth.

A Queens housewife's curiosity about torn paper dropped into a city trash receptable led to the arrest yesterday of an airline employe who, miffed at not receiving a Christmas bonus, allegedly helped himself to the day's receipts -- $3,793 -- last Dec. 31.

TORONTO, Jan. 10 (UP) -- Harry Watson and rookie Eric Nesterenko combined to lift the Toronto Maple Leafs into sole possession of fourth place in the National Hockey League tonight as the Leafs downed the Boston Bruins, 3 -- 1, before 13,118 fans.

ON Jan. 12,1928,a slim, handsome young fellow of 23 hurried tensely down an aisle in the New York Philharmonic string section and sat down nervously at a concert grand in the center of the Carnegie Hall stage. Sir Thomas Beecham on the podium signaled to the orchestra, and Tchaikovsky's B flat minor Concerto got under way.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP) -- An announcement today disclosed the United States had been experimenting five years ago with anti-aircraft guided missiles having speeds of more than 1,500 miles an hour.
NEW ROCHELLE, Jan. 10 -- Iona College conquered the Hillyer College quintet of Hartford, Conn., tonight, 98 to 56. The home team led 57 to 21 at the half.
Horace Ashenfelter of the New York A. C. stole the show at the annual Senior Metropolitan A.A.U. indoor track and field championships at the Third Engineers Group Armory last night.

WEST PALM BEACH -- A new marina accommodating 146 boats is one of the latest additions to West Palm Beach's winter attractions. It lies within a block of the city's business district and across Flagler Drive from one of the largest hotels and represents the beginning of a civic development program designed to make this resort of even greater interest to tourists.
BERLIN, Jan. 10 (AP) -- The West Berlin Telegraf said today that a Moscow-ordered purge of East Germany's Communist party threatened the position of Premier Otto Grotewohl, a former Socialist.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 10 -- The Corps of Cadets of the Military Academy presented a saber today to Brig. Gen. Oscar J. Gatchell, former Professor of Mechanics at the academy, who retired on Dec. 31 after more than forty years in the Army.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Before adjourning its forty-seventh annual convention, the National Collegiate Athletic Association today voted to assume broader powers to discipline members who violate its precepts for conducting intercollegiate athletics.

A virtual working agreement between the State Athletic Commission and the National Boxing Association yesterday was effected, bringing into close cooperation these two governing agencies for the first time since the N. B. A. was organized in 1920.

The Australians who won the Davis Cup for their country the past three years failed to take so much as a set yesterday in their bow before a New York crowd as tennis professionals in Madison Square Garden.

AMONG young readers Alfred Noyes is best known for the swinging rhythms of such ballads as "The Highwayman" and "Forty Singing Seamen" which have brightened up many a routine high school English class.

PUSAN, Korea, Sunday, Jan. 11 (AP) -- More than thirty rescue craft combed the rough waters outside this port yesterday in search of survivors from the ill-fated Korean ship Chang Yung Ho, but they found the bodies of only five passengers.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 10 -- Speculation and controversy about who will or should direct Indian affairs in the new national Administration has reached an unprecedented pitch among both red men and white men in the West.

WHEN United States representatives in Lebanon last summer organized an air lift to help thousands of stranded Moslem pilgrims to reach Mecca in time, they were facilitating the journey of the faithful into territory controlled by His Majesty King Abdul Aziz Ibn Abdur Rahman al-Feisal al-Saud, founder of the kingdom bearing his name and conqueror of Mecca in the twentieth century.

Group psychotherapy was pictured yesterday as a valid tool in the treatment of narcotics addiction and alcoholism at the closing session of the tenth annual conference of the American Group Psychotherapy Association at the Henry Hudson Hotel.

SCOTCH PLAINS, N. J., Jan. 10 -- Sgt. Lindley A. Church of 2086 Newark Avenue, who was scheduled to appear before Magistrate George W. Jackson here on Oct. 13 to answer an automobile speeding charge, failed to do so because he had another engagement -- in Korea.

THIS is one of the most important weeks on the retailer's calendar. It is a time of review and planning. Thousands of store executives, from top management to buyers, will be here to attend the annual conclave of the National Retail Dry Goods Association and to survey market conditions in preparation for spring merchandising.

FOR a generation or more there has been a real need for a first-hand and detailed re-examination of the evidence available on the earliest and most formative era of the Christian Church. The task was undertaken by a scholar of deserved reputation, Hans Lietzmann of the University of Berlin, and magnificently executed in the successive volumes of "A History of the Early Church," until his death brought a halt to the project ten years ago.
A MAJOR part of the history of recorded music in America has been, until quite recent years, essentially the history of the Victor Company; and Victor astutely is making capital of that fact.

TOO often windowsill gardeners raise only the common wax begonia, ignoring the many other types in this family that do equally well as house plants and are almost as easy to grow. It is true, though, that enthusiasm for this clan often starts with the ordinary wax begonia.

FOR THIS WEEK: It is too late to start Dutch hyacinth bulbs to bloom indoors, but not the daintier French Roman hyacinths, which need no cool dark period for root growth. . . . SKIING, contrary to the general impression, is not limited to the Tyrol, Scandinavia or Bear Mountain, nor its practitioners to Alpine sportsmen and Middlebury College coeds. Skiing goes on in a lot of places more popularly identified with sun and water and lush vegetation than with snow, and there are Japanese, Turkish and Kashmiri skiers, although they probably do not call themselves snow-bunnies.

APOLOGIES need not be made here to the English literary chap, one Stephen Potter, who has lately been exploiting the devious byways of getting the better of one's fellow man. For, as any skier will testify, the Potter works are mere extensions of basic behavior patterns developed by generations of skiers. If any apologies are to be made, let them come from Mr. Potter.

The President's advice last week that a war between the East and the West using nuclear weapons might mean the end of both societies and the destruction of civilization is not based on the assumption that such a conflict would be more vicious than other wars. It is based on knowledge of the nature of these weapons.

ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands, Jan. 10 -- This port, the world's third busiest after New York and London, handled more ocean shipping in 1952 than in any post-war year -- even more than the normal pre-war volume -- but authorities are not entirely sanguine about future prospects.

The latest French Cabinet upheaval, which eliminated M. Schuman as Foreign Minister and created new conditions for the ratification of the treaties on which depend both an adequate Western defense and further progress toward European unification, has brought uneasiness and discouragement to the whole Atlantic community.
RATTLESNAKE, Fla. -- Although there may always be a Christmas, Fla. (pop. 250, near Orlando), there is today considerable doubt that there will continue to be a Rattlesnake Fla.

TOKYO, Jan. 10 -- The first murder trial of an American woman in the Far East Command ended today with the conviction of Mrs. Dorothy Smith of the premeditated murder of her husband, Col. Aubrey D. Smith, last October.

ON THE EASTERN FRONT, in Korea, Jan. 10 -- About 98 per cent of the people in North Korea would rather live under democracy, but the other 2 percent are so closely organized that they maintain Communist rule with an iron hand, North Koreans who fled recently to United Nations territory in this area testified yesterday.

Maureen (Little Mo) Connolly, the little brown-eyed blonde package of dynamite who is the world's best woman tennis player, was chosen woman "athlete of the year" for 1952 yesterday for the second successive time.

The local squadrons of the U. S. P. S. can be thought to have a three-faceted existence -- educational, winter activities, and the summer boating season. The national governing board and the districts can be regarded as the organizational and administrative bodies, which set up the. educational courses and direct the nation-wide affairs of the combined squadrons. But the local squadrons are naturally closest to the individual members.

LOS ANGELES -- With the palpitations of the Pasadena Tournament of Roses and its concomitant bowl game subsiding for another year, Southern California is heading into the second half of its colorful -- and generally element -- winter season.

CAMP DRUM, N. Y., Jan. 10 (AP) -- The Army will send thousands of troops into the individual and unit training phase of Exercise Snow Storm on Monday to school them in efficient operation in snow and cold.
