NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 10 -- The annual $1,000 Bollingen Prize in poetry was doubled this year and awarded to two major poets, Archibald MacLeish and William Carlos Williams. The award committee made the announcement today at the Yale University Library.

THE Christmas - New Year holiday week - ends once again proved, to the satisfaction of resort operators and winter sports enthusiasts, that there is nothing wrong with skiing and related winter sports that a good snowfall will not cure.

A forecast that 1953 might be one of the greatest years for the marine industry was made by C. C. Williams, general manager of the Chrysler Marine and Industrial Engine division. The Chrysler engines at the show were produced in a big new plant at Trenton, Mich., completed last summer.
The Big Change takes place nine days from today. All last week the event cast a long shadow.
HAMILTON, N. Y., Jan. 10 (AP) -- Colgate's basketball team trounced the Buffalo squad tonight, 82 -- 67.

ELEVEN years ago Winston Churchill, flying home from a visit to President Roosevelt, made "a sudden descent," as he put it, to thank the people of Bermuda for giving up one-fifteenth of their twenty-square miles of land to the United States for air and naval bases.
A twenty - horsepower motor called the "200" Silver Streak is the newest in the Martin line of outboard engines. Its first public appearance is at the Palace.

THE subtitle of this anthology, "Stories and People in Poetry" indicates its nature but not its variety. The publishers point out that this "is not an academic volume." It certainly isn't, for here Dangerous Dan McGrew rubs shoulders with Miniver Cheever.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 10 -- In brief meetings tonight each of the two houses of Parliament adopted agenda for a joint session Monday to set the stage for revision of the Constitution, creation of new executive organs and reconstruction of political and economic bases of this Socialist regime.

IN an introductory note to the most recent pamphlet of the United States Children's Bureau -- "A Healthy Personality for Your Child" -- Dr. Martha M. Eliot, bureau chief, makes a point that "everybody has a part to play in creating health of personality in children and youth, including children and youth themselves."

In Korea one night last week a group of U. N. soldiers on patrol discovered the entrance to a tunnel in Anchor Hill, key position on the Eighth Army's eastern flank. The soldiers hid behind boulders and tree stumps and watched the tunnel entrance.

Representatives of twenty-one countries are meeting in Bangkok under the sponsorship of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization to talk about rice production. They are concerned with a vital problem in a critical area and there is no note of satisfaction in the reports from their meeting.

The Kiekhaefer Corp., which makes Mercury outboard motors, is featuring two new models this year. They are a ten-horsepower engine called the Mark 15 and one in the fourteen-to-eighteen horsepower range named the Mark 20.

Borrowings by local government through the public bond market are continuing at a lively pace, reflecting the insistent demand of local communities for improvements in school, water, sewerage and highway facilities.

The history of power cruiser racing dates back to the earliest days of motor-driven craft. Recognizing that many factors were responsible for speed and operation in power-cruiser racing, the American Power Boat Association selected a committee of naval architects to formulate a set of rules by which to handicap and control this type of racing.

THERE are three schools of thought about winter vacations: one enrolls the robust, muscular folk who thrive on wind and snow and ice; the second enlists sun-followers whose blood, if it stirs at all, is activated by a rhumba beat, and the third matriculates those who for lack of time and/or money cannot take and, therefore, don't believe in midwinter holidays.

MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Jan. 10 -- Winner of the Eisenhower Trophy each year since 1948, the crack Military Police company here of the Forty-second (Rainbow) Division will share with the marching band of Buffalo's Twenty-seventh Division the honor of representing the New York National Guard in the Presidential inaugural parade at Washington on Jan. 20.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Jan. 10 -- Educational and civic leaders of Long Island, armed with evidence of the area's demand for and ability to support a local educational television station, are scheduled to appear in Manhattan this Wednesday at the final hearing of the State Commission on the Use of Television for Educational Purposes.

The Winged Foot Polo Club, on a goal made as the final bell was ringing, and Meadow Brook, on a score registered after one minute of "sudden-death" overtime, were the winners in the Metropolitan Indoor Polo League double-header at the Squadron A Armory, Madison Avenue and Ninety-fourth Street, last night.
MELBOURNE, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Lewis Hoad, Australia's No. 2 tennis hope, went down to an astounding defeat today in the Australian singles championships as all the American players won their matches.

FORT MONMOUTH, N. J., Jan. 10 -- A new-type splicer, expected to cut to less than thirty seconds the time needed to repair telegraph and telephone wires at the battle front, has been developed under the sponsorship of the Army. Signal Corps Engineering Laboratories here.

" THINGS," observed Eleanor Parker one afternoon last week, "have a way of working out right for me. For instance, I've had no real hard knocks career-wise. I never did any starving in an attic. I happen to come from a non-professional, middle-class background of school teachers, farmers -- around Cleveland -- without any money.

ANOTHER interesting step has been taken in the energetic campaign of choreographers to secure adequate copyright protection for their compositions, comparable to the protection provided to musicians for their creations.

IMPROVED road conditions are offered this year to winter vacationists who travel by car into the brisk air of the northern resorts or follow the sun to the South and Southwest. Strong efforts will be made to free the highways of snow, and more routes will be kept open than ever before.

EVEN without the music Sergei Prokofiev's commentary for his orchestral fairy tale, "Peter and the Wolf" makes a very good story, with its folktale comedy and its genuine -- if small-scale -- suspense. Alan Howard gives it in a most appropriate setting in this picture book, with illustrations which are reminiscent of Russian folk art in detail but notable for a sophisticated simplicity.

Trading in financial markets returned to normal last week after the protracted holiday period. Prices of shares, however, moved downward the first time in five weeks. The State of the Union and budget messages of the President were received calmly and caused little reaction in the stock market, where technical conditions brought an interruption to the long upswing.

DARRYL F. ZANUCK gave Hollywood something to think about in announcing that Twentieth Century-Fox would pour "more than $20,000,000" into production this year in Technicolor of seven pictures carrying the designations of "super-specials."
HANOVER, N. H., Jan. 10 -- Cornell's driving basketball team rallied in the second half to defeat Dartmouth, 76 -- 63, tonight.

THE most powerful tyrant of an earthbound past could manage no more than a city, or perhaps an island, as an exclusive preserve for debauchery. But a Tiberius of the far future won't have to settle for a mere Capri; he may set aside an entire planet as his personal pleasure dome.

A new rule requiring every entrant to a recognized show sign an agreement placing himself under the jurisdiction of the American Horse Shows Association was adopted yesterday at that organization's annual meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The signing would give the A. H. S. A. control of the operations of the show.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Frances Perkins, about to step out of Washington career that began in 1933, says the Democrats were handicapped because the Republicans failed to present "a really good opposition" any time during the Roosevelt-Truman era.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 10 -- Lloyd Mangrum, always one of golf's leading money-winners, took a title grip on the Bing Crosby $10,000 national pro-amateur tournament today. He spread-eagled the field with a 67, 66 -- 133.

The heavy storms that for three days have raged over New York, New England, New Jersey and other parts of the country with rain, snow, sleet, ice and wind continued yesterday, and in the Northeast they showed no signs of abating today.

Diehl Mateer of the University Club and his partner, Jim Foster of the New York Athletic Club, top-seeded team, advanced to the semi-final round of the A. H. Lockett Trophy invitation doubles squash racquets tournament on the courts of the University Club yesterday.

Paced by Jerry Curran, Fordham University's swimming team defeated New York University yesterday, 48 to 36, at the Quigley Memorial Pool on the N. Y. U. campus. Curran won the 440-yard free-style and the 200-yard backstroke and was on the Ram's victorious 300-yard medley relay team.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, convicted atomic spies, appealed this morning to President Truman for executive clemency to save them from the electric chair.

While most people have become accustomed to talking of billions during the last decade, the banking business is one of only a few in which the word "trillion" is on its way toward becoming commonplace. This was the recent comment of William Powers, deputy manager of the American Bankers Association, who pointed out that the annual debits figure for the banking system is now running in excess of one and a half trillion dollars.

Thirteen engine manufacturers are represented at the Palace show with a line of inboard power plants whose capacities fit the needs of most yachtsmen They range in size from a little 5 h. p. gasoline engine to a Diesel of 900 h. p.

BARTOK: Piano Music; Bela Bartok (Remington). Contained on this disk are excerpts from Mikrokosmos (with Bartok's wife, Ditta Pasztory, at the second piano), the Rondo on Folk Tunes, Petite Suite, Five Improvisations and others. The interest here is, of course, the performer.

TOKYO, Jan. 10 -- Japan has both fears and expectations from the new United States Administration. The general belief is that America will be more interested in Asian problems and the contain ment of communism here as opposed to what some call the "Europe first" philosophy and may even attempt to recapture Communist gains through an intensified war in Korea, support to the Chinese Nationalists in mainland raids and the blockade of the China coastline.

The Damon Runyon Memorial Fund for Cancer Research has granted $6,217,359 to institutions and research fellows, Dan Parker president, announced yesterday Contributions now have gone over the $7,000,000 mark, he said.

MIAMI BEACH -- If early tourists and the Christmas-New Year crowds can be used as a basis for prediction, Greater Miami and Florida are entering the greatest winter season in their history. Reports from hotels, airlines, railroads and bus companies indicate that the season this year started a week or ten days earlier than usual, with business setting a record for Christmas and New Year.

IN this novel a young United States Marine and a young nun are cast from the sea onto a small abandoned South Pacific island early in World War II. In the beginning, the only thing these two people have in common is the English language.
Signed contracts continue to roll into the Dodgers' Montague Street offices and yesterday Buzzie Bavasi, Brooklyn's bustling veep, bagged two very valuable ones.

The rules governing the taxation of capital gains have undergone many changes in the administration of income tax laws under the Constitutional Amendment. The primary reason for this is that capital gains are not inherently income; that in order to have made the tax workable as well as productive it was necessary to change from time to time not only the definition of capital gains but also the methods of taxing them.

Paul Badura-Skoda, pianist made his American debut yesterday afternoon in Town Hall, playing an unusual and uncommonly substantial program of compositions that could be pigeon-holed, if one were so inclined, as belonging to the "classic," "romantic," and "modern" periods.

The steel industry's quest for new sources of racy materials, particularly iron and manganese, is showing highly promising results. Financing was arranged last week for the first major commercial recovery of iron from taconite, or low-grade ore, on Minnesota's Mesabi Range and for exploitation of a second huge deposit of manganese in Brazil.

IF Mr. Bing has accomplished nothing else by his production in English of "La Boheme" he has given additional impetus to the public's interest in the question of opera in the vernacular, and he has pointed out, however involuntarily in the process, two of the things which are absolutely essential if opera sung in English is to assume its proper artistic status at the Metropolitan.

ALBANY, Jan. 10 -- The controversy over New York City's finances, which promises to dominate the session of the State Legislature that began on Wednesday, is focusing new attention on the complex relationships between the state and city governments and the responsibilities of each.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 10 -- A big new development in boating has been the outboard cruisers. Scarcely dreamed of ten years ago, the earliest were rather rough, improvised affairs, sort of a cabin on an outboard skiff.

IN London last September the Thirteenth International Horticultural Congress convened to consider, among other things, the problem of plant nomenclature. In an effort to clarify this vast subject the Congress ordered an international code of nomenclature for cultivated plants -- on a trial basis -- to become eventually a part of the International Code of Botanical Nomenclature.

VIENNA, Jan. 10 -- A number of Czechoslovak railway men and others accused of assisting in the escape of a trainload of fugitives across the Czech frontier to Bavaria in September, 1951, have been sentenced in Carlsbad, Czechoslovakia, after a three-day trial, according to the Prague radio.

DETROIT, Jan. 10 -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., prodded the auto industry today to grant by March 1 the union's demands for wage and pension improvements or risk voiding a five- year escalator agreement that has two and a half years to run.

A feat of modern engineering is opening up to new life one of the most desolate but also wildly romantic and sublimely beautiful regions of the earth -- the region of the Dead Sea. The road will serve first of all to exploit the mineral riches which the Jordan River has poured into that sea through the millenniums.
Several hundred pickets paraded in Times Square last night urging clemency for the Rosenbergs. Reaction of spectators ranged from indifference to sneers and profane exclamations.

WASHINGTON, Jan 10 (AP) -- The bunting is going up -- red, white and blue. Along Pennsylvania Avenue, historic route of Presidents and military heroes, a smell of wet paint arises from the rows of new wooden bleachers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Threats and promises of budget cutting and tax relief resounded on Capitol Hill this week as the new Republican Congress received President Truman's valedictory budget. But at least two big questions were unanimously ignored in the rash of statements, many of them patently exaggerated, issued by members.

The Musicians Emergency Fund and the Casa Verdi in Milan, Italy, will be the beneficiaries of a supper dance to be held on the night of Jan. 24 aboard the new luxury liner of the Italian Line, the Andrea Doria. Mrs. Lytle Hull and Mrs. Vladimir Horowitz are co-chairmen of the benefit committee.

DURING Bach's lifetime he published, in 1731, 1735, 1739 and 1742, four volumes of keyboard works that were entitled Clavieruebung ("Keyboard Practice"). In those collections were such pieces as the six Partitas, the four Duets, the Italian Concerto, Overture in the French Style, Goldberg Variations (all for harpsichord) and a large number of Chorale Preludes (for organ).

A PHOTOGRAPH of the new year's first United States stamp, a 3-cent blue "in recognition of the vital contributions the National Guard has made in both peace and war," has been made available by Postmaster General Jesse M. Donaldson. This special item will receive first-day sale at Washington on Feb. 23.

MONTREAL, Jan. 10 (UP) -- Elmer Lach hit his old stride and scored two goals and two assists tonight as the Montreal Canadiens defeated the Chicago Black Hawks, 5 -- 2, to move into second place in the National Hockey League.

DAYTON, Ohio, Jan. 10 -- A lot of water has passed over the dam since the Albany-New York Outboard Association staged its boat race for several classes of stock service outboard motors and strictly utility type boats. This was shortly after World War II.

NOW that time has rounded the corner of the old year a number of Americans are beginning to make plans for summer vacations in Europe. And European festival managers have been even more forehanded. Most of them have already drawn up the programs calculated to attract the vacationers with a special interest in music.

DR. SLAUGHTER here brings his best-selling talents to the task of imagining the life of Mary Magdalene. The results are melodramatic and ingenious. The flame-haired woman who emerges from these fast-paced pages will doubtless delight the romantics, satisfy the reverent, and startle the skeptics.

MIAMI -- Foreign travel in and out of the Miami International Airport has been increasing at a rapid rate, partly because of the growing popularity among winter and summer visitors of short hops to the Caribbean.
Sales of phonographs and records last year were satisfactory if not sensational. Good business is expected this year.

THERE was a press association article in the newspapers the other day to the effect that Joe DiMaggio was leading in the voting for a spot in the Hall of Fame. It made interesting reading. Unfortunately, though, it just isn't true. No one was more astonished by the story than that delightful chap, Kenesaw Mountain Smith, the tireless secretary of the Baseball Writers Association.

GUATEMALA CITY -- A common description of Guatemala is "primitive," and visitors arriving here are often under the impression that, in exchange for a glimpse of the local sights, it will he necessary to give up modern conveniences.

PARIS, Jan. 10 (UP) -- Premier Rene Mayer issued a call today to his top diplomatic representatives abroad to return for week-end conferences in a move aimed at allaying fears in Western capitals that his new French Government would "go slow" on European unity plans.

STRASBOURG, France, Jan. 10 -- Planners of European unity turned from politics to economics today when the meeting of the European Constitutional Assembly was succeeded by a session of the Assembly of the Coal and Steel Community.
The highly critical survey of the Federal Civil Service system issued last month by the National Civil Service League deserves careful study by the incoming Administration.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 10 -- The Friends Committee on National Legislation said today that the United States must take positive steps to reduce the danger of four "sparks" that could touch off a third World War.

Almanacs for 1953 having appeared, it may now be said that 1952 has passed into history. The record is impressive, consisting of almost a thousand pages, covering everything from Abadan to Zoroastrians.

TRENTON, Jan. 10 -- Charles R. Erdman, State Commissioner of Conservation, said today that technicians of his department were continuing the search for a site for a large all-weather landing field as an auxiliary to Newark Airport.

THE disk jockeys of America are getting a fine object lesson these days. They are learning that they don't have to play the worst records extant to be successful; that they can, in fact, earn quite a living and guite a following by spinning popular and jazz sides that do have some musical merit.

Iron lungs are found all over America. Many of them have people inside -- both the young and the aged victims of polio. There are thousands of other lungs to be found on display in stores and public places everywhere. These small replicas are contribution boxes. They are not made to hold people but to hold our donations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Completely unawed by the glowing reputations of his big-name adversaries, Villanova's Fred Dwyer tonight won the first big invitation mile test of the post-Olympic indoor track and field season.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 10 (UP) -- Blue Reading and Stranglehold, top half of a four-horse entry, staged a head-and-head duel down the stretch today, with Blue Reading emerging the victor in the $30,100 Santa Catalina Stakes for California-foaled horses at Santa Anita.

A collection of modern French illustrated books belonging to Harriman Douglas of Los Angeles will be auctioned at 1:45 and 8 P M. Tuesday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue. The sale will continue Wednesday afternoon.

Plans are nearing completion for the annual Animal Kingdom Ball, to assist the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, which will be held on Jan. 29 in the ballroom of the Pierre. Miss Louisa Livingston, chairman of the debutante committee, has enlisted the aid of several other debutantes to work for the success of the fete.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (UP) -- The Senate Republican leader, Robert A. Taft of Ohio, said today there was "complete confusion" about who would hand out political plums in the Administration of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 10 -- Representatives of ten educational institutions and the City of Philadelphia formed the Delaware Valley Television Corporation this week to establish an ultra-high frequency, nonprofit educational television station for the Philadelphia Camden area.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 10 -- Dr. Vernon W. Lippard took over his new duties this week as dean of the Yale School of Medicine, twenty-three years after he received his M. D. degree here. He is noted as a pediatrician.

A dozen engines and two cutaway models are in the Gray exhibit at the Motor Boat Show. Included also, but not yet available for sale, is an example of a Continental "Turbomeca" gas turbine unit which delivers 250 h. p. from a total weight of only 180 pounds.

LOS ANGELES -- The year 1953 will bring progress in Los Angeles' billion-dollar freeway program which should be a boon to the 2,000,000 automobile travelers now coming annually to Southern California. As this is written, State highway officials are preparing to open the next-to-the-last leg of the Hollywood Freeway.
TOKYO, Sunday, Jan. 11 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,491, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M. Sunday, Korean time:

When Southerners rightfully point with pride to the rapid advances they have made in recent years in building a new, dynamic South, they usually refer to agricultural and industrial programs. Here at the University of Florida's Florida Center for Clinical Services, however, is a unique and equally impressive "human" program of para-medical services which, it appears, may well set a pattern for the rest of the nation.
The International Longshoremen's Association, A.F.L., took a challenging position yesterday in the waterfront crime inquiry.

THE snarls and strife that appeared to be inevitable before the opening of the three-day National Theatre Assembly, held here from Jan. 1 to 3, failed to develop as delegates found themselves in ultimate accord on virtually all of the important issues that confronted them.
As co-producer of "The Deep Blue Sea," I would like to reply to the Ruth Starr letter in your Section last Sunday.

ANY large appreciation of Picasso's prodigal oeuvre must await the calming of the tempest that he has blown up over modern art for the past fifty years. Better, meanwhile, to take him piecemeal, a digestive process made easier in his case because his leaps from style to style isolate naturally his work within certain periods.

Fordham's untarnished basketball record was threatened last night by St. Peter's. The visiting team took the lead midway through the third quarter and held it until well into the fourth. Then the Rams came on to win, 77 -- 75. It was the eleventh straight for Fordham.

For his return to the podium of the N. B. C. Symphony last night in Carnegie Hall, Arturo Toscanini selected two works. The Berlioz "Roman Carnival" Overture, which received an unusually rushed performance, is an ever-welcome old friend.

AS the subtitle states, Mr. Sachs' book is a study in music history, not as the title itself suggests, a theoretical treatise on rhythm It is an important and valuable as well as a fascinating book. It is a mine of highly interesting and useful information regarding rhythmic theory and, so far as this can be known, rhythmic practice throughout the ages and the various civilizations.

EACH winter several hundred thousand motorists and several million birds make the 1.370 - mile migration from New York to Miami and environs. Apparently all agree that the destination is worth the effort, but an alarming number of motorists seem to share the mistaken opinion that what lies between is strictly for the birds.

FEB. 26, 1910, was an important day in the history of winter sports in the United States. That day saw the inauguration of the Dartmouth Winter Carnival. Until that date, the first snowfall had usually been a signal for all inhabitants of the north country to fill their pipes, stoke their fires and sit back to wait for spring.

Herbert Callman of the Herbert Callman Company in Long Island City received last night the top award of a $750 Government bond in the Long Island Real Estate Board's contest for the outstanding deal consummated by a member of the organization in 1952. The presentation was made at the annual dinner of the board at the Biltmore Hotel.

THE Horticultural Society of New York's annual meeting for members will be held Wednesday from 2 to 4:30 P. M. at the Essex House, Fifty-eighth Street near Seventh Avenue. The program will open with a business meeting.
All markers indicate that the past year produced many new enthusiasts in the field of recreational boating. Ask the N. A. E. B. M.; ask the Coast Guard. Then let me tell you our side of the story.

ALBANY, Jan. 10 -- The State Budget Director, T. Norman Hurd, characterized today as "malicious propaganda" charges by the American Petroleum Institute that the state was the nation's chief offender in diverting motor fuel and vehicle revenues from highway purposes.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Jan. 10 -- As part of a campaign to end duplication and waste in United States defense building in Europe, Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Supreme Allied Commander, has approved a plan to set up a unified construction agency to handle military building for all three American fighting services on the Continent.

In a position at last to present a solid front with the cooperation of New York's State Athletic Commission, the National Boxing Association at a special meeting at the Hotel Astor yesterday appointed a ten-man committee to explore the effect of television.
PARIS, Jan. 11 (UP) -- Premier Rene Mayer completed today the formation of France's eighteenth post-war Government with the appointment of nine Secretaries of State.

The extent of the restrictions that should be placed on free thought in the interest of our national security proved a thorny question yesterday for six students of junior high school age who participated in the weekly Youth Forum of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

RANGOON -- The dedication of a health center here built with the aid of Technical Cooperation Administration funds was repeatedly delayed by the Burmese official in charge. Finally he set the date, revealing that he had been awaiting the decision of the astrologers regarding a propitious time.

Friday afternoon card games in the basement of the Brooklyn Public Library's Flatbush branch, Linden Boulevard and Flatbush Avenue, are played with full official approval. They take place in the Senior Citizens Room, where the players range in age from 60 to 88 years.
GENEVA, Jan. 11 -- Europe outside the Soviet Union produced a record quantity of steel during 1952, the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe reported today.

PARIS, Jan. 11 -- With the Schuman Plan single market for coal scheduled to begin Feb. 10, only a few weeks off, there has been satisfaction here at the news that French coal production in 1950 beat all previous records with a figure of 57,300,000 metric tons. In 1951, 54,900,000 metric tons were produced.

" On Borrowed Time" is wending its way to New York with a cast including such stalwarts as Victor Moore, Leo G. Carroll, Beulah Bondi, Melinda Markey, Russell Hicks, David John Stollery and Kay Hammond. Due here the week of Feb. 9 or 16, it will mark the first local revival of Paul Osborn's fantasy, based on the Lawrence Edward Watkin novel.
Eight new films, including importations from Italy and France, are arriving in first-run theaters this week. The programs follow:

RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 11 -European representatives of the Socialist International here say they are not surprised by the decision of the Asian Socialists to establish a separate Asian Socialist organization. The Europeans had hoped the Asian parties would join the International to bring about one unified world Socialist grouping, but accept the separate Asian organization as a natural development and one that need not impair cooperation between the Socialists of East and West.

KARACHI -- Here, as in India, the Technical Cooperation Administration's primary task is to assist in village development. A major project is construction of a $12,000,000 fertilizer factory, to which the United States is contributing $4,000,000 and technical assistance.

Among the many exhibitions this week by contemporary painters and sculptors there is one of a historical character opening tomorrow at Durlacher's entitled "Romanticism in Eighteenth-Century England." Today at the Stable Gallery a large group of advance guard painters and sculptors show their work.

The appointment of Bernard J. O'Connell of 2200 East Tremont Avenue, the Bronx, as deputy director of the city's Division of Labor Relations was announced yesterday by Daniel Kornblum, director of the agency.
The Hanover Bank's net operating earnings last year amounted to $9,100,000, or $7.60 a share, compared with $7,800,000, or $6.53 in 1951, according to the bank's annual report issued today.

Caught by a four-day-old strike of gravediggers and other cemetery workers, at least ten families with the help of friends dug and covered graves for their own dead in Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, L. I., in yesterday's murky weather.
NEW DELHI -- In the erstwhile hermit kingdom of Nepal, reached only by air or mountain track, a village-development program is under way with Point Four help.

Hundreds of telephone and electric linemen working around the clock had restored service yesterday to more than half the homes cut off by the ice storm in southern Connecticut, Westchester County and northern New Jersey.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 11 -- John Foster Dulles, General Dwight D. Eisenhower's Secretary of State-designate, plans to visit India, Pakistan and several other Asiatic countries in the spring. His principal aim is to determine to what extent their Governments are ready to cooperate in the new Administration's plans for a coordinated defense against Communist aggression in the Far East.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Jan. 11 (AP) -- Rain and slush today forced postponement of thirteen races in the twenty-first annual Eastern States outdoor speed-skating championships.

SAN SALVADOR -- El Salvador is devoting all the resources she can muster to a balanced development program in which the United Nations and all international agencies are cooperating. The Point Four program is playing a key role in spurring agricultural development.

A warming fog covered most of the metropolitan region and adjoining storm-swept areas yesterday, and a rise in temperatures to just a few degrees above freezing enabled harried utility em ployes to bring tens of thousands of persons back from candlelight and fireplaces to the twentieth century era of electric power and telephones.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Jan. 11 -- In the first review and financial statement to be made public by the trustees of Colonial Williamsburg, the Rockefeller-financed restoration of the historic Virginia capital, Kenneth Chorley, president of the board, announced today that ten more years of work at a cost of about $15,000,000 would be needed to complete the restoration program.

Nell Rankin, mezzo-soprano, who has sung here for a number of composers' groups and who joined the Metropolitan Opera last season, gave her first New York solo recital last night at Town Hall. It turned out to be an evening of almost flawless tonal beauty.
PARIS, Jan. 11 -- The controversy in France over a European army has its source in two United States policies that have proved difficult to reconcile.

A luncheon menu printed on paper made from a shirt belonging to the man honored at the luncheon is among hand-made papers in this month's exhibit at the American Craftsmen's Education Council, Inc., 32 East Fifty-second Street.

If man seeks the "irreducible minimum" of the Christian faith, he will find it in a complete affirmation of and commitment to Jesus Christ, the Rev. Dr. Theodore A. Gill declared in his final sermon yesterday at West End Presbyterian Church.
The engagement of Herva Nelli, American soprano, was announced yesterday by the Metropolitan Opera. Miss Nelli will make her debut in the title role of "Aida" on Friday, Jan. 23.

DETROIT, Jan. 11 (UP) -- Gordie Howe, the National Hockey League's leading scorer, rapped three goals home tonight as the Detroit Red Wings defeated the Toronto Maple Leafs, 5 -- 2, before 14,219 fans at Olympia.

The unpredictable nature of the entertainment world seldom has been more vividly illustrated than in the revival of the art of reading aloud. While Hollywood and Broadway have had their usual troubles with productions boasting lavish settings and big casts, individuals and small groups are trouping the country with nothing more than a handful of books and registering spectacular box-office successes.

RIO DE JANEIRO -- The Point Four program in Brazil is the largest in South America and is based on an investment program aimed to provide improvement of railroads and ports, expansion of electric-power production, equipment for maintaining and improving highways and agricultural machinery.

There were indications yesterday that some parts of Mayor Impellitteri's $218,700,000 fiscal program for 1953-54 might be salvaged despite its apparent rejection last Saturday by the Republican chairmen of the legislative committees to which it will be referred.

NEW DELHI -- The landlocked kingdom of Afghanistan, beyond Khyber Pass, once a "forbidden" land of nomads and herdsmen, is using Point Four aid to supplement efforts of its own to increase food production and spur develoopment of resources.

The two-story taxpayer building at 804 Lexington Avenue, north-west corner of Sixty-second Street, which the Astor Estate built in 1939, has been purchased by an investing client of S. J. Linett, attorney, for cash over mortgages amounting to $125,000. Dwight-Helmsley, Inc., was the broker. The seller, William Rosenblatt, was represented by Joseph Labell.

We are pleased to note that the plans for fine new housing in the Morningside Heights - Manhattanville area, on the upper West Side, are at last only one step away from final official approval. This final step should promptly follow public hearings to be held by the Board of Estimate this week.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 11 -- The Communist leaders of this country have virtually completed a thorough reorganization of their party, changing its function from one of direct control to achievement of the same aims by suasion with the party in the background.

BEIRUT -- Point Four's achievement in Saudi Arabia has been to help that tribal and intensely conservative Moslem country adjust to the impact of sudden wealth, channel its colossal oil revenues in useful directions and set up the machinery of a modern state.
MANIZALES, Colombia, Jan. 11 -- The Roman Catholic Church started today a long-range program designed to improve the lot of agricultural workers in South America.
TOKYO, Monday, Jan. 12 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,492, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Monday, Korea time:

With utilities busy restoring power and telephone lines in the storm-stricken areas, here is how the situation looked last night, section by section, with the estimates given by the various utili ties involved:

WILTON, Conn., Jan. 11 -- Two stone-capped brick chimneys gutted nakedly into the sodden sky atop the Old Belden Hill here today, and smoke still seeped from the ruins of what had been a $50,000 Georgian-Colonial home.
TOKYO, Monday, Jan. 12 (AP) -Japanese newspaper editors lashed out yesterday in an attack on "old heads" in the Imperial Palace for standing in the way of Emperor Hirohito's personal freedom.

MOST Americans, whether they have seen Paris or not, think of it as Gay Paree, the city of light. The Paris of their imaginations includes Notre Dame and the Eiffel Tower, broad avenues and old bridges, the Comedie Francaise and the Folies Bergeres. But it doesn't include the many thousands of Parisians who live in poverty and toil grimly to survive while poised, precariously on the ragged edge of nothing.

A 15,000-acre desert west of Alexandria, Egypt, is being recovered to provide forage for the starving flocks of Bedouins. Ecuador's potato crop, a main food crop, has been increased sixfold. El Salvador's corn crop has been expanded fourfold.

Flocks of merry business men came skipping out of the November elections singing, "No more lessons, no more books, no more teachers' nasty looks." The Eisenhower victory, they thought they knew, meant an end to controls, an end to planned economy.

AMSTERDAM, Jan. 11 -- Reopening of a conference of a working party of the International Rubber Study Group in London is considered here as possibly being of great importance regarding the general policy adopted toward Southeast Asia.

TEL AVIV -- With Point Four help nine trade schools and a photographic laboratory are being equipped for vocational training. Six training centers are being established, as well as a mobile training unit for work in the Negeb. Vocational training advice is being provided the Ministry of Education.

HANOVER, N. H., Jan. 11 -The Amos Tuck School of Business Administration at Dartmouth College has named Dr. Arthur R. Upgren dean and director of research. Dr. Upgren was Professor of Economics at the University of Minnesota Business School.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Some key Democrats joined a Republican group today in backing a move by Representative Daniel A. Reed, Republican of New York, to cut individual income tax rates about 11 per cent July 1.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- On the eve of a grand jury meeting to receive the case, the Federal Government has decided to drop its request for criminal indictment of five major American oil companies on charges of world-wide monopoly practices set forth in a report of the Federal Trade Commission.

IT has been the custom in this corner not to bother with a secret ballot for baseball's Hall of Fame but to do it publicly. There's nothing to be ashamed of. Or there shouldn't be, anyway. So when the formal voting slip arrived from Kenesaw Mountain Smith, the secretary of the Baseball Writers Association, this typewriterpounder began to think out loud. Not only was it loud.
Ghosts thronged the World Building at 63 Park Row yesterday from its darkened sub-basement to its verdigrisy dome as the structure awaited a death sentence from the city.

It is not surprising that the Legal Aid Society, 11 Park Place, New York 7, should have earned the sobriquet of "the poor man's lawyer" in the nearly seventy-seven years since it was incorporated in 1876. Last year alone the society helped 50,00O persons who were unable to pay for legal advice.

Sinclair Oil Corporation is offering to its common stockholders the right to subscribe for $101,758,900 of 3 1/4 per cent convertible subordinated debentures due Jan. 15, 1983, on the basis of $100 of debentures for each twelve shares held.

QUITO -- Among the Point Four program's outstanding achievements in Ecuador is a six-fold increase in the crop of potatoes, which are native to the country and one of the main food crops. Research, at only a slight increase in production cost, achieved chemical control of the late blight that in recent years has ruined 75 per cent of the crop.

BEIRUT -- Despite an unfavorable political climate, several worthwhile Point Four projects are under way in Lebanon, notably a pre-construction survey of the Litani River basin drainage area in southern Lebanon, which would bring power, irrigation and rural improvement to a third of the country.
BOSTON, Jan. 11 (UP) -- Chicago's Blackhawks came from behind tonight to beat Boston, 4 to 2, before 8,042 Boston Garden fans and take over second place in the National Hockey League.
Vince Martinez, Paterson, N. J., welterweight, has been voted "the rookie of the year" in boxing by the Boxing Writers' Association of New York, it was announced yesterday.
Thank you for your editorial entitled "Reparation to Manila."

Grateful tenants of Lavanburg Homes, one of Manhattan's first private slum-clearance projects, joined city and state housing officials yesterday in paying tribute to Fred L. Lavanburg, industrialist and financier, whose contributions helped start the development twenty-five years ago.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) -- The Government reported today that manufacturing corporations showed net profits after taxes of $2,600,000,000 in the third quarter of 1952.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 11 -- Steel output last week continued on a high tonnage level. On the basis of new capacity figures (17 1/2 million tons annually) released last week, steel production then was 98.5 per cent of capacity -- unchanged from a revised rate in the week before.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Jan. 11 -- Seton Hall University maintained its unblemished record for its mid-week meeting with Fordham tonight with an 86-78 victory over Xavier University of Cincinnati before 3,400 at the Seton Hall gymnasium.
The foreign exchange market started the new year bare of any outstanding developments. Rates moved irregular within a narrow range and business transacted was only moderately heavy.
Efforts being made to obtain elimination of separate consular invoices required by Cuba and Venezuela on imports were announced over the week-end by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 11 -- Superficially eighteen months without oil revenue have not changed the appearance of Iran's capital. Although deprived of its so-called life blood, the Iranian economy stubbornly refuses to lie down and die.
Leading New York citizens are already turning their attention to the 1953 Mayoralty election. Committees are being formed to bring about the nomination of suitable candidates.

The creation of four top merchandising positions, new to Gimbels New York, was announced over the week-end by Joseph L. Eckhouse, executive head of the store. The positions, each to carry the title of senior merchandise manager, will be filled by four former divisional merchandise managers -- Saul Goldmark, Meyer Katz, Samuel Trepner and Roland Tripp.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -The development of the large university is one of the major phenomena in American higher education during the last half-century, the United States Office of Education said today in its first study on the size of student bodies.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- A committee of industrial leaders advised today that in the coming decade the Government stresses development of stand-by production capacity for defense rather than the stockpiling of weapons and equipment.

Among Westinghouse's new electric ranges, which go on sale the end of next month, is a model with a surface unit equipped with an electronic eye. Foods cooked over it can never burn even if the water in which they are being boiled evaporates.

LONDON, Jan. 11 -- The stock markets have made a modestly satisfactory start upon the new year. Although the gold and dollars reserves statement showed that the sterling area had dropped from a position of earning surpluses to a deficit of $49,000,000 in December.

Customs collections in New York resulting from last month's shipping activities aggregated almost $27,000,000, an increase of $4,646,374 or more than 20 per cent over the figure for December, 1951. The monthly report of Harry M. Durning, Collector of the Port, traced the increase almost wholly to duty collections on incoming cargoes.
BAGHDAD -- Iraq is embarked on a large, self-financed development program, and Point Four aid supplements this effort.
TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 11 (AP) -- Gardnar Mulloy, the nation's top ranked tennis player, defeated Bitsey Grant of Atlanta in the semi-finals of the Dixie Tennis Tournament today.

So many persons have asked to appear at the public hearing on Wednesday of the Temporary State Commission on the use of television for educational purposes that it has been necessary to add another day, Thursday, so both sides of the question might be heard, the commission announced yesterday.

The striking bus workers are seeking a forty-hour week with no cut in the pay they used to get for working forty-four to forty-eight hours, with five to nine hours of guaranteed overtime. The old basic wage ranged from $1.66 to $1.73 1/2 an hour.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, took time out yesterday from a busy pre-inaugural schedule to welcome home his son, Maj. John Eisenhower, 29 years old, who arrived at La Guardia Airport at 4:15 P. M. from Korea.
MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 11 (AP) -- The Minneapolis Lakers pushed New York out of the Eastern Division lead in the National Basketball Association tonight, winning, 85 -- 79, before 6,070 fans.

Richard Dyer-Bennet brought his Spanish guitar and his singing gifts back to New York Saturday night for his annual Town Hall recital. His program attracted 1,400 listeners, including a high percentage of young people, and when he had gone through his printed list the audience asked for its own favorite encores.

A 20-year-old, unemployed theatre usher confessed to the police yesterday that he had knocked his 64-year-old mother to the floor and then stamped on her neck after an argument yesterday morning over whether she should give him $6 to pay his room rent.

NEW DELHI -- A village elder greeted an Indian agricultural extension worker with the challenge: "When Government people come here, it is either to beat us or collect higher taxes. Which are you going to do ?"

Net earnings of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York last year amounted to $81,839,982, compared with $69,419,789 in the previous year, according to the bank's thirty-eighth annual statement, to be issued today by Allan Sproul, president. Earnings paid the United States Treasury amounted to $69,832,434 against $58,083,910 a year ago.

By the end of 1952, Constellation transports had flown the Atlantic more than 35,000 times on scheduled passenger flights, the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation reports. The company said a survey of airline records showed that no other passenger transport came close to that figure.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- A Republican Representative today suggested that he and his colleagues in political prosperity needed to put up a fresh guard--against talking too much.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Jan. 11 -- With the ice gone but not all the rain, the dinghy sailors carried on today off the Larchmont Yacht Club. Also gone was the wind, which evidently had blasted itself out the last three days. There were wisps of it left, however, and with them a combination of racing and drifting was engaged in out in the cold and water-soaked air.
The North Atlantic Treaty Organization, with sixty to eighty divisions and 5,000 planes spread from northern Norway to the Caucasus, is sick from success.

A feeling of spring is conveyed by the new accessories and furniture to be available this week at the House of Italian Handicrafts, 217 East Forty-ninth Street. Most of the items are comparatively inexpensive.

In your edition of Dec. 25 I read with interest Senator Pat McCarran's attack on Harry Rosenfield and the latter's reply -- a case of pot calling kettle black wherein both employ inaccuracies as arguments against each other.

MONROVIA -- Liberia, the first country to sign a general Point Four agreement embracing its entire economy, is pushing its development by direct contract and by agreements with United Nations agencies, as well as by full use of Point Four aid.

CAIRO -- Tractors driven by young Egyptian army officers are ripping out inedible vegetation and breaking the hard-packed soil in a forty-mile strip of desert west of Alexandria from which Egyptians hope, with Point Four aid, to add 3,000,000 acres of sparsely covered range land to Egypt's 6,000,000 arable acres.

New York City, condemned in the past by countless persons as "an impossible place to bring up children," had some good words spoken for it last week-end at a meeting held at the Biltmore Hotel under the auspices of the the Associates of the Bank Street College of Education.

BENGHAZI -- Ninety Libyans are attending a technical training school newly opened with Point Four help in the capital of this desert kingdom. They are learning plumbing, electrical work and other skilled trades.

Fischer-Landis, investors and operators, have sold the taxpayer building containing the Fleetwood motion picture theatre and ten stores at 998-1002 Morris Avenue and 270-98 East 165th Street, the Bronx, to clients of Jerome F. P. Tobin, lawyer. The building fronts 121 feet on Morris Avenue and occupies a blockfront on 165th Street between Morris and College Avenues. The theatre contains 1,700 seats.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Jan. 11 -- Mezzy Barber, 34-year-old optical research engineer from Sturbridge, Mass., today for the second straight year swept the annual Norway invitation, Harold Nelson and Franklin D. Roosevelt Memorial jump held concurrently over the soft, slushy 50-meter Bear Mountain hill before 4,000.

PARIS, Jan. 11 -- Premier Rene Mayer's present intention is to ask Britain to join in the European Army Treaty to the extent of signing a protocol to it specifying that British forces on the Continent would be closely linked with the units of the continental states fully participating in the European Defense Community which the treaty would establish.

TEHERAN -- Point Four's major effort in Iran is in rural development, under a joint Iranian-United States commission. Operating out of Teheran and seven regional centers, teams of United States technicians work with Iranian technicians and villagers in agriculture, health and rural education.

TOKYO, Monday, Jan. 12 -- Far East Air Forces headquarters intimated yesterday that United States Marine Corps jet pilots probably carried out the tragic mistaken bombing of an Allied artillery position behind the Korean war front last Thursday.
The Maritime Administration has offered for sale fourteen war-damaged ships now lying in foreign areas, ten of which had been offered before.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11 -- The prolonged liquidating period in grains appeared to be tapering off last week, with more two-sided price swings and in some cases sharp recoveries from extreme lows, which generally set new seasonal levels.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (UP) -The American Federation of Labor disclosed today what it called a "Communist plot" by the independent Public Workers Union to enlist the support of George Meany, president of the federation, in its battle with Congress.

In 1933, when the Democrats entered upon their long rule, they faced a national crisis of the first order. When the Republicans come into office next week, after five terms and twenty years in the wilderness, the urgent crisis they have to meet is in the international field.

One of the important controversies relating to the Point Four program in the United States is over its administrative structure. Since the program succeeds or fails mainly according to the degree of cooperation among the participating government, which is often affected by political relations among them, the program's administration was placed within the State Department.

ADDIS ABABA -- When American technicians surveyed Lake Tana to determine its resources for irrigation and power development, they found the Ethiopian inhabitants of the area non-cooperative when they were not obstructive.

AMMAN -- Construction on the Bunger Dam is in progress, along with range water spreading construction, and irrigation and water conservation projects. They mark the beginning bf work, with the help of Point Four funds, on the Yarmuk River-Jordan Valley irrigation project, a key to solving the landlessness of 500,000 refugee Arab farmers from Palestine.

ALBANY, Jan. 11 -- Serious consideration is being given by the State Temporary Commission on Rents and Rental Conditions to the easing of residential rent controls when the law is renewed this year. Unless extended, state rent controls would expire at the end of next June.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 11 -- While the individual screening of seamen, scientists and other international visitors pursues its laborious course under the McCarran Act, the United States borders are being breached virtually at will by aliens in mounting numbers of as many as 5,000 a day.

Although man today can see objects "farther and nearer, faster and slower than any generation has seen them before," his discernment of the meaning of his discoveries is "defective." Bishop Frederick B. Newell of the New York Methodist Area, asserted in a guest sermon yesterday morning at Christ Church (Methodist), Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.
The New York Chapter, Red Cross, appealed yesterday for new or reactivated volunteers to help carry on the winter work of the chapter.

Confidence in stability of the public's buying power, brightening the outlook for sales gains during the first half of this year, was expressed by a majority of merchants in a nation-wide survey conducted by the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

JAKARTA -- United States' aid operates "under wraps" here, ever since acceptance of Mutual Security aid caused a Cabinet crisis in this neutralist country. But Point Four help has made a significant, though not substantial, contribution to the country's economy, even though Indonesians never hear about it and the only indirect result has been to stir up anti-American feeling in the national press.
Cotton prices in the domestic futures market moved downward last week. The sharpest declines were in the near-by deliveries.
In the hope of salvaging part of its $10,000,000 investment, the Port of New York Authority has leased its huge motor truck terminal on the lower West Side to five over-the-road truckers.

Taft School in Watertown, Conn., will serve 108 steaks next Wednesday night, but only one-third of the student body will be at the table. Sound like discrimination? It is, in a way, because only members of the Gamma Club are eligible.
Michael J. Quill's Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., started whipping up sentiment yesterday for a subway slowdown to intensify the impact of the eleven-day-old bus strike.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 11 (AP) -- Lloyd Mangrum, with thousands watching, calmly stroked in a 30-foot putt on the final green today to win the professional honors of the Bing Crosby golf tournament with a 54-hole record-breaking total of 204.

Bretton Woods, once known to most people merely as a geographical point on the map of New England, is today chiefly a figure of speech. It has become a synonym for a peculiarly unhappy, unnecessary and unfruitful conjunction at that geographical point, back in 1944, of two attitudes of mind, neither of which stands at the moment very high in public esteem.
ROME, Jan. 11 -- Pope Pius XII will add twenty-four new Cardinals to the Sacred College at a secret consistory tomorrow morning.
Frank Sedgman came back from one of the worst lickings of his tennis career to turn the tables on Jack Kramer at Madison Square Garden yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 11 -- The Screen Extras Guild, A. F. L., tonight announced that contract negotiations with the Alliance of Television Film Producers were deadlocked. Richard H. Gordon, president of the union, stated that a board of directors meeting has been called for Wednesday night "To consider strike action."

The final quarter of 1952 brought a remarkable spurt in banking activities and climaxed a singularly favorable year for banks here, according to condition statements of the institutions for Dec. 31, just published. New high records in loans, deposits and resources for many years were shown.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) -Senator Styles Bridges, Republican of New Hampshire, said today that President Truman's budget was "so confused it will have to be almost entirely rewriten" by the new Administration.

As customary, the works of two composers were heard at the Saturday evening Composers Forum concert at the McMillin Theatre. Edward Diemente was represented by a String Trio, played by members of the Hartt Quartet, and a "Jubilee" for two pianos, played by Raymond Hanson and Leonard Seeber.

A rank and file revolt against leadership of the International Longshoremen's Association, A.F.L., and abolition of public loaders and the shape-up system of employment were recommended here yesterday by the Rev. John M. Corridan, associate director of the Xavier School of Industrial Relations.

Belying their lowly standing in the National Hockey League race, the New York Rangers skated their way to a smashing triumph over the Canadiens of Montreal last night. While a crowd of 12,506 joyfully witnessed the proceedings, the Broadway Blues managed to get seven goals for themselves and at the same time prevented the Flying Frenchmen from getting even one shot into the local cage.

A new work by Anthony T. Bouscaren, Professor of Political Science at the University of San Francisco, will be issued this spring by Public Affairs Press of Washington, entitled "Imperial Communism." It is a country-by-country report on the workings of Russian policies and agents.
The Federal Bureau of Investigation announced yesterday the arrest of two men who allegedly had got off on the wrong foot in the shoe business.

Point Four has come of age. The survey of thirty-five countries which THE NEW YORK TIMES publishes today is surely ample proof of that. The program is doing enough good in enough underdeveloped nations to justify its conception and its continuance.

A new auditing program, designed especially for the use of smaller banks, and intended as a safeguard against embezzlements, will be outlined at the twenty-fifth annual mid-winter meeting of the New York State Bankers Association next Monday.

ZURICH, Jan. 11 -- On advices from Washington that West Germany would not be on the list of countries "short of dollars" to be submitted to Congress for foreign aid in 1953-54, competent authorities in Switzerland declared that, if effectual measures were taken forthwith to give private initiative in Germany wide scope than heretofore to earn dollars essential for keeping the German balance of payments squared, all Europe would benefit immensely.

The city Department of Air Pollution Control has served the New York Central Railroad with a summons, charging a smoke nuisance in the vicinity of the Putnam division terminal, Sedgewick Avenue and 165th Street, the Bronx, Dr. Leonard Greenburg, commissioner of the city department, said yesterday.

J. Edgar Hoover, head of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, has rejected an offer by James D. Norris, president of the International Boxing Club, to accept a position as chairman of the I. B. C. board of directors, under a ten-year contract at an annual salary of $100,000.

Ch. Tai Chuo Son of Dah Wong, a biscuit-colored dog owned by the Misses Sara F. Hodges and Aimee Perret of Wilton, Conn., became best of breed in the Pekingese Club of America specialty at the Hotel Belvedere yesterday.

CAIRO, Jan. 11 -- The British Ambassador, Sir Ralph Stevenson, saw Foreign Minister Mahmoud Fawzi today to request early resumption of talks with the Premier, Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib, on the future of the Sudan.

Virginia MacWatters, who sang Adele in more than 500 performances of Strauss' "Fledermaus" when it was presented ten years ago by the New Opera Company, stepped into the role at the Metropolitan Opera House on Saturday night.
The days are getting longer; winter is on the wane. A new print dress will hold the promise of spring. With this in mind, Patterns of The Times presents three examples today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson has made a personal appeal to Prime Minister Winston Churchill of Britain to provide more leadership in Western Europe and the...
Irmgard Seefried, Viennese soprano who made her New York debut last season, gave her second local recital Saturday night at Hunter College Auditorium.

Point Four is the United States program of sharing technical skills, knowledge and investment capital with the peoples of underdeveloped areas. It represents an acceleration and expansion of work carried on for many years by private and public agencies.

PARIS, Jan. 11 -- Twenty-two men -- eight Germans and fourteen Alsatian Frenchmen -- will go on trial tomorrow before a French military tribunal at Bordeaux, charged with participation in the blackest crime of Nazi occupation of France -- the massacre of the population of Oradour-sur-Glane.

A public hearing on the proposed rezoning district maps for Manhattan in the city-wide rezoning plan drafted by Ballard, Harrison Allen, consultants, will be held today at 10 A. M. by the City Planning Commission at City Hall.
One of the best known freshwater yachting families of the region that includes Lake Ontario, Lake Erie and the Niagara River, yesterday became the "All-American Boating Family of 1952."

Motetto Da Requiem, a noble and profound work by Alessandro Scarlatti, was the high point of yesterday's concert of the New Friends of Music at Town Hall. And it was nobly sung by William Warfield, the American baritone, who is here on a four-month leave of absence from the London company of "Porgy and Bess."

BONN, Germany, Jan. 12 -- The Government of Federal Germany stands firmly behind the European army treaty and will press for its early ratification by the Bundestag. Chancellor Konrad Adenauer declared today.
A growth of anti-Americanism and neutralism, and a decrease in the sense of military urgency are symptomatic of some of the current troubles faced by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Some hitch may develop to the present "gentlemen's agreement" among the Senate majority and minority leaders whereby this week the path is to be cleared to confirmation of the members of President-elect Eisenhower's Cabinet a few hours after the General is sworn in at noon on Jan. 20.

Ray Bolger, who approached his first full-hour television appearance last month with the thought that it might be his last, has decided to do more programs. He may star in a special Easter program and is considering a regular program series for next fall.

HONG KONG, Jan. 12 -- Of all the American missionaries who have rounded out their long careers in China by going to jail few seem to have attained the prison distinction conferred by the Chinese Communists on 55-year-old Father Joseph Peter McGinn, a Maryknoll priest from Philadelphia.

Manhattan College, which has one of its best teams in Jasper basketball history, will oppose powerful La Salle, 1952 Invitation Tournament champion, in the feature game of the collegiate doubleheader tonight at Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- A memorial bust of Stephen Foster, composer of American folk songs, was unveiled at the Library of Congress tonight. Mrs. Evelyn Foster Morneweck, of Detroit, a niece of the composer, unveiled the statue by Walter Hancock. John Tasker Howard, biographer, gave the principal address.

An era of new prosperity in the pleasure boat building industry was prophesied on all sides yesterday as the National Motor Boat Show resumed in Grand Central Palace. As industry goes, so goes the sport. When yacht yards, motor and accessory manufacturers have difficulty obtaining steel, aluminum, copper and brass, boats cannot be delivered for recreational use.

Underwood Corporation has entered the punched card accounting field by agreeing to act as sole United States distributor for the products of Powers-Samas Accounting counting Machines, Ltd., of London, P. b. Wagoner, chairman of Underwood, announced yesterday.

Controversy over the issue of clemency for Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, who have appealed to President Truman for commutation of their death sentences as spies who betrayed atomic secrets, intensified yesterday. Their execution, originally scheduled for yesterday, has been postponed pending the President's action on the appeal.

ALBANY, Jan. 12 -- William H. MacKenzie Republican of Allegany, was appointed chairman of the Assembly Ways and Means Commitee tonight by Speaker Oswald D. Heck. He succeeds D. Mallory Stephens of Brewster, who resigned from the Legislature last year.

The events to be used by the National Ski Association of America in picking its first representative team to go overseas for the Federation Internationale de Ski (F. I. S.) or world championship games in Sweden next year were disclosed yesterday by Johnny Clair, chairman of the international competitive committee of the N. S. A.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 12 -- Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard University, was noncommittal today about the details of his new assignment as United States High Commissioner for Germany. He said, however, that he expected to leave for Germany before the end of the month.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 12 -- American Federation of Labor motion picture union leaders will hold a formal meeting Thursday with the Association of Motion Picture Producers to air grievances over the increasing amount of film-making being done abroad by the major studios.

Four dwellings in Katonah, N.Y., have been purchased by new owners who plan to remodel the properties for their own occupancy. The sales included a 200-year-old house on Cherry Street which was purchased by Arthur Bernhard from Mrs. Frank P. Kelley in a transaction negotiated by the North Westchester Realty Company.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 12 -- The six-day tieup of dry-cargo handling facilities in the Port of Philadelphia ended tonight when 450 striking waterfront railroad carloaders accepted a pay increase of 27 cents an hour.
DUNEDIN, Fla., Jan. 12 (AP) -- Jock Hutchison of Chicago and Tom Mahan, Beverly, Mass., won the national senior professionals tournament today with a 4-under-par 68.

Nearly $30 million of Rockefeller money has been spent to restore or reconstruct colonial Williamsburg and about $15 million more will be needed during the next ten years to complete the work. This is the gist of the first review and financial statement to be made public by the trustees to whom the enterprise was assigned.
The one-bowl cake (so called because all the ingredients were mixed in one vessel) that is so much in the culinary spotlight today is in reality a revival of an old quick trick in home baking.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Jan. 12 -- William G. Stratton, 38 years old, took office as Governor of Illinois at noon here today, succeeding Adlai E. Stevenson.

The New York Music Critics Circle yesterday named Alexei Haieff's Piano Concerto, Francis Poulenc's "Stabat Mater" and Paul Hindemith's Septet as the best musical compositions of 1952 in the respective categories of symphonic, choral and chamber music.
Color, stained into the wood, provides a major design interest in a new group of furniture designed a precise lines by the Raymond Loewy Associates and now on view at Gimbels.

ALBANY, Jan. 12 -- The Senate unanimously approved tonight a Dewey Administration bill reducing the registration fees paid by farm trucks from 50 to 35 cents for each hundred pounds of maximum loaded weight. There was no debate on the measure.

Pettis Perry, 56-year-old head of the Communist party's Negro commission, charged yesterday that he and twelve other secondary Communist leaders had been brought to trial because they had opposed war and fought for peace, racial equality and economic benefits for the "working class."

ALBANY, Jan. 12 -- Nine bills to give New York City $62,700,000 more in financial assistance from the state in accordance with the program announced last week by Mayor Impellitteri were ready for submission to the Legislature tonight but formal introduction was delayed to give Democratic members more time to study them.
ROME, Jan. 12 (AP) -- The official English translation of the Pope's speech at today's secret consistory, as released by the Vatican:
I always turn with pleasurable anticipation to your Topics of The Times column for comfort against the many disturbing items that make up the news in our present turbulent era.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Jan. 12 -- State highway construction approaching $100,000,000 in cost will be started in Westchester this year, County Executive Herbert C. Gerlach told the Board of Supervisors this afternoon in an annual 10,000-word review of county progress.

How trends in the child-development field have affected parents was discussed last night by Dr. Hilde Bruch, psychoanalyst and pediatrician, at a parent-teacher meeting at the Emerson School, 12 East Ninety-sixth Street.

CHICAGO, Jan. 12 -- Letters introduced to back a Government charge that E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., threw General Motors Corporation's weight around in making sales to other concerns were read into the record of the du Pont anti-trust trial today in Federal District Court here.

LONDON, Jan. 12 -- Sudanese self-government, a pivotal issue in the Near East, will be "delayed" by the "eleventh hour" agreement negotiated among four Sudanese political parties and Egypt, Foreign Office sources indicated here tonight.

MOSCOW, Jan. 12 -- Pravda, the Communist party newspaper, demanded today that Soviet economists "overcome fully and to the end" alien and mistaken "subjectivist distortions "connected with former Politburo member Nikolai Voznesensky.

A series of mishaps, including a short circuit on the Broadway-Seventh Avenue subway at the start of last night's homebound rush, caused the worst disruption of transit service since the bus strike began on New Year's Day.

Commodity prices were lower yesterday in trading on the New York exchanges. Sugar volume was greater than it has been for several months and the No. 1 rubber contract showed more activity than any time since No. 14. Sugar, rubber, cocoa, hides, lead, tin, zinc, cottonseed oil and soybean oil closed lower. Coffee, potatoes and wool were higher.

Three new films open today. At the Bijou Theatre, the attraction is "The Little World of Don Camillo," a Franco-Italian comedy, starring Fernandel and Gino Cervi. Julien Duvivier directed and collaborated with Rene Barjavel on the adaptation of the Giovanni Guareschi novel.

MOSCOW, Jam 12 -- Sven Loftman, vice president of the International Skating Union and head of the speed-skating section, said tonight that he was recommending international recognition of a series of sensational new speed-skating records established by Soviet stars.
LONDON, Jan. 12 -- The stock markets were quietly firm here today with interest centered on Anglo-Iranian Oil Company's new debentures.

Growth of margarine made from vegetable oils has been such in the last few years that its per capita consumption in the United States is now estimated at 7.7 pounds a year. Consumption of butter was only about 7.5 pounds per capita last year.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP) -- The United States and Indonesia concluded today a new aid agreement that omits free military assistance.
ALBANY, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Governor Dewey tonight reappointed his former secretary, Paul E. Lockwood of New York, to a new ten-year term on the Public Service Commission.

KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Jan. 12 -- Maj. Saleh Salem, a member of the Egyptian military high committee and Premier Naguib's special representative to the Sudan, has at this moment succeeded in splitting the Sudan wide open into those tormented by suspicion of Egypt and those dominated by suspicion of Britain.

MY favorite American diplomat as of this moment is Charles W. Thayer, a career servant of the State Department who seems to regard his job as a strenuous joke. It is the comedy and adventure of being a diplomat in an era of permanent international crisis that appeals to Mr. Thayer, and it is about his comic misadventures that he has largely written in his two volumes of gay and uninhibited autobiography.

While unaccustomed sun shone over the metropolitan area yesterday for the first time in five days, more than 6,000 repair men struggled to restore normal power and telephone service in the suburban areas. First estimates were that the week-end ice storm would cost utilities alone in metropolitan New York and New Jersey more than $1,000,000, with Connecticut losses up in the hundreds of thousands.

SYRACUSE, Jan. 12 -- Executives of forty-five New York State daily newspapers were divided today as to whether TV was having an adverse effect on their business. The question came up for discussion at the annual meeting of the New York State Associated Dailies, an organization composed of newspapers published in the state's smaller cities.

The year-long battle by Seatrain Lines to obtain permanent authority from the Interstate Commerce Commission for operation of the coastwise shipping service between the parts of New York and Savannah, Ga., was renewed yesterday.

Edgar Dame of Revere, Mass., representing the Northeastern Skating Association, staved off a late threat by Mario Trafeli Jr. of the Michigan Skating Association to capture the two-mile invitation race of champions at the twenty-ninth annual Silver Skates championships last night.

We hope Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, is right when he tells his union members that "we have no confusion or stupidity in our ranks." Because it would certainly be an act of confusion and stupidity seriously damaging to the union cause if there were to be a slowdown or sympathy strike on the city-owned transit system.

MINEOLA, L. I., Jan. 12 -- Appointment of a new Democratic commissioner of Nassau County's bi-partisan Board of Elections, the party's sole patronage job in the county, was stymied today by the refusal of the Board of Supervisors to accept Rene A. Carreau's certification of himself for the $12,500 post. He is the Nassau Democratic chairman.

The French liner Liberte, whose crew was the first processed under the stringent provisions of the new McCarran - Walter Immigration Law on Dec. 24 with the result that shore leave was denied to 271 seamen, arrived here again yesterday and many of the men were detained aboard.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The Military Sea Transport Service said today that the failure of tramp freighter operators to offer ships for charter was hampering its movement of military cargoes to overseas points and especially to Korea.

An American edition of "Out of Red China," a report on what is happening in China today, will be issued Feb. 5 by Duell, Sloan Pearce-Little, Brown. The author is Liu Shaw-tong, a former minor functionary in Red China's Propaganda Ministry, who is now on Formosa.

More than 200 students of the New York School of Printing, as well as leaders of the printing industry, attended ceremonies at City Hall yesterday in commemoration of the 247th anniversary of the birth of Benjamin Franklin.

KRASIC, Yugoslavia, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Aloysius Cardinal Stepinac said tonight the Roman Catholic Church "is going to remain firm" and will never yield to dictation from Premier Marshal Tito's Communist Government.

CAIRO, Jan. 12 -- British Ambassador Sir Ralph Stevenson saw Foreign Minister Mahmoud Fawzi today for further talks on the Sudan and submitted the draft of a proposed agreement between the two Governments. Premier Naguib was not present at the meeting although he had been expected.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Jan. 13 (AP) -United Nations Command communique 1,493, for the twenty-four hours ended at 6 A. M. Tuesday, Korean time:

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Vic Seixas of Philadelphia and Ham Richardson of Baton Rouge, La., members of the United States Davis Cup team, won their quarter-final match in the Australian double tennis championships today.

Faced with rising student enrollments, the necessity of expanding vital services and the problem of educating the sizable number of recent Puerto Rican arrivals, the city's public schools will need the record sum of $279,022,785 for the next fiscal year, the Board of Education's Committee on Finance and Budget announced yesterday.

A dispatch to this newspaper yesterday reminded us that Congress has not yet seen fit to cope with the problems raised by the large number of "wetback" Mexican laborers who swim or wade the Rio Grande seeking work. The influx of these illegal immigrants is so great that federal officials have despaired of prosecuting any but a handful of repeaters.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 12 -- Two thousand men and women marched through downtown Tel Aviv this evening chanting "Bread, work and peace." The demonstration was believed to be the start of a Communist - sponsored campaign against the new Government of Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion.

The New York Regional Red Cross blood program will present a certificate of merit today to American Airlines for its "outstanding leadership" in contributing blood to the armed forces and civilians. The presentation will be made at La Guardia Airport at 2 P. M.
ATHENS, Jan. 12 -- Alcide De Gasperi, Premier of Italy, left for Rome today after a four-day visit to Greece, the country Italy fought and occupied during World War II.

The granting of an "improvement factor" or increased efficiency wage rise to 1,250,000 railroad employes at this time would have an upsetting effect on the nation's economy, the head of one of the country's carrier groups, declared yesterday.

GENEVA, Jan. 12 -- The Permanent Central Opium Board said today that about 500 tons of opium -- nearly half of one year's legal consumption for the entire world -- was offered for sale in 1951 and presumably sold to illegal traders by Communist China.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Baltimore's new team in the National Football League today got a pair of old coaching hands, Keith Molesworth and Ray Richards.
