Exactly twenty-five years from the night of Jan. 12, 1928, when he made his American debut with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, playing the Tchaikovsky piano concerto, Vladimir Horowitz played the same concerto, with the same orchestra, again in Carnegie Hall, and donated the proceeds of the concert -- $21,000 -- to the Philharmonic-Symphony Pension Fund.

The old Broadway Arena at 930944 Halsey Street, near Broadway, in Brooklyn has been sold by the Bank of New York, as trustee, to a client of Saul C. Kaufman, attorney. Elliott .T. Finkelstein was the broker. The building contains 29,000 square feet of space and there is an adjoining parking lot of 11,000 square feet.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower met yesterday with most of the top leaders of the Republican Administration that will take office in Washington next Tuesday. He also announced the selection of Dr. James Bryant Conant, president of Harvard University, for the vital "cold war" post of United States High Commissioner for Germany.

JACK KRAMER had just finished humiliating Frank Sedgman in Madison Square Garden on Saturday and the tennis aficionados were raving about the sheer magnificence of his performance. They also cast a few slur in the direction of the general caliber of amateur tennis as exemplified by Sedgman and Ken McGregor, the Australians who recently turned professional.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- New rules of the Interstate Commerce Commission controlling interchange of trucking equipment were upheld by the Supreme Court today, although two of the nine justices said the result would be "ruinous" to many small truckers.

A television version of a play that was produced on Broadway last season by Howard Lindsay and Russel Crouse was canceled at the last moment yesterday because of a controversy over how to handle the theme.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The five major American oil companies engaged in overseas production and distribution were in open defiance of the Federal Government tonight after their spokesman had told Attorney General James P. McGranery to his face that he was trying to "blackmail" them into line.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 12 -- The latest set of negotiations for settlement of the oil dispute between Britain and Iran, which has been going on nearly two years, appeared tonight to be approaching a climax. Some informed observers thought the climax might come in a matter of days, but were unable to predict whether it would result in an agreement.

The crucial Trieste issue, again in the news, should not be allowed to linger on unsolved for many more years. It not only causes Italo-Yugoslav relations to deteriorate from day to day, but it also forms the main stumbling block on the road to the Austrian independence treaty.

The Rules Committee of the House of Representatives is supposed to serve the useful purpose of sorting the wheat from the chaff of bills recommended by the various legislative committees and regulating the flow of important measures to the floor. In theory it is a traffic control station for the House; in practice it has often been turned into a Stop sign.

Ministers have been a "forgotten group" in the general trend toward salary increases in the last ten years, a committee of laymen said yesterday in submitting recommendations for ministers' salary increases to the Presbytery of New York.

The Associated Press survey on juvenile delinquency published Jan. 4 should provide abundant food for disturbing thought for social scientists throughout the country. It is the first tangible evidence brought to light proving not merely the utter inadequacy of our social work structure but, more important, it casts a pall of doubt as to whether the social work efforts of the past half century have been channeled in a direction that would ever prove fruitful.

A twelve-story apartment house to accommodate 255 families at 1493-1509 York Avenue, between Seventy-ninth and Eightieth Streets, was among plans filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings. Occupying the entire blockfront, the building will have stores on the street floor and there will be garage space for fifty-three automobiles.

Bob Baker, 216 3/4 pounds, Pittsburgh, won a split decision over Billy Gilliam, 207 1/4, Orange, N. J., in the ten-round feature bout at Eastern Parkway Arena, Brooklyn, last night. This was the third split decision involving the two heavy-weights in the past six weeks.

Approving a recommendation of Robert K. Christenberry, the State Athletic Commission-National Boxing Association coalition yesterday selected a ten-man field to contend in this country for the unclaimed world middleweight title, with the understanding the ultimate survivor would battle either Randy Turpin, England, or Charles Humez, France, in an international final to determine the titleholder.

STRASBOURG, France, Jan. 12 12 -- Jean Monnet, president of the High Authority of the European Coal and Steel Community, told that organization's Common Assembly today "the success of our experiment will be the test for future stages in the unification of Europe."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 12 -- Initial conferences were held here today between representatives of the United Nations and of the United States Civil Service Commission and the United States delegation to the United Nations to outline procedures in implementating President Truman's order of last Friday for screening all American employes of the world organization.

FREEPORT, L. I., Jan. 12 -- One man was dead and a physician and his bride of less than a month were wounded critically here today in what the police described as a double shooting and a suicide by the woman's rejected 58-year-old former suitor.

A rookie patrolman charged into a Brooklyn hardware store yesterday afternoon where three hold-up men were beating the owner, shot one thug and captured all three. He escaped being shot himself when a revolver in the hand of one thug jammed at point-blank range.

The appointment of Robert Ramspeck, former executive vice president of the Air Transport Association of America, as a vice president of Eastern Air Lines was announced yesterday. Capt. Edward V. Rickenbacker, president and general manager of the airline, described Mr. Ramspeck as one of the country's leading authorities on national and state civil aviation policies.

ROME, Jan. 12 -- With the magnificence and solemnity that are traditional in the Vatican Pope Pius XII held a secret consistory in the Apostolic Palace this morning and "created and published" twenty-four new cardinals belonging to thirteen countries. The Sacred College of Cardinals was thus restored to its plenum of seventy members, who are from twenty-seven countries. Among the new Princes of the Church is James Francis Cardinal McIntyre of Los Angeles.

Gifts to the NEW YORK TIMES Neediest Cases over the week-end and yesterday came from as far away as Caracas, Venezuela, and added $1,186.99 sent by eighty-one donors. This brought the total for the appeal thus far to $382,308.75 from 12,059 contributors.
Mayor Milton A. Gibbons of Tuckahoe was cleared yesterday by the Appellate Division, Second Department, of charges of conspiracy to violate the gambling laws.
TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 12 (AP) -- Gardnar Mulloy combined a smashing game with court cuteness to beat Bernard Bartzen for the Dixie tennis championship today. The score was 6--1, 3--6, 6--0, 6--1.

When Lavanburg Homes, a $650,000 "model tenement house" (as it was called in those days) was dedicated on Dec. 28, 1927, Mayor Walker declared to a crowd gathered on the lower East Side that a march was being started "that will lead into every street in the city where there remains even one unsanitary apartment."

If the steel industry's actual production this week hits the level estimated for it yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute, a new weekly output record will be established. The institute said the nation's steel mills are expected to make 2,240,000 net tons of raw steel this week, with operations averaging 99.4 per cent of the industry's theoretical capacity.

Former Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy, who was the subject of extensive testimony before recent hearings of the State Crime Commission, has resigned his post as an Official Referee of the Supreme Court.

LOGAN, Utah, Jan. 12 -- The wreckage of an Army-chartered C-46 transport, carrying a crew of three and thirty-seven Southern states G. I.'s on their way home from Korea, was found today high in the Wasatch Mountains, where it crashed Wednesday, killing all aboard.

PARIS, Jan. 12 -- The future of United States aid for Europe and the prospect of substituting freer trade for that aid head the list of topics that Rene Mayer, new French Premier wants to discuss with the heads of the new administration when he visits Washington, probably in February.

OTTAWA, Jan. 12 -- The story of the horses that managed to get on the Army payroll at Canada's Petawawa military camp has been declared to be a flight of imagination on the part of the investigating auditors.
BERLIN, Jan. 12 -- Industrial production in East Germany fell sharply last year in contrast to the post-war records achieved in the West German Republic.

The United States Court of Appeals reserved decision yesterday after hearing argument on a motion for a new trial for Alger Hiss, former assistant to the Assistant Secretary of State, who is serving a five-year term for perjury.

Besides considering Brandon De Wilde a capable young actor, there also is the chance that Robert Whitehead regards him as a good luck omen. For the third time Mr. Whitehead has cast him for a Broadway assignment. Master De Wilde will have the featured role of Ferike in "The Emperor's Clothes," the new play by George Tabori, which is a joint production of Mr. Whiteheao and the Playwrights Company.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Prominent Republicans -- Congressional leaders and incoming Cabinet members among them -- were taken aback today as they opened a new club across from the Capitol to find it attacked as "a sin, a shame and a blight on the country."

The larger-than-life marble figures that have looked out over the city's Madison Square area for more than half a century from the parapet of the Supreme Court's Appellate Division building are coming down to earth.

PARIS, Jan. 12 -- A French judge, presiding at the trial of former soldiers of the Nazi Elite Guard charged with the massacre of 642 citizens of a French village, delivered an appeal today for the maintenance of reason and basic human values in judging the defendants.

CHATTANOOGA, Jan. 12 -- The Provident Life and Accident Insurance Company has passed the billion-dollar mark in life insurance in force, Robert J. Maclellan, chairman of the board, announced today. He said the total stood at $1,003,897,319 on Dec. 31.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The Army announced today that the first Robert P. Patterson Memorial Award honoring the outstanding 1952 graduate of the Infantry Officer Candidate School at Fort Benning, Ga., had been won by Second Lieut. Herbert T. Perrin of Gambier, Ohio.

GENEVA, Jan. 12 -- A strong brief for making a long-range program for solving Western Europe's problem of excess population one of the cardinal points in the new Republican administration's foreign policy will be laid before John Foster Dulles, Secretary-of-State- designate, probably this week.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Jan. 13 -- The Soviet press announced today the arrest of nine "terrorist Jewish doctors" on charges they plotted to kill top Soviet leaders on instructions from Zionist organizations, and the United States and British intelligence services.

Reo Motors, Inc., announced yesterday the formation of a wholly owned subsidiary, Reo Truck Leasing, Inc., to engage in coast-to-coast truck leasing operations. Capitalized for about $1,000,000, the new subsidiary has offices in eleven cities and is ready to begin operations at once. Eldridge W. Reese will be vice president and general manager.

Please permit me to give my salute to the very effective job THE TIMES has been doing on revisions in the McCarran Acts of 1950 and 1952 covering immigration and naturalization. Your issue of Jan. 2 was outstanding, and I liked very much Luther A. Huston's special article.

Parents of teen-agers were urged last night by Dr. Robert H. Goldenson to find new and more constructive days of dealing with their youngsters' problems. He spoke at a parent-teacher meeting at the Bentley School's West Side Branch, 48 West Eighty - sixth Street. Dr. Goldenson is Professor of Psychology at Hunter College and also president of the Tri-State Council on Family Relations.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 12 -- Comment on the appointment of Dr. Conant was restrained in Government circles today although it was admitted that the appointment "brings Government anxiety to an end."
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were active yesterday and closing prices were 39 points lower to 15 points higher than on last Friday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (UP) -- The International Cotton Advisory Committee said today the outlook was not bright for any relief "in the near future" from currently low cotton prices.

A maximum state prison sentence of three to one-half to seven years and a $5,000 fine were imposed yesterday on George (Muscles) Futterman, who had been convicted of paying $100 to persuade a key witness to perjure himself in the Benedicto Macri trial last year.

The program that the Musicians Guild presented last night in Town Hall adhered to the high musical ideals of the organization. Brahms' Third Quartet, in B flat (Op. 67), is easily as good as the preceding pair by the composer, even if it is the least-played of the three (not that any is overplayed these days).

ACCORDING to the late report from Bimini, the small but magnetic island in the Bahamas, the water is blue, the sky is blue and so are the marlin, and the early angling visitors are finding them cooperative.
WASHINGTON, Jan: 12 (AP) -- The Western powers called on the Soviet Union today to join in a new four-power effort to reach agreement on a post-war settlement with Austria.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 12 (AP) -- Ted Atkinson rode four winners at Tropical Park today and the track had its seventh million-dollar day of the meeting.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 12 -- The first shipment of President Truman's voluminous Washington files arrived today for storage in the Jackson County courthouse, scene of the 1947 ballot theft.
SETAUKET, L. I., Jan. 12 -Fire destroyed today the large two-story frame clubhouse of St. George's Golf and Country Club, on Sheep Pasture Road here. The damage was estimated at $150,000.

The Corn Exchange Bank Trust Company's net earnings, after taxes, last year amounted to $3,534,072, compared with $3,511,432 in 1951, according to the bank's annual report to stockholders. The report, issued yesterday by Dunham B. Sherer, chairman, and John R. McWilliam, president, points out that on Jan. 31 Corn Exchange will have been engaged in the banking business in New York City for one hundred years.

Jose Greco and his company of Spanish dancers opened a two-week engagement at the Century Theatre last night, offering substantially the same program as in their last New York season but with numerous changes in personnel.

A ten - point program for strengthening the role of department stores in the distributive economy was outlined last night at the opening session of the annual convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association by Dr. Malcolm P. McNair of the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 12 -- Revisions in the theoretical structure of the Yugoslav Government were introduced to Parliament today and hailed as an example to international socialism.

CHICAGO, Jan. 12 -- Grain futures had a choppy price course today, with big traders working on the bull side at times, but selling out when the markets turned weak in spite of their support. On setbacks there was fairly active commission buying which steadied futures at times, although this buying did not seem to follow the rallies.

The Council Child Development Center, 227 East Fifty-ninth Street, was established six years ago "to help a small number of young children with their emotional problems before these youngsters become seriously ill; to uncover facts and develop techniques for helping thousands of additional children who are unable to come to the center."

TOKYO, Tuesday, Jan. 13 -- The Communists launched a heavy attack yesterday along the eastern front in Korea, but were thrown back after hand-to-hand fighting with newly organized South Korean troops.

" Dog eat dog" was the rule in the scrap iron industry in the winter of 1927-28. A number of references to this situation, now no longer true, were made yesterday as the Institute of Scrap Iron and Steel, Inc., marked its twenty-fifth anniversary at a convention at the Commodore Hotel and reviewed the advances that had been made.

The canning industry will stage a "tremendous comeback" in the food field this year because of two important developments in that field, it is predicted by John A. Warren, vice president in charge of the packaging division of the American Management Association.

The "midway" developing in Times Square as a result of the continued intrusion of amusement arcades and garish auction shops is earning New York the reputation of a "honky-tonk town," the City Planning Commission was told yesterday at a City Hall hearing.

CAMDEN, N. J., Jan. 12 -- Anthony Valentino, who is under five-year sentence for filing a false non-Communist affidavit, was reelected business agent of Local 80-A, United Packinghouse Workers, C. I. O., as "administration" candidates swept all offices and defeated a "rank-and-file" slate, it was announced today.

Women headed by Mrs. Robert S. Salant and including iIrs. Robert I-I. iuton and Mrs. James Stewart are assisting in plans for the annual White Elephant Party, to be held Friday night in the ballroom of the Pierre for the benefit of the Child Placing and Adoption Committee of the State Charities Aid Association.

Gardiners Island, the historic, 3,300-acre piece of land that lies between the forked, eastern tips of Long Island, has been willed to a niece and a nephew of Miss Sarah Diodati Gardiner, the fifteenth proprietor of the island, who died last Monday at the age of 90.

A few days ago the financial pages of this newspaper carried a story with implications lying far beyond such petty little interests as national and world economy. There had been set up, it said, an organization to be known as the Coffee Brewing Institute, whose business it shall be to conduct research into better coffee-making.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 12 -- During his visit to New York last week Prime Minister Churchill suggested to the Eisenhower Administration the establishment of a Southeast Asia defense pact against Communist aggression along the lines of the North Atlantic Treaty.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Jan. 13 -- Japan complained today against violations of her air by planes of a foreign power, presumably the Soviet Union, and warned that she and the United States would take steps to repel intruding aircraft.

The Superior Oil Company (California) reported yesterday for the quarter ended last November 30 a net profit of $3,791,569 after taxes and all charges, equal to $8.96 a share. The net, realized from gross operating income of $17,226,430, compares with $3,745,943 or $8.86 a share earned in the November quarter of the prior year when the gross was $16,817,545.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 12 -- Harvard University's basketball team defeated Boston College in overtime, 73 -- 70, at the Athletic Building tonight. The regulation time ran out with the Crimson's Bill Dennis missing a shot from midcourt with the score 66-a11.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Dividing four to four, the Supreme Court today ruled that Refugio Roman Martinez could be deported to his native Mexico because of his admission of Communist party membership twenty-one years ago.
PRINCETON, N. J., Jan, 12 (UP) -- Jack Kramer routed the Australian ace, Frank Sedgman, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 1, tonight to take a 3-2 lead in matches in their world professional tennis tour.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The Senate Internal Security subcommittee reported today that despite previous investigations and large-scale dismissals there still were in schools and colleges of the country "many hundreds" of teachers who were full-fledged members of the Communist party.

Shares on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday closed with losses of 1 to 2 points in the second dullest session of the new year. Turnover was only 1,500,000 shares, against 2,080,000 on last Friday.

Myron Heckler has sold the six-story apartment house at 303 East Seventy-first Street to a client of Ira Ginsberg, attorney. The property, assessed at $410,000, occupies a plot about 100 by 102 feet in the block between First and Second Avenues and contains fifty apartments.

HEADQUARTERS, Eighth Army, in Korea, Jan. 12 -- While the United States is providing most of the supplies used in the Korean war, a careful accounting is being made and each country participating in the United Nations effort here is being billed for whatever goods of war its troops are using.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 12 -- John J. McCloy, former United States High Commissioner for Germany, asserted tonight that a closer unity of the free peoples was the "fundamental element" in successfully meeting the Soviet challenge.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Jan. 12 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, and his close military and political advisers are showing signs of optimism over the way the Mayer administration seems to be grasping the European army problem.
CHICAGO, Jan. 12 (AP) -- A spokesman for the nation's appliance dealers said today the industry "should give serious consideration to the need for increasing list prices."

The striking bus workers are seeking a forty-hour week with no cut in the pay they used to get for working forty-four to forty-eight hours, with five to nine hours of guaranteed overtime. The old basic wage ranged from $1.66 to $1.73 1/2 an hour.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The Senate Democratic hierarchy assigned the party's most aggressive new members today to act as counterweights to Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, and to strengthen the internationalist wing of the Foreign Relations Committee.

In a setting of kleig lights, whirring sound tracks and extraneous influences customarily associated with events of such importance, Vice President Emil J. (Buzzie) Bavasi yesterday signed three Dodger players at an estimated cost of $100,000.

Among the many fine appointments President-elect Eisenhower has made the selection of Dr. James B. Conant as the new American High Commissioner in Germany is a particularly auspicious choice. At a time when the whole European treaty system and the progress toward European unification hang in the balance there is urgent need for a man of impressive stature in that strategic post.
ALBANY, Jan. 12 -- Strong opposition by Democratic legislators to any weakening of the state rent control laws was promised today by Richard H. Balch, Democratic State Chairman.

NEWARK, Jan. 12 -- A 12-year-old boy whose heart was exposed to shock with bare electric wires Saturday to relieve a constriction is "holding his own" today in Essex County Isolation Hospital at Belleville. Authorities said the boy was doing as well as could be expected and that the shock had served its purpose in saving his life.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 12 -- A Johns Hopkins University scientist who startled archaeologists in 1949 with a pronouncement that man in North America antedated the last Ice Age, which ended 10,000 to 20,000 years ago, has now upped the ante.

There is much to be said for the reported plan of John Foster Dulles to make visits in the near future to India, Pakistan and other Asian countries. Large areas in East Asia have had less official attention from the United States than has been their due, and Mr. Dulles is right in making an effort to correct this deficiency in a public and obvious manner.

MANIZALES, Colombia, Jan. 12 -- The Latin-American Congress on Rural Life Problems, which began formal business sessions today, was described by Roman Catholic spokesmen from both North and South America as the first serious effort of the Church to carry out on a continent-wide basis the papal pronouncements regarding the responsibility of religion for the social welfare of rural workers.

BOSTON, Jan. 12 (UP) -- Denis W. Delaney, the Federal Government's chief tax collector in Massachusetts for seven years, was indicted today on charges that he evaded $2,971 of his own income taxes during 1946 and 1949.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's diplomatic appointments are being watched here with more than usual interest and they are being subjected to unusually exacting tests, for the outlook is that the next few years will be a period of unusual diplomatic opportunity.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Jan. 12 (AP) -- College football's two-platoon system was ripped apart and sewed back together again today by the powerful Football Rules Committee of the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

ROSLYN, L. I., Jan. 12 -- A modern $4,000,000 plant erected by Mme. Helena Rubinstein in the Greenvale sector here, formerly a part of the estate of the late Clarence M. Mackay, was formally opened here this afternoon. More than 1,500 persons attended the opening reception and inspected the building which covers eight acres.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 12 -- Publication today of Sweden's budget in connection with the ceremonial opening of the Riksdag (Parliament) revealed that for the first time in several decades defense appropriations had topped the funds allotted for social welfare.
Industry was called upon yesterday by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, President-elect, to support the campaign of the National Fund for Medical Education for $10,000,000 for American medical schools.

At his best -- and he was often at his best last night -- William Kapell plays the piano like a master. He is one of the most honest pianists before the public. He has big equipment, he does not bluff, his musical aims are of the highest and he employs a good deal of intelligence.

TRENTON, Jan. 13 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll told the New Jersey State Legislature here today that all levels of government had "underestimated", the power of "syndicated crime," and called for making the six-month-old New Jersey Law Enforcement Council "a permanent continuing agency with adequate financial support."

Beer business figures in the billions for 1952 and prospects for 1953 were disclosed at yesterday's meeting of the seventy-seventh annual convention of the United States Brewers Foundation at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
Telephone service and electric power were restored yesterday to virtually all sections of the metropolitan area where they were disrupted by the sleet and snowstorms of the last week-end.

William W. Remington, former Commerce Department employe, went on trial before a Federal Court jury of eleven men and one woman for the second time yesterday on charges of lying about his alleged Communist party ties.

The first hint of a possible break in the bus strike came last night with an offer by two of the largest companies, the jointly owned New York City Omnibus Corporation and Fifth Avenue Coach Company, to submit the strike issues to arbitration.

The state law prohibiting other than mutual savings banks from using the words "saving" or "savings" in their advertising was upheld yesterday in a 3-to-1 decision by the Appellate Division in Brooklyn.
A new chief to run the scandal-ridden Bureau of Internal Revenue was selected yesterday by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower.

Trading was generally light yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges with prices moving in narrow ranges. The close was irregularly higher with cottonseed oil, soybean oil, cocoa, lead, rubber and sugar showing increases. Hides potatoes, coffee and wool ended lower and zinc closed irregular.
AT least it was one way of learning about hockey, although it ordinarily isn't found in the educational curriculum for presidents of major league hockey clubs.

A single intense color, with variations provided by tone and textures, is the basic color scheme used for each of seven settings just installed at Bloomingdale's. The vivid rooms, in which yellow, coral, red, blue, turquoise, emerald and moss green are the basic colors, offer a challenging and exciting contrast to the "black-and-white-with-a-touch-of-color" decorating that his recently proved so popular.

Young B. Smith, who exemplifies the traditions that have made the Columbia University Law School great, as an institution of learning and in the quality of its product, is being honored this week on his retirement as dean after a quarter century of service in that post.

There has been some theorizing to the effect that the present generation would cotton to the remake of "The Jazz Singer" as much as its forebears did to the original, which served to initiate the talking feature back in 1927.

CHICAGO, Jan. 13 -- Heavy selling orders in grains and soybeans forced prices to new low levels in the initial trading today, but there was enough buying on resting orders to cushion this drive, and a later one around midday when there was another wave of liquidation and local sales.
A preview of the automotive exhibition of the Chrysler Corporation that is to open tomorrow was given yesterday at the Chrysler International Automobile Salon, 405 Lexington Avenue.

The average rate of interest charged by large New York City banks to business concerns on short-term loans (those due on demand or in one year or less) increased 0.04 to 3.25 per cent in the first half of December from the previous year's high of 3.21 per cent charged in the first half of September.
John David Provoo, former Army sergeant on trial in Federal Court for treason, was described yesterday by a defense witness as having been a "medical problem" while a prisoners of the Japanese.
Allen Evarts Foster, a lawyer, collector of engravings and long a leader in work for underprivileged children, has been elected president of the Muncipal Art Commission.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- President Truman submitted to Congress today the report of his Commission on Immigration and Naturalization with a request for "earnest and prompt consideration" of the changes it recommended in the Immigration and Nationality Act of 1952.

James D. Norris, president of the International Boxing Club, told Felix Bocchicchio yesterday that Jersey Joe Walcott must face Rocky Marciano, the heavyweight champion, in Chicago on April 10 if the former heavyweight ruler desired an indoor chance at the crown.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 13 -- An Air Force sergeant who arrived here last night on a furlough from his post at Anchorage, Alaska, will be responsible for the remarriage of his parents. He already won credit for their reunion after eighteen years of divorce.
ALBANY, Jan. 13 (UP) -- The State Commerce Department today reported the following winter sports conditions at New York resorts:

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Jan. 13 (AP) -- The powerful Football Rules Committee of the National Collegiate A. A. gave the two-platoon system another thorough examination today, then put off the final decision on it until tomorrow.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 13 -- The Government acknowledged today that United States aid was an important factor in Indonesia's reconstruction.

The metal industries were urged to go slow in seeking permits for export of scrap, a vital raw material in the making of steel, by Ralph E. Ablon, president of the Institute of Scrap Iron and Steel, Inc.

SEGAMAT, Malaya, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Smoked elephant's trunk, monkey stew, fried snake and bamboo-shoot soup -- that is the kind of diet forcing Communist guerrillas to rebel against their Red leaders and surrender in this section of northern Johore.

CHICAGO, Jan. 13 -- The National Appliance and Radio-Television Dealers Association at the closing session of its two-day conference at the Conrad Hilton Hotel here has agreed to place the encouragement of educational television facilities high on its list of membership activity during the next year.

IN addition to the usual anti-firearms legislation that is certain to make its annual appearance in the legislative hopper at Albany, the sportsmen quite apparently face another battle on the proposed Panther Mountain Dam.

The shirt industry established a record last year with an estimated 18,126,825 dozen production. The figure compares with 16,614,000 dozen in 1950, the previous record year, Sidney Rosenblum, president of the National Association of Shirt, Pajama and Sportswear Manufacturers, said last night at the annual meeting at the Astor Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Farmers have a record number of cattle on heavy feed for the slaughter market, the Department of Agriculture reported today.
A sharp controversy on night openings of stores marked the convention yesterday of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the Statler Hotel.

During the past year more than 92,123 New York City boys benefited from Scouting through membership in 1,910 Boy Scout, Cub Scout and Explorer units under the sponsorship of churches, synagogues, schools, civic groups, veterans' associations and other organizations. In all, 28,812 volunteer adult leaders provided guidance for the Scouts.

CHICAGO, Jan. 13 -- Cost of the development of ethyl gasoline in terms of insanity and death among the men who carried on early production of tetraethyl lead was recalled today at the du Pont antitrust trial before Federal District Judge Walter J. LaBuy.
Detroit's circuit-leading Red Wings, who are seeking a fifth straight National Hockey League title, will face New York's revivified Rangers at Madison Square Garden tonight.

ROME, Jan. 13 -- The Vatican newspaper L'Osservatore Romano published today important diplomatic documents accusing Yugoslavia of being engaged in an intense campaign to eradicate all religious thoughts and sentiments from the minds and consciences of her citizens.

A perjury indictment was returned yesterday against John E. Gleason Jr., a former city employe who was a campaign manager for Mayor Impellitteri, by a New York County grand jury seeking to determine who succeeded James J. Moran as director of a lucrative fuel oil shakedown racket in the Fire Department.

Six Serenades, a beautiful work for String Quartet, by Normand Lockwood, stood head and shoulders above the other compositions presented last night at the second concert in the series that the composers and instrumentalists from the Bennington Composers Conference are presenting at the Lexington Avenue Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 13 (UP) -- Suleiman, a former stakes winner, rescued the form players at Tropical Park today by winning the Varsity Purse after six straight favorites were beaten on the nine-race program.
LONDON, Jan. 13 -- Price movements were narrow and aimless in stock markets here today. Early dullness was partly dispelled in late trading, but closing lists showed no definitive trend.

The financial fairy tale phase of one of post-war Canada's most spectacular industrial ventures -- the 1,150-mile oil pipeline of the Interprovincial Pipe Line Company linking the oil-rich Alberta fields with Superior, Wis. -- is slated to end today.

RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 12 -- A resolution providing for the permanent organization of Asian Socialist parties was formally adopted unanimously here today by the plenary session of the Conference of Asian Socialists.

The city's multi-million-dollar transit deficit cannot be considered in a vacuum. Today's lesson teaching this truth arrives in the new expense budget submitted to the Board of Education. Based on the recommendations of Superintendent Jansen, this budget asks $28,853,322 more than the city's Board of Estimate has provided in the current fiscal year.

Plans have been advanced at luncheon meetings recently in the Persian Room of the Plaza for the art show of Memorial Cancer Center patients to be held from Jan. 20 to Jan. 25 at the Knoedler Galleries, 14 East Fifty-seventh Street.

The days are getting longer now, and naturally that is all to the good. To be sure, the best way at present to learn of the lengthening days is to read about them on the pages of the calendar, for outwardly there are as yet few signs.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Jan. 13 -- The National Cotton Council's fifteenth annual study of industry-wide programs in cotton research, promotion and marketing, foreign trade and public relations will be held in Dallas, Tex., on Jan 26 and 27, it was announced today.

DETROIT, Jan. 13 -- The new Congress can hasten the harnessing of atomic energy for useful work by giving private industry a stake in its development, a Michigan industrialist told the Society of Engineers today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The United States gave full support to day to the Japanese Government's warning against future violations of its territory by "unauthorized foreign aircraft."
DUNEDIN, Fla., Jan. 13 (AP) -- Joe Turnesa, one of the topnotch players of almost thirty years ago, demonstrated today he was still a good tournament golfer.

WASHINGTON, Jan 13 -- President Truman began his final week in office today by tackling a sizable mound of documents requiring action or his signature. He also accepted several resignations and sent Congress a supplemental appropriations request for $ 2,334,667,550 that had been made necessary by acts of Congress or by new requirements.

ALBANY, Jan. 13 -- Lieut. Gov. Frank C. Moore and State Controller J. Raymond McGovern, Governor Dewey's chief advisers on New York City's financial problems, will need at least another week to complete their analysis of Mayor Impellitteri's program for raising $218,700,000 more in revenue to meet the city's estimated needs.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 13 -- A joint session of Parliament voted today a revision of the Constitution, an enabling act to permit rule without Parliament until next spring and an electoral law by which Premier Marshal Tito is expected tomorrow to be named President of the Yugoslav Republic.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 13 -- Rapid expansion in the scope and volume of assistance given by the United Nations to the Far East was registered during 1952 as compared with 1951 but continuation of the tempo reached is imperiled by the precarious situation reported during December to the Economic and Social Council by David Owen, Chairman of the Technical Assistance Board.

The impecunious students of the United States Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point, L. I., have managed to cadge a ride aboard a Navy vessel to Washington so they can march, 700 strong, in the Inauguration Day parade next Tuesday.
Nations of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization now have about 2,400,000 men in uniform in Europe from northern Norway to the Caucasus.

Mozart's "Cosi fan tutte," revived last season in a production that had taste and charm, returned to the Metropolitan Opera repertoire last night. It is still a jewel of an opera, radiant with Mozart's genius, and this presentation staged by Alfred Lunt still iluminates its eighteenth-century spirit and at the same time gives it fresh values for our day.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Following is the vote by which the Senate today denied to Senator Wayne Morse, Independent of Oregon, a seat on its Armed Services Committee by approving a leadership-chosen slate of fourteen other members after Senator Leverett Saltonstall, Republican of Massachusetts, was unanimously chosen as chairman:

LONDON, Jan. 13 -- A chemical called lethidrone has been synthesized by the chemists of the Well-come Foundation here as a long sought antidote for the narcotic effects of morphine, pethidine and other related drugs.

An investment banking syndicate, headed by First Boston Corporation and Collin, Norton Co., will place on the market today an issue of 600,000 new shares of common stock of the Toledo Edison Company at $12.25 a share.

The snift of interest yesterday on the stock market to an array of issues not affected by the previous day's decline enabled the list to show fairly good recuperative powers. The rise just about canceled out much of the loss sustained on Monday and allowed the price structure to return to a basis closer to the general position.

The Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation and its subsidiaries in the fiscal year ended last Oct. 31 achieved the second highest sales in its history, but earnings declined from the previous year, Benjamin Abrams, president, reported yesterday in the annual statement to stockholders.

PARIS, Wednesday, Jan. 14 -- Edouard Herriot, 80-year-old veteran of two French Republics, was re-elected early this morning as Speaker of the National Assembly following almost eleven hours of political wrangling that made three ballots necessary before the issue was decided.

LONDON, Jan. 13 -- War has been declared between the newspapers of Lord Beaverbrook and United States motion-picture companies here over the caustic criticism of Hollywood movies. The film companies have applied their own sanction -- cancellation of their advertising.

The Los Angeles Department of Water and Power sold yesterday $5,000,000 of water works revenue bonds due from 1954 to 1993 to a banking syndicate headed by Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., at an interest cost of about 2.7474 per cent.

Appointments made or pending suggest that the incoming Administration contemplates a pretty thorough revamping of our most important diplomatic missions abroad. This is the usual procedure when a new Executive takes over. Ambassadors are direct envoys of the President, and ordinarily he fills the most coveted posts on a more or less personal basis -- with men he wishes to reward for political support or who will represent his own ideas in foreign capitals.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Lady Makins, who made her debut here in 1928 when her father, the late Dwight F. Davis, was Secretary of War in the Coolidge Administration, received the women of the Washington press corps today in her new role as chatelaine of the British Embassy.

Demand for the new synthetic "miracle" fibers will stay well ahead of supply for some years to come, according to Herman Goodman, executive vice president of Robbins Mills, Inc. The experience of consumers with the man-made fibers, he said, has on the whole been very favorable and their growth in men's wear will be as spectacular as they have been in the women's apparel field.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Robert A. Lovett, the outgoing Secretary of Defense, made a final plea today against any let-down in the defense program. He declared that it would be foolhardy and dangerous for the nation to relax when it had bought only a part of its minimum armed security.

Mighty La Salle, apparently out of the slump that afflicted it during its appearances at the Holidays Festival here, handed Manhattan a decisive 63-52 trimming at Madison Square Garden last night. In the opener of a twin bill witnessed by 7,122 spectators, Dayton vanquished New York University, 82 -- 75.
Fifteen hundred Christian clergymen have signed an open letter to President Truman requesting executive clemency for Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, convicted atomic spies.

WASHINGTON, Jan 14 -- Jack Gorrie, chairman of the National Security Resources Board, recommended to President Truman today that high priority be given to new scientific developments to "make continental defense more effective."

ATLANTA, Jan. 13 -- Increase in the capital funds of the Trust .Company of Georgia was announced following a stockholders' meeting here today. The stockholders voted to increase the bank's capital from $2,000,000 to $4,00,000.

The power cut-off in last weekend's ice storm probably has resulted in less food spoilage in large, well-stocked home freezers than in smaller models or in those that contained only small quantities of food.

Two Turkish athletes and a German, who will compete here this winter, were introduced to local coaches, officials and writers at yesterday's track luncheon at Leone's Restaurant. Another Turkish star arrived later in the afternoon to join the international spiked-shoe brigade assembling here for the indoor season.

The first insurance policy designed to protect legitimate theatre performers against loss of income because of illness or accident was approved this week by the New York State Department of Insurance, Actors Equity Association announced yesterday.

Interesting cargo arriving yesterday aboard the liner Franconia included several antique tin chests containing the first collection of British coronation robes and accessories to be shown in the United States. Carefully guarding the treasures was Mrs. Doris Langley Moore, head of the British Museum of Costume.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 13 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower has offered to appoint former Gov. Val Peterson of Nebraska as Ambassador to India, succeeding Chester Bowles, usually reliable sources reported today. The Indian Government, it is understood, will agree, and the announcement of the appointment is expected shortly.

" Be Your Age," arriving at 8 o'clock this evening at the Forty-eighth Street, will relieve the famine of Broadway openings since "The Children's Hour" settled down Dec. 18. The latest entry is a domestic comedy, written by the husband-wife team of Reginald Denham and Mary Orr, who previously were represented here by three other collaborations, "Wallflower," "Dark Hammock" and "Round Trip." Mr. Denham also did the direction.
Representatives of 200 striking gravediggers and of six cemeteries will meet tomorrow at a joint mediation session at the offices of the State Mediation Board, the board announced yesterday.

An increasingly dangerous violation of civil liberty is the publicity of witness before Congressional committees. The granting of immunity and the publicizing of testimony before the accused have been given a chance to answer is a very unfair abuse of Congressional power.

The Soviet charge that nine doctors had murdered two Politburo members may well be the first move setting off the greatest Soviet public trial since the last great purge trials in the mid-Thirties. There is great parallelism between the charges made now and those made in 1938.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Jan. 13 (AP) -- George Mikan of Minneapolis swept rebounds from both backboards and contributed 22 points as the West scored its first victory over the East, 79 -- 75, in the annual National Basketball Association All-Star game tonight.

Fordham, unbeaten in eleven starts, and Seton Hall, which has won fifteen games without a loss, will clash tonight before a capacity crowd of 3,000 at Fordham's campus gymnasium in one of the season's most interesting college basketball matches.
CHICAGO, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Thanks to the Little Orchestra Society, Thomas Scherman conductor, a large audience heard Weber's "Euryanthe" in concert form last night in Carnegie Hall. The opera was last performed here at the Metropolitan Opera House in the 1914-15 season.

The tentative gains last year in the direction of a greater degree of balance in the national economy "must be preserved and consolidated," Henry C. Alexander, president of J. P. Morgan Co., Inc., declared in his annual report to stockholders.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The House Armed Services Committee was told today that the Air Force planned to reinforce its radar surveillance crews in Alaska and the Northwest United States to enable them to keep on the lookout for friendly, as well as possible enemy, aircraft.

ATLANTA, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Chief Justice W. H. Duckworth of the Georgia Supreme Court commented on the bench today that newspapers have a right to criticize courts "because in this country we do not have a belief that the King can do no wrong.

A total of sixty-eight days out of the 365 in the year 1953 will be observed as holidays somewhere in the United States, its territories and possessions, in addition to Saturday bank holidays, according to a new booklet now being distributed by the Manufacturers Trust Company.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Jan. 14 -- United Nations planes struck in massive force yesterday in day and night attacks on Communist rail and highway communications and river bridges near Sinanju in northwest Korea, a vital link in the enemy's supply line from bases in Manchuria.

Production of raw steel in December established a record for that month; output in the fourth quarter last year was higher than in any previous quarter, and 1952 production of the metal was the third highest for annual output, the American Iron and Steel Institute said yesterday in its monthly production report.
GRIDLEY, Calif., Jan. 13 -- An Air Force B-50 bomber crashed and exploded today in a flooded rice field near this northern California city, causing the deaths of all of those aboard.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 13 -- The Federal police announced today the arrest of a 46-year-old Mexican lawyer on charges of fraud and forgery involving the attempted sale of $81,500,000 worth of non-existent gold and oil to United States buyers.

ON June 3, 1950, two French mountain climbers crawled up a narrow couloir high in the Himalayas and emerged upon the snow-covered peak of Annapurna. They were the first men in the history of mountaineering to reach the summit of a mountain 8,000 meters or more in height, although twenty-two previous expeditions had tried in vain to scale other 8,000-meter peaks.

When her husband is inducted as President of the United States next Tuesday, Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower will wear a soft gray dressmaker suit designed by Hattie Carnegie that will feature a nipped-in jacket and semi-full skirt.

A diamond jubilee is generally a joyous occasion, but in the case of the Empire Theatre, which will observe its sixtieth birthday on Jan. 25, the celebration will be tinged with sadness. The property at the southeast corner of Fortieth Street and Broadway has been sold and the theatre is destined to be torn down next June to make way for a textile building.

With regard to your editorial of Jan. 9 "Questions for Mr. McCarthy," especially the last sentence, may I point out that the American people from every state in the Union, with heavy emphasis in Wisconsin, have by telegram and letter and through such groups as the American Legion and Veterans of Foreign Wars expressed their feelings toward Senator McCarthy as an outstanding American patriot.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 13 -- The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development is preparing to send a mission to the West German Federal Republic to study the possibilities of financing the expansion of heavy industries.

PHILADELPHIA, Wednesday, Jan. 14 -- The general membership of Local 234, Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., voted overwhelmingly last night to go on strike on transit lines of the Philadelphia Transportation Company and at midnight the walkout was effected.

MOSCOW, Jan. 13 (Reuters) -- The Moscow newspapers Pravda and Izvestia today accused officials of the Soviet Ministry of Health of overlooking "the wrecking terrorist activity of the heinous degenerates who sold out to the enemies of the Soviet Union."
MANIZALES, Colombia, Jan. 13 -- A devout and rugged band of Roman Catholic priests from the United States is revolutionizing missionary techniques in Latin America.

Cotton futures had a steadier tone on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday and closing prices were 16 points higher to 14 points lower than on Monday, with old crop months showing the most strength.

SEOUL, Korea, Jan. 13 -- Out of the chaos and confusion of war and the waste and ruin of wrecked lives that result, there is occasionally fashioned a wondrous and ennobling story. One of the modern-day true stories is told of Sgt. First Class Werner Krenzer of Rego Park, Queens.

The wail of the city's fire and police sirens, silenced since Sept. 11, 1950, to avoid confusion with the air-raid alarms, will be heard for a sixty-day period beginning early next week as the result of a plea by the heads of both departments to civil defense officials.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The Senate rejected by 81 to 7 today an appeal by Senator Wayne Morse of Oregon to be allowed to keep an important and erstwhile Republican committee seat though he left the Republican party in the Presidential campaign and became an independent.
TRENTON, N. J., Jan. 13 -- Following are excerpts from the annual message of Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll to the New Jersey Legislature here today:

Carl Sandburg, whose seventy-fifth birthday has been something of a national event, was honored again last night when the Poetry Society of America gave him its gold medal for distinguished achievement.

HONG KONG, Jan. 13 -- Red China's transitional national assembly, the People's Political Consultative Conference, is scheduled to meet in Peiping this month at its first full-dress session since October, 1951, according to a Peiping broadcast heard here today.
Louis E. Schwartz, an attorney who was born in Russia, but lives and has his office in Brooklyn, got off a train, from Durham, N. C., yesterday morning for the seventh time in fourteen weeks.

Deeply concerned over a recent slowdown in European defense preparations, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, yesterday directed John Foster Dulles, Secretary of Statedesignate, and Harold E. Stassen, Mutual Security Director-designate, to make a hurried fact-finding trip to Western Europe within ten days after he is inaugurated as President.

Holding off a game bid by the losers in the fourth period, the New York Athletic Club trio beat Buddy Combs' Red Bank Polo Club, 13 to 12, in the feature match of a benefit double-header last night at the Squadron A. Armory.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Jan. 14 -- Gen. Mark W. Clark, United States Far East commander, announced today that he had issued orders to United States Air Force and ground subordinates to "take all measures necessary" to prevent further violations of Japanese security.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, apologized to three Senate colleagues today for injecting their names into the controversy over the appointment of Martin P. Durkin as Secretary of Labor in the new Republican Administration.

Last night the New York City Ballet at the City Center presented the second new ballet of the season by Ruthanna Boris, entitled "Will o' the Wisp." Its music by Virgil Thomson was written originally for the film "Louisiana Story" and was used last season for the unsuccessful ballet "Bayou."

David L. Marks, special assistant United States Attorney, began in Federal Court yesterday the task of summarizing and interpreting the evidence presented in the last eight months at the trial of thirteen secondary Communist leaders accused of conspiracy to teach and advocate the overthrow of the Government by force and violence.

Dean Young B. Smith looked back this week on his thirty-six-year academic career, including twenty-five years as head of the Columbia Law School, and declared that if he had to do it all over again, "I don't think I'd change a minute of it."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The State Department said today that the Soviet Union's arrest of a group of Russian Jewish doctors on charges of "medical sabotage" was a sign of "an extraordinary and growing sense of internal insecurity."

Your editorial "Korea and Japan," Jan. 6, very properly stresses the importance of reaching a solution in the relations between those two Far Eastern countries. In the same issue a Tokyo dispatch reports the arrival in Japan of President Rhee and the issuance by him of a conciliatory statement designed to pave the way for such an agreement.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 13 -- Capital stock of the National City Bank of Cleveland will be boosted to 875,000 shares from the present 750,000 by the sale of 125,000 to present holders at $36 per share, it was decided today by stockholders at the annual meeting.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Vic Seixas of Philadelphia was the only American to reach the semi-finals of the Australian singles tennis championship today, but his young teammate, Ham Richardson, nearly scored the biggest upset of the tournament.

Jay E. Crane, vice president and director of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) has been appointed chairman of the board of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, it was announced yesterday. He will fill the unexpired term of Robert T. Stevens, who has resigned, effective next Monday, to accept appointment as Secretary of the Army in the Eisenhower Administration.

A Westchester Republican attributed it to Eisenhower. Perhaps that was the reason, although it might have been the clear, sunny day, somewhat zippy but nevertheless a taste of what cruising and vacation weather can be like in next summer's yachting season.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Eight civil rights bills sponsored by seven Democrats and one independent were introduced in the Senate late today with an expression of confidence that some if not all could be passed despite new filibusters such as had blocked similar legislation in the past.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13--An investigation of an oil lease contract to which Representative John L. McMillan, Democrat of South Carolina, was a party has been undertaken to determine if Federal law was violated, the Department of Justice disclosed today.

Nearly every big city in the country can teach New York something about traffic management. In contrast to other metropolitan centers, the largest city of them all clings to antiquated procedures that allow its streets to become choked, increase the accident toll, and add millions to the cost of handling merchandise.

The creative mind of Tina Leser, restless in its search to recreate in exciting new fashions some of the beauties of the world she has seen, has taken the inspiration for her new collection from the tribute silks of China. New certainly and beautiful beyond a doubt are her shorts for dinnerwear of this silk brocade embroidered with jewels at the waistband.

ALBANY, Jan. 13 -- Governor Dewey approved today a deficiency appropriation bill to provide the State Crime Commission with an additional $100,000 to finance its investigations until March 31, when the fiscal year ends.

All the New York maritime unions of the American Federation of Labor formed a new organization yesterday to embark on labor's own waterfront reform. Two hundred men representing longshoremen, seafarers, radio operators and licensed officers of the deck and enginerooms of American-flag merchant ships formed the Greater New York Harbor Port Council and adopted a strong program designed to clean their own houses, ferret out wrongdoing and banish rule-breakers from union ranks.

The Societa Corelli, string ensemble from Rome, made its first appearance in the New York area last evening at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The program, the fourth event in the Major Concert Series presented by the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences, opened a nation-wide concert tour by the Societa Corelli.

PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 13 -- Two prominent Princeton University policy-makers on athletics today put their support behind the resolution introduced by seven undergraduate newspapers last Friday urging the strengthening of the Ivy League.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 13 -- For the edification of Britain and the United States, Dr. Mohammed Mossadegh, Premier of Iran, gave a demonstration of his political power and popularity in the Iranian Parliament today.

Ardyth Kennelly's new novel "Good Morning, Young Lady" is one of two chosen recently as a reserve selection by the Literary Guild. To be published by Houghton, Mifflin, Miss Kennelly's story is about an orphan girl who gets passed around from one member of her family to another as she grows up.

ALBANY, Jan. 13 -- A proposal that would limit parking fines to $5 was put before the Legislature today by Senator Alfred E. Santangelo, Democrat of Manhattan, who declared that parking violations were largely the result of an inadequacy of parking facilities.

Local 802, American Federation of Musicians, A. F. L., has been shaken by a violent internal spasm that already has jolted two employes from their jobs and may change the entire inner structure of the union.

The news is generally good in the Health Department's analysis of life and death in New York City in 1952. Births outnumbered deaths by over two to one. Particularly pleasing is the record on tuberculosis, with "the greatest reduction in deaths * * * ever recorded in one year since the intensive fight to conquer the disease began more than fifty years ago."
John A. McNulty of Teaneck, N. J., West Point graduate, was unanimously elected president of the New York Athletic Club at the organization's annual meeting held last night in the club's gymnasium.

The National City Bank or New York held the longest annual meeting in its 140-year history yesterday. It lasted two hours and twenty minutes and was filled with bickering by two minority stockholders; the disclosure of some additional points of operating information, and the formal approval of an employes' profit-sharing plan and a stock dividend.

The striking bus workers are seeking a forty-hour week with no cut in the pay they used to get for working forty-four to forty-eight hours, with five to nine hours of guaranteed overtime. The old basic wage ranged from $1.66 to $1.73 1/2 an hour.

A dispatch from Khartum, which tells of the struggle in the Anglo-Egyptian Sudan between Communists and anti-Communists for control of the Confederation of Labor, is a reminder that the cold war on the labor front has no geographic limits.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 13 -- The Soviet charges were described here today as a "blood libel," thus comparing them with tales, circulated among Russian peasants by the Czarist regimes, that the Jews used the blood of Christian children in baking their traditional Passover bread.

A New Yorker who served on a criminal court jury for seventeen days sent a check for $51, representing payment to him for his service, to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund yesterday. His donation was one of twenty-nine received by this newspaper to increase the total to $382,746.23 from 12,088 contributors.

" My Favorite Story," which made its debut at 10:30 P. M. Sunday over N. B. C. video, may turn out to be one of the best film series yet produced for television. The opening program was an excellent presentation, well off the beaten path, a dramatization of Tolstoy's indictment of human greed.

The first public hearing on the controversial proposal by management survey consultants for the elimination of many of the city's fire houses will be held at 10 A. M. on Jan. 28 in the City Council chamber at City Hall.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 13 -- Competition appeared on the horizon today for Natural Vision, first company to make a feature-length film utilizing the stereoscopic process to achieve a three-dimensional effect. Sol Lesser, veteran independent producer, and a group of associates announced the organization of a California corporation to sponsor production of three-dimension movies under the trade name of Stereocinema.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Jan. 13 -- Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery, Deputy Supreme Allied Commander, Europe, called here last week for the creation of a high-level committee in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to furnish "political guidance" and "strategical military guidance" from a world viewpoint in the current struggle against world communism.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- A Federal grand jury returned an indictment in the United States District Court here today in a case involving national security. Judge Alexander Holtzoff ordered the indictment sealed pending the arrest of those accused.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Charles (Buck) Herzog, one of baseball's greats with the Giants and Cubs, was taken to a city hospital today, penninless and ill. Magistrate William F. Laukaitis arranged for the 67-year-old former star infielder to be taken to the hospital in an ambulance after he was found in the lobby of a small hotel.

Following is the order of battle (January, 1953) of the North Atlantic Treaty allies that contribute military forces (Iceland, a member of the alliance, does not). The figures are approximate; divisions are of differing sizes and states of readiness; some of the aircraft are jet.

Substitution of a central labor registration system for a shapeup form of hiring has assured reasonably steady work and a regular income for 23,000 longshoremen in the Port of London, England, Viscount Waverley, Chairman of the Port of London Authority, declared here yesterday.
MOSCOW, Jan. 13 -- Today's announcement of the arrest of nine physicians accused of having plotted the deaths of Soviet political and military leaders is expected to be followed by further arrests.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Federal Judge James R. Kirkland found today that the Government was "on dead center," and threw into the lap of the Eisenhower Administration the United States' request for criminal indictment of five major American oil companies as a world-wide monopoly.
BERLIN, Jan. 13 -- RIAS, the United States-operated radio station that transmits from deep in northeastern Europe, will unveil new equipment on Thursday that will triple the power of its broadcasts.
STRASBOURG, France, Jan. 13 -- Jean Monnet, president of the High Authority of the European Coal and Steel Community, tonight defended the strictly European and non-national nature of its work.

BORDEAUX, France, Jan 13 (AP) -- A military tribunal refused today to grant a separate trial for thirteen Alsatians among twenty-one former German soldiers accused of having taken part in the wartime massacre of 642 Frenchmen at Oradour-sur-Glane.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 13 -- Carl Wente, president of the Bank of America, told stockholders today that savings and time deposits of the world's biggest bank had been growing at the rate of $1,000,000 a day and now stood at $3,444,907,411. Demand deposits, he said, totaled $4,040,408,773.

In an attempt to cut its huge backlog of complaints the Department of Housing and Buildings is mailing violation notices to landlords and asking the tenant-complainants to advise the agency if the condition has been corrected.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Jan. 14 (AP) -- United Nation's Command communique 1,494, for the twenty-four hours ended at 6 A. M. Wednesday, Korean time:

A gold cup for its outstanding contribution in the retail advertising field, as illustrated by its new store opening series, was presented yesterday to Woodward Lothrop, Washington department store. The award was one of twenty-four made by the National Association Retail Dry Goods Association in connection with its annual newspaper advertising contest.
LONDON, Jan. 14 -- Queen Elizabeth II today selected two British military heroes of World War II for high honors at her coronation next June.

STRASBOURG, France, Jan. 14 -- Britain will decline to merge her sovereignty in a political union of European states, Lord Layton, leading British advocate of European union, told the Consultative Assembly of the Council of Europe today. He said the future relations of Britain with supranational bodies ought to be governed by the principle of mutual consultation in advance.

GENEVA, Jan. 14 -- A serious and sometimes fatal form of infectious jaundice is being spread throughout the civilized world by an excessive use of blood transfusions, plasma from blood banks and ordinary blood serum injections, the United Nations World Health Organization reported today.

ACTUALLY there could be no doubt about it. When the Boxing Writers Association balloted for its Fighter of the Year, the only choice was Rocky Marciano. If he had any challenger, for the honor, that challenger was Jersey Joe Walcott, who surprised by upsetting Ezzard Charles in June and surprised even more by waging so magnificent a battle against Marciano in September.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today that it will support the 1953 long-staple cotton crop -- including American-Egyptian, Sealand and Sea Island Varieties -- at 2.4 times the support prices on this year's regular cotton crop.

Under the leadership of Herman T. Stichman, State Housing Commissioner, some savings banks and civic organizations have been conferring on the problem of rehabilitating Harlem housing and other property. As a result a "block plan" has been formulated that promises action. Mr. Stichman sees Harlem as a "laboratory" which may inspire a program that would spread for good elsewhere.

MOSCOW, Jan. 14 -- Evidence that the Soviet Union plans to use its charges of a medical plot against Russian political and military leaders to bulwark its complaints against "capitalist encirclement" appeared today.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 14 -- Federal Judge J. Skelly Wright granted a summary judgment today in favor of Eli Lilly Co., pharmaceutical manufacturer, enjoining Schwegmann Brothers, Giant Supermarkets, a commercial partnership, from selling Lilly products below minimum retail sale prices fixed under the Louisiana Fair Trade Act.

BONN, Jan. 14 -- The executive committee of the West German Coal Miners Union has decided to order more than 500,000 men out of the pits Monday unless the mine operators agree to reduce the daily shifts from eight hours to seven and a half hours and at the same pay.
A relative calm settled yesterday over the stock market. While prices in some sections showed signs of moving into better ground, the threat of profit-taking remained as a restraining influence.

Commodity futures closed generally lower yesterday in dull trading on the New York exchanges. Price changes were slight with volume light. Sugar, wool, cocoa, rubber, lead and zinc closed lower. Vegetable oils were higher and hides, potatoes and coffee ended irregular.

The farm support program of the present Administration was attacked yesterday by Llewellyn Watts Jr., president of the New York Mercantile Exchange, trading center for butter, eggs, potato futures and onion futures. In a telegram to President-elect Eisenhower and Agriculture Secretary-designate Ezra Benson, Mr. Watts said the program is placing the dairy industry in a critical condition because of the huge stocks of butter the Government is accumulating.

Tonnage of merchant ships under construction in fourteen American yards rose slightly in December, but for the fourth consecutive month total dead-weight tonnage of vessels under contract remained below the 2,000,000-ton mark.

Strong support for a noncommercial educational television network proposed by the State Board of Regents was voiced yesterday by spokesmen for 102 educational, cultural, civic and welfare organizations at a hearing called by the Temporary State Commission on the Use of Television for Educational Purposes.

The Planned Parenthood Committee of Mothers Health Centers announced yesterday that its application for membership on the Welfare and Health Council of New York City had been turned down because of opposition to its program by the Roman Catholic Charities of New York and Brooklyn.

The Board of Justices of the Children's Court asked every member of the Board of Estimate yesterday to vote against a recent City Council bill to fine parents $25 for acts of vandalism committed by their children.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 14 -- The police all over Brazil are on the lookout for the trouble the Communists are believed planning for tomorrow as the Brazilian Congress meets in special session to discuss ratification of a military assistance agreement with the United States.

The city and the striking bus union rejected last night the arbitration formula put forward by two big bus companies for settlement of the two-week-old walkout of 8,000 drivers and mechanics in the metropolitan area.

An account of holy the Battle of the Atlantic looked to the commander of a German U-Boat is scheduled for Feb. 20 publication by Norton, entitled "U-Boat 977." The author is Heinz Schaeffer, who presents a record of his naval career in U-boat service that brought him fame in Hitler's Germany.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Jan. 14 -- School boards are justified in barring controversial events from school buildings and any appeal from a board's exercise of such discretion should be made to the State Commissioner of Education rather than to the courts, Supreme Court Justice Frank H. Coyne ruled here today.

WHILE other novelists are wringing their hands and saying that this is no time to write, H. E. Bates is writing. While other novelists are howling over the perilous state of current affairs, H. E. Bates is telling the eternal tales of private lives. While other novelists are vicariously saving the world, H. E. Bates is quietly and expertly helping to keep alive the art of storytelling.

TRENTON, Jan. 14 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll announced today that he would not run this year for a third term. He said he wished to respect the "spirit" of the 1947 New Jersey Constitution, which limits Governors to two consecutive terms, even though the "letter" might legally allow him to run this fall.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The Commercial Credit Company of Baltimore applied to the Security and Exchange Commission today for permission to sell $25,000,000 of junior subordinated notes, due in 1973, to be offered for public sale through an underwriting group headed by Kidder, Peabody Co. and the First Boston Corporation.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 14 -- The striking city laborers having defied an ultimatum to end their walkout by noon, union recognition was withdrawn today and the city made ready to try to break the strike with the employment of private help.
A Senate investigation of the New York and New Jersey waterfront, with televised public hearings, is "not at all unlikely," Senator Charles W. Tobey, Republican of New Hampshire, said yesterday.

Although the Broadway theatre has taken a midwinter break, it is no better. It is worse. For "Be Your Age," which was batted back and forth at the Forty-eighth Street last evening, is one of the most trying experiences of the season.

The outlawing of football's two-platoon system took most of the country's coaches by surprise. In a survey by The Associated Press, some thought it was a good idea, others predicted it would help the small colleges and at least one was openly hostile.

Bridal fashions presented by Bonwit Teller yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel indicated a trend to full-length bridal dresses with modified trains. Important were the skirts with wide or low flaring fullness as well as those with tremendous back panels of cascading ruffles.

New Yorkers must read with envy of the determined and intelligent attack some other major cities are making on their traffic problems, as related in Joseph C. Ingraham's series of articles being published in this newspaper. Mr. Ingraham, whose beat as a reporter is traffic, has witnessed the faltering, indecisive steps taken in New York City over the years.

Collapse of its proposed merger with Manufacturers Trust Company in mid-1952 was a principal topic of discussion at the annual meeting of The New York Trust Company yesterday. One stockholder, who held the floor for nearly an hour, badgered the management about the deal and said that "a bank just down the street" was willing to make a better offer than the one made by Manufacturers last May.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The Department of Defense proposed an 8 per cent cost-of-living pay increase today for all members of the armed services.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 14 -- A new "industrial revolution," with machines replacing within a generation a large portion of the white collar workers now doing routine jobs in business and industry, was sketched today in talks before the annual mid-winter meeting of the American Management Association.

Stockholders of the West Indies Sugar Corporation were advised yesterday that directors of the concern might find it advisable at their meeting on Jan. 27 to reduce the quarterly dividend from 75 to 50 cents a share to conserve working capital.

LONDON, Jan. 14 -- A small revival in demand for British Government securities helped stock markets to develop renewed strength today. Leading industrials rose, with giltedge interest being renewed particularly in shipping and store shares.

MANIZALES, Colombia, Jan. 14 -- An influential member of the Roman Catholic hierarchy of South America said here today that private ownership of large land areas was contrary to the "Christian idea of the distribution of property."

CHICAGO, Jan. 14 -- How Gen. Robert E. Wood of Sears, Roebuck Co. threatened E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., to no avail, with an appeal to the Federal Trade Commission fourteen years ago was told in Government exhibits at the du Pont anti-trust trial today in Federal District Court.

Secret Service agents seized a Minneapolis real estate operator here yesterday with twenty-five ounces of fine gold secreted in a 16-mm. motion-picture camera. An additional 100 ounces was found by the agents in a subway station public locker.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- President Truman and his Council of Economic Advisers today forecast continued prosperity and an annual national output of $500,000,000,000 ten years from now if precautions were taken to offset possible deflationary tendencies that might occur in two or three years.

Advertising people should be permitted to participate to a greater extent in the policy-making activities of pharmaceutical companies, it was suggested yesterday by Robert A. Hardt, vice president in charge of sales of Hoffman-LaRoche, pharmaceuticals manufacturer. He spoke at a luncheon meeting of the Pharmaceutical Advertising Club in the Roosevelt Hotel.

The striking bus workers are seeking a forty-hour week with no cut in the pay they used to get for working forty-four to forty-eight hours, with five to nine hours of guaranteed overtime. The old basic wage ranged from $1.66 to $1.73 1/2 an hour.

The military strength of Western Europe has increased -- relative to that of the Soviet Union and its allies -- in the past two years, despite the major problems the North Atlantic Treaty Organization is now facing.

The United States wants to eat its cake and yet have it, too -- which is a viewpoint that ought to be changed for the good of this nation and the rest of the world, Eugene R. Black, president of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, declared before the Economic Club of New York last night in pleading for a sharp downward revision of tariff schedules.

HONG KONG, Jan. 14 -- Mao Tse-tung has been named chairman of a committee to draft a new Constitution for Red China, the Peiping radio said this morning. The broadcast said Premier Chou En-lai has been designated as head of another committee to draw up an electoral law.

Lieut. Gen. Orval R. Cook, Air Force Deputy Chief of Staff for Materiel, told a meeting of small business men and trade officials that filled the Council chamber at City Hall yesterday morning that the Air Force's intensive drive had increased from 46 to 70 per cent the proportion of contracts going to business concerns that employ fewer than 500 hands.
