The public should take warning that a most determined effort is likely to be made in the present Legislature to initiate laws to sweep away the last vestiges of constitutional protection for the Adirondack forests and place them under control of some small commission with views known to be favorable to permitting the forests to be cut for lumber and pulp.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 14 -- Frank Harris' classic story of Western Americana, "Reminiscences of a Cowboy," will be brought to the screen this year by Columbia Pictures. Ranald MacDougall has been assigned to write and produce the adaptation of the book, which the studio has acquired from Horizon Pictures, the independent company operated by John Huston and S. P. Eagle.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The Housing and Home Finance Agency announced today capital grant allocations aggregating $8,946,458 for two slum clearance and urban redevelopment projects in New York.

ROME, Jan. 14 -- Sixteen of the twenty-four Cardinals named in Monday's secret consistory gathered this evening in the papal throne room at the Vatican, where, in a private and simple ceremony, they received from the Pope's hands the scarlet biretta and purple mozzetta that are emblems of the Cardinals' dignity.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 14 -John J. McCloy, former United States High Commissioner for Germany, asserted tonight that our diplomatic representatives must develop new techniques of reaching the common people, as well as politicians, abroad for the successful execution of foreign policy.

In winter anywhere, but especially in a big city, man's attitude toward man-made and man-controlled objects changes utterly. In summer the works of man are bad. Buildings block the breeze or the view or the sky, sidewalks hold the heat and reflect the sun, clothes smother and hamper the body, walls and roofs and floors lock a man away from the goodness of nature.

While the public has gained from social and economic reforms in the last twenty years, Government has outgrown all other business, competing directly with its own citizens who have been fored to underwrite the competition through increasing taxes, the Chemical Bank and Trust Company says in its annual report.

This newspaper has consistently favored action by the rank and file of the International Longshoremen's Association to end racketeering in the Port of New York. We recognize, of course, that employing stevedores and shippers must also share the blame for the evils that infest our piers; if changes are to come, they too must cooperate with state and municipal authorities.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Jan. 7:

The New York Zoological Society ranged further afield in scientific work in 1952 than ever before in its history, Fairfield Osborn, president, reported last night to the annual meeting in Hunter College Auditorium, Park Avenue at Sixty-ninth Street. He concluded his summing up by presenting a gold medal to Rachel L. Carson, author of "The Sea Around Us," the society's first award since 1946. Miss Carson spoke on "The Meeting Place of the Waters."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The Government today was marking time on applications from West Coast petroleum producers for an increase in prices for both crude and refined products. The increases, according to Office of Price Stabilization estimates, will add $180,000,000 annually to the fuel oil and gasoline bills paid by consumers along the West Coast, including purchases by the military.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 14 -- Reports that Pakistan may join the proposed Middle Eastern defense organization have caused acute alarm in India. The Foreign Office has declined to comment on the subject, but every important newspaper has analyzed the possible consequences of such a move to India.

TOKYO, Thursday, Jan. 15 -- United States Sabre jets yesterday scored their biggest victory since last September over Red China's Soviet-designed jet fighters. In battles near the Yalu River in Northwest Korea, the Fifth Air Force's F-86's shot down eight MIG's and damaged three.

GENEVA, Jan. 7 -- If there is still a statesman in the world who believes that Communist governments are just like any others, if only you know how to deal with them, the International Committee of the Red Cross would like to send him a copy of its latest publication.

VIENNA, Jan. 14 -- Moscow's allegation that a group of doctors, most of them Jewish, had been trying to bring about the death of Soviet Communist leaders was foreshadowed by a somewhat similar allegation during the recent trial of Rudolf Slansky for treason in Prague.

An official New York delegation of more than 1,000 Republican leaders, state officials and individuals who supported Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, President-elect, will join Governor Dewey in Washington this week-end to participate in the opening phases of the inauguration ceremonies.

Continental styling and several mechanical improvements are offered in the 1953 line presented yesterday by Nash motor division, Nash-Kelvinator Corporation. The cars will go on display here tomorrow.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between 8 and 14 years old a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.
Just three months short of rounding out a score of years as Customs collector in the country's biggest and busiest port, Harry M. Durning will retire on Jan. 31.

New issues of public utility and railroad securities valued at more that $41,000,000 will be offered to investors today by investment banking syndicates. The offerings include preferred and common shares of utility companies in Ohio and California and equipment trust certificates of a major rail freight carrier.

An appeal for greater preference for Canada in tariffs on chemicals was made yesterday by Victor G. Bartram, president of Shawinigan Chemicals, Ltd., long a leader in the Dominion's chemical industry.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- A proposal that responsibility for the psychological strategy of the United States be lodged entirely with the National Security Council has been submitted to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, and his advisers by O. K. Armstrong, a former Republican Representative from Missouri.
PARIS, Jan. 14 -- Double hats, that is a small or cartwheel sailor for afternoon posed upon a cocktail calot, form one of the exciting themes at Maud et Nano's opening.
Governor Dewey charged last night that Premier Stalin had "swallowed the last drop of the Hitler poison and become the newest and most vituperative persecutor of Jewry."

CLEVELAND, Jan. 14 -- A long-proposed plan to curb labor "monopoly" by making little unions out of big ones received no support today from a five-man panel at a national industrial relations conference of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

The bulk of the $4,000,000 estate left by Mrs. Amelie McAlister Upshur, daughter of the late William H. McAlister, retired tobacco merchant and former secretary of the American Tobacco Company, will be used for educational, scientific, charitable, religious and literary purposes.

TRENTON, Jan. 14 -- Three alleged gamblers, identified by a witness before the Senate Crime Investigating Committee as "members of the New Jersey mob who ran the games in Miami, Fla.," were indicted today by a Federal grand jury on charges of evading a total of $201,276 in income taxes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Richard M. Nixon, the Vice President-elect, proposed the joint Senate-House investigation, now under way, of the circumstances under which settlements were obtained in a number of large Federal tax cases on the West Coast.

Bobby Bragan, one of the most highly rated field managers in the Brooklyn organization, yesterday informed Buzzie Bavasi, Dodger vice president, that he would not manage the Fort Worth club of the Texas League this year.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday turned stronger and closed 4 to 48 points net higher than on Tuesday.
Unlike New York, where the traffic code is so broad and confusing that it seemingly is meaningless, most big cities limit the rules to the capacity of the police to enforce them.

Persons and places should have a chance to develop their own individualities and not be expected to follow the pattern of their predecessors. This observation arose when some persons were heard to sigh that the new Carlton House was not quite like the old Ritz. Who wants it to be?

ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- The City of Yonkers made a strong plea here today for adoption of a constitutional amendment that would increase its real estate taxing powers, but representatives of four other cities that would be affected were distinctly cool to the proposal. The other cities are Buffalo, Rochester, Syracuse and Albany.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- In the face of contrary Republican tides on Capitol Hill, President Truman and his Council of Economic Advisers today urged Congress to retain present tax levels and direct controls on materials, prices and wages.

The text of the resolution adopted by the board of the Welfare and Health Council of New York City denying membership to the Planned Parenthood Committee of Mothers Health Centers, New York City, and the texts of statements by the Catholic Charities of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York and the Planned Parenthood Committee of Mothers Health Centers follow:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The Army, which abandoned plans several weeks ago, after union protests, to erect prefabricated shelters for anti-aircraft battery soldiers at various sites in northern New Jersey, received today an offer from the same unions to help erect the buildings without cost.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 14 -- Horrified by the news of "medical murder" charges against some Jewish doctors in Moscow, representatives of six parties have called for special debate in the Knesset (Parliament) next week. Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion is expected to interrupt his vacation to take part.

SYRACUSE, Jan. 14 -- Members of the New York State Publishers Association heard a panel of seven persons from as many walks of life place the "newspaper on trial" at the closing session of their three-day meeting here today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Eight first-term Republicans were elected to membership on two key committees of the House of Representatives today in a major departure from usual policy.
Thirty-five hundred firemen and custodians in New York's 850 public elementary, junior high and high schools threatened yesterday to strike next Monday to obtain higher wages and shorter hours.

Three new films are scheduled to arrive in first-run theatres today. "The Bad and the Beautiful," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer drama about Hollywood with Lana Turner, Kirk Douglas, Walter Pidgeon, Dick Powell, Barry Sullivan, Gloria Grahame, Gilbert Roland and Leo G. Carroll, is at the Radio City Music Hall.

CORAL GABLES, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Crafty Admiral and Spartan Valor, two of the top handicap horses of 1952, will meet for the third time tomorrow in Tropical Park's closing feature, the $50,000 Tropical Handicap, at a mile and a furlong.

Jesse Moss, National Commander of the Jewish War Veterans, demanded a retraction yesterday of the statement by Representative Francis Walter, Democrat of Pennsylvania, that "professional Jews are shedding crocodile tears for no reason whatsoever" over the McCarran-Walter Act revising this country's immigration statutes.

A potential prosecution witness against William (Bill) Spivey former University of Kentucky player who went on trial for perjury yesterday in General Sessions, has balked at testifying at the trial or before a grand jury that has been carrying on an extended investigation into the college sports scandal.

ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- A drive for passage of a constitutional amendment to give a state bonus to Korean war veterans got under way here today. A resolution, introduced by Senator William F. Condon and Assemblyman Malcolm Wilson, Westchester Republicans, called for the setting up of a bipartisan joint legislative committee to consider all proposals introduced at this session of the Legislature dealing with benefits for Korean veterans.

ROME, Jan. 14 -- Premier Alcide De Gasperi cut short a debate on the Government's electoral reform bill, which has been dragging on in the Chamber of Deputies since early December, by demanding a vote of confidence which shall be taken implicitly to signify approval of the bill.

MANHASSET, L. I., Jan. 14 -- The appointment of a pathologist and a radiologist today to the staff of the $4,000,000 North Shore Hospital apparently ended the bitter controversy between local doctors and the board of trustees over policy in establishing a medical staff executive committee.
Wagner College's basketball team downed a sluggish Brooklyn College squad, 66 -- 46, at the loser's gymnasium last night.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 14 -- A strike of 9,500 employes of the Philadelphia Transportation Company, which their national leader denounced as a "crime," halted all bus, trolley, subway and elevated train service over the system's 1,500 route-miles today.

ALBANY, Jan. 15 -- The State Banking Department has announced that the National City Safe Deposit Company, 17 East Forty-second Street, has received approval for a temporary change in the location of its branch office from the northwest corner of Park Avenue and East Fifty-seventh Street to the northwest corner of Fifth Avenue and Fifty-first Street, Manhattan.

PUSAN, Korea, Jan. 14 -- The National Christian Council of Korea has called upon Gen. Mark W. Clark, commander of the United Nations forces in Korea, and the United States Government "to take measures necessary to tighten up the discipline of some United Nations soldiers violating the rights of Korean civilians."

An issue of $5,000,000 of bonds of the Caddo, La., Parish School District, due from 1954 to 1973, was sold yesterday to a syndicate headed by National City Bank of New York at a bid of 100.127 for 4's, 2's, 2 1/4's, 2 1/2's and 2 3/4's, an interest cost of 2.658 per cent.

The faculty of the General Theological Seminary, 175 Ninth Avenue, has backed its dean, the Rev. Dr. Lawrence Rose, in his protest against the exclusion of Negroes from the Theological Seminary of the University of the South, it was disclosed today.

Once upon a time an opera house was an appurtenance of a seigneur, a court. In little bijou theatres, often within the enclosures of royal or noble estates, in Florence and Mantua, in Rome, Vienna, Venice and Prague, lords and ladies "broke talk off," as Browning puts it, to listen to music and watch the masquers.
PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 14 -- A last-period rally enabled Pennsylvania's varsity basketball team to come from behind and defeat Princeton, 55 -- 53, in Dillon Gymnasium tonight.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 14 -- Maintenance of adequate incentives to induce continuity of management growth in all branches of society is this nation's most imperative need, Crawford H. Greenewalt, president of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., declared here tonight.

For the first time since another distinguished Republican, Gen. Charles G. Dawes, refused to wear knee breeches at Buckingham Palace in 1929, official sartorial tradition has been broken -- this time by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower.

A gold Cornelius Amory Pugsley medal was presented yesterday to Miss Harlean James, executive secretary of the American Planning and Civic Association, Washington, at the annual meeting of the American Scenic and Historic Preservation Society at Federal Hall Memorial, Wall and Nassau Streets.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Announced United States battle casualties -- killed, wounded and missing -- in Korea reached 128,721 today, an increase of 191 since last week.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Australia's Frank Sedgman evened the score with Jack Kramer in their pro tennis tour at three matches apiece in whipping the American star in straight sets tonight, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 4.

The closing session of the United States Brewers Foundation's convention at the Waldorf - Astoria Hotel yesterday heard praise for the hop growers and dealers for terminating their agreement with the Government on production and rejecting suggestions for Government support prices.

Uniform yacht racing rules virtually the world over were ratified last night. Henry S. Morgan, president of the North American Yacht Racing Union, reported at the annual meeting in the New York Yacht Club that a full agreement of the verbiage of the regulations had been reached with the International Yacht Racing Union of England.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -- President Truman says that "nobody can deliver the labor vote" in this country and that is "a very good thing for democracy."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Department of Defense stand against segregated schools on military posts was disclosed tonight in an exchange of correspondence made public by Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota.

Bette Davis, starring here in the musical stage revue, "Two's Company," will make a guest appearance on the "Arthur Murray Party" program over the Du Mont television network on Sunday, Feb. 8, at 10 P. M. The actress' only appearance on television was with Jimmy Durante last April.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Two hours after he had appeared voluntarily before a Federal grand jury here today, Representative John L. McMillan, Democrat of South Carolina, was indicted by the panel on a charge of violating a law that prohibits members of Congress from making or having an interest in a contract with the government.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 14 -- Over the surprise opposition of one Deputy, a joint session of the Yugoslav Parliament formally named and emotionally acclaimed Marshal Tito President of the Federal People's Republic of Yugoslavia today in accordance with the revised Constitution.

PARIS. Jan. 14 -- Announcing a Cabinet decision today to submit the European Army Treaty and the German peace contract to Parliament "without delay," Rene Mayer, the new French Premier, appealed to "international opinion" to trust him to get the army treaty ratified in a form that would allay French apprehensions.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 14 -- Army's basketball team staged a fourth-period rally to defeat Yale, 70 to 67, in the Field House today. The victory was the cadets' fifth in six starts. Yale has lost eight of twelve.

Now that thousands of newcomers are being added each year to the sport of pleasure boating, one of the serious problems is getting elbow room. This means mooring space. There are no garages in boating. There are yacht basins, called, in recent years, marinas.

A girl from West Germany sent $2 to a friend in Kansas and requested that it be turned over to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. This gift was among the twenty-nine received yesterday, adding $235 to the fund and bringing the total for the forty-first annual appeal to $382,981.23 from 13,117 contributors.

NEW CITY, N. Y., Jan. 14 -- An attack on long-standing methods of jury selection in Rockland County was made today by the Rockland County Bar Association, and was seconded immediately by a local post of the Jewish War Veterans of the United States.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 14 -- The West German Government is far from happy about France's decision to clarify the European Army Treaty through the negotiation of additional protocols, but it is willing to discuss them as long as this does not delay ratification of the treaty here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Arthur E. Summerfield, chairman of the Republican National Committee, received prompt and unanimous approval from the Senate Post Office and Civil Service Committee today to become Postmaster General in the Administration of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect.

ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- The State Council of the Congress of Industrial Organizations backed up today Governor Dewey's proposal for an investigation of the state's courts and endorsed the plan of the Board of Regents for operating eleven television stations for educational programs.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 14 -- Anyone looking for an explanation of the anxiety in Teheran for a settlement of Iran's oil dispute with Britain can find it in the facts and Figures of the country's economic situation.

ROME, Jan. 14 -- The 25,000-ton Andrea Doria, described as the fastest, most modern and most sumptuous liner built in Europe since World War II, sailed from Genoa at 11 o'clock this morning on the first lap of her maiden voyage to New York.

NEWARK, Jan. 14 -- The Most Rev. Thomas A. Boland, former Bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Paterson, was enthroned yesterday morning as the second Archbishop of the Archdiocese of Newark, which this year is celebrating its 100th anniversary.

ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- The Legislature was asked today to approve measures that would prevent a repetition of the double tragedy early last month at Hicksville, L. I., where two small children died while playing around an unprotected sump excavated in connection with a housing development.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 14 -- Current methods of handling juvenile delinquents in the United States could be improved by a wiser use of children's courts, better treatment and "a juridical approach," in the opinion of Dr. Paul W. Tappan, Professor of Sociology at New York University.

RIGHT now the man in search of outdoor activity does not have too many choices. He can follow the hounds in pursuit of rabbits or foxes, fish through the ice, shiver through a day on the codfish banks, or abandon the local scene in favor of a trip to Florida.

Reporting on operations of the Mergenthaler Linotype Corporation at the annual meeting here yesterday, Martin M. Reed, president, told stockholders that larger sales of its wholly owned subsidiary, Davidson Corporation, were expected to take up a slack in civilian and military orders for the parent company in the fiscal year ending next Sept. 30.

For the first time this season the Broadway Blues can boast of the tandem achievement. Bill Cook's skaters, showing a reckless aggressiveness that took their rivals by complete surprise, blasted out a 3-to-2 triumph over the Detroit Red Wings in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.

The first new witness in the second perjury trial of William W. Remington, former Department of Commerce economist, told a jury of eleven men and one woman yesterday that he had seen the 35-year-old defendant at a Communist meeting in the fall and winter of 1935-36 at Newport, N. H.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14 -- Grain and soybean futures showed more capacity than expected for holding the rallies of late yesterday, which encouraged the belief that the liquidating activities have run their course, possibly culminating in the early declines of Tuesday. Instead of increasing pressure on small rallies, there was a broader demand on moderate price depressions.
TOKYO, Thursday, Jan. 15 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,495, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Thursday, Korean time:

Donations of blood at the city's three blood centers continue below the quota of 900 pints a day set by the Red Cross for January. Collections on Tuesday amounted to 656 pints at the Manhattan and Brooklyn centers and at four mobile units.

Those who, like the woman in the joke, never throw anything away -- including pieces of string labeled "too short to be used" -- may find uses for and some amusement in a new book called the "Dictionary of Discards."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (UP) -- The American Telephone and Telegraph Company today was authorized to spend an $11,500,000 reserve to improve interstate earnings of Bell System telephone companies.

Writers in various media, and producers and directors in the fields of radio, television and motion pictures, whose works in the last year were selected for "reflecting the power for good" throughout the world, received awards of bronze medallions from the Christophers yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The Federal Civil Service has, within the past fifteen years, evolved from a simple policing agency of the Government to one including the role of central personnel arm of the Executive Branch of the Government, Robert Ramspeck, former Civil Service Commissioner, reported today to President Truman.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Lester Luther, former United States Attorney for Kansas, and Nicholas F. Lopes, a former Department of Justice official, were indicted by a Federal grand jury here today on charges of conspiracy to defraud the Government.

BERLIN, Jan. l4 -- Anti-Communist groups in West Berlin, infiltrating one of the key plants in East Germany's Five-Year Plan, have been undermining the workers' morale and persuading them to sabotage large transformers due to be sent to the Soviet Union.

One of the nation's best known railroad executives, John M. Fitzgerald, vice chairman of the Eastern Railroad Presidents Conference Committee of Public Relations, retired yesterday after a railroad career stretching back more than sixty-two years.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Ezzard Charles, former world heavyweight champion, won a ninth-round technical knockout over stubborn, young Wes Bascom tonight in their ten-round nationally televised fight from the St. Louis Arena.

The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States had the "greatest year" in its ninety-three-year history in 1952, Thomas I. Parkinson, president, said yesterday in a preliminary report to the board of directors. New ordinary life insurance business, he said, totaled $910,000,000, an increase of $128,000,000 over 1951, and the highest total ever recorded in a single year.

Arturo Toscanini and the N.B.C. Symphony Orchestra will perform Beethoven's "Missa Solemnis" at Carnegie Hall on March 28 at 5:45 P. M. This will be Mr. Toscanini's final Saturday afternoon concert of the season with the symphony and the entire performance will be broadcast over the network.

Walter Dukes was the difference last night as undefeated Seton Hall, stretching its winning streak to sixteen games, knocked Fordham from the unbeaten ranks by a 69-62 score before a roof-raising capacity crowd of 3,000 at Fordham's campus gymnasium.
Columbia's basketball team won its eighth straight game last night, defeating the University of Connecticut, 71 -- 59, in the Lions' University Hall gymnasium.

In November THE NEW YORK TIMES in a leading article on the H-bomb said that an international body to exercise control over such a weapon "would have to have powers approaching those of a world government." It continued: "We move toward the supreme crisis of our generation * * * in the face of such a deadly peril it is incredible that any nation or group of men should reject any possible preventive."

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Jan. 14 -- A judge, his voice husky with emotion, ruled today that a nine-year-old boy raised by a devoted "father" actually was the long-sought kidnapped son of a dayton, Ohio, couple.

In November THE NEW YORK TIMES in a leading article on the H-bomb said that an international body to exercise control over such a weapon "would have to have powers approaching those of a world government." It continued: "We move toward the supreme crisis of our generation * * * in the face of such a deadly peril it is incredible that any nation or group of men should reject any possible preventive."

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Jan. 14 -- A judge, his voice husky with emotion, ruled today that a nine-year-old boy raised by a devoted "father" actually was the long-sought kidnapped son of a dayton, Ohio, couple.

The Republican platform, adopted last July 10, declared that while "primary responsibility" lies with the states "the Federal Government should take supplemental action * * * to oppose discrimination against race, religion or national origin." The Republicans promised "to prove our good faith" by federal action toward elimination of lynching and poll taxes, segregation in the District of Columbia, and by curtailment of "discriminatory employment practices."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Maj. Edith A. Aynes of the Army Nurse Corps reported today to Army Medical Headquarters here on her year's study of the utilization of nursing skills as Chief Nurse in the Japan Logistic Command.

Handel and Debussy, for musicians of the past centuries, Nikolai Nabokov and Ernest Toch, for contemporary composers, made the program of the concert of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, Charles Munch conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall. The modern works were both played for the first time in this city.
Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, held a long foreign policy conference yesterday with four of his top advisers, but withheld any news on the subjects they discussed.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Jan. 14 -- College football's costly two- platoon era, which introduced the gridiron specialist and bankrupted the football programs of many small colleges, came to a sudden end today.

Debutantes of this season, headed by the Misses Diane Damon and Barbara Warner and including the Misses Anne Lalor and Judith Lee Tompkins, are aiding in the plans for the entertainment known as the IKE Victory Ball to be held Tuesday night in the main ballroom and adjoining suites of the Plaza, simultaneously with the Inaugural Ball in Washington.

ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- Governor Dewey said today the new state budget would be made public this year in two sections, one covering state subsidies to local governments and the other details of the cost of other state government operations. It will be submitted to the Legislature, in accordance with the usual practice, as a single unit.

An experiment in rehabilitating a block of tenements in Harlem, where fundamentally sound buildings are lapsing into sub-standard condition for want of adequate repairs, was announced yesterday by State Housing Commissioner Herman Stichman. The cost was estimated at $250,000 to $750,000.

The American form of jurisprudence is better than the opinions of individuals, particularly when they assume to comment upon the value of the evidence presented in the Rosenberg case, as did Professor Urey and, by indirection, Professor Einstein.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson, in his final news conference as a member of the Truman Administration, declared today that the movement for unity in Western Europe was "the real vital force" of the mid- twentieth century.

Until by some miracle a civic leader appears with sufficient drive, magnetism, ability, common sense, integrity and love of his city and its people New Yorkers will continue to live lives of civic desperation. Even with a Mayor of such qualities the town would eventually awaken to the fact that the root of its troubles is an outmoded administrative organization of its city government.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- A mild ripple of Republican criticism, diluted by a little Democratic commendation, greeted President Truman's farewell Economic Report to Congress today.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Jan. 14 -- Scientists at the University of Michigan are preparing to match radioactive cesium 137, a by-product of the atomic furnace with an energy output equivalent to 1,500,000 volts, against cobalt 60 and conventional X-rays in a test of their effectiveness for cancer treatment.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Following is the text of President Truman's annual Economic Report submitted to Congress today: TO THE CONGRESS OF THE UNITED STATES:

The nine Soviet doctors accused in Moscow of a plot to kill political and military leaders by medical sabotage include the elite in the Soviet medical profession, men responsible for treating not only the highest Kremlin figures but also the highest foreign Communists who come to Moscow for medical treatment.

The Broadway premiere of the London comedy success. "The Love of Four Colonels," co-starring the husband and wife acting team of Rex Harrison and Lilli Palmer, takes place tonight at the Shubert Theatre at 8 o'clock.
Hughston M. McBain, chairman of the board of Marshall Field Co., Chicago department store, was honored last night "for distinguished contribution to American retailing."

The nation's stocks of gasoline last week increased 3,658,000 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the weekend they amounted to 140,674,000 barrels, compared with 137,016,000 a week earlier and 138,380,000 a year ago.

The nation's stocks of gasoline last week increased 3,658,000 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the weekend they amounted to 140,674,000 barrels, compared with 137,016,000 a week earlier and 138,380,000 a year ago.

Bankers' dollar acceptances outstanding in the United States last month hit the highest point since February, 1935. The increase of $13,386,000 in December lifted the total to $491,849,000, according to yesterday's report by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 14 -- Local friends and colleagues of Prof. Elis Berven, noted Swedish cancer specialist, now lecturing in India, are most skeptical regarding a report appearing in the Stockholm afternoon newspaper Aftonbladet to the effect that Professor Berven's mission to Moscow in January, 1948, concerned the late Andrei A. Zhdanov, who, it was said, was suffering from incurable cancer.

Jacques Abrams is a pianist with a buoyant spirit and a light, sure touch. As a result, his recital last night at Town Hall -- his first here in two years -- was both an agreeable and a refreshing experience.

The trial of thirteen Communist party leaders, charged with conspiracy to teach and advocate overthrow of the Government by force and violence, is expected to go to the jury today, after nine and one-half months.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, who made a campaign promise to end racial segregation in the District of Columbia, has scheduled a conference for today with the new chairmen of the House and Senate committees that handle legislation affecting the nation's capital.

John F. O'Connell, chairman of the State Liquor Authority, announced last night that it was not only urging Congress to reduce the Federal tax on alcoholic beverages, but was asking the State Legislature to "put teeth" in its own law to aid in the fight against illicit liquor.

A plan for the appointment of a city administrator -- an official who would relieve the Mayor of his power to select and control city commissioners and other department executives -- was put forward by the Citizens Union yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense-designate, told the Senate Armed Services Committee today that, in preparation for the job, he had severed all connections with the General Motors Corporation, except the ownership of stock valued at about $2,500,000.
A new approach for solving the city's transit crisis was offered yesterday by the Citizens Budget Commission.

Farewells to Winthrop W. Aldrich, who is retiring on Monday as chairman of the board to become United States Ambassador to Great Britain, marked the annual report of the Chase National Bank of the City of New York.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Jack Frank Sedgman defeated Kramer again tonight 6 -- 3, 7 -- 5, to take a 4-3 lead in their marathon of professional tennis.

The Football Rules Committee of the National Collegiate Athletic Association stirred considerable controversy by outlawing the two-platoon system. There hasn't been a hotter sports issue in years. It is sure to be belabored long and loudly.

Two locals of 3,500 school custodians went ahead yesterday with plans to strike on Monday despite the calling of a mediation session in the dispute for that day by the city's Division of Labor Relations.
A new look and a strong broom are needed to meet head-on the crisis that the North Atlantic Treaty Organization -- and United States policy -- face in Europe this year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The National Lead Company and various other companies were permanently enjoined by the Federal Trade Commission today from acquiring any ownership interest in any other concern making white lead pigment.

Several hours after a perjury indictment was filed yesterday in General Sessions against John Alu, a West Side waterfront figure who is charged with lying in closed hearings last summer before the State Crime Commission, he appeared at the commission's office and was placed under arrest.

A diver's story of his descents into the sea will be issued Feb. 4 by Harper entitled "The Silent World." The book was written by a French naval officer, Capt. J. Y. Cousteau, co-inventor of the Aqualung, a breathing, apparatus that enables men to survive at 306 feet below sea level.

PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 15 -- The proposal by six Ivy League undergraduate newspapers to strengthen the circuit in football and have each team play at least five league games a season received further support here today.

New York home cooks can set a tropical table even in the middle of January. From the Caribbean area each week arrive more than 1,000 tons of exotic warm-weather fruits and vegetables, largely brought into our port by the Bull Steamship Lines.
A capacity audience that included Igor Stravinsky, the composer, gathered at Carnegie Recital Hall last evening to hear the Harpsichord Quartet play its fourth concert of the season.
ATLANTA, Jan. 15 -- Contempt of court charges against two Atlanta Constitution editors who had been sentenced to twenty days in jail were dismissed today by the Georgia Supreme Court.
Rocky Marciano heard himself praised last night as an idol and an ideal of American youth, and the symbol of the way of life which makes America great among nations.

Charles H. Silver, vice president in charge of sales and a director of the American Woolen Company, has retired under the company's regular retirement program, it was announced yesterday. Mr. Silver joined American Woolen in 1907 as a salesman. In 1920 he was appointed assistant selling agent of the company and was responsible for the fabrication and the sale of the company's products to all branches of the women's apparel industry.
The "costume look" was featured in a resort collection shown to the press at Namm Loeser's yesterday. It will be shown to the public at a fashion show tomorrow at 11:30 A. M.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 15 -- The first known serious plot for the restoration of Nazi power in Germany has been broken by the British, who have arrested seven once prominent members of Hitler's National Socialist party.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Jan. 15 -- A conference of the South African Bureau of Racial Affairs, constituting the learned and scientific or pseudo scientific wing of the apartheid movement for separation of the races, voted a resolution today calling for the establishment of more universities for Negroes.

Fashions for southern climes provided attractive fare in Russeks' presentation yesterday at the Plaza Hotel. The cover-up theme in swim suits with some sort of a wrap or jacket took several chic expressions.

ALBANY, Jan. 15 -- A further increase of $90,000,000 in state aid to education, of which $30,000,000 would go to New York City, was proposed today in bills submitted to the Legislature by two Republicans with the backing of the State Educational Conference Board, a private organization representing teacher and parent groups.

MOSCOW, Jan. 15 -- The Government newspaper Izvestia renewed today the charge that "certain Soviet organs and their leaders" had been "infected" with gullibility or carelessness that permitted the alleged plot of nine doctors against Soviet leaders to develop for some time with impunity.

The State Board of Regents' proposal to establish a network of ten noncommercial educational television stations supported by public funds was bitterly attacked yesterday at a hearing before the Temporary State Commission on the Use of Television for Educational Purposes.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 15 (AP) -- Spartan Valor returned to racing today after being idle since September and won the $64,100 Tropical Handicap, closing feature of Tropical Park's forty two-day meeting.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 7 points higher to 1 point lower yesterday than on Wednesday after moderate trading.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 15 (UP) -- The Federal Reserve Board asked the United States Court of Appeals to uphold its order to Transamerica Corporation to break connections with most of the banks it owns.

Twenty-three gifts totaling $302 were received yesterday by the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund from as far away as California, Florida and Germany, as the forty-first appeal rose to $383,283.23 from 12,140 contributors.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The final report of President Truman's National Advisory Board on Mobilization Policy was filed today, together with dissents by a member representing labor and two members representing industry.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 15 -- The Brazilian Congress met today in special sesion to discuss ratification of a military assistance agreement with the United States that was signed ten months ago but is still unratified because of the determined opposition of Communist and nationalist elements.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Jan. 15 -- Seton Hall University, second ranked nationally, stretched its winning streak to seventeen in a row tonight with an 82-74 victory over the University off Dayton before 3,400 at the Seton Hall gymnasium.

It is not surprising that Marshal Tito was the only candidate for the Presidency of Yugoslavia. When the assembled members of the two houses of Parliament were formally asked if there were any other nominations their telltale answer was a burst of laughter. It is not surprising that Tito was elected 568 to 1.

PARIS, Jan. 15 -- Old Flemish paintings, village festivals and the flowered fields of the Netherlands have inspired Rose Valois to create colorful and youthful new bonnet shapes, reduced to a mere curved band framing the face and sitting lightly atop the head.

CHICAGO, Jan. 15 -- Choppy grain markets were the rule today, rallies meeting increased offerings. While there was good buying on setbacks, local operators were cautious in following upturns because of short covering.

BERLIN, Friday, Jan. 16 (UP) -- The official East German Communist newspaper Neues Deutschland announced today the arrest of the Soviet zone German Government's Foreign Minister, Georg Dertinger, as a "Western spy."

Dense fog closed in over New York yesterday, bringing air transportation to a standstill, slowing surface transportation to a crawl, and causing four harbor accidents. The Weather Bureau gave little hope that it would lift before noon today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- President Truman said today that the White House news conference was the direct line of communication between the people and the President and pleaded that his successor, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, preserve the practice.

In its first change of ownership in more than 60 years, the four-story house on lot 16 by 100 feet at 155 West Sixty-first Street has been sold by the Estate of Mary Reed Alhee to Harry Lebon in a deal negotiated by Arnold T. Milton, broker.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- A runaway passenger train plowed through steel and concrete barriers and crashed across the concourse of Union Station today in a spectacular wreck that injured at least forty-one persons. The Pennsylvania Railroad said the cause was an unexplained brake failure.

ROME, Jan. 15 -- In a public consistory held against the magnificent background of St. Peter's Basilica, Pope Pius this morning personally conferred the red hat upon seventeen of the twenty-four Cardinals he created in Monday's secret consistory.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (UP) -- Following is the timetable for the three-day inauguration program next week:

Austin S. Igleheart, president of General Foods Corporation, and Neil McElroy, president of Procter Gamble Co., took different views of the same subject last night. They spoke at a dinner session of the National Industrial Conference Board's 337th meeting in the Astor Hotel.
Following is the text of President Truman's address, his farewell as President, to the nation last night as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

The specter of another Nazi-Soviet conspiracy analogous to the Hitler-Stalin pact is rising on the European horizon as a result of what may prove to be more than an ominous coincidence. For it seems on the face of it more than mere coincidence that the Kremlin's open espousal of an anti-Semitic campaign has been followed by the discovery of a Nazi plot in Western Germany to overthrow the Adenauer Government.

Upon reading a dispatch from Paris concerning the recently completed meeting of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization I was slightly disturbed to read the statement attributed to Howland H. Sargeant, Assistant Secretary of State for Public Affairs, as spokesman for the United States delegation, where mention was made that "Mr. Sargeant placed particular stress on projects dealing with 'education for living in a world community' * * *."

Prices of Government securities improved to a slight extent all along the line yesterday in a trading session that ended before announcement of the increase in the discount rate of the New York and other Reserve District banks to 2 per cent.

Midnight Monday, March 16, will be this year's deadline for Federal income tax returns. This was announced yesterday by Harold B. A'Hearn, Director of Internal Revenue of the upper Manhattan district, which includes all of Manhattan north of Thirty-fourth Street.
The stock market again followed an irregular course yesterday.

Breaking the downtrend of the two previous weeks, commercial loans by New York banks advanced $33,000,000 last week. The rise, in which nine of the nineteen reporting Federal Reserve member banks participated, compares with an increase in the corresponding week last year of $96,000,000.

The letter from Anna M. Grass in THE TIMES of Jan. 5 criticizing Commissioner Moses' proposal to penalize the parents of children who willfully destroy city park property strikes a few illogical notes.

It shouldn't happen. The Metropolitan puts on its fifth "Don Giovanni" of the season, changes nearly the whole cast, with four principals singing their roles for the first time in the theatre, and has a different conductor for good measure.

December males of leading mail order and chain store companies showed an increase of 10.5 per cent over the volume for December, 1951, according to a compilation of forty-one companies made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Jan. 15 (AP) -- Tommy Bolt shot a six-under-par 66 today to take the lead at the end of the first 18 holes of the $10,000 San Diego open golf tournament.

BOAT owners apparently have much in common with the fishermen who encroach on their sport, for both are tempted by the miscellany of "gadgets" offered as a means of making the activity more interesting. The current boat show at Grand Central Palace provides plenty of this temptation -- for boatmen and anglers alike.

Miss Elizabeth T. Bentley, self-styled former Soviet spy courier, told a Federal Court jury under cross-examination yesterday that she had never been arrested, indicted or promised immunity for her testimony despite her activities as a member of the Communist party for a decade and service in its underground apparatus.

A resolution calling on the Welfare and Health Council of New York City to hold a public hearing on the question of accepting planned parenthood groups as members of the council is being circulated among the eighteen clergymen serving as advisers to the Planned Parenthood Committee of Mothers Health Centers.
TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 15 -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh met United States Ambassador Loy Henderson for the sixth time today to discuss a settlement of Iran's oil dispute with Britain.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The rivalry between supporters of Premier Mohammed Mossadegh and Ayatollah Sayed Abolghassem Kashani, Iran's powerful Moslem religious leader, flamed into angry words in Parliament and vicious fist fights in the spectators' gallery today.

Arthur M. Wirtz, dedicated to the arctic type of amusement since the early Nineteen Forties when he daringly converted the stage of the Center Theatre in Rockefeller Center into a frozen rostrum, has brought to New York another eye-pleasing edition of "The Hollywood Ice Revue."

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 15 -- Branding the Communist party as the "enemy of the Jewish people and traitor to our state," the executive of Israel's Federation of Labor (Histadrut) voted tonight to take the first steps toward expelling the representatives of the Communist party from all offices in the federation.

MOSCOW, Jan. 15 -- The well-known Soviet economist Eugene Varga has publicly admitted his errors and acknowledged his indebtedness to the "genius work of Comrade Stalin" in making clear to him the nature of faults in his work.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Following is an unofficial transcript of President Truman's final White House news conference, held today. Presidential press conference rules forbid direct quotation of the President except where authorized, so the President's answers are given in indirect discourse:

The Board of Education directed the public schools yesterday to begin each class day with the singing of the fourth stanza of the patriotic hymn, "America," as an act of reverence intended to help strengthen moral and spiritual values.

An old New Yorker who wasn't born that way, but has what might be called squatter rights to the title, is interested in what they say is going to happen to the little Appellate Court building down on the northeast corner of Madison Square.
The bus strike went into its third week yesterday with all settlement efforts as motionless as the buses.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Following is a list of persons injured today in the train accident at Union Station:

A jurist, an educator and a clergyman, speaking last night at an informal forum on religion's responsibility for public morals, called for a strengthening of religion in the lives of individuals. The forum was held at the Central Synagogue, Lexington Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street.

Events today: Philharmonic-Symphony, George Szell conducting, Arthur Grumiaux, violinist, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P. M.: "La Gioconda," Metropolitan Opera, 8; Jeanette MacDonald, soprano, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Concert Choir, Town Hall. 8:30; Chamber music program, Juilliard Concert Hall, 8:30.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Executives of the Cleveland Pneumatic Tool Company disclosed to the company's employes today a plan to have them buy the company for $11,800,000 through their own profit-sharing trusts.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Abandonment of price controls at this time would cost the nation a minimum of $3,000,000,000 in the coming year, Joseph Freehill, head of the Office of Price Stabilization, told a news conference today.

The series of short blasts on the train horn that Engineman Henry W. Brower sounded yesterday when the brakes failed on the Federal Express, warning passengers aboard the train of the impending crash and allowing Union Station personnel time to flee from the danger area, are standard procedure to signal danger, a Pennsylvania Railroad spokesman said yesterday.

The departure of "Be Your Age." which arrived Wednesday night at the Forty-eighth Street, was quickly decided yesterday when the reviews appeared. The unanimous set of adverse notices is causing the Mary Orr-Reginald Denham farce to shut down after the fifth performance tomorrow night.

Statistics of the November election show that the result was a personal victory for Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, President-elect, and Richard M. Nixon, Vice President-elect, Senator Irving M. Ives declared last night. He added, however, that the election of the Republican national candidates did not indicate a basic change in preponderant American thinking.

Recorded dramatic and operatic productions formerly presented by the British Broadcasting Corporation will be broadcast here by radio station WNBC in a special series on four successive Saturdays, beginning, tomorrow from 2 to 5 P. M.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- General. Eisenhower:.will name Robert C. Sprague, an electronics manufacturer of iVilliams.town,, and North .Adams, lVfass., to be Under Secretary of the Air Force. He will succeed loswell L. Gilpatric, a New York attorneY.

LONDON, Jan. 15 -- The issue of freedom of the British press was injected today into the dispute between United States motion picture companies and Lord Beaverbrook's mass circulation newspapers over "caustic movie criticisms."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that department store sales in the week ended Jan. 10 were 3 per cent below sales in the corresponding week of last year. The following lists percentage changes from like periods a year ago:

VIENNA, Friday, Jan. 16 -- Following the arrest here of Otto Verber and Kurt L. Ponger on espionage charges, Walter Lauber, naturalized American who, like Verber and Ponger, was registered as studying at Vienna University under the G. I. Bill of Rights, was detained as a material witness, as were an unidentified number of others.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The House Ways and Means Committee agreed today to continue under Republican direction a subcommittee investigation of scandals in the Internal Revenue Bureau.

A plan of reorganization under which the Pancoastal Oil Corporation, C. A., will divide its Venezuelan and United States assets and place them into two new corporations, subject to stockholder approval at a special meeting on Jan. 31, was announced yesterday.
GUATEMALA, Jan. 15 -- Thirty-two members of Guatemala's unicameral Congress of fifty-six members will be elected in three days of voting that starts tomorrow.

The Kings County District Attorney, Miles F. McDonald, notes in his annual report that the present trend in crime throws great responsibilities upon the public prosecutor as the chief law enforcement agent of his county and also in criminal investigations.

To many Americans it may be a surprise to learn that during some months more Norwegian ships enter New York than American. When, therefore, Norway says that the McCarran Act is not bad, it is news. A front page article to this effect is to be found in a recent issue of Nordisk Tidende, the largest Norwegian language paper outside of Norway.

From all indications the approaching birth of Lucille Ball's child, both in real life and in the script of "I Love Lucy," has engendered as much public interest as anything since the days when the world stood still every evening to hear "Amos 'n' Andy" on the radio.

Commodity prices moved in narrow range yesterday on the New York exchanges with activity continuing light. Closings were irregular and there were no sales in any of the metals. Hides, cottonseed oil, lead and zinc were higher. Cocoa, potatoes, coffee and wool ended lower and rubber, sugar and soybean oil closed mixed.
LONDON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- An official source said tonight that the United States and Britain had agreed to open the door for Pakistan to enter the long-projected Middle East Defense Organization.

ALBANY, Jan. 15 -- New York State today asked the Appellate Division, Third Department, to rule that it had sovereign rights to Lake George, which, it held, were being violated and interfered with by a 107-foot power dam across the Ticonderoga River at the northern end of the sheet of water.

The Board of Estimate appropriated yesterday $190,000 to be used by the Municipal Civil Service Commission to pay the expenses of a classification bureau under mandate to develop a career and salary plan for city employes. The new bureau, which will be headed by Sidney M. Stern, a career employe of the commission, already is being organized.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- A recommendation that the Small Defense Plants Administration be continued beyond next June 30 and that its authority to aid small plants in getting defense contracts agency.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Two former United States soldiers, both naturalized citizens, were accused of spying for the Soviet Union in an indictment announced today by the Department of Justice.

It's a myth that newspapers and magazines of the country have little, if any, interest in publishing fashion news of men's clothing and furnishings, it was asserted yesterday by F. Eugene Ackerman, president of the Wool Bureau, Inc.

More severe treatment of waterfront thieves and pilferers was urged yesterday by Benn Barber, president of the Security Bureau, Inc. He contended that prosecution had a salutary effect in reducing the incidence of such crimes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Jan. 10 totaled 688,232 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 125,147 cars or 22.2 per cent more than for the preceding week, 56,478 cars or 7.6 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 94,783 cars or 12.1 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

A special group of Young Colony fashions made of M. W. Thomas cottons was presented yesterday by B. Altman. These interesting cottons, woven on silk looms, had a crisp, opaque quality that made them practical for early spring as well as summer. Informal fashion shows will be presented to the public Monday between 11:30 A. M. and 3 P. M. on the store's third floor.
RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 15 -- The Asian Socialists as a group today virtually rejected neutralism in the world struggle between com-own selfish interests."

Aristotle Socrates Onassis, youthful, handsome proprietor of ninety-one ships, offices in six countries and homes in Sutton Place. Paris, Antibes, Athens, and Montevideo, has added a new and glamorous property to his holdings, but for an unglamorous purpose.

A new set-up in the city's police courts, announced last night by Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh, puts into a special division the "social problems courts" to permit an expansion of their crime-prevention services.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 15 -- Scheduled showings of Charles Chaplin's new picture "Limelight" at three local houses operated by Fox West Coast Theatres have been canceled under threat of picketing action by the American Legion, it was confirmed today by Lewis K. Gough, national commander of the Legion.

In his fight to escape deportation, Thomas Luchese, also known as Three Finger Brown, asserted yesterday that he had not practiced fraud or concealment when he received his citizenship papers. In answer to the Government's charge filed in the Brooklyn Federal Court, the 52-year-old ex-convict insisted that he had given a truthful record of his criminal background before he received his citizenship papers in Newark on Jan. 25, 1943.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (UP) -- Fire Chief Willard Sutton and about forty-five other persons, mostly firemen, were injured today when an explosion wrecked a local tire and battery shop where they were fighting a blaze. The owner, William O'Shinsky, who suffered minor injuries in the blast, estimated the dameg at $100,000.

The refreshing emphasis of the theme "Trade Not Aid" as the keystone of American economic relationships with the free countries of the world should be supported by prompt action in the Congress to prepare for this goal. One of the foremost obstacles to the development of a sound trade relationship is the so-called "Buy American Act."

Consumers Power Company is offering holders of its common stock rights to subscribe to 617,669 new shares at $35 a share until Jan. 30 on the basis of one new share for each ten held. A nationwide syndicate of investment houses headed by Morgan Stanley Co. is underwriting the transaction.

The popularity of an alien exchange student who gave up his books for a prize ring career resulted in the conviction late Wednesday night in Federal Court of a former steward aboard the liner America for smuggling the alien into this country.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Harry S. Truman bade his official farewell tonight to the American people, whose national destinies he has had a large share in directing for almost eight years as President of the United States.

The United States citizen must be concerned with the conservation of both the material resources and the spiritual heritage of the nation, Paul G. Hoffman, president of the Ford Foundation, declared here last night.

An exhibition in memory of the late Gertrude Lawrence will open at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue at 103d Street, with a special preview for members and guests on Tuesday, Jan. 27, from 3 to 7 P.M. John Mason Brown, author and critic, will deliver a brief address.
The Board of Estimate gave a reprieve yesterday to the City Council's anti-vandalism bill by voting to reconsider the measure after it had failed of passage by a vote of 8 to 8.

TOKYO, Friday, Jan. 16 -- The United Nations Command charged yesterday that the Communists had used the immunity of convoys purportedly supplying the needs of the Red truce delegation at Panmunjom to bolster their war effort on the western front in Korea.

The attractions of individual motor transportation drew at least 15,000 visitors to the automotive exhibition which opened yesterday at the Chrysler International Automobile Salon, 405 Lexington Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Charles Sawyer, retiring Secretary of Commerce, asserted today that he was leaving office confident that an era of good business was ahead for the country. He is scheduled to turn over his post on Tuesday to Sinclair Weeks, Secretary of Commerce-designate.
New examples of rattan furniture, which today leads an indoor as well as an outdoor life, may be found at the Grand Central Wicker Shop, 217 East Forty-second Street.

The Citizens Union executive committee makes public today a stimulating and practical idea for improving the government of New York City. It calls for the appointment of a city administrator by the Mayor, with the advice and consent of the Board of Estimate after public hearing.

The American Museum of Natural History has found contributors of large sums of money to be almost as extinct as the dinosaurs whose mounted skeletons inhabit its halls. As a result, the institution's eighty-third annual report points out, a broader base of gifts from private, individuals is needed.
LONDON, Jan. 15 -- Newspaper reaction to the arrest of seven former Nazi leaders by British authorities in West Germany stressed two points, showing evidence of Foreign Office "guidance."

TAEGU, Korea, Jan. 15 -- Today, on the seventh anniversary of the Republic of Korea Army, Gen. James A. Van Fleet, the Eighth Army commander, high ranking members of his staff and Gen. Mark W. Clark, the Supreme United Nations chief, paid it the highest compliments.
Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower will leave New York by special train in midafternoon Sunday for Washington, where he will await his inauguration Tuesday as President of the United States.

STRASBOURG, France, Jan. 15 -- After a heated all-day session, members of the General Affairs Committee agreed tonight to recommend adoption by the Council of Europe's Consultative Assembly of the draft proposal for a European political constitution.

Outfielders Carl Furillo, Dick Williams and Don Thompson, along with Clem Labine, righthanded pitcher, were signed by the Dodgers yesterday. Vice President Buzzie Bavasi now has sixteen reasonably contented players under contract.

The striking bus workers are seeking a forty-hour week with no cut in the pay they used to get for working forty-four to forty-eight hours, with five to nine hours of guaranteed overtime. The old basic wage ranged from $1.66 to $1.73 1/2% an hour.

The Board of Estimate was thrown into an uproar yesterday when the question was raised whether the new Republican Congress might reduce Federal housing appropriations and thereby block some city projects, notably the proposed $26,000,000 General Grant low-rent housing near Columbia University.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 15 -- Coast Guard officers, on instructions from Vice Admiral Merlin O'Neill, Coast Guard commandant in Washington, questioned members of the crew of the Matson liner Lurline on its arrival here today about charges that "poor security risks" were boarding ship here to intimidate crewmen.

CHICAGO, Jan. 15 -- Arrangements were made in the du Pont anti-trust trial today which will permit incoming staff of the Department of Justice to take a long look at the case before the defense opens.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Benjamin V. Cohen, United States representative on the United Nations Disarmament Commission, declared today that all nations had an "equal stake" in achieving world-wide disarmament, "for at stake is the survival of our common humanity."
The United States tea industry and the three major tea-producing countries -- India, Ceylon and Indonesia -- agreed yesterday to spend $1,500,000 annually to promote the sale of tea here.

MANIZALES, Colombia, Jan. 15 -- Statistics regarding the value and the extent of land ownership by the Roman Catholic Church in Colombia were revealed here today, and contrary to widespread belief they indicated the church had comparatively small holdings.
BERLIN, Jan. 15 -- All streetcar traffic between East and West Berlin was halted tonight in what could be the first step in a Communist effort to completely split the city in two.

The term "Miracle Fiber" in relation to new synthetic textiles should be banned, according to Carl A. Setterstrom, sales manager of the textile fibers division of the Carbide and Carbon Chemicals Company.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- During the week ended Jan. 14, member bank reserves decreased $242,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The Secretary of State, Dean Acheson, will give a luncheon for President Truman, his Cabinet and other high Administrative officials Tuesday immediately after the inauguration of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower as the new President.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 15 -- Frank G. Clement, 32-year-old former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, was sworn in as Governor of Tennessee today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The attention of the delegates to the nineteenth annual meeting of the American Society of Photogrammetry was turned to the cold North today as a panel discussion took up the problems of aerial photography in the Arctic.
A club providing recreational facilities for 1,000 seamen a day opened yesterday at Casablanca, French Morocco, according to Otho J. Hicks, executive director of the United Seamen's Service.

The case of thirteen Communist party leaders, charged with conspiracy to teach and advocate overthrow of the Government by force and violence, was submitted to a jury of six men and six women in Federal Court here at 2:23 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

BOSTON, Jan. 15 -- The Rev. Leonard Feeney, superior of the Slaves of the Immaculate Heart of Mary, a religious group he founded in 1949 after the outbreak of a controversy over Roman Catholic dogma, said yesterday that he had received letters purporting to summon him to Rome to face charges.

Winter greens from the South are in abundant supply this week- end. Dandelion greens, collards and turnip tops along with Hanover salad -- a leafy green plant that is a member of the cabbage family but not as strong in flavor -- have joined with broccoli rabe, escarole and curly endive to lift market stalls out of the winter doldrums.
ALBANY, Jan. 15 -- The State Board of Law Examiners announced today that 506 of the 1,249 applicants for admission to tthe bar had passed the examination held Nov. 5 and 6.

Rising temperature -- some call it the "January thaw" -- struck the northeastern areas yesterday. However, with the major resorts covered With deep snow and a forecast of winter weather for tomorrow, the week-end skiing should range from fair to good generally.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- In answer to widespread criticism that the public schools of the country are irreligious, Hollis L. Caswell, dean of the Teachers College, Columbia University, declared here today that after twenty years of close observation he could find nothing to support the charge.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board today approved an increase in the interest rates on loans to banks to 2 per cent, effective tomorrow morning. The old discount rate was 1 3/4 per cent.

A General Sessions jury of eight men and four women, plus two male alternates, was selected yesterday for the perjury trial of William (Bill) Spivey, former University of Kentucky All-American basketball player.

BOSTON, Jan. 15 (UP) -- Detroit's mechanical masters of hockey, scoring in every period, handed Boston the third shutout in their rivalry this season with a 4-0 victory before 6,559 Boston Garden fans tonight.

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- Industrial shares led more confident stock markets today. A small increase in demand for industrials, coinciding with the scarcity of stock, sent prices up by one Shilling (14 cents) or more.

With increased capital investment the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and its associated Bell System companies set new records in 1952. Net income of A. T. T., as parent concern of the Bell System, for the year amounted to $358,310,000, or $10.09 a capital share, compared with a net of $326,944,708, or $10.54 a share on fewer shares outstanding, in the previous year.

Richard H. Balch, recently appointed chairman of the Democratic State Committee, presented last night a program aimed at continuing the Democratic party as a "liberal" force in state and national politics.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Hungarian newspapers said today that the dangers "of hostile undermining activities" on behalf of the American Joint Distribution Committee, Jewish welfare organization, were much more imminent in Hungary than in the Soviet Union.
FORT MEADE, Md., Jan. 15 (UP) -- A soldier convicted in Korea of falling asleep while on guard duty was acquitted today at his second trial here and said he wanted to "begin all over" in the Army.

The Naval Commander of the Eastern Sea Frontier, Vice Admiral Walter S. DeLany, will retire Feb. 1 after forty-five years of active service, Third Naval District headquarters announced yesterday. He will be succeeded by Vice Admiral Laurance T. DuBose, now Chief of Naval Personnel.

TRENTON, Jan. 15 -- Paul L. Troast, chairman of the New Jersey Turnpike Authority and head of the Troast Mahoney Contracting Company of Passaic, filed nominating petitions today as a Republican candidate for Governor.

" THERE is nothing in nature to dictate that the world has got to be agreeable." This irrefutable statement is made by Sir Charles Galton Darwin in his "The Next Million Years,"* a learned and challenging book, which foresees a future for mankind that will be disagreeable indeed. Of course, as Sir Charles cheerfully admits, no one ever worries about the future more than a hundred years hence.

MELBOURNE, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Ken Rosewall's upset victory over Vic Seixas of Philadelphia in the semifinal round of the Australian tennis championships, today left two Aussies to fight it out for the title and raised hopes that the Davis Cup remain Down Under at least another year.

TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 15 (AP) -- Mary Lena Faulk, amateur from Thomasville, Ga., equaled men's par of 70 over the Palma Ceia course today for a four-stroke in the first round of the Tampa Women's Open Tournament.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 15 -- The programs of international cooperation represented in the United Nations Technical Assistance Administration will reach their highest degree of effectiveness only when they are planned "for years and decades ahead," rather than from year to year, David Owen, the executive chairman of the body, says in a foreword to a review of operations in a dozen countries, released today.

Some slight solace was seen in the fact that Maureen Connolly of San Diego, United States and Wimbledon champion, and Julie Sampson of San Marino, Calif., are cleaning up in their division. They entered the finals in both women's singles and doubles.

VIENNA, Jan. 15 -- The Czechoslovak Ministry of the Interior issued an order today canceling the ration cards of private tradesmen, including artisans, and their families; kulaks (prosperous farmers) and their families; former members of the capitalist classes, and pensioned former officers and civil servants.

Mr. Truman stepped into the Presidency on a dark April evening nearly eight years ago, a stunned and apprehensive man. He will step out of it next Tuesday much more confident, much more mature, but still, if one judges by his late interviews and by such speeches as he delivered last night, anxious about his place in history.

Car and truckwise, New York is not getting the maximum use of its streets and obtains less for its traffic dollar than many other big cities. The Traffic Department is a municipal stepchild and some of the improvements made by the agency have come in spite of, rather than with, the whole- hearted backing of top city officials.

ALBANY, Jan. 15 -- Calling the present alcoholic beverage control law "a patchwork of repealers and amendments." Assemblyman Anthony P. Savarese Jr. Republican of Queens, today urged a recodification of the law by a joint legislative committee.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 15 -- A secret ballot of 9,500 striking employes of the Philadelphia Transportation Company will be taken Saturday to determine whether the "wildcat" walkout should be continued or annulled.

The level of industrial construction in the last six months has been at a record for the post-war period, J. J. O'Donnell, president of the National Constructors Association, told the group's annual meeting at the Commodore Hotel yesterday.

BERLIN, Jan. 15 -- Four leaders of Jewish community organizations in the Soviet zone of Germany have fled to West Berlin with their families and associates, according to the West German news agency D. P. A., which said the group numbered twenty-five persons.

THE scuttling of the two-platoon system by the Football Rules Committee of the National Collegiate Athletic Association is the best thing that has happened to the gridiron game since the abolition of the flying wedge. It must be confessed, however, that the action was totally unexpected and caught the coaches with their guards (their running guards, no doubt) down.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 15 -- The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences today was faced with a new financial crisis following a decision by four of the eight major companies not to participate in underwriting the cost of the "Oscar" award ceremonies, scheduled to be held here on March 19.

More than thirty representatives of Jewish religious and civic organizations called yesterday for a revision of the Penal Law to permit Jewish merchants to conduct business on Sunday. The requests were made during an all-day session conducted by the New York State Joint Legislative Committee on the Sabbath Law held in the Bar Association Building, 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

Arthur Grumiaux, who played Mozart and Ravel last night with the Philharmonic-Symphony, was making his first appearance with that organization. The young violinist confirmed previous impressions about his talent. His Mozart had a lyric grace; a little oversweet, perhaps, but well-proportioned.

MOSCOW, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The case of the nine doctors accused of plotting to shorten the lives of Soviet leaders was taken up today by Komsomolskaya Pravda as an object lesson on the dangers from internal enemies left over from the treason trials of the 1930's.

MOSCOW, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The case of the nine doctors accused of plotting to shorten the lives of Soviet leaders was taken up today by Komsomolskaya Pravda as an object lesson on the dangers from internal enemies left over from the treason trials of the 1930's.

Being an actor, Peter Ustinov knows how to write for actors. And this is the principal virtue of "The Love of Four Colonels," which opened at the Shubert last evening. Lilli Palmer and Rex Harrison give excellent performances in Mr. Ustinov's intellectual charade.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee unanimously approved John Foster Dulles today to be the new Secretary of State and recommended that the Senate give instant confirmation next Tuesday when the appointment was formally sent up.

The Dow Chemical Company, in the six months ended last Nov. 30 increased its sales over the corresponding period a year before, but earnings were slightly lower, according to the semi-annual report issued yesterday.

0ut front an enormously attractive National Motor Boat Show is thronging Grand Central Palace during this week of unseasonably good weather. But back of the scenes worries over the future of this popular 48-year-old show that pays handsome dividends to its member-exhibitors and returns additional profits to the sponsoring association, are causing great concern.

Regulation of inventory fluctuations by retailers to prevent overbuying in boom times and under-buying in a period of economic stress was urged yesterday as a means of stabilizing the nation's economy.

VIENNA, Jan. 16 (AP) -- A German-born veteran of the United States Army's Intelligence Service is among several persons held for questioning about the operations of a Soviet spy ring, United States officials said tonight. He is Ernest Tislowitz, 40 years old.

ALBANY, Jan. 16 -- Licenses for a record high of 158,502 drivers were suspended or revoked during 1952, the State Motor Vehicle Commissioner, James R. Macduff, reported today. Included in the total were 1,868 suspensions or revocations resulting from New York's point system" for catching up with bad-record motorists. During 1951, there were 136,306 suspensions or revocations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Some Republican Senators expect the party's powerful new recruits on the Foreign Relations Committee to bring to the Senate a degree of influence over making foreign policy it has not known in many years.

CAIRO, Jan. 16 -- Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib, Premier of Egypt, tonight dissolved all political parties, confiscated their funds and announced a three-year transitional period following the discovery of a plot to overthrow his Government.

LONDON, Jan. 16 -- Industrial shares again attracted the most attention on the stock markets today, prices responding with widespread rises to a continued, though) small, demand. Store shares were particularly prominent on Woolworth's higher dividend, and were followed by shipping shares.

A Commission on Asian and Far Eastern Affairs has been set up by the International Chamber of Commerce to parallel the work of its European commission in improving national economies and developing a greater flow of world trade.

Proceeds of a gift of fifty-five shares of North American Cement Corporation Class A common stock from a donor who wished to remain anonymous brought $988.28 to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund yesterday.
MELBOURNE, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The 18-year-old Australian wonder boys of big tennis -- Ken Rosewall and Lewis Hoad -- today became the youngest Australians ever to take the national doubles title.
