I too have read the record of the trial of the Rosenbergs and am amazed by Prof. Harold C. Urey's letter in the issue of Jan. 8. It is because of my deep concern that the process of reason applied to evidence should lead to such varying results that I am writing to point out what convinced me in my reading of the testimony.

Two employes at the New York headquarters of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, tentatively assigned to White House staff jobs, are the subjects of unfavorable reports by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and as a result their job assignments will be canceled.

Ten-year-old Lynn Patricia Finnegan, who weighs fifty-nine pounds and admits to being "forty-eight inches tall," won the Middle Atlantic juvenile ladies figure-skating championship at Iceland, atop Madison Square Garden, yesterday.

This nation's top athletes in training and a sizable coterie of foreign Olympians will have their first 1953 fling at banked-track racing tonight. Their assembly point is the annual games of the Massachusetts Knights of Columbus in the Boston Garden.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of use to homemakers:

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, made his farewells yesterday as president of Columbia University with an uncompromising stand against "traitors" in education and a vigorous defense of academic freedom based upon integrity.

Former Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois arrived at La Guardia Airport on an American Airlines plane from Chicago at 8:45 P. M. yesterday and left immediately for the home of his former wife's sister, Mrs. Ralph Hines of 237 East Sixty-first Street.

There was considerable noise issuing last night from the roof and penthouse of the St. Regis Hotel, but it wasn't the kind of singing that had been advertised in advance. It was just Wall Street's thin red line of graying financiers making an annual pass at the fountain of youth.
Two members of the notorious Anastasia family were central figures yesterday in separate incidents linked to the current waterfront crime inquiry.

A pair of 17-year-old girls, acting on the advice of a priest, confessed late yesterday afternoon that they had committted an assault and robbery two weeks ago for which two of their friends had been arrested.
The following books of a religious or an inspirational nature have been issued recently:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The House committee assignments announced today included the following:
ALBANY, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The following winter sports conditions were reported today to the State Commerce Department:
LONDON, Jan. 16 -- Reports circulating in London tonight named Col. Mohammed Rashad Mehanna as a ringleader in the attempted Egyptian coup.

HOUSTON, Tex., Jan. 16 -- The Tennessee Gas Transmission Company has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington covering an offering of $30,000,000 first-mortgage pipeline bonds due in 1973, Gardiner Symonds, president, announced today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The first purchase of tin from Bolivia since that nation nationalized tin mines was announced today in a joint statement by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and Victor Andrade, Bolivian Ambassador to the United States.

Frank Costello's troubles multiplied yesterday. The Federal Government filed income tax liens for $486,722 against the 62-year-old gambler, now serving an eighteen-month prison sentence for contempt, and against his wife, Mrs. Loretta B. Costello.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The new rules liberalizing the regimen for the mass and holy communion went into effect today for Roman Catholics. The changes are as follows:
ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 16 (UP) -- Eddie Arcaro scored a triple at Santa Anita today, taking the $10,000 Palm Springs Handicap with Grover B.

The music is the dominant element in the approach of the Concert Choir, which began a series of four concerts of choral works at Town Hall last night. There was not a dull piece on the program -- nor an unworthy one. A glance at the remaining three programs would indicate that Margaret Hillis, founder and conductor of the group, will hold to this standard of choral music of past and present.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 16 -- Republic Pictures, one of four film companies that reportedly voted to withhold financial support from this year's academy awards ceremony, announced late today that it "will contribute its same shore this year in support of the academy and Oscar festivities as it has in previous years."

The year 1952 produced a paradox insofar as customs collections at the Port of New York were concerned, since despite the port's increased shipping, revenues dropped almost $11,000,000 below those of the previous year.

ROME, Jan. 16 -- The elevation of Valerian Cardinal Gracias, Archbishop of Bombay, who was among the twenty four prelates created Cardinals in last Monday's secret consistory, has brought about tense relations between Portugal and the Vatican.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16 -- Documentary evidence read at the du Pont anti-trust trial in the court of Federal Judge Walter J. LaBuy today by Ewart Harris, special assistant to the Attorney General, showed that under a contract entered into in 1931, divisions of General Motors have received millions of dollars in rebates for tires purchased from the United States Rubber Company. Both companies are defendants in the anti-trust suit.
TAMPA Fla., Jan. 16 (AP) -- Louise Suggs, the defending champion, took a one-stroke lead today at the halfway point in the Tampa women's open golf tournament.

Another Soviet spy ring, operating here and abroad for more than three years under the direction of a Soviet Embassy secretary in Washington, has been cracked open with the indictment and arrest of two former American Army intelligence men, the detention for questioning of a "substantial number" of others, and the expulsion of the Soviet official.

A moratorium on scientific progress for a period even as short as fifty years would throw mankind back to an existence like that of the Dark Ages, Dr. Charles Allen Thomas, president of the Monsanto Chemical Company and chairman of the board of the American Chemical Society, said here last night.

The United States has been following a policy of stockpiling tin for defense needs and now is reported to have enough on hand to fight a four-and-a-half-year war. If it could also have half the Bolivian production available, a seven-year war would be possible. President Truman recently estimated that the Texas City smelter, which refines the tin concentrates entering this country, would produce 66,800 tons of metallic tin in the year to next June 30.

RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 14 -- The Karen rebellion continues to be a major headache for the Burmese Government. Some progress, both politically and militarily, has been made during the past year in supppressing the Karen insurrectionists but diehard elements among them continue their resistance and seem determined to fight on indefinitely.

The Department of Justice was "100 per cent mistaken" in its view that investment bankers ought to compete for any business they had the slightest chance of getting, Judge Harold R. Medina declared yesterday at the trial of seventeen major investment banking houses accused of conspiracy to monopolize negotiated underwritings.
Frank Patterson Jr. has returned to Quinlan Patterson, mortgage brokers, after two years of service with the Army.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 16 -- City officials joined union leaders this afternoon in urging 9,500 striking employes of the Philadelphia Transportation Company to vote tomorrow to end the walkout.

Perry Como will make his first appearance as the star of "All Star Revue" over the National Broadcasting Company television network on Saturday, Feb. 14, from 8 to 9 P. M. So far, he is committed to only one appearance.
St. John's University defeated the Brooklyn College basketball team, 76 -- 59, on the Josers' court last night. An overflow crowd saw the Redmen lead at the half, 39 -- 31.

Sometimes the fog can be seen rolling in from the distance like a quickened vaporous glacier. More often it comes from nowhere -- not from the horizon or the ground or the sky. Starting with a mist, a light congenial interference to the eye, it thickens like bacteria in a friendly broth. It gathers on itself into the most undisciplined shapes that are destroyed as soon as they are formed.
The market for United States Government securities took in stride yesterday the advance in the Federal Reserve Bank's discount rate from 1 3/4 per cent to 2 per cent.

STRASBOURG, France, Jan. 16 -- Federalists of the proposed six-nation union of Europe, who support a strong snpranational authority, lost a round to the intergovernmental theories of the British and non-member countries in motions suggested today to the Council of Europe's Consultative Assembly for its final opinion on the European draft constitution.

BERLIN, Jan. 16 -- The arrest of East Germany's Foreign Minister, Georg Dertinger, on charges amounting to treason was followed today by reports that ten of his subordinates had been seized or had fled to the West. This could not be confirmed.
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were moderately active yesterday and closing prices were 14 points lower to 12 points net higher than on Thursday.

Donations of 550 pints of blood on Thursday were reported yesterday by the Red Cross Blood Donor Program. The total received thus far during January is 6,154 pints, against a quota of 20,000 for the month.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 16 -- While negotiations are proceeding for a settlement of Iran's oil dispute with Britain, another attempt to break the British blockade on sales of Iranian oil in foreign markets apparently is being prepared.

Now that President Truman's term of office is nearing its close it is time that Americans of all parties should pay tribute to a man who -- having faults as all human beings do -- has done great and lasting service to his country and to humanity.

Arthur Goodfriend has a sequel to his "What Can a Man Believe" on Farrar, Straus Young's list scheduled for Feb. 18 publication. Entitled "What Can a Man Do," the book shows democracy's "hidden but stunning victories in the most miserable areas of Asia." It has a foreword by Carlos Romulo.
GENEVA, Jan. 16 -- The British lion may not roar as loudly as he once did but he still can cause a great to do in Europe by remaining absolutely quiet.

KHARTUM, the Sudan, Jan. 11 -- Britain's million-acre Gezira cotton program, which has provided an excellent livelihood for 25,000 Sudanese families, is being studied throughout Africa and the Middle East as a model for increasing the productivity of under-developed lands and raising the incomes of their people.
The stock market ran into a real congested area yesterday as prices slumped to lows for the week when a burst of selling around midday caught the supporting element off-guard.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 16 -- Tea-drinking is good for intellectuals, a cup of coffee best for the athletic-minded and a fine cigar or a pipeful of tobacco can be counted on to help the ego, according to Dr. Erich von Knaffl-Lenz, professor at the University of Vienna.

Louis F. Budenz, former member of the national committee of the Communist party, told a three-man subcommittee of the State Board of Regents yesterday that Communists had organized shop clubs to gain control of basic industries through strikes and other disputes fomented by the party.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The Bureau of the Census reported today cotton consumption for the period of Nov. 30 to Dec. 27 averaged 36,736 bales for each working day.

REGINA, SASK., Jan. 16 (Canadian Press) -- Harold Wilson, a Cabinet minister in Great Britain's former Labor Government, said here that a 2 per cent recession in the United States would mean the collapse of the sterling area's dollar earnings in North America.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Jan. 16 -- Iraq's first one-stage election of a new Parliament will begin tomorrow morning one hour after sunrise and will end one hour before sunset.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson told his State Department associates in a brief farewell message today that they had a right to ask that they not be "vilified," that their loyalty not be questioned, and that "slanders and libel" not be made against them.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES of Jan. 9 there appears an article on the introduction of permanent personal registration bills at Albany. The article gives the impression that nonpersonal registration is in effect only in communities of 5,000 population or under. Under our present election law nonpersonal registration is also in effect in all unincorporated areas of the state, many of which are thickly populated.

The League of Composers of 115 West Fifty-seventh Street protested yesterday to the Inaugural Concert Committee in Washington against the dropping of "A Lincoln Portrait," set to music by Aaron Copland, from the Inaugural Concert in Constitution Hall Sunday night.

Chicken at 57 cents a pound may seem more economical than sirloin steak at $1.10 a pound. But when waste, such as bone, gristle and fat, is taken into account, the cost of one pound of edible meat from either product at those prices is the same -- $1.90.

Danny Kaye, missing from the legitimate theatre since 1941, when he left it to gain wider fame in the movie field, returns here for a limited "in person" engagement at the R. K. O. Palace Theatre beginning tomorrow night at 8 o'clock.

Decision was reserved yesterday by Third Police Commissioner James A. Delehanty on motions for dismissal of the charges against twelve suspended plainclothes men. They were accused of having taken bribes from Harry Gross, the convicted bookmaker.

Beaten for the first time this season last Wednesday by Seton Hall, Fordham's quintet resumed its winning ways as it downed Syracuse, 92 -- 70, before 1,000 fans in the Rams' gymnasium in the Bronx last night. It was the twelfth victory in thirteen starts for the Maroon.
Jeanette MacDonald, the Hollywood soprano whose face and voice are familiar to moviegoers all over the world, made her second recital appearance last evening at Carnegie Hall.

Disciplinary measures against a member club and players for violations of amateur regulations were considered by the Executive Committee of the United States Lawn Tennis Association last night in preparing the agenda for today's annual meeting of the association.

Proposals designed to encourage the construction of moderate-cost garden-type apartments and facilitate enforcement of housing regulations were discussed and generally approved yesterday at a "round-table conference" conducted by the Joint Legislative Committee on Housing and Multiple Dwellings.

The annual meetings of the Comet Class Yacht Racing Association and the Snipe Class were held here yesterday The Comet group met in the Empire State Club, in the Empire State Building. Dr. Wilbur H. Haines of Philadelphia was made president; Lawrence E. Low of Allandale, N. J., vice president; John J. Fernandez Jr. of Brooklyn, secretary, and Edward W. Vick of Geneva, N. Y., treasurer.

One of two local unions of custodial employes set to strike in the city's schools after 6 A. M. Monday, agreed yesterday to meet with city officials before walking out. A request by the city to maintain the status quo until after a mediation session Monday brought the agreement.

Reacting to the increase in the discount rate announced by the Federal Reserve Board on Thursday, dealers raised the rate on bankers acceptances by 1/8 of 1 per cent yesterday. The acceptances are notes used in payment for commodities in foreign trade, which have been "accepted" by the bank and payment guaranteed.

Mayor Impellitteri presented yesterday to twenty-nine city employes cash awards amounting to $470 and certificates of merit for having made "valuable and meritorious" suggestions for improvement of city services.

SEOUL, Korea, Jan. 16 -- A Silver Star, one of the United States' highest military decorations, was awarded today to Inn Hwan Song, a Korean civilian. The Army here spent well over a year of determined searching to locate the brave 23-year-old youth so that the medal could be presented.

The McCrory Stores Corporation has leased about 150,000 square feet in the former Loeser building in Brooklyn from the J. W. Mays Department Stores, Inc. This move will permit the May store to expand its present space by taking over the premises now occupied by McCrory at 502-6 Fulton Street.

Harold Johnson, Philadelphia's promising light heavyweight, made Jimmy Slade of the Bronx the victim of his thirty-ninth ring triumph last night in a sizzling ten-round bout at the St. Nicholas Arena before 2,075 fans who paid receipts of $4,760.

President-elect Dwight D. Eisenhower announced yesterday afternoon that he would name Mrs. Oswald B. Lord of 770 Park Avenue as United States representative on the United Nations Commission on Human Rights to succeed Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, who has filed her resignation from the post with the State Department.

Acquisition of an estate with a granite castle of Seventeenth Century architecture overlooking the Hudson River at Tarrytown, N. Y., was announced yesterday by Jacques Bolsey, founder and president of the Bolsey Corporation of America.

The Knott Hotels Corporation has added another unit to its chain in the purchase of the Forest Hills Inn in Forest Hills, Queens, James Knott, president, announced yesterday. The purchase included the inn and the Forest Hills Apartments.

The sharp upturn in industrial demand for containers, begun in the third quarter of 1952 following a marked slump in the first half of the year, now shows signs of continuing into the first quarter of 1953. This was the main conclusion of a National Production Authority report released yesterday through the New York regional office of the Department of Commerce.

SCRANTON, Pa., Jan. 16 (UP) -- Ambassador George F. Kennan, in his first address since he was asked to leave Russia, asserted today that unchecked investigations into the loyalty of Government employes were "playing very dangerously into the hands" of the Kremlin.

Your editorial of Jan. 14 on "The City's Health in 1952" is very heartening to those who are genuinely interested in seeing preserved and strengthened the work of this important city department in these times which are so critical, fiscally and otherwise. Today, because the communicable disease death rate is so low and no serious epidemic threatens, the public may overlook the quiet contribution of the Health Department in maintaining the community's health.

Events today: Philharmonic-Symphony Young People's Concert, Igor Buketoff conducting, John Sebastian, harmonica player, Carnegie Hall, 11 A. M.; Little Orchestra Society Young People's Concert, Thomas Scherman conducting, Hunter College Auditorium, 11 A. M.; "Madama Butterfly," Metropolitan Opera, 2 P. M.; Boston Symphony Orchestra, Charles Munch conducting, Claudio Arrau, pianist, Gerard Souzay, baritone, Arnold Moss, narrator, Schola Cantorum, Carnegie Hall, 2:30; Wilnette Mayers, soprano, Town Hall, 5:30.

A Brooklyn dress company executive was held up yesterday by two thugs as he emerged from a bank with a $3,500 payroll, He was forced into his own car at pistol point and driven for a half-mile by the hold-up men who used the car for their get-away.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Senator Margaret Chase Smith, Republican of Maine, today publicly lamented that a woman of the Republican party had not been named Federal Security Administrator instead of Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby.

HONOLULU, Jan. 16 -- Nine Japanese and twenty Americans are scheduled to gather around conference tables here tomorrow to begin a series of conferences -- designed, in the words of the chairman, "to get the frankest expressions of opinion from delegates on problems of concern in the relationship of the United States and Japan and their relations with the rest of the world."

Charles Palmer, member of the Albany staff of The Associated Press, is slated to be named secretary of the Republican State Committee, it was reported yesterday. He had been picked to succeed Thomas E. Stephens, who will become special counsel to the President.
UNION, N. Y., Jan. 16 -- A young couple and their two small children were found shot dead today in their apartment at 1830 Manor Avenue. The police listed the deaths as triple murder and suicide.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The Government set up limits today on speculative trading in cotton seed oil, soybean oil and lard futures delivery contracts.

In 1871 a production named "Thespis" had a rather brief run in London. It had a book by W. S. Gilbert, music by A. S. Sullivan, and it was the first collaboration of the two. Four years later, "Trial by Jury" brought them to national attention and served really to launch their careers.
Mayor Impellitteri's mediation committee in the seventeen-day-old bus strike invited the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., yesterday to talk things over at City Hall today, and the union agreed.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 16 -- A test of political influence wielded by Mexican automobile distributors and United States manufacturers here has been resolved in favor of the distributors. At their insistence the Mexican Government has limited the auto industry here to assembling a maximum of 30,000 units, including trucks, in 1953.

If the Eisenhower Administration tampers with the Securities and Exchange Commissions or its regulatory powers it will make a serious mistake, Donald C. Cook, chairman of the commission, declared last night.

Wesley Roberts of Kansas was nominated without opposition yesterday to be chairman of the Republican National Committee, and the choice received the immediate and hearty approval of his fellow Kansan, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower declared last night that whatever success he had attained as president of Columbia University was made possible by the friendly advice and counsel of men like Dean Young B. Smith, whose retirement as dean -- but not as Kent Professor of Law -- was marked at a dinner of 2,000 persons at the Astor Hotel.

Prices closed irregularly yesterday with only slight fluctuations on the New York commodity exchanges. Volume continued light and action dull on all items but coffee and cocoa, which showed more activity than at any time during the week.

MIAMI, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Hialeah Park, queen of the Florida race tracks, opened its forty-day meeting today before a midwinter gathering of 20,568, and Nimble Fox, 3 -- 1, romped home to win the $19,300 Inaugural Handicap.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 16 -- Edwin B. Swope, warden of the Federal Penitentiary on Alcatraz Island said today he agreed with James V. Bennet, Director of Prisons, that Alcatraz shoul be abandoned. He said the prison could be run much more economically "if it were not on an island far to one side of the nation."

CHICAGO, Jan. 16 -- Week-end profit-taking by longs found the demand for grain futures thin for a time today, and prices reacted sharply from the early tops. On the declines the buying resistance stiffened a little, width buying encouraged by the colder weather in prospect which may have an adverse effect on winter wheat, and at the same time make for a more active demand for feed grains.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The National Science Foundation, in its second annual report to President Truman, warned today of a critical shortage of scientists in the United States that it expected to grow worse in the next few years.

GUATEMALA CITY, Jan. 16 -- The Guatemala Cabinet has approved a plan for exploitation of hardwoods, largely mahogany, in the extensive forests of Peten that reach to the Mexican border, according to the semi-official newspaper, Diario de Centroamerica.

The failure of the city to provide more liberally for the magistrates' courts will result in a move by these courts to seek mandatory powers over salaries and jobs, Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh told Budget Director Abraham D. Beame yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.1 per cent in the week ended on Tuesday, to 109.7 percent of the 1947-49 average, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
BONN, Jan. 16 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer succeeded tonight in temporarily averting a strike of 500,000 coal miners that had been scheduled to begin Monday at 6 A. M.

GUATEMALA, Jan. 16 -- The position of the Communists and anti-Communists in the Congressional election that started here today is the reverse of that in most other countries in this hemisphere. Here the Communist propaganda campaign has been so effective that the name of "anti-Communist" carries much the same opprobrium as "Communist" in other places.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The Truman family said good-by to well wishers by the hundreds today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- H. Freeman Matthews, a career diplomat, has been designated Secretary of State, ad interim, for the interval between the moment that the Truman Administration leaves office and John Foster Dulles takes his oath as Secretary of State under incoming President Dwight D. Eisenhower.
After thirty-one hours of one of the worst fogs this city has ever experienced, the murk was lifted shortly after noon yesterday by a northwest wind.

Once again the city administration's tardiness in coming to grips with labor relations is threatening to produce a serious strike. This time it is custodial employes in the public schools who are aggrieved. Belonging to American Federation of Labor locals, they are not city employes, but employes of custodial contractors.

OUR first book this morning, "The Little Review Anthology,"* should bring waves of uncopyrighted nostalgia to all who remember the jubilantly rebellious experimental writing of the Nineteen Twenties. Our second book, "New World Writing" -- a lively collection of off-beat fiction, poetry, drama and criticism -- shows, by comparison, where experimental writing stands today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The country should have more prisons where the gates are always open and the usual walls, bristling with guards and watchtowers, do not frown down upon the inmates, James V. Bennett, director of the Federal Bureau of Prisons, said in his annual report issued today.

The board of directors of the Lutheran Welfare Council of Metropolitan New York protested yesterday the "coercive action", of Roman Catholic Charities of New York and Brooklyn in threatening to withdraw from the Welfare and Health Council of New York City if that group had accepted for membership the Planned Parenthood Committee of Mothers Health Centers.

Long Island Rail Road commuters were delayed eleven to thirty-nine minutes at the beginning of the afternoon rush hour yesterday by signal trouble in the tunnel approach to the Pennsylvania Station and a mechanical defect in a Babylon-bound train.

Waving and shouting from a tenth-floor window sill he had straddled at 4 A. M. to summon help for his wife and child who were trapped inside their blazing East Side apartment, a 30-year-old television employe apparently lost his balance and fell to his death yesterday.

BOULDER, Colo., Jan. 16 (AP) -- A rocket carried an instrument designed by University of Colorado scientists fifty miles above the earth for the first pictures of the sun's spectrum in extreme ultraviolet wave lengths.
Columbia's basketball team last night turned in its ninth straight triumph, and its second without a loss in the Eastern League, when it downed Dartmouth, 75 -- 65, at University Hall gymnasium.
The Defense Production Administration proposed yesterday that the American Standards Association take steps to reduce the annual waste in lumber production of 448,000,000 cubic feet of solid wood.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Otto Verber and Kurt L. Ponger, accused of spying for the Soviet Union, were brought into a Federal Court here today, a few hours after they had arrived in shackles from Vienna, where they were arrested Wednesday.
A reception honoring the motion picture award winners of 1952 will be given by the New York Film Critics tonight at 11 P. M. at Sardi's Restaurant, West Forty-fourth Street.

An unusually wide variety of styles and techniques are employed by artists in six of our current art exhibitions. The most traditional of these is Eugene Higgins whose paintings are at the Wellons Gallery. A veteran artist, Higgins swims against the contemporary tide by choosing to paint somber and dramatic figure groups which carry on the tradition of emotional realism as founded by Rembrandt, Daumier, and Millet.

TOKYO, Saturday, Jan. 17 -- United Nations fighter-bombers sought out new targets in North Korea yesterday after a week's day-and-night attacks on highway and rail bridges near Sinanju on the Chongchon River. The area is a bottleneck in the Communist foe's communications with his Manchurian bases.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Saturday, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Maureen Connolly of San Diego, Calif., added the Australian women's singles championship today to her United States and Wimbledon titles by beating her team-mate, Julie Sampson of San Marino, Calif., 6 -- 3, 6 -- 2, in the all-American final of the Aussie national tennis tournament.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Stanley Van Voorhees of West Los Angeles offers a power-driven ski (Patent No. 2,625,229) this week as the answer to a need long felt in winter sports. Up to now, he says, skiers have had to use ski tows or toil up a slope with the aid of "climbers" attached to their skis.

Knepper Levin, operators, announced yesterday that court approval had been given in their recent purchase of the fifteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 760 West End Avenue, northeast corner of Ninety-seventh Street, which they bought from the Clinton Trust Company, trustees for the certificate holders. They have taken title to the property.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 16 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie expressed the hope today that the new Presidential order requiring the screening of all United States employes of the United Nations would help solve the staff problems of the world organization.

CHATTANOOGA, Jan. 16 (AP) -- A business recession, but not another major depression, is almost certain after the nation's rearmament program reaches its peak, says John G. Forrest, financial and business editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, in an address to the Chattanooga Chamber of Commerce last night Mr. Forrest said:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- When President Truman admonished Premier Stalin last week to recognize that this was the atomic age and to shape Russia's policies accordingly, he was using a language diplomacy did not know when he became President on April 12, 1945.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- A renewed demand for a Congressional investigation of the oil industry's "world-wide campaign of vilification" of the Federal Trade Commission was Commissioner Stephen J. Spingarn's answer today to the action of a bare majority of members of the agency disavowing his views.

A witness at the second perjury trial of William W. Remington, former Commerce Department economist, swore yesterday that the defendant had asked him to join the Communist party, while another testified Remington was one of three persons who had solicited the witness' membership in the Young Communist League.

Boxing's newly formed Board of Review yesterday ordered Rocky Marciano, world heavyweight champion, to defend his title on or before April 10, regardless of whether Jersey Joe Walcott, ex-champion, is in the opposite corner.

MOSCOW, Jan. 16 -- A sweeping drive for heightened vigilance by Soviet scientists and intelligentsia and against any manifestations of bourgeois "idealism" or "subjectivism" has been launched in the wake of the announcement regarding the "Zionist doctors' plot" against the lives of Soviet leaders.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- About forty experts are being recruited from private business on a loan basis to help the Appropriations Committee of the House of Representatives trim President Truman's budget.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, chose today as his military aides three officers of the Army, Navy and Air Force of much lower rank than those with whom President Truman had surrounded himself.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The President's Committee on Government Contract Compliance said today that the non-discrimination clause in contracts was "almost forgotten" by some Federal departments.
Cleveland has designated Feb. 17 for the sale of $15,920.000 of bonds maturing from 1953 to 1978.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Jan. 16 (AP) -- Tommy Bolt carded his second sub-par round today to keep a firm grasp on the lead at the midway mark of the $10,000 San Diego open golf tournament.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Change of the title Attorney General to "Secretary of Justice" was one of the suggestions in a report today on a management study of the Justice Department.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The Consumers Price Index dropped 0.2 per cent in the month from mid-November to mid-December, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. This latest recession was due principally to a drop of 1 per cent in food prices. The over-all index figure fell to 190.7 from 191.1.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- President Truman today accepted the resignation of Henry H. Fowler, head of the Office of Defense Mobilization. The resignation, submitted last week, will take effect Tuesday, Inauguration Day.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- In his final public statement as Secretary of the Air Force, Thomas K. Finletter today urged the creation of an even more potent Air Force with atomic weapons than now planned. He said the danger to the nation's security persisted and appealed for forces so strong that this danger would be removed.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Irked by Australia's uncertain preparations for the 1956 meet at Melbourne, Avery Brundage, president of the International Olympic Committee, today hinted that the games might be transferred to one of several other cities that want to stage the event.

Denis J. McMahon, director of Internal Revenue for Lower Manhattan, announced yesterday that his offices will be open during regular business hours this month and next, but with extended hours in March, for the purpose of assisting taxpayers in filing their income tax returns.

PARIS, Jan. 16 -- "Inverted baskets" is Simone Cange's own description -- and an apt one -- of her small cloches, worn level but slightly tilted forward over the hairline and with the slightest upward lift at the back.

Sterchi Brothers Stores, Inc., the South's largest home furnishers, operating a chain of thirty-eight retail stores, showed substantially larger sales in the nine months ended with last November, but earnings were only slightly higher than the prior year's period because of increased taxes.

If Hawaii is admitted to statehood another star will be added to our flag, and among the people actively concerned with the problem of a forty-ninth star are the flag-makers. New York City is the home of the largest flag manufacturer in the world, Annin Co., at 85 Fifth Avenue, which turns out over five million flags annually.

The Asian Socialist conference has brought its sessions in Rangoon to a conclusion with a group of resolutions that are hopeful in the main and indicative of goodwill and good intention. Nevertheless, they reflect some of the confusion of large sectors of the public -- not all in Asia -- that occasionally substitute slogans for ideas and warmth of emotion for clarity of thought.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- President Truman asked Congress today to take the Mutual Security Program out of the "stop-gap emergency" status in which its annual appropriations have been considered and to consider military and other aid abroad as part of "a cold war struggle that may be with us for a long time."

Franklin and Marshall received recognition as having the outstanding college soccer team in the country last night at the dinner of the Intercollegiate Soccer Football Association in the Hotel Paramount. The event was part of the convention of the National Soccer Coaches Association of America, which ends today.

Now that Congress has again gone through the quadrennial travesty of counting the votes of the Electoral College, it is time to renew serious efforts to reform this archaic system. The Electoral College as it now functions is not simply a quaint but harmless institution; it is a potential danger to democratic selection of the nation's Chief Executive.

Optimistic forecasts of a year of prosperity preceded a preview of the General Motors Corporation's Motorama of 1953 at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday. The $1,500,000 exhibition will open today at 10 A. M.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Frank Pace Jr., the Secretary of the Army, presented the first Robert P. Patterson Memorial Award today to Second Lieut. Herbert T. Perrin of Gambier, Ohio. The 23-year-old lieutenant was honored because of his outstanding qualities of leadership, academic efficiency and character while a student at the Infantry Officers Candidate School at Fort Benning, Ga.

The Marine Towing and Transportation Employers Association yesterday met again with the oil section of Local 333, United Marine Division of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., in what was described as a "preliminary" session. The meeting was held in the New York Towboat Exchange, 17 Battery Place.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 16 -- The British police hunted an eighth Nazi plottter, Dr. Karl Bornemann, today as German public sentiment began to crystallize in defense of the seven National Socialists arrested by British Public Safety officers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Martin P. Durkin, journeyman pipe-fitter and until recently president of the National Plumbers' Union, A. F. L., was approved today by the Senate Committee on Labor and Public Welfare to become Secretary of Labor in the Eisenhower Cabinet.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The United States told Japan today that Gen. Mark W. Clark had been directed to "take all possible measures necessary and proper" to repel foreign aircraft flights over Japanese territory.

William L. Pfeiffer, Republican State Chairman, replied yesterday to a Thursday night speech of Richard H. Balch to the New York Young Democratic Club, in which the Democratic State Chairman attacked the Republican machine headed by Governor Dewey as "one of the worst in the United States."
TOKYO, Saturday, Jan. 17 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,497, for Friday's operations:

Proof that one of the most entrancing window treatments possible is the "garden window" is found in the exhibition that opened yesterday at the museum building of the New York Botanical Garden. House plants are arranged in six window settings, each different in relation to room decor.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Jan. 16 -- In preparation for reconstruction of an original part of the first public automobile parkway in the world, axemen and bulldozers are wreaking devastation on the famed beauty of the Bronx River Parkway Reservation south of here.

With Max Zaslofsky back on the active list but Sweetwater Clifton a doubtful participant, the New York Knickerbockers will oppose the Philadelphia Warriors tonight at the Sixty-Ninth Regiment Armory. The professional game will follow a 7:30 P. M. scholastic preliminary between St. Ann's academy and Mount St. Michael.

A RECENT column remarking on an apparent increase in the ranks of hunters who had turned to the muzzle-loader for big game hunting apparently was an understatement, for the mail has been flowing in from the black powder contingent ever since.

BERLIN, Jan. 16 -- Samuel Reber, acting United States High Commissioner for Germany, said today he had been given "categorical" assurance by Gen. Vassily I. Chuikov, chairman of the Soviet Control Commission for Germany, that there would be no interference with Allied traffic between Berlin and the West.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Plans of Senate leaders to confirm the entire Cabinet that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower will nominate as soon as he takes the oath of office as President next Tuesday encountered a serious obstacle today when the Senate Armed Services Committee found itself unable to agree that the projected appointment of Charles E. Wilson as Secretary of Defense would be lawful.

The killing of football's free substitution rule, the two-platoon system, by the National Collegiate Athletic Association has provoked what the drama department would call a mixed reaction. This is easy to understand. The adoption of the rule in 1941 changed the face of football.

The striking bus workers are seeking a forty-hour week with no cut in the pay they used to get for working forty-four to forty-eight hours, with five to nine hours of guaranteed overtime. The old basic wage ranged from $1.66 to $1.73 1/2 an hour.

ALBANY, Jan. 16 -- Legislation to terminate by next Nov. 30 at the latest the emergency veterans housing program, which has provided accommodations for 70,000 veterans or members of their families since World War II, was submitted today by Governor Dewey's office to the Republican legislative leaders for introduction.

One ominous aspect of the Soviet anti-Semitic campaign is the growing contempt it manifests for world opinion. It may be argued that the same indifference to outside reactions was shown in the great Moscow trials of the Thirties, when the world was shocked to see most of the "old Bolsheviks," the stanchest leaders of the revolution, liquidated without a qualm, indeed with a flourish of trumpets, by their closest colleagues.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- President Truman's proposal for special tax allowances for the President, Vice President and Speaker of the House of Representatives was turned down today by the House Ways and Means Committee.

DUNEDIN, Fla., Jan. 16 (AP) -- Harry Schwab, Dayton, Ohio, smashed par by six strokes with a sizzling first round 66 today, lowest eighteen holes ever shot in a P. G. A. senior medal play golf tournament.
CHICAGO, Jan. 16 -- Gen. Lemuel C. Shepherd, Commandant' of the Marine Corps, warned today that "there is no royal road to victory" in Korea.

HANOI, Vietnam, Indo-China, Jan. 16 -- In the Thai country of Northwest Indo-China the French are having a curious military experience. Faced with the impossibility of stopping the Communist-led Vietminh mass formations infiltrating through the jungle the French have been forced to enclose themselves in two strongholds, Nasan and Laichau.

Those landlubbers who hanker to buy a pleasure craft from $75,000 down to $39 and go yachting next summer, wearing white caps perched on the starboard side of their heads, have only another twelve hours to place their orders during the current National Motor Boat Show.

I have no desire to prolong the correspondence in your columns regarding religious discrimination in hotels through the use of the phrase "churches near by," but an important fallacy must be pointed out.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Brazil's Northwest Railway, which taps the rich hinterlands of Mato Grosso and Sac Paulo, may get a major face-lifting with foreign help.

The traditional fireplace in New York, the most modern of cities, seems to be enjoying a revival, judging from the increasing business reported by a brief survey of firms engaged in selling firewood or cleaning chimneys.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- President Truman proclaimed the vast wealth of offshore oil and gas today as a petroleum reserve of the United States Navy. Issuing his expected Executive Order in the controversial issue, the President swept the Continental Shelf around the entire United States and Alaska into the reserve.

The annual dinner dance in behalf of the Yorkville Community Association last night in the main ballroom of the Plaza attracted a representative gathering of members of society. Proceeds from the fete will be used to provide summer camp vacations for underprivileged children of all races and creeds in the Metropolitan area.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Stanley M. Rumbough Jr., president of the White Metals Products Company, one of the nation's largest manufacturers of collapsible metal tubes, has been named a special assistant to Sinclair Weeks, Secretary of Commerce-designate, those close to President-elect Dwight D. Eisenhower said today.
The Coast Guard began inquiries yesterday into two harbor mishaps that occurred early Thursday morning during the dense fog.

TRENTON, Jan. 16 -- A meticulously planned bank hold-up was daringly executed here in five minutes this morning by three young, armed robbers who escaped with all the cash they could carry -- almost $70,000.

Sermons anticipating Inauguration Day will be preached at many churches tomorrow. In addition, there will be many brief services Tuesday at 9:30 A. M., at which time Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect; his family and his top aides will attend a private pre-inaugural service at the National Presbyterian Church in Washington.

Hal Smith was a Washington newspaper man for fifty-six years, of which forty-one were spent in THE TIMES bureau. A kindly, thoughtful, nervously energetic man, he had a record of longevity in service in the capital equaled by few reporters and was beloved by all. He was devoted to the cause of completeness and accuracy. There were few "beats" he had not covered, but State, War and Navy were his specialty.

By acting in a "big way," the small agency can combat to a considerable degree the natural preference of large advertisers for larger agencies, it was suggested last night by Walter Weir, a vice president of Donahue Coe, Inc. He spoke at the second annual dinner of the League of Advertising Agencies, Inc., in the Advertising Club.
A two-week seminar for twenty-seven publishers and editors of newspapers of under 50,000 in circulation will begin tomorrow at the American Press Institute at Columbia University.

WHITEFISH, Mont. -- With snowfall lagging behind normal, skiing got off to a tardy start this season: on opening day, skiers at Whitefish limbered up their boards on twenty-five inches of snow. That would be luxurious in the East, but here, where there is often a five-foot cushion, it seemed skimpy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- An easily explained but seldom understood factor called "unexpended obligational authority" in the jargon of Federal budget makers promises to give the new Republican regime its biggest budget-cutting headache.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 17 -- A careful hint was dropped today that if all went well in the development of a Balkan entente among Greece, Turkey and Yugoslavia a signed treaty of mutual defense and cooperation might be concluded after all.
GILBERTON, Pa., Jan. 17 -- A 5-year-old girl was wedged upright in a ten-inch hole twenty feet below the surface for ninety minutes today until rescuers pulled her out with a rope lasso.

Chester Bowles tells us about the needs of the people of India and broadly suggests that "As a wealthy people, we -- " must provide for their needs in order to prevent India from falling into the clutches of communism. Quite so.

Mr. Robert Moses' five-point program is a sound and sensible proposal and should have the backing of all Americans. It should be added, however, that the absence of speed can result in unnecessary accidents.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17 -- While the Big Ten football coaches held a quiet wake over the death of the platoon system in an unannounced meeting today, Coach Frank Leahy of Notre Dame called for an extra ten days of spring practice to realign talent.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Jan. 17 -- Walter Dukes, who had scored 70 points in his last two games, poured in 27 tonight as unbeaten Seton Hall University stretched its basketball streak to eighteen, routing Boston College, 92 -- 71, before 3,400 at the Seton Hall gymnasium.

Reading a back number (Nov. 16, 1952) of THE NEW YORK TIMES recently my attention fell upon an editorial about the possibility of life on other planets. As you suggest in the editorial, Professor Urey is not the only one to say that life is probable on other planets in the universe.
The only blind student enrolled full-time at Hunter College has achieved a record of scholarship that will permit her to carry a nineteen-credit program next semester. The average program is sixteen.

TEHERAN, Jan. 17 -- In the West, Premier Mossadegh of Iran is widely regarded as a ridiculous and stubborn old man who sits in bed while his country goes to ruin. In Teheran, other opinions can be heard.

RIGHT in the middle of the Gordon family, with two older sisters and two younger, was Johnny, 8 going on 9. He had a way, his own way, of thinking things out that made Granny sure he'd be a judge when he grew up.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Nobody was talking for the record, but a lot of the employes around the White House were not happy today about rumors they would lose their bowling alley.

HARTFORD, Jan. 17 -- The expected replacement of Chester Bowles as United States Ambassador to India after President-elect Dwight D. Eisenhower is inaugurated may have a strong effect on Connecticut Democratic politics.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- From an inconspicuous seat rather well back in the Senate, Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin enters upon the new Republican regime in a position of extraordinary power -- in the country as well as in the Senate.

In the symposium, "Future of the Dollar" (Jan. 11) four economists fear further inflation while two anticipate deflation. Both phases of our economic cycle are undesirable, since inflation means decreased purchasing power while deflation means business recession and unemployment.

The two-year silence of commercial bankers regarding latest efforts of New York savings banks to obtain broader branch office powers will be shattered tomorrow. At least that is the prospect, excepting the unlikely possibility of a last-minute compromise.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Indo-China, Jan. 17 -- French military circles here consider that big-scale war in the Tonkin region is over, at least provisionally, without the attainment by the Vietminh of the objectives the pro-Communist forces had set last October when they launched their offensive with shock divisions.

FOR the first eleven years of Bridget Maitland's life the home above her father's bookshop in an English village was the background of her small, secure world. Then came the loss of the shop, her father's illness and the separation of the family.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (UP) -- Howard H. Gordon of Richmond, Va., today was named to head the Department of Agriculture's Production and Marketing Administration when the Republicans take control next week.

FLEMING, Ga., Jan. 17 (UP) -- The Atlantic Coast Line's New York-bound streamliner Miamian smashed into the rear of a stopped freight here in heavy fog at 3 A. M. today and burst into flames. Four New Yorkers and three trainmen were injured, an engineer and fireman critically.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 17 -- Steady gains for neo-Nazism among the youth of Germany and adherents of the Free Democratic party and a trend away from such international concepts as the European army toward a national army are reported in a survey by the United States High Commissioner's office in Germany.

STRASBOURG, France, Jan. 17 -- The Consultative Assembly of the Council of Europe, closing its special session tonight, accepted tentative plans for a six-nation European political authority but adopted resolutions that would place a damper on ambitions of the new supranational community for independence from the national Governments.

Mr. Munch opened the program of the Boston Symphony Orchestra yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall with his own arrangement of the Bach Chorale Prelude and Chorale, "The Old Year is Past" ("Das alte Jahr vergangen ist").

On New Year's Day 540 fewer United States merchant ships were on active duty than a year before. Two hundred and eight of these 1,469 ships were Government owned, contrasting with the 721 Government-owned cargo ships sailing at the beginning of 1952.

Almost 12 per cent of Westchester County's families and unrelated individuals reported incomes of more than $10,000 in the 1950 census, as contrasted with 4.1 per cent in New York State and 2.4 per cent in the nation.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., Jan. 17 -- Junior events topped the opening day of the second winter show of the Northern New Jersey Horse Shows Association today at the West Orange Armory. The two-day show is sponsored by the Second Battalion, 102d Armored Cavalry Regiment.

Reeves Brothers, Inc., will seek to double its production of textiles containing man-made fibers in the next eighteen months, according to John M. Reeves, president. The synthetic fiber operation, he said, is an important segment of Reeves' volume, and the company will make a strong sales bid to increase it.

DUBLIN -- Preparations are now well advanced for the holding of the first Irish Festival. An Toastal, which rhymes with "coastal" and literally means Ireland at Home -- at home, that is, to all its friends. The festival, consisting of three weeks of pageantry and festivities, will begin Easter Sunday, April 5, and run until April 26.

THE plaint has now long been heard, though not very loud, or -- it must be confessed -- too often, that the essay is vanishing from the literary scene. Disappearing also is its traditional devotee, the old-fashioned gentleman settling down before the fire in his shelf-lined, high-ceilinged, oak-paneled library to read Francis Bacon and Montaigne, Addison and Steele, Hazlitt and De Quincey, Emerson and Carlyle.

IT is far from a critical reflection upon "The Little World of Don Camillo" to say that this Franco-Italian comedy looks to be more than it is. On the surface of its tumultuous movement across the Bijou Theatre's screen, it appears to convey a genuine conflict between communism and the Roman Catholic Church.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 17 -- An international seminar that discussed for two weeks the philosophy of the late Mohandas K. Gandhi to evolve a "nonviolent" approach to easing world tensions ended today by making a general appeal to nations to eschew war of any kind -- defensive or offensive.

ON the heels of the successful publication of the first "New World Writing" comes this new selection and the announcement that still another one is in preparation. Like its predecessor, volume two brings material from the little magazines to the railway station and drug store audience.

FOR many people Henry Fielding means only "Tom Jones," a work included in most lists of the world's best novels. Yet he was far more than the author of a piece of great fiction. In everything that Fielding did there are qualities which set him outside the common mold.

THE man who this week will become President of the United States, the thirty-third American citizen to be elevated to the office, has expressed a political philosophy of which the following is a good definition:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Oscar R. Ewing, the outgoing Federal Security Administrator, said today that his recent controversial overseas journey had been undertaken to counteract Communist propaganda that America has no welfare programs for its citizens.

GENOA -- About 1,000 of us went out on the Andrea Doria's "voyage of innocence," her maiden cruise in the Mediterranean and eastern Atlantic waters that shook down the Italian Line's new passenger liner and her crew in preparation for her first transatlantic crossing.

C. Douglas Dillon, who has been named Ambassador to France by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, will bring to the critical Paris post an experienced hand in international finance at a time when the new Administration must chart new economic and mutual aid policies.

PARIS, Jan. 17 -- French Premier Rene Mayer got into office by promising to delay the European army treaty until there was an agreement on the Saar and until the treaty had been modified. He explained this week that he had not abandoned either this treaty or the aim of European union but had to win support of Frenchmen who were filled with apprehension about the project.
J. Edward Lumbard Jr., former Supreme Court Justice, is expected to be appointed United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York to succeed Myles J. Lane Democrat.

THERE'S no point in beating about the bush: if "Ding Dong School" doesn't win a Peabody prize as the season's finest television program for young children, then there's simply no justice. Without doubt this presentation, seen at 10 A. M. weekdays over N. B. C., is superb.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Wesley Roberts, Kansas publisher, was elected chairman of the Republican National Committee today, succeeding Arthur E. Summerfield of Michigan, Postmaster General-designate. He was unopposed for the post.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 15 -- The first public speech by Miguel Aleman since he left the Presidency last December has been interpreted as a move to end recurring reports of a growing split within the governing Party of Revolutionary Institutions between the former President and his successor, Adolfo Ruiz Cortines.
A New York A. C. trio handed the Winged Foot Polo Club its first defeat in Metropolitan League competition, 9 -- 7, in the opening game of a double-header at Squadron A Armory last night.

The annual winter Furniture Market opening tomorrow in the New York Furniture Exchange will be attended by record crowds. J. J. Melniker, exchange president, reported last week a 10 per cent increase over any previous market in requests for retailer passes.

THE sharp crack, loud and clear as a pistol shot, from tree bark on extremely cold winter nights is a familiar sound to those who live in certain parts of the country, or a well-remembered one to many city dwellers.
The bill for the world-wide peregrinations of Uncle Sam's nieces and nephews in 1952 exceeded a billion dollars for the second consecutive year.

THE American Recording Society, aided by a grant from the Alice M. Ditson Fund of Columbia University, is continuing to turn up unusual and interesting works overlooked in the rush of ordinary commercial recording.
Proposed dissolutions of New York Stock Exchange member firms include M. M. Cunniff Co. On Jan. 25 and Leo Eis Co. on Jan. 31.

I DOUBT whether any contemporary writer has made one feel more keenly (than Katherine Mansfield) the many kinds of personal relations which exist in an everyday "happy family" who are merely going on living their daily lives, with no crises or shocks or bewildering complications to try them.

A NEW figure will enter upon the American philatelic scene on Tuesday when Arthur E. Summerfield, who served as chairman of the Republican National Committee during the Eisenhower Presidential campaign, becomes Postmaster General, succeeding Jesse M. Donaldson.

Eighteen steamship companies, alleging losses aggregating $174,000, have brought suit for damages against the International Longshoremen's Association and three locals that on Jan. 2 called a strike the companies considered illegal.

A GENERATION or so ago boys and girls got most of their information about Indians from fiction -- and pretty one-sided information it often was. During the past two decades there has been a heightened effort toward a sympathetic presentation of Indian life and thought, not only in stories and legends, but also in readable non-fiction.

PARTICULARLY noticeable in interior design today is the overwhelming emphasis on textured surfaces. Texture appears on walls, floors, tabletops, drawer fronts. It is achieved with many materials: wood, cork, natural and man-made fibers, metal, plastic and even paper. Sometimes it has only the look and not the feel of texture -- a strongly grained wood surface is one example of this, a flooring of pressed cork another.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 17 -- William O'Dwyer, a former Mayor of New York City and United States Ambassador to Mexico until last month, and his wife, the former Sloan Simpson, have been granted a temporary separation by the Archbishop of Mexico, Luis Maria Martinez.

The discovery of a coelacanth (supposedly extinct 75,000,000 years ago) in South African waters two weeks ago has spurred ichthyologists to re-study of the modern fish market. According to Science Service, a number of fish caught in Baja California waters have been sold in Mexican markets in late years without having been identified by fish experts.

THIS story of the nine-man French Expedition which climbed Annapurna ( 26,493 feet ) of the Himalayas in 1950 is the most beautiful chapter in mountain literature that I know. It was written by the leader of that expedition -- one of the two men to reach the top.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 17 (AP) -- The Pennsylvania Motor Truck Association and thirty-seven trucking companies today filed a suit in the United States District Court here seeking $250,000,000 damages from thirty-one railroads for what they alleged was a "campaign of vilification and slander."

THE inauguration of a President of the United States of America has no exact counterpart anywhere in the world. Its pageantry, involving tens of thousands of people all day and, if you count the inaugural balls, into the early hours of the next day, is surpassed only by that of a coronation in London.

A LITTLE over a year ago, just before the Christmas holidays began, the parent councils of five Hartford, Conn., schools got together on a set of six "guiding principles" for mothers and dads concerned about youngsters' party behavior.

The creation of a Transit Operating Authority with exclusive power to increase the fare on the municipal subway and surface lines after Jan. 1, 1954, if the present 10-cent rate still failed to cover "mere operating costs" was advocated last night by Controller Lazarus Joseph.

LONDON, Jan. 17 -- Less than five years after the abolition of judicial whipping as a punishment for crimes in Britain, a large body of public opinion in this country is crying out for its reintroduction.

THE question of the support of writers like O'Casey is perennial, but the solution, as always, is in the hands of those mostly nearly concerned -- the actors. I think that all actors receiving above a certain amount of income, a respectable amount, should tax themselves 10 per cent and put the money into a kitty under proper control, for the purpose of underwriting the kind of plays that Broadway angels won't finance.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Jan. 17 -- Dr. Daniel Bergsma, State Commissioner of Health, assured the Middlese County Sewerage Authority this week that municipalities and industries that empty their wastes into the Raritan River and that are not affiliated with the proposed $22,500,000 trunk sewer program must meet department standards or be prosecuted.

Fourteen Protestant clergymen, representing nine denominations, and two Jewish rabbis asked yesterday for reconsideration of the exclusion of the Planned Parenthood Committee of Mothers Health Centers from the Welfare and Health Council of New York City.

WHEN the official historians record that on Jan. 20 President-elect Eisenhower was inaugurated as the thirty-fourth President, they will be overlooking a nettlesome fact which has disturbed a minority of experts every fourth year.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17 (UP) -- Outbreaks of "mild flu" appeared to be spreading in many parts of the country today. Physicians at Minneapolis, Chicago and elsewhere diagnosed much of the illness as "a prime" virus influenza, which generally runs its course in three days.

THERE has been recently broad public discussion of two vital religious issues. The first is connected with the growing awareness of the need for emphasis on religion in our life to strengthen moral standards and true democracy.

A jury of six men and six women held their third court day of deliberations yesterday in the trial of thirteen Communist leaders charged with conspiracy to teach and advocate overthrow of the Government by force and violence.

TO the layman the language of the lawyer can be as befuddling as the technical jargon sometimes employed by the music critic. Since this department believes in driving the jargon out of the musical temples, it would not foist legal gobbledegook on its trusting readers.
The first sizable group of American antique furniture to be auctioned here this season will be up for sale on Thursday, Friday and Saturday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Jan. 17 -- Hal Baker of the Harvard Club, playing from scratch, led the way into the semi-final round of the twenty-first annual Luckenbach Memorial handicap singles squash racquets tourney at the Nassau Country Club today with two victories.

AMONG the new courses for beginners that have recently been announced is one that Ford R. Bancroft, photographic consultant for Willoughbys, will teach, "The Fundamentals of Photography," starting at 6:15 P. M. tomorrow at Pennsylvania Railroad Y. M. C. A. The course for "Y" members only will last for ten two-hour weekly sessions; the fee is $12.

WHEN the current crop of detective fiction is uninspired many of us are apt to refresh ourselves by rereading the imperishable canon of Sherlock Holmes -- a vice which, like many others, leads to a demand for stronger and more stimulating doses.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Jan. 17 (UP) -- German Olympic and world champion Anderl Ostler and his brakeman, Franz Kemser, won the 1953 international German twin-seater bob racing championship today.

Robert C. Lee, executive vice president of Moore-McCormack Lines and vice chairman of the company's board; was elected president of the Security Bureau, Inc., last week, at the organization's annual meeting. He succeeds Benn Barber of the Waterman Steamship Corporation.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Following is a timetable of events for Inauguration Day, Tuesday:

OTTAWA, Jan. 17 -- Charges that there have been inefficiency, thievery, laxity, irregularities and an "orgy of waste" in the accountancy and spending of the $2,000,000,000 that Canada is devoting to defense have been thrown across the floor of the House of Commons this week against the Government, which however has remained singularly unperturbed.

When I was in the State Department I was called upon to study with some care problems of oil development in the Middle East. Then I formed some conclusions which I think are pertinent to the current dispute between the Government and the oil companies now engaged in operations in the Middle East.

The National Association of Amateur Oarsmen held its eightieth annual meeting at the New York Athletic Club yesterday and awarded the 1953 national championships to Philadelphia. The title event will be held on the Schuylkill River on July 18 and 19.

ONE week from today the Empire Theatre, at the corner of Broadway and Fortieth Street, will be sixty years old. The jubilee will pass without celebration. Since it occurs on a Sunday, the old theatre, where "The Time of the Cuckoo," the play by Arthur Laurents, is the current attraction, will be closed for the day.

WATCHING the rehearsals of "The Bat" this past month, I found myself thinking back to the days of the original production. That production, in 1920, was the culmination of three years of pretty hard, intensive work.

REDUCTION of police patrol personnel on the highways of Pennsylvania to provide more guards for the Pennsylvania Turnpike has increased the state-wide accident hazard, according to the Keystone Automobile Club. And highway officials throughout the country are wondering uneasily if this "borrowing from one pocket to fill another" policy will be extended to existing and future toll routes and through arteries.

BOSTON, Jan. 17 -- H. Brian Holland, appointed this week by President-elect Eisenhower to head the tax division of the Department of Justice as an assistant attorney general, said today that he "supposed" someone in New York or Washington had recommended him to Herbert Brownell Jr., the Attorney-General-designate.

Diamond sales during the Christmas season reached the second highest volume in the industry's history. It was exceeded only in 1946, when the unusually high marriage rate accounted for the greater demand. About 20 per cent of the annual business is done during December.

The school bell is ringing in six southern Illinois communities for members of boards of education who have decided to return to the classroom for a year's study on how to be better school board members. It may be the first time in the nation's educational history that school board members have had a helping hand from experienced consultants of an institution of higher learning.

THE beautiful winter-flowering shrub of the South and Far West, Camellia japonica, is appearing with increasing frequency in gardens beyond the so-called "camellia belt." Northerners are finding the handsome evergreen shrubs, with their waxlike blossoms, so irresistable that they are willing to give special care to these traditionally Southern favorites.

STANFIELD BRIGHT is the hero of this absorbing novel. We follow him from 10 to 19, from a little boy helpless in the clutches of a mother who represents the worst of Philip Wylie's nightmares, to a bewildered young man for whom enlistment in the Navy and a defiant marriage still have not cut the silver cord.

One of the largest hydroelectric power plants in the world is now under construction. Upon completion it is scheduled to turn out 1,500,000 kilowatts of electric power, or the equivalent of 2,000,000 horsepower.

CHAD WALSH, contrasting the King James and the New Standard Version of the Bible (Book Review, Dec. 21), remarks, "To read the King James Bible correctly requires a greater knowledge of philology than is needed for Shakespeare or John Donne," and points out that the word "charity" was once a simple word for "Christian love."

HELEN RICE has got off the last copy of the fourth directory of the National Association of Amateur Chamber Music Players. It took her weeks. She had to address, stamp and seal all the envelopes, and there were more than 3,000.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Jan. 17 -- To paint a picture of seaweed, Mrs. Sally Armbruster uses seaweed as her medium. So accurate is her composition of oceanic flora that at a distance the forty-five items of her show at the American Museum of Natural History look like water-colors.

The Fund for the Advancement of Education, a unit of the Ford Foundation, is considering the establishment of an "academy" for annual conferences of the world's leading thinkers, it was disclosed yesterday in the fund's first annual report.

The New York Film Critics last evening presented awards to winners of its eighteenth annual poll for distinguished motion - picture work during 1952 at a reception at Sardi's Restaurant, West Forty-fourth Street.

THE second volume of Steven Runciman's projected three-volume history of the Crusades tells a tale almost too complicated to follow. These complications are at least partly the fault of history, and of the racial, dynastic and religious structure of Asia Minor in the twelfth century.

CAPETOWN, Jan. 17 -- The suffering and misunderstanding visited upon men by each other in the name of "race" constitute a human tragedy. Rare are the moments of history when breeds differing in pigmentation of skin or formation of feature have lived together in sympathetic harmony.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 17 (UP) -- William S. Paley, chairman of the board of the Columbia Broadcasting System, called tonight for shorter Presidential campaigns to ease the strain on both the candidates and the voters.

Senator Hubert Humphrey, Minnesota Democrat, attacked the McCarran-Walter Immigration Act last night as discriminatory and as violating the nation's democratic ideals. At the same time he predicted that the national origins principle embodied in the law "will soon be abolished."

FASHIONS in house plants are not quite as fickle as in millinery, for example, but at least one plant seems to reach the height of popularity every decade. At present it is the African violet, a temperamental charmer.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt had one career as the wife and helpmeet of a man who became President of the United States. She has had another since her husband's death. As United States representative on the United Nations Commission on Human Rights, she has worked effectively and spoken eloquently for ideals shared by her fellow-citizens of both major parties.

Setting such a withering pace that his rivals were gasping at the finish, 17-year-old Bob Lippmeier, Forest Hills High senior, ran the fastest mile in his career last night at the fourth annual Cardinal Hayes High School track and field games in the Third Engineers Group Armory.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 17 (AP) -- The University of Pennsylvania quintete, led by Ernie Beck's 22 points, raced to its third Ivy League victory in four starts tonight, defeating Dartmouth, 79 -- 50, at the Palestra.

REVIEWING this novel is a sad task for a strange reason. It contains much continental circus flavor and is built around a plot gimmick which is admirable. But the book seems incomplete, as if the last third of it had been lost on the way to the printers.

LEVITTOWN L. I., Jan. 17 -- Town officials of Oyster Bay and Hempstead, seeking means of reopening Levittown Hall and two community swimming pools with playing fields by establishing two special districts, scheduled a Jan. 30 referendum to determine sentiments of the affected home owners.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 17 -- Yale gained a 12-point half-time lead over Colgate on the Payne Whitney court tonight and, playing control basketball, defeated the Red Raiders, 82 -- 72.

IT is not surprising that there are comparatively few juvenile biographies of Thomas Jefferson if one considers the complexities of his life and genius. His life was not dramatic in the same sense as were Washington's and Lincoln's.

BERLIN, Jan. 17 -- Frau Helene Hamann, wife of East Germany's ousted Supply Minister, Karl Hamann, broadcast tonight a dramatic appeal for the life of her husband and daughter who, she said, were in the hands of the secret police.
Fourteen-year-old Shirley Linde of New York captured the women's senior Middle Atlantic figure-skating title at Iceland yesterday after an exceptionally fine performance.

The tempo of trading in financial markets set a slower pace last week and stock prices moved erratically. After extending the previous week's decline through Monday, the market improved as the pressure of liquidation lifted until Friday, when more active selling sent the list lower again.

A drive to limit imports of heavy fuel oil has been started by the coal industry. Steadily rising entries, mostly from Venezuela, are cutting into coal consumption, particularly in the North Atlantic area. With coal exports down sharply from a year ago, reflecting expanding mining activity abroad, come in the industry are predicting a sharp decline in production here unless oil imports are restricted.
A new Institute of Mathematical Sciences will integrate and expand the program of advanced research and instruction at New York University, it was announced yesterday by Chancellor Henry T. Heald.

ONE of television's most prolific free lance script writers is a 36-year-old former newspaper man -- with the soul of a drifter -- who a year ago had never seen a TV or stage drama or sold a line of fiction to any market, although he had tried writing short stories.

Arturo Toscanini conducted the second concert in his second period with the N. B. C. Symphony late yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. His program consisted of two famous overtures -- Beethoven's "Egmont" and Rossini's "William Tell" -- with a virtually unknown piano concerto in between.

At public hearings last week, arguments were presented on the question of a state-supported, non-commercial educational television network for New York. For some months educators have been concerned about this issue. The State Board of Regents has outlined a program that would reserve ten television channels for educational purposes.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Jan. 17 -- Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan predicted today that the Union of South Africa eventually would declare itself a republic, but added that such a change "must come by constitutional and democratic means."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Uncertainty over the immediate fate of wage controls may lead to industrial unrest, Charles C. Killingsworth, chairman of the Wage Stabilization Committee, warned today.

EVER since the motion-picture studios deserted New York to push westward some forty years ago, our city fathers have been trying to lure a fragment of the multi-million-dollar industry back for the sake of stimulating local business activity.

VIENNA, Jan. 17 -- The anti-Semitism that Hungarian Communist newspapers have been preaching since Moscow's arrest of nine doctors, including Jews, in an alleged plot against Soviet leaders found physical expression in Budapest today in the arrest of Lajos Stoeckler, president of the Hungarian Jewish community.

Through most of U. S. history -- beginning with the Briton John Andre during the Revolution -- the problem of foreign espionage has hit home to Americans principally in time of war. Until 1917, the crime of espionage was not even defined formally by statute.

The convention here last week of the National Retail Dry Goods Association may not have supplied "all the answers" but the heavily attended gathering did an excellent job in bringing major retail issues into clear focus and in helping merchants chart an individual course of action to meet changing conditions.

TELEVISION and radio coverage of the forty-seventh Presidential Inauguration on Tuesday will bring the ceremonies to an audience estimated to be greater than the combined audiences of all preceding inaugurals.

MORE than half of the mushrooms cultivated in this country are grown around Kennett Square, Pa. They are of the agaricus campestris type -- that is, the familiar white field mushroom, and because they thrive in cool conditions, they are abundant and cheap at this time of the year.

GOOD housekeeping is as important a part of maintaining an aquarium as are the plants and fish in it. There are different shapes and sizes of planters. Many add neatness and attractiveness to the scene, for they come in corner and long window-box shapes that may be fitted together to form various patterns.
LONDON, Jan. 17 (Reuters) -- Results of today's British football games:

BOSTON, Jan. 17 -- Charley Capozzoli, Georgetown's rising young distance runnel turned in the brightest of many glowing performances tonight in the Massachusetts Knights of Columbus games, the first major carnival of an indoor track and field campaign that promises a surfeit of thrills.

STANFORD -- Survey Group Stanford University has established a survey research facility, designed to explore people's habits and general social development in the California area. Although set up primarily to aid Stanford faculty members in their own research, the facility will also be available to serve outside organizations and individuals.

SOUTH HILL, Va. -- The completion of the multi-million dollar John H. Kerr Dam and Reservoir near here has opened a new tourist attraction for north - south traffic passing through the Old Dominion.
