Thousands of motorists are converging on the project to view the 2,785-foot-long concrete barrier and the harnessed waters of the Roanoke River which have backed up behind it.

SOMETHING like thirty years and two volumes later, Prof. Edgar Johnson has decided pretty definitely that he likes the works of Charles Dickens. It was not ever thus. MOSCOW, Jan. 17 -- The Soviet Army newspaper Red Star declared today that completion of the current five-year plan would enable Soviet industry to provide the nation's armed forces potentially with "significantly greater quantities" of first-class modern battle equipment and ammunition than were available in World War II.

If I read Ambassador Bowles' article correctly, the tragedy of our relations with Asians is that, in addition to our own obvious short-comings, we show a lack of knowledge of (and, more important, a lack of interest in) the people of Asia.

COMPROMISE is a term which sportsmen have come to regard with considerable distrust when it is employed as a suggested means of settling a conflict between sports and commercial interests involving the use of a natural resource, whether this resource happens to be fish, game, timber or water.

RONKONKOMA, L. I., Jan. 17 -- While public opposition to the proposed $5,000,000 runway expansion program for MacArthur Airport here continued to mount today, civic groups representing three villages surrounding the field were busy checking a report that the project was already under construction.

Another honor was bestowed yesterday upon the already heavily laurel-laden Yankees when their general manager, George M. Weiss, was made the recipient of the Bill Slocum Memorial Plaque, top award of the New York Chapter, Baseball Writers association of America.

HARTFORD, Jan. 17 -- The Connecticut Civil Rights Commission disclosed in a report today that employment opportunities for Negroes in this state were generally limited to unskilled jobs either through "deliberate or unconscious'' discrmination on the part of employers.

FORT MONMOUTH, N. J., Jan. 17 -- The Army Signal Corps announced today the development of a "stratosphere chamber," nicknamed the "teakettle," which is designed to provide the answers to many unsolved meterological problems.
ITHACA, N. Y., Jan. 17 -- Cornell stayed on top of the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League tonight by defeating Princeton, 57 -- 49.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The doubtful legality of Charles E. Wilson's retaining his holdings of General Motors stocks as Secretary of Defense forced Senate leaders today to abandon plans to confirm the entire Eisenhower Cabinet immediately after the inauguration Tuesday.
TOKYO, Jan. 17 (AP) -- A United States Air Force spokesman said today that defense of Japan was a "mission of highest priority." The United States has ordered all steps necessary toward that end.

THAT the most complex and interesting writer developed by France since World War I, the writer who absolutely fathered the generation of Camus and Sartre (so much less interesting than he), has not had until now a book about him in English would in itself be enough reason for calling attention to the present study by W. M. Frohock of Columbia University.

ALBANY, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Officials in the State Motor Vehicle Bureau admitted this week they were still weary from trying to handle a flood of applications for "distinctive" 1953 automobile license plates.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, Jan. 17 -- The dominant position long held by former Premier Nuri es-Said, now a Senator, in Iraqi politics was enhanced by today's general Parliamentary elections, the first in the nation's history by direct vote.
DUNEDIN, Fla., Jan. 17 (AP) -- Harry Schwab, Dayton, Ohio, won the Professional Golfers Association senior medal play championship today with a 2 under par 142.

NEWARK, Jan. 17 -- The Lackawanna Railroad filed today with the Board of Public Utility Commissioners additional data in support of a proposed compromise schedule for passenger car operation on the Boonton branch.

THIS handsome book will introduce some readers, as it did this reviewer, to the work of this Lithuanian poet, who was born in 1877 in Czereia, Lithuania, and died in 1939 in Paris. Oscar Venceslas de Lubiez Milosz spent his childhood in his native country, traveled widely in his youth, and lived most of his mature life in Paris, where, after the first World War, he was Minister-resident for Lithuania.

IT'S nearly a year now since the Authors' League of America passed a resolution stating that it would defend any author who had been debarred from work because of a listing in "Red Channels." Since then the agitation over "Red Channels" has subsided somewhat, but television sponsors are even more determined now than then that authors even faintly tarred with the Communist brush shall not write for their programs.
THIS week, by one of those unaccountable coincidences, the Round-Up seems to be specializing in saddles. Four of the first five books have that essential bit of equipment in their titles.

Bubbles' Soda Pop, C.D.X., U.D., a 3 1/2-year-old black miniature poodle owned, trained and handled by Mrs. Ethel S. Nathanson of New York City, was the main winner yesterday in the trial of the Poodle Obedience Training Club of Greater New York at the Henry Hudson Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Every President has had his share of troubles with the newspaper reporters, but General Eisenhower is having his troubles even before inauguration.

Dr. Mary Bella V. Dodd, former official of the Communist party and the Teachers Union, declared yesterday that the Communists were using progressive education as a means of freeing students from discipline and encouraging them for the day when they could "take matters into their own hands."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- President Truman accepted today, with high praise for them all, the resignations of seven members of his Cabinet.

GORHAM, N. H., Jan. 17 -- Halfway up 6,200-foot, snow-clad Mount Washington, in a rude cottage chained to the rock against frequent 100-mile winds, five men from Brooklyn are encamped for about three weeks and grousing about the mild weather.

A WELL paced, frequently moving novel, "Six Weeks in March" nevertheless starts out on so glum a note that the reader is at first tempted to believe that Miss Robertson is trying to kid Eugene O'Neill. The scene is Elijah Lamb's farm in upper New York State and the time is shortly after the Civil War.

ALBANY, Jan. 17 -- The special prosecutor investigating political corruption on Staten Island has asked the Court of Appeals for permission to appeal a lower court decision exonerating two former Richmond County legal officers of charges of professional misconduct.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 17 -- The report this week that the illegal immigration of Mexican laborers across the nation's southwestern border soared last year to a new high of upward of 1,500,000 persons spotlighted a difficult problem confronting the incoming Administration.

The fallacy of Mr. Moses reasoning becomes manifest when one realizes that in every state, irrespective of its speed limit, traffic is rolling five of the seven days in most weeks with very few accidents. It is on these days that the greatest maintained speed occurs.

I HAVE a bone to pick with Chad Walsh over his cavalier dismissal of "Harper's Bible Dictionary" in his review (Dec. 21). He says "the treatment of theological terms is frankly in the Protestant evangelical tradition." I fail to see the value of this word "frankly."

Six hundred laughing, joking Merchant Marine cadets deserted the classrooms of the United States Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point, L. I., yesterday and sailed for Washington and a command performance in Tuesday's inaugural parade.

If our new Secretary of Agriculture (see "A Bigger Role for Farm Co-ops" by Kenneth S. Davis, Jan. 4) believes that insecurity is a "God-given" part of our society, I suggest his farmers undergo a little of that themselves.

A NEW Paul Strand, the internationally famous American photographer now a resident of France, is revealed in one of two books of photographs recently imported from Switzerland by Museum Books, Inc., 49 East Forty-third Street.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Frank Sedgman, top world amateur tennis player from Australia, was proving just as apt as a pro as he defeated Jack Kramer, 1 -- 6, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 4, before a crowd of 6,019 tonight.

The second of two unions that had threatened to call a strike of custodial employes in the city schools at 6 A. M. tomorrow agreed yesterday to withdraw its strike notice pending the outcome of mediation sessions.
AT THE KOREAN FRONT, Jan. 17 -- The real veterans of the Korean war as far as United States units are concerned are not the hard-bitten sergeants of the line but rather the Katusas.

ALBERT SCHWEITZER as an interpreter of Bach on the organ has become almost a legend. But in recent years it has been hard for gramophone listeners to check the legend against the fact. The three albums he made for the Bach Organ Music Society, which were released here by Columbia between 1936 and 1938, have long been out of print.

The rapid growth in pensions in recent years has raised the question of how complete is our knowledge of this subject, especially as it affects our future benefit planning. Has not the point been reached where more factual information is desirable of where we are and where we are headed in retirement programs?

THIS second volume in "The Rise of Modern Europe" series under the general supervision of William L. Langer of Harvard, covers the sixty years between the fall of Constantinople to the Turks and Martin Luther's revolt against Rome.

CAIRO, Jan. 17 -- The Egyptian Cabinet issued a decree tonight extending the absolute powers of Premier General Mohammed Naguib to a full year and formally disbanding all of the nation's political parties. The Cabinet move came after General Naguib said he was dissolving the parties because of their "uncooperative" attitude toward the Government.
Andy Pafko was sent to the Braves by the Dodgers yesterday for a "bundle of cash" and Roy Hartsfield, a second baseman, who will be assigned to Montreal of the International League.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (UP) -- Secretary of Labor Maurice J. Tobin warned organized labor today it could look to the future with a "great deal of uncertainty."

TOTOWA, N. J., Jan. 17 -- A $1,000,000 nursery, designed and erected by the State of New Jersey especially to care for mentally retarded infants, was dedicated at the North Jersey Training School here today.

It will expose the United States to severe criticism in the United Nations and it puts a regrettable blemish on the President's record of replacing military by civilian rule for the peoples of Guam, American Samoa and the Trust Territory of the Pacific.

MANILA, Sunday, Jan. 18 (AP) -- A scientist reported yesterday the discovery of a pygmy tribe that may have migrated to the Philippine Islands about 10,000 years ago and become the area's earliest inhabitants.

Channel 1 means many things to many people. To the Presbyterian Hospital on West 168th Street it means the Hospital Bedside Broadcasting System, over which Sylvia and Irene Rosenberg will play a recital of music for violin and piano on Thursday evening.

GUATEMALA, Jan. 17 -- Voting speeded up here today on the second day of Guatemala's national election of thirty-two members of Congress. Interest was still focused on two anti-Communist candidates from this city.

Many buyers were in the wholesale market here last week placing substantial orders, Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office, reported. Buyers expect a good spring season and budgets were adequate to take care of early purchases. Better coat and suit departments were very active with spring orders for fleeces, boucles, jersey, silk and faille coats. Spring suits were recorded in box jacket silhouettes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- An apparent policy dispute between John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State-designate, and George F. Kennan, Russian expert and former United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union, was being discounted by high diplomatic authorities today as merely a "case of bad timing."

STOWE, Vt., Jan. 17 -- Othmar Schneider, 24-year-old Austrian Olympic slalom champion, sped down the icy and lighting fast two-mile course in 2:59.4 today to win the downhill, opening event of the sixth annual Captain Vic Constant Memorial Alpine meet.
Entries for the Westminster Kennel Club show closed last week with 2,565 dogs in 110 breeds or varieties of breeds nominated. The event will be held Feb. 9 and 10 in Madison Square Garden.
TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 17 (AP) -- Louise Suggs was one under women's par with a 73 today to cling to a one-stroke lead after three rounds of the 72-hole Tampa women's open golf tournament.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) -- James P. McGranery, Attorney General, today called for appointment of Federal attorneys under Civil Service, instead of by the President with the approval of the Senate.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 17 -- Prof. Raphael Lemkin, father of the United Nations Convention on Genocide, called on the world organization today to find the Soviet Union and its satellites guilty of violating the pact by a determined campaign to wipe out minorities behind the Iron Curtain.

Frankie Carbo, through whom authorities declare "dirty" waterfront money was funneled into professional prizefighting, was arrested at 2 A. M. yesterday for refusing to answer questions at the public hearing of the State Crime Commission last Dec. 19.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. (AP) -- Frank Costello, one-time reputed czar of gambling who is now in prison, asked today for parole and a hearing. The application was filed with the United States Parole Board.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The Inaugural Committee, in discussing plans for next Tuesday's parade after Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower takes the oath of office as President, disclosed today that everybody was trying to get into the act.

TOKYO, Sunday, Jan. 18 -- United States B-29 Superforts from Japanese bases resumed last night their attacks on military installations in the North Korea Communist capital of Pyongyang, main communications hub of the Communists' war effort on the peninsula.

THE use of groundcovers where grass is not desired or will not grow is an attractive feature of many successful gardens. Choosing the appropriate kind for a specific site and purpose determines the final effect, and it often proves difficult -- particularly for the new homeowner.

The action of the Federal Reserve District Banks in raising the discount charge against borrowing commercial banks from 1 3/4 per cent to 2 per cent may not cause a lasting stir in the marketplace or affect measurably the current rate of business activity, but the move will go down, nevertheless, as a historic one in the annals of credit management.

HARTFORD, Jan. 17. -- Connecticut's Republican administration headed by Gov. John Lodge has asked the General Assembly to expand the Superior and Common Pleas Court benches by adding eight new judges in a move to relieve the congestion in the court dockets throughout the state.

AS Esau dipped into the mess of pottage for which he had yielded his birthright, he may have reflected that those who own economic goods exercise a kind of governmental power. Being entitled to retain their property or part with it as they choose, the owners like petty sovereigns can dictate terms and conditions their neighbors must perform in order to have access to the property.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan 17 -- Eiji Wajima, chief of the Asian Bureau of the Japanese Foreign Ministry, who arrived here Thursday to make an informal survey of Jakarta-Tokyo relations, met with Foreign Minister Mukarto yesterday for the first time.

PARIS, Jan. 17 -- The Cabinet agreed today that 86,000,000,000 francs (about $250,000,000) of this year's budget would be cut out or temporarily blocked in the defense budget, and 36,000,000,000 francs (about $105,000,000) would be blocked until April 1.

Department store sales for the country were 3 per cent below the corresponding week a year ago in the seven days ended Jan. 10, on the basis of Federal Reserve Board figures. The preceding week showed an advance of 4 per cent, revised.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- When enemy agents obtain or seek to obtain the military, scientific or political secrets of the United States, that is called espionage and the agents are called spies. When American agents catch these spies at their spying, however, that is called counter-intelligence.

Back in 1893 one of the new tenants of the old World Building, soon to be torn down, was the H. W. Fairfax Advertising Agency. Under the name of Fairfax, Inc., the agency is still in existence, but has long since closed the original downtown offices.

That idea appears to be to help the non-specialist understand current Middle Eastern affairs by providing him with an authoritative account of the region's long and complicated history.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 17 -- Manhattan's track and field team set three records and tied another in beating Army, 55 to 54, in an exciting dual meet in the field house today.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 17 -- This city's paralyzing, four-day transit strike ended tonight when the members of Local 234, Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., voted 2-to-1 to accept the same contract offer that had been rejected by a minority just before the start of the strike at midnight Tuesday.
" O GOD, thou art my God: early will I seek thee: my soul thirsteth for thee, my flesh longeth for thee in a dry and thirsty land, where no water is."

Four artist-educators will give their views on how to appreciate contemporary art at 6:15 P. M. Tuesday at the last of the winter series of free art lectures sponsored by the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty- second Street.

There's the remains of a little "red school house" in the Alleghany Valley in the Pittsburgh area of Pennsylvania. It is a silent token, and a monument, to many of today's industrial leaders who mastered the "three R's" in a room only capable of holding twenty-five pupils.

THIS is the final week of the New York City Ballet's three-month season at the City Center, and of Jose Greco's two-week one at the Century. The ballet will offer its final premiere -- William Dollar's "The Five Gifts" -- on Tuesday.

PARIS, Jan. 17 -- The trial at Bordeaux of twenty-one of the German S. S. troopers who participated in the most ghastly war crime of the occupation period -- the massacre of 642 men, women and children of the southwestern French village of Oradour-sur-Glane in a single day -- is arousing in the French memories of all the bitterness of their days under Nazi domination.

MIAMI, Jan. 17 -- Brookmeade Stable's First Aid drove to victory in the second division of the Hibiscus Stakes at Hialeah Park today after Mrs. Wallace Gilroy's Eternal Will won the first half of the $15,000 added feature for 3-year-olds.

CONTRARY to popular conception, air plants do not live on air. They are merely air minded, for actually they need a bit of leafmold in which to root firmly. Botanically they are known as epiphytes, from the Greek epi (upon) and phyte (plant).

Rather than pay an extra cash fare when he believed he was using a valid weekly commutation ticket on the Long Island Rail Road yesterday, Irving Jacobs, 40 years old, of 20-08 Seagirt Avenue, Far Rockaway, Queens, submitted to arrest and said he was prepared to make a test case in court.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 17 -- United States authorities will comply, if asked by the British, to help in their round-up of former Nazi leaders, an American official said today. No British request has yet reached the United States High Commissioner's office, he added.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 17 -- The emergence of Communist China as a "great and unified" nation has completely changed the balance of power in the Far East and to some extent in the world, Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru declared at a huge public meeting in Hyderabad today.

THE Golden Age of American landscape -- the first three-quarters of the nineteenth century -- is the subject of the current exhibition of paintings at Kennedy Co. It was a glamorous moment. In a few short years the painters living along the Atlantic coast realized that a vast and hitherto unpainted panorama was opening up to them and that its challenge demanded a response worthy of it.

TRENTON, Jan. 17 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll's decision not to seek re-election lifted the lid last week on an intensive struggle among several New Jersey Republicans to win the nomination to succeed him.

A group of unusual musical instruments was demonstrated at yesterday morning's Young People's Concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony at Carnegie Hall. A typewriter was one; it was used in Satie's "Parade." Another was a hurdy-Gurdy, for which Haydn's Concerto for Hurdy-Gurdy and Orchestra supplied the music.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 5 -- A world center for Buddhism on the lines of the Vatican is to be established at Saraburi, in the year 2500 of the Buddhist Era (1957 A. D.) if present plans of the Thai Government are realized.

For I do not mean to minimize the trials which beset any creative worker between his conception of what it is he wants to do and the partial realization -- for it is almost always partial -- of that conception.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Averell Harriman, who is retiring as Director for Mutual Security, expressed "critical concern" today over a deal by Ceylon to ship 250,000 tons of rubber to Communist China during the next five years.

WRITTEN by an East Indian from Trinidad, "A Brighter Sun" is one of the most recent additions to the new Caribbean literature of peasant life. Mr. Selvon's story unfolds in the village slum of Barataria, which is strung along a large malarial swamp, four miles outside of Port of Spain, the capital city of Trinidad.

A campaign to raise a $100,000 scholarship fund to help the city's adults who want additional education but cannot afford it was announced last week by the New York Adult Education Council, 254 Fourth Avenue.

Repealing the eight-week rule as the first step in the direction of a more liberal and realistic amateur code, the United States Lawn Tennis Association yesterday removed restrictions on the number of sanctioned tournaments in which a player may have his expenses paid.

The striking bus workers are seeking a forty-hour week with no cut in the pay they used to get for working forty-four to forty-eight hours, with five to nine hours of guaranteed overtime. The old basic wage ranged from $1.66 to $1.73 1/2 an hour.

Manufacturers, retailers and an imposing array of top-flight lawyers have begun a bitter legal battle that will probably end in the Supreme Court. The issue is whether or not the man in the street will be permitted to buy certain products at cut prices.
NEW HAVEN, Jan. 17 -- Men and women who made outstanding contributions to medicine through the ages are depicted in a varicolored exhibit of postage stamps on display in the Yale Medical Library.

The Communists supply their armies in Korea via a network of narrow roads and rail lines that wind down from the Manchurian capital of Mukden to the Thirty-eighth Parallel some 350 miles away. At the Yalu, at several smaller rivers to the south, and at a series of deep gorges which twist across the Korean peninsula, the roads and rail lines converge on bridges.

SCRANTON, Pa., Jan. 17 -- A former Republican member of Congress, James P. Scoblick, 43 years old, of near-by Archbald, was arrested here today and charged with aiding and abetting the former cashier of the Mayfield State Bank in misapplying $169,151.66 of bank funds.

MELBOURNE, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Maureen Connolly of San Diego captured another major tennis championship and Ken Rosewall of Australia firmly established himself among the top amateurs of the world today when they easily won Australian national titles.
A tall, white-haired gentleman is in this country to explain to Americans something of what British colonialism is all about.

THE Government of India last Friday opened a tourist office at 11A East Fifty-eighth Street, first of a number of travel information centers to be opened all over the world. Under the direction of G. R. Kadapa, the office is now in business as a source of information on India with special attention to travel facilities and conditions.
Re Chester Bowles' "How to Win Friends and Influence Asia" (Jan. 4):

TANGIER, Jan. 1 -- consumption tax of 1 per cent on all products, whether of local origin or imported, has been imposed by the Tangier Legislative Assembly. The yield of the tax -- the first of its kind ever introduced in the Tangier international zone -- is earmarked to pay for the projected expansion of Tangier's port facilities.

There is a superstition, fostered in Wall Street, that prices and earnings of stocks bear some sort, of relation one to the other. In other words, if earnings are rising (falling), prices should be rising (falling).

Construction of a B-17 bomber in World War II took 350,000 engineer man-hours. Today's B-36 takes 3,500,000 hours. That is one reason why the howls over the present shortage of engineers are raised, and it is why the outlook is dismal for supplying the steadily increasing need for more and still more engineering students and graduates.

LONDON, England. -- Less than one hundred yards from the Roosevelt statue in Grosvenor Square, a new bureau has been opened which will help to find accommodations for thousands of visitors before the coronation of Queen Elizabeth II next summer.

A formula used by the Brooklyn Union Gas Company to compute refunds to customers after conversion to natural gas was held subject to review by the courts rather than the Public Service Commission in a ruling yesterday by Justice Daniel Gutman in Brooklyn Municipal Court.

PARIS, Jan. 17 -- The secretary general of the company controlling the Monte Carlo Casino, Auguste Bernard, was quoted tonight as doubting that Aristotle Socrates Onassis, Greek-born shipping magnate, had bought a large enough bloc of shares in the company to give him control over the Casino.
RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 17 -- The next United States Commissioner of Internal Revenue is a longtime trouble-shooter who believes firmly that the Federal Government's financial methods can be improved.

ADELAIDE, Australia -- Two new luxury trains that have recently gone into service on the transcontinental run of the Australian Commonwealth Railways provide what is said to be the world's smoothest ride on rails over one of the world's most desolate stretches of track.

" MY antecedents," Henry Miller says in this book, "are the romantic, demonic, confessional, subjective types of writer." TO adult motorists a truck is either a nuisance or a menace, but to most small boys it is a source of wonder, as compelling as a train or an airplane. WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (UP) -- It was a sort of "good-by day" at the White House today. Old friends dropped by to shake hands and bid godspeed to President Truman. Little business was done.

The annual tea and cocktail dance under the auspices of the Lower East Side Committee of the Visiting Nurse Service of New York will be given on Thursday in the Crystal Room of the Park Lane. Proceeds will be donated to the needs of the Visiting Nurse Service of New York, founded by Lillian D. Wald in 1893.

IT is an established principle of bridge that if you can surely beat an opposing slam bid you don't double it. It is profitable enough to score an undoubled penalty when, presumably, the opponents could have made a game. A double might warn the opponents to try another contract, and they might make it.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 17 -- Trade unions of the Federal Republic of West Germany have scored a marked victory in their first great post-war test of strength with the industrial barons of the Ruhr.

MOUNT HOPE, N. Y., Jan. 17 -- The Toronto Granites' Argyle Campbell rink, with Gordon Campbell as skip, defeated the Winchester (Mass.) No. 2 rink, skipped by Richard B. Neiley, 19 -- 3, at St. Andrew's Golf Club's indoor curling rink tonight to reach the final of the eighteenth bonspeil for the Douglas Medal.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 17 -- In view of the number of Harvard University men already named by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower to key posts in the new Administration some segments of the alumni body are enjoying a quiet chuckle over remark made by him in a campaign speech last September.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Jan. 17 -- Five high school buildings, two junior high schools and twenty-one elementary school structures will be built in Bergen County this year at a cost of $43,000,000, according to figures supplied to County Superintendent of Schools Roy R. Zimmerman.

A forty-five-minute documentary sound film on combating juvenile gang delinquency has just been completed by students in the City College Institute of Film Techniques. Entitled "Step by Step," the film depicts actual gang treatment work along New York's upper West Side by the college's Community Service Division.

AT the annual meeting of the Horticultural Society of New York held last Wednesday at the Essex house, eighteen awards were presented to exhibitors who had accumulated the most points at the Society's monthly shows during 1952.

Forty-five thousand visitors attended yesterday the opening session of General Motors Corporation's Motorama of 1953 at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel to look over the 135 exhibits of automobiles and other products.

Now these same readers, plus those who missed the first voyage. can go along with skipper All-card and Temptress on the return trip.

Awards to 103 of the safest industrial plants in the metropolitan area will be made on Jan. 29 by the Greater New York Safety Council at a dinner at the New Yorker Hotel.

IF the ordinary people who travel by scheduled airlines are somewhat puzzled and confused by the current controversy as to how many people shall ride in a tourist-class plane, there is little wonder. A lot of people in the aviation business are almost equally puzzled and confused.

THE motion picture industry is feverishly striving to come up with a technical development that will put theatres out front in the contest with television for the public's attention. Experiments with cameras, projectors and screens are being pushed as never before at every major studio, but little actual knowledge of what is being accomplished has leaked out.

TOM CORBIN'S father was a reasonable man. When 12-year-old Tom had a great hankering to be a sailor on the Great Lakes. Mr. Corbin arranged for him to ship as cabin boy on the schooner Sea Gull. A passage to Buffalo and back to Milwaukee ought "to get the sailing idea out of his system."

Plans were advanced at recent tea meetings on the Tea Terrace of the Waldorf-Astoria for the bridge and canasta party to assist the Association for the Relief of Respectable, Aged, Indigent Females to be held on Jan. 26 at the Colony Club.

Four members of the Fordham University faculty have received grants totaling $32,157 for advanced research work in science. The National Cancer Institute, United States Public Health Service, gave $2,160 to the Rev. Charles A. Berger, chairman of the Fordham Biology Department, for the study of mitosis.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- This capital, drawing on the nation's top-level organizational and entertainment facilities, but relying mainly on its own heritage of quadrennial extravaganzas, stands apprehensively ready for what many declare will be the biggest, flashiest, most expensive and impressive Inauguration party of them all.

TOKYO, Jan. 17 -- The Japanese Government and the United States military command served grim notice this week on an unspecified foreign power -- immediately identified in the public mind as Soviet Russia -- that all "necessary measures" would henceforth be taken to end the intrusions of its army aircraft over Japan's northernmost island of Hokkaido.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Jan. 17 -- Middlebury College announced today the faculty members and lecturers for the thirty-fourth session of its Bread Loaf School of English. The 1953 session runs from June 24 through Aug. 8 at the mountain campus. Prof. Reginald L. Cook of Middlebury directs the school.

TORONTO, Jan. 17 -- The Toronto Maple Leafs cashed in on a minor penalty to Harry Howell, rookie New York defenseman, in the third period tonight to beat the Rangers, 1 -- 0, in a National Hockey League game.

The House Ways and Means Committee is considering an amendment to a section of the Internal Revenue Code that is designed to eliminate what has been termed unfair discrimination in favor of foreign lines as against American-flag lines engaged in overseas passenger service.
ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 17 -- Mark-Ye-Well, 7-20 favorite from the Calumet Farm, scored a length-and-a-half victory in the $27,900 San Fernando Stakes at Santa Anita Park today.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 17 (AP) -- The Louisville Times said today that "the Army is struggling with a sizable [absent without leave] land desertion problem right in the shadow of the Pentagon."

LONDON, Jan 17 -- The Polish Government has made a strong protest against "spying and diversionist activities on Polish territory" organized by the United States Government, the Warsaw radio said today.

IN England some of the old believers have been recently distressed because the public has not contributed enough money to keep Bernard Shaw's house at Ayot St. Lawrence open as a memorial. Less than one thousand pounds have been donated; 250,000 are wanted to maintain the house and also perform other functions in association with Shaw's name.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Plans for major changes in the Government's public power program were indicated today by Douglas McKay, President-elect Eisenhower's choice for Secretary of the Interior. He proposes to give privately owned utilities a bigger share of the power business.

THE story of "Cast the First Stone" is told in the first person by Jimmy Monroe, a young convict who has drawn a twenty-to-twenty-five-year bit for armed robbery. It is something of a tour de force in that it has the curiously authentic quality of reading exactly like the autobiography of one of those penitentiary lawyers very often thrown up by prison life.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- A "strong" President, such as General Eisenhower is expected to be, usually has had either a submissive or a hostile Congress to deal with. An enduring state of harmony between the executive and the legislative generally occurs when the President lavishly interprets the provision in the Constitution that Congress is a "coordinate" member of the Government trinity.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Jan. 17 -- Tommy Bolt survived the severest sorts of challenges today, including a rival's 8-under-par 64, but managed to remain on top at the end of the third round of the $10,000 San Diego open golf tournament.

MANIZALES, Colombia, Jan. 17 -- A code of social action for the Roman Catholic Church in South America was approved here today at the final business session of the first Latin American Congress on Rural Life Problems.

The Knickerbockers, seeking to catch the pace-setting Syracuse Nationals in the Eastern Division of the National Basketball Association, moved to within one-half game of the leaders last night when they registered an 84-to-76 victory over the Philadelphia Warriors at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The stream of inauguration visitors, a stream that was expected to grow to flood proportions before Monday, began flowing into the Capital this morning through all arteries of transportation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Fort the first time in twenty years the high command of the Republican party finds itself in that enviable place at the head of the table with a succulent patronage turkey before it to be carved and served to a famished family of constituents.

BONN, Jan. 17 -- None of the American proconsuls who have come to Germany since the war faced a more difficult task than James B. Conant, President of Harvard, who late this month will begin his duties as United States High Commissioner to the Federal Republic of Germany.

With an estimated 55,000 cases, the highest in the nation's history, poliomyelitis last year was a medical paradox. At the same time that thirty states were having outbreaks of epidemic proportions, 1952 brought the first scientific demonstration of a temporary preventive for polio -- gamma globulin.

BOSTON, Jan. 17 -- A statewide campaign for the protection of constitutional rights and liberties was announced today by the Massachusetts Council of Churches, representing ten Protestant denominations.

ON the title page of this book there is an appropriate drawing of two outstretched hands about to clench in friendship. The American diplomat's hand is open; the Soviet hand is withdrawn into a tight fist. The drawing helps to sum up another winning performance by Charles Thayer, the State Department's fun-loving Russian expert, whose pre-war adventures in Moscow as third secretary were delightfully noted in "Bears in the Caviar."

THIS department is in receipt of an interesting letter from Franco Colombo, managing director of G. Ricordi Co., publishers of the Puccini operas and of the English translation of "La Boheme" by Howard Dietz, with which the present commentator has taken issue. Mr. Colombo writes as follows:

WHAT does a boy gain by going to college? Stub Larsen wasn't sure. What Quilby College could do for him was still a question on opening day. It was answered by the new friends and experiences he found on that Midwestern coeducational campus.
The estimated 1,540,000 marriages in the United States in 1952, Metropolitan Life Insurance Company statisticians point out, is a decrease of 4 per cent from the 1951 total.

ABOARD the train bound for Wilmington, Delaware, where a preliminary trial of "The Crucible" was to be held, prior to its opening here on Thursday night at the Martin Beck, playwright Arthur Miller and director Jed Harris settled down in their compartment.

BELGRADE, Jan. 17 -- Each day one may find in the Yugoslav press some attack on the Vatican, with which the Government has broken diplomatic relations, some bitter denounciation of Cardinal Stepinac, whose elevation to Cardinal contributed to the break, and, ironically, some editorial comment that this or that foreign news report was designed solely to keep the church issue alive.

THREE books have cracked the best-seller list in 1953 -- two of them late 1952 entries and proof (if proof were needed) that public taste is just as fickle in a relatively slack month as it is when the choice of new books is more abundant. The additions, you will note, are all novels ("Executive Suite," by Cameron Hawley; "the Magic Lantern," by Robert Carson, and "The Sojourner" by Marjorie Kinnan Rawlings).

PHOENIX, Ariz -- Arizona, the only state in the Union without a state park system, is thinking about rectifying the situation. Governor Howard Pyle told the 1953 Legislature when it met this week that some administrative agency of the sort was "urgently needed," and suggested that it be a subject of special attention.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 17 -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh, who met United States Ambassador Loy W. Henderson again this evening to discuss settlement of Iran's oil dispute with Britain, asked the Iranian Parliament today to expedite its vote on the extension of his emergency powers.

FOR THIS WEEK: Start lily of the valley pips in bowls of fiber and water for bloom in not more them a month. . . . Get rid of perennial weeds by treating with chemical brush-killer. . . . Bring pots of Easter lilies into a warmer place (about 68 degrees) and fertilize every two-weeks. Calla Lilies also need fertilizer and ample watering. . . .

Manhattan College's quartet came from behind last night to edge Wagner, 61 to 53, in the loser's gymnasium at Grymes Hill, S. I. After the Seahawks had jumped to a 5-1 advantage early in the first period, it was a seesaw battle for the remainder of the half.

While one can certainly find no great objection to a new translation in itself, any modern work of translation will have to go very far to surpass the magnificent and scholarly King James Version of the Bible. This book was a great labor of love, a part of the slow and bitter struggle to bring the truth to the people thirsting for it and which helped create the Renaissance and our modern times.

The first report of the Fund for the Advancement of Education, created by the Ford Foundation, has now been issued, and all of us who are concerned with the strengthening of the democratic way of life have reasons to be gratified at the beginnings made by this new agency.

MONTREAL, Jan. 17 (UP) -- The Montreal Canadiens battled to a 1-1 tie with the league-leading Detroit Red Wings tonight as Maurice (Rocket) Richard went on a one-man tear and drew the most penalties of any game in which he has played during his eleven-year National Hockey League career.

The inauguration was delayed. It was supposed to take place on March 4, it was now April, and no President or Congress in sight. It is true a Government had been proclaimed in New York, the capital, on March 4; cannon had boomed and people had cheered, but that was all.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower ran into new Senatorial snags yesterday that denied to him a full functioning Cabinet on Inauguration Day and forced him to delay, and probably to abandon, plans to appoint former Gov. Val Peterson of Nebraska as Ambassador to India.

RECENTLY a very rich and very generous man offered a huge sum of money to found a beautifully modern orphans' home. Nobody, fortunately, accepted his well-meaning proposal. The orphan asylum as we used to know it has practically disappeared. Although the child population of the whole country has increased by 18,000,000 during the last fifty years, the number of orphaned has dropped below 100,000 -- most of whom are with their own relatives.

Cancellation or suspension is urged by the National Retail Dry Goods Association of the proposed new regulation of the Post Office Department which would assess a 20-cent surcharge on practically all parcel post packages, handled and transported outside of mail sacks. The regulation is scheduled to go into effect on April 1.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 18 -- The Israeli Foreign Minister, Moshe Sharett, declared today upon his return from the Asian Socialist conference at Rangoon, Burma, that he believed the conference had "offered a new approach" to the solution of Asian problems.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 18 -- An open break on the major issue of policy occurred today between the two most important personalities in Iran's ruling coalition, Premier Mohammed Mossadegh and his long-time ally, Ayatollah Sayed Abolghassem Kashani, Speaker of the Majlis, or lower house.
The Carnegie Corporation of New York granted $1,660,000 to twenty-nine educational institutions and agencies in this country, Canada and Hawaii in the last three months of 1952.

Mayor Impellitteri announced yesterday that he planned to discuss with representatives of the Welfare and Health Council of New York City the establishment of a central agency for collecting and collating all relevant information on employment conditions and the economic factors involved.

A study by the Regional Plan Association of the precise geographical distribution of the 14,000,000 inhabitants of the New Jersey-New York-Connecticut metropolitan region indicates that New York commuters are relying more and more on their own motor cars and less and less on established transit lines to get them to and from work.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 18 -- Elimination or revision of three emergency provisions of the Taft-Hartley Law because they failed to solve the labor-management problem at which they were aimed was recommended here today by Dr. Harry Shulman, Sterling Professor of Law at Yale University.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Possible authorization for the New York Power Authority to go into partnership with the Province of Ontario in hydroelectric development of the International Rapids of the St. Lawrence River depends at the moment on the attitude the Federal Power Commission will take toward the application of H. A. Spalinski, president of the Public Power and Water Corporation of Trenton, N. J.

Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, failed yesterday to make his scheduled appearance on the television program "Youth Wants to Know," presented by the National Broadcasting Company in cooperation with the American Legion. The program originated in Washington.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 17 -- These are worried days for the Israelis. On the one hand, they see in the Slansky trial and the Moscow charges of medical murder proof that the Soviet bloc has become overtly anti-Jewish. On the other hand, they are nervous about the Eisenhower Administration.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, Republican leader of the Senate, looked today to Herbert Brownell Jr., the Attorney General-designate, to suggest a way Charles E. Wilson could be confirmed as Secretary of Defense without liquidating his General Motors stock holdings.

Life needs something more than an advantage to make it great, for trouble carries its own secret blessings, the Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo declared yesterday morning in his sermon at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church at Fifty-fifth Street.

Defense Secretary Lovett will lay down this week one of the heaviest burdens in our public life. He has been obliged to fill this exacting post in a period of grave stresses and to be in the position of making responsible decisions of world-wide importance.

LAS VEGAS. Nev. Jan. 18 -- Construction crews at the Atomic Energy Commission's 600-square- mile desert proving ground near here are rushing work on the stage setting for what is expected to be a $1,000,000 test of the nation's new atomic artillery.

The six-story apartment house at 91 East 208th Street, in the Mosholu Parkway section of the Bronx, has been purchased by an investing client of Nathan Weber, attorney, from Walter Berger and Leo A. Bercow, operators. It is assessed at $215,000.

THE accused who stood in the prisoners' dock was only 18, a short, frail, weakly, handsome youth. Most of the crowd packed into the courtroom was sympathetic and believed him innocent of the crime with which he was charged, the murder of his father. Rupert Laurence Anderson, son of Robert Hemsley Anderson, a moderately successful but undistinguished small-town lawyer, pleaded not guilty.

The marketer is winning over the engineer, the lawyer, the financier and the production man in top management of manufacture. A survey of thirty companies manufacturing for both industry and the consumer, with a combined volume, of $43,600,000,000, revealed that the man with ten years of selling experience is more and more chosen to the board of directors.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 18 -- More than 1,000 convicts, screaming curses and shouting for prison reforms, rioted at Western State Penitentiary tonight. They set fire to the sprawling prison and seized five guards as hostages.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18 -- Soybeans again topped any of the grains in volume of trade last week, purchases being approximately 89,000,000 bushels. Corn was next in line with 64,600,000 bushels. Wheat pit operations fell below the previous week and compared with 40,739,000 bushels a year ago.

Gem I2wight D. Eisenhower left his hom@ at 60 A@orningside Drive for the last time yesterday afternoon, said good-by to the throng gathered to Wish him well, and! left on a special train at 5:10 for Washington to take up his new job as President of the United States.
I wish to congratulate the editors and the staff of THE NEW YORK TIMES upon your survey of the Point Four program which was published in your issue of Jan. 12.

PARIS, Jan. 18 -- An attack on one of the sources of French governmental instability -- the weakness of the executive in relation to an unruly Parliament -- will be pushed actively beginning this week by the near Cabinet of Premier Rene Mayer.
WASHINGTON, Jan 18 (UP)Members of the outgoing Cabinet will be out of the Government-but not out of work--when the new Admilxistration takes over Tuesday.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Jan. 18 -- Roy Sherwood of Salisbury, Conn., completed a week-end sweep of the ski jumping trophies at this 50-meter hill today by taking the Harold E. Doerr Memorial event with the day's longest jumps of 153 and 150 feet.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 18 -- Polish purchases of Swedish iron ore, which ranks high on the strategic materials list, are now endangered by the Polish failure to deliver coal to Sweden in desired quantities.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 18 -- Virtually every aspect of world migration is covered in a ninety-page report to be submitted to the United Nations Population Commission as it convenes here tomorrow. The mimeographed document incorporates the results of seventy study or research activities, conducted since 1946 by the United Nations or its specialized agencies.

TOKYO, Monday, Jan. 19 -- United Nations artillery and fighter-bombers attacked Chinese Communist units moving in the open behind the central Korean front at midday yesterday and killed about 160 of the foe.
MOSCOW, Jan. 18 -- The Soviet press reported today a widening movement against all types of security and vigilance violations.

AMSTERDAM, Jan. 18 -- Yet another sign of the improved Dutch monetary position is that the Netherlands Bank this week practically abolished the so-called "Dera" list containing the names of dollar securities into which Dutch holders of original dollar securities are allowed to exchange their holdings.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 18 -- Mexico's leading Roman Catholics, both laymen and clerics, have converged on the provincial city of Guadalajara for the opening of their first national congress of Catholic culture tomorrow.

Lanny Ross, the popular radio and television tenor, has shown signs from time to time of wanting a concert career. During the 1936-37 season he gave two recitals in New York, and last night he came back for another try, giving a program at Town Hall.
BOSTON, Jan. 15 (UP) -- Woody Dumart, scoring his first goal in nearly a month, furnished the punch as the Boston Bruins beat the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight in a National Hockey League game.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Jan. 18 -- A new approach to the early development of the powers of critical thought and expression among college students was announced today at Brown University, and will be tried probably beginning with the next academic year.

HICKSVILLE, L. I., Jan. 18 -- A head-on collision, ultimately involving three cars, brought death here early this morning to Joseph J. Burkhard, retired policeman who was head of the New York City Patrolmen's Benevolent Association for three terms; and to Miss Mary Lou Ceruti, 22 years old, of 166-05 Highland Avenue, Jamaica, Queens.
Mortgage financing amounting to $3,940,000 has been arranged by the Triboro Mortgage Service for two housing developments in Yonkers, N. Y., and Woodmere, L. I.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Monday, Jan. 19 -- Official United States reports said a Navy Neptune patrol plane was shot down yesterday by Communist anti-aircraft guns off the coast of South China and a United States Navy Mariner amphibian plane sank while taking off with eleven of the Neptune's survivors.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Jan. 18 (AP) -- Tommy Bolt registered his fourth consecutive sub-par round today to capture the $10,000 San Diego open golf tournament with a 14-under-par score of 274 for 72 holes.
BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Italy's Alberto Ascari won Argentina's Grand Prix automobile championship today. Five persons were-killed when another Italian car crashed into a line of spectators.

Recent rejection of an application of the Planned Parenthood Committee of Mothers Health Centers for membership in the Welfare and Health Council of New York City because of disapproval by Roman Catholics was characterized yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Adam Clayton Powell Jr., pastor of the Abyssinian Baptist Church, 132 West 138th Street, as "undemocratic" and "un-Christlike."

Two benefit exhibitions are featured on this week's art program. Paintings by the late Albert Marquet will be shown at Wildenatein's beginning Wednesday for the benefit of the Alliance Francaise scholarship fund for American students. It will open tomorrow evening with a special preview at which admission will be $5. Thereafter admission will be free.

When 4,500 bus strikers were told yesterday that City Hall mediation conferences had failed to produce any basis for settlement of their eighteen-day walkout, they roared their approval of union demands for an official investigation to determine whether "any member of the Board of Estimate or his brother-in-law" had acquired a controlling interest in securities of the struck bus companies.

The fight for establishment of "watchdog" grand juries in this state is being continued by the Grand Jury Association of New York, Inc., despite the failure of enabling bills to pass the Legislature in 1952 and 1951.
The concert presented yesterday at Town Hall by the New Friends of Music came off a little differently than originally scheduled.

SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 18 -- Directors of the Walker Bank and Trust Company have named Reed E. Holt executive vice president of the institution. The title is a new one at the bank. Mr. Holt served as vice president until the promotion.

The State Clime Commission will resume today its public hearings into waterfront evils with the aid of information obtained in the last few weeks by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and through private examination of witnesses by the commission's investigators.

We cannot have less government if private enterprise fails to alleviate social ills, Dean James A. Pike of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine said in a sermon yesterday. "Big government," he declared, "is an expression of human sin."

MOUNT HOPE, N. Y., Jan. 18 -- The Hamilton (Ont.) Thistles, skipped by Ross Tarlton, captured the Douglas Medal for the fourth time in six years by defeating the Argyle Campbell rink of the Toronto Granite Club's curling organization, 14 to 9, in their All-Canadian 14-end final this afternoon at the St. Andrew's Golf Club.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Women speakers representing the Democratic and Republican parties agreed today that women have an important role in elections and politics -- but that's about all they agreed on.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The nineteen-member executive committee of the Republican National Committee started today to map plans for the Congressional elections of 1954.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower arrived in Washington tonight just about forty hours before he was to take the oath of office as the thirty-fourth President of the United States and bring to an end twenty years of Democratic rule under the New and Fair Deals.

The Jaccar Realty Corporation sold the three-story store and loft building on plot 108 by 246 feet at 278-86 North Avenue, New Rochelle, N. Y., to the 320-28 Webster Avenue Corporation, which insured title with the Security Title and Guaranty Company.

With the backing of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the President-elect, a new program to help Korean universities overcome "conditions of want and privation to a degree unheard of in the present century" and to train future democratic leaders was announced yesterday by the World Student Service Fund.

As the country grows older, more and more companies will put on years and come to consider themselves Significant -- in capitals. A great many tame authors will write a great many pages of rich, juicy, appreciative prose on the Pioneers of Business, the Rugged Individualists, the Men With Ideas.

An all-day conference called "We Meet for Children" will be conducted Saturday. by the Play Schools Association at Public School 125, at 425 West 123d Street. Mrs. Ralph J. Bunche, chairman of the association's conference committee, will preside.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 18 -- West German universities, technical high schools and research institutes appear to be well on the road toward recovering, at least in part, the important position they once held in German life in the pre-Nazi era.

PARIS, Jan. 18 -- Three facts stand out in the year-end accounts of the European Payments Union, just published: Great Britain is rapidly improving her payments situation, France is continuing her indebtedness and West Germany has become a debtor after having been a creditor.

New York has just made awards totaling $758,654 to two hotels, a hospital and a church damaged by one of the city's contributions toward a fitting approach to the home for the United Nations -- the widening and rearranging of East Forty-second Street between First and Second Avenues.

TRENTOI@,-Jan. 18---A brief ses-j sion of the New Jersey Legislature be held tomorrow morning before many of the legislators join state Republican leaders in a trip to W.ashington for the Eisenhower inauguration. The session will be limited to introduet/on of bills.

TORONTO, Jan. 18 -- John Laughlin, a 104-year-old eccentric recluse, owner of 150 parcels of real estate and reckoned a millionaire, died today of cooking-gas poisoning in his squalid, junk-filled home. The accident also felled his 62-year-old son, John, Jr., but twenty minutes work with an inhalator revived the younger man.

David E. Lilienthal, former chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority and the Atomic Energy Commission, has a new book scheduled for Feb. 18 publication by Harper. "Big Business: A New Era" analyzes the creativenes of America today as it has evolved through the functioning of "Big Business."

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Jan. 18 -- When the Union of South Africa's Parliament opens this week for a brief session that is to be followed by a national election campaign, it will bring to a focus the sharpest political quarrel in this area since Britain crushed the doughty Boers fifty-one years ago.

Extra-heavy use of silver for coinage last year kept world silver consumption about even with the 1951 level, according to the Handy Harman annual silver market review, published today for the thirty-seventh time. The bullion brokers estimate that the world consumed about 251,300,000 ounces of silver, against 232,100,000 the year before. Production figures are incomplete.

LEXINGTON, Va., Jan. 18 -- A research center for the collection and preservation of the papers and documented record of the career of Gen. George C. Marshall will be established here at Virginia Military Institute, where the former soldier-statesman attended college.

The men's clothing industry produced about 17,565,000 suits during the first eleven months of 1952 and probably manufactured less than 19,000,000 units during the year, according to Harry A. Cobrin, executive secretary of the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U. S. A. During 1951, production was 19,559,000 suits.

' WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (UP)Michael W. Straus, retiring Reclamation Commissioner, predicted today that some Republicans in the new Administration would try "to pull out the cornerstones" of the Government's irrigation and pubIic power programs.

Clifford Curzon, the English pianist, gave a recital Saturday night at Hunter College Auditorium. His chaste and nobel program was devoted to familiar works, which were played with a profundity of insight, soulfulness and wealth of imagination rarely encountered nowadays.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 18 -- Three theories are being advanced by United States, British and German experts on Russia to explain the current events in the Soviet Union.
TOKYO, Monday, Jan. 19 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,499 for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Monday, Korean time:
The Zionist Organization of America called on Soviet Russia yesterday to release 2,500,000 Jews in that country and the satellite states for emigration to Israel.

Eugene Conley will play the part of the Rake, Mack Harrell will be Nick Shadow, Hilde Gueden will be Anne Truelove and Blanche The-bom will be Baba, the Turk, on Feb. 14 in the first American performance of Igor Stravinsky's "The Rake's Progress" at the Metropolitan Opera House.

The interest shown by THE NEW YORK TIMES and others in the education budget is gratifying. We refer to your editorial of Jan. 14, "Low Fare vs. Schools." However the use of the schools as a "whipping post" with which to increase the transit fares is disturbing.

BERLIN. Jan. 18 (UP) -- Flying squads of Communist police hunting "Zionist spies" swooped down on the homes and offices of Jews throughout East Germany today, seized papers and identity cards, and ordered the Jews to stay close to home.

DETROIT, Jan. 18 (UP) -- Two third-period goals lifted the Montreal Canadiens to a 3-2 victory over the league-leading Detroit Red Wings tonight before 15,303 fans, the largest crowd of the season at Olympia.
RIVERSIDE, Conn., Jan. 18 -- The Frank K. Sheldon family monopolized today's frostbite championship regatta, the opener of the mid-winter series, at the Riverside Yacht Club.

AKRON, Ohio, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Firestone Tire and Rubber Company today reported net income of $43,081,717, equal to $10.89 a common share, for 1952 compared with $48,398,950, or $12.26, the previous year.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., Jan. 18 -- There was just enough breath of breeze today to waft around twenty sailing dinghies in six short races of the Larchmont Yacht Club.

GUATEMALA, Jan, 18 -- Two anti-Communist candidates appear to have won seats in the Guatemalan Congress in the elections that started Friday and ended today, according to unofficial and incomplete returns.

The second annual Carioca Ball for the benefit of the Foundation Napoleao Laureano of the National Service for Cancer Research in Brazil will be held Feb. 12 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The event has been arranged through the Damon Runyon Cancer Fund, and will take place under the auspices of the Brazilian Cultural Society, Inc., in cooperation with the Brazilian Consulate General and the Brazilian Government Trade Bureau.

Fog in Europe forced a delay yesterday in the plane flight on which Yuri V. Novikov, second secretary of the Soviet Embassy, whose recall had been demanded by the United States, was to leave New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens. Sabena Belgian Air Lines said the flight would leave at 10 A. M. today.

LONDON, Jam 18 (Reuters) -- Ten persons charged with spying for the United States against Communist Bulgaria will go on trial in a Sofia court tomorrow, the official Bulgarian News Agency reported here.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Jan. 18 (UP) -- American four-man bobsled teams gained second and fourth places in the international championships today as a German crew piloted by Hans Roesch scored a record victory.

BOSTON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Boston's Bob Cousy set a National Basketball Association record with eighteen assists today as he led the Celtics to a 99-83 victory over the New York Knickerbockers in the second game of an A. B. A. twin bill.

STRASBOURG, France, Jan. 18 -- Two divergent directives worked out in a series of meetings last week were forwarded today as guidance to the special drafting committee that will complete a text for a six-nation European political constitution.

After moving into new low ground for the season at the outset of last week, cotton prices in the domestic market turned firmer to close the week with only moderate net changes. At the close of trading on Friday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were 6 points lower to 21 points higher, or 30 cents off to $1.05 a bale higher, from the levels of the preceding week.

The drive of Commissioner Paduano of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity to effect economies in city operation by persuading city departments to go easy on water, light and power may not bring about any radical savings in a $1,500,000,000 budget, but at least it is a step in the right direction.

The first proof of cargo diversion brought about by waterfront work stoppages here is expected if the current damage suit brought by steamship lines against the International Longshoremen's Association goes on trial, shipping men said yesterday.

WASMINGTON, Jan. 18--Carpenters raced against time in a remote corner of the National Guard Armory here today to complete an added starter to the procession of floats in Tuesday's Inaugural Parade. To the three men who conceived the idea it is k@ow'n as "God's Float."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (UP)Attorney General James P. IVicGranery said today that he helieved his successor, Herbert /3rownell Jr., would bring to a "fruitful conclusion" the Justice Department clean-up that Air. 1V[eGranery started.

Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense-designate and still president of the General Motors Corporation, strolled leisurely through the Motorama of 1953 at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday. He inspected with interest and approval all the exhibits in the G. M. organization's show, which drew an estimated attendance of 50,000 before closing time.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 18 -- Steel production last week remained unchanged at 98.5 per cent of capacity and somewhat the same rate was expected this week. There is every indication that steel production this month will make a new high for the month of January.

In the agrarian South, North Carolina is one of the most agrarian of states, with one-third of its population earning its livelihood on farms. The state has been linking these farms to markets with hard-surfaced highways under a $200 million road-building program now nearly completed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, the Defense Department's manpower chief, said today that a monthly draft call of 52,000, at least until summer, and a tightening up of deferments, including those for some fathers, were needed to keep the nation's military strength at 3,600,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 18 (UP) -- Paul G. Hoffman, former Economic Cooperation Administrator, said today that he thought the Senate should confirm Mr. Wilson as Defense Secretary despite his refusal to give up his General Motors stock holdings.

@VASH@GTOI@, Jan. /$ (UP)--I The forthcoming inauguration ofl Gem Dwight D. Eisenhower as/ President on Tuesday recalls some i inaugur@ "firsts," for example: First inauguration h@d outdoors ---James 1Vionroe, 1817.

Inflated costs have compelled many communities in this area to double their school expenditures in the last twelve years, it was announced yesterday in a report made public by the Metro politan School Study Council.

CAIRO, Jan 18 (Reuters) -- The Government of Premier Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib will take drastic action against the foreign power linked with Egyptian anti- state plotters, an authoritative spokesman said tonight.
Three new films, including an importation from Poland, will arrive in first-run houses this week. The programs follow:

STOWE, Vt., Jan. 18 -- Othmar Schneider, the stylish Tyrolean from Lech - Am - Arlberg, Austria, one of the world's foremost Alpine racers, today completed a sweep of the sixth annual Capt. Victor Constant Memorial races.

LONDON, Jan. 18 -- The quietly cheerful manner in which the stock markets opened the new year has, in the past week, shown signs of blossoming into something more impressive. Expectations that when the large amount of money temporarily locked up in connection with the sensational oversubscription of the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company issue was returned it would seek investment either speculative or permanent in other directions appear to have been confirmed.
CHICAGO, Jan. 18 -- The men who put up most of the homes in America began arriving here today from all parts of the country for the formal opening tomorrow of their biggest annual convention.

OSLO, Norway, Jan. 18 (UP) -- Kees Broekman of the Netherlands finished first today in the over-all standings of the two-day international speed-skating meet at Olympic Bislet Stadium where he won the 10,000-meter race and placed fourth in the 1,500-meter event.

PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, Jan. 18 -- Strong opposition has developed in some quarters to the proposed federation of the British West Indies under a single governor general and with a unified customs administration.
ROME, Jan. 18 -- One of the world's editorial curiosities, a quarterly magazine called Latinitas written entirely in Latin, was put on sale in Rome for the first time today.

Peru today is announcing an adjustment program for its dollar debt. It appears to be the same as that suggested on Nov. 13, 1951, in response to complaints by the Foreign Bondholders' Protective Council against the 1947 settlement to which 72 per cent of the holders had assented.

A forum of high-school students generally agreed last night that the continuing Korean war posed the major problem for the incoming Eisenhower Administration. The students heard that State Department quarters were interested in the idea that Soviet Premier Joseph Stalin might have personally "committed" himself to trying to end the war.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18 -- The grain markets last week had the most substantial recovery since mid-December, but whether this meant a change in the price trend was debatable. The reversal started after the lowest prices for the crop year had been established early in the week, and there was basis for belief that the liquidating period had culminated.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18 (UP) -- Goalie Al Rollins scored his third shutout of the season tonight as the Chicago Black Hawks tripped the New York Rangers, 2 -- 0, before 10,814 fans to take third place in the National Hockey League.

No one has been exaggerating Danny Kaye's genius for entertaining. He sang, talked and grimaced for an hour and three quarters at the Palace last evening, and everyone came away beaming and refreshed. Even the crowds massed in Seventh Avenue seemed to have been having a good time, being in the neighborhood.

Two accidents occurred in quick succession at almost the same spot early yesterday on the Miller (West Side) Highway at Forty-fourth Street, injuring eleven persons and causing several minor collisions among cars that had slowed down because of the wrecks. Among the injured were four policemen who had been called to the scene.
CHICAGO, Jan. 18 (UP) -- Only a few states are making active investigations of communism in schools, a survey showed today, but the teacher loyalty oath appears to be gaining in acceptance.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Jack Kramer beat Australia's Frank Sedgman, 22 -- 20, in the longest set of their professional tennis tour here today, but the hour-and-a-half performance prevented completion of the match.

ROME, Jan. 18 -- After taking possession of his titular church this morning. James Francis Cardinal McIntyre, the only American among the twenty-four Roman Catholic prelates elevated to the Sacred College in last week's consistories, left by air on the first stage of his return journey to his Archdiocese of Los Angeles.

Pending the receipt by ecclesiastical authorities here of the full text of the apostolic constitution promulgating new rules governing the eucharistic fast for communicants of the Roman Catholic Church, two relaxations, of the fast were announced yesterday at all masses in St. Patrick's Cathedral.
Modest, perhaps a bit outmoded in appearance, the bakery at 493 Ninth Avenue, between Thirty-seventh and Thirty-eighth Streets, might not attract the eye of the uninitiated shopper.

WAEKINGTON, Jan. 18 (UP)Government fiscal experts predicted today that President-elect Dwight D. Eisenhower would be able to do little in the first year of his administration to increase@ the value of the present "52-cent dollar."
WASHINGTON, Jan, 18 -- Washington was festive and bulging today in anticipation of the first Republican inauguration in twenty-four years.
Prayers for divine guidance ofl Ithe new Federal Administrationl will be offered at many houses ofI worship tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Millions of Americans who cannot get to Washington will see a considerable portion of Tuesday's inaugural ceremonies in their own homes, the television industry said today.

Rent increases granted to New York State landlords in December by the Temporary State Housing Rent Commission totaled 30,547 out of 32,294 applications, Joseph D. McGoldrick, State Rent Administrator, reported yesterday.

BERLIN, Jan. 18 -- President Wilhelm Pieck of East Germany said today that if West Germany ratified its peace contract with the Western powers and the European Defense Community Treaty, measures would be taken to prevent infiltration of West Berlin "criminal elements" into the Soviet sector of the city as well as into East Germany.

Two significant changes in the distribution of population in the New York-New Jersey-Connecticut metropolitan region should be of "special interest to city officials concerned with the mounting parking problem," the Regional Plan Association reported yetserday.

For sixty days beginning at 8 A. M. today, police and fire sirens will be heard again after a twenty-eight-month ban imposed by the city's Office of Civil Defense because the imperative warning sound might be confused with air-raid sirens. Permission for use of sirens on ambulances and on television and radio programs was not granted.

As the various administrations take over, including the main one, there is heard the cry in the land that the new broom will sweep clean. Now there is nothing against a clean sweep -- unless you happen to be the dust -- and every administration, including the main one, is entitled to operate its own way of life.

TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 18 (UP) -- Louise Suggs fired a magnificent six-under-par 68 in the final round of the $5,000 Tampa women's golf tournament today to successfully defend her title and tie a world record with a total score of 288 for 72 holes.

THE Chicago Bears had just walloped the Brooklyn Dodgers and were heading for their dressing room. It was approximately a decade ago and the once white uniforms of the Monsters of the Midway had absorbed dirt and grime from vigorous contact with the Ebbets Field turf.

Raymond A. Norden, president of Seaboard and Western Airlines, pioneer transatlantic all-freight carrier, predicted yesterday that air freight across the North Atlantic this year should be 25 per cent greater than the 1952 record-breaking industry total of 46,000,000-ton miles.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, Jan. 18 -- As had been expected, yesterday's general Parliament elections, the first direct ones, in the history of Iraq, resulted in a victory for the forces of former Premier Nuri es-Said, now a Senator.

Andres Segovia is varying his pattern this year. Instead of presenting a single recital at Town Hall, he is giving two. The first one, on Saturday night, drew so many persons that there were fifty standees and fifty seated on the stage, in addition to the 1,500 in the auditorium.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 18 -- Garson Kanin and his wife, Ruth Gordon, have delivered to Columbia Pictures the second in a series of original screen plays they recently contracted to write for the studio.

Christy Mathewson was pitching against the Cardinals and winning with little trouble. Princeton's Fred Alexander, one of the nation's top netmen, was capturing the metropolitan title in Harlem and the English-bread Sysonby was taking the $20,000 Tidal Stakes at Sheepshead Bay.

Fifty owners of tramp-ship tonnage have replaced their informal committee with a permanent organization to conduct, among other campaigns, a drive for greater consideration by Congress of the industry's needs.

Last week the Federal Reserve authorities announced that the rediscount rate (the rate at which a member bank may borrow from its regional Reserve bank against "eligible" commercial, agricultural and industrial paper) was being stepped up from 1 3/4 per cent to 2 per cent.

Seven young men, four of whom have been out of baseball for the major part of two seasons because of service in the armed forces, yesterday were invited to join the Giants in spring training at Phoenix, Ariz., this year.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 18 -- A steady two-day downpour that brought nearly twelve inches of rain at the Oregon border resulted today in the isolation of several coastal communities in northern California.

A delightful and instructive television program on the meaning of movement in the dance, which made ballet and the modern dance vividly comprehensible and enjoyable to the layman, was offered at 3 o'clock on Saturday afternoon over WCBS-TV.

MADRID, Jan. 18 -- In an effort to curb widespread tax evasion, the Spanish Government has decided to tighten its tax-collecting system, which in the past has given the state less than 10 percent of the national income.

The Chinese Nationalist Government is able to report that Formosa's foreign trade for 1952 was in the black. In a total of about a quarter of a billion dollars exports exceeded imports by about four and a half million dollars. The largest import commodity was fertilizer, designed to increase agricultural production and the export of agricultural products.

Although he is convinced that the American people "regard the coming inauguration of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower with solemnity and in the spirit of prayer," the Rev. Dr. Edgar Franklin Romig cautioned in a sermon yesterday morning that "manifestly a power greater than ourselves is necessary if we are to look with confidence to a new Administration."

PJJTT.ADELPI-IIA, Jan. 1E-W. L /vlyers, chairman of the interim Commission on AgxSculture of Gem Dwight D. Eisenhower, President-elect, says a recession is likely some time during the middle Nineteen Fifties.

Operations of the West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company in the fiscal year ended last Oct. 31 resulted in a net profit after taxes and all charges of $9,471,000, compared with $10,326,000 earned in the previous fiscal year.

Giving a polished exhibition, Phyllis Schroeder of the Skating Club of New York and Martin Forney of the Hershey (Pa.) Figure Skating Club captured the Silver Dance event as the Middle Atlantic figure skating program came to a close at Iceland yesterday.

The Swiss Football Club of the German-American League upset Brookhattan-Galicia of the American League, 2-1, in a National Challenge Cup soccer match yesterday at Sterling Oval, the Bronx. A record crowd of 3,000 saw the Brookhattans eliminated from the competition of the United States Soccer Football Association.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (UP) -- Mrs. George Gordon Moore announced today that she would wear a new white gown to the Presidential Inaugural Ball. But the only reason she got a new dress is because her sister, Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower, insisted on it.

The increasing variety in materials used for contemporary accessories is pointed up by three collections introduced here today. They are by Ferris-Shacknove, designers who formerly concentrated on black iron and have now turned to brass and wood.
The fashion for stoles was revived almost two seasons ago, and now, instead of waning, has taken on new impetus for spring. Leading designers show stoles with a great many of the new spring designs.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (UP) -- Robert C. Goodwin, director of the Labor Department's Bureau of Employment Security, predicted today that employment would reach a record-breaking peak of 63,000,000 this year.
