WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The Inauguration festivities were started today with a reception for the nation's Governors that filled the entire mezzanine of the Statler Hotel with a mood of jubilation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- A new Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee on subversion was reported today to be planning an investigation of Government policies for preventing disloyal Americans from getting or holding jobs with the United Nations and other international organizations.

It is valuable to be reminded -- as we were last week -- that nazism is not dead in Germany. We need to be taught that lesson again and again for a variety of reasons. Among them is the postulate that totalitarianism, whether of the left or of the right, is a profoundly felt and virile manifestation of our times.

The results of a three-year study of the nursing profession, published yesterday by the Russell Sage Foundation, indicate a critical shortage of nurses has developed and that much of the blame for the shortage rests on colleges and universities for failing to provide adequate nursing education.
Theatregoers will be gratified to know that better things are in store for the last half of a wobbly season. At least, it looks that way on paper.

An agreement among three American and three Dutch manufacturers was announced yesterday through which technical assistance will be provided from here for the construction in Holland of a hundred diesel-electric locomotives for the Netherlands Railways, at a total value of about $15,000,000.

The general improvement in loan rates has "eased but by no means solved" the problem of inadequate bank earnings, S. Sloan Colt, president of Bankers Trust Company, says in his annual report to the stockholders. The report, now being mailed to the stockholders in advance of their meeting on Jan. 28, points out that the bank will mark its fiftieth anniversary on March 30.

LONDON, Jan. 18 -- Jews behind the Iron Curtain were warned today by Jewish leaders here that their hope of safety lay in flight. Prof. Selig Brodetsky, former president of the Board bf Deputies of British Jews, said to that organization:

ALBANY, Jan 18 -- Strong pressure is being developed by New York educational, teacher and parent organizations to have any legislative program for solving the city's recurrent budgetary crises include some provision making the Board of Education financially independent of the City Administration and Board of Estimate.
ALBANY, Jan. 18 -- The Dewey Administration has turned thumbs down on a request by Civil Service organizations for a pay increase for state employes.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., Jan. 18 -- Credited with three first and one fourth place ribbons, Royal Knight, a 6-year-old gray gelding owned by Harry D. Ryan of Uniontown, Pa., won the open jumper championship today as the second winter show of the Northern New Jersey Horse Shows Association ended at the West Orange Armory.

MONTPELIER, Vt., Jan. 18 -- About 500 Vermont clergymen, representing all faiths and denominations, today delivered similar sermons from the pulpits of their churches in which they stressed the commandment "Thou Shall Not Kill" as part of a highway safety program.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 18 -- A plea to business corporations to increase their support of colleges and universities was contained in the annual report to Yale alumni of Dr. A. Whitney Griswold, president of Yale University. The report was made public today.
In connection with your Dec. 31 editorial entitled "Balkan Entente" we consider it pertinent to make the following remarks:

In an unusual Sunday session of court the jury in the trial of thirteen Communist leaders deliberated yesterday for the fourth day on the charge that they had conspired to teach and advocate overthrow of the Government by force and violence.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19 -- Home builders of the nation today were warned that maintenance of their current high level of production would depend largely on the type of houses they would offer in the competitive market which faces them.

" Contemporary Spanish Painting," a handsome, new loan exhibition, opened yesterday at the Schaeffer Galleries, 52 East Fifty-eighth Street. Logically enough, this show is being held for the benefit of the scholarship fund of Barnard College's Department of Spanish.

The State Crime Commission turned its investigation yesterday to the Staten Island waterfront. It spotlighted a union local that spent money beyond its means, lost its cash expense books, allegedly cheated its parent union of per capita dues and was dominated for twenty years by a president who had a long police record and accepted substantial gifts from stevedoring and steamship companies.

Walter Hirsch, a former teammate of William (Bill) Spivey on the University of Kentucky basketball team, testified yesterday in General Sessions that he and Spivey, who is being tried for perjury, agreed to accept bribes of $1,000 each to limit scores of games played in 1950-51.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower will use two Bibles when he takes the oath of office tomorrow.

Charles E. Wilson, who is on leave as president of the General Motors Corporation because of his designation as the new Secretary of Defense, urged a quick reexamination of materiel and procurement, the effects of the Korean war and of commitments to the North, Atlantic Treaty Organization yesterday in summarizing his preliminary investigations or defense operations.

SAIGON, Vietnam Indo-China, Jan. 19 -- French reinforcements were rushed today to Ankhe [cross on map], fortress town in central Indo-China, where five to six Vietminh battalions are bringing heavy pressure in a new offensive.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 19 -- Judge Thomas J. Clary of the United States District Court granted permission today for the taking of depositions from seven of the defendants and six witnesses in the $250,000,000 treble damage suit against thirty-one railroads.

William Remington yesterday coupled a denial that he ever had been a member of the Communist party with the statement that he had sometimes described himself as a Communist, but a philosophical follower of the ideology.

The junior lady of the house had been seated on the piano bench staring out of the window at the gray January sky, her father was in the back room thinking about his income tax, and the senior lady of the house had been darning a sock while she listened to the piano.

There is a possibility that freshmen will be eligible for the National Invitation Tournament, booked for Madison Square Garden, March 7 to 14, according to Asa S. Bushnell, chairman of the Metropolitan Intercollegiate Basketball Association, sponsor of the N. I. T.

George Morton Grinnell, investment banker, was found dead of a bullet wound yesterday morning in the bathroom of his home, 57 East Eightieth Street. The police forced the locked door after Mrs. Grinnell had heard a shot and telephoned for help.

ALTHOUGH the majority of winter visitors think of Florida angling in terms of sailfish, marlin and tarpon, a report of the Game and Fresh Water Fish Commission indicates that more fishermen spend more money in pursuit of the largemouth bass than for any other species of fish found in that state.

The Save the Children Federation has embarked on new programs of relief in Yugoslavia and South Korea, Dr. Richard P. Saunders, president, announced last night at the twenty-first annual meeting in the Fifth Avenue Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The Supreme Court refused a hearing today to five Baltimore and Washington local Communist leaders and an attorney -- all convicted of conspiring against the Government.
While the free concentrate on Korea they continue to do nothing effective to prevent new, and worse, "Koreas."

Dock wallopers who said they had to pay $1 a day to "kickback clubs" to hold their jobs, and other longshoremen who insisted they ran the clubs for the sheer joy of seeing their buddies get work, shared the stage at the New York State Crime Commission's hearing at the County Courthouse yesterday.

The first concert of the Composers Committee for Israeli and American-Jewish Music will be held Feb. 8 at the Lexington Avenue Y. M. and Y. W. H. A. Carrying out the purposes of the committee, the program will feature both American and Israeli composers.

The threat of a strike by 3,500 custodial employes in the city schools was renewed yesterday as a stormy mediation session indicated that two union locals involved would wait until Thursday but probably not beyond that before calling a walkout unless their demands were met.

A Presidential inauguration is a day of rejoicing for members of the party whose candidate is being inaugurated; it is a big show for everybody, including today even the Democrats; and it is, or should be, a day of jubilee for all of us. It means that government of the people, by the people and for the people still stands, as it did nearly ninety years ago when President Lincoln used the words.

The Air Force and the Air Materiel Command are canning airplane engines and clothing for overseas use. The operation is not only successful, but cheaper than ordinary packing practices. Savings to the Air Force are over $6,000,000 a year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The United States has asked the Soviet Union to send a representative to a meeting of Big Four deputies Jan. 30 in London for another discussion on a peace settlement for Austria.

With the warm endorsement of General Eisenhower, who becomes President today, the World Student Service Fund has announced plans for enlarging the field of its appeal on behalf of Korean universities and colleges. There are several reasons why this cause arouses more than usual sympathy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- New York and Hollywood merged their showmanship tonight for the Inaugural festivals at Uline Arena and later at the Capitol Theatre -- same 150 stars, same twenty-seven-number program.

BERLIN, Jan. 19 -- The Mutual Security Agency announced today a long-range investment program designed to strengthen the economic position of West Berlin. The program will finance new and old private enterprises capable of permanently absorbing part of the 250,000 unemployed in the former German capital.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Otto Verber and Kurt L. Ponger, former soldiers in the United States Army, pleaded innocent today when arraigned in Federal District Court on charges of spying for the Soviet Union. Their trial was set for March 2.
TRENTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The 1953 horse racing season in New Jersey for thoroughbreds and standard-breds will give fans three more days than they had last year to get out to the tracks.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Jan. 20 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,500 for the twenty-four hours ended at 6 A. M. Tuesday, Korean time:

With patterns of marketing and consumer tastes changing rapidly, the cigarette industry is in its most turbulent state since World War I, it was asserted yesterday by Alfred E. Lyon, chairman of the board of Philip Morris Co., Ltd., Inc. He spoke at a thirteen-state regional sales meeting of the company's staff in the Savoy Plaza Hotel, where this year's advertising and merchandising plans were outlined.
GUATEMALA, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Official parties, with which the Communist Workers party was aligned, apparently won a landslide victory in Guatemala's week-end Congressional elections.

TRENTON, Jan. 19 -- Forces backing several candidates for the Republican nomination, for Governor joined today to try to defeat in the Assembly a Senate bill to defer the New Jersey primary election to June 9.

The Prague trial and more recent events in the Soviet Union are creating ripples that extend outward in ever-expanding circles. In point is the decision of the Israeli Federation of Labor (Histadrut) to take the first steps toward expelling representatives of the Communist party from all offices in the federation.

CAIRO, Tuesday, Jan. 20 (UP) -- Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib, Premier of Egypt, ordered the formation of a "revolutionary tribunal to try persons endangering national security" today shortly after the Government had announced that 213 persons, including forty-eight Communists, had been arrested for planning to foment unrest.

NEWARK, Jan. 19 -- Federal Judge Guy L. Fake, in sentencing a convicted bookmaker for violation of probation on tax fraud charges, called today for abolition of race tracks in New Jersey as "the only means of ending rampant gambling, racketeering and political corruption."
A new production of "The Bat," the mystery drama by Mary Roberts Rinehart and Avery Hopwood, will open tonight at 8 o'clock at the National Theatre under the sponsorship of James Withers Elliott.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 19 -- Pang Tsu Mow, former head of Nationalist China's air procurement mission in Washington, appealed to the Mexican Government today to extend to him its "traditional right of asylum" as a political refugee from the Government of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek.

Commodity prices closed irregular yesterday on the New York exchanges. Activity continued slow with only potatoes showing sizable volume. Cottonseed oil, soybean oil, coffee, rubber and hides closed higher. Potatoes, cocoa, wool and lead were lower and sugar and zinc ended mixed.

The Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation was forced yesterday to halt defense work at its two plants in Valley Stream and Farmingdale, L. I., when 1,200 employes walked out and began picketing at 6 A. M.

The striking bus workers are seeking a forty-hour week with no cut in the pay they used to get for working forty-four to forty-eight hours, with five to nine hours of guaranteed overtime. The old basic wage ranged from $1.66 to $1.73 1/2 an hour.

Children, firebuffs and others to whom a fire engine without a siren just wasn't a fire engine could take heart yesterday, as the city began a sixty-day experiment of allowing Police and Fire Department vehicles responding to emergencies to sound the availing warnings again.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 19 -- Irving Allen, the globetrotting independent producer, has his sights set on Burma. He has acquired the screen rights to "Elephant Bill," a semi-autobiographical novel of adventure written by Col. J. H. Williams, retired British Army officer.

The following exceerpts are from testimony given yesterday at the State Crime Commission hearings into waterfront conditions. They deal mainly with the Staten Island local of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., and with extortion and intimidation on piers in other parts of the city.
Eugene Conley, American tenor, assumed his tenth role at the Metropolitan Opera House last night when he sang Cavaradossi in the season's eighth presentation of Puccini's "Tosca."

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Jan. 19 -- The Westchester Board of Supervisors took the first step today toward expansion of its spending powers. Under the "model" county charter adopted in 1938 a public referendum is required for issuing bonds for a project costing more than $1,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Personal chores and public business filled President Truman's final full day in the White House. His main action was to send to Congress a long message urging continued water control and public power development for "all the people."

John E. Reeves, vice president and treasurer of Reeves Brothers Inc., has been named executive vice president as well as treasurer, according to John M. Reeves, president. The formation of an executive committee with Henry C. Hoffman, vice president, as chairman was also announced. S. L. Lewis Jr., vice president and general sales manager, has been named vice president in charge of sales.

The Chesapeake and Ohio Railway announced yesterday that it has acquired directly and through a wholly owned subsidiary 244,741 capital shares of the New York Central Railroad. With the 400,000 shares acquired late in 1946, the C. O. of which Robert R. Young is chairman, now holds 644,741 shares of New York Central, or exactly 10 per cent of the 6,447,410 shares outstanding.

About nineteen centuries ago the historian Josephus wrote: "The Egyptians appear never in all their history to have enjoyed one day of freedom." A lot of water has flowed down the Nile since those words were written, and yet today one cannot safely change them.

ALBANY, Jan. 19 -- The Senate Judiciary Committee reported out favorably tonight six proposed constitutional amendments that would be submitted to referendum in November if they got through both Houses of the Legislature at this session.

A ferryboat smashed into another yesterday morning near the Battery in a pea soup fog that disrupted harbor traffic, delayed plane arrivals and departures at the city's airports and hampered street traffic. By 2 P. M. a warming sun had dissipated the fog to permit full restoration of harbor, air and highway operations.

Presentation of evidence in the departmental trial of thirty policemen accused of taking bribes from Harry Gross, convicted Brooklyn bookmaker, failed to end as scheduled yesterday and was continued until today.

One of the bitterest fights the banking industry has seen in years took on renewed fury yesterday when the New York State Banking Superintendent endorsed the plea of New York savings bankers for broader branch office powers.

A permanent career and salary plan for city employes that will not reduce the pay of any municipal worker or abridge any rights and that will embody a progressive promotion system was assured yesterday by Mayor Impellitteri.

In a surprise move to end the bus strike, Mayor Impellitteri proposed last night that the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., and the struck bus companies pick their own three-man arbitra tion panel to decide the dispute over union demands for a forty-hour week with no loss in pre-strike take-home pay.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19 -- Buying was hesitant at times today, with investors reluctant to follow rallies, but the general trend of grain futures was irregularly upward. While the demand was not urgent, it was noticeable that selling pressure also was limited. There appeared to be little liquidating of long lines.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 19 -- Reduction in maintenance costs "may be the difference between profit and loss," Henry W. Shockley, maintenance consultant for the engineering department of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., Willington, Del., said here tonight.

The cost of overseas military construction could be radically reduced if Americans would learn to use native materials, labor and building methods, it was contended yesterday at a meeting of consulting engineers.

Three of twenty-five contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund yesterday apologized for sending donations in "late." One of them, however, added the opinion with which all will agree: "Better late than never."

JERUSALEM, Jan. 19 -- Government action against Communists and fellow-travelers supporting the Soviet anti-Jewish campaign was threatened in the Knesset (Parliament) tonight by Foreign Minister Moshe Sharett at the close of a discussion on Moscow's allegations against nine Russian doctors.

MORE than one major league owner has remarked of recent years with a bitterness that almost amounted to a snarl, "The trouble with baseball these days is that your money is worthless. No one ever will sell a ball player any more." If that be so, it's comforting to know that the Brooklyn Dodgers have the proper appreciation of the once almighty dollar.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 19 -- Secretary General and Mrs. Trygve Lie were hosts today at a farewell luncheon in honor of Ambassador Warren R. Austin, whose term as head of the United States Mission to the United Nations ended today, and Mrs. Austin.

HONOLULU, Jan. 19 -- A Japanese economist has expressed the view that capitalist economy could bring about the economic development of Japan and other dependent nations, but suggested that the United States reassesses certain "contradictions" in its economic viewpoint in regard to his nation.
ALBANY, Jan. 19 (UP) -- The State Commerce Department today reported the following winter sports conditions:

A loans-and-discounts goal of $10,000,000 has been set up by the management of the Kings County Trust Company with a view to putting the bank's resources to work more effectively. Until further progress toward this goal has been made there is little likelihood that the bank's capital shares will be split up.

The six-story loft budding at 45-47 West Twenty-ninth Street has been purchased for occupancy by the Zshara Trading Corporation, an export-import organization. Murray Goldin was attorney for the seller, the Barbrat Realty Corporation, and Julius Richman acted for the buyer.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The Big Ten, prompted by a formal invitation from the Pacific Coast Conference, today voted to consider renewal of the Rose Bowl game when the present contract expires with the Jan. 1, 1954, contract.

The annual winter local furniture market opened yesterday in the New York Furniture Exchange and showrooms outside it with record attendance and buying reminiscent of post-Korean "scare" purchasing. Although orders placed did not approach panic buying they were heavy enough to assure one of the most successful markets since the end of World War II.
Your thoughtful editorial "Mr. Wilson's Predicament" recalls a historical analogy which is as instructive as it is pertinent, and which has been curiously overlooked in the press.

Sales of eight houses in New Milford, N. J., were reported by J. I. Kislak, Inc., broker. Bernard Kinberg of New York bought the dwelling at 173 River Lane from Oscar Albrechtson, and Dale S. Randall sold the house at 1018 Maple Drive to John Leszkowicz.

Seton Hall, the only undefeated team in the major college ranks, took over yesterday as the nation's No. 1 basketball power in the closest ballot in the three-year history of The United Press ratings.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower will name Charles S. Thomas of Los Angeles, a director of the Navy League of the United States, as Under Secretary of the Navy. He will succeed Francis P. Whitehair of Florida.
The press and radio are saying a good deal about the bus strike causing very little inconvenience. The subway is said to be adequate and everybody is getting along just fine.

The Board of Education's tentative budget request for the next fiscal year was sharply criticized at a public hearing yesterday for failing to ask for sufficient funds to improve pupil and community services and to increase teacher and staff, salaries.

LONDON, Jan. 19 -- Most sections of the Stock Market here were firm today although the turnover was relatively light. Small gains were widespread among industrials, with store and textile issues making the best showing.
Undefeated Seton Hall rose to the top of the national basketball rankings yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 19 (UP) -- Ten Bulgarians went on trial for their lives in a Sofia court today on charges of plotting a "counterrevolution" directed by the United States against Bulgaria's Communist Government.

One hundred eighty-five alien crew members of the French liner Ile de France were denied shore leave privileges when the vessel docked here at 1:30 P. M. yesterday because they either had declined to answer questions of immigration inspectors or had refused to sign temporary landing permits.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Jan. 20 -- United Nations planes and guns battered Communist positions all along the Korean front yesterday, and raiding patrols fought in No Man's Land against small enemy groups.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The Wage Stabilization Committee approved today wage increases averaging 10 per cent for 21,000 employes of the shipbuilding division of Bethlehem Steel Company. The increases are effective as of Aug. 27, 1952, and average about 16 cents an hour.

PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 19 -- Nature forms fingernails, hair, muscles and feathers by twisting the constituents of ordinary body tissues into veritable ropes of as many as seven strands, two California Institute of Technology scientists reported today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Secretary of the Interior Oscar L. Chapman told Congress today that the synthetic liquid fuels program of the Bureau of Mines "again forged ahead during 1952."
ALBANY, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The State Banking Department tonight urged the Legislature to permit a larger number of foreigners to be directors of banks or trust companies licensed in New York State.

CAIUS SEMPRONIUS FELIX, Praeses of Britannia Prima, was an honest and conscientious civil servant. A civil governor of one of the five provinces of Britain, with his treasury and offices in Londinium, his chief responsibility was to collect taxes so that the soldiers could be paid and civilization kept alive in the remote island where he represented the power and dignity of Rome.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The Supreme Court of the United States upheld today a section of the New York Workmen's Compensation Law that permits state awards in interstate cases if employer and worker waive their Federal rights.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 19 -- By a majority of 59 to 1, the Iranian Parliament voted tonight to extend for one year the plenary powers held by Premier Mohammed Mossadegh. Six Deputies, all dissident members of Dr. Mossadegh's nationalist coalition, abstained from voting.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange, after a weak start, turned stronger yesterday and closed 4 to 19 points higher than on Friday.

RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 19 -- Officials here say the Burmese forces will step up their pressure against the Chinese Nationalist troops in East Burma soon. The area around Taunggyi, the capital of Southern Shan State, has been put under military control and is being prepared as a base for action against the Chinese.

Representatives of motion picture councils today wil start a three-day conference at the Museum of Modern Art with some discussions taking place at the Gotham Hotel, the Motion Picture Association of America announced today.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Jan. 19 -- The women's coat and suit industry has an opportunity in 1953 to build a sales volume larger than in several years, Max E. Weinstock, chairman of the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board, declared here today.

OLDSMAR, Fla., Jan 19 (AP) -- Tony DeSpirito, who set a record of 390 winners in 1952, returned to the saddle at Sunshine Park today for the first time since Jan. 1 and scored easy victories in his only two races.

Unless United States capital can be attracted to investments in Korea, even while hostilities continue, the Korean people may "choose other friends," Dr. You Chan Yang, Korean Ambassador to the United States, warned yesterday. Speaking at the twenty-fifth annual mid-winter meeting of the New York State Bankers Association at the Commodore Hotel, he said that under the circumstances victory on the battlefield might become "meaningless in terms of economic and political necessity."

Forty-two states, it is reported, are considering bills to create several Monday holidays, as follows: a "President's Day" to be celebrated the third Monday in February; Memorial Day, last Monday in May, and Independence Day, first Monday in July. One's initial response to this proposal is to applaud briskly, but a sobering second thought yields other reactions -- very unpleasant ones.
LARAMIE, Wyo., Jan. 19 (AP) -- Bowden Wyatt, head football coach at the University of Wyoming formally was released from his 10-year contract tonight by the University board of trustees.

" Youth," said Franz Liszt, "is the time for virtuosity!" We thought of this last night, listening to the first appearance in this city in recital of the young pianist, Theodore Lettvin, in Town Hall.

A jury of six men and six women yesterday held their fifth day of weighing evidence in the trial of thirteen Communist leaders charged with conspiring to teach and advocate overthrow of the Government by force and violence.
Another attempt at "tightening up" this port's waterfront industry will be made today as its leaders meet under the auspices of the New York Trucking Authority.

Directors of the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company increased the quarterly dividend yesterday with the declaration of 62 1/2 cents a share on the common stock, for payment on March 16. The previous quarterly rate was 50 cents a share. In addition Panhandle last year paid a year-end extra of 50 cents and a stock dividend of 2 1/2 per cent in December.

LIMA, Peru, Jan. 19 -- Two American archaeologists have just uncovered near here wall paintings that date back 2,000 years and promise to furnish new evidence of interchange of cultures between coastal and mountain civilizations in Peru.

PEARL HARBOR, Jan. 19 -- A Pacific Fleet headquarters spokesman today said that the Chinese Communists, who shot down a Navy Neptune patrol bomber, had fired on a United States destroyer attempting to rescue survivors in the Strait of Formosa.

ALBANY, Jan. 19 -- Governor Dewey's refusal to recommend a cost-of-living pay increase for state employes was assailed tonight as arbitrary by Richard H. Balch, Democratic State Chairman, following a conference with Senator Francis J. Mahoney of Manhattan and Assemblyman Eugene F. Bannigan of Brooklyn, Democratic minority leaders of the Legislature.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The streets and the hotels of the capital city are overflowing today with citizens drawn here by the event of tomorrow, and presumably enough of the visitors are Republicans or those who voted for a "change with Eisenhower" to differentiate them in that particular from the Administration Democrats and supporters at last November's polls.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 19 -- For the first time since military and diplomatic talks were initiated among Greece, Turkey and Yugoslavia, Yugoslav official sources speak openly of their receptiveness to a written alliance for the defense of the Balkans to be integrated with the North Atlantic Treaty Organization defense system.

Compensation of top executives in this country increased 5 per cent in the 1951-52 fiscal year, compared with the previous year, according to the third annual study issued yesterday by the executive compensation service of the American Management Association.

MELBOURNE, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Ken Rosewall, the 18-year-old Australian champion, and four other ranking players today were named to represent their country in tournaments abroad, including the United States singles and doubles championships.

SYDNEY, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Australian trade figures for November show a 70 per cent drop in imports from Britain, a sharp rise in exports and the first favorable balance with the dollar area in the present financial year.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Jan. 19 -- A "showdown" between two feuding deputy attorneys general appeared to have taken precedence today over their separate investigations into Bergen County crimes and criminals.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Jan. 19 -- The spacious George Wythe Mansion in Colonial Williamsburg, the Rockefeller-restored capital of the Virginia colony, has become the permanent home for the portraits of four illustrious Americans -- George Washington, Thomas Jefferson. James Madison and James Monroe.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower, holding to her husband's tenet of no public appearances before the inauguration, spent today in the twelfth-floor Statler Hotel suite of the President-elect.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 19 -- West Germany is and will remain the "useful and reliable" partner of the free world, Chancellor Konrad Adenauer declared tonight in an effort to reject and explain the British charges of a Nazi plot and the United States conclusions on the recrudescence of nazism and nationalism.

Over the week-end two plans for a transit authority were made public. The Citizens Budget Commission in a thorough study proposed a principle of "gradualism" in cutting off city tax subsidy, until in fiscal year 1958-59 there would be no tax coverage of operating expenses at all.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 19 -- Yale University announced today that it had entered into an agreement with the University of Hawaii and the Bernice P. Bishop Museum of Honolulu for cooperative research in science in the Pacific area. The program is being supported by a $200,000 grant from the Carnegio Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Senate committees gave prompt and unanimous advance approval today of three more prospective members of the Cabinet of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, who takes office as President of the United States tomorrow.

Two robbery suspects were captured yesterday morning in a rooftop pistol battle with a detective after they had allegedly held up a Bronx food market, forced the store manager and five other men into a refrigerator, and escaped with $692 from a safe.

" I Joined the Russians," by Count Heinrich von Einsiedel, grandson of the German Empire's first Chancellor, Bismarck, will be published by Yale University Press on Feb. 25. The author, a Luftwaffe lieutenant with thirty-five Russian planes to his credit, has based his book on the diary he kept after being shot down over Stalingrad in World War II.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Officials of the Georgetown University Hospital reported today "improvement" in an operation that involves putting of a plastic valve into the aorta, the main trunkline of blood from the heart.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- In his fiftieth and final appearance before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Dean Acheson, the retiring Secretary of State, declared today that the West was so strong that the Communist forces in adjacent areas could not overrun Western Europe.

The maintenance of academic freedom does not require Communists on a university faculty, Chancellor Henry T. Heald of New York University declared yesterday. He addressed the opening general session of the annual meeting of the American Institute of Electrical Enginers at the Statler Hotel.
A show of paintings and sculpture by patients of the Memorial Cancer Center opened yesterday for a week at the Knoedler Galleries, 14 East Fifty-seventh Street.

Olive oil, which has been made in about the same way since ancient times, now is fortified by one company with Vitamins A and D. This innovation was devised by Strohmeyer Arpe, which announced that its improved product, under the Re Umberto label, would be distributed to stores here this week.

Cardinal Spellman returned here yesterday from his second successive Christmas visit to the Korean war front to report that "inevitably time is on the side of our enemy," and to voice "bafflement because one sees no end to the present situation." Nevertheless he hailed the "inspiring" spirit of American troops.

LONDON, Jan. 19 -- Referring to the "militant campaign" against Israel by Arab leaders, Eliahu Elath, the Israeli Ambassador to Britain, warned tonight of the dangers of an armament race in the Middle East.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Tuesday, Jan. 20 (AP) -- official United States quarters said today an unidentified hostile aircraft, presumably Communist fired at a United States plane yesterday as it searched for survivors of a Navy patrol bomber shot down by Red anti-aircraft guns Sunday off the coast of China and a rescue plane that crashed.
Need for establishment of a positive new foreign trade policy by the Eisenhower Administration was stressed yesterday by spokesmen for major groups in this field.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The Government today granted the nation's "big three" aluminum producers a ceiling price rise of 1/2 cent a pound for primary aluminum pig and ingot and 4 per cent on fabricated aluminum products.

An assertion that the national wage and price stabilization structure has broken down, with "economic planners doing everything possible to frustrate business," was made yesterday by Senator Henry C. Dworshak, Republican of Idaho.

The steel industry established a new production record of 2,238,000 tons last week and expects operations this week to dip only slightly below that level. The mills have scheduled production of 2,234,000 tons of ingots and steel for castings, with operations set at 99.1 per cent of capacity this week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The first stage of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's "great crusade" draws to a close tomorrow as he takes the oath of office as President of the United States and begins the new, more challenging and more trying assignment in the White House.

ROME, Tuesday, Jan. 20 -- The extreme right has joined the extreme left deputies in a filibuster against the Government's electoral reform bill designed to cut down the parliamentary strength of the Communists. The measure is in its seventh week of debate in the chamber.

STOWE, Vt., Jan. 19 -- The Mount Mansfield Ski Club, which has played an important role in the development of skiing in this country, will sponsor another training school for American hopefuls for the world and Olympic championships.

In the death of Douglas Chandor we have lost a portrait painter of high ability, the Joshua Reynolds of our day, some believed. He was about to fly East from his home in Texas to do a portrait of President-elect Eisenhower when the doctor advised that he postpone the picture until spring.
BIRMINGHAM, England, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Former middleweight champion Randy Turpin of England knocked out Vic D'Haes, Belgian light heavyweight king, in the sixth round of a ten-round match tonight.

MIAMI, Jan. 19 (UP) -- Sammy Boulmetis, who does some of his best riding at Hialeah, boosted his victory total at the current meeting to seven today when he brought home three winners, including Real Brother and Subahdar in the co-features.

On this day when General Eisenhower becomes President Eisenhower it is appropriate to remind the new Administration and the new majority in Congress that on Oct. 17 in Newark he made the following statement:
Flowers that bloom in the spring are rushing the season by coming out all over the fashion field. Floral prints are staging a revival and accessories follow suit.

NORWALK, Conn., Jan. 19 -- The Zoning Commission here announced today that it had approved, by a vote of three to one, a petition of the Connecticut Light and Power Company to erect a $20,000,000 steam power plant on Manresa Island, former retreat of the Roman Catholic order of the Society of Jesus.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- President Truman's effort to restore to the White House some of its own antiques, started Aug. 14, 1952, re-suited in some lively leads -- too-late, however, for the slow acquisition process.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 19 -- Two of three prison riots that broke out in and near Pittsburgh within twenty-four hours beginning early last night had ended by 8 o'clock tonight. The third found prisoners and the state police, both armed, on the alert at either side of inmate barricades.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, Jan. 19 -- Any outbreak of trouble in the Union of South Africa would have an immediate and direct effect on the security of the United States.

The stock market still awaited yesterday a cue as to the policies of the new Administration, although prices on the day turned a bit firmer after some early indecisiveness. With eyes and ears on the Inaugural in Washington today and the coming messages from General Eisenhower, traders remained cautious.

Adlai E. Stevenson will make his first television appearance since his defeat for the Presidency as the principal speaker at the eastern states Jefferson-Jackson Day dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel Saturday evening, Feb. 14.

An issue of $18,000,000 of twenty-year 4 1/4 per cent sinking fund debentures of the Montreal Transportation Commission will be placed on the market here today by an underwriting syndicate of forty-six investment houses headed by Shields Co. and Savard Hart. The debentures are priced at 98.67 to yield 4.35 per cent to maturity.

ALBANY, Jan. 19 -- A bill that would extend for one month the expiration date of 1952 truck and trailer registrations was introduced in the Legislature tonight at the request of Spencer E. Bates, State Commissioner of Taxation and Finance, and James R. MacDuff, State Motor Vehicle Commissioner.
AT THE KOREAN FRONT, Jan. 19 -- Corp. Lee Yong Suk was in the Korean war so long his luck was bound to run out.
PARIS, Jan. 19 -- Seldom has the inauguration of a President of the United States been awaited so impatiently by the outside world as the one that will take place tomorrow.
Two military problems, both intangibles, that faced Eisenhower, the general, confront Eisenhower, the President, as he takes office today.

SEOUL, Korea, Jan. 19 -- President Syngman Rhee said here today that his recent trip to Japan had made him "hopeful" that future good neighbor relations could be established between South Korea and Japan.

Two of forty-one sponsors of the Emergency Civil Liberties Committee resigned yesterday rather than become involved in a controversy started by the American Committee for Cultural Freedom, which accused the liberties group of being a "Communist front."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Senator Leverett Saltonstall, Republican of Massachusetts, said today that Herbert Brownell Jr. would sit with the Armed Services Committee on Wednesday when Charles E. Wilson, who has been designated but not approved for Secretary of Defense, would clarify his position on his stock in the General Motors Corporation.

WomerL headed by Mrs. Donald S. Stralem and including Mrs. MorI timer Rodgers and Mrs. Henry i Anthony Barclay are aiding in plans for a public inspection of i the new Italian luxury liner Andrea Doria, to be held Sunday afternoon for the benefit of the Travelers Aid Society of New I York.

Despite all the obstacles put in its path the movement toward some kind of European unification achieved further progress when the Consultative Assembly of the Council of Europe (comprising fifteen countries) endorsed the tentative plans of six of these nations to unite in a federative "community."

A pleasant, countrified flavor is exhibited by the objects in a small, new collection of Danish ceramics at Bonnier's, 605 Madison Avenue. Provincial in feeling as compared with the more sophisticated ceramic pieces from Denmark, this group is the work of Mrs. Felix Moehl-Hansen of Alleroed, near Copenhagen, and her family.

Reflecting a rise in sales to the highest volume in its history, net profit of the Caterpillar Tractor Company for 1952 exceeded that of the year before by 40.59 per cent, according to the report issued yesterday by L. B. Neumiller, president.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Jan. 19 (UP) -- E. J. (Dutch) Harrison tipped in a 50-foot approach shot for an eagle on the eighteenth hole to tie with Ben Hogan, playing in his first tournament of the winter, with 7-under-par 65's today for the first day lead in the $10,000 Palm Springs invitational golf tournament.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The District Attorney of Amsterdam advised a court here today there were sufficient grounds for the extradition of Harold J. Adonis of New Jersey.

Visitors to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in 1952 numbered 2,328,322, second only to the record of 2,451,778 set in 1950, according to the annual report of the board of trustees, made public yesterday. It was the seventh successive year that attendance had excelled the two million mark.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19 -- Attorneys for major defendants in the du Pont anti-trust trial today announced their intention to fight the case through to the finish to obtain a full clearance on the Government's three-and-a-half-year-old charges of monopoly and conspiracy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Described as "full of life and drive and ready to go," Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower managed today to preserve a surprising amount of privacy on his final day as a private citizen before assuming the burdens of the thirty-fourth President of the United States.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 19 (UP) -- Lucille Ball, the actress, followed the script of her "I Love Lucy" television show to the letter today by giving birth to a boy at Cedars of Lebanon Hospital.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 19 -- Mr. Thomas, a prominent Los Angeles business man and World War I naval aviation veteran, served for nearly three years during World War II as a special assistant to Secretary Forrestal and Artemus L. Gates, Assistant Secretary of the Navy for Air.

Some practical and reassuring pointers on dealing with child behavior were set forth last night by Dr. Luther Woodward before a group of parents and teachers at the Bentley School's East Side Branch, 112 East Seventy-first Street.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 20 (AP) -- Jockey Eddie Arcaro was grounded today for five days by the board of stewards at Santa Anita because of his ride on Mark-Ye-Well in last Saturday's San Fernando Stakes.

For a brief period this week Wilfred J. McNeil, who has been an Assistant Secretary of Defense in charge of budgetary matters since 1949, became, ad interim, Acting Secretary of Defense. Mr. McNeil has provided continuity for the Secretary's office through several Pentagon administrations and it is to be hoped that he is a permanent fix ture in the office of Assistant Secretary.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 20 -- Although defeated in Parliament, Ayatollah Sayed Abolghassem Kashani, principal religious figure in the Iranian nationalist movement, persisted today in his challenge to the authority of Dr. Mohammed Mossadegh, Premier of Iran.

WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Jan. 21 -- The two inaugural balls that celebrated the arrival of the Eisenhower Administration will be remembered as the biggest-ever in entertainment, following a tremendous tangle on tickets.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Jan. 20 -- Experts in various antiques fields continued today to trace and identify European influences in American fine and decorative arts in the second day of the five-day forum here. The symposium is under the sponsorship of colonial Williamsburg and the magazine Antiques.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Harry S. Truman headed tonight for Independence, Mo., a carefree man, leaving behind the New Deal-Fair Deal era and in a sense walking into the pages of history.
Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., set machinery in motion yesterday for ending the twenty-day-old bus strike under Mayor Impellitteri's arbitration plan.

AUGUSTA, Me., Jan. 20 -- The ninety-sixth Legislature of the State of Maine today began meeting what Gov. Burton M. Cross has described as a "challenge to restore to the people of this state, faith in the honesty and integrity of its public officials."

SAIGON, Vietnam, Indo-China, Jan. 20 -- French circles are wondering whether a new jungle war on the Thai country pattern but on a smaller scale is not beginning on the high Moi Plateaus against which the Vietminh has just launched an offensive.
ADELAIDE, Australia, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Only one American player experienced any difficulty in the second-round singles matches of the South Australian tennis championships today.

BACK in the old days, cynics always defined an amateur as "a fellow who won't take a check." In other words, those pseudo-amateurs protected their standings by being paid off in untraceable cash rather than traceable checks. In Canada, though, the hockey players lead a totally unrealistic Alice-in-Wonderland existence.

Trading continued dull and in-active on the New York commodity exchanges yesterday with only potatoes showing sizeable volume. Prices closed irregularly higher with coffee, sugar, soybean oil, hides, lead and zinc improved. Cocoa, rubber, potatoes and wool were lower and tin and cottonseed oil closed mixed.

SIOUX LOOKOUT, Ont., Jan. 20 -- A Canadian National Railways passenger train speeding from Montreal to Vancouver was wrecked early today when it hit a broken rail about 140 miles north of the Minnesota border. The temperature was 30 below zero and there was nine inches of snow.

The number of commercial and industrial failures turned downward in the week ended Jan. 15. The latest total was 158, against 163 the week before and 158 in the 1952 period. The number of casualties was far below pre-war figures. In the 1939 week the figure was 367.
LONDON, Jan. 20 -- Dr. Gunnar Fischer of Sweden has isolated a biochemical preparation that, he claims, is effective against viruses, all of which have hitherto been chemically unassailable.
TULSA, Okla., Jan. 20 (UP) -- J. O. (Buddy) Brothers resigned as head football coach at the University of Tulsa today. A few hours later Assistant Coach Bernie Witucki was elevated to the top post.

A new Carmen is always news, and Fedora Barbieri, singing her first Carmen at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, was the center of attention. George London made his contribution to the occassion with his first Escamillo here.
The larger part of $1,191.14 received yesterday from contributors to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund was made direct to two of the agencies through which the fund is administered.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Dwight David Eisenhower was inaugurated today as the thirty-fourth President of the United States and he pledged that his Administration would "neither compromise, nor tire, nor ever cease" in its quest for an honorable worldwide peace.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- As darkness descended on the District of Columbia, and the streets and the windows of the capital blossomed with electric lights, the mightiest pageant ever to pass befor a President on the afternoon of his Inaugural was still in motion, its length testifying, as did its splendor, to the enormous significance of the election of Nov. 4, 1952.

The culinary demands of the Christmas holidays never fail to bring a flood of reader mail and to prompt many questions and comments, some of the most interesting of which are shared here today with other readers.

Last Thursday and Friday newspapers told of General Eisenhower's determination to wear a homburg instead of a high silk hat for the inaugural ceremonies. The Frank H. Lee Company, maker of Lee and Disney hats, boasted yesterday that merchants had in their hands an order blank and a promotion piece for the homburgs as they turned from their television sets showing the parade.
CHICAGO, Jan. 20 (AP) -- The White Sox today obtained Infielder Fred Marsh from the Browns for First Baseman R. T. (Dixie) Upright and an undisclosed amount of cash.

Your paper printed a letter from Arthur R. Silsdorf recently referring to the reform expected to be urged in the Legislature calling for a direct method of electing political district leaders. Your correspondent was in error, however, in saying that change from the present indirect method may be brought about by the voluntary action of party leaders.

Some special problems of concern to parents in getting along with children were discussed last night at the third in a special series of programs for parents presented by the Child Study Association of America in the Kaufman Auditorium, Lexington Avenue at Ninety-second Street.

KAOHIUNG, Formosa, Jan. 20 (UP) -- Ten United States Navy and Coast Guard survivors of a double air tragedy off the Chinese Communist coast arrived here today aboard a Navy ship that had helped to rescue them from the sea under Communist gunfire.

The Emergency Civil Liberties Committee announced yesterday that it would go ahead with plans for a two-day conference on the Bill of Rights in spite of a charge by the American Committee for Cultural Freedom that the liberties group was a Communist front.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Jan. 20 -- Prayers for President Eisenhower and for his support of a spiritual revival and eventual world peace keynoted the opening session today of the thirteenth annual meeting of the Board of Missions and Church Extension of the Methodist Church.

TROY, Ohio, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Tiny Rio Grande College and its national scoring ace, Clarence (Bevo) Francis, defeated Cedarville, 66 -- 29, tonight despite Cedarville's stalling tactics that sent fans into an uproar.

The annual exhibition of the Audubon Artists will open this evening in the galleries of the National Academy with a preview for members at which the numerous prizes and awards will be officially bestowed.
LONDON, Jan. 20 (AP) -- British newspapers generally paid high tribute to General Eisenhower as well as to what he had said in his Inaugural Address.
LONDON, Jan. 20 -- Food Minister Gwilym Lloyd-George disclosed tonight that a method had been devised for exporting London fog to the United States.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 20 (UP) -- Jack Kramer overpowered Australia's Frank Sedgman in two fast sets before 5,100 tonight, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 2, cutting Sedgman's lead in their professional tennis cross-country tour to six matches to four.

The design of nuclear reactors is posing difficult problems for engineers, even in such simple matters as turning a reactor "off" and "on," according to discussion here yesterday at the annual meeting of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers.

Wholesalers were urged yesterday to join a national drive for public understanding and support of fair trade legislation. Maurice Mermey, director of the Bureau Education on Fair Trade, at the convention of the Wholesale Dry Goods Institute at the New Yorker Hotel, said wholesalers have a vital stake in preservation of fair trade laws.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Dec. 20 -- Representative Don. D. Wozniak of St. Paul introduced a resolution in the legislature today to allow the televising of all University of Minnesota home athletic contests.

The overwhelmingly Democratic City Council -- twenty-four Democrats to one Republican-Liberal -- unanimously adopted a resolution yesterday wishing President Eisenhower "the fullest measure of success." The Council also "pledged its support" as follows:

CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Venezuela's National Security Director announced today that Dr. Alberto Carnevali, leader of the outlawed Accion Democratica party, and thirteen others had been arrested after a gun-blazing police raid on their secret headquarters.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 20 -- An interim report on progress toward establishment of the Inter-Governmental Maritime Consultative Organization, prepared for submission to the United Nations Transport and Communications Commission when it meets Feb. 2 at headquarters here, shows that eleven governments have taken formal action in favor of the move.

PARIS, Jan. 20 -- As a proposed reprisal against application of the McCarran Act to French merchant sailors, the Socialist group in the National Assembly introduced a bill today providing for screening of United States seamen who arrive in French ports. The bill would apply to any foreign country engaged in such a practice.

William W. Remington testified at his second perjury trial in Federal Court yesterday that he had given data to Elizabeth T. Bentley, former Communist spy courier, because he felt he was "being an important guy" and a "big shot."

PAMELA FRANKAU'S new novel, "To the Moment of Triumph,"* is nearly as good as "The Willow Cabin," which is high praise indeed, for "The Willow Cabin" was one of the most brilliant novels of recent years, a triumph of wit, psychological insight and fictional craftsmanship. Although Miss Frankau's casts of characters are very different and the problems which beset them different, too, there is a striking similarity in spirit and general atmosphere in these novels.

The striking bus workers are seeking a forty-hour week with no cut in the pay they used to get for working forty-four to forty-eight hours, with five to nine hours of guaranteed overtime. The old basic wage ranged from $1.66 to $1.73 1/2 an hour.

The television networks in the main did a fine job in covering the ceremonies and parade attendant to President Eisenhower's inauguration. They caught in sharp close-up all the highlights of the historic occasion and enabled the viewer at home to see far more than the spectators on the scene in Washington.
Following is the text of President Eisenhower's Inaugural Address in Washington yesterday. delivered after a brief prayer, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

City officials should set an example for other citizens in obeying traffic rules, Magistrate Frederick L. Strong informed Councilman Earl Brown yesterday in fining him $140 for seven parking tickets and one summons for failure to obey a patrolman's signal.

Vice Presidents don't often make history, yet consider Alabama's William Rufus Devane King, who became Vice President of the United States in 1853. King, a Senator and respected public figure, had been a strong supporter of James Buchanan for the Presidential nomination; and when his party chose Franklin Pierce instead it was logical to seek party unity by selecting a Buchanan man for second place on the ticket.

The initial steps toward an organized effort to "tighten up" the Port of New York were taken yesterday by waterfront management and labor in a meeting in the offices of the New York Trucking Authority at 141 Broadway.

Harvey Bistany, a former associate of William Francis Sutton, the convicted bank robber, pleaded guilty yesterday before Judge Matthew T. Abruzzo in Brooklyn Federal Court to an indictment charging him with participating in the burglary of the Brevoort Post Office Station, 1205 Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn, on April 29, 1951.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- President Eisenhower has chosen as his personal airplane an Air Force Lockheed Constellation that veteran Air Force pilots consider the "sweetest-running" plane in the deluxe transport fleet.

ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- The selection of a candidate for Mayor of New York by a political party wishing to run a member of another party would be barred unless the choice was agreed to by a majority of the political executive committees of the five boroughs, according to provisions of a bill introduced in the Legislature today.

Richard M. Nixon, a dark-haired California Quaker who has thrived on controversy, won the nation's second highest post after a campaign without parallel in modern political history -- and at the age of 39.

INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Jan. 20 -- Former President Truman was promised today a warm welcome by the citizens of Independence when he returned here tomorrow night after seven and one-half years in the White House.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The nation's capital and its hundreds of thousands of visitors gave President Eisenhower a gay and colorful welcome today, with sunny skies bringing mild temperatures, jovial good humor and a carnival spirit to the city.

HOBOKEN, N. J., Jan. 20 -- A surprise raid by sixty agents of the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service and sixty Coast Guardsmen on the morning shape-up of longshoremen on three piers here resulted in a round-up of thirty-four men without proper alien registration cards. Five of them admitted being ship jumpers and were held.

Stockholders of W. A. Sheaffer Pen Company, at their meeting held yesterday in Ft. Madison, Iowa, voted to increase the authorized common stock from 825,000 to 1,500,000 shares and to authorize the future issuance of 100,000 shares for sale or compensation to employes.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20 -- The Government rested its du Pont anti-trust case today in Federal District Court after twelve fast-moving trial days in which more than 1,000 documents went into the record and some of the numerous defendants went out.

ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- T. Norman Hurd, state Budget Director, defending his rejection of a blanket pay increase for state employes, said today that state salaries had outstripped both the rise in the cost of living and pay increases granted in private industry since 1946.
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange, after a steady opening yesterday, lost ground in the afternoon trading, and closed 23 to 31 points net lower than on Monday.

The Republican State Committee will be sponsor of legislation to extend the hours of registration here "to keep women voters' interest at high pitch," David B. Costuma, secretary of the Board of Elections, reported yesterday.

PARIS, Jan. 20 -- Reports of the Inauguration were conspicuously displayed in the French press today and the commentators found in President Eisenhower's address a reassurance against any marked changes in United States foreign policy.

WEEHAWKEN, N. J., Jan. 20 -- One person was critically injured and eleven others cut and bruised this afternoon when the bus in which they were riding plunged twenty-five feet from Pershing Road into the New York Central West Shore Division freight yard at the waterfront here.

Reflecting the 12 per cent increase in sales, net earnings of the General Foods Corporation for the nine months ended last Dec. 31 rose to $15,861,715 after taxes and all charges from the $13,000,913 earned in the corresponding period of the previous year.

LONDON, Jan. 20 -- Britain has tried to dispel suspicions held by her partners in the Organization for European Economic Cooperation that she would bypass them in forthcoming trade and financial talks with the United States, official sources said today.

HARTFORD, Jan. 20 -- Connecticut's General Assembly, which reconvenes tomorrow after a week's recess, will be asked to approve a bill reducing the size of juries from twelve members to six, Representative Daniel F. Flynn, Republican of West Hartford, announced today.
CHICAGO, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Today's report on the livestock market here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Evidence of the continuing and, as reported from the recent Chicago furniture market, increased interest in combining traditional furniture designs in contemporary decorating schemes may be found in the group of model rooms on view at Stern's.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- General Eisenhower became the thirty-fourth President of the United States today but there was no likelihood that his taking office would still amateur historians who will contend that his number should be thirty-three.

GREAT NECK ESTATES, L. I., Jan. 20 -- A former handyman at a Lakewood, N. J., hotel, who the police say same here to steal a car fitted by a set of keys that he had stolen at the hotel, was shot dead last night as he attempted to escape after being caught by a village policeman.

The glaring searchlight of the Congressional investigators is now directed at our colleges and universities. The proceedings will surely be provocative, as the investigators are probing an area more sensitive than any examined so far. There is certain to be a furor. Criticism of the investigations will be unrelenting, and has preceded even the first of the investigators' disclosures.

New York has in general held its own in the post-war competition for shipping, has made absolute gains in tonnage and receipts, but has slipped on a percentage basis relative to other Atlantic and Gulf ports -- notably Baltimore and New Orleans -- it was reported yesterday to the New York State Crime Commission by an engineering group retained last July to make such a study.

SEOUL, Korea, Jan. 14 -- The soldier in the Seoul post exchange is like a wide-eyed child in the midst of a fairyland of toys. He wanders through the galaxy of goods picking up an item here and an item there. He dips his spoon into a rich chocolate sundae and has his shoes polished to a high shine by a bootblack.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Richard Milhous Nixon took a big forward stride in a meteoric political career today as he took the oath of office as the thirty-sixth Vice President of the United States.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Jan. 20 -- A feud between Deputy Attorney General Harry L. Towe, who investigated the murder of gangster Willie Moretti, and Deputy Attorney General Nelson F. Stamler, who investigated gambling and corruption in Bergen County, continued today despite Mr. Stamler's four-hour appearance before the Bergen County grand jury yesterday under subpoena by Mr. Towe. Mr. Towe said:
NEW YORK deer hunters set a record during the recent season, when 42,080 deer, including 18,525 antlerless deer, were killed, topping the previous mark of 1948, when the total was 37,683.

ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- Legislation repealing the state's antique patchwork trade-mark law and substituting a uniform statute now in effect in a score of other states will be introduced in the Legislature next week with the backing of the Joint Legislative Committee on Interstate Cooperation.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Following are the texts of the invocation, prayer and benediction at the Inauguration ceremony here today:

This port is "just about keeping its head above water" in competition for the post-war increase in the nation's shipping, Edward F. Cavanagh Jr., City Commissioner of Marine and Aviation, told the State Crime Commission yesterday.
BELLEFONTE, Pa., Jan. 20 (AP) -- Four hundred of the 800 rioting convicts at Rockview State Penitentiary ended their mutiny tonight but six guards remained captives in another cellblock.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Jan. 21 (AP) -- United Nation Command communique 1,501, for the twenty-four hours ended at 6 A. M. Wednesday, Korean time:

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Jan. 20 -- One hundred and fifty Levittown home owners attended a meeting of the Oyster Bay Town Board in Town Hall here today. They voiced objections to a plan whereby the board is seeking to settle a three-month-old controversy over the Levittown community hall and swimming pools.

Estimated consumption of newsprint in the United States during 1952 was 5,988,471 tons, the American Newspaper Publishers Association reported yesterday. While constituting a new high, the 1952 figure was but slightly greater than totals for the two preceding years, being 0.2 per cent above the 1951 consumption of 5,974,865 tons, and 0.9 per cent over the 1950 estimate of 5,936,941.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 20 -- Members of the United States Congress and the British House of Commons were invited today to come to West Germany and ascertain for themselves if there was a resurgence of nazism.

Don Gehrmann stands at the crossroads of his footracing career. The name of the four-year king of the indoor miles was not included among the five starters named yesterday for the Wanamaker Mile in the Millrose Games, which will open the five-meet Madison Square Garden track schedule a week from tomorrow night.
The Association of the Bar of the City of New York affirmed last night its support of lawyers who were subjected to criticism when they represented unpopular clients or causes.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 20 -- President Eisenhower's statement that his Administration intended to strengthen the United Nations had a warm welcome today from delegates and members of the Secretariat.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Pennsylvanians proudly marched down Pennsylvania Avenue today in honor of a President they hope will be a part-time resident.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Harry S. Truman ended his career as President with a defense of Federal employes against "reckless attacks."

Judge Edward J. Dimock decided last night in Federal Court that there would be no more night sessions in the trial of thirteen Communist party leaders charged with conspiring to teach and advocate overthrow of the Government by force and violence.
Foggy weather, which has plagued shipping and plane schedules in the metropolitan area this year, was in evidence again here yesterday morning.
History is not only the great speech, the fateful vote, the bold decision. It is also small things. It is the web on which the design of the tapestry is embroidered.

Four teachers and a school clerk who were suspended by the Board of Education last Nov. 20 for failing to answer questions concerning Communist party affiliations pleaded not guilty yesterday before Arthur Levitt, board trial examiner, at a hearing at 110 Livingston Street, Brooklyn. The trial date was set for Feb. 18 at 10 A. M.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 20 (AP) -- A $2,500,000 suit charging Follansbee Steel Corporation with conspiracy in the purchase five years ago or Federal Enameling Company was brought yesterday in Federal District Court by Rex Murdock on behalf of himself and other shareholders.

LONDON, Jan. 20 (UP) -- One man was sentenced to death today and nine others to prison terms for plotting to overthrow the Communist government of Bulgaria as part of an American-financed spy ring, the Bulgarian Telegraph Agency reported from Sofia.

Two new films will arrive at first-run theatres this morning. "Taxi," a Twentieth Century-Fox comedy-drama featuring Dan Dailey and Constance Smith, is at the Globe. Gregory Ratoff directed and Samuel G. Engel produced from a screen play by D. M. Marshman Jr. and Daniel Fuchs and a story by Hans Jacoby and Fred Brady, as adapted from the French film, "Sans Laisser d'Adresse" by Alex Joffe and Jean Paul Le Chanoi.

The Bank of the Manhattan Company's unsuccessful plan to sell its banking assets to Chase National Bank now threatens its latest proposal to increase capital through sale of additional shares. Holders of substantial interests in the Manhattan Company have indicated their dissatisfaction to its management, and one important stockholder has written each of the bank's directors demanding an explanation of the situation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Spiritual guidance was sought by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and all of his top appointees and their families today at a special pre-inaugural service at the National Presbyterian Church.
ALBANY, Jan. 20 (UP) -- The State Commerce Department today reported the following winter sports conditions:
Following are excerpts from editorial comment in newspapers gathered by THE NEW YORK TIMES and The Associated Press on President Eisenhower's inaugural address:

The Vanderbilt will formally resume its career as a legitimate house with the premiere of "Mid-Summer" at 8 o'clock this evening. Since 1939 the cozy showcase, seating 716, has been utilized by radio. Attribute the change in policy to Irving Maidman, the new landlord.

Blood donations to the Red Cross program continued to lag again this week, it was reported yesterday, with only 232 pints contributed on Monday. They came from the three borough centers in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx, and the American Machine and Foundry Company in Brooklyn.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Jan. 20 -- Responsible diplomats are beginning to predict that unless South Africa alters her present racial policy there will be an explosion in this country within the next few years. Observers who once calculated that any disruption could be staved off for perhaps another quarter of a century have revised their estimates.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- President and Mrs. Eisenhower entered the White House, which will be their home for the next four years, at 7:02 P. M. today.

Inauguration of the President and Vice President on the steps of the Capitol yesterday with oaths administered respectively by the Chief Justice and a leading Senator provided a symbolic demonstration of the interweaving of power among the three separate divisions of our Government.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Jan. 20 -- A Bolivian airlift over the Andes broke a Chilean transport blockade that had brought stocks of foodstuffs and machinery parts at this country's tin mines to a dangerously low level.

BERLIN, Jan. 20 -- East Germany's united front of political parties and organizations indicated tonight that Georg Dertinger, the Government's imprisoned Foreign Minister, would be tried as the head of an entire spy ring.

For one group of New Yorkers the glamour of the ceremonies attending the inauguration of President Eisenhower yesterday was outshone by the lure of the cars at the General Motors Corporation's Motorama of 1953 at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. From 11:30 A. M. until 1 P. M., which included the time of the swearing into office of General Eisenhower, 12,000 visitors passed through the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel inspecting motor products.

MIAMI BEACH. Fla., Jan. 20 -- Continuing vigilance against trade abuses is necessary to maintain the outstanding record of good relationships between the nation's retailers and the women's coat and suit industry, Samuel Klein, executive director of the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, said here today.

ROME, Wednesday, Jan. 21 -- Riots fist fights and other disturbances both inside and outside the Parliament building marked the attempt to filibuster the Government's electoral reform bill to death as the Chamber of Deputies yesterday afternoon entered its third day of continuous session.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 20 -- Hollywood union leaders took their first definite steps today to discourage production of pictures outside this country for economic reasons. Union members, running the gamut from grips to the personnel of the Screen Actors Guild, were counseled by the Hollywood American Federation of Labor Film Council not to accept employment in such pictures without first ascertaining that the project had been approved by the union.

George P. MacNichol Jr., vice president in charge of sales of Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company, has been elected executive vice president, it was announced yesterday by John D. Biggers, president. Mr. MacNichol succeeds to the post which was left vacant at the retirement of the late D. H. Goodwillie. F. Earle Cazayoux, comptroller and treasurer, was elected a director.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Gil Turner battered Bobby Dykes tonight as he pounded out a unanimous ten-round decision over the tall Texan at the Arena. Turner weighed 149 1/2 pounds and Dykes 154 for the bout that drew boos, catcalls and stamping of feet because of long moments of inaction.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The thing that impressed most observers here about President Eisenhower's first state paper was that he spoke almost entirely in universal terms. His Inaugural Address was directed not to the United States alone but to the world; not to nationalist solutions of the Republic's problems but to international solutions; not to collective security in the military field alone but to collective political action and collective international economic cooperation as well.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The simple inauguration that President Eisenhower wanted somehow snow-balled itself into the most costly and splendid show in some 150 years of this Capital City.

The Republican party returned to power yesterday in a gay and wildly celebrating Washington, but there was no note of jubilation and no promise of easy gains to come in the inaugural address of the new President of the United States. There was, instead, a sober facing up to the facts of a grim world situation.

Cleveland, Jan. 20 -- All-important in the day of the "push-button factory" will be its maintenance organization, Walter A. Adams, Maintenance engineer of the J. M. Lehmann Company of Lyndhurst, N. J., said here today at the Plant Maintenance Show.

For the final new work of its City Center season, the New York City Ballet last night presented William Dollar's "The Five Gifts," set to the music of Dohnanyi's "Variations on a Nursery Tune," and basing its scenario on a fable by Mark Twain.

The Washington scene came to the center of the stage yesterday and the stock market took the inauguration of the new President in stride. Those who expected that the change of Government would radically alter the market's position evidently were wishful thinkers. The hard-headed traders kept to an even line.

At least half the population of the United States, including millions of school children, were able to "attend" the Inauguration of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower as the thirty-fourth President of the United States yesterday -- by means of the largest television hook-up in history.

The women's United States squash racquets team sailed yesterday on the S. S. America for England, where it will participate in a number of tournaments and defend the international trophy, the Wolfe-Noel Challenge Cup.
Former Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson left New York yesterday for a Caribbean vacation, saying that his prayers were very much with Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower as the new President began his term of office.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Jan. 21 -- The Government - controlled Peiping radio boasted today that the Communists had built a fortified line across the Korean peninsula through which United Nations troops would be unable to break.

Hal Block is expected to return as a panel member of "What's My Line?" on Sunday evening at 10:30 o'clock over Channel 2. Steve Allen, who had replaced him, will continue on the show in the absence of Bennett Cerf, who is away on a seven-week lecture tour.

Sixty educators from colleges and universities in and around New York attended yesterday a luncheon in honor of Gen. Yaacov Dori, president of Technion. Israel's Institutes of Technology in Haifa. The American Technion Society gave the luncheon, which was held in the Commodore Hotel.
Lace, together with embroidered organdy, net, and other gossamer fabrics, led in the parade of bridal fashions for spring and summer shown to the press yesterday in Best's bridal salon.

THE NEW YORK TIMES is to be commended for its excellent coverage of the agricultural migrant problem over the last two years and its fine editorial on Jan. 13 "'Wetbacks' and Farm Labor." Articles from Gladwin Hill from the Western viewpoint and Stanley Levey in the East have pinpointed many of the problems involved in this blight on our country, and still Congress has not effectively begun to meet the problem head on.

Donald F. Hagerty of the Yale Club, only seeded player to see action yesterday in the annual Yale Club squash tennis Bulldog handicap tournament, came through handily in his first round match with W. W Holden, a clubmate. Hagerty (scratch) beat Holden (plus 9), 15 -- 10, 15 -- 11.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20 -- A sharp advance in grain and soybean futures in the early trading today was brought to a halt by increased selling on the upturns, most of the gains being erased before the market began to get general support again.

Amid charges of "hypocrisy, originating in Albany" the City Council yesterday adopted resolutions requesting Governor Dewey and the Legislature to take action leading to the legalization of lotteries and off-track betting.

A carefully prepared and conscientiously performed recital was played in Town Hall last evening by the pianist Emil Danenberg. 1r. Danenberg, a faculty member f the Oberlin Conservatory of 1VIusic since 1944, played his first Town Hall recital two years ago.
CHICAGO, Jan. 20 (AP) -- A Federal court was told today that the U. S. Rubber Company got half of the General Motors Corporation's tire business in 1931.

Testimony in the six-month departmental trial of thirty suspended policemen ended yesterday, and as it did Harry Gross moved swiftly to profit from his role of prosecution witness against the men accused of conniving in his vanished bookmaking "monarchy."

SEOUL, Korea, Jan. 20 -- The first modern Korean translation of the Bible was off the printing presses in Tokyo today. The edition will consist of 100,000 copies to be given to orphanages, hospitals and prisoner-of-war camps and sold through about 100 book stores.

In an extraordinary passage -- Point Seven -- in his moving inaugural address President Eisenhower addressed himself directly to "the enlightened and inspired leaders" of Western Europe and exhorted them again, and on this solemn occasion, to strive with renewed vigor to make the unity of their peoples a reality.
