WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- A hushed throng of more than 100,000 watched Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower take the Presidential oath at the East portico of the Capitol today in the most solemn moment of the inaugural ceremonies.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 20 -- Arriving here on a state visit tonight, the Turkish Foreign Minister, Fuad Koprulu, stressed the seriousness of his mission, which may lead to a formal Balkan defense alliance among Greece, Turkey and Yugoslavia.

OTTAWA, Jan. 20 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's Prime Minister, Louis St. Laurent, in leters made public today, bade farewell to Harry S. Truman as the retiring President and welcomed President Eisenhower with a hope that he would visit Canada soon.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower was elected President last Nov. 4, after he had gained world-wide fame as Supreme Commander of the Allied Expeditionary Forces in Europe in World War II, and as postwar Supreme Commander for Western Europe.

The Home Lines has signed an agreement with Furness Withy Co., Ltd., for the use of the latter's piers at West Fifty-fifth and West Fifty-seventh Streets, it was announced yesterday by Capt. Mario F. Vespa, Home Line representative in North America.

CAMDEN, N. J., Jan. 20 (AP) -- Jersey Joe Walcott said today that he had every intention of fighting the heavyweight champion, Rocky Marciano, and to tell the New York State Athletic Commission -- Chairman Robert K. Christenberry in particular -- he did not need any help in deciding when to retire.

ABADAN, Iran, Jan. 20 (UP) -- An Italian tanker challenged Britain's right to blockade Iranian oil today by sailing with the second "hot" cargo since the British-Iranian dispute paralyzed the biggest refinery in the world.

The Public Service Commission denied yesterday an application by the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad for permission to close its station at Nineteenth Street and the Avenue of the Americas. The company connects New York and New Jersey by tube.
St. Petersburg, Fla., announced yesterday that it will receive bids Feb. 19 on $3,600,000 of water revenue bonds dated Oct. 1, 1952, and due Oct. 1, 1953 to 1972.

Dr. Hugh W. Gray has been appointed laboratory director of the textile fibers department of the pioneering research division for E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Wilmington. Dr. Allan K. Schneider succeeds him as a research supervisor in the chemical department.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20 (AP) -- A rules committee meeting is the first order of business tomorrow night when the National Football League will open its annual meeting here.

PORT CHESTER, N. Y., Jan. 20 -- The Standard-Vacuum Oil Company filed an application with the Rye Town Council here tonight for a rezoning of twenty-six acres of vacant residential property on Anderson Hill Road, in an unincorporated part of the town, so that a new national headquarters for 700 executive and administrative employes could be constructed.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 20 (UP) -- The Peronista evening newspaper Critica took an eight-column slap at John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State in the new United States Administration, for "suspicious duality in Yankee foreign policy."

HONOLULU, Jan. 20 -- A four-day conference on Japanese-American relations found no disagreement on aims of the two nations but did confirm misunderstandings of these aims, Dr. Harold Fisher, the conference co-chairman, told delegates today at the closing session of the informal and private meetings at the Halekulani Hotel.

An employer offer to renew the present two-year contract, which expires on Jan. 31, was rejected yesterday by the negotiating committee of Local 333, United Marine Division of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The inaugural parade today appropriately featured the motif of the atomic age. The Vermont float, about which the Parade Committee had grave doubts on the ground it would be too subtle for the crowds, had an unexpected success and provoked considerable laughter.

STOWE, Vt., Jan. 20 -- Endowed with all types of natural facilities, Vermont today boasts of having more ski lifts and tows than any other state in this country. Rolling hills and woodlands, rugged mountain ranges, with many summits poking up above the 4,000-foot mark, and heavy snows are to be found in a belt stretching from Canada to Massachusetts and roughly following the range of the Green Mountains.

Edwin (Duke) Snider, one of the two outstanding Brooklyn hitters in the world series, yesterday became the seventeenth Dodger to sign his 1953 contract, which called for an estimated salary of $24,000, a rise of between $2,000 and $3,000.

Like a lot of old bats that hang around this town, "The Bat" that Mary Roberts Rinehart and Avery Hopwood wrote in 1920 has some funny moments. With Lucile Watson scowling at everyone imperiously and ZaSu Pitts bellowing and waving her hands, it opened at the National last evening, looking every bit 33 years of age but still in good humor.

LONDON, Jan. 20 -- Two phrases in President Eisenhower's inaugural address aroused special interest in Government circles here today. One was his hint that the new Administration might make trade a little easier, and the other was that the United States might expect a little more British cooperation toward European unity.
LONDON, Jan. 20 (Reuters) -- Britain's ancient fishing ports, which together make up the sixth largest industry in the country, today are filled with uneasy men.

A list of 600 to 700 privately owned Manhattan businesses that might start making charitable gifts of $500 or more to the Greater New York Fund has been submitted by the fund to three major money-raising federations to avoid a conflict in appeals.

Since the Slansky trial the world has received very little information of what is happening to the Jews in Hungary and in Rumania. Besides the Soviet Union they are the two Eastern European countries with the largest Jewish population: 130,000 in Hungary and over 300,000 in Rumania.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Jan. 20 (UP) -- Firing a 6-under-par 66, Pete Fleming, a former professional prize fighter from Hot Springs, Ark., and St. Andrews, Ill., took over the lead today at the end of two rounds in the $10,000 Palm Springs invitational golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Plans for President Eisenhower to carry eight of his nine Cabinet appointees into office with him today were blocked in the Senate within an hour after the inauguration ceremonies by Senator Wayne Morse of Oregon.
A broad hint that the spring season will have bright coats and suits was given yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in Bonwit Teller's showing of Seymour Fox designs.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Congress responded with general warmth and in many cases with profound bipartisan approval today to President Eisenhower's Inaugural Address. There was an all but visible gathering behind him of great blocs of members of both houses, Democrat and Republican alike, in his strong, somber pledge to carry this nation forward in full unity with the free world.
MANNING, S. C., Jan. 20 (AP) -- Two school buses one filled with children, crashed head-on in thick fog near here early today, causing the deaths of two persons and injuries to about forty.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 20 -- A spokesman for the Israeli delegation said today that Foreign Minister Moshe Sharett's statement in Tel Aviv Sunday about a third force among Asian countries referred to the need for economic and social reforms, not to their position on political issues.

Of particular interest to prospective homeowners with a taste for contemporary design is a showing opening at the Museum of Modern Art today. Of the firty-three buildings shown in photographs, models and colored slides, nineteen are private homes.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 20 -- Amid partisan cheers and applause, the Board of Education virtually abolished last night the controversial United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization program from the Los Angeles schools system.
LONDON, Jan. 20 -- Industrial shares continued to dominate stock markets here today with good rises among miscellaneous. British Government securities made small gains.

LONDON, Wednesday, Jan. 21 (Reuters) -- Japan, building new ships at a faster clip than any other country, brought her merchant fleet up almost to its prewar level in the year ending last July, Lloyds Register of Shipping announced today in issuing this year's edition of its statistical appendix.

Pierre Monteux appeared as guest leader of the Philadelphia Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall, and it was an evening of superb conducting. The concert opened very appropriately to Inauguration Day with an impressive performance of "The Star-Spangled Banner."

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 20 -- Calling for the foundation of a Roman Catholic university in Mexico, leading Mexican churchmen told the opening session of the First National Congress on Catholic Culture yesterday that there was no conflict between science and religion.

Courtroom exchanges yesterday between Federal Judge Harold R. Medina and Department of Justice lawyers winding up their antitrust charges against seventeen investment banking houses suggested that the Government thus far has fallen short of convincing the judge of the merits of its case.
MOSCOW, Jan. 20 -- The newspaper Soviet Lithuania, published at Kaunas, reports that "some of our organizations have been penetrated by enemy elements -- bourgeois nationalists and Jewish Zionists."

The alertness of a patrolman, combined with the wiles of a fast-thinking night watchman, frustrated a seven-man hold-up gang early yesterday at the Croydon Hotel, 12 East Eighty-sixth Street, off Madison Avenue, and resulted in the capture of six of the men.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 20 (AP) -- Four-Way Ranch's Dulat, conditioned in sprint races, furnished a surprise as he drove to victory in the $5,000 Trade Winds Purse, the mile-and-a-furlong event on the turf course that topped the program today at Hialeah Park.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Today's ceremony was not just another inauguration. It was more than a transfer of government from one party to another. The jubilation of the Republicans returning to power after twenty years of exile was, of course, the dominant note in the celebration.

Factory shipments of gas-operated central heating equipment last year increased substantially while most large household electrical appliances lagged considerably. This was made clear yesterday in reports from the Gas Appliance Manufacturers Association and the National Electrical Manufacturers Association.

LONDON, Jan. 20 -- The arrest of seven suspected Nazi plotters last week by British occupation authorities in West Germany was justified today by Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden in the House of Commons on the ground that a "potential danger" could not be ignored even though there was no present risk.

Equipped with sandwiches and copies of the Constitution of the United States, the eighth grade of Public School 9 saw the inauguration of President Eisenhower on a television set in the fifth-floor gymnasium of the building at Eighty-second Street and West End Avenue.
The Army goes far in seeing that ample provisions are made for the wives of soldiers, but when a man has two wives and wants allotments for both -- that's going too far.
The Ohio Power Company raised $32,000,000 in the public market yesterday by the sale of $22,000,000 of first mortgage bonds due in 1983 and 100,000 shares of $100 par value preferred stock.

There is nothing like a couple of dozen vigorous, aggressive and determined little children -- except perhaps more children -- when it comes to separating the amateur baby sitters from the professionals. That is the opinion of the staff nurses at Mount Sinai Hospital's new Klingenstein Maternity Pavilion, who completed yesterday their first week of supervising a new playroom for the children of mothers visiting the pavilion's prenatal clinic.

Events tonight: "Der Rosenkavalier," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P. M.; Philharmonic-Symphony, Vladimir Golschmann conducting, Edmund Kurtz, 'cellist, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Adolph Baller, pianist, Gabor Retjo, 'cellist, Town Hall, 8:30; "The Dumka," Ukrainian Men's Chorus, Presbyterian Labor Temple, 242 East Fourteenth Street, 8:30; Blodwen Evans, soprano, English-speaking Union, 19 East Fifty-fourth Street, 8:30.

ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- Arguments for and against the state's, acquisition of ten television channels tentatively assigned to it by the Federal Communications Commission were heard here today in the last of three open hearings conducted by the Temporary State Commission on the Use of Television for Educational Purposes.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 21 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has decided to produce at least one three-dimensional film and is about to close a deal with the Natural Vision Corporation for the use of its photographic equipment.

A Citizens Committee for Planned Parenthood called upon the board of the Welfare and Health Council of New York City yesterday to reverse its recent decision denying membership to the Planned Parenthood Committee of Mothers' Health Centers, Manhattan-Bronx affiliate of the Planned Parenthood Federation.
Changes in hospital operating rooms were recommended yesterday at the annual meeting of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers in the Statler Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The Equitable Gas Company of Pittsburgh filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission today for the sale of 100,000 shares of convertible preferred stock (cumulative $100 par value), to be offered for public sale through a group of underwriters headed by the First Boston Corporation, Kidder, Peabody Co., Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane and White, Weld Co.
PARIS, Jan. 21 -- The heavy persistent fog over much of northern Europe for the last two weeks has played havoc with air schedules, Channel shipping and many other activities, including breathing.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- James M. Mead submitted his resignation as chairman of the Federal Trade Commission to president Eisenhower today.

NEWARK, Jan. 21 -- The third Reconstruction Finance Corporation loan for hospitals in the metropolitan area, which were certified as necessary by the Federal Civil Defense Administrator, was announced today by the Clara Maass Hospital here.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 21 (AP) -- The Springhill Stable's De Anza raced to his second straight stakes victory for California-breds today when he captured the $18,600 Santa Barbara Stakes by two lengths at Santa Anita.

TRENTON, Jan. 21 -- Setting the pattern of a campaign to elect a Governor in the fall, New Jersey Democrats announced today a legislative program designed to correct an alleged breakdown of law enforcement in the state under the present Republican Administration.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were steadier yesterday, and active months closed 27 to 35 points net higher than on Tuesday.
Section 434 of Title 18 of the United States Code, entitled "Interested Persons Acting as Government Agents," reads as follows:

MOSCOW, Jan. 21 -- The Soviet journal New Times, which speaks here with a voice of substantial authority on questions of foreign affairs, asserted today that the entire Jewish Zionist movement had "sold out" to American intelligence and was helping United States imperialists to create a "fifth column" in the Soviet Union and the "People's Democracies" in return for United States support of the state of Israel.

KINGS PARK, L. I., Thursday, Jan. 22 -- Fourteen patients in the Kings Park State Hospital, a mental institution here, broke out of a ward at 12:15 A. M. today, a hospital spokesman said. The state police and the police of Smithtown, who protect this community, were notified.

Arthur Miller's new play, "The Crucible," will open tonight at 7:45 o'clock at the Martin Beck Theatre under Kermit Bloomgarden's sponsorship. Walter Hampden and Arthur Kennedy are co-starred in the drama, which deals with witchcraft trials held in 1692 in Salem, Mass.

The Philippine President, Elpidio Quirino, has had some sharp things to say about a Mutual Security Agency report on land and tenancy problems in the Philippines. Philippine reaction to the agency's criticism of tenant conditions, especially on Luzon, arises in part from the feeling that the American approach to land problems in Asia has often been somewhat doctrinaire.

CHICAGO, Jan. 21 -- Dr. Henry H. Kessler of Newark, N. J., orthopedic surgeon and founder and medical director of the Kessler Institute for Rehabilitation, West Orange, N. J., received tonight a Presidential award for outstanding service to the physically handicapped.
The jurors in the Communist trial were:

It is not too much to say that the Yehudi Menuhin who played at Carnegie Hall last night performed like an important new violinist. The importance lay in the thrust and personality Mr. Menuhin revealed as an interpreter. It was as though he had moved up to a higher level of accomplishment, a level one had expected him to achieve sooner.

The atmosphere was electric chez Lilly Dache yesterday morning. The famed milliner, whose collection was being reviewed by the fashion press, had just returned from Paris and the Inauguration in Washington.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 21 -- Lewis Mumford, Visiting Professor in Land and City Planning at the University of Pennsylvania's School of Fine Arts, received today the Fairmount Park Art Association's medal of honor for distinguished service.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (UP) -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee will question Dr. James Bryant Conant, slated to be United States High Commissioner in Germany, next week, Congressional sources reported today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- If an observer could have followed the new President of the United States today he would have had a busy time with an extremely animated man tackling his new job with vigor, seriousness and humor.

CHICAGO, Jan. 21 -- Plans for a national drive by its members to eliminate substandard houses in American cities through enactment and enforcement of state and municipal sanitation and health codes were announced today by the National Association of Home Builders.

A jury of six men and six women, which included one Negro, convicted thirteen Communist party leaders yesterday of conspiring to teach and advocate the overthrow of the Government by force and violence. The verdict came in the seventh day of the jury's deliberations, at the end of a nine-and-a-half-month trial in the United States Court House in Foley Square.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (UP) -- The Federal Communications Commission today invited Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, to give his reasons for opposing a television application filed by a newspaper editor with whom he has had disputes.

TOKYO, Jan. 21 -- Officials of Japan's Conservative government applauded today the Inaugural address of President Eisenhower yesterday, but Japanese Socialist parties and a considerable section of public opinion voiced uneasy qualms that heavier demands now would be made on this critically located nation.
GENEVA, Jan. 21 -- Israel and the Intergovernmental Committee for European Migration have signed an agreement covering the migration of European Jews to Israel, it was announced here today.

GENEVA, Jan. 21 -- David Owen, chairman of the United Nations Technical Assistance Board, told the World Health Organization today that it must share in the worldwide technical assistance program as a loyal member of the United Nations team or not at all.
ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- A dangerous "philosophy of fear" has developed on the American college campus, a panel of five college educators warned here today.

The National Labor Relations Board has been accused of inconsistency for allowing an independent communications union to participate in an organizing election even though the union's officers had refused to verify their non-Communist oaths filed under provisions of the Taft-Hartley Law. The refusal had been made before a Federal grand jury and a Senate committee.
CHICAGO, Jan. 21 (AP) -- United Air Lines announced today it would add DC-6 air coach service on two daily trancontinental runs by April 26.

Prices closed irregularly yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges with volume generally light. Activity improved on sugar and potatoes had more trades in the first hour of business than on any full day this year. Potatoes, sugar, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, coffee and tin closed mixed.

A Guarnerius violin, appraised at $10,000, has been presented to the Juilliard School of Music by an anonymous donor, Mark Schubart, dean of the school, announced yesterday. The instrument, made by Joseph Guarnerius del Gesu in 1731, is known as the "Mayseder" Guarnerius.

RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 21 -- Hard-fighting Karen rebels inflicted heavy casualties on Burma Government forces in bitter clashes at Kawkareik [cross on map] on southern Burma's border with Thailand, army dispatches said tonight.

Supreme Court Justice Carroll G. Walter reserved decision yesterday in an action brought against the Hanover Bank by Laurence Frazier and others who surrendered bonds and defaulted coupons in acceptance of an offer made by the Government of Peru in 1947.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 21 (UP) -- Polly Riley fired a one-under-women's-par 74 today to win the medal in the twenty-first annual Helen Lee Doherty amateur golf tournament and will share the favorite's role with Mary Lena Faulk when match play begins tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- The Defense Production Administration announced its approval today of tax benefits to assist the Harvey Machine Company, Inc. in construction of a $65,250,000 aluminum plant in Oregon.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 21 -- Count Ettore Della Zonca, an Italian oil trader, said today that although he ran afoul of the British legal blockade in his first attempt to export oil from Iran he would try again.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 21 (UP) -- The National Football League rules committee adopted recommendations for minor rules changes tonight but stood pat on the platoon system and killed suggestions for eliminating the point after touchdown and altering ball-carrying regulations.

SAPPORO, Hokkaido, Japan, Jan. 21 -- The people of Hokkaido are not afraid of the Russians, a half-dozen miles across the sea, as long as American armed forces remain on this northernmost island of Japan.

HOLLYWOOD BEACH, Fla., Jan. 21 (AP) -- Third-seeded Yvon Petra of Paris was upset by Jason Morton, Corpus Christi, Tex., in today's second round of the national professional clay courts tennis championships at the Hollywood Beach Hotel.
TOKYO, Thursday, Jan. 22 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,502, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Thursday, Korean time:

ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- The Veterans Bonus Bureau of the State Department of Taxation and Finance reported today that in five years of operation it had paid out $338,806,860 in bonus checks to 1,555,265 veterans of World War II.
The Young Women's Christian Association of New York has raised 78 per cent of its campaign goal of $285,000, Mrs. Albert Francke Jr., chairman of the fund drive, reported yesterday.

BELLEFONTE, Pa., Jan. 21 (AP) -- One hundred heavily armed state policemen were massed today at the Rockview Penitentiary where 325 convicts held six guards hostage for the third straight day. Forty-five of the troopers were rushed to the prison today following the issuance of a "get tough" order by Gov. John S. Fine.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 21 -- Sir Ivone Kirkpatrick, British High Commissioner, was reported tonight to have informed Chancellor Konrad Adenauer yesterday that Dr. Werner Naumann, foremost of the seven former Nazi leaders arrested last week by British public safety officers, had access to the secret files of the Free Democratic party, second largest in the Government coalition.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Jan. 21 -- Some criticism of the Revised Standard Version of the Bible is "religious racketeering," Bishop William C. Martin, president of the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A., said here today. He is attending the annual meeting of the Board of Missions and Church Extension of the Methodist Church.

TORONTO, Jan. 21 (UP) -- A first-period goal by Bernie (Boom Boom) Geoffrion tonight carried the Montreal Canadiens to a 1-to-0 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs and to within 3 points of the National Hockey League leaders, the Detroit Red Wings.

Judge Clarence G. Galston in Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday directed the Government to turn over to Thomas Luchese, also known as Three Finger Brown, any records relating to the 52-year-old ex-convict's naturalization.
The Board of Education will break ground tonight for an addition to Public School 19 at Post and Greenleaf Avenues, West New Brighton, S. I. Improvements to the school will cost $1,000,000.
SEOUL, Korea, Jan. 21 -- The reserve pool of Korean manpower on which the United States and the rest of the United Nations was counting so heavily is slowly but surely being drained off.

Federal Judge Edward J. Dimock, who presided at the Communist trial that ended yesterday, indicated in an interview later in his chambers that he was not surprised by the length of the jury's deliberations. The jury was in its seventh day, of study when it returned its guilty verdict.

HONOLULU, Jan. 21 (UP) -- Pacific Fleet headquarters today identified six men missing after the crash of a Navy Neptune bomber that was hit by a Communist shore battery's fire off the China coast Sunday.
The thirteen who were convicted in the Communist trial are:

SAIGON, Vietnam, Indo-China, Jan. 21 -- A battle at Ankhe, on the high Moi plateau of central Vietnam, is now taking shape. Red Vietminh forces struck last night against the French Deomong post, which fell before dawn.

BOSTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- George Ratkovicz' 20-foot shot with seven seconds left gave the Milwaukee Hawks a 72-70 victory over the New York Knickerbockers tonight, their second consecutive National Basketball Association upset triumph.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower on her first complete day as First Lady had a typical sampling of her role for the next four years.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee gave informal approval today to Harold E. Stassen for the post of Director for the Mutual Security Agency.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 21 (AP) -- John Landy, who is said to be the fastest miler in the world today, will go out Saturday in a calculated attempt to crash through the four-minute barrier.

ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- Provision for continuing for two years the plan to supplement the pensions of retired public employes receiving less than $1,200 a year is contained in administration bills introduced today by Senator Walter J. Mahoney of Buffalo and Assemblyman William H. MacKenzie, chairman of the fiscal committees of the Legislature.

The Jewish Morning Journal announced yesterday that it would merge Monday with The Jewish Day and the joint publication would appear as The Morning Journal-Day. The combined Yiddish language paper will be published from the Day plant at 183 East Broadway.

BRIDGETOWN, Barbados, B. W. I., Jan. 21 (Up) -- Adlai E. Stevenson today described President Eisenhower's inaugural address as an "eloquent and splendid restatement" of the past policies of the United States.

The duel between Charley Capozzoli, 21-year-old Georgetown senior from Bayside, Queens, and Horace Ashenfelter, the Olympic steeplechase champion, which provided the highlight of the track meet in Boston last Saturday, will be re-enacted at the Millrose games in Madison Square Garden next Thursday night.

BERLIN, Jan. 21 -- Dr. Ernst Reuter, West Berlin's Mayor, said today that in face of the growing Communist pressure the city would stand or fall depending on how much aid was provided by the West -- primarily the United States.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 21 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie sent a telegram to President Eisenhower today in acknowledgment and commendation of two references to the United Nations in the General's Inaugural Address yesterday. The Lie message said:

" THE WHITE RABBIT,"* by Bruce Marshall, is the most exciting story of a secret agent's adventures behind the enemy's lines I have read in a Maugham's age. It is the tale of Wing Comdr. Forest Frederick Edward Yeo-Thomas, a brave and brilliant Briton who parachuted into Occupied France time and again during the war to work with the men of the Resistance and prepare the way for the Allied landings.

MADRID, Jan. 21 -- Spain's second High Fashion Festival ended tonight in Barcelona on a note of international good-will with the proposal by the Couturiers Association and the Silk Guild to present a Spanish-made and designed dress to Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower "to reciprocate the interest and sympathy shown by United States buyers and fashion magazines" for the couturiers of Spain.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- A new procedure to make effective the nondiscrimination clause in Government contracts was put into effect here today by the General Services Administration on orders from Jess Larson, administrator of the Government buying agency.

MOSCOW, Jan. 21 -- Nikolai A. Mikhailov, recently named secretary of the Russian Communist party, demanded tonight that that party mercilessly drive from its ranks all "degenerates or double-dealers," root out hidden enemies no matter what mask they wear and incessantly strengthen the Soviet armed forces and intelligence organs.

Various college choirs and glee clubs will be heard in a series of weekly radio programs to be presented by WOR and the Mutual Broadcasting System network, beginning Saturday afternoon from 4:30 to 5 o'clock.

The two four-story apartment houses at 343-349 Marlborough Road in Brooklyn have been sold by Dr. George E. Mulen to the Mid-Hub Realty Corporation. M. S. Gaumont were the brokers in the sale of the property, which occupies a plot 77 by 75 feet and is assessed at $54,000.

A brief ceremony early last night at the Vanderbilt Theatre, 148 West Forty-eighth Street, just before the premiere curtain of "Mid-Summer" went up, officially marked the transition of the 716-seat house from a radio studio to the so - called legitimate fold.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 21 (UP) -- A young man found dead of cyanide poisoning with a mysterious note taped to his abdomen was identified today as a chemistry student at the New York University Washington Square College or Arts and Science.

The Jewish National Fund, the land development agency for Israel and the World Zionist movement announced yesterday it would start an immediate campaign to enroll 50,000 volunteers throughout the country to place 750,000 blue-and-white collection boxes in Jewish homes.
ROME, Jan. 21 -- Implicit approval of the electoral reform bill by Italy's Chamber of Deputies paved the way today for action by the Senate.

Among the many auspicious portents attending the inauguration of President Eisenhower one of the most promising is the warm welcome accorded him by the statesmen and the press of the free world. Putting aside misunderstandings and misinterpretations of the campaign period, which in some cases affected their earlier judgment, they hail the inaugural address as a declaration of faith to which all free nations and all free men can subscribe.

Government funds for scientific research tempt research men to study only in the fields for which those funds are available, Dr. Edmund W. Sinnott, dean of the Yale Graduate School and a past president of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, said in a panel discussion here yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 21 -- The rise in Exchequer revenues for last week, coupled with the strength of the sterling-dollar exchange rate, enabled British Government securities to make further gains on the Stock Exchange today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- President Eisenhower has accepted defeat in the first Senatorial challenge of his appointive powers. He has abandoned plans to name former Gov. Val Peterson of Nebraska as Ambassador to India and will appoint him instead as a member of the White House staff, a post that does not require Senatorial confirmation.

CHICAGO, Jan. 21 -- Free selling of corn was responsible for a sharp recession in corn prices, and this affected other grains adversely. The pressure on corn stemmed largely from the fact that Government-owned grain is being offered in liberal volume about every day.
A new collection of colored wood furniture, achieved through painting the surfaces with a semi-gloss enamel, is on view at Abraham Straus in Brooklyn.

A $500,000 grant to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology for research in the molecular structure of biological materials and other work in biology was announced yesterday by the Rockefeller Foundation.

ROME, Jan. 21 -- A possibility that the Rev. Leonard Feeney, superior of the proscribed Slaves of the Immaculate Heart of Mary in Boston, would receive an extension of the Jan. 31 deadline when he must appear in Rome to face ecclesiastical charges, on pain of excommunication, appeared here today.

Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., accepted Mayor Impellitteri's arbitration formula yesterday, but snags over arbitration terms delayed settlement of the three-week-old bus strike.

A five-for-one split of Guaranty Trust Company's capital stock, increasing authorized shares from 1,000,000 to 5,000,000 and reducing the par from $100 to $20, was approved yesterday by the bank's stockholders at their annual meeting.

The Federal Maritime Board in Washington yesterday granted the motion of the Isbrandtsen Company, Inc., for a public hearing into the dual rate contract system proposed by the Japan-Atlantic and Gulf Conference. However, it denied the shipping company's request that application of rates be suspended pending a decision by the board.
President Eisenhower started his first day in office yesterday confronted with military problems of long duration that have so far defied solution.

At any time now there will come a stretch of two or three days when, in the early afternoon, the temperature will rise into the sixties, perhaps even higher. The ice on the ponds will grow soft, will then become slush, will disappear altogether.

NEWARK, Jan. 21 -- An olive oil display counter became an arsenal for Mr. and Mrs. Dominick Ventura when they discovered their daughter, Frances, 26 years old, being held at bay by a bandit with a pistol in their grocery store at 224 Warren Street shortly after 2 P. M. today.
Substantial improvement in operating result was shown last year by two major aircraft manufacturers, according to reports issued yesterday.

An easier tone developed in the stock market yesterday, but not because of any news developments. It was purely a traders' market. Public participation was at a minimum and selling was easily absorbed.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Jan. 21 (AP) -- Jimmy Demaret emerged on top in a battle of golf's greatest players today, winning the $10,000 Thunderbird Country Club invitational tournament with a final round of 67 for a 15-under-par 201 for the 54-hole event.

THE HAGUE, Jan. 21 -- Indonesia produced 3,176 tons of tin concentrates in December for a year's total of 35,003 tons, or 13 per cent more than in 1951, the International Tin Study Group reported today. The only other December figure available was for the Belgian Congo of 1,150, making 13,320 for the year, or 2.5 per cent lower than the previous year.

William W. Remington said at his second perjury trial yesterday that he might have been "indiscreet" in the selection of subject matter for his discussions with Elizabeth T. Bentley, former Communist courier.

Persons active in behalf of the Finch College Building Fund have taken over the performance of "The Love of Four Colonels," with Lilli Palmer and Rex Harrison in the leading roles, on the night of April 13 at the Shubert Theatre to augment the fund.

Smooth-looking Michael Clemente, the East River pier union boss who is under local indictment for extortion and under Federal indictment for filing false income tax returns, was a suave but defiant witness at yesterday's waterfront hearing by the State Crime Commission.

Your editorial of Jan. 17 on the dispute concerning custodial helpers in the public schools was an exercise in ill-temper rather than fact or reason. As in the private bus strike you betray an editorial anxiety to involve and embarrass the city administration into a position hardly in the public interest, an anxiety inexplicable except in terms of partisanship.

" Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci" received their first performances of the season last night at the Metropolitan Opera. The casts were almost entirely familiar. The only newcomer was Mario Del Monaco, singing his first Canio at the house.

The record $1,170,000,000 spent by iron and steel companies last year to expand and improve their plants resulted in the greatest yearly increase to date in combined annual steel capacity. Rising nearly 9,000,000 net tons, the 117,500,000 tons of ingots and steel for castings established a new high level, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

BOSTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- A New York advertising executive said today hundreds of millions of dollars are wasted needlessly each year in the faulty introduction, promotion and establishment of new products.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 21 (AP) -- Mrs. Wallace Gilroy's Emardee, a 10-to-1 shot, soundly whipped a dozen other promising 3-year-old fillies, including Sweet Patootie, the champion juvenile filly of last year, in the $15,000 added Jasmine Stakes at Hialeah today.

Rain failed to dampen the motoring public's interest yesterday in the General Motors Motorama of 1953 at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The estimated attendance of 40,000 was 2,000 more than on Tuesday. Buying continued brisk, and estimated orders totaled $100,000, bringing the aggregate since the opening on Saturday to $600,000.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 21 -- Greater production from existing plants through modernized facilities is the nation's answer to inflation, Tell Berna, general manager of the National Machine Tool Builders Association, said tonight. Mr. Berna, a Clevelander, spoke at the annual dinner of the Plant Maintenance Show in Public Hall.
Your editorial comes to a well-reasoned and justified conclusion which I believe may be buttressed by the following:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The new Federal Security Administrator, Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby, a Democrat, speaking today before a gala Republican luncheon of 1,350 women, appealed for a continuation of the Eisenhower crusade and warned against "junking all at once the policies of the past."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Kid Gavilan, welterweight champion from Havana, pounded out a unanimous ten-round decision tonight over game but outclassed Vic Cardell of Hartford, Conn. Gavilan weighed 152 pounds for the non-title bout; Cardell 149.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 21 -- The United Nations has dismissed Miss Ruth Elizabeth Crawford, the only American member of the organization's staff who said she had been a member of the Communist party and still was at least partly sympathetic to it.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Senate investigators learned today that the engine of the train that plowed into Washington's Union Station last Thursday, injuring fifty persons, had been thrown into reverse and braked.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Vic Seixas of Philadelphia and three Australians gained the semi-finals of the South Australian tennis championships today but the newly crowned Australian champion, Ken Rosewall, failed to make the grade.

Jerome Herman (Dizzy) Dean, who long ago won his place in baseball's Hall of Fame, got official recognition yesterday when 209 of 264 voting members of the Baseball Writers Association of America cast their ballots to install Ol' Diz' in the Cooperstown, N. Y., shrine.

A $2,685,000 damage suit was filed yesterday in Federal Court against American Airlines, Inc., by Mrs. Margaret W. Patterson as the result of the death of her husband, Robert P. Patterson, former Secretary of War, in an air crash a year ago.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 21 (UP) -- Jack Kramer moved to within one match of tying his pro tennis series with Frank Sedgman tonight as he defeated the Australian, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 4, at the Cincinnati Gardens before 4,975 fans.

Forty-seven local housing authorities in forty-three states borrowed $127,215,000 yesterday on bonds backed by Public Housing Administration assistance contracts at an average interest cost of 2.396 per cent. This compares with an average cost of 2.544 per cent incurred by seventy-nine authorities last September in borrowing $170,719,000 on bonds maturing over a term of ten years or longer.

New York City's goal in the annual Red Cross appeal for funds, which will begin March 1, will be $7,000,000. This is 23 per cent higher then the amount raised here last year, and approximately 7.5 per cent of the national goal of $93,000,000.

The following excerpts are from testimony given yesterday at the State Crime Commission hearings into waterfront conditions. They deal mainly with the operations of gangsters who controlled the important Hudson River trans-Atlantic docks.

When a change in the rediscount rate of the Reserve banks is introduced the sequel is usually a lively discussion of its significance as a reflection of how the banking authorities feel about the immediate state of the money market. Last week the rate was increased from 1 3/4 to 2 per cent by most of the nation's regional Reserve banks, and there was the usual conjecture in the financial community as to its significance.

The West Side waterfront was described yesterday before the State Crime Commission as a principality of larceny, racketeering and murder ruled by the Mickey Bowers gang, which seized control of the longshore union's "Pistol Local" without election.

Camembert usually is thought of as a French cheese as it originated in a village of that name in the Orne department. It also is made with success in the adjoining department of Calvados and in other parts of Normandy. But the Maison Glass, 15 East Forty-seventh Street, has just announced the first arrival of camembert from Germany.

Six men seized Tuesday morning as they attempted to rob the Croydon Hotel, 12 East Eighty-sixth Street, were held without bail yesterday in Felony Court after Magistrate Thomas H. Cullen Jr. was informed that a grand jury already was receiving evidence in the case.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Now that the great. Inaugural jubilee is over, making tangible by its size and enthusiasm how determined was the large majority of the voters last November that there should be a "change" in officialdom at Washington, it is a reportorial duty to record these things:

Banking syndicates will offer to investors today new issues of public utility securities amounting to $44,000,000. Consisting of mortgage bonds and preferred stocks, the financing transactions will yield the issuing companies funds to be used largely to finance expansion and to retire bank debt.

A one-story taxpayer containing four stores at 870-92 Franklin Avenue in Garden City, L. I., has been sold by the R. C. B. Properties Company to the Ess Jay Realty Company, of which David Filderman is president. L. V. Hoffman Co. and Murray Adler were the brokers.

A three-man committee will approve the final list of privately owned businesses in Manhattan that will be solicited personally by representatives of the Greater New York Fund in its 1953 campaign to raise gifts for 423 philanthropic agencies, Earl B. Schwulst, fund president, said last night.

American Relief for Korea has recently dispatched a large shipment of an anti-tuberculosis drug that was generously given by the Charles Pfizer pharmaceutical firm in Brooklyn. This is the type of help that can be of enormous value in morale building. It has an immediate impact because it meets an obvious and immediate need.

The annual local winter furniture market opened Monday in the New York Furniture Exchange and outside showrooms of manufacturers with a rush of orders. It continued to be highly successful Tuesday, in line with expectations of both store executives and manufacturers' representatives.
INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Jan. 21 -- Harry S. Truman and his wife returned tonight to Independence amid the most tumultuous reception by fellow-townsmen they have ever experienced.

Efforts to gain repeal of the 20 per cent Federal retail excise tax on leather goods, handbags toiletries, jewelry and furs will be strongly pushed during the new session of Congress, spokesmen for the affected businesses declared yesterday.

If the New York Legislature agrees, as we believe it must, that justice delayed is in many cases justice denied, then there will surely be no doubt of necessary second endorsement of a constitutional amendment to permit temporary transfer of judges in New York City and thus cut down the intolerable backlog of business that chiefly afflicts the Supreme Court. County, General Sessions, Special Sessions, city and municipal courts could be affected.
ALBANY, Jan. 21 (UP) -- The State Commerce Department today reported the following winter sports conditions:

In the fourth annual Children's Dental Health Week, from Feb. 2 to 6, local affiliated societies of the American Dental Association will present a special educational program including a children's dental health exposition, held in cooperation with the city's Civil Defense Commission at the letter's headquarters, 500 Park Avenue, at Fifty-ninth Street.

ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- Assemblyman Lee B. Mailler, Republican of Orange, Majority Leader of the Legislature's lower house, said tonight that he favored elimination of all rent controls outside of New York City.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 21 -- The Director General of the Iranian National Police, Brigadier Aziz Kamal, was dismissed today by Premier Mohammed Mossadegh, apparently because he was too friendly with Ayatollah Sayed Abolghassem Kashani, Nationalist religious leader who lately has been in open disagreement with the Premier.

The Monsanto Chemical Company and its consolidated subsidiaries had a net income last year of $23,189,243 after all deductions, against $23,477,884, second largest earnings, made in 1951, the preliminary report revealed yesterday.

The striking bus workers are seeking a forty-hour week with no cut in the pay they used to get for working forty-four to forty-eight hours, with five to nine hours of guaranteed overtime. The old basic wage ranged from $1.66 to $1.73 1/2 an hour. This would go up to $2.17 to $2.30 1/2 under the union's program.
Prof. Albert Einstein was among prominent persons who condemned yesterday the anti-Semitic moves behind the Iron Curtain.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Jan. 21 -- Staff privileges for seven physicians at St. Francis Hospital here, who were ordered a year ago to sever connections with the Dutchess County League for Planned Parenthood or resign from the hospital staff, have been renewed for the current year.
Department stores, to regain their outstanding position in the field of distribution, must put on a "better show" and will have to become "better department stores, not better supermarkets."
LONDON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- The outlook is good for world trade in wool during 1953, according to the International Wool Secretariat here.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 21 -- The United Nations Commission on the Legal Status of Women, meeting here in March, will discuss plans to remove discriminations against women in such matters as family law and property rights. These were among a number of topics suggested today for the commission by Secretary General Trygve Lie. Mr. Lie's suggestions were based on replies to a questionnaire sent to eight intergovernmental and non-governmental organizations in thirty countries.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 21 (UP) -- Robin Roberts, the husky young right-hander with the most victories in baseball last year, signed a 1953 contract with the Phillies today.

ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- Governor Dewey's proposal to increase drivers' license fees from 50 cents to $1 a year to finance expansion of New York's highway safety program received widely varying reactions today from two major organizations of motorists in the state.

TOKYO, Thursday, Jan. 22 -- The Communist radio in Peiping reported today that Red Chinese fighter planes had shot down a United States B-29 reconnaissance plane over Manchuria the night of Jan. 12. Peiping charged that the alleged flight marked "aggression" by the United States.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Jan. 14:

Private placement of $15,000,000 of 3 1/4 per cent debentures, due on Sept. 1, 1977, has been made by the Hartford Electric Light Company, it was announced yesterday. Arrangements were made by Putnam Co. Proceeds will be used in part to pay temporary borrowings of about $3,000,000 and the remainder will be used to finance construction.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 21 -- Army put on a freeze act during the final three minutes as it shaded Amherst College, 55 -- 53, for its seventh basketball victory of the season today at the field house.

Elimination of gangsters and racketeers from the waterfront is a job that can best be done by the unions themselves and that cannot be accomplished by "so-called crime investigations" or by legislation, in the opinion of Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, C. I. O.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- In a decision charging discriminatory price practices in the sale of gasoline, the Federal Trade Commission today renewed its twelve-year controversy with the Standard Oil Company of Indiana.
WASHINGTON., Jan. 21 (AP) -- Announced United States battle casualties in Korea reached 128,971 today, an increase of 250 since last week.
Business men and savings bankers in particular should fight retrictive practices in the building industry, Allan Sproul, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, said yesterday.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Jan. 21 -- The new Administration was called upon to maintain a favorable climate for small business by management and labor leaders attending the annual meeting of the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board.

Vina Delmar's "Mid-Summer," which opened at the Vanderbilt last evening, is an interesting play that seems always on the verge of distinction. Set in a squalid hotel room in New York in 1907, it is the story of two penniless young married people who are of two minds about the future.

For the first time on a national scale, blind persons will be welcomed into civil defense work with the Air Force Ground Observer Corps. This was made known yesterday by M. Robert Barnett, executive director of the American Foundation for the Blind.
New Mrs. Felix Wakely knows how Mickey Mouse must feel when he gets caught in the electric mixer, and if anybody thinks that is funny -- well, it all depends upon who is being churned up.

Earnings of the Institutional Securities Corporation last year amounted to $222,743, or $2.23 a share, against $203,690, or $2.04 a share in 1951, Robert E. Pratt, president, told the annual stockholders' meeting yesterday. The corporation, wholly owned by the savings banks of this state, is engaged primarily in the fields of mortgage investment and servicing.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The new Administration of President Dwight D. Eisenhower officially began the work of guiding the nation today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- President Eisenhower not only will continue the time-honored custom of regular White House news conferences but will enlarge the scope of the meetings between the President and the press. That was the word today from James C. Hagerty, White House press secretary.

After nearly a week's deliberation a jury in Federal Judge Dimock's court has returned a verdict of guilty in the case of the thirteen Communist leaders -- the party's second-stringers, as they were perhaps not too accurately called -- who have been on trial for nine and a half months for violation of the Smith Act.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Jan. 21 -- One of the few forces uniting the politically divided white population of South Africa today is a very real fear of being submerged by the Union's majority population of nonwhites.

Applications for new or expanded parking garages in midtown Manhattan and on Third Avenue, drew heavy fire yesterday from garage associations, property owners, and some miscellaneous business groups at a public hearing before the City Planning Commision at City Hall.

Keyed to the theme "Modern Living," a campaign involving several millions of dollars will be conducted this year by E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., Wilmington, Del., on its five man-made fibers. The theme reflects the changes in the patterns of living affecting almost every American industry, says E. F.

The Federation of Jewish Women's Organizations, the coordinating body of 450 Jewish groups representing a combined membership of 200,000 women, presented citations yesterday to five women for distinguished services in their fields and in recognition of their activities on behalf of human welfare.
CHICAGO, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock market here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
CHICAGO, Jan. 21 (AP) -- A battle over a proposal to merge Webster-Chicago Corporation with Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation loomed today.

LONDON, Jan. 21 -- The trial of five Roman Catholic priests and two laymen on charges of espionage and black market activities began today before the Cracow District Military Tribunal in Poland, the Warsaw radio reported.
PARIS, Jan. 21 -- While seeking a balanced budget and stable prices, the new French Government of Rene Mayer is nevertheless obliged to begin by borrowing from the Bank of France.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- One of the major problems confronting Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, is what to do about butter. Whatever he does about it is almost certain to have repercussions in Congress and throughout the Farm Belt that might affect the political fortunes of the Eisenhower Administration.

An increase last week of 2,603,000 barrels in the Nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, supplies were 143,344,000 barrels, compared with 140,741,000 a week earlier and 140,941,000 a year ago.

BUFFALO, Jan. 21 -- The Marine Trust Company yesterday reported the election of Paul A. Schoellkopf Jr. as a director. He is the son of the late Paul A. Schoellkopf, who was a director of the Marine Midland Corporation and former president of the old Niagara Hudson Power Corporation.

LONDON, Jan. 21 -- In a farewell speech stressing "the strength of Anglo-American unity," the retiring United States Ambassador. Walter S. Gifford, said tonight that nothing could please the Kremlin more than the "signs of self-satisfaction or relaxation slowly permeating the combined efforts" of the North Atlantic Treaty powers.
ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- The Court of Appeals paved the way today for a United States Supreme Court test of the New York City local law requiring policemen to give thirty days notice before retiring.

Two six-story apartment houses at 52-54 Park Avenue, adjoining the northwest corner of Thirty-seventh Street, have been purchased by the Carlton Construction Corporation from Shampan Shampan, architects. Schlesinger Krinsky were the attorneys for the buyer.

Donald White, baritone, sang his first recital at Town Hall last evening. A native of New Bedford. Mass., Mr. White studied at Boston University, the Longy School and the Juilliard School. He has sung with Boris Goldovsky's New England Opera Theatre and in opera performances staged here by Leopold Sachse.
ABOARD TRUMAN TRAIN, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Harry S. Truman, just another sentimental Missourian going home, had the time of his life today making the most of his freedom from the burdens of the Presidency.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The Soviet Ambassador, George N. Zarubin, refused today to see a delegation protesting his Government's behavior toward Jews in Communist-ruled countries.

THE increased and still increasing interest in varmint shooting and bench rest shooting has greatly swelled the ranks of hand-loaders, many having been forced into this activity by economic necessity, combined with a desire to experiment themselves in finding the best bullet and load for the job.

Lanny Budd, Upton Sinclair's famous hero, will make his eleventh appearance in May for Viking Press when it publishes "The Return of Lanny Budd." The story follows the protagonist from his retirement through his adventures searching out a post-war ring of Nazi counterfeiters and Russian espionage agents.

Would it not be possible to arrive at a solution which would enable Mr. Wilson to keep the stock (since he does not seem to wish to dispose of it because of the taxes involved) but retain no financial interest in these holdings so long as he remains in Government service?

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission disclosed today that a petition had come from the Post Office Department for a new increase in parcel post rates averaging close to 35 per cent.
Harry Gross' plea for a reduction of his twelve-year prison sentences for bookmaking was bitterly and successfully opposed yesterday by Kings County District Attorney Miles F. McDonald.

LONDON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Western Europe gave a warm welcome to President Eisenhower today and hailed his Inaugural speech as proof of continued American cooperation. There were signs, too, that Western Europe would pledge its support to President Eisenhower's anti-Communist policy just as it cooperated with outgoing President Truman.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Jan. 21 -- The sole answer for the driver who disregards the safety of others and himself is the "big club of enforcement" that is in prospect in New York State, Motor Vehicle Commissioner James R. Macduff said here today.

The directors of The Freeman, a fortnightly journal of conservative opinion, announced yesterday that Henry Hazlitt had been elected editor. All of the directors present at the board's meeting on Monday, with the exception of Alfred Kohlberg, were re-elected.

IT was highly embarrassing. The American team was galloping madly for a goal. Little Pete Bostwick had ridden in front of the goal mouth and was trying to maneuver away from Enrique Alberdi, the Argentine defender. Thundering downfield to set up the score was Clarence (Buddy) Combs. The powerfully built veterinarian had measured the entire situation exactly with his eyes.

The speedy confirmation yesterday of eight members of President Eisenhower's Cabinet indicates that the Senate has no desire to thwart the Chief Executive merely for the sake of doing so. In fact, these appointments would doubtless have been ratified on the very day of the Inauguration, as the President desired, had it not been for the single objecting voice of Senator Morse.

The Schola Cantorum of New York will be the beneficiary of the performance of "The Love of Four Colonels," with Lilli Palmer and Rex Harrison in the leading roles, on the night of Feb. 25 at the Shubert Theatre. Mrs. Reginald Fincke is chairman and Mrs. Ralph J. Hines, co-chairman of the benefit committee.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 21 -- Standing in the shadows, watching the present struggle between the rival leaders of the Iranian nationalist movement, there is a sinister and enigmatic force, Iran's Tudeh (Communist) party. Everybody wonders what role it will play in the political situation now developing.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- The Immigration Service said today that there was nothing in the McCarran-Walter Immigration Act that would disrupt international sports by burdening visiting teams with unreasonable entry expense.

MADRID, Jan. 21 -- Joaquin Ruiz Jimenez, Minister of Education, urged Spain's wealthier classes today to help the Government in making available to all Spanish children elementary and secondary education.
Young misses and petite women could both find a complete trousseau in the Bonwit Teller collection of junior-size dresses shown yesterday at a luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

CLIFFSIDE PARK, N. J., Jan. 22 -- Police Chief Frank Borrell denied emphatically tonight that he had ever known Francis Smith, convicted gunman and hijacker, who testified today before the New York State Crime Commission that he and other criminals had been sheltered by the police official in 1935.

Three hundred and fifty business, governmental and educational leaders attended a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night, paying tribute to Marion B. Folsom, Under Secretary of the Treasury-designate with special duties in tax policies.
TOKYO, Friday, Jan. 23 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,503, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Friday, Korean time:

A blockfront parcel containing 53,000 square feet of land on Hunters Point Avenue, between Thirty-second Place and Thirty-fourth Street, in Long Island City, Queens, has been sold by the Degnon Realty Terminal Improvement Company to the Interboro Realty Company, headed by Lawrence and Richard Zirinsky.
CHICAGO, Jan. 22 -- Abraham Teitelbaum, a lawyer and real estate operator here, was indicted by a Federal grand jury today on charges of evading $135,060 in taxes on his 1946-47 income.
The second annual "Friends Fund" campaign or the Philharmonic-Symphony Society so far has raised two thirds of its desired $150,000, Floyd G. Blair, president of the society, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday were 705,479 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 17,247 cars, or 2.5 per cent more than for the preceding week, 42,181 cars, or 5.6 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 74,271 cars, or 9.5 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

Events today: Philharmonic-Symphony, Vladimir Golschmann conducting, Edmund Kurtz, cellist, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P. M.; "Aida," Metropolitan Opera, 1; "Cosi fan tutte," Metropolitan Opera, 8:15; Gina Bachauer, pianist, Town Hall, 8:30; Paul Loyonnet, pianist, Greenwich House Music School, 8:30.

On record sales of $176,034,005, Food Fair Stores, Inc., had a net income of $2,732,589 in the thirty-two weeks ended last Dec. 6, according to figures filed in a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering the issuance of $12,500,000 of debentures due Feb. 1, 1973.

Vladimir Golschmann, musical director of the St. Louis Symphony, has given up his winter vacation to help out the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in the absence of its ailing conductor, Dimitri Mitropoulous, and last night at Carnegie Hall he began a fortnight of guest conducting here.

Beefsteak eaters can rejoice; prices are at their lowest levels in more than two years. This welcome bulletin, issued by the city's Department of Markets yesterday, also listed cheaper prices for several utility cuts of beef as well as for loin lamb chops.

A thousand patients in Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center took a special tonic last night, and later called it good medicine. The new prescription was a piano-violin recital by two talented sisters that was piped into bedside headsets through a hospital broadcasting system.

The valuable experiences with popular government, gained by the United States and the Netherlands in the last three centuries, have enabled these nations to acquire "a capacity toward peaceful evolution which no other form of government has been able to produce," Dr. Herman J. Friedericy, attache to the Netherlands Embassy in Washington, said yesterday.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 22 -- Atom-smashing machines of 100,000,000,000 - volt - energy -- more than thirty times the energy of the best in that line now -- may be possible because of a recent discovery, two atomic scientists said today.

The snag in the nomination of ex-Governor Peterson as Ambassador to India gives President Eisenhower a splendid opportunity for furthering two excellent objectives of the new Administration: Government economy and strengthening of the free world.
The text of General Sessions Judge Francis L. Valente's ruling on the contempt motion against Jerry Finkelstein follows:

Hats are off to the millinery division of the Fashion Group for the excellent choice of hats it put on the heads of the models at yesterday's luncheon meeting held in the ballroom of the Astor Hotel. Not only were the hats good, they were shown with good taste in combination with suits, coats and dresses.

As a member of the American Civil Liberties Union's board of directors I was part of that overwhelming majority by which it voted to take no action in the Rosenberg case. We felt that the trial had been fair. And that no civil liberties issues were involved in the death sentence.
The cotton futures market opened with gains of 3 to 9 points yesterday, and closed barely steady 15 to 35 points lower than on Wednesday as trading on the New York Cotton Exchange quieted.
CAIRO, Jan. 22 -- The Egyptian Government made known today details of the plot announced last Friday against the regime of Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib, the Premier.

Students of manners may lightly refer to this period in another fifty years as the Age of the Buffet Supper. It remains, next to the cocktail party, the favorite means of entertaining, at least on the part of the women. Men show small enthusiasm over what they call balancing a plate on one knee, but in any protests they are defeated before they start.

A Federal rackets grand jury investigating waterfront crimes indicted two former operating managers of two Bethlehem Steel Company subsidiaries yesterday on charges of evading Federal income taxes and conspiracy to violate the Internal Revenue Laws.

LONDON, Jan. 22 -- Recent criticism by a visiting American "productivity team" that Britain's textile industry suffered from management inertia was challenged today by Sir John Grey, head of the largest cotton spinning combine in the world.

TOKYO, Friday, Jan. 23 (AP) -- The Peiping radio charged today that Japan had fanned war fever under orders from the United States. The Chinese Communist radio struck back at Japan's recent warning to the Soviet Union against violations of Japanese air by Soviet planes.

Advertisers are losing many of the benefits they should be getting from advances made in technical research because of loose notions about the reliability of media studies, according to W. R. Simmons, head of the research organization bearing his name.
Stockholders of the Seaboard Finance Company, at a special meeting yesterday in Los Angeles, voted to increase the number of authorized preferred shares from 400,000 to 500,000.

The Board of Education has decided that the fourth stanza of "America" might properly and effectively form a portion of an opening "devotional exercise" for the city's public schools and has ordered that it be so used.
Democratic enrollment in New York City, exceeds that of the Republicans by more than two to one, according to figures made public yesterday by the Board of Elections.
SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Jan. 22 (AP) -- Undefeated Seton Hall went over the 100 mark for the first time this season in a wild 103-85 victory over Memphis State tonight.

Registering their third decline in four weeks, loans to business by New York banks dropped $29,000,000 last week to bring the total reduction in the period to $110,000,000, against $6,000,000 a year ago.

THE islands of the Indian Ocean, so little known to literature as compared with those of the Pacific, have been breaking into the news and into books recently. The sultan of the Maldive Islands has become the president of a republic and that 300,000,000-year-old fish, the coelacanth, was caught near Madagascar. Last summer F. D. Ommanney's excellent book about Mauritius and the Seychelles, "The Shoals of Capricorn," was published.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 22 -- There is an odd view held in some of the highest quarters in Teheran that there are two Communist parties in Iran -- one Russian, one British. Some insist that the British, although their Embassy in Teheran has been closed, still send money to the Iranian Communists.

JERSEY CITY, Jan. 22 -- A panel of 117 prospective jurors who were being screened for service on a special grand jury to investigate waterfront crime and racketeering was dismissed today by Superior Court Judge Haydn Proctor after Deputy Attorney General Benjamin Van Tine had charged that a large percentage of these on the jury list were "closely connected with the political affairs of the community."
The performance of "Der Rosenkavalier" last night in the Metropolitan, the first of the season, has the distinction of being the worst performance of this opera that the writer has experienced.

When you start to cross the street with a green light nowadays you have a surprisingly good chance of landing on the other side all in one piece. When you go out for a stroll the air seems oddly fresh and clean. When you settle down for a night's rest there is a strange and uneasy silence: clashing gears, roaring motors and angry toots are, if not exactly absent, at least rarer than they were.

Earnings of The Marine Midland Trust Company of New Yofk in 1952 were the largest in the bank's history, amounting to $2,146,826 against $1,918,321 in the previous year, according to the annual report of the bank's president, James G. Blaine.

Prominent rabbis and civic, educational and philanthropic leaders paid tribute last night to the Jewish Education Committee of New York at a dinner at the Commodore Hotel. The dinner was given for the benefit of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York, of which the committee is a member agency.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Vic Seixas of Philadelphia, captain of the United States Davis Cup team, and Straight Clark of Los Angeles were eliminated by an Australian tandem today in the men's doubles semi-finals in the South Australian tennis championships.

ALBANY, Jan. 22 -- State Senator Thomas C. Desmond said today that the "amazing drop" in syphilis cases upstate had led him to consider introduction of a bill repealing the premarital examination law.

Frank Rounds Jr., who recently returned from an eighteen-month tour of duty at the American Embassy in Moscow, has written an account of what he saw and heard in the Soviet capital. Scheduled for April publication by Houghton Mifflin, "18 Months Inside Russia" presents his version of how Russia "looks and sounds and feels and smells," what its people are eating and wearing and how they work and divert themselves.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Allen W. Dulles of New York was reported today to be definitely slated for appointment by President Eisenhower as Director of the Central Intelligence Agency, thus putting in the hands of two brothers the direction of open and secret foreign policy designed to win the "cold war" against communism.

The city administration was described last night by Harold Riegelman, counsel to the Citizens Budget Commission, as being "bankrupt in leadership" and as having "wholly failed" every test of character, caliber and capacity for municipal management.

ROME, Jan. 22 -- An attack of influenza obliged Pope Pius XII to remain in bed today and to suspend all public and private audiences until further notice. He insisted, however, on receiving his two prosecretaries of state, Msgrs. Domenico Tardini and Giovanni Battista Montini, who are his most intimate collaborators.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Members of the Senate Commerce Committee split openly today, as hearings ended, over what had caused a sixteen-car train to crash into Washington's Union Station last week, injuring fifty persons.

ALBANY, Jan. 22 -- Senator Francis J. Mahoney of Manhattan and Assemblyman Eugene F. Bannigan of Brooklyn, Democratic leaders of the Legislature, announced today that they would press for restoration of the full 5 per cent New York City tax on pari-mutuel betting at tracks within the city limits.

LONDON, Jan. 22 -- Oliver Messel, famous for his stage decors and paintings, was persuaded recently to design a collection of coronation year fabrics for the West Cumberland Silk Mills. The result was seen yesterday at an exhibition opened by Lady Clark, president of the Incorporated Society of London Fashion Designers.

SINGAPORE, Jan. 22 -- An academic dispute that had been brewing the past week boiled up today with an announcement by Malaya's largest Chinese language newspaper, Nanyang Siang Pau, that it would give 1,000,000 Straits dollars (about $330,000) toward the establishment of a Chinese University in Malaya.

British Overseas Airways Corporation announced yesterday afternoon that it had grounded its entire fleet of ten double-deck, four-engine Boeing Stratocruisers used in trans-Atlantic service because of an unspecified engine defect.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Reports filed by General Motors Corporation and Charles E. Wilson with the Securities and Exchange Commission showed that as of last Dec. 31 he owned the equivalent of 39,045 shares of General Motors common stock.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Jan. 22 -- The Westchester Recreation Commission presented a concert of familiar music by the Boston Pops Orchestra in the county center tonight. It was the third concert by the orchestra since beginning on Tuesday its first tour away from Boston.

Now comes word that members of the Montreal Curb Market are to meet on Feb. 2 to consider a proposal to change its name to Canadian Stock Exchange. Names are tending to grow longer. The New York Curb Exchange, which could be abbreviated merely to "Curb" or "N. Y. Curb," recently became the American Stock Exchange, which cannot be abbreviated.
General Sessions Judge Francis L. Valente denied yesterday a motion to cite for contempt Jerry Finkelstein, who served as campaign manager when former Mayor William O'Dwyer was re-elected in 1949.

Richmond Borough President Cornelius A. Hall, who has been seriously ill since Nov. 17, has asked to be retired on pension. The office of the New York City Employes Retirement System confirmed yesterday a report that Mr. Hall had filed his retirement papers, but declined to name either the filing or effective dates.

KINGS PARK, L. I., Jan. 22 -- Two of seventeen young male patients who broke out of the State Mental Hospital here shortly after last midnight were still at large tonight, and it was believed they had fled toward New York City. A riot in the dormitory preceded the break.

Negotiations for a new labor contract in the tugboat industry may be expected to gather momentum next week as a result of a strike authorization vote predicted for union membership meetings to be held Sunday afternoon.

Admiral Corporation is prepared to turn out more than $225,000,000,000 worth of television receivers, home appliances and other consumer products this year exclusive of defense and export production. Ross D. Siragusa, president, said that in 1950, the company's previous record year, dollar volume was $230,000,000 for civilian and defense sales combined.

The Girl Scout movement in New York has a waiting list of 9,000 children, Mrs. Howard Phipps, president of the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York, reported yesterday at the council's annual meeting and luncheon in the McAlpin Hotel.

PARIS, Jan. 22 -- The new Government of Rene Mayer passed its first hurdles in the National Assembly today when it was, in effect, approved by a vote of 393 to 210 and received the authority it had asked for additional borrowing from the Bank of France.

The following excepts are from the testimony given yesterday by Francis Smith, a gangster, at the State Crime Commission hearings into waterfront conditions. They tell of murders, robberies and other criminal activities of longshoremen who operated along the waterfront in the area used by most of the major passenger liners.

With frequent regularity editorials appear in your newspaper urging an increased fare and emphasizing that the transit system should be operated on a businesslike basis. As far as can be discerned, the fare-paying public has paid little heed to this, for an obvious reason.

The major obstacles to settlement of the bus strike through Mayor Impellitteri's arbitration plan were eliminated yesterday, virtually assuring resumption of service by Sunday morning on lines that normally carry 3,500,000 daily riders. There was even a possibilty that the first buses might roll before midnight tomorrow.
MINEOLA, L. I. Jan. 22 -- A panel discussion was held here yesterday on freezer-frozen food plans with Mary Wood, New York City extension food marketing specialist, as moderator.

PARIS, Jan. 22 -- A centuries-old tradition of the French Academy, by which a new member eulogizes his predecessor, forced Andre Francois-Poncet, French High Commissioner in West Germany and prewar ambassador to Berlin, to use all his diplomacy today.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 22 -- Failure by some judges and lawyers to adhere to canons of judicial and legal ethics has helped bring the legal profession into disrepute with "a large minority" of the public, a report of the American Bar Association said today.

Antonio F. Vigorito, 35-year-old former plainclothes man, was found guilty early today of perjury in the first degree. He was tried before Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz and an all-male blue ribbon jury in Kings County Court. The trial began on Monday.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Jan. 22 -- In the minds of the United party opposition there will be only one overriding issue when South Africa holds its national elections this spring -- whether the Union will remain a democratic state or, under stern Afrikander domination, gradually establish an authoritarian government.
ATMORE, Ala., Jan. 22 -- A nation sprang from the pages of history tonight to demand $29,000,000 from the United States Government.

LONDON, Friday, Jan. 23 (UP) -- Soviet industry as a whole topped by 1 per cent the production targets set for 1952, the Moscow radio said today. The gain of 1952 on its goals was put at 0.6 per cent.

The Federal Home Loan Bank of New York had a year of record-high business in 1952, chalking up net income of $1,407,233 on central banking operations and services for 416 savings and loan associations and three savings banks having total assets of $2,783,454,362.

The Joint Distribution Committee, a target of attack by the Communist leaders of the Soviet Union and the satellite states, announced yesterday the discontinuance of its relief activities among 130,000 Jewish persons in Hungary.

Six automobiles, ranging in vintage from a 1937 Packard convertible to a 1948 Oldsmobile convertible, were converted into a quick profit for Uncle Sam yesterday at a periodic auction of unclaimed and seized merchandise held by the United States Customs Service at 201 Varick Street.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- The Petroleum Administration for Defense today set aside 2,828 tons of steel, plus some copper and aluminum, for use in building a new oil refinery at Tacoma, Wash.
