The city's housing shortage and overcrowded schools are caused by the lack of a long-range program for expansion and growth and not by any influx of population, a Puerto Rican Government official declared here yesterday.

William Spivey, former All-American basketball player, at the university of Kentucky who is on trial for perjury, took the stand yesterday in General Sessions to deny that he had ever participated in fixing basketball games or shaving points while a member of the team.

WELL, sir, you coulda knocked me over with a steam-roller when the balloting was announced for election to the Hall of Fame. The shock was not so much that Dizzy Dean and Al Simmons achieved their deserved places among the immortals but that Joe DiMaggio should get such a rude back-of-me-hand-to-you dismissal.

One hundred liberal leaders -- Democrats now in opposition for the first time in twenty years, Republicans confronted with the responsibilities of power, Liberals accustomed to lead and to oppose regardless of the party in power and independents inclined to opposing the party in power -- took counsel on their future political course yesterday.
VIENNA, Jan. 22 (AP) -- United States authorities in Vienna have turned over to the British an English woman detained for questioning in connection with the Soviet spy ring in Washington and Vienna.

SEOUL, Korea, Jan. 22 -- J. Donald Kingsley, Agent General of the United Nations Korean Reconstruction Agency, acknowledged this afternoon at a press conference that he did not believe his organization was going to stabilize Korean economy.

Mickey Bowers, gangster chief of the upper West Side piers, and two partners got a rich monopoly in the public loading concession on those docks in 1945 as the gift of the second highest officer of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., it was testified yesterday at the public hearing of the State Crime Commission into waterfront rackets.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 22 -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh, who found himself in conflict this week with one of his chief associates in the Iranian National Front, appealed to the Iranian people tonight "to maintain unity and harmony so that we may achieve our goal."

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Jan. 22 -- The 39-year-old Duke of Roxburghe took legal action today in Jedburgh Sheriff's Court on the Scottish border to evict his 37-year-old Duchess from the ancestral home, Floors Castle, Kelso, one of Britain's show places.

UNION CITY, N. J., Jan. 22 -- Harry S. Truman did more for music in Washington than any previous President. That is the opinion of Paul Hume, music critic for The Washington Post to whom Mr. Truman had sent a bitter personal letter for criticizing his daughter Margaret's singing.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Jan. 22 -- A resolution protesting the persecution of Protestants in Colombia and calling the situation to the attention of the United Nations and the State Department, was passed today by the Board of Missions of the Methodist Church at its annual meeting here.

VIENNA, Friday, Jan. 23 -- The Czechoslovak Government yesterday notified the French Embassy in Prague to withdraw immediately its military attache, Colonel Gastaldo, and two assistant commercial attaches named Moulin and Gaillard.

MINEOLA, L. I., Jan. 22 -- Nassau County was subjected to a simulated air attack by an enemy using conventional bombs, submarine shelling of coastal areas and sabotage explosions here tonight as the preparedness of sixty-nine Civil Defense units in the county organization was put to test.

This winter has proved that given snow, and lots of it, skiers will flock in record numbers to popular areas. This week-end should find the city enthusiasts turning out strongly in the nearby Berkshires of Western Massachusetts and Catskills of New York, where good sport is reported.

GENEVA, Jan. 21 -- European governments are tremendously interested in the struggle now getting under way in the new United States administration and in the new Congress to master the gigantic problem of the Federal budget. get.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 22 -- The United Nations today released in book form a study entitled "Instability in Export Markets of Under-Developed Countries," which was prepared at the instance of the Economic and Social Council.

TOKYO, Friday, Jan. 23 -- Sabre jets of the Fifth Air Force, flying a protective screen for United Nations fighter-bombers deep over North Korea yesterday, shot down four more of the enemy's fast MIG's and damaged three. Claims of the destruction of still another of China's Soviet-designed jets and the damage of three were awaiting further evaluation.
Robert Moses, City Construction Coordinator, was honored last night by the Stevens Institute of Technology and its alumni association for his "outstanding contributions to public service."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee unanimously approved today a measure intended to speed the "clean-up" of the State Department that the Republicans pledged in the campaign.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations will insist on a job with some responsibility in the Department of Labor or it will take none at all, Walter P. Reuther, president, said today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The United States Court of Appeals ruled 5 to 4 today that Washington restaurants might legally refuse service to Negroes.

In the present bus crisis much has been said about the hardships of the striking drivers, and it is certain that they deserve a good deal of sympathy in their claim for better hours and higher remuneration in their difficult and trying work.

BERLIN, Jan. 22 -- East Germany's Christian Democratic Union announced today that there would be a thorough purge of all functionaries within the party to weed out the enemies of socialism and of the Soviet Union.

Immigration authorities picked up the passport of the Rev. John Whittier Darr Jr., 33-year-old Congregational clergyman, of 330 High Street, Middletown, Conn., when he arrived yesterday at the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, aboard a Scandinavian airliner from Copenhagen.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Under the proposed increase in parcel post rates the package that now costs $1 to mail would cost about $1.35. The proposal is before the Interstate Commerce Commission and is subject to hearings.

The ten companies in this country found to be "best managed" were listed yesterday by the American Institute of Management, a nonprofit organization. Of the ten, said Emil V. Hegyi, vice president of the institute, the Hotels Statler Company Inc., was "without doubt the best company in production efficiency."

BELLEFONTE, Pa., Jan. 22 (UP) -- Rebellious inmates at Rockview Penitentiary surrendered unconditionally tonight and released six guards held as hostages unharmed after Gov. John S. Fine had alerted National Guardsmen to end the mutiny by force. State Adjutant General Frank A. Weber announced the surrender, which ended a four-day riot at the Central Pennsylvania prison.

The twelve-story loft building occupying a plot 124 by 98 feet at 229-39 West Twenty-eighth Street, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, has been sold by the Radley 28th Street Company to Frederick Brown in a deal negotiated by Frederick Fox Co., brokers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The State Department dismissed today as "propaganda" a charge by the Chinese Communists that a United States B-29 bomber shot down by Communist fighter planes Jan. 12 had violated Manchurian territory.

The Government moved yesterday in Federal Court to denaturalize two of the thirteen secondary Communist party leaders convicted Wednesday of conspiracy to teach and advocate the violent overthrow of the Government.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22 -- Home builders of the nation were advised today to move more actively into the housing-repair market on the ground that it will offer one of the major fields of operation for their organizations in the future.

The suggestion that television periodically cover the White House press conferences of President Eisenhower is an excellent one and deserving of early adoption. Only good can come from millions of persons having a continuous intimate insight into the job of government and the problems confronting the President.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Organized baseball got assurances today of some unexpected Government help in seeing to it that foreign players on American teams did not jump their contracts.

Arthur Miller has written another powerful play. "The Crucible," it is called, and it opened at the Martin Beck last evening in an equally powerful performance. Riffling back the pages of American history, he has written the drama of the witch trials and hangings in Salem in 1692.
In effect, the Stalin regime has now declared a state of open hostility against Israel, Zionism and Jews in general. They are denounced as instruments of British and American "imperialism."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The problems of the Presidency began to come thick and fast to President Eisenhower's desk today. He accepted the resignation of a Fair Deal holdover, Michael V. DiSalle, Director of the Economic Stabilization Agency, and was looking for a successor though it was by no means certain that the price-wage controls program would be continued.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 22 (AP) -- A stockholder's suit filed in Federal District Court today named Secretary of the Treasury George M. Humphrey and fourteen officers of two coal companies.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Talk by Republican leaders as they took over the new Congress, to the effect that the emphasis would be upon legislation and a subsiding of investigations, appeared to run into contradiction today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- During the week ended yesterday member bank reserves increased $81,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- William Howard Taft 3d, son of Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, has asked Senators to back him for appointment as Ambassador to Ireland in a move that could become politically embarrassing to President Eisenhower.

Commodity futures on the New York exchanges closed irregular yesterday with volume continuing light. Potatoes were active, approaching Wednesday's record volume of the year. Cocoa, rubber, hides, tin and lead closed higher. Potatoes, coffee, cottonseed oil, soybean oil and wool were lower. Zinc and sugar ended mixed.

Arthur Lourie, Israel's Consul General in New York, lashed out at the anti-Semitic campaign in Soviet Russia and the satellite states last night, terming the "build-up" of anti-Semitism as "planned, deliberate and diabolical."
CLEVELAND, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Ownership of the multimillion-dollar Cleveland Pneumatic Tool Company passes into the hands of its two employe profit-sharing trusts next Tuesday.

The newsmen first obtained a foothold within the White House in the days of Theodore Roosevelt half a century ago. Before that they stayed away or stood outside in all sorts of weather. It would have been a shame if progress were to be reversed, as has recently been rumored, by exiling them to the old State Department Building across the street.

The discovery of a remarkable and, at the moment, inexplicable correlation between human health and comfort and the electrical charge of the atmosphere in a room was disclosed here yesterday at the annual meeting of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers at the Statler Hotel.

An 18-year-old Negro boy was stabbed under the right eye yesterday when a fist fight broke out among a group of teen-agers in the audience of a motion picture house in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn. The argument allegedly started after a white boy made a slurring remark about a Negro girl.

TOKYO, Jan. 22 (UP) -- A Japanese newspaper said today Soviet planes that have flown over Northern Japan might be studying high-altitude air currents for a potentially swift bomber route to the United States.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 22 -- Dr. James Bryant Conant, the new United States High Commissioner -- to Germany, bade farewell today to the students of Harvard University, where he has been president for almost twenty years.

The three major developments in the New York banking field last year were the expansion of resources, the continuing shift from low into higher yielding assets and the hardening of money rates, William A. Lyon, New York State Superintendent of Banks, pointed out in his annual report to the Governor and the Legislature.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 22 (UP) -- The five former titleholders came through in "championship" style today to advance into the second round of the twenty-first annual Helen Lee Doherty golf tournament on the Miami Country Club course.

The Student Councils of the Riverdale Country School for Boys and Girls sent a check for $250 yesterday to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund as part of their Christmas donations. This was one of thirty-one contributions totaling $735.29, bringing the total to date for the forty-first annual appeal to $387,142.44.
DETROIT, Jan. 22 (UP) -- Paul Ronty and Jack Stoddard scored twice each tonight as the New York Rangers routed the league-leading Detroit Red Wings, 8 to 2, before 11,229 at Olympia.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 22 -- Former President Harry S. Truman disclosed today that he had ordered Major John Eisenhower home from Korea to attend the Inauguration of his father, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, as President.

MIAMI, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Blinker Light, a 5-to-1 shot, owned by Dave Shaer, displayed a strong liking for the turf course at Hialeah Park today as he led all the way in the featured $5,000 Land o'Sun Purse, at a mile and a furlong.

The sharp criticism directed at the Impellitteri administration last night by Harold Riegelman in his address, as counsel, to the Citizens Budget Commission's annual dinner is not only justified, in our opinion, but, when taken in context of circumstances, is a measure of the low estate to which that administration has fallen in public esteem.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Charles E. Wilson agreed tonight to sell his stock in General Motors Corporation, said to be worth $2,500,000, and President Eisenhower thereupon sent to the Senate his nomination of Mr. Wilson as Secretary of Defense.

BOSTON, Jan. 22 (UP) -- Gerry Couture, scoring twice with some tricky stick-handling, set the pace for Chicago tonight as the Black Hawks came from behind to gain a 3-3 tie with Boston before 6,101, smallest hockey crowd of the season at Boston Garden.
CANNES, France, Jan. 22 (AP) -- The Aga Khan said today he had received no offer of $1,000,000 for Tulyar, unbeaten champion 3-year-old in England last year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Cross-examination of witnesses at a Federal Power Commission hearing in the long fight for the New England natural gas market droned on today with no prospect of an early end.

AT THE KOREAN FRONT, Jan. 16 -- Like excited school children gathered about a birthday party grab bag, the soldiers here crowd about the G. I. mailman when the sack of letters arrives from home. Mail call is the height of everyone's day and the man without a letter is like a puppy without a bone or a baseball fan without his peanuts.

JACKSON, Mich., Jan. 22 (AP) -- Earl Ward was convicted by a circuit court jury today of kidnaping a guard in the $1,000,000 riot at Southern Michigan Prison last April. The guard was held as a hostage.

HONG KONG, Jan. 22 -- An intensified campaign against "bureaucratism" and "paper-workism" is being unfolded in Communist China with the dual objective of making Government economic organs more efficient and accumulating larger capital surpluses for the state's industrialization program.
Color in furniture woods as well as in room settings strikes a cheerful midwinter note in Macy's semi-annual furniture show that will open on Monday.

The arrival of any new ocean liner is always a cause for rejoicing, but a special welcome must go to the gracious Italian luxury liner Andrea Doria as she sweeps up the harbor today on her maiden voyage from the Mediterranean. For the Doria symbolizes not only the rebirth of the Italian merchant marine.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Ezra Taft Benson took over his office as Secretary of Agriculture today and immediately announced a major departmental overhaul that will include the regrouping of twenty agencies and bureaus.

BERLIN, Jan. 22 -- West Berlin's Chamber of Deputies appealed today to the Bonn Government and to West German state regimes to unburden the city of its staggering load of refugees, which grows more ponderous daily.

The Illinois Central Railroad borrowed $6,000,000 in the public market yesterday on trust certificates maturing over fifteen years to help finance the purchase of 1,500 steel gondola cars costing about $8,400,000.
The Port of New York will pull out all stops today to welcome the Italian liner Andrea Doria, a luxurious 30,000-ton symbol of Italy's resurgence as a maritime power.

Smoke tunnel tests at New York University will make it possible for the Rockland Light and Power Company to increase the generating capacity of its Hudson Station at Tomkins Cove, N. Y., without increasing air pollution in the area.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Jan. 22 -- A person at the wheel of a towed motor vehicle is not a driver, because he neither actually controls the movement nor directs the course of the machine, Magistrate John L. McGuire ruled today.

Minneapolis borrowed $5,524,887 yesterday on two issues of bonds maturing serially over from twenty to twenty-five years. Both issues were bought at public sealed bidding by a syndicate headed by First Boston Corporation.

Lord Taylor gave ample proof yesterday in a showing at the store that second-floor customers could go happily South, with costumes in the height of fashion, but budget-priced. Indeed, in not one of the designs -- chic linens and cottons, coats, suits and evening fashions -- was there a hint of the modest price tage.

MONTREAL, Jan. 22 (UP) -- Scoring in every period, the Montreal Canadiens beat the Toronto Maple Leafs, 4 -- 1, before 14,426 tonight to move within a point of league-leading Detroit in the National Hockey League.

A telephone call to a lawyer here yesterday has solved in part the five-week-old mystery of what happened to a Cherry Valley, N. Y., family that had "dropped out of sight" on Dec. 21 after trimming a tree for Christmas.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, demanded today that his "associates" show "positive loyalty" to the policies of President Eisenhower and Congress but added that such loyalty did not call for "intellectual dishonesty" or distorted diplomatic reporting.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- The Office of Price Stabilization today lifted price Controls on higher priced watches and clocks and practically all hollow ware, including silver plate.

The Yankees signed their first regular yesterday when Gil McDougald accepted a contract that called for a salary estimated at $12,000. Gil was only the third of the world champions to come into the fold.

The results of the Guatemalan Congressional elections, while not yet official, give a picture which will doubtless stand. They show that of the thirty-two seats contested twenty-seven went to the Democratic Electoral Front, which contains the three Government parties and the Communists, who are now parading under the new name of the Labor party.
Daily newspaper circulation throughout the country showed a drop of a fraction of 1 per cent during 1952 despite a net increase of thirteen new daily publications.

CEDARHURST, L. I., Jan. 22 -- Miss Joan Francke Remick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Gould Remick of Cedarhurst, has completed plans for her marriage to Edward Duffy French, son of Mr. and Mrs. Seth Barton French of Hewlett, on the afternoon of Feb. 14 in Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Hewlett.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Jan. 22 (UP) -- German and Austrian skiers and bobsledders won the first three events today as a field of international stars opened a week of winter sports competition.
A form of influenza or grippe has spread across most sections of the United States and has hit areas in Mexico, Europe, Japan and Hawaii, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

The case of William W. Remington, former Commerce Department economist who is charged with having lied five times in testifying at his first perjury trial in the winter of 1950-51 will go to the jury on Monday.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 22 -- Harry Babcock, University of Georgia end from way down South in Pearl River, N. Y., today achieved the surprise distinction of being the first player named in the professional National Football League's 1953 draft of college players.
Orville A. Petty, Eastern district sales manager in New York, has been promoted to field sales manager of Schick, Inc., at the home office, Stamford, Conn.

The stock market reached one of those points yesterday wherein the technicians found a "field day" for explanations. There was nothing to distinguish the day's performance as prices see-sawed throughout.

It was a casual remark but it cost Steve Ellis, television announcer and fight manager, $1,000. Mr. Ellis had accompanied his boxer, Chico Vejar, to the office of Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh so that the 20-year-old athlete could pay $650 in traffic penalties that had been assessed last week.

ALBANY, Jan. 22 -- The Public Service Commission refused today to order the Utica Transit Corporation to reduce fares on its bus lines serving the city of Utica. It acted on the basis of a finding that the fares were just and reasonable.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Rebounding from two successive setbacks, the New York Knickerbockers trounced the Boston Celtics, 112 -- 89, in a National Basketball Association test tonight. Max Zaslofsky, back in condition after being handicapped by a hip bruise, paced the Knicks with 26 points to gain the scoring honors.

Saluting the general output of Hollywood motion pictures for playing "a leading role as ambassadors of democracy," Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, urged industry representatives, at a community relations conference held at the Hotel Gotham last evening, to participate in the "big battles against censorship ahead."

The Republic Steel Corporation, the first steel producer to announce 1952 operating results, had a consolidated net income of $44,274,053 last year on the second highest sales in its history, despite the idleness of its plants resulting from the two-month steel strike in June and July.

A gunman for the former Ackilitis waterfront gang, brought here from state's prison for the public hearing, testified yesterday before the State Crime Commission that Frank Borrell, police chief for the last thirty-two years in Cliffside Park, N. J., had helped racketeers hide out from the law.

Assurance has been given to the Japanese that United States forces will protect the integrity of the archipelago against foreign incursion. Specifically, this means that United States planes will retaliate if the Soviet Union persists in flying its aircraft over northern Hokkaido, presumably by forcing the Soviet planes down.
HANOI, Vietnam, Indo-China, Jan. 22 (AP) -- The French announced today the capture of an underground regimental command post of the Communist-led Vietminh fifty miles southeast of Hanoi.

SOME anglers wait for word that the ice is "out," so they may rush for the northern lakes, but others delay their winter trip until the wire arrives reporting that the sailfish are schooling up off Stuart. If your bag is packed, you can head for Florida right now.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Department store sales in the week ended Jan. 17 were 2 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year. This was reported today by the Federal Reserve Board, which listed the following percentage changes from like periods of 1952:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 22 -- The American Legion will actively support efforts by the Hollywood American Federation of Labor Film Council to bar from this country motion pictures made abroad by persons who have failed to clear themselves of charges of being Communists or Communist sympathizers.

ALBANY, Jan. 22 -- A plea for legislative action to construct and operate eleven educational television stations in this state was made here today by college officials attending the eastern regional convention of the American College Public Relations Association.
CHICAGO, Jan. 22 -- An early buying spurt gave cereal futures temporary firmness, but the demand quickly faded and later heavy selling caused sharp declines.

With Menasha Skulnik, Yiddish comic who is in his Broadway debut, and Richard Whorf occupying stellar roles, "The Fifth Season" will make its delayed debut at 8 o'clock tonight at the Cort. It will mark the fifth and final arrival of a busy week for first-nighters. As of the moment, there won't be another opening until "Love's Labour's Lost" comes to the City Center Feb. 4.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- A three-man board is expected to be set up soon in New York to approve pre-war German dollar bonds legitimately held in this country and to weed out any looted bonds which may have reached this country.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 22 -- The West German Government is considering a substantial reduction in income tax rates as a further incentive to private enterprise, which set up post-war production records last year.
The five Beethoven 'cello sonatas were heard at Town Hall last evening at a joint recital played by Adolph Baller, pianist, and Gabor Retjo, 'cellist.
SAPPORO, Hokkaido, Japan, Jan. 22 -- Japan's northernmost island of Hokkaido, facing Soviet territory on three sides, is being bolstered with additional Japanese and American military strength.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The 5-to-4 decision of the Federal Court of Appeals here today, that public restaurants in the District of Columbia may legally continue to refuse service to Negroes, once more illuminates the obstacles to a total ban on racial segregation that are represented by long-maintained laws and policies as well as by embedded customs.

LONDON, Jan. 22 -- The stock markets opened hesitantly today, but grew confident and closed with most groups slightly higher. Gold mining shares in particular strengthened following the statement of Lord Burleigh, chairman of Lloyds Bank, concerning the world price of gold.
OLDSMAR, Fla., Jan. 22 (UP) -- Officials at Sunshine Park staged a "Tony DeSpirito Day" today, but the guest of honor failed to pilot a winner.
NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 22 -- Maj. Gen. Julius Ochs Adler endorsed today the Vannevar Bush plan for splitting top-level planning and command duties in the armed forces.

Indefinite postponement of a departmental trial, scheduled to get under way today for four firemen charged with neglect of duty and failure to enforce department rules was announced yesterday by Fire Commissioner Jacob Grumet.

LONDON, Jan. 23 -- Only sixty persons in Britain could boast annual net incomes of more than 6,000 ($16,800) after paying their income tax last year, it was disclosed today in the annual returns of the Inland Revenue Commission for the year ended last March.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, "closed" an "episode" today that had developed from an apparent policy disagreement with George F. Kennan, Foreign Service expert on Soviet affairs.

Unless the Fire Department receives an immediate increase of 304 men and 110 officers in its uniformed force, the department cannot institute the forty-two hour week as directed by Mayor Impellitteri, Commissioner Jacob Grumet told Budget Director Abraham D. Beame yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican of Wisconsin, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, was joined by sixteen other Senators today in introducing a measure to authorize this country to join with Canada in building the St. Lawrence River Seaway.

" Aida" was presented at the Metropolitan yesterday afternoon, with Herva Nelli making her debut in the title role, Giulio Gari singing his first Metropolitan Radames, and Renato Cellini conducting the work for the first time at the house.

MIAMI, Jan. 23 (UP) -- Sunny Dale, a stretch-running mare from the Buddah Stable, headed a parade of long-shot winners at Hialeah today by galloping to a seven-length victory in the featured Crandon Park Purse.
John P. Nicholson Gallery, paintings, in 18 E 57th St, moving from 69 E 57th St -- James F. Durnell Co, broker.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 23 -- Shareholders of the Cleveland Trust Company have approved the reduction in par value of stock from $100 to $50 a share and the issu ance of two shares of new stock for each of the old shares, it was announced today.

Marked interest was shown in retail circles here in the announcement yesterday by Scruggs-Vandervoort-Barney, leading St. Louis department store, that it will return to a single night opening for its downtown store, effective on Feb. 2. Since September the store has been open two nights a week, Mondays and Thursdays, but will revert next month to night openings on Mondays only.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Jan. 23 -- The state institutes of applied arts and sciences should be continued at state expense rather than at the expense of students and communities, the community college committee of the Westchester County Federation of Women's Clubs declared today at the federation's winter conference here.

The first issue of a monthly newsletter for parents of pre-school boys and girls published by a new group, the Children's Book and Record of the Month Club, was released yesterday. Titled "The Two to Five World," the eight-page bulletin features articles by leaders in the child development field concerning such topics as baby-sitting problems, nursery school benefits, facts on fluoridation and some advice on the use of wonder drugs.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 23 -- The closing sessions of Mexico's first Congress of Catholic Culture established today a permanent commission to press for the elimination of the last vestiges of the country's anti-clerical laws.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 23 (UP) -The Louisiana State Athletic Commission today rescinded a 60-year-old rule that prohibited Negro and white fighters from appearing on the same program.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Confirmation of John Foster Dulles as Secretary of State and of former Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. of Massachusetts as United States Ambassador to the United Nations should start a new and better relationship between the United Nations and this country.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Jan. 23 -- University of Michigan scientists are awaiting a shipment of what they call the "most power experimental gamma ray source in the World."

Daniel (Danny Brooks) Gentile, serving a life sentence for the murder six years ago of Anthony Hintz, a longshoreman, testified before the State Crime Commission yesterday that he had gone into hiding after the crime on the orders of Edward J. McGrath, an organizer of the International Longshoremen's Association, A.F.L.

TOKYO, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Maj. Gen. George E. Armstrong, Army Surgeon General, said today that soldiers in Korea "have a better chance of not being wounded -- or of living if wounded" than fighters in any other comparable conflict.

IF we are to have another rousing controversy over air power, stirred by Ruth Mitchell's spirited portrait of Brig. Gen. William L. Mitchell, 1879-1936, "My Brother Bill,"* why, it couldn't happen to a livelier book. The court-martial of General Mitchell is one of the great trial scenes of American history. It has full play here, and Ruth Mitchell is a splendid advocate.
Arsene Tingaud died at the year's end at 79 years of age. He was a fine meat merchant, a figure to be reckoned with in what might be called the inner food circles of New York.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 23 -- The Soviet Union no longer cooperates with Western nations around the Baltic in maritime life saving, Capt. Hans Hansson, who heads the Swedish Association for the Saving of the Shipwrecked, said today.
LONDON, Jan. 23 -- The stock markets opened cautiously today but closed on a note of quiet confidence. Most sections closed higher despite late profit-taking.

Twelve little Girl Scout Brownies visited Gracie Mansion, residence of the Mayor of New York, yesterday, and were shown around it by the Mayor's wife, Mrs. Vincent Impellitteri. So at home did the girls, all 9 years old, feel that they addressed their hostess and guide fondly, and quite respectfully, as "Betty."
AKRON, Ohio, Jan. 23 (AP) -Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said today it has a new type of synthetic rubber to make automobile tire treads which "could easily outwear the automobile itself."
Johnny Sain yesterday telephoned Roy Hamey from his home in Newport, Ark., that his signed contract was "on the way." So the Yankees were able to announce they had four players under contract.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -Following are excerpts made public today from the transcripts of the Senate Armed Services Committee's hearings of Jan. 15 and of today on the proposed nomination of Charles E. Wilson to be Secretary of Defense. Senator Homer Ferguson, Republican of Michigan, presented Mr. Wilson to the committee.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Indo-China, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Communist-led Vietminh troops have advanced to within mortar range of Ankhe, 250 miles northeast of Saigon, and the French have established a baby "airlift" to hold the strategic plateau of central Indo-China, it was disclosed today.
DETROIT, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Dave Milford and John Thompson, the British champion, easily won their first match today to reach the semi-finals of the national racquets doubles championships.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 23 -- A nation-wide radio promotion of leading brands of perfume which manufacturers complained was unauthorized and misleading was halted today by a Federal Court order.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23 -- The grain list had another sharp recession today as selling followed the announcement that Great Britain planned to turn the grain trade back to private hands, abolishing controls on April 1. The impression here was that the move was bearish, indicating a belief that grain and feed supplies will be ample the next few years.

Hopes for immediate agreement on the terms under which the private-line bus strike would go to arbitration appear to have been premature. This is the twenty-fourth day of the strike, and in view of the ease and readiness with which the public is taking its inconvenience one would have expected that the union would be less exacting in its pre-arbitration demands.

Francis Lederer has agreed to play the leading male role in "Masquerade," the romantic comedy by Jeroam Stagg and L. S. Birchard. The production is scheduled to arrive on Broadway on April 2 after three weeks of out-of-town tryouts, probably in Wilmington, Del., and Philadelphia.

A small increase in the amount of drama programs and a slight decrease in sports programs televised by seven local stations were noted yesterday in the third annual survey report issued by the National Association of Educational Broadcasters.

VIENNA, Jan. 23 -- The United States Embassy revealed today that of those questioned in connection with the arrest here last week of Kurt L. Ponger and Otto Verber on charges of espionage on behalf of the Soviet Union, only two persons, a naturalized American and a naturalized British woman, were still being held.
Railroad workers should receive a 3 per cent wage increase each year to keep up with the expanding American economy, a lawyer representing nineteen major railway unions asserted yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Judge F. Dickinson Letts of the United States District Court dismissed today a restraining order barring the arrest of Serge Rubinstein, Russian-born financier.
A patrolman distributing those neat little messages informing a car owner that he has parked illegally found a windshield note yesterday anticipating his own.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23 -- Before coming to grips with the big question of their annual meeting -what to do with Baltimore? -- the National Football League owners this afternoon turned down two major and adopted five minor proposals affecting the playing rules.

An ownership of fifty-nine years has been terminated in the sale of the fee of the property at 95-01 to 95-19 Thirty-seventh Avenue and 35-09 to 36-65 Ninety-fifth Street in Jackson Heights, Queens. John F. Burns was the buyer and H. Schuyler Clark was agent for the seller.

LONDON, Jan. 23 -- Mattiwilda Dobbs, American Negro coloratura soprano who recently started her operatic career, will sing the lead in a Strauss opera next summer at Glyndebourne, Britain's most fashionable music festival.

The 30,000-ton luxury liner Andrea Doria, her single mast and upper works alive with signal pennants, moved sedately into the harbor yesterday to receive the acclaim accorded to every new ocean queen, Not even the bleak sunless setting of the Upper Bay could chill the spirits of ocean-going and small craft masters who saluted the first new Italian liner to touch here since before the war.
The Coast Guard completed yesterday its inquiry into the stenrn-on crash in hear fog last Monday of the Staten Island ferryboats Pvt. Joseph F. Merrell and Ellis Island at Slip 8, the Battery.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 23 -- A fantastic mail tampering case unfolded today with the recovery of 25,000 stolen letters in a musty courthouse basement room. Charles W. Lewis, 32 years old, a mail clerk in the Dade County tax collector's office, was arrested by postal inspectors yesterday.
Robert W. Dowling, real estate dealer and president of the City Investing Company, has been named Manhattan and Westchester chairman of Brotherhood Week to be held Feb. 15 to 22.
The Peruvian freighter Tumbes sailed yesterday on the first direct voyage since pre-war days from New York to Iquitos, which is farther upriver than any other deep-water port in the world.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (UP) -A pardon by former President Truman for the late Huey Long's political heir, Richard W. Leche, one-time Louisiana Governor, who went to prison for mail fraud in the early Nineteen Forties, was disclosed today.

Representatives of civic organizations held an emergency meeting yesterday to protest an impending cut in pay for five provisional, or temporary, employes of the Department of City Planning who will have to go back to starting salaries if they accept appointment as permanent civil service employes.
PARIS, Jan. 23 -- The man who would be King of France if France had a King charged today that his fellow countrymen lacked the civic spirit required to make democracy work.

A broad program of public education to remove the stigma generally attached to mental illness was recommended yesterday at the conclusion of a two-week institute for vocational rehabilitation of the mentally ill. Arranged by the Federal Security Agency, the institute was conducted by the department of guidance at Teachers College, Columbia University, under a grant from the National Institute of Mental Health.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Jan. 23 -- Sight-seers, gazing at old houses and such like, are, for the most part, "not educated up to being satisfied with architectural features alone," according to Mrs. Frances B. Crowninshield, who spoke last night at one of the closing meetings of the Fifth Annual Williamsburg Antiques Forum.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 23 -- Marshal Tito and Faud Koprulu, Turkish Foreign Minister, ended their talks today, forging still another link in the Balkan entente between Yugoslavia, Turkey and Greece for mutual defense against the threat of a Soviet attack.

TRENTON, Jan. 23 -- Two of the three young, armed robbers who brazenly held up a bank here a week ago and escaped with almost $70,000 were captured without a struggle today by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The third member of the gang, who is known to the authorities, became the object tonight of a widespread manhunt.

GRANDVIEW, Mo., Jan. 23 -Harry S. Truman, unmindful of a biting sub-freezing wind that swept the fields he trod as a boy, today inspected the site here for the proposed Harry S. Truman Library. The $1,500,000 project would house the letters, communications and documents accumulated by him, as President, during the war and post-war years of his Administrations in Washington.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The Navy, a bit bewildered, found itself today with two sets of civilian chiefs. One of them was a carry-over Acting Secretary of the Navy whose formal resignation apparently has been mislaid in the White House.

Marc Connelly, whose play, "The Green Pastures," won the Pulitzer Prize in 1930, has been elected president of the National Institute of Arts and Letters. He succeeds Douglas Moore, the composer, who had served since 1947.
ALBANY, Jan. 23 -- The Board of Regents backed today the decision of the director of the Division of Motion Pictures to deny a license for the showing of the film, "Teenage Menace."
LONDON, Jan. 23 -- Walter S. Gifford, the retiring United States Ambassador to the Court of St. James, sailed for home today aboard the United States liner United States.

LONDON, Jan. 23 -- Foreign diplomats and British sources are almost unanimously convinced that the new wave of anti-Semitic persecution in the Soviet Union and the satellite states is motivated entirely by reasons of internal security.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 23 -- The prospect of a three-sided controversy involving Hollywood labor unions, the big independent producers and the American Legion loomed today.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 23 -- Erich Ollenhauer, leader of the Social Democratic party, which opposes ratification of the Bonn peace contract with the Western Allies and the European Defense Community treaty, announced tonight that his party would favor a grand coalition including Britain, Denmark and Norway as the organization for Western defense.
MENASHA, Wis., Jan. 23 (AP) -- A merger of Northern Paper Mills, Green Bay, into the Marathon Corporation, Menasha, was announced Wednesday by the presidents of the two companies.

Pakistan is a logical force with which one must reckon when the strength and stability of southern Asia are under consideration. There are good reasons for this. First is the fact that Pakistan has done a remarkable job of building since the nation became independent in 1947.

Ernie Vandeweghe of New York and Dick Groat of Fort Wayne will be missing from the line-up when the Pistons seek their fourth straight triumph over the Knicks in a National Basketball Association game on the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory court tonight.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Average primary market prices dropped 0.2 per cent over the week ended on Tuesday to 109.6 per cent of the 1947-49 average, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

Willie Troy, Washington (D. C.) middleweight maintained his unbroken string of ring victories last night with a decision over Bobby Jones, Oakland, Calif., in the ten-round feature bout at St. Nicholas Arena before 2,108 fans.

More than 25 per cent of the persons sentenced in Kings County Court in 1952 were between 21 and 25 years old, according to the annual report of Francis J. Sinnott, County Clerk, made public yesterday.

The Rev. Dr. Carl McIntire, president of the International Council of Christian Churches, called on the National Council of Churches in the United States of America yesterday to respond to objections to the Revised Standard Version of the Bible and to disclose what royalties it was receiving on each copy sold.

Our elderly visitor confessed that he had not been present on that enchanted evening in January sixty years ago tonight when Charles Frohman's Empire Theatre began a distinguished career by putting on a play written for the occasion by David Belasco assisted by Franklin Fyles, then dramatic critic of The Sun.

Demolition and construction along Fifty-seventh Street have forced a number of galleries to move to new quarters. One of these is the John Nicholson Gallery which celebrates its settling down at 18 East Fifty-seventh Street with a large exhibition of old master drawings and paintings.

Brooklyn Tech and Evander Childs finished in a tie for the team championship and the John J. McHugh Memorial Trophy in the annual P. S. A. L. swimming meet in New York University's Quigley Memorial Pool last night. Each finished with 20 points.

In order to enjoy Menasha Skulnik, a theatregoer has to be resigned to seeing a make shift play. Mr. Skulnik is a funny low comedian who has kept Second Avenue in good humor for a number of years. He is short and plumpish; his hair is moodily receding.
ALBANY, Jan. 23 -- The Board of Regents approved today two amendments to the regulations of the Commissioner of Education.

The executive order issued by former President Truman a few days before the expiration of his term of office setting aside the offshore submerged lands as a naval petroleum reserve was termed "unsound and without basis" yesterday by Frank M. Porter, president of the American Petroleum Institute.
Real estate transactions in Westchester reported recently involved residential properties.

Railroads in this country are presently fostering the destruction of all competition so that they may revert to the "public-be-damned policy of old." This charge was made yesterday by Samuel A. Markel, chairman of the board of the American Fidelity and Casualty Company of Richmond, Va., at the annual meeting of the New York State Waterways Association.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Jan. 23 -- The Malan, Government announced today in a speech from the throne opening Parliament that it would ask for special powers and an amendment of the criminal code to fight the resistance movement begun by the Negro African Congress and the Indian Congress movement in the South African Union.

PARIS, Jan. 23 (Reuters) -France has demanded the recall of Maj. Vaclav Vimr, Czechoslovak military attache in Paris, in retaliation for Communist treatment of the daughter of France's military attache in Prague, the French Foreign Office said today.

MOSCOW, Jan. 23 -- The Government newspaper Izvestia today attacked leading Soviet jurists, the Institute of Law of the Academy of Science, and the All-Union Institute of Juridical Science for "formalism," "dogmatism," a lax attitude toward ideological matters and nepotism.
PARIS, Jan. 23 -- One after the other, Paris millinery openings are confirming the smallness of hats with decorative back interest.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that the nation's stocks of wheat on Jan. 1 were 20 per cent larger than a year ago and stocks of corn were 9 per cent larger. The increase reflected the fact that production in 1952 was larger than in 1951.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Jan. 23 (AP) -The State Association of Health, Physical Education and Recreation today presented its distinguished service award to Prof. Frank S. Lloyd, suspended as athletic director by the City College of New York following the basketball "fix" scandals.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The country probably will learn next week the directions that the Eisenhower Administration will take in domestic and foreign policies.

Stockholders of the Bank of the Manhattan Company, at a special meeting yesterday, approved plans to increase the bank's capital stock by the sale of 250,000 additional shares. The vote was 1,697,620 shares in favor of the proposal and 184,055 against.

A retired dress manufacturer was killed and two patrolmen of a radio car were injured yesterday morning as the result of a freakish accident between a private automobile and the police car at the intersection of Seventy-second Road and Main Street in the Kew Gardens area of Queens.
The cotton futures market was moderately active yesterday and prices on active months on the New York Cotton Exchange finished 9 to 20 points higher than on Thursday.

CAIRO, Jan. 23 -- Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib, Premier of Egypt and chief of the Egyptian Army's revolutionary movement, took the salute at a parade of youth formations in Liberation Square this morning at the start of a four-day "Liberation Festival," marking the first six months of his regime.

An arbitration agreement to end the twenty-three-day bus strike was snarled again yesterday by a lawyers' debate over language. Union and company officials were close to an accord, but tempers were growing so frayed that it seemed the wrangling might go on for days.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- A plastic umbrella that the user blows up like a toy balloon made its appearance among the inventions patented this week. One advantage stressed by the inventors is that the device can be turned inside out by the wind without damage.

HEADQUARTERS, Eighth Army, in Korea, Saturday, Jan. 24 -- Gen. James A. Van Fleet, "with a heavy heart," said good-by today to the United States Eighth Army, attached Allied units and the Korean people after nearly two years as commander of United Nations ground forces in the Korean war.
The election of C. V. Whitney as a director of Cinerama Productions was announced yesterday by Dudley Roberts Jr., president. Mr. Whitney is chairman of Hudson Bay Mining and Smelting Company.

ALBANY, Jan. 23 -- By unanimous vote, the eastern regional district of the American College Public Relations Association, ending its three-day sessions here, adopted a resolution endorsing the development and operation of television stations for educational purposes.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 23 (UP) -State troopers used submachine gunfire as a warning today to cow 1,100 defiant convicts at riot-torn Western Penitentiary.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Vic Seixas of Philadelphia and Australia's erratic southpaw. Mervyn Rose, gained the singles final of the South Australian tennis championships today while two misses from California took charge of the women's division.
As one of the earlier counsel in the so-called "tidelands" litigation and legislation may I make a few observations on your editorial of Jan. 8 entitled "A Coup in Oil."

The aloofness shown by the investment banking firm of Kuhn, Loeb Co. toward market borrowers having relations with other banking houses was interpreted in Federal Court here yesterday by Judge Harold R. Medina as an "intangible" form of competition which might prove more successful than aggressive efforts to keep potential customers away from other bankers.

VIENNA, Jan. 23 -- The Nazitinctured Independent party protested today to the United States High Commissioner, Llewellyn E. Thompson, against the refusal of American-owned Red White Red radio network to grant the party radio time for its election campaign.

Stockholders of Federated Department Stores, Inc., at a special meeting here yesterday approved a profit-sharing retirement income and thrift incentive plan for regular employes with at least five years of continuous service and a stock option plan for certain management officials.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The United States has protested again to the Soviet Union against restrictions placed on the property and interests of American owners in East Germany and the Soviet sector of Berlin.

Among those present at the ceremonies in Washington last Tuesday was Maj. John Eisenhower, temporarily detached from service with the Third Division in Korea. He was there because his commanding officer, Gen. Mark W. Clark, had told him to be. He may not have been "raising hell" about this order, as has been reported.

HONG KONG, Jan. 23 -- A new head of steam for the "Resist America, Aid Korea" movement started building up in China today following Communist Premier Chou En-lai's charge that a United States B-29 had violated Manchuria's "territorial air" before being shot down Jan. 12.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Joseph M. Dodge, President Eisenhower's Director of the Budget, has arranged to keep his predecessor, Frederick J. Lawton, at his side in the Budget Bureau as special assistant.

The Public Service Commission yesterday directed the Jamaica Water Supply Company, serving 105,000 customers in parts of Queens and Nassau Counties, to file a new rate schedule effective on Feb. 1, designed to eliminate disparities between metered and unmetered customers.
The Charles E. Wilsons have a combined fortune of more than $5,000,000, according to calculations of their holdings in various companies, The United Press reported yesterday.

John Kieran, editor of "Information Please Almanac," is writing a book on one of his favorite subjects, natural history. His new work will be titled "The Natural History of New York City." In it he describes the meteorological and geological background of the city and discusses the flora and fauna within the city's limits.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Postal authorities are redoubling their efforts here to stamp out one of the oldest "inheritance" frauds in the country. It is generally admitted, however, that the efforts will now, as in the past, prove ineffectual until the public becomes aware that it is being duped.

Events today; "Aida," Metropolitan Opera, 2; "La Boheme," Metropolitan Opera, 8:30; "Aida," Amato Opera Theatre, 159 Bleecker Street, 8:30; "La Traviata," Sal-maggi Opera, Brooklyn Academy, 8:30; "Carmen," presented by Music Performance Trust Fund, Hunter College, 8:30; "Tales of Hoffmann," Walton Community Center, Reservoir Avenue and 196th Street, 8:30.

The Isbrandtsen Company, Inc., steamship operative concern has successfully blocked, at least temporarily, the institution of a dual rate system by the Japan-Atlantic and Gulf Freight Conference. It was to have gone into effect yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The president of America's biggest corporation had trouble paying his grocery bill during the 1932 bank holiday, it was disclosed today.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 23 -- India and Pakistan have agreed to begin still another round of talks on Kashmir in Geneva next month.

Price changes were irregular yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges, with most items continuing inactive. The volume in hides improved and potatoes continued active. Hides, sugar, rubber and wool closed higher and lead and potatoes were lower.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Jan. 23 -- The staff here of Supreme Allied Headquarters submitted today to North Atlantic Treaty Organization officials in Paris the first of a new series of chart-type analyses, showing -- as nearly as possible -- the true combat readiness of military ground forces guarding the treaty organization's area.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23 (AP) -The National Football League's club owners beat down Commissioner Bert Bell's pet economy move tonight and decided to retain the present player limit of 33 active men on each squad.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -President Eisenhower's nominees for three top jobs in the Commerce Department quickly won unanimous approval from the Senate Commerce Committee today.

ROME, Jan. 23 -- The sovereign Military Order of Malta, whose history dates from the crusades, came into sharper conflict with the Vatican today when it declared that it would refuse to accept any curtailment of its sovereign powers even if suggested by the committee of Cardinals appointed by the Pope.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- A decision on the future of wage and price controls one on which President Eisenhower is being closely pressed, was reported today to be still pending. Details of his views on the subject are expected to be contained in his message to Congress, which is slated to go to the Capitol late next week.

A preview of the total eclipse of the moon, to occur on Thursday, will be added to the regular January presentation of the Hayden Planetarium, Eighty-first Street and Central Park West, from Monday through Thursday. "Beneath Arctic Skies," the January presentation of the Planetarium, is a representation of a trip to the North Pole, featuring a display of the northern lights.
PERTH, Australia, Jan. 23 -John Landy drew the No. 1 lane today for tomorrow's heralded try at the four-minute mile, but he was concerned about another needed break -- the weather.

Authorization for a strike was voted last night by the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union, independent, against newspaper and magazine handlers represented by Suburban Wholesalers, Inc., and Morning and Evening Wholesalers, Inc.

There is no influenza epidemic here, Dr. Ralph S. Muckenfuss, assistant commissioner of the Health Department, declared yesterday. He said a day-by-day check had been maintained since news was received of epidemic influenza in scattered regions throughout the world.

The election of Charles J. Hogan, publicity manager of the French Line here, as general chairman of the allied membership of the American Society of Travel Agents, was announced yesterday. These members are those not in travel agency business, but in associated fields.

Roy M. Cohn, chief counsel of the Senate Committee on Investigations and Expenditures, told 200 members of the Ninth Assembly District Republican Club last night that investigations of subversive activities would be widened and deepened under the new Eisenhower Administration.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Several methods of Federal tax relief for small companies were proposed to Congress today by the Small Defense Plants Administration.
TOKYO, Saturday, Jan. 24 (AP) -Eight Army tactical summary for the period ended 6 P. M., Friday, Korean time:

Lack of progress in treating narcotics addiction has raised "serious doubts" about the wisdom of continuing to operate the city's Riverside Hospital for juvenile addicts, Dr. Marcus D. Kogel, Commissioner of Hospitals, said yesterday.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 23 -- For four days the current series of negotiations on the British-Iranian oil dispute has been becalmed and the impression here is that Teheran is waiting for the next move from London and Washington.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Lieut. Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, who has led a varied Army career in a succession of key assignments, was named today to succeed Gen. James A. Van Fleet as commander of the Eighth Army, which embraces all United Nations forces fighting in Korea.

At the State Crime Commission hearing yesterday an official of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., refused to testify about charges that he and other union officials had run the numbers racket on lower West Side piers that they controlled.

A mutual advertising campaign will be used to back up the marketing agreement recently concluded between the Pepsi-Cola Company and Schweppes, Ltd., of England, it was revealed yesterday. Under the arrangement, Schweppes, Great Britain's leading producer of soda water, tonic and mixers, has been franchised to bottle Pepsi-Cola in that country while Pepsi-Cola will bottle Schweppes products in North America.

Increases in taxes on business in the last twenty-five years have virtually halved the ratio of current assets to current liabilities and have aroused doubts that, without tax changes, private industry will be able to finance the sort of expansion demanded by the report of the President's Materials Policy Commission, according to Theodore H. Silbert, president of Standard Factors Corporation.

Promptly on taking over his responsibilities as Secretary of Agriculture this week Ezra Taft Benson announced a major departmental overhaul. In regrouping some twenty agencies and bureaus in the department the new Secretary was launching a program which he hopes will eventually result in increased efficiency and economy.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Jan. 23 (AP) -- Six cars of a Pennsylvania Railroad freight train detailed near here tonight, disrupting service on the railroad's main line for three hours.

MONTREAL, Jan. 23 (Canadian Press) -- Prices at the first Canadian fur sale for 1953, the $3,000,000 offering of Canadian fur auction sales, remained at approximately last year's levels, Arthur Prentice, company manager, said today.

MIAMI, Jan. 23 (UP) -- Mary Lena Faulk of Thomasville, Ga., the 1952 winner, whipped Pat Garner of Midland, Tex., 5 and 4, today to gain the semi-final of the twenty-first Helen Lee Doherty women's amateur golf tournament.
DJIBOUTI, French Somaliland, Jan. 23 (UP) -- More than 200 natives are dead and many have been wounded in a tribal war in central Ethiopia, press reports reaching Djibouti said today.

Modern machines are becoming so complicated that many make mistakes trying to operate them, it was decided here yesterday at the closing session of the annual meeting of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (UP) -- Non-farm employment rose to a record of 48,8,00,000 in mid-December, the Bureau Of Labor Statistic reported today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Controlling Republican members of the Committee on Government Operations of the House of Representatives, the general investigative group of that branch, decided today to start hearings Tuesday on the question whether the President should continue to have authority to propose reorganizations of departments and agencies of the Federal establishment.

Lumber production for the week ended Jan. 17 was 20.9 per cent above the comparable week last year, according to reports wired yesterday to THE NEW YORK TIMES by regional associations. Shipments were up 17.9 per cent and orders 33.4 per cent. Following are the weekly statistics in thousands of board feet:

The stock market idled yesterday, following a middle of the road course. It was a session which could be classified as a complete standoff as shown by the loss of 0.02 point in the composite rate of THE NEW YORK TIMES index.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23 -- With world-record performances, Harrison Dillard launched and Ken Wiesner anchored a wholesale spree of record breaking at The Philadelphia Inquirer's ninth annual indoor track meet tonight.

HONOLULU, Jan. 23 -- Federal Judge John Wiig today took under advisement a defense motion for mistrial based on the content of two newspaper editorials as the trial of seven Hawaii residents on charges of Smith Act violations continued. The Smith Act makes it a crime to teach or advocate overthorw of the United States Government by force.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The Senate Armed Services Committee voted unanimously today to recommend the confirmation of Charles E. Wilson as Secretary of Defense. Under present plans, the nomination will be brought to the floor of the Senate for debate on Monday.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Jan. 23 -- Continuance of the "constructive program" started in India by Ambassador Chester A. Bowles was urged upon the State Department today by the Division of Foreign Missions of the Methodist Church.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Jan. 23 -- More than a dozen petitions and resolutions, most protesting the dismissal of two university professors, were received by the Rutgers University Board of Trustees when it met here today.
TOKYO, Saturday, Jan. 24 -Charging South Korean infantrymen struck at the Communists on the ground and United States F-86 Sabre jets hit them aloft in the Korean war yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- President Eisenhower's nomination of Harold E. Stassen to be Director of the Mutual Security Agency was held up today in the Senate. Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. was instantly and unanimously confirmed to head this country's delegation to the United Nations.

Prime Minister Churchill sailed for home yesterday aboard the Cunard liner Queen Mary after a vacation during which he conferred with President Eisenhower, former President Truman and Bernard Baruch and spent two weeks resting in Jamaica, British West Indies.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 23 -- Government price controls of steel, which have been in existence in one form or another since 1926, were abolished last night by the Ministry of Economics in one of the most important moves undertaken by Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's Government to implant firmly a free-enterprise economy in West Germany.

The first break in the mysterious shooting last March of Sol A. Rosenblatt, the lawyer involved in the disputed will case of Mrs. Eleanor Morgan Satterlee, developed yesterday with the indictment of three men, two of whom were believed to have been "imported" from Boston to carry out the shooting.

Sales of the Torrington Company and its domestic and Canadian subsidiaries in the six months to Dec. 31 expanded over the previous year's period, but net earnings declined to $1,864,606 from $2,372,406 for the final half of 1951.

ALBANY, Jan. 23 -- The State Banking Department announced today that it has approved a certificate of amendment of incorporation of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York, 140 Broadway, providing for an increase in the number of shares of authorized capital stock from 1,000,000 to 5,000,000, and for a reduction from $100 to $20 in the par value.
EVANSTON, Ill., Jan. 23 (AP) -Frank Sedgman of Australia overcame Jack Kramer in a blistering first-set victory tonight and went in to an 11-9, 3-6, 6-1 triumph in their pro tennis match.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Harry S. Truman, in one of his last acts as President, asked Congress for a special appropriation of $1,000,000 for loyalty investigations of United States citizens holding or seeking jobs in the United Nations Secretariat.

A survey of moral and spiritual resources in the United States will be a leading project this year of the National Conference of Christians and Jews, it has been announced by Roger W. Straus, co-chairman of the conference, which is marking its twenty-fifth anniversary.
Everett Peterson has been named wage and salary administrator of the General Aniline and Film Corporation.

Competitive abuses by individual savings and loan associations can "degenerate into a form of selfdestruction," weakening the entire industry, savings and loan executives were told yesterday. Speaking at a meeting of the Savings Association League at the Roosevelt Hotel, William H. Husband, general manager of the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, pointed out that the growth of savings associations during recent years carries matching responsibility.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- In their ride together down Pennsylvania Avenue before the Inaugural the retiring President and his successor are said to have congratulated one another on the orderly transition they had arranged from one Administration to the next.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Much of official Washington and Rome takes it for granted that Clare Boothe Luce of Connecticut will be the next United States Ambassador to Italy, and the only point believed unsettled is the timing of the appointment -- whether it should precede or follow the critical Italian elections in April.

In last night's Town Hall recital, Gina Bachauer displayed the form she had shown on the occasion of her debut in 1950. There was the same combination of majesty, imagination and sheer pianistics virtually beyond reproach.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -Many farmers and stockmen who sent dairy cattle and breeding animals to market last year will reap heavy income tax savings, a Treasury spokesman said today.

Evidence of an apparent shakedown of a vegetable trucking company for $50,000 by Ed McGrath and the late John M. (Cockeye) Dunn, longshore union gangsters who formerly controlled piers on the lower West Side, was produced yesterday at a public hearing of the State Crime Commission.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 23 (AP) -Mel Ott, who slammed his way into baseball's Hall of Fame and won thousands of fans with his warm smile, hung up his spikes for good today.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of use to homemakers.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 23 (UP)--Jimmy Clark of Laguna Beach, Calif., finding the sometimes difficut Phoenix Country Club course to his liking, today shot a four-under-par 67 to take a one-stroke lead in the first round of the $10,000 Phoenix open golf tournament.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Jan. 23 (AP) -- The Manhattan College basketball team staved off a last-period challenge tonight and downed LeMoyne, 63 -- 57.

JOHANNESBURG, Jan. 23 -The most powerful single force in the Government of the Union of South Africa is a tightly disciplined secret society with highly reactionary tendencies, rigid notions of a permanent color bar and a strong anti-British bias.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -Two former Government prosecutors pleaded innocent today to charges of conspiring to accept fees in a case before the National Security Resources Board. The pleas were entered before Federal District Judge Charles F. McLaughlin by Lester Luther, 73 years old, of Topeka, Kan., and Nicholas J. Lopes, 35, who now lives in Chevy Chase, Md.
In a letter published by THE TIMES on Jan. 19 Superintendent of Schools William Jansen wrote:
Your recent news dispatches and editorial comment on Trieste are of unusual interest to me because of my study of the problem and my deep concern as to its solution.
CHICAGO, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock marke[' here by the Department of Agriculture follows.

SPARSE GREY HACKLE, whose critical comments on methods and procedures involving the taking of trout are always to the point, occasionally dabbles in the field of shooting, which accounts for a communique on his typical foolscap based on a recent handloading column.

ALBANY, Jan. 23 -- An attempt by the American Federation of Musicians to expel a member who refused to continue weekly payments of 10 per cent of his salary to a booking agency licensed by the union was halted temporarily today by the State Supreme Court.

Yesterday's unanimous vote in the Senate Armed Services Committee ought to make it certain that Charles E. Wilson of General Motors will be our next Secretary of Defense. If he had been better advised by his own lawyers or those in President Eisenhower's entourage he would already be Secretary of Defense.

The four-story building accommodating sixteen families at 489 Sixth Street in Brooklyn has been sold by Frederick A. Heine to Philip T. Johnson. L. L. Yearsley, broker in this transaction, also reported the sale of the three-story dwelling at 511 Second Street for Edna Kelly to Brill-Ett, Inc.
Those who think they have no time to read the testimony on waterfront racketeering disclosed by the State Crime Commission may perhaps absorb its flavor from these highlights:

ROME, Jan. 23 -- News from Washington that Ambassador Tarchiani gave a lunch in Mrs. Luce's honor was taken as confirmation here that the State Department was about to ask the Italian Government's agreement to her appointment as Ambassador.

Services provided at Beekman-Downtown Hospital last year included 26,335 patient days, 14,302 clinic visits and 13,330 emergency first aid treatments, it was reported yesterday by Howard S. Cullman, president of the institution.
CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Jan. 23 (UP) -- George Barclay, who served a year s an assistant at North Carolina, was elevated to head coach today as the successor to Carl Snavely.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 23 -The Thai Government's policy of making the baht a high-priced hard currency is having an adverse effect on Thailand's exports. Preliminary figures for foreign trade in 1952 indicate Thailand had an unfavorable trade balance for the first time since the Japanese war.

The status of marriage and family life today in India, Turkey and other Asiatic countries was discussed yesterday by Dr. Abraham Stone, vice president of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America, at a meeting of the Tri-State Council on Family Relations.

Danny Holt, 13 years old, of North Haven, Conn., has been named as the 1953 recipient of the second annual "Real Boy of America" award, it was announced yesterday by Melvin L. May, chairman of the award committee. Mr. May, who is vice president of the Economy Blouse Company, sponsor of the award, said that Danny, a polio victim since he was 5, was chosen in a national survey by the Youth Research Institute.

In one of his first official acts as the new Secretary of State Mr. Dulles has issued an admirable personal directive to his 16,500 "associates" in the State Department and the Foreign Service abroad. It is designed to make these all-important branches of the Government more effective instruments of national policy and to eliminate some of the causes for criticism directed against them in the past.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -The Government's case against Ray Brennan, Chicago Sun-Times reporter, collapsed today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Ten Democratic Senators from the South introduced today a joint resolution calling for a constitutional amendment that would outlaw the poll tax as a qualification for voting in Federal elections, those for President, Vice President and members of Congress.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 23 (AP) -- The National Petroleum Council has been authorized by President Getulio Vargas to proceed with a $12,500,000 expansion of the oil refiner at Mataripe to permit production of lubricating oils.

A twelve-ton oil truck struck a pillar on the B. M. T. Fulton Street elevated line in Ozone Park, Queens, yesterday morning, causing the support to buckle. A six-car elevated train passed over the damaged structure a few minutes later and sagged "like a roller coaster," but miraculously stayed on the tracks.

THE silver jubilee presenta-this March of the Academy of Motion picture Arts and Sciences' "Oscars" may yet become a lavish, happy occasion. The Academy's board of governors has decided to entertain bids for commercial sponsorship of a radio broadcast of the ceremony on March 19 to offset the financial crisis occasioned by the refusal of three member companies of the Association of Motion Picture Producers to help to underwrite the affair's estimated $100,000 cost.

If Robert Moses, author of "To Turn Back the Killer, Speed" (Jan. 4), the National Safety Council and all others who are terribly concerned with the daily automobile killings due to excessive speed, would consider my humble opinion, there is one thing they can do that will bring about the end of, or at least greatly reduce, all this slaughter.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Jan. 24 -- Denmark is moving steadily toward greater defense responsibilities and strength under the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
THINGS should be a lot livelier in the Hall of Fame from now on. The brash, impudent and ever-laughing Dizzy Dean has arrived as a full-fledged member and the joint never will be the same again.

TO THE EDITOR: Mr. Bowles' article, "How to Win Friends and Influence Asia" (Jan. 4), contained many vital points every American should put forth an effort to digest and understand. For unfortunately some of us toy with the mistaken idea of being the only ones in position to give advice, govern or make decisions without being guilty of any offense when we disregard the decent, honest rules we set up. * * *

A MARROW-CHILLING coldness by no means accountable entirely to the latitude it deals with, pervades this first novel about a young couple living in Montreal, written by a British-born former Royal Air Force man who is now a naturalized Canadian.

HAMILTON, N. Y., Jan. 24 -Staving off three determined drives and putting on a similar number of scoring sprees, Colgate's basketball team downed a stubborn Cornell quintet tonight, 70 -- 61, to take the second half of the annual home-and-home series.

Women headed by Mrs. Louis IVf. I Rousselot are ~vorking for the suc-i cess of the performance of 'ff-,aI Tosca" on th~ night of Feb. 14I at the lV[etropolitan Opera HouseI for the benefit of the Alumnae Association of 1Wanhattanville College of the Sacred Heart.

Urgent conferences on the anti-Semitic campaign being waged in the Soviet Union and the satellite countries will be held next week between members of the Israeli Government and leaders of the World Zionist Organization, Dr. Nahum Goldmann, chairman of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, disclosed yesterday at his departure from the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, for Germany and Israel.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 24 -- On the basis of his talk with Marshal Tito, President of Yugoslavia, Fuad Koprulu, Turkish Foreign Minister, forecast today an improvement in relations between Italy and Yugoslavia and suggested that Italy would subsequently be brought into the Balkan entente.
TONIGHT the New York City Ballet closes the longest repertory season of ballet ever given here. At the end of twelve weeks, however, both company and spectators are in fine shape. Next round in May.

PRESIDENT Eisenhower devoted his inaugural address to broad principles of international policy, which found ready support in business and industrial circles. Now business executives await his specific recommendations on pressing domestic issues, such as reduction in Government spending, taxes, price and wage controls, farm price supports and the country's tariff and reciprocal trade policies.

Recipients of the annual Philip Murray awards of the National Congress of Industrial Organizations Community Service Committee will include this year three individuals and two organizations, it was announced yesterday.

TO me, the general reaction to "High Noon" indicated a remarkable naivete on the part of nearly everyone who saw the picture. It's certainly true that Westerns are almost invariably so thoroughly pedestrian and ridiculous that it's something of a relief when such a picture doesn't end with Bat Masterson and his horse in a passionate embrace.

Mrs. Bennett Cerf, Mrs. Gardner Cowles and Mrs. Alfred F. Hess head the committee in charge of the arrangements for the performance of Danny Kaye on the night of Feb. 16 at the Palace Theatre for the benefit of the Menninger Foundation, Emerson Foote is chairman, of the committee of sponsors.
Confronted with the "discouraging" problem of too few volunteers, the Air Force Reserve soon will launch an intensive drive for officers and enlisted men.

HAVING seen his play for this autumn reach Broadway -- having also seen it leave with a disturbing celerity -- John van Druten has retired for a time to commune with the corn, the cotton, the cabbage and the carrot.

Senator Wayne Morse, who twice has prevented speedy confirmation of President Eisenhower's Cabinet choices, declared yesterday that he would not vote to approve Charles E. Wilson as Secretary of Defense because such an appointment violated the principles of American justice.

WHEN, a few years back, the Port of New York Authority looked into its crystal ball and estimated the volume of all types of air traffic into the New York metropolitan area for the next ten, fifteen and twenty years many a non-aviation eyebrow was lifted.

BRIDGEHAMPTON, L. I., Jan. 24 -- "The Long Island Rail Road gave wonderful service in those days," said the dignified, white-haired elder as he watched the Montauk-bound afternoon train rattle into this village's shack-like depot.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 24 -- Dade County's incredible growth continues unabated despite the fact that land is running out in the Miami Beach area. This mecca for tourists draws more than $350,000,000 annually into the county and well over $200,000,000 to the beach area.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 24 -- Approval by the Army Engineers of a proposed 40-foot channel in thirty-one miles of the Delaware River from the Philadelphia Naval Base to Newbold Island, opposite the United States Steel Corporation's Fairless Works in Morrisville, was hailed today by Joseph K. Costello, executive director of the Delaware River Port Authority.

Mrs. E.
