Wood Gauss heads the committee in charge of the plans for the dance to be held under the auspices of the Parents Guild of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest on the night of Feb. 6 in the Squadron A Armory, Madison Avenue at Ninety-fourth Street, for the benefit of the youth program of the parish.

One of the most thrilling and exultant experiences in the cinema I have ever had was encountered upon viewing Stanley Kramer's thoughtful and affecting production of Carson McCullers' "The Member of the Wedding." This film, which illustrated the various frustrations and thoughts of the adolescent, was also notable in the sensitive and sweeping us of the camera to evoke a responsive mood upon an audience.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 24 -Creation of the Connecticut Development Credit Corporation, which would finance the development of new industrial and business firms in this state, will be asked in a bill to be filed this week in the General Assembly.

THE obvious, almost unavoidable thing to say about Sherman Adams, President Eisenhower's chief assistant in the White House, is that he seems to have been cut from the same bolt of plain, hard cloth as the late Calvin Coolidge. He was raised in a Vermont hill village, East Dover, some thirty miles north of Coolidge's Plymouth. He looks a good deal like

TORONTO, Jan. 24 (UP) -- George Armstrong scored two goals while the Detroit Red Wings were shorthanded to lead the Toronto Maple Leafs to a 2-0 victory tonight before 13,639 National Hockey League fans.

THE flower shows which are as much a part of spring as the daffodils are scheduled in several cities around the country during the next two months. Each one is as individual as the city in which it is held.

IT will be some time before history can judge of the success of the United Nations in its gleaming skyscraper home. And it will be some time before anyone can judge finally the success of the brothers' effort to set up a new economic pattern in underdeveloped areas or its effect if any, on the position of the United States in world affairs.

Gen. Hoyt S. Vandenberg, Air Force Chief of Staff, will speak tomorrow at the Hotel Astor, where the Institute of Aeronautical Sciences will open its twenty-first annual meeting. The sessions will run through Thursday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24 -- Accounts receivables held by Chicago concerns took a favorable turn in November, the Chicago Association of Credit Men reported in its quarterly review of conditions. There was an important upturn in the percentage of accounts discounting bills as the figure moved from 52.4 per cent in the August quarter to 61 per cent three months later.
The old Truman slogan had a new twist for Communists in the United States last week. Their watchword was: "We never had it so bad." Things were black for them and were getting even blacker.

HONG KONG, Jan. 24 -- The crashes of two United States Navy aircraft off the East China Coast last Sunday provided the most dramatic patrol episode in this area since President Truman ordered the Seventh Fleet to "neutralize" Formosa, on June 27, 1950.

Norway's merchant marine is manned by 40,000 seamen, most of whom will sooner or later call at a United States port, Hans J. Darre Hirsch, president of the Norwegian Shipping Employers' Association, said last week in out-lining the purpose of his visit to this country.

THE recent revival of interest in writers of the Twenties is difficult to account for in view of the diversity of kinds of writing that are being reexamined and the variety of approaches to them. We have had John Hutchens' anthology of texts from the period, and such critical and reminiscent essays as Edmund Wilson's and Katherine Anne Porter's.

THE Seventh Annual National Photographic Show will be held Feb. 12 to 16 at Grand Central Palace. The show will open 1 to 10 P. M. daily throughout the five-day run. Admission will be $1 for adults, 50 cents for children and students under 18 years of age.

Debutantes of this season, including the Misses Julie Shield, Marietta Everett and Barbara Hoge, are aiding in plans for the forty-fourth annual Blue Ridge Ball for the benefit of the Blue Ridge School in Bristol, Va., to be held Friday night in the main ballroom of the Pierre.

PARIS, Jan. 24 -- As a result of diplomatic talks in Paris and London in the last few days it has become clear in Western Europe that the new United States Administration will face in the next few weeks the problem of reconciling British policy with the American aim of unifying Western Europe.

THERE is no official American national dish. What such a dish might be always stirs a debate when gastronomes get together. Steak is sure to be mentioned, of course. It may not be voted the top favorite unanimously (there is always the fried-chicken contingent), but there is no arguing that a juicy sirloin and porterhouse are strong title contenders.

The New York A. C. remained undefeated in Metropolitan League competition by beating the Ramapo Polo Club, 13 -- 7, last night in the feature game of a double-header at the Squadron A Armory. In the first game, a non-league contest, Squadron A defeated a Manhattan trio, 13 -- 8.

Three of the four seeded players in the seventh annual Harry Cowles squash racquets invitation tournament at the Harvard Club reached the semi-finals yesterday, when all first and second round matches were played.

ROME, Jan. 24 -- The health of Pope Pius caused some apprehension in the Vatican this evening, when, on the third day after he took to his bed with an attack of influenza, his fever showed no sign of decreasing.

AT 82, Bernard M. Baruch still gets his name legitimately in the news by doing significant things. Perhaps he acts as host to a British Prime Minister. Perhaps he has a new idea about atomic energy or what is plaintively called the "defense effort."

IN my home town there are two ways of having garden-fresh vegetables on a small budget -grow your own or live next door to Lucky O. Clapp. Since most suburbanites are not gifted with a neighbor like Mr. Clapp, who has plenty of space and an insatiable desire to turn a packet of seeds into a tasty crop, they have to grow their own.

FRED ZINNEMANN, a soft-spoken, unassuming motion-picture craftsman of slight European accent and intense beliefs, culled from twenty-three years of West Coast seasoning, came to Manhattan the other day bursting with frank pride and gratitude.

A few mild days don't necessarily constitute a January thaw, but when they come beyond the middle of the month they are like peepholes through which one can see, still at a long distance, the slow approach of spring. It is only by contrast with the bite of icy winds that the air on such days seems warm, but when the temperature gets up into the forties it feels almost balmy.
ALBANY, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Civilian Defense aircraft spotting in the state currently is 15 to 45 per cent effective, an Associated Press survey indicated today.

GRANTED a clear sky along the Eastern seaboard Thursday evening, amateur astronomers and photographers will have a rare opportunity to photograph the major sky spectacle of a total eclipse of the moon.

TOKYO, Jan. 19 -- The Finance Ministry now has made public the figures of Japan's foreign trade in 1952, causing considerable worry among those Japanese who realize that these small, overpopulated islands must import and export to live.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 24 -William Benton, former United States Senator from Connecticut, appealed to Gov. John Lodge today to give his "most earnest consideration" to the plan for a three-station educational television network in the state.

SEOUL, Korea, Sunday, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The retirement of Gen. James A. Van Fleet as Eighth Army commander sent a surge of regret through the Republic of Korea Government yesterday, but President Syngman Rhee pledged warm cooperation to General Van Fleet's successor, Lieut. Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor.
Representative reaction of the foreign trade community to President Eisenhower's inaugural address was hopeful.

Prof. Alice V. Keliher, a New York University authority on childhood education, was honored yesterday at a fiftieth birthday reception given at the Hotel Brevoort, Washington Square. Three-hundred friends and former students attended.

THE group of new roses which will be ready for spring planting is distinguished, although smaller than the total in recent years. There are representatives in the home gardener's favorite classes -- hybrid tea, floribunda, climber and miniature.

TWENTY years ago the Tennessee Valley Authority was created -- one of the most widely discussed and greatly visited projects in our national history. In "All Down the Valley" Henry Billings gives a comprehensive picture of this project -- it history, its construction and operation and its economic and social results.

Ralph Cordiner, dignified president of General Electric Company, shows no inclination to deliver fast jokes and snappy patter from a stage in order to sell his company's appliances. Gwilym A. Price, his equally dignified counterpart at Westinghouse Electric Corporation, has no thought of performing a soft shoe routine before an audience to induce the public to purchase Westinghouse appliances.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Jan. 24 -- The Adult Education Council of the Chattanooga area, one of the twelve test projects over the country, has coordinated in one year of operation workshop and program activities affecting 150 community organizations impinging on a three-state area.

Meat, white of egg, hair, feathers, hormones, bacteria and thousands of other structures that are either alive or parts of living organisms are composed largely of protein. This is one reason why organic chemists have been paying so much attention to the structure of the protein molecule.
PROVIDENCE, Jan. 24 -- Dartmouth established a solid lead in the first quarter and scored a 7659 basketball victory over Brown tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) -Senator H. Alexander Smith, Republican of New Jersey, chairman of the Senate Labor Committee said today he hoped for substantial union-industry agreement on changing the Taft-Hartley Law.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 24 -Another attempt to resolve the deadlocked war reparations issue between Japan and Indonesia, major bottleneck in the restoration of normal diplomatic and trade relations between the countries, appeared today to have ended in failure.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Jan. 24 -- State Senator Kenneth C. Hand of this city said today he was considering a proposal by leaders of the Union County Republican organization that he enter the race for Republican nomination for Governor.

Two Yale University scientists, Leon A. Greenberg, associate director of Yale's Laboratory, of Applied Physiology, and David Lester, research associate, have shattered a growing belief that bad diet has much to do with alcoholism. Their tests were made with rats, but are all the more startling because they are an extension of others made here and abroad.
A passenger liner of revolutionary design is under construction in the Harland Wolff yards at Belfast, Northern Ireland.

SINGAPORE, Jan. 24 -- If some superhuman authority could wave a wand tomorrow and call a halt to all the wars in Asia in which Communists are engaged, upward of 3,000,000 armed men would be involved in the magic truce. The total of men committed on both sides in Asia's big and little conflicts between Communist and anti-Communist forces comes to something like this figure.

TOKYO, Sunday, Jan. 25 -United States Sabre jets scored for the fifth successive day yesterday against China's Soviet-designed MIG jet fighters. They shot down four, probably destroyed another and damaged two in battles at 45,000 feet over North Korea.

The problem of helping children to have a normal, happy childhood in an era of fear and tension for their parents and teachers was discussed yesterday at the annual conference of the Play Schools Association attended by 600 teachers, social workers and others interested in the problems of children between 5 and 13 years old.

A GREATER variety of home furnishings styles will be available to the homemaker this spring. This was strongly indicated by the offerings to buyers shopping the wholesale home furnishings market here.

The American Communist party is a flexible organization which operates in a shadowy world of its own -- half underground, half above ground. Few persons outside the party -- and probably only few in it -- know where the real power rests or who makes the real decisions.

THE artist occupies a perilous place in life, for he is the most expendable of men. Really, he hasn't a place in life, but spends most of his time in a nook. He is brought out occasionally, shy, but hopeful, to show a picture or two, a figure on a stand, or a book in a shop window; gets a pat on the back, and then is coldly shouldered back into his hidden nook again.

The New York State Junior Chamber of Commerce awarded gold keys, for outstanding community service to five persons at the wind-up of its convention here last night.

PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 24 -Stability of character and integrity of purpose are the two most desired qualifications in a man seeking admission to college, according to a report to the president and trustees of Princeton University by Dean Radcliffe Heermance, director of admissions at Princeton for twenty-eight years before his retirement in 1950.

AT this time we need and want all the background information about the Far East and its problems that we can get. There are valuable lessons to be learned. Two new books shed additional light on the relationship of Woodrow Wilson and his Administration to the Far East.

GARMISCH - PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Andreas Ostler, Germany's dare-devil Olympic champion, made two record-breaking runs down the 1,800-yard icy chute today to take the halfway lead in the world two-man bobsled championships.

ONE of the aspects of science fiction which readers seem to find most fascinating is the detailed creation of a future or alien civilization, handled with skilled indirection so that the reader finds himself absorbing, along with the story, all the sociological and psychological minutiae of a strange way of life.

Yesterday's late afternoon program in Town Hall by the National Association for American Composers and Conductors presented works by an early American and some contemporaries. The program opened with a String Quintet by John F. Peters (1746-1813), a German who settled in Pennsylvania.

In adding his tithe to this growing legend, Turnley Walker is not only helping to enhance a burgeoning record but revealing facts in a fabulous career which have been noted often and familiarly, but never as fully.
The purchase of a nine-story building at 25 Waverly Place to house New York University's expanded activities in the mathematical sciences was announced yesterday by Vice Chancellor LeRoy E. Kimball.

An analysis of the 2,565-dog entry for the Westminster Kennel Club show in Madison Square Garden Feb. 9 and 10 developed that five of the six dogs that battled for the best-in-show, crown a year ago would be back to try again.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) -The Chamber of Commerce of the United States said tonight its 3,200 member organizations had voted overwhelmingly for a "sweeping expansion of the Social Security program to cover all working and all retired persons."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- President Eisenhower announced today that Allen W. Dulles would be his choice for director of the Central Intelligence Agency, the nation's highest organization for collecting vital international information.

A trend toward higher educational requirements in business was pointed out yesterday by Dean G. Rowland Collins of New York University's School of Commerce, of 1,618 companies in the New York are were enrolled in the evening student body last year, the dean announced.

To the Radio-Television Editor: THIS is about the letter from Maxwell Anderson, in last Sunday's TIMES, in which he said that the Authors League of America "passed a resolution stating that it would defend any author who had been debarred from work because of a listing in 'Red Channels'."

In Korea last week the main armies of the Communists and the United Nations remained immobile, burrowing still deeper in fortifications the like of which have not been seen since World War I. The Korean stalemate had acquired the physical trappings of a static war -- barbed wire, deep bunkers and underground labyrinths, trenches echeloned in depth.

COLOGNE, Germany, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Forty-eight veterans of Germany's pre-war Lufthansa have been chosen from hundreds of applicants to fly the first planes of the Bonn Republic's proposed global airline, it was announced today.

FOR THIS WEEK: When cleaning up branches and twigs felled by the ice storm, sort out any suitable for staking and stack them flat. Large branches are good firewood. . . . Empty old packages of seed, then mix some with suet and scatter others outdoors for the birds. . . . Order seeds and needed equipment for spring planting promptly. . . .

BORN in 1875, Jacques Villon began as an illustrator and printmaker and arrived comparatively late at painting. An orderly mind seems to have held him back instinctively from the excesses of Impressionist and Fauve alike.

MOSCOW, Jan. 24 -- The newspaper Komsomolskaya Pravda reported today the case of a blind Fagin named Cohen who had succeeded in persuading orphan boys from Moscow children's institutions to lead him around and carry out his commands.

WAHINGTON. DESPITE a period of war, mutual hatred and occupation, for nearly a hundred years since Commodore Perry officiated at the meeting of the two civilizations, Japan and America have been attracted to, curious about and fascinated by, one another. Japan has admired and emulated our scientific and technological advances; American intellectuals have respected and even been influenced by Japanese culture, especially its architecture and prints.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Republican leaders in the Senate went on record today for continuation of the Senate Small Business Committee.

ONE of Poulenc's typically irreverent pieces is his Piano Concerto, which pokes fun at a good many sacred musical cows. It is, indeed, a type of smart-aleckism that some serious-minded listeners deplore. If, however, it is taken in the spirit with which it is offered, the concerto can be a lot of fun, reminiscences of "Swanee River" and all.

Montague, president of the Borden Company, one of the largest dairy products concerns in the world.

The weekly recorded concert on Wednesday between noon and 2 P. M. at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street, will feature piano compositions, among them Chopin's "Barcarolle in F Sharp, Opus 50" and Rieti's "Second Avenue Waltzes."

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Jan. 24 -- The Rutgers board of trustees today stood by its Dec. 31 dismissal of two faculty members who last year refused to answer questions of the Senate Internal Security sub-committee on Communist affiliation.

The indoor track season at Madison Square Garden will get off to an auspicious start on Thursday night. An outstanding field, including nine Olympic gold medalists and ten other Olympians, will participate in the forty-sixth Millrose Games.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 24 (UP) -The California Horse Racing Board has asked the state attorney general's office to investigate the activities of Alfred B. Fiske as secretary of the board, William V. O'Connor, deputy state attorney general, said today.

" ACTION in the Afternoon," the Columbia Broadcasting System's new Western horse opera originating in Philadelphia, will start on Feb. 2 and will be seen Monday through Friday from 3:30 to 4 o'clock. For the setting for the episodic Western story, C. B. S. has created, in appearance at least, the frontier copper mining town of Huberle, Mont.; altitude 2,291 feet: population 486. The year will be 1890.

THE work of the late Albert Marquet is far less familiar than it should be in this country. The current big loan exhibition at the Wildenstein Galleries should go far to correct this situation. More than seventy paintings, chiefly on loan from French museums and private collections, have been assembled for this impressive showing -- work covering a span of fifty years.

THE Ruhr is one of the salient economic and political facts of Europe, yet the true proportions of the Ruhr are obscured by legend and misconception. The great value of Norman Pounds' book is that it offers to the general public a compact, accurate picture of what the Ruhr is, what it has been and what it may become in the future.

THIS second volume of Phyllis Bottome's memoir (the first, "Search for a Soul," appeared in 1948), deals with the years in which she found her maturity. Miss Bottome has achieved the rare distinction of telling a most personal story with great objectivity and honesty.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- President and Mrs. Eisenhower will attend 9 o'clock services tomorrow morning at the National Presbyterian Church, the White House announced today. This is the church in which he and his Cabinet members and other families attended a special service just prior to inauguration ceremonies last Tuesday.

If a man at the controls of a plane is knocked into semi-consciousness and there is no one else to guide his plane, disaster is at hand. Hence the studies of helmets that the Cornell Aeronautical Laboratory is making for the Office of Naval Research.

ST. PAUL, Minn. -- Good weather for the St. Paul Winter Carnival -- from next Friday to Feb. 8 -- will mean snow and cold. A thaw will not entirely spoil the fun because so many of the events are held inside the big municipal auditorium.

A group of some three hundred educators and other interested and qualified persons has met in Washington under the sponsorship of the Office of Education to discuss language study. They have made a recommendation that instruction in a second language be initiated at an earlier stage in our school curricula and that further work be done to qualify teachers for such a program.

ROME, Jan. 24 (AP) -- An American Roman Catholic priest asserted today that complete disillusionment with new United States immigration laws seriously threatened to drive many Italians into Communist ranks.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UP) -- Secretary of Labor Martin P. Durkin is seeking a representative from industry for a top place in the Labor Department. L., had urged business men to recommend someone from their ranks to be an assistant secretary.

TOKYO, Jan. 24 -- The Japanese are growing increasingly skeptical that there is any prospect of early development of an anti-Communist security pact among nations on the rim of the Communist heartland of Asia.

Winners of the First Army's photography contest were announced yesterday. From 200 entries, ten were selected to compete in an all-Army contest in March in Washington, and in April in the fourth inter-service judging.

HONG KONG, Jan. 24 -- Building plans submitted by Government ministries for primary construction under Communist China's first five-year plan have been slashed about 30 per cent because of "inadequate working force and materials," according to the official New China News Agency.

ROME, Jan. 24 -- Official circles stated today that the Italian Government was well aware of the United States Battle Acts ban on exportation of strategic materials to Iron Curtain countries and that it could be taken for granted that none of the oil loaded in Abadan by the tanker Miriella would find its way to a proscribed area if it were landed in any Italian port.

I should like to correct a misstatement made by your reviewer, and indeed by every other reviewer whose notice I have seen. The appointment of a postmaster or a postmistress in Ireland is, under the Irish Government, a Civil Service appointment.

The twenty-five-day-old strike of 8,200 employes of nine private bus companies serving Manhattan, Queens and the Bronx can be settled without any rise in fares, with two exceptions, if the city makes the hard choice between a fare rise and drastic cuts in service, the State Public Service Commission declared yesterday.

GREENFIELD, N. H., Jan. 24 -A dream of New Hampshire health and public welfare groups for fifteen years will be realized next week with the official opening of the Crotched Mountain Rehabilitation Center. Fourteen crippled children will arrive on Jan. 31 to receive care and training to prepare them for useful lives.

BOSTON, Jan. 24 -- New Haven Railroad police and Federal Bureau of Investigation agents cheeked today a second instance of apparent tampering with the braking equipment of one of the line's trains since the crash of the Pennsylvania Railroad Federal Express in Union Station, Washington, on Jan. 15.

JOHANNESBURG, Jan. 24 -- When South Africa's Parliament reopened yesterday beneath Capetown's magnificent Table Mountain, dripping clouds, a political battle commenced whose outcome is likely to have important repercussions in world history.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Harold E. Stassen has advised members of the Senate that they could expect President Eisenhower's State of the Union Message to spell out proposed changes in the nation's foreign policy.

The Citizens Union announced yesterday that its committee on legislation had voted to oppose the proposed amendment to the State Constitution providing for a combined vote for Governor and Lieutenant Governor. The amendment has passed one session of the Legislature and is on third reading in the State Senate for action Monday night.
NEWARK, Jan. 24 -- Two separate moves aimed at improving the City Commission form of government in this city or recommending its replacement with a Mayor-and-Councilman type were made this week.
A former convict was killed yesterday at 1:50 P. M. in an attempted robbery of a jeweler's apartment when he fell five stories into a courtyard from a window ledge at 1240 Lexington Avenue.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 24 -- In recent weeks Premier Mohammed Mossadegh has been negotiating with foreigners on two fronts -- the oil front and the caviar front. The United States and Soviet Ambassadors have been calling at the Premier's home in alternation.

Since the report of the President's Commission on the Health Needs of the Nation was released a month ago, there has been considerable discussion about a number of the conclusions. There is one aspect of the report, however, with which few objective observers disagree.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The Senate gave every indication today of its readiness to confirm Charles E. Wilson as Secretary of Defense early next week, but approval of his choices for Secretary of the Army and Air Force was much in doubt.

THE next step in what is obviously a revival of interest in the modern dance will be the "festival" series to be presented at the Ziegfeld Theatre by New Dance Group Presentations on Feb. 22 and Mar. 1. WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- A complete outline of the 1953 collective bargaining and economic programs of the International Union of Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, C. I. O., was issued today and ordered by its executive board sent to all employers in the industry.

PHILADELPHIA, Sunday, Jan. 25 -- After eleven hours of deliberation the National Football League owners early this morning reached a decision on a "permanent" divisional alignment and inflexible schedule pattern. The plan calls for each club to play its five divisional rivals home-and-home games and meet two rivals from the opposite division, one home and one away.

PHOENIX, Jan. 24 -- Johnny Bulla of Pittsburgh captured the lead with a 67 today for 136 as the nation's better known professionals surged toward the top at the midway mark of the $10,000 Phoenix open golf tournament.

NO hero of Horatio Alger worked harder, suffered more trying reverses or struggled more resolutely "upward and onward" than Charlemagne Tower, whose one consuming ambition was to make a million dollars. His success story is now told for the first time by Hal Bridges, who teaches history at the University of Arkansas.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UP) -- The nation's election laws are "loaded with loopholes" and should be tightened at once, the Elections subcommittee of the Eighty-second Congress reported today.

THE British women's contract bridge team, which set a record last fall by winning the European women's championship without losing a match to the team of any other country, has come to the United States to compete with two or three teams of the best American women players.

In your Jan. 21 issue John D. Morris wrote of "the literal interregnum in the office of the Presidency" as a result of General Eisenhower's not taking the oath of office until 12:32 P. M. This view assumes that the taking of the oath is a condition precedent to the assumption of office.
ALBANY, Jan. 24 (AP) -- The Association of New York State Young Republican Clubs urged today that the state double the salaries of the Governor and Lieutenant Governor.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) -- A midnight session of the United States Court of Appeals has snatched Serge Rubinstein again from the hands of immigration inspectors who want to get him to Ellis Island on a deportation warrant.

Sales of New York City department stores showed an increase of about 2 per cent in the week, according to estimates by trade observers. This is on the basis of twelve stores against the same number a year before. Retail trade is showing a healthy undertone, it was said, with good response to clearances and special promotions.

TOKYO, Sunday, Jan. 25 -- Army authorities announced yesterday that one officer and eighty-seven men of the United States Sixtyfifth Infantry Regiment, Third Division, in Korea had been tried by courts-martial and convicted of refusing to go into action against the enemy during heavy fighting on the front last fall.

MONTREAL, Jan. 24 (UP) -- Sid Abel's second-period goal put Chicago ahead, but three goals during 80 seconds of the final period made it a rout tonight as the Black Hawks crushed the Montreal Canadiens, 5 -- 1, in a National Hockey League contest.

SOUTH LEE, Mass., Jan. 24 -- "Rain, rain, go away" was being chanted today by thousands of metropolitan skiers, who started rolling into the popular Berkshire skilands last night and this morning in anticipation of one of the finest week-ends of sport this season in western Massachusetts.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 24 (AP) -- Warren Lee Pierson, chairman of the United States Council of the International Chamber of Commerce, declared today that "only a firm and effective policy, backed up by strength, will ever persuade the Soviets to change their ways."

ELIZABETH, N. J., Jan. 24 -The State Highway Department has instituted condemnation proceedings against a section of the Graceland Memorial Park cemetery in near-by Kenilworth, through which it already has constructed part of the new Garden State Parkway.
THE observations set down here a fortnight ago about the failure of television to do much with good music, especially non-operatic material, have produced a fairly widespread reaction from readers.

JERSEY CITY, Jan. 24 -- Fairleigh Dickinson posted its ninth straight basketball victory without a defeat on Sam Schumer's lay-up shot in the last ten seconds to beat St. Peter's, 74 -- 72, in the Armory before 2,600 fans tonight.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 24 (AP) -Navy's center, Don Lange, hitting 70 per cent of his floor shots and all of his free throws, rallied the midshipmen to a 59-52 basketball victory over Temple today.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 24 -- Opposition to the "reserved" clauses in the Bonn treaties with the Western powers has begun to crystallize among the Bundestag Deputies belonging to the Government coalition parties in reaction to the British arrest of seven former Nazi leaders and to the United States High Commission's report concerning the revival of National Socialist sentiment among the German people.

In an effort to help civic-minded persons do a more effective job in planning, programming and enlisting aid to obtain action for school improvements, the Public Education Association will start an eight-session course tomorrow on "Effective Group Leadership" at Teachers College, Columbia University.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Indo-China, Jan. 24 -- Vietnamese elections will take place tomorrow with the modest aim of selecting municipal councilors who in turn will later choose regional councilors who, in their turn will name deputies for a parliamentary assembly, the powers of which have not been defined.

THIS account of the five sons of John D. Rockefeller Jr. begins, as you might expect, by giving us a glimpse of their grandfather, the founder of Standard Oil, who in their opinion was a better humorist than Will Rogers.

Two hold-up men got $350 from a Borden's Farm Products plant in Queens yesterday afternoon, but missed accumulated weekly collections of $10,000 that had been taken away by a Brink's, Inc., armored car only twenty minutes earlier.

A UNITED NATIONS AIR BASE, in Northern Japan, Sunday, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Soviet jet bombers, which travel at almost the speed of sound, are based in strength within easy striking distance of every major Japanese city, it was reported today by a highly qualified authority.

The Diamond Council of America has completed preparations for an educational program directed at the jewelry stores and the public. Most phases of the program will go into operation tomorrow. The group hopes to raise the level of salesmanship in the retail outlets and present the consumers with information for intelligent buying.

COLORADO SPRINGS -- Travel patterns are changing drastically in the Rocky Mountains. A few years ago the tourist business languished for nine months after Labor Day. Today, in Colorado and New Mexico especially, the winter tourist volume is nearly half of the summer volume.

For more than six years the Rev. John M. Corridan has been boring into the almost impenetrable shell of the waterfront of the world's greatest port, and some of these days he is going to call the whole thing off and devote his almost boundless energies to some other labor problem.

HANOI. THIS city, the headquarters for French forces in the Indo-China war and capital of North Vietnam, combines the atmosphere of a war-zone military bastion with many of the more normal aspects of any crowded provincial city of the Orient. In fact, Hanoi is the only capital in the world where peaceful pursuits go on to the echo of booming guns and, occasionally, the crack of rifle fire inside the city.

ROME, Jan. 24 -- At the end of a continuous sitting of more than sixty-nine hours, which gave rise to fist fights inside the Parliament building and riots and bloodshed outside, the Chamber of Deputies approved this week the Government's electoral reform bill.

LONDON, Jan. 24 (Reuters) -- West Bromwich Albion was downed by lowly Stoke City, 5 -- 1, today and dropped to a tie for the lead in the first division of English soccer. Sunderland drew, 1 -- 1, against Blackpool to share the top spot in the table with 33 points, one ahead of Burnley and the Wolverhampton Wanderers.

Because of their "faith and trust in God" as expressed by President Eisenhower in his own inaugural prayer, he "and those who serve with him will triumph in the war against fear and slavery," declared Rabbi Samuel M. Segal in a sermon yesterday morning at Mount Neboh Temple, 130 West Seventy-ninth Street.

Steps have just been taken by the Public Housing Administration to hold down the borrowing cost incurred by the new-type public housing bonds pending their further curing in the present finicky market for prime investments.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Members of the House of Representatives who are trying to lessen the power of the Committee on Rules to block legislation from floor consideration faced indefinite delay today in carrying the issue to a voting showdown.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The Republican-controlled Eighty-third Congress is three weeks old, and the ear now catches a certain sharp undertone to the mellow, symphonic theme of "constructive opposition" that the Democrats so recently brought forth.

AROUND what they call the stroke department, or front office, of the big oil companies in Dallas and Houston, in New York and on the West Coast, the odds are at least five to one that some time soon the Eisenhower Administration is going to give them a law restoring ownership of the offshore oil areas to the states, despite President Truman's executive order which put them into the naval reserves.

Sunbeam Corporation, which has struck many a telling blow for fair trade, and Masters, Inc., which cuts store prices fixed by manufacturers, are locked in a bitter legal battle. Last week Masters won a preliminary round, but both contestants indicated that the fight will go further and that they will carry it through to an irrevocable decision.

" BARBER," in addition to being the name for the man who cuts your hair, is a widely used intransitive verb which has the meaning "to be talkative." It sums up American folklore to the effect that a barber's customer is not so much in danger of having his ear shaved off as talked off.

Netting a 100 per cent profit in any business deal seems to be almost in the realm of fantasy to most people, but not to Harold H. Jaeger, vice president and general manager of Geyer Advertising, Inc.

CONTINUING the Whetstone clan chronicle that she began in "Foundation Stone," Lella Warren builds her new novel around Ma'am Gerda's adolescent grandson, Rob. As he drives with his doctor father over the red clay roads of post-Reconstruction Alabama, the lad is determined to study medicine.

THESE first-rate popular biographies get the McGraw-Hill "They Made America" Series off to a galloping start. Aimed at the mature teen-ager, these can also be recommended to the grown-up reader who wishes a well-written, historically sound but dramatically presented one-volume study.

Capt. John Nordlander, master of the Swedish American liner Stockholm, has been named to command the line's new Kungsholm now being completed in a Dutch shipyard. Captain Nordlander will also become commodore of the company's fleet, succeeding Capt. Sigfrid Ericson, master of the Gripsholm, who will retire in December.

MINEOLA, L. I., Jan. 24 -- A sprawling one-story brick building on the old Mineola fairgrounds, converted to a roller skating rink in 1932 after it had proved to be a white elephant as a cattle barn for agricultural expositions, became a new problem this week for its present landlord, Nassau County.

On Dec. 22 there appeared in the Helsingin Sanomat -- Finland's NEW YORK TIMES -- an article describing investigations by Gallup Institutes in Finland, Norway, Holland, Canada and the United States on the attitude of people in the respective countries concerning the following question:

The expected change in the command of the United Nations ground forces in Korea has now been announced. General Van Fleet will return shortly to the United States for his required statutory retirement. General Taylor is now getting his final briefing in Washington before going out to Korea to take over.

HAVING lived in Vienna for thirty years I should like to add my version of the origin of Kaiserschmarrn. The dish owes its imperial title to Emperor William the First, who, in the Eighteen Eighties was a regular visitor to Bad-Gastein, the famous spa in the Austrian Alps.
To the Radio-Television Editor: As a blacklisted writer, I would like to take exception to Maxwell Anderson's assumptions, inaccuracies and misconceptions.

OUR trim, white cargo vessel moved slowly from the pier into the pink and mauve twilight of Oslofjord. The passengers waved white handkerchiefs to friends, the missionaries among them valiantly singing out the refrain of a parting hymn.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Jan. 24 -- The Chamber of Commerce of Eastern Union County, on recommendation of its harbor and waterways committee, again will seek to have the Baltimore Ohio Railroad's single-track swing bridge, built in 1888 over the Arthur Kill here, replaced by a modern structure.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower was at last installed in his highest command post this week and in no time at all was acting like a President of the United States.

THE new crop of seed and nursery catalogues brings sparkle to the eyes of confirmed gardeners. Those who contemplate starting a garden this year may be bewildered by the annual January outpouring. For again in 1953 the basic lists are spearheaded by tantalizing new varieties.
Sailing forth next summer in the waters on this side of the Atlantic will be a fleet of sturdy yawls being built in Germany, with deliveries here to start June 1.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- John C. Montgomery, State Department official in charge of Finnish affairs, was found hanged to death early this morning in Georgetown.
SEATTLE, Jan. 24 (AP) -- The University of Washington Board of Regents dismissed Howie Odell as head football coach today but took no action on naming a successor.

HYBRIDIZERS have introduced recently several new varieties of small fruits, which are well worth growing in the home garden. In fact, some of these may well displace an older, inferior variety in each of its kind.

There was a wait of about an hour between courses last night at the Commodore Hotel as 1,200 members and guests of the Grand Street Boys Association dawdled over fruit cups while the hotel management and the waiters' union were engaged in a labor dispute.

IF another locale than Paris is evocated by a vision of mist splotched with the colors of azalea, pot-marigold, orchids, tea roses and the incredible spring-fire of rhododendron, it is San Francisco. Not far away from its corner flower stands are the florists' shops, as august and fashionable as the tea shops in Rome.

ON the twenty-first of last month the Bohemians honored this writer in a manner that he never will forget. On the occasion was included a wholly exceptional program of music. The opening event of that program was an astonishing performance by seventeen violinists playing in unison the finale of the Mendelssohn concerto.
The Communists boasted last week that their field fortifications across the 155-mile Korean front were "impregnable" -- the first such invincible defenses in the history of warfare.

Volume reorders were received in the wholesale markets here last week for spring apparel and January sales merchandise, according to Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office, Many buyers were in the market. Milium-lined coats sold well in fleece and poodles at better prices.

AN OPEN LETTER TO AN ANGRY PAINTER: Your letter asking why the Museum of Modern Art should have a Department of Architecture and why it should devote some of its third-floor gallery to the newly opened exhibition of post-war architecture surprised me.

OUR garden has flowers six feet tall and colored like a tropical sunset. The fruits and vegetables drip with ambrosial flavor and are as big as pumpkins. (The pumpkins are as big as watermelon.) The garden is bugless, blightless and weedless.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UP) -- President Eisenhower selected today the crew that will fly his personal plane, a four-engine Constellation. They are:

BAUXITE, Ark., Jan. 24 (AP) -A new inductrial empire is rising in one of the poorest states in the Union -- Arkansas. Driving force behind this surge is aluminum. Its potential magnitude is seen in the fact that seven aluminum plants now have or will have operating facilities aggregating nearly $180,000,000 this year.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 24 -- Harry S. Truman has turned down a number of offers of jobs paying $100,000 a year and upward, sources close to the former President said today. They did not disclose from what organizations the offers had come. However, they related, one concern offered a sales managership in which Mr. Truman could have earned $100,000 a year.

TWO deaths -- one natural, one by accidental poisoning -motivate the suspenseful game of hide-and-seek that makes up the major portion of this novel. Old Jonas Breen, former South Sea trader, has come to the home of his niece, Dee Allison, to live out his last days.

The rate of increase of over-all Soviet industrial production declined sharply last year and was apparently at the lowest point of the last half decade, data released last week by the Soviet Government indicate.

WHEN the United States Government began its new Presidential on St. Agnes Eve, officers both inbasket and outbasket were too busy to remember an eightieth anniversary coming up. I am at pains to recall it, for reasons severely my own.
THI.'GS we didn't think actually got into print: "},farch came in like a lion. At daybreak when Ruth Lamb awoke * * *" (The first two lines of Constance Robertson's "Six Weeks in March").
WASHINGTON, Jan. (AP) -The American Bar Association today proposed alimony tax relief for some husbands separated from their wives.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles has decided to abolish the $25,000-a-year position of Ambassador at Large, Administration sources said tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- President Eisenhower's inaugural address sounded a little like the second verse of President Truman's farewell address, but it doesn't follow from this that his foreign policy will be the same.
Frequently equity provisions under the Federal income tax laws have their origin in court decisions and are given permanence by statutory amendments.

The inability of the Fire Department to obtain Oregon spruce in lengths suitable for fashioning into aerial ladders for fire trucks has compelled the department, against the wishes of its high command, to switch to metal ladders.

THE author of this imaginative essay on the long-range prospects of the human race is a grandson of the famous evolutionist. Though interested throughout his career in biology, he is best known as a mathematical physicist.

DENVER, Jan. 24 -- The wide range of problems confronting American Indians -- from deciding how to use $32,000,000 in the case of one tribe to easing a deep-seated suspicion of all outsiders and even of fellow members in another tribe -- was suggested in the first annual report of American Indian Development.

A PATHHY on the part of individual drivers toward the subject of highway safety is cited by the Inter-Industry Highway Safety Committee as one of the outstanding causes of accidents today as well as one of the major obstacles in carrying out successful programs for protecting motorists and pedestrians alike.

A slight, 55-year-old Brooklyn grocer, who thinks he works too hard for his money to surrender it without a struggle, took on three teen-aged robbers yesterday and besides getting the better of the scuffle delayed the youths long enough to get them arrested.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 24 -- Army's basketball team gave favored Fordham a merry time of it for three quarters today, but was unable to match the blistering attack unleashed by the in vaders in the final chapter and bowed, 63 -- 54, before 3,500 persons on the Academy's field house court. It was the thirteenth triumph for the Rams, who have been beaten only by Seton Hall this season.

The statement in your editorial article in THE TIMES of Dec. 21, that the "smashing decision of the (Supreme) Court" in freeing "The Miracle" from the New York State Board of Regents' ban "has vastly encouraged those people and those elements that are determined to free the screen from the censor's grip," deserves circulation.

The steady increase in the number of criminal cases brought before the Queens County Court in the last two years has begun to strain the physical facilities of the aging courthouse in Long Island City, it was shown in the annual report for 1952 made public today by the four county judges.

TO THE EDITOR: I agree fundamentally with Chester Bowles' thesis but I am disturbed by one point of emphasis. We will never win friends anywhere except by representing America exactly as it is, with all its faults and foibles.
DAVOS, Switzerland, Jan. 24 -An 11-year-old world speed skating record for 3,000 meters was shattered three times today in the space of 25 minutes by a trio of flashy Dutch speedsters.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 24 -There has been a sudden sharp deterioration in relations between India and the United States in recent weeks. This abrupt reversal of encouraging trends during the past year or more can be traced to a series of coincidental developments after the United States election.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Jan. 24 -- The musical highbrows and the devotees of bop may have stayed away, but 3,000 enthusiastic music lovers of the great middle level flocked to the Westchester County Center here one night this week to hear familiar tunes played by the Boston Pops Orchestra and to give to the "problem child" auditorium a pattern and a hope for survival as a music hall.

FOR the first time in twenty years the Administration in Washington has turned to leading American business men to fill Cabinet and other top positions in the Federal Government. The new emphasis on business leadership by the Eisenhower Administration marks a sharp break with the past.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) -House of Representatives tax fraud investigators go back into action Feb. 2 with public hearings on the Alcohol Tax Division of the Internal Revenue Bureau.
Eugene F. Bannigan, minority leader of the Assembly, declared yesterday that the Democrats in the Legislature would oppose any attempt by the Republicans to weaken rent controls.

IF the Inaugural Ball had been held at the Palace Theatre last Sunday night, Duffy Square could not have been packed more tightly. Fifteen stern patrolmen were bravely holding the mob at bay and keeping an aisle open for the lucky people with tickets.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 24 -- A Borzoi from Brooklyn, a smooth fox terrier from Far Hills N. J., and an imported Pekingese from Lock Haven, Pa., entered the final tonight in a new-style Maryland Kennel Club dog show.

HAIFA, Israel, Jan. 24 -- Alexander Taub is a small, excitable United States engineer who bubbles with ideas. He thinks Israel could make and export automobile engines and could use alcohol instead of gasoline as fuel.

The Bennington College Scholarship Fund will be the beneficiary of Stephen Vincent Benet's "John Brown's Body," starring Judith Anderson and Tyrone Power, on the night of March 10 at the Century Theatre. Tickets may be obtained the Burden Littell Bureau at 114 East Sixty-second Street.

MIAMI, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Barbara Romack of Sacramento, Calif., and Mary Lena Faulk of Thomasville, Ga., shot their way into the final of the Helen Lee Doherty women's amateur golf tournament at the Miami Country Club today.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 24 -- Frostbite dinghy racing at the Indian Harbor Yacht Club was called off today because of a stiff, rain-laden southwest wind which puffed up to 46 miles. It was the second Saturday championship event of the eight scheduled to be wiped out by bad weather since the season started.
DETROIT, Jan. 24 -- Cab drivers rate the booby prize for safety and courtesy on the nation's streets and highways as far as the general public is concerned.
FORT BRAGG, S. C., Jan. 24 -- The Army Quartermaster General's Office has approved a new device for use by the Psychological Warfare School here.
Rain drenched New York and most of the Northeast yesterday while temperatures were soaring far above normal to nearly record-breaking heights.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Jan. 24 -Old test tubes that for more than thirty years guarded the secret of a "mysterious and deadly" virus have been recovered here and have yielded the strange knowledge they had hidden so long.

BORDEAUX, France, Jan. 24 (UP) -- An attorney demanded the death sentence today for all twenty-one Germans and Frenchmen on trial for the massacre of 642 French men, women and children in the village of Oradour-sur-Glane in World War II.

NEW varieties of annual flowers each year are one expression of the good American competitive system. New beauty or better plants create new enthusiasm and new interest among gardeners of every degree.

Bob Kubic, Manhattan College junior, celebrated his twentieth birthday last night by scoring a surprise triumph in the mile run, feature of the annual junior Metropolitan A. A. U. track and field championships at the Third Engineers Group Armory.
PERTH, Australia, Jan. 24 -John Landy failed in his bid for the fabulous four-minute mile today but he won the Australian championship by 120 yards in the good time of 4:04.2.
STOWE, Vt. -- The way of a skier in America is that of a youthful, supercharged monomaniac.

LONDON, Jan. 24 -- Nearly forty-eight hours of intensive investigation has failed to solve the mystery of a series of inexplicable engine failures peculiar to the British Overseas Airways Corporation's fleet of ten Boeing Stratocruisers, each powered with four Pratt Whitney Wasp engines.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UP) -- Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat of Virginia, who keeps a sharp eye on the Government's money, was invited by Senate Republican leaders today to continue as chairman of the House-Senate Committee on Reduction of Nonessential Federal expenditures.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 24 -- Less reliance on the printed page and more emphasis on the use of films, transcriptions, radio and television in Christian education was urged here today by Dr. Donald Bridges of New York City, executive director of broadcasting and films for the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 24 -- An eight-alarm fire wrecked a block-long paper box plant in West Philadelphia today and caused damage estimated at $1,500,000.

THE Howard Lindsay-Russel Crouse confection, "Remains to Be Seen," shown here recently at Her Majesty's Theatre, scored one of the most sensational flops in our recent stage history, but at least it provided your faithful scribe with a subject.

NOT all, by any means, of the recent developments in turf management can be considered spectacular. Still, work on the lawn today is indeed less arduous than it was a decade or two ago. Certainly the advent of power mowers has eliminated much labor.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Jan. 24 -Eighty-two clubs comprising the second district of Federated Garden Clubs of New York will be asked to join in the campaign to save Sunken Forest, a fifty-acre woodland on Fire Island, at a meeting to be held here Monday at the Cathedral House.

Few home gardeners realize that the seed they plant has been tested not only by State and Federal agencies but, in many cases, by the seed growers themselves. The aims and processes of seed testing by a large commercial grower and a state experiment station are outlined below:

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Jan 24 -- Victorious in all five of his appearances here this season, Merrill (Mezzy) Barber, United States open champion, finally suffered his initial setback at the Palisades Interstate Park 50-meter hill tonight when he was outpointed by Roy Sherwood of the Salisbury (Conn.) Winter Sports Association in the Swedish Club championship.

With the prices of some major farm products now about 25 per cent below the high levels reached early in 1951 and surpluses building up at a fast pace, the Eisenhower Administration is faced with a difficult farm problem. The problem stems largely from a drop in export demand, greater yields, with last year's crops being the second largest in history, and increased farm mechanization which has created larger-sized farms and more efficient operation.

Last week's testimony before the State Crime Commission threw new light on the pier boss and his role in waterfront activities. What follows is an attempt to sketch a composite profile of the pier bosses who control the various stretches of New York's vast port.
PARIS, Jan. 24 -- Maurice Bourges-Maunoury, Minister of Finance, denied emphatically today that the Government had any intention of devaluing the franc now.

BELGRADE, Jan. 24 -- If there is any area vulnerable to possible Soviet aggression where progress toward regional mutual defense cooperation has not been faltering it is here in the Balkans. Indeed, while the West European defense project is visibly stalled, the new Balkan entente among Greece, Turkey and Yugoslavia seems to be advancing toward a goal not at first foreseen.

TODAY, We of the theatre celebrate a very special birthday. The Empire Theatre, Queen of Broadway, is sixty years old. Throughout the world, wherever there are English-speaking actors, it is likely they will pause momentarily on this Sunday to recall the glories of the Empire and, if they a fortunate enough to have ever played there, they may well reminisce far into the night.

BERLIN, Jan. 24 -- Shortages of food, clothing, fuel and power, plus upheavals in the countryside and in the political sphere, have combined this winter to make life more difficult in East Germany than at any time since the "hungry winters" immediately after World War II.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 24 -- Four Agrarian members of the Riksdag (Parliament) have sponsored a bill to restore to the civil penal code capital punishment, which was abolished in Sweden in 1921.
CHICAGO, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Volunteer workers completed today a house for a young mother, stricken with polio Aug. 16, 1951, before a court order would force her to vacate her present home.

FEW performers within easy memory have been given as many fine songs to work with as has Fred Astaire. Down through the years of his stage and movie careers, he has had some of the most inspired efforts of the Gershwins, Irving Berlin, Cole Porter, Jerome Kern and Arthur Schwartz showered on him.

" THE SEVEN YEAR ITCH," the comedy which has been giving its stars, Tom Ewell and Vanessa Brown as well as appreciative audiences such a fine time at the Fulton Theatre, seems destined for the movies too.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 23 -Among those who are working against the Communists here there are many who believe that the specter of Communist rule in Iran has been too much magnified in the eyes of the West.

ROME, Jan. 24 (UP) -- The police arrested more than eighty youthful followers of the neo-Fascist party tonight and broke up their attempt to march on Parliament to protest the Government's electoral reform bill.

IN 1885 there wasn't a more reluctant adventurer in the Washington Territory than 14-year-old Nancy Kadderly. Daughter of an Indian agent, Nancy was tired of the wilderness and had her heart set on studying art at the new seminary in Tacoma.

IN reply to two letters in your section of Jan. 11, that are somewhat about me: In the first somebody remarks on my "sacrosanct attitude toward amateur presentation" of my plays and a "negative element" in my "egotistical behavior which tends to alienate" me "from a once admiring public * * * which saw my demise in 'Wesley Jackson'" and "numerous potboilers."

" I SHALL set forth the philosophy which is being suggested by the triumphs of science and will contend that this philosophy, if unchecked, may inspire a form of unwisdom from which disastrous consequences may result," writes Bertrand Russell in the first chapter of this collection of lectures.

RUTLAND, Vt., Jan. 24 -- Othmar Schneider, Austrian Olympic star skiing for the Mount Mansfield Club, leads the two-day mid-Vermont Slalom Derby tonight. Rain caused postponement of one of three runs till tomorrow.

* * * I cannot imagine Mr. Dawson or any other Englishman facing Armageddon or anything else in the garb Mr. Barrett describes. About the beginning of this unfortunate century certain individuals in "the City" got away with wearing a "topper" with a short black jacket, but a "bowler" with a morning coat was and still is considered "the outside edge."

WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 24 -Army and Notre Dame are going to resume their football rivalry. The announcement was made here today in the form of a short typewritten statement posted in the United States Military Academy's public information office.

The spring series of courses in astonomy and navigation at the Street and Central Park West, will begin tomorrow at 7:15 P. M. with the first session of a comprehensive course in "Applied Navigation."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The influence of Governor Dewey of New York in the new Republican National Administration is far greater than is indicated by the number of people close to him who have found their way into high Executive posts.
STOCKHOLM -- A notable contribution in the effort to relieve this city's acute shortage of accommodations for tourists is Stockholm's newest hotel, the 288-room Malmen.

X-ray treatment may endanger the growth of children's bones, according to a report published in Radiology by Drs. E. B. D. Neuhauser, M. H. Wittenborg, C. Z. Berman and J. Cohen. Their studies were paid for by grants from the Atomic Energy Commission and the Playtex Park Research Institute.
IT is a fair assumption that a major operatic event of 1953, at least as far as new works are concerned, will be the Salzburg premiere of Gottfried von Einem's "The Trial."

Two significant changes are taking place in the battle of man and the machine. The worker is coming to be regarded, partly as a result of union pressure, as having as much importance as the machine and requiring as much care in selection and maintenance.

PERHAPS it is because of an austere, patriarchal quality that Abraham seldom fits into stories for children as easily as do certain other biblical character like David and Joseph, who led more dramatic lives. It is, therefore, a pleasure to read Abraham Rothberg's fluid narrative which is based on the Bible but also incorporates certain legendary material which lends color and vitality to the character of Abraham.
CINCINNATI, Jan. 24 (AP) -- All eight clubs in the National League will open the spring exhibition season on March 7 at sites in Florida, Arizona and Cuba, the loop's headquarters disclosed today.

MIAMI, Jan. 24 -- Crafty Admiral took kindly to the mud today and galloped home to win the $15,000 Royal Palm Handicap at Hialeah Park before a crowd of 21,421. Only five horses went postward and Crafty Admiral, owned by the Charfran Stable, was easily the best under 126 pounds and Jockey Kenny Church.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Jan. 24 -- A new course for teachers, designed to help meet the ever-increasing problems of conservation, has been started by Rutgers University's School of Education.

CONCORD, N. H., Jan. 24 -- New Hampshire, which gave Sherman Adams to the national Administration, is turning its eyes to a new public figure, Gov. Hugh Gregg, as the 133d Legislature begins its deliberations.

ALBANY, Jan. 24 -- In the last year 3,118 employes have been added to the state payroll, making a total increase of 33,584 employes in the last ten years, a report of the State Civil Service Commission disclosed today. The ten-year increase amounts to 76 per cent.

REGARDLESS of how the forthcoming drama season fares at the City Center, it is reasonably certain to be something of a success from the standpoint of comfort. For the Center, long aware of complaints over audibility for the drama in the mammoth Fifty-fifth Street auditorium, has decided to cut itself down from a 3,100-seat house to one of 2,100.

BOSTON, Jan. 24 -- Jerry Toppazzini notched three goals tonight as the Boston Bruins staged their first scoring spree of the season to cool off the New York Rangers, 9 to 0, in the first game of two on successive nights at the Boston Garden.

A new apparatus consisting of glass tubing has been developed as a counter-current extractor which in a single run can provide up to 200 separations of a chemical based on solubility factors. Armour Co.'s scientists use the apparatus in experimental work on various hormones, vitamins and enzymes.

WHEN young Ashbel Field returned from the Revolutionary War he rebelled against the hidebound New England laws and those who made them. In a preceding book, "Now We Are Free," Marguerite Allis recounted Ashbel's journey with his family to the raw wilderness of Ohio.

Although the main fight has just been started, savings banks won the round last week in their conflict with commercial banks over branch office powers. Savings bankers are convinced they must have additional branches to survive.

LET'S hope it was only a momentary lapse from grace, but last Sunday's edition of "Omnibus," the ninety-minute production of the TV-Radio Workshop of the Ford Foundation, was enough to rattle a viewer's teeth. In its almost pitiful pursuit of art the program exhibited only a pretentious ineptitude.

I feel sure that many students of our foreign relations shared my surprise on reading the recent speech of George F. Kennan, a career diplomat who has been declared persona non grata as United States Ambassador to Moscow.

TO THE EDITOR: I read with much interest Harrison E. Salisbury's fine article, "Man, Dig That Stilyag!" (Jan. 11). But how did Mr. Salisbury get the idea that the "Krakowiak" is a Russian native dance? (Notice my spelling of the word, which differs from his.) This is a Polish folk dance. As such it may have been imported by Russia, but it never was a Russian "native dance." * * *

Under the direction of a Republican Administration, the Federal Power Commission is scheduled to reopen its study of a natural gas supply for the Pacific Northwest next month. Hearings set to begin on Feb. 16 promise to be among the bitterest ever held before this Governmental regulatory body.

THE story of Hernan Cortes and the conquest of Mexico has remained a favorite with American readers ever since it was set down by Prescott in 1843. It is a timeless and wonderful history: thirteen horsemen, four hundred soldiers, and seven falconers tumbling in a few battles the barbaric kingdom of Montezuma.
BATON ROUGE, La., Jan. 24 -In unusual moves in Louisiana politics, both political parties are now girding for future battles at the polls.

CHORAL recordings have been piling up steadily in the last few months. They range from Palestrina to Schubert, with Mozart's Requiem standing head and shoulders above the lot, not only for its own quality, but because of the performance Robert Shaw has led for Victor.

The historic moment when Dwight D. Eisenhower placed his left hand on the open Bible, raised his right hand and swore faithfully to "execute the office of President of the United States" and "to preserve, protect and defend the Constitution" will not soon be forgotten by the thousands of Americans who were present and the millions who saw this moving ceremony on the television screen.

ONE of the world's oldest games, chess, still has its faithful fans among the younger set -- even in this TV age. This story of a boys' chess club is a good introduction to the Royal Game for those who are not players and good entertainment for those who are.

FOR the first time available on LP, Verdi's Un Ballo in Maschera can now be had in a recorded performance conducted by Rene Leibowitz, with the Paris Philharmonic Chorus and the Orchestre Radio-Symphonique de Paris (Renaissance, three disks).

The National Geographic Society is lowering a strange new diving chamber called the "aquascope" into the sea off the Florida Keys for experiments in underwater color photography at night at depths of fifty to 100 feet. This aquascope is a 2,700-pound tank of armorplate steel with wide plastic windows.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 24 -Spanish Cream raced to her third straight and richest stakes triumph of the meeting today as she captured the $60,150 Santa Margarita Handicap for fillies and mares at Santa Anita by threequarters of a length.
ALBANY, Jan. 24 -- Manhattan staged a strong second-half drive to overpower Siena College, 61 -- 49, tonight before more than 5,500 fans.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- It probably was one of the shootinest moonshine raids in history. Internal Revenue headquarters officers told the story today of the recent battle in a wooded section near Aberdeen, Md.
LONDON, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Alarmed Londoners called today for Government action to stop a series of smogs -- the worst in memory -that have killed many persons here this winter.
The entire stock of Carlton Antique Silver, Inc., the New York branch of David Black Sons of London, will be auctioned on Friday and Saturday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.
Union Settlement will be the beneficiary of a Valentine tea dance to be held on Feb. 13 in the Chanteclair Room of the SherryNetherland.

The first Hunter College student to complete the Naval Reserve Officer Candidate Program for Women will receive a commission as ensign in the United States Naval Reserve, in addition to a Bachelor of Arts degree, at the college commencement exercises Thursday night.

The transition to a Republican Administration in Washington last week after a twenty-year Democratic reign was observed calmly in financial markets. Stock prices moved irregularly, within a narrow range, and trading was rather apathetic.

Persons interested in the work of the Northside Center for Child Development have arranged a theatre party in behalf of the organization, to be held Feb. 16 at the performance of "The Love of Four Colonels," with Lilli Palmer and Rex Harrison in the leading roles, at the Shubert Theatre.
The New York Knickerbockers triumphed over the Fort Wayne Pistons, 82 to 76, in a National Basketball Association game at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory last night.

The second National Theatre Assembly, composed of professional, community, and college theatre leaders, held in Cincinnati, Ohio, recently, went on record as saying that the American National Theatre and Academy's main project was the encouragement of professional theatre in the United States.

PAMELA FRANKAU is an Englishwoman very much at home in midtown Manhattan through she always writes from the English point of view. In this novel, her first since she wrote "The Willow Cabin" in 1949, the action is divided between England and the United States and is primarily concerned with strong family relationships.
BERLIN, Jan. 24 -- The purge-ridden Communists have now figured out thirty-five different ways to denounce someone.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 24 -Foreign newspaper men dubbed him "Iran's Black Eminence." They went to his house in Teheran, listened to his crackling, old man's voice and broadcast his words to the world. They described his picturesque garments, the flowing black cape and twisted turban of a Moslem divine.

We were talking a few weeks ago with Dr. Peter B. Neubauer, director of the Council Child Development Center, an agency set up to help 2- to 6-year-olds who are suffering from emotional problems. The center has just added a research department to analyze its experience and derive knowledge helpful to parents, doctors, nurses, teachers, social workers and other representatives of community agencies working with small children.

Many college campuses today are suffering from excess fear and caution, it was declared this week at the Eastern Regional Convention of the American College Public Relations Association in Albany. A panel program on academic freedom, led by four leading college presidents, described this disquieting development on the American campus.

In view of the recent sale of Greenbelt, Md., one of the pioneer ventures in Government-built cooperative housing, and because I had surveyed Greenbelt during a holiday visit, I found the article by Kenneth S. Davis, "A Bigger Role for Farm Co-ops" (Jan. 4), intensely interesting and educative.

FREEPORT, L. I., Jan. 24 -Engine overhauls and paint jobs are the order of the day for seagoing members of Nassau County's police navy, as all units of the department's Long Island Sound and South Shore fleets are prepared to resume watchful patrol during the forthcoming pleasure cruising season.
Borough President John Cashmore submitted yesterday to Budget Director Abraham D. Beame a budget estimate $150,000 below his present year's departmental expenditures.
NEW YORK may be the nation's musical capital, but more and more, as new operas are appearing, they are receiving their first performances elsewhere.
Although the tournament season in this area is still some time away, several days this week promise to be active ones for golf officials, champions, manufacturers and just plain fans.

TO THE EDITOR: I would like to amend John McAndrew's title, "Our Architecture Is Our Portrait" (Jan. 18). The fine modern houses which he admires are beyond the reach of most people. Most of us must compromise for quite ordinary-looking houses and apartments; the occupants inside them, however, may not be ordinary. Architecture is not always our portrait any more than the fine clothes we wear.

Described by Assistant District Attorney Anthony J. Liebler as "the golden girl of cafe society," Diane Harris, 21 years old, of 2 East Eighty-sixth Street, was held yesterday in $25,000 bail as a material witness in the compulsory prostitution case against Minot Frazier Jelke 3d, oleomargarine heir.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Jan. 24 (AP) -- Top-seeded Frank Kovacs, Oakland, Calif., stroked his way into the final of the national professional clay courts tennis championships at the Hollywood Beach Hotel today, but suffered a fall that may force him to default in the final.

BUFFALO, Jan. 24 (UP) -- Villanova's fast-moving basketball team opened a 10-point lead in the first period and then withstood St. Bonaventure's late rally tonight to turn back the Olean (N. Y.) quintet, 74 -- 69, for the second time this season.

WHITHOUT waiting for Arthur E. Summerfield to tackle his new job as Postmaster General, Senators and Representatives began introducing stamp-request bills immediately after the Eighty-third Congress was called to order on Jan. 3.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Lieut. Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, new Eighth Army commander, discussed the Korean military situation with President Eisenhower this morning, two hours after Gen. J. Lawton Collins, Army Chief of Staff, had left for his own inspection tour of the battlefront and conferences with the Far East Command in Tokyo.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Jan. 25 (UP) -- Switzerland's Felix Endrich and his brakeman, Fritz Stoeckli, sped to the 1953 world two-man bobsled racing championship today, with the United States entries finishing seventh and ninth.

LONDON, Jan. 25 -- Wage increases for coal miners, the workers who hold the key to Britain's entire economy, will be one of the critical problems to face Prime Minister Churchill on his arrival in London next Wednesday after his Jamaica vacation.
A plea for the reunion of Christendom was voiced yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral by the Rev. David Gannon of the Graymoor Franciscan Friars of the Atonement, Garrison, N. Y.

If the outside world could watch a new administration easing into power in Washington, our friends and our enemies would have a better understanding not only of the American political process but of the American character. The spectacle is instructive even for the native observer, and most instructive of all, perhaps, for the citizens for whom the change is not a spectacle but an experience.
FLORENCE, Italy, Jan. 24 -- Designers and buyers from the United States and Europe witnessed today the opening of the fifth Italian fashion show organized by G. B. Giorgini, Florence exporter.

ALBANY, Jan. 25 -- Democratic legislative leaders announced today that they would attempt to place the New York Legislature on record as favoring a complete revision of the Federal McCarran-Walter Immigration Law, enacted by Congress last year over the veto of President Truman.

The United States' privately owned merchant fleet of dry cargo and passenger ships is slightly smaller than it was a year ago, but nevertheless it is substantially larger than at any time in the preceding twelve years. Moreover, during this period the nation's foreign commerce has more than doubled, according to a statistical review released yesterday by the National Federation of American Shipping.

GUATEMALA, Jan. 25 -- Farm workers, inflamed by the oratory in the recent Congressional campaign and led by Leftist union leaders, are taking the administration of the agrarian law into their own hands, according to reliable reports reaching here, and are seizing and occupying privately owned lands.

Plans for a gasoline service station, auto laundry and parking lot have been announced in connection with the leasing of a vacant plot of land measuring 300 by 100 feet on the west side of Sherman Avenue, 100 feet north of 161st Street, in the Bronx.

A little while ago someone had observed, while the strains of a pseudo - western ballad floated through the house, that children often benefit by being exposed to music of the masters, and that the winter months -- encouraging indoor pursuits -- offered a splendid opportunity to plant, gently, a little culture where it might take root and, in time, grow.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Jan. 25 (AP) -- A British woman doctor, her husband and their 6-year-old son were hacked to death on their farm last night by Mau Mau terrorists. A native servant also was killed.

Relations between India and the United States will not be cemented in "a military alliance" but will depend upon "Christian fellowship under the Supreme Commander," the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman declared yesterday at Christ Church (Methodist), Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

In an unexpected move to smash the stalemate over arbitration of the bus strike, Theodore W. Kheel, former impartial chairman of the private transit industry, cut short a Bahamas vaca tion yesterday and flew back to New York to confer with strike leaders.

Memo for June -- no cure, is in sight, but it may comfort those who are susceptible to poison ivy to know that scientists at work in a Columbia University laboratory have moved a step nearer the solution of the mystery of why that noxious North American plant causes such suffering.

Jennie Tourel, mezzo-soprano, was the soloist and Paul Hindemith the guest conductor at yesterday's New Friends of Music concert in Town Hall. Miss Tourel concluded her program with the revised version of Mr. Hindemith's song cycle, "Die junge Magd," with the assistance of a sextet from the Philharmonic Chamber Ensemble (two violins, viola, 'cello, flute and clarinet).
The United Hospital Fund suggested yesterday that voluntary hospitals could reduce operating burdens by shifting emphasis from the expensive task of curing the ill to preventive medicine.

ZURICH, Jan. 25 -- Resentment was expressed in Switzerland last week against two statements in the United States implying that the traditional policy of neutrality of Switzerland facilitates the operations of unscrupulous profiteers in smuggling products of vital strategic value into countries behind the Iron Curtain.

PARIS, Jan. 25 -- The French National Assembly opened debate today on France's largest post-war military budget -- the equivalent of $4,057,000,000 -- and heard a warning from Defense Minister Rene Pleven that the Soviet menace was as great as at any time in the post-war period.
