HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 25 -- Thirty-two important movie personalities, whose names were not disclosed, today were charged by Roy Brewer, chairman of the Hollywood American Federation of Labor Film Council, with responsibility for the upsurge in film making abroad by American producers and consequent loss of employment to local workers.

PARIS, Jan. 25 -- One or two points descending in back, balancing the slight forward tilt of doll-size toques and sailors that conceal the hairline, is Legroux's main theme. Delicacy of fabric and workmanship is equaled by that of color: nutshell, blond and caramel tones allied with white or the subtle blues of Chinese porcelain.

Rear Admiral Ellis M. Zacharias. retired expert on Navy intelligence and psychological warfare, proposed before a panel of high school students last night that the United States establish a new psychological warfare and information agency outside the State Department to carry the war of ideas overseas.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 25 -- Mordechai Namir, head of the nine-man secretariat of the Histadrut (General Federation of Labor), has been called on to offer a Solomon's judgment at Kibbutz Ein Harod to decide between the rival claims to the settlement made by the Mapam and Mapai parties.

The trial of Socrates was the theme of a half-hour television drama yesterday afternoon on the "Hall of Fame" at 5 P. M. over N. B. C. video. The play said things that badly need saying in these times; the only pity is that it didn't say them a great deal more effectively.
The 265th anniversary of the birth of Emanuel Swedenborg, Swedish scientist, philosopher and theologian, was celebrated at an interdenominational church service yesterday afternoon.

PARIS, Jan. 25 -- Economic and financial circles here greeted with satisfaction a statement made on Saturday by Minister of Finance Maurice Bourges-Maunoury according to which the Government's aim is to maintain the value of the franc at home and abroad.

ALBANY, Jan 25 -- Following are the conclusions and recommendations in the first report today by the New York State Crime Commission to Governor Dewey, Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein and the Legislature:

If more companies were governed by the philosophy of William B. Given there would be less truth in the engineers' definition of an executive: "A man who doesn't know much of anything giving orders to those who do."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (UP) -- Representative Robert B. Chiperfield, Republican of Illinois, hinting at possible drastic foreign aid cuts, said today that the fate of the program depended on a report by Secretary of State John Foster Dulles on his forthcoming European trip.

Cotton prices in the domestic market tended last week to back and fill within a relatively narrow trading range, and wound up with small net gains. At the close of trading on Friday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were up 15 to 60 cents a bale from the levels of the previous week.

SYRACUSE, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The New York Knickerbockers shattered a pair of winning streaks in resounding fashion tonight walloping the Syracuse Nationals, 97 -- 62, in a National Basketball Association game.

L. Roy Blumenthal's blast at the failure and cost of "do-good" agencies is objective, factual and logical in one respect -- its highlighting of the continued rise in juvenile delinquency Beyond emphasizing that point, his letter and reasoning have little to recommend them.

AMSTERDAM, Jan. 25 -- Algemene Kunstzijde Unie, N. V., of Arnhem has sold privately to Lazard Freres Co. of New York 10,000,000 guilders nominal new common A. K. U. shares at 136 exclusive of the 1952 dividend. The plan is to create against them American certificates of 50 guilders and to get them quoted on the New York stock market.

Cassius C. Mallory has been elected president of the Grace Line to succeed the late R. Ranney Adams. The line also announced yesterday the election by the board of directors of James E. Magner as senior vice president and Ted B. Westfall as treasurer.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- President Eisenhower went to church on his first Sunday in the White House, and occupied a pew near those once used by Presidents Jackson, Polk, Pierce, Cleveland, Buchanan, Grant and Benjamin Harrison.
DAVOS, Switzerland, Jan. 25 (AP) -- A quartet of speedy Dutchmen bettered two world records and captured all four races of the international speed skating meet over the week-end.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 25 -- California business and farm organizations are joining, one by one, a movement aimed at taking away from the Federal Department of Labor the responsibility for supplying agricultural labor and giving the job to the Federal Department of Agriculture.

Bryson Rash, American Broadcasting Company White House correspondent, quoted former President Harry S. Truman yesterday as having said that he was in favor of President Eisenhower's pre-inaugural trip to Korea and that "it probably did some good."

Laurance S. Rockefeller and some of his associates have formed a group with Reaction Motors, Inc., of Rockaway, N. J., to take over Flight Refueling, Inc., of Danbury, Conn., the American subsidiary of Flight Refueling, Ltd., of England, founded by the veteran pilot Sir Alan J. Cobham.

NEW DELHI, Jan. 25 -- With the importation of several hundred tribal dancers from remote hills and jungles India's third Republic Day celebration tomorrow will have an indigenous flavor previously lacking in the annual patriotic festivities of this westernized capital.

John V. Lindsay, president of the New York Young Republican Club, announced yesterday that its board of governors had approved Assemblyman John R. Brook's bill for amendment of the state's election laws to provide for permanent personal registration.

Five women physicians, four of them octogenarians and one in her seventies, were honored for their work in several medical fields yesterday when they received the Elizabeth Blackwell Citations of the New York Infirmary.

OTIS, Mass., Jan. 25 -- With the meet possessing all the trimmings of a national competition, the New York City Ski Council today routed the New Jersey Council by 20.6 seconds in their second annual interstate giant slalom. Smarting from their upset a year ago, the New Yorkers compiled a score of 224.2 against the losers' 244.8.

WASHINGTON Jan. 25 (AP) -- The police expressed the belief today that loneliness and thwarted ambition had brought about the death of John C. Montgomery, 41-year-old State Department aide who was found hanged early Saturday.

SOUTH NYACK, N. Y., Jan. 25 -- The air of tranquil permanence of this community is deceptive, now that the New York State Thruway is due soon to pass through on its great course from Buffalo to New York. People who have lived here for many years, and others of more recent arrival, are just beginning to realize the effects that construction of the Rockland County segment of the $500,000,000 highway will have.

MILWAUKEE, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Jack Kramer broke Frank Sedgman's two-match winning streak tonight by whipping the Australian star in straight sets, 8 -- 6, 6 -- 1, before a capacity crowd of 3,600 at the Milwaukee Auditorium.

MONTREAL, Jan. 25 -- Indian drums beat out an optimistic tone at Caughnawaga today as Canada's Iroquois Indians held a powwow with their lawyer to finalize plans for their $1,000,000 claim against the State of Vermont.

CHICAGO, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Some 800 members of five railway unions struck the Chicago Great Western Railway today because of more than 600 unsettled claims and grievances. The disputes range from pay rates to sanitary conditions on cabooses.

MAFALALLA, Mozambique, Jan. 25 -- Witch doctoring is illegal in Portuguese East Africa, yet, like moonshining in the past in the United States, the profession is popular. Having learned the whereabouts of an eminent practitioner, this correspondent, in company with a native guide, paid a call on one.

The foreign exchange market continued quiet during the past week, with spot sterling displaying a strong undertone throughout and the Canadian dollar fluctuating within a narrow range on light dealings.
LONDON, Monday, Jan. 26 -- The liner Empress of Canada, ablaze at a Liverpool pier since 4:20 o'clock yesterday afternoon, capsized shortly after 1:30 o'clock this morning.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The Federal Trade Commission announced today the start of its second action against the maker of Chesterfield cigarettes for alleged "false and misleading" advertising.
BALBOA HEIGHTS, C. Z., Jan. 25 -- There is little likelihood that any change will be made in the tolls charged at the Panama Canal, at least for several years, according to informed sources here.

INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Jan. 25 -- Harry S. Truman marked the first Sunday since he left the White House and became a private citizen with a brisk morning walk through the familiar streets of his home town. He spent the afternoon reading newspapers and helping Mrs. Truman straighten out their home.

Under threat of picketing by the American Legion, some West Coast theatres have canceled scheduled showings of Charles Chaplin's latest picture, "Limelight." The ostensible reason for Legion pressure is that doubts have been raised as to whether Mr. Chaplin, a well-known Britisher who has lived here some forty years, is eligible for readmission to this country under the immigration laws.

A fundamental reorganization of the entire structure of elementary education to meet the challenge of television and help solve the teacher shortage problem is advocated in the annual report published today by the Educational Testing Service of Princeton, N. J.

CHICAGO, Jan. 25 -- Sharp price cutting that swept the country's retail beef markets last week, following similar reductions in prices paid by meat packers for cattle at the stockyards here, was viewed today as probably the most encouraging news in several years for the American housewife and other consumers.

While the nation was giving more for philanthropic purposes in 1952 than in the preceding year, New Yorkers were more inquisitive than they had been since 1946 about local philanthropic agencies seeking financial contributions.

" Touchstone" will reach Broadway Feb. 12. Although no house had been designated officially, it was thought likely that the Golden would be the destination of the William Stucky play that Elaine Perry is presenting. On Saturday night it will wind up a Philadelphia engagement. From there it will be sent to New Haven Feb. 4.
Billy Loes, who established himself as a major league pitcher last year, became the twenty-fourth Dodger to sign his contract, Buzzie Bavasi, Brooklyn vice president, disclosed yesterday.

At the Copenhagen Restaurant, 3 East Fifty-second Street, New Yorkers are being introduced to one of Denmark's most delightful customs, the smorrebrod. Not to be confused with the Swedish smorgasbord, the Danish version consists of open sandwiches, usually consumed with schnapps and a beer chaser, often at lunch or as an after-the-theatre supper.
CALCUTTA, India, Jan. 25 (Reuters) -- Nalini Ranjan Sarkar, prominent indian politician and economist, died of a heart attack at his home here tonight at the age of 70.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 25 -- It was evident today in the wake of the National Football League's annual meeting that the circuit's club-owners are firmly convinced that professional football is headed toward an era of great prosperity.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Women active last fall in the Eisenhower campaign left the capital after the inauguration with a year's work mapped out for them by Bertha S. Adkins, assistant chairman of the Republican National Committee and director of its Women's Division.

ALBANY, Jan. 25 -- The State Crime Commission urged the Legislature today to establish a permanent Commission of Investigation that would give Governor Dewey and his successors a powerful new weapon to root out organized crime and political corruption in the state.

Sales of the International Harvester Company exceeded the billion dollar mark for the second consecutive year, but along with earnings were under the previous year's figures, the annual report for the fiscal year ended last Oct. 31 disclosed today.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Jan. 25 -- One hundred of the 250 charter members of the Classic Car Club of America, founded last summer, held their first national convention and blow-out today at Glen Island Casino. Some arrived in "classic" cars, but a majority traveled by train, air or in heated cars built to production-line specifications of the last three years.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 25 -- The feeling was growing last week that material controls on steel may be relaxed soon. It was too early to test the rumor that controls will be junked completely. Some sources believe materials in excess of military requirements will be open-ended after they have filled defense priority orders.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- A private American mission in Istanbul, Turkey, is slowly bringing to light a rare array of Byzantine mosaic and fresco painting concealed for centuries behind plaster and whitewash.

TOKYO, Monday, Jan. 26 -- Chinese Communist infantry, dug deep in bunkers and trenches, beat off yesterday a United Nations raid that early reports indicated was the biggest assault of its type by the Allied armies in Korea this year.

BERTRAND ARTHUR WILLIAM RUSSELL will soon be 81. But his advanced years, a burden most lesser men his age find sorely trying, in no way diminish Lord Russell's enthusiasm and energy. Last Dec. 15 he was married for the fourth time. Today the latest in the long series of books which has flowed almost continuously from his facile pen since 1896 is published.

Not the mechanical and scientific achievements but the great lives that have been lived and the great ideas that are abroad in the world are what is right with the world, the Rev. Dr. Lowell R. Ditzen declared yesterday at the Riverside Church.

Dr. Aryeh L. Kubovy, who spent seventeen months behind the Iron Curtain as Israel's Minister to Czechoslovakia and Poland, and recently was declared persona non grate by these satellite states, emphasized yesterday that the Jewish people and Israel were not the "only targets" of the Communist rulers.

The New York Americans of the American Soccer League advanced to the quarter-finals of the United States Soccer Football Association challenge cup play by beating the Eintracht Sports Club of the German-American League, 3 -- 1, at Sterling Oval, the Bronx, yesterday. At half-time, the victors held a 2-1 lead.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, retiring chief of the Central Intelligence Agency, said today that the United States intelligence service was as good as any in the world -- except possibly that of the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (UP) -- Representative August H. Andresen, Republican of Minnesota, said today that he would urge Ezra T. Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, to decrease imports of dried milk as an alternative to cutting support prices on butter.

One goes to a concert by Doda Conrad, who gave a song recital last night in Town Hail, for the program and the interpretive intention rather than for the singing! And this is unnecessary, because one has the-impression that a correction of certain vocal defects by Mr. Conrad would by no means be impossible, and would greatly improve this highly intelligent artist's means of communication.
Reliable sources report that the jumper is counted high among the favorites of the young American girl. It is easy to wear, and it can be adapted to so many uses.

CHICAGO, Jan. 25 -- Marked weakness developed in the grain market in the last few days, following a show of strength for a week or more during which there was heavy short covering as well as considerable investment buying. New buying however, was slim on the rallies, and the markets were vulnerable to local selling.

LONDON, Jan. 25 -- While the rising trend of the stock markets was checked a little here and there in the last week, the greater confidence and increased activity recently displayed has, on the whole, been very well maintained. One of the things that chilled sentiment a little was the presentation of the supplementary estimates of Government expenditure to the tune of something like 63,000,000.
Nine new films, including imports from England, Australia and Poland, will arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

MONTE CARLO, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Maurice Gatsonides, a 41-year-old Dutch journalist, won this year's Monte Carlo auto rally, officials disclosed tonight after laboring through more than 10,000 arithmetical calculations.

Dean James A. Pike of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine voiced objection yesterday to the recent exclusion of the Planned Parenthood Committee of Mothers Health Centers from the Welfare and Health Council of New York City.
RYE, N. Y., Jan. 25 -- John R. Howard Jr., noted hospital administrator and former superintendent of New York Hospital, died today in his home at 76 Overlook Place. He was 72 years old.

A request last week by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York that Cuba and Venezuela drop their demand for separate consular invoices on all imports was criticized here yesterday by Delfin Paez, Venezuelan Consul General.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (UP) -- Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of New York, said today he would introduce legislation tomorrow proposing a three-year emergency immigration program to admit an additional 328,000 Europeans to this country.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- James C. Hagerty, White House Press Secretary, explained on a television program today why President Eisenhower had decided to let television and radio into his press conferences.

A Brooklyn man who, in twenty-eight years, has amassed a total of 103 arrests on charges involving drinking was remanded yesterday to the newly established Homeless Men's Court on Rikers Island after he had been described as "exactly the sort of person this court was created to help."

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 25 -- Russian trawlers are repeatedly violating Swedish territorial waters around the Baltic isle of Gotland, according to Gotland fishermen who are urging that the Swedish Coast Guard drive them off. At the end of a day's fishing the Russian trawlers anchor for the night well inside the three-mile limit, the Swedes say.

We are confident that the Labor and Appropriations Committees of Congress will be interested in the quiet, unpublicized progress of the office of General Counsel George Bott of the National Labor Relations Board in the handling of cases.

If Charles E. Wilson is confirmed as Secretary of Defense, as he probably will be early this week, it will be important that his assistants, the Under Secretary of Defense and the heads of the Departments of the Navy, Army and Air, be also confirmed without delay.

DETROIT, Jan. 25 (UP) -- Bud MacPherson's third-period goal enabled the Montreal Canadiens to tie the Detroit Red Wings, 3 -- 3, tonight at Olympia before 15,307 fans, the largest crowd of the season.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 25 -- Tyge Rothe won today's frostbite championship regatta at the Indian Harbor Yacht Club for his first victory of the season. Sailing Skid, Rothe took the spring championship series opener with 45 points.

Your complimentary editorial of Jan. 20 regarding the Citizens Budget Commission's plan for a Transit Authority contains one reservation. You express the opinion that the commission conceded too much delay in achieving self-sustaining operation "in order to make an authority politically palatable."

" Bernardine" is planning to move from the Playhouse March 2 or go on tour if the local housing shortage hasn't been alleviated by that date, Stanley Gilkey, general manager, confirmed yesterday. Presented and staged by Guthrie McClintic for the late Irving L. Jacobs, the Mary Chase comedy has been residing at the Playhouse since Oct. 16.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Former Vice President Alben W. Barkley announced today that he would start a new career next Sunday as a weekly television commentator for the National Broadcasting Company. The program will be called, "Meet the Veep."

In its first change of ownership in seventy years, the property at 14 Reade Street, at the corner of Elk Street, has been sold by the heirs of Richard W. Block to a client of Moses Kooperstein who resold it to Meyer Feldman for investment. It is improved with a seven-story store and office building and was sold through William A. White Sons, brokers.

Nearly 20,000 men, women and children converged on Pier 84, at West Forty-fourth Street and the Hudson River, yesterday to view the new 30,000-ton Italian luxury liner Andrea Doria, which arrived here Friday on her maiden voyage.

Erna Berger, soprano, gave the first of a series of three song recitals yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. The artist was heard in an all-Shubert program composed of offerings demanding highly varied types of approach, a wide range of moods, and much versatility in the treatment of color effects.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Jan. 25 -- Public investigation of universities is legitimate, but the interference of any outside group with the proper functions of the university must be resisted, Dr. Lewis Webster Jones, president of Rutgers University, said yesterday.

Shipment has begun of transistors -- tiny gadgets using a speck of germanium to replace the familiar vacuum tube -- to more than fifteen manufacturers of hearing aids, it was announced over the week-end by Raytheon Manufacturing Company of Waltham, Mass.

A recommendation to Mayor Impellitteri and the Board of Estimate for creation of a New York transportation authority with discretionary power to meet ordinary operating deficits of the municipal transit lines either by fare rises or requisition against the city treasury is under consideration by the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey.
ROME, Jan. 25 -- After having passed a peaceful night, Pope Pius was somewhat better today, it was reported at the Vatican.
Unusual items that might be used for decoration in a contemporary room are included in a new collection of Japanese imports at Kogei, 23 East Sixty-seventh Street.
Archbishop Joachim Souris led 400 members of the Greek Orthodox Church, lined along Pier 1, North River, yesterday in the fortieth annual celebration of the Feast of the Epiphany at the Battery.

There is a serious effort to extend the term of office of members of the House of Representatives from two to four years. For that purpose bills have been offered in Congress, notably one by my friend and distinguished colleague, Frederic Coudert of New York.

The police have set up a detail of twenty-five detectives, chosen from ten West Side precincts because of their familiarity with the waterfront and its habitues, to prevent a renewal of the pier gang wars that were described at the State Crime Commission's public hearings last week.

MIAMI, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Mary Lena Faulk of Thomasville, Ga., won the Helen Lee Doherty women's amateur golf tournament for the second straight year today, defeating Barbara Romack of Sacramento. Calif.. 5 and 4, in the thirty-six-hole final.

Work stoppages in New York State last year lost only 0.32 per cent of the available working time, comparing favorably with a national figure of 0.5 per cent, State Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi said yesterday.
Stewart B. Iglehart of Old Westbury, L. I., and Delray Beach, Fla., Cecil Smith of San Antonio, Tex., and Robert Skene of Beverly Hills, Calif., continue as outdoor polo's top men.

A major step toward working self-government was taken yesterday in Vietnam, the largest of the three states of Indo-China. For the first time there was a nation-wide popular election. This was a first step, and that only, since the voters balloted on the municipal basis.

Dr. James Bryant Conant, president of Harvard University, recently named United States High Commissioner for Germany, will have his new book, "Education and Liberty," published by Harvard University Press on Feb. 9. Subtitled "The Role of the Schools in a Modern Democracy," the work assesses current and coming problems in education and proposes for high schools and colleges a "farseeing" ten-point program.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Jan. 25 -- The second longest ski jump in Bear Mountain's history was recorded today by a 34-year-old Brattleboro (Vt.) athlete, Merrill (Mezzy) Barber, who leaped 167 feet. The feat helped Barber retire the annual Norsemen invitation trophy.

JUST before the Hall of Fame elections, Bing Miller spoke out with harsh bitterness. The one-time outfield star of the Athletics isn't normally a bitter man. He's a happy-go-lucky chap whose greatest pleasure in life comes from needling his boss, Jimmy Dykes. Manager Dykes constantly dismisses Miller as coach of the A's and Bing just as constantly ignores him.
When teachers receive only $3,000 to $5,200 a year and their students earn as much as $7,800, there is bound to be a problem.
Plans to combat anti-Semitic outbreaks on the lower East Side were discussed at a meeting yesterday afternoon of a hundred representatives of religious, educational and civic groups.

A "conscious determination on the part of retailers and manufacturers to become more advertising-minded" was credited yesterday with the phenomenal growth of jewelry sales in 1952. Albert E. Haase, president of the Jewelry Industrial Council, thus reported yesterday to its seventh annual meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

ALBANY, Jan. 25 -- Governor Dewey will meet his chief legislative and political advisers tomorrow for discussions that may determine his Administration's policy on continuation of state rent controls, New York City's fiscal program and other controversial measures to be considered by the Legislature at this years session.
TOKYO, Monday, Jan, 26 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,506, for Sunday:

G. Diehl Mateer Jr. of Philadelphia, ranked second nationally, retained the honors in the seventh annual Harry Cowles invitation squash racquets tournament, defeating Carter Fergusson, also of Philadelphia, in the final round at the Harvard Club yesterday.

Rudolf G. Sonneborn, national chairman of the United Israel Appeal, asserted yesterday that Israel's serious economic position had been caused, in large measure, by the decline in philanthropic funds received from this country.

Analysts of Soviet affairs surmised yesterday that the Kremlin, looking for kernels of truth on which it could build details of the alleged "Jewish Zionist murder plot" against high Soviet figures, might hit upon three possibilities.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Close associates do not expect President Eisenhower to send to the Senate the nominations of Robert T. Stevens as Secretary of the Army and Harold E. Talbott as Secretary of the Air Force until the two men reach understandings with Senate leaders on how to wind up their private affairs.

It is the calling of every Christian to "radiate and reflect the light which comes into our lives from Christ," the Rev. Dr. Louis Saunders declared in a sermon yesterday morning at the Park Avenue Christian Church at Eighty- fifth street.

MORGAN CITY, La.. Jan. 25 (UP) -- A spectacular million-dollar fire, fanned by a brisk wind and visible as far as fifty miles away, raged out of control tonight at a well drilling platform in the Gulf of Mexico ten miles off the Louisiana coast.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 25 (AP) -- Lloyd Mangrum shot a spectacular eight-under-par 63 to take charge of the $10,000 Phoenix open golf tournament today with a fifty-four-hole total of 202.

BOSTON, Jan, 25 (UP) -- Rookie Defenseman Warren Godfrey of the Boston Bruins handed what proved to be the winning goal to the New York Rangers tonight by sinking a shot into his own net as the Blues won, 2 -- 1, in a National Hockey League game before 8,189 fans at the Boston Garden.

SEOUL, Korea, Monday, Jan. 26 (AP) -- The Third Division said yesterday that ninety-two members of the Sixty-fifth Regiment -- not Eighty-eight as previously announced -- had been convicted by general court-martial of refusal to enter combat and had been sentenced to prison.

Nine outstanding Soviet physicians accused of having plotted the deaths of Soviet political and military leaders languish in jail. "Plots" to wreck the Soviet system have been detected and exposed over and over again ever since Stalin rose to power. But this one is different.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., Jan. 25 -- The new village-owned escalator at the elevated Long Island Rail Road station here will carry passengers upward only beginning tomorrow, according to Mayor W. Harry Lister.

The public assistance case load continued to fall last month, Henry L. McCarthy, Commissioner of Welfare, reported yesterday. Last month 267,306 persons received aid, a drop of 670 from the previous month.

In his twentieth and final annual report to the Board of Overseers of Harvard University, Dr. James Bryant Conant says in a few words what educators throughout the length and breadth of this land are thinking today:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Careful advance blueprinting of the nation's manpower needs was urged on Congress today lest democracy, in its insistence on letting each citizen choose his own job, "lose out in world leadership." The plea was in a report by two University of Minnesota professors on a study made for the Senate Labor-Management subcommittee of the last Congress.

MADRID, Jan. 25--Spanish authorities were reported today to have decided to restore to bullfighting its "classical purity" by checking widespread practices that have turned what is known here as the "national fiesta" into a mere business enterprise.

Celebrated for her stinging wit, Dorothy Parker has fashioned a drama with Arnaud d'Usseau labeled "The Ladies of the Corridor." Described as "a tender play," it swirls around widows and divorcees living in a fashionable New York hotel.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 25 -- Two Nobel Prize winners will be members of a team of fifteen scientists from seven countries who will go to India early in February to exchange the latest medical knowledge with Indian physicians. The project, under the joint auspices of the United Nations World Health Organization and the Unitarian Service Committee, will include five United States medical men.

Low, sweeping lines reflecting European styling are incorporated in the redesigned 1953 Centennial line of cars presented yesterday by the Studebaker Corporation. The cars are expected to be put on display in dealer showrooms in this city within two weeks.

The business prospects for the first six months of this year are good, according to a survey of eighty-five men's wear stores throughout the country conducted by the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers. Fifty-five of the stores expect dollar volume to increase 1 to 15 per cent over the 1952 period, seventeen refused to make a forecast and thirteen of the outlets predict declines of from 3 to 10 per cent.

Local 252 of the Transport Workers Union, whose contracts with three bus lines serving 45,000 daily passengers on the south shore of Long Island expire at midnight Saturday, made public last night its offer to arrive at a contract by arbitration.

A performance of "Carmen" was staged in concert form at Hunter College Auditorium Saturday evening with the "Oldtimers" Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Enrico Leide. The orchestra was provided by a grant from the Music Performance Trust Fund of the Recording Industry in cooperation with Local 802, American Federation of Musicians.
NEW HAVEN, Jan. 25 -- Complete renovation of the interior of Connecticut Hall, the oldest building on the Yale campus, will begin next week.

Art exhibitions, both group and one-man shows, continue to supply the New York gallery goer with a wide variety of attractions. Among other events this week, the American Abstract Artists will hold their seventeenth annual exhibition, this time at Artists Equity, 13 East Sixty-seventh Street, and the organization is putting on simultaneously a memorial exhibition of paintings by A. E. Gallatin, who was closely identified with the group.

Within the next few days the International Wheat Council will convene in Washington to begin deliberations on a question which vitally concerns the direction of American farm policy. That is the question of whether the international wheat agreement of 1949, scheduled to expire on July 31, next, is to be extended, presumptively for another four years.

Fedora Barbieri will sing her first local Santuzza on Feb. 3 when Mascagni's "Cavalleria Rusticana" is presented at the Metropolitan Opera House. The same cast also will see the seasonal bow of Jussi Bjoerling in the role of Turridu.

The report from New Delhi that Indians are upset, and even see a change in American policy toward India, because Ambassador Chester Bowles is going to be replaced, provides food for thought. It indicates that outsiders have not grasped the first principles of the American system of diplomacy.

CAIRO, Jan. 25 -- A decree law enabling the Egyptian Government to proclaim a state of general mobilization in the event of war or threat of war or international tension appeared in the Government's official journal today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 25 -- Two major problems confronting American scholars are how they may serve a free nation under partial mobilization, and how they may reconcile "the essential tradition of dissent with the need for national unity in the face of danger," Dr. James Bryant Conant, retiring president of Harvard University, said today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 25 -- Fuad Koprulu, Turkish Foreign Minister, departed today for Athens after a five-day visit to Yugoslavia that resulted in progress toward a Balkan entente among Greece, Turkey and Yugoslavia.

Settlement of a strike of 347 maintenance and office employes of the Jamaica Water Supply Company, which serves 90,000 customers in Queens and 15,000 in Nassau, was announced last night. The strike began Jan 14.

SEOUL, Korea, Jan. 25 -- Gen. James A. Van Fleet, retiring Eighth Army commander, said tonight that South Korean troops could man the entire Korean front unassisted within a year, provided "the high command wants to remain on the line we hold now."

Officials at Vermont Academy in Saxtons River, Vt., claim they have the "granddaddy" of winter carnivals. It was at the academy on Lincoln's Birthday, 1909, that the first carnival was held, thereby pre-dating the inaugural Dartmouth Carnival by a year.

A mature program of propaganda aimed at the eventual liberation of national groups behind the Iron Curtain was advocated yesterday by Representative Charles J. Kersten, Republican of Wisconsin, who told an audience of Ukrainian-Americans that such an approach was "the only road to peace."

BALTIMORE, Jan. 25 -- A liver and white English springer spaniel, Mrs. Joseph F. Barthold's Ch. Wilmar's Whirlaway, from Norristown, Pa., became best in show tonight in the new-style event of the Maryland Kennel Club.

Plans for the retirement of 35,054 shares of Standard Power and Light Corporation's $7 cumulative preferred stock have been approved, the corporation announced yesterday. The price would be $212.31 a share, made up of the $110 call price and accumulated dividends to Dec. 31 of $102.31 a share.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Hiram Bingham, chairman of the Loyalty Review Board, himself headed the panel that decided that John Carter Vincent, a career diplomat, was a security risk and recommended that he be dismissed from the service.

Mr. and Mrs. James N. Dunlop of New York and Driftwood, Point O'Woods, L. I., will give a reception tonight in their home at 535 Park Avenue in behalf of the conservation of the Sunken Forest in Fire Island Beach, L. I. Mr. Dunlop is chairman of the Sunken Forest Committee, which is seeking to preserve this miniature wilderness.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee and the men who served with him on the Senate Crime Investigating Committee introduced eight more bills today de signed to follow through on committee recommendations.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The Senate confirmed tonight three more of President Eisenhower's nominees for key posts in the Department of Commerce. They were:

The Public Service Commission's report on the New York City bus strike issues is a masterpiece of poker-faced political neutrality, careful not to embarrass any party to the dispute. Nevertheless some valuable fact-finding has been presented. It is plain, for one thing, that unproductive time and builtin overtime, along with other featherbedding, can be cut.

A sparkling rally over the last three rounds earned Joey Giambra, 156 1/2 pounds, of Buffalo, the decision over Danny Womber, 151 1/2, of Chicago last night in a ten-round battle at Eastern Parkway Arena, Brooklyn. The decision was unanimous.
Robert H. Briggs has been made manager of the chemical sales division of Charles Pfizer Co., Inc.

BOSTON, Jan. 26 -- The Massachusetts House of Representatives today killed an attempt to introduce a resolution inviting a United States Senate committee to Massachusetts to investigate communism in universities. By a roll call vote of 99 to 118, the House refused to suspend rules so that the resolution offered by Representative Joseph D. Ward, Democrat of Fitchburg, could be taken up.

WASHINGTON, Jan 26 (AP) -- The military forces have been authorized to treat as a deserter anyone who is found absent without leave with the intent to dodge hazardous duty or to escape military service altogether.

SEOUL, Korea, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Gen. J. Lawton Collins, Army Chief of Staff, and Gen Mark W. Clark, United Nations Commander, arrived today for a meeting with Gen. James A. Van Fleet, retiring Eighth Army Commander.

GAINESVILLE, Fla., Jan. 26 -The fact that people in this country are living longer and extending their period of optimum performance should emphasize the need for positive health programs as a national resource, the third annual Southern Conference on Gerontology was told today.

ALBANY, Jan. 26 -- The Legislature approved unanimously tonight and sent to Governor Dewey a bill that will extend all 1952 truck registrations and licenses until March 2. They are now scheduled to expire next Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The Senate confirmed today, by a vote of 77 to 6, the nomination of Charles E. Wilson, president on leave of the General Motors Corporation, to be Secretary of Defense in President Eisenhower's Cabinet.

Paul Loyonnet, French pianist, who has not given a New York concert in six years, returned last night to Carnegie Hall to present the first of three programs he is devoting to Beethoven, a composer to whom he has given "thirty years of work, research and meditation."

PARIS, Jan. 26 -- In preliminary talks with the French, British officials have proposed limited technical cooperation between British forces and the projected European army. Their proposals fall far short of the close and contractual association between Britain and the European Defense Community that the French Government seeks to insure ratification of the European Defense Community Treaty by the French Parliament.

MALAKAL, the Sudan, Jan. 25 -- The chiefs of the Shilluk tribe, gathered near here yesterday for one of the periodic sessions of their courts, declared emphatically that they wanted the British administration to stay in the southern provinces of the Sudan until the people were equipped to hold their own with the northerners in a self-governing Sudan.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -Following is the 77-to-6 roll-call by which the Senate today confirmed the nomination of Charles E. Wilson as secretary of Defense:

Reflecting the record sales volume last year of National Biscuit Company, net profit increased to $17,819,160 from $16,202,212 earned the year before, according to preliminary, unaudited figures issued yesterday by George H. Coppers, president.

" Wherever She Goes," an Australian-made musical biography featuring a child actress, Suzanne Parrett; Eileen Joyce and the London Philharmonia Orchestra, which arrives at the Beekman Theatre, is today's lone film newcomer.

ALBANY, Jan. 26 (UP) -- Governor Dewey was asked tonight to step in and settle cemetery wage disputes in the New York City area. Attendants in seven Protestant and Jewish cemeteries have been on strike for higher pay since Jan. 7.
PARIS, Jan. 20 -- Sophisticated abstract designs for daytime, natural flowers on evening fabrics, herald the return to fashion of prints this spring.

The case has been proved for a permanent state commission, to be called perhaps a Commission of Investigation, to make a continuing study of the relation between crime and government. The public had ample evidence in the testimony adduced by the State Crime Commission, in hearings upstate and in the city, and in the earlier picture drawn by the Kefauver inquiry.

MANILA, Tuesday, Jan. 27 (AP) -- A United States scientist said Monday that he had located the main band of a newly discovered tribe of pygmies who are leading a primitive bow-and-arrow existence and practicing polygamy.

WESTPORT, Conn., Jan. 26 -- Mrs. Montgomery Evans, a 30-year-old brunette, was found strangled in her ranch-house home on Woodside Avenue here at 9:30 o'clock tonight by three Westport policemen who had gone to investigate a report of her death.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 26 -Close friends of Harry S. Truman are investigating at least a half a dozen offers from publishers for publication rights of the former President's memoirs, Mr. Truman said here today.

Following is the section of the speech by the Right Rev. Horace W. B. Donegan, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of New York, before the Church Club of New York at the Plaza Hotel last night it which he described how "New York has fallen on evil days":

A minority stockholders' application for the appointment of a temporary receiver for the $50,000,000 R. K. O. Pictures Corporation and its subsidiary, R. K. O.-Radio Pictures, Inc., was withdrawn yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Henry Clay Greenberg.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Jan. 26 -- An experiment in televising educational programs in secondary and elementary schools was started here and in near-by Highland Park today by the New Jersey Department of Education.

A quiet decline took place in the stock market yesterday, with softness generally centered in some of the automotives and building materials issues, while several lower price railroads showed considerable strength.
FARMINGDALE, L. I., Jan. 26 -- A top secret midget submarine that might play a vital role in the guided missile program is being developed here by the Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 26 -- Communist leaders in this country apparently are experiencing some difficulty in getting party functionaries to operate subtly instead of exercising direct control.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The Atomic Energy Commission announced today that it would start a new series of tests of "new and improved nuclear devices" in March at its huge proving ground in the wastelands near Las Vegas, Nev.

ALBANY, Jan. 26 -- Governor Dewey proposed to the Legislature tonight that the state-operated institutes of applied arts and sciences be turned over to the cities in which they are located to be operated as community colleges under the State University program.
SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 26 (AP) -- The Melbourne conference to try to save the 1956 Olympic Games for Melbourne reached no decision in a four-hour session today and adjourned until Feb. 2.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Despite a vast step-up in steel output for defense, the Defense Production Administration questioned today whether the industry is providing enough mill capacity to turn the ingots into the usable steel products essential in wartime.

Ships now in the American merchant marine could be replaced only at a cost four and a half times that of the present vessels, and not one cargo or passenger ship is being constructed in the United States for private ownership or operation because of uncertainties involved in Government aid, James A. Farrell said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- James Mc I. Henderson, Director of Rent Stabilization urged today that the Federal rent control program be extended at least fourteen months beyond its expiration date of April 30. He suggested amendments to prohibit local authorities from decontrolling "critical" defense housing areas.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- President and Mrs. Eisenhower will hold a "diplomatic circle," not a "diplomatic reception," tomorrow afternoon.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26 (UP) -- Newspaper advertising executives today heard an appeal for the use of simple words and language in advertising slogans, and a prediction that classified advertising and the men who sell it may provide an answer to newspapers' present problems.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26 -- A demand that the United States "develop positive and long-range international economic policies that will help our associates in the free world to stand firmly on their own feet" was voiced today by Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association of America.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (UP) -It would cost about $11,000,000 to set up a typical theatre television system in the New York-Washington area, the Federal Communications Commission was advised today.

For the first three months of its fiscal year net income of Black Decker Manufacturing Company was $674,991, or $1.69 a share against $608,936, or $1.56 a share in the last 1951 quarter, it was reported at the annual meeting yesterday.

Civic groups have recently voiced the idea that a city manager should be installed to run municipal affairs under the political dictates of the Mayor and the Board of Estimate; the idea being that a more efficient and businesslike government would result. I question whether such an experiment under the present municipal set-up would fulfill expectations.
PARIS, Tuesday, Jan. 27 (UP) -The French National Assembly overwhelmingly approved France's biggest post-war military budget early today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (UP) -- The engineer of the runaway express train that plowed into Union Station here Jan. 15 said today that he "never touched the brakes" from the time he had left Baltimore until he reached the outskirts of Washington.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- A series of manpower economy orders issued from the Pentagon is reducing the size of Army infantry divisions 7 per cent from that of two years ago. The reduction is 1,362 men.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -Harvey Machine Co., Inc., of Torrance, Calif., announced plans today to build a $20,000,000 rolling mill for the production of sheet, strip and circular aluminum.

Four of the eighteen Justices of the Domestic Relations Court came to the support of the child vandalism bill yesterday when they filed a "minority opinion" with the Board of Estimate urging passage of the measure.
The fifty-seventh annual rodeo in Fort Worth, Tex., will be televised from the Will Rogers Memorial Coliseum on Saturday afternoon from 3 to 6 o'clock by the National Broadcasting Company network.

LOURENCO MARQUES, Mozambique, Jan. 26 -- There are no visible signs of racial segregation here in Portuguese East Africa, a situation unlike that prevailing in the neighboring Union of South Africa, where apartheid is the rule, and in Southern Rhodesia, where a similar theory applies, if not so blatantly.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The Dutch decision to suspend Mutual Security aids involves $15,000,000, tentatively assigned it.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Gen. Nathan F. Twining, vice chief of staff of the Air Force, said today the Russians were believed to have completed the build-up of their long range bomber force and to be planning to provide it with faster planes.
ALBANY, Jan. 26 -- Democratic legislative leaders restated their opposition tonight to any relaxation of state rent controls as upstate Republican pressure for a substantial liberalization grew.

Commodities continued inactive on the New York exchanges yesterday with the exception of rubber, which showed an increase in volume. Prices closed lower in rubber, potatoes, wool, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, cocoa and zinc. Sugar ended irregular, lead and tin were unchanged and coffee and hides were higher.

For the second consecutive year the Bendix Aviation Corporation in its fiscal year ended on last Sept. 30 accomplished an expansion in sales equivalent to approximately half the previous year's volume, the total of $508,701,892 comparing with $340,540,415.

The following excerpts are from testimony given yesterday at the State Crime Commission hearings into waterfront conditions. They deal mainly with the finances of a trucking company and two collection companies operating in the Washington Market area, the finances of Local 202, of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A. F. L., and relations between the companies and the local.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -The investigating subcommittee of the Senate Committee on Government Operations put a top secret label today on a study of charges that the United States had paid Iron Curtain areas inflated prices for defense material.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 26 -- The National Rural Electric Cooperative Association began its second decade of annual meetings today, with nearly 4,000 persons on hand, in an atmosphere of uncertainty over intentions of the new Republican Administration concerning public power and rural electrification.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Indo-China, Jan. 26 -- Premier Nguyen Van Tam appears to have won the gamble he took in staging the first nation-wide elections ever held in Vietnam. Only partial results of Sunday's voting are available, but it already is clear that the balloting represents a success for the Vietnamese Government.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Jan. 26 -- The Netherlands, which has received almost $1,000,000,000 in direct United States assistance since the Marshall Plan started in 1948 has decided to renounce dollar grants for the year ending next June. A formal announcement to this effect is expected tomorrow.

It is too bad that American ex-Presidents are not provided with something like the poet Horace's Sabine Farm to which they might retire in dignified ease after their terms of office were finished. Our earlier Presidents did have something of the sort, although they usually had to provide it themselves.

HONOLULU, Jan. 26 -- A defense motion for a mistrial in the Smith Act case here was denied today by Federal Judge Jon Wiig and testimony was continued by the eighth Government witness, Robert Kempa, who has declared that he was a member of the Communist party of Hawaii from 1946 to 1950 and has identified four of seven defendants.

Increasing support by export shippers for a move to have outbound steamship conferences make their tariff rates (shipping charges) available to foreign traders was reported yesterday by the National Export Traffic League.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 26 (UP) -- Maurice S. Weinzelbaum, Chicago attorney who flew here after borrowing $1,000,000 from friends and business associates, said tonight he would remain in Rio until the "tremendous misunderstanding'' was cleared up.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (UP) -- The Senate Finance Committee approved Mrs. Ivy Baker Priest today to be Treasurer of the United States after gallantly suggesting that her picture -- as well as her name -- should appear on United States paper currency.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 26 -- Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., in his first official action as United States representative to the United Nations, asked J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, today to make a full field investigation of the 144 members of the delegation who were serving under him.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES The task of preserving and extending our civil liberties, while taking due cognizance of the needs of national security, has never been an easy one. In this fear-ridden and war-haunted year of 1953 it is especially difficult. Therefore it is incumbent upon all those who have a genuine attachment to the ideals of civil liberty to strive for the greatest clarity of thought and sobriety of action.

Drafts owed United States exporters by Brazilian traders continued to increase last month, rising $2,200,000 to a new high of $202,900,000, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The data, based on reports from fifteen banks which participate in a monthly export credit survey, showed that new drawings on Brazilian importers as well as drafts paid by them rose moderately to $7,100,000, and $4,900,000, respectively.
Theodore W. Kheel, former impartial chairman of the private transit industry, made substantial headway yesterday toward an arbitration pact to end the twenty-seven-day bus strike.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -Secretary of the Interior Douglas McKay said today he favored a policy of "letting local people help themselves," without Federal intervention, in developing the nation's natural resources.

Richard L. Gelb of the home club, playing with an allowance of ten, rallied yesterday to defeat James E. Osborn 2d, a club-mate, in the second round of the annual Bulldog squash tennis handicap tournament at the Yale Club. Osborn, also playing with a 10-point handicap, bowed, 3 -- 15, 15 -- 12, 17 -- 14.

The Glenn L. Martin Aircraft Manufacturing Company has freed itself of debt to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation within eighteen months of a financial revamping which included a credit agreement with major banks and a sale by convertible notes and capital stock.

Operating revenues and net income of the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation in 1952 increased 11 per cent and 19 per cent, respectively, above the figures attained in 1951, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Sir Roger Makins, the new British Ambassador, confirmed today after an hour's conversation with Secretary of State John Foster Dulles that the British Foreign Secretary, Anthony Eden, would visit the United States in the near future.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Australia's Mervyn Rose, 2 points from defeat, staged a spectacular finish today to defeat Vic Seixas of Philadelphia for the South Australian tennis championship.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26 -- W. Harold Brenton, president of the American Bankers Association, told the A. B. A.'s National Credit Conference today that the capital structure of banks can be improved and that added protection can be given to bank deposits by the elimination of excessive taxes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of New York and foe of the McCarran-Walter Immigration and Nationality Act, failed today to obtain a place on the Joint Congressional Committee that will study operation of the new law.

The news item about the new Roman magazine, a quarterly called Latinitas, must quicken the pulse and the subscribing impulse of many a so-called classical scholar. Most quickening are the suggested translations of modern terms such as "Rugby," which is to be called "oblongi follislubus."

Jack Simon, chief of Bloomingdale's grocery department, said yesterday that several of the unusual foods ordered during recent buying tours of Europe had arrived in his shop. A single thrush from the French Alps, packed whole in a tin, was one. Another was grouse in port wine jelly from Scotland; a third, peeled anchovies from Malaga that had been fried in olive oil.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26 -- Circuit Judge Robert Jerome Dunne today granted the custody of 7-year-old Mary Louise Judd to her mother in a courtroom scene marked by a hysterical outburst of the grief-stricken father, Dr. Maurice Judd, 43, a physician of suburban Elmwood Park.

An invitation to the city's Protestant, Roman Catholic and Jewish religious leaders to unite in a group that would condemn evil and neglect and that would stimulate citizens "to take their part in working a change in our city's affairs" was sounded last night by the Right Rev. Horace W. B. Donegan, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of New York.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The Women's Division of the Democratic National Committee, established in 1922, was integrated into the Men's Division today in a reorganization at the committee's national headquarters.

Vaccination of children to control paralytic poliomyelitis now promises to be an effective and practical technique, although all the laboratory testing has not yet been done, it was announced here last night by the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Jan. 26 (AP) -Angry white settlers 1,500 strong marched on Government House today with demands for stronger measures against the terroristic Mau Mau and attempted to storm the building.
LONDON, Jan. 26 -- British Government securities and South African gold mining shares were the firmest spots in otherwise quiet and irregular markets here today.

Any attempt by William Wyer, trustee of the bankrupt Long Island Rail Road, to use the $8,500,000 from the sale to the city of the Rockaway Division for settlement of tax liabilities instead of for rehabilitating the railroad will be opposed vigorously by the Long Island Transit Authority.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The Women's Forum on National Security, a group of ten organizations spearheaded by the American Legion Auxiliary, heard speakers today advocate accelerated action against communism on all fronts -- military, psychological, political, and in American homes and committees.

The need for educating students so they will have a firm knowledge of the culture and heritage of the past and be able to think through a current issues and assume the responsibilities of intelligent citizenship was emphasized yesterday by Dr. Richard D. Weigle, president of St. John's College, Annapolis, Md.

Dave Beck, newly elected president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A. F. L., acted speedily last night to take over the affairs of Local 202 in this city after testimony before the State Crime Commission had indicated that its leaders were looting the union treasury and taking a heavy cash toll from New York produce merchants.

Pomp and circumstance still hold their fascination for everyone, young and old: Witness the interest we take in the coming English coronation and the influence this event is having in fashion's own kingdom.
Women active in behalf of Stony Wold Sanatorium met yesterday afternoon at a tea given by Mrs. Hoyte Joyce, president of the institution's board of directors, in the Terrace of the Waldorf-Astoria.
Acceding to the requests of many stores, the Irish Linen Guild has decided to celebrate Irish Linen Week this year, from March 16 to 21. Heretofore, the week has always been celebrated in May.

The State Crime Commission, turning its attention yesterday to a local of the teamsters' union, disclosed racketeering in the city's wholesale fruit and vegetable market that was comparable to some of the conditions this inquiry has shown to exist on the piers.

The thirteen-day perjury trial of William (Bill) Spivey, 23-year-old former All-America and University of Kentucky basketball star, ended in a deadlocked jury at 1:28 o'clock this morning when the jury of four women and eight men were unable to reach a verdict.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Jan. 27 -- The Chinese radio aid today that an American jet fighter plane was shot down last Friday over Manchuria and the pilot was captured after he had parachuted from the damaged aircraft.

HAVANA, Jan. 26 -- Leading American and Cuban scientists and physicians today discussed nutrition problems facing the world and presented findings on the treatment of vitamin deficiency diseases at a nutrition conference sponsored by the Foundation of Medical Research in collaboration with the Cuban Medical Association.

Our big, bustling city must be extremely confusing to a new visitor, who probably wants to see it all at one time, in a rush.. Generally he winds up by patronizing a few of the most publicized, and usually most expensive points of interest.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 26 (AP)--Bobby Shantz and General Manager Arthur Ehlers of the Athletics virtually have agreed on a new contract for the little left-handed pitcher, the most valuable player in the American League in 1952.

From time to time criticism is voiced of the American system of selecting successful business men to fill key diplomatic posts. Yet the system seems to work fairly successfully. On the whole, the United States has been well represented by its Ambassadors. The case of Walter S. Gifford, who for two years and a little more has been the United States Ambassador to the Court of St. James, is an example.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 26 -- The costly trainlift of "wetbacks" from Southern California by the United States Immigration Service has been imperiled by Mexican authorities. They have withdrawn their military escort from trains at Bunker Hill, only sixty-five miles south of the border.

Yesterday was officially the coldest day of 1953 and it seemed also to be the windiest. City dwellers bundled up their dogs against the icy blast, frosty-eared men chased their hats, and 600 sailors spent the end of Sunday night in a Coney Island garage when rough water sent their ship's launches to shelter.
TRENTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll's office annouced today his administraton had prepared legislation to make the New Jersey Law Enforcement Council a permanent body with new powers.
The case of William W. Remington, former Commerce Department economist, went to a Federal Court jury at 2:40 P. M. yesterday -- the ninth day of his second perjury trial in two years.
BERLIN, Jan. 26 -- Refugee officials said today that 5,800 East Germans fled to West Berlin last week -- more than in any comparable period since the closing of the East-West German border last June.

The headquarters of the New York Military District announced yesterday that Army Reservists in this area, "alarmed by the critical shortage of blood donors," would open a campaign of their own at the Sub-Treasury Building. Wall and Nassau Streets, at noon Thursday.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 26 -- Field Marshal Alexander Papagos, Premier of Greece, stressed this evening the importance of the proposed Balkan entente among Yugoslavia, Turkey and Greece, particularly as it might affect the defense of the region of Thrace.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 26 (AP) -The Government opened is antitrust suit against the National Football League with a statement that it considered the N. F. L. television restrictions illegal because they deprive individual clubs of the right to make their own decisions.

After several years of research a group of scientists at Columbia University has come up with an important finding. Four of the toxic elements in the sap of poisen ivy have been isolated and two of them have been synthetized. This is a big step toward finding the techniques of immunization.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 26 -- An army of tough-minded young Americans is needed to go into Asia and Africa to win the battle of ideas being waged against the Communists, Dr. James H. Robinson, pastor of the Presbyterian Church of the Master of New York, said tonight.

CAMDEN, N. J., Jan. 26 -- A county judge ruled here today that a prospective juror need not take the state oath of allegiance. The oath was prescribed in 1949 for all public officials and has been given to all jurors since then in Camden and several other New Jersey counties.

MANILA, Jan. 26 -- The election year Congress opened a 100-day session today with a demonstration of partisan warfare against President Elpidio Quirino's Liberal party Administration. The President was accused of assuming extraordinary unauthorized powers, and attempting to bypass the Legislature and run the Country by executive decree.

John David Provoo, 35-year-old former Army sergeant and prisoner of war, took the stand yesterday at his Federal Court treason trial and denied that he had given aid and comfort to the Japanese after the surrender of Corregidor on May 6, 1942.

CHICAGO, Jan 26 -- Prices for grain futures dropped sharply today under long liquidation and some local pressure. This selling met an indifferent demand, although on the extreme declines was some evidence of scale buying through commission houses.

TORONTO, Jan. 25 (Canadian Press) -- Massey-Harris Company, Ltd., reports a net profit for the fiscal year ended Oct. 31, 1952, of $12,493,600, a drop of $2,885,121 from the $15,378,721 in the previous year. Net profit declined from $2 to $1.62 a share.

Counsel for thirteen secondary Communist leaders scheduled to be sentenced tomorrow for conspiracy to teach and advocate the violent overthrow of the Government will argue today before Federal Judge Edward J. Dimock for a judgment of acquittal or an order for a new trial and an order arresting judgment in the case.
BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 26 (AP) -- The wool market here is enjoying a very brisk season with prices up about 20 per cent in two months and a steady demand both for export and for local consumption.

SEVERAL who made their southern fishing trips early this season have reported with enthusiasm on both the fresh and salt water activity, and many wrote that they had intended making an initial sortie after Florida quail but were frightened off by what they termed the "snake menace."

Failure to exploit the renovation market for old houses and outmoded commercial buildings may result in unprofitable operation for many lumber yards this year, Paul S. Collier, executive vice president of the Northeastern Retail Lumbermen's Association, warned yesterday.

A two-story office building recently constructed at 41-14 Twenty-ninth Street in Long Island City, Queens, by C. Grant Keck has been leased by Madigan Hyland, engineers, in a transaction negotiated through the C. Grant Keck Organization. The lessee will use the premises for engineering and drafting.

A tribute from President Eisenhower to former Secretary of War Robert P. Patterson, killed in a plane crash a year ago last week, was read last night at a ceremony at the Seventy-seventh Division Association Clubhouse, 28 East Thirty-ninth Street.

The Memorabilia Committee of the Metropolitan Opera Guild held a meeting yesterday that was followed by a party to mark the acquisition by the Metropolitan Opera of a bronze bust of Arturo Toscanini, a portrait of Giuseppe De Luca as Rigoletto and John McCormack's Don Ottavio costume for Mozart's "Don Giovanni."
The Amateur Athletic Union yesterday launched a $500,000 drive to maintain United States supremacy over Russia in the 1956 Olympic Games.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 26 -Paramount Pictures has hopped on the three-dimensional film bandwagon and will put its first "3-D" picture, "Sangaree," into production tomorrow morning. The studio will use its own twin-camera system in making the Technicolor picture.
DETROIT, Jan. 26 (AP) -- L. L. Colbert, president of Chrysler Corporation, said today America must foster "a realistic international trade among friendly nations" to remain strong.
THE pre-battle statement will not have changed one iota. On Oct. 12, 1957, Frank Leahy will wince visibly and sigh. Then he will issue his formal statement in sepulchral tones.

Events today: Julian Olevsky, violinist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30 P. M.; American Bach Society, Paul Matthen, bass, Town Hall, 8:30; Louis Persinger, violinist; Leonid Hambro, pianist, Juilliard Concert Hall, 8:30; John Ferris, organist, St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University, 5:15; Isaac Stern, violinist, Brooklyn Academy of Music, 8:30.

A proposal that three social scientists from the United States be selected to investigate charges that the Roman Catholic Church in Colombia is engaged in wide-spread persecution of Protestant missionaries was made in Bogota by Msgr. Luigi G. Ligutti, a prominent North American church man and executive director of the National Catholic Rural Life Conference.

The successful revival of "The Male Animal" will end its run at the Music Box Saturday night after 317 performances. The next attraction there will be William McDowell Stucky's drama, "Touchstone," which is scheduled to have its premiere next Tuesday night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The United States Court of Appeals today issued an order restraining Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr., from arresting or revoking the bail of Serge Rubinstein, Russian-born financier who has been ordered deported, pending a further order of the court.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady yesterday, 6 points higher to 20 points lower than on last Friday.
A proclamation issued yesterday at City Hall by Mayor Impellitteri designated this week as Salvation Army Week.

LONDON, Jan. 26 -- British research into the possibility of transforming atomic energy into electricity for industrial purposes has progressed to the point where the Government is considering the construction of such a generating plant, Duncan Sandys, Minister of Supply, told the House of Commons today.

The fiftieth anniversary of the Building Trades Employers Association of New York City will be celebrated at the organization's annual dinner tomorrow night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. About 1,200 persons are expected to attend the affair.
ROCQUENCOURT, France, Jan. 26 -- Bingo, that hardy perennial among the milder games of chance, has become a new factor in Western defense.

The tugboat Nancy Moran, a 1,200-horsepower, Diesel-powered craft, has been equipped with a newly designed controllable-pitch propeller, which is being tested under all types of operating conditions to determine its advantages, if any, over propellers with conventional, fixed blades.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Jan. 27 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,507, for Monday's action:

Another coordinated collection of kitchen, bath and bedroom accessories was announced yesterday, this one keyed to a previously introduced Martex towel design called Terry Tweed. The towel, which won a Home Fashions League Trail Blazer Award this autumn, was designed by Robert S. Low and John and Eadine Brice.

A gold medal was presented yesterday to Mrs. Adrian Van Sinderen by the Downtown Brooklyn Association for the "most distinguished service to Brooklyn" in 1952. The presentation was made by Dr. Harry S. Rogers, president of the association, at a luncheon in the Towers Hotel in Brooklyn. Five hundred persons were present.
A New York Airways Sikorsky S-55, carrying more than 700 pounds of luggage and cargo, took off from La Guardia Airport yesterday to start the first helicopter cargo service in the metropolitan area.
BERMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 26 -- A month-long festival of arts is under way here, with Alabama musicians, artists, writers and players sharing the spotlight with widely known professionals.

KONXVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 26 (UP) -- A walkout of operating engineers and truck drivers of the American Federation of Labor closed down the big atomic project here tonight. It was the first "significant" strike since construction started on the new uranium-235 plant last August, a Government official said.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 26 (AP) -- Lloyd Mangrum scored his third victory in the first five tournaments of the 1953 winter trail today when he posted a 1-under par 70 for a 72-hole tally of 272 in the $10,000 Phoenix open.
Directors of the Texas Company yesterday elected J. S. Leach as chairman of the board and chief executive officer and A. C. Long as president, succeeding Mr. Leach, effective March 1.

In the interests of speed, directors of the Missouri Pacific Railroad Company have decided to abandon reorganization proceedings under Section 77 of the Bankruptcy Act and seek it under Section 20-b of the Interstate Commerce Act, also called the Mahaffie Act.

A syndicate headed by William Albert, attorney, has purchased the six-story store and apartment building at 201 East Fortieth Street from the estate of Arthur Fishberg and others. The sale was negotiated by the Maxwell Brody Company and Arthur Walker as brokers.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Indo-China, Tuesday, Jan. 27 (AP) -- French officials said today Moscow-trained Ho Chi Minh, leader of the Communist-dominated Vietminh rebels, possessed a written promise from Red China for direct Chinese intervention in Indo-China if the rebels should face defeat by French Union forces.

LONDON, Jan. 26 -- Some of the color of coronation pageantry was introduced at two opening spring fashion collections in London by the "top eleven" designers. Mannequins walked on in peeresses' robes carrying coronet. At Victor Stiebel's, the regal effect was enhanced by a scarlet liveried footman and a master of ceremonies to open the collection.

SEOUL, Korea, Jan. 26 -- Five of the six armed Communist prisoners who escaped Friday from the compound on Koje Island were recaptured on Tsushima Island in the Sea of Japan today by the Japanese police, according to a spokesman for the Korean communications zone.

The domestic steel industry established a production record again last week in turning out 2,248,000 net tons of ingots and steel for castings, as operations averaged 99.7 per cent of capacity. This output exceeded by 10,000 tons the previous record, achieved the week before.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today ordered the Union Pacific Railroad to set up joint freight rates with the Denver and Rio Grande Western Railroad on a group of selected commodities moving through the Ogden (Utah) Gateway.

Firemen had a busy time visiting Bellevue Hospital yesterday afternoon, although there was not work for them there. On the first occasion an alarm was turned in at 1:30 P. M. because of an explosion near the hospital that injured four men but caused no fire.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 26 -- Ratification of the Allied-German treaties in this country depends to a great degree on the presence of a strong and influential United States High Commissioner, Chancellor Konrad Adenauer indicated today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- President Eisenhower created today a nine-member board to study the problem of unifying this country's psychological warfare to give it a dynamic thrust in the "cold war."

Our immediate reaction to the first composition on the program of the concert given by the Little Orchestra Society, Thomas Scherman conductor, last night in Town Hall, was that of Oliver Twist, for "more"!

Roberta Peters sang the role of Sophie in last night's "Rosenkavalier" at the Metropolitan Opera House. It was the third new part the young coloratura has assumed there under difficult circumstances, for, as she did with Zerlina two seasons ago and with Gilda last season, she went on at short notice in a role she had never sung.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Government employes are getting the word from the Eisenhower Administration that a full day's work is expected of them.

Leo Durocher, manager of the Giants, yesterday planned a "dream infield," with Capt. Al Dark at second base, that could be the "real thing' if Willie Mays, crack centerfielder now in the Army, swaps his khaki uniform for a baseball uniform.

ALBANY, Jan. 26 -- Arthur T. Berge, former Richmond County Assemblyman, protested tonight to Joseph M. Proskauer, chairman of the state crime commission, that parts of his testimony had been lifted out of context in the commission's report to the Legislature.
A "frightfully high number" of American soldiers in Korea are victims of narcotics addiction, Cardinal Spellman said last night in his first public appearance since visiting the front.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 26 -- A three-month expedition into the Humboldt Current, a stretch of the Pacific Ocean along the western coast of South America, will be under taken this year by Yale University scientists.
MIAMI, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Showing sharp improvement, Royal Bay Gem captured the $5,000 Sunny Isles purse at 24 to 1 before 19,610 chilled fans at Hialeah Park today.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 26 (UP) -President Eisenhower made a wise and statesmanlike decision in agreeing to have wide open news conferences, Hugh Baillie, president of the United Press, said tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- The Defense Department today identified 27 Korean battle casualties in a new list that included 5 killed, 20 wounded and 2 injured. It also confirmed the capture of 12 men previously reported missing in action.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 26 -India's annual stocktaking today on the third anniversary of the Republic revealed a predominant feeling of hope for the future but not much satisfaction with the past.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Jan. 26 -Rightist elements in the Bolivian Government dealt a severe blow today to their Communist colleagues and set the nation on the road to economic recovery by contracting for the sale of half of the nation's tin production for the next three years to Britain.
The State of Maryland announced yesterday that it will offer for sale on Feb. 10 an issue of $15,575,000 of general public school bonds dated March 1, 1953, and due March 1, 1956, to 1968.

Invisible jet-speed streams of wind high in the skies may be detected by observation of cloud formations from the ground, Dr. Vincent J. Schaefer reported here yesterday at the opening of the annual meeting of the American Meteorological Society.

Edward J. McGrath, the former West Side dock union official who had been linked to murder and lesser crimes in previous testimony before the State Crime Commission, told the commission very little about himself yesterday when he appeared as a reluctant witness at the waterfront hearing.

LONDON, Jan. 26 -- Refloating the liner Empress of Canada, which burned and sank early this morning at a Liverpool pier, will take a year and will cost more than 100,000, the port's marine surveyor estimated today.

PLAINFIELD, N. J., Jan. 26 -Final tribute was paid by national and state leaders here this afternoon to former United States Representative Charles A. Eaton, 84-year-old dean of the New Jersey Congressional delegation, at a funeral service in the First Park Baptist Church.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Ever since 8:02 o'clock last Wednesday morning, when President Eisenhower began his first full day in office, those visitors who have not arrived and left by the side door, and hence eluded the White House reporters entirely, have been notably uncommunicative to the representatives of the press.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- President Eisenhower will deliver his first Message on the State of the Union, outlining his domestic and foreign policy programs for this year, before a joint session of Congress next Monday at 12:30 P. M.
TOKYO, Jan. 26 -- The North Korean Communists have apparently launched a propaganda drive to entice United Nations troops, particularly South Koreans, to stop fighting and surrender.

WILMINGTON, Del., Jan. 26 (AP) -- Establishment of the world's richest horse race for fillies and mares was announced today by Delaware Park with the disclosure that the New Castle Handicap would be increased to $100,000 in added money.

" Harps in the Air," Eve Le Gallienne's story of her life, is planned for April publication by Viking Press. It is an account of Miss Le Gallienne's years on and off the American stage, of her triumphs and near-tragedies, of her tours in this country and abroad and of her friendships and encounters with stage notables and distinguished persons outside the theatre.
