To commemorate the 300th anniversary of the establishment of a municipal form of government on Manhattan Island, Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr. yesterday officially proclaimed next Monday as "New York City Anniversary Day."

NEWBURGH, N. Y., Jan 26 -This city has been cited as a 1952 "All-American City" for its outstanding "citizen action" in putting the financial affairs of the city on a sound footing. The citation was announced today by the National Municipal League, sponsor of the award.

Eight key men charged with care and maintenance of hundreds of trucks, buses and cars owned and operated by the city have been appointed to the preventive maintenance education committee of the National Transport Vehicle Show and Fleet Maintenance Exposition.

The new tanker Petro Kure, a 38,000-deadweight ton vessel, is now on her maiden voyage from the Persian Gulf to Marcus Hook, Pa., where she will enter regular service as the flagship of the fleet of the Sinclair Refining Company.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Jan. 26 -- The ruling Nationalist party and the United party Opposition, who are bitterly hostile, joined today to admit to Parliament a bill to make provision for the safety of the public.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Sixteen amendments to the Taft-Hartley Labor Act, two of them designed to meet the campaign criticisms of President Eisenhower, were introduced late today by Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, the Republican floor leader.

A cheerful note is sounded in the fourth directory issued by the National Association of Amateur Chamber Music Players. That far-flung organization announces, with a bow in the direction of an undisclosed number of the members who, it says, have complained that N. A. A. C. M. P. is an ungainly title, that its name is being changed to Amateur Chamber Music Players.
HARRISBURG, Jan. 26 (AP) -Gov. John S. Fine submitted to the Pennsylvania General Assembly tonight a record budget of $1,428,777,543 for 1953-55 and called for $157,202,397 in new state taxes.
The future of France was being discussed yesterday by the French National Assembly.

The law of demand and supply, it would appear, is in process of accomplishing something that never was achieved by the post-Korea price control legislation. It is operating to restore the beefsteak to the family dinner table.

Because spiritual beliefs and social responsibilities "go hand-in-hand," the churches of this country can play a major role in influencing a "materialistic society" that is "hungry not for food but for understanding and compassion and hope," Dr. Henry Townley Heald, chancellor of New York University, said yesterday.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Jan. 26 -- The island's two leading newspapers, El Mundo and El Imparcial, concur in editorials to be published tomorrow morning in demanding a thorough' investigation of the conviction of Puerto Rican soldiers on charges of refusing to go into action in Korea and of the court-martial procedure.
ALBANY, Jan. 26 (UP) -- The State Commerce Department today received the following winter sports reports:

DALLAS, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Senator Burnet R. Maybank, Democrat of South Carolina, told 1,000 cotton industry leaders today he believes the economy-minded new Congress will make, "sizable reductions" in the new Federal budget.

The Air Force is putting as much effort into a research and development program for missiles of all sorts as it is into the development of conventional aircraft, but no super-missile is likely "soon" to make the airplane "as out of date as a silk hat at a Presidential Inauguration."

HACKENSACK, N. J., Jan. 27 -- Nelson F. Stamler, widely known throughout New Jersey as a racket-busting prosecutor, was summarily dismissed today from his post as Deputy Attorney General on the ground that he had impeded justice by making false statements.

A television dramatization of a novel published only a week earlier is hardly a common occurrence, so that the "Studio One" production on Tuesday evening of "To the Moment of Triumph," by Pamela Frankau, undoubtedly aroused more than usual interest. The experiment, if such it can be called, was anything but a success.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Postal inspectors said today a twelve-year hunt for John M. Dredger Jr., a lawyer, accused of using the mails to defraud friends and relatives of $570,000, had ended at a grave in Northwood Cemetery here.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 27 -- In a new technique for remedying an often fatal physical malformation, a surgeon at Children's Hospital here has succeeded in "building" an esophagus in a 3-day-old baby born without one .

The 1953 National Book Award gold medals were presented yesterday to Archibald MacLeish for "Collected Poems, 1917-1952," to Bernard De Voto for "The Course of Empire," and to Ralph Ellison for his first novel, "Invisible Man."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 27 -- New contract demands presented to the Association of Motion Picture Producers by the Screen Writers Guild were outlined to the union's membership at a meeting here tonight.

Mar-za is the name caterer Daisy Amoury has given the exotic sweets of Lebanese origin she now packages twelve to a gaily decorated box. On orders of $5 or more the pastries will be delivered smaller purchases must be picked up at her kitchen workshop, 425 East Seventy-second Street.

A date for the sentencing of William W. Remington, who was convicted early yesterday by a Federal Court jury on two counts of a five-count perjury indictment, will be set tomorrow at 10:30 A. M. by Judge Vincent L. Leibell.

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- Crowds demonstrated tonight and 200 Members of Parliament, balked in their efforts to debate the issue in the Commons, petitioned Sir David Maxwell Fyfe, Home Secretary, in a last ditch effort to stop the hanging tomorrow morning of 19-year-old Derek Bentley, convicted accessory to the shooting of a policeman.

Aggregate personal savings in this country last year exceeded the high level of 1951 and reached the highest total ever attained except for the war years, 1942 through 1945. The total is approaching $200,000,000,000, the Institute of Life Insurance reported yesterday.

The first of twelve air cargo flights with part of 1,804 pieces of furniture arrived in Bogota, Colombia, yesterday at 9:35 A. M. after a 2,805-mile flight from Westerly, R. I., that took sixteen hours and two minutes. The entire consignment ultimately will furnish the Toquendama Hotel, operated by the International Hotel Corporation in Bogota.

The Port of New York Authority announced yesterday that it would build a 90,000-square-foot hangar and related facilities at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, for the overhaul of aircraft engines. The new building will cost $2,700,000 and is expected to be ready for occupancy late this year.

Commodity prices closed irregularly higher yesterday on the New York Exchanges. Volume was generally larger with rubber, coffee and hides showing more activity than for the last few weeks. Hides, sugar, cocoa, vegetable oils and wool closed higher.

PARIS, Jan. 27 -- Maurice Bourges-Maunoury, the new French Finance Minister, said today that the only convertibility of currencies that would be worth while was one that permitted the greatest freedom of trade and payments.

A more kindly official attitude has developed recently toward salvaging the eminent lawgivers who stand in crumbling effigy on the building of the Supreme Court's Appellate Division at Madison Avenue and Twenty-fifth Street.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Branch Rickey, the economy-minded general manager of the Pirates, today sought to cut the salaries of Ralph Kiner, the homerun hitter, and Rookie Frank Thomas.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York yesterday reported a substantial improvement in 1952 earnings, increased its quarterly dividend by 5 cents a share and elected as a trustee Howard C. Sheperd, chairman of the National City Bank of New York.
The year-long commemoration by New Yorkers of the 300th anniversary of the incorporation of New Amsterdam on Feb. 2, 1653, will begin next week-end.

ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- The budget estimates for the state's fiscal year starting April 1 indicate that New York City will receive $266,801,176 in state aid, a decline of $3,936,841 from the comparable estimates a year ago.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 (AP) -- A judge today awarded $100,000 damages to Dick Hanley, former coach of the defunct Chicago Rockets football team, in a malicious libel judgment against Hanley's onetime employer.

The Yankees, who on occasion have been known to give vent to some caustic remarks whenever a contender reached out to grab a name player, were inclined last night to take the White Sox-A's player swap pretty much in stride.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- A statement in Kansas City by former President Harry S. Truman expressing his doubt that the Soviet Union had an atomic bomb was criticized quickly today by three members of the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy.

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- British Government securities and South African gold mining shares gain were in most consistent demand on markets here today and both finished with fresh gains. In other sections the effect of profit-taking sales on the last day of the bookkeeping account gave a ragged appearance to prices, especially industrials.

By bringing the Police Department to its full authorized strength of 20,372 men and women and keeping it there, the department can get along in 1953-54 without additional manpower, Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan asserted yesterday.

ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- A proposal to permit the Jones Beach State Parkway Authority, headed by Robert Moses, to impose a 10-cent toll on the Southern State Parkway to finance a $40,000,000 parkway improvement program in Nassau County appeared today to have run into a serious snag here.

The white settlers of Kenya have become more and more aroused as the anti-European, terrorist Mau Mau society continues its sporadic murders and arson. It was reported from Nairobi on Monday that the settlers have demanded -- and are going to get -- firmer governmental measures to suppress the Mau Mau.

A tract of 300 acres north of Hawthorne, N. Y., has been chosen by Webb Knapp, Inc., as the site for a development for decentralized offices of major corporations or for light manufacturing. William Zeckendorf, president of Webb Knapp, announced that his company has taken an option on the property, which is owned by Clarence Y. Palitz of New York.

The Canadiens of Montreal will oppose the New York Rangers in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight. The contest will be the first home test for the Blues since the fourteenth of this month, when they defeated the Detroit Red Wings, 3 to 2.

VIENNA, Jan. 27 -- Factories are shutting down in Czechoslovakia and trains are standing still on tracks for want of coal, according to statements this week by Czechoslovak Premier Antonin Zapotcky and other officials. Their statements were made at a conference of trade union functionaries.

HARTFORD, Jan. 27 -- A bill outlawing discrimination because of race, color or creed in admissions to Connecticut's colleges and universities was introduced in the state senate today by Senator Jack Stock, Democrat of Bridgeport.
NOW that elections and inaugurations are over, our Legislature, as well as our Congress, must come to grips with the serious problems that affect our people and our community.

WESTPORT, CONN., Jan. 27 -- The police sent out a nine-state alarm today for William Davis, a 29-year-old handyman believed to have murdered Mrs. Montgomery Evans, 28, at her home here last evening. Because he was formerly a merchant seaman, New York police were asked to search for Davis along the waterfront.

GENEVA, Jan. 27 -- Twenty-three new projects designed to assist refugees to establish themselves permanently as normal members of the community have been announced by United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, said today the Netherlands should be "warmly congratulated" for her decision to forego United States economic aid, which was reported yesterday.
Herbert D. Euwer has been appointed chief engineer of passenger cars for the American Car and Foundry Company.
AIKEN, S. C., Jan. 27 -- An explosion set off by a spark in a gas-filled building turned a business block here into a row of raging fires today and the police listed ten persons killed.

ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- Reorganization of the state Civil Service Department to vest administrative authority in one administrator but retain rule-making and appellate functions in a bipartisan commission was assured today with the introduction of a bill supported by all groups concerned.
ACAPULCO, Mexico, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Protests against the apparent victory of Moonbeam in the San Diego-Acapulco yacht race were allowed today, giving the honors to the Mexican yacht Conejo.

ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- Following is a table computed today to show how New York City is expected to share in local assistance from the state during the state's next fiscal year, which starts April 1. The first column gives the figures of a year ago.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Jan. 28 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,508, for Tuesday's operations:

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 -- The position of newspapers in the advertising field must be strengthened through more aggressive selling in 1953, members of the Newspaper Advertising Executives Association were told today at the group's annual meeting.

Eleven twenty-inch-high models of sculpture on the theme "The Unknown Political Prisoner," which were selected as the American entries for the first world-wide sculpture competition ever to be held, will be placed on view today at the Museum of Modern Art.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Jan. 28 -- Gen. J. Lawton Collins, United States Army Chief of Staff, toured the battlefront in Korea yesterday while the fighting dwindled almost to a minimum along the 155-mile line.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- A Federal Court permanently enjoined the National Labor Relations Board today from ordering labor leaders to reaffirm non-Communist oaths that were made under the provisions of the Taft-Hartley Act.
Seton Hall, with nineteen straight victories, once again edged Indiana as the nation's No. 1 college basketball team in The United Press ratings.

Women headed by Mrs. Reginald Conklin, and including Mrs. Peter Darlington and Mrs. John Campbell Henry, are serving on the women's committee for the third annual ball of the St. Nicholas Society of New York, to be held Friday night in the main ballroom of the Plaza.

LONDON, Wednesday, Jan. 28 -- The Soviet Union, in notes to the United States, Britain and France, has rejected a Western invitation to resume four-power talks on a Western draft treaty that would establish Austria's freedom and independence.

Steel demand is holding up well, with the prospect that 1953 will be a good year, said Benjamin F. Fairless, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation. Thus far the backlog has held at about nineteen weeks of current production, he added.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 27 (AP) - The Government established two important points today as the anti-trust suit against the National Football League's restriction of broadcasting and television dragged through the opening stages.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The Senate passed today an Administration bill to set up a special office for the promised Republican "clean-up" of the State Department and approved Harold E. Stassen to be Director for Mutua1 Security.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 (AP) -- The Athletics and the White Sox today sprang the off-season's biggest deal -- a first baseman exchange of a two-year American League batting champion, Ferris Fain of the A's, for power-hitting Eddie Robinson of the Sox.

HONG KONG, Jan. 27 -- A thirteen-member delegation headed by Tadatsugu Shimazu, president of the Japanese Red Cross Society, arrived here today by plane from Tokyo en route to Peiping to discuss procedures for the repatriation of 30,000 Japanese national stranded in Communist China.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 27 -- Howard Hughes, board chairman of R. K. O.-Radio Pictures Corporation and a principal stockholder in the R. K. O. Theatres Corporation, announced today his support of efforts by the American Legion to prevent showings of the Charlie Chaplin picture "Limelight." The film was shown last week at the R. K. O. Albee Theatre in Brooklyn.

John D. Provoo, former Army sergeant charged with treason while a captive of the Japanese in World War II, hotly denied in Federal Court here yesterday one of the accusations that had been made against him.

SINGAPORE, Jan. 27 -- Perhaps the most drastic of food-control regulations aimed at Communist bands that have been imposed in the Malayan Federation in the last few months will come into operation next week, M. F. Garling, Kuala Lumpur district officer, said tonight.

The appointment of Mrs. Corinne M. Murphy as arts and crafts adviser on the national staff of the Girls Scouts of the U. S. A. was announced yesterday by Miss Dorothy Stratton, the organization's national executive director.

Merger negotiations between the Bank of the Manhattan Company and Chase National Bank are "quite dead, as I read the resolution of the board of directors of the bank in question," John J. McCloy, chairman of Chase, told stockholders of that bank yesterday.
A series of anonymous telephone threats made in the last three weeks on the life of Edgar F. Luckenbach Jr., heir to the Luckenbach shipping fortune, came under investigation yesterday by the police.

ROME, Jan. 27 -- Touch and talent -- a touch for using gray magically and a talent for creating coats that float -- epitomize Simonetta's Rome collection. Formerly known in New York and Italy as Simonetta Visconti, this black haired lively designer presented a smooth, elegant show with ideas.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 -- An operation in which gossamer thin bags of nylon webbing are placed over the bottom of the thigh bone to relieve pain and increase the motion of legs immobilized by arthritis was described today at the twentieth annual meeting of the American Academy of Orthopedic Surgeons.

A rising tide of merchant shipbuilding orders over the last twelve months has almost doubled the volume of business for the world's shipyards since the beginning of 1951, Walter L. Green, president and chairman of the board of managers of the American Bureau of Shipping, reported yesterday.

Police Capt. John M. Bou, under suspension on charges of accepting graft from Harry Gross, Brooklyn bookmaker, was found dead in the closed garage of his West Brighton, S. I., home early yesterday. He was lying on his back on the floor, his head near the exhaust pipe in the rear of his car.

Several thousand service men's children living on or near military installations are expected to benefit from organized efforts by the Child Welfare League of America and the Department of Defense to improve the day-care facilities available to them.
The Jan. 15 news report about the reaction of the Israeli Government to the Prague purge trials and the Moscow "medical murder" charges points up the inadequacy of world reaction to these horrors.

ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- Assemblyman Janet Hill Gordon, Republican of Norwich, renewed today her fight to get the Legislature to authorize a study of the state's rigid divorce law. A similar effort last year came to naught when her bill failed to emerge from the Ways and Means Committee.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 27 -- United Nations officials will meet with representatives of the United States tomorrow to work out the process of investigating American members of the organization's secretariat.

For better public understanding Governor Dewey is dividing his annual budget message into two installments this year. Yesterday the figures on local assistance were given and the costs of operating the state government in fiscal 1953-54 will come along later this week.

DUBLIN, Jan. 27 -- Ireland is in the throes of a milk strike in which a big proportion of the farmers in the south have refused to supply milk to the cities and towns unless their demands for higher prices are granted. Prime Minister Eamon de Valera and his Government have rejected the farmers' demands.

Net assets of the Massachusetts Investors Trust, an open-end investment company, amounted to $512,365,938 as of Dec. 31, 1952, it was announced yesterday. This compares with $437,873,741 at the close of 1951.

A two-for-one split up of the 10,041,081 shares of $10 par common of American Gas and Electric Company into 20.082,162 shares of $5 par common was approved by stockholders yesterday at a special meeting. It is expected that the split will be effective after the close of business on Jan. 29.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Representative Daniel A. Reed, Republican of New York, anticipated President Eisenhower and leaders of the House of Representatives today by starting a drive for early enactment of his tax relief bill.
Julian Olevsky, violinist, who made his debut here in December, 1950, returned to play a recital at Carnegie Hall last evening.

ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- Governor Dewey notified the Legislature today that he would ask it to appropriate $603,419,780 for distribution to cities and other local governments as state aid in the new budget this week. This total represents an apparent reduction of $7,647,417 from last year's appropriations but it actually will give the localities $18,589,715 more in state funds than they received last year.

John J. (Gene) Sampson, union boss of the Chelsea piers, appeared yesterday before the State Crime Commission in the role of defender of the union longshoreman against the greed of "sanctimonious shipping operators" and the conniving of the "hierarchy" of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 27 -- Mr. Truman today brushed aside varied and widespread comment on his expressed belief that the Soviet Union did not posses the atom bomb.

With talent from many sources, the ninth annual March of Dimes showing of fashions, presented yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel by the Couture Group of the New York Dress Institute for the benefit of the National Foundation] for Infantile Paralysis, was, in this reporter's opinion, a huge success.

Eight thousand striking bus drivers will vote today on a union-approved formula for ending their four-week walkout through arbitration, but there was no certainty last night that the vote would mean an immediate return to work, even if a majority of the men went along with the recommendation of their leaders.

MOSCOW, Jan. 27 -- The Health Ministry newspaper Medical Worker reported today the case of Myra Israilevna Chernyakova, who allegedly tossed specimens of live tissue into an ashcan instead of carrying out biopsies (examination of tissue from living bodies) to determine whether they were cancerous.
BERLIN, Jan. 27 -- Count Ferdinand Thun, chief of protocol in East Germany's Foreign Ministry, has registered as a refugee in West Berlin, West Berlin officials reported tonight.

Eight Brooklyn savings banks were honored yesterday by the Brooklyn Red Cross chapter for organizing blood donor recruiting programs last year. Special awards were presented by Hugh H. Cuthrell, chairman of the chapter's recruiting program, at the monthly meeting of the Group Five Savings Banks held in the Dime Savings Bank, Albee Square, Brooklyn.
ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- Following is the Local Assistance (State Aid) Section of the 1953-54 State Executive Budget message, made public today by Government Dewey:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The Federal Government received a stay of ninety days today in order to give it time in which to decide how it wanted to proceed on monopoly charges against seven American overseas oil companies.

H. J. Rose of the Princeton Club, seeded fourth, eliminated Don McN'eill, former national tennis champion, in the second round of the Yale Club squash tennis Bulldog handicap tourney yesterday. Rose at plus one, beat McNeill, plus 5, in three games, 5 -- 15, 15 -- 8 and 15 -- 12.
MADISON, Wis., Jan. 27 -- A University of Wisconsin professor told today how he had set out to breed a "superbee" but had produced instead "the most vicious strain of honey bees known to man."

The willingness of American athletes to work hard in training was cited yesterday by Gunter Koester, the coach accompanying Heinz Ulzheimer and Rolf Lamers, the German runners who will make their debut here in tomorrow night's Millrose Games at Madison Square Garden.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Following is the text of a statement by Secretary of State John Foster Dulles recorded yesterday and broadcast tonight, as transcribed by the state Department:

Southern Railway Company had a net income of $27,834,900, equal to $19.13 a common share, in 1952, according to the report released yesterday by Harry A. DeButts, president. This was 47 per cent above the net income of $18,856,597, or $12.21 a share, reported for 1951.

Commercial airliners may eventually hiss through the sky at supersonic speeds, but Clifford C. Furnas, director of the Cornell Aeronautical Laboratory, doubts that such schedules will be Achieved within the next half-century.

The first of ten Stratocruisers grounded last Thursday by the British Overseas Airways Corporation because of a malfunction in the engine system will be placed back in trans-Atlantic service tomorrow on a London-to-New York flight.

OFF THE LOUISIANA COAST, in the Gulf of Mexico, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Four Army infantry men, in a tense drama filled with flying shrapnel and metal-melting heat, continued their accurate fire with a 75-millimeter recoilless rifle tonight in an attempt to control a multi-million-dollar gas well blaze.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The Office of Price Stabilization today simplified methods by which automobile manufacturers may include in their list prices for new passenger cars, the higher costs involved in using conversion steel. The new procedure, price officials said, will make calculations easier.

The first politician to lose his job as the result of the current crime hearings was discharged yesterday. He is William J. Connolly, $7,900-a-year chief confidential attendant to the board of justices of the State Supreme Court.

BONN, Germany, Jan 27 -- The German Federal Government's 1953-54 budget, designed to accentuate West Germany's current prosperity and high productivity through heavy cuts in income taxes and corporation taxes, will be submitted to Parliament tomorrow by Finance Minister Fritz Schaefer.

Some answers by housewives that made a veteran pollster "happy as an American man" were reviewed yesterday by Archibald M. Crossley in a report on a survey by his concern for the Schaefer Brewing Company. The results were announced at a luncheon at the Pierre Hotel.

WITH THE THIRD DIVISION in Korea, Jan. 27 -- Maj. Gen. George W. Smythe, commander of the Thirty Infantry Division, disclosed today the events leading to the incidents for which ninety-two members of the United States Sixty-fifth Infantry Regiment, composed largely of Puerto Ricans, were convicted of having refused to go into action last year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (UP) -- Senator George D. Aiken, Republican of Vermont, announced today that his Senate Agriculture Committee would open an investigation Thursday into "the unwarranted recession in farm income and purchasing power."

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 27 -- Conditions in India are not too favorable for large-scale investment of private capital, Sir George Schuster, a leading British financier here on a survey of the Indian economy, said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- President Eisenhower stayed home with a cold again today but his condition was improved and he continued work on his State of the Union Message. With Mrs. Eisenhower, who also has a cold, he held a reception for the Chiefs of Missions of the Foreign Diplomatic Corps.

Negotiations for a new tugboat labor contract will resume this morning, backed up for the first time in the talks by a union strike threat. In addition, today's meeting will mark the first official intervention of Federal and municipal mediators.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Senate and House committees ignored an Eisenhower Administration plea for "no more and no less" reorganization authority than President Truman had as they reported today bills that would allow any Presidential plan to be killed by a simple majority of those present and voting in either body.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- With voice votes and with little debate, the Senate confirmed today President Eisenhower's nominations for nine more key posts in his Administration. They were:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- When a general becomes Mr. President, how should he be addressed? Inquiries today indicated that President Eisenhower was not fussy over the etiquette of Presidential nomenclature.

The current bus strike has forced this correspondent to travel by subway from uptown West Side to uptown East Side, via Times Square and Grand Central. At first he faced the prospect of the situation with uneasiness and some apprenhension, knowing how milling throngs in an overcrowded subway station can become distempered and often get out of hand.

Danny Nardico, the busy Tampa, Fla., light-heavyweight who knocked out Jake LaMotta, is rated "fighter of the month" for January in the copyright monthly ratings of Nat Fleischer, editor of Ring Magazine.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 27 -- In a change of front, Chancellor Konrad Adenauer defended today the arrest by British authorities of seven Nazis.

SAN SALVADOR, Jan. 27 -- The National Police announced today that it had frustrated a plot by what was characterized as "a group of international gangsters" to assassinate Roberto E. Canessa, El Salvador's Minister of Foreign Relations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Lawrence Appley, president of the American Management Association, New York, was reported today being considered for appointment to the United States Civil Service Commission.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles today announced three appointments. They are Roderic L. O'Conner and John W. Hanes Jr., special assistants, and Mrs. Burnita O'Day, personal assistant.

Events today: Lecture-recital on "The Rake's Progress", W. H. Auden. Chester Kallman, lecturers; Hilde Gueden, Blanche Thebom, Eugene Conley. Mack Harrell, vocalists, Town Hall, 2:45 P. M.; "La Gioconda," Metropolitan Opera, 8; Ralph Kirkpatrick, harpsichordist, Town Hall, 8:30; Union Theological Seminary Chamber Orchestra, James Memorial Chapel, 8:15; Joseph Schuster,
Three men who allegedly obtained money from stevedoring companies "under duress" were indicted yesterday on income tax evasion charges by a Federal rackets grand jury investigating waterfront crimes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- In the first of a series of moves expected to lead to a revision of the public debt structure, the Treasury today offered holders of $8,868,000,000 of one-year certificates the choice of exchanging them for similar certificates or for a new security to run five or six years.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 27 -- A new approach was made last weekend by Eastern European observers in the search for a satisfactory explanation of the current upheaval in the Communist world as reflected in recent purges and indications of others.

FORT WORTH, Jan. 27 (AP) -- What was reported to be the first hydrogen bomb drop was made in the South Pacific by a B-36 that returned here with bomb-bay doors blackened and blistered, a newspaper said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (UP) -- American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organization officials described as "completely inadequate" and "piddling" today Senator Robert A. Taft's sixteen proposed changes in the Taft-Hartley Act.

Distressed at an estimated shortage of 40,000 engineers in United States industry, officials of the Engineering Manpower Commission and the Advertising Council outlined yesterday for the benefit of interested industry representatives a joint campaign aimed at stimulating high school students to consider careers in engineering.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Jan. 27 -- Legislation drafted by the Nationalist party, published today, would empower Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan's Government to suspend all existing law and rule dictatorially if it chose. The measure will be debated next Monday after the second reading and will be pushed through by the Nationalist majority in Parliament.

The American Bach Society, which gave the first of its two Town Hall concerts last night, paid its respects to the composer in its name with a cantata, but devoted the bulk of its time to other men of several centuries ago. Besides Bach,
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 27 -- Harry S. Truman today revealed that he did not plan his daily walks at painfully early hours to punish newspaper men.

The following are excerpts from yesterday's testimony at the State Crime Commission hearings on conditions along the waterfront. They are concerned with the financial operations of the Commission Drivers and Chauffeurs Union, Local 202, International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A.F.L., and with practices of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L.

GAINESVILLE, Fla., Jan. 27 -- -- Dr. William Sanger, president of the Medical College of Virginia, said today that all resources of modern society should be marshaled to help realize the potentialities of the aged. This should be done, he said, in the same manner that youth is systematically prepared for leadership and responsibility.

Two new films will arrive at first-run theatres today. "The Star," a Twentieth Century-Fox drama of Hollywood with Bette Davis, Sterling Hayden, Natalie Wood, Warner Anderson and Minor Watson, is at the Rivoli. Stuart Heisler directed and Bert E. Friedlob produced from an original screen play by Katherine Albert and Dale Eunson.

The retirement of Harry S. Truman to private life means that the United States for the first time in a generation has two living ex-Presidents, one Democratic and one Republican. This is an ideal occasion for Congress to do something practical about utilizing the services of former Chief Executives and assuring them financial independence for the rest of their lives.

ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- The chairman of the State Workmen's Compensation Board today urged the Joint Legislative Committee on Industrial and Labor Conditions to make a study of the costs of the state's compensation program, which has been under heavy fire from employers' groups.
Prices of cotton futures closed steady, 8 points up to 5 points off yesterday, with business on the New York Cotton Exchange rather quiet.

Senator Taft has offered for Congressional consideration sixteen amendments to the Taft-Hartley Act, which he co-authored in 1947. The sixteen are wrapped up in five Senate bills, and they include two specific reforms proposed by President Eisenhower during his campaign for election.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 27 (UP) -- President Victor Paz Estenssoro announced that Bolivia is negotiating with the United States for the sale of 50 per cent of her annual tin production, the newspaper Tribuna da Imprenda said today.

ON his twenty-first birthday some time in the early winter of 1941 Russell Braddon was captured by the Japanese. For the next four years and four months he was a prisoner in Malaya and Thailand, enduring every kind of horror imaginable, surviving only by luck, courage and the physical vigor of his youth, while thousands of his companions perished.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 27 -- Imports through the Port of San Francisco last year were reported today at 860,000 tons, a post-war record, but Robert H. Wylie, port manager, said total tonnage had dropped 11.7 per cent from that of 1951.

An estimated $61,000,000 will be spent by the nation's commercial banks for advertising this year, according to the annual survey on this subject by the American Bankers Association. The sum represents an increase of about $13,000,000 over last year and is more than double that of 1946, the first post-war year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, declared tonight that a "deadly serious" threat of "encirclement" by the Russian Communists and their allies was the basis and main concern of United States foreign policy. He thus threw back at the Soviet Union the charge of "encirclement'' so frequently made against the capitalist world in Moscow's explanations of Soviet rearmament efforts.

Purchase by the American Blue Print Company of the six-story store and ofice building at 7 East Forty-seventh Street in connection with plans of the buyer to expand its midtown quarters. The structure was bought from the 7 East Forty-seventh Street Corporation in a deal negotiated by Cushman Wakefield, Inc., and Robert Joseph Co., brokers.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 27 -- Public power was pictured today to members of the National Rural Electric Cooperative Association as "the greatest economic issue the American people now face or will face in this generation."

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Jan. 27 (AP) -- Vince Boryla arched in a forty-foot set shot with one second remaining to enable the injury-riddled New York Knickerbockers to gain a 74-72 National Basketball Association victory over the Rochester Royals tonight.

Payments by retailers, wholesalers and manufacturers are showing a slight decline in promptness, according to the results of a nation-wide survey announced yesterday by the Credit Research Foundation, an affiliate of the National Association of Credit Men.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Jan. 27 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Supreme Allied Commander, returned here with his wife and son today from a week's holiday in West Germany to find on his desk a pile of news clippings implying that he was dissatisfied with his task in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and wanted a transfer.

TORONTO, Jan. 27 (Canadian Press) -- Frank Sedgman, Australia's Davis Cup star, whipped Jack Kramer, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4, tonight to go ahead, 9 -- 6, in matches in their exhibition professional tennis tour.

MIAMI, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Brush Burn, a gelding that had been racing in stakes company, was dropped down in company in the first division of the Silver Springs Purse at Hialeah Park today and came on with a sensational charge to capture the event at a $21.60 straight pay-off.

An interest cost of 2.3564 per cent won the offering yesterday of an issue of $12,500,000 of bonds of Dallas, Tex., maturing from 1953 to 1972. The best bid, 100.004 for 5s, 2s, 2 1/4s and 2 1/2s, was submitted by a syndicate headed by Northern Trust Company, Bankers Trust Company and First Boston Corporation.

No immediate move for a retrial was made yesterday by the District Attorney's office in the case of William Spivey, whose thirteen-day perjury trial in General Sessions ended in a deadlocked jury at 1:28 A. M. yesterday.

The English Channel is a very narrow strait, at one point hardly twenty miles across, yet of all the gaps that worry the Western World, including the dollar gap, this little strip of stormy water is as wide as any.

Improvement in the 1952 financial status of the Presbyterian Hospital in the City of New York was reported yesterday by its president, Charles P. Cooper. Affiliated with Columbia University, the hospital is part of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center.

Before leaving for Europe on the first of a series of fact-finding trips Secretary Dulles last night gave this nation a picture of the world situation as he sees it and a broad outline of the fundamental concepts which will determine our foreign policy.

T. Vincent Quinn, Queens District Attorney, moved yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court to have the Government dismiss a criminal indictment charging him with taking lawyer's fees illegally while he was a member of the House of Representatives.
When "The Moon Is Blue" leaves Henry Miller's, where the F. Hugh Herbert comedy has been entertaining the populace since March 8, 1951, it will be followed by "Horses in Midstream.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- An information leak today knocked out a plan for the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to sell its common stocks holdings in the Central of Georgia Railroad, R. F. C. Administrator Harry C. McDonald reported.

Eight witnesses, several of them ex-convicts, were examined yesterday at the State Crime Commission waterfront hearing to substantiate the commission's contention that public loading was a racket exacting around $5,000,000 a year from inbound New York cargo.
PARIS, Jan. 27 -- Marius Renard, 16-year-old French youth, died of uremia tonight thirty-three days after he had received an extraordinary Christmas gift from his mother -- one of her kidneys.

In his letter published Jan. 15, Willard G. Van Name took it upon himself to warn the public "that a most determined effort is likely to be made in the present Legislature to initiate laws to sweep away the last vestiges of constitutional protection for the Adirondack forests and place them under control of some small commission with views known to be favorable to permitting the forests to be cut for lumber and pulp."

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- A Roman Catholic priest and two laymen have been sentenced to death in Cracow, Poland, on charges of spying for the United States and engaging in black market currency deals, the Warsaw radio reported today.

Officers and members of the board of the Children's Health Service of the New York Diet Kitchen Association will hold their annual meeting, to be followed by a reception and tea, next Tuesday at the headquarters of the Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 -- After sharp early declines in all pits, buying resistance stiffened on the Board of Trade today and the market became strong in late trade. On the decline selling was cushioned by investment buying, and this was followed by short covering in a big way.

The Protestant Council of the City of New York, central planning body for 1,375 churches here, promised "fullest cooperation" yesterday to the proposal by the Right Rev. Horace W. B. Donegan, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of the diocese of New York, for a new consultative body of the city's religious leaders to spur action against "evils" in housing, schools and crime.

One of the big problems that any weather man faces is the wrath of the public when his predictions do not "prove." The weather man says his predictions do not prove when the weather turns out to be other than what he has forecast. Then angry picnickers, sodden hunters and ordinary commuters who left their umbrellas at home make meteorology more an active than an ivory-tower science.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Jan. 27 -- With Eddie O'Connor contributing 37 points for a new school record, the Manhattan College Jaspers easily defeated the Providence College Friars, 98 to 72, before 1,000 fans tonight at the Rhode Island auditorium.

NOTHING can provoke an argument faster than to begin comparing sports heroes of the past with sports heroes of the present. And a fellow doesn't have to go wandering into saloons in order to stir up such a debate. He can do it right where he is. Such conversations are endless, unproductive and unprovable. Could Joe Louis have beaten Jack Dempsey?

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Representative Frederic R. Coudert Jr., Republican of New York, called on Congress today to delay action on statehood for Hawaii and Alaska pending "serious consideration" of a proposed Constitutional amendment for Senate representation of new states.

Clergy and lay members of several faiths and denominations yesterday honored Dr. F. Ernest Johnson, who retired after thirty years as secretary of the department of research and education of the National Council of Churches of Christ in the United States of America. Dr. Johnson was guest of honor at a luncheon at the Marble Collegiate Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission has announced that it would have a special hearing on a disclaimer by the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western that the I. C. C. has jurisdiction over any control the Lackawanna might exercise in the Nickel Plate by reason of ownership of 330,000 shares of the latter's common, with the right to elect two directors.
In its preliminary annual report for 1952 the Allied Chemical and Dye Corporataion showed a drop in sales, but earnings were little changed from a year ago.

The New York Yankees baseball club will make a further check on television's effect on gate receipts this summer by withdrawing a limited number of home games from video coverage and supplanting them with an equal number of televised games on the road.

BALTIMORE, Md., Jan. 27 (UP) -- Six Communist leaders were taken into custody by United States marshals today to begin prison terms for conspiring to teach and advocate violent overthrow of the Government.

KHARTUM, The Sudan, Jan. 10 -- Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib's regime is promoting its revolutionary plans for a high-level dam in Upper Egypt with great enthusiasm. There is confusion over them because of their departure from earlier projects.

As a preliminary to the drafting of local legislation designed to correct New York's waterfront crime conditions, the City Council unanimously approved yesterday the creation of a seven-man special committee to study findings of the State Crime Commission and other agencies looking into pier evils.

A new effort to alleviate the housing shortage here among middle-income families was suggested last night by Paul Tishman, president of the Paul Tishman Company, general contractors, who urged savings banks to adopt a long-range program for ten years involving $360,000,000.

Minus signs were in the minority in the stock market yesterday. The market advanced warily, by fractions, rather generally on reports of better earnings, better dividends and split-up proposals. Rails, steels, motors, rubbers, and chemicals led the parade. Only two of the ten most active issues were lower.
Seton Hall, carrying a nineteen-game winning streak, sat down on the No. 1 seat in the college basketball standings for the second straight week yesterday, but found it hard to relax.
ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 27 (UP) -- Imported Royal Serenade, considered the sprint champion of England, scored his first American victory today at Santa Anita.

The name of Governor Peter Stuyvesant will be cropping up in the news again soon, not only in his native Holland but also on the Dutch island of Curacao in the West Indies and right here in Manhattan, both of which islands he once governed.

THERE are always new gadgets to reduce the bank balance of the hunter and fisherman, and we had a preview of most of them yesterday at the annual convention and show of the National Sporting Goods Association at the Hotel New Yorker.

Jack Gross' failure to testify truthfully before the Brooklyn rackets grand jury in October, 1950, saved from criminal prosecution "many policemen now retired on pensions," Aaron E. Koota, special assistant District Attorney, declared yesterday in outlining the perjury case against the younger brother of Harry Gross, the convicted bookmaker.

KANDANGAN, South Borneo, Jan. 27 -- President Sukarno lashed out today in angry tones at guerrilla elements still disturbing the young Republic of Indonesia and called upon the people to "give content to independence." He spoke at a rally here only an hour after the Presidential party had passed the still smoldering wreckage of six houses and a truck that had been demolished in an attack by local terrorists.
TORONTO, Jan. 27 (Canadian Press) -- Floods of "buy" orders for low-priced speculative mining stocks today gave the Toronto Stock Exchange the busiest session of its 100-year history.

An analysis of the book publishing field in the current issue of Publishers' Weekly shows that 1952 hung up a new record, 11,840 titles published, to surpass the peak year of 1940, when 11,328 titles were published.

Failures Highest in 7 Months Business and industrial failures for the week ended on Thursday rose to 173, the largest number for any week in seven months, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The total compared with 158 in the preceding week and 142 in the comparable week of last year.

Joseph G. Papa, president, and Arthur A. Dorf, secretary of Local 202, International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A. F. L., have until noon today to resign their offices or face removal on charges of racketeering brought out by the State Crime Commission.
The Iowa-Illinois Gas and Electric Company raised $15,000,000 in the public market yesterday by the sale of $9,000,000 mortgage bonds maturing in 1983 and 60,000 shares of preferred stock.

Forty-eight local housing authorities with assistance contracts with the Public Housing Administration borrowed $286,746,000 in the public market yesterday by the sale of notes maturing from July 19 to Sept. 18.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, Director of Selective Service, said today there might be more emphasis soon upon the drafting of young men as soon as they finished school. General Hershey told the American Legion Security Commission that there was a growing awareness that the draft would get young men early or late, and that they had best get in their twenty-four months of duty early.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (UP) -- William J. Patterson, an Interstate Commerce Commissioner, today attributed the wreck of a runaway passenger train in Washington's Union Station on Jan. 15 to the mysterious closing of a brake control valve. Mr. Patterson is conducting the I. C. C.'s investigation into the accident, in which fifty persons were injured.

The synthetic detergents that have been introduced in recent years are cutting sharply into sales of conventional soaps. Over the last five years soap production has dropped from 3,660,000,000 pounds annually to 2,260,000,000 pounds. In the same period production of the detergents has risen from 400,000,000 pounds annually to $1,780,000,000 pounds, with further rises in view.

A former "cave dweller" as well as a veteran who studied at night and his wife who studied by day will be among 512 Hunter College graduates to receive degrees tomorrow evening. The 103d commencement exercises will be held at 8 o'clock in the assembly hall, Sixty-eighth Street and Park Avenue.

TRENTON, Jan. 27 -- A Federal Court jury of eight women and four men today awarded $75,000 to Miss Josephine O'Brien, 35 years old, of Manasquan, for injuries suffered in the Woodbridge commuter train wreck on Feb. 6, 1951.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -The Senate Internal Security subcommittee made public today letters from Dean Acheson declaring that he had not attempted to influence the special commission reviewing the loyalty investigations of John Carter Vincent.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 27 -- Andrew W. Cordier, executive assistant to Secretary General Trygve Lie, looked mildly surprised this morning when enthusiastic applause for him rose from packed galleries in the United Nations General Assembly hall, punctuated with shouts of "Bravo!" He had just completed a direct, simple exposition of the objectives and accomplishments of the United Nations.

LONDON, Jan. 27 (Reuters) -- Ostrich feathers are the latest trimming for evening gowns used by John Cavanagh, youngest of London's "big eleven" couturiers in his spring and summer fashions seen here for the first time today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- The nominations of True D. Morse of St. Louis as Under Secretary of Agriculture and J. Earl Coke of Berkeley, Calif., as Assistant Secretary of Agriculture won unanimous approval of the Senate Agriculture Committee today.

ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- D. Mallory, Stephens, chairman of the Temporary State Commission on Rents and Rental Conditions, announced today that a public hearing would be held here next Tuesday to receive proposals and arguments for extending or modifying the state's rent control laws.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 27 (AP) -- A spokesman for the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Mexico said today that there were no plans for submitting the William O'Dwyer marriage to the church's marriage tribunal here, and that there was no question of a divorce.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 27 -- The first public inkling of Pakistan's possible attitude toward the proposed Middle East defense organization was given by Prime Minister Khawaja Nazimuddin in a speech last night. Speaking at a dinner given by the Indian High Commissioner in Pakistan to celebrate the third anniversary of the inauguration of the Indian Republic, he said:

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 28 -- Vicente Lombardo Toledano, the pro-Communist Mexican labor leader who once was a powerful figure throughout Latin America, declared his support today for the President who defeated him in the last elections and urged his party to rally around the new Administration.

John D. Provoo, former Army staff sergeant on trial for treason, testified yesterday that he had been hounded from Army post to Army post and finally into a padded cell because of the suspicion that he had worked for the Japanese while a prisoner of war.
Argentine Ambassador Hipolito Paz asserted yesterday that anyone who classified Argentina as an "extremist" nation showed a deplorable ignorance of the nation's social and political realities.

In their first important legislative action under the new Administration Republican-dominated committees of both House and Senate have delivered a severe blow to President Eisenhower on one of the key points of the program that helped elect him (and them) to office.

BERLIN, Jan. 28 -- Charges in the West Berlin press that certain foreign correspondents in the city were "well" poisoners or had abused German "hospitality" brought a sharp reply today from the Foreign Press Association here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (UP) -Representative Jesse P. Wolcott of Michigan, chairman of the House Banking Committee, which handles controls legislation, predicted today that all wage and price ceilings would be ended on or before April 30.

Three awards for important contributions to the knowledge and uses of glycerine were presented yesterday at a session of the Association of American Soap and Glycerine Producers, Inc., in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
Net income of the Hercules Powder Company last year declined to $11,218,120, equal to $4.03 a common share, from $13,655,855, or $4.96 a share, in 1951, the annual report disclosed yesterday.

The handyman suspected of strangling and stabbing to death a Westport, Conn., housewife on Monday was caught at dawn yesterday after the police of three cities had tracked him from his Connecticut home to the apartment of a woman friend in Brooklyn and thence to the friend's sister's house in Newark.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 28 -- The Communist daily newspaper Kol Haam was suspended for ten days today by order of the Minister of Interior, Israel Rokach.

A three-story building at 1315-21 Boston Road, the Bronx, containing the old McKinley Square Theatre, three ballrooms and two stores, has been sold by the Kinetta Holding Corporation to Paul Liftman, investor. The property, assessed at $150,000, fronts about 101 feet on Boston Road and 102 feet on Clinton Avenue.

CAIRO, Jan. 28 -- Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib, the Premier, presented the British Ambassador, Sir Ralph Stevenson, with a new "final" draft agreement on the Sudan at a six-hour meeting of British and Egyptian negotiators here today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 28 -- A broadcast over the Government-operated Belgrade radio declared today Italy would be acceptable in the Balkan entente now being fashioned among Yugoslavia, Greece and Turkey.
Pier watchmen, two of whom had had their noses broken by longshoremen, described yesterday to the State Crime Commission the futility of trying to stop thefts of cargo.
Flowers and foliage imported from southern France were introduced yesterday at the Goldfarb flower shops in Manhattan.

Five hundred and twelve Hunter College students will receive degrees at the college's 103d commencement exercises at 8 o'clock tonight in the college assembly hall, Sixty-eighth Street and Park Avenue. Twenty-three students will receive awards and scholarships.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee yielded today to urgent appeals from the Eisenhower Administration and set aside a three-week-old committee policy that required diplomatic appointees to undergo loyalty investigations before taking up their posts.
Federal Judge Edward J. Dimock postponed yesterday until Monday the sentencing of thirteen secondary Communist leaders because one of the defendants was ill in the Federal House of Detention.

There is a strong possibility that the hour-long "All Star Revue" television program, on which Jimmy Durante, Tallulah Bankhead, George Jessel and Martha Raye alternate their appearances, will be discontinued by the National Broadcasting Company after April 18. It is presented on Saturdays at 8 P. M.

Not long ago in many nearby places householders suddenly found an interruption to the placid course of their lives. An ice storm crushed down the power lines, immediately turning back suburban living from the twentieth century to about the seventeenth.
PARIS, Jan. 28 -- Premier Rene Mayer today suffered a setback in the National Assembly which, if he cannot reverse it, will make it harder for him to obtain a balanced budget.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Jan. 21:
PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 28 (AP) -- One of the "boys" who gets his diploma from John Muir College this semester is 83 years old.

TORONTO, Jan 28 (Canadian Press) -- Trading records were broken for the second day today on the Toronto Stock Market. Volume for the session was 12,264,000 shares -- highest day in the stock market's 100-year history. It was close to 2,000,000 shares greater than the previous record set on Tuesday.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 28 (UP) -- The Carnegie Hero Fund Commission gave bronze medals today to seventeen persons for heroic efforts to save lives. Two of the heroes were honored posthumously. One died of burns suffered while taking an aged woman from her burning home and the other drowned after saving the life of a 9-year-old boy.

Supreme Court Justice Bernard Botein reserved decision yesterday on a motion by Joey Giardello, Philadelphia middleweight to compel the State Athletic Commission to declare him the winner of a tenround bout with Billy Graham, boxer from New York's East Side.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -Announced United States battle casualties in Korea reached 129,153 today, an increase of 182 since last week.

INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Jan. 28 -- Harry S. Truman said this morning that: he did not believe the new Republican Administration of President Eisenhower would achieve progress in the "cold war" with the Soivet Union "just by talking loud."

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 28 (AP) -Five drug and cosmetic companies were granted injunctions against Schwegmann Brothers Giant Supermarkets, Inc., today prohibiting the New Orleans grocery concern from selling their products at other than established fair trade prices.
Engineering advances in the next five to ten years are likely to be faster than at any other period in history.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Jan. 28 -- Seton Hall prepared for its nationally significant basketball battle against Villanova with a leisurely 82-52 victory tonight over Albright College of Reading, Pa., before 1,500 at the Seton Hall gym. The triumph stretched the Seton Hall streak to twenty in a row, longest among the nation's major colleges.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (UP) -The State Department said tonight that the Soviet Union was out of order in agreeing to attend an Austrian peace treaty conference only if the Western Allies abandoned plans for an abbreviated treaty.
ROME, Jan. 28 -- Mme. Battilochi thinks all her customers are "very beautiful" and she designs clothes just that way. This tiny, enthusiastic designer's spring collection is for the young.
The charge that Governor Dewey was "ruthlessly playing politics with the needs of our city" was made yesterday in a statement issued from City Hall by Council President Rudolph Halley.
KINGS POINT, L. I, Jan. 25 -- The United States Merchant Marine Academy's basketball team capped an all-winning day for the Mariners tonight with a 66-48 triumph over Pratt Institute of Brooklyn.

State Housing Commissioner Herman Stichman's proposal for block-by-block repair of run-down properties is illtimed and ill-conceived so long as the State Residential Rent Law denies owners the funds to repair and maintain buildings properly.

Prices of most commodity futures advanced yesterday on the New York exchanges. Volume generally declined but lead was more active than it has been in four months and hides were more active than in the last two weeks. Hides, coffee, cocoa, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, zinc, tin and wool made gains.

Thirty-five public loaders on Pier 6, Bush Terminal, Brooklyn, earned between $250,000 and $300,000 a year in 1950 and 1951, but their combined income tax returns listed their total income as only $25,000.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Jan. 28 -- Pressure by the Nationalist Government has caused the Opposition-controlled City Council here to abandon for a time its campaign to allow 20,000 Negro families to retain freehold rights to land in the city's western sector that now is surrounded by "white" areas. The Negroes are to be moved out of the "black" spots to a new settlement fifteen miles away.

LONDON, Jan. 28 -- Documents ters arrested by British authorities in West Germany two weeks ago show that the prisoners were planning a mass movement based on Nazi ideology to capture political power in West Germany, An-captured with the seven Nazi plotthony Eden, Foreign Secretary, told the House of Commons today.

IF the inaugural dinner of the Metropolitan Golf Writers Association had been scheduled for last year instead of tonight, it's very probable that Julius Boros would have had to buy his ticket -- provided he even could have wangled one out of the harassed and over-subscribed dinner committee. That, however, would have been the situation a year ago.

The Feb. 26 performance of "The Love of Four Colonels," with Lilli Palmer and Rex Harrison, at the Shubert Theatre has been taken over to raise funds for the Grosvenor Neighborhood House. Mrs. Edward A. Hill and Mrs. Sidney Mathews are co-chairmen of the benefit committee.

ALBANY, Jan. 28 -- New York City landlords will press for a change in the state rent law that would authorize rent increases amounting to 20 per cent of the rates prevailing on June 30, 1947, William E. Russell, chairman of the Metropolitan Fair Rent Committee, a landlord organization, informed members of the Legislature in letters received here today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, told his co-workers in the State Department and Foreign Service today that they were "the 'shock troops' in the cold war which is being waged against us."

MOSCOW, Jan. 28 -- The journal Communist warned today that "the carriers of bourgeois views and bourgeois morals" were enemies of the people and supporters of imperialism who would damage the Soviet state as long as they existed.

The leasing of city piers directly to "bona fide terminal operators and stevedoring companies" has been authorized by Mayor Impellitteri, reinstating a practice discontinued in 1947 by Mayor William O'Dwyer because of irregularities uncovered at that time.

Frederick Lewis Allen, editor in chief of Harper's Magazine for twelve years, will resign his post effective Sept. 30, it was announced yesterday. He will be succeeded by John Fischer, present general book editor of Harper Bros., who will become the magazine's seventh editor since its establishment in 1850.
HARTFORD, Jan. 28 -- James C. Shannon of Bridgeport, former Governor, resigned today as Republican National Committeeman from Connecticut after serving in the post for eight months.

There were two instruments on the stage of Town Hall last night. On one, a reconstruction of a typical piano of the eighteenth century, Ralph Kirkpatrick played Haydn's A flat Sonata. On the other, a standard concert-grand harpsichord -- to use the most appropriate term -- Mr. Kirkpatrick played Bach, Rameau and Scarlatti.

LONDON, Jan. 28 -- Continued activity in South African gold mining shares was a main feature of the stock markets here today. Interest broadened and prices rose. British Government securities also advanced in fairly active trading on improvement in Treasury returns and hopes of further rise in gold and dollar reserves figures for January, to be announced next week.

ALBANY, Jan. 28 -- Bills setting up a New York code of military justice to apply to the State Militia were introduced in the Legislature today under the sponsorship of the joint legislature committee studying the military law.
The South African newspapers print extracts from an interview with the South African Prime Minister, Dr. Malan, which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Jan. 18.

TOKYO, Thursday, Jan. 29 -- The United Nations headquarters of Gen. Mark W. Clark charged yesterday that the Communist delegates conducting truce negotiations at Panmunjom simultaneously had planned and had organized the bloody riots by war prisoners in South Korean camps last year and warned that similar incidents might be expected to recur.
Governor Dewey summarily removed Joseph G. Papa. president of Local 202, International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A. F. L., as a member of the State Industrial Council last night.

A unit that combines the functions of several pieces of kitchen equipment was one of the "double-duty" objects included in the second annual Hess Brothers Versatility in Designs selections, announced yesterday at a breakfast at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Twenty-four concerns received awards, in the form of plaques, from the Hess Brothers store of Allentown, Pa.

The refunding option announced by the Treasury for holders of $8,867,000,000 of 1 7/8 per cent certificates of indebtedness due on Feb. 15 must have been thoroughly discounted by the market, because there was little new adjustment of prices yesterday except among obligations of intermediate term, which moved lower.
Executives of the United States Golf Association announced after a conference here yesterday that their organization would sponsor a women's open championship for the first time this year.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 28 -That an atomic energy plant could be built within two years, at a cost of $30,000,000 to $40,000,000, to supply electric power to a city of 100,000 population was estimated here today by Senator Henry M. Jackson, Washington Democrat.
TOKYO, Thursday, Jan. 29 -Communist troops on the Eastern Korean front punched a hole in the United Nations lines yesterday, then were virtually wiped out in less than half an hour's fighting.

SEOUL, Korea, Jan. 28 (UP) -- Troops of four United States divisions have been court-martialed for cowardice before the enemy since the start of the Korean armistice talks, a high Eighth Army officer said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Democrats in Congress, a minority by very slender margins in both Senate and House, organized today for a fight to give President Eisenhower the reorganization authority he sought.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Five major steel companies alleged now to control 75 per cent of the steel barrel business of the country are charged with rigging prices for the steel drums in a complaint made public today by the Federal Trade Commission.

A "last-ditch campaign" against tuberculosis with weapons now available is possible, logical and "perhaps even imperative," Dr. Marcus D. Kogel, Commissioner of Hospitals, told Mayor Impellitteri in a letter released yesterday with the Department of Hospitals report for 1952.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 28 -- All five starters scored in double figures as Army easily outclassed St. Michael's College for, a 95-58 basketball victory this afternoon in the field house. The hockey, team, however, suffered a 6-2 lacing at the hands of Norwich University at Smith Rink.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 28 (AP) -- A. broadcasting company official, testifying in the Government's anti-trust suit against the National Football League, said today that he had been denied permission to carry two N. F. L. games although his station was outside the league-established seventy-five-mile home territory limit.

Spring fashions by the winners of the 1952 American Fashion Critics Award, Harvey Berin and his designer, Karen Stark, were presented by Bonwit Teller yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Well known for the delicacy of his evening fashions, Mr. Berin brought forth more of those, designs for the coming season as well as a collection of chic costume ensembles and daytime frocks.

After a delay of eight months since the signing of the European Defense Community Treaty the French Cabinet has now, at long last, submitted that treaty and the related pacts, including the peace contract with Germany, to the National Assembly.

ATHENS, Jan. 28 -- Admiral Robert B. Carney, North Atlantic Treaty Organization commander for Southern Europe, returned to his headquarters in Naples today after a series of conversations with Greek Government officials and military chiefs.

A dull performance was given by Gerardo (Jerry) Anastasia, one of the notorious Anastasia brothers, in a return appearance yesterday at the State Crime Commission's hearing on waterfront activities. He testified at his own request.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 28 -- Machinery for loyalty investigations of all United States citizens employed by the United Nations -- the first such check in the history of the organization -- was set up and put into operation today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Sir Roger Makins, the new British Ambassador, expressed confidence today in the continuing unity of purpose between the United States and Britain despite "secondary" differences on ways to reach their common objectives.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- In his television report to the nation last night, John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, took on the most difficult, and in some ways the most dangerous, project of his long and distinguished career in international affairs.

A gracious lady of the sea played hostess earlier this week to food writers. She was the newest member of the Italian Line's fleet, the Andrea Doria, and the form her hospitality took was one sure to interest devotees of the table art.

If the investment banking twenty years ago was thought to be outside the scope of the anti-trust laws, and if the banking houses involved in the current anti-trust trial believed each had a right to the new business of his old customer, why didn't Kidder, Peabody Co., one of the defendants, sent out letters asserting such a right following its reorganization in 1930?

ALBANY, Jan. 28 -- State Senator Walter J. Mahoney, Buffalo Republican and chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, disclosed today that he was the one responsible for holding up a bill to permit the Jones Beach Parkway Authority to impose a 10-cent toll on the Southern State Parkway.

The biggest bus strike in the city's history came to an end early this morning when two of the eight struck bus companies, after several anxious hours, followed the lead of the six other companies and the union in agreeing to submit their dispute to arbitration.

A plot 200 by 150 feet at Eighty-sixth and Dahlgren Streets in Brooklyn has been sold by Good Fair, Inc., to Chuckrow Wyckoff, Inc., builders, for improvement with a building to be occupied by Robert Hall Clothes. A. A. Robinson was the broker.

Four inspectors for city departments testified yesterday in Domestic Relations Court that there were no serious violations of safety laws in Public School 19, a 94-year-old building at 344 East Fourteenth Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Legislation designed to guarantee equal opportunities for employment regardless of race, creed, color or national origin, will be reintroduced in the new Congress tomorrow. Its principal sponsors will be Senators Irving M. Ives, Republican of New York, and Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota.

The knowledge and equipment necessary to make airplane flight fully automatic exist now and must be brought together in one complete system, it was declared yesterday at the twenty-first annual meeting of the Institute of Aeronautical Sciences at the Astor Hotel.

After a five-day trial Nathan Mennen, 41-year-old suspended policeman, was acquitted yesterday by a jury in Brooklyn Federal Court on a charge of participating in the burglary of the Brevoort Post Office Station, 1205 Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn, on April 29, 1951.

Seven Olympic champions head a star-studded international entry in the forty-sixth annual Millrose Games at Madison Square Garden tonight. New York's first big meet of the indoor track season will provide non-stop action from 7:15, when the pole vaulters begin competition, until 11:20, when the last of six college mile relays gets away.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The Atomic Energy Commission reported today that the United States was entering the second decade of the atomic age with a Capital investment in nuclear research and development of about $7,500,000,000.

The stock market yesterday staged a mild but mixed advance, with aircrafts and selected rails making gains and most of the steels losing fractions. Sales were the largest since Jan. 17 at 1,640,000 shares, a moderate gain over the 1,550,000-share figure of Tuesday.

ALBANY, Jan. 28 -- Governor Dewey has promised to take under consideration a plan to save Champlain College at Plattsburg, now destined for extinction in June to make way for an Air Force jet bomber base.
TOKYO, Thursday, Jan. 29 (AP) -United Nations Command communique 1,509, covering Wednesday's operations:
The State of New Jersey borrowed $15,000,000 in the public market yesterday on bonds maturing over fifteen years to finance the construction of colleges for teachers.

ALBANY, Jan. 28 -- Democratic fiscal leaders in the Legislature attacked Governor Dewey's local assistance budget today as a "befuddled document" that discriminated against New York City by denying to the city its just share of state aid.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said today, in her first Washington speech since she ceased to be a United States delegate to the United Nations, that the United States delegation had been almost ready to relinquish the veto.
A third-period goal by Floyd Curry gave the Canadiens of Montreal a 2-to-1 victory over the New York Rangers in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned stronger yesterday, and closed unchanged to 26 points net higher than on Tuesday, with old crop months showing the most strength.
The National Retail Dry Goods Association expressed disapproval yesterday with the proposed trade practice rules which the millinery industry has outlined for the Federal Trade Commission.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Requests for revival of an abandoned consumers' price index have reached the White House, giving President Eisenhower his first labor problem.
An ominous warning on the slums existing in this city and their rapid spread was sounded yesterday by a Kings County grand jury.

ALBANY, Jan. 28 -- A constitutional amendment to clarify the question whether cities may impose a tax on pari-mutuel betting at horse race tracks was proposed today by Senator Seymour Halpern and Assemblyman Fred W. Preller, Republicans of Queens.

Adversely affected by the two months' steel strike which restricted operations, earnings of four steel companies were sharply reduced last year from those of 1951, according to their reports issued yesterday.

The following excerpts from testimony yesterday at the New York State Crime Commission's hearing tell of a "friendship" that led a boss loader to share his earnings with other men, allegedly without receiving anything in return. They outline also a picture of pier watchmen encountering danger, injury and reproof for reporting some thefts and blocking others, while leaders of the watchmen's union received automobiles, life insurance policies and other benefits.

No one with taxable wealth of any kind can afford to leave an "estate," large or small, unplanned and unprotected against the costs of death. This was the conclusion reached by a panel of estate planning experts yesterday before a gathering of 600 life underwriters, attorneys, trust officers and accountants at the McAlpin Hotel.
A loaded oil barge broke loose from a tug in the Narrows yesterday and struck an anchored oil tanker, causing slight damage to both craft.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Gen. Walter Bedell Smith told the American Legion this week that the United States Intelligence Service was as good as, or better than, any in the world, except possibly that of the Soviet Union.

Many parties will be given at the third annual Animal Kingdom Ball for the benefit of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, to be held tonight in the ballroom of the Pierre. Proceeds will be used to aid in the payment for the society's new animal emergency ambulance, which will be on display tonight near the street entrance to the ballroom.

PARIS, Jan. 28 -- The French Cabinet decided today to submit to Parliament the long-pending European army treaty and with it the German peace contract, and agreed on a long explanation of its reasons for doing so. The treaty was submitted tonight.

Queens Councilman Aloysius Maickel has been elected chairman of the planning and coordinating committee of a new rehabilitation program for that borough's 3,750 orthopedically handicapped children, it was announced yesterday. He succeeds Leonard W. Mayo, director of the Association for the Aid of Crippled Children, who has headed the community-wide planning group for almost two years.

Although general demand for capital this year may be lower than in 1952, the need for mortgage money is likely to hold at last year's level with the volume of housing declining slightly from the rate of production which has prevailed during the past two years.

OSLO, Norway, Jan. 28 -- The Morgenposten, an independent newspaper, published yesterday an article and map showing five Soviet airfields less than thirty-one miles from the Norwegian border. Some of the airfields have runways more than 2,000 yards long.
The Fire Department, as shown by air aid drills, can not protect New York in case of attack, Herbert R. O'Brien, Director of Civil Defense, told Fire Commissioner Jacob Grumet yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -The Securities and Exchange Commission cited Milton P. Kroll, its associate general counsel, and two attorneys in its New York regional office today for outstanding performance.

Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz attacked yesterday prevailing social and moral conditions as being largely responsible for the increase of juvenile delinquency and crime. He blamed especially "the men in high places who hobnob with and 'protect' the criminals and racketeers."
