In the period since 1929 that has been marked by rapid expansion of all segments of national income, the profits of the largest corporations represented a declining share of that income, Dr. A. D. H. Kaplan of the Brookings Institution reported last night.

" No progress" was reported late yesterday afternoon after two meetings between the Marine Towing and Transportation Employers Association and representatives of the 3,500 local tugboat workers involved in a wage contract dispute.

HONG KONG, Jan. 28 -- The Chinese Communist Ministry of Heavy Industry in Peiping has criticized the "poor execution" of production plans and demanded a quick improvement of this situation in various factories and mines under its control.

The movement to band the city's religious leaders into a consultative body to spur action on critical civic problems gained new strength yesterday when the New York Board of Rabbis, comprising 600 Orthodox, Conservative and Reform members, endorsed the proposal. The movement was started Monday night by the Right Rev. Horace W. B. Donegan, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of New York.

PARIS, Thursday, Jan. 29 (Reuters) -- The National Assembly approved early today the 1953 budget of 3,831,000,000,000 francs ($10,726,800,000). About 37 per cent of the budget will be spent on defense.
SOUTHAMPTON, England, Jan. 28 -- Fire of suspicious origin broke out in a main deck cabin of the British liner Queen Elizabeth, world's biggest ship, as she lay in drydock here tonight.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 28 -- The Pennsylvania Railroad and the Reading Company today reported sizable jumps in net earnings in 1952.
Amid the usual fanfare and with Leo Durocher providing a ready flow of conversation, Bobby Thomson. Staten Island's Fly Scot, yesterday became the sixteenth Giant to sign a contract for 1953.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Jan. 28 -Asserting that his ouster as a Deputy Attorney General was "a challenge to the honest and decent citizens of this state as well as to the press who genuinely want uncorrupted Government," Nelson F. Stamler declared today that he did not intend "even as a private citizen to sit quietly by while corruption in Government and racketeering flourish without restraint."

RALEIGH, N. C., Jan. 28 -- The State Attorney General's office joined today with the defense in asking the State Supreme Court to scrutinize the case of Mack Ingram, Negro share cropper who received a suspended sentence in November, 1952, on a charge of assaulting Willie Jean Boswell, a white girl.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -The Truman Administration's split over investigation of an alleged world oil monopoly reached a point where Oscar L. Chapman, then Secretary of Interior, protested what he termed inaccurate representations in court arguments by the Government's lawyers.
Ensemble suits and coat dresses highlighted a collection by Hannah Troy that was presented by Saks Fifth Avenue yesterday in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre Hotel.

Two new films will arrive at first-run theatres this morning. "Road to Bali," in Technicolor, the latest in the series of Paramount comedies featuring Bing Crosby, Bob Hope and Dorothy Lamour, is at the Astor. Hal Walker directed and Harry Tugend produced from a screen play by Frank Butler, Hal Kanter and William Morrow and a story by Mr. Butler and Mr. Tugend.

MARSHALL, Tex., Jan. 28 (AP) -- A six-year experiment in this East Texas city was cited today as proof that fluoride in drinking water could reduce dental cavities drastically. The test is hailed as one of the most carefully controlled experiments in modern dental research.
Hunter College will go nautical tomorrow night with the start of a free course in small boat handling and seamanship for men, women and teen-agers.

The Atlantic and Gulf District of the Seafarers International Union, A. F. L., has re-elected Paul Hall as secretary-treasurer. The election of Mr. Hall and forty-eight other officials of the district was announced last night by the tally committee at a membership meeting in the union's headquarters at 675 Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn.

Cotton was the by-word yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel when Alice Corr, 1953 Maid of Cotton, and her all-cotton wardrobe were presented before an audience of seven hundred members of the fashion press and industry as well as representatives of the American Soap and Glycerine Producers.

President Eisenhower was elected yesterday as an honorary member of the Pilgrims of the United States, a group pledged to furthering good will among English-speaking peoples, at its annual luncheon and business meeting. The President had served on the executive committee since 1948.

LONDON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The International Amateur Athletic Federation accepted thirty-five additional world records in track and field today, including nine marks set by American individuals or teams.

Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, former Assistant Secretary of Defense, was honored by the Armed Forces Chaplains Board at a dinner at the Plaza Hotel last night for "her outstanding contributions to the cause of spiritual life in the armed forces."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- At the moment a good many Washington theatregoers are enjoying Robert Anderson's "All Summer Long," which is on view at the Arena Stage, New York Avenue and Ninth Street. In fact, some New York theatregoers, absenting themselves for a few hours from the felicity of Broadway, can also be located in the audience.
DARWIN, Australia, Jan. 28 (AP) -- A Canberra twin-jet bomber, hurrying to secret experimental work at the Woomera rocket range, has halved the official record for a flight from Britain to Australia.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (UP) -- Two holdover officials from the Truman Administration told the Senate Banking Committee today they see no present need to increase interest rates of home loans guaranteed by the Veterans Administration or insured by the Federal Housing Authority.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- President Eisenhower today appointed former Gov. Val Peterson of Nebraska an administrative assistant to serve as Presidential liaison with Government departments and agencies. The White House announcement explained that he would work under the direction of Sherman Adams, assistant to the President.

In its latest semi-annual report the Atomic Energy Commission presents a reasonably clear picture of what the development of atomic energy has cost us since June, 1940. The grand total to June 30, 1952, comes to $7,963,373,536, which includes only the funds allotted to agencies that have been specifically charged with carrying out the atomic energy program.

Reo Motors, Inc., made it clear yesterday that it does not intend to be caught unprepared when its booming war contracts terminate in the not too distant future. During a luncheon for the press at Toots Shor's the company introduced a variety of new products it will introduce on the civilian market in the next few months.
HEADQUARTERS, Eighth Army, in Korea, Jan. 28 -- Qualified officers here said today that there was no narcotics problem among troops of the Eighth Army.

Traffic congestion caused by trailer-trucks, refuse trucks and double-parked cars is costing $100,000 a day in the Manhattan area between Eighteenth and Twenty-eighth Streets, the Twenty-Third Street Association estimated yesterday.

The new framework for the "Supreme Command" of the State Department is now assured. The Senate has already passed the bill creating a second Under Secretary of State and the House will undoubtedly follow suit quickly. This will complete the top of the pyramid, with Secretary of State Dulles at the apex, Gen. Bedell Smith as the Under Secretary in charge of policy matters and Donold Lourie as the Under Secretary doing the administrative work.

CHICAGO, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Orlando Zulueta, sixth-ranking lightweight from Cuba, scored a fifth-round technical knockout over Chicago's Luther Rawlings, who suffered a gashed left eyebrow in the fourth of the scheduled ten-round feature at the Chicago Stadium tonight.

VIENNA, Jan. 28 -- An attack by Scanteia, chief organ of the Rumanian Communist party, on "anti-scientific distortions in the field of pedagogy" and on a number of leading Rumanian psychologists seems to herald a purge of scientists and professional men like the one Moscow is carrying out among Soviet doctors.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 28 -- Fred M. Saigh was sentenced to prison today for Federal income-tax evasion and it looked as if the St. Louis Cardinal owner had struck out.
The importance of research was stressed yesterday by speakers at the annual Midwest conference of the Associated Business Publications in the Drake Hotel in Chicago.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Passage of the Reed tax-relief bill in ample time for it to take effect July 1 appeared likely today as most Democratic members of the Ways and Means Committee of the House of Representatives indicated their intention to support the measure.

The State Crime Commission appears to have proved its case that the public loading racket on New York's piers exacts as much as five million dollars a year from in-bound cargo deliveries. If anything, this sum appears to be an underestimate. The public loading racket is a cardinal reason why this port is losing out in competition with other ports.

The New York State Bar Association opened its seventy-sixth annual meeting yesterday with a domestic relations symposium at which there was agreement on three ways to reduce divorces and other family breakdowns:

THE annual quack-fest of the local wildfowlers, one of the few events of the winter season which always brings a capacity attendance, will be held .next Thursday, when Ducks Unlimited, the hunters' own conservation group, holds its annual dinner at the Hotel Roosevelt.
The New York Chapter of the American Red Cross awarded citations yesterday to two large contributors to its blood bank. The citations cover the period beginning in July, 1951.
CHICAGO, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The Chicago Cardinals, directed by seven head football coaches in four years, today discharged Joe Kuharich, who made his debut as the field boss last season.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between 8 and 14 years old a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified. The programs follow:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 28 -- Twentieth Century-Fox now has two pictures, "Prince Valiant" and "Princess of the Nile," scheduled to be made with the studio's new large-screen process known as Anamorphoscope. The development is said to give screen images a three-dimensional effect without the audience having to wear glasses to help foster the optical illusion.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 28 (AP) -- Oil Capitol, who hadn't won a race since September, came streaking up on the outside to catch the favored Battlefield at the wire and win the $15,000 added Palm Beach Handicap at Hialeah Park today.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Jan. 28 -- J. G. N. Strauss, leader of the opposition United party, accused Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan today of having appealed for aid to Adolf Hitler during World War II. Dr. Malan denied the allegation, but United party leaders shouted across the floor of the House of Assembly that they would supply proof.

The nation's gasoline stocks rose 2,387,000 barrels last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, supplies were reported at 145,879,000 barrels compared with 143,492,000 a week earlier and 143,621,000 a year earlier.

Merger of the Bayside National Bank of New York with Bankers Trust Company was approved yesterday by stockholders of both banks at their annual meetings. The plan, which will become effective on Feb. 2 gives Bankers Trust Company four additional branch offices in Queens County; adds about $26,000,000 in deposits, and raises its number of offices to seventeen.

Despite all obstacles, Great Britain has made considerable progress in its program of "Trade -- Not Aid," it was reported yesterday by Lord Rochdale, vice president of the National Union of Manufacturers there. He spoke at a luncheon meeting of the Export Advertising Association in the Shelton Hotel a few hours after his arrival here aboard the S. S. Mauretania for a series of talks throughout the country.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Indo-China, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The pro-French Vietnam Government's candidates won almost solid approval in Sunday's local elections -- except in populous Hanoi, hub of French Army operations to save the vital Red River delta from the Communist-led Vietminh rebels.

A police captain and two patrolmen who had been suspended because of their involvement in the recent departmental trial of policemen accused of accepting graft from Harry Gross, convicted bookmaker, have filed applications for retirement.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission called for revisions today in the Electric Bond and Share Company's proposal for preliminary steps to be taken before the company becomes an investment company.

A project to find part-time jobs for men and women now trying to live on their Social Security or other old age assistance funds will be started on Monday, the Federation Employment Service announced yesterday.

PARIS, Jan. 28 -- A coordinated effort by the fourteen North Atlantic Treaty Organization countries to counter the unending stream of Soviet propaganda and distortion against the treaty and its motives will be carefully discussed at the coming closed meeting of the national information officials of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization area. The meeting will be held at the Palais de Chaillot in Paris Feb. 4 through Feb. 7.

Naughty little Susan Posner 6 years old, was doing what she had been expressly told not to do -- jumping on the bed. But her father, Capt. George E. Posner, chief of the pictorial division of the First Army Signal Section, Governors Island, was in a lenient mood.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- In an unexpected move, the Senate Armed Services Committee late today scheduled for tomorrow morning a public hearing on the qualifications of Robert T. Stevens to be Secretary of the Army, Robert B. Anderson as Secretary of the Navy, and Harold E. Talbott as Secretary of the Air Force.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Hourly earnings of factory workers have risen an average of 12 per cent in two years, the Bureau of Labor statistics estimated today.

An increase of more than $52,000,000 in net assets in 1952 was reported yesterday by Wellington Fund, Inc. This gain, according to the mutual fund's twenty-fourth annual report to stockholders, boasted assets at the year-end to a new high of $246,183,017 from $193,930,722 at the close of 1951. Net asset value a common share at the year-end totaled $20.87, compared with $20.02 the year before.

The American Jewish Congress held two public meetings last night at which civic leaders and Senator Hubert Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, called for a drastic revision of the McCarran-Walter Immigration Law, terming the act biased and discriminatory.

Stockholders of Foremost Dairies, Inc., at a special meeting here yesterday, voted to amend the certificate of incorporation to authorize an increase in the $50 par cumulative preferred stock from 100,000 to 160,000 shares and to increase the authorized 20-cent par common stock from 1,000,000 to 1,950,000 shares.

A vacant plot containing 25,000 square feet at Warner Avenue and Merrick Road in Laurelton, Queens, has been sold by Sabo Kennels to the Wegeman Construction Company, which plans to improve it with a building to be used for light manufacturing.
Attacks on Jews behind the Iron Curtain were condemned here yesterday by the New York Board of Rabbis and by the General Board of the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A.
Correlations between the weather on earth and sun spots, flares, and other solar events have never been satisfactorily established, a panel of astronomers reported here yesterday.
BERLIN, Jan. 28 -- A. D. N., East Germany's official news agency, reported today that in three separate trials persons who had "slandered" Jews had received terms up to two years at hard labor.

Although it is not scheduled to reach Broadway until early next season, the revue bearing the working title "John Murray Anderson's Almanac" already is getting considerable attention from Mr. Anderson, as well as from Stanley Gilkey, Harry Rigby and Michael Grace, its sponsors.

A banking syndicate headed by Harriman Ripley Co., Inc. and Wood, Gundy Co., Inc., will place on the market today an issue of $50,000,000 of twenty-two year debentures of the Canadian Province of Ontario. The securities bear 3 1/4 per cent interest and will be offered at 96 3/4 to yield about 3.46 per cent.

The value of United States exports this year will show a decline of about $700,000,000 from last year's figure to $12,500,000,000, according to a balance of payments forecast announced yesterday by the National Foreign Trade Council.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 28 -- West Germany finds itself today in the unusual position of having become a creditor power almost overnight as a result of last year's high production and export record.

Supreme Court Justice Carroll G. Walter denied yesterday a motion for a temporary injunction in an action brought by Laurence Frazier and other Peruvian bondholders, to prevent the Hanover Bank, fiscal and exchange agent of the Peruvian Government, from delivering scrip certificates to others than those who surrendered defaulted certificates.

The St. John's University basketball team won its "big game" last night, defeating the heavily favored Fordham quintet on the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory court, 62 to 56. A crowd of 4,500 fans witnessed the battle, in which St. John's second-half sharpshooting enabled the Redmen to register their surprise triumph.
TRENTON, Jan. 29 (UP) -- New Jersey Democratic leaders drafted a plan tonight for an active campaign under a revived state committee to elect a Governor and members of the Legislature this year.

Dr. George N. Shuster, president of Hunter College, conferred 512 degrees last night at the college's 103d commencement exercises in the Hunter assembly hall at Sixty-eighth Street and Park Avenue. Seventy-three students were graduated with honors, and twenty-three received scholarships and awards.

Officials of Arab nations, from Tunisia to Afghanistan, joined American educators and voluntary agency representatives yesterday in depicting the United States position in the Moslem world as precarious. They held that our friendly relations there had suffered a setback because of the continuance of "imperialistic" policy and Zionist "aggression."

WITH THE UNITED STATES SECOND DIVISION, Korea, Jan. 29 (UP) -- Maj. Gen. J. C. Fry, commander of the United States Second Division, said today it was confusion more than cowardice that caused about 100 American soldiers to "straggle" toward the rear in the battle of "Old Baldy" hill last summer.

Disclosures of widespread waterfront crime and corruption by the State Crime Commission have produced a ghost-like silence along the port's 750 miles of piers, wharves and bulkheads. Longshoremen, long noted for their reticence, have become less communicative than ever.

William J. McCormack, the fabulously powerful waterfront employer, insisted before the State Crime Commission yesterday that he knew almost nothing about racketeering and corruption of union officials along the piers.

PARIS, Jan. 29 -- The Sultan of Morocco, isolated by the arrest of his Nationalist supporters in the past two months, continues to resist French proposals for limited political reforms and to demand replacement of the treaty giving France a protectorate over his country by a new accord providing for a greater degree of independence.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 29 -The race is getting hotter among the major studios to capitalize on what appears to be a growing public interest in three-dimensional motion pictures. Today, "III D" projects were on the planning boards at Paramount, Warner Brothers and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.

Six hundred members of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union, independent, went on strike last midnight against wholesale newspaper and magazine distributors in New Jersey, Long Island and Westchester County.

The Iranians are nothing if not consistent. Having nationalized the oil industry, they now seem determined to nationalize the caviar industry. Having given short shrift to the "British imperialists," they are preparing to do likewise with the "Russian imperialists." At least, dispatches from Teheran agree that Premier Mossadegh is no more willing to reach an agreement with the Russians, whose twenty-five-year concession expires tomorrow, than he is with the British and Americans.

Simplicity of design, achieved through intricate cut, typifies the Charles Cooper of California collection of dresses and suits exclusive with B. Altman in New York. It was shown to the press yesterday.

CLOVIS, N. M., Jan. 29 -Police disclosed today that the manuscript of a murder story led them to a shallow grave where a baby's body had been buried. They arrested the author and charged her with second-degree murder.

All the loose ends in connection with bringing the delayed presentation of "Carnival in Flanders" to New York are in the process of being tied up. The latest information on the subject is that the spectacular extravaganza, rehearsals of which have been set back again (this time from Sunday to Feb. 26), is due here April 30 either at the Century or Ziegfeld.
HOUSTON, Tex., Jan. 29 -- The value of foreign commerce passing through the Port of Houston during 1952 passed $1,000,000,000 for the first time, port officials announced today.
Deteriorated highways and lack of parking facilities add at least $75,000,000 a year to auto maintenance and repair costs for motorists in the Eastern Seaboard states and Ohio.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 29 -- The United Nations Technical Assistance Administration announced today the arrival in Cairo of Arthur Napier Magill of Ontario, to set up a rehabilitation center and training institution for the blind, and for students and teachers of blind welfare, throughout the Arabic-speaking countries.

NEWBURGH, N. Y., Jan. 29 -Leaders of a local group arranging a celebration to mark the city's designation as an all-American city today extended an invitation to Mayor Impellitteri to come to Newburgh to see how the city won the distinction.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Senate approval of President Eisenhower's choices for Secretaries of the Army, the Navy and the Air Force was recommended today by the Senate Armed Services Committee.

The Canadian National liners Lady Nelson and Lady Rodney, after twenty years of service to the storied islands of the Caribbean, will leave Halifax next month for the equally fabulous Red Sea run to Mecca and the Moslem Holy Land.

Plans designed to "speed up" the reorganization of the Missouri Pacific Railroad were announced yesterday by T. Colburn Davis, chairman of the road which has been in bankruptcy proceedings for twenty years.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 29 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie has called the attention of the United States to provisions in the McCarran Immigration Law that could cost 400 foreign employes of the United Nations their status as permanent immigrants in this country.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Jan. 29 -- An announcement made yesterday by the newspaper El Diario that the Bolivian Government would call for Congressional elections this May caused surprise in official and diplomatic circles but evoked new reassurances that such elections would be held this year and probably before mid-year.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 29 -- The forty-member Staff Council, representing the secretariat of the United Nations, met in emergency session today and unanimously adopted two resolutions pointedly critical of the loyalty investigations here and Secretary General Trygve Lie's role in them.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- A yearbook titled "The American School Curriculum," prepared to give parents and the community "something positive and constructive to believe about the schools," was issued today by the American Association of School Administrators.
The astronomers apparently were right again last night, although a series of three cloud layers prevented New Yorkers from seeing a good part of what had been forecast as a total lunar eclipse.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Department store sales in the week ended Jan. 24 were 4 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1952.

The National Broadcasting Company has agreed to lend part of one of its most prized program properties to a major competitor, the Columbia Broadcasting System. Also, an N. B. C. staff television director will be sent along to make certain that the performance on the rival network is carried out in accordance with N. B. C. policy.

PARIS, Jan. 29 -- The British Government has told the managing board of the European Payments Union that it would agree to prolong the life of the union for a year beyond June 30 next, when the convention creating it is renewable, if an "escape clause" were added enabling Britain to withdraw from the union on short notice.

Emergency deliveries of materials from manufacturers to dress contractors by private cars, station wagons, and privately-owned trucks, have averted a serious stoppage of production in low-end and popular price dresses in New York's garment market.

Mayor Impellitteri will open the fourteenth annual WNYC American Music Festival in a broadcast from Town Hall on Thursday, Feb. 12, at 3 P. M., according to Seymour N. Siegel, director of the city station.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (UP) -Americans are buying more United States savings bonds than they are selling this month, for the first time since the Korean war.

LONDON, Jan. 29 -- Ole Bjoern Kraft, Danish Foreign Minister, rebutted here today the Soviet Union's charges that Denmark was participating in war preparations against Russia through her membership in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Conflicting reports from the White House and the Capitol only added today to the confusion on the circumstances under which Senate and House committees voted to restrict Presidential reorganization authority.

The necessity of increased spiritual motivation in the United States was emphasized at the annual luncheon of the Religion in American Life movement at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday. The attendance was 250.

The hold-over June grand jury in Queens that has been investigating faulty sewer construction handed up an indictment yesterday in County Court, Long Island City. It was the first criminal action to grow out of the inquiry.

In his first pronouncement on foreign policy the new Secretary of State emphasized the secondary aspect of the war in Korea. The primary purpose of the action of the United Nations was and is, of course, to resist an open act of aggression and prove to the world that the charter of collective security means what it says.

SEOUL, Korea, Friday, Jan. 30 -- Army sources in Korea today expressed surprise and some puzzlement over the tempest created in Washington by the Operation Smack raid on an enemy outpost on the western Korean front Sunday.
LONDON, Jan. 29 -- Detective work to reconstruct the effigies of long-dead Kings and Queens was described today by Robert P. Howgrave-Graham, Assistant Keeper of Muniments at Westminster Abbey.
I wish to commend THE NEW YORK TIMES for its fair reporting and editorial support of the proposed block-by-block plan of rehabilitating tenements in Harlem.

MONTREAL, Jan. 29 (UP) -Maurice (Rocket) Richard dazzled 14,056 fans in the Forum tonight as he scored two goals and set up another to pace the Montreal Canadiens to a 5-2 victory over the New York Rangers in a National Hockey League contest.

Excess profits taxes took 85 cents a share from National Dairy Products Corporation last year, L. A. van Bomel, chairman, told the New York Society of Security Analysts yesterday, but all that amount won't be added to profits if the tax is allowed to lapse.
Two former cabinet members under the Truman Administration have returned to private business.

The prospect for good supplies of the raw materials that are used to make soaps and detergents is excellent. This was the substance of reports presented at technical sessions yesterday of the annual convention of the Association of American Soap and Glycerine Producers, Inc., at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The Long Island Rail Road announced yesterday the start of its stepped-up program of passenger car rehabilitation, and only hours later had the stamp of inadequacy put on it by the Long Island Transit Authority.
The work of a group of designers of the future, now students at interior decoration and design schools here, will go on view today at the Scalamandre Museum of Textiles, 20 West Fifty-fifth Street.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 29 -Playing no favorites, the Iranian Government, which nationalized the British-owned oil industry in Iran twenty-one months ago, will now terminate the Soviet Union's caviar concession on the Caspian Sea.

TUCSON, Ariz., Jan. 29 (UP) -Confident E. J. (Dutch) Harrison grabbed a one-stroke lead today in the opening round of the $10,000 Tucson Open Golf Tournament by blazing over the course in a six-under-par 64.

Net income of the Union Pacific Railroad and leased lines in 1952 amounted to $69,665,483, equal to $14.77 a common share, it was announced yesterday. This compares with $65,872,246, or $14.59 a share in 1951.

The roar of jet -- powered airplanes has reached frequency ranges so high and so wide that it not only causes fatigue and nervous strain but can break down human tissue, it was revealed yesterday at the closing session of the twenty-first annual meeting of the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences.

PARIS, Jan. 29 -- With the passage today of the Government financing bill, Premier Rene Mayer obtained a respite from the budgetary fight to deal with the pressing problems centering around French foreign policy.

The First Army has begun an intensive public relations and safety campaign to reduce the high incidence of highway accidents involving military personnel on leave, it was announced yesterday at Governors Island by Maj. C. E. McCandless, safety director.

A Greenwich Village property remodeled to provide eighteen apartments has been sold by the Manpel Realty Corporation, William Silverman, president, to the Lakespring Realty Corporation. The property, at 325 West Fourth Street, consists of a five-story building with a four-story structure in the rear.

The International Society for Contemporary Music presented the first of its forum concerts of the season last evening at the Theresa L. Kaufman Auditorium of the Lexington Avenue Y. M. and Y. W. H. A.

With Protestant and Jewish religious leaders already pledged to support a new consultative group to spur civic reform, Cardinal Spellman said yesterday that Roman Catholics wanted to "integrate our own institutions and agencies with the efforts of the community for the elimination and, above all, the prevention of the ills that afflict us."

Many prominent women are active in formulating plans for the second A. N. T. A. Theatre Ball to be held on Feb. 9 at the Plaza. Besides the American National Theatre and Academy the beneficiaries of the fete will be the Actors Fund, the Actors Studio, the American Theatre Wing and the Riverdale Children's Association.

Although trading remained unruffled, volume and prices both rose yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Volume, rising to 1,830,000 shares against 1,640,000 on Wednesday, was the heaviest since Jan. 9. Prices went to the best levels of the recovery movement.
BERLIN, Jan. 29 -- The current torrent of refugees pouring into West Berlin is bringing with it enough driftwood of the East German population to cause serious alarm in this city.

The City Council bill to penalize parents for vandalism committed by their children against city property was killed yesterday in the Board of Estimate by a tie vote of 8 to 8. A minimum of nine votes was required for passage.

CHICAGO, Jan. 29 -- A fast-acting new drug made from tissue extract of bulls enables patients to walk around on a sprained ankle shortly after receiving a single injection, the American Academy of Orthodepic Surgeons was told today at the concluding session of its twentieth annual meeting.

Through poor planning and inept sales training many advertisers would be bankrupt within a year were it not for the strong desire to buy which their advertising creates among consumers. Kevin B. Sweeney, vice president of Broadcast Advertising Bureau, Inc., contended yesterday at an advertising seminar in Baltimore, that too many advertisers still hold the attitude that all advertising does is "keep their name in front of the public."

Clark Foreman's letter to THE TIMES makes it appear that there's something new about witnesses making charges before Congressional committees. Witnesses have been making charges, not always accurate or true, before properly constituted committees or decades.

Chief Justice Arthur T. Vanderbilt of the New Jersey Supreme Court told New York lawyers and judges yesterday that his plan for reducing congestion in the courts and shortening the law's delays had succeeded in his state under conditions indicating it would work here also.
A bold use of large stoles of matching fabric or brilliant fringed wool highlighted the Elfreda-Fox designs shown yesterday by Jay Thorpe at the Plaza Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Chairmen of the Senate and House Labor Committees said today they expected an order would be issued soon reviving an abandoned consumers' price index, but the White House acknowledged only that the question was under study.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 29 -- The Government has forwarded two draft laws to Parliament to create a new central banking system that would combine some features of the Federal Reserve System in the United States and of the former Reichsbank.
Your article and picture on Jan. 16, 1953, showing how San Francisco has coped with the parking problem by having a subterranean garage under a park was a revelation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- An official of Detroit radio Station WJR, Worth Kramer, general manager, testified today that an announcer was discharged last month for injecting personal opinion into a newscast. He identified the announcer as Robert Conger and said he was dismissed for criticising a Fair Employment Practices Commission law that had been passed by the Pontiac, Mich., City Commission.

Federal Judge Vincent L. Leibell yesterday set next Wednesday for sentencing William W. Remington, former economist of the United States Department of Commerce, who was convicted early Tuesday of two counts in a five-count perjury indictment.

The clear need for modernizing federal election laws has been examined by committees of both House and Senate, which have come up with somewhat parallel proposals as a basis for new legislation. This need has been apparent for years, but never more so than during the recent Presidential campaign.

LONDON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- The United States transport General Hodges today escorted the cracked and wallowing Belgian freighter Clervaux toward the safety of Glasgow harbor after steaming through heavy seas to the side of the stricken ship.

BOSTON, Jan. 29 -- On petition of United States Attorney George F. Garrity the life of the November grand jury was extended today to June 1. The jury, already on an extension of service since Dec. 15, has been investigating the $1,219,000 Brink's, Inc., armored car company robbery.

Pledges of 1,307 pints of blood from Army reservists and cadets of the Reserve Officer Training Corps were presented to the American Red Cross at a blood donor rally held at noon yesterday on the steps of the Sub-Treasury Building at Nassau and Wall Streets.

Commodity prices generally declined yesterday on the New York Exchanges. Volume was light, most items showing less activity than the previous day. Rubber, lead, zinc, hides and cocoa closed lower. Potatoes, cottonseed oil and tin were higher and sugar, soybean oil and wool ended mixed.

WESTPORT, Conn., Jan. 29 -William Davis, 29-year-old handyman signed today a twenty-six-page confession admitting the slaying of Mrs. Senada Coats Evans, 29, in her home here on Monday, the police reported.

President Eisenhower in a message yesterday to the American Jewish Committee, denounced the "vicious anti-Semitism raging behind the Iron Curtain," and called on "every free citizen" to guard "our precious civil and religious liberties and to decry, with candor and courage, any violation of them."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -Forty high school seniors from ninteen states were named today as the nation's most promising future scientists.

Judge Harold R. Medina asked lawyers at the investment banking anti-trust trial yesterday to prepare a memorandum dealing with the purposes and conclusions of two Congressional investigations which touched upon the investment banking business -- the Pecora inquiry of 1933 and that of the Temporary National Economic Committee in 1939-1940.

Control of the New York Shipbuilding Company is scheduled to pass today from the Avco Manufacturing Company to a group headed by Louis E. Wolfson of Jacksonville, Fla., chairman of board of the Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation, and including members of his family and associates.

As luckless suburbanites now are discovering, an ice storm has many an aftermath. Among them is such a matter as deciding where to store the new kerosene stove pending use during the next similar emergency.

LONDON, Jan. 29 -- Egypt's note replying to British proposals on the future of the Sudan was being studied here tonight, together with the report of Sir Ralph Stevenson, British Ambassador, on his latest conversations with Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib, Egyptian Premier.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Jan. 29 -- The South African Parliament's lone Communist, elected by the African natives of the heavily African Eastern Cape Province to replace a Communist whom they had previously elected and who had been thrown out, warned the Government in his maiden speech today that violence was ahead if it did not change its policy toward the Negroes.

India's five-year plan for basic economic development should bring a 30 per cent increase in the country's export trade by the time the plan is completed in 1956, Gaganvibari L. Mehta, new Indian Ambassador to the United States, said here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- El Paso (Tex.) Natural Gas Company asked the Federal Power Commission today for authority to build new natural gas pipeline faculties estimated to cost $175,250,000.
G. W. Field has been appointed sales manager of the clothes drier department of the Bendix home appliance division of Avco Manufacturing Company.

The United Nations Command in Tokyo has issued a new and detailed intelligence report which would seem to call for immediate consideration by the Security Council. The report reveals more clearly than ever before the direct connection between the Kremlin and the North Korean regime, the Korean war and the prison camp riots at Koje and elsewhere which have been organized and exploited as instruments of total war.

PARIS, Jan. 29 -- A "shirt sleeve" conference of nineteen young United States Army Air Force and Navy officers, meeting here today, studied ways to smooth out the relations between the 400,000 United States soldiers, sailors and airmen in Europe and the European civilians among whom they live.

Yesterday's favorable vote in the Senate Armed Services Committee means that Robert T. Stevens will be confirmed as Secretary of the Army and Harold E. Talbott as Secretary of the Air Force. Both men have interests in concerns dealing with the Federal Government through the Department of Defense.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -Secretary of the Treasury George M. Humphrey today announced the terms under which the new Administration will carry out its first public debt operation. They include a moderate rise in interest rates.

The retention of existing rent control laws was urged last night by Rudolph Halley, City Council President, and other speakers at a two-hour meeting of the Cathedral Heights Citizens Committee in the Synod House of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

Activities parents and children can share together, from painting to piano playing, will be offered soon in classrooms at a number of institutions and centers throughout the city. Fees are nominal, and registration for most of them should be made now.

The Sun Oil Company, in its annual report issued yesterday by Joseph N. Pew Jr., chairman, reported consolidated net income for 1952 at $43,013,063. This amount was exceeded only by the $45,353,643 earned in 1951.

Rising $1,703,000,000 or 8.1 per cent last year, deposits in the nation's 529 mutual savings banks touched a new high of $22,603,000,000 at the year-end, Robert M. Catharine, president of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks, announced yesterday.

The following excerpts from yesterday's proceedings before the New York State Crime Commission set forth the long-awaited testimony of William J. McCormack, whose multitudinous interests in the Port of New York and elsewhere have been the subject of many colorful reports.

The Westerns lost a great script writer when Michael J. Quill decided to go in for union leadership. The blustery head of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., is the first union president to apply the techniques of "horse opera" to labor-management relations.
TOKYO, Friday, Jan. 30 (AP) -United Nations Command communique 1,510, covering Thursday's activities:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Harold S. Vance, president and chairman of the board of the Studebaker Corporation, who refused an offer to head the Office of Defense Mobilization, will serve that agency on a part-time basis, he disclosed today. Mr. Vance will advise on problems of production in connection with defense but will not have any decision-making powers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, said tonight he was going to ask that a Senate report that raised many unanswered questions about his financial affairs be returned to investigators for a revision.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 29 -President Eisenhower and Congress were called upon today to investigate "multimillion-dollar expenditures" by the private power industry for activities alleged to have "attacked the very processes of democratic government and the Government itself."

Thinking about the use of cheese in cooking -- cheese being relatively inexpensive at the moment -- we happened on a new recipe for a cheese wafer for cocktails that seems to have what is demanded of such things -- novelty.

The Boston Metropolitan District sold yesterday bond issues amounting to $7,781,000 due from 1954 to 1983 to a banking syndicate headed by J. P. Morgan Co., Inc., at a bid of 100.34 for interest of 2 3/4 per cent and 2 1/2 per cent, an interest cost of 2.7007 per cent.

Widely differing reform plans for the racket-ridden Port of New York were offered to the State Crime Commission yesterday by two authoritative agencies, the Port of New York Authority and the New York Shipping Association.

Despite the impact of the steel strike in June and July of last year, the nation's second largest steel producer, the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, had a net profit in 1952 of $90,900,771, or $8.80 a share on its outstanding common stock.

Meat receipts for the last week set a new high. Approximately 39,500,000 pounds came to market, with beef accounting for about one-half the total volume, the city Department of Markets reported yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 29 (AP) -The Knickerbockers gained their fifth straight triumph in the National Basketball Association tonight by beating the Warriors, 72 -- 61, in the feature game of a double-header.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- An Interstate Commerce Commission safety expert blamed today what he called an incorrectly placed air valve for the wreck of Washington's runaway train on Jan. 15. Howard R. Longhurst, an old-time railroader, who testified concerning the wreck at Union Station, said:

PANAMA, Jan. 28 -- The bloodless coup that made Col. Marcos Perez Jimenez Provisional President of Venezuela last month is being used by anti-American elements to stir feeling against the United States among the popular majority that had voted against the colonel.
ROME, Jan. 29 -- The projected appointment of Clare Boothe Luce to the United States Embassy in Rome was criticized today by Il Mattino, conservative newspaper of Naples.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Jan. 29 -- Krugersdorp Town Council's insistence that the entire area of the town should be reserved for whites was denounced today as a "gross travesty of justice" by the Krugersdorp branch of the Transvaal Indian Congress.
In connection with the current discussion of the appointment of Charles E. Wilson to the President's Cabinet I would like to offer the following comment upon Cabinet appointments in general.

An attempt to take the first group of New York Telephone Company employes into the Congress of Industrial Organizations has touched off a legal turmoil within the ranks of the United Telephone Organizations, representing 17,000 plant workers in the metropolitan area.

ALBANY, Jan. 29 -- Low bids totaling $15,598,196 on four construction projects on the state Thruway and $2,079,306 on three in the New York City area were received today by B. D. Tallamy, State Superintendent of Public Works:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- President Eisenhower accepted the honorary chairmanship of the American National Red Cross today and started its 1953 fund campaign.
A gold tee became the badge of merit last night as members of the Metropolitan Golf Writers Association honored outstanding golfers at their inaugural dinner at Toots Shor's.

LONDON, Jan. 29 -- After signing the final draft of a plan to create a federated state in British Central Africa, Sir Godfrey Huggins, Prime Minister of Southern Rhodesia, predicted today that chaos like that in Kenya would come to central Africa if the plan was rejected.

ALBANY, Jan. 29 -- New York State spent more than half a million dollars in the five-year period 1947 to 1952 to provide hospital care for 283 tuberculous aliens, Dr. Herman E. Hilleboe, state health commissioner, reported today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Members of Congress today demanded a full explanation of reports from Korea that official observers of a combat operation in Korea dubbed Operation Smack watched the attack from a safe distance aided by fancily bound "timetables" showing how the assault would go off.

Two new films will arrive at first-run theatres today. "Above and Beyond," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer tropical drama with Robert Taylor and Eleanor Parker, is at the Mayfair. Melvin Frank and Norman Panama directed and produced the offering from a screen play they wrote, assisted by Beirne Lay Jr., based on Mr. Lay's original story.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Grave suspicions of sabotage -- possibly by political fanatics bent on upsetting coronation year plans -- attended the probe by Scotland Yard detectives today of a mystery fire on the liner Queen Elizabeth yesterday.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was somewhat quieter yesterday than in recent days and closing prices on active months were somewhat irregular, 18 points lower to 9 points higher than on Wednesday.

A statement by John David Provoo, former army sergeant and prisoner of war, in which he said he complained to his Japanese captors that an American captain, subsequently put to death, had been "uncooperative," was placed in evidence yesterday in Federal Court by the Government.

Several well known public figures have recently refused to join in public statements against anti-Semitism in the Soviet Union and Soviet satellites on the ground that such protests can never effectively influence the actions of Communist regimes and hence are futile.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (UP) -The Department of Commerce today suspended for four months the export license privileges of the Schmoll Fils-Deevy Corporation of New York City and James J. Grabell, its vice president.

Thirty-six pedigreed dogs, ranging from tiny Pekingese to husky boxers, formed a picket line with seventy-five animal lovers last night in front of the Pierre Hotel, Fifth Avenue and Sixty - first Street.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 29 (AP) -- The president of a television station seventy-four miles from Philadelphia testified today at the anti-trust trial of the National Football League that he was forced to cancel telecasts of five N. F. L. games because his station lies one mile inside the league's blackout limit.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday were 697,641 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

A meet record, 1 minute 52 second half-mile by a German racer making his first appearance on banked boards and the sight of two brash young collegians romping away from four seasoned internationalists in a 4:08.2 mile were among the top thrills provided for 15,000 Madison Square Garden onlookers by last night's forty-sixth annual Millrose Games.

Jerome Rappaport, who gave his annual Town Hall recital last night, was in very good form. His playing frequently had vitality, it was always professional in its technical standards and, save for one notable lapse, honest in its musicianship.

HONG KONG, Jan. 29 -- A "support the Government and love the people" month has been launched by the Communist Military Command in Central-South China under directives requiring all troops to strenghten their discipline, improve their relations with the people and prepare themselves to "smash any aggressive intrigues of the enemy."

The Dunwoodie Golf Club in Yonkers, N. Y., occupying 125 acres between the Sawmill River and Cross County Parkways, has been sold by Joseph LoCascio Jr. to the Sherdrei Corporation, whose principals are A. Dreier and William J. Sherry.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -Senators estimated today that more than five million dollars worth of securities would be surrendered by five business leaders in order to take key defense jobs.

Vince Martinez, the Paterson welterweight who was recently named the rookie of the year by the New York Boxing Writers' Association, will encounter Carmine Fiore of Brooklyn in the main event at Madison Square Garden tonight.

Mrs. Ward Melville will give a tea this afternoon in her home at 1020 Fifth Avenue for those serving with her on the executive committee of the New York Committee of the National Cathedral Association.

SEOUL, Korea, Jan. 29 -- At an impressive and moving ceremony on the steps of their burned-out Capitol, Gen. James A. Van Fleet, the retiring commander of the Eighth Army, said good-bye to the Korean people today and promised that he would come back to visit them.

Milton Berle, television comedian, paid a $76 fine in Traffic Court yesterday, but the show was "stolen" by a six-foot four-inch songwriter, who was fined $2,205 for ignoring forty-five traffic tickets dating to Aug. 20, 1951.

LONDON, Jan. 29 -- Prime Minister Churchill returned to London today after an absence of almost two months and expressed the view that "nothing but good" should result from President Eisenhower's pre-inauguration visit to Korea.

MANILA, Jan. 29 -- The conflict between President Elpidio Quirino and Defense Secretary Ramon Magsaysay over the conduct of the Philippine Government's anti-Hukbalahap campaign came into sharper focus today over certain "negotiations" for the surrender of Luis Taruc and Jesus Lava, two top leaders of the Communist-led rebellion movement.
ALBANY, Jan. 29 -- Following is a digest of Governor Dewey's Budget Message to the Legislature today, exclusive of the Local Assistance section, whish was published on Wednesday:

EAST PATERSON, N. J., Jan. 29 -- Top executives as well as managers of the 300 stores of the Grand Union Company food chain were reduced to silent but interested observers today when 600 clerks from the six-state chain took over top functions in the company's third annual "Clerks' Day."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -The Public Health Service said today that the current influenza epidemic apparently was causing some increase in deaths over the nation. It was the first time the Health Service had referred to the widespread incidence of influenza across the country as an epidemic.

Three new appointments to the Art Commission, two reappointments and one new appointment to the board of trustees of the Queens Public Library and five reappointments to the New York City Commission for the Foster Care of Children were announced yesterday by Mayor Impellitteri.

The familiar cry, "Step back in the bus, please, plenty of seats in the rear!" rang through buses taken out of hibernation yesterday, but only on crosstown lines and not until the evening rush hour. Late afternoon riders were not numerous and were fairly apathetic. They were mainly casual travelers and shoppers, not as heavily dependent on buses as men and women who normally use them to go to and from work.

Metropolitan skiers will have to travel this weekend for running trails and slopes unless snow visits the nearby areas. Observations last night indicated the best opportunities are in the Catskills of upper New York State, the Green and White Mountains of Vermont and New Hampshire, respectively, and the rolling Laurentians of northeastern Canada.

BOSTON, Jan. 29 -- Emil Rieve, president of the Textile Workers Union,. C. I. O., rejected today a proposal by a group of Fall River, Mass., mill operators for wage and benefit reductions for 10,000 members of his organization. He indicated that the union would call a strike unless a new contract, restoring an earlier wage cut, were not signed by March 15.

The six-story building with fifty- six apartments and nine stores at 2304 Sedgwick Avenue, the Bronx, was sold by Geisinger Rau, operators, to a client of Martin Teichman, lawyer. The property is assessed at $270,000.

SEVERAL years ago when I met Victor Gollancz, the English publisher, at a luncheon given by a successful British novelist now settled in this country, I had only a vague idea who he was. But as we strolled around the garden after lunch I began to realize that here was no ordinary man. Victor Gollancz appearance is striking (see photograph).

A plot of 30,000 square feet at Avenue I and Ford Street in Brooklyn has been acquired by the Lefrak Organization for improvement with a cooperative apartment project under Section 213 of the Federal Housing Administration. The development will be known as American Park.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (UP) -Members of Congress fired back that no one cared anymore what Mr. Truman said.
HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Jan. 29 (AP) -- Favorites came through as expected today in first-round matches of the women's invitation four-ball golf tournament at the Orange Brook Club.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Bills to authorize development by private utility companies of the vast unused power potential at Niagara Falls were introduced in the Senate and House of Representative today under circumstances giving high promise of favorable action.

Repayments by sales finance companies were a major influence in the continuing decline of New York bank loans to business last week. Largely seasonal, the $23,000,000 reduction included pay-offs by wholesale and retail trades, food products manufacturers, textile and apparel interests.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -Senator Walter F. George, Democrat of Georgia, on his 75th birthday today pictured the nation in a state of semi-darkness and uncertainty because of the Korean war. But he saw a chance of possibly making some headway toward peace with the Soviet Union. President Eisenhower, he said, was in a position to deal concretely with any proposal sincerely put forward.

CHICAGO, Jan. 29 -- Both grains and soybeans turned weak after a steady opening, but support developed on the declines and tended to steady the markets. There was some hesitation in pressing the selling side because of statements by the Secretary of Agriculture pledging Government support of farm prices. Some buying was induced by reports of expanding export business in wheat in February.

MOSCOW, Jan. 29 -- The 2,300,000 Young Communists of the Ukraine have been directed by their leader to carry out a "merciless" struggle to expose what he described as "beastly" agents of American imperialism, "Ukrainian and Jewish bourgeois nationalism and Zionism."

The annual campaign of the Roman Catholic Bishops' Fund for Victims of War was formally started yesterday at a luncheon in the New Weston Hotel attended by twenty-five fund directors from the Eastern seaboard. The 1953 goal was set at $5,000,000.

Are you a victim of midnight madness? It is far more prevalent -- and virulent -- than any passing epidemic of flu. Midnight madness knows no season and no doctor can cure it. The surest sign you are afflicted is when you wake up and no longer say, "Good morning." Instead, in deepest perplexity, you just ask, "Why?"

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Jan. 29 -- Irked by the alleged failure of the Algonquin Gas Transmission Company to make a single move toward removal of a twenty-six inch natural gas pipeline from northern Westchester County, two groups of property owners will deman in Supreme Court tomorrow that Algonquin be ordered to act "forthwith."

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 29 -- A proposed multi-million dollar development of the mid-city site of the old Broad Street railroad station and the "Chinese Wall" into a business, shopping and hotel center along the lines of Rockefeller Center in New York was disclosed here today.

Columbia poured in 20 points to Brown's 2 in the last eight minutes to sweep to a 70 -- 45 triumph over the Bruins last night in the Morningsiders' gymnasium. The victory was the Lions' tenth straight.

The Bureau of the Census offered some clues yesterday as to the identity of the state's "typical" man at mid-century. He was 33.7 years old, lived in a household containing 3.27 persons and had an annual family income of $3,055. If he were a true representative of the adult population, he would have completed three semesters of high school.

The Whitney Memorial Hall at the American Museum of Natural History, housing the twenty-two reproductions of bird habitats of the Pacific that have taken nearly a quarter of a century to complete, was dedicated last night.

Mediation efforts were begun yesterday in an attempt to prevent a strike by 3.000 produce drivers, loaders and salesmen at Washington Market on Sunday. Representatives of Local 202, International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A. F. L., and the employers met at the State Mediation Board, 270 Broadway, with Louis Yagoda, mediator.

CLEARWATER, Fla., Jan. 29 -- Regional characteristics are absent from an exhibition of Florida architecture and design at the Gulf Coast Art Center here. This seems to supply further evidence of the universality of modern design. Whether it be New York, Chicago, California or Florida those designing textiles, wall surfaces, furniture or accessories for the home appear to be thinking and working in one direction.

The average market value of stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange rose 97 cents a share last month, going from $42.26 on Nov. 30 to $43.23 on Dec. 31. The latter was the highest month-end figure since the $46.04 average price on July 31, 1946.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 29 (AP) -Cpl. Robert W. Von Kuznick, 25-year-old war hero, and his 17-year-old bride, Shirley Taylor, are on a brief honeymoon today at an undisclosed place.
MIAMI, Jan. 29 (AP) -- The Trio Stable's consistent Do Report made it four straight this winter when he defeated nine other sprinters in the $4,500 Thoroughbred Purse at Hialeah today.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 29 -Orthodox Israeli Jews are waging an angry campaign against the growing number of their meat-hungry, protein - starved fellow Jews who have taken to raising pigs and eating pork.
Mayor Impellitteri has approved the block-by-block plan for rehabilitating substandard housing areas, State Housing Commissioner Herman T. Stichman announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- During the week ended Jan. 28, member bank reserves decreased $239,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, and Harold E. Stassen, Director of Mutual Security, who will leave tomorrow morning for a ten-day trip to Western Europe, will be accompanied by four representatives of their departments.
Evidence that another baseball campaign is just around the corner Began popping up all over town yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 29 -- Fresh gains by South African gold mining shares again were the main feature of the stock markets today. The rise continued in the inter-office dealings after the exchange closed on the news of the first profits from uranium production.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, a former United States delegate to the United Nations, said yesterday that in the last session of the General Assembly she had thought "we might possibly consider giving up the power of veto because there were so many frustrations."

It was the maxim of an eminent Greek philosopher that music should communicate a gentlemanlike joy. The concert of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Vladimir Golschmann, guest conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall, was of this prevailing nature.

ALBANY, Jan. 29 -- A budget calling for general fund appropriations totaling $1,072,484,440 in the next fiscal year, a decrease of $36,362,238 from the amounts voted for the current year, was submitted to the Legislature today by Governor Dewey with the statement that it could be financed without any change in existing state taxes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (UP) -An Agriculture Department inspector, Stephen B. Sarrapede, testified today that a grain concern reaped a $600,000 profit by mixing low-grade Canadian wheat with Government stocks and exporting it under the foreign aid program.

The market for prime securities is still touch and go. Investment money is visible on many sides, but buyers continue to be discriminating. The dealer market for United States Treasury securities continues to be a thin affair, immobilized by the pending refunding of $8,867,000,000 certificates of indebtedness, and by the heavy investments in short-term Government paper by corporations in anticipation of the March tax payment.

BOSTON, Jan. 29 (UP) -- Fifth place Boston suffered an eight-minute letdown during sixty minutes of hockey tonight and dissipated a two-goal lead to Toronto as the two National Hockey League teams played to a 2-2 tie before 7,559 Boston Garden fans.

LONDON, Jan. 29 -- Whatever his hopes may be John Foster Dulles, United States Secretary of State, is regarded as unlikely to succeed in nudging Britain any closer toward European unity on his forthcoming visit to London and Western Europe. This country continues to look with a benevolent eye on such projects as the Schuman plan and the European Defense Community but it will not join them.

Members of the shipbuilding, industry received unconfirmed reports yesterday that the New York Shipbuilding Corporation had sold its extensive holdings on the Delaware River at Camden, N. J. The concern has built scores of vessels there in recent decades and in World War II the yard was engaged exclusively in the construction of warships for the Navy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -Senator Olin D. Johnston, Democrat of South Carolina, urged a sweeping overhaul today of the Government's activities abroad, saying that at least 100,000 employes overseas could be discharged.

C. Douglas Dillon, Ambassador-designate to France, declared yesterday that this country should "never forget the importance of a friendly and strong France." He praised that nation for "still giving intellectual leadership and strength to the world today."
OLDSMAR, Fla., Jan. 29 (AP) -Jockey Edward Danhauer died today a few minutes after his mount broke a leg, fell and rolled over him in the fifth race at Sunshine Park.
ALBANY, Jan. 29 -- Governor Dewey needs only $9,225,000 more in revenue to balance his 1953-54 budget than the state expects to collect in the present fiscal year ending March 31.

Events today: "Carmen," special students' performance, Metropolitan Opera, 1 P. M.; Philharmonic-Symphony, Vladimir Golschmann conducting, John Corigliano, violinist, Carnegie Hall, 2:30; "Don Giovanni," Metropolitan Opera, 8.

A new feature in built-in gas cooking units is a griddle-broiler combined with four burners in the In-a-Top model of Chambers, Shelbyville, Ind. The new product was shown to the trade here for the first time yesterday at Town House.

VIENNA, Jan. 29 -- The Austrian Government, if the People's party has its way, will seek foreign and domestic capital to complete Hitler's automobile highways, to convert the state railroads and the post office into independent self-supporting corporations and to develop this country's extensive water-power resources.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 29 -More than 1,000 chemists and chemical engineers were told today that a Doctor of Philosophy degree in science or engineering would dd about $40,000 to the lifetime salary of a Bachelor of Science.

LONDON, Jan. 29 -- A wonderful preview of dresses that peeresses will wear under their robes in Westminster Abbey was given yesterday by the Queen's dressmaker, Norman Hartnell. The colors were gold and white, dictated by coronation dress regulations.
Bus service got off to a slow start yesterday after a four-week strike, but all the bus lines promsed near-normal operations in time for the morning rush today.

TOKYO, Friday, Jan. 30 -- Top United States Army commanders gathered here yesterday for conferences that might presage new steps in the Korean War. On the peninsula United Nations troops fought in patrol actions and minor probing attacks and Allied planes pounded enemy communications.

THE upstate foxhunters seem to be having an unusually active season, and reports from some of the areas indicate that foxes are more than merely plentiful and come under the heading of "abundant," which is not too bright a prospect for the pheasant and grouse populations and rather black for the rabbits.

INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Jan. 29 (UP) -- Former President Harry S. Truman called some members of Congress "squirrel heads" and "pinheads" today in a broadside supporting President Eisenhower on the issue of Government reorganization.

TUCSON, Ariz., Jan. 30 (AP) -- Another round of so-called "lucky" golf today kept E. J. (Dutch) Harrison of Ardmore, Okla., in the lead in the $10,000 Tucson open golf tournament at the halfway mark with a ten-under-par total of 64, 66-130.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Senator Charles W. Tobey, Republican of New Hampshire, told the Senate today he would investigate organized crime on the United States waterfronts and "clean these rats out of the country."

For the fourth day in a row prices on the New York Stock Exchange rose yesterday. The high was the best since Jan. 5, the close the best since Jan. 6. Industrials were at their highest since 1951, with du Pont in the lead.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Congressional Armed Service Committee leaders today declared themselves satisfied that Operation Smack in Korea was a routine combat operation and that criticism of the attack suggesting that it had been a "demonstration" for the benefit of high-ranking observers was unjustified.

The Phillips Petroleum Company last year achieved the highest gross and net income in the history of the company, according to preliminary annual figures issued yesterday by K. S. Adams, chairman, and Paul Endacott, president.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UP) -- Representative John W. McCormack, Democrat of Massachusetts, said tonight that the Republican-controlled Congress already had shown it would not cooperate with President Eisenhower. He predicted that Congress soon would become embroiled in an "intra-party fight."
PUSAN, Korea, Jan. 30 -- The worst fire in the recent history of this city destroyed hundreds of buildings in the black market area here tonight. At least 2,000 persons were homeless.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UP) -- A majority of the House of Representatives Ways and Means Committee supports Representative Daniel A. Reed's bill to cut personal income taxes 11 percent beginning July 1, it was disclosed today.

The photograph published in your paper of Jan. 27 showing "Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib, Premier of Egypt, as he addressed a recent rally in Cairo," deserves more than the passing remark you gave it. This photo is much more significant in what it represents; it loses its real value on account of what is omitted.

Gay pre-sailing parties, lively band music, paper streamers and confetti were the order of the day at the departure yesterday of the Italian luxury liner Andrea Doria. The 30,000-ton ship left at noon on a West Indies cruise.

If President Eisenhower did not owe his election to the votes of women, they at least made possible his large majority, it was asserted yesterday by Miss Bertha Adkins, assistant chairman of the Republican National Committee. She said the women's division of the committee intended to try to retain this vote in an attempt to increase in the 1954 elections the present narrow Republican majorities in both Houses of Congress.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 30 -- The Republic of Korea's spokesman at the United Nations said tonight that removal of the Seventh Fleet's guard against Chinese Nationalist invasion of the mainland would be a move that could lead to total victory in Korea.

Mildred Miller, young American mezzo-soprano, got her chance to sing the title role in "Carmen" at the Metropolitan Opera yesterday afternoon. It was the second matinee of the season for students arranged by the Metropolitan Opera Guild, and the house full of boys and girls made as respectful and responsive an audience as any new Carmen is likely to have.

TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Jan. 30 -- Bids of $4,213,735 for construction of more of the preliminary parts of the State Thruway bridge across the Tappan Zee of the Hudson River here were reported today by the Thruway Authority. Contracts are expected to be awarded in two weeks.
GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Saturday, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Lake Placid, N. Y., was chosen early today as the site for the 1955 world bobsled championships.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Representatives of forty-six nations attended today the opening of a conference that will decide whether the International Wheat Agreement will be extended after July 31 when the four-year-pact officially expires.

Twenty years ago this week Hitler came to power in Germany. It is hard to believe that only two decades have elapsed since the ominous event; in those two decades the face of the world has changed so drastically that looking back is like trying to trace the features of childhood in the ravaged visage of an old man.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 30 -- The Federal Government has decided to submit the Israeli restitution agreement to Parliament next week for ratification. Barring unforeseen developments, the Government hopes the agreement willl be ratified before April 1.

Our Park Department makes it quite clear to good neighbors to the south of us who propose setting up in New York statues of national heroes -- or favorite sons -- that, while the city is glad to provide the site, the cost of the statue must be paid by the donor and the design approved by the Municipal Art Commission.

Judge Harold R. Medina said in Federal Court here yesterday that the more he understands about the investment banking business, the less he suspects the conspiratorial intent of certain acts alleged by the Department of Justice to be in violation of the anti-trust laws.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The Senate late today confirmed President Eisenhower's nomination of Roger M. Kyes, until recently vice president of the General Motors Corporation, as Deputy Secretary of Defense.

Changes in commodity prices were irregular yesterday on the New York exchanges. Volume continued low except in hides, which were more active than at any time in three months, and sugar, which showed improvement. Vegetable oils were slower than in recent months.

LONDON, Jan. 30 -- South African gold mining shares continued to rise on the stock markets here today and had their busiest day in a long time. Buying was stimulated by last night's disclosure of high uranium earnings of West Rand Consolidated and prices made general advance under lead of the gold mine uranium producers.
MONTREAL, Jan. 30 (UP) -- Robert M. Fowler, president of the Canadian Pulp and Paper Association, denied today that newsprint companies make too much profit.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today a further drop of about 1 per cent in farm prices during the month ending Jan. 15, putting them about 11 per cent below a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles was en route to Western Europe today after receiving last-minute instructions from President Eisenhower on his delicate assignment of persuading the Allies of the United States that their unification for defense might well determine the future of the American aid policy.

TOKYO, Saturday, Jan. 31 -- The Chinese Communist-controlled press and radio last night accused the Japanese Government of criminality and violation of international conventions for turning over to the United Nations Command five North Korean war prisoners who had escaped from a stockade on Koje Island.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- President Eisenhower has decided to end the "neutralizing" role of the Seventh Fleet in the Strait of Formosa to permit the Chinese Nationalists to attack the mainland, as their improved capabilities permit.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Spirits became a White House mystery today.

Senator William Langer, Republican of North Dakota, new chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, announced last night that he had appointed a five-member subcommittee on civil liberties that would work "unhesitatingly" toward protecting "the interests of the people."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- The Government has increased substantially the amount of carbon and alloy steel makers of refrigerators, stoves and other appliances can use in the second quarter of this year.

The general executive committee of the United Telephone Organizations, an independent union of 17,000 plant workers of the New York Telephone Company in the metropolitan area, postponed the election of its officers scheduled for yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 30 (AP) -- The United States mission said today that so far as it knew the McCarran Immigration Law had caused no hardship either to foreign employes of the United Nations or to Secretary General Trygve Lie in his administration of the organization.

Kenneth Amada, the young American pianist who made a favorable impression at his debut a little more than a year ago, returned to Town Hall last night with a program built around three works -- Haydn's popular Sonata in D, Schumann's Symphonic Etudes and the Ravel Sonatine.

Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh was denounced yesterday at a Municipal Building budget hearing for his "arbitrary and capricious" policy of upholding traffic tickets issued to city em ployes who drive either their own or city-owned cars on official business.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Both the Chilean Senate and the Chamber of Deputies have approved a plan to give the Government of President Carlos Ibanez authority to set the price of copper bought from United States companies operating in Chile.

A "climate of distrust and fear" created by the investigations of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin and by the passage of the McCarran-Walter Immigration Act has heightened intercultural tensions in settlement house areas, the National Federation of Settlement and Neighborhood Centers reported yesterday.

Efforts to check further reduction in cash discounts by manufacturers are gathering headway among retailers, it was reported here yesterday. Manufacturers in a number of lines in recent years have cut "historical" cash discounts or adopted a net basis, a trend that was said to have cost merchants millions of dollars.
The Corporation of the City of New York will be 300 years old on Monday and a search of the records shows that only one other New York institution is as old -- and older.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The Railway Express Agency today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to authorize a complete revamping of express rates and charges, involving increases in all but a few categories.

The Board of Estimate, by a tie vote, has again defeated the anti-vandalism bill that would have carried home to parents some of the financial responsibility (to a limit of $25) for damage committed by their children against city property, especially the public schools and parks.

Events today: Little Orchestra Society, Young People's Concert, Hunter College, 11 A. M.; "Carmen," Metropolitan Opera, 2 P. M.; Augsburg College Choir of Minneapolis, Town Hall, 5:30; "Rigoletto," Metropolitan Opera, 8:30 and Philharmonic-Symphony, Vladimir Golschmann conducting, Vera Franceschi, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 8:45.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- A second scheduled speaker canceled an address before the Women's Patriotic Conference on National Defense today. Officials of the organization announced that Alfred Kohlberg, head of the American China Foundation, had sent a note saying he would not appear.

T. Vincent Quinn, Queens County District Attorney, was indicted again yesterday by a Brooklyn Federal grand jury on a charge of accepting illegally lawyer's fees while he was a member of the House of Representatives. Also indicted were his two former law associates, James D. Saver and Martin Schwaeber, who were accused of "aiding and abetting" in the acceptance of the fees.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- John E. Coogan of Carbondale, Pa., has solved things for the man who shuts off the alarm and goes back to sleep, waking at 11 o'clock to find that he's missed four appointments. Mr. Coogan patented this week an alarm clock that keeps an electric eye glued on the sleeper and forces him to get out of bed and stay out.

HICKSVILLE, L. I., Jan. 30 -- Rival referendums, one conducted by the Oyster Bay Town Board and the other by a group of Levittown home owners, were held tonight to sample public opinion on redistricting recreational facilities in the huge Levitt Sons home development.

Continuing his investigation into Communist influence in the city school system, Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, suspended three more teachers yesterday for refusing to answer questions about alleged party, membership.

ATLANTA, Jan. 30 -- The development of undergraduate programs for the training of psychologists in Southern colleges is essential if the South is to overcome a severe shortage of community psychological services, an eight-state conference study group heard today.
