The State of Mississippi ,announced yesterday that it would receive bids March 3 on $9,200,000 of Pascagoula River bridge revenue bonds due from 1957 to 1983.

Two new films, both imports, will open at first-run theatres today. "Curtain Up," a British comedy featuring Robert Morley and Margaret Rutherford is at the Sixtieth Street. Trans-Lux. Ralph Smart directed and Robert Garrett produced the J. Arthur Rank presentation, a Noel Meadow-Fine Arts release, from a screen play by Michael Pertwee and Jack Davies, as adapted from Philip King's play, "On Monday Next."

All independent thinkers will agree with your editorial in THE TIMES of Jan. 26, in which you quote Dr. James B. Conant's final annual report (Harvard) as saying: "* * * it is the freedom to disagree, to quarrel with authority on intellectual matters, to think otherwise, that has made this nation what it is."

Negotiators for the American and National Broadcasting Companies and the National Association of Broadcast Engineers and Technicians, C. I. O., will continue discussions today in an effort to agree on new wage scales and job reclassifications for network technical personnel.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange in January not only fell below the activity of the previous month, but receded to the smallest volume for a corresponding month since 1949. Sales were above the million-share mark in every session, the largest of which was 2,135,184 shares on Jan. 5.
Prices of the cotton futures market closed steady yesterday, with active months 3 to 8 points net higher Trading on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderate in volume.

Making no headway but still battling for a share of the television receipts for his club's road games, Bill Veeck, owner of the Browns, yesterday intimated that he had a "secret weapon" in reserve for use against the Yankees, Red Sox and Indians.

The Noma Electric Corporation's plan for transfer of the assets of the Decorative Lighting Division to Noma Lites. Inc., has been approved by directors of both companies, Henri Sadacca, president of Noma Electric, announced yesterday.
This month was both warmer and wetter than the average January, the Weather Bureau reported yesterday, and compared to an average February next month will likely be the same.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The Atomic Energy Commission announced late today that there was no doubt but that the Soviet Union had produced fissionable materials in quantity and built up its own "supply of atomic weapons."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., Democrat of New York, today urged the Federal Power Commission to safeguard the public interest in any license it might grant for development of St. Lawrence River power.

CHICAGO, Jan. 30 -- The grain markets were under pressure much of the session on the Board of Trade today, but there was considerable professional evening-up for over the week-end, which made for an uneven price course.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Jan. 30 -- The southern part of the Bronx River Parkway in Westchester will be closed for a year or more beginning Monday morning, the County Park Commission announced today.

New York's taxable realty wealth for the next fiscal year has been set tentatively by city assessors at $19,912,291,020, the highest official estimate of the worth of privately owned property in the city's history.

The National Association of Women Artists is exhibiting work in many mediums in the Delmonico Hotel. About ninety works in all are on view and they include oils, water-colors, sculpture and miniatures and, on the whole, they are realist and conservative.

A new work by Shepard B. Clough, Professor of History at Columbia University Graduate School, will be published by Crowell on March 24 under the title "The American Way: The Economic Basis of Our Civilization."
LONDON, Jan. 30 -- If there was ever any question about how most of the British feel about their quiet Sunday, it was answered today. They like it.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30 -The Jewish altar of the Chapel of the Four Chaplains was formally dedicated here tonight in memory of Rabbi Alexander D. Goode, one of the chaplains honored in the cause of brotherhood.

The threat of interference with a scheduled bout between Paddy De Marco, Brooklyn lightweight, and George Araujo of Providence in Madison Square Garden on Feb. 20 disappeared yesterday when the State Athletic Commission approved the match on the condition that De Marco's next subsequent engagement must be for Promoter Sam Silverman of Boston.

In the midst of our excitement in inaugurating a new Administration at Washington it might be interesting to note how our neighbor Mexico is going about the same business. For instance, one comparison could be made in reference to handling the problem of private gain made from public office, which both Candidate Eisenhower and Candidate Ruis Cortines announced as one of their chief concerns.

Six tanker companies under conract to the Seafarers International Union. A. F. L., already have signed, the union's new general agreement, which was described yesterday as the "top tanker contract in the industry." The remaining twelve companies are expected to sign in the next few days, the union reported yesterday.

Jack Gross, 25-year-old brother of Harry Gross, the convicted bookmaker, was found guilty yesterday in Kings County Court by a blue ribbon jury of perjury in the second degree. The charge, a misdemeanor carries a penitentiary term of up to three years and a $500 fine.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Dr. Arthur S. Adams, president of the American Council of Education, today put before the organization's members two important issues -- solving the problems of educational television and increasing public understanding of education.

In another impressive exhibition of boxing skill and punching accuracy, Vince Martinez, promising young welterweight from Paterson, last night scored his thirteenth straight ring triumph and his twenty-sixth conquest in twenty-seven engagements.

ABOARD A PATROL BOAT IN GULF OF MEXICO, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Myron Kinley, a 54-year-old veteran fire fighter scarred from previous battles, successfully lassoed a flaming offshore gas well today to send its flames shooting straight up in the air and away from other installations.

A building containing 10,000 square feet of space on Fifty-fourth street, 100 feet west of Thirty-ninth Avenue, in Woodside, Queens, has been leased from the 55 Woodside Corporation by Classy Products and All Star Costumes. The C. Grant Keck Organization was the broker.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 30 -- The Swedish Army has contracted for eighty Centurion tanks from Britain, Defense Minister Torsten Nilsson stated today. The United States and France had also been asked to submit bids for their respective type of tanks, but the Centurion was accepted because Sweden's dollar shortage proved an obstacle to the buying of American tanks and because Swedish experts found turret defects in the French type.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- A Federal judge ruled here today that the section of the Federal Lobbying Act requiring registration of lobbyists was unconstitutional.
Vincent P. Brennan has been appointed personnel director of Bloomingdale's.
MADRID, Jan. 30 -- Negotiations for a new agreement between the Motion Picture Association of America and the Spanish Government are scheduled to begin next March, Spanish officials said today.

BRAZZAVILLE, French Equatorial Africa, Jan. 30 -- To some degree, the national characteristics of colonial powers are mirrored in their overseas possessions. Just as this is true of commercially minded Britain and industrious Belgium, it is also the case with France, heir to a tradition of revolutionary humanitarianism and a center of artistic culture.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Funds to finance what promised to be one of the most ambitious investigating programs yet undertaken by Congress were approved by the Senate today.

In a carefully chosen 200-word statement, which he read to reporters in the presence of Baseball Commissioner Ford C. Frick and President Warren C. Giles of the National League, Fred M. Saigh, Cardinal owner who faces a fifteen-month term in prison for income tax evasion, removed himself yesterday from active participation in organized baseball. His exit will follow as soon as he is able to sell his stock holdings.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 30 -- Advocates of a port authority for the San Francisco Bay area find no early prospect of such an organization.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Jan. 30 (AP) -- The defending champions, Polly Riley of Fort Worth, and Bea McWane of Birmingham, Ala., led the way into the semi-finals of the women's international four-ball golf tournament today.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 30 (AP) -- Balmy weather, a fast track, and more than 55,000 fans are expected to greet the sixth renewal of the $100,000 added Santa Anita Maturity tomorrow, with Mark-Ye-Well the short-priced choice. Nine 4-year-olds are entered.
HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 30 (AP) -- The Einhart Manufacturing Company proposed today a two-for-one split of its common stock to be followed immediately by a 20 per cent stock dividend.
The following are excerpts from testimony given yesterday before the New York State Crime Commission by three men old in the affairs of this city.
Nursing a five-game winning streak, the Knickerbockers return to the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory tonight where they will face the Boston Celtics in a National Basketball Association contest.

Negotiators for Independent towboat operators in this area and officials of Local 333, United Marine Division of the International Longshoremen's Association, A.F.L., still were unable to agree on new contract demands in a day-long session yesterday at the Maritime Exchange, 80 Broad Street.

The Port of New York Authority and the New York Shipping Association have placed before the State Crime Commission plans which they believe will minimize the waterfront evils exposed by the Commission.

Smaller flotations of bonds and larger stock offerings featured the new financing by underwriters here this month. Special issues of tax-exempt bonds and large issues of public utility stock, lifted the totals of securities offered publicly in the month.
TRENTON, Jan. 30 -- A Federal grand jury will receive evidence and may hand up indictments Tuesday against three gunmen who grabbed nearly $70,000 in a Trenton bank two weeks ago.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- The Defense Production Administration announced today it has made arrangements for construction of a $70,000,000 aluminum plant, probably to be built in the Tennessee Valley.
Bus operations and service were back to normal yesterday for the first time since the strike ended early Thursday morning, but by pre-strike standards passenger traffic appeared light.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Jan. 30 -- The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad would dispose of its vast New York City real estate holdings jointly owned with the New York Central if it could interest the Central in the proposition.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Representative Charles A. Halleck of Indiana, Majority Leader of the House, predicted today that the chamber would strengthen the reorganization bill if President Eisenhower wished.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Official sources say that Uruguay is delaying the return of her ambassador to Buenos Aires pending a review of diplomatic relations with Argentina.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower dropped a five dollar bill into a basket today for the benefit of the American Cancer Society.

The Government of the Netherlands has notified the United States that as a result of unexpectedly favorable economic developments which have increased the country's gold and dollar reserves it has decided not to ask for any dollar aid this year. This is welcome news, and the American people will join Secretary Dulles in congratulating the Netherlands on a step which, as Mr. Dulles said; is in the best Dutch tradition of self-reliance.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Jan. 30 -- Danish Foreign Minister Ole Bjoern Kraft, current chairman of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization Council, urged Matthew B. Ridgway, Supreme Allied Commander, today to plug a threatened gap in Allied defenses along Denmark's southern border by redeploying NATO forces in West Germany.

The entire complement of the aircraft carrier Tripoli, due at Pier 26, North River, Monday, have volunteered to donate blood to the Red Cross, the Military Sea Transport Service announced here yesterday after receipt of a radiogram from the ship, on its way from Europe.
Lieut. George H. Redding of the Gates Avenue police station in Brooklyn was promoted to captain yesterday, the first Negro to reach that rank in the department.

A spokesman for District Attorney Frank S. Hogan said yesterday that a letter from Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., threatening to '"precipitate a strike on the waterfront,'' had failed to stop the prosecutor's investigation.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 30 -- The Yugoslav Government is preparing a new law to regulate religious guarantees it insists are contained in the constitution. The law, it is said, will be patterned after the policies concerning free worship that exist in France, Switzerland and the United States.

Toothaches and injuries to teeth and jaws from occupational hazards are costing industry $12,240,000 annually through millions of man-days lost, 100 dentists, physicians and public health officers learned yesterday at the first public health workshop on industrial dental care arranged by the First District Dental Society.

CAMP DRUM, N. Y., Jan. 30 Snow Storm, the Army's winter training exercise, currently under way here, is providing another example of service unification with weather forecasting made available to all Army units by the Air Weather Service of the Air Force.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 30 -- The school children in the Greek village of Yiannitsa soon will have a belated Christmas present in the form of $200 worth of equipment and supplies for their classrooms -- paid for with gift coupons sent by 3,000 British teenagers through the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

PARIS, Jan. 30 -- In his capacity as Minister of Public Health, Andre Boutemy has tried several times since the Mayer Government was formed Jan. 8 to be heard by the National Assembly. He has yet to succeed.
Following the annual meeting of the United States Golf Association, scheduled for noon today at the Princeton Club, Bob Jones will House, 40 East Thirty-eighth Street.
ALBANY, Jan. 30 (UP) -- The State Commerce Department today reported the following winter sports conditions:

For the fourth consecutive year the National Book Awards, sponsored by the entire book industry, have provided an occasion for bringing together from all corners of the country outstanding figures of the literary and publishing world. The three choices for this year's awards reinforce the impression of a consistent tradition.
A large collection of decorative tiles by Warner Prins will go on exhibition at the Contemporaries, 959 Madison Avenue, tomorrow. It will remain through Feb. 21.

ABADAN, Iran, Jan. 26 -- Here, on a man-made island at the head of the Persian Gulf, sits the world's largest oil refinery just barely ticking over, operating at less than 7 per cent of capacity while its Iranian management and workers wait -- wait for the politicians to turn the tap that will start Iran's oil flowing again to the markets of the world.

Deposits in the nation's 300 largest banks at the end of last year amounted to $103,600,000,000, an increase of 4.5 per cent over those held by the top banks in 1951. According to the annual listing prepared by the American Banker, daily newspaper of the banking field, the country now has eighteen banks with deposits of more than $1,000,000,000 and 218 with deposits of more than $100,000,000.

OMAHA, Jan. 30 (AP) -- The National Association of Wheat Growers heard its president come out today in favor of continuing farm price supports at present levels "for the duration of the present emergency," even if it does cost the Government some money in subsidies.

With a parade up lower Broadway followed by City Hall ceremonies, New York accorded its honors yesterday to retiring Vice Admiral Walter S. DeLany, commander of the Eastern Sea Frontier, Atlantic Reserve Fleet and Western Atlantic subarea of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's naval forces.
INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Jan. 30 (UP) -- Mr. Truman warned today against bombing Communist bases in Manchuria unless the United States was ready to commit 5,000, 000 ground troops to a Far Eastern war.

Volunteer workers and staff members of Young Men's Christian Association branches throughout the city raised $451,384 toward the maintenance fund in the organization's current budget, it was announced yesterday at the final report luncheon in the Commodore Hotel.

The seventy-seven-family apartment house at 77 South Munn Avenue in East Orange, N. J., has been sold by Rose and Morris Fish and Milton J. Lesnik to the Seventy-Seven Corporation, of which I. Robert Sherrin is president and Philip Troy is secretary and treasurer. Brooks Co. were the brokers and the attorneys were Milton J. Lesnik for the sellers and I. Robert Schefrin for the buyers.

TOKYO, Jan. 30 -- Japanese Government leaders in major policy addresses urged their nation today to oppose communism, reject neutralism and align themselves firmly with the free world, especially the United States.

ALBANY, Jan. 30 -- The parole application of Joseph Fay, former American Federation of Labor vice president now serving seven and one-half to fifteen years in Sing Sing Prison for an extortion conspiracy, has been denied, the State Parole Board disclosed today.

The problem of supplying water-resistant and water-repellent cotton fabrics to the Armed Forces must be re-examined according to J. Fred Oesterling, chief of the textile and leather division, Quarter-master Research and Development Laboratories.

Coconut-flavored ice cream packed in individual servings in small coconut shell halves is a new delicacy here, as authentically tropical as it sounds. The luscious desserts are made in Cuba in Havana and Camaguey, imported by Iron Gates Products and offered at retail by Vendome Table Delicacies, 415 Madison Avenue.

Importers yesterday welcomed the announcement that recent modification of import restrictions on goods long associated with China, but originating in non-Communist areas, has been applied to trade with Japan. They previously had applied only to Hong Kong.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The White House was reported tonight to be hoping to reach a final decision on wage and price controls tomorrow so as to include reference to the problem in President Eisenhower's speech to Congress Monday.

MANILA, Saturday, Jan. 31 (UP) -- Six leaders of the Communist Hukbalahap rebels asked today for a nation-wide truce while they consider Government surrender demands, but there appeared little chance it would be granted.

The State Mediation Board interviewed yesterday in an effort to end the strike of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union, independent, against wholesale newspaper and magazine distributors in Westchester County, Long Island and New Jersey.

A month-long series of programs will be presented in the Greater New York area to mark the ninth annual Jewish Music Festival that begins today, according to Rabbi Emanuel Green, chairman of the National Jewish Music Council.

Ninety-seven of the city's 110 agencies and departments have asked for $913,216,301 to finance their operations in 1953-54, Budget Director Abraham D. Beame announced yesterday. The amount if granted, would be $77,841,093 greater than the total allocated to the same departments in the 1952-53 budget.
May I offer a simple step to easing the ludicrous "football rushes" that take place in the subways morning and evening?
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 30 -- Walt Disney nature Study film series, steadily growing in terms of audience popularity, is about to undergo an increase in running time as well.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Railroads serving New York, Baltimore, Philadelphia and Boston are engaged in a new rate controversy.

Three persons, including a 9-year-old girl, lost their lives yesterday as a result of a fire that swept through a three-story brownstone tenement at 405 Classon Avenue in the Bedford-Stuyvesant area of Brooklyn.

LONDON, Jan. 30 -- A three-year survey of fifty of the windiest places in Britain has shown that a chain of "aero generators" along the west coast should be able to supply wind energy at approximately half the cost of steam-generated power.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Savings of more than $100,000,000 were reported today by the General Services Administration in its annual report for Congress for the fiscal year 1952. The report came as the White House announced the resignation of Jess Larson as General Services Administrator and as Administrator of the Defense Material Procurement Agency, a subsidiary unit.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of use to homemakers.

URBANA, Ill., Jan. 30 -- The average small house being built today. no matter how its rooms are arranged. just doesn't seem to be big enough. it was indicated here yesterday by the Small Homes Council of the University of Illinois at the Eighth Annual Short Course for Contractors and Builders.

More than 50,000 homes will be equipped with complete air conditioning systems this year, S. J. Levine, general manager of the General Electric Company's home heating and cooling department, predicted yesterday. He said this will represent an increase of approximately 100 per cent compared with 1952, when about 25,000 old and new homes were air conditioned throughout.

Walter P. Zeller, founder and president of Zeller's. Ltd., a Canadian variety chain, has been elected a director of W. T. Grant Company. The W. T. Grant Company recently made an investment in Zeller's with the prospect of affiliating the two companies.

An accusation that William J. McCormack had extorted $81,500 from Tex Rickard, sports promoter, thirty years ago -- a charge that the powerful waterfront contractor laughed off on Thursday as an "alcoholic's dream" -- returned to haunt him yesterday.

DENVER, Jan. 30 -- In what is described as one of the greatest grass-roots movements in recent times, 8,000 citizen committees have been founded to work for better schools in this country, it was reported today by Roy E. Larsen, president of Time, Inc., and chairman of the National Citizens Commission for the Public Schools.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Jan. 30 (AP) -- A couple of newcomers to Southern ocean sailing slipped past Hoot Mon and moved into the lead tonight in the seventh annual 54-mile Fort Lauderdale-to-Cat Cay yacht race.

The five-story business building on lot 19 by 75 feet at 296 Fifth Avenue, adjoining the southwest corner of Thirty-first Street, has been sold by Beatrice Davis to Harry Horwitz, operator, in a deal negotiated by William A. White Sons, brokers.

CLEARWATER, Fla., Jan. 30 -- "People are their own best decorators," Edward C. Hoffman, interior designer, told an audience here yesterday at a panel discussion on interior design held at the Florida Gulf Coast Art Center. Other participants were Miss Barbara morn and James Merrick Smith of Miami and Phill Hall of Sarasota. also interior designers.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30 (UP) -- R. J. Littlefield, general tax agent for the Pennsylvania Railroad, said today that 95 per cent of America's trucks aid and improve railroad transportation "by making it easier for most people to ship things by rail."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 30 -- Representatives of the Secretariat Staff Council met today with Secretary General Trygve Lie to explain their position on the loyalty investigations of United States employes of the United Nations.

Dr. Charles H. Malik, minister of Lebanon to the United States and chairman of the United Nations Commission on Human Rights, called last night for a re- examination by the West of its total policy with respect to the Near East.

Protestant and Eastern Orthodox churches in America will be asked to contribute more than $7,000,000 this year for relief and reconstruction abroad. This represents an increase of more than $1,000,000 over 1952, Harper Sibley, chairman of Church World Service, a department of the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A., has announced.
Col. William R. Apetz, commander of the Central Area of the Volunteers of America, unveiled a plaque yesterday noon dedicating a wing of the Bowery Tabernacle, Elizabeth and Houston Streets.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Indo-China, Jan. 30 -- French Union forces yesterday made the biggest naval landing of the Indo-China war, it was officially announced tonight.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Jan. 30 -- The pomp and circumstance attendant on the crowning of an English monarch was described in colorful detail today by Doris Langley Moore, English costume historian, at the fifth annual Antiques Forum, sponsored by Colonial Williamsburg and the magazine Antiques.

Irving M. Engel, chairman of the executive body of the American Jewish Committee, charged yesterday that "anti-Semitic and racist rabble-rousers" in this country were "giving aid and comfort to the Kremlin in the latest Moscow hate campaign."

ALTHOUGH we generally get along with only one President at a time in this country, we always have at least ten million Secretaries of State at Large. All of them express themselves with awesome force and vehemence on what America should and should not do. Millions of them are addressing one another at this moment.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission said, in effect, today the South and Southwest are now economically grown up and no longer require special financial consideration in rail freight operation.

The extinct custom of dallying in the diner over seven course repasts costing only $1 was recalled yesterday by Richard G. Robinson as he retired as superintendent of the dining car department of the Pennsylvania Railroad after more than a half century of railroad service.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Is President Eisenhower merely freeing the Chinese Nationalists to raid the China mainland, or is he promising them air cover and naval support in such operations against Communist China? This was the fundamental question raised in diplomatic quarters here tonight about the President's new orders to the United States Seventh Fleet off Formosa.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Jan. 30 -- The maze of litigation entangling the Algonquin Gas Transmission Company's natural gas pipeline became more complicated today when the company began proceedings in Supreme Court here for reconsideration of the Jan. 8 order requiring removal of two and one-half miles of the line in northern Westchester County.

Victor Clemente, the contractor who built the defective Laurelton sewer in Queens, his son Dominic and six others were arrested yesterday and brought into Queens County Court to face a thirteen-count indictment charging them with conspiracy and fraud in obtaining payments for work later found to be faulty or incomplete.
CHICAGO, Jan. 30 (AP) -- America's 1952 champion woman weight shedder was picked today and she admitted she was just as hungry now as when she went on a rigid diet a year ago.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., Jan. 30 -- National, state and county leaders sent congratulatory messages tonight to Mrs. Edith J. Mitchell on the eve of her retirement as executive director of the Westchester County Children's Association, a position she has held for thirty years.
BERLIN, Jan. 30 -- The American Joint Distribution Committee announced today a full-scale emergency aid program for fugitives fleeing anti-Semitic persecution in the Soviet zone of Germany.

ALBANY, Jan. 30 -- Early approval of Governor Dewey's 1953 1954 budget calling for general fund appropriations of $1,072,484,440, a decrease of $36,362,238 from the amounts voted a year ago, was forecast today. The budget, meanwhile, came under attack from a taxpayers' group that charged actual spending would be $30,000, 000 more than this year's record outlay of $1,108,846,678.

HEADQUARTERS, Eighth Army, in Korea, Jan. 31 -- The incident of the attack Sunday on a little potato-like hill that rises just before the mass of "T-Bone Hill" on the Western Korean front has been given notoriety far out of proportion to its significance, official and unofficial observers here believe.

CHICAGO, Jan. 30 -- A doubled television program for the National Council of Churches of Christ in the U. S. A. was announced at the fifth annual meeting of the National Council of Presbyterian Men today by Dr. Clayton T. Griswold of New York, executive director of the radio department of the Presbyterian Church.

TOKYO, Saturday, Jan. 31 -- United States Sabre jets shot down a Russian-type twin-motored bomber off the northwest coast of Korea yesterday -- the first time such a plane had been engaged over the Korean war theatre since November, 1951.

ALBANY, Jan. 30 -- The state banking department announced today it has approved a certificate of increase of capital stock of The Manhattan Company, 40 Wall Street, from $25,000,000, consisting of 2,500,000 shares of the par value of $10 a share to $27,500,000, consisting of 2,750,000 shares of the same par value.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- President Eisenhower today directed the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Labor Department to revive its old cost-of-living index and publish it until June 30 along with the revised index that begins this month.

THERE is considerable speculation among the gun cranks, the majority of whom are included in the ranks of the bench rest shooters, as to how much the ten-shot group will be reduced during the coming season, but considering the marks set during 1952, it is unlikely that the size of the group will shrink more than a few thousandths of an inch.

LONDON, Jan. 30 (Reuters) -- Czechoslovakia has decided to withdraw from the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization and has sent a letter to this effect to its headquarters, the Prague radio reported tonight.

A multi-industry Lenten promotion built on a recipe known as Pipe Olive Tuna Ring. is scheduled to start the middle of next month. Participating groups are the United States Steel Corporation. the Olive Advisory Board, Pet Milk Company, Associated Independent Canners, the Tuna Research Foundation and the Can Manufacturers Institute.

The issues of communism in the schools and Presidential powers to make treaties roused controversy yesterday at the seventy-sixth annual meeting of the State Bar Association. The session was held at the House of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

Uta Hagen, who has been playing important roles in Broadway plays since 1938, has been signed for her first directorial assignment. The actress will stage Barry Hyams' production of Dorothy Monet's drama, "The Wrastling and the Fall," due here late this season.

New chemical techniques to allow the regulation of growth and organ formation in plants grown in test tubes were described here last night by Dr. Folke Skoog of the University of Wisconsin. Dr. Skoog addressed the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences meeting at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- George M. Humphrey, Secretary of the Treasury, announced plans today to check the nation's hoard of $23,036,000,000 in gold bullion to make sure it's all there.

The respective merits of appointment and election as methods of selecting competent judges were discussed last night by a six-man panel of legal experts in New York University's Vanderbilt Hall auditorium.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 30 -- Failure to establish a European Defense Community would produce a gradual withdrawal of the United States from Western Europe, Chancellor Konrad Adenauer predicted tonight.

A group headed by Louis E. Wolfson of Jacksonville, Fla., acquired control of the New York Shipbuilding Company, Camden, N. J., from the Avco Manufacturing Corporation yesterday. Victor Emanuel, chairman of the board and president of Avco, announced sale of Avco's stock holdings to the U. S. Wolfson Brothers Corporation and a group of individual investors, including members of Louis E. Wolfson's family.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 30 (AP) -- A mother wants to keep her seven children home from school so she can teach them hereslf.
MIAMI, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Mudlarks had a track made to order at rain-swept Hialeah Park today.

PUSAN, Korea, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Three North Korean Communist prisoners of war beat a United States soldier to death Wednesday in a compound on Koje Island, the United Nations prisoner of war command said today.

Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., insisted before the State Crime Commission yesterday that there was no more crime along the waterfront than in any other section of New York. He admitted, however, that he had sent a warning to District Attorney Frank S. Hogan in 1948 of a pier work stoppage because union officials had been questioned about a murder that is still unsolved.

VIENNA, Jan. 30 -- A shake-up of the Rumanian Cabinet, including ten transfers or new appointments of ministers, has been revealed to the public by Bucharest newspapers in connection with the presentation of a new budget to Parliament.

New York as a great gateway for the movement of foreign commerce is indebted to Harry M. Durning, who retires today as Collector of Customs. He has administered the affairs of this major customs district for nearly twenty years and from the beginning has considered his appointment an opportunity for service.
SYRACUSE, Jan. 30 -- The Syracuse basketball team exploited its height advantage to beat Army by 78 -- 66 tonight.
OTTAWA, Jan. 30 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's wheat exports rose to $621,292,000 during 1952, an increase of more than $180,000,000 over 1951, making wheat Canada's leading export commodity.

SYRACUSE, Jan. 30 -- Peace-time use of atomic energy is playing an increasingly important role in forestry research, Donald E, Moreland, research assistant of the State University College of Forestry, told members of the New York section, Society of American Foresters, at their mid-winter meeting here today.

Secretary Dulles and Mutual Security Director Stassen embarked yesterday on a whirlwind tour of seven Western European capitals for the purpose of gathering information on the political trends that have stalled both the European defense build-up and the European unification projects.
TOKYO, Saturday, Jan. 31 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,511, covering Friday's activities:

It seemed to me to me unpardonable haste to headline a recent Sunday's "Mail Pouch" as "Flaws in the Subsidy Scheme" since it was only based on one man's rather short-sighted opinions. The only substantial complaint registered by Mr. RePass in his letter was the lack of high quality in the field of opera under the system of the British Arts Council subsidization.

THE story of the poor little rich boy who just can't grow up has been told in more than one language, before and after Fitzgerald. It is surely a healthy sign that pity for this perennial enfant fatal is now replaced by a clinical detachment bordering on contempt.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Official election returns for the 435 Congressional districts, now made available here, emphasized anew today that President Eisenhower's November landslide was a personal, rather than a Republican party triumph. They also underlined the difficult problem facing the Administration in retaining nominal Republican control of the House of Representatives in the 1954 mid-term elections.

THERE is still a boyish look about him and the mischievous twinkle still flickers in his eyes. That's why it is something of a shock to realize that Peewee Reese is now the Grand Old Man of the Dodgers in point of service. It's also obvious that the New York chapter of the Baseball Writers' Association has just realized it too.

AN extensive new evening program in photography for amateurs and professionals will start Feb. 9 at the State University of New York, Institute of Applied Arts and Sciences. Offering a varied curriculum organized with the help and advice of leaders in photography, including Victor Keppler, Joseph Costa, Leonard Perskie and Bennett Saltzman, the courses are designed chiefly to teach photography as a useful adjunct to other professions.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The Senate Armed Services Committee, which on Thursday approved the nomination of Harold E. Talbott to be Secretary of the Air Force, today ordered further questioning of him at the request of Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UP) -- Government scientists reported developments of new techniques today that would help solve one of the nation's most pressing problems -- its failing water supply.
TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 31 -- Iran formally notified the Soviet today that their joint company for production of caviar from the Caspian had "automatically dissolved."
DURHAM, N. C., Jan. 31 (AP) -- Duke fought back in the fourth period tonight to upset a favored Navy basketball team, 78 -- 73, before a crowd of 6,000.

The nation's small, independent retailers have not only survived chain store and supermarket competition, but they are on the brink of a "golden era" in the history of privately owned store operation.

BRAZZAVILLE, French Equatorial Africa, Jan. 29 -- Vast mineral resources in the African hinterland are being opened up now with the aid of American capital and are helping to develop this continent into one of the world's most important strategic storehouses.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 31 -- The first book to be composed by a new photo-electric process instead of by metal will be presented to the library of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology Thursday, the Graphic Arts Research Foundation, Inc., which developed the process, announced today.

A painting by Peter Paul Rubens of St. Gregory of Nazianzenus, who was called St. Gregory the Poet, was brought to this country recently and sold to the Albright Art Gallery in Buffalo. The painting had been in the collections of the Dukes of Gotha in Germany for 150 years.

A number of buyers were in the wholesale markets here last week but the rush has tapered off, according to McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buying office. Activity in the ready-to-wear field has been steady, lingerie continued active and sportswear and separates are expected to be very popular for spring.

ROME, Jan. 31 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles and Harold E. Stassen, Director for Mutual Security, conferred for thirteen hours today with leading Italian and United States officials shortly after the two leaders had arrived here to begin their European fact-finding tour.

CANOE PLACE, L. I., Jan. 31 -- The fight against encroachment by sands of the Atlantic upon Shinnecock Inlet is rapidly overcoming the danger. More than 1,100 feet of the planned 1,500-foot stone jetty on the east side of the waterway already have been laid.
