LINCOLN, Neb., Jan. 31 -- President Eisenhower's appointment last week of former Nebraska Gov. Val Peterson as a White House assistant instead of as Ambassador to India is the upshot of the latest round in a political bout between Mr. Peterson and Senator Hugh A. Butler, Republican of Nebraska, who threatened to block Senate confirmation for the New Delhi assignment.

SPEED traps are multiplying. With more cars and more money on the roads, vacationing motorists are reporting increasing instances of tricky and capricious arrests, arrogant judicial decisions and ridiculous bail, "bonds" and fines.

Plans for the 1953 British Industries Fair, to be held in London and Birmingham from April 27 to May 8, were announced here last week. A sampling of British products, with 2,500 manufacturers exhibiting and ninety industries represented, will be shown to overseas buyers.

Mr. Dulles' broadcast last Tuesday had been recorded and filmed in his office the day before, against a background of a wall map of the world. He pointed to the map as he traced the global problems facing the United States. He spoke extemporaneously from a few jotted notes.

TO those who lack the patience, experience, skill and knowledge of woods lore of the Indian, the trackless wilderness often proves to be an unhappy hunting ground, a fact that was impressed very forcibly upon a number of hunters who took to the big woods for the first time during the recent hunting season.

Thieves breaking open lockboxes at random in a subway arcade at the Avenue of the Americas and Forty - second Street struck "pay dirt" yesterday in the form of $100.000 of precious stones deposited there for a day or two by a jeweler.

The recent invitation extended by Bishop Horace W. B. Donegan of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York to leaders of all religious faiths to unite in a common fight against civic corruption in this city was commended by Rabbi William F. Rosenblum in aI sermon yesterday morning atI Temple Israel, 210 West Ninety-first Street.

SO much has been said and written of the neo-classicism of the new Igor Stravinsky opera "The Rake's Progress," which will be given its American premiere Feb. 14 at the Metropolitan, that we were wholly unprepared for the quality of the libretto by W. H. Auden and Chester Kallman.
I've been with you all along, in your fights for better TV, but now I've found something to argue about. It's "Ding Dong School," which you reviewed two Sundays ago.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 31 -- The Calumet Farm entry of Mark-Ye- Well and Fleet Bird ran one-two today in the $161,975 Santa Anita Maturity with Happy Go Lucky third in the mile and-a-quarter race for 4-year-olds.

For the first time in its history, Union College is offering senior students an urban areas interdepartmental course combining the social sciences and engineering techniques in the study of urban problems.

NEW ORLEANS -- With the month-and-a-half-long formal social phase of the carnival season now in full swing, New Orleanians and visitors, present or on their way here, are preparing for a special Mardi Gras with something new -- a Louisiana Purchase theme.

THE year 1953 -- golden anniversary of the first flight of the Wright brothers at Kitty Hawk, N. C. -- undoubtedly will be marked by many reviews of the first half century of powered flight and predictions of developments in the second half of the period.

NEW YORK has become the music center of the Western World. Its power and prestige have grown as two catastrophic world wars impoverished old centers of the art and the scourge of totalitarianism drove gifted men and women to our freer and more hospitable shores.
LONDON, Jan. 31 -- About 130 persons were feared to have drowned today when the motor vessel Princess Victoria sank in a storm off the coast of Northern Ireland.

ANYONE who had been accustomed to think of Victorian ladies and gentlemen as stuffy stay-at-homes, cabined, cribbed, and confined on their foggy little island, would be likely to find in Herbert Van Thal's book a series of minor revelations.

Reissues of celebrated recordings will highlight on Wednesday the weekly concert between noon and 2 P. M. in Room 213 at the New York Public Library. Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. Among these will be Lotte Lehmann's interpretation of Schubert's lieder, recorded at the peak of her career, and Maria Ivogun's performance of "So war es mit Pagliazzo" from Strauss' "Ariadne auf Naxos."

THE third volume of poetry by Eda Lou Walton. "So Many Daughters," is divided into two categories, which the author calls "Elegies" and "Celebrations." With all respect to the blurb-writer, who finds this book characterized by "an affirmative outlook on life," it must be said that the celebrations seems hardly less elegiacal than the elegies.

The Philippine International Fair of 1953 is open this morning in Manila. More than a score of countries are represented officially and there is a large showing of private enterprises, both Philippine and foreign.

MUSING in the library of the Camera Club one sunny afternoon several years ago, Otto Mayer, one of the club's leading members, became intrigued by a patch of sunlight on the floor. It introduced a striking pattern of light and shade.

TO THE EDITOR: Mrs. Roosevelt, according to A. M. Rosenthal's "On Dealing With the Russians" (Jan. 18), has discovered that no amount of goodwill and discussion can change the thinking of Russian delegations. A similar discovery was made in the Thirties, when, at scientific congresses, instead of free discussants, delegations under leaders appeared.

Symptomatic of world monetary sickness, a $5,000,000-a-month business in "clearing currencies" has sprung up in New York in the last year. It is entirely legal. A central bank or official exchange control agency generally approves each side of a deal.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Washington's famous Alfalfa Club had some fun tonight by "nominating" Justice Robert H. Jackson of the United States Supreme Court for President before the Eisenhower Administration was two weeks old.

The centennial celebration of Western College for Women, Oxford, Ohio, will begin this spring and continue through commencement of 1954. The theme for Western's centennial observance is that of Columbia University's bicentennial -- "Man's right to knowledge and his free use thereof."

GENEVA, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Plans for an East-West conference were abandoned twice last year because the Soviet and its satellites failed even to answer invitations to attend. There was no indication here today of the reasons for Moscow's apparent change of attitude.
ALLENTOWN, Pa., Jan. 31 (UP) -- Muhlenberg College defeated Temple for the second time this season, taking a 92-69 decision over the Owls tonight before 1,500 fans at Rockne Hall.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- A documented story of physical and economic terrorism used by Communists to dominate a union whose members are predominantly non-Communists was made public today by a Senate subcommittee.

NEW YORK is the only city I have ever lived in. I have lived in the country, in the small town, and in New York. It is true I have had apartments in San Francisco, Mexico City, Los Angeles, Paris, and sometimes have stayed for months, but that is a very different thing.

ATLANTA, Jan. 31 -- The Southern Regional Conference on Psychological Resources voted approval today of a comprehensive program designed to improve the South's educational training for psychologists and to strengthen community psychological services in an eight-state area.
DETROIT, Jan. 31 (AP) -- At least one more, and possibly two or three smaller-size passenger automobiles, will be introduced to the market this year by American car makers.

A new two-year degree of Associate in Applied Science will be offered by the School of General Studies at Brooklyn College in September with police science as one of the majors, Edwin H. Spengler, director, announced last week.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The Civil Service Commission disclosed today that in December nine persons were dismissed or denied employment by the Federal Government on loyalty grounds. This brought to 490 the number of persons who have been dropped from Government jobs or whose applications have been rejected because of questionable loyalty since March, 1947.

HAVANA, Jan. 27 -- Failure of the major groups opposing the Government to register their organizations as political parties appears to have cleared the way for the victory of President Fulgencio Batista at the polls next November.

The death of Mrs. Dolly Curtis Gann brings back those relatively happy days when it seemed to make a difference whether the sister of the Vice President, which Mrs. Gann was, or the wife of the Speaker of the House, which Mrs. Longworth was, went in first at formal Washington dinners. Mrs. Longworth, as a daughter of a former President, and by temperament, was unaccustomed to taking back seats.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UP) -- Robert A. Taft, Senate majority leader, said today that taxes should not be cut until Government spending was reduced.

The operation of automobiles without 1953 license plates after 12:01 A. M. Tuesday is illegal, Deputy Commissioner Niles R. Becker of the State Motor Vehicle Bureau warned yesterday. The normal deadline is 12:01 on Feb. 1, but since it falls on Sunday this year, the deadline was extended for forty-eight hours.
ALBANY, Jan. 31 -- The State Thruway Authority told Governor Dewey and the Legislature today that it was determined to make the expressway "the safest highway in the world."

Air travel to and from the Port of New York Authority's regional system of airports in 1952 broke all records in all types of transport, with air traffic reaching a level that had been anticipated for 1960, Howard S. Cullman, chairman of the authority, reported yesterday.

AT a conference on the life and times of city children conducted by the Associates of the Bank Street College of Education a couple of weeks ago, Dr. Edward Stainbrook, chairman of the department of psychiatry at the College of Medicine, State University of New York in Syracuse, made a plea for less indiscriminate use of the term "therapy," currently applied in many and varied quarters to any procedure that makes its participants feel good.

The real growth of the City of New York begins when it first became a city -- when. on Feb. 2, 1653, Peter Stuyvesant. as director-general of the New World province of New Netherland. proclaimed the grant of municipal government for "New Amsterdam," giving it for the first time its own government, separate from that of the province.

DETROIT, Jan. 31 (UP) -- Gordie Howe scored his thirty-fifth goal of the season tonight as the Detroit Red Wings blanked the Chicago Black Hawks, 4 to 0, to move into a first-place tie with the Montreal Canadiens.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., Jan. 31 -- A team of four Larchmont Yacht Club representatives defeated frostbite skippers from the host Riverside Y. C. at near-by Indian Harbor in triangular competition in Riverside dinghies today.

HEADQUARTERS FIFTH AIR FORCE, Jan. 31 -- Officials of the Fifth Air Force announced here today that the score of the running jet battles over North Korea between American-built Sabre jets and the Russian-built MIG's was 548 to 45 in the United Nations' favor.

APPLICANTS for driving licenses and renewals would have to present evidence of good health and vision under the terms of a bill presented to the State Legislature by Senator Joseph Zaretzki, Democrat of Manhattan.
Sustained good business for the next three to four months is foreseen by the National Association of Purchasing Agents.
The writer is technical director for Stereo Techniques Ltd. of London, producers of the film program which opens Tuesday at the Globe and is released here under the trade name "Tri-Opticon."

LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, Jan. 31 -- It remains highly debatable whether the age of imperialism was truly ended by the Second World War. Certainly one power, the Soviet Union, has staked out control over huge new domains whose independence is no more than theoretical. Nevertheless, the old-fashioned type of colonialism, which attained its peak during the past hundred years, is certainly on the wane.

The people of New York and New Mexico, of South Carolina and South Dakota, and of all the other forty-four states are the gainers from former President Truman's action, shortly before he left office, of adding to the Olympic National Park in the State of Washington approximately 50,000 acres of land already owned by the Federal Government.

More than a million American youths between 20 and 26 have been drafted since the outbreak of the Korean war. Although the Selective Service law makes 18 1/2 the minimum draft age, local draft boards have been calling older eligibles first to fill monthly quotas.
ABADAN, Iran, Jan. 27 -- If world markets should be opened again to Iranian oil the Abadan refinery could very soon be producing at the rate of 4,000,000 tons a year, a fifth of its total potential.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Senate hearings on the appointment of Charles E. Wilson of General Motors as Secretary of Defense have raised questions as to what influence a Defense chief might have on the placement of military production contracts.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 31 -- Yale's basketball squad threw just about everything in the way of zone-geared defensive maneuvers and a slow-'em-down attack at Fordham tonight.

FROM the time of the Marshall mission to China there has been continuous talk in the United States about a "third force." It was to be something that was not Communist, not Kuomintang (that is, Chiang Kai-shek), but was to be liberal, enlightened, democratic and devoted to the welfare of China, present and future.
LONDON, Sunday, Feb. 1 (AP) -- A raging hurricane whipped up death-dealing seas off the British Isles today and spread peril and destruction inland.

OSWEGO, Ore. -- In the Pacific Northwest January is likely to be the coldest month. Still it has flowers, all the more precious for their rarity and contrast with ice and snow which may overtake but do not daunt them. And each week in February brings more blooms.

Arthur Krock starts his article "As Eisenhower Takes Up the Burden" (Jan. 18) by saying, "The man who this week will become President of the United States, the thirty-third American citizen to be elevated to the office * * *."

FROM the publication of Bernard Berenson's essay "The Venetian Painters" to the present volume, which incorporates his subsequent commentaries on the Central and North Italian and Florentine painters, is just short of sixty years.

I somehow never thought that THE TIMES Magazine would descend to the level of comparing the White House to a place of carnage and slaughter; yet look at the caption under a picture illustrating "Nine inaugurations, Nine Turning Points" (Jan. 18).

Citing testimony before the State Crime Commission, Speaker Oswald D. Heck of the State Assembly told the State Bar Association here yesterday that "a small minority" of judges "must be erased and erased soon."

IF Aaron Copland were simply one of the ablest composers America has produced, which he is, that would be sufficient to fix his place securely in the cultural accomplishments of our time. But he has done much more than write notable music.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Diplomatic officials heard today that Charles E. Bohlen, State Department counselor and adviser on relations with Russia, may be named by the Eisenhower Administration to be Ambassador to Moscow.

BARONESS VON GUTTENBERG'S tale starts at the beginning of this century and winds its way through fifty years -- eventful years for her as indeed they were for any European woman who lived through wars and dictatorship.

ALBANY, Jan. 31 -- The Democratic leaders in the Legislature announced today that they would oppose Governor Dewey's plan to convert the four State Institutes of Applied Arts and Sciences into community colleges under the State University System.

ALBANY, Jan. 31 -- Governor Dewey's capital construction budget submitted to the Legislature this week provided $135,015,867 in new funds for highways, state institutions and other public works. The bulk of it was for roads, mental hospitals and new buildings in the State University system.

ATLANTA, Jan. 31 -- Incomes of individuals in the Southeast during 1952 were an estimated 6 to 8 per cent greater than the previous year, the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta reported today. A continued high rate of Government expenditures added substantially to the income.

TORONTO, Jan. 31 -- Eric Nesterenko, a gangling, 19-year-old high school student playing his fourteenth game of professional hockey, and goal tender Harry Lumley, a much traveled athlete from Detroit and Chicago, led the Toronto Maple Leafs to a 4 -- 0 victory over the New York Rangers tonight.
Industrial expansion in the important steel center and lakeport of Cleveland may soon take a happy detour from the narrow, twisting path of the Cuyahoga River to an overhead high-speed "rubber road."

IT is easy to understand, as her publishers inform us, why Antonia Ridge receives twice as much fan mail as any other writer for the British Broadcasting Company's Woman's Hour. She is a friendly, sentimental, quietly humorous writer, and an intelligent one.

Led by Herb Pennell, with six goals, Farmington won its first game in Metropolitan League competition last night, 13-7, defeating Winged Foot in the feature game of a double-header at the Squadron A armory. In the opener, a non-league contest, Ramapo was forced into overtime to defeat Westbury, 12-11.

A renewed effort to settle the strike of 600 members of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union, independent, against wholesale concerns that distribute newspaper's to New York City's suburbs was made last night by Martin Wersing of the State Mediation Board.

ALTHOUGH opinions vary about details of the workmanship, Arthur Miller's new play, "The Crucible," has made a deep impression on the town. Put it down as the most notable new play by an American so far this season, for Mr. Miller has an independent mind, professional skill and personal courage.

HOLY HANNAH MORE! Does anyone read her now? Dr. Johnson gave her some formidable praise. Speaking of her, he said "she was the most powerful versificatrix in the English language"; speaking to her, he praised her "Bas Bleu" as a creation which "no name in poetry * * * might not be glad to own."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 31 -- Nationalist Chinese sources here cautioned today against any idea that removal of the Seventh Fleet's guard against attacks on the Chinese mainland would lead to any immediate large-scale invasion by Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's troops.

TUCSON, Ariz., Jan. 31 -- E. J. (Dutch) Harrison of Ardmore, Okla., and Tommy Bolt of Maplewood, N. J., tied for the lead of the $10,000 Tucson open golf tournament today at the end of 54 holes with scores of 199, eleven under par.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) -- A drastic overhauling of overseas information programs -- including the Voice of America -- was urged today by a Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee.

EASTON, Pa., Jan. 31 -- Lafayette College has elected Thomas Roy Jones a life trustee, Dr. Ralph C. Hutchinson, president of the college, announced today. Mr. Jones is president of Daystrom, Inc., Elizabeth, N. J., parent company for American Type Founders, Daystrom Furniture Division, Daystrom Electric Corporation and Daystrom Instrument Division.
EXCERPTS from La Gioconda are heard on an LP re-issue by Eterna of old acoustical recordings made soon after the turn of the century.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 31 -- Japan is in urgent need of applied research as a basis for attracting foreign investment capital and building her export trade, according to a study prepared by aides of the Stanford Research Institute and presented this week to the World Trade Association of the San Francisco Chamber of Commerce.

From time to time, at meetings where educators gather, it has been suggested that the teachers' colleges are the stepchildren of the school system. Not infrequently it has been intinated that the brightest students steer clear of teacher-training institutions. The other professions, so the argument runs, get the cream of the intellectual crop.
Volume in the area's department stores was about even with 1952 in the week, according to trade observers. No departments stood out as leaders and the weather was close to normal for the season.
Eight marketing and distribution experts are here from the Netherlands to study marketing techniques as part of a drive to increase productivity at home.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Jan. 31 -- Danish Foreign Minister Ole Bjoern Kraft, meeting for the second time in two days with Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Supreme Allied Commander, told newsmen here today that he was '"very favorably impressed" with General Ridgway's attitude about the need for more Allied forces to guard Denmark's southern flank.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Opponents of the "sudden death" technique for disposing of direct Government controls over wages and prices are reported to have won a victory at the White House today.

The New York County chapter of the Catholic War Veterans adopted a resolution yesterday asking the City Council to "forbid" the leftist May Day parade from being held on Eighth and Ninth Avenues on May 1, and in-steady require the marchers to parade on Twelfth Avenue "or on some similar route far removed from the heart and center of the city."

THE tower is by no means ivory; it is red and yellow brick. But it is nevertheless a remarkable, slow-paced retreat, set down among the cloud-scraping towers of New York. It is populated by men of keen devotion and strong opinions, waxing eloquent in their discussions of an ancient line of research.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Jan. 31 -- A comely young suspect was unwittingly the "guinea pig" this week in a police-merchant plan designed to facilitate the capture of bogus check passers and shoplifters in this city of 46,000.

Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands arrived yesterday to help celebrate the 300th anniversary of the establishment of municipal government in New York. The Prince was met at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, by the Dutch Ambassador, J. H. Van Royen, and Consul General J. A. De Vos.

HONG KONG, Jan. 31 -- Reports that the Eisenhower Administration is preparing to alter its Formosa "neutralization" policy and lift present restrictions on Chinese Nationalist offensive operations were interpreted here today as a harbinger of ultimately intensified hit-and-run raids by the Nationalists against the Southeast China coast.
The Coast Guard has named Comdr. Richard Baxter head of the Coast Guard Air Station at Floyd Bennett Field, Brooklyn.

THE Senate Foreign Relations Committee is unique among world parliamentary bodies -- unique in power and, quite possibly in perquisites. It is the Senate's own representative and high spokesman in the realm of foreign policy under the constitutional requirement that the President and his Secretary of State let the Senate help shape and operate that policy.

CAIRO, Jan. 31 -- Egyptian Premier Mohammed Naguib's adoption last week of the "liberation movement," first launched by his Syrian counterpart, Col. Adib Shishekly, as the ideological basis for his military dictatorial regime, is in a sense a response to the tendencies which Communists of the Middle East have been encouraging to further their cause.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 31 -- After an extensive study of the year-old Pennsylvania Loyalty Act in operation, Prof. Clark Byse of the University of Pennsylvania Law School wrote today that the law had contributed "little or nothing to security" but had harmed innocent persons and had created an atmosphere of resentment, fear and mistrust.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 31 -- Army's track and field team captured seven first places and tied for another in defeating Penn State's squad, 63:2.3 to 45:1.3, in the Field House today.
WORCESTER, Mass., Jan. 31 -- Before a capacity crowd of 3,500 the Holy Cross Crusaders moved back into the limelight tonight, setting down Columbia, 78 -- 65, in basketball.

THE life of Josip Broz. who was born to poor peasants sixty years ago in the Austro-Hungarian Empire's province of Croatia, reads like a picaresque novel with ideological overtones. In a curious sense the history of our epoch had engulfed him long before he, as Tito (a party alias), became one of the leaders of his time and his name a byword in the great political conflict which is sweeping the world.

The United States Supreme Court was held responsible yesterday by Alexander Meiklejohn, former president of Amherst College, for the "destruction" of the very constitutional principle it was intended to defend.

TWENTY-TWO years is a long time in anyone's life; in radio it seems like a century. Yet for that long, Nila Mack, whose passing her friends now mourn, brought her program, "Let's Pretend," to children through the Columbia Broadcasting System.

IT'S been true for three hundred years, and it's truer than ever today, that New York has no such thing as a typical inmate. Elsewhere in the world, the modern impulse to package and label things being what it is, you will hear the words "typical New Yorker" used now and then, but there is really only one way in which any New Yorker is like another.

Drew Middleton's article of Jan. 18 on the results of the Reactions Analysis Staff public opinion polls may, in my opinion, create some misconceptions. Especially I am worried that the conclusion can too easily be drawn that there would be little effective resistance to any new upsurge of nazism in West Germany.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UP) --Lieut. Allen M. Dulles, whose father and uncle help direct the nation's global defense strategy, entered the Naval Hospital at Bethesda, Md., today for treatment of serious wounds received in Korea.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) -- The Army's Chief of Staff, back today from Korea, stoutly defended Operation Smack as "perfectly sound and legitimate" and not a shooting show staged for brass hat observers.

IN a recent Sunday article on the English "Boheme," Olin Downes implied that it seemed unnecessary to him to have a new translation for "Boheme" as, in his view, the existing one by Grist-Pinkerton is better than the Dietz version.

LOS ANGELES -- Newcomers to California have difficulty accepting the fact that there is no closed season here for gardening. The truth is that the home owner can have as much color in his garden during January and February as in June or July.

IN discussing the many social and medical problems of tuberculosis, the author of this remarkable book refers to Maugham's story "Sanatorium." As any good doctor would, he feels a natural pity for the consumptive lovers who chose between a prudent separation and a dangerous marriage.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Wesley Roberts, newly elected chairman of the Republican National Committee, said today that plans would be made immediately for the 1954 Congressional elections.

When the steel pool set up by the Schuman Plan goes into effect on April 10 it will have a pronounced effect on the world market, Prof. Fernand Baudhuin of the University of Louvain, Belgium, said last week.
A slight, short, dark-haired 18-year-old athlete, John Kopil of Bayonne (N. J.) High, last night ran the fastest mile ever achieved by a schoolboy in the United States.

BOSTON, Jan. 31 -- Marvelous Mal Whitfield, the two - time Olympic 800-meter champion with the silky stride, tonight thrilled a capacity crowd of 13,584 at the Boston Garden for the sixty-fourth Boston Athletic Association Games by equaling the world indoor record for the 600-yard run.

A $3,500,000 program for advanced study in social relations and human behavior was announced yesterday by the Ford Foundation. Frank Stanton, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, has been named chairman of the project.

SINCE a glance at the calendar this morning can serve only as an ominous reminder that January's bills are due -- as well as some thought on those income tax returns -- the departmental samaritan hastens forward with the antidotal notion that the theatre shortly will be trying to help chase those "blues."

MOTORISTS and other tourists planning Midsouth tours are checking the dates of open-house and garden weeks in various towns. Two of these events, and those among the most popular, are scheduled for March 15 to April 12 in Charleston, S. C., and from April 25 to May 3 through Virginia.

IT is only natural that, as one of the world's largest cities, New York should be one of the world's greatest centers of education. The number of its colleges, universities, museums, institutes, academies and schools probably exceeds that of any other metropolis, past or present.

One of the best financial "shows" of the season completed its three-week run on Wednesday. Cast with some of the best-known "players" in Wall Street, the performances in the annual series of bank stockholder meetings were generally sparked with variety and excitement.

LAST year Charles Angoff published his first novel of a planned trilogy, "Journey to the Dawn," a story of the Polansky family who migrated from a small village in Russia to Boston fifty years ago. "In the Morning Light" continues the story of the Polanskys through World War I and the beginning of the subsequent depression.

There was a revolution in physics at the close of the last century and the beginning of this one. One of the revolutionists was Dr. Gordon Ferrie Hull of Dartmouth. He is one of the very few left of the bright band that laid the foundation on which physics now rests.
SEOUL, Korea, Jan. 14 -- Seldom has the youth of a nation struggled more for an education against adverse circumstances than the children of Korea are doing today.

MIAMI, Jan. 31 -- The third choices were the right choices in the divisions of the seven-furlong Bahamas Handicap for 3-year-olds at Hialeah Race Course today. Hal Price Headley's King Pin, at $19.20 for each $2, won the first division, and Brookmeade Stable's First Aid, at $13.60, led 'em home in the second.

MR. CASTEEL seems a devotee of the practice of changing the meaning of his words in mid-air. To anyone interested in the bull-ring of the twentieth century there is only one Joselito. If by Joselito, instead of the man who was perhaps the greatest torero of the century, Mr. Casteel meant some obscure character that certainly stirs no memory in any aficionado I know, then he should have said so in his book.

SINCE the advent of the long-playing record, the search for music that is off the beaten path has taken on the proportions of a gold rush. Equipped with tape recorder, magnifying glass, feather duster and a disdain for standard repertoire, the forty-niners of the record business have descended upon musicians, museums and music libraries all over Europe.

BERLIN, Jan. 31 -- Samuel Reber, acting United States High Commissioner for Germany, ridiculed today a Soviet assertion that anti-Communist organizations in West Berlin threatened the liberties of the Soviet zone's population Mr. Reber said that the "mass exodus" under way from East Germany hardly supported the Soviet contention.
The State Crime Commission plans to submit recommendations for the reform of New York dock conditions to Governor Dewey before the Legislature ends its current session, it was learned yesterday.

THE repetitious ritual of awarding prizes to television programs is getting to be a colossal bore. A viewer can hardly turn on his set these days without some performer looking moon-faced at the camera and mumbling about how he has been tremendously honored to receive this or that prize.

A strike of 3,500 tugboat and other harbor craft workers began here at 12:01 A. M. today amid fears that the walkout might curtail seriously the city's vital flow of fuel and foodstuffs within a few days. The strike was called after the collapse of bargaining conferences held for nine hours yesterday under the auspices of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service.

" UNQUESTIONABLY," wrote George F. Kennan recently, "our relation to the peoples of the Far East was colored by a certain sentimentality toward the Chinese -- a sentimentality so disrespectful to them and so unhelpful to the long-term interests of our relations as the feelings of blind petulance into which it now has a tendency to turn."

DALLAS, Jan. 31 -- Department store sales during the first two weeks of January ran ahead of the same period last year as weather remained mild, but cold weather the third week cut sales sharply, the Eleventh Federal Reserve Bank reported in its monthly business summary.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif. -- A two-year, $300,000 project to restore the famous 132-year-old Santa Barbara Mission to its pristine structural integrity is being pushed to completion in time for this year's Easter services.

OBVIOUSLY Marjorie Kinnan Rawlings is not the carefree type of novelist who finds a plot on Monday, is speeding through chapter three on Tuesday and is all finished and is reading proofs at the time of the next full moon.

NOT every ambassadress is born with the beauty, the native wit and charm of Elisabetta Cerruti, wife of the Italian diplomat. If there were more like her, the halls of diplomacy might be gayer and history richer. Added to her other accomplishments were those of a great actress -- in Budapest they spoke of her as the Hungarian Duse.

The memory of Frank Merriwell, the paragon of manly virtue and for forty years the fictional hero of generations of clean-living, red-blooded American boys, will never be allowed to die -- if a group recently formed here has its way.

Dr. Rollo May, president-elect of the New York State Psychological Association, said yesterday that the immediate task confronting psychologists was to establish and improve standards for their profession and formulate methods to police it.

The first post-war experience of a Republican Administration with public debt management is about to unfold in the refunding of $8,868,000,000 of Treasury debt into new obligations maturing either in one year or in slightly less than six.
Referring to R. Treno's "Crisis in France -- What Crisis?" (Jan. 18):
City College's basketball team last night rolled to its seventh victory of the season, and its fifth in succession, as it downed Franklin and Marshall, 86 to 80, in the Beaver's gymnasium.

AN Everest made of anthills. That is New York's industry. Taken individually, the city's manufacturing enterprises are so puny that European visitors, seeking the heart of American mass production, hurry through New York for a close-up view of the giant automobile plants that wall in Detroit or the sooty steel mills that spin their metallic web near Pittsburgh or the sprawling aircraft factories that catapult hundreds of military and transport planes into the California skies.

ONE of the two sons of the creator of Sherlock Holmes, Adrian Conan Doyle is an acidulous citizen who doesn't much like the way the world is going. For some years, he tells us, he and his wife have been wandering from place to place "in a hopeless search for sanity and freedom."

GIVEN the opportunity to get away with it, just about anybody, at some time or other, would just as soon commit murder. In novels the opportunity coincides with the desire more often than in real life, and that is perhaps unfortunate for you and me, but fortunate for novelists.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UP) -- A group of prominent educators split sharply today on whether to welcome or deplore the forthcoming Congressional investigations into "subversive" influences in the nation's schools.

Chemists believe they have identified a chemical that stops tetanus infection in laboratory animals, according to a report presented to the Fifth Annual Scientific Conference of the American Chemical Society's Philadelphia Section by Dr. Harold W. Heine. Earlier work had demonstrated that tetanus toxin is strongly attracted by the cells of the central nervous system.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Jan. 31 -- A Swiss bobsled hurtled over a fifteen-foot wall of ice on Garmisch's notorious "dead man's curve" today and crashed into a tree, killing its world champion driver and seriously injuring two of the three other riders.

ONE good reason for Edward John Stevens' rapid and early success -- the present exhibition of his paintings at Weyhe's is his tenth and he is not yet 30 -- is that he is one of the cleverest artists going. There are, none the less, great pitfalls for the kind of fantasies he favors, especially so since he is not overwhelmingly original.
LONDON, Jan. 31 -- The British Government is not saying much but there is considerable uneasiness in Whitehall over current trends in Washington.

FRANCONIA, N. H., Jan. 31 -- This diversified state-owned ski development today was jammed with skiers, most of whom were of the rank and file variety. Ordinarily, Cannon Mountain, with its mile-long aerial tramway, the only one in North America, its "T"-bar and rope tows and huge network of downhill runs and open slopes, is alive with the intermediate and experts.
A school-building program of unusual speed is putting the Los Angeles public school system ahead of an equally difficult problem of rapidly growing enrollments.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- To do, or not to do, that was the question that troubled Washington this week as White House, State Department and Pentagon discussed the problem of Korea.

Aboard the U. S. S. Helena, as it steamed from Guam to Hawaii last Dec. 5-11, President-elect Eisenhower and his Secretary of State-designate John Foster Dulles made their first hard exploration of the new foreign policy. The President-elect was returning from a three-day personal inspection of the front in Korea.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31 -- Manufacturers of soft lines at the shows here reported spotty buying, but orders seemed to average ahead of last year. There has been no stampede of buyers in the display rooms, but better-than-average attendance has been shown. The market was described as "healthy but choosy."

A REALLY satisfactory life of Cardinal Gibbons, the Baltimore churchman who attained a national influence that no other Roman Catholic prelate has begun to approach, has long been needed A. S. Will's two-volume life, published thirty years ago, gave a warm and intimate picture of the man, but it was deficient where the present book is strongest -- in its treatment of ecclesiastical matters.
CAT CAY, Bahamas, Jan. 31 -- Doris III, blue-hulled cutter skippered by Baxter Still, Boston and Miami, easily won the seventh annual Fort Lauderdale-to-Cat Cay ocean-sailing race today.

As the Administration's new line on foreign policy went forward last week, the President and his sides were settling into the routines of their jobs. The new routines were having their impact on bureaucratic life: reporting times were earlier, and memoranda from the new department heads to their staffs were sprinkled with phrases like "a full day's work for a full day's pay."

Sulphur, the yellow mineral essential in a long list of products -- rubber, steel, newsprint paper, chemicals, textiles and the like -- is commonly referred to by dealers as one of the cheapest products on earth. Its price runs generally at a cent a pound at Gulf Coast ports.

Solution of Brazil's heavy foreign commercial debt problems is proving more complicated than expected by United States exporters with sizable amounts due them for goods shipped to the South American country as much as a year or more ago.

PACIFIC GROVE, Calif., Jan. 31 -- Gov. Earl Warren, plus "too much deadwood" in Democratic county committees, plus emphasis of local Democrats on foreign affairs while "forgetting the suck-holes in front of the voters' homes," were blamed today for turning California, a great Democratic state on paper, into an overwhelmingly Republican state in practical politics.

The taxation of income or gains from transactions in patents is a confusing subject. Even the most fundamental of its rules has exceptions. An unconditional and outright sale of a patent is usually taxable as a capital gain -- except when the sale is made by a dealer in patents.
The writer is an associate professor of English at New York University who recently returned from a trip to South America.

LIKE everything else in Canada, writing feels a new strength and a livelier hope; the past year was a successful and in certain respects a distinguished one in our literature. In the long run it may appear that the most important literary event of 1952 was the publication of "Creative Writing in Canada," by Desmond Pacey; this is the first careful consideration of Canadian writing to appear in a quarter of a century.

You are to be complimented for your editorial on early language training and for the letter on languages as an aid to peace, written by our Minister to Finland, both of which appeared in the issue of Jan. 25. It is not often that a language teacher comes across such a clear exposition in the public press of the values of languages.
SINGAPORE, Jan. 31 -- Up until three years ago one of the basic political facts about Vietnam was that a majority of the Vietnamese favored the Communist-led movement called Vietminh.

THE oldest furniture market in the country the one held semi-annually in this city celebrated its seventy-fifth year here last month. It provided a timely occasion to review the changes that have taken place not only in this representative city's production of furniture, but the country-wide development of the entire industry.

THE Bach Guild has come forward with a recording of Handel's Israel in Egypt which competes with the other long-playing version issued a year and a half ago by the Handel Society. Since the oratorio is an acknowledged masterwork, which quite a few might want to buy, and since a two-disk set involves considerable outlay, some comparisons are in order.

ANSWERING Harry Sylvester's criticism in his review of my book "The Running of the Bulls," I should like to point out that I did not call the Joselito who fought with Belmonte "el Gallo." Straddling the nineteeth and twentieth century there lived a family named Gomez, five of whom (and I say this with diffidence, as it's arguable) were better than average fighters.
JERSEY CITY, Jan. 31 -- Capt. Andy McGowan and Junius Kellogg, each with 20 points, sparked Manhattan College to victory against St. Peter's, 67 -- 61, in the Jersey City Armory tonight.

AFTER all the long years that the people in Hollywood gently shied away from the raw stuff of highly personal drama that was kicking around in their own backyard, it is funny -- and just a bit ironic -- that there should suddenly be in New York two not inconsiderable pictures having to do with the Hollywood scene.

A five-point proposal for an objective survey of municipal housing projects to permit accrual to the city of more Federal and state aid than heretofore was proposed to Mayor Impellitteri yesterday by the Real Estate Board of New York.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 31 (UP) -- Harry S. Truman, who touched off a controversy last week by saying he was not convinced Russia had the atomic bomb, said today that "I've said everything about anything that I'm going to say" for some time.

ON the point of continuing the discussion recently begun here on the question of mountains vs. the sea in literature, a bevy of inconsiderate bacteria laid me low. The enemy has now been routed, and I return to the question fortified by some interesting opinions offered by readers of this column.

Trading in financial markets continued to move cautiously as January came to a close. With President Eisenhower's Cabinet completed finally, one of the uncertainties that had affected the markets the last two weeks has been removed.

A dictionary to help scientists study Russian advancements in metallurgy and mathematics is nearing completion at Columbia University, Prof. Ernest J. Simmons, head of the Department of Slavic Languages, announced yesterday.

Approval by the Board of Estimate last week of a lease for Pier 57, the city's newest at West Fifteenth Street, to the Grace Line for eight years at an annual rental of $250,000 marks the first instance of a radical departure from the city's long-disputed 1938 pier rental formula.

OF the well-known pianists who recently have graced the catalogues with examples of mature artistry, Solomon especially stands out for a Beethoven disk that Victor has issued. The British pianist plays three sonatas -- the Waldstein, the Sonata in F, Op. 54, and the Sonata in E, Op. 109.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 31 (UP) -- Freshman football star Charlie Sticka decided on a speedy "re-matriculation" to Trinity College today when he learned he would be unable to play football at Notre Dame.

MOSCOW, Jan. 31 -- The Soviet Union's leading scientists in many fields, including medicine, nuclear physics, chemistry, biology, philosophy and electronics, met today and heard warnings of the need for the highest vigilance and elimination of the kind of laxness that allegedly permitted a "miserable band of doctor wreckers" to operate for a long time without exposure.
A DECADE or so ago there was a scramble among various sportsmen to organize a professional football league which would rival the old and established National Football League in the post-war era.

BUSINESS and industry have completed the first month of the year without significant change either in actual developments or prospects. The near-term outlook continues favorable, and confidence as to conditions well into the spring has not been shaken.

DOROTHY COLLINS epitomizes the American success story, although she was born Marjorie Chandler in Canada and is still in the process of becoming an American citizen. Miss Collins, inextricably identified with "Your Hit Parade" (Saturday, 10:30 P. M. -- Channel 4), is pretty, but not beautiful.

" HOW do I submit a manuscript to a publisher? How long should a picture book be? What payment should I expect for my book?" These are the questions which anyone connected with children's books hears everyday from hopeful but bewildered authors.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Fleet Admiral William D. Leahy, former Chief of Naval Operations, said it was "a bright idea" to utilize Chinese Nationalists "to help us to settle the problem on the China coast."

IN spite of extraordinary recent accomplishments, New York City still has plenty of major problems. If you, gentle or other reader, regard them as insoluble, go no further. The bellyachers, Cassandras, cynics, scoffers, timid souls, defeatists and existentialists scoff at all practical remedies.

OMAHA, Neb., Jan. 31 -- The nation's meat industry has been caught in a deflationary squeeze that has brought worried looks to producers and, for the first time in a decade, faint smiles to the faces of consumers.

NORTH, South, East and West, a cross-section of present-day American living unfolds in these twenty-seven regional stories by Elizabeth Coatsworth, Cornelia Meigs, Elizabeth Yates, John Tunis and others. The drama in each is shaped by environment but directed by family life.

THE British women's team, holders of the European women's team championship, whose visit to the United States was reported in this column last week, are playing their last American match today in New York.

SEATTLE, Jan. 31 (AP) -- The University of Washington Board of Regents today hired John Cherberg to succeed Howard Odell as head football coach for a one-year term. His selection came as no surprise. From the time that the news broke on Odell's discharge Cherberg was the popular choice.

IT was the custom of the Action Francaise to carry on its front page each day a quotation from the current pretender to the throne of France and, below it the message: "heir of the forty kings who in a thousand years made France." This book, which won the Grand Prix d'Histoire de l'Academie Francaise, is in a sense an elaboration of this theme.
To the question. "What will tomorrow's New York be like!," four distinguished contemporaries -- two of them residents, two non-residents of the city -- have made characteristic, brief replies:

Common stocks grew as a medium of investment for the protection of pensiohns in 1952. Special funds were created for the purpose of investing in equities in an effort to bring greater stability to pension payments and to offset fluctuations in the purchasing power of the dollar.

SOME day, perhaps, some able biographer will write a life of Gen. Billy Mitchell, the impetuous advocate of air supremacy who was court-martialed and convicted of insubordination in 1926, that is not the account of a martyr or a genius -- or a brother.

PEOPLE often come and stare at us. Others ask for our autographs. One or two even snap our pictures for their albums. A few avoid us ostentatiously. No wonder my wife and I feel like animals at the zoo on Sunday.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sunday, Feb. 1 -- Forty-four survivors of the Princess Victoria had been landed in Northern Ireland by 2 A. M. today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The Secretary of State, John Foster Dulles, has dissolved a special five-man board set up by former President Truman at the recommendation of former Secretary of State Dean Acheson to review disloyalty charges against John Carter Vincent, career diplomat.
CHICAGO, Jan. 31 -- Representatives of eight midwestern schools, including the University of Chicago, met today and discussed plans for the formation of a new collegiate athletic conference.

TEMPE JARVIS, suddenly widowed, journeys to a tiny copra-producing island called Telor where for three months she is both guest and secretary of its supreme ruler, Kurt Long. She finds Telor a well organized paradise -- at first. All Long's actions, she quickly discovers, are exact, methodical, regular as clockwork.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Regardless of the construction placed on the action, the decision of Senate and House committees to allow veto of Presidential reorganization plans by a simple majority of either branch of Congress will not help President Eisenhower to live up to campaign promises.

Young women, headed by Miss Anne J. Murray and including Mrs. Frederic F. Flach, are serving on the junior committee and aiding in the arrangements for the annual luncheon and card party for the benefit of the Catholic Big Sisters, to be held Feb. 17 in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 31 -- For the fourth month in succession industrial employment in this Federal Reserve District held close to the record with slightly higher average hourly wages and more overtime work. In durable goods there was a nominal gain in number employed, which was offset by fewer employed in non-durables.

BEGINNING with America's birthday of freedom -- the signing of the Declaration of Independence -- this picture-chronicle goes back to prehistoric times and then forward to the fall of Rome to show that "each land and nation has had its heroes of freedom, its great teachers and prophets, its anniversaries or birthdays which it celebrates."

MAN'S accelerating progress in unlocking the doors to nature's mysteries has put a premium on scientific brains. As a discoverer of new horizons the scientist plays a crucial role in today's world. He and his works are in great demand.

FOR the countless parents constantly harassed by a child's nagging cry of "Now what can I do?" here is an answer as practical as a safety pin and as exciting as baby's first step. Cornelia Stratton Parker is a grandmother with a better-than-average understanding of what besides medicine makes little Johnny well.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) -- The Defense Department today identified 163 Korean war casualties. The new list included twenty-two killed, 130 wounded, ten missing and one injured. The following were from New York and New Jersey (none from Connecticut):

The enmity of French and Germans may be traced as far back as the Treaty of Verdun, A. D. 843, which divided the empire of Charlemagne and created two nations, the one predominantly Latin in culture and the other Teutonic. French and Germans could march together in the Third Crusade in the twelfth century, but beginning with the next century French and Germans were on different sides in European struggles
Boys High School of Brooklyn won the eighteenth annual New York University interscholastic fencing tournament yesterday by defeating Frankford High of Philadelphia in the final round.

BUDGETS are allegedly trimmed to the last ha-penny and schedules tightened to the last half-day, but with that flair for proving rules by exception which is one of the eccentric charms of the film business, the most important-sounding production for this year is likely to be a 1954 release.

On Dec. 9, 1949, the Nationalist Government of China abandoned its last stronghold on the mainland of China and retreated to the island of Formosa. The event marked the culmination of a basic alteration in the world power balance. The Communists had taken undisputed possession of the Chinese mainland, the most populous land mass on earth.

PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 31 -- A nation-wide campaign to interest outstanding young men and women in the teaching profession moved into its final stages this week. Regional selection committees throughout the country began screening nearly 1,000 nominees for the National Woodrow Wilson Fellowship program sponsored by the Association of Graduate Schools in the American Association of Universities.
NINE children living in a crowded tenement might ordinarily be objects of sympathy, but not the Tracy brood.

Dispatches from Moscow in recent weeks have told of a series of articles in the Soviet press, both in Moscow and in other areas, exposing alleged criminals of all types. Such exposures are not new in themselves, but what is new in this latest group of reports is the sudden predominance of obviously Jewish names among the denounced culprits.

WHILE no vegetable made the All-America Selections list for 1953, nonetheless several newcomers this year are well worth the attention of home gardeners. Early ripening is characteristic of some. Still others are especially suited to planting in gardens farther south.

In a laboratory of the University of Wisconsin, not in a smoke-filled room, poker is to be played in the interest of science. Bluffing, faking, unsportsmanlike behavior -- everything will be tolerated except violence. Object: To collect material for Prof. R. Creighton Buck's course in the "theory of games," a complex and important mathematical concept born of the American male's traditional excuse for a night out with the boys.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 31 -- A behind-the-scenes struggle is going on between the West German Federal Government, which is seeking passage of an ironclad decartelization law, and West German industrialists who, though they have benefited greatly from the present regime's economic policy of free enterprise and free competition, wish to have the draft law amended to leave the door open for the reconstitution of cartels in periods of depressions and crisis.

THE jacket on "Out of the Dust" tell us that its author dedicated herself to the cause of the new Jewish state after she had toured post-war Europe with the U.S.O. Now, choosing for her immediate subject the courageous undertaking of a group of young Israelis, in the tense and uncertain months before the end of the British mandate in Palestine, she has tried to translate some of her experience into a novel.

MADISON, Wis., Jan. 31 (AP) -- Land, sea and air units fanned out over southern Wisconsin and northern Illinois tonight in a search for the pilots of two Air Force jet planes who bailed out of their craft in bad weather earlier tonight.

An attractive assortment of English period furniture and decorative accessories, of Victorian jewelry and precious objects by Carl Faberge, court jeweler to the Russian Czars, will be auctioned on Friday and Saturday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

General of the Army Douglas MacArthur declared last night that the decision of President Eisenhower to modify orders to the Seventh Fleet to open the way for attacks on the Communist-controlled Chinese mainland by Nationalist Chinese forces on Formosa would "correct one of the strangest anomalies known to military history."

THIS amiable story begins in New York in the period immediately following the American Revolution. The conflicting loyalties of the time are epitomized in the rift between Felicity Dorsett's Tory grandparents and her only brother, a Yankee soldier.

THOSE mammoth, all-star, hour-after-hour "telethons" for worthy causes will not be carried by the N. B. C. television network this year. The network has so notified Dean Martin and Jerry Lewis, who were already preparing for a muscular dystrophy appeal, and Milton Berle, who does an annual Damon Runyon Fund marathon show.

PANAMA, Jan. 31 -- Venezuelan leaders, through the current Constituent Assembly in Caracas, are setting up a political machine that, in the opinion of experienced observers there, cannot be overthrown within the foreseeable future except by a coup within the Army circles that are behind it.

Dvorak's "New World" Symphony was the chief work of Arturo Toscanini's program with the N. B. C. Symphony late yesterday afternoon. As in previous events of the series, the program was given before a capacity audience at Carnegie Hall and broadcast on a coast-to-coast network.

THREE HUNDRED years ago this month a little group of leathern-breeched, ponderous, pipe-smoking Dutch burghers in absurd high-crowned headgear met as the first City Fathers in an ill-lighted tavern at the foot of Manhattan Island, at the southern tip of the living map that glows a quarter-mile below this turret window of the Empire State Building tonight, a map drawn in running fire and with spangles and jewels from The Battery to Westchester.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UP) -- Representative Edward H. Rees, chairman of the House Post Office Committee, promised early hearings today on a bipartisan move to restore twice-a-day home mail deliveries.

THE living architecture of a city is a mixture of the beautiful and the beloved. Unfortunately, some of New York's best buildings have not always awakened enough love to preserve them -- witness the fate of the original Madison Square Garden -- while some of its most beloved buildings, like the old Aquarium, were not sufficiently beautiful to deserve indefinite preservation.
Representative Walter H. Judd of Minnesota declared yesterday that the primary task of the Administration of President Eisenhower was to end "the mess in Washington."

ANTHEMS: Ave Verum Corpus, The Lord's Prayer, Panis Angelicus, The Holy City, God So Loved the World; Canterbury Choir, conducted by Macklin Marrow, Ernest White, organist (M-G-M ten-inch). Religious favorites, straightforwardly done.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 31 (UP) -- Marty Satalino's one-handed goal with one second of play remaining gave St. John's a 64-62 triumph over St. Joseph's in the opener of a college basketball doubleheader at Convention Hall tonight.

POSSIBLY there is such a thing as being too enterprising. It was admirable of the New York City Ballet to attempt a three-month repertory season (which it carried off triumphantly, all things considered), but when it undertook to add seven new works to the repertory in its final six weeks, it definitely over-reached itself.

HAVANA, Jan. 31 -- James Schoonmaker of Nassau sailed his yacht Dingo over the finish line today to win the first race of the Bacardi Cup series in the twenty- second annual international Star Class regatta. Schoonmaker's time was one hour forty-eight minutes fifteen seconds.

SAXTONS RIVER, Vt., Jan. 31 --The ski laurels at the annual Vermont Academy Winter Carnival were won by Kimball Union today. Bancroft's victory in the final event, the cross-country, clinched the triumph for Kimball Union.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 31 -- New Delhi reacted with concern and dismay to President Eisenhower's decision to call off the blockade against Chinese Nationalist forces on Formosa should they wish to attack the Chinese mainland while at the same time holding the Seventh Fleet in readiness to repel Communists should they attempt to strike the island.

ANNUALS are the easiest flowers to grow and, in return for little effort, the most colorful. The only disadvantage is that they bloom and live only one season. But there is an advantage to this, too. Each year the gardener can start a fresh batch of plants, trying out new varieties and arranging new color combinations.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Jan. 31 -- An open split between the rightists and the leftist elements in President Victor Paz Estenssoro's Government of the National Revolutionary Movement appeared in the making tonight, as both groups made final preparations for the Movement's long-delayed convention.

MIDWINTER garden lectures are still the order of the day. Colored slides showing steps in flower arranging will be shown Wednesday evening at the Library Clubrooms of the Horticultural Society of New York in the Essex House, Fifty-eighth Street near Seventh Avenue.

Mrs. Harold Ruckman Mixsell and Mrs. Clendenin J. Ryan head the committee for the forthcoming benefit performance of "Hazel Flagg," the new musical with Helen Gallagher, on the evening of April 20 in the Mark Hellinger Theatre.

One of the country's largest Corporations and a former Hoboken "dock walloper" have joined forces. They have developed a new product that may accelerate considerably the widespread use of atomic energy in industry for civilian peacetime uses.

IT took just one ballot for the National Books Awards jury -- voting four to one -- to pick "Invisible Man," by Ralph Ellison, for the fiction prize. For the second year in a row the award went to a first novel, and although "Invisible Man" was not the stem winder, in point of sales, that "From Here to Eternity" was, it did manage a respectable flirtation on the Book Review's best-seller list.

" GOLD is where you find it," said Charlie Clemens, wagon-train scout -- but to 15-year-old Wint Hanners it could only be in California. When his rickety old farm-wagon was wrecked on the trail Wint set up camp at the fork of the Platte River and salvaged enough from the household goods and broken wagons left by the gold-wild emigrants to build himself a comfortable tent-house.

Mrs. Mary Roberts Rinehart's interesting account, in your issue of Jan. 18, of the accouchement of the murder-mystery melodrama, and of her participation in it, is inaccurate in one particular. She recalls having spoken to Edgar Selwyn about a new type of mystery play, in which the audience would not know the identity of the criminal until the final curtain.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- A Senate Judiciary subcommittee sharply criticized the Office of Alien Property in a report today but offered only one specific suggestion to remedy the conditions it had criticized.

IT was standard Sunday-dinner practice in our family. Father would suddenly and irrelevantly roar, "Can Baudelaire be done into English?" and we kids, my sister and I, flopping our curls, would pipe in unison, "Hell, no!" A truth implanted in the very young is hard to abandon, though I must confess that such temptations to abandon it as I have met since those childhood days have been very feeble indeed.

Plans have been formulated for a luncheon and fashion display for the benefit of the Trifles and Treasures Thrift Shop of the Social Service Department of the Society of Memorial Cancer Center to be held on Feb. 24 in the main ballroom of the Plaza.

CAMDEN, N. J., Jan. 31 -- A railroad right - of - way problem threatens to delay construction of a new $91,000,000 bridge across the Delaware River between Philadelphia and Gloucester, N. J., Joseph K. Costello, executive director of the Delaware River Port Authority, reported today.

WHILE much of the stew in New York's melting pot is gone, the flavor lingers on. The fact that nearly five of our eight million people are immigrants or their offspring still keeps old country customs going, with American trimmings.

CAIRO, Jan. 31 (Reuters) -- Egypt's Liberation front, set up to replace the dissolved political parties, tonight announced its charter and program, including "the unconditional evacuation of foreign troops from the Nile Valley."

ISRAEL'S Ministry of Posts in Jerusalem advises that a series of seven airmail stamps depicting native landscapes will appear this year. The first, to be issued in March, is a 1,000-pruta dark and light green showing "a site of Tel Aviv-Jaffa (Old Jaffa)."

IN the current seventeenth annual exhibition by members of the American Abstract Artists in the galleries of Artists Equity Association there is one outstanding factor which sets this work apart from so much of the abstract work in general. That factor is discipline, for one may apprehend at a glance that almost all of the fifty examples in the display are decidedly disciplined work.

DETROIT, Jan. 31 -- Philip J. Monaghan was appointed today general manager of the G. M. C. Truck and Coach Division of General Motors Corporation to succeed Roger M. Kyes, who has become Deputy Secretary of Defense.
President Eisenhower paid tribute to a great golf champion, Bob Jones, in a message read during the ceremony marking the unveiling of a portrait of the famed Atlantan at Golf House yesterday.

As baseball's sixteen major league club owners yesterday completed one of their shortest joint sessions on record, it remained for Bill Veeck, militant owner of the Browns, to drop a bombshell as a reminder that the executives may yet have some troubles ahead.

Fighting off a desperate but futile bid by the visitors in the last quarter, the New York Knickerbockers moved a full game ahead of Syracuse in the Eastern Division race of the National Basketball Association last night by halting the Boston Celtics, 76 to 69, in a rugged battle on the Sixty- ninth Regiment Armory floor.

PATSY and Jacky, teen-agers, had come home for the holidays to a north-of-England farm. At boarding school they had acquired grim report cards and a broken-down pony. The girls hardly deserved Father's letting them take the new pet and their own, regular ponies to the caravan in the far pasture for a week's adventure.

ST. PAUL, Jan. 31 (UP) -- The Democratic National Chairman, Stephen A. Mitchell, said here today that the party was $578,000 "in the red" after the Presidential election but that the deficit had been cut to $350,000. He declared that he hoped to have the deficit cleared by spring.
TRENTON, Jan. 31 -- Republican and Democratic leaders in New Jersey are looking for "the best man" to run for Governor this year.

TODAY Chicago and Kansas City, Mo., are being joined by a new fast rail passenger service as the Burlington places in operation two streamlined Vista Dome Zephyr trains between the two cities. This will signal the start of active competition by the Burlington for a share of the business on this lucrative run.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- In the life of Ezra Taft Benson, the new Secretary of Agriculture, there are three major influences -- his church, his family and his interest in agriculture.

NEWARK, Jan. 31 -- Officers, the executive board and the executive council of the New Jersey State Federation of Labor, A. F. L., at a meeting in the Essex House today adopted a resolution by a vote of 30 to 2 approving the recent dismissal of Prof. Simon W. Heimlich and Prof. Moses I. Finley from the faculty of Rutgers University for their refusal to answer questions about possible Communist affiliations.
Supreme Court Justice Bernard Botein has reserved decision on a motion by Henry Shields, assistant corporation counsel, to transfer the appeal of a dismissed Queens sewer engineer to Queens County.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- All those brooms the Eisenhower campaign train picked up last summer to "clean up" Washington are now poised in the hands of the chief sweepers, and the changeover dust is beginning to rise.

Finley from the faculty of Rutgers University for their refusal to answer questions about possible Communist affiliations.

TO the average American whose knowledge of Latin and of Roman history does not often go beyond Caesar, this novel by Alfred Duggan may be a little hard to get into. The author takes his own comprehensive learning so easily and naturally that he makes little allowance for non-classicists.

The coat story for spring, 1953, is one of silhouette. Most extreme are those that are straight when viewed from front or back as well as from the side. They show a new, slightly extended and dropped shoulder seam. Equally important are the ones that flare from narrow shoulders to wide hem, or those that are nipped in at the waist and have a rippling skirt.

THE big story of the moment in Hollywood is three-dimension movies. Last week two major studios -- Warner Brothers and Paramount -- each had one such picture in actual production and other studios were rushing preparations to film similar projects.

The 514th Troop Carrier Wing, New York-Long Island Air Force Reserve unit called to active duty at Mitchel Air Force Base, L. I., twenty-one months ago was deactivated at midnight last night and its equipment and personnel taken over by a new wing, the 313th.

MAKE no mistake about it. These days art flourishes at the grass roots. Regional shows often expose talents to put Big City ones to shame. "Provincial museums," especially such a uniquely well-directed one as Cleveland, often make off with treasures that once would have been inevitable "New York buys."

TOKYO, Sunday, Feb. 1 (AP) -- United States pilots for Japan Airlines disclosed today that Soviet radio transmitters on land and sea were trying to lure American fliers off course. For many months, false radio signals from Siberia and the open Pacific -- possibly from submarines -- have baited aircraft over northern Japan, the pilots said.

MARCH 3 is the date of the Metropolitan Opera's first presentation of its new production of "Boris Godunov." The revival, the first in six years, is being awaited with a combination of theatrical curiosity and musicological interest.

MIAMI -- Here in Miami five-foot poinsettia shrubs bloom in casual profusion about the doorways of nearly every home. Northerners like myself who have lovingly nurtured a delicate poinsettia as a house plant through the hazards of drafts and steam heat can only gaze with wonder and envy on this horticultural achievement.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Jan. 31 -- Disapproving of Governor Dewey's proposal for transfer of four state institutes of applied arts and sciences to community operation, Westchester County officials and business leaders will confer with the Governor's policy adviser, Lieut. Gov. Frank C. Moore, next Friday to seek reversal or modification of the plan.
TOKYO, Sunday, Feb. 1 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,512, covering Saturday:

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 31 -- Ever Bright, a dark bay filly discarded by Calumet Farm, led nearly all the way today in scoring a two-length victory over Hiram Jr., in the first running of the $14,125 Pelleteri Memorial Handicap at the Fair Grounds.
COURTLAND, Ala., Jan. 31 (AP) -- The judges today named four dogs for three-hour final heats of the National Field Trial Club's free-for-all, and the defending champion was omitted.

ALTHOUGH Broadway in the Times Square area looks like a carnival midway, it is one of the world's centers of theatrical culture. Many plays first acted in the Broadway district appear later throughout the United States, performed either by touring companies or local troupes; and some Broadway plays are acted in England, Europe, the Near East, Australia and South America.

OUR food affects our health more than any other factor in our environment, a leading nutritionist has said. The meals we consume from cradle to grave, in haste or leisure, aversion or enjoyment, mean more to us than most of us realize.

PARIS, Jan. 31 -- One of the first requests the French will make to John Foster Dulles, United States Secretary of State, who will arrive here tomorrow, will be for an explanation of President Eisenhower's decision to remove the United States naval barrier to Chinese Nationalist action from Formosa.

Just twenty-nine years ago a small band of New York baseball writers decided on the spur of the moment to hold a beefsteak dinner with the then high commissioner, the late Kenesaw Mountain Landis, as their special guest. In fact, there was a bit of a squabble as to whether the Judge, as the former Federal jurist was always known, was to be the guest of the scribes, or the other way around.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The Eisenhower Administration has come up with something which may be described as a foreign policy of "stern alternatives." To the Communists they are saying: If you want to continue making war in Korea you must pay a higher price than in the past.

" LOVE'S LABOUR'S LOST," an early play of Shakespeare opening Wednesday at the City Center, is seldom seen on the stage. When the talented Brattle Theatre produced it last year in Cambridge, Mass., with an Edwardian decor and costumes, the public sat up and rubbed its eyes: Many people had never heard of it or supposed it was a "youthful exercise."
For three mad hours yesterday, the Bowery was turned into a jungle and the life of its normally somnolent residents was considerably brightened by a monkey.

It is no accident that sales of Cadillac cars -- in the past associated only with the very wealthy are booming these days. Behind the scenes is one of the most experienced and astute minds in the automobile business -- James R. (Big Jim) Adams, president and treasurer of MacManus, John Adams, Inc., Detroit ad agency.

LONDON, Jan. 31 (Reuters) -- Rotherham United upset Newcastle United by 3 -- 1 today, knocking the first division team out of the soccer series for the Football Association Cup it had won for the past two years.

MOST people this side of the Iron Curtain would rate freedom as the top value to be preserved, but few recognize the full dimensions of the threat to our freedom. Gabriel Marcel, a French philosopher of the existentialist school, would have us see that the problem is not primarily that of an obtuse political threat, but is that of a more pervasive trend of which communism is but an egregious symptom.

PARIS, Jan. 31 -- At the same time that Secretary of State John Foster Dulles arrived in Rome today on a Western European tour London and Paris were disturbed by the news that President Eisenhower planned to remove the Seventh Fleet as a barrier to Chinese Nationalist forays on the mainland from Formosa.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 31 -- Seton Hall, the nation's last remaining undefeated college basketball team, had trouble for the first half tonight, but spurted in the third quarter to defeat Villanova, 84 to 76, before a capacity crowd of 8,608 at the Palestra.

FEW men can write a better Western than William MacLeod Raine, who has turned out more than seventy in earning his undisputed title of dean. His latest, GLORY HOLE (Houghton, Mifflin, $2.50), is laid in Leadville, Colo., when that wild town was at the peak of its boom.

When the liner President Polk sailed out of Jersey City yesterday afternoon for the run to San Francisco few of the passengers and pier visitors realized that two milestones were being quietly passed.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 31 -- Now that everything is pleasant again between Baltimore and the National Football League, the directors of the defunct Baltimore Colts have called off their damage suit against the league.

Despite a doubtful outlook for world shipping, as reflected in the current low level of freight rates for both dry cargo ships and tankers, world-wide shipbuilding activity has reached its highest level since the days of mass producing ships for war emergency.

MONTPELIER, Vt., Jan. 13 -- An increasing flow of bills this week stepped up the pace of Vermont's General Assembly, as the Legislature is officially known. Veteran legislators foresaw the biennial session developing into one of the most lively since the state was incorporated in 1791.

ALISON GRAY has just finished her teachers' training course when she takes, sight unseen, a one-room school in rural Oregon. Her first panic comes when she realizes she has to live alone in a house removed from her neighbors; her second comes when she sees her thirteen assorted pupils.

EVERY boy's parents have had the exasperating experience of dragging a reluctant child to the barber and trying to picture it to him as a happy event. This book opens amazingly with a child who says, in effect, "Good, Let's go."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- President Eisenhower wants a psychological warfare organization that can seize the initiative in the "cold war." This was his aim in creating this week a committee to vitalize the substantial but scattered force that is available for the crucial mission.

I AM not likely to "snuggle down for the evening with Machiavelli's "The Prince'" after having joined the Great Books Foundation in my later years and I doubt that "What America Needs Is More Bad Musicians," as the heading of chapter seven of this charming book proclaims.

LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, Jan. 30 -- Belgium, one of the last of the European powers to enter the field of African colonialism, has begun to adjust her Congo legislation to the requirements of twentieth-century concepts of racial equality.

TUSKEGEE, Ala., Jan. 31 -- Hillard P. Jenkins, 33-year-old Negro farm operator whose planning and industry brought him a gross farm income of $130,101 for 1952, has received Tuskegee Institute's annual Negro farm family merit award.

MONTREAL, Jan. 31 (UP) -- The Boston Bruins battled Montreal to the second scoreless tie of the National Hockey League season tonight as Goalies Sugar Jim Henry and Gerry McNeil gave scintillating exhibitions of skill.
Busy French shipyards recently obtained orders for eight more vessels -- two colliers for Brazilian interests and six freighters for France's second largest shipping company.

John J. McCloy, former United State High Commissioner for Germany, asserted last night that Soviet Russia's anti-Semitic campaign now afforded Germany the opportunity to play "a positive part in, opposing the Communist threats and purposes and the new evils coming out of Moscow." He also said that while there was not the adherence to democratic tradition one finds in England or the United States, there was a democratic structure in Germany.
GEORGES HEUILLARD is dead now.

WHEN Zachary Solov -- whom a critic once described as "one of the most glowing and theatre-wise talents among all the young dancers" -- was appointed choreographer of the Metropolitan Opera in the spring of 1951 and began planning the following season's ballet there, he decided he wanted Janet Collins as a premiere danseuse.
ALBANY, Jan. 31 (UP) -- The State Department of Commerce today reported the following winter sports conditions:

BALTIMORE, Jan. 31 (AP) -- The Republican Governor of Maryland today asked the Democratic Governor of Oklahoma for a "personal favor" -- tell Billy Vessels he should play professional football for Baltimore.
