ALTHOUGH recently introduced varieties of hybrid tea roses offer so-called new and unusual colors or new combinations of color, many older sorts still appeal to experienced rose growers. Tried and true over the years, these older varieties have proved their hardiness and vigor, have been prodigal in bloom and, in many cases, are still unexcelled for sheer beauty by modern hybrid teas.

DENVER, Jan. 31 -- Greater citizen help to the nation's public schools, with the community and the educators becoming "partners," was urged at the closing session here today of the fourth annual Citizens Assembly of Public Education.

THE armed services have a habit of tagging momentous things with deceptively prosaic labels, and this California base -- 100 miles northeast of Los Angeles -- is one of them. Here are 300 square miles of the Mojave Desert comprising, with assorted hangars, barracks and auxiliary buildings, the Air Force Flight Test Center.

DENVER, Jan. 31 -- Greater citizen help to the nation's public schools, with the community and the educators becoming "partners," was urged at the closing session here today of the fourth annual Citizens Assembly of Public Education.

THE armed services have a habit of tagging momentous things with deceptively prosaic labels, and this California base -- 100 miles northeast of Los Angeles -- is one of them. Here are 300 square miles of the Mojave Desert comprising, with assorted hangars, barracks and auxiliary buildings, the Air Force Flight Test Center.
The New York museums, the Metropolitan and the Brooklyn, recently made important acquisitions to their collections, which will be on exhibition tomorrow.

VIRTUALLY unnoticed by the general public, former President Truman took an -- important conservation step early last month when he added nearly 50,000 acres of Federally owned land to the Olympic National Park in northwestern Washington.

Mr. Taubman's interesting article on the Pittsburgh plan of broadening the audience base of the Pittsburgh Orchestra and bringing the orchestra to the people of that area, particularly to the members of trade unions, certainly has a direct bearing on our own problems here in New York.

TOKYO, Jan. 31 -- President Eisenhower's decision to abrogate the United States Seventh Fleet's "neutralizing" role in the Strait of Formosa to permit the Chinese Nationalists to carry on whatever operations they can mount against the Communist mainland was seen in Tokyo today as a preliminary move to enlist more Asians in the war against Asian Reds.

REPRESENTATIVE Hale Boggs, Democrat of Louisiana, is not content with only one stamp which, as Jesse M. Donaldson announced before retiring as Postmaster General, will be issued this year for the sesquicentennial of the Louisiana Purchase.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- A new policy of complete publicity in connection with all pardons and commutations of sentences granted by the President has been inaugurated by the Department of Justice with President Eisenhower's approval, Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. announced today.

PARIS, Jan. 31 -- Eight European countries agreed today to establish a pool of railway freight cars that, it was said, could make available shortly a total of 200,000 cars for use within their territories.
TOKYO, Sunday, Feb. 1 -- Patrols clashed sharply along the Korean front yesterday while ground and carrier based planes and big naval guns pounded the Communists' rear areas.

The outlook for the toy industry this year is favorable, according to Robert B. M. Barton, president of the Toy Manufacturers of the U. S. A. The year undoubtedly will continue the string of record sales volumes, he predicted.
This is becoming a nation of navigators. Perhaps that's as it should be in a hemisphere that had been discovered and explored by Columbus, Amerigo Vespucci, Magellan and the Vikings.
CHICAGO, Feb. 1 (UP) -- An agreement by which International Shoe Company of St. Louis will buy the Florsheim Shoe Company for $21,000,000 was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- In politics, as in war, the victor inherits not only the spoils but also the wreckage of the campaign. Thus the Republicans are now left not only with the headlines but with the headaches, not only with a vast catalogue of world problems, but with the reputation of the State Department, which they helped to tear down.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UP) -- The Democratic National Chairman, Stephen A. Mitchell, has praised a former party official ousted during the Presidential campaign for alleged negotiation of a "5 per cent" deal.

Prices on the domestic cotton market continued to move irregularly last week. Friday's active future contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were up 41 points to down 7 from the close of the previous week.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission has asked Congress to give it stronger control over the submission of proposals to holders of railroad securities for voluntary changes in the securities at a time the railroad is hard-pressed for funds.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 1 (AP) -- The Lauderdale Yacht Club received a delayed report tonight giving the order in which the first ten yachts finished in the Fort Lauderdale to Cat Cay race.

MOSCOW, Feb. 1 -- Pravda marked the tenth anniversary of the great Stalingrad battle today with an attack on the attitude of the United States toward this greatest of Soviet battle successes in World War II. It charged that the Americans were trying their best to wipe the memory of Stalingrad out of Americans' minds.
Abolition of the city's 252 corporation inspectors, "odd fish who are public officials with their salaries paid by private utility companies," was urged yesterday by the Citizens Union.

Representatives of labor and management remained deadlocked early this morning in their attempts to settle a three-day strike of loaders of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union, independent. The stoppage has halted circulation of metropolitan newspapers within a radius of fifty miles outside city limits.

William L. Pfeiffer, Republican State Chairman, has called a meeting of the Republican chairmen of the five New York City counties and of Nassau and Suffolk Counties for next Thursday to discuss Federal patronage.
Benjamin Welles' dispatch from Paris in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Jan. 29, concerning the lack of coordinated information policy of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, touches upon a vital subject.

BANFF, Alberta, Feb. 1 (Canadian Press) -- Washington State scored 385.6 points to capture the team championship for the second straight time at the international intercollegiate ski meet that ended today.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 1 (AP) -- A cast made up entirely of Cincinnati residents and persons studying here gave the world premiere tonight of Vittorio Giannini's opera, "The Taming of the Shrew." Thor Johnson, conductor of the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra, led the orchestra and the singers.

Twenty-one unusual and original contemporary tapestries designed by Jean Lurcat and made in Aubusson, France, go on exhibition today through Feb. 28 at the Associated American Artists Galleries, 711 Fifth Avenue.

Leonard Rosenman and Milton Babbitt were the composers who shared the Saturday evening Composers Forum concert at the McMillin Theatre. Both presented points in common. Their music was highly surcharged with modernism -- a self-contained type of modernism not dealing with superfluous dissonance improperly digested, but handling the tools of composition with integrity.

Safety awards for three American-flag ships, a college course in safety and accident prevention and the publication of the first issue of a new magazine on safety by a major steamship company were announced here yesterday.

Yaacov Dori, president of Technion, Israel's Institute of Technology at Haifa, and commander of Israel's armed forces during the Palestine war, asserted last night that the threat of war and the "bantam posturings" of her "neighbors imposed upon Israel the obligation of continued vigilance and maintenance of full military strength."

CHICAGO, Feb. 1 -- The National Safety Council reported today that 38,000 persons were killed in traffic accidents on the nation's highways last year, an increase of approximately 2 per cent over the 37,700 killed in 1951. In 1952, an estimated 1,350,000 persons were injured by automobiles.

TOKYO, Monday, Feb. 2 -- Ten United States Superfort bombers from bases in Japan and Okinawa dropped 100 tons of high explosives on Communist front line positions early today in what the Air Force called the largest B-29 attack against the enemy's battle posts in more than a year.

Thirty acres of old farm land lying partly in Yonkers and the adjoining town of Greenburgh, N. Y., have been sold by the estate of Matthew S. Eylar to Tanglewood Homes, Inc., clients of Farber-Wittman, Inc., of New York, brokers. The acreage lies along Fort Hill Road, which runs through Yonkers and Greenburgh.

LONDON, Feb. 1 -- Despite many uncertainties which still make the investment outlook obscure, the stoc kmarkets continue to display marked firmness and increasing activity. It is the short-term view rather than the long-term one that is responsible for this interest and optimism.

The New York Americans battled to a 1-1 tie with the Scots-Americans of Harrison, N. J., and the Brooklyn Hispanos defeated the Brookhattan-Galicia eleven, 2 -- 1, in an American Soccer League double-header yesterday at Sterling Oval, the Bronx.
OGDEN, Utah, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Christian Pravda, Austrian ski star, flashed over the one-mile giant slalom course at Snow Basin in 1:27.1 today to take top men's honors in the annual Eccles Cup event.
BERLIN, Feb. 1 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer called on the entire Western world today to help West Germany solve the problem of refugees pouring into West Berlin.

PACIFIC GROVE, Calif., Feb. 1 -- A new and brighter day for the Democratic party in California under changes in the procedure for choosing major candidates and a broader base for money raising was envisioned by party leaders assembled at the Asilomar Conference Grounds here today.
Vera Franceschi, pianist, was soloist with Vladimir Golschmann and the Philharmonic-Symphony at Carnegie Hall Saturday evening, playing the Mozart D Minor Concerto (K. 466).

Life among the patroons and Mohawks in early New York and the role exercised by the Rev. Johannes Megapolensis, "apostle to the Indians," in preventing a massacre in the surrender of New Amsterdam to the British in 1664 was recalled in a sermon yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Edgar Frankin Romig at West End Collegiate Church at Seventy-seventh Street.

Some of the finest chamber music of the season was provided by the New Music String Quartet late yesterday afternoon when it played for the New Friends of Music at Town Hall. The ensemble's program ran the gamut of the Friends' schedule -- "Italian classics, Mozart and Contemporaries."

LONDON, Monday, Feb. 2 -- A storm and floods that devastated the east coast of Britain yesterday and Saturday night took at least 200 lives. Thousands of persons were homeless and communications were still so badly disrupted this morning that it was impossible to establish the number of dead or the extent of damage.

May I add something to the excellent presentation of the sufferings of the bus rider as described in a recent letter by Senta Rypins. But not all of the passengers' hardships can be blamed on the driver, whose rudeness and lack of consideration stem partly from the unsatisfying conditions which caused the strike.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1 (UP) -- Goalie Lorne Worsley scored his second shut-out of the season tonight as the New York Rangers downed the Chicago Black Hawks, 1 to 0, before 12,228 fans for the first Ranger victory on Chicago Stadium ice of the National Hockey League season.

All employed in the motion-picture industry have talents they must use, even if they may not be stars, declared the Rev. Edwin B. Broderick, director of radio and television for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, at a communion breakfast here yesterday.

Diligent day-by-day investigation by detectives who questioned more than 200 youths produced yesterday what the police called the solution to the murder of a 15-year-old Bronx boy found beaten to death last Dec. 26 in a junk-filled lot at 175th Street and Carter Avenue in the Tremont section.

HAVANA, Feb. 1 -- The second race of the Bacardi Cup series in the twenty-second international Star Class yacht regatta was won today by the Cuban yacht Brisote, skippered by Alberto Tunon. Brisote, representing the Havana Yacht Club, negotiated the course in 1 hour 22 minutes 25 seconds. Brisote has 36 points and holds fourth place in the series.

In World War II the so-called Little Steel formula was used as a basis for the stabilization of wages. Since this formula tied wage rates to the consumer price index of the Bureau of Labor Statistics (popularly referred to in those days as the cost-of-living index), one result was to make the index the object of almost continuous controversy.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 1 -- Yugoslav sources asserted today that the Cominform countries surrounding this country were showing signs of sensitivity to the development of a Balkan entente among Yugoslavia, Greece and Turkey.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 1 -- Strong indications that the American Federation of Labor would take direct action to force a clean-up in its racket-ridden affiliate on the New York waterfront, the International Longshoremen's Association, developed tonight as the federation's fifteen-member Executive Council gathered here for the opening of its midwinter meeting tomorrow.

The Rev. Canon Victor J. Pike, honorary chaplain to the Queen of England, speaking yesterday in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, sought to answer President Eisenhower's question: "How far have we come in man's long pilgrimage from darkness towards light?"

Sweeping recommendations for the enactment and enforcement of regulations to safeguard the lives and health of occupants of one and two-family homes in this city have been sent to Mayor Impellitteri by the Committee on Housing of the Community Service Society.
HUNSTANTON, England, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Forty persons, many of them Americans, were believed to have drowned today in North Sea flood waters that overwhelmed this Norfolk coastal resort.

Two young children were burned to death and six other persons suffered burns and injuries last night as fire swept through a two-story frame dwelling in South Jamaica, Queens, that housed twenty-one persons.

Josef Marais and his wife and partner, Miranda, returned to Town Hall Saturday night to give a program of folk songs. It was their third formal concert at the auditorium and it drew an audience of 1,570, which meant that the overflow had to be accommodated in seats on the stage.
LONDON, Feb. 1 -- Right, left and center joined today in expressions of hostility to new trends in a United States policy, and especially to its spokesman, Secretary of State John Foster Dulles.
The 579 fixed air-raid-warning sirens in the city will be tested simultaneously at 11 A. M. Wednesday, Feb. 11, Herbert R. O'Brien, city director of civil defense, announced yesterday.

The press has just reported that the State Department and the S. E. C. intend to put the "Validation agreement" into operation by an executive agreement. The "Validation agreement" is an integrated part of the London Conference agreement which is to settle Germany's pre-war debts.
A blanket of cold air slid down over the northeastern United States from Canada yesterday, sending temperatures skidding to their lowest level so far this year.

The Rev. Dr. Franklin Cole of the Congregational Church-in-the-Gardens, Ascan Avenue and Greenway North, Forest Hills, Queens, offered proposals in his sermon yesterday morning as a guide to correcting civic corruption here. He urged all citizens to unite in their support.

Two issues of the Federal Home Loan Bank's consolidated notes amounting to $142,050,000 which mature on Feb. 16 will be redeemed from current resources, it has been announced through Everett Smith, fiscal agent. The issues are $75,400,000 of 2 per cent Series A-1953 consolidated notes dated May 15, 1952, and $66,650,000 of 2 per cent Series B-1953 consolidated notes dated June 13, 1952.

The Textile Economics Bureau, Inc., reported production of man made fibers in the United States in 1952 was 1,396,400,000 pounds, or 7 per cent below the record output of 1951. World-wide production of rayon and acetate was estimated by the bureau at 3,400,000,000 pounds, or 14 per cent below that of 1951.

Additional indictments of waterfront racketeers were foreseen yesterday as a result of the study by local prosecutors on both sides of the East and Hudson Rivers of testimony given at the State Crime Commission's hearings.

Sixteen retailers in many lines and ranging from chains and department stores, were named yesterday as finalists in the New York area in the Brand Names Foundation nation-wide contest for Brand Name Retailer-of-the-Year. In all there are 20,000 finalists against whom they will compete.

The judiciary committee of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, through Francis H. Horan, its acting chairman, announced yesterday that it favored the renomination and re-election of four Supreme Court Justices in the First Judicial District and two Judges of the Court of General Sessions whose terms will end this year.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 1 -- By the time official figures are in they will show that steel production last month produced a new record for any January output in steel mill history. This quick tempo is the result of steel companies attempting to catch up on some of their delayed deliveries and at the same time keep up with heavy current demand.

By way of Europe, having played triumphal engagements in Vienna, Berlin and London, the memorable American Negro folk musical, "Porgy and Bess," based on "Porgy," the DuBose and Dorothy Heyward play, will come to the Ziegfeld March 11. Abroad, William Warfield, Cab Calloway and Leontyne Price (Mrs. Warfield) were hailed for their performances as Porgy, Sportin' Life and Bess, respectively.

TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 1 (UP) -- Tommy Bolt of Maplewood, N. J., shooting some of the best golf of his career, won the $10,000 Tucson open at the El Rio golf course today with a 15-under-par 265 for the 72 holes. He finished with a 66 this afternoon.

ABADAN, Iran, Jan. 28 -- If large-scale production is ever resumed in the Abadan refinery there will be jobs here for about 350 foreign oil technicians and a market for $10,000,000 to $15,000,000 worth of oil-refining equipment needed here.

The Port of New York girded last night for possible shortages in coal and fuel oil as the strike of 3,500 towboat workers on 450 harbor craft moved into its second day with no indications of a settlement.
Disposition of city-owned property in high-tax areas "to stop waste and squandering of the taxpayers money" was called for yesterday by the Fifth Avenue Association.

PARIS, Feb. 1 -- Increased exporting from France to Germany is provided in the new Franco-German trade agreement signed on Jan. 24. This was in accord with a declaration by the Organization for European Economic Cooperation that the creditor countries (among which is Germany) ought to aid the debtor nations (among which is France).
Luis Galve, a pianist from Spain, made his debut last night in Town Hall.
ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- The State Liquor Authority charged today that local law enforcement officers in many counties of the state were shirking their duty of enforcing the Alcoholic Beverage Control Law.
DALLAS, Feb. 1 (AP) -- H. N. (Rusty) Russell resigned tonight as football coach of Southern Methodist University. He had been under fire after two losing seasons.

BOSTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- New York's Knickerbockers were outscored from the floor today but had a big edge at the free throw line to whip the Philadelphia Warriors, 90 -- 85, in the first game of a National Basketball Association doubleheader in the Boston Garden.

The United States still has the world's largest fleet of privately owned ocean-going tankers, but it is not expected to keep this prominent position much longer in the face of heavy tanker construction by other maritime nations.

The American premiere of Stravinsky's "The Rake's Progress" on Feb. 14 will be the highlight of the1 Metropolitan Opera's fourteenthl week of the season. The perform-I ance will be broadcast across thel nation.

PARIS, Feb. 1 -- Wide, flat crowns on tiny brims, small flat bowlers, both worn dead straight to conceal the hairline, are an important part of Paulette's varied millinery collection, outstanding for workmanship and combinations of straw-jersey with straw or grosgrain in suave two or three tone contrasts.

The State Crime Commission has done yeomen service in opening the eyes of the public to some of the evils on the Port of New York's sprawling waterfront. Its investigation has exposed vicious criminals, corrupt labor leaders, cowed and leaderless employers, unscrupulous politicians and ineffective law enforcement.

The official women's contract bridge champions of Great Britain and Europe started play last night against a highly rated expert United States women's team in the last of a series of challenge matches between the English champions and the best United States women's teams.

David Tirrell, hockey coach at Trinity-Pawling School, Pawling, N. Y., was laughing the other day about his experiences as headmaster at the Evans School in Tucson, Ariz., some twenty years ago. "The temperature hit as much as 111 degrees in the daytime but nevertheless I found myself wishing for a hockey team the year-round.

LONDON, Feb. 1 -- All the gasolines that make a motor purr, give it that smoo-oo-ooth zip, keep microbes out of cylinders, contain anti-knock specifics or provide that extra getaway came back to Britain today.

Alben W. Barkley, former Vice President, started his own television program yesterday afternoon (5:30 over N. B. C.-TV) under the title of "Meet the Veep." The Veep was in good spirits as he told a few stories and took a kindly and amiable glance at the Washington scene.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 1 -- The Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation announced today a conversion of its "entire production output forthwith to a new photographic and sound system to be known as Cinemascope."

New York rose and fell the thickness of a half dollar on Election Day as a result of a nonpolitical disturbance that provided supporting evidence for the theory that the earth's core is liquid and not solid.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UP) -- American Federation of Labor textile union leaders will give Martin P. Durkin, Secretary of Labor, a first-hand account of textile unemployment tomorrow and will urge Government action to help the industry.

Marvelous Mal Whitfield collected nine of ten first-place votes as the outstanding performer of Saturday's sixty - fourth Boston Athletic Association games, in which he equaled the world indoor record of 1 minute 10.2 seconds for 600 yards.
Four new films, including an importation from Sweden, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Jan. 20 -- There is probably no place abroad less foreign to an American than Johannesburg and its environs, the gold-laden ridge of the Witwatersrand. It is about as foreign as Dallas or Houston or Kansas City.

Four Indian chieftains representing the Yakima tribe in Oregon appealed last night to an audience at the Madison Avenue Baptist Church, at Thirty-first Street, and to "Christians throughout the land" to support their efforts to save Celilo Falls on the Columbia River.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- The American Red Cross reported today that in the last year it had doubled its task force of nursing volunteers for work in epidemics and other disasters, the blood program and instruction in classes for home nursing and nurse's aid service.
" Decade of Decision for Higher Education" is the theme of the fifth annual Barnard Forum, which will take place on Saturday, Feb. 14, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Monday, Feb. 2 -- The North Sea, with an 85-mile-an-hour gale as its ally, laid deadly seige today to the dikes and dunes of the Netherlands, which have held it at bay for centuries.

The fact that Charles E. Wilson and others in his position have to pay large capital gains taxes when they sell their stock holdings indicates that originally they paid much less for these stocks. If these gains had been in the form of yearly income they would, under our present laws, have been paying taxes on a "pay-as-you-go" basis.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1 -- Plans for a world-wide Surgeons' Hall of Fame to be established in the headquarters here of the International College of Surgeons were announced today in the official journal of the college.

MUNICH, Germany, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Fritz Kuhn, once the arrogant, noisy leader of the pro-Hitler German-American Bund, died here more than a year ago -- a poor and obscure chemist, unheralded and unsung.

The home freezer is moving off the farm into the great cities of the country. E. L. Hinchliff, sales manager of Amana Refrigeration, Inc., said yesterday that the future for mass sales of freezers lies in urban areas with populations of 500,000 or more.

Our designer biography today is one that reaches back to the early beginnings of the ready-to-wear industry in New York. Few consumers realize that the women's garment manufacturing business is little more than half a century old and that, when it got under way, it was concerned solely with the making of skirts, then with blouses and that, as the demand grew, the two were combined to make dresses.
Six young people, who had served apprenticeships in government in "the Junior Legislatures" of their states, agreed last night that there was room for ethics in adult government.

PARIS, Feb. 1 -- John Foster Dulles, United States Secretary of State, and Harold E. Stassen, head of the Mutual Security Agency, arrived today and spent the afternoon and evening listen ing to more than a score of United States officials -- political, economic and military -- in a rapid briefing on the outlook for European defense and unity.

A number of large museum exhibitions as well as several featuring modern French paintings make this an art week of unusual interest. To honor New York's 300th birthday a special exhibition from the Municipal collection of The Hague, the Netherlands, will be opened tomorrow at the Metropolitan Museum.

GARMISCH - PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Lloyd Johnson, who took up the sport only three years ago and almost wasn't chosen for the American team, drove the United States No. 2 sled to a world championship in four-man bobsled racing today.

The American Jewish Committee adopted unanimously yesterday a "Declaration on Communist Anti-Semitism" that sharply condemned Communist attacks against freedom of thought throughout the world, the undermining of human rights and persistent Communist persecution of "social classes, ethnic minorities and religious groups."

An investing client of Irving Kulick, attorney, bought the one-story brick taxpayer building with a frontage of 100 feet at 1979-91 Hughes Avenue, the Bronx, from Leah Stern. The property is assessed at $32,000 and was sold through Langsam Schiffman, brokers.

Expressing "sheerest admiration" for the work of editors and reporters on secular dailies, Msgr. William T. Greene nevertheless warned Roman Catholics yesterday against "accepting as their Bible or catechism the daily newspaper account of some item that pertains to faith and morals."

A wily and agile little rhesus monkey that has been at large in Lower Manhattan for six weeks has earned the affection of fruit dealers whose stands he has been raiding. They no longer care whether the police succeed in capturing him.

ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- The State Congress of Industrial Organizations warned legislators in a letter distributed here today that any relaxation of state rent control would disrupt the economic stability of the state and lead to fresh demands by labor unions for Wage increases.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- President and Mrs. Eisenhower were received into membership of the National Presbyterian Church today in a private ceremony described by the pastor as "simple and modest."

CANTON, N. Y., Feb. 1 -- Art Devlin, Lake Placid Sno-Birds, won the third annual St. Lawrence University invitation ski jumping tourney at South Colton today, but failed by twenty-six feet to match the hill record of 186, set by Art Tokle in 1951.

New York's 300th anniversary as an incorporated city was marked yesterday by special services in the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. Mark's-in-the-Bouwerie, Second Avenue and Tenth Street. Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands took part.

The Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority has recast its $90,000,000 construction program, dropping $30,000,000 of twin projects in the Bronx and substituting $33,000,000 of improvements in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 1 -- A. T. Lennox-Boyd; British Minister of Transport, ordered today an investigation of the capsizing of the 2,694-ton ferry Princess Victoria yesterday on a trip from Stranraer, Scotland, to Larne, Northern Ireland.

DETROIT, Feb. 1 (UP) -- Gordie Howe pumped in two goals and assisted on three others tonight as the Detroit Red Wings defeated the Toronto Maple Leafs, 5 -- 1, to break a tie with Montreal and take sole possession of first place in the National Hockey League.

Now and again you pick up the kind of book you wouldn't dare recommend to a man unwilling to stretch his mental muscles on occasion. Such a volume is "Principles of Private and public Planning,"* by Wilhelm Keilhau, a leading Norwegian economist.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 1 -- While public officials, educators and laymen throughout the country are discussing the pros and cons of educational television, what may be the first full-fledged telecasting station in this field is preparing to go into operation here.

PARIS, Feb. 1 -- French Senators discussing the defense budget showed concern tonight about delays in settling United States offshore orders for the purchase of defense items manufactured in France but financed by United States funds.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 1 -- With every appearance of confidence, West German Chancellor Konrad Adenauer announced today that the third and final reading of the Allied-German treaties would take place in the Bundestag or Chamber of Deputies between March 10 and 15 at the latest.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 31 -- The Israeli Government and the public have been thoroughly alarmed by a series of sharp border incidents and by the threat by Egyptian Premier Mohammed Naguib to "liberate Palestine."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- President Eisenhower will appear before a joint session of Congress tomorrow to spell out the course he proposes to follow at home and abroad in the year ahead.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public, which will mature within twelve months, amount to $71,397,882,626. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

The King of the Sea, large and popular fish restaurant at 879 Third Avenue, has made it possible for its wide following to dine at home on some of its specialties. It has just opened what the proprietor, Adolph Flashner, calls a "take-home food shop" next to the eating establishment.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES of Jan. 13 I find a fine picture and an article on the subject of the statues on the Appellate Court building in New York. It seems that the building is to be reconstructed and the statues do not fit into the plans of the architect. The museums of the city have been canvassed and naturally and quite rightly they are not interested.
TOKYO, Monday, Feb. 2 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,513, covering Sunday's actions:

Our lives are geared to a stop-watch. More and more of us are trying to get somewhere in a hurry. We run for buses and trains, race our cars along the highways and hurry to the job and home again. On land, on sea and in the air men try to go higher and faster than anyone has ever gone before.

A revival of belief in a divine moral order would "cleanse and renew" the "whole moral tone of civilization," the Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken, minister of Riverside Church, said yesterday in his sermon.

Leo Durocher, who long has harbored a notion he would like to be a movie director, and Miss Tallulah Bankhead, whose most cherished hopes have always been to manage a major league ball club, just about saw their ambitions brought to fruition last night.

So far as Italy and European unity were concerned, Secretary of State Dulles had nothing to worry about. He started his European trip on Saturday in an auspicious place. Prime Minister De Gasperi and his Governments have been champions of European integration for years.

BOMBAY, India, Feb. 1 -- While the United Nations continues trying, without success, to settle the dispute between India and Pakistan over the allegiance of the state of Jammu and Kashmir, disaffection within the strategic northern state itself is erupting into almost daily violence with mob demonstrations against authorities.

Father may acquire a few family budgeting techniques, mother a new hair style, or both some practical pointers on raising Junior when a number of courses offered for parents get under way this season. Enrollment for most of them can be made now.

Two years ago the Department of City Planning was authorized to hire ten assistant planners. It employed six on a provisional basis, with salaries running up to $5,410 a year. Last spring three of these temporary appointees placed, respectively, fifth, tenth and eleventh in a civil service examination taken by thirteen candidates.
A new boathouse for model yachts in Central Park soon will replace the old, unsightly and inadequate frame structure on the east side of Conservatory Lake opposite East Seventy-fourth

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 1 -- American President Lines plans to institute trans-Pacific passenger sailings on a two-week basis if it is successful in chartering from the Military Sea Transportation Service a ship to join with the luxury liners President Cleveland and President Wilson in the run between San Francisco and the Far East.

Two years ago the Department of City Planning was authorized to hire ten assistant planners. It employed six on a provisional basis, with salaries running up to $5,410 a year. Last spring three of these temporary appointees placed, respectively, fifth, tenth and eleventh in a civil service examination taken by thirteen candidates.
A new boathouse for model yachts in Central Park soon will replace the old, unsightly and inadequate frame structure on the east side of Conservatory Lake opposite East Seventy-fourth

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 1 -- American President Lines plans to institute trans-Pacific passenger sailings on a two-week basis if it is successful in chartering from the Military Sea Transportation Service a ship to join with the luxury liners President Cleveland and President Wilson in the run between San Francisco and the Far East.

Jack P. Fischer and Joseph Walzer bought the five-story warehouse building on lot 50 by 100 feet at 144-46 West Ninetieth Street from Henry Angelbeck for the storing and shipping of bearings and motive specialties. J. P. and L. A. Kissling negotiated the sale of the property, which is assessed at $75,000.

More than half of the jewels stolen early Saturday from a subway public locker were recovered by the police yesterday in another ten-cent lock-box, and detectives were wondering last night whether they, like the thieves, had merely stumbled on the loot or whether it was meant that they should find it.

The first English translation of Robert Musil's "The Man Without Qualities," a novel about the Austrian Empire on the eve of the first World War, will be issued in June by Coward McCann. Set in Vienna, the story covers one year in the life of a young man whose attempts at various careers have been unsuccessful.

DONAGHADEE, Northern Ireland, Feb. 1 (UP) -- Ships' nets were dragging from the sea today the bodies of victims of the ferry Princess Victoria, which sank in a storm with a loss of 132 lives yesterday in the North Channel off this port.

ALBANY, Feb, 1 -- The Democratic State Chairman and his party's two legislative leaders announced today their opposition to a proposed constitutional amendment that would require the election of Governor and Lieutenant Governor on a single ballot.

The Metropolitan Opera's production of "Fledermaus," especially trimmed and tailored for television, was broadcast over a national network late yesterday afternoon. Several of the Metropolitan's opening- night presentations in seasons past have been telecast from the stage of the opera house, but this was the first time the company has had a chance to show what it could do when it aimed strictly at the viewer sitting before his home screen.

President Eisenhower and Vice President Richard M. Nixon joined leaders of the American Legion yesterday in a half-hour interfaith religious program broadcast nationally and extensively televised to mark the beginning of the Legion's 1953 "Back to God" campaign.
The National Steel Corporation had net earnings last year of $37,559,477 after all deductions, compared with $45,287,093 earned in 1951, the preliminary annual report disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Lowell Mason, whose salty, dissenting opinions as a member of the Federal Trade Commission have pilloried bureaucratic practices in government, was reported today to slated for the chairmanship of the commission.

AMSTERDAM, Feb. 1 -- The Amsterdam stock market generally has displayed a cheerful mood throughout January and the general average has risen from 138 to 144 1/2. This improvement was seen in all sections -- especially in certain internationals, shipping and Indonesian issues, particularly suggars and tobaccos.

Branch Rickey, general manager of the Pirates, admitted last night that three National League clubs were seeking Ralph Kiner, the Bucs' slugging outfielder. Two of the clubs are the Braves and the Reds.

Continued strength in the spot rate for the British pound sterling was the only point of interest in the foreign exchange market during the past week. Canadian dollar held within a narrow range on light dealings that were mostly routine.

Three hundred years ago today Nieuw Amsterdam, a community of 800 souls, as incorporated in a grant of municipal government proclaimed by Peter Stuyvesant. It was, as the Florentine navigator Giovanni da Verrazano had said in 1524, "a very agreeable location.'

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Feb. 1 -- The debate in Parliament on the record of the Government of Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan appears to have proved that the Nationalists have had no more success in ameliorating South Africa's race problems than did their predecessors, the United party, now the Opposition.

WINE may improve with age but the baseball writers-turned-actors definitely do not. They get worse. What is more, they prove it every year by perverting and disgracing the dramatic art with the annual Baseball Writers Show. They wooed the muse Thespis at the Waldorf-Astoria last night and none even got to first base.

SEOUL, Korea, Feb. 1 -- The celebration of the fifty-second anniversary of the Army Nurse Corps today also marks the third time that the anniversary has been observed in Korea. Since the first small group of nurses landed in Pusan shortly after the outbreak of war in June, 1950, the young women in khaki and white have won the respect and admiration of the men in Korea from all nations of the free world.

Incredulous one may be, thinking of spotless operating rooms and modern techniques in surgery, upon reading a tale of witch doctoring in Portuguese East Africa as recounted the other day by C. L. Sulzberger, yet one need not travel very far beyond this metropolitan area to find "cures" being tried that are only a little less startling than those employed in the witch-doctoring trade.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 1 -- Israel's new Minister of Commerce and Industry, Peretz Bernstein, who is a member of the pro-free enterprise General Zionist party, said in a radio address tonight that "we will move toward decontrol of everything possible because it is certain that we can cure the basic maladies of our economy only to the extent that we restore freedom of enterprise."

Bronx Zoo keepers, in the spirit of a wake, told warm stories last night about their Pete, the happy hippopotamus, who for nearly half a century amused young and old by posing -- always willingly -- with his huge mouth agape.

Every Thursday afternoon at 4 o'clock J. H. Carmichael, president of Capital Airlines, picks up his telephone in his Washington office and starts talking. On the other end of the line 4,100 of the airline's employes in thirty-six cities throughout the eastern United States hear the boss.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 1 -- The Screen Directors Guild tonight paid tribute to John Ford and Cecil B. DeMille at its fifth annual award dinner at the Biltmore Hotel in Los Angeles.

NORTH CONWAY, N. H., Feb. 1 -- America's best Alpine skiers today continued to pursue Othmar Schneider, the Olympic gold and silver medal winner from Austria's Tyrol, who remains unbeaten this winter. The 25-year-old athlete, who has taken time off from his pharmaceutical studies at the University of Innsbruck for an invasion of the United States, again won by a decisive margin against a formidable field in the fourteenth Gibson Trophy slalom competition.

ST. PAUL, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Ken Bartholomew of Minneapolis made a determined comeback to sweep his last three races and retain his senior men's crown in the national outdoor speed-skating championships today.
A survey will be launched soon as part of a campaign to determine the extent to which televising of major league baseball has affected the minor leagues and pave the way for a remedy.

The North Sea is the lavish friend of many folk: herring fishers and shrimp trawlers, coastwise sailors, ship builders -- even farmers, when it marshals its lieutenant-clouds to enrich a stubborn soil.

TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 2 -- The Soviet Union is proving to be unusually accommodating in settling the affairs of the Iranian-Soviet Caviar Fishing Company, which was dissolved Saturday upon the expiration of the twenty-five-year agreement between the two countries.

Mr. and Mrs. H. Howard Babcock will give a cocktail party this afternoon in the Tapestry Room of the Park Lane for members of the committee aiding in plans for the benefit performance of "Can-Can," Cole Porter's new musical show, on May 4 in behalf of the Madison Square Boys Club.

The Southern Pacific Company last year had a consolidated net income of $63,440,367 after charges and taxes, equal to 57.09 each on the 8,941,994 capital shares outstanding, according to a preliminary report for 1952 issued yesterday.

The strike of newspaper deliverymen against suburban wholesalers has curtailed distribution of The New York Times outside New York City within a 50-mile radius. The Times may be obtained, however, at all newsstands within the New York City line.

BOSTON, Feb. 2 -- Dr. Paul Dudley White, Boston heart specialist, received tonight the Albert Lasker Award for "distinguished achievement in the field of cardiovascular diseases." The presentation was by Dr. Irving S. Wright, president of the American Heart Association, at the 1953 Massachusetts Heart Fund dinner.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 2 (Reuters) -- The Chinese Communists are building three big military roads across Tibet.

ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- The Democratic State Chairman and his four chief Legislative leaders today attacked Governor Dewey's 1953-54 budget as "a hodgepodge filled with skillfully devised schemes to mislead and misguide the taxpayers of the state."

Directors of the General Motors Corporation elected Harlow H. Curtice as president yesterday. The 59-year-old former executive vice president, who has been acting president of the company since last November, succeeds Charles E. Wilson, new Secretary of Defense.

VIENNA, Feb. 2 -- A reorganization of the Czechoslovak Government on Russian lines to place chief power in the hands of a presidium was decided at a special Cabinet sitting Saturday and announced today by the Prague radio.

Operations of the nation's steel mills this week are estimated at 95.6 per cent of rated capacity which, in terms of production, would equal 2,154,000 tons of ingots and steel for castings. The American Iron Steel Institute, in its report yesterday, explained that this sharp decline was partly caused by the work stoppage at Inland Steel Company in Chicago.
Far East naval forces summary, for Sunday:
LONDON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- A rare combination of wind and tide was responsible for the storm that spread death and destruction over Britain, the Netherlands and Belgium over the week-end.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (UP) -- The Michigan Communist party asked the Supreme Court today to invalidate the state's Anti-Communist law on grounds it was unconstitutional and placed many persons in "the position of a prisoner on parole."
Obsolete records cost the country's business and industrial concerns $300,000,000 annually, it was asserted yesterday by Emmet J. Leahy, president of the National Records Management Council.

LONDON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Approximately a million persons were in the area of the Netherlands inundated by the week-end floods. They were either homeless or threatened. The country's historic dikes were broken in sixty to eighty places, and water swept forty miles inland, swamping up to 1,500 square miles and penetrating a sixth of the Netherlands land surface.

NEWARK, Feb. 2 -- Superior Court Judge Walter Freund today signed an order requiring the Newark Housing Authority to show cause Friday why it should not be restricted from requiring tenants to sign an oath that they and members of their families are not members of any of 200 organizations listed by the United States Attorney General as subversive.

Attendance records were broken during the first two days of exhibiting at the Men's Apparel Club of New York City at the New Yorker Hotel, it was announced yesterday by officials of the group. Buying was reported heavy, with sportswear and novelties for spring and summer most in demand.

An issue of $4,650,000 of 3.90 per cent revenue and refunding bonds of the Philadelphia Parking Authority was placed on the market yesterday by an investment banking syndicate headed by Alex, Brown Sons, Shields Co. and Kidder, Peabody Co.
ALBANY, Feb. 2 (UP) -- The State Commerce Department today reported the following winter sports conditions:

WINNIPEG, Feb. 2 (Canadian Press) -- The Canadian Grain Journal in its January issue says reopening of the wheat futures market at Winnipeg is a "distinct possibility" following Britain's announcement of plans to quit grain-buying in non-dollar areas.

About 90 per cent of the children in this city are "beset with tooth decay," according to Dr. H. William Frankel, chairman of Child Dental Health Week, which began yesterday. Recent statistics indicate that there are more than 1,500,000 children under 14 years old here.
Net income of the Atlantic Refining Company and its subsidiaries last year declined to $40,427,000 from $45,067,000 earned in 1951, the annual report disclosed yesterday.

There was little in the market yesterday to show that investors had been listening to President Eisenhower's State of the Union message. Aircrafts, steels and motors -- all considered "war stocks" -- gained fractions in the last two hours of trading but most other sections of the list continued the trends they had started earlier.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Michael J. McDermott, State Department press officer, said today that the Netherlands was the only country that had thus far mentioned possible use of counterpart funds for use in relief of the flood emergency in Europe.

LONDON, Feb. 2 -- The stock markets here started the week quietly and in general prices moved aimlessly. The underlying buoyancy of last week, however, was maintained on the expectation that a statement showing an improved gold and dollar reserve would soon be issued.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The board of directors of the American Association of University Women issued a statement today declaring for a bold Attack against communism through a whole-hearted commitment to all that democracy stands for.

Charles E. McMahon, an attorney who served for several months as a Municipal Court justice in the administration of the late Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia, was found dead in bed late yesterday in his apartment in the Belvedere Hotel, 319 West Forty-eighth Street.

Price changes were irregular yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges. Trading was moderately active and in coffee sales were heavier than at any time in the last three weeks. Potatoes, coffee, sugar, cottonseed oil, hides and wool closed higher.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Tuesday, Feb. 3 -- Hundreds of ships, ranging from Queen Juliana's yacht to the humble herring trawler, were assembling in Dutch ports early this morning for an effort to evacuate tens of thousands of survivors trapped in flood-stricken Zeeland, the islands to the south and the adjoining mainland.

PARIS, Feb. 2 -- Premier Rene Mayer, Foreign Minister Georges Bidault and Defense Minister Rene Pleven appear to have convinced Secretary of State John Foster Dulles today that they firmly intended to push the European Army treaty to ratification when modified, not to block it or delay it.

Mayor Impellitteri swore in John E. Cone Jr. yesterday as an associate justice of the Court of Special Sessions. About seventy-five persons, including District Attorney Miles F. McDonald of Kings County, Acting Brooklyn Borough President John J. Lynch, members of the judiciary and other officials, attended the ceremony in City Hall.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The Senate confirmed today President Eisenhower's nominations of Robert T. Stevens to be Secretary of the Army, Robert B. Anderson to be Secretary of the Navy, Winthrop W. Aldrich to be Ambassador to Britain and Francis A. O'Neill Jr. to be a member of the National Mediation Board for another term of three years.

Sir Roger Makins, acknowledging last night the traditional welcome of a British Ambassador by the Pilgrims of the United States predicted that the old concept of close association between Great Britain and the United States as the cornerstone for world peace was now broadening to include the entire Atlantic community.

New York's early days as the tiny island community of Nieuw Amsterdam 300 years ago, recaptured through paintings and prints, historical documents and maps were recalled yesterday in the preview of an exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art at which Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands was the guest of honor.
Eddie Brannick, hale and hearty, was back at his desk in the New York Giants' offices yesterday. Refreshed from his vacation, Eddie said five more Giants had signed their 1953 contracts.

President Eisenhower's first message to Congress, yesterday, on the State of the Union was a straightforward statement of high principles, reasonable objectives and sound procedure. There will be time and occasion later for a more detailed examination of the policies he outlined. Here we attempt only first appraisal.

ZURICH, Feb. 2 -- Although in fulfillment of the accord reached in London on Aug. 8 between West Germany and her foreign creditors for settlement of German pre-war external debts, West Germany would be willing to resume debt service on April 1, a further delay has become inevitable.

William Stucky's drama "Touchstone" will open tonight at 8 o'clock at the Music Box Theatre under the sponsorship of Elaine Perry. Set in what the author describes as "the horse country of the upper South," "Touchstone" is the story of a Negro boy, played by Josh White Jr., who believes he has seen supernatural visions, and the effect of his belief on persons close to him.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Feb. 2 -- The Nationalist Government of Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan introduced in Parliament today a measure making anyone who protests against any law (meaning, specifically, race segregation and white supremacy legislation) subject to five years' imprisonment, a fine and fifteen strokes of the lash.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 2 -- The Rev. Leo Rudloff was solemnly enthroned as Abbot of the Dormitian Abbey on Mount Zion this morning, with the Latin Patriarch of Jerusalem, Msgr. Alberto Gori, officiating in the name of Pope Pius.

Walter P. Reuther, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, called last night upon President Eisenhower's Administration to redeem Republican campaign promises through promotion by the Federal Government of "a comprehensive health program for all the American people."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Following are the major recommendations on foreign and domestic policy in President Eisenhower's first State of the Union Message today:
LONDON, Feb. 2 -- A vast coastal region of southeastern Britain lay submerged by salt water today, as the Romans found it 2,000 years ago. Seen from the air the land was awash and lifeless.
The Spanish Line will place two new passenger-cargo liners in service on its trans-Atlantic run between Europe and New York, Garcia Diaz, agents for the line in this country, announced yesterday.

Further evidence of the fact that the United States leads the rest of the world in contract bridge was given last night at the Regency Club. There the United States team of Mrs. Helen Sobel, Miss Ruth Sherman, Mrs. Henry Kemp, all of New York, and Mrs. Margaret Wagar of Atlanta, Ga., finished a two session sixty-four board match 5,130 points ahead of the official women's European championship team.

ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- The State Power Authority reported to Governor Dewey and the Legislature today that it had "every reason to hope" that the Federal Power Commission would soon grant it a license to construct the St. Lawrence Power Project.
Sales of Manhattan and Brooklyn department stores declined 2.5 per cent in January, in comparison with the same month a year ago, according to the survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- President Eisenhower today ended the United States Seventh Fleet's protective screening of Red China, thus permitting the Nationalist forces of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek on Formosa to attack the Communist-held mainland.

Events tonight: Mascagni's "Cavalleria Rusticana" and Leoncavallo's "Pagliacci," Metropolitan Opera House, 8:15: Philadelphia Orchestra, Eugene Ormandy, conductor. Zino Francescatti. violinist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Virginia Reinecke, pianist, Town Hall, 8:30; program of Netherlands music, Ruth Freeman, flutist, Desi Halban, soprano, Ethel Bartlett and Rae Robertson, duo-pianists, Ralph Hollander, violinist, Harvey Shapiro, 'cellist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30; John Upham, organist, St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University, 5:05 P. M.

The contemporary mood of the paintings, sculpture and mobiles that comprise the second annual art exhibit at Ludwig Baumann, 500 Eighth Avenue, is mirrored in the furniture and objects used in conjunction with the display.

Rufus Smith, a gifted ballad singer who has sung in such Broadway musicals as "Street Scene," "Allegro" and "Paint Your Wagon," last night at Town Hall gave his first New York recital. In his program he confined himself to Bach arias, lieder by Schubert and Wolf and French art songs.

Net income of the Long Island Lighting Company for 1952 amounted to $6,311,930, it was announced yesterday by Errol W. Doebler, president. This represents an increase of 27 per cent above the $4,971,137 cleared in 1951.

Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh wrote yesterday to Mayor Impellitteri outlining his views on the responsibility of city officials to observe traffic regulations and requesting the Mayor to meet with him for discussion if there was disagreement on policy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- President Eisenhower's State of the Union Message marks the official beginning of the new Administration's psychological offensive against the Kremlin and its allies. This is the general interpretation here of the foreign affairs section of his first address before Congress.

ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- Over solid Democratic opposition, the Senate approved tonight a constitutional amendment providing for the election of the Governor and Lieutenant Governor as a team. At present they are elected separately.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- President Eisenhower omitted any reference to the oil-rich submerged coastal lands in his message to Congress today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 2 -- Dr. T. F. Tsiang, Nationalist China's representative in the United Nations, said today that President Eisenhower's statement on "the deneutralization of Formosa" had given "hope and encouragement not only to the people on that island but also to 12,000,000 overseas Chinese and millions and millions of Chinese on the mainland of China."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The President's first message to Congress, which he delivered at the Capitol, was striking for many reasons, but none more so than for its fidelity to the moderate political philosophy he told the voters he would apply to domestic government if he were elected. On Nov. 4, 1952, General Eisenhower was walking down the middle of the road, and that is where he was walking today.

PARIS, Feb. 2 -- President Eisenhower's message to Congress, which will reach the French public in tomorrow morning's newspapers, created an extremely favorable impression among those who had read it tonight, notably French officials, except for the decision to "deneutralize" Formosa.
The methods of the circuit rider, common among jurists and clergymen a century ago, have helped the small business man in this region in the last year.

The Manhattan grand jury investigating waterfront crime has subpoenaed Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., to appear at 2 P. M. today, District Attorney Frank S. Hogan announced last night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Opposition cropped up today in an influential Republican quarter to President Eisenhower's proposal to let price and wage controls die on April 30 without maintaining stand-by machinery to reimpose them if needed.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Feb. 2 -- Ecuador's Foreign Minister, Teodore Alvalado Garaicoa, declared here today that with or without Venezuela's support the states of this region would continue to develop and intensify cooperation for their mutual benefit.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- President Eisenhower appeared to please nearly all the political Center in Congress today by the civil rights, loyalty and immigration policies laid down in his State of the Union Message.
THE HAGUE, Feb. 2 (Reuters) -- Hundreds of persons were reported missing in the once-fertile countryside of Belgium, now a salty morass from the flooding North Sea.

HAVANA, Feb. 2 -- The Bacardi Cup series in the twenty-second international Star class regatta was won today by James Schoonmaker of Nassau when he sailed his Dingo over the finish line in fourth place to gain 57 points for the series.
Sweeping changes in New York Stock Exchange rules and in the laws that govern it have been proposed by a special committee headed by Joseph Klingenstein, a partner in Wertheim Co.

The reaction of business men to President Eisenhower's assurance yesterday that he would not ask Congress for renewal of wage and price controls when they expire April 30 was favorable. Some said they expected no increases in prices as a result of decontrols.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (UP) -- Industrial production reached another postwar peak in January, showing an increase for the seventh successive month, the Federal Reserve Board said today.

BERLIN, Feb. 2 -- The East German Government announced tonight that a new state commission had been formed to supervise the work of the Supply Ministry. Elli Schmidt, head of the German Democratic Women's Federation, was named chief of the new commission and Curt Wach was appointed head of the Supply Ministry.

Louis Marx, toy manufacturer, and Bernard F. Gimbel, president of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., were honored yesterday at an informat ceremony in the suite of Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The Prince, consort of Queen Juliana, bestowed Netherland orders on the two men and expressed thanks to them for their services to his country and to the United States and other lands.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Feb. 3 -- Japan met with mixed reactions today President Dwight D. Eisenhower's State of the Union message to Congress with the order for the withdrawal of the United States Seventh Fleet from Formosan waters and with its repudiation of "secret agreements" leading to enslavement of peoples.

The cannister drive of the Salvation Army, part of the organization's campaign to raise funds, was started yesterday at a rally in Times Square. For the next two weeks volunteers will collect funds throughout the city.

Lully's "Armide," an opera completed in 1686, served as the vehicle for the public introduction last night of a new organization known as "Music for 1953." With this presentation in concert form, the new group lived up to its own description as "a society of young artists for the performance of unusual music.
Cargo and passenger vessels berthed and departed on their own power yesterday in New York, Philadelphia and Norfolk as the three-port strike of tow-boat crews continued without signs of a break.

Americans in Jakarta, Indonesia, are proud of the Way the United States Information Library brings into the homes of the Indonesians, and of many foreigners as well information about America and the American way of life. It circulates free of charge American books, newspapers, journals, magazines.

ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- D. Mallory Stephens, chairman of the Temporary State Commission on Rents and Rental Conditions, declared tonight he favored ending all controls "as soon as we can safely do so without causing chaos."

MIAMI, Feb. 2 -- Jock Whitney and his sister, Mrs. Charles Shipman Payson, win be happy to learn that the top 3-year-old in their Greentree Stable made a triumphant 1953 debut at Hialeah Race Course today.

LONDON, Feb. 2 -- President Eisenhower's address to Congress today terminating the neutralization of Formosa and charting new directions for United States domestic and foreign policy hit this country with a terrific impact.
Fifty to sixty cargo checkers walked off the Royal Netherlands Steamship Company's pier at Thirty-first Street, Brooklyn, early yesterday after a dispute over the appointment of a new dock boss.
SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 2 (AP) -- The Melbourne Conference today decided unanimously to seek international approval for the Melbourne Cricket Ground to be the site for the 1956 Olympic Games.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- A record high number of women in forty-four State Legislatures, 285, was reported today by Bertha S. Adkins, assistant to the chairman of the Republican National Committee.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 2 (UP) -- The Federal suit against the National Football League for "blacking out" professional games went into its second week today with attorneys wrangling over admisability of evidence the Government hopes to use as a foundation for its anti-trust case.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 2 -- Acting to stamp out racketeering in its ranks, the American Federation of Labor made two sharp breaks today with its tradition of noninterference in the internal affairs of its affiliated unions.

SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, Feb. 3 -- North Koreans launched a 650-man attack on the eastern Korean front today, but stout South Korean defenders repulsed the assault and pursued the Communists across the craggy No Man's Land in below-zero cold.

Thirty-eight student waiters representing the dining rooms of twenty-two New York hotels received diplomas yesterday after impeccably (though somewhat nervously) serving an elaborate luncheon to a group of hotel executives at the Waldorf-Astoria.

BREMERHAVEN, Germany, Feb. 2 (AP) -- The German Sea Rescue Society today awarded silver medals to four American seamen who took a seriously injured German sailor aboard the United States transport General William O. Darby in midatlantic in 1951.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2 -- The report over the week-end that President Eisenhower would order the Seventh Fleet to discontinue its "neutralizing" operations against Chinese Nationalist forces on Formosa, inspired considerable early buying of both grain and soybean futures.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Prock Stone was working on the railroad in Missouri one day, trying, with the help of another man, to remove a recalcitrant cross-tie from the roadbed. The pair could not budge the tie. It later was discovered that there was a spike in it.

Dante Brigliante, the diamond dealer who last week-end reported the theft of $100,000 worth of jewels he had left in a subway lockbox, showed little immediate interest yesterday in reclaiming more than half of the loot, which the police found on Sunday.
Following is the text of President Eisenhower's State of the Union Message, delivered to a joint session of Congress yesterday, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

Greenland, whose coastal waters are said to contain the largest supplies of shrimp in the world, is shipping the shellfish here for the first time. Packed by the Royal Greenland Trade Department, a government franchise, these are the tiny shrimp common in Denmark and other Scandinavian countries.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Bobby Shantz signed a two-year contract today to pitch for the Athletics in 1953 and 1954 for a total of more than $50,000.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Feb. 2 -- Both Chinese and United States officials began re-evaluating the implications of Washington's new Formosa policy here today in light of official confirmation that the Eisenhower Administration had decided to "deneutralize" this Nationalist-held island.
Norman Hartnell, dressmaker to Queen Elizabeth II of England arrived yesterday morning by plane from London, where he has just completed his Coronation collection.

PARIS, Feb. 2 -- Outstanding for subtle, semi-fitted lines are the Lanvin-Castillo spring suits with low, square, or rounded necklines framed by small collars. On some of these smart, youthful jackets the waistline is barely indicated by single buttons holding down two rolled box pleats at either side in front or an inverted pleat in back.

The Health Department's "pilot study" of the treatment of tuberculosis with the new anti-tuberculosis drug isoniazid indicates that in a few months a full-scale attack on the disease can be started by the department, Dr. John F. Mahoney, Health Commissioner, told Budget Director Abraham D. Beame yesterday.

Salesmen may be overlooking good bet by not investigating the direct-to-consumer sales field, in the opinion of C. D. Griggs, division manager of the Encyclopaedia Britannica The division takes in the State of New Jersey and New York City, with headquarters at 230 Park Avenue.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Feb. 3 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,514, for Tuesday's action:

Joey Giardello, 155 3/4 pounds, Philadelphia, evened an old score by decisively outpointing Harold Green, 161, Brooklyn, in the ten-round main bout at the Eastern Parkway Arena in Brooklyn before 1,505 fans last night. Green knocked out Giardello in six rounds in their only previous meeting in October, 1950.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The "secret understandings of the past" to which President Eisenhower referred in his State of the Union Message today were taken to mean the results of the three occasions on which Presidents of the United States had met and negotiated directly with Premier Stalin of the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- President Eisenhower's first message on the State of the Union, delivered personally today to a joint session of Congress in the packed House of Representatives chamber, got a rousing reception.

Many foreign nations in recent months apparently have been making greater advances toward stabilizing their economies, domestically and externally, then at any time since World War II, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

EACH year about this time bills, usually of obscure origin, are introduced in the State Legislature which would violate one of the shortest and most emphatic amendments to the Constitution of the United States.

TRENTON, Feb. 2 -- The New Jersey Senate adopted tonight a resolution calling for an investigation into the dismissal of Deputy Attorney General Nelson F. Stamler as Bergen County crime investigator, and the Assembly approved another.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- President Eisenhower in his message today asked that statehood for Hawaii be "granted promptly" by Congress but failed to suggest that similar status be given immediately to Alaska.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The fullest possible return to a "free enterprise" economy in which monetary and fiscal policy would function as "automatic" regulators of economic activity and growth was set forth by President Eisenhower today as a goal of his Administration.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The constitutional guarantee against double jeopardy does not apply when a criminal trial is stopped because prosecution witnesses refuse to testify, then agree to talk at a later trial, the Supreme Court ruled, 6 to 2, today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The Republican leadership of the House of Representatives pledged to President Eisenhower today precisely the reorganization authority he wanted. The pledge came as the House Rules Committee cleared for a floor vote tomorrow legislation continuing existing powers.

FORT DEVENS, Mass., Feb. 2 (AP) -- A New Haven, Conn., doctor left today to take basic infantry training at Camp Pickett, Va., as an Army private because he refused to list the organizations to which he belonged. He is Pvt. Charles A. Nugent, a Yale Medical School graduate, who had been a staff physician at the New Haven Hospital.

Dispensing with scenery and other stage paraphernalia to reduce costs, the Equity Community Theatre, jointly sponsored by the Bureau of Community Education and Actors Equity, soon will put on revivals of "Ah, Wilderness!" "Man and Superman," "Finian's Rainbow" and 'Mamba's Daughters" in high school centers.

The aggregate market value of bonds on the New York Stock Exchange fell $295,204,882 in December and the average market value declined from $98.19 on Nov. 30 to $96.86 on Dec. 31, a loss of $1.33 for each $100 of par value, the Exchange reported yesterday. The average is the lowest month-end figure since $96.70 on Dec. 31, 1942.

Efforts to settle a strike that has interfered with the delivery of metropolitan newspapers in suburban areas failed again yesterday after an arbitration session between the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union and the Publishers Association of New York City was adjourned without a decision.
The nation's basketball experts again voted Coach Honey Russell's Seton Hall team into the No. 1 spot in the weekly college rankings yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- President Eisenhower, the new Commander in Chief, gave the armed forces a broad hint today that their rivalries and feuds must end. He said there was no place for tradition or habit in formation of the nation's military force.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Feb. 2 -- Sagamore Hill, one time summer White House and home of President Theodore Roosevelt, which has been undergoing complete redecorating and renovation for three years, will get back .Wednesday the furniture and contents that were removed after the death of Mrs. Edith Kermit Roosevelt, widow of the President.

The trial of Minot Frazier (Mickey) Jelke 3d, 22-year-old heir to an oleomargarine fortune, who is charged in a nine-count indictment with compulsory prostitution and living off the proceeds of vice, began yesterday in General Sessions.

The statement in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Jan. 29 concerning the future control .program of tuberculosis, attributed to a letter from Dr. Marcus D. Kogel, Commissioner of Hospitals, to Mayor Impellitteri contains aspects with which I agree and aspects with which I disagree.

Thirteen secondary Communist leaders got the chance yesterday to go to Russia as an alternative to going to prison for criminal conspiracy to teach and advocate the overthrow of the United States Government by force and violence. The offer was made by Federal Judge Edward J. Dimock.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 2 -- Capt. H. T. Hallman, in fear of more violence among his restive crew, radioed a request to the Coast Guard today to place an armed guard aboard his ship, the freighter Fairhope, aground in the San Benito Islands, off Lower California.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Importing countries can now buy their full quotas under the International Wheat Agreement, it was announced today.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Feb. 3 -- Sabre jets of the United States Fifth Air Force shot down two Soviet-designed MIG jet fighters over northwest Korea yesterday, probably destroyed another and I damaged two more while fighter-bombers I and high-velocity tank-mounted guns hammered at the enemy-entrenched line across the peninsula.

A need to clarify understanding of the terms "dollar gap" and "trade gap" as used in consideration of United States foreign economic and tariff programs was pointed up in an analysis issued yesterday by the American Tariff League.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- General of the Army Omar N. Bradley, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff and thus the highest active ranking United States military leader, said tonight that President Eisenhower's new policy on Formosa did not increase United States chances in becoming involved in a "big war" in the Far East.

I've been an admirer of President Eisenhower right along. I've liked his naturalness, his simplicity, his humaneness; I've liked such little things as his rejection of the topper and his non-compliance with the standards, but silly, practice of being photographed in a writing posture -- a pet pose for the press (to prove literacy?).

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The Supreme Court ruled today that an unfair labor practice charge filed by a union was valid even though officers of the federation it was affiliated with had not taken the non-Communist oaths under the Taft-Hartley Act at the time the charge was filed.

Asa Bushnell, head of the National Invitation tournament committee, announced yesterday that the event again would be a 12- team affair. Speaking at the basketball writers luncheon at Leone's, Bushnell said the field's size would follow the 1952 pattern with two triple headers and three twin bills.

SOME people commit murder for pay in the ordinary course of their occupation. We have been reading about them in the papers for months now as the investigation of racketeering on the New York docks drags along. According to an article by Virgil W. Peterson in the February Atlantic Monthly, most murderers are never even inconvenienced by an arrest, let alone a conviction.
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 2 (AP) -- The threat of possible contempt action against Fred M. Saigh, the troubled owner of the Cardinals, was removed today by United States District Attorney George L. Robertson

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (UP) -- The American Telephone and Telegraph Company contended today that it was "not necessary" for the Federal Communications Commission to reserve special radio channels for theatre television.
Prices of cotton futures yesterday closed 10 points lower to 2 points higher than on last Friday, with a fairly heavy volume of business on the New York Cotton Exchange.

BERLIN, Feb. 2 -- So many refugees pressed into West Berlin's reception center today that the building bulged. When the doors closed late in the evening 2,600 had been registered in a day -- a new record.
Two armed thugs held up the Birdland Theatre Restaurant, 1678 Broadway, at Fifty-third Street, at 11 A. M. yesterday and escaped with $5,000. A thirteen-state alarm has been broadcast for them.

Groundhogs had their day in the sun yesterday, but the marmot forecasters emerged from their winter quarters with confusing reports, which could mean anything, and which the Weather Bureau stuffily insisted meant nothing.

The British Government is once again negotiating trade with Communist China. This time of nonessential war materials. To this observer this seems utterly incongruous -- for, any commodity, no matter how far removed from the front lines in Korea, is nevertheless for the betterment of the country, in one degree or another.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The Federal Trade Commission's contention that long-term exclusive contracts to exhibit advertising films in motion-picture theatres restricted competition was upheld by the Supreme Court today.

Officials of British, Greek and Scandinavian seamen's unions will meet here today to discuss alleged hardships visited upon their members by application of the McCarran-Walter Immigration Act. They will talk over their problems to Willi Dorchain, American representative of the International Transportworkers Federation, with which the unions are affiliated, at 1 P. M. at the Nordic Seamen's Center, 165 Montague Street, Brooklyn.

ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- The Senate passed tonight by a strictly party vote of 37 to 19 a bill revising the registration fees for motor vehicles and eliminating an exemption which has permitted 50 per cent of the trucks in the state to escape the weight-distance tax.
New film offerings will arrive in two first-run theatres this morning.

This year, for the first time since 1946, the major institutional investors will probably become small buyers of Government securities, on balance, according to a study issued today by Bankers Trust Company. The study, "Investment Funds -- Supply and Demand," was prepared under the direction of Dr. Roy L. Reierson, vice president.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 2 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, as well as Twentieth Century-Fox, is seeking to arrive at a uniform system of three-dimensional production and exhibition, Nicholas M. Schenck, president of Loew's, Inc., announced tonight.

ACCORDING to Greek legend, Apollo gave the gift of prophecy to Cassandra as a token of his love for her. Then in a lovers' quarrel he ordained that no one ever should believe what she said. So the poor gal kept calling the turn with uncanny preciseness and none paid her heed.
Following are excerpts from editorials in the nation's newspapers on President Eisenhower's State of the Union Message yesterday as gathered by The Associated Press and THE NEW YORK TIMES:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- The Defense Production Administration today announced that Canada will ship to this country this month and next an additional 44,000,000 pounds of aluminum originally destined for England.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Feb. 2 -- A four-engine British troop transport plane with thirty-nine persons aboard was believed to have crashed in the icy, gale-whipped North Atlantic today. Strong winds and torrential rains restricted search operations and little hope was held for rescue.
