Television Station WNBT is planning to resume on Feb. 14 "It's A Problem," the panel discussion program devoted to family relations and child psychology. The program would be limited to Saturday afternoon presentations only, rather than the old schedule of Monday through Friday mornings.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today granted new financing authority to Electric Energy, Inc., which is building a power plant for the atomic energy plant at Paducah. Ky.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The Supreme Court ruled today that efforts of the State of Georgia to collect certain state, county and municipal taxes from the Georgia Railroad and Banking Company impaired the charter granted the company in 1833 and violated the United States Constitution.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Feb. 2 -- At a double meeting this afternoon, its first, the Westchester County Board of Supervisors approved by 25 to 4 proposed state legislation that would permit the county to give 1,100-acre Mohansic Park at Yorktown to the state for development into a comprehensive park of multiple golf courses, swimming pools, ball fields and picnicking facilities.

LONDON, Tuesday, Feb. 3 -- As the gales abated and the raging waters of the North Sea began to recede, three nations counted their dead today and assessed the damage resulting from their worst flood disaster in recent history.

A biographical study of Abraham Lincoln's mother, a woman who has been comparatively overlooked in literature, will be issued later this month by Bookman Associates, entitled "Nancy Hanks Lincoln: A Frontier Portrait." The authors, Ernestine and Harold Briggs, have reconstructed from the available records the life and times of Mrs. Lincoln, and they describe the unusual and decisive role she played in the formation of her son's character.

The freight business of the New York Central System this year should approximate that of 1952 with the exception of coal, which is running below last year's rate, William White, president, said yesterday. He Said that the decline in the system's passenger business is continuing.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- President Eisenhower's State of the Union Message today appeared to have gone far to restore any prestige he might have lost by the rough spots encountered in his first days in office.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Britain has made representations to the United States about President Eisenhower's decision to allow the Chinese Nationalists to raid the China mainland.

MOSCOW, Feb. 2 -- The Kiev newspaper Ukrainian Pravda charged today that United States "bosses" had organized repeated attempts on the life of Jacques Duclos, French Communist leader, and other foreign Communist chiefs, including Maurice Thorez, Palmiro Togliatti, "the Government tribune in China" and Kyuichi Tokuda, the Japanese Communist chief.

ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- The Board of Trustees of the State University today declared that a downward revision in tuition and other fees at the state institutions was needed to broaden the educational opportunities for qualified students irrespective of their economic status.

A two-story apartment house on the north side of Locust Avenue, 100 feet west of High Street, in Baxter Estates, L. I., has been purchased by Richard R. and Ernest J. Thompson from Helen Marie Hehn. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company. The property occupies an irregular plot about 50 by 217 feet.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Feb. 3 -- The fourth annual award in this city for outstanding achievement in promoting human relations was given today to Edward P. Dowdall, deputy chief of police, head of the detective bureau and a member of the Police Department for twenty- eight years.

Joseph P. Kelly, Bronx business man and foreman of the 1951 Federal grand jury that investigated the employment of subversives in the United Nations, urged yesterday the "changing or strengthening" of present laws so "we will not have interference with Federal grand juries."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- While President Eisenhower gave a "social" luncheon today for eighteen Republican leaders of the Senate, the Senate Democratic Policy Committee met and pledged cooperation with the President in the development of foreign policy on a bipartisan basis.

A smiling little Queens boy with a lump in his throat and the cold muzzle of an 11-week-old puppy in his hand expressed his thanks as best he could yesterday at Madison Square Garden to a woman who had just given him the dog as a mascot for his Cub Scout pack.

The proposed amendment to the New York State Constitution that would provide for election of the Governor and Lieutenant Governor as a team, with votes for them cast jointly, seems to us after a review of opposing arguments to be a net improvement. Such an amendment was defeated in referendum in 1945.

One-man shows of painting and sculpture outnumber group exhibitions among the art attractions in galleries this week. Two of these are of small sculptures, the work of Frank Eliscu at the Wellons Gallery being primarily in traditional vein, while that by Herbert Kallem at the Davis Gallery is essentially in modern idiom.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 3 -- One of the most serious consequences of the flight of thousands of refugees from East Germany and the purging of the Government is expected to be an acceleration of the Soviet plans to establish a loyal, well-armed and militant Communist "people's democracy" there.

MINEOLA, L. I., Feb. 3 -- Nassau County Executive A. Holly Patterson turned down today a request by the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., that he order Bee Line Bus Company officials to submit a contract dispute to arbitration.

Taylor Wine Co, in the Empire State Building, 350 5th Ave; Royer Roger, Inc, advertising and publishing, in 133 E 39th St; American Committee for the Evangelization of the Greeks, in 156 5th Ave -- Cushman Wakefield, Inc. brokers.

Readers of The New York Times who experience difficulty getting their copies in the suburbs during the strike of newspaper deliverymen against suburban wholesalers may obtain The Times by mail subscription.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Feb. 3 -Premier Nguyen Van Tam said today that Vietnam would maintain strict neutrality in the event that the deneutralizing of Formosa brought about a renewal of civil war between the Chinese Communists and the Chinese Nationalists.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The State Department has instructed John Carter Vincent, who has been under fire in a loyalty case, to remain at Tangier, where he has been serving as this country's diplomatic agent and consul general, "subject to call."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (UP) -- The Senate Agriculture Committee today approved President Eisenhower's selection of five new board members of the Commodity Credit Corporation, multi - million - dollar farm agency that handles the Government's farm price support program.

Officials of the Electric Bond and Share Company, once one of the nation's largest public utility holding companies, are planning to make the changes requested recently by the Securities and Exchange Commission in acting on the company's plan for compliance with the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

New issues of corporate securities valued at more than $67,000,000 will be offered to investors today. Included are mortgage bonds, preferred stock and common stock to help finance expansion of public utility companies, convertible debentures of a finance company, convertible preferred stock of a chemical manufacturing enterprise, and serial trust certificates to help an eastern railroad finance the purchase of new equipment.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Dwight E. Avis, Director of the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax Division of the Bureau of Internal Revenue, testified today that politics had interfered substantially with the administration of Federal liquor tax laws.

Retailers must work together to meet the competition of supermarkets selling men's apparel, Isidore S. Immerman, counsel and executive director of the Associated Men's Wear Retailers of New York, Inc., said yesterday. He spoke at the annual convention of the Virginia Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers at the Chamberlin Hotel, Old Point Comfort, Va.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The names of the nine senators who are expected to conduct the chief Senate investigations of Communists and subversives were announced today by Senator William Langer, Republican of North Dakota, chairman of the Judiciary Committee.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Gen. J. Lawton Collins, Army Chief of Staff, told the House Armed Services Committee today that Operation Smack was an ordinary infantry raid and one of a series authorized by the I Corps' commander to test enemy strength and intentions in a sector of the Korean front that appeared threatened.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (UP) -Secretary of Agriculture Ezra T. Benson appealed to livestock growers today to help stabilize cattle prices by holding their animals off the market until they reach their best weight.

BOMBAY, India, Feb, 3 (AP) -- Arthur Hays Sulzberger, publisher of THE NEW YORK TIMES, said at a news conference today that he was puzzled by India's neutrality in the conflict between communism and the West. He expressed hope that his visit to India would throw light on the reasons for India's stand.

G. H. Mangravite of Twin Trees Gardens said there was no doubt chives imparted deliciousness to steak Diane, but did we realize how hard they were to find in food stores much of the time? The president of the herb company had read the recipes for the steak dish that, given by three eating establishments in the city, had appeared in the Sunday Magazine of THE NEW YORK TIMES ten days ago.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Feb. 3 -- Rutgers' basketball team broke the century mark for the first time tonight, defeating Johns Hopkins, 102 -- 95, as three court records were set.
With reference to your editorial of Jan. 28 dealing with Mr. Dulles' policy, I am more than pleased with his honest and straightforward presentation of the foreign situation.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Feb. 4 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,515 for Wednesday's action:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Some leading critics of the public schools were named today in a report, "Forces Affecting American Education," issued by a division of the National Education Association.

In one of the grim coincidences of fate the furious waters of the unpredictable North Sea have broken the dikes of Holland on the same day that New York City celebrated the 300th anniversary of its founding by the Dutch. England and the Lowlands are lashed by waves defying description, but Holland appears most severely hit by far.

Unfavorable international trade conditions -- chiefly currency - exchange restrictions and other barriers to goods, plus prospective reduction of dollar earnings abroad -- presage decline of United States export-import business this year, but remedial action is confidently expected from the Eisenhower Administration.
A policeman's blue ranked second yesterday to the forest-green of the Marine Corps in the eyes of two children whose parents both belong to the city's uniformed force.
We commend the A. F. L.'s Executive Council for its prompt and forthright action yesterday in taking the first important step toward eliminating racketeering from its affiliates.

The hearings before the Federal Power Commission in Washington on the St. Lawrence River hydroelectric project ended yesterday. The Commission is studying applications for a license to carry out the American side of this vast plan, which is to cost some $450,000,000 and provide New York alone with 6,000,000,000 kilowatt-hours of electricity a year.
Bette Davis will not appear on the Arthur Murray television program Sunday evening, as had been announced recently. She was to have been paid $10,000 to do an eight-minute sketch.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The Eisenhower Administration placed sharp restrictions on the spending authority of all departments and agencies today in its first official move toward the goal of a balanced budget.

The opening lecture in a seminar on "Women in Today's World" will be held at 8:30 o'clock tonight at the headquarters of the auxiliary council to the Association for the Advancement of Psychoanalysis, 220 West Ninety-eighth Street.

Milton Klein, warden of Queens City Prison, who charged last November before the State Crime Commission that bookmaker Frank Erickson had received special privileges at Rikers Island Penitentiary on orders of Correction Commissioner Albert O. Williams, will be transferred today to the old Raymond Street Jail in Brooklyn.

The forty-six-family apartment house at 3195 Decatur Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by Walter L. Rothschild to a client of Alfred Lipschitz, broker, for cash above mortgages of $136,000. The property is assessed at $150,000.

CHICAGO, Feb. 3 -- Selling by discouraged longs with considerable local pressure forced prices for all wheat and corn deliveries to new lows on the crop today, but the declines ran into rather impressive support with late rallies registering substantial recoveries from the low spots of the session.

The decorative uses of ceramics, a form of art that seems to be undergoing a twentieth century "renaissance," are demonstrated in a group of eight room settings that form part of the fifty-ninth annual exhibition of the New York Society of Ceramic Arts at the American Museum of Natural History. The show, which opens today, will continue through Feb. 23.

President Eisenhower began his first State of the Union message with a clear announcement of the foreign policy of the new Administration. The key to this policy is to be found in one pregnant statement. "We have learned that the free world cannot remain in a posture of paralyzed tension," he said.

IT takes more than a lot of ducks to make a successful waterfowl season, as the majority of the wildfowlers can testify after reflecting on the past season, but B. W. Cartwright, chief naturalist of Ducks Unlimited, has prepared an interesting analysis of the factors which brought about the disappointing hunting of last fall.

Although its tax bill was 124 per cent greater, net income of the Consolidated Vultee Aircraft Corporation for the fiscal year ended last Nov. 30 rose to $10,426,476 from $7,750,524 in the previous year, Floyd B. Odlum, board chairman, reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The executive committee of B'nai B'rith, oldest Jewish service organization in the United States, has adopted a resolution condemning the recent trials of Jews behind the Iron Curtain and the implied anti-Semitism of the action as a "complete negation of human rights and fundamental freedoms."
HOBOKEN, N. J., Feb. 3 -- Full administrative powers were restored today to City Commissioners John J. Grogan and Edward J. Barrone by a unanimous vote of the five-man city commission.

John J. McCloy, chairman of the board of the Chase National Bank and former United States High Commissioner in Germany, opened the 1953 Brooklyn Red Cross Fund Drive at a luncheon yesterday at the St. George Hotel.

Six five-story apartment buildings occupying a plot 150 by 100 feet at 435-45 West Fifty-seventh Street, between Ninth and Tenth Avenues were sold by the 435-45 West Fifty-seventh Street Corporation to a syndicate of investors organized and represented by Joshuah Sidney Shultz, attorney.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 3 -- Togo Palazzi, six-foot four-inch forward from Union City, N. J., tallied 25 points tonight to lead Holy Cross to a 59-52 basketball triumph over Yale.

Charles D. Halsey and Robert L. Raclin have been admitted as general partners of Bache Co., while Harold C. Price and Marvin J. Silberman have become limited partners. Mr. Raclin will be in the Chicago office and the other three here.

The marriage of Miss Phyllis Nahl to John de Cuevas, son of Mr. and Mrs. George de Cuevas, the Marquis and Marquessa de Piedrablanca de Guana, of 54 East Sixty-eighth Street, took place yesterday morning in the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church. The minister, the Rev. Dr. George Buttrick, performed the ceremony. The couple was unattended.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 3 -- Leopold Stokowski interrupted a symphony concert here tonight and refused to continue the program until a Dixieland band in an adjoining ballroom stopped playing.

BERLIN, Feb. 3 -- Dr. G. J. Van Heuven Goedhart, United Nations Commissioner for Refugees, has appealed to all members of the United Nations and several other countries for aid to the West German Government in housing the refugees pouring out of East Germany.

ALBANY, Feb. 3 -- Landlord and tenant spokesmen debated the need for relaxing or strengthening state rent controls for more than five hours this afternoon at a noisy hearing before the Temporary Commission on Rents and Rental Conditions.

PARIS, Feb. 3 -- John Foster Dulles, United States Secretary of State, told leaders of the European Marshall Plan Council today that the United States would make no commitments to the British in the economic or monetary field without consulting the council and the Managing Board of the European Payments Union.

In your editorial "Mr. Dulles Shapes His Policy," you state: "He makes plain * * * that the pledge of aid in the liberation of the enslaved nations, which aroused so much apprehension at one time, does not involve a threat of war."

A letter by John David Provoo, former Army sergeant on trial for treason, which he wrote to his mother confessing his guilt, was introduced yesterday in Federal Court as the Government ended four days of cross-examination.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Feb. 3 -- An airlift of 150 planes and a bridge of 2,000 vessels worked desperately today and into the night to evacuate more than 50,000 flood survivors from the Zeeland and South Holland Islands and to supply 250,000 others.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 3 (UP) -- Bugle, dead last on the turn, got up to win the $5,000 Old English Rancho Purse at Santa Anita today by a head, surviving an inquiry to gain the victory.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Feb. 3 -- Colombia's Committee on Constitutional Studies was reported today to have put aside a proposed anti-Communist provision without discussing it. One more meeting is expected before completion of the draft but it was...

Rear Admiral J. M. Will, commander of the Military Sea Transport Service, Atlantic Area, joined with 302 officers and enlisted men of the Navy's baby flattop Tripoli, in donating blood yesterday to the American Red Cross.

The Philadelphia Orchestra drew its largest house of the season last night when it paid its sixth visit to this city. The lure that filled every seat of Carnegie Hall was an all-Brahms program, with Zino Francescatti as the soloist in the Violin Concerto.

The one-story industrial building at 136 Hawthorne Avenue in Hawthorne, N. J., has been leased by the Central Engraving Company of Paterson with an option to buy. The building is owned by Rudolf Spieker, who occupied it for his weaving business before he retired.

LINDEN, N. J., Feb. 3 -- The Board of Education here today adopted its 1953-54 budget, including funds for a $600 across-the-board increase for teachers and all other employes of the school system. The raise was larger than they had asked.

ALBANY, Feb. 3 -- The Assembly postponed action today on a bill revising registration fees for trucks and the trucking weight-distance tax after a public Democratic protest and expressions of Republican reluctance behind the scenes.

WEEHAWKEN, N. J., Feb. 3 -- A derailed freight car that blocked three of the four main tracks of the West Shore Railroad at the east end of the Weehawken-North Bergen tunnel here this morning crossed up the "eager beavers" on sixteen commuter trains from Bergen and Rockland Counties.

A survey to determine why 44 per cent of high school students in the state drop out before completing their studies shows that the two leading factors are retardation and low intelligence. These causes were reported by 77 per cent of the 487 high school principals canvassed.

LONDON, Feb 3 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden told the House of Commons today that the British Government had been informed in advance of President Eisenhower's decision to give Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's Nationalist troops on Formosa freedom to make forays on the coast of Communist China and had at once told the United States Government that in its view the new policy would have "very unfortunate political repercussions without compensating military advantages."

Theodore D. Parsons, Attorney General of New Jersey, moved yesterday to take Joe Adonis, convicted gambler, from State Prison in Trenton to the Bergen County grand jury in Hackensack to tell all he knew about gambling in that county.

Thirteen secondary Communist leaders who rejected a court offer to go to Russia rather than to prison received jail sentences yesterday ranging from a year and a day to three years and fines totaling $64,000 for conspiracy to teach and advocate the overthrow of the Government by force and violence.
The signing of ten more players was announced by the three local major league clubs yesterday. The Yankees listed the more important man in Ray Scarborough, 35-year-old right-handed pitcher.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Louis H. Bean, former economic adviser to the Secretary of Agriculture and an employe in the department for the last thirty years, has been relieved of his official duties.

The selection of a General Sessions Court jury to try Minot Frazier (Mickey) Jelke 3d on vice charges continued through its second day yesterday and added only six male jurors to the three chosen in the opening session.
CLEVELAND, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Bob Feller, once one of the highest-paid pitchers in baseball, signed his fifteenth contract with the Indians today with what was believed to be a $10,000 pay cut.

Why cigarette companies continue to stress the "health" theme in their advertising when it gets them into so much trouble with the Federal Trade Commission and induces so much criticism on the part of the public, is a puzzle to the layman.

A full-scale stoppage of harbor activity in the Port of New York -- effective tomorrow -- was threatened last night when the International Longshoremen's Association voted complete support of the four-day walkout of tugboat operators.

If the infant death rate now was the same as that in 1900, only 772 children of each thousand born would live to be 20 years old, Miss Katherine F. Lenroot, former chief of the United States Children's Bureau, said yesterday. But now, she said, 950 infants in a thousand may be expected to survive to the age of 20.
Ronald Browning's complaint that postal service is slow is unjustified. The dates he quotes from Dec. 19 to Jan. 3 include the holiday season, when millions of pieces of mail are handled.

PARIS, Feb. 3 -- Jacques Fath introduces what he terms "the plunging line" in a collection of elegance and subtle cut. Bodices molding the natural figure plunge down onto the back of skirts. Jacket, redingote and dress necklines plunge extremely low.
With the blessing of the Netherlands' Embassy in Washington, a program of that country's contemporary music was presented last night at Carnegie Recital Hall.

BOMBAY, India, Feb 3 -- India's leading newspapers, whose editorials often are written with Government policy in mind when dealing with international affairs, commented in blunt and vigorous language today on President Eisenhower's State of the Union address as it applied to foreign policy -- particularly the decision to free Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's forces on Formosa to raid the Chinese mainland.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 3 -- Three cars of a freight train traveling from Haifa to Lydda were derailed last night by explosive charges placed on the tracks by Arab infiltrators, the Israeli army announced today. The incident took place about one mile north of the Israeli kibbutz of Nir Eliahu, at a point where the railway tracks run within a few hundred yards of the Jordan border.

MANILA, Feb. 3 -- The Philippine Supreme Court by a unanimous decision Monday ruled out President Elpidio Quirino's use of wartime emergency powers to appropriate funds unauthorized by Congress. The decision put an end to a bitter seven-year dispute between
ALBANY, Feb. 3 -- The Joint Legislative Committee on Housing and Multiple Dwellings voted unanimously today to make plans for investigation of slum conditions in New York City.

" All the fountains of the great deep burst forth, and the windows of the heavens were opened." The angry waters rose out of the North Sea and from Lincolnshire to Kent and along the sunken coast of Holland beat with giant force against the narrowing borders that lead to the Strait of Dover.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 3 -- A dozen United States citizens resigned today from the United the employe association's stand on current loyalty checks of Americans working at the world organization.

Indictments charging violations of the gambling laws and other public statutes may be voted soon against a score of Staten Island bookmakers, policemen and others involved with them by the special grand jury that has been investigating crime and official corruption on the island.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Estimates that the United .States Treasury was being milked of $60,000,000 to $70,000,000 a year -- and sometimes perhaps $100,000,000 -- by making Social Security and other benefit payments to persons not eligible for such aid, were made before a Senate investigating group today.

After drifting lower in the early dealings, stock prices developed strength yesterday, with final quotations mixed. Many leading issues held virtually unchanged and gains and losses were mostly in fractions.

PARIS, Feb. 3 -- By a vote of 407 to 205 the French National Assembly today decided to postpone the debate on reprisals by French immigration authorities for the treatment of French sailors visiting the United States under the provisions of the McCarran-Walter Immigration Act.

LONDON, Feb. 3 -- In an optimistic review of Britain's economic position. R. A. Butler, Chancellor of the Exchequer, announced in the House of Commons tonight that gold and dollar reserves of the sterling area increased by $132,000,000 during the last month and stood at $1,978,000,0,00 on Jan. 31.
LONDON, Feb. 3 -- Britain began today the long and heavy task of restoring her sea-ravaged towns and fields to orderly productivity.

The fifteen-story and penthouse apartment building for sixty-three families on plot 52 by 100 feet at 33 Fifth Avenue, southeast corner of Tenth Street, has been sold by the Salmos Realty Corporation to an investing client of Leon Rothberg, attorney, it was announced yesterday.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Feb. 3 -- Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan's policy of apartheid (segregation) is bringing on a crisis in the Union of South Africa's vast gold and uranium mining industry, two authorities on native affairs and economics warned the Government in Parliament last night and today.
MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 3 -- Following is the text of a statement issued today by the American Federation of Labor on the situation in the International Longshoremen's Association:

Subway delays ranging from thirty-five to forty-eight minutes occurred at three different points on the city's transit system yesterday morning as the result of a collision and the finding of two persons dead on subway tracks.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Charles W. Crawford, Food and Drug Administrator, has expressed the hope that Congress speedily would pass a law firmly establishing the inspection power of the Food and Drug Administration, as recommended by President Eisenhower in his State of the Union Message yesterday.

A trailer-truck loaded with 2,542 cases of radio and television tubes, with a retail value of $400,000, was hijacked yesterday morning by two or three men, who kidnapped the driver and took him to a remote spot in Queens in a smaller car.

To fill two exceedingly important posts in his new Administration President Eisenhower has nominated two exceedingly good men. One of them is Dr. James Bryant Conant, retiring president of Harvard University, to be High Commissioner to Germany. The other is Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, former director of the Central Intelligence Agency, to be Under Secretary of State.

Today's new film is "The Stooge," the latest Paramount comedy starring the team of Dean Martin and Jerry Lewis, at the Paramount. The Hal Wallis production was directed by Norman Taurog, from a screen play by Fred F. Finklehoffe and Martin Rackin and a story by Sid Silvers and Mr. Finklehoffe. Polly Bergen, Marion Marshall, Eddie Mayehoff, Richard Erdman and Frances Bavier are featured.

Jack Resnick, operator, who recently bought the taxpayer at 393-99 East 200th Street, the northwest corner of 200th Street and Bedford Park Boulevard, the Bronx, has resold it to Mrs. Rose F. Golden. The property was held at $90,000. John J. Reynolds, Inc., broker, negotiated the sale.

CAMP DRUM, N. Y., Feb. 3 -- As the temperature dropped to zero here tonight, near the junction of the St. Lawrence River and Lake Ontario, men of the Eighty-second Airborne Division dug into a fresh fall of six inches of snow to spend another training night in the open.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 4 -- Medical science is on the verge of its conquest of influenza, the executive board of the United Nations World Health Organization, in session in Geneva, announced today.

The Women's Center of the National Council of Women of the United States, Inc., which includes twenty-one organizations promoting better conditions for women and world peace, will move to the new building of the Carnegie Foundation for International Peace at Forty-sixth Street and First Avenue in the spring.

Two of the city's top commissioners sounded warnings yesterday of serious deterioration of their departments -- with resulting progressively inferior service, if not actual danger, to the public -if they were compelled to keep their 1953-54 budgets down near 1952-53 levels as directed by Mayor Impellitteri.

Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation announced yesterday plans to sell $200,000,000 of long-term debentures in the public market. The securities are to be marketed by underwriters headed by Morgan Stanley Co.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The White House today announced the appointment of three special assistants to help out in President Eisenhower's dealings with Congress and Federal agencies.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Legislation to establish a Small Business Administration as a permanent part of the Government was urged today by John E. Horne, retiring head of the Small Defense Plants Administration.

A spring collection of brides' dresses, shown to the press yesterday in Gimbels bridal salon, was enhanced by the introduction of a group of headdresses imported from Paris exclusively for this store. Inspired by coifs of Tudor times and from portraits of Queen Marguerite de Navarre and Queen Mary Stuart, fashion leaders of their day, the headpieces display exquisite handwork.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The House of Representatives respected the wishes of President Eisenhower today in granting him the same reorganization powers for the next two years that President Truman had had since 1949.

HAVANA, Feb. 3 -- Dingo, sailed by James Schoonmaker of Nassau, was first across the finish line today in the opening race of the Cuba Cup series in the twenty second international Star Class regatta. Dingo, timed in 1 hour 32 minutes 48 seconds, gained 8 points.

ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, French West Africa, Feb. 3 -- An interesting constitutional question is posed in the case of Senator Victor Biaka-Boda, who disappeared in the jungle here three years ago and may have been eaten by his constituents.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 3 (UP) -- Robert Pierce, manager of a Cleveland radio station, testified today that despite repeated appeals he had been denied permission to broadcast a professional football game.

The city's expanded parking meter program will go into effect today when the first of 13,000 new meters will be installed in the Jamaica area of Queens. There will be 610 of the devices in that section, most of which collect a dime-an-hour fee. A few in fringe areas will permit two hours' parking for 10 cents.

The biggest buyer for the Air Force is retiring. It was announced here yesterday that Maj. Gen. Arthur Thomas. commanding the Eastern Air Procurement District of the Air Materiel Command with $3.200,000,000 in orders under his administration in the territory between Fairfield County, Conn., and the South Carolina border. the major portion in the New York metropolitan area, will go on the retired list Feb. 28.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, the Senate Majority Leader, forecast quick Congressional approval today of President Eisenhower's bid to repudiate any secret agreements made in the past with Russia. The Senator said he wholeheartedly endorsed the proposal.

HARTFORD, Feb. 3 -- Gov. John Davis Lodge predicted today that Connecticut's general fund budget for the two-year period to begin July 1 would total at least $252,600,000, while anticipated revenues came to only $214,200,000.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Official Navy spokesmen said today, that no new instructions had reached Navy chiefs from the White House on a change in the Seventh Fleet's patrol operations in the Strait of Formosa.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Mrs. Leon Keyserling, cleared by the Commerce Department's Loyalty Appeals Board early in Janu ary, resigned her $10,500 job Jan. 19. Department officials would not comment.

Trading was generally light yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges and prices closed irregularly. Sugar and potatoes were moderately active and coffee had its most active day of the year, Coffee, hides, cocoa and tin closed higher, and potatoes, sugar and wool were mixed. Lead, rubber, zinc, soybean oil and cottonseed oil ended lower.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The Controller General's office reported today it had decided that the retirement disability payments made to Senator William E. Jenner, Republican of Indiana, by the Air Force were illegal.

NEWBURGH, N. Y., Feb. 3 -- A Newburgh girl was killed and two of her college classmates were injured today when their car skidded on a snow-covered highway ten miles south of this city and crashed head-on into another vehicle.

LONDON, Feb. 3 -- The stock markets started business today with some uncertainty following news of President Eisenhower's order to the Seventh Fleet but later shook off the dullness and made small gains in many sections.
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were firmer yesterday and closing prices were 3 to 23 points net higher than on Monday, with new crop months showing the greatest strength.

James B. E. Olson, former district supervisor of the Alcohol Tax Unit of the Bureau of Internal Revenue, was indicted yesterday by a Brooklyn federal grand jury on a charge of "fraudulently and willfully" evading the payment of $22,179 in income taxes for the years 1946 through 1950. The indictment charged also that Olson had concealed additional income of $50,498 in the five-year period.

ALBANY, Feb. 3 -- The State Senate approved unanimously the administration bill reorganizing the State Civil Service Department today to vest administrative powers in a single administrator instead of the present three-member bipartisan commission.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Feb. 3 -- Stanley La Benskey of Yonkers, a former Westchester parkway patrolman, was placed on trial in county court here today on Sullivan Law charges and Henry A. Wallace, former vice president, almost became juror No. 12.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 3--Negotiations that may lead to an offer by the Crown Zellerbach Corporation to take over holdings of the Canadian Western Lumber Company, Ltd, through a multi-million dollar exchange of stock are under way, it was made known today.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 3 -- Seven major power companies in Pennsylvania, New Jersey and Delaware have contracted for the construction of a $400,000 alternating current network analyzer in the Industrial Research Laboratories of the Franklin Institute, it was announced today.

One of the most potentially important declarations made by President Eisenhower in his State of the Union message was his announcement that he will ask Congress to join in a resolution formally repudiating any kind of commitment contained in secret understandings of the past which permit the enslavement of other nations.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The Defense Production Administration announced today approval of Federal tax benefits to assist 230 defense plant expansion projects costing $286,029,425.

Negotiations were completed here yesterday for the return heavyweight championship bout between Rocky Marciano; unbeaten titleholder from Brockton, Mass., and Jersey Joe Walcott, thirty-nine-year-old former champion from Camden, N. J.

MOSCOW, Feb. 3 -- Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky, speaking, in his capacity as law academician, has excoriated leaders of Soviet law for their "serious mistakes" and their failure to cope effectively with what he called the "bourgeois pseudoscience" of law.

George S. Counts writes in his letter published Jan. 27 that the responsible defender of civil liberties should be careful of the company he keeps, and that joining with Communists or pro-Communists to defend civil liberties is like joining with known gangsters to attack indiscriminate wiretapping. Well, I, for one, see nothing wrong with saying my full say about indiscriminate wiretapping on the same platform or in the same forum with know gangsters.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Feb. 3 -- President Chiang Kai-shek hailed the "deneutralization" of Formosa today in a statement that reiterated the determination of his Chinese Nationalist Government to fight for the recovery of the Communist-ruled China mainland.
" Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci" had their second performances of the season last evening at the Metropolitan, with a number of new faces in the casts.

A news story headed "Big Leftist, Gains in Guatemala" was buried in the shipping news on page 47 of the Jan. 21 issue of THE TIMES. The story reported that Communist-dominated parties had won twenty-eight of thirty-two parliamentary seats. Last year, when Stalinist infiltration of the Guatemala Government still was in an embryonic stage, two United States Congressmen voiced fears of a Soviet "bridgehead" in Central America.

Bishop D. Ward Nichols, secretary of the Bishops' Council of the African Methodist Episcopal Church, said yesterday that he had sent word to Sherman Adams, Assistant to the President, commending President Eisenhower for the "honest and fair approach" to civil rights and segregation set forth in the State of the Union Message he delivered on Monday.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Feb. 4 -Troops on both sides in the Korean war launched the heaviest attacks in recent days yesterday at the eastern and western ends of the frozen front.
" One of the difficult problems which face the new Administration," said President Eisenhower in his State of the Union message, "is that of the slow, irregular decline of farm prices." And he added:

ALBANY, Feb. 3 -- Republican legislative leaders have agreed on the constitutional amendment, permitting the temporary assignment of judges in New York City, which will be submitted to the voters in November.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Feb. 3 -- The budget surplus of 1952 amounts to $24,302,000, colones (more than $3.600.000), a record. President Otilio Ulate announced at a press conference called last night in Presidential headquarters.

Women headed by Mrs. Bennett Cerf, Mrs. Gardner Cowles and Mrs. Alfred F. Hess, and including Mrs. Casimir de Rham, are active in furthering plans for a benefit performance by Danny Kaye at the Palace Theatre on Feb. 16 in behalf of the Menninger Foundation. An encouraging subscription has been reported.
CHICAGO, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The chances of the Cubs to obtain Ralph Kiner from the Pirates "don't look too good," Wid Matthews, Cubs personnel director, said today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Dr. James B. Conant, President Eisenhower's selection for United States High Commissioner for Germany, defended his views today before an apparently friendly Senate Foreign Relations Committee and approval of his nomination there was strongly forecast.

MIAMI, Feb. 3 -- George P. (Maje) Odom, who majored in economics at Columbia University, is a horse trainer whose avocation is fishing. He's having a most enjoyable winter. He has hauled a dozen sailfish out of the Gulf Stream and he is tied for the lead among the winner-saddlers at Hialeah's race meet.

William Stucky has written an earnest play about some complicated people. It is entitled "Touchstone" and it opened at the Music Box last evening. Set "somewhere in the horse country of the upper South," as the program phrases it, it is the story of a young Negro boy who has religious visions and turns the community upside down.
Fordham University's basketball team won its fifteenth game in seventeen starts by routing a hardfighting Colgate squad, 74 -- 56, at the Rose Hill gymnasium last night before 1,600 fans.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Manufacturers last year delivered goods valued at $276,500,000,000, 3 per cent more than in 1951, the Department of Commerce said today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- An executive Order establishing procedures for dealing with Federal employes as internal security risks will be issued next week by President Eisenhower.

Armand Chankalian, who was revealed by the State Crime Commission as the mutual friend and go-between of Thomas Luchese (Three Finger Brown) and high public officials and po litical powers, has resigned "on request" from his $9,200 post as administrative assistant to United States Attorney Myles J. Lane, it was disclosed yesterday.

GUATEMALA, Feb. 3 -- President Jacobo Arbenz Guzman has called a halt to the Communist-inspired illegal seizures of land by workers for distribution under Guatemala's radical agrarian reform law, Prensa Libre reported today.

Cooperation with city health authorities in treating non-hospitalized cases of tuberculosis with isoniazid and other drugs was forecast yesterday by Dr. Herbert R. Edwards, executive director of the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association.

The appointment of Robert Tripp Ross, former Republican Representative from the Sixth Congressional District in Queens, as liaison man between the Republican State and National Committees was announced yesterday by William L. Pfeiffer, Republican State Chairman.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Production of world food supplies, based on the already-completed 1952 harvest, has exceeded all records in such commodities as wheat, rice, meats and citrus fruits, according to a report issued today by the Office of Foreign Agricultural Relations in the Department of Agriculture.

VIENNA, Feb. 3 -- Die Volkstimme, central organ of the Austrian Communist party, announced today that Walter Lauber, naturalized American who was arrested, questioned and then released in connection with the recent arrest here of Kurt Ponger and Otto Verber on charges of espionage on behalf of the Soviet Union, had sought refuge in the Soviet zone.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Feb. 4 -The official Peiping radio today denounced President Eisenhower's order to the Seventh Fleet to evacuate Formosan waters and permit raids by Chinese Nationalist troops on the Chinese mainland as a plan to extend the Korean war "to the entire Far East" foredoomed to end in defeat.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The Wage and Salary Stabilization Boards, expecting an executive order quickly ending controls in their areas, stopped processing cases today and handed job termination notices to their 2,000 employes.

Plans for development of a new sulphur mine at a salt dome deposit in the Louisiana marshland were announced yesterday by the Freeport Sulphur Company. The project is the company's fourth in two years.

A strike by 600 members of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union, independent, which has halted the delivery of metropolitan newspapers in suburban areas, continued yesterday, but there were expressions of hope that a settlement might be reached today.

The State of California raised $100,000,000 in the public market yesterday to finance farm and home loans to war veterans, by selling an issue of bonds maturing over twenty years at an interest cost of 2.415 per cent.

There is a danger that the production of new textile fibers is coming at a rate faster than the ability of the industry to assimilate it properly in satisfactory fabrics, Marvin R. Cross, president of Greenwood Mills, declared yesterday.

Calvin MacCracken of the Princeton Club, defending champion, triumphed in a second-round match of the Metropolitan squash racquets Class A championship last night at the Harvard Club. Against George Miley, University Club, in his first appearance in the tourney, MacCracken won by 18-15, 18-16, 18-13.

Two hundred and thirty-eight students will receive degrees at Queens College's semiannual commencement tonight at 8 P. M. in the gymnasium. Dr. John J. Theobald, president of the college, will confer 180 Bachelor of Arts degrees, thirty-four Bachelor of Science degrees and twenty-four Master of Arts degrees.
Record sales of $956,931,021 were achieved last year by the Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation, but earnings declined from 1951 under the impact of higher operating costs.
TRENTON, Feb. 3 -- Police magistrates are planning to confront speeders on the New Jersey Turnpike with fines of $1 for every mile by which they exceed the 60-mile-an-hour legal limit.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 3 -- The American Federation of Labor today ordered its racket-encrusted affiliate on the New York waterfront, the International Longshoremen's Association, to clean house by April 30 or face expulsion from the federation.

At least 3,000 persons who work in the Equitable Building at 120 Broadway had little or no lunch yesterday. The dieting was the result of an early morning water main break on Nassau Street beween Pine mid Cedar Streets that put the building's sixty-two elevators out of commission.

Of late years there has been increasing clamor from minority groups of one kind or another claiming that this or that group is the subject of discrimination. It seems high time that another minority group should raise its voice against discrimination, that group being the owners of rental housing property in New York City.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 3 -- The American Federation of Labor asserted today that President Eisenhower's State of the Union Message contained "several major departures from past national policy, which labor considers loaded with potential danger."

President Eisenhower was urged yesterday to fortify his broad statements on civil rights and immigration with detailed proposals for legislative action. The appeal was made by Dr. Israel Goldstein, president of the American Jewish Congress.

The Federal Maritime Board, at a hearing in Washington yesterday, denied a motion by the North Atlantic Continental Freight Conference that the board by-pass its trial examiner in determining the reasonableness of the dual-rate system proposed by the conference.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Feb. 3 (AP) -- North Sea waves pounding through broken Dutch dikes threatened tonight to swell by hundreds the death toll of storms and floods that already have claimed more than 1,600 lives in the Netherlands, Britain and Belgium.
" Love's Labour's Lost," one of Shakespeare's early comedies, last done here professionally in 1891, will usher in the City Center's six-week winter drama season at 8 o'clock tonight.
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 3 (UP) -- Fred Saigh, scheduled to start serving a fifteen-month sentence for income tax evasion on May 4, today talked terms with prospective buyers of his Cardinals.

Here and there, in IND subway stations from West Fourth Street to 168th Street, there are posted short typewritten notices asking for the return of a small, old leather doll "of great sentimental value."

Resolutions calling on the Legislature to restore the city's share of the pari-mutuel tax to its full 5 per cent rate, and to extend the emergency rent law beyond its presently scheduled expiration date of June 30 were adopted yesterday by the City Council.
President Eisenhower has seized the initiative from the Communists in the two crucial conflicts the United States faces this year -the battle for Germany and the struggle in Korea.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 3 -- The Rev. Dr. Oscar A. Benson of Minneapolis was elected president of the National Lutheran Council here today on the fourth ballot. The council is a cooperative agency representing eight Lutheran bodies in this country with a total membership of 4,000,000 persons.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 3 -- L. B. Smith, Inc., a central Pennsylvania manufacturing concern, has refunded voluntarily to the Defense Department a saving of $1,500,000 in the cost of repairing World War II Army vehicles for service in NATO countries.

Armand Chankalian, whose resignation "by request" as administrative assistant to United States Attorney Myles J. Lane was announced yesterday by Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr., was a relatively obscure civil service employe until last November, when he admitted a long and close friendship with Thomas Luchese (Three Finger Brown), reputed underworld chief.
There is a virus, or perhaps just the common cold, which every now and again permits the head of the house to spend a day at home.

IN 1943 Capt. J. Y. Cousteau of the French Navy and Emile Gagnan, an engineer, invented the aqualung, a system whereby compressed air carried in three metal tubes on the back is fed by an automatic pressure regulator through tubes to the nose. The problem of swimming under water for prolonged periods unencumbered by heavy diving suits was solved.

HEADQUARTERS, Eighth Army, in Korea, Feb. 3 -- Lieut. Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, who has been designated the new commander of the Eighth Army, arrived in Korea today and said he felt the American people were interested enough in the war to support any reasonable plan for ending the struggle.

" Hollywood Screen Test," which has been on the air virtually since television's start, is a program that in its own quiet way often does more real experimentation in drama than many of its more publicized counterparts. This week -- 7:30 P. M. Monday over the A.B.C. network -- it came up with an item of theatre that was thoroughly intriguing.

Walter E. Maloney was re-elected president of the American Merchant Marine Institute yesterday at its annual meeting at 11 Broadway. The members, representing seventy-three major steamship passenger lines, oil tanker companies and cargo-ship operators, also re-elected William G. Mullins as vice president; R. J. Baker as secretary-treasurer and John J. Burns as general counsel.

The Board of Transportation, in its third estimate in a year, has predicted an operating deficit of $41,000,000 on the municipal transit system for the current fiscal year ending June 30, it became known yesterday.

Public school administrators who have barricaded themselves against discussing changes requested in the schools by religious leaders may find that the changes will be brought about from outside the schools, the Very Rev. James A. Pike, dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, declared yesterday.

The Mayor's Committee on Management Survey urged yesterday that an independent agency make an immediate study of bus routes in the city with a view to eliminating some and improving service on others.

Madison Square Garden's first college basketball doubleheader in three weeks promises to provide one of the liveliest court shows of the local season tonight. Undefeated Seton Hall, in quest of its twenty-second straight victory, will oppose formidable St. Bonaventure in the 7:45 opener, while Manhattan and St. John's will clash in the televised feature.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 4 -- Navy stopped Penn State without a field goal in the third period today to clinch an easy 77-53 basketball victory over the Nittany Lions.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Winthrop W. Aldrich, former chairman of the board of the Chase National Bank, was sworn in as Ambassador to Britain at a Department of State ceremony this noon.

LONDON, Feb. 4 -- Britain's armed forces and civilian volunteers are racing to rebuild miles of broken seawall in nine days. The race is against the sun and the moon, which will then again combine forces to pull the tides up beyond the level of last Sunday morning's destructive inundation of the east coast.

Legislation that would permit local assessors to levy indirect real estate taxes against residents of trailer camps was proposed by a state official yesterday at the opening of a three-day conference of township officers at the Statler Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat of Virginia, was joined by forty-five colleagues today in sponsoring a bill "to establish procedures by which Congress could regain control of annual obligations for Federal expenditure."

Motion-picture issues still were benefiting yesterday from the discovery that a third-dimension movie may be a marketable commodity. Otherwise, the stock market was static. Movements on the New York Stock Exchange were small, as was volume. The close was irregularly lower, with rails, motors and chemicals soft.

It is not surprising that there have been proposals in the French Parliament to take reprisals against the United States for the treatment accorded foreign sailors under the McCarran Act. France is only one of several seafaring nations -- including Britain, Holland and Norway -- to have protested the absurd lengths to which Mr. McCarran's law goes in erecting a paper curtain about the United States.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 4 -- Having agreed in principle that the projected Balkan entente must not give the appearance of being exclusive, particularly with reference to Italy, Yugoslavia, Greece and Turkey are now working on a formula that would permit Italian membership without prejudice to the interests of the three original partners in the alliance.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -Permian Basin Pipeline Company, Chicago, and Northern Natural Gas Company, Omaha, Neb., today filed revised plans with the Federal Power Commission for a proposed expansion of Northern's natural gas pipeline system.

Paul G. Hoffman resigned yesterday as president and as a trustee of the Ford Foundation, effective March 1. He will return on that date to the Studebaker Corporation as chairman of its board of directors.
PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 4 -- Forward Hal Haabestad set a new Princeton basketball scoring record tonight as the Tigers defeated Colgate, 72 -- 61, in Dillon gym.

A jury of eleven married men and one bachelor will hear evidence starting tomorrow at 10 A. M. in the General Sessions trial of Minot Frazier (Mickey) Jelke 3d on charges of compulsory prostitution and living from the earnings of vice.

The Board of Transportation now estimates that its operating loss for the present fiscal year will run to $41,000,000. This is a revision, an increase from the previous estimate of $32,000,000. But this is only the operating loss. If the debt service is added the annual charge against the taxpayer to subsidize the city-owned transit system is $113,000,000.

Governor Dewey put it up to the city itself last night to solve its financial crisis without new state aid, and called on Mayor Impellitteri to make new proposals for raising $218,700,000 additional revenues the city is seeking to balance its budget.
The Board of Estimate authorized the Transit Advisory Commission yesterday to study all bus operations -city and private -- to find out whether service was adequate or excessive.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- A change in the McCarran-Walter immigration law was called for in a statement of principles adopted today by the board of directors of the National Council of Catholic Women.

A fashion show depicting styles in vogue from 1850 to 1900 will be a feature of the entertainment at the annual luncheon for the benefit of the New York Women's Bible Society, to be held on Feb. 13 in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre. The costumes, many of them family heirlooms, will be worn by members of the organization, including Miss Rosanne Bennett and Miss Marian Bradley.

A union contract, providing for a wage increase and new pension benefits worth $10,000,000 a year to 25,000 employes, was agreed upon yesterday by Consolidated Edison system and the Utility Workers of America, C. I. O.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 4 -- Although Twentieth Century-Fox is preparing to film its future pictures in a new wide screen process called Cinemascope, the studio is not ignoring the revived interest in Stereoscopic movies that create a three-dimensional illusion when viewed through corrective glasses.
Excerpts from Governor Dewey's speech last night on the city's, financial crisis follow:

In reply to questions propounded by the Securities and Exchange Commission concerning a special offering of Bristol-Myers Company's common stock some days ago, followed by a reduction in the company's dividend. Fundamental Investors, Inc., and Bache Co. issued the following statement yesterday:
A denial of rights to offshore oil to the states could raise international doubts about the country's territorial boundaries; it was asserted here yesterday by Gov. Robert F. Kennon of Louisiana.

Dante Brigliante, the unhappy jeweler whose loss of $100,000 in gems last Saturday to a public locker thief led to even more trouble after he reported the robbery to the police, was arrested last night and charged with grand larceny.

Improvements Will Include Bridge Over the Mississippi, Expressway, Causeway The State of Louisiana plans to borrow $200,000,000 in the public bond market within the next couple of years, Gov. Robert F. Kennon announced here yesterday at the Rockefeller Center office of the Colonial Trust Company. The bonds would be designed to finance public improvement projects, chiefly in the New Orleans area.

New issues of corporate securities valued at more than $67,000,000 will be offered to investors today. Included are public utility company common and preferred stock, common stock and debentures of industrial and trucking companies, and railroad equipment trust certificates. The offerings are as follows:

J. J. Haggerty of the New York A. C., Harold Baker of the Harvard Club, Victor Elmaleh of the Bayside Tennis Club and Thomas Kempner of the Yale Club were winners last night to complete the second round of the metropolitan Class A squash racquets championship tournament at the Harvard Club.

Your editorial on Dr. James Conant leads me to suggest that open-minded citizens who are disturbed by the tactics of McCarthy, McCarran and others like them, as well as by the power of the right-wing Republicans in Congress, would do well to restudy the history of the Reconstruction Era following the Civil War.

Today's new film is "Pimpernel Svenson a Swedish-made comedy starring Edvard Persson, at the Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse. Emil A. Lingheim directed the Scandia Films, Inc., release from a scenario by Ake Ohimarks and Margit Beckman.

Alexander Brailowsky's reading of the Bach-Busoni Chaconne, which opened his recital last night in Carnegie Hall, was one long to remember. It stands out in a perspective of many interpretations of this familiar and gigantic piece not only for the grandeur of its proportions and logic of thought.

CAMDEN, N. J. Feb. 4 -- Anthony Valentino, who was convicted last October of swearing falsely to the National Labor Relations Board that he was not a Communist, has resigned as business agent of Local 80-A, United Packinghouse Workers Union, C. I. O.

THE sport of angling is on the increase rather than the wane, and is more than holding its place as the No. 1 participant sport, with 17,127,896 fresh water enthusiasts, and no one knows how many salt water followers.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Fresh gales in the North Sea loosed new terror tonight along flood-ravaged coasts of Britain, Belgium and the Netherlands. High winds, high tide and rain threatened to expand the havoc.

THERE isn't much doubt about it. Mal Whitfield is in a rut. However, it is a pleasant sort of rut and Marvelous Mal is quite content to stay there. He plunged into that furrow at Helsinki last summer and shows no inclination to climb out. Here are the facts:

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 4 -- Dr. Hans Wolff, Associate Professor of English at the University of Puerto Rico, is en route to Nigeria to spend a year in an attempt to solve one of the most complex problems confronting educators, the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization announced today.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Feb. 4 -- Army's basketball team registered its ninth victory of the season by defeating Swarthmore College, 79 to 60, today in the Field House.
DETROIT, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Ezzard Charles methodically cut down Tommy Harrison of Los Angeles tonight and stopped him in the ninth round to continue his bid for another shot at the heavyweight title.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., Feb. 4 -- There is a lack of sufficient interpretation of problems of children and youths as well as services the Government should be providing for them, it was said in the opening discussion this morning at the Eastern Regional Conference here of the Child Welfare League of America.
TOKYO, Thursday, Feb. 5 -- The United Nations Command charged yesterday that the Communists in Korea used the old truce conference site at Panmunjom as a "shield" for military operations.

A joint resolution by the Council for Social Action and the executive committee of the General Council of Congregational Christian Churches yesterday urged members to resist "every expression of anti-Semitism wherever it may be found."

ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- Companion bills changing the dates for the payment of part of the state's financial contributions to New York City operating expenses were submitted to the Legislature today by Senator Samuel L. Greenberg of Brooklyn and Assemblyman Julius J. Gans of the Bronx, both Democrats.

The possibilities of utilizing films made for television would seem to be unlimited. Tomorrow night one film series will begin its second run over a network, while the first run continues on another networ .

After a glimpse of "Love's Labour's Lost," which opened at the City Center last evening, it is easy to understand why this Shakespearean comedy has not been played here since 1891. It is not very good. Or, to be more exact, it is most uneven.

Continued delay by Brazil on taking more effective action toward liquidating the heavy backlog of commercial dollar debts due United States exporters is causing increasing impatience among affected traders, according to views aired yesterday at a meeting of the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau in the Statler Hotel.
Gifts of money, clothing, medicines and food for general distribution through the Netherlands Red Cross will be accepted and shipped without charge, the Holland-America Line announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- An order decontrolling "red" meats as well as a number of unspecified other consumer items will be issued by the Office of Price Stabilization Friday, Joseph H. Freehill, price director, predicted today.

NEWARK, Feb. 4 -- Nelson F. Stamler, who was dismissed last week as Deputy Attorney General, testified for two and a quarter hours this morning before the Federal grand jury here about crime and corruption in Bergen and Hudson Counties.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 4 -- Taking a new tack in organized labor's efforts to build up its political strength, the American Federation of Labor decided today to make a year-round effort to enlist women unionists and the wives of union members in the federation's political league.

The pulse of the vast waterfront of the Port of New York will die down this morning as thousands of longshoremen throw their weight in support of striking tugboat workers of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L.

Development of a new electronic brain weighing ten tons and using 4,500 electron tubes was announced yesterday by Remington Rand, Inc. The device would make it possible to apply automatic processing to a large oil refinery or chemical plant, the concern said.

The one-story taxpayer recently completed at 114-12 to 113-34 Merrick Boulevard in St. Albans, Queens, has been sold by the Union Corner Eight Corporation to the Merlind Realty Corporation, represented by Aronow, Brodsky, Einhorn Dann, attorneys.

SEOUL, Korea, Feb. 4 -- Lieut. James D. Goff was convicted today of "assault with intent to commit grievous bodily harm" and sentenced to two years at hard labor and dismissal from the United States Army. He was tried in connection with the death of Pang Hwa Il, a Presbyterian minister who died after a beating the night of Dec. 5.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Feb. 4 -- The Mission Indians living on reservations of San Diego County are as entitled to relief from the county as any other needy residents, Superior Judge Arthur L. Mundo declared today in a ruling of far-reaching importance.

Whenever an able-bodied person presents himself for a job he will have preference over a disabled person because ancient aversions to the handicapped are still influencing us, it was suggested here last night at the New York Academy of Medicine, 2 East 103d Street.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Feb. 4 (UP) -- From all over Western Europe, the United States and other parts of the world offers of men, money, clothing, beds, medicine, planes, boats and shelter for homeless children came today in the wake of the floods that struck the Netherlands, Belgium and Britain.

TRENTON, Feb. 4 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll submitted to the New Jersey Legislature today a balanced budget of $219,842,162, representing a decrease of $913,883 from the previous year's record high budget. It calls for no new taxes.

Louis Levin and Solomon Turetsky, builders, have sold the one-story taxpayer at 56 Engle Street in Englewood, N. J., to the Baltimore Realty, Inc. J. I. Kislak, Inc. was the broker, and Heller Laike were attorneys for the sellers. The building, constructed four years ago, has a seventy-four-foot frontage and contains five stores.
Marc Connelly, who won the Pultizer Prize in 1930 for his play, "The Green Pastures," has written a new stage work entitled "There Are Two Points," which may be presented on Broadway next season.
Merger plans of the Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation and the Webster-Chicago Corporation, scheduled to be voted upon at meetings of stockholders of both companies yesterday, were abandoned.

ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- In letters to members of the Legislature, the New York State Conference Board of Farm Organizations suggested today that the state should investigate the possibility of presenting television programs over private stations before it set up a state television network.

With the release of the Yankees' 1953 home schedule yesterday, it became official that the Browns would not appear under the Yankee Stadium lights during the coming baseball season. To make up for the omission of the Browns from the customary fourteen-game stadium night schedule, the Bombers will play one extra night game each with the Indians and the Red Sox.

Henry L. Hoffman, director of internal revenue for the First New York District, filed tax liens yesterday against the property of Thomas (Three Finger Brown) Luchese and his family for a total of $162,838. Mr. Hoffman said the figure represented a Government claim for unpaid taxes plus interest and penalties.

Billy Cox, regular third baseman, and Bill Sharman, rookie outfielder, yesterday agreed to 1953 contract terms with the Dodgers. This gave the National League champions the distinction of being the first of the three major league baseball clubs here to bring its complete roster of eligible players into the fold.

Stockard Co. and the Boise-Griffin Steamship Company have signed contracts with the Staff Officers Association of America A. F. L., covering wages and working conditions of pursers and purser-pharmacists employed on the vessels of the two steamship operators.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 4 (AP) -- The co-favorites had narrow escapes today in the opening round of the annual Palm Beach women's golf tournament.

ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- The establishment of a national reinsurance fund to guard against the possible bankruptcy of any state's unemployment insurance system and resulting destruction of the present federal-state arrangement was proposed by the State Advisory Council on Employment and Unemployment Insurance.

Dividends paid last year on New York Stock Exchange common stocks aggregated $5,594,616,000 and set a new record, the Exchange reported yesterday in its monthly publication. The figure was 1.8 per cent above the 1951 total.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The American farmer has been caught in a price-cost "squeeze" in the last year in which the decline in prices of the products he sells has substantially exceeded the drop in costs of the items he purchases.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 4 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie said today that the "glass house" of the United Nations was not a profitable base for spies, but emphasized that he intended to continue with his plans for taking subversives off the organization's payroll.

PROVIDENCE, Feb. 4 -- Leigh Quinn of Belmont, Mass., scored four goals tonight to lead Yale to a 9-7 victory over Brown in a Pentagonal League hockey game at the Rhode Island Auditorium. The victory was the second of the season for the Elis over the Bruins and gave the defenders a 3-0 record in league competition this season.

Yesterday was Mayor Impellitteri's fifty-third birthday. He observed it by putting in a full day of work at City Hall. The calendar included office ceremonies and two executive sessions of the Board of Estimate -- one morning and one afternoon. Last night he attended the Hotel Association dinner at the Commodore Hotel.

Five leading chefs collaborated to create a menu in the classic tradition for the dinner served last night to 700 guests at the Commodore Hotel. The occasion was the diamond jubilee celebration of the Hotel Association of New York City.
ITHACA, N. Y., Feb. 4 -- Cornell defeated Syracuse, 69 -- 65, in basketball tonight.

The House has acted speedily to give President Eisenhower the kind of reorganization bill he wants and needs. In doing so it killed a committee amendment that would have virtually destroyed any chance of real reorganization in controversial areas. Whether or not this amendment had been due to genuine confusion over just what the President wanted, he left no possible grounds for doubt in his State of the Union speech Monday.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Feb. 4 -- The French landing at the Vietnamese port of Quinhon has fulfilled its primary aim of relieving Vietminh pressure on encircled Ankhe, twenty miles to the northwest. However, the Communist-led rebel forces seem to be establishing themselves in strength around the Quinhon bridgehead.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Feb. 4 -- Removal of two and one-half miles of new natural gas pipeline from disputed easements on private lands in northern Westchester County would be a violation of the Federal Natural Gas Act and ultimately add $205,000 to consumers' bills, the Algonquin Gas Transmission Company told Supreme Court Justice Elbert T. Gallagher here today.
LONDON, Feb. 4 -- Britons may now satisfy their sweet tooth to their heart's content. After eleven years the rationing and price control of candy came to an unexpected end today.

New legislation to plug holes in the existing tenement house and penal laws under which landlords and owners of firetrap tenements escape at least some punishment for offenses has been drafted by the city for prompt consideration by the present session of the Legislature, Bernard J. Gillroy, Commissioner of Housing and Buildings reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, whose nomination to be Under Secretary of State was unanimously approved today by the Foreign Relations Committee, went back to Lord Palmerston to suggest a United States policy toward Russia.

Napoleon and the Napoleonic era are the subjects of six novels being published in the first four months of 1953. The first to be issued was "Desiree," by Annemarie Selinko (Morrow), which dealt with the wife of Napoleon's marshall, Jean Baptiste Jules Bernadotte, who became King of Sweden.

LONDON, Feb. 4 -- The philosophy underlying the British Government's attitude to civil liberties and security during the "cold war" period was outlined today to a group of American correspondents by the British Home Secretary, Sir David Maxwell Fyfe.
St. Francis College of Brooklyn defeated Siena College of Albany, 69 to 66, in an overtime game before 2,500 in the Second Corps Armory, Brooklyn, last night.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Thursday, Feb. 5 -- Evacuation of the flood-swept Netherlands islands is in full swing, spurred by fears that new storms may crumble intact but weakened dikes and spread the devastation.
NEWARK, Feb. 4 -- Plans for a $1,500,000 Rutgers University Law Center were outlined tonight at a dinner in the Robert Treat Hotel opening a fund-raising campaign.

Budget Director Joseph M. Dodge has served notice, if such notice had been needed, that the Eisenhower Administration means to do something about bringing the federal budget under control, and not merely talk about it. He has done this by announcing a series of drastic curbs on Government spending. These include:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Representative Dewey Short, Republican of Missouri, chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, called today for immediate repeal of the so-called Davis amendment to the current Defense Appropriation Act that would put a ceiling on promotions in the armed services after April 1.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- "Billy" Butlin, who provides British stenographers, clerks and other workers with "packaged" vacancies at camps he runs throughout the British Isles, applied to the Securities and Exchange Commission today for authority to sell $1,350,000 worth of debentures of the Grand Bahama Company, Ltd., of Nassau.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 4 -- The Federal Government is prepared to offer a most favorable trade agreement to Egypt to avert a boycott threatened by the Arab states should the West Germans ratify and implement the $822,000,000 restitution agreement with Israel.

CHICAGO, Feb. 4 -- A plan to merge Webster-Chicago Corporation into Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation, New York, was abandoned today, giving Martin C. Remer, a Chicago securities man, the victory in a fight he led against the proposed transaction.
ALBANY, Feb. 4 (UP) -- The State Commerce Department today reported the following winter sports conditions:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The Senate's Republican foreign affairs spokesman, Senator Alexander Wiley of Wisconsin, declared today that the Eisenhower Administration's new Asian policy involved a hope that Chinese Nationalists using United States supplied aircraft would break up Communist rail communications in mainland China.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 4 (UP) -- June Haver, the 26-year-old motion picture actress said tonight she would give up her film career to enter religious training and become a nun.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 4 (AP) -- The Argentine yacht, Juana, held fast to its lead in the 1,200-mile Buenos Aires-to-Rio race today but the United States had two craft in strong contention.
A steady trend toward conservatism can be observed today in the work of Britain's younger composers, according to Howard Ferguson, who is one of them.

LONDON, Feb. 4 -- The rise in Britain's gold and dollar reserves last month and sustained strength of sterling gave a brighter tone to stock markets today, although nervousness about the Far Eastern situation acted as a restraint on business.
Certificates of merit were awarded yesterday by the New York chapter of the American Red Cross to top contributors among organizations to the regional blood bank.
New York faces the loss of one-third of its grain-handling facilities within six months unless there is a decided upswing in grain export through the port, it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The Senate committee on Government operations responded today to an unusual personal appeal by Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, Republican leader, by reversing its position to give President Eisenhower the reorganization power he wants.

HAVANA, Feb. 4 -- James Schoonmaker of Nassau sailed Dingo to victory again today in the second race of the Cuba Cup series of the twenty-second international Star Class regatta. He covered the ten-mile course in 2 hours 8 minutes 26 seconds to run his point total to 16. Donald Pritchard crewed.

The nation's gasoline stocks increased 3,564,000 barrels last week, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. At the weekend, supplies amounted to 149,443,000 barrels, compared with 145,879,000 a week earlier and 145,500,000 a year ago.

Ralph Naimoli, regular guard on New York University's basketball team, was ruled ineligible for furtheir intercollegiate competition yesterday, on the eve of the Violet squad's departure for road games against Duke tonight and North Carolina Saturday.
DETROIT, Feb. 4 (AP) -- The Ford Motor Company announced today it will build an assembly plant in the San Francisco area to expand its manufacture of Ford cars and trucks.

The growing number of border clashes, complaints and counter-complaints between Jordan and Israel have now taken a more serious turn. Jordan has invoked her mutual aid treaty with Britain, while in Tel Aviv Premier Ben-Gurion hurried back from a vacation to preside over a special Cabinet meeting on the subject. Again we are reminded that the Near East is an area of friction and danger.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Representative Clarence E. Kilburn, Republican of upstate New York, reported today that the Air Force had come around to his view that Camp Drum, N. Y., was a suitable site for the bomber base originally proposed for Plattsburg.

CHICAGO, Feb. 4 -- Grain futures wound up irregular today, a generally strong undertone early yielding to selling pressure. On the declines, however, selling was offset by commission support, some mill buying of wheat, and some short covering after the market had steadied.

William W. Remington, former Government economist, was sentenced yesterday by Federal Judge Vincent L. Leibell to three years in prison for having perjured himself on two counts on the question of Communist party ties.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Eight Democratic Senators joined today in proposing new anti-filibuster rules and urged the Republican leadership to start hearings on the whole filibuster question.

The dash and fashion flair associated with Charles James designs were in full evidence in the coats and suits created by this designer for William Popper and shown yesterday by Lord Taylor at the Pierre Hotel. With these were coats and suits styled for the diminutive figure by the same manufacturer.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Government attorneys indicated today they might complete tomorrow their portion of the Federal anti-trust suit against the National Football League.
