Marjorie Fulton, in her debut violin recital last night at Town Hall, presented a somewhat short but demanding program with complete assurance and a high level of artistry. All of her interpretations had a thoughtful, mature approach that took the music into consideration as well as her instrument.
More cooperation by manufacturers with retailers was urged yesterday by Edward Sachs, merchandise analyst of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., as the key to selling goods in the present buyer's market.

Two items in the news provide an ironic comment on the "workers' paradise" which the Communists claim they are building. One deals with the flat refusal of the thirteen second-rank Communist leaders to go "on probation" to Soviet Russia instead of to jail here on charges of teaching the overthrowal of this Government by force and violence.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Feb. 4 -- Henry A. Wallace, former Vice President, fared a bit better today than he had yesterday and Monday in serving as a talesman in the Westchester County Courthouse here. He was impaneled as juror No. 1 in an owner-contractor damage suit scheduled for trial in Supreme Court tomorrow, but lawyers still could remove him before testimony begins.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The Senate confirmed today the nomination of Harold E. Talbott to be Secretary of the Air Force by a vote of 76 to 6. The action completed the formation of President Eisenhower's top civilian command at the Pentagon.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 4 -- Pennsylvania remained a top threat for the Eastern League basketball title tonight by beating Columbia, 63 -- 56, in the first game of a Palestra double-header.

Emil Schram, former president of the New York Stock Exchange, is the new president of the United Service Organizations, Inc. He succeeds Lindsley F. Kimball, vice president of the Rockefeller Foundation, who retired as U. S. O. president last June.

COVE NECK, L. I., Feb, 4 -- Sagamore Hill, the big, comfortable old home of Theodore Roosevelt, was a cheerfully busy place today as moving men carried in heads of wapiti and buffalo, skins of lion and zebra and other exotic and homely furnishings that were part of the everyday home life of the late President.
An exhibition designed to inspire entries into a competition on lighting design will open today in the American Craftsmen's Educational Council gallery at America House, 32 East Fifty-second Street.

New York knows well, from the experience of February, 1946, how serious is a strike of tugboat operators in this city surrounded by water. On that occasion, when the strike lasted ten days, the city administration grew almost hysterically alarmed and took the impetuous action of locking the public out of its business properties.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Organizations required to register with the Attorney General under the Subversive Activities Control Act of 1950 faced tighter controls as a result of a revised regulation promulgated today by Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr.

TRENTON, Feb. 4 -- Assembly Republican leaders failed tonight to break a deadlock with the Senate over procedure for an investigation of the dismissal of Nelson F. Stamler as Bergen County Crime Investigator and the conduct of law enforcement in the state.

TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 3 -- For the past two days your correspondent has been feasting on a super grade of caviar that is reputedly available in ordinary circumstances to only three men -- Soviet Premier Stalin, the Shah of Iran and A. A. Sepehr.
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange continued moderately active to yesterday and closing prices for active months were barely steady and 17 points lower to 2 points higher than on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Jan. 28:

TOKYO, Thursday, Feb. 5 -- Chou En-lai, Chinese Communist Premier and Foreign Minister, has called on the Eisenhower Administration for an unconditional resumption of the armistice talks at Panmunjom to lead to an "immediate" cease-fire in Korea, Peiping's Government-controlled radio said this morning.
Robert A. Lovett, former Secretary of Defense, will rejoin Brown Brothers Harriman Co., private bankers, as a general partner on March 1, it was announced yesterday.

Commodity prices closed irregularly lower yesterday on the New York exchanges, with activity, improved on most items. Coffee volume was more than twice Tuesday's figure, the previous record for the year. Rubber, cocoa, wool, hides and tin closed lower.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The Federal Trade Commission, when it soon submits its annual report, will lead what may become a procession of independent agencies that will ask more money from a Congress bent on economy.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Feb. 4 -- The Bolivian Government today was asked by the powerful Federation of Factory Workers to expropriate the newspaper Los Tiempos of Cochabamba. At the same time, it also faced the question of domestic censorship of news.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The bill which was introduced today by forty-six Senators -- only three less than a majority of that branch -- offers a practicable means by which Government expenditures can be brought into line with Government revenues in the next several fiscal years without serious risk to rearmament for national security. That is because:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) -- The White House declined comment today on whether President Eisenhower planned to rescind former President Harry S. Truman's controversial order applying tight military security to the handling of information by civilian Government agencies.
LONDON, Feb. 4 -- The cherished United States ideal of helping to build a unified Europe capable of defending itself moved a little nearer to realization tonight.

Tatiana du Plessix, ace millinery designer for Saks Fifth Avenue, has reversed the order of things in her collection for spring and summer, presented to the press yesterday morning. Trimmings go to the back of the head while fabrics take on added importance.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- An Interstate Commerce Commission examiner today recommended denial of an application by Commercial Barge Line, Inc., to establish a general freight service throughout the Mississippi Valley.

A thief with a taste for eighteenth-century porcelain absconded yesterday with a ceramic likeness of William Pitt the Elder from the Metropolitan Museum of Art, after having ripped the statuette from its moorings.
ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 4 -- Lutheran churchgoers were taken to task here today for neglecting the spiritual welfare of their sons and daughters in the armed forces.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Failure of United States efforts, to date, to stop a China-bound Finnish tanker with a full cargo of jet fuel has raised the question of whether some new steps might be taken to shut off the flow of strategic materials to Communist China.

ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- Judge George Sylvester of the Court of Claims today ordered the state to pay $40,712 to the widow of a Brooklyn man who was stabbed to death in 1950 by a former patient in the Matteawan State Hospital for the Criminally Insane at Beacon.

KARACHI, Feb. 4 -- The Pakistan Government announced today it will permit barter transactions in foreign trade. The announcement said "exportable commodities, particularly cotton," could be exchanged with any country for imports of essential items such as machinery, iron and steel, chemicals, drugs and medicines, dyes, cotton yarn, art silk yarn, sugar, coal and wheat for a limited period and up to a certain value.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The Senate Internal Security subcommittee, assigned to investigate subversion and espionage, organized today with Senator William E. Jenner of Indiana as chairman and six areas tentatively staked out for inquiry.

Serious students of vocal art, if there were any in the audience at Hunter College last evening, must have been sorely perplexed to hear the baritone, John Raitt, doing everything they had been warned not to do, and delighting his audience immensely in the process.

PARIS, Feb. 4 -- With conviction and the assuredness of a master dressmaker, Balenciaga carries the middy silhouette and semi-fitted lines straight through his epoc-making collection, even to ball gowns.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Another former high official of the Internal Revenue Bureau, Carroll E. Mealey of Albany, N. Y., was revealed today to be in trouble with the Federal Government over his own income taxes.

The Bristol-Myers Company yesterday announced a sharp drop in earnings for the year ended Dec. 31 and the board of directors voted to reduce the interim dividend on the common stock to 25 cents a share.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -Government officials told Congress today that newsprint supplies for United States publishers probably will be more than adequate this year -- but prices still may go up.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 4 -- The "Israeli Government is taking, the necessary steps," Foreign Minister Moshe Sharett told the Knesset (Parliament) this afternoon following a special meeting of the Cabinet in Jerusalem called by Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion to decide what should be done about the recent wave of incursions by Arab infiltrators.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Feb. 4 -- Patrick Duncan, son of a former Governor General of South Africa; Manilal Gandhi, son of the late Mohandas K. Gandhi, and six other persons, all white, were convicted today on charges of having behaved in a manner calculated to cause Negroes to resist and contravene the law. They had led a procession of Negroes into the Germiston Negro compound on Dec. 8 without permits to enter the location.
TOKYO, Thursday, Feb. 5 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,516, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Thursday, Korean time:

Events today: Herbert Burtis, organist, St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University, 12 noon; "Aida," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P. M.; Philharmonic - Symphony, conductor, Kurtz, piano soloist, Myra Hess, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Bronislav Gimpel, violinist, Town Hall, 8:30; Program of Chamber Music, Mannes Music School, 8:30; Amadeus String Quartet, McMillan Theatre, 8:30; Bucknell University Men's Glee Club, Evangelical Lutheran Church of the Holy Trinity, 8:15.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Continuing the economizing and streamlining process he started yesterday, President Eisenhower today merged the Defense Production Administration with the Office of Defense Mobilization.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Announced United States battle casualties in Korea reached 129,424 today, an increase of 271 since last week.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The Foreign Relations Committee unanimously recommended today Senate confirmation of Dr. James Bryant Conant to be United States High Commissioner to Germany and Gen. Walter Bedell Smith to be Under Secretary of State.

ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- With the endorsement of the State Banking Department, a bill was introduced in the Legislature today to clear the way for savings banks in the seven largest cities of the state to establish branches within a radius of fifty miles from the cities.

Immediate renewal of the city's unsubsidized housing program was voted yesterday by the Board of Estimate. The board directed the City Housing Authority to proceed at once with nine projects costing $147,000,000 and providing 9,840 apartments for 35,000 persons.

The currently prevailing attitude of the insurance industry toward Governor Dewey's proposal for compulsory auto insurance would tend to indicate a lack of sense of public responsibility on the part of that group. Obviously, the proposed legislation would force the companies to insure the so-called "bad risk" driver, who is accident-prone because of physical or psychological defects.

Control of the seas, when mentioned today, more readily invokes thoughts of tourist dollars and blue ribbons than of torpedoes and yellow rafts. But a recent announcement by the Maritime Administration that bids for fourteen war-damaged ships would be opened on Feb. 11 recalls the desperate exigency of that control not too long ago.

WILLOW RUN, Mich., Feb. 4 -- The Kaiser-Frazer Corporation announced today that its Fiberglas sports car, called the DKF-161, would have a six-cylinder high compression engine with multiple carburetion and a newly designed chassis.

MIAMI, Feb. 4 -- Some perfectly charming mutuels were flashed on Hialeah's pay-off board today, including a $26.90-for-$2 return on the Buddah Stable's Sunny Dale, who won the $20,375 Columbiana Handicap for fillies and mares. She was the seventh choice in a fifteen-horse line-up.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Senator John J. Williams, Republican of Delaware, denounced today what he termed "an unjustifiable raid on the Federal Treasury," which he said gave many Government workers double pay amounting possibly to millions of dollars.

THE NEW YORK TIMES air edition of Jan. 12 has brought me the excellent survey of Point Four and its operations throughout the world. While it is not my intention to question the high purpose of this program, which, to quote from your editorial, "is doing enough good in enough underdeveloped nations to justify its conception and its continuance," permit me to stress certain fallacies, particularly as they refer to our Latin-American neighbors.
Mediation efforts to end a strike by 600 deliverers that has interfered with the distribution of metropolitan newspapers in New York's suburbs were begun last night.

NORWALK, Conn., Feb. 4 -- A man who put his foot in the door to protest the exclusion of the public from a meeting of the Norwalk Board of Education was arrested last night on the order of Mayor Irving C. Freese and charged with breach of the peace.

Candy manufacturers, already experiencing record orders for both Valentine's Day and Easter, are planning to spend more for advertising this year than ever before, according to a spokesman for the industry.

In tax-exempt bond circles, bond men are heaving a big sigh of relief at having put behind them the $100,000,000 borrowing by California to finance farm and home loans to war veterans. From all accounts, a successful distribution has been made by the merged syndicate that submitted the only bid for the big bond issue.

Citing its own policies as indicative of those followed by most large concerns, the Raytheon Manufacturing Company yesterday took issue with the belief that small businesses -- companies employing 500 or less -- are being left out in the cold in Government defense business.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The Senate Investigating subcommittee was told by a State Department supervisor today that John Stewart Service, dismissed last year because of a "reasonable doubt of loyalty," not only had general access with 300 to 400 others to confidential Foreign Service personnel files in 1949 but a key to the file room for work there, alone if he wanted, at night.

ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- A measure making it a misdemeanor for labor union officials to solicit or accept bribes aimed at influencing their activities was introduced in the Legislature today by two Republicans, Senator MacNeil Mitchell of Manhattan and Assemblyman Justin C. Morgan of Buffalo.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 4 -- President Eisenhower was declared here today to have put his assets in an "irrevocable trust," so that he could not be accused of letting his personal finances influence his decisions as President.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 4 -- More than 1,000 delegates from all parts of the country gathered here today for the opening of the national assembly of the Party of Revolutionary Institutions, the political organization that has ruled Mexico without a break for nearly thirty years.

WOENSDRECHT, the Netherlands, Feb. 4 -- Seven United States helicopters flying without interruption from dawn to dusk rescued 450 flood victims from trees, roofs and other exposed places on the islands of Goeree-Overflakkee today.

INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Feb. 4 (AP) -Harry S. Truman, the man who went from road overseer up the political ladder to the White House, will be honored tomorrow night at a homecoming dinner, a homey affair with lots to eat and few speeches.

THOMAS MERTON'S "The Sign of Jonas"* is a book of temporal and spiritual adventure written with candor and grace. It is the story, told in the form of a diary, of his thoughts and his acts as a Trappist monk at Gethsemani Monastery in Kentucky during the last seven years -- the years since he wrote "The Seven Storey Mountain." You will not find many more dynamic records of a pilgrim's progress.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 4 -- Assurances of West Germany's desire to follow United States foreign policy, appeals for political intervention and questions on future United States foreign policy will be the main elements in the Federal Government's reception of John Foster Dulles, United States Secretary of State, tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -The Securities and Exchange Commission, which regulates the nation's stock market transactions, today published tighter rules for conduct of present and past commissioners and employes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Speaker Joseph W. Martin Jr. of Massachusetts, reiterated today his opposition to cutting taxes before appropriations were reduced, and hinted at a 50 per cent slash in the State Department budget.

TOKYO, Friday, Feb. 6 (AP) -- The Peiping radio broadcast yesterday an English translation of Premier Chou En-lai's remarks on a Korean truce and, while still belligerent in tone, it was somewhat milder than the previous Chinese language version.

Discussing legal aspects of water fluoridation programs before a group of local and county atorrneys of New York State, Dr. David B. Ast, chief of the State Health Department's Dental Bureau, said that despite opposition he could see no reason why local communities should not proceed with fluoridation programs "with the assurance they were within their legal rights."

The value of the Boy Scout movement in helping youths prepare to meet "the saddest need of this tired and aching world -- the need for good free leadership" -- was praised yesterday by Governor Dewey.

From this time forth the student of American life, as lived in New York City for the two-fifths of a century. between 1835 and 1875, and even the merely curious in this field, must turn to the newly published "Diary of George Templeton Strong." Its four volumes are a treasury of highly intelligent gossip and reflection upon local and national matters -- civic, legal, artistic, political, academic, religious and social.
TOKYO, Friday, Feb. 6 -- High-flying B-29 Superfort bombers flew to within twenty miles of the Communists' "MIG nest" in Manchuria last night and blasted the enemy supply and troop complex of Taeyu.

AURANGABAD, Hyderabad State, India, Feb. 5 -- Beset by threats of famine, regional dissensions, internal political conflicts and an opposition headed by one of the strongest Communist cells in India, the Congress party Cabinet governing Hyderabad resigned this week to be reconstituted for a fresh start.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- A White House source asserted today that President Eisenhower would appoint six professional Foreign Service officers to top ambassadorial posts and three others to be Assistant Secretaries of State.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- A speedy end to all wage controls and an accelerated program of terminating price regulations will be recommended to President Eisenhower's Cabinet when it gathers at the White House tomorrow.
The early morning clang of milk bottles has disappeared from seventy apartment houses where "mechanical milkmen" have been tested quietly in lobbies for a year.
A Westchester neighbor of mine, J. H. Wallis, has recently had published in your columns a letter praising Mr. Truman's Administration. I think it bears thoughtful examination.

Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley announced yesterday that the new drastic ban on parking in rush hours by barring "standing, loading and unloading" in peak periods would go into effect Monday on First and Second Avenues between Thirty-fourth and 125th Streets.
Red Cross headquarters, 70 West Fortieth Street, announced yesterday that 1,066 pints of blood were collected Wednesday at three city centers and at points reached by five bloodmobile units.

The Amadeus Quartet, a group of four young musicians who got together in London after World War II, played its first New York concert last night at the McMillin Theatre. Three Mozart Quartets made up the program -- D minor (K. 421), A (K. 464) and F (K. 590).

Somewhere in the Indian Ocean the tanker Wiima, 7,717 tons displacement, is steaming eastward. Her destination is Red China. Her cargo is described by our State Department as jet fuel. If she reaches Red China she will supply this fuel to Communist planes which will use it in their efforts to shoot down young American pilots flying over Korea on a mission of the United Nations.

Three of Robert Anderson's scripts have been snapped up for Broadway production, an unusual procedure for a comparatively unknown dramatist. The latest to be sold is "All Summer Long," adapted from Donald Wetzel's novel, "A Wreath and a Curse."

The "economic seminar" method of buying city supplies instituted five years ago by Purchase Commissioner John Splain can be credited with savings to the city of $10,000,000 since the procedure was intrduced, Mayor Impellitteri said yesterday.
LONDON, Feb. 5 -- The British Government today entered on Jordan's side the dispute between Israel and Jordan over recent border incidents.

DETROIT, Feb. 5 (UP) -- Allan Stanley deflected Hy Buller's long shot past Terry Sawchuk, goalie, with less than four minutes to play tonight to give the New York Rangers a 3-3 tie with the Detroit Red Wings before 11,970 National Hockey League fans at Olympia.

Food habits affect the emotional atmosphere of the home and the home atmosphere also can affect food habits, according to an article entitled "The Nutrition of Mothers and Children" in the current issue of The Journal of Home Economics.
BERLIN, Feb. 5 -- Four seats in East Germany's Volkskammer, or People's Parliament, were empty today as a result of the current political upheavals in that Government.

LONDON, Feb. 5 -- The immediate danger of fresh inundations along 1,000 miles of England's east coast passed this morning. Unceasing work on the breached and battered sea defenses had made them strong enough to withstand the high tides that crashed against them just before dawn.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UP) -- The Federal Reserve System's 6,800 member banks had a record $55,829,000,000 outstanding in loans at the end of 1952, the board of governors reported today.

Color is the primary consideration in two of this week's numerous exhibitions of painting. In his first one-man show, at the Artists Gallery, Allen Leepa demonstrates gifts as a colorist. His work is in the vein of abstract expressionism with figures half hidden and half suggested in the midst of color surfaces that might be almost lurid were they not so thought out and controlled.

The Telephone Employes Union land its parent group, the United Telephone Organizations, filed papers yesterday before Justice Carroll G. Walker in State Supreme Court seeking to enjoin each other from electing officers until differences between them are ironed out. The court reserved decision.

Robert H. Lindsay is a writer with sensitivity and ideas. To the Kraft Television Theatre on Wesdnesday evening over N. B. C., he contributed an original play, "The Chess Game," which was intellectually provocative and decidedly out of the ordinary, even if the climax unfortunately was somewhat contrived.

CANNES, France, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Tulyar, winner of the 1952 English Derby and eyed enviously by American horse breeders, has been sold by the Aga Khan to the Irish National Stud Company for 250,000 ($700,000).

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 5 (AP) -- A Texas radio executive carried the ball for the Government today in its anti-trust suit against the National Football League and, after making a couple of points, ran headlong into intensive defense questioning.

The official opening of the Italian Film Export Releasing Corporation's new sound studio at 233 West Forty-ninth Street yesterday was highlighted by a demonstration of "dubbing" -- the substitution of one language for another on the sound track -- conducted by Dr. Mauro Zambuto, director of the studio.

I have just had the opportunity to read the interesting summary which Hanson Baldwin has written, based on his three months' survey of thirteen European countries, published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Jan. 16. This is my second visit to Europe since the war and I have now been traveling throughout Europe since last September.
Three pounds of pure heroin were found yesterday by customs officials aboard the American Export liner Constitution, ruining what one officer called the "best concealed job we've run into in years."

A thin layer of smoke and soot gave a faint gray cast to the blue sky here yesterday afternoon and dimmed the winter sunlight on a day that might normally have been considered a clear one for New York.

A long week-end of amassing money and clothing for flood victims in the Netherlands, Belgium, France and England began yesterday in New York, which also became the depot for contributions forwarded from other cities in this country.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) -- A 17-year-old bride who won a national essay contest and came to Washington with considerable fanfare lost out today on what was left of her gala reception.

ALBANY, Feb. 5 -- A legislative investigation of charitable organizations to wipe out dishonesty and inefficiency in fund-raising organizations was urged today by Senator Bernard Tompkins and Assemblyman Samuel Rabin, Republicans of Queens.

As Mr. Dulles and Mr. Stassen near the end of their European fact-finding trip there is cumulative evidence that their visit has achieved considerable success. They have managed not only to allay some of the initial European alarm over President Eisenhower's declaration of a "new and positive" foreign policy but also to create among European statesmen a better understanding of the American point of view.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, today called a conference of leaders in the cotton industry for next Thursday to discuss price and marketing problems.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 5 -- Greece, Turkey and Yugoslavia plan, as part of the Balkan entente that they are now fashioning, to extend an invitation to join to any Cominform country in the Balkans that succeeds in throwing off Soviet domination.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- President Eisenhower attended a breakfast prayer meeting today and in an informal talk declared that "every free Government is imbedded soundly in a deeply felt religious faith or it makes no sense."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Sales of United States Saving bonds totaling $504,000,000 in January exceeded redemptions by $69,000,000 and were 14 per cent above sales in January, 1952, the Treasury announced today. Redemptions of all types last month totaled $435,000,000, or 12 per cent less than in January a year ago.

Magistrate Abner C. Surpless chided a United Nations official yesterday in Flatbush Court for refusing to testify in a case and added that "in an American court we do not heed directives of the United Nations or any foreign nation."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday amounted to 697,616 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 25 cars fewer than for the preceding week, 33,602 cars, or 4.6 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 46,451 cars, or 7.1 per cent, more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

In a series of organizational changes leading to further expansion of its construction activities abroad, Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation announced yesterday the election of Louis E. Wolfson, chairman, as president, and Ralph E. DeSimone, former president and director, as board chairman of Merritt-Chapman Scott Overseas, Inc. Mr. DeSimone will have responsibility for planning and developing construction operations outside the United States.

On a cold February day a home cook can turn out the jams, jellies and marmalades that her grandmother prepared only in the fall, at harvest-time. The frozen and canned products that have simplified other departments of cooking also have made possible "off-season" preserve-making.

A decision of the Internal Revenue Bureau, holding that disability or accident benefits to employes from employers' self-insurance plans are taxable, has been protested by the Controllers Congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was somewhat irregular yesterday, and closing prices were 8 points lower to 2 points higher than on Wednesday.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 5 -- The National Lutheran Council, at its thirty-fifth annual convention here, formally requested Congress today to rewrite the controversial McCarran-Walter Immigration Law. The council is a cooperative agency representing four million churchgoers affiliated with eight Lutheran denominations.

The Government moved yesterday to foreclose on the property of Frank Costello and his wife to satisfy unpaid income tax liens totaling $486,722. The action, filed by United States Attorney Myles J. Lane in Federal Court, contended that Costello's known assets in this state, Kansas, Texas, Louisiana and Florida were worth $206,819.

WASHINGTON. Feb. 5 -- The Department of Defense, after a series of unexpected delays over confirmation of its officials, today became fully staffed at the highest policy-making level for the first time in three weeks. New officials, however, expressed apprehension over the problem of filling remaining key posts.

LONDON, Feb. 5 (Reuters) -- The contest for Great Britain's Football Association Cup became an all-professional struggle today as Walthamstow Avenue, last amateur soccer team in the competition, bowed, 5 -- 2, before Manchester United in a fourth-round replay.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 5 -- Paramount has called off filming of "A New Kind of Love," which was to have marked the screen debut of Yul Brynner, star of the Broadway hit "The King and I."

LONDON, Feb. 5 -- John Foster Dulles, United States Secretary of State, and Harold E. Stassen, Mutual Security Administrator, left today for West Germany satisfied that their visit to London had furthered the cause of European unity and hopeful that constitutional and other problems regarding West Germany's ratification of the European Defense Community Treaty and the Bonn peace contract with the Western Allies could be surmounted.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 5 (AP) -- William White, president of the New York Central Railroad, today suggested pooling of railroad services in certain areas as a means of reducing revenue losses caused by passenger runs.

CHICAGO, Feb. 5 -- With heavy pressure on corn futures, prices for all cereals were lower in early trading today. Later, wheat turned strong, working to above the previous close, but other grains and soybeans were inclined to drag.
OTTAWA, Feb. 5 (UP) -- The Bank of Canada hinted strongly today that the United States should lead the way in cutting restrictions on international trade.

Net earnings of the Nash-Kelvinator Corporation for the quarter to last Dec. 31 rose to $5,522,374, equal to $1.27 a common share, from $1,034,024, or 23 cents a share, in the final three months of 1951.
The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund received yesterday $1,831.10 from thirty-three contributors, bringing the total for the forty-first annual appeal to $389,587.54 donated by 12,329 persons.

A vacant blockfront parcel on the south side of Linden Boulevard, between 226th and 227th Streets in Jamaica, Queens, has been sold by the Philger Realty Corporation to the Cambria Holding Corporation, of which E. Fleigler is president.
The general strike of longshoremen ordered by Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, in sympathy with striking tugboat workers, raises these questions:

The violinist Bronislav Gimpel was heard in recital last evening at Town Hall playing a refreshing and unhackneyed program that included Beethoven's Romance in F Major, the G Major Sonata of Mozart (K. 301), Bartok's Second Violin Sonata, Sibelius' Sonatina in E Major, Op. 80; Paul Creston's Suite for Violin and Piano and Ravel's "Tzigane."

In a masterful display of seamanship, Capt. Franck Garrigue brought the huge, 44,356-ton French liner Ile de France into her West Forty-eighth Street pier yesterday without the aid of tugs. He did it as easily and surely as he might have docked a small pleasure launch.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The new Administration's long-term agricultural policy, endorsing price upports primarily for disaster prevention and discouraging Federal aid where all means of self-assistance have not been exhausted, was enunciated today by Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture.

The American Jewish Committee reported yesterday that the total Jewish population of the world was 11,558,830, of which 2,500,000 "are trapped behind the Iron Curtain." The census is reported in the "American Jewish Year Book," which will be published today by the committee and distributed by the Jewish Publication Society.

THE importance of protecting and improving our wildlife resources in order to encourage rather than discourage the increasing ranks of outdoor enthusiasts was emphasized by the report of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, which indicated an increase of more than a million hunting license sales during the fiscal year ended June 30, 1952.
WASHINGTON, Feb 5 (AP) -- The Senate Interior and Insular Affairs Committee approved today the nominations for four high Interior Department posts.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Harry Lundeberg, president of the Seafarers International Union, A. F. L., after a visit with President Eisenhower today, said that ships trading with Red China should be "blown" out of the water.

Thirty-five extra detectives were assigned to Manhattan's East Side yesterday to press the investigation of the mysterious death and stabbing of James Doyle, 55-year-old clerk in the Pupin Physics Laboratory of Columbia University.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The Justice Department announced today the appointment of Leo A. Rover, a Washington lawyer, as a Special Assistant to the Attorney General to prosecute Prof. Owen Lattimore.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The Office of Education reported today that the salaries of college faculties in fifty-one land grant colleges had increased from the school year 1949-50 to the next at a rate varying from 9.1 per cent for professors to 12.7 per cent for instructors.
It costs the Soviet Union $1,500,000,000 a year to conduct a propaganda program "fabricated on a tissue of lies," Alfred H. Morton, director of the Voice of America, declared here yesterday.

Indian Head Mills, Inc., a new corporation has acquired from Textron, Inc., the inventories, assets and trademarks of Textron's Indian Head department, it was made known yesterday following the announcement that Textron had adopted a reorganization plan.

Dr. Abba Hillel Silver, noted American Zionist leader, called last night on the highest leadership of Soviet Russia to clarify its policy on the widely disseminated charges against the Jewish people "which cannot help but incite and inflame the people of the Soviet Union."

LONDON, Feb. 5 -- British Government securities led the stock markets today with fresh rises ranging up to one-quarter of 1 per cent. Other sections were extremely quiet although the tendency was upward, particularly among South African gold mining shares.

Spot sterling, which has been showing some strength recently, yesterday reached the control price of $2.82, at which the Bank of England will make unlimited quantities available. However, only a small amount of business was done at that level.

The novel feature of the concert last night in Carnegie Hall of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society, Efrem Kurtz guest conductor, was the American premiere of the Concerto for Piano and Strings by Howard Ferguson, with Dame Myra Hess as soloist.
MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 5 (AP) -- The New York Knickerbockers' eight-game winning streak ended tonight as the Minneapolis Lakers scored an 81-73 National Basketball Association triumph before 6,121 fans.
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 5 (UP) -- Fred Saigh set $4,250,000 today as "a fair figure" for anyone interested in buying the Cardinals.

Whether or not the latest call from Peiping for a renewal of truce discussions is in any way the result of the impact of President Eisenhower's modification of the orders of the Seventh Fleet, it is clear that the Communist proposal offers nothing new, promises no fresh or different approach. It is the same old phonograph record being played over again and it is just as cracked now as it was ten weeks ago.

Rocky Castellani, clever campaigner from Luzavne, Pa., will oppose Pierre Langlois of France for the feature bout at Madison Square Garden tonight. The clash is part of the tournament designed to produce a world middleweight champion, and is scheduled for 12 rounds.

Willa Cather, the American author who died in 1947, is the subject of two books to be published by Knopf on May 9. One is "Willa Cather: A Critical Biography," a work begun by the late E. K. Brown. It was completed by Leon Edel from the notes left by Mr. Brown and with the cooperation of Edith Lewis, Miss Cather's literary executrix and trustee.

Sanitation Commissioner Andrew W. Mulrain announced yesterday that the crews of the three departmental tugboats, strikebound since Monday morning, would be automatically suspended unless they reported for duty today.

Plans for erecting an apartment house at 804-12 Madison Avenue, southwest corner of Sixty-eighth Street, have been announced in connection with the recent purchase of the plot measuring 100 by 95 feet there by the Rockwood Realty Corporation, David Rose, president, in a deal negotiated by Douglas L. Elliman Co., brokers. The property at present contains forty apartments and six stores and was sold by the 812 Madison Avenue Corporation, Jacob A. Barkey, president.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations and of its United Auto Workers Union, said today that President Eisenhower's order reviving the old consumers' price index of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, had been the result of political pressure and did not solve his union's wage contract problem with the automobile industry.
MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 5 -- George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor, predicted today that abolition of Federal wage controls would cause widespread industrial unrest.

A syndicate headed by White, Weld Co. will place on the market today 303,595 of shares of common stock of Canadian Prospect Ltd., a company which holds extensive unproven oil and gas interests in Canada and in several of this country's north central states.

With only two "name" players in the fold -- Catcher Yogi Berra and Infielder Gil McDougald -- the Yankees yesterday came up with their ninth signer, Ewell Blackwell, who, they hope, will become a name player in 1953.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- A substantial delay in Senate confirmation of Dr. James B. Conant to be United States High Commissioner to Germany was forecast today, although any organized opposition seemed to be on the point of collapse.

Richard H. Balch, Democratic state chairman, replied last night to Governor Dewey's Wednesday night speech by declaring that residents of New York City are being "short-changed" by the Dewey Administration and that they are going to be "short-changed" as long as the present top-heavy Republican representation continues in the Legislature.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 5 -- West Germany and Europe must defy the Soviet Union and press forward to the creation of the European Defense Community if the reunification of Germany is to be accomplished, John Foster Dulles, United States Secretary of State, told West German leaders today.

Events today: Philharmonic-Symphony, Efrem Kurtz conducting; Myra Hess, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P. M.; Audrey Kooper, pianist, and Gertrude Prinzi, soprano, Town Hall, 5:30, and "Carmen" at the Metropolitan Opera, 8.

The Advertising Federation of America reached more than 75,000,000 consumers last year in its campaign for a better public understanding of advertising, according to Robert M. Gray, advertising manager of the Esso Standard Oil Company of New Jersey and chairman of the federation, told members in a progress report. All media cooperated, he said.

HOUSTON, Tex., Feb. 5 -- A group headed by Theodore W. Berenson of Boston, Mass., president of Dreyfus Properties, announced plans here today to build a "shopping city" just off the Gulf Freeway, this city's multi-million-dollar super highway.

Albert V. Moore, the late president and director of the Moore-McCormack Lines, Inc., left part of his estate to endow a $500,000 foundation to aid young men training for administrative or operational positions in mercantile shipping.

The season's largest college basketball crowd at Madison Square Garden was treated to a rousing competitive show last night. The 15,482 spectators first saw unbeaten Seton Hall, with big Walt Dukes scoring 25 points, batter down the stubborn resistance of St. Bonaventure, 74 -- 67, for its twenty-second straight victory.

LONDON, Feb. 5 -- After an interval of more than two years, representatives of the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union will meet here tomorrow to resume consideration of a treaty for Austria.

The Texas and Pacific Railway Company last year had a net income of $11,655,792, an increase of $3,146,141 over the $8,509,651 reported for 1951, W. G. Vollmer, president, reported. He said that completion of the dieselization program last April accounted in part for the better showing. Gross revenues were up $6,059,002 to $83,625,516.

The strike by gravediggers and other workers against ten Jewish and non-sectarian cemeteries in Long Island, Westchester County and Brooklyn enters its second month tomorrow with no sign of settlement.

INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Feb. 5 (UP) -- Former President Harry S. Truman told 650 neighbors and old friends tonight that he had been as "thoroughly vilified" as any United States President, with possibly two exceptions, but "I have come through without any scars."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The Army today answered Congressional charges that it had too much "brass" with an assertion that it actually did not have enough officers.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- During the week ended Feb. 4, member bank reserves increased $82,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

CARDINAL SPELLMAN drew a beautiful analogy between baseball and war in a moving speech at the baseball writers' dinner the other night. He spoke feelingly of his impressionistic reaction to seeing troops in Korea silhouetted on a hilltop against a setting sun, their guns slung carelessly on their shoulders in the bat-carrying fashion of kids returning from a ball game.

Four men received prison sentences and two others suspended sentences in Queens County Court yesterday after pleading guilty to grand larceny charges in obtaining fraudulent Federal Housing Administration loans for home improvements.
DURHAM, N. C., Feb. 5 (AP) -- Duke University's Blue Devils scored their fifth straight basketball victory tonight, rallying in the second half to whip New York University, 89 -- 82.

Presiding Justice David W. Peck of the Appellate Division reported last night the courts had made "marked progress" in the last year toward clearing congested calendars of a backlog of personal injury cases.
MOSCOW, Feb. 5 -- Pravda today placed its authoritative stamp of approval on Sergei Prokofieff's long-awaited Seventh Symphony, which it labeled "one of the best of the composer's productions."

The new steelmaking capacity of 117.5 million tons a year of ingots and steel for castings in the United States at the beginning of this year is equivalent to almost three-quarters of a ton for every man, woman and child in the country. The exact figure for a population of over 158 million is 1,483 pounds per capita, the American Iron and Steel Institute said yesterday.

ALBANY, Feb. 5 -- A compromise is being negotiated in the dispute between the Jones Beach Parkway Authority and state officials over a bill to authorize a 10-cent toll on the Southern State Parkway as a means of financing a $40,000,000 parkway improvement program in Nassau County.

THE island of Trinidad (1,863 square miles, population 530,276) lies only ten miles off the coast of Venezuela. Most North Americans, if they know anything about Trinidad, which is unlikely, remember that Columbus discovered it and that he somehow failed to notice the asphalt lake whose mysterious presence is their only other item of Trinidad information.

MOSCOW, Friday, Feb. 6 -- Pravda, newspaper of the Communist party, announced today the arrest of three men and one woman charged with espionage against the Soviet Union. It said the arrests were made by Russian state security organs.
TOKYO, Feb. 5 -- Foreign Minister Katsuo Okazaki said today that Japan had no legal claim to territories she held before World War II, including those now occupied by the Soviet Union.

One of the most highly regarded features of the educational system of this state -- and of many another -- is that school session known as the Snow Day. This is, of course, the session which does not exist. It is the session which is canceled because of snow, ice, power failure or other thoughtful act of a benign Deity.

A syndicate headed by the First Boston Corporation will place on the market today an issue of $15,000,000 in 3 3/8 per cent sinking fund debentures of the Diamond Alkali Company due Feb. 1, 1978 at 101 1/4 to yield about 3.3 per cent.

A syndicate headed by First Boston Corporation placed on the market yesterday afternoon two issues of Miami, Fla., sewer serial and term bonds amounting to $27,100,000. The bonds were sold by negotiation to the banking syndicate at an interest cost of 3.707 per cent to the city.

Directors of the W. A. Sheaffer Pen Company yesterday elected a new president, declared an extra common dividend in addition to the regular quarterly payment and voted a 30 per cent profit-sharing bonus to employes.

William L. Pfeiffer, Republican State Chairman, conferred yesterday with county chairmen of the metropolitan area and set up a "chain of command" system for recommendations for Federal appointments. The meeting was held at state headquarters of the party at 41 East Forty-second Street.
Prospects for the settlement of the port's crippling tugboat strike brightened last night when the disputing parties agreed to resume negotiations at 10 o'clock this morning.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 5 -- William W. Garth, president of the Graphic Arts Research Foundation, announced today that a photoelectric typesetting machine has been completed by Photon, Inc., and ten other machines were now in production.

TORONTO, Feb. 5 -- Canada's first subway, the most talked about construction job in this city's history, is fast nearing completion, and the city's residents will soon be straphanging on one of the world's cheapest rapid transit systems at three rides for a quarter plus unlimited transfer privileges.

Four amendments to curb landlords from receiving rent increases fraudulently were recommended yesterday in a presentment that was handed up by a holdover Kings County grand jury to the Temporary State Housing Commission.

Continuing their seasonal down-trend, business loans by New York banks declined $37,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, bringing the total reduction so far this year to $170,000,000. In the corresponding week a year ago, business loans increased by $11,000,000, although in the first five weeks of 1952 there was a decline of $54,000,000.
LONDON, Feb. 5 -- The British Government published today its plan to carve a new federal union out of Central Africa by conjoining Northern and Southern Rhodesia and Nyasaland.

The great majority of those receiving institutional care at public expense in this state are cared for not in public but in voluntary institutions, State Social Welfare Commissioner Robert T. Lansdale declared yesterday. Without voluntary agencies, public welfare could not carry out its job, he said, adding that the two programs combined served 4,000,000 people annually in this state.

EL PASO, Tex., Feb. 5 (AP) -- Ted Kroll and Chandler Harper, who win enough to be among the "known golfers," carved five-under-par 66's today to lead the first round of the $10,000 El Paso open tourney.

A change in the procurement of tanker tonnage for military service was made possible yesterday at a monthly meeting of the Tankers Requirements Committee of the Voluntary Plan for the Contribution of Tanker Capacity.
The Russians intensified their attempts last week to make the Baltic a Soviet lake.
Striking members of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union, independent, will vote tonight on a proposal to end their eight-day-old walkout against suburban wholesale newspaper distributors.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that department store sales in the week ended Jan. 31 were 2 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year. The following table lists sales in terms of percentage changes from like periods of 1952:
DETROIT, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Thomas J. Riggs Jr. has been named general sales manager of F. L. Jacobs Company, automotive parts concern, it was announced today by James D. Mooney, president.
TOKYO, Friday, Feb. 6 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,517, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M. Friday, Korean time:

The council of the National Academy of Design, acting through its president, Lawrence Grant White, told the Municipal Art Commission in a letter made public yesterday that removal of the sculptures from the parapet of the Appellate Division Building of the Supreme Court would establish "an unfortunate precedent."

HAVANA, Feb. 5 -- The Cuba Cup series of the twenty-second International Star Class regatta was won by James Schoonmaker of Nassau with 22 points when he sailed his yacht, Dingo, across the finish line in third position today in 2 hours 10 minutes 14 seconds.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- An unusual deadlock between the Senate and the House of Representatives arose today over the election of a chairman for the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy. After two meetings its members were unable to agree on a chairman and adjourned until tomorrow afternoon.

PARIS, Feb. 5 -- By masterful cut and manipulation of material so that it stands away from the bust, Christian Dior gives the bosom new emphasis, tailored yet supple. He calls his schematic line the "open tulip."
PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 5 (UP) -- Pat Garner of Midland, Tex., found easy going in two rounds of the Palm Beach women's amateur golf championship today.

President Eisenhower's thinking on foreign affairs, as indicated so far, presents a hopeful prospect for complete review of United States world trade policy to bring about a reduction of obstacles to greater two-way foreign trade, members of the National Council of American Importers were told yesterday at a meeting in the Astor Hotel.

BOSTON, Feb. 5 (UP) -- Johnny Peirson, playing with a mask protecting his broken jaw, paced Boston to a 4-1 victory over Chicago tonight as the Bruins tied the Black Hawks for fourth place in the National Hockey League before 7,132 Boston Garden fans.

LONDON, Feb. 5 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden told the House of Commons today that he saw no reason for panic about United States policy in the Far East. On the contrary, he said, his talks with Secretary of State John Foster Dulles had increased his hopes of continued cooperation with the United States.

After a day of pressure but moderate losses on the New York Stock Exchange, trading gathered momentum in the last hour and prices went back to their levels of Jan. 26. Losses were small but general, but THE NEW YORK TIMES averages registered their biggest losses this year.

The number of personalities, some fairly well known, who have recently made news by virtue of past revenue derelictions may come as a forbidding reminder to many Americans who are now receiving their W2 forms from employers or calling in accountants to look over their books. The practical foolhardiness of stretching exaggeration into falsehood on tax returns is adequately communicated by such ancient sentiments as concern honesty being the best policy and crime not paying.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby, Federal Security Administrator, today announced her first appointment, that of Jack B. Beardwood, former newspaper man, as assistant to the administrator.

DETROIT, Feb. 5 -- Henry Ford 2d, chairman of the Ford Foundation's board of trustees, announced today the appointment of H. Rowan Gaither Jr., a San Francisco lawyer, as acting president of the foundation.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 5 -- United States Ambassador Monnett B. Davis and British Ambassador Sir Francis Evans called today on Foreign Minister Moshe Sharett who explained to them the background of recent incidents on the Israel-Jordanian frontier. The Government announcement said the ambassadors called at Mr. Sharett's request.

OTTAWA, Feb. 5 -- There was warm applause from all parties in the House of Commons this afternoon when Lester B. Pearson, the Secretary for External Affairs, said that the announcement of the "deneutralization" of Formosa was only part of a statement by President Eisenhower that was wise and heartening to all Canadians.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UP) -- The Office of Rent Stabilization announced today that two officials were being suspended for permitting fifty-three employes to collect $95,000 in annual leave payments and then get back on the payroll.

A three-story corrugated metal warehouse in the New York Naval Shipyard, Brooklyn, burned to the ground last night in a spectacular five-alarm fire that was visible from many sections of Brooklyn and mid-Manhattan. The warehouse contained heavy machinery and oil, but no estimate of the loss was available immediately.

Commodity prices closed generally higher yesterday. Volume was light in most lines except for potatoes, which displayed more activity than in over a week, and coffee, which continued at high levels. Coffee, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, wool, lead and tin ended higher. Cocoa was lower and potatoes, sugar, rubber, zinc and hides closed mixed.
TRENTON, Feb. 5 -- The New Jersey Highway Authority told today how it plans to make a paragon of safety of the 165-mile Garden State Parkway through enforced and built-in accident-prevention factors.

Vincent W. Howard has been elected a director of the North American Acceptance Corporation, it was announced yesterday by Randolph C. Fernon, executive vice president of North American. Mr. Howard is vice president of J. G. White Co., Inc.

TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 5 -- Unless somebody -- the Eisenhower Administration, the British or Iranian Premier Mohammed Mossadegh -- can come up with a new idea, the current set of negotiations for the settlement of Iran's oil dispute with Britain may come to naught.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UP) -- Senator Russell B. Long, Democrat of Louisiana, gave the Senate Armed Services Committee a "startling" top-secret report on waste at overseas military bases today and the committee promptly summoned Gen. Omar N. Bradley to "comment."

Some thirty-six years ago President Wilson declared in a moment of justifiable irritation: "The Senate of the United States is the only legislative body in the world which cannot act when its majority is ready for action." In later years the rule to which Mr. Wilson was referring was chiefly used to filibuster against legislation not desired by Southern Senators -- largely measures having to do with civil rights.
Prices on several beef cuts dropped sharply this week as supplies continued to arrive in record quantities.

A recent news item reported that the on-time performance index of the Long Island Rail Road for December was 98.64. I would like to protest the repetition of this statistical hoax which has repeatedly attempted to mislead the public over the years.

HO, Togoland, Feb. 5 -- One of the most important American influences in sub-Sahara Africa -- and certainly the most selfless -- is that of the hundreds of missionaries sent out by United States churches to help the inhabitants of backward areas. Every year thousands of dollars are spent in remote corners of this huge continent by representatives of American congregations seeking to improve the lot of unfortunate people.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 5 -- The expanding economy of West Germany is absorbing the younger generations at a rate that is regarded as one of the most significant indications of the stability achieved in the brief span of the Federal Republic's existence.
A three-judge statutory court ruled by a 2-to-1 decision here yesterday that radio and television stations can broadcast giveaway programs so long as they are clearly not lotteries.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Carroll E. Mealey and his wife spent $40,897 more than their visible income while he was Deputy Commissioner of Internal Revenue and still were able to double the family's capital assets, according to evidence taken today in a Congressional investigation.
ALBANY, Feb. 5 (UP) -- The New York State Savings Bank Association denied today that the controversial branch bank bill would have an "adverse effect on any segment of the banking industry."

House-to-house merchandisers, distributors and retailers were warned yesterday against a "tiny minority" of door-to-door salesmen whose unethical practices may well bring legislative curbs on the entire direct selling industry. The warning was sounded at a dinner in the New Yorker Hotel by Kenneth B. Willson, president of the National Better Business Bureau.
Persistent violations of traffic regulations attributed to automobiles bearing United Nations insignias have brought a second protest from the Thirty-fourth Street Midtown Association.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Feb. 5 (AP) -- New York and New England dairy farmers are taking steps to avert a threatened $6,000,000 income slash during the first half of this year.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Feb. 5 -- President Chiang Kai-shek's Government has been asked by the United States for its agreement on the appointment of Karl L. Rankin as Washington's Ambassador to the Republic of China. Swift approval by the Nationalist Foreign Ministry was expected here.

COLD SPRING, N. Y., Feb. 5 -- The New York Trap Rock Corporation announced today that it planned to abandon a huge stone-crushing plant near here, thereby eliminating the threat of further defacement of Mount Taurus on the east bank of the Hudson River, in the historic Highlands.
The motion picture industry, with an eye on the potentialities of three-dimensional films as an international entertainment, is seeking standardization and interchangeability of the processes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The Senate Investigating subcommittee, looking into alleged disappearances of "derogatory" information from State Department security and personnel files, today served notice on the Executive Branch of the Government that it would not tolerate any "tampering" with witnesses by their superior officers.

For nearly six years now the Western Powers have never given up prodding Soviet Russia for a treaty for Austria. To date 258 meetings have been held on this issue, and every time the negotiations have seemed on the verge of success the Soviet representative has introduced a new question that started the argument all over again.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Feb. 5 -- The Netherlands began to get her five-day-old flood, the worst in five centuries, under control today and immediately turned her attention to reconstruction.

Governor Dewey has restated some ancient truths about government and taxation and exploded the fallacy that federal aid or state aid means getting something for nothing. Government does not create wealth, the Governor reminds us. "We should not try to deceive the people that there are painless ways of solving revenue problems.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) -- President Eisenhower talked for forty-five minutes today with American Medical Association leaders, but no one would say what they had discussed.

HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 5 -- On the eve of the forty-third annual Dartmouth winter carnival, the committee seemed in agreement tonight that at least one statue along fraternity row could be erected with the suggested theme: "More snow."

Kinsey M. Robinson, president of the Washington Water Power Company and an outstanding advocate of private enterprise in the Pacific Northwest, is ready to "put the chips on the line" today in his offer to merge with, or buy out, the Puget Sound Power and Light Company.

In the upstairs galleries at Knoedler's is a small number of sketches by Toulouse-Lautrec, mostly heads verging toward caricature, on-the-spot jottings-down of motifs to be used more importantly later on. They are shown alongside some of his commercial posters, made for Paris cafes, and one which was to be used to advertise an ink factory in Cincinnati.

Three public school teachers who were suspended last Friday for failing to answer questions concerning membership in the Communist party appeared before the Board of Education yesterday and challenged its right to question or suspend them, A sympathetic audience of about 100 persons applauded loudly at each defiance.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Two War Claims commissioners proposed today that Congress enlarge the payment of Americans' World War II claims by using $34,000,000 in seized funds of three Russian satellites -- Bulgaria, Hungary and Rumania -- and adding $161,000,000 in new appropriations.
WOESNDRECHT AIRBASE, the Netherlands, Feb. 5 -- First Lieut. Kenneth Coble of the United States Air Force, listed as missing last night, showed up here this morning, ready to go again.

LOWELL, Mass., Feb. 5 -- Massachusetts fire prevention authorities this afternoon began an investigation of a flash fire at Lowell State Teachers College this morning that sent thirty-nine students to hospitals, where thirteen were held for further treatment for second and third degree burns.
MIAMI, Feb. 5 -- "I don't know how well he'll go," said Horatio Luro, "because a big spider bit him last night, and I had to put epsom salts on him."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The statement by Foreign Secretary Eden in the House of Commons today that, in view of the 128,000 casualties on our side in Korea, the "restraint" of the American people has been "quite remarkable" was in answer to a suggestion by the Opposition orator, Herbert Morrison, that "profound hatred of communism" has led Americans to support risky policies in the Far East.

ASBURY PARK, Feb. 5 -- Day-care centers must give more than the educational experiences usually found in the short day nursery school or kindergarten, according to Miss Claire Coble, assistant director of the Division of Day Care, Department of Welfare, New York.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 6 -By a 9 to 1 vote ratio the Screen Writers Guild has elected to cancel the organization's long-pending "blacklist" court action against the Motion Pictures Association of America. The membership voted on the controversial issue by mail ballot. The result were tabulated last night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- An anti-snoring device, consisting of a sheet of plastic to be inserted in the mouth at bedtime, was patented this week by Elsa L. Peppich of Seattle. The dam, as the inventor calls it, effectively stops mouth-breathing, giving the wearer a choice of either breathing through his nose or not at all.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Feb. 6 -- The flood-ravaged Netherlands sadly asked Secretary of State John Foster Dulles and Harold E. Stassen, Mutual Security Director, today to put her back on the United States aid list, from which she had crossed herself off only last week.

PARIS, Feb. 6 -- The evening scene at Pierre Balmain's opening was worthy of the great European palaces -- Buckingham, Escurial, Versaille -- whose names he has given to magnificent ball gowns. Dedicated to the coronation, the gowns are shown with sparkling tiaras, or little coronets mounted on velvet, and shoulder-high white kid loves.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 6 -- The Republic of Korea's shattered economy will require $1,750,000,000 in outside aid in the next seven years to meet its needs, according to a report issued here tonight.

There are rational arguments for and against progressive education, and reasonable people can and do differ over the pros and cons. But one of the most ill-founded arguments against progressive education is the argument that it leads to, or is a tool of, or is somehow connected in a sinister way with, communism.

CAIRO, Feb. 6 -- Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib, Premier of Egypt, and British Ambassador Sir Ralph Stevenson met here today, together with their respective advisers, to resume talks on the future of the Anglo-Egyptian Sudan.
DUBLIN, Feb. 6 (AP) -- A horse set the stage tonight for an all out fight in the Irish Republic Parliament.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb 6 -- Greece, Turkey and Yugoslavia have abandoned the idea of signing a written treaty of military alliance and will content themselves with a written treaty of friendship and mutual assistance, including presumably military assistance.
On only one think was there agreement last night in the middleweight championship elimination bout in Madison Square Garden.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 6 -- Armed with a letter from President Eisenhower emphasizing the importance of German rearmament to Europe's defense, Chancellor Konrad Adenauer appealed to his countrymen today for swift and positive action on the Allied-German treaty system.

CHICAGO, Feb. 6 -- What seemed to be a spontaneous desire to get out from under on the part of bulls in grain and soybeans started the most drastic break of the season today. For a time, long lines in all pits were spilled overboard without regard to price, and any small recoveries appeared to be the result of short-covering from time to time, rather than of any general demand.
EL PASO, Tex., Feb. 6 (AP) -Jack Burke used an old putter effectively today to take the lead in the $10,000 El Paso open golf tournament with 136 for thirty-six holes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr., Democrat of Manhattan, acting on information given him by his wife, Hazel Scott, a concert pianist, protested today what he said was segregation of Negro patients in veteran hospitals in Nashville and Murfreesboro, Tenn.
Netherlands Fashions, Inc., one of the first importers of women's coats from Holand, will double its sales of Dutch apparel in the United States this year, according to Bertram Zuckerman, president.

There are two items in the paper of Feb. 3 which seem to indicate a basic change in our foreign policy and which may bode evil for the future of the world. The first is from the President's State of the Union message: "We have learned that the free world cannot indefinitely remain in a posture of paralyzed tension.

A wounded Korean veteran joined New York State employes yesterday in their annual blood donations to the American Red Cross. Nearly 200 pints of blood were donated in the five hours that the Red Cross Bloodmobile visited the State Office Building at 80 Centre Street.

A Port of New York Authority policeman jumped over one of the railings of the George Washington Bridge at 3:55 P. M. yesterday and, while hanging-onto the structure with one hand, pushed a would-be jumper back onto the span.

A committee of lawyers reported yesterday that the Legislature at its last session had made "some modest gains" in meeting demands from bar and public for more adequate consideration of important measures, but that "sorely needed improvements" should be undertaken at the present session.

MIAMI, Feb. 6 -- The chief bit of business before the house at Hialeah Race Course tomorrow will be the eighteenth running of the mile-and-a-furlong McLennan Handicap. It should be a great horse race.

HAVANA, Feb. 6 -- The Cuban skippers today won their race against a foreign team, 55 points to 49, in the last event of the Twenty-second International Star Class Regatta. Seven entries from each team sailed a course that was three times around a triangle for a total of ten miles.

General Sessions Judge Francis L. Valente yesterday halted the trial of Minot Frazier (Mickey) Jelke 3d on a nine-count indictment charging compulsory prostitution, living off the proceeds of vice, and conspiracy, to take under consideration a request that the public and the press be excluded from the courtroom.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy was deadlocked aga' today on the selection of a chairman and deferred further discussion to "a later date."

The instant case is that of twenty-seven crewmen on three tugboats of the Department of Sanitation who have been absent from work since last Monday morning, along with other striking tugboat workers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Chief Judge Bolitha J. Laws of the Federal District Court today set May 11 as the tentative date for the trial of Prof. Owen Lattimore on perjury charges. The judge said that if there was undue delay in disposing of expected defense motions, it might be necessary to fix a later date for the trial.

Commodity prices closed mixed on local exchanges yesterday as volume improved generally. Coffee continued active and trading in domestic sugar, cottonseed oil potatoes and cocoa was the highest for the year. Rubber had its smallest volume for the year.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 6 -- President Eisenhower's plan to give industry representation in the Labor Department brought from the American Federation of Labor today a suggestion that labor be represented in the Commerce Department.

Representative Clifford P. Case of Union County announced yesterday he was a candidate for Governor of New Jersey. Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll had announced last month he would not seek a third term.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Under direction of the White House, the Office of Price Stabilization today removed a major segment of consumer goods from price controls.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -Following is the 64-to-16 vote by which the Senate rejected today a proposal to let a simple majority of the Senate or House veto any reorganization plan sent up by President Eisenhower under a two-year extension of such powers:

BONN, Germany, Feb. 6 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's electoral draft law, designed to consolidate the chances of his middle-of-the-road coalition for victory in the forthcoming general elections received a slight setback today in the Bundesrat or upper house, of the federal parliament.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., Feb. 6 -- Are foster homes the beginning of an answer to the adoptive placement of the "hard-to-place" child? Members of the Child Welfare League of America attending the Eastern Regional Conference were asked this question here today.

The Brooklyn rackets grand jury, in a scorching criticism of police laxity, demanded yesterday that Commissioner George P. Monaghan punish high-ranking officials of plainclothes commands who have "tolerated or encouraged" continued ties between gamblers and policemen.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- President Eisenhower suspended all Government controls on wages and salaries today and decontrolled a long list of consumer goods, including meat, furniture, clothing, nearly all the items normally sold in department stores and meals and drinks sold in restaurants and bars.
LONDON, Feb. 6 -- The Government announced today that the aristocracy could use art works to pay off their taxes in the future.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UP) -The Senate confirmed today the nomination of four Defense Department officials and four directors of the Commodity Credit Corporation.
The Hempstead High School music department will present its twenty-second annual winter concerts on Saturday evening. Feb. 14, and Sunday afternoon, Feb. 15, at Hofstra College.

" It's Worth Knowing," produced in cooperation with the National Education Association, will mark its first anniversary this afternoon at 3 o'clock over Channel 2 when the program will be devoted to ethnic dance.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Senate Democrats today assailed the "implications" of the Eisenhower Administration's new Formosa policy and called on the President to tell this country and its allies how far the United States would go in military support of the Chinese Nationalists.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 6 (AP) -- A contract dispute involving the boy who recorded "I Saw Mommy Kissing Santa Claus," has been settled out of court.

The Federal Government failed last night in an effort to end the six-day-old tug strike in the Port of New York, when the employers rejected a proposal to submit the wage contract dispute to a special fact-finding panel.

Charles H. Tuttle, chief counsel from 1926 until last April for a Greater New York committee in defense of released time religious education, will receive a citation next Wednesday for his services. The award will be made at a dinner to be held at the Mount Washington Methodist Church in Chicago.
City and state mediation board officials failed last night in their attempt to end a month-old strike of gravediggers.

EASTERN FRONT, Korea, Saturday, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, the Eighth Army's incoming commander, had plane trouble and Gen. James A. Van Fleet, retiring commander, got his first seventeen-gun salute as they began their joint tour of the Korean battle front today. General Taylor will succeed General Van Fleet on Wednesday.
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady yesterday, 2 to 13 points net lower than on Thursday, with near months showing the greatest weakness.
LONDON, Feb. 6 -- Temporarily reassuring news for flood victims was contained in two Government announcements today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.2 per cent in the week ending on Tuesday to 109.3 per cent of the 1947-49 average, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Farm products dropped 1.2 per cent, chiefly because of lower prices of fresh fruits and vegetables, livestock and eggs.

PARIS, Feb. 1 -- It comes as a pleasant shock to the directors of Paris' municipal services to hear from visitors from New York that streets are cleaner here, and that traffic moves more rapidly and freely than in New York.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 6 (AP) -Betsy Rawls, Spartanburg, S. C., professional, carded a 36, 36 -- 72 today to lead the field as play opened in the 54-hole $3.500 women's invitation open golf tournament at the Bay Shore Country Club.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Vladimir I. Toumanoff, a 29-year-old Foreign Service personnel official, defended before the Senate Investigating subcommittee today the State Department's practice of keeping the board that recommended promotions and pay rises ignorant of derogatory information -- including that concerning homosexuality -- on those under consideration for advancement.

Because ordinary nails exposed to the weather fall apart with rust a new and steadily more important industry -- nails that won't rust -- has sprung up in recent years. Leaders in the making of aluminum nails, believe that volume will come to $10,000,000 annually in three years or so if supply and production equipment are available.

PARIS, Feb. 6 -- France's budget for 1953 was assured tonight when the National Assembly passed the financing bill on the second and final reading by a vote of 415 to 205. Only the Communists and Socialists opposed.

SANTA FE, N. M., Feb. 6 (AP) -- A spokesman for Patrick J. Hurley, Republican, whose election contest with Senator Dennis Chavez, Democrat of New Mexico, is to be investigated by a United States Senate subcommittee, asserted tonight that ballots vital to the investigation had been burned in three counties.

A Tokay wine from Hungary of the vintage of 1876 is a delightful curiosity on view, and what is more to the point perhaps, on sale at Lehmann's. The Park Avenue wine shop acquired this rarity when the estate of the widow of the original importer was liquidated.
The scheduled week's engagement of Charles Chaplin's "Limelight" in metropolitan theatres of the R. K. O. circuit will be played through in only eight of the houses.
