SAIGON Vietnam, Feb. 6 -- The French High Command for Indo-China announced tonight that the Quinhon bridgehead had been evacuated last night and today. The re-embarkation was accomplished systematically without opposition from the Communist-led Vietminh. In fact, the Vietminh deliberately allowed the French to leave.
Memberships in the New York Stock Exchange have been transferred from David B. Bandler to David Weinberg and from Barnett Faroll to Joseph Klein.

HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 6 -- With disqualifications marring the cross-country race, Dartmouth's ski team gained the lead at the completion of the opening day's program of the forty-third Winter Carnival.

WILLEMSTAD, Curacao, Feb. 6 -- The population of this little Dutch island has raised more than $250,000 in contributions for flood relief in the Netherlands and dispatched it today, members of a relief committee here said. This represents nearly $2.50 per capita of Curacao's population.
The Motion Picture Chapter of the American Veterans Committee strongly supports your editorial comments on "Limelight" and the American Legion's efforts to forestall the exhibition of this film.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 6 -A San Francisco orchestra audience was silently reproved twice this afternoon by Victor de Sabata the guest conductor, during the playing of Brahms' Third Symphony.

An appeal through the press was made yesterday by the office of District Attorney T. Vincent Quinn of Queens for an anonymous letterwriter to come through with "proof" of sewer scandals, which he had promised "if you ask for it in the newspaper."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- President Eisenhower appointed a Cabinet committee today to speed American aid to the storm-stricken people of Britain and Western Europe.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -Charles E. Shaver, former counsel of the Senate Small Business Committee, today was fined $1,000 and drew a suspended prison sentence for accepting money to influence Reconstruction Finance Corporation loans. He pleaded guilty early last month.
HAMMOND, La., Feb. 6 (AP) -Three women were killed and several persons injured by a tornado that struck this general area about 1 P. M. today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 6 -- Mrs. Oswald B. Lord paid a call today at United Nations headquarters, where she is soon to take up her new duties as United States representative to the Human Rights Commission.

Playing four-hand piano music is one of the most relaxing and entertaining forms of musical endeavor, and certainly the most companionable. The art is not as popular as it used to be in pregramophone and radio days, when stumbling through a four-hand reduction of a symphony or chamber work was the best way for an amateur or music lover to become familiar with it.

Edward Choate and George Ross are planning to present the thriller, "Murder Mistaken" on Broad-way in mid-October after a spring tryout run in San Francisco. Their production of the play, which has been a London hit since it opened in the West End in October, may have a cast including David Wayne and Alexis Smith.

SEWANEE, Tenn., Feb. 6--A new dean and four faculty members for the University of the South's School of Theology were chosen today as replacements for part of the group of Protestant Episcopal clergymen who resigned their academic positions last November in protest against a ban on the admission of Negro seminarians.

HAMILTON, N. Y., Feb. 6 -- Holy Cross staved off a last-quarter rally tonight to defeat Colgate's basketball team, 65 -- 54, after taking the lead from the home forces midway through the second quarter.

With volume rising on the setbacks, prices on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday suffered the sharpest break since mid-October. THE NEW YORK TIMES combined average of fifty stocks at its 189.90-point low for the day was at a new low for 1953.

DeFord C. Mills and Richard Kimball have been elected partners in Cresap, McCormick Paget, management consultants.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The Senate Committee on Government Operations, headed by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, obtained authority from President Eisenhower today to scrutinize confidential tax returns in a hunt for graft and influence peddling in the Government.
Audrey Kooper, pianist, and Gertrude Prinzi, soprano, winners of the annual Debut Award of the New York Madrigal Society, made their appearance in a joint recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall.

TEL AVIV, Feb. 6 -- Israelis who for several weeks have been indignant over thefts and crimes of violence committed by Jordanian Arab infiltrators, were dismayed to read in their papers today that, according to a British Foreign Office spokesman, Britain had conveyed to Israel a "warning" to avoid incidents along the Israeli-Jordanian border.

Cardinal Hayes recent winner of the New York University interscholastic meet, last night scored 42 points to win the fifth annual Bronx - Manhattan - Westchester Catholic High School track and field title at the Kingsbridge Armory, Bronx.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 6 -- The Communist party is one of four political organizations recognized by the Election Commission as "national parties" for the purpose of allotting ballot symbols on an all-India basis, it was officially announced today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 6--The American Library Association announced today its list of "Notable Books of 1952." Issued annually since 1944, the list, containing fifty-three titles, is intended to provide adult readers with "recommendations for good reading of a broad and general character."

ALBANY, Feb. 6 -- The State Banking Department announced today that the plan of merger of the Bayside National Bank of New York, Bayside, Queens, into the Bankers Trust Company, 16 Wall Street, New York, was filed. Bankers Trust received approval for a certificate of increase of capial stock from $30,000,000 consisting of 3,000,000 shares of $10 each par value, to $30,512,000, consisting of 3,051,200 shares of the same par value.

Forty-two split-level dwellings are planned by Sam Grossman for his Manchester Park Homes development on a sixteen-acre tract in Seaford, L. I., where a furnished model is on display. Karl Bloch is the architect and Trylon Realty is handling sales.

BONN, Feb. 6 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer and the minister presidents of nine states of West Germany agreed tonight on a number of urgent measures to relieve the pressure of refugees from East Germany on the West's sectors of Berlin.

The congratulations of New Yorkers without exception, we feel, will go to the Children's Aid Society as it celebrates its 100th anniversary year of service to children. An undisputed leader in the field of child care, the society never has lost sight of its original principle that its young wards should be treated as individuals.

A smoldering fire in a forward hold of the Chilean Line freighter Aconcagua, inbound from Hamburg, Germany, was brought under control by city firemen at 3:45 P. M. yesterday as the ship lay at anchor in a remote part of Gravesend Bay.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 6 -- The Eisenhower Administration is planning a long-range program to train and equip the ground forces of those Asian countries that wish to participate in the common defense of the area against Communist aggression.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Throughout the 1951-1952 crop year, 15,572,835 metric tons of wheat and wheat flour, or 572,203,733 bushels, were bought and sold under the International Wheat Agreement, the international wheat council reported today. The figure amounted to 98.5 per cent of the total guaranteed for sale and purchase under the agreement.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UP) -- The Federal Government collected $68,502,564,268 in taxes during the last calendar year, a record total, it was shown today by statistics of the Bureau of Internal Revenue.

THE so-called "deer of either sex" season held in a number of counties during the past fall brought forth considerable comment of a very heated nature in some areas, especially in Greene and Delaware Counties, and a bill ha been introduced which would prevent the future shooting of antlerless deer in those sections.

With farmers caught in the squeeze between falling prices for their products and rising costs of machinery, the makers of farm equipment are facing a hard selling period this year. Consequently, spokesmen for the industry predict a considerable increase in ad budgets and more sales effort than has been exerted in some years.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The Senate confirmed today Gen. Walter Bedell Smith to be Under Secretary of State and Dr. James Bryant Conant to be United States High Commissioner for Germany.
LONDON, Feb. 6 -- The continued strength of sterling helped most sections of the stock market to make slight advances today despite slackening of business before the week-end.

It is appropriate that the first annual Albert Lasker Award of the Albert and Mary Lasker Foundation and the American Heart Association should have been given this week to Dr. Paul Dudley White of Boston. The award is for "distinguished achievement in the field of cardiovascular disease," a field in which Dr. White has been a pioneer for more than thirty years.
Both sides rested yesterday in the Federal Court treason trial of John David Provoo, former Army sergeant, and the case is expected to go to the jury on Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Francis White of Baltimore, who was an Assistant Secretary of State in the Hoover Administration, is slated to become Ambassador to Mexico in succession to William O'Dwyer.
TOKYO, Saturday, Feb. 7--Heavy clouds stalled the air war over North Korea yesterday. Along the 155-mile battlefront only minor clashes were fought by patrols in No Man's Land.

I was born and have lived for some thirty-odd years in the worst slum area of its kind in the nation today -- Harlem, New York City. All I have seen in this period of time is general decay and overcrowding. There are hundreds of decayed boarded-up apartment and residential buildings in Harlem that have been standing like this for the past twenty years.

President Eisenhower put into execution yesterday an adage with which it might be a good idea for all of us to refresh ourselves, because the evidence to date suggests we're going to see a good deal of it in the next four years. That is the adage that the way to begin is to begin.

GUATEMALA, Feb. 6 -- Arturo Herbruger, the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court, and three associate justices were removed from office today by a vote of 41 to 9 in a special session of Congress that ended at 1 A. M. The justices all had signed an opinion granting an injunction to Ernesto Leal Perez against the seizure of his farm.

Mal Whitfield, Horace Ashenfelter and Fred Dwyer are favored in the spotlighted cup-racing features of the New York Athletic Club's eighty-fifth anniversary games, which will bring out the track and field set in full force at Madison Square Garden tonight.

Young matrons headed by Mrs. Huntington Lyman and including Mrs. George S. Johnston Jr., have been holding meetings recently at the Ambassador to further plans for the recital to be given by Anna Russell, singing comedienne, on April 23 at the Town Hall for the benefit of the Third Street Music School Settlement. Mrs. John L. Tonnele is chairman, and Mrs. Cyrus McCormick, co-chairman of the executive committee for the benefit.

Two 4-year-old Yonkers boys wandered down the New York Central's tracks near the city for more than a mile yesterday and were sitting between the rails, playing happily, when a south-bound passenger train bore down on them. Two hours later, unharmed, they were home.

DOBBS FERRY, N. Y. Feb. 6 -- The removal of the Children's Village, an institution for 400 unadjusted boys, from the 250 acres it has occupied here since 1905 and the development of new buildings on some site upstate would cost $3,500,000 to $5,000,000, officials of Dobbs Ferry and neighboring villages were told today by Frederick W. Ecker, board president of the institution.

For the second time in her sixteen-year career, the 81,237-ton Cunard liner Queen Mary ran the gantlet of a tugboat strike and docked safely under her own power yesterday at her West Fiftieth Street pier.

PARIS, Feb. 6 -- No evidence of sabotage was discovered in connection with the breakdowns experienced by the French Line ship Flandre during her maiden voyage to New York last July, a special investigating committee reported today.

PARIS, Feb. 6 -- Premier Rene Mayer. Foreign Minister Georges Bidault and Defense Minister Rene Pleven conferred today with leading Cabinet members and technicians to prepare the drafts of the additional protocols interpreting the European army treaty that will be submitted to the French Parliament and to the five other signatory nations.

JERSEY CITY, Feb. 6 -- Nelson F. Stamler, former New Jersey deputy attorney general, and a former investigator into Bergen County crime and gambling, was closeted for one hour and fifty minutes today with a new Hudson County special grand jury charged with the investigation into waterfront lawlessness here.

Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley was accused yesterday of planning to turn First and Second Avenues into race courses to the detriment of commercial interests. The charge was made by the Lexington-First Avenue Association in a protest against restrictive traffic regulations that go into effect on these thoroughfares Monday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Charges of income tax evasion against Carroll L. Healey, former Deputy Commissioner of Internal Revenue, have been forwarded to the United States Attorney at Albany for prosecution.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 6 -- The fear of being different was deplored here tonight by Rabbi Ira Eisenstein, president of the Rabbinical Assembly of America, as this nation's most serious menace from within.
Let's hope no insinuations are intended, but the new Republican Secretary of the Treasury is having the nation's gold bullion checked to be sure there's as much of it as the books indicate.

ELMONT, L. I., Feb. 6 -- Three young children drowned in the icy waters of a sand pit pond here today when they slipped off a floating plank on which they had been playing. The tragedy occurred shortly after 5 P. M.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Lieut. Gen. Anthony J. McAuliffe today was named to succeed Lieut Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, the new Eighth Army commander in Korea, as Deputy Chief of Staff for Operation and Administration of the Army.

Great Britain is making available to the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development nearly three-fourths of its sterling subscription to the Bank, thus widening substantially the Bank's ability to extend sterling and other non-dollar credits in soft-currency areas unable to make repayment in dollars.

TOKYO, Saturday, Feb. 7 (AP) -- The Communists' Pyongyang radio said today Premier Kim Il Sung, supreme commander of the North Korean Army, had been promoted to generalissimo. The broadcast, heard here, said promotion of the 41-year-old Communist chieftain marked the fifth anniversary of the Korean Red Army.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UP) -- A House Agriculture subcommittee urged the Army today to step up beef purchases to bolster sagging cattle prices, and a member said officials had promised to "look into the possibility."
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 6 (UP) -- Bob Bragan tonight was named player-manager of the Pacific Coast League Hollywood Stars, succeeding Fred Haney, who moved up to the Pirates.
CHICAGO, Feb. 6 (UP) -- Butchers are not planning any immediate mark-up in their meat prices following the end of controls, a spot check indicated today.

Given a beautiful play and a sensitive performance, the Equity Library Community series has begun its fourth season in fine fettle. The play is Eugene O'Neill's "Ah, Wilderness!" which had the first of two performances last evening at the DeWitt Clinton Community Center in the Bronx. It will be repeated next Friday and Saturday at the Bryant Youth Center in Long Island City.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, has called on the armed services to make a thorough review of all planned construction and all projects that are in early stages. He has also instructed the services to hold down the employment of civilians and to halt further staffing of headquarters.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 6 -- Fresh from one controversy over his painting, Diego Rivera has run into a new and even more bitter one with an outdoor mural he is finishing on the front of a new Mexico City theatre.
The big contest announcement said: "This mink coat can be yours."

Business leaders were almost unanimous yesterday in assertion that the man in the street need not world about immediate price increases now that President Eisenhower has exempted many items. Some were not so sure about the future if wages and the cost of basic materials, particularly steel, went up.

President Eisenhower's extensive travel by air prior to his inauguration indicates that the use of aircraft as the prime means of Presidential transportation will be continued. Although the late Franklin D. Roosevelt was the first President to take advantage of air travel, it is Harry S. Truman who will be remembered as the President who really took to the air.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Feb. 6 (AP) -Federal Judge Roger Foley warned all persons in his courtroom today not to make faces or gestures that might tend to influence the jury trying a $225,000 damage suit against Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat of Nevada, and a score of gambling casinos.
A proposal to merge Jim Brown Stores, Inc., with Bearing Specialists, Inc., will be acted upon by stockholders of Jim Brown Stores at a special meeting called for Feb. 26.

The world champion Yankees signed two players yesterday but the move came strictly under the classification of "dealing in futures." The prospects are Harry Schaeffer, a southpaw pitcher, and Art Schult, an untried rookie outfielder.
It was with great interest that I read Jay Walz' article of Jan. 26, "Project Restores Old Byzantine Art."

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 6 -- American Federation of Labor leaders expressed gratification today at President Eisenhower's decision. The reaction of members of the federation's executive council, holding their midwinter meeting here, was that there was no point to keeping controls in force after the President had announced he intended to let them die when the Defense Production Act expired April 30.

Among the art exhibitions opening this week is one of drawings by seven artists at the Midtown Gallery. Isabel Bishop's figures fall between being slices of metropolitan life and carfeully posed studies. Emlen Etting is more economical with his means and catches in fluid line some lively moments of dancing by the Sadlers Wells Company.

With all due respect to Commissioner Goodhue Livingston's recent letter, one must not forget the public's burden of responsibility for civic improvement. There is a common tendency these days to assume that all defects are in the system and that names have magical properties.

Secretary of Agriculture Benson has thrown some light on his own, and presumably the new Administration's, attitude toward farm price support policy. In formulating long-term policy on this matter, he said, he views farm price supports primarily as a means for disaster prevention.
The installation of the Rev. G. Barrett Rich 3d as pastor of the Olmstead Avenue Presbyterian Church, 1235 Olmstead Avenue, the Bronx, took place last night.

Bank Boards, Then School Boards January is the month of the annual meetings of banks and their stockholders, when directors are elected and the earnings are scrutinized. February brings -- to communities in a large part of this metropolitan area, at least -- the school board elections and all the wholesome, democratic excitement that these stir up.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The Senate, by voice vote, passed and sent to the White House today a bill to grant President Eisenhower the same powers to reorganize the executive branch of the Government as President Truman had enjoyed during most of his time in the White House. The authority would extend to April 1, 1955.
INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 6 (AP) -Sweetwater Clifton and Vince Boryla led the New York Knickerbockers to an 84-73 victory over the Indianapolis Olympians tonight.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Feb. 6 -- Immediate reforestation of 2,000,000 acres of New York State lands was urged by M. N. Taylor, Wisconsin conservationist and executive director of "Trees of Tomorrow," in an address before the 101st annual meeting of the New York Press Association today.

Lost sight of in the churning backwash of Secretary Dulles' trip to the capitals of Western Europe, the Governments of Yugoslavia, Greece and Turkey are engaged in a little quiet fence-building of their own. Actually the enterprise makes a good deal of noise in the capitals directly concerned and raises echoes as far east and west as Moscow and Rome.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 6 -- Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd plans another South Pole expedition to seek natural resources and study weather conditions to help train American soldiers to fight in polar areas.

Recommendations that academic credits be given in Catholic high schools for some extra-curricula activities, such as outside oratorical and poetry contests, were the subjects of panel discussions yesterday at the Ninth Annual Institute for Religious Teachers held at the Cardinal Hayes High School, 650 Grand Concourse, the Bronx.

Members of the Newspaper Mail Deliverers Union, independent, rejected last night a recommendation by their executive board to end their nine-day strike against suburban wholesale newspaper and magazine distributors.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 6 -- Dr. Gerald Wendt, head of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization's science teaching program, said today that requests from member states for help in introducing modern science in primary and elementary schools increased notably during the last year.

The completion of the installation of a new street lighting system in Pittsburgh is demonstrating how a municipal government made use of life insurance company investment money to finance the capital improvement on the installment plan, instead of through issuance of bonds.
Three persons were injured slightly at 7:50 o'clock last night when a Northeast Airlines Convair sped off a runway at LaGuardia Airport, swung around and ripped off a wing.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UP) -Edwin D. Dupree Jr., general counsel of the Office of Rent Stabilization, was suspended today, effective Monday, for alleged participation in a discharge-and-rehire scheme involving about $95,000. He was the third agency employe suspended since the alleged scheme was revealed by Senator John J. Williams, Republican of Delaware, in a Senate speech Wednesday.
LONDON, Feb. 6 -- The Soviet Union showed itself today just as determined as ever to prevent a treaty restoring Austrian independence.

Advocates of public power received a serious setback yesterday. A special committee of stockholders of the Puget Sound Power and Light Company favored a merger with the Washington Water Power Company. The companies are leading producers of electricity in the Pacific Northwest.

The apartment house for four families at 365-67 East Seventy-sixth Street has been sold for cash by the Elfred Realty Company to Harvey E. Regan, an investor, who insured title with the Lawyers Mortgage and Title Company. The tax valuation is $84,000.

The United Nations is a free association of states and not a cell of world government, Dr. Benjamin Cohen, Assistant Secretary General in charge of the Department of Public Information of the United Nations, told the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs yesterday.

With New York's 300th anniversary in the limelight, the history of the early community and its development as evidenced in relics of the past is being stressed in the city's museum's and other institutions.

The International Shoe Company, which last week announced plans to buy the Florsheim Shoe Company, yesterday reported consolidated net earnings of $8,286,892 for the year ended last Nov. 30. For the first time, the company's profits were consolidated with all of its subsidiaries.

" Evolution in Action," a new work by Julian Huxley, will be issued Feb. 18 by Harper. The biologist takes a look at the two thousand million years of biological evolution, the process that has resulted in modern man. He concludes that "the progress of biological evolution is finished," and that now it is up to man to direct his own development.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- The Army issued a draft call today for 53,000 men in April, the same as that issued for March. Only the Army is drafting soldiers now. Today's call brings to 1,361,430 the number of men drafted or earmarked for induction since September. 1950.
ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 6 -- President Eisenhower was warned today by the National Lutheran Council that it would oppose "with all possible vigor" the appointment of an Ambassador to the Vatican.

It is next to impossible to convince anybody who is looking down a traffic-clogged, refuse-littered street in New York that the gridiron pattern of avenues and crossroads was laid out for the "public convenience and benefit and, in particular to promote the health of the city."

The four-story apartment house accommodating twenty families at 580 East Twenty-second Street in Brooklyn has been acquired for investment by Jaypol Associates, Inc., represented by Theodore M. Rogers, attorney. Sandra Gnazida and Herman Ginsberg were the sellers.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Feb. 6 -- Stockholders of Doehler-Jarvis Corporation, which has die-casting plating and metal polishing plants in Grand Rapids, Chicago, Toledo, Bativia, N. Y., and Pottstown, Pa., voted at a special meeting here for a merger with National Lead Company, according to an announcement by F. J. Koegler of New York, president of Doehler-Jarvis.
MINEOLA, L. I., Feb. 6 -- Three former employes of the Office of Price Stabilization were acquitted on extortion charges by a Nassau County jury tonight.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Feb. 6--After fifty minutes' deliberation, a jury in Westchester County Court here this afternoon convicted Stanley La Benskey of Yonkers, former Westchester County parkway patrolman, on two charges of illegally possessing firearms. He was remanded to the county jail pending sentence by Judge John P. Donohoe.
BONN, Germany, Feb. 6 -- They Free Democratic party wants to attract former Nazis and convert them into "positive" supporters of democracy, Dr. Friedrich Middlehauve declared today.

The electrical generating capacity of Colombia will increase more than 50 per cent by next spring, according to Carlos Kebe, who is supervisor in that country for Westinghouse Electric International Company, wholly owned export-import subsidiary of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation.

Friends of Averell Harriman, former Director for Mutual Security, have started a movement to nominate him for Mayor on the Democratic ticket. Although no approach has yet been made to the Democratic county leaders, the movement already has gained considerable strength among leaders of organized labor.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- State J Department spokesmen declined tonight to confirm or deny reports that Finland had promised the United States that her tankers would not carry oil and gasoline to Communist China in the future. The reports of assurances grew out of the failure of United States efforts, to date, to stop a Finnish tanker en route to Communist China with a cargo of kerosene oil, used in jet aircraft.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The House Armed Services Committee agreed informally today to restudy officer strength of the armed forces between now and June 30, to see whether presently authorized percentages were too generous in their allocations in the highest ranks.

Friends of Averell Harriman, former Director for Mutual Security, have started a movement to nominate him for Mayor on the Democratic ticket. Although no approach has yet been made to the Democratic county leaders, the movement already has gained considerable strength among leaders of organized labor.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- State J Department spokesmen declined tonight to confirm or deny reports that Finland had promised the United States that her tankers would not carry oil and gasoline to Communist China in the future. The reports of assurances grew out of the failure of United States efforts, to date, to stop a Finnish tanker en route to Communist China with a cargo of kerosene oil, used in jet aircraft.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The House Armed Services Committee agreed informally today to restudy officer strength of the armed forces between now and June 30, to see whether presently authorized percentages were too generous in their allocations in the highest ranks.

Seventy-two of the nation's bestqualified contract bridge experts, drawn from twenty-two states and forty-three cities, last night commenced play at the McAlpin Hotel in the twenty-third annual Life Masters Individual Championship, in the American Contract Bridge League's national championship tournament schedule.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt was honored last night as an outstanding citizen at the fifth annual Roosevelt Day dinner given by Americans for Democratic Action.

Black, white and brass, all three now popular for use in interiors, are much in evidence in a new furniture and accessory shop called Pygmalion House, Inc., which opened yesterday at 10 West Fifty-fifth Street.

Competition in the annual Sherman Memorial indoor polo tournament got under way at the Squadron A Armory last night as Long Island defeated New Jersey, 9 -- 7. In the second game of the weekly twin bill, the New York A. C. stopped the Ramapo Polo Club, 19 -- 14, in an exhibition match.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Feb. 7 -- Less than four years ago the Chinese Nationalists, who took refuge on Formosa after being driven off the mainland of China, had just about been counted out as a Government. Today, with their administrative apparatus restored, their island economy running smoothly and their military machine showing new signs of life, the Nationalists are planning to resume offensive operations against the Chinese Communists.

ACCRA, Gold Coast, Feb. 6 -- The most hopeful spot in sub-Sahara Africa today is this hot and humid British colony, now well along the road of self-government. Under the leadership of Kwame Nkrumah, elected Prime Minster from his prison cell in 1951 when Britain granted a new Constitution, the Gold Coast Negroes are completing the organization and preparations requisite to demanding full independence.

A NEW projection lamp for home movies that is said to produce twenty per cent more light on the screen than any other projection lamp of equal wattage is announced by the Westinghouse Lamp Division. The lamp was developed with the assistance of Bell Howell Company, who now use it as standard equipment in their projectors.
The solid citizens of Flint; Mich., rejoiced last week. Their own "Mr. Flint" assumed the presidency, of the automotive colossus, General Motors Corporation, on Tuesday.

WORKING in television may be just another job for some members of the acting clan, but not for Maria Riva. She has embraced television as both a profession and hobby, praising its potentialities and sharply criticizing its shortcomings.

IN one of the more ludicrous passages in this novel a young man, on his way to join a party exploring the "dungeons" of a restored castle, suddenly hears a spectral voice calling his name. Through a barred window he can barely distinguish the face of a friend named Widmerpool.
" IN the long run, free and competitive prices will best serve the interests of all the people, and best meet the changing, growing needs of our economy."

A VERY BRUNDAGE is a brave man of such lofty principles that he deems compromise or expediency a coward's cloak. No sooner had the millionaire ex-decathlon champion been elected president of the International Olympic Committee last July, the first American ever so honored, than he flailed away with his usual vigor at the evils threatening the Olympic movement. He pointed one accusing finger at the curse of "gigantism."

AN American in Paris always has fun, particularly if he's a fictional American. No exception is Mr. Ridgely Howard of Baltimore, hero of Jere Wheelwright's ingratiating new historical novel. In 1805, when Rid Howard came there, Paris was still Paris -- a place where young men wrote pamphlets, and old men schemed governmental changes, and women were women.

IF you pick up the telephone anywhere in Europe and ask for No. 8841 in the city of Luxembourg, the reply you will get, in a French-speaking female voice will be: "Communaute." This will mean you are connected with the switchboard of the High Authority of the European Coal and Steel Community, more popularly known in its earlier stages as the Schuman Plan.

THE best bridge players in the country are assembled in New York this week-end, competing for the individual championships in the two highest classifications in the American Contract Bridge League's rankings. There are seventy-two "life masters" (the highest rank) and seventy-two "senior masters" (the next highest) playing.
IN New York last week, Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands, speaking sadly of the news he had just received of the toll of the storm at home, said, "Our oldest enemy, the sea, has struck again."

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Feb. 7 -- The tour of Secretary of State John Foster Dulles and Harold E. Stassen, Mutual Security Director, to stimulate European unification has partly been turned into a survey of flood damage in the Netherlands, Belgium and Britain to assist the Eisenhower Administration in framing recommendations to Congress for assistance.

When underwriting groups meet to price new bond issues there is always one kind of syndicate associate that the bidding manager is glad to have around -- an investment house which is willing to risk its capital in support of a purchase price as high as the traffic will bear.

IN 1906, when the Twentieth Century Limited was serving majestic nine-course dinner for $1, Albert E. Yarlott went to work for the New York Central Railroad as a dining car steward. The next year Richard G. Robinson started as a commissary clerk on the Pennsylvania Railroad.

PORT-OF-SPAIN, Trinidad -- Easter falls early this year, a fact of special significance to those who are planning to escape the tag end of winter by a trip to the Caribbean, for just prior to Lent, on Feb. 16 and 17, Trinidad will stage its annual Carnival.

MITCHEL AIR FORCE BASE, L. I., Feb. 7 -- Bill Nottingham typewrites eight hours a day in the law office here, transcribing from disks reams of court-martial records and other legal documents. He is one of the best typists at the base, even though he is totally blind.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 7 -- The Pennsylvania Water Resources Committee today unanimously rejected the Incodel plan for the Delaware River water supply, on the ground that it would benefit mainly New York City and Northeastern New Jersey.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 7 -- The United States delegation to the United Nations has started work on its most important job since it came under Republican direction: the planning of strategy to be followed in the Korean case when the General Assembly reconvenes late this month.

HERE is the account of a ten-weeks' journey, by automobile and rail, across lower South America from the Atlantic to the Pacific and back. It is happily unlike the more pretentious volumes on the continent which build a heavy house of conclusions on a rickety stilt-work of inadequate reporting.

Phil Rizzuto's understudy, Andy Carey, was among the four signers listed yesterday by Roy Hamey, assistant general manager of the Yankees. This put fifteen Bombers under contract, with several topflight men still not in agreement with the salaries offered.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The Eisenhower Administration gave a preview this week of an internal security program that it hopes will make it easier to get rid of employes classed as security risks who are now on the Federal payroll and prevent applicants who might menace national safety from getting Federal jobs.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 7 (AP) -- Larry, a 43.6-foot sloop, owned by Jacobo L. Cabassa, Miami, and sailed by an all-Miami crew, won the twentieth annual Sir Thomas Lipton Cup race tonight in weather cranky enough to test the best yachtsman's spirit.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Party politics calls the tune on whether Hawaii or Alaska should get priority for admission as the forty-ninth of the United States.

New Yorkers, who usually tunnel under their rivers, seldom remember that they are an island folk and that the Bronx is the only part of their city on the American mainland. But that situation was emphasized last week by the labor troubles which shut down 75 per cent of the Port of New York.

RECORDINGS of folk music present certain problems for the home listener. Often the more authentic the music is -- that is, the closer it is recorded to its source of origin -- the greater the problems are.

DVORAK at his best is one of the most delightful of all composers. Close to his native Bohemian soil, completely uncomplicated, untroubled by neuroses, a melodist of the first rank, one of the great orchestral technicians of all time, he composed music that is natural and unspoiled. A bit naive sometimes; here and there a trifle over-simplified in form, but always singing, healthy and rhythmic.

Excessively high income tax rates are in themselves harmful to the economy in that they deter investment in new enterprise and discourage expansion of existing businesses. High rates, in combination with the double taxation of income, withal, can destroy the private enterprise system.

WASHINGTON -- In November, 1836, a young Indiana Congressman-elect named George L. Kinnard set out for what was then called Washington City to begin his first term. But Representative Kinnard did not reach his destination.

TOKYO, Feb. 7 -- President Eisenhower's State of the Union message, with its announcement that he would revise the orders to the United States Seventh Fleet in Formosan waters and free the Chinese Nationalist forces for raids against the Communist mainland, touched off a storm of comment and speculation in Asia.

KANSAS CITY, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Harry S. Truman said today that he would have retired from the Presidency four years earlier if the experts had not predicted that he could not win the election of 1948 and if there had been better prospects for world peace.

HONOLULU, Feb. 7 -- President Eisenhower's declaration in his State of the Union Message this week that statehood for Hawaii should be "granted promptly" brought an immediate enthusiastic response here in official quarters.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Feb. 7 -- A collection of several hundred trade cards, a popular advertising medium before the turn of the century, is being exhibited at the Rutgers University Library here.

CANADA will issue on April 1 three commemorative stamps with designs illustrating "commonly known wild animals of Canada" -- polar bear on 2-cents blue, moose on 3c brown, bighorn sheep on 4c black -- in connection with National Wildlife Week.

ANDOVER, Mass., Feb. 7 -- Andover's $1,200,000 memorial gymnasium was dedicated today in ceremonies witnessed by 1,200 alumni and undergraduates as Andover athletes engaged four Yale freshman teams. Andover captured the track meet, 63 -- 41, but the Elis won in swimming, 45 -- 29; in wrestling, 29 -- 3, and in basketball, 87 -- 47.

Debutantes of this season headed by Miss Diane Damon, and including Miss Leone Howard, are aiding in plans for the Carioca Ball to be held next Sunday night in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the Foundation Napoleao Laureano of the National Service for Cancer Research in Brazil.

The New York Civil Liberties Union, affiliate of the American Civil Liberties Union, will be sponsor for a luncheon and conference on Thursday, Lincoln's Birthday, at the Henry Hudson Hotel. The gathering will be the first annual one arranged by the New York group.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 7 -Johnny Longden, aboard a horse that likes to run in front, today rode Andrew J. Crevolin's Decorated to a two-and-a-half-length victory in the $29,300 San Felipe Handicap for 3-year-old Derby contenders at Santa Anita.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Feb. 7 -- Eighty-five civil defense officials of Suffolk County were briefed on filter center operations and alerted to the need for further volunteer "sky-watchers" in the ground observer corps in a session at the Eastern Air Defense Force's filter center at 21 Court Street this afternoon.

Commissioner of Public Works Frederick H. Zurmuhlen withdrew yesterday as a candidate for Borough President of Richmond to fill the vacancy caused by the retirement of Borough President Cornelius A. Hall because of ill health.

Editor William R. Mathews in "Tucson Looks at the World" (Jan. 25) says Americans generally do not appreciate the Russians' suspicion and fear of us when they see us building a ring of bases "stretching from Iceland, Britain, North Africa, Cyprus and Saudi Arabia to the Philippines and Okinawa."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Pitcher Randy Gumpert, who worked for three American League clubs in the past two seasons, was sold today by the Senators to Los Angeles of the Pacific Coast League.

DETAILS of the 1953 Tops-in-Photography program to be given Friday, March 13 at Hunter College Auditorium, Park Avenue and Sixty-eight Street, by the Metropolitan Camera Club Council, have been announced by William Hunn of the Staten Island Camera Club, this year's "Tops" show chairman.

MANKIND loves an argument; and since there is nothing in the intrinsic quality of Vaughan Williams' "Antarctic Symphony" that mankind could possibly argue about, mankind has decided to argue about the title.

PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 7 -- The Lawrence Hutton collection of life and death masks of famous men, described as the largest collection, on of its kind, is now on display in the Princeton University Library and will remain on view throughout the month.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 7 (UP) -Spur On, a bay son of Whirlaway, showed some of the stretch speed that made his sire famou as he carried top weight of 121 pounds to an easy, thre length victory in the $14.175 Louisiana Handicap today at Fair Grounds.

THE simplest way to construct a book is to select something (anything) and stack around it all the facts that are even faintly related to it. Thomson King, a retired Baltimore engineer, has constructed a book on this plan with water as its focal point.

After witnessing "The Star" and many similar movies dealing with the emotional conflicts of ambitious, masculine-protesting career women, I am beginning to wonder just what kind of hokum the Hollywood script writers are trying to put over on the American people.
MIAMI, Feb. 7 (UP) -- Former President Herbert Hoover, the grand old man of the Republican party, entered a hospital here tonight with an attack of influenza.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Feb. 7 -- George Babcock Cressy, Maxwell Professor of Geography at Syracuse University, voiced doubt today that an invasion of the mainland of China by Nationalists under Chiang Kai-shek could be a success. He addressed the State Press Association at the final session of its annual meeting here.

SALEM, Ore., Feb. 7 -- "A newspaper without enemies has no friends." This is the creed that has been followed for more than fifty years by George Putnam, who recently sold his newspaper. The Salem Capital Journal of which he was editor and publisher for thirty-four years.

THIS once quite little fishing village on Jamaica's north coast, some sixty miles diagonally across the island from the capital city of Kingston, has just known it "greatest day in history," so styled by its leading citizens with complete disregard for the fact that Christopher Columbus chose nearby Discovery Bay for the spot where he first set a white man's foot on Jamaican soil way back in 1494.

Support of the nation's military services by the American merchant marine industry was praised by Vice Admiral Francis C. Denebrink, commander of the Military Sea Transportation Service, at a meeting in New York on Friday.

THE best way of inviting birds to make your property their home is to provide them with ample food and suitable nesting places. No shrub or vine will give more generous free meal tickets than do the honeysucles (lonicera).

GARMISCH - PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 7 (UP) -- Andreas Ostler, former German world champion, won an international four-man bobsled race today. The 1953 world champion, Lloyd J. Johnson of Madison, Wis., was third.

Bond men are now taking a second look at the 1953 market for prime investments because of the continued heavy public borrowings by local governments and the inability of syndicates distributing new issues of corporate bonds to maintain prices at levels first designated.

SAN FRANCISCO -- A "World's Fair of Photography" is planned for the Civic Auditorium here from June 30 through July 5 under the sponsorship of the San Francisco-Oakland Press Photographers Association headed by Bob Campbell of The San Francisco Chronicle's photographic department.
The Children's Aid Society, celebrating its 100th anniversary today, has set a fund goal of $1,000,000 for 1953, Morgan Dix Wheeler, president of the society, has announced.

WHILE your reviewer justly praises Lord Acton in the three books devoted to him in your Jan. 11 issue, he does him less than justice by omitting mention of some basic aspects of his libertarian attitude.

GUATEMALA, Feb. 7 -- While the action of Congress in removing four Justices of the Supreme Court and replacing them with members of revolutionary political parties has created a furor here, especially in professional circles, no definite action is expected before next week.

ALBANY, Feb. 7 -- Legislative measures that would strip the state of the most powerful club it now has to force the settlement of claims arising out of the acquisition of property for the Thruway and for parkways will be ready for a vote in the Senate Monday night.
OTTAWA, Feb. 7 -- With a few minor exceptions, all comment in the Canadian Parliament and press on President Eisenhower's State of the Union message this week was favorable and graceful.

HUNTINGTON, L. I, Feb. 7 -- The Heckscher Trust, a body of local citizens controlling Heckscher Park and the adjacent athletic field here, announced today that the park and field would be open the third Saturday of each month until a final determination of litigation affecting them.

Although President Eisenhower's State of the Union message last week was considered one of the most constructive in recent years, it had no marked effect on financial markets. While the message indicated clearly that the President has a sound grasp of many of the nation's problems and is determined to solve them, caution was still evident in financial circles.

BOSTON, Feb. 7 -- Carl (Bobo) Olson, America's top ranking middleweight, chalked up his eighth straight victory tonight by drubbing Norman Hayes of Boston in a ten-round bout telecast coast to coast from the Garden. Olson, a 5-to-2 favorite, weighed 162 1/2 to Hayes' 160 pounds.

ROBERT SHAW cares so profoundly about the choral masterworks that he insists on investing his own money in performing them. Even if he were a man of great, independent means, his behavior would be unusual.

PARIS, Feb. 7 -- Foreign Minister Georges Bidault obtained today the French Cabinet's approval for a series of "interpretative" protocols to be added to the European Defense Community treaty as a means of overcoming opposition to its ratification by the National Assembly. Severe opposition to the treaty has developed in the Assembly.

The turbulent history of the city's radio station WNYC has served as the backdrop for the conferring of the first Master of Public Administration degree to be awarded by the City College School of Business and Civic Administration.

Manhattan's basketball team piled up the highest score in the history of the series, which started in 1905, when it overwhelmed City College, 88 -- 46, in the Jasper gymnasium last night.

Since Charles E. Wilson was first invited to join the Eisenhower Cabinet there has been a great deal of muddy thinking on the sale of his holdings of General Motors stock. THE spate of unverified reports as to the forthcoming productions from Cinerama now can be considered checked. Last week it was revealed that two camera crews are hard at work in both Rio de Janeiro and Cuba shooting color footage for Cinerama's first story adventure.

Licensed Beverage Industries, Inc., public relations organ of the distilling trade, yesterday documented what it has long called the "law of diminishing returns" due to the increase in the Federal excise tax on whisky from $9 to $10.50 a gallon on Nov. 1, 1951.

ROME, Feb. 7 -- President Eisenhower's decision to "deneutralize" the United States Seventh Fleet may become the starting point for "a reconstruction of Western policy toward Asia" but may also sharpen the divergencies between the Western powers on his problem, the Vatican newspaper L'Osservatore Romano said today.

Brandeis University, Waltham, Mass., has made plans to open its first graduate school, awarding advanced degrees in the arts and sciences. Courses of instruction will begin in September. Degrees awarded by the Brandeis Graduate School of Arts and Sciences will be the Master of Arts and Doctor of Philosophy in Near Eastern and Judaic Studies, Master of Arts in Chemistry, Master of Fine Arts in Musical Composition and Doctor of Philosophy in Psychology.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Officials of twelve major conferences today discussed ways and means to streamline investigations in the new National Collegiate Athletic Assoication "get tough" policy agianst recruiting.

In the face of opposition from Governor Dewey and from Republican legislative leaders, Mayor Impellitteri announced last night that he intended to have his limited-dividend bus reorganization bill introduced at Albany this week.

Harry S. Truman, formerly of 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue, Washington, D. C., now of Independence, Mo., has been telling his neighbors that he thought he had been as "thoroughly vilified" as any United States President except Washington and Lincoln. It is true that Washington was called "treacherous," "mischievous," "inefficient, "ungrateful," "insignificant," hypocritical, dishonest and arrogant.

FRUIT growers on a large or small scale can do their part in helping to test and introduce new fruits recommended as worth a trial by the New York State Experiment Station at Geneva. The only requirement for membership in this unique "Fruit Testing Co-operative Association" is that the tester be a fruit grower.

A combination of circumstances is drawing United States wool manufacturers away from the Australian and New Zealand wool markets. Last week, dispatches from Sydney indicated that the chief support of the market was supplied by Great Britain, Europe and Japan. Americans held a poor fourth position from the standpoint of purchases.

A POIGNANT note, unusual in picture books, runs through this story of a small boy's search for companionship. Peter was lonely -- "lonely as a chicken in an egg." A country boy, he had ducks, sheep, a dog and cat, but no playmate.

DEFTLY touching upon truths of a greater reality than most "realistic writers" of World War II aspire to, Francis Beauchesne Thornton, a Catholic priest and former chaplain, has written a sensitive account of the four American chaplains who died heroically in 1943 aboard the torpedoed troopship Dorchester.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 7 (AP) -- Paced by Don Lange and John Clune, Navy's midshipmen rolled to a 77-56 basketball victory over Pittsburgh today in Dahlgren Hall.

President Eisenhower's reference in his State of the Union Message to Congress of the need for improving public and private welfare programs is expected to facilitate not only the movement to broaden Government pensions but also the removal of obstacles that have retarded the spread of private pension and welfare plans.
MONTREAL, Feb. 7 (UP) -- The Detroit Red Wings defeated the Montreal Canadiens, 3 -- 1, before 14,503 fans in the Forum tonight to move 3 points in front in the National Hockey League race.

BERLIN, Feb. 7 -- Communist terror by interrogation and pressure to support the current purges and the campaign against Zionism prompted the decision by eight leading Jews of Eastern Germany to flee to the West.

The possibility that grade distinctions in junior high schools might no longer be necessary was indicated yesterday by Dr. Warren W. Coxe, director of the division of research, State Department of Education, who is making a survey of the schools in the city.

ALEXIS LICHINE suggested the other day that Americans explore more fully the red wines of Bordeaux. The author of "Wines of France" (Knopf, 1951) said he was not implying that the delicacy and great lasting power of the clarets, as they generally are known, were ignored here.
BANDUNG, Indonesia, Feb. 7 (AP) -- The Soviet Union accused the United States and Britain today of using economic aid and capital investments in Asia as "a means of robbing these countries."

It bore down heavily on problems in two areas, interrelated and interacting, that dominate the dollars and cents side of American life -- the U. S. economy and the U. S. budget.

THE Seventeenth Annual Exhibition of the New York Press Photographers Association will be held Feb. 12-16 at the Seventh Annual National Photographic Show at Grand Central Palace. Winners in the annual contest, to which 150 New York news photographers have contributed 650 entries, will receive their awards from Mayor Vincent Impellitteri on Thursday, the opening day of the show.
Fordham's favored basketball team suffered a 73-64 setback at the hands of Villanova last night, the third defeat of the season in eighteen starts for the Rams.
THIS admirable survey of Mexican music, the first in English dealing with the entire subject, is an example both of fine scholarship and intelligent and engaging writing.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 7 -- The American Federation of Labor's decision to crack down on any union that allowed racketeers to seize control marked the start of a new era in the relationship between the federation and its 110 affiliated unions.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- President Eisenhower's promise, in his State of the Union message on Monday, to repudiate the so-called secret treaties that have permitted the "enslavement" of free peoples, redeems a pledge that has been reiterated by Republican spokesmen for the last five years.

WHATEVER the ultimate public reaction may be to Cinemascope, the wide-screen process to which Twentieth Century-Fox has committed its future product, the facts of the moment are that the company's stock has shot upward and that the rest of the motion-picture industry has been thrown into a tizzy.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 7 -- Three-power discussions among Greece, Turkey and Yugoslavia to forge a Balkan entente have been scheduled for resumption in Athens before the end of this month, it was announced today.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 7 (AP) -Hill Gall may return to racing Thursday.

The Foster Parents Plan for War Children, Inc., 55 West Forty-second Street, released $50,000 of its funds yesterday for the rehabilitation of 4,000 war orphans in the flood-stricken areas of northern Europe.

Worried over the uncertain trade outlook, the Japanese Government has undertaken active consideration of a program to promote increased exports to the dollar market.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- President Eisenhower received at the White House today representatives of the American Society of Newspaper Editors and was invited to address the organization at its annual meeting here, between April 16 and 18.

Many boxes and seats have been purchased for Saturday night's performance of "Tosca," with Dorothy Kirsten, Jan Peerce and Paul Schoeffler, at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the scholarship fund of the Manhattanville College Alumnae Association.

Rain caused the postponement until next Wednesday at 1 P. M. of the Metropolitan Intercollegiate varsity and freshman field events, scheduled to have been held yesterday at Columbia University's South Field. Construction bids for Queens College's new $2,632,000 library have been approved and ground-breaking ceremonies are scheduled to take place in the early spring, the college announced yesterday.

A. Berle or M. R. Cohen. Mr. Hale is that rara avis, a deep and able thinker * * * and a primary contributor to the world of legal scholarship.

HARTFORD, Feb. 7 -- Gov. John Davis Lodge, who will submit his biennial budget message to the Connecticut General Assembly on Feb. 17, was expected today to call for a sharp increase in state taxes to balance a two-year budget starting July 1. It is expected, too, that the estimates may be the largest in Connecticut's history.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Feb. 7 -- Because Lieut. Raymond Tierney of the State Troopers went after three New Yorkers for speeding, they were under arrest here today for having kidnapped a television engineer on Central Park West, New York. They drove him to New Jersey in his own car.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Feb. 7 -- While the producers of the potato, crop kingpin of Suffolk County's fertile farmlands, are expected to dominate the twenty-first annual convention of potato growers to be held here on Monday and Tuesday, other growers are reported planning to push rival crops.

THE "At Work" books, newest of the series which have lately sprung up so prolifically in the juvenile book field, are aimed at children who have a lively curiosity about the mechanics of our everyday world -- an audience which includes a large portion of the younger generation.

TOPEKA, Kan., Feb. 7 (AP) -- The death of Burton C. Hoffman, former president of the Dial Press, Inc., a New York publishing firm, was labeled a suicide today by Dr. Donald H. Macrae, coroner.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Dr. James Bryant Conant, retiring president of Harvard University, took the oath of office today as United States High Commissioner for Germany and because of the "urgency" of his mission announced plans to leave by plane Monday for his post in Bonn.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Feb. 7 -- Deciding what to do with a $100,000 mansion that has been left to the Village of East Hampton for "cultural and artistic purposes" under the will of Sarah Diodati Gardiner, a summer resident who died in New York on Jan. 5, has occupied professional and amateur planners in the village since the will was probated on Jan. 15.

The premiere of Bohuslav Martinu's one-hour opera after Gogol's comedy "The Marriage" was given yesterday afternoon by the National Broadcasting Company Television Opera Theatre. The production was of excellent quality, in the 1840 Russian costumes and scenic sets, and the admirable level of the singing and English diction.

OF the many, too many, Italian books I have been reading (in Italy and, more recently, here), two at least have impressed strongly. Placed at opposite points of the literary me spectrum, they are a collection of poems by a Catholic friar and a fantastic novelette by a Communist writer.

LONDON, Feb. 7 -- The mission of Secretary of States Dulles and Mutual Security Administrator Stassen in their visit this week to half a dozen European capitals, was nothing less than an attempt to breathe new life into the moribund project of European joint defense.
OSLO, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Pat McNamara of Minneapolis finished in a dead heat with Norway's Finn Hodt today in the 500-meter race of a two-day international speed skating meet at Olympic Bislet Stadium.

HAMILTON, N. Y., Feb. 7 -- Albany Academy tonight clinched its third straight championship in the New York State Prep School swimming tournament, by defeating Peekskill Military Academy and Trinity-Pawling.
Agreement was reached yesterday between the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union, independent, and eight metropolitan wholesale newspaper distributors on the terms of a new contract.

Senator Kefauver, who has shown more concern than most members over improving the procedures of Congress, has again introduced a proposal that might ease the perennial friction between the White House and Capitol Hill. His idea is to establish a report-and-question period in the Senate for Cabinet officers and other heads of executive agencies.

Volume in department stores in this area continued to trail the 1952 figures in the week, and observers, comparing twelve major stores with the same number a year before, estimated that the decline would be at least 8 per cent. The weather was considered not favorable for consumer interest in early spring merchandise.

TORONTO, Feb. 7 (UP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks snapped a five-game losing streak by rallying for three goals in the third period to defeat Toronto, 4 -- 2, tonight before 13,175 fans in a National Hockey League game.

MELBOURNE, Feb. 7 (AP) -- A gaunt and weary John Landy won the Victorian mile in a disappointing 4 minutes 11 seconds today and then announced he would make no more attempts this year to crack Gunder Haegg's world record.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 7 -- Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, the principal architect of armistice agreements that regulate present relations between Israel and the Arab states, arrived at Lydda Airport this morning for a two-day unofficial visit to Israel.
ITHACA, N. Y., Feb. 7 -- A hardpressed Pennslyvania team rose to the top of the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League standings today with a 50-49 triumph over Cornell.

Arturo Toscanini yesterday afternoon led the N. B. C. Symphony Orchestra in its regular Saturday afternoon concert at Carnegie Hall. The program consisted of two works, Schubert's Seventh Symphony in C major and the Overture to "Die Meistersinger."

Accused of the armed robbery of a bread company truck driver, three men, including an escaped convict, were held yesterday for hearings tomorrow by Magistrate Louis Fusco in Bronx Magistrates Court.

The primary objective of American Heart Week, which starts today and ends next Saturday on St. Valentine's Day, is to raise $10,000,000 for research, education and community services for the prevention, care and treatment of heart disease.

A NOTICEABLE increase in the number and variety of the educational features and picture-taking subjects offered highlights the program of the Seventh Annual National Photographic Show, which opens Thursday for a five-day run at Grand Central Palace. In addition to educational exhibits and events, about 150 photographic manufacturers will be represented in product displays.

A news report of a half-dozen lines in the Feb. 3 TIMES seemed to this writer a story of major and alarming domestic significance. A Newburgh (N. Y.) theatre canceled a week's engagement of Charlie Chaplin's "Limelight" on account of "protests from American Legion members."

The railroad management (since changed) considered the name of Mary Todd Lincoln unworthy of being ranked with that of her husband. In this, beyond question, it represented the sentiment of most Americans.
