Louis E. Wolfson, industrialist and new chairman of the board of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation, one of the largest shipbuilding plants in this country, with yards at Camden, N. J., outlined plans last week for full-scale operation. Control of the corporation was acquired recently from the Avco Manufacturing Company.

The Eisenhower Administration's "raid" on the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, stripping its board of a chairman and two members, has created a situation unique in the history of the bank. Not since the Federal Reserve System was organized in 1914, have all the member banks in this district been called upon to vote simultaneously for replacements on the board, as they were last week.
The question of managerial jurisdiction over Rocky Castellani, Luzerne, Pa., middleweight, will come up for review Friday at a meeting of the State Athletic Commission, it was learned yesterday.

Time will probably show that there were other aspects of President Eisenhower's first policy address to the Congress more significant than the announcement that the Seventh Fleet would no longer "neutralize" the activities of the Chinese Nationalists. During the past week, however, comment and controversy on this question seemed to overshadow the other materials Some of the adverse reaction was certainly expected.
HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 7 -- With a grey mist hanging over the hills of Hanover, Dartmouth's skiers won their own forty-third winter carnival today for their nineteenth triumph in this event.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 7 -- How legends are born in India was demonstrated today as several thousand devout Hindus from the old city of Delhi gathered in the chilly winter dawn at Rajghat, where Mohandas K. Gandhi was cremated, to witness the resurrection, in their eyes, of a sadhu, or holy man, who had himself buried alive exactly nine days before.

The 1953 Life Masters Individual championship went into the third session last night at the McAlpin Hotel with a field of seventy-two top-ranking United States bridge experts contending for one of the American Contract Bridge League's prize titles.
CHICAGO, Feb. 7 (AP) -- The Republican victory of President Eisenhower, says Adlai E. Stevenson, has not weakened the Democratic party.

PUSAN, Korea, Feb. 7 -- Lieut. Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, designated to be Eighth Army Commander, now has a good idea of the kind of support he can expect to receive from the rear area military installations on the southern tip to Korea.

Music lovers will hear Geraldine Farrar in duets with Enrico Caruso in excerpts from the Puccini classic "Madame Butterfly" at the noon to 2 P. M. recorded concert on Wednesday at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.

The decision of the thirteen second-rank Communist leaders to go to an American jail rather than to the "first workers' republic in history" is naturally attracting a good deal of attention. It is well known that Lenin in his day did not hesitate to go into foreign exile when confronted with prison at home.

BEYOND, as the phrase goes, per-adventure, one of the hottest dogs around these days, outside of the Gaiety Delicatessen, is a big, self-assured Doberman pinscher of 38 months named Ch. Rancho Dobe's Storm, who is owned by a taut, whippet-type advertising man of 39 years named Len Carey of Greenwich, Conn.

BOSTON, Feb. 7 -- Retail sales are running at a satisfactory level in New England, considering that it this is traditionally the dullest season of the year. One notable difference compared with a year ago is the greatly increased demand for consumers' durables.

A man of his word is Marvelous Mal Whitfield. As promised, the two-time Olympic 800-meter champion last night produced a world indoor record for 500 yards. He made it in the Buermeyer 500, gliding home invincibly ahead of three rivals in 56.6 seconds as 13,000 spectators at Madison Square Garden for the eighty-fifth anniversary games of the New York Athletic Club roared their approval.
Auctions at galleries here this week will be marked by a rich variety of offerings.

Despite record appropriations for education and increased citizen interest, the nation's public schools are still in serious trouble. The long awaited upward turn in educational support has not taken place as yet.

IF you are one of those imaginative people who in fancy or reality would like to enter another world where none of the ordinary rules apply, and where on every hand scenes new to the eye of man unfold in endless succession, then "The Silent World" is the book for you.
ASA, Tex., Feb, 7 (UP) -- Joe Browder, who hates crows, dynamited an estimated 50,000 of them last night as they croaked in the Brazos River bottoms.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Feb. 7 -- Spurred on by leftist agitators, Indians in the Cochabamba valley country have started new and "serious disturbances" against the local authorities, according to reports received here today. The newspaper El Diario reported that "revolutionary farmers" were carrying out a "bloody" purge against farmers unwilling to join their syndicate and apparently had resorted to murders as a demonstration of their determination and power.

FOR several years airline officials, airplane designers and safety experts have pondered the question: Are passenger seats facing backward safer than those facing forward in the event of a "straight-in" crash on landing or take off?
These three facts have put the country's copper producers and users in a dilemma that has effects of the first importance on the defense outlook:

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 7 -- An end to pari-mutuel betting, which would mean the halting of horse racing in California, was announced this week as the objective of a campaign about to be started under the joint auspices of the Protestant churches and groups of business men.
PASSAIC, N. J., Feb. 7 -- A redevelopment program that will bring a "new look" to the Pulaski Park area of this woolen center and provide modern housing for 500 families is under way.

THE exhibition which opened this week at the Morgan Library, made up of loans and of treasures from its own collection, is called "Landscape Drawings and Water-colors From Bruegel to Cezanne." Nature is thus its theme.

MORRISTOWN, N. J., Feb. 7 -- A total of $50,000, representing interest from a $700,000 trust fund set up by the late Mrs. Silvia Green Wilks, will be distributed to civic and church organizations by St. Peter's Protestant Episcopal Church here, one of the beneficiaries.

A group of twenty-three independent liberal arts colleges, located in the six New England states, has been organized to seek financial support from business and industry. To be known as the New England Colleges Fund, the organization is headed by Dr. James P. Baxter, 3d, president of Williams College.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (UP) -- Senator George D. Aiken, Republican of Vermont, chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee, declared today that "mischief-makers" were spreading rumors the new Administration "is going to make it tough on farmers."

A careful survey of Korea's needs for immediate help and for rehabilitation has been made for the United Nations by the Robert R. Nathan Associates, consulting economists. Their preliminary report has been public, apparently just as it was prompted, because of what Mr. Nathan said was the need for "great urgency in initiating the reconstruction program."

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Feb. 7 (AP) -- The Syracuse University basketball team outsped Holy Cross tonight, 86 -- 78. Frank Reddout, acting Syracuse captain, pumped 29 points through the hoop to lead the winners.

The Westminster Kennel Club's dog show, almost unique in sports in that it goes back in an unbroken line to 1877 despite the world's troubles, will be held tomorrow and Tuesday. It will bring 2,561 dogs of 110 breeds or varieties of breeds into Madison Square Garden for day and night competition.

EVERY year, millions of atomic-age Americans, in a frenzy of superstitious malaise, shy away from black cats and ladders, recoil from the match that has lit two cigarettes, fervently knock on wood, fling tons of salt over their left shoulders, slip rabbits' feet or other good-luck charms into their pockets and shiver over broken mirrors. Worst of all, they seem to dread Friday the 13th.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Feb. 7 -- Discriminatory registration practices in rural areas and widespread Negro apathy toward suffrage responsibilities now constitute the two main "roadblocks" to civic progress for Southern Negroes, the Southern Regional Council reported today.

RECENTLY on these pages an interview with New York City Commissioner of Commerce Walter T. Shirley revealed that the municipal government was making an all-out effort to bring more of the motion picture industry to New York.

The welfare work of the Association of Deportees and Internees of the Resistance in France will be aided by a reception and cocktail party to be held on Feb. 16 in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria.

THE big cruise ship moves southward into warm sunlit waters, as per advertisement, carrying its passengers to fascinating, exotic ports of the storied Caribbean. A few days out, the sun makes for becoming tans; entertainment artists appear as promised; tropical fruits and seafood spice the menu; deck sports, card tournaments and contests keep the day's program lively.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 7 -- Forty-nine countries have promised $93,179,726 so far to United Nations relief and technical assistance programs.

Celebrating the 106th anniversary of the birth of Thomas A. Edison, 250 members of the Edison Pioneers met at their annual luncheon at the Astor Hotel yesterday and heard former Postmaster General James A. Farley laud the deceased inventor as a man whose career "would be impossible in any other country but America."

WITH the publication of "The Collected Works of Abraham Lincoln," we have for the first time a truly definitive edition of the writings of our foremost statesman. To be sure, we have had, for almost sixty years, successive recensions of his "complete works," sometimes presented under august and austere auspices.

A vagrant fog that spun around the city yesterday morning curtailed operations at two airports here and harassed outgoing ocean liners, which had to back away from their North River piers into a close mist without the aid of tugs.
THE continuing rise of production costs may call a halt to a current phase in television's development: The multi-star, hour-long extravaganzas are pricing themselves right off the television screen.

SCARCE though the detective story proper has become, there are still, I trust, a few other enthusiasts who rejoice in the pure tour de force of construction, in the classic Christie -Carr-Queen manner; and it's to them in particular that I commend Christianna Brand's FOG OF DOUBT (Scribner's, $2.50) -- though, like all of Miss Brand's novels, it's not to be overlooked by anyone interested in the well-written modern British suspense novel.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- President Eisenhower announced today that he would nominate Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce to be United States Ambassador to Italy.

HENRY BRANT'S "Signs and Alarms" and Peggy Glanville-Hicks' "Letters From Morocco" will be the works to receive premieres at the third and final program that Leopold Stokowski will conduct at the Museum of Modern Art for the American Composers Alliance.
TOKYO, Sunday, Feb. 8 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique for Saturday's action:

THE OGBURNS have produced the most formidable of the works attempting to prove that Edward de Vere, the seventeenth Earl of Oxford, is the real author of all the works generally attributed to William Shakespeare.

DISCUSSING design, architect George Nelson once said: "Familiarity breeds acceptance." This was proved last month at the opening of the Good Design exhibit in Chicago. The continuing display, jointly sponsored by the Merchandise Mart of that city and the Museum of Modern Art of New York, appeared at its inception three years ago to be filled with extreme, even revolutionary, designs. The present version seems almost conservative.

PARIS, Feb. 7 -- The European Marshall Plan Council decided today that the six-member nations of the European Coal and Steel Community could abolish quantitative restrictions on imports of coal and steel without being obliged to extend similar treatment to the twelve other nations in the European Payments Union.

ELKTON, Md., Feb. 7 (AP) -- A third marine died tonight of injuries he had received when a car in which he and four buddies were en route from Camp Lejeune, N. C., to their homes in the New York area crashed into the rear of a tractor-trailer truck on U. S. 40 near here.

IN the title story of this double-decker, two beautiful queens battle each other for the right to exist in the future. The evil queen seems to have everything in her favor, but then her rival reaches through time to enlist Denny Lanning, American, who leads a band of fighting men to victory and Utopia.

THE final choices have been made for the works to be played at Oslo next May at the annual festival of the International Society for Contemporary Music. The United States will be represented by a single chamber music work -- Milton Babbit's "Du," a song cycle for voice and piano.

TOKYO, Sunday, Feb. 8 -- The United States Government has been "attentive" to the Japanese desire to regain administrative control over Okinawa and the Bonin Islands, Premier Shigeru Yoshida told the Budget Committee of the Diet (parliament) yesterday.

EL PASO, Tex., Feb. 7 -- Chandler Harper and Leo Biagetti took a two-stroke lead at the fifty-four-hole mark of the El Paso open golf tournament today. Harper, the 1951 P. G. A. champion from Portsmouth, Va., and Biagetti, an ex-serviceman from Baltimore, each posted a 2under-par 69 for 206 totals at the three-quarter mark of the $10,000 tournament.

Possibly Mr. Walter Bernstein's error, and that of a thousand other artists and educators for whom his concluding sentence is the final summation, lies in this: that they confuse an acceptance of "communism" as of today with a mere intellectual choice.

In his State of the Union Message to Congress last week President Eisenhower declared, "We have incontrovertible evidence that Soviet Russia possesses atomic weapons." In doing so the new Chief Executive placed himself in direct opposition to former President Truman, who in an interview in Kansas City the week before had said he was "not convinced that they [the Russians] have the bomb."

IF American history were taught in terms of personality few Americans would find it dull. Two very different, yet very colorful, characters whose lives were interwoven through the years during and immediately preceding the Civil War, are the subject of Harlan Horner's very interesting essay.

THE Fourth Annual Photographic Industry Dinner Dance in behalf of the rehabilitation photography programs of Volunteer Service Photographers, Inc., will be held at 7 P. M. Tuesday on the Starlight Roof of the Hotel Waldorf Astoria.

GENERALLY speaking, everybody danced better than usual in the recent season of the New York City Ballet, but no one more so than the company's first ballerina, Maria Tallchief. When a dancer arrives at Miss Tallchief's level of accomplishment, it is slightly foolish to talk about "improvement," for she has long been impeccable in style and with few, if any, peers in virtuosity.

PEEKSKILL, N. Y., Feb. 7 -- Four new elementary schools and a high school will be built in this city and within an eight-mile area at a cost of $4,505,000 if building programs planned by school boards are approved by the citizens in March.

THE late Constance Whitney Warren was an honest and adept animal sculptor and the memorial exhibition of her work (mostly horses in bronze) at the Ferargil contains a judicious selection of her best pieces. Some dashing gouaches of equestrians, done before she was 20, show the line she was to take.

The North Sea, separating Great Britain from the continent of Europe, is 600 miles long and shaped like a great funnel. The top of the cone -- from Rattray Head in northeast Scotland to the coast of Norway -- is 280 miles. The bottom of the cone -- from Yarmouth to the Hook of Holland -- is 110 miles wide.

MIAMI, Feb. 7 -- Charfran Stable's Crafty Admiral, the top cashcollector among the nation's racehorseslast year, ran off with the biggest share of the swag in the $64,000 McLennan Handicap over a muddy track at Hialeah Race Course today. He led from shortly after the start in the once-aroundthe-track run of a mile and an eighth.

A LITERARY scandal, or "scandale," as the French would say, is raging in Paris at the moment. The highly touted author of "The Twenty-fifth Hour," Virgil Gheorghiu, has turned out to be the author of a pro-Nazi, anti-Semitic book, "Les rives du Dniestr brulent," published in 1941 in Rumania.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (UP) -- The jeep, military vehicle of all trades, has been converted into a front-line ambulance.

Dutch men, women and children were saved from the icy waters of the North Sea inundation last week in part, at least, because the production line of the Grumman Aircraft Engineering Corporation extends all the way from its plant at Bethpage, L. I., to Evansville, Ind.

" THE CRUCIBLE" is taken from history. No character is in the play who did not take a similar role in Salem, 1692. The basic story is recorded, if briefly, in certain documents of the time. It will be a long time before I shall be able to shake Rebecca Nurse, John Proctor, Giles Corey and the others out of my mind.

Since 1946 receipts of motion-picture theatres have fallen off by more than 30 per cent because of the ever-increasing popularity of television. How are the boys and girls who now sit before the television screen to be lured back to the movies? "Three dimension" seems to be the answer.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 7 -- The Princeton basketball team breezed to an 83-53 victory over Harvard tonight. It was the first Ivy League victory this season for the defending champion Tigers and Harvard's seventeenth straight Ivy League loss, the string starting in the 1951 finale against Yale.

PLAINFIELD, N. J., Feb. 7 -- Top-seeded Harry Conlin of the United States Air Force and John Russell of the University Club joined Henri Salaun of Boston and Carter Fergusson, Merion Cricket Club of Philadelphia, in the semi-finals of the seventh annual DeForest-Tyler Memorial invitation squash racquets tournament at the Plainfield C. C. today.

I AM an American, of the fifth generation, who senses a growing encroachment to throttle our American freedom of expression. The numerous factions that are springing up which foster hatred cannot help but lend a fear to thinking Americans that we can be losing our freedom.
Referring to the dance called the Krakoviak (mentioned in a recent letter in your columns and by Harrison Salisbury in "Man, Dig That Stilyag!", Jan. 11):

WASHINGTON'S Birthday falls on Sunday this year but it means a three-day -- for some a four-day -- week-end. Monday will be a legal holiday with banks and schools and most offices closed. Hotels in Lakewood and Atlantic City and resorts in the Poconos and Catskills are planning special festivities for their guests.

The annual card party and tea under the auspices of the Committee for Scholarships of the Cornell University-New York Hospital School of Nursing will be held Wednesday afternoon in the New York Hospital Nurses' Residence, 1320 York Avenue.

POSTMASTER GENERAL ARTHUR E. SUMMERFIELD made available last week the design of the promised Washington Territory centenery commemorative stamp, a 3-cent green which will have first-day sale on March 2 at Olympia, Wash.

ALL autobiographies, remarked playwright John van Druten in a recent interview with Lewis Nichols, "are best when they are about childhood and adolescence." That has the air of a sweeping and dogmatic statement, but it is an opinion which many readers, including myself, would share.

IRWIN EDMAN'S "The Art of the Unhurried Essay in a Hurry-up World" is delightful. One feels like saying "The essay is dead; long live the essay." His article was itself a splendid essay. The greater extremes of heat and cold in the United States as contrasted with Britain and France may be related to our own lack of relaxation and meditation.
CHICAGO, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Gerardo Gonzalez, better known as Kid Gavilan, welterweight champion from Cuba, and Charles Pierce Davey will meet at the Chicago Stadium Wednesday night in a tiitle bout.

The present financial straits of the country's schools and colleges -- arising from inflation, increased enrollments and the need for more teachers, more buildings and more supplies of all kinds -- has created an increasing awareness of business and industrial firms as a potential source of added support.

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 1 -- Portugal would like to export more of her port wine to the United States, and producers would like to see a commercial treaty drawn up between the two countries by which large quantities of wine would find their way into the American market.

Like most thoughtful Americans, I shudder at the prospect of an investigation of schools and colleges by men of the character of Senators McCarthy and Jenner, using the methods they habitually employ. Much unnecessary damage has already been done to the teaching profession -- itself not exceptional for outspoken courage -- by special loyalty oaths and various forms of ill-considered, witch-hunting, legislation.

FERTILIZER is applied to the soil by farmers and gardeners to help crops give their best performance. Since soils differ, the grower adds fertilizer in varying degrees to maintain the desired level of fertility. Other factors that influence the application of fertilizers are the needs of the plants themselves.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 7 (AP) -- Jack Kramer's steaming service was his most potent weapon before 4,000 fans tonight as he defeated Australia's Frank Sedgman, 6 -- 4, 11 -- 9, in a tense professional tennis match. Sedgman leads Kramer, 13 -- 11, in their cross-country tour which continues Monday and Tuesday at Boston.

AFTER crashing a test car at forty miles an hour against a stone wall, researchers have come to the conclusion that simple changes in design can eliminate some of the collision dangers that exist in thousands of automobiles.

THERE is a Russian saying that Russia is not a country but a world. The sprawling domains of the U. S. S. R. are inhabited by 177 or 180 distinguishable nationalities, of which, perhaps, forty-five are politically important. But even the existence of these forty-five is sufficient to make the tasks of the Soviet nationalities policy extremely complicated.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 7 -- Ratification of the Israeli restitution agreement regardless of the Arab threat to boycott the Federal Republic was virtually guaranteed today as a result of assurance given by Erich Ollenhauer, head of the Social Democratic party, to Kurt R. Grossmann of the Jewish Agency for Palestine that his party would support unconditional ratification at the earliest.
LONDON, Feb. 7 (Reuters) -West Bromwich Albion regained the lead in the first division of English soccer today with a 2-1 victory over lowly Manchester City.

IMMENSELY industrious, immensely thorough, the authors of "Hamlet Through the Ages" have compiled a pictorial record of scenes from productions put on since 1709. To give their picture book practical value they have annotated the pictures with all the necessary facts and some facts that are also entertaining.

CALL it altruistic dedication to the profession and the public or merely the drive to put advice down on paper for profit, but the legion of physicians who are as adept with the pen as with palpation seems to be growing larger. Among these, Miriam Lincoln, no newcomer to the field, writes in straightforward fashion on physiology, disease and sane living.

ON THE CENTRAL FRONT, Korea, Jan. 29 -- Fighting men in Korea have moved back and forth between the front line and reserve areas so many times since the stalemate began more than a year ago that they have it down to a science.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (UP) -- Senator William F. Knowland of California, chairman of the Senate Republican Policy Committee, said today the United States, alone if necessary, should blockade Communist China to increase Allied pressure for Korean peace.

An opera which one would not be likely to hear in a lifetime of casual opera-going, Rimsky - Korsakoff's May Night, has just been released in a performance by soloists, orchestra and chorus of the Bolshoi Theatre, Moscow (Vanguard, three disks).

FRANKLIN, W. Va., Feb. 7 (UP) -- Two "spelunkers" -- amateur cave explorers -- lost for three days without food in a freezing cave were found by a search party today as they wandered aimlessly in the dark only 400 yards from the entrance.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 7 -- The prospects for reuniting Germany by methods short of war or surrender on Russian terms are being hopefully re-examined as a result of the visit of Secretary of State John Foster Dulles to West Germany.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Feb. 7 -- President Eisenhower's failure to mention Alaska while calling for a prompt grant of statehood to Hawaii in his State of the Union Message has caused surprise and disappointment here.

The New York Rangers will be back on their own ice tonight, opposing the Canadiens of Montreal in a National Hockey League game. Bill Cook's skaters have been on the road for the greater part of the last four weeks, and their return to Madison Square Garden is expected to attract a large crowd.

The port's tugboat strike enters its second week today but hope of a settlement rose last night when negotiators for harbor craft workers and their employers reported an agreement "nearer than at any time since the walkout began."

Few buyers were in the wholesale markets here last week having returned to their stores to prepare for spring and Easter selling, according to McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buying office. Many summer dress lines opened and some suit lines began to appear.

A REMARKABLY disquieting sight can be seen through a thick glass window here in the high-altitude laboratories of the Wright Air Development Center. Inside a steel chamber a beaker of warm water stands on a stool. Huge pumps are set in motion evacuating the air, simulating high altitude.

The Belmont Stakes has attracted a record number of nominations this year, it was announced yesterday. With the closing of the entry books last month, there were 126 horses named for the $100,000-added race that is regarded as the third and most important jewel in thoroughbred racing's triple crown.

NEWARK, Feb. 7 -- Samuel K. McKee, special agent in charge of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in New Jersey, will retire Feb. 27 after twenty-three years with the Government agency. Mr. McKee, who is 51 years old, said he planned to accept a position in private industry.
Rabbi Zev Zahavy of Congregation Zichron Ephraim, 163 East Sixty-seventh Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning that "all nations of the world must seek a Godly inspiration."

The one consoling feature of the flood disaster which has hit the coasts of Britain, Holland and Belgium is that there was no human malice behind it. This great destruction of lives and possessions was what the lawyers call an act of God, meaning a combination of forces beyond human will or control.

That hardy perennial blooming on the shores of the Potomac since World War II -- the problem of how to get more combat effectiveness for less money -- was flowering again last week, as the Pentagon's new chiefs settled down to work.

LUXEMBOURG, Feb. 7 -- The High Authority of the European Coal and Steel Community, which will acquire power over the single market of the six countries when that market officially opens on Tuesday, decided today to proceed gradually and cautiously in applying its powers so as to ease the transition to a single market.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., Feb. 7 -- Buses serving central and South Shore communities in Nassau County were immobilized by a strike of drivers and maintenance workers today. Forty thousand commuters faced difficulty in getting to work on time Monday morning, while state mediators were making efforts to settle the dispute over the week-end.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 7 -- President Sukarno and his Governmental party returned here yesterday after a twelve-day tour through Borneo and East Indonesia in which the President again demonstrated his position as Indonesia's chief factor in national unity and stability.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 7 (AP) -- "If the battle of Waterloo was won on the playing fields of Eton, it may well be that the ideological struggle with communism in the next fifty years will be won on the playing fields of the public high schools of the United States."

Soviet production of minerals grew almost eightfold between 1926 and 1950, but even in the latter year was less than 25 per cent of comparable United States production, Dr. D. B. Shimkin concludes in his book, "Minerals -- A Key to Soviet Power," just published by Harvard University Press.

ACCRA, Gold Coast, Feb. 7 -- Without Africa the Western world could not hold out indefinitely in a "cold war" and might lose a "hot" one. The United States depends on this continent for key strategic materials. France and Britain, the chief United States allies, would go bankrupt if deprived of their African trade. Twentieth-century democracy draws heavily here for metals to make its machinery and food to nourish its workers.

IN every generation someone is accused of corrupting the youth and contributing to our decadence. Now, A. E. Johnson, writing in your section last Sunday, finds nothing constructive dramatically or morally in Bernard Shaw's plays.

A VERY impressive exhibition has opened at the Metropolitan. In "Berthe Morisot and Her Circle," a selection of paintings from the collection of the artist's daughter Julie (Mme. Ernest Rouart) pays homage to the very considerable attainments of Berthe Morisot and reveals her close association with Degas, Renoir, Manet and other contemporaries for whom she was friend, hostess and fellow-artist during the long struggle of the impressionists for recognition.

PROBABLY the most unfriendly neighbors in the world have been living across from each other for fifteen months on a 155-mile stretch of land shaped like a gnarled hickory bow. Each has been making life miserable for the other but neither has had the strength nor confidence to drive the other away. So they sit watching, waiting and continuing to be miserable.

AURORA, N. Y., Feb. 7 -- Wells College trustees are seeking $1,300,000 for a student union building, combined with a new gymnasium, swimming pool and bowling alleys. The president, Louis Jefferson Long, said today the amount sought would include endowment for maintenance.

The manufacturing of machine tools, intricate devices for making the machines that produce consumer goods, contains the elements of many human interest stories. This was discovered more than a dozen years ago by Fred Wittner, erstwhile copy reader on the sports desk of a New York newspaper.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Feb. 7 -- Belgian leaders told John Foster Dulles, United States Secretary of State, today they would take no further action on the European army treaty until they knew how France wanted to change it.

PRESIDENT EISENHOWER, by indicating in his State of the Union message last week that he believed a review of the McCarran-Walter Immigration Act was in order because it contains injustices and discriminates against some aliens, brought comfort to opponents of the law.

AT THE KOREAN FRONT, Feb. 7 -- Lieut. Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor completed the first leg of a front-line inspection tour today in the company of retiring Gen. James A. Van Fleet, Eighth Army Commander. Both United States and Republic of Korea divisions were visited.

ROME, Feb. 7 -- The news of Mrs. Luce's selection reached Rome shortly before 9 o'clock this evening, long after the last newspaper had gone to press, therefore it still is not known to a large majority of Italians. However, the choice will cause no surprise as it has been expected for some days.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Feb. 7 -- The Royal Palace announced today that King Baudouin was expected back in Brussels tomorrow from the south of France and "will pay a second visit to the devastated flood areas."

PARIS, Feb. 7 -- The Information Conference, which delegates from the fourteen North Atlantic Treaty countries have been attending for the past four days in an effort to agree on how better to inform their peoples about the Western defense build-up, ended today.

A PERCEPTIBLE splash of cold water was thrown upon the public's built-up hopes for something sensational and spectacular in the three-dimensional movie line with the opening of the first full-program showing of stereoscopic films here last week.

President Eisenhower, honorary president of the Boy Scouts of America, greeted the organization yesterday on its forty-third anniversary with the advice to follow the scout oath and thus help the United States keep "peace on earth."
PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 7 (AP) -- Polly Riley of Fort Worth won her second Palm Beach women's golf championship today with a 3-and-2 victory over Pat Garner, Midland, Tex.

Educators will have to take a more active part in establishing non-commercial television if they hope to retain the 242 channels allotted by the Federal Communications Commission for educational purposes, Dr. Harold E. Wigren, director of audio-visual education for the public schools of Houston, Tex., asserts in the Teachers College Record, professional education journal of Teachers College, Columbia University.

WITH his new novel, Ronald Kirkbride provides a good example of the high-motive book with low readability. Its triumph is one of industry and conscientiousness rather than of art. This is not to decry either the usefulness or the appeal of the didactic novel but only to insist that the book that aims to guide has first of all to grip.

ELMONT, L. I., Feb. 7 -- For many years a large five-block-long sandpit pond along Freeman Avenue has been a source of summer pleasure to many of the neighbors whose well-kept modern homes line its edge on three sides. It has been used by its owner and his guests for swimming and boating.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 7 -- Mrs. Babe Didrikson Zaharias shot a tournament record 33 on the last nine holes of the Bayshore course today and moved into fourth place after two rounds of the women's $3,500 Miami Beach invitation golf tourney, three strokes behind the leader, Betsy Rawls.

IN all the literature of curiosa few twentieth-century books are as permanently entrenched as Frederick Baron Corvo's HADRIAN THE SEVENTH (Knopf, $3.50), which made its third appearance in this country last month. (Written in 1904, it was first published here in 1925.) Although formally "Hadrian the Seventh" is a novel, in actuality it is a rather thickly disguised autobiography, based on the author's astounding capacity for wishful thinking.

Today we look again at two problems of continuing interest to parents. One, the matter of baby sitters, is of principal concern to mothers and dads of youngsters in elementary school. The other, which we shall consider first, involves the possibility of community agreement on acceptable social behavior for teen-agers.

FORT LEE, N. J., Feb. 7 -- The students of Fort Lee High School do not share the opinion of out-of-town high schools that have petitioned the Mayor and Council here to make a historical shrine out of Fort Lee Bluff rather than sell it to an apartment house builder.

SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Anxiety of Australians over whether they are in danger of losing the 1956 Olympic Games heightened today when one of the country's most influential Olympic officials abruptly resigned.

PATCHOGUE, L. I., Feb. 7 -- An outdoor fresh water municipal swimming pool would be added to this village's recreational facilities, according to specifications for the proposed project that are expected to be submitted to the village board on Feb. 16.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Senator Homer Ferguson, Republican of Michigan, said today that the Air Force had planned to spend "hundreds of millions of dollars" for spare engines and other aircraft parts that it now admitted were not necessary.

HANOVER. N. H., Feb. 7 -- Dartmouth's basketball team saw its first action in ten days here tonight, and polished off Yale, 61 -- 51. An overflow winter carnival crowd in Alumni Gymnasium saw the Green's captain, Fred Gieg, lead his team to victory. It was the seventh for the Indians against nine defeats.

THE anti-firearms groups, in an attempt to obtain passage of bills to obstruct hunters and shooters, usually cite the "high" Casualty rate resulting from the use of firearms, but the latest Uniform Casualty Report compiled by the National Rifle Association provides figures which nullify this argument.

SAM THOMAS, theatrical producer and director, able, prosperous and professionally wise, was leading a satisfactory life until the afternoon he encountered Emmy Hulett in the living room of Lily Grainger, gaudy stage star.

Could the moat that separates our two nations be even deeper than I had believed? I had sent my letter of Jan. 9 (published in THE TIMES of Jan. 18) to a young Frenchman living in the United States asking that he translate it and if it were too long eliminate a few paragraphs. Obviously convinced that America could not bear the truth, he so altered my text that virtually nothing was left.

CLARETS not thought fine enough to bear a chateau label are sold to a shipper who blends them to produce, in some cases at least, a pleasant vintage. These regional wines may be mixtures of a single parish (commune), such as St. Julien in the Medoc, or of an entire district, such as Graves.

McCHORD AIR FORCE BASE, Wash., Feb. 7 (AP) -- An Air Force enlisted man has been arrested and an investigation is under way into charges that equipment was stolen from wounded Canadian veterans brought here from Korea for treatment.

THE television version of "You Are There," which made its bow at 6 P. M. last Sunday over the C.B.S. network, may prove a good example of one advantage radio has and video does not. That advantage is the imagination of the audience.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 7 -- American Federation of Labor leaders made plans today for an independent campaign to drive racketeers off the New York waterfront if the International Longshoremen's Association and the president, Joseph P. Ryan, failed to obey federation orders to clean house by April 30.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 7 -- William Jenkins, publicity-shy American multi-millionaire whose great wealth has made him one of modern Mexico's legendary figures, suddenly has become the target of a full-fledged newspaper campaign.

" Give me a place to stand and I will move the earth." Archimedes, as reported at the time, made his celebrated statement with a simplicity and directness never achieved by Homer or the Greek dramatists studied in the schools: "Dos moi pousto kai kino ten gen" -- "Give me where I stand and I will move the earth."

WEST POINT, N. Y., Feb. 7 -- Jack Molinas ran wild against Army's basketball team this afternoon as he sparked Columbia to an 83-to-57 triumph. The rangy 6-foot, 6-inch Lion center broke a 43-year-old Columbia field goal record and established a new West Point field house mark by rustling the cords for 38 points.

ADD to the shelf of books that explain the physical world to children and young people three interesting new items. Boys who have learned about rockets, magnetism, batteries and like subjects from Raymond Yates, earlier books will pounce on his "Atomic Experiments for Boys."

As President Eisenhower outlined his foreign policy to Congress and the nation, the man who will administer the policy (Secretary of State John Foster Dulles) and the man in charge of the economic program on which much of the policy depends (Mutual Security Administrator Harold Stassen) were touring the capitals of western Europe.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7 (AP) -- A survey by the Associated Press at the forty-four state capitals where legislatures are meeting shows that proposed budget are higher than the previous fiscal period estimates in twenty-one states and lower in only five.

Duveen Brothers, Inc., has just placed on view in a special room a large panel of "The Assumption of the Virgin," which was painted by the Sienese artist Andrea di Bartolo around 1400. The painting is pure enchantment and I know of no pleasanter respite from wintry winds than its company.

MOUNT HOLLY, N. J., Feb. 8 -- Gustav A. Scherer, 46 years old, of 1017 Mollbore Terrace, Philadelphia, a commercial fisherman, was fatally injured at 7 A. M. today in an automobile accident on Route 70, Southampton Township, sixteen miles south of here.

MOSCOW, Monday, Feb. 9 -- Pravda bitterly attacked President Eisenhower's order deneutralizing Formosa today, describing it as an act intended to prevent settlement of the Korean war and expand war activity in the Far East.

ALBANY, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Democratic fiscal leaders proposed tonight that the Legislature turn over to New York City and Nassau and Saratoga Counties the pari-mutuel "breakage" that goes to operators of thoroughbred horse-racing tracks.

If this city's population is to continue to improve its standard of living at the rate of the last decade, an average increase of 44 per cent in income of wage earners will be required by 1960, according to research experts of the Department of City Planning.

Color in furniture, a trend that appears with some frequency this season, can create a bright and unusual appearance in a room. A new group of unpainted pine furniture units planned for every room in the house and currently on display at Abraham Straus, among other stores, gives a homemaker the opportunity of expressing himself both in color and in arrangement.
CHICAGO, Feb. 8 (UP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks defeated the Toronto Maple Leafs for the second straight game tonight, 4 to 2, to gain third place undisputed in the National Hockey League.

SINGAPORE, Feb. 8 -- One year ago today Lieut. Gen. Sir Gerald Templer arrived at Kuala Lumpur to take up his new duties as High Commissioner of the Federation of Malaya. On his arrival he declared: "Our task is the building of a strong, free and truly united country. I demand help from every single man. I shall not spare myself."

In an age that is somber and men have lost faith in God, the "purveyors of despair" should be discarded for the optimism of Christ, the Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken, minister of Riverside Church, declared yesterday.

A six-story apartment house for twenty-five families on plot 105 by 50 feet at 20 East Fourth Street, corner of South Third Avenue, Mount Vernon, N. Y., has been purchased by Fischer-Landis, operators, in a deal negotiated by Arthur Lee, Mount Vernon broker. The tax valuation is $100,000.

Carl Pilnick defeated Peretz Miller yesterday in the semi-final round of the Marshall Chess Club championship tournament to make his score 11 1/2 to 2 1/2 .With one more game he has an opportunity of either gaining a tie or beating Anthony E. Santasiere, who finished last week with 12 -- 3.

" The Emperor's Clothes," starring Lee J. Cobb, will open at 8 o'clock this evening at the Barrymore. It will mark George Tabori's second local attempt to hit the bull's-eye, his first play. "Flight Into Egypt," having had a short romp last season.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Pressure for an increase in the interest rate on home mortgages guaranteed by the Veterans Administration was expected to increase here this week as builders and real estate interests prepared to put their case before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee.

EL PASO, Tex., Feb. 8 (AP) -- Ted Kroll, a 33-year-old star of the golf trail, sank an eagle 2 on the eleventh hole today and it helped him to tie Chandler Harper for first place in the $10,000 El Paso open. Each had 6-under par 278's for the 72 holes.

The threat of an additional tug strike by a small but important independent union against the Esso Standard Oil Company, largest suppliers in the Port of New York of fuel oil for shipping, was averted over the week-end, it was learned yesterday.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public, which will mature within twelve months, amount to $71,397,283,626. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

An amendment to the State Constitution of vital importance to the preservation of the Adirondack Preserve has been introduced in the Legislature. This measure, known as the Ostrander Amendment, passed almost unanimously last year and we hope will be passed again to comply with the necessary first steps for submission to referendum.

The trial of Minot Frazier (Mickey) Jelke 3d on charges of compulsory prostitution and living off the proceeds of vice will resume this morning with arguments on whether the press and public shall be admitted to the courtroom.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (UP) -- An Agriculture Department official said today that the New Zealand beef was selling at low prices in this country because it was largely "low grade" meat. He denied that imports of the beef had played a major part in cutting United States beef prices, which have been down because of a large supply.

A young man who went to Felony Court yesterday looking for his girl found that detectives were looking for him. He is James (Sonny) Smith, 21 years old, of 1980 Park Avenue. Both he and his friend, Linda Blanchet, 18, of 100 West 114th Street, were charged with possession of narcotics.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- In a unanimous decision here today the National Labor Relations Board ruled that five-year collective bargaining contracts in the automobile and farm equipment manufacturing industries could be used to prevent union representation elections for the duration of the contract.

The American Federation of Labor's reported plans for ending racketeering on our docks appear to be sound. Assuming that there is little likelihood that the International Longshoremen's Association, the breeding ground for evil elements, will rid itself of its anti-social forces by April 30, the Federation is preparing to fill the vacuum.

A $28,796,062 program for modernizing the Long Island Rail Road's electric passenger-car fleet, calling for the purchase of 112 new cars and the rehabilitation of 558 others, has been forwarded by a special committee to William Wyer, trustee of the bankrupt road. The plan, which provides for the eventual retirement of 431 of the line's oldest cars, assertedly is the most economical way of modernizing the entire fleet.
LACONIA, N. H., Feb. 8 -- Jon Riinaes, Norwegian electric engineering student at New Hampshire University, won the Eastern States ski jumping tournament on the 65-meter Torger Tokle Hill today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations criticized today changes in the Taft-Hartley labor law proposed by Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, the Republican Majority Leader, as falling short of "the standard of justice and fairness to labor promised by President Eisenhower."

Gordon K. Greenfield, formerly president of Oppenheim Collins Co., was elected president and director of City Specialty Stores, Inc. of which Franklin Simon Co., Inc. and Oppenheim Collins are subsidiaries. Under the new corporative setup, Mr. Greenfield will also function as executive head of the Franklin Simon Division, it was announced over the week-end.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Roger Tubby, who served for a time as White House press secretary for Harry S. Truman, returned from a Bermuda vacation with his wife today to find that their three children had been injured in an automobile accident yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 8 -- Four British manufacturers have concluded arrangements to equip a 10,000,000 ($28,000,000) iron and steel plant at Aviles in Asturias, Spain. The plant, designed to exploit virgin iron and coal deposits in Asturias, is scheduled to start production late in 1956 or early in 1957 with art initial output of 350,000 tons a year.

TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 8 -- Almost without warning, prohibition hit Iran today. After only five hours' debate the Iranian Parliament unanimously approved a bill prohibiting the importation, manufacture, purchase, sale and use of alcoholic beverages anywhere in the country.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Representative Harold H. Velde, Republican of Illinois, chairman of the House Un-American Activities Committee, said today, "It's a lot better to wrongly accuse one person of being a Communist than to allow so many to get away with such Communist acts as those that have brought us to the brink of World War III."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (UP) -- Twenty-three members of the House of Representatives from big cities called today for the creation of a joint Congressional committee to "counterbalance" producer lobbies and help protect the housewife now that controls were being lifted.

The Weather Bureau has a number of phrases which are as cheerful and pleasant as any in the language. In the middle of a long winter, for example, it always is good to read or hear "sunny and warm tomorrow."

The flying trip to Europe which Secretary of State Dulles completes this morning was a success. Such a judgment naturally depends on what one expected and what could have been achieved -- not to mention the positive damage and setback to the defense of the West which could have occurred if Mr. Dulles had handled himself less well.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Feb. 8 -- One week after their worst flood in five centuries, 10,500,000 Dutch -- except those engaged in rescue and repair -- paused today for a day of national mourning for the 1,372 officially recorded dead and the hundreds missing.

ZURICH, Feb. 8 -- At least as regards transport of international goods European integration already has been established as the outcome of a conference, the first of its kind ever held, of the ministers of traffic of eight European countries successfully concluded in Paris a few days ago, according to Dr. Joseph Escher, Swiss Minister for Posts and Railways, last week.

The creation of an independent transit authority with initial jurisdiction over all municipal lines (at a 15-cent fare), the four East River bridges, the city's Staten Island ferry service and the metered parking of automobiles on city streets has been recommended by two former city officials.

Going into the final session last night of the 1953 life master's individual championship, Norman Kay of Merchantville, N. J., continued to lead a field of seventy-two contract bridge experts at the McAlpin Hotel in the annual contest for one of the American Contract Bridge League's most highly regarded national titles.

A $50,000 telescope-like device that uses cobalt in the fight against cancer was unveiled yesterday at the Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx. Dr. John C. Bugher, director of the Atomic Energy Commission's division of biology and medicine, said Montefiore thus became the first hospital in the United States to use the machine and that its use marked "one of the more significant moments in the medical history of this country."

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 8 (AP) -- Top-seeded Gardnar Mulloy and Doris Hart, both of Miami, moved into the finals of the men's and women's singles today in the ninth annual Austin Smith tennis tournament.

VIENNA, Feb. 8 -- Recent rumors of widespread arrests of Hungarian law enforcement officials were partly confirmed today by an announcement of the Budapest radio that Gyula Decsei had been succeeded as Minister of Justice by Bela Kovacs.

Ch. Majara Mihrab, 3 1/2-year-old dog owned by Mr. and Mrs. Frederick A. Jagger of Somerville, N. J., led among ninety entries for the breed laurels yesterday at the seventh annual specialty event of the Afghan Hound Club of America at the Henry Hudson Hotel.

ROME, Feb. 8 -- All newspapers except those of the extreme Left gave prominence this morning to Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce's nomination as Ambassador to Rome, publishing the news from Washington with long, eulogistic biographies and photographs.

Disagreement on a formula for determining the size of crews on small tugs and Diesel-powered craft was the sole issue yesterday that was holding up the settlement of the eight-day-old strike of 3,500 towboat workers.

ALBANY, Feb. 8 -- Mayor Impelliteri will appear Wednesday at a public hearing on Governor Dewey's state budget to plead for $62,700,000 more in state aid for New York City, Victor F. Condello, the city's legislative representative, announced here tonight.

TO THE average sports follower the Amateur Athletic Union is an unnecessary collection of stuffed shirts, badge wearers and pompous individuals who clutter up the footracing finish lines so that the paying customers can't even see what's happening. They also are an egregious group of free-loaders who junket all over the world at fancy salaries and with all expenses paid, dictatorial parasites on the athletes who do the work.

BERLIN, Feb. 8 -- Soviet secret police began planting agents in East German Jewish communal organizations as early as last June, according to the eight leading Jews of that region who recently fled to West Berlin in a body.

BERLIN, Feb. 8 (AP) -- The East German Communist purge, forcing a mass flight of refugees to the West, showed some signs of boomeranging today. A new crop of East Germans who fled to West Berlin said the Russians had ordered the German Communist regime to put a halt to the exodus and that twenty-four border police had been arrested for helping Soviet zone residents escape.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Gen. Hoyt S. Vandenberg, Air Force Chief of Staff, said today the Soviet Union has hundreds of B-29 type bombers "capable of carrying atomic bombs on one-way flights to targets anywhere in the United States."

" All of us make excuses, everyone is prone to put a screen of lies between himself and reality," the Rev. William R. Woofended said yesterday in a sermon at the New Church (Swedenborgian) at 118 East Thirty-fifth Street.
In this period of doubt as to whom to put in the City Hall, it seems to me that we are admitting our inability to think.

TOKYO, Monday, Feb. 9 -- Fifth Air Force and Marine Corps fighter-bombers of the United Nations Command took advantage of clear weather in Korea yesterday to work over the Communist front line positions and behind-the-lines supply areas.

OTTAWA, Feb. 8 (Canadian Press) -- Three new cobalt "bombs" for the treatment of cancer are expected to go into operation before the end of March, R. F. Errington, chief of the commercial division of Atomic Energy of Canada, said tonight.

The Concordia Choir, consisting of thirty men and thirty-five young women from Concordia College in Moorhead, Minn., gave a concert Saturday night at Carnegie Hall. It was conducted by Paul J. Christiansen, who has bean director of the choir since 1937.

Three thousand Boy Scouts of the Roman Catholic faith marched yesterday from the armory at Lexington Avenue and Twenty-sixth Street to St. Patrick's Cathedral in the annual observance of Scout Sunday, part of Boy Scout Week.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 8 (UP) -- Betty Jameson of San Antonio today won a three-way play-off in the Miami Beach women's invitational golf tournament.

The Citizens Budget Commission, unofficial watchdog of the city treasury, took issue yesterday with Governor Dewey's declaration of last Wednesday that "the city cannot maintain its services without additional revenues."
BOSTON, Feb. 8 -- Dr. James B. Conant left by train tonight on the first stage of a trip that will confront him with the urgent problems of West Germany.

TADISON, Wis., Feb. g (PJ-- William Antas of Earasota, Fla., former radio press agent for Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus, died here today at the age of 47. Pie had entered Wisconsin General Hospital with a heart condition a week ago. ,r. IAntas was former editor of the weekly Evansville Review. He was a graduate of the University of Wisconsin.

Mal Whitfield lowered the world indoor 500-yard record to 56.6 seconds, Bob Richards raised the meet pole vault mark to 15 feet 4 1/4 inches and Fred Dwyer, Ken Wiesner, Harrison Dillard and Arthur Bragg also turned in brilliant performances to remain unbeaten for the season at Saturday's New York Athletic Club games.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Feb. 8 -- After two week-ends of forced idleness because of wind blasts, the sailing dinghies at the Larchmont Yacht Club were brought out of storage today. Too much wind none at all or harbor ice stops them.

Carrying out simple scientific experiments in the manner of parlor magic tricks can be fun for adults and children, but the activity will not help youngsters acquire a "scientific attitude," Dr. Glenn O. Blough, specialist in elementary science in the United States Office of Education, Washington, told members of the Metropolitan New York Association for Childhood Education recently.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 8 -- Warner Brothers, with more than 1,600 production workers engaged in nine "major" films, is operating at the full capacity of the studio's twenty-one sound stages. The company is engaged in a filming spurt not equaled since the boom days of the late Nineteen Forties, according to Jack L. Warner, vice president in charge of production.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8 (UP) -- Meat packing experts said today that the New Zealand beef being sold at reduced prices in some sections of the country had come to the United States as a substitute for the normal import of Canadian beef.
BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Feb. 8 -- Roy Sherwood, a 20-year-old Connecticut tree surgeon, today beat Mezzy Barber and Artie Devlin to capture the annual Telemark Ski Club Trophy.
BOSTON, Feb. 8 (AP) -- The Boston Celtics ran their winning streak to three today by beating the New York Knickerbockers, 87 to 79, at the Boston Garden.
Christianity is "not a religion of the common man" but a "religion of the elite," Canon Derby W. Betts asserted in a sermon yesterday morning at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

The canine elite will meet today at Madison Square Garden to compare best points, but the somewhat doggier event was staged yesterday, when the Madison Square Boys Club held its annual pet show. Contestants were judged by their lovable qualities alone, by the length of their tails, by the look in their eyes.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 8 -- Steel ingot operations last week were estimated at 99 per cent of capacity, down a half a point from the week before. Had the steel strike in the Chicago district at a major plant continued last week the national steel operating rate would have been at a lower level.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress during the period of Jan. 31 to Feb. 6 are given in the appended tabulation:

Senator Charles W. Tobey promised yesterday that the Federal investigation into waterfront evils, which is to begin public hearings here in two weeks, would go beyond the disclosures of the State Crime Commission.

ELMONT, L. I., Feb. 8 -- Civic leaders here, spurred by the drowning Friday of three children in an abandoned sand pit, held a series of conferences today and canvassed their neighbors in seeking a feasible way to prevent a recurrence of the tragedy.

Cesare Siepi, the Metropolitan Opera bass, gave an enthusiastically received recital Saturday night at Hunter College Auditorium. Ably accompanied on the piano by Martin Rich, one of the Metropolitan's assistant conductors, Mr. Siepi was heard in a program comprising offerings in Italian, German, French and English.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (UP) -- Small cities now are surpassing larger ones in getting new television stations.

The Steamship Historical Society of America has re-elected Capt. Earl C. Palmer, assistant vice president of the Moran Towing and Transportation Company, as its president. Other officers rename were Frank O. Braynard, American Merchant Marine Institute, vice president; Edwin A. Patt of West Barrington, R. I., secretary, and H. Graham Wood of Baltimore, treasurer.

PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, Feb. 8 -- Princess Mary, the Princess Royal, arrived in Port of Spain this afternoon for a four-day visit as part of a tour of the British West Indies. The casual welcome given her by the city's public was an indication of the changing times and relationships with the mother country.

Directors of the National Broadcasting Company at their meeting last Friday elected William H. Fineshriber Jr. vice president and general manager of the radio and television networks and David C. Adams vice president for administration.

LONDON, Feb. 8 -- Having regard to numerous events of conflicting and varying importance, the stock markets have well maintained their strength in the past week although losing some of their activity.

PARIS, Feb. 8 -- When Premier Rene Mayer goes to London on Thursday with Foreign Minister Georges Bidault and Robert Buron, Minister for Economic Affairs, he will ask the British to relax the restrictions they have placed on imports from Western Europe.

A striking illustration of the quality of English dogs developed in the combined specialty of the Associated Terrier Clubs yesterday when five of the thirteen main winners in breeds or varieties were from that nation.

Some timeless musical issues were debated yesterday by six teen-agers and a critic who admitted to having been alive in 1920. Their discussion, over the New York Times Youth Forum, proved nothing about the relative mortality of jazz and the classics. But it tried hard to do so, and revealed some interesting young prejudices in its course.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 8 (UP) -- Hundreds of persons formed a line four blocks long outside the Metz Supermarket today to buy imported T-bone and sirloin steaks for 39 cents a pound. The line started forming at 6 A. M. for a sale of 7,000 pounds of New Zealand beef that lasted from 9 o'clock until noon.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8 -- Prices for all grains and soybeans dropped to new lows for the crop year last week, although there were intervals when it appeared that investment buying was effecting a gradual change in the market position. However, demand faded out on comparatively small rallies, and the grain market has been vulnerable to selling by professional operators who have little faith in the stability of prices.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Feb. 8 -- Nearly one-half of all new chemical plants approved in the current defense program have been located in the Southern states, the Southern Association of Science and Industry reported today.

AMSTERDAM, Feb. 8 -- The enormous damage in the southwestern Netherlands caused by the flooding of some 450,000 acres of fertile soil as well as the damage to many towns and villages is considered a major setback to the recent spectacular economic recovery staged here.

TOKYO, Monday, Feb. 9 -- Far East naval headquarters said Sunday that the United States Seventh Fleet was "manned and ready" for any job assigned to it as a result of "policy changes affecting the Orient."

This country is lucky to have in so important a post as that of High Commissioner to Germany a man as capable as Dr. James Bryant Conant. As an academic scientist, as an educator who revitalized Harvard University, as one who served his country well in the immensely important research work of the Second World War, standing firmly in defense of freedom against the successive Nazi and Communist tyrannies, Dr. Conant has proven his worth.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8 -- Pit trade in grain and soybean futures was slightly less in volume last week than the previous week and much smaller than a year ago. Average daily purchases of futures were 40,000,000 bushels approximately against 41,000,000 bushels the previous week and 55,000,000 bushels a year ago.

MOSCOW, Feb. 8 -- The Government newspaper Izvestia asserted today that Soviet security agencies had "liquidated" a nest of American spies established by George Roulard, former United States assistant naval attache in Vladivostok in 1947.

Do the United States and other Western powers have spy networks within the Soviet Union capable of stealing secret Soviet documents, as the Moscow press has been charging recently? The men in Washington, London, and elsewhere who know will not say, but those who are familiar with the problems and enormous difficulties involved in espionage within the Soviet Union are most doubtful that there is any truth to the Soviet charges.

Television and radio fans torn between strict loyalty to the old regular-sized cigarettes and neighborliness toward the king-sized newcomers can sneak in a little relief from the turmoil by discriminating dial flicking. Some programs oozing through here and there make an effort to entertain an audience instead of being satisfied with killing time or making a commercial pitch.

The life of the average man today is little different from the condition of a wind-tossed fishing schooner on an angry sea, which may be "in trouble but not in danger," the Rev. Albert L. Neibacher declared in his sermon yesterday morning at St. Luke's Lutheran Church, 308 West Forty-sixth Street.

" Keep calm!" That's the expression being used most by Bill D'Antonio, wrestling coach at the Loomis School, Windsor, Conn., these days. One of the youngest prep school mat coaches in the East, D'Antonio, 27, has found soothing words will do more than the much heralded pep talk.

MOSCOW, Feb. 8 -- Premier Stalin gives the impression of excellent physical condition, mental agility and a general state of robust health that belie his seventy-three years, in the opinion of Argentina's new Ambassador to Moscow, Luis Bravo, who spent forty-five minutes with Mr. Stalin in the Kremlin last night.
SEOUL, Korea, Feb. 8 (AP) -- An Eighth Army court yesterday sentenced a private to fifteen years and dishonorable discharge for the carbine murder of a Korean and the wounding of a second.

LYNDONVILLE, Vt., Feb. 8 -- Bowdoin College, with 550.40 points, won the Eastern Intercollegiate Ski Association's six-event meet at Lyndonville Outing Club today, beating eight other teams. Harvard was second with 548.26 points. Richard Church of Bowdoin was the skimeister for the third straight year.

Reading Jeremy Bentham's hitherto unpublished works is a little like coming upon the venerable economist in the locker room and discovering that he wears the colorful shorts of the Broadway haberdasher -- shorts decorated with sketches, wisecracks and inspirational slogans.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 8 -- The support given Chancellor Konrad Adenauer and his Government by the Eisenhower Administration during the last week appeared today to have insured the Federal Government's approval of pending Allied-West German accords.

Outstandingly fine dogs appeared in various parts of the city yesterday to remind passers-by that the seventy-seventh show of the Westminster Kennel Club was imminent. It will begin this morning and end tomorrow night.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Feb. 8 (UP) -- The ruling Conservative party made public today the draft of a new constitution for Colombia. The Liberal opposition charged immediately that it would ban freedom in the country.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Recent "go-slow" signals from the White House have failed to change prospects for passage of the Reed tax-relief bill by the House of Representatives in ample time for it to become effective on July 1. The measure was put forward by Representative Daniel A. Reed, Republican of upstate New York.
