NEWINGTON, N. H., Feb. 8 -- The bell in Newington's 241-year-old church sounded repeatedly today the town's rejoicing over an indicated halt in construction of the Portsmouth-Newington jet bomber base.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 8 -- "The growing shadow of World War III together with shipments of jet planes from the West and anti-Zionist broadcasts from the East have given the Arabs new impetus in their 'little war' against Israel. Their effect on the public has been to make it more sensitive about incidents [such as the attempt to blow up an Israeli train] and the demand for 'active defense' is growing."

Valentine sweets, some new, some familiar even to the most venerable sentimentalist, are featured at a candy fair being held today through Friday in Altman's first-floor delicacy shop. There are confections free for the nibbling, distributed by twelve prettily costumed salesgirls.

The establishment of an extensive mental health program in a Federal Department of Health and Welfare, and the formation of a permanent state mental health commission are among twenty recommendations made in a new New York University study of mental Health services in the metropolitan area.
Any attempt to link wages to the changes in the efficiency of the economy is "impractical and undesirable," it was asserted yesterday by the National Association of Manufacturers.

Vice Admiral Ma - Chi-chuang, Commander in Chief of the Chinese Nationalist Navy, asserted yesterday that the Chinese Nationalist Army in Formosa numbered 600,000 soldiers who were well equipped and trained and were "continuously preparing for the offensive against the mainland." He said that such an offensive would be supported by 1,500,000 guerrillas on the mainland.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Senator Everett M. Dirksen, Republican of Illinois, said today that Senate investigators of "gravy train" charges against the Justice Department's alien property office would start public hearings on Feb. 17.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 8 -- The American Federation of Labor called upon all its affiliated unions today to press for higher wages this year as a necessary measure to head off a major depression in 1954 or 1955.

The fifteenth week at the Metropolitan Opera will see the season's last "Meistersinger," on Tuesday, Feb. 17, and the first Metropolitan appearance of Paoli Silveri as Scarpia in the Wednesday "Tosca."
LEAVENWORTH, Kan., Feb. 8 (AP) -- June Haver stepped today from a glamorous life of movie stardom into the quiet sanctuary of the Sisters of Charity.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Feb. 8 -- Torch Commando, the war veterans' group that last year roused the liberal and British elements in South Africa to a storm of protest against authoritarian tendencies of Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan and his Nationalist Government, acknowledged today that the "despotic powers" the Government was demanding might be necessary to deal with the mounting crisis in race relations.
The day is not far off when winter coats and furs will be discarded. Soon plans must be made for a spring and summer wardrobe.

DAVOS, Switzerland, Feb. 8 (UP) -- John and Jennifer Nicks, son and daughter of a Brighton (England) sports shop owner, today defeated a star Canadian team to win the pairs title in the world figure skating championships before a crowd of about 2,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 8 -- Contemporary examples of traditional American crafts ranging from hooked rugs to handsome silver objects make up an exhibit at the Philadelphia Art Alliance. The exhibition, which opened last Friday and will continue through March 1, is the result of a regional competition of craftsmen within sixty-five miles of Philadelphia.

A dress manufacturer and eleven of his employes will appear today in Magistrates Court, Long Island City, Queens, on charges of conspiring to draw unemployment insurance benefits on top of pay, Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- The American Association of School Administrators suggested today that school builders do away with such things as "fancy doodads" to achieve economy in school construction without compromising education.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, Republican Leader of the Senate, added fuel today to the major foreign policy debate, now shaping up in Congress, by declaring that the United States already was "at full war" with Communist China.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 7 -- Business men and foreign traders have no information on how foreign exchange regulations to be deccreed by the Superintendency of Currency and Credit will affect business.

Seven leaders in the communications and amusement fields will be honored at a dinner to be given Feb. 19 by the National Conference of Christians and Jews in the Waldorf-Astoria to mark Brotherhood Week, Feb. 15-22.

Held off by the visiting net guardian through most of the game, the persistent New York Rangers finally broke through the defense of the Canadiens of Montreal to gain a goal in the National Hockey League clash at Madison Square Garden last night. The tally enabled the Broadway Blues to go into a 1-to-1 tie with the Habitants, and the deadlock obtained to the end of the battle.

ALBANY, Feb. 8 -- Gov. Dewey announced today that he had requested the State Law Revision Commission to undertake a study of the proposed uniform Commercial Code that was introduced in the Legislature last year but not reported out of committee.

A photograph of President Eisenhower, scowling, won the seventeenth annual competition of the Press Photographers Association of New York for Bert Brandt, a United Press photographer, the organization announced yesterday.

In my humble opinion Pieter W. Fosburgh's letter, published Jan. 28, on Willard G. Van Name's earlier letter calls for comment. Dr. Van Name is a sincere and realistic citizen. He is also a professional naturalist and an old hand on lumbering techniques. As voluntary guardian of our natural resources for more than thirty years, his warnings to the public in the past have been well founded in fact.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 8 -- India will require $1,310,000,000 by way of foreign assistance if her five-year plan is to be successfully completed by the end of March, 1956, according to an official analysis by the Ministry of Finance.

Facts about heart diseases "which we should all know and take to heart" were listed yesterday by Dr. John H. Keating, president of the New York Heart Association, in connection with the city-wide observance of Heart Week. The facts follow:

The International Longshoremen's Union, A. F. L., demanded yesterday the immediate payment of a wage rise of 17 cents an hour awarded by an arbitrator last November. The new wage rate had been under consideration by the Wage Stabilization Board, which President Eisenhower ordered abolished Friday.

" Alicia Markova: Her Life and Art," a biography of the ballerina by her equally famous partner, Anton Dolin, will be published by Hermitage on Feb. 19. The book takes her from childhood to her present "pinnacle of success."

The news that two more South Korean divisions will go into action comes at the time that there is discussion of a broad plan to equip and train larger numbers of Asian troops for the defense of their countries. What is being done in Korea can be done elsewhere, and there are several points in Asia where the need for stronger defense forces is clear.

LONDON, Feb. 8 -- The storm that blew up in the British press over President Eisenhower's decision no longer to enforce the neutrality of the Chinese Nationalists of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek on Formosa has not abated, although Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden's calm and reasoned words in the House of Commons went far toward allaying Parliamentary fears, except among the Left extremists.

As an Englishman visiting the United States on business I have had to make a visit to the United States Tax Department at the end of each trip to make a declaration that I have not received any income while in the United States or, if I have received an income, that I have paid my taxes.

Three museum shows are featured on this week's local art program. Recent acquisitions of European and American painting and sculpture will go on view Wednesday at the Museum of Modern Art, while the Metropolitan will show contemporary American and British paintings from the Edward Root collection, beginning Thursday. At the Brooklyn Museum is an exhibition of prints by Hogarth and Cruikshank entitled "Fashions and Foibles."

Members of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union, independent, voted yesterday to accept a new wage and hour agreement with metropolitan wholesale newspaper distributors, but at the same time resolved to continue a strike against suburban dealers.

TOKYO, Monday, Feb. 9 (UP) -- The Chinese Communist radio broadcast today a purported "record" of United Nations losses in the Korean war that proved ridiculously out of line with the United Nations Command's count. The Peiping broadcast said United Nations losses included more than 736,000 troops killed or wounded, 322,000 of them American.
Twelve months ago the writer offered this observation here:

LIMA, Peru, Feb. 8 -- The Government charged today that the Cominform was organizing Communist movements throughout Latin America and said there was definite evidence of Red conspiracy in last week's abortive strike in the Peruvian port city of Arequipa.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Senator Russell B. Long, Democrat of Louisiana, said today that a Defense Department order to hold up all new military construction until it has been reviewed and justified, might save taxpayers a billion dollars or more.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 8 -- Reports emanating from the discussions for a Balkan entente among Turkey, Greece and Yugoslavia have reinforced the view among diplomats here that the Western powers must make a drastic direct intervention in the dispute between Italy and Yugoslavia over the Free Territory of Trieste if a settlement is ever to be achieved.

BOSTON, Feb. 8 (UP) -- The Detroit Red Wings scored twice in the closing minutes tonight against a tiring Boston Bruin team to extend their unbeaten streak to seven games with a 5-3 victory before 10,004 Boston Garden fans.

Four hundred industrial concerns in the metropolitan area will be invited to send representatives for specialized training in economic mobilization to be given by the armed services at the Astor Hotel in the weeks of March 23 and April 3.
CHICAGO, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Many Chicago tavern patrons have wondered why Budweiser beer seemed scarce in recent weeks.

Active cotton futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange closed Friday with net changes ranging from 42 points lower to 17 higher, with all the losses in the near deliveries. In the previous week the market had been 41 points higher to 7 points lower, with all the gains near-by.

Dr. James Perkins, managing director of the National Tuberculosis Association, has seen fit to comment rather acidly in his letter published Feb. 3 on the recent reference in my annual report to the "nonscientific, highly emotional reaction from certain quarters of the tuberculosis world" at the first news of the anti-tuberculosis drugs.

The five-story house containing seven apartments on lot 20 by 100 feet at 52 East Sixty-fourth Street, near Park Avenue, was resold by Joseph L. Ennis Co., operators, to Henry Payson, operator. Assessed at $65,000, the property was sold for cash through Harold M. Silverman, Inc., broker.

IN the spring of 1951 the Sixty-sixth Fighter-Bomber Wing was stationed at the Akuni Air Force Base, in Japan. Its commander, Col. William A. Straker, was an efficient soldier and a good man in a jet plane. But he was also a sanctimonious bully who mistook his self-righteous pleasure in killing for virtue and religious faith.

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 8 -- A warning that partition of Iran may be inevitable and that the United States "should either, with or without the conjunction of the British, lend every possible support to a Persian [Iranian] Government sympathetic to the Western world, in the southern half of Persia," is contained in a letter from a United States Ambassador who is resigning from the Foreign Service after many years' experience in Near Eastern affairs.

State and city mediation teams were scheduled to join forces today in a new attempt to settle the four-week-old strike of more than 200 gravediggers against the owners of seventeen cemeteries in Long Island, Westchester and Brooklyn.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb 8 -- Denouncing Israel's Communists as "avowed enemies of the Jewish nation, the State of Israel and the Hebrew workers movement," the secretariat of the General Federation of Labor (Histadrut) voted today to bay the Communist party from the organization, take action in a court of honor to expel the party's representatives from membership and, pending the court's verdict, to suspend all Communist office holders.

Television set advertising in newspapers, both national and dealer, ran to over 4,285,000 column inches in 1952, according to an analysis of over 250,000 appliance advertisements made public yesterday by the Advertising Checking Bureau, Inc., in Chicago.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) -- The Army, apparently concerned over recurrent reports of ammunition shortages in Korea, said tonight that more than 52,000,000 rounds of artillery and 3,000,000,000 rounds of small arms ammunition had been made last year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (UP) -- Representative Katharine St. George, Republican of Tuxedo Park, N. Y., said today that a constitutional amendment guaranteeing equal rights for women had a good chance of passage in the present Congress.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- President Eisenhower today attended the church that the first Republican President, Abraham Lincoln, had attended, and with Mrs. Eisenhower he witnessed the unveiling of a historic document -- Lincoln's handwritten draft of his first proposal to abolish slavery.
TOKYO, Monday, Feb. 9 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique, 1520, covering Sunday's activities:

MONTCLAIR, N. J., Feb. 8 -- A rarely seen bird, which legend says suffered a permanent twist in its beak while trying to pull the nails out of Christ's hands and feet on the cross, is staging what may be its greatest invasion here since 1900.

Making his first formal showing, Mrs. Henry W. Lark's 2-year-old fawn dog, Meritairis Fancy Free, by Ch. Bang Away of Sirrah Crest, 1951 winner at Westminster, took the top award last night in the tenth annual specialty show of the American Boxer Club at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory. The competition drew a total of 258 boxers.

SEATTLE, Feb. 8 (AP) -- A tanker is aground in Grays Harbor. A tug is slowly towing 500 tons of explosives in a leaking barge off the Washington coast. A crippled fishing boat has a broken rudder, also off the Washington coast.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 8 -- A Mau Mau gang killed another European settler last night -- the eighth European murdered by the native terrorists.

LUXEMBOURG, Feb. 8 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles left Europe tonight after having paid his respects here to the most advanced form of European unity yet attained, the Coal and Steel Community. He appeared to be convinced, from visits to each of their capitals, that the six nations that had formed the heavy industry pool would succeed in forming a European army on similar principles.
The reorganization of the Israel America Line and the establishment of Israel's first tramp shipping venture became known here yesterday.
Five new films, including an importation from Italy, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

To the extent that government can be shaped by the character and ideas of the directing personnel, a new pattern is clearly emerging in the first weeks of the Eisenhower Administration. The epochal "First Hundred Days" of the Roosevelt regime seemed more dramatic because the action then was all on the home stage, whereas today a great part of it is in the international theatre.

A concert was presented last night at the Lexington Avenue Y. M. H. A. under the auspices of the Composers Committee for Israeli and American-Jewish Music. On the program were works by Paul Ben Haim, Karol Rathaus, A. W. Binder, Julius Chajes, Karl Salomon, Jacob Weinberg, Heinrich Schalit, Daniel Samburski, Josef Tal, Itzchk Edel, Haim Alexander and Isadore Freed.
Religious faith cannot be acquired by man without the operation of God's grace, the Rev. Charles J. McManus of St. Patrick's Cathedral staff declared at solemn mass there yesteray.

Claudio Monteverdi's "The Coronation of Poppea" was composed in 1642, yet when it was revived yesterday for the New Friends of Music at Town Hall it was revealed as a work more pertinent in its comment on the world as we know it, more sensible and plausible in its plot and much more moving in its characterization than most of the operas written since.

Bishop James E. Kearney of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Rochester, N. Y., who recently ended fourteen years as Episcopal Moderator of the National Federation of Newman Clubs, received a plaque yesterday morning in tribute to his services.

TANGIER, Feb. 8 -- Spain has formally assured France that she will not permit in Spanish Morocco any activity designed to further the cause of Arab nationalism in the French-administered North African territories, diplomatic circles said today.
CINCINNATI, Feb. 8 (AP) -- The Kroger Company today reported a net income of $12,110,087 for 1952 or the equivalent of $3.30 a share after taxes.

Whether the present Congress and Administration will give us two new states, or one new state, or no new state is uncertain. The Republican platform promised "immediate statehood for Hawaii" and "statehood for Alaska under an equitable enabling act."

ALBANY, Feb. 8 -- The Republican State Administration is reported to have reached a tentative agreement to include in the bill extending state rent control a provision giving upstate cities and other local governments power to end controls in their areas.

Installation of signs to make effective the Traffic Departments new rule of "no standing, loading or unloading" at peak periods on First and Second Avenues will start today. The police will issue warnings until next Monday, whereafter violators will be subject to $15 fines.

Four proposals for reducing the extent of double taxation on income from foreign sources were announced yesterday by the world trade department of the Commerce and Industry Association of New York.

With reference to your editorial oi Feb. 4 "Perspective on Farm Prices" I own and have eperated a. 400-acre fruit and dairy iarm in this ,state for eighteen 5,ears, and profoundly hope that the Federal Government will promptly cut out all of the nonsense and waste involved in phantom farm subsidies.

John V. Lyon, chairman of the New York Shipping Association, announced yesterday that association member companies would begin payment "as soon as possible" of an estimated $12,000,000 in retroactive pay due 40,000 New York longshoremen under an arbitration award made Nov. 25.

Most folks who live in the cities and suburbs get along without porches -- those little roofed platforms just about big enough to hold a doormat, found in suburbs, aren't really porches at all -- but country people still vote for the old-fashioned porch.

Sidney L. Cahn, special arbitrator for the publishing industry, yesterday extended for twenty days his recent order forbidding members of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union to interfere with the transport of metropolitan newspapers to railway stations.

Two large works of religious inspiration shared the season's seventh concert of the Little Orchestra Society at Town Hall last night. Thomas Scherman joined a modern master with a classic master in bracketing Darius Milhaud's Sabbath Morning Service with Beethoven's dramatic oratorio, "Christus am Oelberge" (Christ on the Mount of Olives).

LUXEMBOURG, Feb. 9 -- A revolutionary step toward an economic integration of six European countries will be taken tomorrow with the inauguration of a single market for coal and steel embracing France, West Germany, Italy, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg, which form the European Coal and Steel Community.

Industrial working capital is "tight but adequate," despite postwar plant expansion and growth of markets, according to a survey of 200 manufacturing companies announced yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board.

Small business men and their trade groups throughout the country were urged last night by Telford Taylor, former head of the Small Defense Plants Administration, to take "prompt and organized action to preserve and strengthen" the agency.

Although the architects of European unification still argue over the blueprints for the superstructure of their project, the first concrete cornerstone of what is ultimately intended to become a United States of Europe will be laid today when the High Authority of the European Coal and Steel Community establishes in practice the first single free-trade market Europe has known.

Reporting on a research study of the nation's productivity, the National Association of Manufacturers finds that so many factors enter into productivity, and so many obstacles stand in the way, that it is "impractical and undesirable" as a matter of national wage policy to consider tying wages to estimates of output per man hour.

All-day parkers on First and Second Avenues won yesterday a forty-eight-hour reprieve when the Traffic Department found that installation of 626 "no standing, loading or unloading" signs for use in peak periods could not be completed until tonight.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- A check today showed that proposals for sixty-three investigations were in the hands of the House Rules Committee, apparently held there by Republican policy makers.

TRENTON, Feb. 9 -- The New Jersey State Legislature late tonight climaxed a day of bitter debate and repeated caucusing by creating an eight-man committee to examine publicly the manner in which crime has been fought by the state.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- President Eisenhower and Republican Congressional leaders met today and agreed on an eleven-point legislative program covering measures proposed by the President in his recent message on the State of the Union.
ALBANY, Feb. 9 (UP) -- The State Commerce Department today reported the following skiing conditions:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (UP) -- A Protestant group protested today that Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce "should not go" to Rome, if she was to serve as Presidential contact with the Vatican as well as Ambassador to Italy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The system of selecting jurors used by North Carolina does not involve facial discrimination and hence does not violate the Federal Constitution, the Supreme Court ruled, 6 to 3, today.

Fresh color schemes are combined with contemporary, comparatively inexpensive furnishings to give a "high style" look to this year's Queens County Catholic War Veterans Prize Home, now on view to the public. Located at 85-88 Parsons Boulevard, Jamaica, Queens, the house, the sixth in a series, will be open until May 23.

No doubt was seen here yesterday that the deal would strengthen the A. B. C. radio and television networks, giving them a higher competitive standing among the other chains. It has been indicated that United Paramount has about $35,000,000 to invest in broadcasting activities.

SYRACUSE, Feb. 9 -- Educational television operated by the state as recommended by the Board of Regents ran into sharp opposition from newspaper editors when it came before the two-day winter meeting of the New York State Society of Newspaper Editors at their session today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The State Department completely dissociated the Government today from the suggestion of J. Rives Childs, former United States Ambassador to Ethiopia, that American forces prepare to "occupy" southern Iran.

Net admitted assets of the Home Insurance Company on Dec. 31 amounted to $396,933,148, according to Harold V. Smith, president. This represents an increase of 6 per cent above assets of $374,933,359 reported for Dec. 31, 1951.
With the rush for 1953 license plates virtually over, a drop of nearly 4 per cent in automobile registration here has been recorded, the Bureau of Motor Vehicles disclosed yesterday.

ALBANY, Feb. 9 -- Governor Dewey, in a special message tonight, urged the Assembly to approve a proposed Constitutional amendment providing for the joint election of the Governor and Lieutenant Governor the same as the joint Presidential ticket in national elections.

GENEVA, Feb. 9 -- The Red Cross disaster relief operation in the Netherlands following last week's invasion by the North Sea is "without any doubt" the speediest in history, Edward Winsall, director of relief for the League of Red Cross Societies, said today.

American business apparently fears no depression or even serious recession before the end of 1955 at the earliest, M. Joseph Meehan declared yesterday. He is director of the Office of Business Economics, United States Department of Commerce.

GUATEMALA, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Federal troops fired tonight on thousands of students and white collar workers demonstrating in front of the National Palace, seat of the Communist-tinged Government. At least one person was killed and several others were wounded.

Three members of Local 65 of the Distributive, Processing and Office Workers of America, an independent union, were arrested yesterday after they allegedly had overturned chairs and had pulled telephone lines from the switchboard of the Stein-Tex Fabrics Corporation at 1441 Broadway.

London, Feb. 9 -- Western deputies in the Austrian treaty negotiations joined today in telling Andrei A. Gromyko, the Soviet representative, that the Russians' "obstructionist tactics had forced them to the conclusion that his Government had no desire for serious negotiations and that they must soon report to their Governments.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 9 -- The American Federation of Labor drew up proposals today to relax the ban on the closed shop, abolish injunctions under the Taft-Hartley Act and restore many of the privileges enjoyed by unions under the old Wagner Act.

Bankers have a responsibility to assert their leadership in the promotion of "democratic capitalism" and the preservation of sound money, the Midwinter Trust Conference of the American Bankers Association was told yesterday. Nearly 1,800 banking executives from all sections of the nation are attending the three-day sessions at the Waldorf-Astoria.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Feb. 9 -- The Americanism committee of the Westchester County American Legion said today it would hold a "civil liberties" forum here on the night of Feb. 20 and had invited Dr. Harold Taylor, president of Sarah Lawrence College or Bronxville, to speak but he had declined.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Feb. 9 -- The Williams College chapter of Phi Delta Theta was suspended last night from membership in the national fraternity for accepting a Jewish student in contravention of a clause in its constitution that restricts membership to "men of white and full Aryan blood."

Judge Harold R. Medina expressed the belief at the investment banking anti-trust trial yesterday that the Government's complaint was fashioned to include things that could not have been thought true so that the complaint could withstand an attack for legal insufficiency.

Stung by repeated assertions by the Kings County rackets grand jury that there were continuing links between gamblers and policemen, Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan relieved three top ranking Brooklyn officers of their commands yesterday. He also sent their twenty-five plainclothes men back to pounding beats, and incidental to the shake-up shifted eight other superior officers.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 9 (AP) -- "High Noon" and "The Quiet Man" tied for top honors in the Motion Picture Academy nominations, which were announced tonight.

NORMAN, Okla., Feb. 9 (AP) -- The Edmonton Eskimos of the Canadian Football League today used security as a selling point to get All-American Halfback Billy Vessels of Oklahoma away from the Baltimore Colts of the National League, who had named Vessels their No. 1 draft choice.

At the annual election yesterday of the American Stock Exchange, Stanley E. Symons, Frank C. Masterson and Louis Reich were elected to the board of governors. John H. Mann, board chairman, was re-elected, Edward T. McCormick, president, announced.

The board of managers of St. Barnabas Hospital for Chronic Diseases, 4422 Third Avenue, the Bronx, has elected John B. Marsh, New York lawyer, its president. He succeeds Rogers H. Bacon. He also succeeds Mr. Bacon as president of the Braker Memorial Home, an affiliate of the hospital situated on its grounds.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 9 -- The kitchen is the hub ground which other areas are placed in a one-story- nine-room, contemporary house designed by Oscar Stonorov. Completely constructed, furnished and landscaped, the house is part of a home-show exhibition at the Commercial Museum in Philadelphia, which opened today and will continue through Saturday.

TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 9 -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh today ordered legal action against three former high officials he accused of causing a 2,243,543 ($6,281,920) loss to the Iranian National Bank at the time of devaluation of the pound.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Mutual Security Director Harold E. Stassen today told a group of fifty-five business men and financiers going abroad to evaluate the foreign aid program thier job was to see how it could be improved and not scuttled.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The Interstate Commerce Commissison announced today that it had suspended until next September a group of railroad tariffs reducing rates on imported iron ore from Boston, Baltimore, Philadelphia and New York to Youngstown, Pittsburgh, Wheeling and adjacent areas.

As Mayor Impellitteri moved yesterday to complete the personnel of the new Board of Air Pollution Control, the air pollution department moved against waterfront smoke by issuing a summons against the liner Queen of Bermuda.

Five of twelve overt acts listed in the treason indictment against John David Provoo, Army sergeant, were struck out yesterday by Federal Judge Gregory F. Noonan. The case is expected to go to the jury today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The fact that only a handful of Senators was present last Friday night when the vote was taken on motions to confirm Gen. W. Bedell Smith and Dr. James B. Conant has led to the impression in some quarters that their confirmations were sneaked through to prevent the revelation of a large and strongly opposed minority.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The Federal Communications Commission approved today the merger of the United Paramount Theatres, Inc., and the American Broadcasting Company, the biggest transaction in broadcasting history.

THOSE whose pursuit of philosophical angling can encompass a fairly heavy financial burden will be interested in the availability of several stretches on New Brunswick's famous Upsalquitch, scheduled to go on the block at public auction on April 1.

President Eisenhower is expected within the next few days to issue an executive order revising present loyalty and security procedures. If advance reports are correct, the effect of his order will be to give to the head of each executive agency the ultimate authority (subject only to appeal through the courts) to dismiss any employe on "security" grounds alone.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Feb. 9 -- The French have just destroyed six Vietminh war factories hidden in the jungle of South Vietnam (Cochin China).
American Enka Corporation has been licensed to manufacture nylon textile fiber by E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., it was announced yesterday.

ALBANY, Feb. 9 -- The Democratic minority in the Assembly tonight attempted unsuccessfully to force out of the Judiciary Committee a bill that would put permanent personal registration in effect in New York. The maneuver failed by a vote of 96 to 51, with the Republican members of the Assembly voting unanimously against it.

George Tabori, an amiable Hungarian, has scribbled a play about Budapest in 1930, "The Emperor's Clothes," which opened at the Ethel Barrymore last evening. In this case the word "scribble" is used advisedly. For Mr. Tabori likes to write at random, putting in an amusing bit here and a trenchant bit there -- hoping to make a dramatic point through indirection.

Dr. James B. Conant, new United States High Commissioner in West Germany, left by air for Frankfurt at 4:15 P. M. yesterday to assume his new post. Before leaving, he emphasized his awareness of the responsibilities and difficulties ahead.

ROCQUENCOURT, France. Feb. 9 -- Supreme Headquarters, Allied Powers in Europe, has made its recommendations to the permanent North Atlantic Treaty staff on how the Allied nations can best increase their combat readiness during the rest of 1953.

PARIS, Feb. 9 -- Opening a conference here with Saarland officials for a revision on the French-Saar conventions, Georges Bidault, French Foreign Minister, insisted today on the necessity for the continued economic attachment of the Saar to France.
According to Chaucer and Donne, birds begin mating on St. Valentine's Day. Ever since their time it has been the day chosen for hearts and flowers to bloom in Unison.
TRENTON, N. J., Feb. 9 (AP) -- The New Jersey Supreme Court today upheld the sale of the assets of the Paterson and Hudson River Railroad to the Erie Railroad.

Frank W. Nolan, president of the Jarka Corporation, one of New York's largest stevedoring enterprises, doing an annual business of $25,000,000, or more, was arrested yesterday on a four-count criminal information charging that he had given sizable financial gifts to steamship line officials to steer business to his concern.

The American Tramp Shipowners Association, Inc., meeting yesterday at the Maritime Exchange, 80 Broad Street, adopted tentative by-laws by which the organization will be governed temporarily. A nominating committee to select future officers also was chosen.

The New York County Lawyers Association suggested yesterday that the Internal Revenue Bureau revert to its old policy of sparing from criminal prosecution cheating taxpayers who voluntarily disclosed their fraud and paid cash penalties.
SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, Feb. 10 -- General James A. Van Fleet, retiring Eighth Army commander, sent a personal "good-by" today to those who have suffered and lost the most in the Korean war.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce said today that although replacement costs declined during 1952, business inventories at the end of the year were valued at $700,000,000 more than at the end of 1951.

HONG KONG, Feb. 9 -- Although the chances of an immediate United States Navy blockade of the China coast are now being discounted here, responsible quarters in this British commercial entrepot are still concerned about the possibility of another kind of blockade that might affect Hong Kong's remaining trade with the China mainland.

ATHENS, Feb. 9 -- Foreign Minister Stephan Stephanopoulos, who returned to Athens tonight with his aides after a four day visit to Yugoslavia, told the press that collaboration between representatives of the two Balkan countries had progressed toward a point where it might take "a definite form."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 9 -- On behalf of the World Council for the Blind. Col. E. A. Baker, as president, today presented to Helen Keller a citation honoring her for her work on behalf of handicapped persons in all parts of the world.
MEXICO CITY, Feb. 9 -- Roman Catholic sources said today that evidence appearing here showed that international Communist leaders had decided on a new campaign against the church.

The Avco Manufacturing Corporation achieved the highest sales in its history and increased its consolidated net income to $11,028,927 in the fiscal year ended last Nov. 30, from $10,089,214 earned in the previous fiscal year. Last year's net was exceeded only by the record $12,635,633 earned in the 1950 fiscal year, Victor Emanuel, president, reported yesterday in the annual statement to stockholders.
The sale of the Home liner Argentina to the Zim Israel Navigation Company was announced here yesterday.

More than thirty years have gone by since men made the first known attempt to climb Chomo Lungma, the "Goddess Mother of the World," (called otherwise Mount Everest. The latest expedition, a group of Swiss Alpinists, came down off the mountain in November, after two tries during 1952.
JERSEY CITY, Feb. 9 -- City officials and municipal white collar workers went on a city-wide scavenger hunt today, making the regular Monday garbage collections.
LONDON, Feb. 9 (Reuters) -- Prime Minister Churchill said today that if he ever went to Moscow for talks with Premier Stalin, he would take his own doctor along.

Estimates are that the nation's steel mills will operate this week at 98.8 per cent of rated capacity. In terms of production this would equal 2,226,000 tons of ingots and steel for castings, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. Last week, when Inland Steel Company's Chicago Works were crippled by a wildcat strike, actual operations of the industry were at 97.7 per cent of capacity, yielding 2,202,000 tons.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- House investigators were told today that "friendliness" probably induced Carroll E. Mealey, former deputy revenue commissioner, to settle a $33,000 tax bill against a New York City wine company for $500.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (UP) -- Following is the text of the statement of Secretary of State Dulles today on his trip to Europe with Harold E. Stassen, Mutual Security Director:

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Feb. 9 -- Three members of the Board of Education of Pittston Township have resigned, saying they were "tired and disgusted" with the way they and their families had been abused by taxpayers, irate over a 1 per cent wage tax imposed on them.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 9 -- Still another method for giving "depth and panoramic size" to flat-surface motion pictures without bringing about any changes in present production or projection equipment was announced today by Sol Lesser, the independent producer and movie theatre investor.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- A veteran majority member of the revenue-writing Ways and Means Committee of the House of Representatives introduced legislation today that he predicted would raise at least $1,400,000,000 a year from new sources and permit similar cuts in existing personal income and corporate taxes.

DAVOS, Switzerland, Feb. 9 (UP) -- Two United States stars, Jimmy Grogan of Colorado Springs, Colo., and Hayes Alan Jenkins of Akron, Ohio, ranked one, two and well ahead of the third man after the compulsory figures of the world figure skating championship tonight.

VIENNA, Feb. 9 -- Walter Lauber, United States veteran who fled into the Soviet sector of Vienna last week after he had been interrogated by the United States Counter Intelligence Corps in connection with the recent arrest of two alleged spies, said at a press conference here today that "I would have been allowed to return to the United States only as another Greenglass."

FORT MEADE, Md., Feb. 9 (AP) -- A lieutenant colonel, defending a fellow officer charged with violating censorship regulations, today challenged the Army's right to censor for other than security reasons.
CLEVELAND, Feb. 9 (AP) -- The director of Lewis Flight Propulsion Laboratory told today of new synthetic lubricants that assure faster and safer jet planes.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Feb. 10 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,521, covering Monday's action:
The nine top officers of the United Jewish Appeal issued yesterday a statement urging "in the name of humanity" that Communist countries permit Jews to emigrate to Israel.

White goods buyers are filling in inventories depleted by January sales, but are showin ga tendency to be cautious concerning long range commitments, it was indicated yesterday at the Allied Linens and Domestics Association showing in the Commodore Hotel.

LONDON, Feb. 9 -- The first test of how far John Foster Dulles, United States Secretary of State, succeeded in convincing the British Government that this country can do more than it has done toward making the proposed European army a reality is expected this week.

ALBANY, Feb. 9 -- The Assembly tonight approved by a vote of 93 to 53 an Administration bill revising truck registration fees and extending the weight-distance tax to cover all vehicles with an over-all burden, loaded, of 18,000 pounds or more.

Cuba and the whole of Spanish America have been celebrating the centenary of the birth of Jose Marti. It is strange that so little was done here in the United States to join in these tributes. Marti was more than a Cuban patriot and martyr, and he did more than help to liberate Cuba from the Spaniards.
Following is the text of the ruling yesetrday by General Sessions Judge Francis L. Valente barring the press and public from the Jelke trial:

Arthur Larsen of California and William Talbert head a field of sixty-four players, including representatives of Denmark, Sweden, Canada and Chile, drawn for play last night in the national indoor tennis championships. The tournament will start Saturday at 10 A. M. at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.

A collection of glass objects by Maurice Heaton is on exhibition at Talents Unlimited, 61 Grove Street, a shop that displays a variety of decorative items for the home. This shop will also undertake almost any assignment for furnishing a home, from creating a decorating scheme to designing furniture or framing pictures.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The conviction of three persons for conspiracy to gain the admission of aliens unlawfully under the War Brides Act was upheld today by the Supreme Court in a 6-to-3 decision.
Salvatore T. Sollazzo, convicted "master fixer" of college basketball games, testified in Special Sessions yesterday as the bribery trial of Sol Levy, former professional basketball referee, began.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Thirteen Boy Scouts dropped in at the White House today to report to the head scoutmaster, Dwight D. Eisenhower. Their report, delivered for the nation's 3,183,266 Scouts, said enrollment was the highest in the Scouts' forty-three-year history.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, returned today after his ten-day trip through Europe, which he said had "encouraged" him about the prospects for Western defense unity.

ALBANY, Feb. 5 -- Many communities have built too few or too many schools because of haphazard planning and poor forecasting of enrollments, the State Commission on School Buildings, headed by Lieut. Gov. Frank C. Moore, reported today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The Senate Armed Services Committee decided today to suspend judgment on continuance of construction of certain air and naval bases overseas and in the United States, pending a review of the world strategic situation by Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- The Treasury, describing the new Administration's first national debt refinancing as a big success, reported today that at least 98.5 per cent of nearly $9,000,000,000 in certificates of indebtedness maturing Feb. 15 were exchanged rather than being cashed in.

Ben Ames Williams, before his death last week, had turned over to his publishers, Houghton Mifflin, the completed manuscript of a new novel. Originally, Mr. Williams had planned to carry "House Divided" through the reconstruction period, but discovered that it would make his book too long.

Among the most plentiful vegetables now are greens, including escarole, kale, collards and the more common lettuce and spinach. They are recommended not only because of their ready availability and reasonable cost but also because they are especially rich in two important nutrients, vitamin A and iron.

The drama and beauty of parts of the universe that are hundreds of millions of miles away have been brought closer to earth at the Hayden Planetarium. Today a permanent exhibition of giant "black-light" murals will open there, depicting some of the celestial wonders.

ALBANY, Feb. 9 -- Senator John H. Cooke, Republican of Erie, declared today that any legislation providing for local option in ending residential rent controls would be "passing the buck" by the state.

All advertisers using television probably will benefit from the approved merger of the American Broadcasting Company and United Paramount Theatres, time buyers agreed yesterday. With the additional capital available they look for improved programs, personnel and facilities in the combined organization.
Two first-run theatres will present new film attractions today.
The pitching problem of the Giants drew nearer solution yesterday with the disclosure that Larry Jansen, twenty-three-game winner in 1951, had agreed to terms for 1953.

PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 9 -- One hundred and forty-seven New Jersey bankers will revisit the the classroom here on Wednesday with the opening of the fourth annual session of the public relations school sponsored by the New Jersey Bankers Association.

Work on the 60,000-ton super aircraft carrier Saratoga, destined to be the world's most powerful vessel, has been proceeding smoothly and at a steadily increasing tempo since the keel was laid on Dec. 16, a visit to the New York Naval Shipyard in Brooklyn showed yesterday.

An unexpected postponement by the tugboat workers' union until 10:30 A. M. today of a mediation session scheduled for last evening kept their port-wide strike alive for at least another day. Representatives of the union and of the New York Maritime Towing and Transportation Employers Association had spent the afternoon in the office of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, 341 Ninth Avenue, seeking a formula to govern the size of tug crews.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 9 -- Senator Thomas H. Kuchel, who replaced Richard M. Nixon this year as California's junior Senator, discussed Federal patronage with Republican leaders here today amid reports of a sharp rivalry between Mr. Nixon, now the Vice President, and Senator William F. Knowland over patronage matters.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Pressure on the British to cease nearly all traffic with Communist China rose today among Congressional leaders, but they showed new reserve toward any suggestion that the United States might alone blockade the China coast.

WALLA WALLA, Wash., Feb. 9 (AP) -- Two Washington State prison officials were injured critically today when one of two crude, prisoner-made bombs found earlier in a cell blew up in their hands. Five other members of the prison staff, including Warden John Cranor, escaped with minor injuries.

LONDON, Feb. 9 -- Sparks from welding apparatus caused a third of the fifty-seven fires on ships built and repaired in British shipyards last year, according to a report by the Liverpool Underwriters Association issued today.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange turned easier yesterday and closed 24 to 37 points net lower than on last Friday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Secretary of the Interior Douglas McKay today announced approval of a power contract between the Bonneville Power Administration and Harvey Machine Company, Los Angeles, for operation of a $65,000,000 aluminum plant near The Dalles, Ore.

ALBANY, Feb. 9 -- Cornelius W. Wickersham of Cedarhurst, L. I., an attorney and retired lieutenant general, will be nominated tomorrow as new member of the State Board of Regents. Mr. Wickersham will succeed W. Kingsland Macy of Islip, whose term expires on April 1.

A $12,000,000 damage suit was filed yesterday in Federal Court here against the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company, Ltd., and three individuals by an attorney who charged that the defendants conspired illegally to restrain the attorney in negotiations for the purchase, sale and lease of oil tankers to the National Iranian Oil Company of Iran.

EL PASO, Te., Feb. 9 (AP) -- Chandler Harper broke his driver on the second hole today but used a brassie to whip Ted Xroll by three strokes in the play-off for first money in the $10,000 El Paso open.
PARIS, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Percy Basset of Philadelphia stopped France's Ray Famechon in three rounds tonight to win the interim featherweight championship of the world.

Investment banking syndicates will place on the market today $58,000,000 of new debt securities of gas transmission, department store and railroad enterprises. Much of the money raised by the financing will be used by the issuing companies to pay off short-term debt incurred in expanding facilities and services. The offerings are as follows:

President Eisenhower's abandonment of the "loyalty" program is a welcome step. As chief law officer of the Department of Commerce for the past two years I was able to observe its operations intimately. In my opinion the program has outlived its usefulness, however necessary or advisable at the time of its promulgation.

THE prose in which V. Sackville-West's "The Easter Party"* is written is so smooth and graceful that it almost disguises the hollow artificiality of this suavely mannered novel. There are minor virtues in plenty here: deft elusive suggestions of momentous truths about to be revealed. Polished and poised, civilized and gracious, "The Easter Party" ought to be beguiling reading.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Radio is the best friend professional football ever had, Gordon McLendon told Judge Allan K. Grim today as he testified in the Government's anti-trust suit against the National Football League.

NOW that Sugar Ray Robinson has retired from the beak busting business it's possible that Kid Gavilan is the best man in the trade. He's fast with both hands and feet. He's durable. He's an excellent boxer and a reasonably rugged hitter. As far as physical equipment is concerned, his flaws are trifling. But he has the irritating habit of showboating.

PARIS, Feb. 9 -- Original beachwear is featured in Schiaparelli's collection. Five pockets down one leg of narrow gray linen pedal pushers lend a gay note with a different hued handkerchief in each pocket. Small bowknots range down the sides of violet pedal pushers worn with a shocking pink nylon shirt.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Two more Eisenhower nominees received unanimous approval today of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee after they were questioned in an executive session.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 9 -- Ohio proceeded today with plans to celebrate its 150 years of statehood next month despite a resolution in Congress that carries the implication the state is not yet in the Union. The resolution would end an "error" and admit the state retroactively to March 1, 1803.

Commodity future prices eased yesterday on the New York Exchanges. Volume also was lower after Friday's pick-up. Cocoa, potatoes, rubber, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, lead and zinc declined. Sugar, wool and hides closed irregular and coffee and tin ended with gains.

The need for a new administration of our city government is, in our opinion, a demonstrated fact that requires no elaboration or argument. The question for the average person in New York is how to be sure of bringing about the sweeping changes needed. We are all for "reform."

The hope of Mr. and Mrs. Len Carey of Cos Cob, Conn., that their Doberman pinscher, Champion Rancho Dobe's Storm, would achieve a second successive best-in-show at the seventy-seventh Westminster Kennel Club event was kept alive in Madison Square Garden yesterday.

On a single night in May, 1942, 1,130 Allied planes came over the ancient city of Cologne and smashed 5,000 acres of streets and buildings with a loss of life still to be accurately estimated. This was one of many raids on Cologne. Three years and some weeks later a single American plane dropped an atom bomb on Hiroshima in Japan, wrecking most of the city and destroying close to 80,000 lives.

Next week, Feb. 15-21, will be Brotherhood Week in this city, according to a proclamation issued yesterday by Mayor Impellitteri at City Hall. In his document the Mayor said that "never in the history of our city and our nation was the need greater for a unified people joined together in the bonds of common understanding."

TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 9 -- A violent explosion inside the Soviet Legation shook downtown Tel Aviv at 10 P. M. The police announced three Russian members of the Legation staff had been injured, one of them seriously.

GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 9 -- An Irish setter with an affinity for cocktail party canapes at a neighbor's home, and three French poodles, faced possible execution today after three children complained of being bitten.
BANDUNG, Indonesia, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Pakistan challenged today Russia's charges that American and British "monopoly capitalists" still were exploiting Asians.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- A three-member bipartisan Senate Elections subcommittee has concluded unanimously that documents purporting to link Vice President Richard M. Nixon to an alleged $52,000 private fund asserted to have been raised by the oil industry in 1950 were forged. It has asked the Department of Justice and the Federal Bureau of Investigation to seek out and punish the authors.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 9 -- India signed today a "technical assistance" agreement with the United States under which Washington will provide funds to enable three Indian officials to visit foreign countries to study various processes of manufacturing fertilizer.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 9 -- President Eisenhower and Secretary of Defense Charles E. Wilson will be asked to help settle a dispute that has halted the installation of heated prefabricated shelters for anti-aircraft gun crews in the New York area and the area of other large cities, leaders of American Federation of Labor building unions said here today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9 -- A flood of stop-loss selling orders swept into the grain pits in the final half hour of trading today, swamping the buying demand, and forcing prices into new lows for the crop year. Earlier in the session there had been several rallies, but as the session neared the close final prices were not far from the low points of the day.

MILAN, Italy, Feb. 9 -- Maria Callas, American - born opera singer, will decline a Metropolitan Opera engagement if her husband cannot get a visa to accompany her to the United States, the couple said today.

Of the 99,928 persons flown out of Berlin last year by Pan American World Airways, about 25,000 were refugees bound for the West. The airline said yesterday that this volume of traffic toward Western Germany and beyond reflected increased pressure on displaced persons in the Russian-controlled zone of Germany.
CINCINNATI, Feb. 9 (AP) -The question whether organized baseball is a business monopoly and its players the peons of the club owners advanced another step toward an answer today.

Holding the upper hand virtually all the way, St. John's University defeated C. C. N. Y., 72 -- 64, in their thirty-second basketball meeting at the DeGray Gymnasium in Brooklyn last night. Dick Duckett, with 24 points, set the pace for the Redmen, who led at the intermission, 39 -- 29.

SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, Feb. 10 (UP) -- Gen. James A. Van Fleet reflected unmistakable bitterness over the stalemated Korean war today as he told men of the Eighth Army they had the Communists defeated in the summer of 1951 and the Communists knew it.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The United States rejected today as "unfounded" a recent Polish protest that this country was engaging in "aggressive subversion" in Poland.
The John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company announced yesterday the election as vice presidents of Frank B. Maher and Robert E. Slater. George B. Thompson Jr. was elected a second vice president.
NORFOLK, Va., Feb. 9 -- Norfolk shipping officials filed unfair labor practices charges today against a striking tugboat union and other International Longshoremen's Association locals here.

LONDON, Feb. 9 -- Prices moved haphazardly on the stock markets here today, with several of the leading industrials advancing. On the whole, however, volume of business was restricted by the end of the bookkeeping account influences.

There is presently before the City Council of the City of New York a bill which is, I believe, deserving of favorable consideration. The bill to which I refer is the Treulich bill, which would amend the Administrative Code of the City of New York with reference to annual increments for lower-paid city employes in the competitive class of civil service.
LONDON, Feb. 9 -- If President Eisenhower has any intention of inflicting a blockade on Communist China, the British Government knows nothing about it, a Foreign Office spokesman said today.
The women's division of the United Jewish Appeal of Gresler New York raised $803,000 yesterday at a special gifts luncheon that followed the opening rally of its campaign in the Astor Hotel.

After declining sharply in early trading when losses of 1 to 2 points were fairly numerous throughout the list, the stock market recovered the greater part of its losses in slow trading yesterday. Gains however, were only of fractions, while losses in some issues which failed to rally were substantial.

TETUAN, Spanish Morocco, Feb. 9 -- Lieut. Gen. Rafael Garcia Valino, High Commissioner for Spanish Morocco, said today he had just completed an extensive administrative reform giving 1,000,000 Moslems in this protectorate a voice in the solution of problems affecting their villages.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Feb. 9 -- Premier Willem Drees promised swift reconstruction of the flood-ravaged regions of the Netherlands -- at the cost of delaying the great Ijsselmeer (Zuyder Zee) reclamation project, if necessary -- and told Parliament tonight that the Government was considering a plan to make the country "floodproof" by damming off North Sea inlets.

In connection with the appointment of Clare Bootlle Luce as Ambassador to Rome, many newspaper men ariel radio commentators have asserteol that the Italian women have no part in Italian public life and in political activities.

The public and the press were excluded yesterday from the trial of Minot Frazier (Mickey) Jelke 3d by General Sessions Judge Francis L. Valente on the argument that it was not a function of the judiciary to satisfy a widespread and avid appetite for "lurid and salacious details."
Gross revenues and earnings of the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company reached new highs last year, W. G. Maguire, chairman, informed stockholders yesterday in the twenty-third annual report.

LONDON, Feb. 9 -- So many short circuits have occurred at dawn along the 66,000-volt overhead transmission lines of the Yorkshire and North Lincolnshire Electricity Board areas that linesmen kept watch throughout the night.

TOKYO, Feb. 9 (Reuters) -- The problem of how to use American profits in Japan is the main issue holding up completion of the United States-Japan treaty of commerce and navigation now being negotiated, Foreign Minister Katsuo Okazaki said today.

A new production of the comedy, "On Borrowed Time," written by Paul Osborn from a novel by Lawrence Edward Watkin, will open at 8 o'clock tonight at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre. Victor Moore, Leo G. Carroll and Beulah Bondi will be co-starred in the presentation, which is under the sponsorship of Richard W. Krakeur and Randolph Hale, in assocition with William G. Costin Jr.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The Army, Navy and Air Force have been ordered by the new Administration to submit by the end of this month heavily revised spending and contracting estimates based on achieving "intelligent savings." Former President Harry S. Truman's request for new military funds, sent to Congress on Jan. 9, totaled $41,535,000,000.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9 -- Almost 37,000 doctors in the United States gave more than $3,150,000 in direct support of medical education during 1952. Dr. Donald G. Anderson, secretary of the American Medical Association's Council on Medical Education and Hospitals, announced here today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Dr. Emerson P. Schmidt, economist of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, said today that some of industry's productivity gains, instead of going into wage increases, should be distributed in the form of lower prices for those "who haven't had their share," such as persons living on pensions and other fixed income.
MIAMI, Feb. 9 -- Eleven 3-year-olds, including seven that are candidates for the $100,000 added Flamingo Stakes on Feb. 28, ran in the seven-furlong main event at Hialeah race course today.

The Philharmonic Chamber Ensemble completed its second successful year last night when it gave its third and final concert of the season at the Lexington Avenue Y. M. and Y. W. H. A. The printed programs carried the assurance that the group will continue, for they announced a third season of concerts for 1953-54.

Nearly all members of the Board of Estimate or their representatives will accompany Mayor Impellitteri tomorrow when he goes to Albany to plead for $62,700,000 more in state aid for New York City. The city officials will appear at a joint public hearing of the Senate Finance and Assembly Ways and Means Committees.

Two unidentified thugs who forced a young, newly married woman into their car as she emerged from a bank in Brooklyn last night and then robbed her of $300 and a wrist watch went a step too far when they ordered her to give up her engagement and wedding bands.

Tobias Stone of New York came from behind at the close of the final session of play early yesterday morning to win the 1953 life masters individual contract bridge championship. Mr. Stone outpointed a field of seventy-two outstanding bridge experts in the event at the McAlpin Hotel to capture one of the American Contract Bridge League's most important national championships.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- The Government today removed price controls from marine towing services performed by contract tug and barge operators.

Fred Heller, a second-year student at Andrew Jackson High School in Queens, got to class late yesterday. Instead of being reproached by his teachers, however, he was greeted with friendly smiles and such unusual questions as:

LONDON, Feb. 10 -- A quiet session on the Stock Exchange today was relieved by a late burst of activity in the South African gold mine shares which replaced the early losses with substantial gains. The rally began with the buying of Orange Free State issues in the expectation of good borehole results and spread to most of the Orange Free State section and to several of the uranium producers.

At least fifteen men of questionable loyalty, including eight who had been members of the Communist party or other subversive groups, were certified for appointment to the Police Department by the Municipal Civil Service Commission between 1946 and 1951 over departmental objections, Bruce Smith, internationally recognized expert on police affairs, charged yesterday.

The "melon" cut by the ninety-four partners of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane was a smaller one last year than in 1951. Although the gross income was down only 1.6 per cent, about $570,000 less was divided than in 1951 and about $1,580,000 less than in 1950.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Wednesday, Feb. 11 (AP) -- A senior Chinese Nationalist general disclosed Tuesday that seaborne anti-Communist raiders had hit the Chinese Communists fifteen times in the past seven months in a prelude to heavier blows.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 10 -- The Federal Government believes the European Coal and Steel Community's common market for coal and iron ore must be regarded only as the first step in creating a unified economic system in Western Europe without which political and military cooperation will rest on an impermanent foundation.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 10 -- Undaunted by the past failure of such union stalwarts as John L. Lewis and Michael J. Quill, Dave Beck, the forceful new leader of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, set in motion today a fresh drive to unionize New York's 35,000 taxicab drivers.

A Valentine-inspired showing presented yesterday by Jane Engel at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel played no favorites. There were as many, and equally charming, styles for children as for those who wear misses' sizes.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 10 (AP) -- The Government said today it was not concerned whether its anti-trust suit against the National Football League might kill professional football.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Eight railroads asked the United States iDstrict Court today to dismiss a $250,000,000 damage suit filed against them by thirty-seven trucking companies and the Pennsylvania Motor Truck Association.

First-nighters hastening to the Hellinger this evening to attend the delayed premiere of "Hazel Flagg," which will start at 7:55 sharp, will be admitted at the Fifty-first Street side because the Broadway entrance has been discontinued.
New HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 10 (AP) -- The Hamilton Watch Company of Lancaster, Pa., today filed suit in United States District Court here against the Benrus Watch Company of Waterbury and New York.

Richard H. Balch, Democratic State Chairman, charged last night that "the ruthless political machine operated out of Albany under the iron hand of Thomas E. Dewey" was the most powerful ever seen in this country.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 10 -- Capt. Jack Molinas tallied 28 points tonight to lead Columbia to a 68-63 triumph over Yale in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game on the Payne Whitney court.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 10 -- The Insurance Company of North America and its affiliated companies. Philadelphia Fire and Marine Insurance Company and Indemnity Insurance Company of North America, reported today net operating profits of $20,447,000 for 1952 against $15,079,015 the previous year.

Judge Harold R. Medina rebuked Government counsel in the investment banking anti-trust trial yesterday for keeping Drexel Co. as one of the defendants in the case in spite of the fact that the Government's only evidence linking Drexel with the alleged conspiracy is price-fixing -- a practice common to all businesses in the securities industry.

Underwriting syndicates will offer to investors today $25,000,000 of new long-term debentures of the J. I. Case Company, farm machinery manufacturer, and $10,000,000 of new convertible preferred stock of the Equitable Gas Company, Pennsylvania and West Virginia distributor of natural gas.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 10 (AP) -- Stockholders of Aetna Life Insurance Company today gave overwhelming approval to a $10,000,000 increase in the company's capital, to be followed by a 50 per cent stock dividend.

BANDUNG, Indonesia, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Newly independent Asian nations joined the United States and Britain today in rejecting Soviet charges that American economic aid was enslaving Far Eastern nations.

CHICAGO, Feb. 10 -- Selling of grains appeared to have been overdone today as there was a more general demand to cushion the sales while shorts were free buyers in all pits. There was further scattered liquidating pressure at times, and buyers were cautious in following upturns.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 10 (AP) -- N. W. Ayer Son reported today that combined circulation of English-language dailies in the United States reached a new all-time high of 53,738,000 by the end of 1952, an average of one paper for every three persons.

The Executive Council of the American Federation of Labor has reached agreement, at its midwinter conference, on the key changes it would include in any revision of the Taft-Hartley Act. The most important of these -- and the one which we believe will invite the most serious opposition -- calls for elimination of the eighty-day no-strike injunction in the case of "national emergency strikes."

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Feb. 10 -- As a result of demands by a delegation of seventy-five parents today for safety precautions at the sandpit pond in Elmont, L. I., where three children drowned last Friday, the Hempstead Town Board will ask the owner of the property to turn it over to the town for construction of a playground.

Projecting the ideals of brotherhood into reality, students of diverse racial and religious backgrounds from six Manhattan public schools and a parochial school paid tribute last night to the Negro contribution to the development of the United States.
Stockholders of the Associates Investment Company will be asked at the annual meeting on March 10 to approve a three-for-one stock split, according to Robert L. Oare chairman of the board.
BONN, Germany, Feb. 10 -- The Freikorps Deutschland, a neo-Nazi secret society pledged to overthrow democracy in Germany, was banned by the Federal Government today and four of its leaders arrested.
VATICAN CITY, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Vatican sources said today that the seat of the Roman Catholic Church would enter no secret diplomatic arrangements with any country.

Victor Moore has brought us another part as ideal for him as Throttlebottom and just as irresistible in the theatre. He is playing Gramps in the new production of Paul Osborn's "On Borrowed Time," which opened at the Forty-eighth Street last evening and will not close for quite a long time.
Recent tragedies that have befallen children give poignancy to a bulletin published recently by the National Safety Council concerning dangerous "unauthorized play spaces."
TOKYO, Wednesday, Feb. 11 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,522, for Tuesday's activities:

THE TIMES editorial of Feb. 7 rendered an important public service, I believe, in clarifying the disparity that exists between certain basic principles of progressive education and of communism; the former encouraging individuals to think for themselves on all matters, free of the limitations of any dogmas, the latter requiring individuals to surrender completely to the unqualified acceptance of a very narrow and rigid dogma.

It was with some amazement that I read in a recent issue of THE TIMES that Senator Joseph McCarthy was going to ask that the report "Investigations of Senators Joseph R. McCarthy and William Benton" of the subcommittee on Privileges and Elections "be returned to the elections subcommittee for a rewrite. * * *"
Production of primary aluminum in the United States in 1952 set a record, Donald M. White, secretary of the Aluminum Association, reported yesterday.

In seeking to persuade Western Europe to speed ratification of the European Defense Community treaty Secretary Dulles has emphasized our Government's opinion that the danger of further Soviet aggression is increasing rather than diminishing. This is particularly true in Germany, where the Soviet zone is being rearmed at a rapid pace and being converted into a Soviet air and naval base to dominate the Baltic.

HONG KONG, Feb. 10 -- Percentage figures for the 1953 targets of Communist China's first Five-Year Plan became available here today in published proceedings of the recently concluded People's Political Consultative Conference in Peiping.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb 10 (Reuters) -- The Indian Government has set a target date of April 1 for nationalization of the country's airlines, making it plain that economic and not ideological motives are behind the largest nationalization project it has yet undertaken.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Feb. 10 -- A 72-year-old boyhood friend of Will Rogers today trudged across the frozen tundra of Alaska on the way to the desolate marsh near Point Barrow where the entertainer and philosopher died Aug. 15, 1935, in a plane crash with Wiley Post.

CAIRO, Feb. 10 -- Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib, the Premier, proclaimed today the interim Constitution under which he reserved to himself, in consultation with his Army Council of the Revolution, supreme authority for three years.

Marine Midland Corporation had consolidated net income last year amounting to $6,647,262, equal to $1.06 a share, compared with $6,145,802, or $1.03, in the previous year, Charles H. Diefendorf, president, and Bayard F. Pope, chairman, announced yesterday in their annual report.

GREENWICH, Conn., Feb 10 -- A jury of three spared today the lives of six dogs charged with being vicious, but gave a decision tantamount to imposing a life sentence on each. Under the ruling the animals, until their natural deaths, must be confined to their owners property and must be kept on leashes when taken out for walks.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The Navy announced today that it would give 70 per cent of its stock of gamma globulin, valued at $2,750,000, to the American Red Cross in time for distribution before the start of the 1953 polio season.
Drapery fabrics handprinted in white, metallic and colored pigments similar to Swiss pigment prints are now produced in this country by the Dorian Company.
The Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, C. I. O., announced yesterday demands for a general 15-cent hourly increase and other gains for 250,000 men's clothing, shirt and cotton garment employes.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 10 -- Gerald A. Brown, regional directtor of the National Labor Relations Board, recommended to the parent board in Washington today that it hold hearings on two of four charges made by the Marine Cooks and Stewards, A. F. L., following a representation election on board steam schooners Nov. 21 to ec. 8.

The winter's carrot crop is about 16 per cent above average and prices are as low as in the summer when the vegetable arrives in quantity from near-by areas. This information was included in a recent statement from the local office of the State Extension Service in Marketing, while the City Department of Markets in its weekly bulletins has been emphasizing the increasing quantities and declining prices of beef.

Bond distributors now have the current checkered market for new issues of corporate bonds in somewhat clearer perspective following the success of underwriting syndicates yesterday in distributing major blocks of new debt securities of May Department Stores, Tennessee Gas Transmission Company and the Nickel Plate Railroad.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 10 -- The Five-man Foreign Affairs Section of the Indonesian Parliament tendered a motion today calling for the establishment this year of an Indonesian Embassy at Moscow. The motion was formulated on the initiative of Otto Rondonuwu, a member of the House's progressive faction and brings to a climax two weeks of bitter controversy over the issue.
MOSCOW, Feb. 11 -- "The Star-Spangled Banner" is now resounding in a score of Moscow movie houses and in dozens of others throughout Russia.

The American Management Association has leased two floors, comprising 20,000 square feet of space in the six-story building at 375 Eighth Avenue, southwest corner of West Forty-third Street for headquarters for their Eastern division which will move from the McGraw-Hill Building, 330 West Forty-second Street.

Changes in prices were irregular yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges. Most of the trading was dull. Coffee, wool, rubber, lead and tin closed lower. Soybean oil, cottonseed oil, hides and zinc ended higher and cocoa, sugar and potatoes were mixed.

LUXEMBOURG, Feb. 10 -- In the new single market embracing the six countries of the European Coal and Steel Community, which had its official beginning today, coal prices are expected to be kept not far from their present level while steel prices appear likely to rise.

After posting bail totaling $80,000 yesterday in Federal Court, four of the recently convicted thirteen secondary Communist leaders were freed from prison pending appeal. The remaining nine Communists still were held in lieu of $25,000 bail each.
Lightness of build, grace and femininity featured the spring and summer shoe collection that Saks Fifth Avenue exhibited for the press at the Park Lane Hotel yesterday.
DAVOS, Switzerland, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Hayes Alan Jenkins of Akron, Ohio, succeeded to the crown of Dick Button today by outskating his teammate, Jimmy Grogan, to win the world figure-skating title.

A bill calling for replacing the Mayor's Committee on Unity with a statutory Commission on Intergroup Relations was introduced into the City Council yesterday by Majority Leader Joseph T. Sharkey, Brooklyn Democrat. The measure was sent to the committee on general welfare.

Yesterday a trainload of German coke crossed duty-free into France. This does not sound very exciting. It was not an occasion for flag-waving; quite the contrary, indeed, for the short journey from one side of Europe's great industrial basin to the other marked the denationalization of a frontier.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 10 -- The Consolidated Edison Company of New York gave aid to the Algonquin Gas Transmission Company today in Algonquin's fight before the Federal Power Commission and a multitude of courts to win a major part of the multimillion-dollar natural gas distribution business in New England.

Five convicted Staten Island bookmakers were found guilty of criminal contempt of court yesterday when a State Supreme Court Justice ruled as invalid their plea of self-incrimination in refusing to testify before the grand jury that is investigating gambling and corruption in Richmond.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The State Department made it clear today that it does not intend to buy back United States property seized by Communist Hungary. This decision, nevertheless, left a United States Air Force transport plane and its equipment, valued at $98,779.29, still in the hands of the Soviet satellite authorities.

Herbert Schade, Germany's outstanding distance runner, here to compete in the National A. A. U. indoor track and field championships at Madison Square Garden on Saturday, voiced optimism concerning his debut in an appearance at the metropolitan track writers' luncheon at Leone's yesterday.

HONG KONG, Feb. 10 -- Gen. Yeh Chien-ying's Fourth Field Army was officially reported today to have dispatched "comfort missions" to Communist-held islands off the Southeast China coast to bolster the morale of the local defenders and urge them to safeguard the sea approaches on Communist China's "frontline of national defense."
ALBANY, Feb. 10 -- The State Department of Law, in its annual report to the Legislature, disclosed today that it had collected $4,841,136 for the state during 1952.

Several recent items have told of new tuition increases raising such fees at various colleges to $700 and $800 annually. The news of these increases has been accompanied by the explanation that the rising trend of faculty salaries and other costs have made such adjustments unavoidable.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Gordon E. Dean has resigned as chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission but has agreed to remain on the job for the next three months so that President Eisenhower's new chairman can get accustomed to the job.
CHICAGO, Feb 10 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

ALBANY, Feb. 10 -- Governor Dewey signed into law today a bill revising the basis on which trucks pay their annual registration fees and weight-distance taxes. The new law gives owners a chance to pay less than the maximum amounts if they normally carry lightweight products.
