NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 10 -Aneur'm Bevan, left-w'[ng British Labor leader, who arrived here today, expr, essed the. vlewthat President. Eisenhbwer's Formosa . , - ,. ported the move 'to deneutralize the United. States Seventh Fleet.

Further substantial expansion of consumer credit is likely this year, according to a survey of thirty-seven companies in the retail installment field announced yesterday by the Standard Factors Corporation. These concerns operate stores in New York, Chicago and Los Angeles doing an annual volume of about $170,000,000.

Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan will have to attend a "regular" performance Saturday morning of movies showing bookmakers conferring with unidentified men in civilian garb on a street corner in the Brownsville district of Brooklyn.

ROME, Feb. 10 -- Renewed apprehensions for the health of Pope Pius XII were expressed in the Vatican today when, for the first time since he was raised to the Pontificate in 1939, he failed to attend the solemn requiem mass that is held every year in the Sistine Chapel for his predecessor, Pius XI.

BERLIN, Feb. 10 -- There is some concern in official circles here lest any implementation of President Eisenhower's plan to renounce secret treaties affect the legal position of the Western powers in Berlin.
Unionized funeral drivers announced yesterday that beginning tomorrow they would not cross picket lines set up at ten cemeteries by a striking gravediggers union.

An agreement to settle the twelve-day-old strike of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union, independent, against wholesale concerns that distribute metropolitan newspapers and magazines to suburban dealers was reached last night under the auspices of the State Mediation Board.

ATHENS, Feb. 10 -- The actual drafting of a friendship pact involving Greece, Yugoslavia and Turkey will begin as soon as the Yugoslav Ambassador, Rados Ivanovic, returns to his Athens post, Greek Foreign Office sources revealed-today.
SOMEWHERE IN KOREA, Feb. 2 -- On a raw cold day here not so long ago, a group of the Chinese enemy had the misfortune to surround some Ethiopian soldiers. The Chinese should have known better.

Bruce Marshall, who recently wrote of the exploits of Wing Commander F. F. E. Yeo-Thomas in "The White Rabbit" (Houghton Mifflin), has a new novel on the concern's list scheduled for March 10 publication. "The Fair Bride" is a story about a young Spanish priest who is driven from faith in God to communism at the beginning of the Spanish civil war and of his subsequent regeneration.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- The Department of Defense identified today eighty-nine Korean war casualties in a new list, which included nine killed, seventy-three wounded, four missing and three injured. The following casualties were from New York (none was reported from New Jersey or Connecticut):
The nation's steel mills set a new production record last month in turning out slightly less than 10,000,000 tons. The industry's new capacity was an important factor in the increased output.

Attainment of more than $5,000,000,000 life insurance in force and writing of new business during 1952 of $5,455,581,000, an increase of 18 per cent over 1951, are among the highlights in the eighty-second annual report of the Sun Life Assurance Company of Canada, released yesterday by George W. Bourke, president.

TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 10 -- Once more a deadlock seems to be developing between London and Teheran on the issue of Iran's nationalization of the British-owned oil industry in this country. Local commentators have begun to prepare public opinion for the possibility of an impasse.
Seven new areas in which parking will be restricted to alternate sides of the street will be established by late summer, the Departments of Sanitation and Traffic announced yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 10 -- John B. Blandford Jr., head of the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees, has resigned after a year and a half as head of that agency.

Formal agreement on an Export-Import Bank loan to Brazil to help liquidate her high commercial dollar debt may be deferred until the South American country can assess effects of a new free exchange market expected to be officially established on Feb. 21.

BOSTON, Feb. 10 (UP) -- Senator Leverett Saltonstall, Republican of Massachusetts, today defended Senate procedure in confirming Dr. James B. Conant, former president of Harvard University, as United States High Commissioner for Germany.

Your able correspondent in India, Robert Trumbull, is quite correct in reporting in THE TIMES of Jan. 25 that "There has been a sudden sharp deterioration in relations between India and the United States in recent weeks."

The making over of Fifth Avenue into a modern period piece is proceeding with consequences which do not please everybody. But old inhabitants recall that this showplace of our city has been made over twice since the last century's age of brownstone gave it uniform monotony, and that the first transformation made it an eclectic sampler of period pieces of past centuries in Europe.

MIAMI, Feb. 10 -- A 5-year-old horse named Royal Vale, who was imported from England by Mrs. Esther du Pont Weir of Wilmington, Del., put a little pep into the proceedings at Hialeah race course today. In the role of a 20-to-1 outsider in a ten-horse line-up, he won the first of a pair of $4,500 races over the seven-furlong course.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 10 -- At least thirty persons suspected of possible connection with the bombing of the Soviet Legation last night were taken into custody today while Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion expressed in the Knesset (Parliament) in Jerusalem his "deep regret and apologies" and offered to pay compensation to the Soviet Government.
Customs collections in the Port of New York for January were $23,350,198, or $2,000,000 more than was collected in January, 1952, but $3,000,000 less than the revenues for December.

In the belief that this is a propitious time for such a move, the International Cut Stone Contractors' and Quarrymen's Association is embarking on a national advertising and public relations campaign.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 10 -- With but one fatality for each 2,400,000,000 miles traveled during 1952, the railroads achieved a safety record never before equaled by any form of transportation. William T. Faricy, president of the Association of American Railroads, reported here tonight.

New York, the city from which thousands of words of newspaper copy are dispatched abroad each day to thirty-eight foreign countries, played host yesterday to 200 members of the Foreign Press Association by honoring them at City Hall ceremonies and providing a three-hour ferryboat excursion around Manhattan.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Feb. 11 -- Fighting continued minor along the Korean battle front yesterday and clouds grounded most United Nations aircraft, Sabre jets, which flew through lifting overcast late in the afternoon, encountered no opposition from the enemy's Soviet-designed MIG's.
An experienced air traveler like Tiny had no qualms last night as carpenters and handlers shipped her on the midnight freight from La Guardia Airport to Kansas City.

MIAMI, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Caribbee, 1952 champion, surged into the lead today on the first leg of the fifteenth Miami-Nassau race, a major blue-water event on the Southern Ocean Racing Conference program.

The American Stock Exchange and its operating affiliates, American Stock Exchange Realty Associates, Inc. and American Stock Exchange Securities Clearing Corporation had a consolidated income in 1952 of $2,162,410, it was reported yesterday by Edward T. McCormick, president.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture today estimated this season's production of citrus fruit at 173,160,000 boxes, a drop of 2,730,000 from a forecast of a month ago.

Parents and professional people concerned with child care ask themselves what is best for the infant, and each year they have different answers, according to Dr. Frederick H. Allen, Clinical Professor of Psychiatry at the University of Pennsylvania Medical School.

FORT MEADE, Md., Feb. 10 (AP) -- A court-martial today turned down the legal argument of a former censor that the Army had no constitutional right to censor the book he wrote about Korea, "Korean Tales."

Removal of price controls will have little, if any, inflationary effect in the ready-to-wear markets, according to Harry Udoff, vice president and divisional merchandise manager of Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers. Speaking yesterday at a dress clinic in the Governor Clinton Hotel, Mr. Udoff pointed out that intense competition among dress producers precluded any undue advances in prices at the wholesale level.

" Uncle Joe" Stalin appears to have been in his best avuncular mood when he went out of his accustomed way to receive Ambassador Luis Bravo of Argentina. Somehow it seemed natural, and the impression was fortified for us here when the New York Daily Worker rose gallantly to the occasion and spread a cordial account of the meeting on its front page.
LONDON, Feb. 10 -- Prime Minister Churchill indicated today in the House of Commons that he was less sure than he had been that the danger of war had receded.

A couple of television shows that began a few weeks ago seem to be earning their keep. One is the Lilli Palmer show, an educated chitchat session over Channel 2 on Sundays at 2:45 P. M. The other is "Talent Patrol," a servicemen series on Channel 7 on Mondays at 9:30 P. M., which got off on an unsteady footing but shows promise of improving.
The State of Maine announced yesterday that it would receive bids March 3 on $23,000,000 of highway and bridge general obligation bonds

Legal representatives of the Cadman Memorial Congregational Society of Brooklyn have filed a brief with the Court of Appeals in an effort to obtain a final ruling on their move to block the national merger of the Congregational Christian Churches of the U. S. and the Evangelical and Reformed Church.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Feb. 10 -- Associate Justice Stanley F. Reed of the United States Supreme Court today presented the hundred thousandth book to the library of the University of Virginia Law School, where he studied forty-five years ago.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 10 -- Israel has assured the United Nations that, in spite of increased Arab-Israeli friction, the Government plans to carry out its pledge and release $2,800,000 March 1 from the blocked bank accounts of Palestinian Arab refugees.

ENDICOTT, N. Y., Feb. 10 -- Glenn G. Bartle, provost of Harpur College, one of the two liberal arts colleges of the State University of New York, said today he believed no Communist deserved the right to be a teacher. He upheld the Government's right to investigate the political beliefs of college faculty members.

ALBANY, Feb. 10 -- Governor Dewey explained and defended his $1,072,484,440 general fund budget today in a three-hour closed meeting with Republican legislators. The session was held in preparation for tomorrow's public hearings on the subject before a joint session of the Senate Finance and Assembly Ways and Means Committees.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- President and Mrs. Eisenhower, members of Congress and the diplomatic corps, and other Washington officials attended tonight a special advance showing of the motion picture "Mahatma Gandhi, Twentieth Century Prophet."

New York City's gross receipts tax is forcing another major investment company to move out of the city limits. The United Corporation, once a leading public utility holding company, but now primarily an investment concern, announced yesterday that it is moving its head offices to New Rochelle, Westchester, from the Grand Central Building "because the gross receipts tax imposed by New York City has become excessively burdensome to the company."

The familiar huffing of towboats returned to the waters of this port at nightfall yesterday as the ten-day strike of harbor workers came to an end. The snub-nosed little craft moved out from lay-up points all over the port to work throughout the night breaking the log jam of waiting ships.

ALBANY, Feb. 10 -- Housing segregation is on the increase despite a reduction in racial discrimination in education and employment, the fifth annual conference of the New York State Committee on Discrimination in Housing was informed today.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Feb. 11 -- Gen. James A. Van Fleet turned over the reins of the Eighth Army in Korea to Lieut. Gen Maxwell D. Taylor today and left for the United States and retirement.

Business management must begin now to reduce the cost of effective selling, because the much-heralded buyers' market will become a hard fact by the end of this year. Howard L. Franks declared yesterday. He is manager of sales personnel and control of the chemical division of the General Electric Company.

Stocks drifted downward yesterday after moderate gains in the early dealings and final quotations were irregularly lower in the slowest trading in more than two weeks. Price changes generally were in fractions, but an advance or decline of around a point cropp i up now and then in the list.

Steve Hannagan, nationally known press agent who died in Nairobi, Kenya, Africa, last Thursday at the age of 53, left the physical assets of his organization to five of his aide, it was learned yesterday when his will was filed for probate.

Nearly 1,000 employes of the American Broadcasting Company met in the St. Nicholas Arena at 69 West Sixty-sixth Street yesterday to hear company executives outline the television and radio plans for the newly created company known as American Broadcasting-Paramount Theatres, Inc.

TANGIER, Feb. 5 -- After years of a sustained economic boom, the International Zone of Tangier administered by eight Western powers including the United States is in the throes of an economic slump or, as business men here prefer to put it, a readjustment due chiefly to the improvement of conditions in Western Europe.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Feb. 10 -- Gov. John S. Fine said today he would follow the recommendations of a special committee, which he appointed, and which rejected a plan of the Interstate Commission on the Delaware River Basin (Incodel) for Pennsylvania participation in a $500,000,000 river control program.
When the competitive trials and tensions of the Westminster Kennel Club dog show ended last night, a Doberman pinscher stood alone in the center of the large ring in Madison Square Garden.

Millicent C. McIntosh, President of Barnard College, announced yesterday in her annual message to the undergraduates and faculty that a $1,000,000 rehabilitation of the interior of Milbank Hall, the main classroom building of the college, would begin on April 15.
CHICAGO, Feb. 10 -- The explosive Kid Gavilan of Cuba defends his world welterweight championship at the stadium tomorrow night for the fifth time.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Robert Chapman Sprague, Massachusetts manufacturer, who had been selected for nomination as Under Secretary of the Air Force, bowed out today after learning that the Administration preferred not to risk a possible new Senate controversy over the issue of defense officials holding stock interests.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Arthur S. Flemming, head of the Government's stabilization and defense mobilization activities, has been instructed by the White House to draw up a report on the need, if any, for stand-by controls legislation.

Women headed by Mrs. William B. Jaffe and including Mrs. Lytle Hull are furthering the sale of tickets for the concert to be given by Arturo Toscanini and members of the N. B. C. Symphony Orchestra on March 28 at Carnegie Hall for the benefit of the Artists Veterans Hospital Program of the Hospitalized Veterans Music Service. Mrs. Hull is president of the music service.
BONN, Germany, Feb. 10 -- Dr. James B. Conant arrived here today to assume his post of United States High Commissioner and immediately pledged his support of "peace with freedom for all of Germany."

Percy and Harold D. Uris builders, announced yesterday that they had reached an amicable settlement with residential tenants over possession of the fourteen-story apartment building at 300 Park Avenue, which formerly housed Sherry's Restaurant.
Your leading editorial on Feb. 10, entitled "City Reform in 1953," hits several nails on the head, and two of these seem to me vital.

A jury of five men and seven women filed out of a Federal courtroom here at 4:09 P. M. yesterday charged with the task of deciding whether John David Provoo, 35-year-old former Army sergeant, was guilty of treason.
The 144th anniversary of the birth of Abraham Lincoln, sixteenth President of the United States, will be celebrated by New Yorkers tomorrow.

The Mayor of New York City makes his annual march on Albany today. This year he will have company to sweeten the lonely trip, an impressive delegation of Board of Estimate members in search of gold up the river. The legend that state aid money is easy money just won't die.

FOR the first half of the 1951 season, the White Sox were the sensations of the American League. They burned it up with their swift movements on the base paths. Manager Paul Richards, a young guy with old-fashioned ideas, reached into the past and exploited to the full such comparatively outmoded stratagems as the steal, the extra base and the hit-and-run.

The Giants and Yankees yesterday each signed two pitchers, and a first-line hurler was included by each of the local clubs. Jim Hearn was the top man for the Giants and Tom Gorman for the world champions.

LONDON, Feb. 10 -- The British atomic bomb explosion on the West Australian islands of Monte Bello last October has provoked a mild state of fission among zoologists here who are now arguing whether the expedition blasted come irreplaceable specimens out of existence.

ALBANY, Feb. 10 -- An important break in the Republican opposition to a state-wide system of permanent personal registration was seen today in the disclosure that Herbert C. Gerlach, the Westchester County Republican chairman, had advised the League of Women Voters that he favored the proposal.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The Republican leadership of the House of Representatives barred any vote on taxes before May 1 as the Ways and Means Committee prepared today to report a bill for a tax cut Monday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The Labor Committee of the House of Representatives opened hearings on the Taft-Hartley law today and was promptly urged to write a ban on industry-wide bargaining.

To nobody's surprise another Western attempt to end the deadlock over the Austrian treaty has ended in failure. After only two sessions the latest conference of the Foreign Ministers' deputies, charged with drafting a treaty, had to be adjourned because the obstructionist tactics of Mr. Gromyko, the Soviet delegate, forced his associates to the conclusion that his Government had no desire for serious negotiations.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Feb. 11--Communist war prisoners on Koje Island, off the south coast of Korea, staged a new riot Monday, United Nations Headquarters here announced last night. One North Korean captive was killed and thirty-eight were injured when United Nations guards stormed a compound under a hail of rocks to enforce order. Four more prisoners died later of injuries, reports from Korea said.

The Chemstrand Corporation will reach capacity production in its new nylon plant at Pensacola, Fla., within eight months after it begins operation, according to Murray H. Morse of Chemstrand's sales department. The plant, with a capacity of 50,000,000 pounds annually, will begin production during the first quarter of 1954.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The second volume of the report of the Truman Commission on the Health Needs of the Nation, issued today under the title "The People Speak," presents testimony developing the theme that catastrophic illness costs too much for the average man's pocketbook even if he is aided by average current voluntary health insurance plans.

Senator Charles W. Tobey, Republican of New Hampshire, conferred yesterday with Spruille Braden, chairman of the New York Anti-Crime Committee, and Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. in preparation for the open hearings on watefront conditions and port security to be held by a Senate Commerce subcommittee.
The Port of New York was described last night as a "savage jungle" that could be cleared only by changes in laws and law enforcement methods.

ALBANY, Feb. 10 -- The Assembly gave final legislative approval today to two proposed Constitutional amendments affecting the method of election and the salaries of the Governor and Lieutenant Governor. Both will be put before the voters for ratification at the November election.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Americans earned more in 1952 than ever before, the Department of Commerce reported today. But the average wage earner's net income for 1952 was Just about the same as in 1951.
Dwight W. Bloser has been appointed vice president of Transicoil Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The assertion was made and quickly denied today that the Democratic National Committee once had accepted as authentic and had tried to obtain publicity for a letter describing Vice President Richard M. Nixon as the recipient of a $52,000 oil industry fund in addition to the $18,000 private fund he already had explained to the nation.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 10 -- Generalissimo Rafael Leonidas Trujillo, source of political power in the Dominican Republic, said today that his country planned to bring the question of Soviet anti-Semitism before the United Nations.
The Cleveland Orchestra, which gave a concert last night in Carnegie Hall, has developed remarkably in sensitiveness and beauty of tone and technical precision under George Szell's leadership.

Cotton futures trading on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday and closing prices were up 9 to 37 points, near the best levels of the day, with old crop months showing the most strength.

PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 10 -- Herman T. Stichman, New York State Housing Commissioner, asserted here tonight that unless New York City's officials developed a plan for "neighborhood living," middle-income families and large-scale employers would quit Manhattan.

DUBLIN, Feb. 10 (AP) -- A member of the Dail (Irish Parliament) claimed that the Government had paid $560,000 for a horse's neck in the purchase of Tulyar, 1952 English derby winner, by the Irish National Stud.

WASHINGTON, Feb. l0 -- The Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation of Syracuse was authorized by the Securities and Exchange Commission today to sell $25,000,000 of general mortgage bonds, due February, 1983. In addition, the agency authorized the company to sell 1,000,000 shares of its common capital stocks (no par value).

The Detroit Red Wings will tackle the New York Rangers in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight. In keeping with custom, the holiday eve attraction will be a "family" affair, children under 16 accompanied by parents being admitted at half price.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- A stiffening of the United States position in both East and West, though one not involving a blockade of Communist China by this country alone, was indicated authoritatively today before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

The new Administration's first national debt refinancing clearly indicates that the investment market is not yet ready for a long-term bond, Dr. Marcus Nadler, Professor of Finance of New York University said yesterday. He was a speaker at the thirty-fourth mid-winter trust conference of the American Bankers Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

W. L. WHITE, son of the late William Allen White, has always been a good reporter. He knows how to get men to talk and how to capture the "feel" of their stories by using their language and seeing things through their eyes. He has a sure instinct for the revealing detail and a dramatic sense that helps him get the most out of any situation, no matter how terrible or pitiful.
Operators were active yesterday in the purchase and sale of housing properties in Manhattan.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 9 -- Yugoslavia may shortly abandon another of the accoutrements of Communist regimes: Those startling percentages of voters participation in which it is reported that 97 or 98 or even 99.9 per cent of the electorate went to the polls on Election Day, all voting for the designated candidates.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9 -- Ezra T. Benson, the Secretary of Agriculture, has written to a Troy (Ohio) farmer that the Government has been advised that packers in the United States attempting to merchandise New Zealand beef are having difficulty disposing of it.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (UP) -- President Eisenhower scheduled a conference with Administration and Congressional leaders tomorrow, apparently to discuss the reciprocal trade program and its relation to foreign aid.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, Feb. 10 (Reuters) -- The South African Government announced today in an election move that immigration from India Would be put back on a quota system.

With 108 out of 116 city agencies reporting and all big requests in, departmental requests for 1953-54 to date have totaled $1,594,417,387. If granted, this would be $131,145,400 more than the same 108 departments received in the current budget.

ALBANY, Feb. 10 -- A special legislative committee studying the problem of providing compensation for innocent victims of highway accidents has split three to two over acceptance of Governor Dewey's recommendation to require all motor vehicle owners to carry liability insurance.

As reporters and photographers along with a handful of curious spectators stood vigil outside a General Sessions courtroom yesterday, Miss Pat Ward testified for the second day in the vice trial of Minot Frazier (Mickey) Jelke 3d.

The man-made mechanical heart, which resembles a six-cylinder automobile engine and keeps a patient's blood circulating through the body while an operation is performed on the living human heart, will be demonstrated in a documentary program on N.B.C.-TV's "American Inventory" on Sunday from 2 to 2:30 P. M.

MOST of the futile and discriminatory anti - firearms measures recently introduced in the State Legislature have been amended, withdrawn or killed in committee as a resultof the prompt protests by sportsmen's groups.

Terramycin has taken a leading position in the antibiotic field, the New York Society of Security Analysts was told yesterday by John E. McKeen, president of Chas. Pfizer Co., Inc., a major manufacturer of antibiotics.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The White House denied today that Miss Louise Hachmeister, longtime chief of the White House telephone switchboard, had been dismissed, but announced that she was on sick leave. The understanding was, however, that she would not return to her position but would retire when she reached 62 years of age next October.

Support for the Williams College chapter of Phi Delta Theta that was suspended for having pledged a Jewish student came yesterday from the fraternity's chapter at Brown University and from other organizations.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 10 -- It looks now as if "Paint Your Wagon" will be the first feature-length entertainment film to be made in the Cinerama process.

Spring-like in colors as well as patterns, predominantly floral in motif, roller-print wallpapers by Katzenbach Warren may be ordered after Feb. 28 at stores such as Lord Taylor, W. J. Sloane, Gimbels and Bloomingdale's.

On record sales of $476,884,615, the Continental Can Company had a consolidated net income of $14,387,839 last year, according to the preliminary statement issued yesterday by Gen. Lucius D. Clay, chairman.

I was surprised at the naivete of your editorial of Feb. 7 "On Progressive Education." You say that "Progressive education may be good or bad, but at least it has the merit of being at the opposite pole from communism." Therefore you conclude that Dr. Bella V. Dodd is wrong in saying that Communists use progressive education for their own ends.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Directors of the American Farm Bureau Federation representing about 1,500,000 farmers, presented to President Eisenhower today at what was termed a "very satisfactory meeting" their organization's recommended policies on agricultural matters in the domestic and foreign fields.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 10 (AP) -- Favorites moved through first-round matches in the Everglades Clubs mixed foursomes golf tournament today as expected, with Marlene Stewart, Fonthills, Ont., and Hobart Manley, Savannah, Ga., the medalists, leading the way.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Four teachers and administrative aides from three New York City colleges today challenged the right of the Senate Internal Security subcommittee to ask whether they were now or had been Communists. Two of them defended the right of Communists to teach in public educational institutions.
Winthrop W. Aldriich, new United States Ambassador to Britain, left by air at 6 o'clock last evening to take up his duties in London.

The American Export liner Constitution was ready to sail on schedule at 5 P. M. yesterday on a fifty - five - day Mediterranean cruise with many of her 515 passengers on board unaware that the 29,500-ton ship had been the object of an intensive four-hour bomb search until an hour before the scheduled departure time.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -Secretary of State John Foster Dulles reported to the National Security Council today on his recent European trip and scheduled a nation-wide radio and television address for 10:30 tomorrow night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Approval of the Reed tax-relief bill by the Ways and Means Committee of the House of Representatives Monday was regarded as a virtual certainty at the Capitol today after a meeting of Republican committee members with Secretary George M. Humphrey and other Treasury officials.

FROM Nags Head to Duck, through the fragrant yaupon, scrub pine and live oak, the welkin will ring and the dunes will echo the sweet music of hounds, for the annual Valentine Season Fox Hunt, now an institution on North Carolina's Outer Banks, will get under way this morning.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -United Airlines argued before a Civil Aeronautics Board examiner today that it could serve the public better and provide more dependable schedules if it received the authority to operate non-stop flights between the Pacific Northwest and Chicago.

The national Wage Stabilization Board enforcement commission has confirmed the guilt of thirteen local ship-repair concerns in paying over-the-ceiling wages and has increased the amount on which they must pay back taxes, it was announced here yesterday.

Guido Cantelli, known to this public already by his appearances as conductor of the N. B. C. Symphony Orchestra and as guest leader of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony, appeared as guest conductor of the Boston Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall.
CHICAGO, Feb. 11 -- Chuck Davey, college-bred challenger for the world welterweight title, tonight discovered the tremendous value of practical experience.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Feb. 11 -- Premier Willem Drees today gave Parliament a rough calculation of 1,000,000,000 guilders ($263,000,000) as the damage toll in the eleven-day-old flood in the southwest Netherlands -- the first official estimate -- and indicated how rehabilitation would be financed.
CAIRO, Feb. 11 -- Full agreement between Britain and Egypt on the future of the Anglo-Egyptian Sudan is expected to be reached tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -The Veterans Administration in the next few days will be mailing out 1953 dividend checks to National Service Life Insurance policy holders in all but three states, a survey showed today.

TORONTO, Feb. 11 -- Canada has embarked on research to develop a revolutionary type fighter aircraft that would take off vertically and fly at speeds in excess of 1,000 miles per hour, it was revealed today.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 11 -- The West German Government indicated today that it would fight Nazis whenever and wherever they were found to prevent a repetition of the overthrow of the Weimar Republic by fascism.

LONDON, Feb. 11 -- Winthrop W. Aldrich, new United States Ambassador to Britain, arrived here today to take over the post vacated by Walter S. Gifford last month. He told British reporters he foresaw no difficulties in Anglo-United States relations stemming from President Eisenhower's Far East policy.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 11 -- The Federal Executive Council, this country's highest Government authority, has adopted a draft law providing for the first time in the post-war history of Yugoslavia's Communist regime individual secret balloting in elections.

According to word received yesterday from Rome, Vittorio Gassmann has confirmed reports that he will tour this country early next year in an Italian repertoire program. The bill will include the production of "Hamlet," in which Signor Gassmann and his own company have been enjoying a successful run in Rome since last November.

PARIS, Feb. 11 -- The French submitted five protocols to the European army treaty to the other signatories today, but Government and Parliamentary circles predicted that the debate on ratification of the treaty could not come before June or July.
After coming through the most explosive year in American prison history, many penal institutions in various parts of the United States are still racked by unrest.

CHICAGO, Feb. 11 -- Ralph E. Stolkin of Chicago today turned back to Howard Hughes the controlling interest in R. K. O. Pictures Corporation. He and three associates last Sept. 23 had purchased from Mr. Hughes 27 1/2 per cent of the corporation's stock for $7,093,940.

PORT-OF-SPAIN, Trinidad, Feb. 10 -- Rear Admiral James E. Maher, commanding the United States Service Force of the Atlantic Fleet, left Trinidad today after his annual inspection of the last active United States Navy base in the British Caribbean territories at Chaguaramas, just outside Port-of-Spain.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 11 (AP) -- Caribbee, the swift-defending champion, moved back into a commanding lead today on the final leg of the fifteenth annual Miami - Nassau ocean sailing race.

The Soviet Union officially recognized Israel on May 17, 1948, in a note from the then Soviet Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov to Moshe Sharett, the Foreign Secretary of Israel's Provisional Government.
The city's Welfare Department asked the Welfare Department of New York State yesterday to increase the amount the city may pay to drug stores filling prescriptions for welfare cases.
Reports from Germany that a new Washington policy dictated that 90 per cent of the watches and cameras sold in post exchanges must be bought from United States manufacturers were discounted here.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 11 -- At the closing meeting of its biennial session tonight, the United Nations Transport and Communications Commission sent to the Economic and Social Council a series of recommendations involving international action to facilitate travel and transport.

HAMAMATSU, Japan, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Japan's cotton market is caught in a squeeze between shrinking markets and stepped-up foreign competition. The Japanese Government has ordered drastic operation cuts.

In your editorial "The Formosa Policy" you state in part that "the neutralizing order to the fleet could not do otherwise than give an additional sense of security to the Communist foe" and that "at this point it is the Communists that are off balance as the result of our initiative."

GENEVA, Feb. 11 -- Both Europe and Latin America, preoccupied with their economic relations with the United States, are failing lamentably to develop the potentialities of trade with each other, according to a special United Nations study published here today.
The port's force of towboats and other harbor craft returned to normal yesterday in the first full day of operation after the ten-day strike that was settled late Tuesday.

An increase last week of 3,050,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end supplies were 152,493,000 barrels compared with 149,443,000 a week earlier and 147,941,000 a year ago.
YOKOHAMA, Japan, Thursday, Feb. 12 (UP) -- The American President Lines freighter President Pierce reported today she was afire 110 miles east of here after a series of explosions in her holds.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 10 -- The post exchanges are one of the principal foundations of the "American way of life" in West Germany and West Berlin for hundreds of thousands of soldiers, airmen and their dependents.

ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- Mayor Impellitteri and City Council President Rudolph Halley made separate appeals to the Legislature today for $62,700,000 more in state subsidies for New York City but disagreed sharply as to the possibilities of reducing city operating costs.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 11 -Capt. Dick Lionette and forward Bill Dennis combined to give Harvard's basketball team its first Eastern Intercollegiate League victory in eighteen games, a 50-46 triumph over highly favored Dartmouth, at the indoor athletic building tonight. Harvard staged a torrid finish in the last three minutes to overcome the Green in a game which was tied eleven times.

Forty well-known American Roman Catholics denounced anti-Semitism of the "Communist world" yesterday and called upon the "conscience of the world, through governments and the United Nations, to protest" against it.

LONDON, Feb. 11-- A government spokesman affirmed in the House of Lords today that Britain stood by the international agreements that took Southern Sakhalin and the Kurile Islands from Japan after the war and gave them to the Soviet Union.

The process of education is not static, and sometimes, when a parent discovers that his child is not being taught in quite the same way he was taught, doubts may arise as to the efficacy of contemporary instruction.

" The home localizes us, gives us a place," Elizabeth Bowen, British novelist and short story writer, declared in a talk on "The Idea of the Home" at Barnard College Tuesday evening. Focusing mainly on the American home, Miss Bowen considered the function of modern home life in promoting the mental health of the individual.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Stabilization officials worked late tonight compiling the list of new items that will be freed from price controls before the end of the week.

A good many sensible people must wonder why casualty insurance companies, whose agents spend their working days trying to convince motorists that every car owner ought to be insured, are trying to convince the New York Legislature to the contrary. We wonder, too, and the reasons offered are not persuasive.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Air Force spokesmen began today a detailed defense against charges of "fabulous waste" in the construction and manning of overseas bases before a closed meeting of the Senate Armed Services Committee.

TAIPIN, Formosa, Thursday, Feb. 12 -- The Nationalist Defense Ministry's Military Information Service reported yesterday that more than 100 Chinese Communists were killed and forty-seven taken prisoner in a sea battle of junks off the Red mainland Monday.

Anthony V. Camarda, 34-year-old member of the notorious family that controls the six so-called Italian locals of the International Longshoremen's Association in Brooklyn, was held yesterday in $50,000 bail as a material witness as Kings County District Attorney Miles F. McDonald stepped up his waterfront investigation.

It is curious how ready various charities and good causes are to lend themselves and the public interest in them (their "goodwill") unthinkingly to promote the billboard nuisance in this country. It works this way:

All financial and commodity markets in the United States will be closed today in observance of Lincoln's Birthday. Various livestock reports of the United States Department of Agriculture will be issued as usual. Canadian grain and securities exchanges and London financial markets will be open.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- President Eisenhower conferred today with Republican Congressional leaders on renewal of the reciprocal trade agreements program and simplification of customs procedure. At an hour's conference the President and his aides discussed international trade problems and plans to promote such commerce.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -United States diplomatic authorities assured West Berlin occupation officials today that they were there by virtue of the conquest of Germany and not by any "secret agreements" that might be abrogated.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 11 (AP) -- A United States delegate told the Inter-American Economic and Social Conference today that although there are limits to United States economic aid, Washington wants to know Latin America's needs.

ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- A proposed constitutional amendment that would bar construction of the $6,000,000 Panther Mountain Dam and all other river-regulating projects in the Adirondack forest preserve was introduced in the Legislature today.
The New York City Office of Civil Defense removed yesterday, on a trial basis, the ban on use of sirens by ambulances under the jurisdiction of the Department of Hospitals.

On the eve of Peter Cooper's 162d birthday, alumni, faculty members and students observed Founder's Day ceremonies last night in the historic Great Hall of Cooper Union, Fourth Avenue at Eighth Street.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Feb. 11 -- The boards of directors of Nassau County's second and third largest commercial banks approved a merger agreement here today and each board scheduled special meetings of stockholders to ratify the agreement of consolidation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- President Eisenhower refused today to grant clemency to Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, asserting that their betrayal of United States atomic serets to Russia might bring death to "many, many thousands of innocent citizens."

Parents are apt to fall short in their efforts to get across to children the meaning and importance of human values if they don't actually live these values with them, Millicent C. McIntosh, president of Barnard College, said last night.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 11 -Outbreaks of anti-Semitism behind the Iron Curtain are believed by Associate Justice William O. Douglas of the United States Supreme Court to reflect a Soviet attitude of "confidence, not fear."

Students in the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism will conduct an experimental news program over television station WPIX beginning Monday, March 2, from 9 to 9:30 P. M. Entitled "News-O-Rama," the program will feature at least five students each week in a dramatized dissection of major news events.

The announcement which is expected this morning that Britain and Egypt have agreed on a settlement of their dispute over the Sudan will be the best news that has come out of the Middle East in many a long month. The importance of this understanding can hardly be exaggerated.

CHICAGO, Feb. 11 -- Judge Walter J. LaBuy of Federal District Court cited today the historic right of the press to report trial proceedings with a freedom and latitude of expression which is "beyond the control" of parties in the case being tried.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Martin P. Durkin, Secretary of Labor, has set his sights on getting the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service back into the Labor Department and by way of performance in that direction, contributed without notice to the settlement of the New York tugboat strike yesterday.

The McCarran Immigration Act was sharply attacked as a threat to American prestige abroad at the seventh annual dinner of the New York region of the American Veterans Committee at the Commodore Hotel last night.

Directors of the American Farm Bureau Federation, representing about 1,500,000 farmers, called on President Eisenhower on Tuesday and outlined their ideas on farm policy at home and abroad. The Federation is one of the strongholds, among farmers, of a policy of flexible farm price supports, and it may be said that this policy more or less symbolizes its general approach to economic problems.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the age of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown, tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified. The programs follow:

The election of William A. Paton as a director of Kalamazoo Vegetable Parchment Company was announced yesterday by Dwight L. Stocker, president. Mr. Paton is Edwin F. Gay, Professor of Accounting at the University of Michigan.

HOBE SOUND, Fla., Feb. 11 -Private family funeral services for Valentine Crouse Bartlett, 59 years old, who was found shot in his Jupiter Island home Tuesday morning, will be held at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church at Stuart Thursday morning at 10 A. M.
CHICAGO, Feb. 11 (AP) -- To Kid Gavilan, relaxed and jovial after knocking Chuck Davey's welterweight title hopes into the canvas at the Chicago Stadium tonight, it was "just another fight."

The Chrysler Corporation achieved a record sales volume last year on a lower vehicle output and increased net earnings to $78,696,599 from the $71,973,469 earned in 1951, despite taxes that were up 114 per cent.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 11 -- Edward C. McAuliffe, chairman of the Delaware River Port Authority, said here tonight that a $2,000,000,000 industrial expansion could be expected in southern New Jersey within the next five years.

In a move to protect a large section of Manhattan's garment and fur centers from the encroachment of undesirable developments, the City Planning Commission approved yesterday a rezoning of about 160 acres of midtown Manhattan.

DAVOS, Switzerland, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Jean Westwood and Lawrence Demmy, 21-year-old British world ice dancing champions, were well on their way tonight toward winning the title again after spending the day dancing the rocker, fox trot, a Viennese waltz, the Argentine tango and the kilian, a quickstep.
The city of Chicago announced yesterday that it would put up for sale on March 10 an issue of $21,500,000 in bonds.

Federal Judge Harold R. Medina remarked in Federal Court here yesterday that it is "beginning to be apparent * * * that there isn't any conspiracy and that there never was any conspiracy" as charged by the Department of Justice against seventeen investment banking houses.

CHICAGO, Feb. 11 -- Wheat and corn futures showed considerable strength at times today. There was active mill buying of wheat futures, reflecting sales of upward of 4,000,000 sacks of flour overnight, while corn was influenced by the jump of 1 1/2 to 2 cents in spot prices relative to May.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 11 -- Yugoslavia today demanded that fellow members of the Danube River Commission -- the Soviet Union, Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Bulgaria and Rumania -- annul "in due time" a resolution adopted last December condemning Yugoslavia's towing of vessels by a locomotive in the Sip Canal near the Iron Gate at the point where the Danube crosses the Rumanian-Yugoslav frontier.

Confidence that Congress will enact measures to encourage greater imports by this country was expressed yesterday by Warren Lee Pierson, chairman of the United States Council of the International Chamber of Commerce.
MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 11 -- President Eisenhower is studying a joint industry-union plea to strip the Interstate Commerce Commission of authority over the nation's trucks, it was disclosed here today.

Gerard W. Purcell, former financial secretary of the Uniformed Firemen's Association who pleaded guilty June 11 to charges involving the theft of about $238,000 of organization funds, was sentenced yesterday to serve from two and a half to five years in state prison.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Feb. 11 -- Fordham's basketball team fought back from a first-quarter deficit tonight and went on to score its sixteenth victory in nineteen starts, defeating Rutgers, 88 -- 73.
The need for business men to take a closer look at their distributive processes was stressed yesterday by a management consultant and an industrial designer.

IT was just a minute or two before the running of the Baxter Mile at Madison Square Garden last Saturday. Mal Whitfield had clipped the world record in the Buermeyer 500, Bob Richards had raised the meet mark in the pole vault and the boys were moving in high gear as far as record-shattering was concerned.
Potted plants -- acceptable as indoor decorative accents the year round -- seem especially pleasant now when spring may be just around the corner though the sky is still too often gray.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Feb. 4, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:

The eligibility committee of the Eastern College Athletic Conference ruled yesterday that Jack McGuire, transfer student at City College who attended Queens College during the first term of the present academic year and was a member of the Queens varsity basketball team, was ineligible to represent City in basketball during the remainder of the campaign.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Feb. 11 -- Cologate fought off a last-period bid to defeat Army, 76 to 74, in basketball at the Field House today.

I am interested in your editorial of Feb. 7 where you praise President Eisenhower's rejection of the "philosophy of unlimited emergency" which was demonstrated by the removal of most price and wage controls. Just a few days before, Secretary of State Dulles warned our Western allies to get ahead with European unity, putting a time limit on their performance.

In a new effort to wreck the unification program pressed upon Western Europe by the Eisenhower Administration the Communist party of East Germany has issued a blunt threat of a Berlin blockade which would bring "further isolation, distress and danger" to the West Berlin population if the Bonn Government ratifies the European Defense Community Treaty.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- President Eisenhower today signed the bill authorizing him to propose plans for the reorganization of the Executive Branch of the Government.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The White House was noncommittal today on reports that President Eisenhower intended to do away with the Council of Economic Advisers, an agency of the Executive Office of the President.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 11 (AP) -- New York retained its first-place hold in the National Basketball Association's Eastern division by trouncing Baltimore, 86 -- 60, tonight.

PARIS, Feb. 11 (UP) -- Art Larsen of San Francisco and Budge Patty of Los Angeles won straight sets victories today to gain the singles semi-finals of the French international hard courts tennis championship along with Sven Davidsson of Sweden.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 11 -- A demand by Egypt that the West German Federal Republic grant the Arab states, including Egypt, between $750,000,000 and $1,000,000,000 in long-term credits in reparation for so-called damage caused the Arabs by the Bonn restitution agreement with Israel was rejected today by the Federal Government.
John David Provoo, 35 years old, a former Army sergeant, was found guilty last night by a Federal Court jury, of treason while a prisoner of the Japanese after the fall of Corregidor.

The New York Dress Institute, which is terminating on March 1 its operations under the aegis of the Joint Board, Dressmakers Union of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, will continue as a voluntary enterprise of leading New York dress manufacturers.

ROME, Feb. 11 -- The Vatican newspaper, in an unusually vigorous, unsigned editorial, repudiated today the suggestion that the newly nominated United States Ambassador to Italy, Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce, might "cultivate useful relations with the Holy See" and thus act as United States diplomatic representative to the Vatican.
Under the terms of Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman's stay of execution, a new date for the execution of the Rosenbergs will be set in Federal Court on Monday.

In an age when jet planes, rockets to the moon and space ships seem to monopolize the imagination of the transport-minded, a quiet little voice from England wafts across the ocean a gentle hope reminiscent of the ambitions of little boys of a yesterage, when the affairs of the world moved, or seemed to move, more slowly, and there was time for dreaming.
MOSCOW, Thursday, Feb. 12 -- The Soviet Union broke off diplomatic relations with Israel early today.

The first concrete steps toward the design and construction of a super atomic machine that would accelerate atomic particles to energies up to a hundred billion electron volts were announced yesterday by the Brookhaven National Laboratory of the Atomic Energy Commission at Upton, L. I.

PATERSON, N. J., Feb. 11 -Senator Leverett Saltonstall, Republican of Massachusetts, who is chairman of the Armed Services Committee, told an audience of 400 party leaders tonight that Gen James A. Van Fleet would be asked to testify before the committee when he returned to this country.
TOKYO, Thursday, Feb. 12 (AP) -- General and Mrs. Van Fleet will travel to San Francisco aboard the liner President Jackson after a brief holiday in Honolulu.

Today's new film is "Tonight We Sing," a Twentieth Century-Fox Technicolor biography of Sol Hurok, with David Wayne portraying the impresario, at the Radio City Music Hall, Ezio Pinza, Roberta Peters, Tamar Toumanova, Anne Bancroft, Isaac Stern, Byron Palmer, Oscar Karlweis and Mikhail Rasumny are among the featured players.

The Sherman Act is a "potential pitfall to every aggressive business leader," bankers were told yesterday by the president of the American Bar Association. Robert G. Storey, a speaker at the thirty-fourth midwinter trust conference of the American Bankers Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, said also that even more disturbing was "inconsistent enforcement" of anti-trust legislation, which, he said, can be "dangerously uncertain" for American business.

Calf-roping not being one of the regularly scheduled courses at the Police Academy, the crews of several police radio cars, called yesterday morning to Kissena Boulevard and Forty-fifth Avenue, Flushing, did their rounding up with shooing noises plus a certain amount of persuasion.
Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, and his new team in the Pentagon, were beginning yesterday the difficult business of trying to save men and money in the armed services.
The cotton futures market declined 5 to 17 points yesterday, with activity on the New York Cotton Exchange moderate in volume.

ROME, Feb. 11 (AP) -- An Italian-born American Protestant Evangelist said today he had appealed to Premier Alcide de Gasperi to save him and his wife from being expelled from Italy by Government order. He reported that at least two other Evangelists faced a similar threat.

The renewal of a court rivalry dating back to 1909 will headline the college basketball program at Madison Square Garden tonight, when Manhattan College faces New York University, starting at 7:45. A meeting between St. John's and Westminster will follow.

Although they outrushed their foes for the greater part of the game, the best the New York Rangers could do against the Detroit Red Wings in Madison Square Garden last night was to hold them to a tie. With Nick Mickoski and Wally Hergesheimer of the Broadway Blues matching goals with Ted Lindsay and John Wilson, the teams played to a 2-to-2 tie before a crowd of 8,469.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- A Government fact-finding board is reported to have filed a second report at the White House today on the long labor dispute between the American Locomotive Company and members of the United Steelworkers, C. I. O., employed in the company's plant at Dunkirk, N. Y.

The ten-day strike of tugboat employes is over, and with it has vanished the threat of a curtailment of fuel and other essential supplies. The settlement gives the employes a wage increase. The problem of how many employes are to man the tugs is to go to fact-finding and arbitration.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Feb. 11 -- Seton Hall University turned down a stubborn bid by Siena College tonight, recording a 62-49 victory to stretch its winning skein to twenty-three, longest among the nation's major colleges.

This is Negro History Week. It is the one week in which all of us, regardless of our ethnic background, should pause and consider some of the problems and accomplishments of fifteen million of our compatriots who trace their ancestry to Africa.

MIAMI, Feb. 11 -- The $21,150 Florida Breeders' Stakes, for 2-year-olds foaled in this state, was the main item of business at the Hialeah Race Course today. A three-horse entry trained by Elmer Heubeck Jr. was favored at 9 to 5 -- and made a one, two, nine finish in the field of eighteen that raced over the three-furlong straightaway course.

Craig Woodruff has been named manager of the international division of L. C. Smith Corona Typewriters, Inc. He will be responsible for subsidiaries outside the United States as well as for export sales.

BERLIN, Feb. 11 -- East Germany's Communists stated flatly today that further measures would be taken to isolate West Berlin. At the same time they presented a comprehensive program for unification of the city based on the "overthrow" of the present government in the Allied sectors.
TOKYO, Thursday, Feb. 12 -Fighting lagged in Korea yesterday, as the Eighth Army passed to the command of Lieut. Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, succeeding Gen. James A. Van Fleet.

Manhattan, tuning up for the defense of its intercollegiate A. A. A. A. title, made a complete runaway of the fourteenth annual Metropolitan intercollegiate indoor track and field championships last night. George Eastment's Jaspers, victorious for the fourth straight year in the local carnival, won seven of the thirteen events and piled up 78 points.

TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 11 -- Under a big front-page headline Teheran newspapers printed today assurance from the United States Embassy that Washington had no intention of violating the "political independence and territorial integrity" of Iran.

World demand is expected to absorb all of Cuba's present raw sugar crop of 5,000,000 tons, B. Rionda Braga, president of the Francisco Sugar Company, told stockholders at their annual meeting yesterday. He noted, however, that there is still the Cuban stabilization reserve of 1,400,000 tons overhanging the market and a normal carryover of about 280,000 tons, largely United States retained.
SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 11 (UP) -- Several prominent Australian athletic officials expressed doubt today that Melbourne would be able to stage the 1956 Olympic Games.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Mal Whitfield, Grand Street Boys Association top middle-distance runner, continued his string of 1953 successes by coasting to victory in the Orange and Black 600 at the seventh annual 175th Regiment-South Atlantic Association track games tonight.
ALBANY, Feb. 11 (AP) -- The Legislature today elected Cornelius W. Wickersham, a retired lieutenant general, to the Board of Regents.
The weatherbeaten, statue of Abraham Lincoln in Union Square Park will attract patriotic and civic groups today for ceremonies marking the 144th anniversary of the birth of the sixteenth President.

Manufacturers must give all-out aid to stores grappling with entirely new problems resulting from the phenomenal growth of self-service retailing. This was the theme of remarks yesterday by top executives in two important phases of retailing at concluding sessions of the American Management Association's annual marketing conference in the Statler Hotel.

ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- The issue of public versus private inspection of automobiles was revived today with the introduction by a Republican of a bill providing for inspections at private garages licensed by the state. The bill, put in by Assemblyman Thomas J. Runfola of Buffalo, carries out the recommendation of the New York State Automobile Dealers Association.

Women who have long taken an active interest in the work of the Catholic Big Sisters are among the subscribers to the annual luncheon and card party in behalf of the organization, to be held on Tuesday in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. Kimball G. Colby heads the benefit committee. Mrs. H. Lester Cuddihy is president of the beneficiary.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -The Maritime Board begins tomorrow the first of two hearings on applications by two steamship lines to charter vessels for use in the Pacific Northwest-Alaska trade.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -The text of President Eisenhower's statement on the Rosenbergs' plea follows:

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 11 -The Government of India views with "grave concern" recent developments in the Far East following the United States Government's change of orders to the Seventh Fleet regarding Formosa, President Rajendra Prasad said today in an address to a joint session of Parliament.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Out in the big backyard of the White House, where the eggs used to roll on Easter Monday, President Eisenhower's golf balls are rolling now.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The Georgia Power Company of Atlanta applied to the Securities and Exchange Commission today for authority to market $16,000,000 worth of first mortgage bonds, maturing in not less than thirty years, and 100,000 shares of preferred stock, of no par value.

The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, in a special twenty-page study of the Prague purge trials issued yesterday, holds that the current Kremlin-led anti-Semitic campaign parallels the hoax known as the Protocols of the Learned Elders of Zion, which was used by the old Czarist regime for similar purposes.

TOKYO, Thursday, Feb. 12 -Gen. James A. Van Fleet prepared to depart today for home and retirement leaving unanswered the question whether the Eighth Army, which he commanded until yesterday, is now capable of breaking the back of the Communist opposition in Korea and forcing a peace settlement.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 11 -- Frank Lloyd, one of the top movie directors before his retirement in 1945, joined Republic Pictures today under a long-term multiple-picture contract calling for his services as director and associate producer. He has not decided what his first film will be.

Three elderly women, all of whom have lived for many years in an old building at 124 East Fortieth Street, near Park Avenue, were threatened with eviction yesterday because the rooms they occupied, designated as "maids' rooms" under the city code, were considered too small for occupancy by other than domestics.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (UP) -Several Senators today quoted General of the Army Omar N. Bradley as having told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on Tuesday that a win-the-war offensive in Korea would cost heavy casualties and could not assure an early victory. The Senators added that he had been "glum" about the prospects of such a drive.

Your Jan. 31 editorial lamenting the blessed demise of the so-called anti-vandalism bill impels me to voice astonishment at the tenor of that editorial. For it is altogether alien to the generally discerning, accurate, informed and progressive policies of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Changes in prices of commodity futures were irregular yesterday on New York commodity exchanges. Volume continued fairly light on most items but potatoes, coffee and domestic sugar were active. Cocoa, potatoes, soybean oil, lead and zinc closed lower than Tuesday's final prices.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Feb. 11 -The Town of Hempstead, stymied in its initial attempt to gain possession of the abandoned Elmont sand pit in which three children drowned last Friday, issued three summonses today to its owner for the alleged violation of ordinances controlling sand-pit maintenance.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The National Archives made the public a Lincoln's Birthday present today of a newly identified Gettysburg photograph that may, for the first time, show the Civil War President at the scene of his historic address.

FRANKFURT, Germany, Feb. 11 (AP) -- The United States State Department authorized a statement today that the intensive wartime bombing of Dresden, Germany, by American and British airmen had been done in response to Soviet requests and had been cleared in advance with Soviet authorities.
PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 11 -Led by Center Foster Cooper's 19 points, the Princeton basketball team defeated Cornell, 59 -- 50, to night in an Eastern Intercollegiate League contest.

A lengthy and demanding program of piano music was played last night in Town Hall by Ines Carillo. The young Argentine pianist, heard in such works as Bach's English Suite in A minor, Ginastera's Six American Preludes (Vol. I), Ravel's "Alborado del Grazioso" and six Chopin Preludes, presented some very fleet, if a little immature, playing.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 11 -- Communists and fellow travelers who marched through downtown Tel Aviv today to the Soviet Legation to convey expressions of sympathy to Pavel Ivanovitch Yershov, the Soviet Minister and the Legation staff on Monday night's bombing were stoned along the route by organized groups of anti-Communists.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (UP) -The Government reported today that both United States and world consumption of rubber rose to records in 1952.

The frozen food industry's output in 1952 was valued at nearly $1,000,000,000, according to estimates presented at a gathering of more buyers, distributors, retailers and others at the Roosevelt Hotel yesterday.

PARIS, Feb. 11 -- The dollar-rich market made up of approximately 40,000 United States soldiers, airmen and sailors stationed in France has become an important potential source of hard currency for this dollar-hungry nation during the last year.

Many parties will be given at the Valentine tea dance, to be held tomorrow afternoon in the Chanteclair Room of the Sherry-Netherland under the auspices of the Thrift Shop Committee of the Union Settlement Women's Auxiliary. In lieu of the admission fee, guests may bring packages of useful and decorative articles suitable for resale later at Everybody's Thrift Shop.

The alarm expressed in Western Europe lest American action in "deneutralizing" Formosa extend the war is another reminder that the Western and Eastern fronts are practically inseparable. Secretary Dulles' trip to the Western capitals was undertaken for the purpose of discussing European policy, but invariably and inevitably the talk veered from NATO and the European Defense Community to the situation in the East.

The formation of a nation-wide organization to help colleges and universities obtain funds from business and industry was announced yesterday. Headed by five industrialists, the Council for Financial Aid to Education has been incorporated in this state to advise business and higher education on programs for the latter's financial support.

More than 130 paintings from a highly personal and fascinating collection of modern art went on view last night at the Metropolitan Museum. They are on loan from Edward Root, son of Elihu Root Sr., who served as Secretary of State under Theodore Roosevelt.

SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, Feb. 12 (UP) -- Dr. Syngman Rhee, South Korean President, endorsed today proposals for a blockade of Communist China and angrily attacked "fence-sitting nations" fearful of taking any action that might irritate Moscow.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 11 -- The Mexican Navy has ordered two gunboats to reinforce its patrol of coastal waters in the Gulf of Mexico with orders to shoot at any foreign fishing vessels caught working Mexican waters if they resist instructions to proceed to port.

BOSTON, Feb. 11 -- The American Woolen Company, which permanently closed five of its twenty-four mills in the New England and New York areas in 1952, will open a third southern mill at Tifton, Ga., by mid 1953, Francis W. White, president, said today.

Papers in a suit in which five New York newspapers and two press associations are seeking to have General Sessions Judge Francis L. Valente lift his ban on the public and press attendance at the vice trial of Minot F. (Mickey) Jelke 3d were filed in Supreme Court yesterday and later served on Judge Valente.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Feb. 11 -- The Opposition in Parliament concurred in principle today in the Government's demand for dictatorial power to suspend virtually all laws in case it decides to declare a state of emergency.

WASHINGTON, Feb 11 (AP) -Secretary of the Interior Douglas McKay today announced approval of a development contract with Phillips Petroleum Company, Bartlesville, Okla., looking toward discovery of oil in Alaska.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 11 (UP) -Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson said today Government farm price supports should be used as "disaster insurance" and not to encourage "uneconomic production" leading to big surpluses and subsidies.
TOKYO, Thursday, Feb. 12 (AP) -United Nations Command communique 1,523, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Thursday, Korean time:

Atlantic and Gulf Coast ship operators and agents bowed yesterday to the demands of the National Maritime Union, C. I. O., and granted the full wage and overtime increases won by the seamen in an award announced Nov. 25 by Aaron Horvitz, arbitrator.
Stock prices declined yesterday for the sixth successive day. Volume was the smallest since Oct. 30. Only 1,240,000 shares were traded, against 1,350,000 on Tuesday.

As the result of an alleged scheme to raise money to fight communism, three persons were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury for mail fraud and conspiracy to impersonate an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

FORT MEADE, Md., Feb. 11 (AP) -- Letters in which Lieut. Col. Melvin B. Voorhees announced his intention to override Army censorship and ignore a Sixth Army command were read into the evidence at his court-martial today.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Feb. 11 -Legislative action was promised today to correct a defect in the Bridgeport Civil Service Law which, according to the City Attorney, denies benefits to veterans of the conflict in Korea.

ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- Senator Irving M. Ives warned New York Republicans tonight that their victory in last fall's election was "in reality a frail thing" and should not lead the party into overconfidence in preparing for the 1954 off-year contests.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -Publicly announced corporation dividends came to $548,000,000 in January, 8 per cent more than in January a year ago, the Department of Commerce said today.

RAMLE, Israel, Feb. 11 -- A new village for "displaced Arabs" -- fifty one-room concrete houses set in an olive, grove a few miles south of this town -- was proudly handed over to the tribe of Arab-el-Guarish today by Foreign Minister Moshe Sharett and Minister of Agriculture Perez Naftali.

The police in Brooklyn were unable to "uncover evidence of gambling sufficient to make an arrest" during the time investigators for the Kings County District Attorney's office seized bookmakers on streets. Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan acknowledged yesterday.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 11 -- A unilateral offer of a 5 per cent wage increase was made today by the Pacific Maritime Association to stewards in more than 4,000 jobs on ships of association members.

That American diets often are low in Vitamin C (ascorbic acid) seems odd in view of the availability of the foods rich in this nutrient -- fresh and processed citrus fruits, fresh and processed tomatoes, and cabbage, which is a good source when eaten raw.

LONDON, Feb. 6 -- A substantial contribution to Britain's dollar reserves is made by the post exchanges operated by the United States Third Air Force for its 35,000 airmen and their families in this country.

" MERELY COLOSSAL,"* by Arthur Mayer, is a rambuctiously entertaining freehand sketch of life in the art that lost the virtue of silence. These restless memoirs of the cinema carry a subtitle only faintly reminiscent of the ones that used to be flashed on the silent screen ("Came the dawn, and Lynn's long vigil was over").

A new work by Bruce Hutchison, "The Incredible Canadian," will be published next Wednesday by Longmans, Green. It is a candid portrait of Canada's "enigmatic statesman," the late Mackenzie King, dealing with his work, his time and his nation. Mr. Hutchison is the author of "The Unknown Country."
TOKYO, Feb. 6 -- In 1952 the post exchanges in Japan and Korea did $175,000,000 worth of business, with slightly more than half the volume accounted for in the exchanges in Korea.

Arthur Krock, the Washington correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, told an audience of public school teachers, here yesterday that President Eisenhower was "starting off well and decisively down the middle of the road."

Frothy organdy, gossamer chiffon and lace, with fairy tale heroines for inspiration, are what spring and summer bridal gowns will be made of, according to Mrs. Ruth English, director of the Rosette Pennington Bride's Shop. In this shop's collection yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, she presented one enchantingly pretty gown after another, each so lovely it was named for a fairy tale heroine and stamped with this bridal director's flair for chic and excellent taste.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -The Air Transport Association, which represents the nation's scheduled domestic airlines, said today it had gone twelve full months without a passenger fatality.

Columbia University started yesterday the first of two drives -- for $1,250,000 -- in behalf of its Bicentennial Fund for the Medical Sciences, and announced the appointment of John G. Jackson, a university trustee, as chairman of the fund's steering committee.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- At least two, and possibly more, Congressional investigations into the extent to which Communists might have infiltrated their persons and philosophies into the educational system of the country were definitely in sight at the Capitol today.

LONDON, Feb. 11 -- The stock markets started confidently today on new bookkeeping account. British Government securities led an advance that embraced industrials as well as South African gold mine shares which were the busiest section.

GUATEMALA, Feb. 11 -- The medical and law schools of San Carlos University have closed and eighty-five law offices have joined in a protest with the schools against the ousting by Congress last week, at the instigation of the Government, of the judges of the Supreme Court.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 11 -- A field goal by John Clune with just one second left broke a six-game Pennsylvania winning streak as Navy's middies upset the Quakers today, 62 -- 60.

Events today: WNYC American Music Festival Concert, Town Hall, 3 P. M.; "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci," Metropolitan Opera, 8:15; Philharmonic-Symphony, Bruno Walter conducting, John Corigliano, violinist, William Lincer, violist, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; The Concert Choir, Margaret Hillis, conducting, Town Hall, 8:30; WNYC American Music Festival Concert, Carl Fischer Concert Hall, 8:30; Mozart Damenchor, Leonard A. Temme conducting, Guiseppe Valdengo, baritone, Hunter-College Auditorium, 8:30.

What Freddie Monroe really would have liked to do was padlock old Public School 27. School was getting very tiresome, same old thing every day. And to a fellow only 10 years old and in the fifth grade, the years of that dull stuff seemed to stretch endlessly into the future.

Even if the best authorities have long agreed that the association of St. Valentine's Day with the traditional lovers' festival is accidental, Feb. 14 continues to flourish as a day of tender sentiment.
Net sales of Container Corporation of America dropped to $178,408,152 in 1952 from $212,562,019 in 1951, Walter P. Paepcke, chairman, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Members of the House Education and Labor Committee debated in open hearing today the desirability of continuing the non-Communist oath provision of the Taft-Hartley law, with the temper of the dominant members indicating an extension of the oath requirement to employers.
LONDON, Thursday, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Following is the text of the Soviet note to Israel announcing a break in relations between the two countries, as broadcast from Moscow:

To judge by "Hazel Flagg," which opened at the Mark Hellinger last evening, borrowing from the movies may not be such a bad thing. This is the musical show that has been manufactured out of the screen play "Nothing Sacred" of 1937, and it turns out to be a fast and brassy Broadway show.

A vacant irregular parcel about 217 by 98 feet on the north side of Thirty-ninth Avenue, west of Francis Lewis Boulevard, in the Auburndale section of Queens has been purchased by the Sam-Lou Building Corporation for improvement with ten one-family dwellings.

Many passengers embark on outbound liners from limousines or shiny taxicabs, but three Manila-bound travelers outdid them yesterday when they rolled into Pier 3, Bush Terminal, Brooklyn, in their own private trailer.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 11 -- A field goal by John Clune with just one second left broke a six-game Pennsylvania winning streak as Navy's middies upset the Quakers today, 62 -- 60.
LONDON, Feb. 12 -- The Soviet Union's break in relations with Israel was regarded in many diplomatic circles here today as a further tightening of its domestic security.

FORT MEADE, Md., Feb. 12 (AP) -- A censor's uncensored book on Korea accused General of the Army Douglas MacArthur of "a most serious security break which proved costly in casualties," an Army court-martial was told today.

TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 12 -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh appointed a committee today to prepare a full list of Iran's claims against the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company, which formerly operated the oil concession in this country, in case the claims should ever be submitted to an international tribunal.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The White House announced today that all Government departments, with the exception of Defense and State, would henceforth be prohibited from sending information officers to White House news conferences.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Now that the false witness against Richard M. Nixon during the campaign has been exposed (in Look by Richard L. Wilson), and a Senate subcommittee is investigating the evidence, it is possible to report new ideas about the Presidential succession without seeming to reflect on the capacity or character of the able and honorable young Vice President of the United States.

An investigating of the Municipal Civil Service Commission by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan was asked yesterday by the Grand Jury Association of New York County. Lee Thompson Smith, president, said the request was based on the report made Tuesday by the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey which charged, among other things, that political pressure had controlled Police Department appointments.

Advocating that religious training be given to children in the home and the church rather than in schools through the current practice of opening prayers, Dr. Israel Goldstein president of the American Jewish Congress declared yesterday that this use of prayer in the schools had no influence on the moral development of children.
