Long Island Rail Road trains bound for Manhattan were delayed from twelve to forty-five minutes yesterday morning when a Far Rockaway train struck an automobile near the Cedar Manor station in Jamaica, Queens.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations asserted today the Social Security Law needed many improvements in coverage and benefit provisions, but that the proposals of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States would do more harm than good.

CHICAGO, Feb. 12 -- Industry can and should make its most effective contribution to education in the field of finance, Charles R. Sligh Jr., president of the National Association of Manufacturers, said today. He addressed the American Association of Colleges for Teachers Education.

DALLAS, Tex., Feb. 12 (AP) -- A Federal indictment involving the smuggling of $250,000 worth of small arms to Mexico was returned here today against a famous Texas rifle sharpshooter and eleven other men.

YOKOHAMA, Japan, Friday, Feb. 13 (UP) -- Fire broke out again in the flame-crippled American President Lines freighter President Pierce today a few hours after the heavily listing vessel anchored two miles off this port.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture said today there has been only one minor change in its policy of selling Government-owned grains at home and abroad since Secretary Benson took office last month.

With Lent starting next Wednesday meatless main dishes are once more in order. The recipes for them that follow, suggested by THE NEW YORK TIMES home economist, Mrs. Ruth P. Casa-Emellos, are simple and inexpensive to execute.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Feb. 12 (UP) -- Carleton Mitchell's 57-foot yawl Caribbee won her second straight Miami-to-Nassau sailing race today, completing the 184-mile distance three hours ahead of her closest rival. The Caribbee's corrected time was 32 hours 52 minutes 18 seconds.
Following is the text of a speech by John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, delivered over the combined radio and television networks last night as transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 12 (AP) -- The medalist, Marlene Stewart of Fonthill, Ont., and Hobart Manley of Savannah, Ga., gained a berth in the final of the Everglades Club mixed foursomes golf tournament today with a 6-and-5 victory over Edean Anderson of Helena, Mont., and Art Ruffin, of Wilson, N. C.
City College's basketball team staged a second-half surge last night to defeat Ithaca College, 79 to 70, in the Beavers' main gymnasium.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Congressional committees were told by the Federal Court of Appeals today that they should not attempt to punish witnesses for contempt in refusing to answer questions unless the queries were pertinent to the matter under investigation.

BOSTON, Feb. 12 -- A New York syndicate headed by Roger L. Stevens signed an agreement today to buy the 28-acre Boston and Albany Railroad yards in the Back Bay for $4,500,000. Although asserting that plans were in a tentative stage, Mr. Stevens said that he envisioned a $75,000,000 development similar to Rockefeller Center in New York.

TOPEKA, Kan., Feb. 12 (UP) -- Republican National Chairman C. W. Roberts received $11,000 from an insurance company in connection with a $110,000 hospital sale to the state of Kansas in 1951, although he was not a state-registered lobbyist, State Insurance Commissioner Frank Sullivan said today.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 12 -- Paul A. Walker, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, urged leaders in the field of education tonight to mobilize behind the movement to build noncommercial educational television stations and thereby save the 242 channels reserved for this purpose "from being lost by default."

The season's second Town Hall performance by the Concert Choir and Orchestra, Margaret Hillis conducting, began last night with the Mozart Requiem. The soloists in the work were Suzanne der Derian, soprano; Charlotte Boehm, contralto; Simon George, tenor, and Eugene Brice, bass.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 12 -- The Budd Company reported today net profits of $9,190,618, or $2.42 a common share, on gross sales of $297,363,844 in 1952, compared with earnings of $12,482,613, or $3.34 a share, on sales of $317,664,486 a year before.

Michael J. Quill resumed yesterday his transit war of nerves after only two weeks of peace. The aggressive president of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., demanded that the Board of Transportation reopen at once its memorandum of understanding with the union, covering 45,000 city subway, bus, trolley and elevated employes, even though the agreement does not expire until next Dec. 31.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The State Department warmly praised its "two great friends," Britain and Egypt, today for settling their dispute on the future of the Anglo-Egyptian Sudan.

LONDON, Feb. 12 -- The agreement ending the condominium under which Britain and Egypt have jointly ruled the million square-mile Sudan for fifty-four years was termed today by Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden in the House of Commons "a reasonable settlement of this question which has for long bedeviled our relations with Egypt."

RALEIGH, N. C., Feb. 12 (AP) -- A veteran railroader, L. P. Kennedy of Raleigh, took over the controls of the Norfolk Southern Railway today in a sweeping reorganization which bounced Joseph T. Kingsley out of his job as president.
Spring fashions from American designer collections were presented yesterday by De Pinna in the Plaza Hotel's Terrace Room. Included were the newest trends in fabrics and silhouette for all occasions.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 12 -- The Foreign Ministry charged tonight that the Soviet Union's breaking off of diplomatic relations with Israel was the official culmination of a long Soviet bloc campaign of virulent slander and outspoken hostility against Israel, the Zionist movement and "Jews as such."

A photographer at Gettysburg, Pa., on Nov. 19, 1863, lost the supreme opportunity of his career: he did not have his camera ready when Abraham Lincoln got up to make "a few appropriate remarks." The remarks were indeed, as has since been realized, appropriate, but they were also few.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- In the second sweeping decontrol order by the Office of Price Stabilization within a week the Government today removed price ceilings on poultry, eggs and allied products, soaps, cleansers, detergents, tires and tubes, gasoline and all other petroleum products except home heating oils.

The publication of a letter from the retiring American Ambassador to Ethiopia advising the United States to be prepared to occupy the southern half of Iran if the Russians moved into the north naturally caused something of a sensation in Teheran. The excitement seems to have died down when the American Embassy assured the Iranians that this was the view of a private citizen and had no official significance whatever.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, affirmed tonight his renewed faith in the advance of West European integration, but he called again for even swifter progress toward a "constructive program of unity" that would justify continued United States help and cooperation.

GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 12 -- The National Council of Protestant Episcopal Churches of the United States closed a three-day meeting at its Seabury House headquarters here today with the adoption of the largest budget in the church's history, $5,546,566.

A housewife of average height, 5 feet 4 inches, can avoid the worst of the stretching and bending necessary to pull out her pots and pans if her kitchen cupboard space is placed no higher than her height or lower than 20 inches from the floor.

Songs and chamber music were featured on the program of the WNYC American Music Festival last night in the Carl Fisher Concert Hall. Helen Boatright, an intelligent soprano with a fine voice, sang two groups of songs. The composers represented were Lukas Foss, John Edmunds, Douglas Moore, William Bergsma, Norman Dello Joio, Isadore Freed and John Duke.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- An appeal to two Congressional committees to weigh further their plans to continue investigations into Communist infiltration into the country's educational system was made in the House of Representatives today by Representative Chet Holifield, Democrat of California.

Iceberg lettuce is the best quality salad green in the market today. Coming from the big producing centers of California, Arizona and Texas, the heads are green, solid and crisp. The price range, the consumers' service division of the City Department of Markets reports, is 15 to 25 cents a head, with the prevailing cost about 19 cents.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The United States joined eight Western European nations today in a dramatic airlift of millions of bags to Britain, to be filled with sand and thrown against flooding seas that may cause havoc when the new spring tide begins to rise through breached sea walls next week-end.

ALBANY, Feb. 12 -- Carrying out a recommendation of a New York County grand jury, the Democratic minority leaders of the Legislature introduced bills today to make it mandatory for the Board of Transportation in New York to seek competitive bids on all purchases of materials over $2,500.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- A movement was growing in Congress today to have Gen. James A. Van Fleet, the retiring United Nations ground forces commander in Korea, appear before at least four Congressional committees in a search for some new formula for the conduct of the Korean war.

BOSTON, Feb. 12 (UP) -- Fifteen fighting Bruins, led by Fleming Mackell, overpowered league-leading Detroit, 3 -- 1, at the Boston Garden tonight to move into a fourth - place tie with Toronto in the National Hockey League.

With business prospects continuing favorable, nearly two-thirds of 187 companies surveyed by the National Industrial Conference Board expected sales gains in the first half of this year, the board reported yesterday. The increase will reflect a rise in volume rather than price advances.
It was with profound shock and dismay that I read Judge Valente's order excluding the press from the courtroom for the duration of the People's case against Jelke.

About 1,200 persons connected with the Metropolitan Opera, the music world, the theatre and other phases of entertainment attended yesterday the dress rehearsal of Igor Stravinsky's opera, "The Rake's Progress," which will have its American premiere at the Metropolitan tomorrow afternoon.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 12 -- Three dimensional films will bring back the intermission to motion picture theatres. This was made clear today by the Motion Picture Research Council, Inc., which has drawn up a set of recommendations for the guidance of exhibitors in showing stereoscopic movies that require audiences to wear polarizing viewers.

Robert F. Wagner Jr., Borough President of Manhattan, urged Governor Dewey last night to recommend the abolition of all state aid to localities and to give back to this city and other communities the taxing powers that now support state assistance.

COLLECTIONS of magazine and newspaper essays and reviews, since they usually consist of quite unrelated pieces written over a substantial period of years, are linked together only by the personality and point of view of their authors. If these are attractive and stimulating such collections can be very good reading indeed. An example is "The Singular Preference: Por traits and Essays"* by Peter Quennell, which is published today.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 12 -- Rules governing the new free market in foreign exchange allow full freedom in the "over the counter" type of transaction that interests tourists and other foreign visitors. The final draft of the regulations was sent to President Vargas last night for his approval.

Mourners at three cemeteries were forced yesterday to trundle or carry the coffins of eleven persons to graves the mourners had dug, as union hearse and limousine drivers refused to cross picket lines of striking grave diggers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Experts on the Soviet Union here were ready for the Moscow Government's diplomatic break with Israel almost before the dust had settled from the bombing of the Soviet Legation in Tel Aviv Monday night.

According to the Incodel plan of the Interstate Commission on the Delaware River, New York City and northeast New Jersey would be permitted to draw from the Delaware River Basin 440 million gallons of water a day. By 1980, and certainly not later than 2000, the metropolitan district, which includes northern New Jersey, will need an additional 930 million gallons a day.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 12 -- The International Brotherhood of Teamsters, the largest and most powerful union in the American Federation of Labor, volunteered its help today in the drive to oust racketeers from control of the New York waterfront.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- President Eisenhower solemnly marched up the steps of the temple-like memorial on the Potomac today and paid a silent tribute to Abraham Lincoln.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development announced a $30,000,000 equivalent loan to Yugoslavia today. The non-dollar loan will be advanced in ten foreign currencies to help finance completion of industrial projects expected to increase production 30 per cent by 1955 and improve the country's balance of payments position by $50,000,000.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Feb. 12 -- A strike of 1,200 employes that has held up defense work at two engine division plants of the Fairchild Engine and Aircraft Corporation for twenty-four days ended tonight when 1,100 members of Local 661, United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., voted approval of a new contract.

HONG KONG, Feb. 12 -- Alleged United States plans to extend the Korean war and "harassing raids" by Chinese Nationalist commandos have been listed by the Chinese Communists among factors responsible for a transportation shortage causing many Shanghai residents to forego Chinese New Year visits to their native villages.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 12 -- The Hollywood American Federation of Labor Film Council called tonight on the Federal Government to investigate the filming in Silver City, N. M., of a feature-length motion picture by a group of persons who the council named as Communists at Congressional committee hearings.

ROME, Feb. 12 -- Widespread apprehension for the health of Pope Pius was somewhat calmed today by an official statement in the Vatican newspaper L'Osservatore Romano that he "entered into full convalescence some days ago." It added, however, that he still was weak and that his physician continues to visit him twice daily.

New York turned back Fairfield, 12--7, and Manhattan defeated the Turtles, 12 to 5, in first-round matches in the annual George C. Sherman Memorial indoor polo tournament at the Squadron A Armory last night.

ALTHOUGH a number of sportsmen's groups are carrying on winter feeding programs to insure a better survival rate of upland game birds, some have switched to food-cover plantings and report much better results with greater economy and less effort.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Friday, Feb. 13 (AP) -- Two New Jersey State Troopers, who came here two months ago to take Harold J. Adonis back to the United States, are heading for home tonight without him.

Many of the disorders that have broken out in twenty-three penal institutions across the country can be traced to a "new type" of lawbreaker -- a youthful and notably vicious offender who is the product of the war years.

VIENNA, Feb. 12 (AP) -- A military court in Communist Rumania tonight found twenty-three Rumanian oil experts and an ex-Cabinet Minister guilty of slowing down production consigned to the Soviet Union. The formal charges were high treason and spying for the Western powers.

A solution of the present Broadway booking jam, caused by the shortage of playhouses, seems to be at hand. The possibility became apparent yesterday with the official disclosure that the Longacre, 220 West Forty-eighth Street, and the Avon, 251 West Forty-fifth Street, former legitimate houses utilized by WOR and the Columbia Broadcasting System, respectively, were to be released for other purposes.
A 45-year-old insurance broker who a successfully routed a burglar from his Brooklyn home last night found himself arrested for his part in the affair.

GENEVA, Feb. 12 -- Unless some new last-minute instructions are received by a United States delegation here, the United States Government is likely to have to bear the responsibility for blocking Japan's early accession to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

Eastman, Dillon Co. and associates will offer today $12,500,000 of twenty-year 4 per cent sinking fund debentures of Food Fair Stores, Inc., due Feb. 1, 1973. They are priced at par and accrued interest from Feb. 1, 1953.
PARIS, Feb. 12 -- The drafters of a European constitution reached agreement today on a proposal under which members of the projected European union would remove all economic barriers among them.

Emnauel H. Bloch, attorney for Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, who are slated to be executed for their betrayal of atomic secrets to Russia, promised yesterday that there would be "plenty of struggle yet" before the convicted couple paid the death penalty.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Senator Robert C. Hendrickson, Republican of New Jersey, said today that a report on a Senate committee investigation of the Claremont Terminal on the Jersey City waterfront would be issued by Senator Lyndon B. Johnson, Democrat of Texas, former chairman of the preparedness committee.

The Electric Bond and Share Company announced yesterday that it has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission the amendments which the Commission had required as a condition to approving Bond and Share's plan for compliance with the Holding Company Act. Bond and Share said that it had requested the Commission to apply to a Federal Court for approval and enforcement of the amended plan.
LONDON, Feb. 12 (Reuters) -- Eight European nations promised today to rush nearly 6,000,000 sandbags to Britain to help army workers shore up sea walls against a new North Sea invasion threat.

DOBBS FERRY, N. Y., Feb. 12 -- Seeking a method of harmonizing the Children's Village, a philanthropic institution here for unadjusted boys, with the near-by residential neighborhoods, the state Department of Welfare is making a study of the institution's program, Frederick W. Ecker, board president of the village, said today.

The number of teen-age users of narcotics last year dropped slightly below the peak year of 1951, but addiction among youngsters remains a serious problem, it was reported yesterday by the Welfare and Health Council's Committee on the Use of Narcotics Among Teen-Age Youth.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- The Interior Department reported today that crops produced on land irrigated by Federal water projects reached a record value of more than $821,000,000 for the fiscal year ended last June 30.
Stanley A. Corfman has been appointed president of Carbide and Carbon Realty Company, a division of the Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation.

A thorny problem will be handed to the International Air Transport Association next week when Pan American World Airways seek a sharp reduction in air cargo rates and a simplification of commodity categories for airlines flying the North Atlantic.

New York can be proud of its over-all system of health services for mothers and children, but contrasts in health conditions between areas within the city are in some ways almost as striking as those between different sections of the country, Dr. Leone Baumgartner said recently.

DAVOS, Switzerland, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Tenley Albright, 17-year-old Boston girl, will carry America's main hopes when twenty-two from nine nations take the ice tomorrow to compete for the women's world figure skating championship.

George F. Cranmore, 36-year-old assistant director of Region 9 of the United Automobile Workers Union, C. I. O., was killed early yesterday morning when his car skidded on wet pavement and crashed into the rear of a truck on Queens Boulevard.

" O Rugged Land of Gold," a first book by Martha Martin, will be published on March 3 by Macmillan. It is an account of the author's experiences during an Alaskan winter. With her husband off to catch the mailboat, the author was caught in a landslide and badly injured (a broken arm and a useless leg).

CHICAGO, Feb. 12 -- Chuck Davey was nursing his battle wounds today, after being knocked out in ten rounds of his welterweight title bid last night against Champion Kid Gavilan, richer in pocket, wiser in experience and disillusioned in spirit.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The Navy's system of promotion for the higher grades was attacked today by Representative Sidney R. Yates, Democrat of Illinois, as antiquated, unfair and a product of "convoy mentality." In a House speech Mr. Yates urged changes in the law to give civilian officials greater control over the promotion decisions of admirals.

HONOLULU, Feb. 12 -- General Van Fleet said today that launching a winning offensive in Korea depended "on a number of variable factors and circumstances." He added that he never had stated flatly that the United Nations Command could stage a winning offensive with the forces it now had.

SEOUL, Korea, Feb. 12 -- The United States Fortieth Infantry Division, formerly of the California National Guard, reported yesterday that the last original member of the group that came to Korea in 1951 was on his way home.

LONDON, Feb. 12 -- Industrial and South African gold mining shares provided the highlights in a generally firm stock market today. Buying was still moderate, but, with little stock available, some prices rose rather sharply.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 12 (AP) -- President Juan Peron extended an olive branch to the Eisenhower Administration last night and implied Argentina's anti-Yankee campaign was called off with the change of Government in Washington.
NEWARK, Feb. 12 (AP) -- The New Jersey Bell Telephone Company reported today an increase in 1952 business and net income, but a drop in its return on investment.

MIAMI, Feb. 12 -- For non-workers, this was a day for things like sipping sarsparilla while lolling alongside a swimming pool, or sitting under a palm free with Shakespeare's sonnets in hand. It was, for a change, a blazing hot day.

In rejecting the Rosenberg appeal for executive clemency President Eisenhower put the case squarely on its merits and in a way designed to increase public confidence in him. His emphasis upon the fact that we live under a government of law is salutary in a case such as this when pressure groups have tried to put us under government by slogan.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., Feb. 12 -- It was bankers and brokers' day for dinghy racing at the Larchmont Yacht Club, They observed the holiday and went winter sailing under none too favorable conditions.

Today's new film is "Paolo and Francesca," an Italian-made drama of the Renaissance based on part of Dante's "Divine Comedy," at the Cinema Verdi. Armando Francioli, Andrea Checchi and Odile Versois are featured in the Lux Film, which was written by Vittorio Novarese and Vittorio Montuori, directed by Raffaello Matarazzo and produced by Valentino Brosio.
MOSCOW, Feb. 12 (UP) -- Anti-Zionist feeling appeared to mount today as news of the bombing in Tel Aviv and the rupture in relations with Israel became common knowledge.

BORDEAUX, France, Friday, Feb. 13 (AP) -- Two former sergeants in Hitler's Elite Guard (SS) Das Reich Division, one French and the other German, were sentenced to death today for the massacre in June, 1944, of 642 persons at Ora-dour-sur-Glane, near here.
TOKYO, Friday, Feb. 13 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,524, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Friday, Korean time:

MOSCOW, Feb. 12 -- M. K. Kortnev walked into the grounds of Moscow's fire engine factory and blandly drove a shiny new red fire truck off to the suburban town of Babushkin, where he parked it in his backyard for months without any questions being asked, either by neighbors or by the directors of the factory, Pravda revealed today.
Roland La Starza of the Bronx and Rex Layne of Lewiston, Utah, high-ranking heavyweights, will provide the action in the feature ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The Democrats who controlled the Federal Government for twenty years charged today that the new Republican Administration already had changed the rules on politicking -- at added cost to the taxpayers.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 12 (UP) -- The accolades for his 1952 riding performances went to Eddie Arcaro today as he received the George Woolf Memorial Award at Santa Anita, but a parade of long shots kept him from getting a winner.

Record sales of $712,655,143 were made last year by the F. W. Woolworth Company's chain of 1,960 stores in the United States, Canada and Cuba. Earnings, however, were slightly less than for 1951 as a result of higher operating costs.

Secretary of Labor Durkin is reported to be eager to have the conciliation functions which are now performed by the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service restored to his department. The Conciliation Service, as it was formerly known, was taken out of the Labor Department by the Taft-Hartley Act in 1947.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 12 -- The Dominican Republic said tonight that "several countries" would ask the United Nations General Assembly to open formal debate on the Soviet Union's anti-Zionist campaign.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 12 (UP) -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek said in a wireless interview today that his forces could invade Red China whenever they chose, without sanction of the United Nations and with no fear of Soviet intervention.
TOULON, France, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Seven men, including two Americans, were acquitted today by the correctional tribunal of charges of smuggling United States cigarettes into France.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of Brooklyn, said today he had reintroduced his bill to establish a commission on the legal status of women in the United States for the purpose of removing remaining discriminations.
No good, and perhaps a great deal of harm, must be expected to follow the break in diplomatic relations between Moscow and Tel Aviv.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Art is changing with the politics in Washington. There were new faces on the walls of the Cabinet room of the White House today, and as might be expected they are faces that have a little stronger appeal to Republicans than the ones they replaced.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Feb. 12 -- Belgium is pushing legislative procedure for the ratification of the European Defense Community Treaty without waiting for action by other countries, an official spokesman said here today.

A 34-year-old admitted bookmaker and loan shark, one of six men on trial in Kings County Court on charges of taking part in the alleged payroll-padding of the Atlantic Stevedoring Company of Brooklyn, turned state's witness yesterday.

BOSTON, Feb. 11 -- Sinclair Weeks, Secretary of Commerce, declared tonight that the "Washington mess is worse than the public thought," but that the new Administration had the backbone to clean it up.

CAIRO, Feb. 12 -- An agreement providing for the immediate introduction of self-government in the Anglo-Egyptian Sudan and for the exercise of self-determination by the Sudanese people was signed here this morning by Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib, Premier of Egypt, and British Ambassador Sir Ralph Stevenson.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Feb. 12 -- Marking a new departure in Scandinavian relations, the first conference of the Nordic Council will open in Copenhagen tomorrow with a solemn plenary meeting at which King Frederik IX of Denmark will welcome parliamentary delegations from Denmark, Norway, Sweden and Iceland headed by the Premiers and Foreign Ministers of each country.

America's "unilateralism" in dealing with its allies was sharply criticized yesterday by Stringfellow Barr, president of the Foundation for World Government. He addressed the opening session of the sixth annual Institute of the United Nations at New York University.
A full-scale investigation into "mismanagement and subversion" of the Voice of America will be brought into the open next week at televised hearings in the United States Court House, Foley Square.

A convincing 68-55 victory over New York University was Manhattan College's contribution to the basketball double - header at Madison Square Garden last night. The top local quintet streaked past the Violets for the fifth season in a row, after which St. John's had its hands full edging Westminster, 69 -- 68, before 9,142 fans.

The Yankees, still lagging in the contract-signing derby, corralled their nineteenth player yesterday in the person of Jim McDonald, 25-year-old right-handed pitcher. McDonald won three games and lost four last year and had an earned-run mark of 3.52.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- President Eisenhower announced today something unheard of in the modern annals of the White House. He is going to have all Democratic members of Congress for luncheon sometime or other, along with all the Republicans.

Beginning Monday and continuing during the week, enumerators from the United States Census Bureau will visit some families here and others in northeast New Jersey for information for the monthly population survey, it was announced yesterday.

Counsel to two Senate committees asserted yesterday in a defense of Congressional investigations into organized subversion that the number of infringements of individual civil liberties had been minimal.

CASEY STENGEL tells the story of the rookie ballplayer who spent weary years working his way up the minor league ladder to the majors. But on the very day he reported, another rookie ballplayer rolled majestically into camp, a collegian who had been paid a fat bonus for signing.

The atom smasher or particle accelerator has become a considerable commercial insurance risk. The National Board of Fire Underwriters recognized this some time ago and appointed a committee under the chairmanship of W. H. Forristall of Factory Insurance Associates of Hartford, Conn., to study the problem.
Memorial wreaths were laid at the foot of the Abraham Lincoln statue in Union Square by three patriotic organizations yesterday to mark the 144th anniversary of the birth of the Great Emancipator.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Democratic members of Congress denounced today the speech Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, made in St. Paul yesterday in which he advocated using price supports as "disaster insurance" and not to encourage "uneconomic production."
BOSTON, Feb. 12 -- The Massachusetts Investors Trust signalized today the attainment of its 100,000th shareholder by presenting the certificate of ownership at a luncheon in the Boston offices.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, Feb. 12 -- Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan announced in Parliament today that elections would be held April 15. They will provide a test of the Government's racial policies.

Heavy snow fell in the Northeastern ski country yesterday and indications are that, with the exception of the Pennsylvania Poconos and nearby Hudson Highlands, good skiing will be available this week-end. The continued fall of snow and the forecast of seasonably cold weather the next few days means that firm bases and depths will be the rule for the Washington holiday program, too.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 12 (AP) -- A story of terror aboard the freighter Fairhope -- fighting, disappearance and presumed murder of the chief steward, suspicion, and eventual grounding in Mexican waters -- came from the ship's skipper last night.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 12 -- Walter E. Hoadley, economist of the Armstrong Cork Company, told today's annual meeting of Group Two, Pennsylvania Bankers Association, that business men should be prepared for lower prices, a buyers' market and new demands for higher wages.

Hailing the induction of President Eisenhower as "a new emancipation of the deepest world significance," Governor Dewey declared last night that Secretary of State John Foster Dulles on his recent trip had given "a great lift" toward a united Western Europe, which he said would be the greatest force for world peace.

ALBANY, Feb. 12 -- Man-made procedures for coaxing rain from the clouds may become potent weapons against costly electrical storms that menace the northwest, Vincent J. Schaefer, a rainmaker, said today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (UP) -- The Treasury told holders of a small bloc of Government bonds today they must turn them in by June 15. But it announced it will not call on the same date four other bond issues worth almost $16,500,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- President Eisenhower was urged by the Congress of Industrial Organizations today to reject a recommendation by the Tariff Commission for higher duties on imported briar pipes because the increase "would do great harm to the international commitments and prestige of the United States."

Members of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union, independent, returned to work last night after they had ratified unanimously an agreement ending their fourteen-day strike against suburban wholesale delivery concerns.

Dense fogs, which blanketed Long Island several days last month, shrouding railroad signals and stations, and requiring trains to crawl, were responsible for many of the delays on the Long Island Rail Road in January, the railroad reported yesterday.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Feb. 12 (UP) -- Walter Burkemo of Franklin, Mich., carved nine strokes from par today in the opening round of the $10,000 Texas Open Golf tournament but it still left him with only a stroke lead.

ALBANY, Feb. 12 -- Less than twenty-four hours after Mayor Impellitteri and other members of the Board of Estimate made their final pleas for $62,800,000 more in state aid for New York City, the Assembly Ways and Means Committee reported out today without change Governor Dewey's $1,072,484,440 budget.

None of the novelties that Rudolf Bing has put on at the Metropolitan this season has caused such quivers of excitement as the one scheduled for tomorrow afternoon: the American premiere of Igor Stravinsky's opera, "The Rake's Progress," with libretto by W. H. Auden and Chester Kallman.
BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Feb. 12 -- Harold Jones, 14, of Salisbury, Conn., won the New York State junior ski jumping championship today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 12 -- Official sources assert that in the future greater stress will be laid in this country on legal processes and that hereafter many of the problems that were settled administratively will be turned over to the courts.

Apparently inspired by the tactical success of the platoon system used in football, a three-platoon sales force has been formed by the Ideal Toy Corporation, one of the largest toy producers in the country. Herbert Sand, general sales manager, said yesterday that the program has been evolved from a merchandising set-up which Ideal has been developing five years.
The ease with which Manhattan's rapid transit lines absorbed the extra passengers in the recent bus strike proves that in a crowded city nothing moves people around like the rails.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 12 -- German hopes that the Eisenhower Administration intended to repudiate the Potsdam protocol on Germany's temporary frontiers were squelched today by Dr. James B. Conant, United States High Commissioner.

As the anniversary of the birth of Abraham Lincoln was celebrated yesterday sharp words flew North and South again, raising once more the old, unlaid ghost of racial equality that so plagued the Great Emancipator.

TOKYO, Friday, Feb. 13 -- United Nations bombers, flying through heavy clouds, continued yesterday to smash at enemy supply areas and communications lines behind the western front in Korea. On the ground, although the fighting generally was limited to patrol actions, Allied infantry and artillery smashed one Communist hill position in a hit-and-run raid typical of recent operations against the deeply entrenched Chinese-North Korean Reds' line.

LONDON, Feb. 12 -- The French Premier Rene Mayer and a delegation of ministers in his Government came here today to try to find out how much further Britain is prepared to go in supporting the European Defense Community and relieving France of some of her economic problems stemming from Britain's drastic restrictions on imports.
With a strong British entry competing for the first time in recent years, the amateur racquets championship of the United States began yesterday at the Racquet and Tennis Club on Park Avenue.

CHICAGO, Feb. 12 (UP) -- Dick Gamble scored two goals tonight as the Montreal Canadiens beat the Chicago Black Hawks, 3 to 2, for the sixth time this season to gain a full game on the league-leading Detroit Red Wings.

An evening of almost subdued enchantment was spread out before the subscribers of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall last night. The composers were Mozart and Dvorak, and there was nothing high-pressure in their song, not even in Dvorak's G major Symphony at its most turbulent, for its country freshness keeps it on a modest, human-scale.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- The Great White Fathers in Washington today sent word to the worried Sioux Indians that they could not return Sitting Bull's skull.

United States Senator Herbert H. Lehman and Richard H. Balch, Democratic State Chairman, favor passage of the Cook-Ostrander resolution for an amendment to the State Constitution to bar construction of the $6,000,000 Panther Mountain Dam and all other river regulating projects in the Adirondack Forest Preserve. Announcement of their position was made by Herman Forster, president of the Adirondack Moose River Committee.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Harmar D. Denny of Pittsburgh, an Air Force officer in both World Wars and a member of the House of Representatives from 1951 to 1953, was reported today to be slated for appointment to the Civil Aeronautics Board, giving the Republicans a 3 to 2 edge on this agency for the first time since its creation.

TROY, N. Y., Feb. 13 (AP) -- Justice Donald S. Taylor directed the New York City Board of Education today to postpone department trials scheduled next Wednesday for four teachers suspended for refusing to answer questions about possible Communist party membership.

LONDON, Feb. 13 -- Prof. Herbert Dingle, president of the Royal Astronomical Society, castigated the new British astrophysical theory of "continuous creation" at a lively meeting of the society tonight.
Adlai E. Stevenson, former Governor of Illinois and Democratic nominee for President last year, announced yesterday plans for his forthcoming trip around the world.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- A Congressional barrage of criticism against Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson continued into its second day today with Southern Democratic Senators firing on the farm policies outlined in the Secretary's speech at St. Paul, Minn., on Wednesday night.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 13 -- Ernest Hemingway's novel, "The Old Man and the Sea," will be filmed independently under a partnership arrangement involving Leland Hayward, theatrical producer, Spencer Tracy and the author if current negotiations are concluded successfully.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (UP) -- Senator Edwin C. Johnson warned baseball's leaders today that Congress would not permit them to "destroy" minor league clubs by nation-wide television broadcasts of the big league's games.
LONDON, Feb. 13 -- Tired, muddy troops manned the outworks of the eastern frontier tonight, on guard against the sea, Britain's oldest ally now turned enemy. Their ammunition was sandbags.

Although an encouraging number of individual specialists in the field of parent-child relations is striving for an understanding of the needs of parents as well as of children, too many still indulge in "mother-blaming" when a youngster shows signs of any difficulty, Jane Loevinger, research assistant in medical psychology at Washington University, St. Louis, said recently.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- The Government is considering legal moves to block, at least temporarily, the commercial sale of plastic body armor used by combat troops in Korea.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) -- Donold B. Lourie was approved by the Senate today to be Under Secretary of State for Administration. A resident of Illinois, Mr. Lourie resigned as president of the Quaker Oats Company to take the Government job.

LONDON, Feb. 13 -- The stock markets ended the week on a confident note today. Early profit-taking was well absorbed and in the afternoon prices resumed their advance with home issues again in the lead. Industrials and gold shares were most in demand.

The flood disaster in Britain and Western Europe has created a sudden demand for one commodity that is not ordinarily associated with emergency relief -- namely, sandbags. The situation is most acute on the east coast of England, where nothing but the swift restoration of sea walls may prevent inundations from the high tides of the next few days.

The New York Teachers Union, which has come under frequent fire for alleged Communist domination, announced yesterday it was severing affiliation with its parent organization, the left-wing United Public Workers, and would continue as an independent local.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Feb. 13 -- The house where Tom Thumb, the famous circus midget of the last century and his wife lived for twenty years has been bought by a real estate developer who intends to demolish it. The new owner, William H. Hogan, said today he planned to build an office building on the site, near the corner of Main Street and North Avenue.

The sixty-sixth annual observance of a World Day of Prayer will be conducted next Friday by Protestants. The observance will start at dawn in the Fiji Islands and New Zealand, west of the date line, and will encircle the globe, ending at dusk with services in Alaska and on the Tonga Islands.

Though 1953 is only six weeks old, the problem of inadequate coal supplies has already emerged as this year's most dangerous bottleneck impeding the realization of satellite Eastern Europe's plans to build up military economic strength.

General Bridgeford, retiring commander of the British Commonwealth forces in Korea, took the occasion of the change in command to announce that South Koreans are being integrated into the First Commonwealth Division. They will go into the rifle companies of the Commonwealth troops at the rate of about 100 to the battalion, and a total of about 1,000 Koreans will be so deployed.

CROTON-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., Feb. 13 -- A pattern for preserving historic structures on a basis making them self-sustaining in perpetuity is being drafted in an attempt to save the 300-year-old Van Cortlandt manor house on the Albany Post Road.
A would-be convert to Episcopalianism who has been seeking out clergymen in Brooklyn in recent weeks was being sought yesterday -- not for a pew but a cell.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 13 (AP) -- Trainer Jimmy Jones, balking at the record 133-pound burden assigned to Mark-Ye-Well for tomorrow's $25,000 added San Antonio Handicap at Santa Anita, refused to enter him today.

MOSCOW, Feb. 13 -- Komsomolskaya Pravda told yesterday the story of a Moscow speculator who amassed a hoard of 3,000,000 rubles, took his fifth wife on swank tours of the Black Sea resorts and hoped for a return of capitalism when he might live "as the Morgans and Du Ponts live abroad."
Urging support of the building program of the Medical College of Yeshiva University, Mayor Impellitteri declared yesterday that New York had "a dearth of doctors in all boroughs."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Abba S. Eban, the Israeli Ambassador, called upon the United States and other free countries today to rally to the support of Israel as the sole defender of democracy in the Middle East.

Synthetic fibers are gaining a foothold in the work clothing field, it was observed yesterday. Two manufacturers of denim, the colored yarn cotton cloth that has been a mainstay for overalls, dungarees and work jackets, announced that they are offering these goods with nylon at a price of about 16 to 19 cents a yard more than the regular all-cotton cloth.

VIENNA, Feb. 13 -- Reports current since last fall about plans for coordination of oil production, distribution and consumption in the satellite countries, under Soviet auspices, were revived today by the Vienna newspaper Die Presse.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 13 (AP) -- Herbert Hoover left St. Francis Hospital today "feeling much better" and immediately went aboard a chartered yacht for two weeks of fishing in the Florida Keys. The former President, now 78 years old, was taken to the hospital Saturday with a mild case of influenza.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Perhaps Mother Goose should now be rewritten to combine Rockabye Baby and Hickory, Dickery, Dock. For Mack M. Pruett of Faye, Ky., patented this week a swing for infants that is operated by the pendulum of a large clock.

The two important events of the week did not occur in Europe, scene of Secretary of State Dulles' effort to invigorate and speed up Atlantic defense, or in Asia, focus of the hottest debate on policy at home and abroad. Moscow's diplomatic break with Israel and the Anglo-Egyptian accord on the future of the Sudan drew attention to a third battleground in the international struggle.

Twenty persons were assisted down aerial ladders last night when fire swept the upper three floors of a five-story East Bronx tenement. A 65-year-old woman suffering from smoke inhalation and a fireman who was gashed by flying glass were taken to Lincoln Hospital.

The waves of attacks on the public schools and ways to over-come them are discussed by thirty leaders in American education, government and community life in "Freedom and Public Education," which Frederick A. Praeger will publish on March 4.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- During the week ended Feb. 11, member bank reserves decreased $208,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

MIAMI, Feb. 13 -- When the owners of twenty-two horses put up $250 per horse to enter them in tomorrow's $25,000 added Everglades Stakes for 3-year-olds, Hialeah Race Course found itself faced with a little problem.

DAVOS, Switzerland, Feb. 13 (UP) -- Young Tenley Albright of Boston took a commanding lead in her quest for the women's world figure skating championship today by rallying after a stern rebuke stopped a dispute between two judges.

John R. Crews, Kings County Republican chairman, has recommended Walter Bruchhausen for appointment as United States district judge in the Eastern New York District to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Judge Harold M. Kennedy last October.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Department store sales in the United States during the week ended Feb. 7 were 1 per cent above sales in the same period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. Following is the Federal Reserve Board's weekly report on sales by Districts in terms of percentage changes from like periods of 1952:
TRUMBULL, Conn., Saturday, Feb. 14 -- A Connecticut state trooper was shot and fatally wounded at 9 o'clock last night by a speeding motorist he had stopped on the Merritt Parkway.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 13 -- The Federal Government forwarded the Israeli restitution agreement to the Bundesrat, the upper house of Parliament, today for ratification despite the Arab League's threat to organize an economic boycott of Western Germany.

This week the domestic scheduled airlines of the United States completed twelve full months of operation without a single passenger fatality. This record is especially impressive when the volume of traffic, and therefore the exposure to accident, is considered. The airlines involved flew in the period 13,150,000,000 revenue passenger miles with an average of a landing or take-off every seven seconds, or approximately 13,000 a day.

Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, declared yesterday that "there are some people in the Voice of America who are doing a rather effective job of sabotaging Dulles' and Eisenhower's foreign policy program."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Senator Wayne Morse, Independent of Oregon, denounced the Eisenhower Administration today as "a reactionary" one with "designs on the public welfare," and called on all declared liberals to fight it immediately.

CHICAGO, Feb. 13 -- Export buying and mill support reversed the early weak trend in prices on the Board of Trade today, the market showing a substantial recovery from the low spots. Export sales were light, but a substantial volume of wheat business with several countries is in negotiation.

TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 13 -- With scarcely a peep of protest from the press, one of the most stringent newspaper control laws in the world has come into effect in Iran. It was promulgated by Premier Mohammed Mossadegh under his plenary powers without reference to Parliament and became operative last Saturday.

Joseph M. Proskauer, chairman of the state Crime Commission, sailed with his wife aboard the Grace Liner Santa Paula yesterday for a twelve-day cruise to the Dutch West Indies, Venezuela and Colombia.

PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 13 -- Nine top Republican state leaders, four of them members of Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll's Cabinet, met tonight in an effort to agree on a candidate for Governor they could support unanimously.
MEXICO CITY, Feb. 13 -- The Civic League of Mexican Women has prepared a protest to President Adolfo Ruiz Cortines complaining that too many Mexican diplomats have foreign wives.

PARIS, Feb. 13 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, was reported today to have warned visiting officials of the fourteen North Atlantic Treaty Organization nations against any stretchout in Western defense preparations caused by a belief that new "unconventional" weapons might make security "cheaper."

Five employes of the Atlantic Stevedoring Company halted their trial abruptly yesterday in Kings County Court to plea guilty to taking part in a waterfront payroll-padding scheme and then promised to tell the rockets grand jury about "higher-ups" who profited from the fraud.

The Harry Levy Realty Company of Mount Vernon, agent for the Alanwood Center a retail shopping development projected on a three-block site at 99 Tarrytown Road, White Plains, N. Y., yesterday reported receipt of deposits on more than 60 per cent of the stores and offices that will comprise the shopping center.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 13 -- The womenfolk of the Soviet Legation shopped in downtown Tel Aviv today, buying perfumes, blouses, linens, food and candy prior to their departure following Moscow's rupture of diplomatic relations with Israel.

LONG BEACH, Calif., Feb. 13 (AP) -- Declaring that everyone in the crew's quarters appeared to be drunk the night the steward vanished, the navigator today blamed compass failure for the grounding off Mexico last Jan. 30 of the S. S. Fairhope.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Feb. 13 (AP) -- Walter Burkemo of Franklin, Mich., didn't yield an inch to pressure today and romped in with a six-under-par 65 to hold the lead at the halfway mark of the $10,000 Texas open golf tournament with a total of 127.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 13 -- The Government of Pakistan today said it "faces starvation and economic ruin by a process of slow strangulation at the hands of India."

The more than twenty major prison disturbances which have taken place during the past year in various parts of the country have focused attention upon the causes of these dramatic outbursts of violence. A survey made by this newspaper has called attention to such factors as overcrowding, poor food, incompetent personnel, idleness, brutality and politics as among the main agents making for these flare-ups.

At tremendous financial loss Charles E. Wilson is now our Secretary of Defense, a leading candidate for designation as one of our nation's most loyal and patriotic Americans of 1953. But the cost of his appointment, both to him personally and to the country, has received far less attention than it merits.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) -- The Navy is "both asking and urging" Capt Hyman G. Rickover to stay on his job of directing the building of the world's first atomic-powered submarines.

Senator McCarran predicted last December that the fight against the new McCarran-Walter Immigration Act would "be pushed vigorously after the new Congress convenes by the Communists and those who serve them" and others. President Eisenhower, who in his State of the Union message called the act unjust and discriminatory, is of course among the "others."
Sales of electricity and gas by the Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago in 1952 again reached new highs, Charles Y. Freeman, chairman, announced yesterday.
BERLIN, Feb. 13 -- The reorganization of East Berlin's city government along Communist lines was initiated today with the debut of the new "People's Assembly."
So much attention has been given to the drop in beef prices that a similar, though less marked, decline in lamb has gone almost unnoticed.
NAPLES, Italy, Feb. 13 (AP) -- Italy today ordered a Protestant American evangelist and his wife deported today.
NORFOLK, Va., Feb. 13 -- Norfolk's tugboat strike is no nearer an end today after another collapse of negotiations between the union and companies last night. Both sides held to previous proposals.
Stock prices yesterday staged their first upward movement in six days. The list advanced generally, with gains in almost all sections adding up to the widest upswing since Dec. 12.
MARION, Ohio, Feb. 13 (AP) -- Ohio-grown beef challenged the New Zealand product today in a state-wide price war.
Four exhibitions of paintings by European and American artists add to the lively variety of this week's art shows.

WASHINGTON, Ind., Feb. 13 (UP) -- Sidney Cecil Carnes, 43 years old, of Laredo, Tex., a movie and television director and writer and one of the five original members of the "Citizens for Eisenhower Committee," was killed in a traffic accident last night.

The Algonquin Gas Transmission Company obtained yesterday from the Appellate Division, Second Department, a temporary stay from an order by Supreme Court Justice Elbert T. Gallagher directing the company to remove two and one-half miles of new natural gas pipeline from private lands in Westchester County.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 13 -- The short lengths of wire with which bunches of carrots are tied have burgeoned into a farm labor issue with international ramifications.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Feb. 13 -- A $1,575,000 suit, one of the largest ever filed here, was docketed today by a young woman whose honeymoon ended with the death of her husband in a plane crash here on Feb. 11, 1952, the third of the three tragedies that followed closely upon one another. She also asked $160,000 for her own injuries.
Efforts to salvage a car float and a freight car lying in twenty-seven feet of water between South Ferry and Governors Island will be started Monday morning by Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation.

Prices were irregularly higher yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges with volume continuing light on most items. Activity in cocoa improved and potatoes, which have been active for four weeks, had the largest day's volume of the year.
Roland La Starza hammered his way back into the heavyweight title picture last night in Madison Square Garden with a slashing victory over the rotund Rex Layne of Lewiston, Utah.

PARIS, Feb. 13 -- The Soviet Union's break with Israel was seen in most leading French editorials as a preconceived move in Moscow's anti-Zionist policy for which the bombing of the Soviet Legation at Tel Aviv served as a convenient excuse.

The New York Legislature has been in session more than a month. Experience has taught us not to expect much in the way of public accomplishment in the initial period, and not much has been achieved. But now the pace will have to quicken greatly if the final accomplishments are to measure up to public wishes and the Legislature's responsibility.
BOSTON, Feb. 13 (AP) -- The Weather Bureau today issued the following forecasts and lists of winter sports conditions:

CINCINNATI, Feb. 13 -- The Rev. Dr. Gerald E. Knoff of Chicago was installed tonight as the executive secretary of the Division of Christian Education of the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A.

" The Sage of Monticello" and "Old Hickory" will be recalled at the Jefferson - Jackson Day dinner to be given tonight by the Democratic party in New York and at similar dinners elsewhere throughout the country.

PARIS, Feb. 13 -- The church bells of France's Germanic province of Alsace rang out tonight in protest against the conviction by a military tribunal in Bordeaux of thirteen Alsatians for participation in the destruction of the French village of Oradour-sur-Glane and the massacre of 642 of its inhabitants on June 10, 1944.
MIAMI, Feb. 13 (AP) -- New world records were set today by three outboard drivers and one inboard pilot in Biscayne Bay Regatta time trials over an inland waterway course.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Procurement controls on steel. copper and aluminum were relaxed by the Government today. The Office of Defense Mobilization announced that producers could supply civilian buyers on a free market basis after they had met defense demands.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (UP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson named a seven-man advisory committee today to study ways of "enlarging the foreign market" for American cotton to prevent surpluses.

The Transport Workers Union has a memorandum of understanding that continues its working arrangements with the city transit system throughout 1953. The city is carrying out this contract, with its forty-hour-week clause, at the cost of an annual operating deficit of about $41,000,000.

LONDON, Feb. 13 -- The French mission that came here hoping that John Foster Dulles, United States Secretary of State, had softened the way for it in overcoming British reluctance to join in uniting Europe against aggression, wound up its talks with British Government officials tonight with some grounds for satisfaction.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Feb. 13 -- King Frederick IX, with Queen Ingrid by his side, formally opened today the Nordic Council's first conference.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- The Apostolic Delegation here announced today that, at the request of the Holy See, it had transmitted to the Department of Justice in December the information that Pope Pius XII had received "numerous and urgent" appeals for his intervention in behalf of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, condemned atom spies.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Two of the eleven top Communists and Frank Costello, New York gambler, were denied paroles today by the United States Parole Board.

Stanley W. Pearson Jr., the defending titleholder, was eliminated from the national amateur racquets championship yesterday as three British players reached the semi-finals with Robert Grant 3d of New York.

PARIS, Feb. 13 -- After a period of relative lull the "cold war" is again focusing attention on the l Middle East. Moscow appears to have stepped up its new anti-Semitic campaign by breaking relations with Israel. It probably hopes thereby to gain favor with the Arab masses, resentful over the very existence of Israel.
With the signing yesterday of Dave Williams, second baseman, and Marvin Blaylock, rookie first baseman, thirty-five Giants are now under contract.

Men's wear retailers must find a way to increase profits through reduction of operating costs or better mark-ups, a panel of merchants agreed yesterday at the New Yorker Hotel. The panel held in conjunction with the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers, whose convention opens tomorrow, said greater profits could be obtained without taking advantage of the consumer.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (UP) -- Douglas McKay, Secretary of the Interior, banned today the award of Interior Department contracts for more than $10,000 without direct approval from his office.
The joint statement issued by the religious leaders who met yesterday at the Synod House of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine and the resolutions they adopted follows:

The Catholic Youth Organization pursued in 1952 a four-fold program designed to channel young persons' interests into constructive activities to combat delinquency, according to a report released yesterday by the agency at 122 East Twenty-second Street.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Feb. 13 -- The Amsterdam district court has advised the Ministry of Justice it does not consider Harold J. Adonis, former executive clerk to New Jersey's Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll, extraditable under treaties in force between the Netherlands and the United States, it was learned tonight.

A warning of political and social problems to come if Communist prisoners of war are later permitted to live in South Korea was voiced yesterday by Edgar Kennedy, refugee expert who recently returned from Korea.

FORT MEADE, Md., Feb. 13 (UP) -- Three top generals violated the Army censorship regulation under which Lieut. Col. Melvin B. Voorhees was brought to trial, Army officials disclosed today. A Defense Department information specialist identified the officers as Gen. Lucius D. Clay, Lieut. Gen. Edward C. Almond and Lieut. Gen. Robert L. Eichelberger.
SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Feb. 13 -- "Planetary waves" have been responsible for a series of mild Eastern winters, the tenth annual Eastern Snow Conference was told here today.

Supreme Court Justice Benjamin F. Schreiber reserved decision yesterday on a petition to lift the ban on attendance imposed on the press and the public by General Sessions Judge Francis L. Valente at the vice trial of Minot F. (Mickey) Jelke 3d.
PARIS, Feb. 13 -- Interesting detail and discreet suggestions of a lowered waistline mark Alex Maguy's suits and coats.

TOPEKA, Kan., Feb. 13 (AP) -- The Kansas Senate today refused an immediate inquiry into a deal in which Republican National Chairman C. W. Roberts collected an $11,000 fee for sale of a building to the state.

Representatives of a group of small export concerns seriously affected by the long delay in payments for goods shipped to Brazil will confer in Washington on Monday with officials of the State and Treasury departments, the Export-Import Bank and the Senate Small Business Committee, it was announced yesterday.

There were some new faces in the cast when the Metropolitan Opera offered the third performance of its new English version of "Boheme" last night. The romantic leads -- Lucine Amara as Mimi and Brian Sullivan as Rodolfo -- sang their "Boheme" roles for the first time in their Metropolitan careers.
MEXICO CITY, Feb. 13 -- William O'Dwyer, former Ambassador, announced today that he had become a Mexican immigrant and would live permanently in this country as "adviser" to a Mexican law firm.

Companies losing sales may be interested in an idea advanced recently by Charles W. Smith, associate manager of McKinsey Co., management consultants. Briefly, it is the market potential concept of selling.
A special three-man investigation committee, set up by the State Mediation Board, opened hearings yesterday on the issues in the strike by gravediggers against ten cemeteries.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday and closing prices for active months were 8 points net lower to 6 points higher than on Wednesday.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of use to homemakers:

The personal attack on me in Victor Lasky's recent letter is both inaccurate and misleading. He bases his attack on a letter to me by Harold Keele, whom Mr. Lasky referred to as a "Congressional spokesman." Actually, Mr. Keele wrote his letter on Jan. 10 and in it said that the life of the committee which had formerly employed him had terminated on Jan. 3.

ROME, Feb. 13 -- Pope Pius XII appealed to the United States Government for clemency in the Rosenberg atomic spy case, the Vatican newspaper L'Osservatore Romano revealed today. L'Osservatore was careful to point out that when it was a matter of saving human lives, the Pope never refused to intervene, "though without being able to enter into the merits of the case."
MOUNDSVILLE, W. Va., Feb. 13 -- Mrs. Eisenhower has made Paula just about the happiest girl in West Virginia.

Events today: Young people's Concert, Philharmonic - Symphony, Carnegie Hall, 11 A. M.; Boston Symphony, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P. M.; Jan Gorbaty, pianist, Town Hall, 3; WNYC American Music Festival, Brooklyn Academy, 3; WNYC American Music Festival, Juilliard School of Music, 4.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 13 (AP) -- The Brazilian yacht Cairu II won the Buenos Aires-to-Rio De Janeiro race tonight on a corrected time of 10 days 15 hours 4 minutes 36.5 seconds. An American entry, White Mist, piloted by George Blunt White of Mystic, Conn., crossed the finish line first.
Jersey City, N. J., yesterday announced that it will receive bids Feb. 26 on $6,304,000 of school and general improvement bonds dated March 1, 1953 and due March 1, 1954 to 1983.
DETROIT, Feb. 13 (AP) -- Automotive quarters here welcomed word today that allocation controls on steel, copper and aluminum had been relaxed.

An old brownstone dwelling that has been boarded up for almost twenty years will be modernized as a result of the sale of the former home of the late Supreme Court Justice Nathan Bijur at 122 East Sixtieth Street to Fred H. Hill, realty operator and president of the Hansair Realty Corporation.

Breaking the decline of three previous weeks, loans to business by New York banks rose $16,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday. The rise, which compares with a gain of $40,000,000 in the corresponding week a year ago, brought the decline since the start of 1953 to $154,000,000, against a reduction of $14,000,000 in the similar 1952 period.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- President Eisenhower today began a series of bipartisan luncheons designed eventually to bring every Democratic member of Congress to the White House to break Presidential bread. And, John W. McCormack of Massachusetts, the House minority leader, declared afterward he thought the luncheons would help the President's relations with Congress.

Sales of leading mail order and chain store companies during January showed an aggregate gain of 4.4 per cent over volume of the comparable month last year, according to a compilation of forty-four companies made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.
BONN, Germany, Feb. 13 -- The French protocols to the European Defense Community Treaty have discouraged friends of the pact and encouraged its foes in West Germany.

MADRID, Feb. 13 -- The Spanish Government has authorized United States oil interests to start drilling for oil early next month in an area thirty-two miles long and six miles wide in the Province of Navarro, United States business circles reported today.
The United States Gypsum Company and its subsidiaries had a net income of $19,031,216 in 1952, against $19,820,261 the year before, the annual report disclosed yesterday.

Federal Paper Board Company, Inc., announced yesterday that it has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 200,000 shares of outstanding shares of the company which are proposed to be sold by major stockholders.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Average primary market prices increased 0.3 per cent during the week ending Tuesday to 109.5 per cent of the 1947-49 average, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Farm products rase 1.4 per cent mainly because of higher prices for livestock, live poultry, fresh fruits and vegetables and eggs.

Nine Olympic champions and thirty other Olympians from the United States, Germany, Sweden, Turkey and Jamaica head a blue-ribbon entry for the Amateur Athletic Union's sixty-fifth national indoor track and field champion ships at Madison Square Garden tonight.

GENEVA, Feb. 13 -- Representatives of textile workers, employers and governments in twenty-two countries, attending the Textiles Committee of the International Labor Organization, declared today that international competition for textile markets "should not lead to a worsening of conditions of employment or a lowering of the standards of living" in the industry.
LONDON, Feb. 13 -- The House of Commons rejected today by 159 votes to 63 a private Member's bill to restore to judges discretionary power to order corporal punishment for crimes of violence.

Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman declared yesterday that both "the temper and the tempo" of harassment aimed at saving atomic spies Ethel and Julius Rosenberg from the death penalty had increased greatly since President Eisenhower refused them executive clemency last Wednesday.

MOSCOW, Saturday, Feb. 14 -- The death of Lev Zakharovich Mekhlis, the former Minister of State Control and for many years a leading member of the Government and an old comrade-at-arms of Premier Stalin, was anonunced in in a special broadcast by the Moscow radio early today.

LONDON, Feb. 13 -- The magnificent purple velvet robe that Queen Elizabeth II will wear from Westminster Abbey after the coronation is being embroidered at the Royal School of Needlework. This is the famous school founded by Princess Christian in 1872.

A report favorable to the application of the Bloomfield Steamship Company of Houston for an operating differential subsidy on two Gulf-Europe routes was submitted to the Federal Maritime Board yesterday by F. J. Horan, trial examiner, after a series of public hearings.

TRENTON, Feb. 13 -- In a further move to justify, his recent dismissal of former Deputy Attorney General Nelson F. Stamler for "insubordination." Attorney General Theodore D. Parsons made public today a report submitted to him six days ago by Deputy Attorney General Edward Gaulkin.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 13 -- A Yugoslav Government source disclosed today that the United States Mutual Security Agency was considering proposals for allocating funds to this country for a long-term investment in agriculture and industry as well as direct food and defense aid.

Llewellyn Watts Jr., president of the New York Mercantile Exchange, charged yesterday that Senator James E. Murray had attempted to excuse "disastrous" farm policies of the last Administration by blaming big business for their failure.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 13 -- Investigation by the United Nations General Assembly into the Communists' anti-Jewish drive has been urged by the International League for the Rights of Man.
MIAMI, Feb. 13 (UP) -- The qualifying round of the fourteenth annual baseball players' golf championship produced low and high rounds today.
NASSAU, Bahamas, Feb. 13 (AP) -- The yacht Galway Blazer, overdue on the Miami-to-Nassau race, was reported late today about 14 miles north of Rose Island, in the Bahamas group.

TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 13 -- An earthquake that caused a slight tremor in Teheran yesterday devastated the hill village of Turud, 250 miles east of the capital. Two-thirds of Turud's population of 1,500 was reported killed. No final and authentic count of the casualties had been received in Teheran this evening.

Legislation requiring that all merchant seamen aboard American-flag ships carrying passengers for hire must understand orders given in English has been introduced in Congress at the request of the Treasury Department.

TOKYO, Saturday, Feb. 14 -- The Communist Command in the Korean war charged late yesterday that United Nations patrols had twice this week invaded the neutral zone around the truce conference site at Panmunjom. The Communist called on the United Nations Command to declare whether or not the stalled armistice negotiations should formally be broken off.
Prices of domestic copper scrap advanced sharply yesterday as a result of the Washington order freeing it from price controls.

Nine-year-old Louise Santos yesterday proved herself a fit mother and won permanent custody of her doll, Nannette, which she had taken out on loan from the Police Athletic League's Moppet Mother Adoption Center at 974 East 156th Street, the Bronx.

Bird counters and skyscraper gardeners in this city reported yesterday that Nature's timetable was way off this year because the metropolis had had an open winter. Traces of snow at 4 P. M. didn't change the picture.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 13 -- A determined minority in the Brazilian Congress succeeded in adding today to the eleven-month delay in ratifying a military aid agreement with the United States when it managed to drag out debate until the chamber adjourned over the five-day carnival holiday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) -- The House of Representatives Armed Services Committee, duplicating action of its Senate counterpart, today in effect placed an indefinite freeze on construction of an Air Force bomber base at Plattsburg, N. Y.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- A bipartisan drive to abolish the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, billion-dollar. Government lending agency, was renewed in Congress today under the leadership of Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat of Virginia.
ALBANY, Feb. 13 (AP) -- The State Department of Commerce today listed the following winter sports conditions at New York resorts;

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- A letter from the wife of the President of the United States to a little girl in Moundsville, W. Va., was made public by the White House today after it had created much excitement in Moundsville.

In reporting to the nation on his trip to Europe Secretary Dulles performed a valuable service when he met head-on some of the European fears and misunderstandings of American leadership which have been at the bottom of most differences between us and our allies.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, was understood to have given assurances to a Senate subcommittee today that the United States had no intention of risking a split with its Allies over Korea.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 13 -- A minimum of 4 per cent of our national income should be spent for the support of the nation's public schools, Dr. Lawrence G. Derthick, Superintendent of Schools for Chattanooga, declared here today. This he added, would double the present amount.

Joining together "in a fine spirit of understanding and cooperation," leaders of the major religious groups here organized at a meeting yesterday an interfaith movement to quicken and sustain public morality in this city.
TOKYO Saturday, Feb. 14 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,525, covering Friday's activities:

" THE role of literature in human history is to lead and not to follow," the editors of "Discovery"* tell us in their preface to Vol. 1 No. 1 of a challenging new publishing venture. "As in the thirteen preceding volumes," the editor of "New Directions 14" tells us, "this year's New Directions Annual contains the fresh, the stimulating, the out-of-the-way in contemporary writing."

Herbert Benington has been appointed director of plant operations of the Simplicity Pattern Company, Inc., effective March 1. Robert M. Shapiro, former assistant sales director, has been named general sales director.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) -- The Texas Congressional delegation honored Senator Lyndon B. Johnson today as the youngest man ever elevated to a party leadership in the Senate. At 44 years and in his first term in the Senate, he took over the Democratic leadership with the opening of the present Congress on Jan. 3.

Ch. Rancho Dobe's Storm, the 38-month-old Doberman pinscher who gained a second successive best-in-show award at the Westminster Kennel Club event in Madison Square Garden Tuesday night, was retired from competition yesterday.
A major change in the building industry since the end of Word War II has been the "passing of seasonal business," in the opinion of Ernst Heumann, president of Trylon Realty of Forest Hills, Queens.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 13 -- The name of Shibe Park, home of the Athletics, will be changed to Connie Mack Stadium next spring in honor of the club's 90-year-old president and former manager.

ANOTHER effort to limit the striped bass fishing to hook and line in New York is now in the state legislative hopper. In view of the increased interest by sports groups and coastal resorts, anglers believe the new bill has an excellent chance of becoming a law.

FARGO, N. D., Feb. 13 (UP) -- Paul V. Keyser, general manager of domestic marketing for the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, said today he expected prices on gasoline to go up about 1 cent a gallon throughout the nation and crude oil prices to rise from 35 to 40 cents a barrel.

YOKOHAMA, Japan, Feb. 13 (AP) -- Survivors of four mysterious explosions at sea that blasted sheets of flame through the United States freighter President Pierce landed here today with tales of heroism, panic and a sailor's ordeal by fire and icy waves.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 13 -- Twenty United States citizens dismissed by the United Nations as a result of loyalty investigations, have filed formal requests for an airing of their cases before the Administrative Tribunal. The tribunal is an international panel that acts as a top court of appeals on staff matters.

" John Brown's Body," a dramatization by Charles Laughton of the poem by Stephen Vincent Benet about the Civil War years, will open at 8:30 this evening at the Century Theater under the sponsorship of Paul Gregory. Tyrone Power, Judith Anderson and Raymond Massey, who are co-starred, will do a series of characterizations in the production.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 13 -- Moshe Sharett, the Foreign Minister of Israel, explained today why in his opinion the Soviet Union had broken off diplomatic relations with Israel, why it had, five years ago, supported the creation of the new state and what he expected would be the consequences of the rupture.

The South African Parliament has passed the bill to strengthen the powers of the Malan Government against any disturbances by Africans, and as an expected accompaniment a general election has been called for April 15. This will be another "Black Peril" election, as the South Africans called two previous polls in 1929 and 1948 when the basic appeal was to unify the white voters against a real or imagined danger from the natives.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 13 -- The Locust Street subway, started in 1917 and long celebrated as Philadelphia's "hole in the ground," will open on Sunday, it was announced today at the tube's formal dedication.

Bond syndicates underwriting will be called on next week to price $65,000,000 of AA-rated bonds of New York public utility companies -- $40,000,000 of mortgage obligations of Consolidated Edison Company and $25,000,000 of mortgage bonds of Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation.

Several years ago as I was going down the Columbia River Highway I came to a large and impressive signboard, put up, I suppose, by the Federal Government. This, it said, was the Celilo Falls, secured to the Yakima tribe of Indians forever by treaty with the United States of America.
LONDON, Feb. 13 -- The Communist Government of Poland has issued a decree sharply limiting the right of the Roman Catholic Church to make its own appointments to high church offices.
