Glidden Company, maker of paints and food products, expects both sales and earnings in the fiscal year which ends Oct. 31, 1953, to show improvement over the previous twelve-month period, Adrian D. Joyce, chairman, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- The United States will rush to Britain as many as 200,000 sandbags in time for them to be filled and emplaced against the expected flood tides of Monday. The White House said the bags would be drawn from United States military stock in Germany.

NORWALK, Conn., Feb. 13 -- Mayor Irving C. Freese requested city court officials today to withdraw a breach-of-the-peace complaint against Hans P. Truenenfels who was arrested at a meeting of the Board of Education on Feb. 3. The complaint had been made by the Mayor.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 13 -- Asian and Arab members of the United Nations said today that the job of trying to bring peace to Korea must now be handled as part of the over-all Far Eastern situation.

I was surprised and puzzled to see that THE TIMES gave credit for the break on the Eisenhower-Formosa story to The Associated Press in your News of the Week in Review of Feb. 1, when actually the records show that this was an important "beat" by columnist Robert Allen.

Headed by the sharp-shooting Herb Pennell, the Farmington Polo Club upset the New York A. C., 14 to 4, in the Metropolitan League tournament match marking the weekly double-header at the Squadron A Armory last night.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 14 (UP) -- Pennsylvania fought off Army's fourth-period rally tonight to score a 77-65 victory before 3,277 fans at the Palestra.

The positive tribute to things cultural in the recent (Continued ]rom Preceding Page) TIMES' tercentenary supplement, "New York, 1653-1953" (Feb. 1), accentuates the incomparable progress made by the corporate city of New York over a span of three centuries.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Feb. 14 (AP) -- Manhattan barely got by Canisius, 52 -- 49, for its ninth straight victory, and Niagara clinched the western New York Little Three championship by trouncing St. Bunaventure, 61 -- 48, in a basketball double-header in Memorial Auditorium tonight before a crowd of 10,132.

TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 14 -- Although Parliament voted unanimously this week to prohibit the use of alcohol and opium in Iran, cynics in Teheran, of whom this city has more than its fair quota, are saying the law never will be rigidly enforced.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Feb. 14 (AP) -- A Federal Court jury today found Robert L. Knetzer, 39 years old, guilty of concealing assets of his new-used car business, which went bankrupt for $2,500,000 in 1948 and left 600 creditors holding notes.

Brooklyn policemen dug yesterday in a back yard at 338 De Graw Street, Red Hook, hoping to find the weapon used last year by the assassin of Arnold Schuster, who had provided the tip that led to the arrest of William Sutton, the bank robber. They did not find the pistol.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Feb. 14 -- The Tennessee Valley Authority warned today that stream pollution might hamper development of the valley area at a time of population and industrial expansion.

THERE is a reassurance in these alphabet verses which ought to send a child off to bed with the feeling that all is well. As in many of the late Margaret Wise Brown's books, the familiar, domestic aspects of a child's life are combined with a poetic sense of the larger world. Thus "M is for Mother who tucks you in tight," "N is for the dark and starry night."

IT is scarcely surprising that an industry which can breed tycoons, an authentic genius or two, quick fortunes and quick bankruptcies, as well as an astonishing number of works of art, could also nurture an impressive list of idolators.
SLOATSBURG, N. Y., Feb. 14 -Four men were fined $2,400 in Justice of the Peace Court here today on charges of deer poaching.

The Kingston Avenue Contagious Hospital and the Dr. John E. Jennings Cancer Research Hospital have been added to the Kings County Hospital Center, Dr. Israel Magelaner, superintendent of the center, announced yesterday.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Feb. 14 -- The twenty-second annual winter concert, a two-day musicale given by the Hempstead High School, opened tonight in Calkin Gymnasium of Hofstra College before an audience of 1,700 persons. The event celebrates the opening of the high school's new music building on Prospect Street.

FORT WORTH, Tex., Feb. 14 (AP) -- The Eighth Air Force announced tonight that Master Sgt. Carroll W. Butin, 34 years old, listed as killed in the crash Thursday night of a Carswell Air Force Base B-36 in Labrador, had been found alive in wreckage of the plane today. The wreckage was buried in five feet of snow.

By one of those coincidences often provided by lunar calendars, the Chinese New Year fell on St. Valentine's Day and also on the third anniversary of the treaty of friendship between the Communist Government of China and Soviet Russia. So far, everything was fine and dandy from Peiping's point of view.

THE question is raised again whether the limitations of the photographic medium are really so great that photographers are handicapped in their efforts to express themselves without resorting to extraordinary measures which seek to force a desired effect by manipulation and excessive compromise.

The bitter fight between commercial and savings banks over the latter's attempts to establish additional branches in this state was given a new twist last week when the savings and loan associations stepped into the controversy.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 14 - Trusting, the late-developing little brother of California's famed On Trust, raced to a three-quarter-length victory today in the $28,600 San Antonio Handicap, the last big stepping stone to the Santa Anita Handicap.

TOPEKA, Kan., Feb. 14 (UP) -Alf M. Landon, the 1936 Republican Presidential candidate, said today President Eisenhower's satisfaction with the explanation of C. Wesley Roberts, Republican National Chairman, of an $11,000 fee he received "does not satisfy the people of Kansas by a long shot."

TOKYO, Sunday, Feb. 15 -- The Communists stepped up their local attacks against the United Nations outpost line across Korea yesterday. For the first time in almost a week the Chinese Reds sent their Soviet-designed MIG's into the air south of the Yalu River. One was shot down. In the ground fighting the enemy casualties were estimated at more than 100 men.

HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 14 -- The Dartmouth College Library acquired today its 700,000th volume with the gift of a Shakespeare Second Folio of 1632 from Donald L. Stone, Professor of Business Law at the Amos Tuck School of Business Administration at Dartmouth.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Feb. 14 -- Dartmouth moved into first place in the annual Williams College winter carnival today scoring impressive victories in both the downhill and the slalom skiing.

Movies showing open activities by gamblers on a street corner in Brooklyn were viewed yesterday by Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan and his two top aides. "The pictures were excellent," Mr. Monaghan commented at the end of the forty-five - minute screening. "They gave very powerful evidence of bookmaking."

LITERARY monthlies (or semi-monthlies) have for a long time played a leading part in French cultural life. The oldest of them, the Mercure de France, born 1672, is still going strong. La Revue de Paris and La Revue des Deux Mondes are both over a century old and in good health.

PHOENIX, Ariz. -- Recent improvements on the old stagecoach route between this resort center and Prescott to the north have opened up to venturesome motorists territory that has changed little since the days of the old Wild West.

IT all started several months ago when members of the family became fascinated by advertisements of the Southland. With increasing regularity, maps, folders and bathing girls on brochures began arriving at our home along with our usual quota of bills.

Representatives of twenty-six international voluntary organizations met last week at a conference called by the United Nations and its specialized agencies to plan improved services to the handicapped on a global basis.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (UP) -- The National Labor Relations Board today made an "unfair labor practices" ruling against a division of J. P. Stevens Company, in which the Secretary of the Army. Robert T. Stevens, was until recently the biggest stockholder. He sold his interest in the textile concern, largely a family enterprise, as a requisite to gaining Senate confirmation for the Army position.
ALBANY, Feb. l4 -- Of 76,320 persons at present employed by state departments and agencies, 44,194 are men and 32,126 are women, according to a report of the state Civil Service Commission.

MUSIC may not be the most remunerative or securest of professions, but surely it is one of the most challenging. Its practitioners usually stick with it under discouraging circumstances, and they often lavish their extra time on it with a devotion people usually reserve for deeply treasured hobbies.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 14 -- The Urban League here declared in its annual report this week that "responsible community and civic leaders, as a whole, did not take advantage of the improved racial 'climate' generated last year to advance the cause of human and race relations in St. Louis."

GIRLS who have followed Tobey Heydon's romantic ups-and-downs in "Practically Seventeen" and "Class Ring" will be glad to know that she is still having a wonderful time. This is the story of the summer after high school graduation -- a complicated one, what with getting a summer job, dabbling in modern art and keeping peace between Brose, her best beau, and the dashing Dick Allen.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (UP) -- A series of informal talks with fellow Democrats on the party's out-of-power role was arranged today for Adlai E. Stevenson's visit to Washington during the next three days.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- President Eisenhower and members of his Cabinet received today at the White House the second interim report of the President's Advisory Committee on Government Organization.

THE TIMES' editorial of Feb. 1 lauding President Truman's executive order enlarging the Olympic National Park in the State of Washington by about 47,000 acres stems, I think, from your editorial writer not being fully informed on all the facts about this park.

Western Europe's reluctance to unite its forces has brought the unofficial suggestion that what Europe needs is another Charlemagne. The old King of the Franks and Roman Emperor, dragged into arguments about coal and steel, the Saar and a European Army, recalls the ancient feeling that somehow Western Europe ought to be united.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Feb. 14 -- Weakened dikes were being shored up and precautionary evacuations were in progress today in the flood-battered southwestern Netherlands in preparation for Monday's new-moon spring tide, but authorities said little trouble was expected if present favorable weather forecasts were fulfilled.

WESTPORT, Conn., Feb. 14 -- John Donahue, 20-year-old reformatory parolee of Arlington, Mass., has confessed the slaying of a Connecticut state trooper on the Merritt Parkway last night, State Police Commissioner Edward J. Hickey said today.

ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 14 -- Employment continues to climb in the Southeast. Factory workers in December totaled 1,987,000 which was an estimated 77,000 above the corresponding month of the previous year, the regional Bureau of Labor Statistics in Atlanta reported this week.

WILLEMSTAD, Curacao, Feb. 8 -- While British Caribbean possessions are debating the idea of a federative government and preparing to confer on it in London in April, the six Dutch islands of the West Indies are living under much the same kind of loose federation the British are considering.
William F. (Billy) Talbert made a thirty-minute appearance on the courts of the Seventh Regiment Armory yesterday as the golden jubilee tourney of the national indoor tennis championships began.

FROM Oslo to Istanbul the mood of Europe this winter is a strange complex of ancient fears, present problems and future hopes, of apathy and vigor, of fatalism and determination, of permanence and change.

Two awards for outstanding work last year in the field of adult education were presented yesterday at the annual luncheon meeting of the Adult Students Council, attended by 650 persons at the Commodore Hotel. The council represents 42,000 registered students in the adult elementary education program of the Board of Education.

BOSTON, Feb. 14 -- The Boston Bruins scored five times in the first period, but just managed to beat the fighting New York Rangers, 5 -- 4, tonight before 7.579 Boston Garden fans. The triumph enabled Boston to tie for third place in the National Hockey League with Chicago.

HARTFORD, Feb. 14 -- A bill in the Connecticut General Assembly to reform minor courts, favored by Gov. John Davis Lodge and Republican legislative leaders, appeared today to have little chance of passage in the Republican-controlled Legislature now holding its biennial session.

ALBANY, Feb. 14 -- Motorists suspected of drunken driving would have to submit to a chemical test to determine the extent of their intoxication or surrender their driving privileges under the provisions of a bill that will be introduced in the Legislature Monday.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 14 -- A serious dispute has arisen between the Allied High Commission and the West German Government concerning the latter's unilateral interpretation of earlier agreements.

EVERY Friday evening at about 7 o'clock, dozens of buses set off from different locations in midtown Manhattan for near-by and more distant ski areas -- wherever last-minute weather reports have indicated sufficient base and cover to provide skiing.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The month-old Administration of President Eisenhower has run into potentially serious political trouble by choosing a period of falling farm markets to expound the thesis that, while Government price supports "should provide insurance against disaster," they should not be used to "encourage uneconomic production and result in continuing heavy surpluses and subsidies."

The National Sportsmen's Show, bringing a touch of wilderness life and living to encourage the outdoor enthusiast will open for its annual nine-day run at Grand Central Palace at noon next Saturday.

GENEVA, Feb. 14 -- Japan was brought a step nearer to admission to membership as a contracting party to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade by the completion of action today on a formula for eventual Japanese adherence to the thirty-four-nation trade accord.

BUFFALO, Feb. 14 (AP) -- A search 100 miles long and seventy wide over western New York failed today to find four Niagara University students missing since yesterday in a rented plane. Authorities were none too hopeful for the safety of the youths as night postponed the search.
Western Europe now appears in danger of developing too many "Schuman Plans."
In "France and Germany -- Fear and Hatred" (Feb. 1) Theodore H. White ascribes to Frederick the Great this definition of happiness: "Froehlich wie der lieber Gott in Frankreich." He should not.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 14 -- By unanimous action the National School Boards Association adopted today a resolution calling upon the Federal Communications Commission to give educators an additional year in which to apply for the 242 television channels set aside for educational purposes.
DAVOS, Switzerland, Feb. 14 -- Seventeen-year-old Tenley Albright of Boston glided closer to the world figure skating championship for women today when she easily won the compulsory figures class.

The tenth anniversary of the Broadway opening of "Oklahoma!'' will be celebrated on March 31 in Washington, where the Theatre Guild's touring company of the phenomenal musical will be playing at that time. The event also will commemorate another significant occasion: The tenth year of the collaborative partnership of Oscar Hammerstein 2d and Richard Rodgers, whose inspiration for "Oklahoma!" came from Lynn Riggs' play, "Green Grow the Lilacs."

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 14 -- American Jewish leaders strongly warned here tonight that this country's Jewish communities must raise within the next ninety days "vast funds" to be able to cope with the "eventualities that are certain to flow from mounting Soviet hostility to Israel and Communist oppression of Eastern Europe's 2,500,000 Jews."
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 14 (AP) -- Alvin Dark, Giants' shortstop, went into the semi-finals of the national baseball players' golf tournament today by eliminating Dizzy Trout of the Red Sox, 3 and 2.

BOSTON, Feb. 14 -- All evidence points to the continuation of high-level business activity in New England. The sustained volume of incoming orders, in the opinion of most industrial executives, makes the maintenance of the present good business probable for some months to come.
STEAMBOAT SPRINGS, Colo., Feb. 14 (UP) -- Two Michigan skiers shared top honors as the 1953 national ski jumping championships opened today.

THIS is a remarkable book and one that is remarkable at two levels. First of all, it is a first-class piece of historical scholarship, a revision of an accepted historical legend, done with acuteness, learning and judgment.

BRIG. GEN. CARLOS P. ROMULO'S achievements as a journalist, soldier and diplomat are known and admired throughout the free world, and Miss Spencer's biography was evidently directed toward younger readers.

The long awaited American premiere of "The Rake's Progress," with libretto by the distinguished poet, William H. Auden, and Chester Kallman, and the score by Igor Stravinsky, the most famous composer of the modern world, took, place yesterday afternoon in the Metropolitan Opera House.

IN show business there is not much room for the literature of the stage. The established plays that are studied in college and read by people interested in art and ideas are seldom produced in the commercial theatre. By one of those ironic paradoxes familiar to people steeped in the vagaries of Broadway, the plays that make the drama one of the great public arts are seldom seen on the commercial stage.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 14 -- German opposition to the French protocols to the European Army Treaty hardened today with Chancellor Konrad Adenauer and his Government taking a "very serious" view of the delays that they regard as an inevitable consequence of the protocols.

Stephen A. Mitchell, Democratic National Chairman. told a conference of Democratic State Chairmen and members of the Democratic National Committee from eleven Eastern states yesterday that the deficit of $500,000 resulting from last year's Presidential campaign would soon be liquidated.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 14 -- An anti-alcoholic movement has appeared in Yugoslavia. Although it is not widespread, it has already caused some excitement in the letters column of Borba, the official Communist newspaper.

HILLSIDE, N. J., Feb. 14 -- Set behind a grove of trees, the new $1,600,000 home of Pingry School, an early American-style brick structure in North Avenue here, was dedicated today. The exercises capped the transfer of the institution, one of the oldest country day schools for boys in New Jersey, from its former quarters in near-by Elizabeth.
CAMP DRUM, N. Y., Feb. 14 -- Eighty-second Airborne Division troopers had their first brush with "atomic" weapons this week as Exercise Snowstorm neared its climax in tactical maneuvers.

VERA SACKVILLE-WEST is mistress of the practiced style and the well-bred detail which surround English upper-class novels with protective elegance. In "Easter Party" she has assembled a number of attractive week-end guests, posed a psychiatric problem and offered a solution smooth and tidy enough to fit into the glossier magazine sections.
The New York Knickerbockers were knee-deep in trouble last night at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory.

BANDUNG, Indonesia, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Strong Asian opposition to Soviet propaganda attacks on the United States and Britain was the surprise development of the nine- day conference of the United Nations Economic Commission for Asia and the Far East that ended here today.

LIKE everyone else of that age now entitled to thoughtful reflection, H. E. Bates, somewhat back, began to brood about the Twenties. Contrary to what may be the local viewpoint, the Twenties were not copyright by the United States Patent Office alone. but they also stretched across the Midlands of England.
NORTHFIELD, Vt., Feb. 14 -Norwich University's skiers made a sweep of their winter carnival today by winning the downhill and slalom events after taking yesterday's giant slalom at Mount Mansfield.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (UP) -- The Army-Navy-Air Force Journal predicted today a special Defense Department commission on incentive pay would recommend that premium flight pay be taken away from officers who collect it just for flying as passengers a few hours monthly.

TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 14 (UP) -- A National Airlines DC-6 with a crew of five and forty-one passengers aboard, most of them apparently bound for the gay Mardi Gras in New Orleans, was presumed to be down in the rough waters of the Gulf of Mexico tonight.

OFFHAND a tree -- just an ordinary tree on a country road -- might seem a static subject for a story. It isn't, not when treated with the style and imagination which Glenn O. Blough brings to "The Tree on the Road to Turntown."

THE best bridge players have never been noted for their modesty. Surveying the field of seventy-two "life masters" (the highest rank) who assembled in New York to play for the individual championship last week-end, A. M. Sobel, the chief tournament director, mused, "And at least forty of them, if asked who is the world's best player, would answer 'I am.'"

IN a world divided between two antagonistic systems of social and political thought Thomas Jefferson has now come to be accepted in America as the chief spokesman for those who love freedom. But he who has so lately become our Democratic god did not always remain green in the memory of posterity.

The Eisenhower Administration seems to be moving speedily to carry out the campaign promise to return to the states control of offshore oil lands. At a meeting in the White House with Congressional leaders last Monday it was agreed that legislation on these lands would be considered immediately.

LAGOS, Portugal -- The Algarve, which sprawls across the southernmost section of Portugal, is to this compact country what Texas is to the rest of the United States. The scenery, weather, architecture, customs, attitude, accent, dress and diet are different from that of other Portuguese provinces.

PRESIDENT EISENHOWER shook the American two-party system to its roots -- shook this party, certainly -- right after his inauguration when he called his first Presidential conference, with Herbert Brownell, for 8 o'clock of a morning (he made it at 8:02) and his first meeting with the leaders of Congress for 8:30 of another morning made it on the dot).

David Milford of England, world open champion from 1937 until he gave up the crown in 1946, and Robert Grant 3d of New York, nine times winner of the American amateur title, will meet at noon today in the prize racquets match of recent years.

Now that the speed-boat regatta season of 1953 is already putt-putting along for outboards and roaring for the inboards on a variety of waterways in Florida, and other areas warm enough, the American Power Boat Association high brass has been able to take stock of the months ahead as the performing daredevils move north.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 14 -- Capt. Jack Molinas threw in 30 points to lead the Columbia basketball team to a 77-56 victory over Harvard tonight. The 6-foot 6-inch forward connected on eight of ten floor shots and converted all his fourteen free throws to keep the Lions in the running for the Ivy League crown.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- The United States is considering the strengthening of Chinese Nationalist naval forces substantially. This would enable them to disrupt more effectively shipping destined for Communist China.

In an effort to make the American Theatre Wing a more complete service to the combined elements comprising the entertainment world, a new type of training course is being instituted by the Wing's Professional Training Program.

Twenty-six newspaper advertising directors and managers from sixteen states will meet tomorrow for the opening session of a two-week seminar given by the American Press Institute at Columbia University.

THE fourteenth annual WNYC American Music Festival began last Thursday, Lincoln's Birthday, and ends on Washington's Birthday, ten days later. No festival of the extent and scope of this one is given in America. It is not a festival featuring internationally famous stars of the opera house or concert hall.

LIKE its recent few issues, the latest New Directions annual is mixed lot. Its most stimulating feature is that the selections are either good or bad, but almost never indifferent. In the present volume the longest and most important prose piece is Gide's "Le Voyage d'Urien," translated by Martha Winburn England.

The Soviet Government's severance of diplomatic relations with the Republic of Israel last week was described in sermons by several rabbis here yesterday as a logical continuation of the Kremlin's program.
Lieut. Comdr. George A. Woodard, U. S. N. R., has joined the firm of H. Newton Whittlesey, Inc., naval architects and marine engineers, as assistant to the president, Souther Whittlesey.

LIST Dino De Laurentiis as a typical exponent of the burgeoning Italian movie industry. Signor De Laurentiis, a partner in the successful Ponti-De Laurentiis company, stopped here briefly en route to Hollywood and took a moment or two to reveal that his group not only had three of its twelve features for this year already completed but that the remainder of the program was ambitious.

The Lenten sewing classes of the Cribside Social Service Committee of the Babies' Hospital will begin Thursday morning and will be held on successive Thursday mornings throughout the Lenten season. Mrs. Leo Fennelly is chairman and Mrs. Joseph R. Ramee vice chairman of the Cribside Social Service Committee.
The much talked-of policy of "trade, not aid" is not going to work in the case of Italy, it was declared here last week by an editor-economist on returning from an extended visit to that country.

Children have more capacity for understanding themselves than most people (including educators) realize, reports Dr. Arthur T. Jersild, Professor of Education at Teachers College, Columbia University, and well-known psychologist and consultant. In a study published by the college's Bureau of Publications, entitled "In Search of Self," Dr. Jersild declares that there is a tremendous need today to change our educational program so that children will get more realistic attitudes of self-acceptance.
CHICAGO, Feb. 14 -- President Will Harridge of the American League today stepped into the controversy between the Browns, Yankees, Red Sox and Indians.

EVERY American school child knows how Francis Scott Key came to write "The Star Spangled Banner" but there is another chapter, almost, forgotten, in the history of the flag that flew over Fort McHenry. Carl Carmer puts into fictional form, the story of Caroline Pickerskill who helped her mother and her grandmother make that huge flag, stitching patiently through the hot, anxious weeks which preceded the British attack.

TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 14 -- Armed clashes between Iranian Government forces and traditionally fierce and independent Bakhtiari tribesmen led by Abul Ghassem Khan Bakhtiari, one of their chiefs, were reported today in dispatches from the oil-field area of southern Iran.

Uncertainty regarding Congressional legislation, particularly as it affects taxes, and a further decline in commodity and security prices had a depressing effect on sentiment in financial markets last week. Stock prices were firmer at the week-end, while commodity futures underwent the widest decline in more than a year before staging a modest rally.

John Schwegmann Jr. of New Orleans stood embattled last week. Encircled by an iron ring of court injunctions against him, he promised a fight to the finish against determined manufacturers and some of the country's best lawyers who are seeking to make him stop cutting prices of fair-traded products.

The problems of minority groups, particularly those of Spanish-speaking persons in New York City, were discussed yesterday at a conference of the Spanish-American Youth Bureau, Inc. The sessions were held in the McBurney Branch of the Young Men's Christian Association at 215 West Twenty-third Street and were attended by 300 persons.

If anybody in Wall Street ever did any betting, the odds would be heavy that this time -- despite failures in the past -- permissive incorporation would be approved by the New York Stock Exchange. On Thursday, at a "policy meeting," the governors will vote on submitting a constitutional amendment to the membership.

A TRAYFUL of small pots on a window sill can be a more efficient seed-starting bed than unwieldy wooden flats. Many a gardener makes unnecessary work for himself by starting dozens of specimens in a flat on the window sill, when much smaller plantings will be all he'll ever have space for or need.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The United States Secret Service reported today a reduced number of persons literally manufacturing their own money.
TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 14 -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh and United States Ambassador Loy Henderson spent an hour together today talking over the British-Iranian oil dispute and other problems.

TWO artists who have been seen here infrequently of late will be among the week's attractions. Pearl Primus will make her only appearance of the season this afternoon in Walter Terry's series at the Lexington Avenue "Y" and Harald Kreutzberg will give two performances next week-end at the Needle Trades High School.

THE story from the Yankee pre-season baseball school in California was startlingly casual about it. The Dean of Men, naturally enough, was the Ol' Perfessor himself, Charles Dillon Stengel. His assistants included Frankie Crosetti, Babe Herman -- whoa! Babe Herman a Yankee? That's what the man said.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Alleged smuggling of strategic materials to countries behind the Iron Curtain has been chosen as the first target of a Senate investigation of conditions on the New York waterfront.

HEADQUARTERS, Eighth Army in Korea, Feb. 14 -- Gen. James A. Van Fleet, retired Eighth Army commander, is expected here to tell Congressional committeemen that the launching of a decisive attack here on a firm basis would require an extension of the term of Selective Service.

IN one of its surveys of what critics across the country like to pick as presents The Saturday Review elicited an interesting opinion on recordings from Victor Prahl of The Springfield (Mass.) Sunday Republican. As one of the "greatest services" rendered by long-playing records Mr. Prahl cited the recording of forty Bach cantatas.
ALLENTOWN, Pa., Feb. 14 -- Walter Dukes, Seton Hall's star, scored 26 points to lead his team to an 88-75 victory over Muhlenberg here tonight.

FOR young Rowdy Halloran, the security which surround her in Riverbank, La., is strangely depressing. Her coming marriage to a clean and handsome young man fills her with foreboding. She wonders about her mother, a weary and worldly woman whom Riverbank distrusts, and her father, a wealthy oil man whom his wife describes as a "big, pink boyish animal."

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Feb. 14 -- Tiny Tony Holguin tore Brackenridge Park's course apart for the third consecutive round today to forge into a one-stroke lead at the three-quarter mark of the $10,000 Texas open golf tournament with a 17-under par 196.

I was much interested in your article "Dirty Work at the Crossroads" and very glad you mentioned Hinesville, Ga., as one of the chief offenders. We were stopped there. Yes, we were going perhaps five miles over the limit, but as it was, we were being nearly swept off the road by Georgia cars going 75 and 80 to judge by the way they flew past us.

AS one who has deeply felt the stunning impact of Arthur Miller's "The Crucible" I am astonished at much of the critical quibbling. That Mr. Miller has not equaled his shattering "Death of a Salesman" we may readily grant, but, then, Melville is not a lesser master for having written only one "Moby Dick."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The White House announced today the resignation of Carlisle H. Humelsine as Deputy Under Secretary of State for Administration. Mr. Humelsine, who joined the State Department in March, 1946, as director of the Office of Departmental Administration under Secretary George C. Marshall, officially resigned as of the close of business yesterday. However, he has agreed to remain as a consultant until April 1, the announcement said.

Nine chemists of the Upjohn Laboratories of Kalamazoo, Mich., announce in the Journal of the American Chemical Society that they have developed a new fermentation process for making scarce Compound F, a chemical relative of cortisone. A more abundant supply and a reduction in the price of Compound F are foreseen.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- President Eisenhower, playing bridge the other day, drew the kind of hand that might have induced a reasonably spunky man to suggest three clubs. The President bid four spades -- and made it.

ALL Kate Jerold wanted as she arrived in Washington from California was a room so that she could get on with her work at the Berg Foundation of Contemporary Art. She finds temporary haven with her beautiful cousin Sylvia Pleydell in a collector's dream of a house in Georgetown -- only to discover that she is in the middle of a kind of romantic nightmare.

THE argument is sometimes advanced (both flatteringly and unflatteringly) that the United States and Australia have more in common than any other two English- speaking countries. For the unraveled reader of fiction, and particularly of the mystery novel, it's hard to judge, since we see so few Australian works.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 14 -- The Pennsylvania Supreme Court, in a 4 to 2 decision, ruled today that the conflict in Korea was not a war "within what may be termed the constitutional or legal sense."

IN a man-made jungle cluttered with electric cables and junction boxes, in the ancient Japanese capital of Kyoto, Josef von Sternberg is currently filming the celebrated "Anatahan story," a weird footnote to the last war.

HONG KONG, Feb. 14 -- A partial eclipse of the sun marked the advent of the Chinese Lunar New Year here today as the Year of the Water Snake replaced the Year of the Water Dragon in the old Chinese almanac cycle.

Milton Campbell, the amazing athlete from Plainfield High School, who finished second to Bob Mathias in last summer's Olympic decathlon at Helsinki, provided the program's highlight yesterday as he paced his team to an impressive victory for the second straight year in the high school division of the national interscholastic track and field championships at Madison Square Garden.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 14 -Brazil gave up all other business at noon today for a serious celebration of the carnival lasting until Thursday. Even the dockworkers' union, which had threatened to tie up the port over the dismissal of a foreman, decided to postpone the strike until Thursday so as not to disappoint 600 tourists expected aboard two liners tomorrow morning.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 14 -- More than 10 per cent of West Germany's annual gross national product is devoted to various forms of social security, according to a statistical study prepared by West German insurance companies.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 14 -- Much has been said about the shortcomings of the nation's public schools -- the need for additional qualified teachers, the acute lack of classroom space and the growing school enrollment. Vital as they are, they are, in a sense, superficial items, dealing as they do with the peripheral aspects of education.

PRESIDENT EISENHOWER and his administrative staff are mastering their routines in the most important governmental offices on earth. The two wings of this office flank the White House itself and in them are the persons, from messengers to policy-makers, who help the President.

WITH a record year forecast for motor touring, an appeal has been made for a Congressional appropriation to prevent deterioration of the national parks. The appeal is spearheaded by the American Automobile Association on behalf of the thousands of members of the organization who visit these areas annually.

" New York, 1653-1953" contained an article by Robert Moses entitled "Problems: Many -- and a Program." Mr. Moses' extensive experience as a gifted public servant is reflected in his list of the "twelve major problems we have," i. e., housing, safety, transportation, traffic, schools, recreation, hospitals, sanitation, water, port, personnel, financing. * * *

Progress in tracking down the underlying chemical causes believed to have a major role in the development of hardening of the coronary arteries, the underlying background of most heart disease, were reported yesterday at a meeting of the Northwestern Section of the American Chemical Society at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Mass.

The serious question of whether a judge can bar press and public from the courtroom in a criminal trial, for the protection of public morals, was raised last week in the opening of the vice trial of Minot F. (Mickey) Jelke 3d.

TORONTO, Feb. 14 (UP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs dropped into fifth place in the National Hockey League tonight as they played a 2-2 tie with the Montreal Canadiens before 14,289 fans, the largest crowd of the season here.

After a three-mile chase, radio-car patrolmen arrested yesterday at 4:30 A. M. a plumber's helper for allegedly stealing a tow truck. The police fired several shots in the chase. The prisoner, Joseph T. Carberry, 29 years old, of 409 East Eighty-seventh Street, was held without bail for the grand jury by Magistrate John R. Starkey in Felony Court.

Removal of Office of Price Stabilization ceilings on meat brought an announcement yesterday from John Bess, president of the Freezer Owners Association that his group would bring out on April 1 its own brand of meat, poultry, vegetables and fruit.

VATICAN CITY'S Basilica of St. Peter and portraits of eight Popes who were associated with its architectural development across the centuries, together with St. Peter's likeness and one of Pius XII, the present Pontiff, figure in the designs in a stamp series in preparation by the Vatican postal administration.
LONDON, Feb. 14 (UP) -- Blizzards pounded Britain today, slowing dike workers fighting desperately to strengthen east coast sea defenses before the peak tides Monday.

Adlai E. Stevenson, defeated Democratic candidate for President, declared last night that the Republican party under the leadership of President Eisenhower was attempting what had not been tried for a long time -- government by business men.
THE Windmill Theatre, a little piece of London that holds a place in the heart of thousands of wartime GI's, is celebrating its twenty-first birthday this month

TELEVISION'S frenetic efforts to put more and more comedy programs on home screens prove one thing: mass production works swell for the auto industry. Too many programs still lack real humor, although some of the best minds in the entertainment field are trying for comely that really perks.

ON this Sunday in mid- February, while fathers in many parts of the country are still concerned with keeping driveways free of snow and mothers in too many households are striving valiantly to keep sniffly youngsters quiet in bed, it may seem a bit early to discuss the matter of choosing a summer camp.

St. Francis defeated a fighting Queens College five by a score of 67 -- 53 at the Second Corps Armory in Brooklyn last night. The score at the quarter was 17 -- 10 in favor of St. Francis. At the half, St. Francis led 31 -- 24. The Terriers could never get started as the Queens five kept pressing them.

Traditional divertissements in keeping with pre-Lenten fetes will be features of the second annual Mardi Gras Ball of the New York Junior League, to be held Tuesday night in the ballroom of the Astor for the benefit of the organization's welfare fund.

To mark Pan American Day, April 14, the Pan American Union announced yesterday a prize essay contest open to all students in the United States on the subject of the Organization of American States as an instrument of inter-American cooperation.

Chapman, formerly Fellow of Magdalen College.

WITHIN the endless strangeness of the Chinese Communist Revolution only a few things have shone clear. We know, for example, a good deal about the character of the leaders, their doctrinal quarrels and their implicit faith in their mission, though the mission with its accompanying mystique has never been defined in intelligible terms.

An important experiment in merchandising of undergarments has been started by Peter Pan Foundations, Inc., according to Herbert E. Mayer, vice president in charge of sales. The company, one of the five largest in the foundations field, has started production and distribution of a line of lingerie with which it hopes to add $1,000,000 to its sales volume in 1953.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 14 -- California business activity, as measured by the Wells. Fargo index, continued at record levels during 1952, tapering off in November and December after an upward trend beginning in February last year. The preliminary index for December, 299.6, compares with 299.2 (revised) for November and 272.7 for December, 1951.

James P. McGranery, former United States Attorney General, made clear yesterday that Pope Pius XII had not made a personal plea for clemency for Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, atomic spies condemned to death, but only had transmitted the information that the Vatican had received "numerous and urgent" appeals on their behalf.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- A subcommittee of the Senate Armed Services Committee reported today that the current war planning by the Armed Forces might not be sufficient to prevent a crippling surprise attack by an enterprising enemy, might not provide the capability for immediate retaliation following such an attack and might not assure this nation of the ability to carry on a sustained offensive against a powerful adversary.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Feb. 14 -- Brown won its second Pentagonal Hockey League victory in five starts tonight, beating Dartmouth, 7 -- 3, at the Auditorium. Capt. Frank DiBiase and John Farrell each scored two goals for the winners. John Titus tallied twice for the Indians. '

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 14 -Whether there will be war or peace on the labor-management front in the first year of the Eisenhower era depends, in large measure, on what happens in industries that had no unions when the Republicans lost control of the White House twenty years ago.

SPORTS and conservation groups are not always in happy accord, despite the frequency of a common goal, but increasing unity between these factions, especially in New York, has grown as a result of threats to the Forest Preserve by agencies motivated more by private gain than by public interest.

The third annual April in Paris Ball for the benefit of charitable organizations here and abroad will be held on April 20 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. Grover A. Whalen is general chairman of the executive committee for the fete with Bernard F. Gimbel as treasurer and C. C. Philippe as secretary.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The social scene in the capital at the moment reminds old-timers of what takes place on a battlefield when a new commander takes charge. Action is limited to small patrols and probing actions intended to secure intelligence for planning bigger moves later.

The Air Research and Development Command wants to know more than it does about the state of winds, temperatures, atmospheric pressures, turbulence and types of cloud formations at altitudes of 50,000 to 100,000 feet. Controlled balloons launched from West Coast sites will therefore carry, in addition to their recording instruments, pressurized test tubes containing harmless fruit flies (drosophilia), similar to those sometimes seen on bananas.

The monthly evening recorded concert at 8:15 P. M. Wednesday at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street, will illustrate the many descriptive uses that composers have made of voice and instrumentation.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Feb. 14 -- Concerted opposition to a call by the Union of Factory Workers for the expropriation of the Cochabamba newspaper Los Tiempos has resulted in a clear-cut statement by Government officials that the rights of a free press will continue to be respected.

BEACH HAVEN, N. J., Feb. 14 -- James Gerard McRory, 47-year-old supervisor in the New Jersey area for Western Electric Company, was killed today when his rented Piper Cub Special plane crashed into Tuckerton Bay, 5 miles from this place.

THE UNITED STATES ARMY last week, presumably concerned with reports of ammunition shortages in the Korean fighting, issued a statement of the amount of ammunition produced in this country last year. The figures were more than 52,000,000 rounds for artillery and 3,000,000,000 rounds for small arms. The cost, the Army said, was about $2,000,000,000.

A DASHING story of the English slave trade toward the end of the eighteenth century, this is told as the personal history of young Peter Millet of London. It starts with all the makings of high adventure -- murder, a mysterious wreck in the Thames, a skeleton, an exotic amulet and a missing girl.

LIMA, Peru, Feb. 14 -- Although Peru had its biggest cotton crop in history last year, value of the crop was some $20,000,000 less than in 1951 because of the drop in world prices, according to the preliminary annual report issued by the Cotton Chamber of Peru.

IRAN'S recent move to nationalize a twenty-five- year-old Russian fishing concession on the Caspian Sea, even as the Iranian Government previously seized British oil installations along the Persian Gulf, has been causing repercussions in New York caviar circles.

The Museum of Modern Art, through John Hay Whitney, chairman of its board of trustees, announced yesterday "a radically important departure from the museum's past policy" -- the creation of a permanent collection of modern masterworks.

He may be meddlesome, misguided and patiently dogmatic where family, friends and business associates are concerned.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Feb. 14 -- Several American industrial concerns have enlisted the aid of the Stamford Research Institute in a quest for information about scientific facilities in Western Europe. They seek possible assistance in certain lines of research.

CARLSBAD, N. M. -- An Easterner touring the Southwest for the first time is like a man who unexpectedly finds a pirate treasure. Everything makes such an impression, it's hard to separate what is only valuable from what is priceless.

The adverse effects of high taxation and inflation on employe benefit plans in recent years and efforts of management to meet these developments points up the need for continuous review and possibly revision of plans to bring them more in line with present economic conditions, it is contended.
Correction of vision for industrial workers is one of the major requisites for any plant seriously trying to cut down on occupational injuries.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., Feb. 14 -- Susan Hayward and John Wayne tonight were named the most popular film stars of 1952 on the basis of a poll conducted among movie fans in fifty countries by members of the Foreign Press Association of Hollywood. They received statuettes called "Henriettas" at the association's third annual awards banquet held here at the Club Del Mar.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Considerable difference of opinion has developed within President Eisenhower's Administration regarding his proposed new loyalty program, it is understood.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Feb 14 -- The "tyranny" of majority opinion and the fear of speaking out against it pose a greater danger to American freedom of expression than any abridgement by official action, it was asserted today by high school students from thirty states, Hawaii, the District of Columbia and two foreign countries.

The Eisenhower Administration now has behind it its first experience with managing Uncle Sam's war-swollen public debt. An issue of $8,868,000,000 of one-year certificates of indebtedness due today has just been converted into two issues of debt -- $8,114,092,000 of new one-year certificates and $620,228,000 of bonds not due until Dec. 15, 1958.
ITHACA, N. Y., Feb. 14 -- Yale's basketball team defeated Cornell, 72 -- 66, before 3,500 in Barton Hall tonight for its second victory in five Eastern Intercollegiate League games.

Five years of inter-group cooperation and good fellowship will be celebrated at Hunter College on Tuesday at a Brotherhood Week birthday party for Alpha Omega Pi, the college's first and only inter-faith, interracial sorority, in the Sara Delano Roosevelt Memorial House, 47 East Sixty-fifth Street.

Prices of men's clothing will increase next fall, manufacturers forecast last week. Negotiations with the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, which opened Tuesday, are expected to result in wage increases that will be reflected in the prices of suits, it was said.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (UP) -- The Selective Service Director Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, said today that it might be necessary to draft fathers in eight to fourteen months to maintain the armed forces strength of 3,600,000 men.
LONDON, Feb. 14 (Reuters) -- Arsenal, strong favorite for the Football Association Cup, defeated Burnley by 2 -- 0 in a fifth-round game today.

IT is news when the president of one of our leading universities concerns himself with the philosophy and curriculum of secondary school education. It is extraordinary and good news, when, out of a discussion marked by sobriety and uncommon sense, proposals emerge for some far - reaching curricular and organizational changes to strengthen the tradition of American freedom.

With the tax - exempt - interest bonds of local government selling at the lowest levels of the post-war period, the value of the tax-exemption privilege is now the highest of record to individual investors in the high Federal income-tax brackets. The same is true for corporate investors, except that during the 1933 depression municipal bond prices made record lows.

JAIPUR, India, Feb. 12 -- Several years of patient tracking by police on camel, horse and jeep have almost cleared the notorious dacoits or desert robbers from the rolling dunes and craggy rock knolls of the great Rajputana, or Thar desert, the immense sandy No Man's Land between Pakistan's Indus basin and India's Gangetic plain.

MIAMI, Feb. 14 -- There were some flossy figures on the payoff board after the running of the $37.800 Everglades Stakes at Hialeah Race Course today. The winner was the $37.40-for-$2 seventh choice. Royal Bay Gem, owned by Eugene Constantin Jr. of Dallas and the ninth-place finisher in the field of nineteen 3-year-olds was the 3-to-4 Straight Face owned by Greentree Stable.

Never in the history of the United States has the need been greater for a unified people joined together in the bonds of a common understanding. Prejudice is a hateful business at any time. It is even more hateful these days, when people of all faiths -- Protestants, Catholics and Jews -- are considered dangerous by those biased persons who believe that man was made for the state and not the state for man.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 14 -- Unless widespread remedies are applied to deteriorated highways and parking congestion, this country will be up against a "dead end" in motor transport, delegates were told today at the opening of the thirty-sixth annual convention here of the National Automobile Dealers Association.

Members of the social service committee of the new Francis Delafield Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases, affiliated with the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, have arranged a card Party in behalf of the organization to be held on the night of Feb. 27 at the hospital, 99 Fort Washington Avenue.

IN an effort to be somewhat cautious about announcing plans, the Greater New York Chapter of the American National Theatre and Academy recently dispatched a rather circumspect release -- to put it euphemistically -- about initiating a survey to determine the availability of talent for the formation of a resident acting company.

THE photojournalist's approach to photography and its application to other fields as well will be the theme of a Photographic Society of America Regional Town Meeting to be held March 21 at Sturbridge, Mass.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 14 -- A Yale quartet of Jimmy McLane, Capt. Wayne Moore, Don Sheff and Marty Smith, shattered the world record for the 800-yard relay in the final event of the Thirty-first annual Yale swimming carnival in the Payne Whitney pool tonight.

LET Clare J. Bousquet, proprietor of the skiers' Brighton Beach in the Berkshire Hills 150 miles north of New York, broadcast on Friday that he has six inches of powder, and the following week-end two to three thousand snow-bunnies will be happily making "bathtubs" all over his 200-acre playground.

The Senate Permanent Investigating subcommittee will hold an open hearing in Washington tomorrow to inquire into a case that may involve reprisal by a civil service superior against a witness before the subcommittee, Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, head of the subcommittee, announced last night.

CITY COLLEGE -- Inauguration Dr. Buell G. Gallagher will be inaugurated as the seventh president of City College in day-long ceremonies on Thursday. More than 2,100 persons will be present as the former United States Assistant Commissioner for Higher Education is installed as head of the college.

Three works by Debussy made up the program that Arturo Toscanini conducted last night with the N. B. C. Symphony. The program. broadcast from Carnegie Hall, consisted of "Iberia," "L'Apres-midi d'un faune" and "La Mer."

WILLIAM RESWICK must be an extraordinary man, and this book of his Soviet recollections from the period between 1922 and 1934 is quite amazing. Any student of the counter - revolution engineered by Stalin after Lenin's death would do well to read it.

FOR THIS WEEK: Look over the plan of the property or make a simple plan in order to decide where seed must be sown this spring, what kinds of seed are needed and in what quantity. Early ordering of seed means prompt delivery. . . . It is too early to start seed of tomatoes or of any flowers in the house. Petunias, snapdragon and verbena might be sown later this month. . . .

YVOR WINTERS has staked out a peculiar place for himself as critic, poet, and West Coast spokesman. His spokesmanship has often consisted of regional tirades against the decadent Eastern Universities.

THAT much-talked-about commodity known as "American music" receives a fine gramophonic boost with the initial release of the Modern American Music Series sponsored by Columbia. Planned as an annual event, this series will concentrate on chamber music.

MOST recent reissues of jazz recordings of an earlier day have come, because of the very nature of such projects, from the three or four biggest and most firmly rooted recording companies. One of the prime requisites for such reissues is a catalogue of properly aged masters, and Victor, Columbia and Decca have amassed more ample catalogues than their newer competitors.

Sales of department stores for the country as a whole were up 1 per cent from the 1952 figure in the week ended Feb. 7, on the basis of Federal Reserve Board figures. The week before there had been an advance of 2 per cent. In the latest week there were five decreases and seven increases.

MOSCOW, Feb. 14 -- The death certificate for Lev Zakharovich Mekhlis, State Control Minister until 1950, was published by the papers today and bore the signature of Ivan Ivanovich Kuperin, head of the Kremlin Medical Hygiene Administration. Other signers were Prof. P. E. Lukomsky and A. V. Rusakov, Docent V. T. Boev and Dr. N. I. Kuzmina.

THE HAGUE, Feb. 14 -- When the Roman, Pliny the Elder, visited what is now the Netherlands in 50 A. D., he saw "a miserable country where twice daily the ocean penetrates the land in enormous width and with unmeasurable waves * * *. It is difficult to say what part of the soil belongs to the land and what part to the sea."

EDWARD ROOT had just returned from the Metropolitan Museum where his very personal collection of modern American and British paintings is now on view. He is a tall, dignified man with short white hair that sits flat like a skull-cap on his head.

Federal and state jurists were among the honorary pallbearers at the funeral service yesterday for former Justice Clarence J. Shearn of the New York State Supreme Court, held in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Park Avenue at Fifty-first Street.

Several precautions against over-confidence on business prospects were suggested yesterday by Henry H. Heimann, executive vice president of the National Association of Credit Men, in his monthly business review to members.

THAT wonderful world of high mountains, dazzling in their rock and ice, acts as a catalyst. It suggests the infinite but it is not the infinite. The heights only give us what we ourselves bring to them. Climbing is a means of self-expression. Its justification lies in the men it develops, its heroes and its saints.
The concert scheduled for this afternoon by the New Friends of Music in Town Hall will not be presented as originally announced, it was learned yesterday.

MOST published symposia disappointing; this collection of eighteen essays is a notable exception. I wish it could be read, and re-read, by thoughtful men and women in every walk of life. It is a most illuminating commentary on modern literature in our contemporary society -- on the predicament, and the failures and achievements of the writer, but also on our cultural situation, our spiritual hazards and opportunities.

The reciprocal trade agreements program, which has been an integral part of American foreign economic policy for nearly twenty years, will expire in June unless Congress acts to extend it. By conferring last week with a group of Cabinet and Congressional officials concerned with such matters President Eisenhower emphasized the importance he places upon American encouragement of international trade.

IN this remarkably sustained long poem the reader is provided with a trip to Europe and a return to California. It is an idiosyncratic journey, descriptive and philosophical, a voyage among rediscovered cultures and art objects, essentially a poetic voyage of the spirit.

A recent one-sentence story datelined Seoul, Korea, read: "The United States Air Force retired its last propeller-driven F-51 Mustang from the Korean war today." That was all. The complete obituary of a grand old fighting machine that took on the best the enemy had in the Second World War and usually came back to "buzz" its home base and do a "victory roll" was covered in seventeen words.

ALBANY, Feb. 14 -- Captain Billy Hogan's driving one-hander in the last 18 seconds and two foul shots by Jack Merry with four seconds left enabled Siena to upset Fordham, 61 to 57, before 5,000 fans last night at the Albany Armory.

THE Museum of Modern Art and Station WNBT are going to bring "Through the Enchanted Gate" back to television. The art education series will start on Saturday and will be seen from 5:30 to 6 o'clock, immediately following "It's a Problem," which also has just returned to the TV screen.

" I AM planning to have a garden of dwarf fruit trees," wrote a friend of mine who recently acquired a half-acre lot in the country. My correspondent was definitely enthusiastic and so it was with real regret that I found it necessary to inject a note of caution into this dwarf Eden.
Prints by modern masters never before offered at a public sale in this country will be auctioned at 8 P. M. on Tuesday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 14 -- The mystery of the Soviet Legation bombing Monday night was still puzzling authorities today.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Gov. John S. Fine said today that "there is no censorship, implied or real" in his recent order to state officials that all news releases must be approved by the Governor's office.
Re: Sophie Van S. Theis' "The Passing of the Orphanage" (Jan. 18):

Robert F. MacLeod of the Plainfield Country Club and Peter Truesdale of the Short Hills Club, both unseeded, gained the semi-final round of the invitation Class B squash racquets tournament at the City Athletic Club yesterday. They were joined in the round of four by top-seeded W. A. Flagg of the Racquet and Tennis Club and Charles A. Sullivan of the New York Athletic Club, the No. 3 man.

I WANT to congratulate you on your article concerning speed traps, which appeared in the Feb. 1 issue. This was of particular interest to me, since Jesup is only eleven miles from Ludowici -- a constant source of shame to us.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Feb. 14 -- A formidable array of Eastern Canadian women skiers easily turned back an Eastern United States team today in winning the Lake Placid Club Sno Birds' international competition for the Kate Smith Trophy.

SOUTHERN RHODESIA is proud of its status as a self-governing dominion in the British Commonwealth and when the centenary of the birth of its founder, Cecil Rhodes, comes in July, the occasion will be celebrated handsomely. Grand opera is to make the big splash, with London's Covent Opera Company and Manchester's Halle Orchestra to be flown to Africa to give performances.

FRANKLY preferring coincidence to probability, Oriel Malet has concocted a light-hearted tale of three English children on the loose. Brought up by a veritable dragon of a great-aunt, the Mallory orphans were greatly surprised to learn that their father had been a famous actor and their mother a dancer.
LONDON, Feb. 14 (Reuters) -- East Germany, once the granary of the nation, now is on the verge "of something like famine," Dr. Ernst Reuter, Mayor of West Berlin, said here today.

With reference to C. B. Palmer's article, "Checkmating the Weather Man" (Feb.1), when the original report was published in THE TIMES more than a year ago of the donation which made the Central Park chess and checkers shelter a reality, it was noted that a photograph, taken some time earlier, had inspired the generous act. It showed two old men playing chess on a park bench.

THE new annual flowers which are presented every year are tried first in the many widely scattered testing grounds of the All-America Selections committee and then -- when they become generally available -- by keen gardeners everywhere.

OF all brave men in wartime, none is braver than the unarmed man of the Army's medical corps -- the "medic" who picks up the wounded, carries them to comparative safety and then, still within range of enemy shells, gives them the surgical treatment that will keep them alive.

Like Helena LeClair Lewis and Joseph M. Duffy Jr., whose letters appear in THE TIMES of Feb. 8, I am opposed to the current campaign against Charlie Chaplin's movie, "Limelight." However, I am also slightly irritated at your two correspondents' air of belligerent indignation, since it so obviously stems from ignorance of the actual charges leveled against Chaplin.

Showing the same second-half punch which enabled it to overcome a 14-point deficit against Ithaca earlier in the week, City College's basketball team last night rolled to a 71-64 victory over Hofstra College at the winner's gymnasium.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Feb. 14 -- A leading adherent of the Nationalist Government of Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan painted today a picture of world conflict, with the 2,500,000 whites in South Africa in the center. Their enemies, he explained, are made up of the overwhelming majority of the world's population.

Buyers placed orders last week in good volume for Easter selling, according to the market report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co. Strong activity was reported in accessories, dresses, sportswear and children's wear.

In Malraux's book on the arts, "Les Voix de Silence," immensely popular in France, he strives to show the underlying unity of genius. For example, he brings together the two pictures shown here, one by Henri Rousseau, the French primitive, and one of an unknown American primitive.

Engineering and science graduates of Carnegie Institute of Technology are few in comparison to the number of jobs awaiting them. The placement bureau announced that there were more than two jobs for every male graduate in the engineering and science fields. The shortage is expected to increase within the next few years.

THE three-performance "Festival" to be given by New Dance Group Presentations is the second project to testify to the trend of the modern dance to return to something approximating its proper place in public interest.

Twenty prominent American artists will be represented in an international art show opening March 1 in India. The pictures were assembled from galleries and private collections by the American Federation of Arts, with funds provided by the Ford Foundation through Intercultural Publications, Inc.
Sound and fury arose from the banks of the Potomac last week as Senators and generals, the Congress and the Pentagon discussed one of the oldest military measures in history -- blockade.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Feb. 14 (AP) -- Arthur Tyler and Ed Seymour of Rochester, N. Y., zoomed to the national Amateur Athletic Union two-man bobsled championship today over the Mount Van Hoevenburg run.

THE Ming tree is an artistic reproduction of a decorative tree of centuries ago. This tree, inspired by living dwarf trees handed down from generation to generation in Oriental families, found great popularity as a symbol of long life and strength of character in a Chinese home of the Ming dynasty.

THE Scots, if we are to credit the anonymous poet, are a hardy race. Mr. Garside's roister-doister novel will do nothing to dispel that well-founded belief. The Highland hero he has invented to power his picaresque tale ranges from the Clyde to the Cameroons, and from Bahia to Plymouth in search of life's ultimate meaning.

THERE is, among scrupulous critics, a natural inclination to request that movies be fairly faithful to the material from which they are derived. A film based upon a classic novel should be moderately respectful of that work; a film based upon a personal history should come close to the actual facts of life.

The Great Neck Elks Lodge, No. 1543, has announced that its twenty-fourth annual charity ball on April 4 will raise funds for a memorial chapel to merchant seamen who lost their lives in World War II.

PARIS, Feb. 14 -- The inauguration by six nations this week of a single market for coal and iron ore, which will be extended to steel on April 10, might have been described as the abandonment by the six of a vast conspiracy in restraint of trade -- to use the language of the Sherman Anti-Trust Act.

ONE of the most vexing and urgent problem facing present and prospective designers, builders and operators of commercial jet airliners is the annoying, even harmful, noise the new planes make on the ground.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- A highly placed source said today the Administration backed Secretary Benson's stand on farm price supports and was prepared to make an issue of it.
HAMILTON, N. Y., Feb. 14 -- Colgate turned on a torrid fourth period scoring burst here tonight to down Syracuse, 106 -- 88, for a new all-time Red Raider scoring record.

SYRACUSE, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Dick Wagner, hard punching light-heavy-weight from Toppenish, Wash., knocked out Joey DeJohn of Syracuse in 1 minute 44 seconds of the fourth round at the State Fair Coliseum tonight.
The port of Baltimore is carrying on an active drive to attract more general export cargo, long a mainstay of New York's maritime commerce, and has made headway in one area so far, the Caribbean.
A marriage of education and business, a vital partnership in which the families of both would benefit, was proposed yesterday by Robert R. Young, chairman of the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway Company.

TWO barometric factors which business men would be well advised to watch carefully in the period ahead are commodity prices and trends in business inventories. Perhaps, even more than political developments, they will give a clue as to what readjustments may lie in store.

For the first time since 1950, the Industrial College of the Armed Forces will conduct one of its two-week courses in economic mobilization here. The sessions, beginning March 23, will be held at the Astor Hotel. They will be attended by 310 students, including 160 business and industrial executives, educators and representatives of civic organizations, and 150 Reserve officers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (UP) -- Republicans in the House of Representatives talked angrily today of "retaliation" against the Senate if Senators carried out threats to scuttled a proposed July 1 income tax cut.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Feb. 14 (AP) -- Arthur Tyler and Ed Seymour of Rochester, N. Y., zoomed to the national Amateur Athletic Union two-man bobsled championship today over the Mount Van Hoevenburg run.

THE Ming tree is an artistic reproduction of a decorative tree of centuries ago. This tree, inspired by living dwarf trees handed down from generation to generation in Oriental families, found great popularity as a symbol of long life and strength of character in a Chinese home of the Ming dynasty.

THE Scots, if we are to credit the anonymous poet, are a hardy race. Mr. Garside's roister-doister novel will do nothing to dispel that well-founded belief. The Highland hero he has invented to power his picaresque tale ranges from the Clyde to the Cameroons, and from Bahia to Plymouth in search of life's ultimate meaning.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (UP) -- Two House Agriculture Committee Democrats accused the Eisenhower Administration today of trying to renege on campaign promises to producers of meat, eggs, and other perishables.

IN many a suburban greenhouse flowering trees and plants are being groomed to reach their peak of bloom the week of March 8, when the International Flower Show will be held in Grand Central Palace, Lexington Avenue at Forty-sixth Street.

Dr. Buell Gordon Gallagher will be installed as the seventh president of City College on Thursday afternoon before educators from 200 colleges and universities, representatives of 130 learned societies and public officials and guests from this country and abroad.
OSLO, Norway, Feb. 14 -- King Haakon VII formally gave his consent tonight to the engagement of his granddaughter, Princes Ragnhild, to a commoner, Capt. Erling Svenn Lorentzen, a shipping executive.

NEW ORLEANS, Sunday, Feb. 15 -- Coast Guard headquarters here said SOS messages were heard from "somewhere in the Gulf of Mexico area" early today and that they were believed to have been sent by someone aboard a National Airlines DC-6 missing since last night with forty-six persons aboard.

KNOWN chiefly as a writer on democratic values, esthetics, and problems of general culture, James Fiebleman has also in the last two decades been composing reflective poems, mostly with a setting in New Orleans, its environs and the Gulf country. The present volume has two parts, "Trembling Prairie" and "The Wild Data."

SEOUL, Korea, Sunday, Feb. 15 (AP) -- The inflation-ridden Republic of Korea today renamed and revalued its national currency, cutting the face value by 100 but leaving its official dollar value unchanged.
Reducing the field of eligibles to three, American boxing authorities yesterday took steps to hasten the development of a successor to the unclaimed world middleweight title.
FOLKWAYS RECORDS has had the interesting idea of sending a representative named Tony Schwartz about the city to make on-the-spot recordings of kids singing at their play.

Interest coupon clipping time for holders of about $1,000,000,000 of outstanding railroad income Londs is drawing near. This section of the list, which was pretty well ignored during the last several months when rail stocks were speculative favorites, is expected to command increasing attention.

Jan Gorbaty, Polish pianist who made his local debut in December, 1950, with the New York Little Symphony, gave his first New York recital at Town Hall yesterday afternoon. He proved to be a serious and perceptive young musician with boldly dramatic ideas.

Since the end of World War II most foreign countries have been subjected to visits by American marketing experts who have attempted to sell the business men of those nations on our concept of modern advertising and distribution methods. One notable exception is Australia, where there has been little need for such activity because that country has been duplicating American ideas in many ways for years.

In a recent letter published in your columns V. Henry Rothschild, formerly chief counsel and thief vice chairman of the Salary Stabilization Board, expresses severe criticism of the Federal Civil Service system, citing as a basis for his charges certain events which he alleges to have occurred during his year of service with the board.

For a present-day audience, when the drive to conformity is relentless, Mr. Miller's dramatization of the conflict between the sincerely convinced (and not "vengeful," as your critic says) righteousness of the supporters of the dissolving theoracy and the challenge of rising dissent in seventeenth century Massachusetts has tremendous impact.

WHAT is wrong with the British? Ever since the war they have been more or less under attack first from one, then from the other side of the Atlantic -- and often from both -- and always for the same reason. They are bad at cooperation. They "drag their feet." They put a brake upon the advance toward closer association. They are even "isolationists."

LONDON, Feb. 14 -- The British-French talks on European defense that have just been concluded here will have a sequel in Washington next month. Britain is expected to inform the United States that she is ready to take a further step toward reassuring France provided the United States moves in the same direction.

An international conference of major Jewish organizations in thirty-eight countries "to consider the implications of anti-Semitism for over 2,500,000 Jews under Soviet and satellite rule" has been called for March 11. The place has not yet been determined, but it will be in Europe.

Friday the thirteenth proved an unlucky day for 13-year-old Judith Jaimes, Venezuelan pianist. Because of influenza, she had to cancel her appearance at the young people's concert of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony. But the illness that brought bad luck to Judith brought good luck to her friend, 12-year-old Leah Mellman.
SUNNY February days show subtle changes in plants and their coloring. The promise of spring may be evanescent but even the cold days of February show changes worth observing.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Democrats are finding that their chosen role of a "constructive opposition'' is not all piety and hair shirts by any means; it can be good clean fun and apparently pay dividends as well.
WORDS are queer things. A couple of weeks ago. wishing to make a not too serious reference to illness, I spoke of "a bevy of inconsiderate bacteria."

In a letter printed on this page today Representative Russell V. Mack of Washington adds nothing substantially new to the attacks he has been making on former President Truman's recent order enlarging the Olympic National Park. Nevertheless, we will endeavor to reply to Mr. Mack's principal arguments point by point.

Brotherhood can be achieved "only as specific discriminatory practices are wiped out," Dr. Israel Goldstein, president of the American Jewish Congress, said yesterday in a statement marking the opening of Brotherhood Week. The annual observance is under the sponsorship of the National Conference of Christians and Jews.
Columbia University announced yesterday the major details of its bicentennial celebration next year on the theme "Man's Right to Knowledge and the Free Use Thereof."

AN impressive assembly of recent acquisitions has gone on view in third - floor galleries at the Museum of Modern Art. Simultaneously the museum, through John Hay Whitney, chairman of the board of trustees, has issued a statement which should go far toward clearing up some widely held misconceptions of the role of the museum and its collections.

The Soviet Government has adopted a policy of banning Jewish technicians from strategic plants in border areas, reports of recent refugees from the Soviet Union indicate. This policy is being followed even in cases where it means that such plants must operate less efficiently than otherwise.

Milton Zahner, 39-year-old butcher who studied real estate "ads' in his spare time, answered one ad too many Friday and found himself talking to a policewoman He waived examination on a grand larceny charge in Felony Court yesterday and was held without bail by Magistrate John R. Starkey for grand jury action.

ROME, Feb. 14 -- The Vatican newspaper L'Osservatore Romano protested strongly today against the decree published by the Polish Official Gazette Feb. 10 declaring the appointment, transfer and dismissal of ecclesiastical personnel in Poland to be the exclusive concern of the Government authorities.
HARTFORD, Feb. 14 -- A Samoyed, Ch. Silver Spray of Wychwood. went to best in show tonight in the twenty-fourth event of the First Company Governor's Foot Guard A. A.

UNLESS one examines the hole in the green shutters carefully, the mark looks like a rust spot. Closer up, however, it is easy to see -- the torn edges of the hole, furling back like petals of iron, mark the passage of a bullet fired too low to hit its mark, but aimed from the street to pass directly over the writer's desk.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Feb. 14 -- Dominating both the track and field events Army's well-balanced track team routed Princeton, 69 1/2 to 39 1/2, in a dual meet in the Field House today.

THE fiftieth anniversary of Camille Pissarro's death is pleasingly celebrated in a little exhibition at the Jewish Museum, mostly of etchings and lithographs as well as three paintings, from the collection of Michael Zagayski.

TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 14 -- A special train with food for 3,000 persons was being loaded in Teheran tonight for the relief of Turud and other hill villages in eastern Iran where, on Thursday, the ground opened up and houses crumbled in an earthquake that reportedly took about a thousand lives.

The Chinese, who invented gunpowder, exploded an inordinate amount of it yesterday in the vicinity of Mott, Pell and Doyers Streets. Since the powder came in the form of neat little firecrackers from Hong Kong and Macau, no one was hurt, and the annual celebration of the Chinese New Year was an unqualified success.
