ROME, Feb. 14 -- The Italian tanker Miriella, carrying 4,600 tons of Iranian crude oil, put into Porto Marghera, the port of Venice, this morning at the end of a twenty-four-day voyage from Abadan, Iran. She had scarcely tied up when a legal battle began between the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company land the charterers of the tanker to establish ownership of her oil.

" TWO'S COMPANY," a revue built around the reputation of Bette Davis, opened at the Alvin last Dec. 15. The critics, regardless of whatever else they may have said, singled out a droll, deceptively innocent chap by the name of Hiram Sherman for a strong round of applause.

THE specter of poverty no longer haunts the twenty-fifth anniversary presentation of the annual "Oscar" awards by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences and so the event will be held with all the traditional lavish trimmings on March 19 at the Pantages Theatre in Hollywood.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The groundswell in the House of Representatives for quick action on tax reduction has reached such proportions, apparently without the full realization of President Eisenhower and his fiscal advisers, that nothing short of a firm stand by the Administration is likely to stop it now.

HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 14 -- Captain Fred Gieg led Dartmouth to a 60-51 basketball victory over Princeton before a capacity crowd in the Alumni Gymnasium tonight. Gieg scored 15 points, high for the night, and led the efficient Dartmouth rebounding corps.

Although certain spot goods are moving well and bringing premium prices, textile manufacturers are finding the going hard in their efforts to sell the great bulk of their cotton, rayon, and acetate fabrics.

By mid-February we have begun to weary of winter, and wish, no matter what the weather is like, that spring were really at hand. The wish always outruns the fact by at least a month, and oftener by two. A mild February day is greeted like a promise; a February snowstorm, normal as sunrise, is suffered grudgingly.

DRINKING vessels through the ages are the nucleus of an exhibition opening at the Brooklyn Museum on Wednesday and continuing through April 19. As arranged by Helen McKearin, it includes more than 350 containers for liquids of various sorts and a series of paintings, woodcuts and tapestries showing these and similar objects in use. There are recipes, too, some useful, others that seem remote.

THERE is no telling how many telephones rang the night Fanny Brice died, as her youngest and last public sadly told each other there could be no more "Baby Snooks" on the air. There is no telling, but there were a great many indeed.

ALBANY, Feb. 14 -- Governor Dewey approved tonight without comment a bill that is expected to save New York City $300,000 a year in sanitation expenses and make for more efficient enforcement of its sanitary regulations.

MOSCOW, Feb. 14 -- Pravda charged today that there was a "direct connection" between "subversive activity that the intelligence service of Israel is carrying on against the Soviet Union" and the bomb explosion in the Soviet legation at Tel Aviv.

A PICTURE chronicle of our national capital, this begins with an account of the Indians who once inhabited this region, goes on to the planning and building of the city and the story of L'Enfant, the architect who was responsible for its design.

FOR the sake of filmic make believe, grips and technicians were busily gathered the other day in Piazza Campitelli, a stone's throw from the ruins of ancient Rome, in a valiant attempt to hide and obliterate a seasonally unusual, stubbornly sunny and bright blue sky with the aid of various firehoses, smokepots, damp rags and sticks, and considerable yelling.

THESE lines are from Virgil's "Aeneid": "Broken in war sand thrust back by the fates, the Danaan chiefs built a horse of mountainous bulk, and interweave its ribs with planks of fir. Here, within its dark sides, they stealthily enclose the choicest men * * *."

Since the onset of the cold war, there have been two contending pressures on Europe: United States pressure to effect greater unity of its European allies, and Communist pressure -- much of it through harassing actions against West Berlin -- to discourage unification.

Two methods of accounting are recognized for income tax purposes: the cash basis and the accrual basis. The first reflects actual cash receipts and disbursements, except that constructive receipts may be included. The second method takes into account income earned, although not received; and expenses incurred, although not paid.

THIS is the fourth in a series of present-day African adventure tales and, unfortunately, the last -- for Dock Hogue died shortly after finishing it. Here young Bob Clifton faces enemies more dangerous in their way than the snarling lions, the thundering elephant herds or the wily witch doctors with which he contended when he and his father established their vast coffee plantation in the jungle.

I have just finished reading William R. Mathews' "Tucson Looks at the World" (Jan. 25) and it contains many important points which should be considered by every American. Too many citizens feel that any negotiation with Stalin has to end with disastrous effects to the United States.

BOCA RATON, Fla., Feb. 14 -- Beverly Hanson of Indio, Calif., gained her first major victory as a professional by taking the first section today of the Weathervane golf championship with a 79, 69 -- 148.

In the subterranean labyrinth that houses the mechanical "heart" of Rockefeller Center, 25-year-old Vittorio Rampini goes about his rounds as a watch engineer's helper. His job is to check the center's many air-conditioning units. In his khaki work clothes he looks no different from the others employed to keep the plaza buildings operating, but Vittorio is no typical worker.

VIENNA, Feb. 15 -- Austrians will vote next Sunday in a general election that will be the third since the liberation of 1945 and perhaps the most interesting. It will be significant for Europe, since it will be the first of a series in which, in Austria, Italy, Germany and perhaps later France, more than a third of the voters of Western Europe will go to the polls.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Feb. 15 -- Members of the African National Congress, bearing banners reading "Freedom in Our Lifetime" and carrying placards calling for resistance to the Nationalist Government, paraded past the Parliament building here today.
BAD GODESBERG, Germany, Feb. 15 -- A Princess lives across the street from us and a gentleman nearly lost his trousers. That is how we know that the Fasching, the German pre-Lenten carnival, is on.

This week's art program is unusually interesting and widely varied. On Wednesday the National Institute of Arts and Letters will open the fifth annual exhibition of work by candidates for grants, and the Brooklyn Museum will have an exhibition entitled "Here's How," a collection of drinking vessels and paintings of drinking scenes.

GENEVA, Feb. 15 -- The United States Government has been caught in the middle of an old but somewhat dressed-up European quarrel over monetary policy, and both American and European monetary experts on this side of the Atlantic are wondering whether the issues are clear to Washington's new policy makers.
Witty Brothers is completing an experiment in the men's clothing field. The company is selling its spring and summer Dacron suits in the winter months at regular prices.

With surprise and not a little dismay we noted an article recently, "Mahoney says 'We must beat Russia.'" The point of the quotations in the article seemed to be that it would enhance the nation's prestige to employ the same dubious subsidization of athletes used by the Soviet Union.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 15 -- Forty-nine American clergymen, educators and other public figures have appealed to President Eisenhower to take action in the United States and the United Nations against a possible extension to other countries of the Soviet anti-Semitic campaign.
A teen-aged couple returning from a St. Valentine dance was killed by a hit-and-run motorist at 2:40 A. M. yesterday in Brooklyn.

In an effort to underbid ship-line costs in the North Atlantic trade, Pan American World Airways announced yesterday it would propose to the International Air Transport Association a 45 per cent cut in air cargo rates for bulk shipments. The proposal will be made to a special committee of I. A. T. A. at a meeting in the Lexington Hotel today.

ALBANY, Feb. 15 -- The State Commerce Department asserted today that the high relative cost of workman's compensation insurance in the state was creating "a serious threat to New York's economy" that might result in increased unemployment.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 15 -- A hungry mob has sacked a cooperative food shop in one northeastern town, according to news dispatches received here today, and further trouble is feared elsewhere in Brazil unless some quick relief is found.

Solomon, the English pianist, gave his first New York recital of the season Saturday night at Hunter College Auditorium. His interpretations at this event were individual, rich in interesting detail, sharply differentiated in style. Suavity, refinement and grace were fundamental elements in his work, but power also was at his disposal when required.

To promote good will between the city's Puerto Rican citizenry and their neighbors, the Mayor's Committee on Puerto Rican Affairs in New York City, 250 Church Street, has set up a subcommittee on neighborhood relations.
Sixteen years after he first won the national amateur racquets championship Robert Grant 3d carried it off for the tenth time yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 15 -Spokesmen for the education profession declared here today that the 27,000,000 children now in the elementary and high schools of this country receive a better education, both in fundamental skills and in Citizenship training, than the pupils of the past.

The many thousands of Lithuanians in all parts of the world, including more than a million loyal Americans of Lithuanian birth or descent, today observe in sorrow but with renewed hope and confidence the national holiday of their former homeland -- the thirty-fifth anniversary of the proclamation of Lithuania's independence.
ROME, Feb. 15 -- The heavy deficit Italian international trade suffered in 1952 has jeopardized the policy of trade liberalization that the Italian Government has pursued since the middle of 1950.

ALBANY, Feb. 15 -- Two Queens Republican legislators proposed today the creation of a special state commission to develop a long-range solution for New York City's fiscal problems so that "the yearly frantic scramble to obtain more state aid and new city powers without adequate planning" could be avoided in the future.

The Federal Maritime Board announced over the week-end that it had denied a motion on the part of the North Atlantic Continental Freight Conference, an organization of shipping lines, to dismiss a complaint against the conference system made by the Department of Agriculture.

If Christians will live "the unadulterated teachings of Jesus of Nazareth and implement these principles into democracy, communism will soon become a thing of the past, the Rev. Dr. Dana McLean Greeley declared yesterday at the Unitarian Church of All Souls, Lexington Avenue and Eightieth Street.

A pillow fight among teen-age narcotics patients in the Riverside Hospital on North Brother Island touched off a call for police reinforcements last night, but all was quiet before they arrived. There were no casualties.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 15 -West German industrialists are planning to raise a fund of 35,000,000 deutschemarks ($8,333,000) to finance the campaign of Government coalition parties in the forthcoming general elections.

CHICAGO, Feb. 15 -- Grain trade zoomed in volume on the Board of Trade last week, the increase representing heavy liquidation by longs in all pits. Business was especially active in coarse grains, with corn purchases the largest of any grain at 99,750,000 bushels, compared with 37,326,000 a year ago. Oats were a close second, purchases running up a total of 97,674,000 bushels, compared with 39,170,000 the previous week and 34,427,000 a year ago.

BERLIN, Feb. 15 -- Although East Germany announced today that its industrial production last year was 103 per cent of that planned, its report and other official sources tell of shortages that have left many homes without light or heat in the dead of winter.

Festival Mass, a soaring, jaggedly bold and most unorthodox setting of the famous liturgy by the Czech composer, Leos Janacek, received its first United States performance last night when it was presented at Carnegie Hall in the opening concert of Robert Show's Choral Masterwork Series.

Some lively discussion on what play means in the young child's life may be prompted by two recently released films on this subject. Both are intended for parent associations or other interested groups and are available now.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Standard Oil of California announced today price increases which will raise the retail cost of gasoline a maximum of 2.1 cents a gallon at Standard service stations in five Pacific Coast states and Hawaii and Alaska.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 15 -- Dr. Moshe Sneh charged today that Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion had approved the blowing up of the King David Hotel in Jerusalem by the Irgun Zvai Leumi in 1946 in which more than seventy Britons, Jews and Arabs were killed Mr. Ben-Gurion had denounced the outrage at the time and organized sanctions against the terrorist Irgun.

Mary Bothwell, Canadian soprano, was heard in her annual recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. Accompanied at the piano by Paul Meyer, she presented a program containing "Dich theure Halle" from "Tannhaeuser," the "Liebestod" from "Tristan und Isolde," two of the Wesendonk songs of Wagner, a group of lieder by Wolf and a final group of offerings by Strauss.
At least three persons from the New York area were aboard the National Airlines DC-6 that went down Saturday in the Gulf of Mexico.

Influenced by the designs of furniture made and used in the farm houses of Normandy many years ago is a new furniture group styled by Erik Bolin. Consisting of pieces for the living, dining and bedrooms, it is on view at the old Hickory Furniture Company, 40 West Fifty-first Street.

There is a pattern of racketeering in the fresh-food, garment-trucking and building industries here that is "strikingly similar" to that exposed on the waterfront, the New York City Anti-Crime Committee said yesterday.

Production of men's clothing during 1952 was well below normal. Increases during the last few months of the year however indicate that substantial improvement will be shown during the first half of 1953, according to Harry A. Cobrin, executive secretary of the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U. S. A.

TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 15 -- Manna from heaven fell today on the poor Iranian village of Turud, which was shaken to pieces by an earthquake Thursday. A ton of bread, a gift from the United States, was dropped to surviving villagers by a United States Navy plane.

The city's Department of Public Works was engaged last year on a program of constructing new public projects totaling $241,104,000, a record for work under way in any one year, Frederick H. Zurmuhlen, Commissioner of Public Works, told Mayor Impellitteri yesterday.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Feb. 15 -- Giving the thumbsup sign of the nonwhite resistance movement, 874 delegates from 274 organizations -- Negro, Asian and white -- voted unanimously here today for a nation-wide work stoppage on teh eve of the national elections.

Cotton prices in the domestic market held to a narrow trading range last week but closed the period in slightly lower territory. At the close of trading on Friday active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were off 9 to 27 points, or 45 cents to $1.35 a bale, from the levels of the previous week.
Hollywood, Italy and Austria will be represented in new films arriving in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

AMSTERDAM Feb. 15 -- The extent of the flood damage gradually is becoming known, along with its subsequent effect on the economic and financial situation. A tentative estimate by the Prime Minister, Dr. Willem Drees, put the damage at around 1,000,000,000 guilders.

SAN ANTONIO, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Tony Holguin, a youngster with a broad grin, hit a golf jackpot and gladdened the hearts of his hometown folks today as he posted a 3-under-par 68 to win the $10,000 Texas Open with a 72-hole total of 264.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 15 -- A sudden surge in the perpetual stress of illegal immigration from Mexico into the United States has Federal officials mystified. During January, Mexican "wet backs" -- so called because many swim the Rio Grande -- swarmed across the 1,600-mile international border at an estimated rate of upward of 175 an hour, twenty-four hours a day.

SARANAC LAKE, N. Y., Feb. 15 -- Guttorm Berge, 23-year-old Norwegian who finished third in the 1952 Olympic Games, today demonstrated brilliant technique in the face of tremendous odds to lead a field of ninety in the New York State slalom ski championship.

ZURICH, Feb. 15 -- Speaking before a distinguished international audience at St. Gall Commercial High School last Monday, Robert Schuman, who on May 9, 1950, began the movement that culminated in the creation of the European Coal and Steel Community, which began operating last week, restated its aims and principles to allay fears now prevailing in all Organization of European Economic Cooperation non-member nations.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 15 -- A representative of Mexico's communal farmers called today for a transformation of communal farms into small private holdings as the only way to solve the serious problems facing Mexican agriculture.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 15 -- A 4-year-old cream-colored miniature poodle imported from Wales, Ch. Braeval Biscuit, became best in show tonight in the thirty-first event of the Elm City Kennel Club.

The executive committee of the American Petroleum Institute has endorsed the principles of the national oil policy adopted by the National Petroleum Council in 1949. Frank M. Porter, president of the institute, announced over the week-end.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 15 -- In an attempt to block the development and exploitation of Bolivian oil fields by United States interests, the Argentine Government has delivered a strong diplomatic protest to the Bolivian Foreign Office. La Paz has rejected the protest.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- congregation of 1,500, including ranking members of the executive, legislative and judicial branches of the Government, attended the traditional Red Mass at St. Matthew's Roman Catholic Cathedral today. The "blessings of God" were asked for the country's leaders.

Theodore Morrison, the poet who for twenty-eight years has been a teacher of fiction writing at Harvard University and director of the Bread Loaf Writers Conference, has "waived his pedagogic immunity" and produced a first novel, "The Stones of the House."

THE heart went out of Mel Ott on that fateful July day in 1948 when Horace Stoneham, his boss, unexpectedly notified Master Melvin that he was through as manager of the Giants. The one-time Boy Wonder of the Polo Grounds hung on in various roles for the next few years after that, a couple of seasons as a minor-league talent scout and a couple of seasons as a minor-league manager.

Wagner's "Tristan und Isolde" will be returned after a season's absence to the Metropolitan Opera repertoire Monday evening. Feb. 23, to open the sixteenth week at the house. Margaret Harshaw, as Isolde, and Hans Hotter, as Marke. will be singing those roles for the first time in their Metropolitan careers.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Mrs. J. Cornelius Rathborne, the wife of a New Orleans business man and a member of a socially prominent Maryland family, also was among those on board.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Feb. 15 (AP) -- Stan Benham of Lake Placid, winner of two world bobsled championships, piloted his four-man team to victory today in the national A. A. U. one-mile event and took the Billie Fiske trophy.

At a service yesterday morning where the entire offering was donated to the relief of the suffering people of the Netherlands, the Rev. James A. Pike called for prayers and continued financial aid to that country as an expression of Christian love.

Julius Rosenberg, 34 years old, and his wife Ethel, 36, atom bomb spies condemned to death, read newspapers and listened to the radio in the Sing Sing death-house yesterday as their attorney, Emanuel H. Bloch, worked on new legal moves to save their lives.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Adlai E. Stevenson, the defeated Democratic candidate for President in 1952, came to Washington today for his first post-election meeting with President Eisenhower and sidestepped questions about whether he might make another White House bid in 1956.
PARIS, Feb. 15 -- French exports dropped by 10 per cent between December, 1952, and January, 1953. The figures for these months are 76,700,000,000 francs compared with 68,800,000,000 francs.

The national offices of the Boy Scouts of America will be moved from New York to New Jersey in 1954, Dr. Arthur A. Schuck, chief Scout executive, announced last night. The move, which will coordinate all national operations of the organization, will be made as soon as a two-story office building and a one-story warehouse are constructed on a forty-acre tract in North Brunswick Township.

ONLY a little over two years ago Sinclair Lewis died in Rome. He was just a month short of his sixty-sixth birthday, the most celebrated American writer of the twentieth century, the first American to win the Nobel Prize for Literature, a wealthy but lonely, restless, deeply unhappy man. He had written twenty-two novels, of which four, perhaps five, are certain to be read for many years to come.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 15 (AP) -- The police said today that four men had been charged with planting the bomb that blasted the Soviet Legation here last Monday. Fourteen others have been charged with conspiring in the plot.

The fifth Composers Forum of the season Saturday night at the McMillin Theatre of Columbia University was broadcast as part of WNYC's annual American Music Festival. Heard both as composers and responders to questions from the audience were Hunter Johnson and Jacob Avshalomoff.

The New York City Anti-Crime Committee, whose report for 1952 is made public today, has done an excellent job in investigating and disclosing gangster and corrupt infiltration on the waterfront and in the perishable foods, garment trucking and building industries. We applaud its decision to continue its "hue and cry" against racketeering until intelligent public opinion is aroused to the need for action.

The date of the twentieth annual outing of the Municipal Bond Club of New York has been set at June 12, E. Noman Peterson, president, announced yesterday. David H. Callaway Jr. has been appointed general chairman.

Four neighbors of this country shared equally the highest rating as export markets given in the forty-ninth semi-annual survey on commercial credit and collection conditions in Latin America conducted by the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau.

A syndicate of builders represented by Jacob Mishler, attorney, has sold the apartment house for 225 families at 144-02 Seventy-eighth Road, Kew Gardens, Queens, to Leo A. Bercow and Waler Berger, operators, who were represented by Charles H. Kelman, attorney.

I read in your issue of Feb. 11 some statements by the Dominican dictator Rafael L. Trujillo. In the last paragraph he is quoted as saying that he ''helped (Spanish) Republican refugees, but that most of them had turned out to be Communists and had left the Republic for the United States and Mexico."

GENEVA, Feb. 15 -- The contracting parties to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade have agreed provisionally through their intercessional committee that no special modifications or additions to the world-wide trade agreement, whose principle is nondiscriminatory tariff treatment by all signatories, will be necessary to incorporate Japan into the free world's trading system.
In Ezra Taft Benson, his Secretary of Agriculture, President Eisenhower obviously has a Cabinet member whose basic economic philosophy closely parallels his own.

In a pre-Lenten sermon at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday, the Rev. Edwin B. Broderick stressed the importance of "wholesome, elevating reading" between now and Easter and at the same time warned parents of their "serious moral obligation" at all times to protect children from "morally offensive" reading matter.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 15 -- Screen rights to "Diane de Poitiers," a fifty-page unpublished manuscript by the late John Erskine, have been purchased from the author's estate by Edwin H. Knopf. The story deals with romantic intrigue in the court of King Henry II of France.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 15 -- Authors of the screen plays of fifteen pictures released during 1952 have been nominated for the best writing awards, to be presented by the Screen Writers Guild at its annual ceremony March 10 at the Hollywood Palladium. Ballots will be put in the mail tomorrow for voting by the organization's membership. The closing date is Feb. 24.

Track fans still were talking yesterday of the spectacular finish of the 600-yard run in Saturday's National A. A. U. championships. Mal Whitfield, Ollie Sax and Reggie Pearman plunged across the line abreast in this thriller, with the victory, and a championship mark of 1:10.4, going to the Olympic 800-meter champion on a split decision.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 15 -- The consensus in the steel trade at the week-end was that the open-ending of the controlled materials plan will not be felt much until the beginning of the second quarter. Here is the way things looked from this steel center:

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 15 -- Part of the country-wide election of delegates to the Socialist Union of the Working People of Yugoslavia, the new name for the People's Front, has been completed. So has the draft statute for the organization, which includes a frank statement of readiness to join "progressive democratic movements" elsewhere in the world.

Women headed by Mrs. Henry L. O'Brien, chairman of women's committees, New York Chapter of the American Red Cross, and including Mrs. Richard S. Atterbury, are aiding in the plans for the Greater New York luncheon to be held today in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria opening the 1953 Red Cross fund campaign.
TOKYO, Monday, Feb. 16 (AP) -- United Nations Command commuique 1,527 for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Monday, Korea time:

The noise of aircraft leaving and landing at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens -- which has been particularly irksome to the area's residents on summer nights when windows are open -- will be reduced for them by an operational change at the field.

Although Stephen Vincent Benet wrote "John Brown's Body" for readers, it is a piece of vivid theatre now. For the reading that Judith Anderson, Raymond Massey and Tyrone Power installed at the Century Saturday evening is a stage performance of fire and beauty.

BOSTON, Feb. 15 (UP) -- Milt Schmidt, scoring for the first time in forty-two days, led the Bruins to a 1-0 victory over Montreal tonight and gave Boston a vital lift in its drive for a play-off berth in the National Hockey League.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) -The American Farm Bureau Federation said today a proposed economic conference between Western European nations and Russia might be the "opening wedge by which the Soviet Union hopes to divide the alliance of free nations for mutual defense."

TOKYO, Monday, Feb. 16 (AP) -Two United States jet interceptors fired on two Russian-type fighter planes over Northern Japan today and damaged one in a chase back toward the Kurile Islands, the Far East Air Forces said.

SYRACUSE, Feb. 15 -- Syracuse University's well-balanced ski forces captured today's jumping event during an afternoon blizzard to take the Western division championship in the two-day meet of the Eastern Intercollegiate Ski Association.

ALBANY, Feb. 15 -- A special joint legislative committee, with Governor Dewey's active encouragement, recommended today that all automobile owners in New York State be required to carry liability insurance and that insurance companies be required to set up a plan for compensating innocent victims of hit-and-run accidents, stolen car operators and uninsured out-of-state drivers.

The Military Sea Transport Service headquarters in New York said last night that it had received a radio message that the leaking Italian motorship Tripolitania was sinking in the central Mediterranean, but that the 119 passengers and crewmen had been rescued.

Representative Jacob K. Javits of the Twenty-first Congressional District announced yesterday his willingness to run for Mayor on the Republican and Liberal party tickets if he bad the support of the good government forces of the city, among which he included these parties.

MIAMI, Feb. 15 -- Because of injuries suffered in yesterday's running of the Everglades Stakes at Hialeah Race Course, the Greentree Stable's 3-year-old Straight Face, who finished ninth in the role of odds-on favorite, is a "very very" doubtful prospect for the $100,000 Flamingo Stakes to be run over the same mile-and-a-furlong route on the last day of this month.

MANILA, Monday, Feb. 16 (AP) -- In the Philippines' stormiest national tennis singles final, tiny Felicisimo Ampon last night successfully defended his championship against Italy's Fausto Gardini, who tussled with an official, chased a photographer and drew a shower of empty pop bottles from the booing crowd. Ampon won the wild match, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 3, 0 -- 6, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 4.

The City Center of Music and Drama is seeking an enabling act in the State Legislature to permit municipal authorities to lease the premises, 131 West Fifty-fifth Street, at $1 a year on a long-term basis. The group is seeking the same privilege as that enjoyed by the Brooklyn Academy of Music, which pays the city a rental fee of $1 a year.

The bitter attacks on Secretary of Agriculture Benson last week by several Democratic members of Congress give clear notice that the problem of falling agricultural prices is moving into the center of the Washington stage. The questions involved are fundamental and important.
Motifs suggestive of the approaching spring and the warm summer to follow make up many of the fresh-looking designs included in collections of moderately priced decorating fabrics.

ZIERIKZEE, the Netherlands, Feb. 15 -- Despite imminent flood danger, some of the people of this eleven-century-old town have defied a Government evacuation order, some are being taken to boats by the police and many are reported to have gone into hiding.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Feb. 15 (AP) -- The New York Knickerbockers tightened their grip on the Eastern Division lead by beating the Syracuse Nationals, 85 to 81, in a foul-strewn National Basketball Association game tonight.

The voice of the Christian conscience has as much right to speak out and influence our Government as a labor union, a real estate lobby or a manufacturers association, the Rev. Dr. Albert J. Penner declared yesterday morning in his sermon at the Broadway Tabernacle (Congregational) Church, at Fifty-sixth Street.

LONDON, Feb. 15 (UP) -- Surging spring tides smashed through hurriedly plugged dikes in Belgium tonight, but in the Netherlands and Britain the newest battle against the sea appeared to have been won.
There was not one thing the boys competing in the national interscholastic track and field championships at Madison Square Garden this past Saturday had in common. It was nervousness.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Whitney N. Seymour, past president of the Association of the Bar of New York, was appointed chairman today of the seven-member committee of civilians to make a progress report on operations of the code of military justice of the Department of Defense, now two years old.

The seventh annual Brotherhood Award of the Men's Club of Congregation B'nai Jeshurun was presented at its community center, 270 West Eighty-ninth Street, yesterday afternoon to John J. McCloy, former United States High Commissioner for Germany.

Three new records were set as the host school took the point-score lead yesterday in the third annual Fordham Prep relay carnival in the Fordham University gymnasium. The meet, with entries from nineteen schools, was scheduled outdoors, but was moved into the gym because of the rain.

The American Cyanamid Company, manufacturer of chemical, pharmeceutical and other allied products, in its annual report for 1952, released today, showed a decline in consolidated net earnings to $26,612,000 from $34,788,000 earned in 1951.

MOSCOW, Feb. 15 -- Important Chinese economic officials who came to Moscow six months ago with Premier and Foreign Minister Chou En-lai are still in the Soviet capital, possibly conducting discussions-with Soviet economic leaders.

VALLEY STREAM, L. I., Feb. 15 -- The son and daughter-in-law of Alvin Starkins, 62-year-old retired Richmond Hill patrolman who was found dead of gunshot wounds in the basement of his home here last night, were arraigned today in First District Court, Mineola, on a first-degree murder charge.

Rain, snow and cold blanketed most of the nation yesterday as Hew York was shrouded with fog and soaked with more than an inch of rain. The weather hampered operations at La Guardia Airport for more than seven hours.
MIAMI. Fla., Feb. 15 (AP) -- Allie Reynolds proved today you can't beat a Yankee when the chips are down -- even on a golf course.

AMMAN, Jordan, Feb. 7 -- One hundred acres of grass is sprouting in the desert thirty miles north of here. It is a result of a rain-saving method developed in the western United States, but to the Arabs it is nothing less than a miracle.

TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 15 -- An Iranian Army detachment that set out to help suppress a reported insurrection among Bakhtiari tribesmen in southern Iran has been ambushed, according to a dispatch today from Ahwaz to the newspaper Ettelaat.

The sort of programming that can spell only trouble for the television industry was exemplified in two shows over the week-end. One was "Time for Adventure," presented at 10 o'clock Sunday morning over WNBT, and the other was "Tales of Tomorrow," seen at 9:30 P. M. Friday over the A. B. C. network.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The Democratic minority in the House of Representatives will ask that an authorized spokesman state the Eisenhower Administration's position before the Ways and Means Committee votes tomorrow on a specific proposal for a tax cut.

William Christian Brossman, 80year-old retired clothing cutter, of 1411 Gates Avenue, Brooklyn, finally lost a gallant fight for his life at Wyckoff Heights Hospital early this morning. He was pronounced dead at 1:20 A. M., the second time within fourteen hours.

To obtain full benefit of the nutrients in corn meal and hominy grits, cook them for a short period with a minimum of baking powder or soda. These words of advice came from the United States Department of Agriculture's Texas Experiment Station.
The Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken had a word of advice yesterday for those tempted to give up prayer.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Communist labor union officials who resigned from the party only so that they could take the non-Communist oath under the Taft-Hartley Law were believed today to be facing prosecution on another count -- the false swearing to their beliefs.

Olga Coelho, the soprano-guitarist and singer of Latin-American folk songs, gave an exceptionally interesting program last night in Town Hall. Mme. Coelho never chooses unimportant songs to present to her audience. The songs may be slight of structure or sentiment, for that matter, but they are significantly characteristic of the country and locale from which they come.

This week, for the first time in its history, the Philippine press is celebrating a National Press Week. The emphasis in a wide range of meetings is on the freedom of the press, of which the Filipinos are strongly and rightly jealous. Attention will be given also to some of the achievements of this press in the past.

It is unfortunate -- and remarkable -- that in our English language the adjective generally has an opprobrious or uncomplimentary connotation -- especially since the residents of the lowlands of Holland have time and again demonstrated their courage and tenacity in the face of tremendous odds.

William F. (Billy) Talbert of New York, ranked sixth nationally, continued his advance in his bid for a third national indoor tennis singles title yesterday by turning back King Van Nostrand of the Bronx, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 0, in a second-round engagement at the Seventh Regiment Armory.

The power of newspaper advertising received two very tangible tributes yesterday. In Chicago, Seymour Mintz, advertising vice president of the Admiral Corporation, attributed its leadership in television sales to heavy newspaper schedules and in the same city it was learned Evinrude Motors Company will go heavily into newspapers for the first time for its outboard motors.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Mount Katmai, a slumbering volcano about 300 miles southwest of here, blew up late today in what residents of a near-by village said was a major eruption. No adjacent settlements were believed in immediate danger, however.
TOPEKA, Kan., Feb. 15 (UP) -- Kansas Republicans were split widely today over President Eisenhower's expression of confidence in C. Wesley Roberts, Republican National Chairman.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, proved by his speech in New York on Saturday night that his sense of humor has survived his defeat in the late Presidential election. But in the course of his address he said one or two things that showed a lack of knowledge of what has been happening here, and demonstrated the necessity for doing something to restore the bipartisan exchange of information.

Several thousand persons heard speeches and adopted resolutions yesterday in various parts of the city condemning the Soviet Union for its anti-Semitic policy and calling for increased military and financial aid for Israel.

TOKYO, Monday, Feb. 16 -- Two dozen United Nations F-84 Thunderjet planes flew in waves along the southern bank of the Yalu River in North Korea yesterday and dropped bombs on two generators of the important Supung (Suiho) hydroelectric plant.

DAVOS, Switzerland, Feb. 15 -- Tenley Albright, 17-year-old ice ballerina from Boston, became the first United States girl ever to win the world figure-skating championship today. She received the unanimous vote of a seven-man panel of judges.

CHICAGO, Feb. 15 (UP) -- Gordie Howe scored his 200th and 201st National Hockey League goals tonight as the Detroit Red Wings dropped the Chicago Black Hawks into fifth place by beating the Hawks, 4 -- 1.

The Government of Pakistan has referred to the Secretariat of the United Nations a detailed complaint that India is diverting vital water from the source streams of the Indus River. This charge has been made previously and it constitutes one of the more grievous of the causes of friction between the two countries.

Where does atomic power stand today? After seven years of discussion we can say no more than that atomic power will propel a submarine by 1954 and perhaps an aircraft carrier by 1957. The Atomic Energy Commission has fostered industry's interest in atomic power by encouraging eight companies to consider the possibilities, but can do no more.

There is one paragraph in a book now on this desk that should be made required reading for a lot of planners and lawmakers. The book is a report on "Mobilization of Domestic Capital in Certain Countries of Asia and the Far East"* prepared in Bangkok by the United Nations Economic Commission for the Far East (E. C. A. F. E.). Here is the paragraph:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The chief threat to continued unregulated installment buying of automobiles, refrigerators and other appliances lies not in the current record volume of consumer debt but in published speculation that the Eisenhower Administration will try to bring back consumer credit controls.

The first month of the Eisenhower Administration has been marked by a sharp acceleration of action in the international sphere. After a long period of drift the nations of the world are suddenly stirred up, partly by signs of a bolder and more independent attitude on the part of the United States, partly by the menacing and defiant moves launched by the Soviet Union.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 15 -- Seventeen bodies were recovered from the Gulf of Mexico tonight before darkness halted a wide air and sea search of the area where an airliner with forty-six persons aboard crashed into the storm-swept waters.

Profiting on their rivals' inability to find the range early, the Toronto Maple Leafs defeated the New York Rangers in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. The visitors, enjoying a 2-0 lead at one time, managed to remain in front despite a strong closing bid by the Blues and took the victory by the score of 2 to 1.
CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Feb. 15 (AP) -- Jim Campbell of Chicago and Barbara Marchetti of Detroit won the senior men's and women's titles today in the national indoor speed skating meet.

A panel of high school students discovered last evening that it was difficult to define precisely the meaning of democracy, but they seemed to agree, in a spirited discussion, that the very fact they could talk freely about the weaknesses of American democratic life was exemplary of its vitality.

WESTBURY, L. I., Feb. 15 -- Former Mayor Dominic J. Piscitelli, now a village trustee and Police Commissioner here, was charged with assault and resisting a police officer last night by a policeman investigating the fatal shooting of a man and woman in a local tavern.

The performance of "John Brown's Body" tomorrow night at the Century Theatre has been taken over to raise funds for the Vocational Advisory Service. Mrs. L. Emmett Holt and Mrs. Walter E. Beer Jr. are co-chairmen of the benefit committee.

Not very long ago there were despairing wails that the two-party system in the United States was dead. The wailers meant that the Republican party was dead. Last November this belief was definitely proven wrong. Now it is up to the Democratic party to take up the role of the loyal opposition.

Now is the time for New York City Democrats to start thinking about their candidate for Mayor. Otherwise, the politicians, who have lost touch with people, will have the job done, and once again the majority party will go down to defeat.

HELSINKI, Feb. 15 (UP) -- Soviet skaters scored a smashing victory in the fiftieth world speed-skating championships today when Oleg Goncharenko won the 10,000-meter race and Boris Shilkov captured the 1,500 meters.

The first rental housing development to be started in New Jersey under the terms of the Wherry Act will rise at Pinebrook and Hope Roads, Eatontown, where ground was broken recently by Maj. Gen. Kirk B. Lawton, commanding general of Fort Monmouth.

CHICAGO, Feb. 15 -- Grain prices leveled off after further declines early in the week, and registered fair recoveries later. Heavy short profit-taking afforded a cushion for belated liquidating sales. There was evidence of investment buying from time to time with active buying by mills against large flour sales.
SN FRANCISCO, Feb. 15--A curb on the stolen car racket was described today at the thirty-sixth annual convention of the National Automobile Dealers Association.

Consolidated net income of C. I. T. Financial Corporation reached $29,604,166 in 1952, the second highest level on record. This was equal to $7.71 a common share on the 3,580,948 shares outstanding at the 1952 year-end, and compared with $28,165,060, or $7.31 a share earned in 1951.

Key measures in Mayor Impellitteri's 1953-54 fiscal program, including his proposal for a transit authority designed to preserve the basic 10-cent fare on the municipal transit lines, will be introduced in the Legislature today, or tomorrow.

During the past week foreign exchanges fluctuated within a narrow range in a market that was extremely dull and lacked the enthusiasm of previous weeks. This was due in part to the abbreviated session caused by the holiday on Thursday, when banks here were closed in observance of Lincoln's birthday.

HELSINKI, Feb. 15 (UP) -- Soviet skaters scored a smashing victory in the fiftieth world speed-skating championships today when Oleg Goncharenko won the 10,000-meter race and Boris Shilkov captured the 1,500 meters.

The first rental housing development to be started in New Jersey under the terms of the Wherry Act will rise at Pinebrook and Hope Roads, Eatontown, where ground was broken recently by Maj. Gen. Kirk B. Lawton, commanding general of Fort Monmouth.

BUFFALO, Feb. 15 (AP) -- A low veil of mist covered western New York and Pennsylvania today, forcing the abandonment of plans to continue the air search for four Niagara University students missing since Friday in a hired airplane.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Feb. 15 -- The Dartmouth College ski team, led by Olympian Ralph Miller, outclassed all the opposition this week-end to win first honors in the annual Williams College winter carnival.

Music lovers who went to Town Hall yesterday afternoon prepared to attend the concert of the New Friends of Music found a notice on the door that began: "We regret that for reasons beyond our control, this afternoon's concert has been cancelled."

DENVER, Feb. 15 -- A religious group known as the Brotherhood of the White Temple has built an "atom-proof" retreat in the foothills of the Rocky Mountains near Denver and several hundred members of the cult apparently have retired there to await Armageddon.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 15 -- A record outpouring of $14,150,000 in contributions was made here today by Jewish communal leaders, representing every section of the country, as the United Jewish Appeal formally opened its 1953 campaign to meet critical Jewish needs throughout the world.

A certificate of merit will be presented today by the Red Cross to New York University for 2,500 pints of blood contributed by faculty members and students. Presentation of the award will be made in LaGuardia Hall, 100 Washington Square East, at 3 P. M. by Dr. William M. Markel, New York administrator of the Red Cross blood program, to Harold O. Voorhis, vice chancellor of the university.

Camilla Wicks was the soloist at the New York Philharmonic-Symphony's concert yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. She played Beethoven's Violin Concerto and her performance was evidence that the young artist has developed into a violinist of distinction.

The Prison Association of New York will warn the Legislature today that the state's prisons are not immune to the disorders that have erupted in twenty-three penal institutions across the country in the last eleven months.
Joseph P. Moloney, president of District 4 of the United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., has been appointed a fifth member of the C. I. O. Maritime Committee.

Today we turn our attention to the little miss, perhaps between the ages of 4 and 12. We offer suggestions for her Easter topcoat. She'll look attractive in any of the models illustrated, when she takes her place in "the parade."
NORFOLK, Va., Feb. 15 -- The two-week-old tugboat strike here has not been without an accident at local piers, authorities revealed today.

LONDON, Feb. 15 -- The encouraging feature of the revival of activity in the stock markets is the broadening interest in industrial equities. Several influences have combined to bring back investors' confidence in this market after the shake-out following restricted credit measures and the recession in trade after the slump in the wool and textile markets.
The ship's log will record that the superliner United States, four days out of Le Havre, docked yesterday morning at Pier 86, West Forty-sixth Street, in thirty minutes "without incident."

PARIS, Feb. 15 -- Extensive powers in the field of foreign affairs would be granted to the proposed six-nation European political authority under an agreement reached today by a working party drafting the text for a European constitution.

BENEVENTO, Italy, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Speeding at sixty-five miles an hour, the Bari-Naples express crashed into a closed switch here early today and nine of ten cars hurtled off the track. At least twenty-one Italians were killed and eighty injured, twenty-three seriously.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) -- The Defense Department today identified 50 additional Korean war casualties in a new list that included 15 killed, 33 wounded, 1 missing and 1 injured. It also reported 6 captured who were previously listed missing in action. The following were listed from New York (none from New Jersey or Connecticut):

The Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation sold $27,500,000 of new common stock at competitive bidding yesterday to a syndicate headed by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane, Kidder, Peabody Co. and White, Weld Co. The winning bid designated a price of $26,939 a share.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The Office of International Trade denied today all export privileges for eighteen months to Martin Enterprises of New York City and its partners, Bernard Martin and Alvin E. Shulman, for "export control violations in connection with shipments of stainless steel sheets to Brazil and Switzerland."

Hostesses who make a specialty of doing their own cooking and serving should welcome a new and fresh series of serving accessories that are being sold under the name of "multi-serve." Adaptable both to indoor and outdoor entertaining, the units can be combined in a multiplicity of ways that are sure to serve divergent needs and satisfy varying tastes.

BOSTON, Feb. 16 -- Handicapped persons, with a far greater life expectancy than was possible at the turn of the twentieth century, should receive total assistance to meet their total needs, Dr. Howard A. Rusk, Professor of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation at New York University, said today at the Harvard School of Public Health.

Several dinner parties will be given in private homes in advance of the performance of Stephen Vincent Benet's "John Brown's Body" on the night of Feb. 26 at the Century Theatre for the benefit of the Academy of American Poets.

The group of three million persons for whom forty-nine distinguished Americans appealed in a letter to President Eisenhower made public the other day are of Jewish faith. They might have been of any faith or of any race, for it is their situation, not their creed, that claims our attention.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 16 -- Directors of the Tradesmen's National Bank and Trust Company and the Land Title Bank and Trust Company voted today to merge.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 16 (Reuters) -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru today urged the building up of a "third area of nations who wish to work for peace and do not want to align themselves with any bloc."

ALBANY, Feb. 16 -- Legislation that would permit New York City's eight privately operated bus lines to finance the cost of the pending strike settlement without a fare increase was introduced in the Legislature today with the backing of Mayor Impellitteri.

CAIRO, Feb. 16 -- The action of the Soviet Union in breaking diplomatic relations with Israel and in loosing the Cominform's propaganda against Zionism has perhaps warmed the cockles of the Arab heart but it does not seem to have drawn the Arab world any closer to the Soviet orbit.

Stock prices yesterday returned virtually to their levels of a week earlier in a slow, drifting market that saw its best moments in the morning and closed near its lows. Rubbers and coppers were the firmest spots on the list, and rails the softest.

Although the official opening of Bernard Shaw's comedy, "Misalliance," at the New York City Center will not take place until tomorrow night, critics will see the production at a preview performance tonight and their reviews will appear in Thursday's newspapers.

Alben W. Barkley, former Vice-President of the United States, will be the principal speaker at a Brotherhood Week luncheon arranged by the New York Region of the National Conference of Christian and Jews on Friday at 12:30 P. M. in the Roosevelt Hotel.

TEL AVIV, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Israeli authorities have granted a patent to a local inventor for his "hydraulically driven differential" -- a unit which supposedly will make possible the manufacture of automobiles without clutch, drive-shaft, gear box or conventional brakes.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Following is the text of the letter from Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. to Secretary of Defense Charles E. Wilson ruling on title to offshore oil lands:

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 16 -- Juan B. Rosetti, Finance Minister, said today that the visit of President Juan Peron of Argentina to Chile, beginning Friday, would probably mark the opening of a period of "complementary economy" between the two countries, with mutual benefits to both.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Feb. 17 -- The Japanese Government has given full endorsement to the action of two United States Thunderjet pilots, who pursued and fired on two Russian-made fighter planes over Hokkaido Island yesterday, but the rest of the nation greeted the news with some trepidation

The Musicians Guild is almost too generous. In the three pieces on its program at Town Hall last night there was so much music -- not only in length but in density -- that it tended to overwhelm even the most conscientious of listeners. If this be a failing, charge it to the eagerness of the guild's members to make its concerts full and rewarding.

BOSTON, Feb. 16 -- Twenty-five manufacturing companies that turn out products largely unheard of before World War II will open tomorrow a three-day exhibition of what venture capital can do for struggling businesses.
The new-found optimism in Washington about the prospects of the European Defense Community is not supported by recent reports from Europe.

ALBANY, Feb. 16 -- Nature is out of balance in New York State, the Conservation Department revealed today in issuing a plea for intrepid trappers willing to tent up for a month in the Adirondacks to cut an "overabundance" of beaver.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The White House announced today that President Eisenhower would nominate Samuel Wilder King of Hawaii as Governor of that island territory, thus resolving a patronage dispute over the appointment in favor of Senator Robert A. Taft, of Ohio, Senate Majority Leader.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Arrangements to give Congressional leaders a complete briefing from the White House Thursday on the United States military situation were announced today. It was reported they would learn in detail the new Administration's plans for handling the war in Korea and the Communist threat, generally, in the Far East.
Indiana's Big Ten conference leaders topped the United Press college basketball ratings again yesterday by a comfortable margin over undefeated Seton Hall.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16 -- Dust storms covering a wide area in Eastern Colorado, Nebraska, Kansas and Oklahoma caused apprehension among wheat traders this morning, and this was reflected in sharply higher quotations at the start of trading.

TRENTON, Feb. 16 -- There will be no reapportionment of State Assembly seats based on the 1950 census for at least another two years, as the result of the failure today of the Legislature to approve a bill authorizing such a procedure.

Nine five-story apartment buildings occupying the entire blockfront on Central Park West from 103d to 104th Streets have been purchased for investment by the Harlank Realty Corporation from Rosenstock Bachrach, operators, in a deal negotiated by Rubin Solove, broker.

Teachers of courses on money and banking from colleges and universities in the Second Federal District became "students" of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York yesterday. The classes marked the start of a three-day seminar on central bank problems, described as the first of its kind to be conducted by the Federal Reserve in its offices at 33 Liberty Street here.

After a week's warning, enforcement of the drastic new "no standing, loading or unloading" rule in peak periods on First and Second Avenues started yesterday and the police tagged 155 violators, who are subject to $15 fines. Seventy-seven summonses were served in the morning rush and seventy-eight in the evening.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The Reed tax-relief bill was approved today by the House Ways and Means Committee, 21 to 4, but faced a possible ten-week delay in the Rules Committee and an uncertain fate in the Senate.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Feb. 16 -- A Danish general singlehandedly quelled today an attempted march on Copenhagen by army conscripts dissatisfied with prolongation of their service from twelve to eighteen months. There were indications that the march might have been Communist-inspired.

Amid all of Secretary Dulles' efforts to allay the fears of London and Paris lest the United States make some kind of stabilization agreement with one of them at the expense of the other it has been almost completely overlooked, notes our correspondent Michael L. Hoffman from Geneva, that West Germany might beat either or both of these countries to the punch.

Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman yesterday set the week beginning on March 9 as the new date for execution of death sentences upon Julius Rosenberg and his wife, Ethel, who were found guilty on March 29, 1951, of conspiracy to commit espionage in transmitting atomic secrets to Soviet Russia.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 16 -- The dispute between the Allied High Commission and the West German Government concerning future occupation costs, eventual contributions to the European Defense Community, and a proposed 15 per cent cut in income tax rates that would affect these obligations, has focused attention on West Germany's ability to pay such obligations.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The prospect of a foreign policy split between the Eisenhower Administration and many Congressional Republicans was raised today on the issue of the agreements of Yalta and Potsdam.
Within a few years the public may come to regard employers who resist union efforts to increase wages as the champions of public interest, a Harvard University economist predicted here last night.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Feb. 16 -- The House of Assembly adopted today the public safety bill, which gives the Government dictatorial powers if it declares an emergency. The measure was sent to the Senate, where it will be voted automatically since the Opposition United party is supporting the Nationalists on the issue.
STEAMBOAT SPRINGS, Colo., Feb. 16 (AP) -- Leaps of 276 and 289 feet, coupled with flawless form, won the national ski jumping championship for Arthur Tokle of Chicago today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- The Treasury has told Congress the public is cashing in savings bonds at a slower rate than the Treasury expected -- but faster than Congress provided for.

The differences between a Japanese house and an American one are as striking as their similarities to Yoshinobu Ashihara, a Tokyo architect who is now studying in this country. He referred, in an interview, to the present overwhelming interest in the relationships between traditional Japanese residential architecture and contemporary homes in America.

LONDON, Feb. 16 -- The Canadian Pacific Railway Company announced today that it had bought from the Compagnie Generale Transatlantique the 19,918-ton liner De Grasse to replace the Empress of Canada, which was destroyed by fire at her Liverpool dock on Jan. 25.
ALBANY, Feb. 16 -- Senator Dutton S. Peterson, Republican of Odessa, introduced in the Upper House tonight a bill calling for a commission to study the state's divorce laws.

ALBANY, Feb. 16 -- A departmental bill authorizing life insurance companies to increase commissions to agents was submitted to the Legislature tonight with the backing of the Life Insurance Association of America and the American Life Convention, the two leading life insurance organizations.

FORT MEADE, Md., Feb. 16 (AP) -- The Government declined today to declare a mistrial in the court-martial proceeding against Lieut. Col. Melvin B. Voorhees on the issue of a mysterious telegram addressed to the court.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The Immigration and Naturalization Service of the Department of Justice has estimated that it must increase its administrative, investigative and other staffs by 751 persons in order to enforce the McCarran-Walter alien control law.

Two biographies of Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower are planned for publication in the fall. One will be the life story of Mrs. Eisenhower by Dorothy Brandon, a member of the Washington staff of The New York Herald Tribune, which Scribners will publish in September.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 16 -- Maurice Pate, executive director of the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund, appealed today to Government leaders in Washington to rush action on a $9,814,000 appropriation for the agency.

After hearing additional argument yesterday, Supreme Court Justice Benjamin F. Schreiber again deferred his ruling on whether to sustain or reverse an order by General Sessions Judge Francis L. Valente barring the press and the public from the vice trial of Minor F. (Mickey) Jelke 3d. But he said he expected to hand down a decision by noon today.

Interest in the national indoor tennis championships picked up last night as Arthur Larsen of San Leandro, Calif., and Kurt Nielsen of Denmark appeared for their opening matches. Both of them flew here from Paris, where Larsen was runner-up to Budge Patty in the international indoor tournament.

HARTFORD, Feb. 16 -- The Connecticut Supreme Court ruled tonight that James G. Plunkett of Stamford, who was convicted of manslaughter in the shooting of his wife in November, 1949, was entitled to inherit her $279,888 estate.

The dean of tea testers, who admits to liking his coffee, was toasted by his peers yesterday as he attended his fortieth and last annual meeting of the Board of Tea Experts. The board is a group of seven men who set the standards for the quality the hundred million pounds of the leaf that will come through the port of New York in the year beginning May 1.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (UP) -- Dr. Paul Hawley, director of the American College of Surgeons, said today the public would be "shocked" if it knew the "amount of unnecessary surgery performed" by dishonest doctors.

MONTREAL, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Armand Savoie of Montreal, Canadian lightweight champion, tonight won a split ten-round decision over Jimmy Carter of New York, the world lightweight champion, in a non-title bout. Savoie weighed 138 3/4 and Carter 136 1/4.
CHAPPAQUA, N. Y., Feb. 16 -Three hundred volunteers led by policemen and bloodhounds were searching the snow-clad hills near here tonight for a 3 1/2-year-old boy missing since early this afternoon.

Russ Meyer, the 29-year-old right-hander who had a 13-won and 14-lost record with the Phillies last season, was acquired by the Dodgers yesterday. But the Brooks did not get the pitcher from the Phillies. They made their deal with the Braves during an afternoon that saw four National League clubs, five players, and, in some instances, cash involved in a chess game, as it were.
The end of Federal wage controls brought $4,500,000 in retroactive pay increases yesterday to 22,000 employes of the Republic Aviation Corporation at Farmingdale, L. I.

The moderate-size woolen mill attuned to the quick changes in style demand can more than hold its own profitwise against the giants of the industry regardless of its location, Bernard Goldfine, New England woolen manufacturer asserted yesterday.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 16 -- The Israeli Government, in a statement read to the Knesset (Parliament) today by Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion, maintained that the bombing of the Soviet Legation in Tel Aviv was no ground for Moscow's action in rupturing diplomatic relations.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 16 -- If, for fear of Congressional investigating committees, the nation's million public school teachers grow timid about discussing controversial issues in the classroom, the way would be paved for dictatorship in this country, Dr. Harold Benjamin, head of the social foundation division at the George Peabody College for Teachers, warned here today.

It is surprising that so few Americans realize that the chief issue at stake on Formosa is the same as that for which our own soldiers fought at Valley Forge: representative government versus tyranny. It is a mistake to speak of China's constitutional Government on Formosa as "Chiang's Government." Chiang Kai-shek did for China what Kemal Ataturk did for Turkey in establishing the machinery for democratic representative government.

MIAMI, Feb. 16 -- In a brisk tune-up for Saturday's $100,000 added Widener Handicap, George D. Widener's Battlefield finished a head in front of the Hampton Stable's Alerted at Hialeah Race Course today. The distance was a mile and a furlong, and the clocking, 1:49 4/5, was the best of the meeting.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The National Safety Council today presented to Admiral Emory S. Land, president of the Air Transport Association, a plaque honoring the domestic scheduled airlines for their completion last week of twelve months of operation without a single passenger fatality.

The traditional Thursday night concerts of the Berkshire Festival will be dropped this summer in favor of concerts on Friday nights, Charles Munch, conductor of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, announced yesterday in revealing plans for Tanglewood this summer.
The irresolvable controversy between the abstract and representational schools of art in this country has erupted again with new vigor.
La Salle of Philadelphia, last year's winner, yesterday accepted a bid to participate in the sixteenth annual National Invitation Tournament, which starts at Madison Square Garden on March 7.

In Chinese, lapchong means "live forever." Lapchong also denotes a kind of sausage prepared from duck liver. On the Chinese New Year the duck-liver sausage is served: it implies the host's wish that one will have longevitey, if not immortality, on earth.

Purity Bakeries Corporation of Chicago and the American Bakeries Company of Atlanta are planning to ask their stockholders to approve a merger at meetings in May, it was announced yesterday. The successor company will be the American Bakeries Company.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 16 -- Formal charges of negligence were filed today against Capt. Harold T. Hallman, master of the freighter Fairhope, which went aground on San Benito Island, off Baja, Calif., Jan. 30, less than twenty-four hours after murder had marked her voyage.

BERLIN, Feb. 16 -- United States headquarters here said today that Communist authorities were preparing to evacuate all residents from a projected No Man's Land around West Berlin and were planning to split the city in two about March 1 by instituting a system of strict border controls.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The common and ever-present problem in recent years of the Government, the press and the public -- how to maintain the free flow of legitimate information without risking national security -- has been made more difficult by the facts that the United States and other nations are engaged in a war in Korea and that Soviet foreign policy is suddenly sprouting with new causes of global war.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16 -- Pierre S. du Pont, 83-year-old patriarch of the munitions and chemical clan, today took the witness stand in Federal District Court here to deny that his relatives, their associated industrial affiliations or he conspired to violate the Sherman Anti-Trust Law.

Joe Adonis, one of the principal targets of the Senate Crime Investigating Committee, was found guilty yesterday by Federal Judge John F. X. McGohey of one count of a sixteen-count contempt indictment. The gambler and racketeer was sentenced immediately to three months in prison.

New York City is losing a good Canadian friend today and gaining a worthy successor. A new Canadian Consul General, Ray Lawson, is taking over from Kenneth A. Greene, who is returning to his native Ottawa after more than three years at his post.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 16 -- The Labor party's victories in the state elections in New South Wales and Western Australia Saturday leave only one state Liberal Government in Australia -- that of South Australia. They suggest that Prime Minister Robert Gordon Menzies has slender hope of retaining control of the Senate at the election May 9.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 16 -- United States Ambassador George V. Allen announced today the support of the United States for the Balkan entente being developed by Yugoslavia, Greece and Turkey.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- A State Department security officer who recently found himself transferred suddenly to a job in which he was no longer given access to Foreign Service personnel files told the Senate Permanent Investigating subcommittee today that he was demoted after having testified that those files were in a "deplorable" condition.

ALBANY, Feb. 16 (UP) -- The Laconia-Belknap--Seven to fifteen !State Commerce Department to-i inches with one inch granular; day reported the following winter .partly cloudy; good. Mount Sunapee--Four to twenty :sports conditions:

TRENTON, Feb. 16 -- Seventeen county Republican chairmen or their representatives met here tonight and strongly indicated their preference for Paul L. Troast, State Turnpike Authority Chairman, as the party's gubernatorial nominee.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Feb. 16 (AP) -- A new scandal involving star athletes at the College of William and Mary became known today. About thirty students have been dismissed or suspended for periods up to a year for Violating the honor code.

PARIS, Feb. 16 -- A fashionable first night audience that included James C. Dunn, United States Ambassador, gave an enthusiastic reception here tonight at the Empire Theatre to the Robert Breen-Blevins Davis revival of George Gershwin's "Porgy and Bess."
TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 16 -- Successful attacks on Bakhtiari tribesmen who have taken up arms against Government forces in southern Iran were reported today in newspaper dispatches from the south.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- President Eisenhower said today that "national security is everybody's job" and urged nation-wide support of National Defense Week. The "week" is being stretched from last Thursday, Feb. 12, to Feb. 22 to encompass, as the President said, "the birthdays of our two greatest Presidents."

ALBANY, Feb. 16 -- Republican legislative leaders have agreed in conferences with Governor Dewey to push through a bill imposing a fee of $10 a year for distinctive automobile license plates beyond the regular registration charge. Some 115,000 to 125,000 sets of such plates are now issued every year.

LONDON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- The United States entry list in the British women's squash racquets championship was cut in half today as a result of the first-round play. Four Americans lost while four advanced.

ALBANY, Feb. 16 -- A constitutional amendment that would permit municipalities to develop water supplies in excess of their own needs for sale to other Government units was introduced in the Legislature tonight on the recommendation of a special committee headed by State Controller J. Raymond McGovern.
As a farm reader of THE TIMES I want to object vigorously to your recent editorial on Eisenhower's farm commission.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Feb. 17 -- More than 200 United Nations fighter-bombers struck at a Communist troop assembly and supply concentration at Kyomipo, southwest of the North Korean capital of Pyongyang, yesterday and the Fifth Air Force said the attack had left the target area a "sea of smoke and fire."

STEWART MANOR, L. I., Feb. 16 -- A five-year-old girl was burned seriously and her mother suffered slight burns here this morning when the child set fire to her nightgown while playing with a cigarette lighter. Bed covers used in extinguishing the flaming gown, started a fire through the second floor of the house, causing $5,000 damage.
FITCHBURG, Mass., Feb. 16 -- A drive started today in several cities with large Finnish populations to finance trips to America of two Finnish runners for the Boston A. A. Marathon on April 19.

TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 16 -- Food, medical supplies, clothing and equipment were pouring into the Iranian earthquake area today from many sources, including the United States Point Four technical assistance administration and the American Red Cross. Still more necessities were being gathered for delivery tomorrow. Donations of money and supplies came from all over the world.

A Federal grand jury began an investigation here yesterday of charges of police brutality against Negroes as Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan failed, on a mission to Washington, to restore exemption for New York policemen from questioning by the Federal Bureau of Investigation in cases involving complaints of civil rights violations.

A site has been assembled in Brooklyn for the Lefrak Organization, builders for improvement with a cooperative apartment project under Section 213 of the Federal Housing Administration. A plot of 65,000 square feet on Ford and Batchelder Streets, between Avenues X and Y, was acquired from the estate of Mary Thiel.
Court action was taken here yesterday against the Banco do Brasil over long-delayed payment of dollars on a private export-import transaction between a New York company and a Brazilian concern.

Conditional approval of the retirement applications of two policemen under suspension because of their involvement in the departmental trial of thirty members of the force accused of accepting graft from Harry Gross, convicted bookmaker, was granted yesterday by the board of trustees of the Police Pension Fund.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (UP) -- The Air Force today announced a revision of the geographical areas covered by its three Air Defense Forces.

The Little Orchestra Society, which presented Bizet's "Les Pecheurs de Perles" ("The Pearl Fishers") last April at Town Hall, repeated the work last night at Carnegie Hall. It again showed the drawing power of opera in concert form, for the big house was full as the smaller one had been.

May I commend your editorial "Keep Mediation Independent." Experienced participants and students of labor-management relations in this state and in this nation should endorse your position as unassailable. The Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, independent of the United States Department of Labor since 1947, should maintain that status in order to insure its impartiality in labor-management disputes.

Three of four teachers or administrative aides in municipally operated colleges here, who had refused last Tuesday to tell a Congressional subcommittee whether they were or had been members of the Communist party, were dismissed yesterday afternoon, according to Abraham Lederman, president of Teachers Union.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan yesterday denounced Joseph P. Ryan, the troubled head of the International Longshoremen's Association. A. F. L., as "the chief stumbling block to remedial action" on the city's crime-infested waterfront.

LONDON, Feb. 16 -- Britain won her two-week race against the sea and could relax tonight as hundreds of hastily repaired breaches in the sea walls along the East Coast stood stoutly against the climax of the high spring tides.

GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 16 -- A mother and daughter of Mystic, Conn., were killed here today, while on their way to a vacation in Florida, when their sedan careened off the Merritt Parkway and rammed a tree. The driver, Mrs. Clara B. Wilcox, 64 years old, apparently was dozing at the wheel.
LONDON, Feb. 16 -- Under the lead of a buoyant industrial market, most sections of the Stock Exchange here began the week cheerfully today.

GUATEMALA, Feb. 16 -- The Government declared today it would take "measures" against foreign correspondents and local newspaper men who, in the Government's opinion, reported falsely on the situation in Guatemala.

A waterlogged railroad box car weighing eighty-three tons was plucked from its muddy and current-swept resting place on the bottom of New York harbor 400 yards northwest of Governors Island yesterday by the Monarch, the port's most powerful floating derrick.

ALBANY, Feb. 16 -- A series of bills designed to subject Federal and state savings and loan associations to a 4 1/2 per cent tax on net income and to make other changes in tax laws applicable to banking institutions was submitted to the Legislature tonight by the State Tax Commission.

An Austrian importation is the solo offering at a first-run theatre today. "Marika," a Boris Morros Presentation in Natural Color, starring Marika Rokk, opens at the Beekman. Fred Liewehr, Harry Fuss and Fritz Mulliar head the supporting cast.

MINEOLA, L. I., Feb. 16 -- The forging of another link in Nassau County's first complete improved north-south highway was started here this morning with the Board of Supervisors' approval of acquiring land to close a 1,000-foot gap in Peninsula Boulevard at Hewlett.

ALBANY, Feb. 16 -- Governor Dewey reaffirmed tonight, in a special message to the Legislature, his demand for the enactment of a compulsory automobile insurance law despite strong opposition from Republican legislators and segments of the insurance industry.

WHEN a fellow starts to wrestle with influenza germs, he is likely to find himself catching up with his reading, especially if it be a book he has been saving for such an emergency. To this reporter there always has been a cobra-like fascination to the infamous Black Sox scandal of 1919, a sordid tale that is described in precise detail by Warren Brown in his lively book, "The Chicago White Sox."

Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy began yesterday a screening of all supervisory employes of the Department of Welfare, "to kill, once and for all, any intimation that the department will tolerate the presence of any Communist sympathizers in its ranks."

Local government borrowing authorities in Texas and Minnesota postponed yesterday the public sale of two bond issues totaling $6,100,000. Harris County, Tex., which had planned to sell $5,000,000 of bonds tomorrow, put off the sale until Feb. 27. Ridgefield, Minn., postponed until March 2 the sale of $1,100,000 of sewer bonds scheduled for Feb. 23.

A continuation of the fight to persuade the Republican majority in the Legislature to reverse its "arbitrary action" of last week and grant at least a part of the state aid the city seeks was pledged yesterday by Mayor Impelliteri, Democratic county organization leaders and minority legislative chiefs.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The Munitions Board of the Department of Defense notified Congress today that the purchase and stockpiling of strategic and critical materials had improved further during the last six months of 1952. A leveling off of military and industrial needs combined with better supply were given as the reasons.
