SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Feb. 16 -- Unbeaten Seton Hall scored its twenty-fifth victory tonight, routing Villanova 83 -- 68, before 3,500 at the Seton Hall gymnasium. Walter Dukes, 6 foot 11 inch Pirate center, scored 31 points.

Denmark has set aside about $9,600,000 to retire its dollar debt in 1953, it was announced yesterday by the Danish Ministry of Finance. The figure compares with about $5,700,000 made available for that purpose during each of the last three years.

Robert F. Wagner Jr., Manhattan Borough President, announced yesterday a program to exchange "goodwill ambassadors" between Puerto Rico and the Borough of Manhattan. The program, he explained, was aimed at creating better understanding between the people of Puerto Rico and residents of this city.

The five-story apartment house accommodating twenty-five families at 145 Kensington Avenue in Jersey City, N. J., has been sold by Frank and Leon Schwartz to Ethel Morrison in a transaction negotiated by J. I. Kislak, Inc., as broker.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Adlai E. Stevenson got a rousing reception on Capitol Hill today and one Democratic leader expressed belief that the former Illinois Governor's defeat for the Presidency last November might have provided "the foundation for his future victories."

The French Government has now formulated the conditions which it feels must be met before the National Assembly can be counted upon to ratify the European Defense Community Treaty. These conditions are: (1) agreement on six interpretative protocols to be attached to the Defense Community Treaty, giving France special rights within that Community; (2) additional British and American guarantees against Germany; (3) final settlement of the Saar question.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady yesterday, unchanged to 13 points lower than on last Friday, with old-crop months weakest.

The nation's steel mills are expected to operate at 99.7 per cent of rated capacity this week and to produce 2,248,000 tons of ingots and steel for castings, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. In both tonnage and operating rate, these figures equal the highest ever attained by the industry -- a point set first a month ago in the week of Jan. 19 and equaled again last week.
For the fifth straight week, undefeated Seton Hall was rated as the nation's No. 1 college basketball team in The Associated Press poll yesterday.
Complete integrity of the appointive process, free of political pressure and favoritism for any reason, is essential if civil service itself is to have integrity.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- A Federal District Court temporarily restrained the Federal Government today from requiring a minimum wage of $1 an hour for work on most Government textile contracts.

TRENTON, Feb. 16 -- Establishment of the county as the primary assessment district for taxation purposes, improved valuation procedures, including a redefinition of "true value", and the abolition of levies on household goods and personal effects, heretofore a statewide practice, were recommended by the Commission on State Tax Policy.
SEOUL, Korea, -- Feb. 16 The economic life of this war-wrecked country dried up today like puddles of water on a city pavement under a hot sun.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The Senate moved today toward a denunciation of Communist persecution of Jews amid indications that the Eisenhower Administration itself was taking an interest in the move.

THERE are still some foxes in the dunes of Dare, and unless the last of the running hounds has finally answered the hunter's horn, some of those foxes are still on the move. For the Nags Head (N. C.) Valentine's Hunt is easy to start but difficult to stop.

A variety of products that can be made by the molding of plastic materials under great pressure in giant presses was put on display by the plastics division of the General American Transportation Company of Chicago at the Plaza Hotel yesterday.

For the seventh consecutive year securities registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission have topped $5,000,000,000, Donald C. Cook, chairman, reported to Congress yesterday. The fiscal 1952 aggregate of $9,500,000,000 topped the previous high of $7,070,000,000 set in fiscal 1946.

MOSCOW, Feb. 16 -- The attack on Soviet war correspondent Vassily Semenovitch Grossman, launched last week by Pravda, was broadened today by the central committee organ Kommunist into a criticism not only of Mr. Grossman but of the directors of the writers union magazine New World for publishing Mr. Grossman's new Stalingrad novel.

With all advance forecasts indicating a big spring for suits, blouse designers have outdone themselves, bringing forth one of the most exciting crops in many seasons. They have shown a keen recognition of suit trends and the importance of the ensemble look.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Lewis J. McKesson, a former radio engineer employed by the Voice of America, estimated today that the organization had wasted about $31,000,000 in various construction projects around the world, adding that the alleged mistakes sprang from intent rather than stupidity.

LONDON, Feb. 16 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden found himself today in the position of defending the United States' Far Eastern policy in the House of Commons against an unfriendly Opposition and some skeptical supporters.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- W. A. Scharrfenberg will leave tomorrow on a world tour to check on how much drinking is being done by United States diplomats, but he said today he was quite sure what his private research would prove: That they are drinking too much.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The first money bill of the Eighty-third Congress was slashed today 61 per cent from departmental requests -- most of them made in budget estimates of the Truman Administration. The Appropriations Committee of the House of Representatives, which voted the drastic cuts, acted as Republican key men, who had the votes on their side, opened their campaign for reduced expenditures and lower taxes.

The hope that the memorial to be erected here to the 6,000,000 Jews slain by the Nazis will become a world symbol of unity among people of all races and creeds was expressed by President Tito of Yugoslavia in a message read last night at a meeting in the Pierre Hotel under the sponsorship of the memorial committee.

MAPLEWOOD, N. J., Feb. 16 -- Mrs. Marge Moretti, widowed mother of two young children, hoped today to salvage her life savings of $1,000 and stock worth $640 that she had baked yesterday along with a cake in the oven of her home at 92 Tiffany Place.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- The Interior Department has asked Congress for a supplemental appropriation of $275,000 for research into utilization of saline water during the fiscal year ending next June 30.

OTTAWA, Feb. 16 (Canadian Press) -- A Canadian company has been given Federal permission to make water power surveys in the Yukon with a view to establishing a huge hydro-electric development on the Yukon-British Columbia border that could become one of the world's largest.

PARIS, Feb. 16 -- Moscow has given no official indication as to how the Asian Communist bloc plans to meet the new situation implicity created by President Eisenhower's deneutralization of Formosa. Nevertheless, a careful collation of available evidence shows no softening in the attitude of the Chinese-Soviet alliance, which has just observed its third birthday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 16 -- Ethel Merman, continuing her vacation from Broadway, will lead the singing for Twentieth Century-Fox in the Irving Berlin musical "There's No Business Like Show Business." Sol Siegel, the producer, plans on a June starting date.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- A recent Treasury refinancing of $8,868,000,000 of one-year certificates was attacked today by Senator James E. Murray, Democrat of Montana, as a "totally unnecessary payment to the bankers" that would cost taxpayers an extra $136,000,000 in the next four years.

Commodity futures prices moved irregularly yesterday on the New York exchanges. Volume was generally light, but coffee was active and cocoa and potatoes were moderately active. Coffee, cocoa, soybean oil, cottonseed oil, wool and rubber closed higher.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The initial move toward making the Federal Security Agency a department of Cabinet rank was made today in President Eisenhower's office during his regular Monday morning conference with Congressional leaders.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 16 -- While United States exporters are pressing in Washington for a loan by the Export-Import Bank to enable Brazil to pay them amounts overdue, authorities here are said to fear such a loan would make a long-term solution of the problem more difficult than ever.

There is that extra emotional heart tug in the story of Tenley Albright, 17-year-old Boston girl, who has just brought the women's world title in figure skating to the United States for the first time. In 1947 she had polio. She not only skated herself back to health, she skated herself into a world championship.
SAYBROOK, Conn., Feb. 16 (UP) -- Two Coast Guardsmen, marooned for five hours on a breakwater within 200 feet of land, froze to death early today. A third was reduced in critical condition.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Senator Russell B. Long, Democrat of Louisiana, in a Senate speech today, warned the Pentagon it must revise its strategic plans if these included, as he thought they did, projects for billions of dollars' worth of bases around the world and the deployment of hundreds of thousands of troops in distant spots for many years to come.

LEICESTER, England, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Randy Turpin, Britain's contender for the world middleweight boxing championship, outpointed Duggie Miller of South Africa in a ten-round bout tonight before a capacity crowd of 8,000.

Lieut. Gen. Withers A. Burress, commander of the First Army, presented the Bronze Star Medal with "V" device yesterday morning to Elias Mercado Jr., 18 months old, son of Pfc. Elias Mercado, who was killed under fire in Korea while rescuing three wounded comrades.
Marking the first action of its kind among specialty stores here, De Pinna and Gunther Jaeckel, Inc., have discontinued openings on Thursday nights, their officails said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The Eisenhower Administration's determination to seize the initiative in the "cold war" received new impetus today with the appointment of C. D. Jackson, a New York City publisher, as adviser to the President on psychological warfare, and with the briefing of top officials on atomic energy secrets.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 16 -- The United States was understood today to be prepared to mediate between France and West Germany in settlement of any basic differences that might bar ratification of the Bonn peace contract with the Western Allies and the European Defense Community Treaty.

Judge Leo F. Rayfield, in Brooklyn Federal, Court, reserved decision yesterday on a motion to dismiss the indictment against T. Vincent Quinn and his former law partners, James D. Saver and Martin Schwaeber.

A mass meeting under the sponsorship of thirty-one national Jewish organizations called last night on the Soviet government to cease its anti-Semitic activities and permit Jews behind the Iron Curtain to migrate to Israel.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Feb. 17 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,528, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M. Tuesday, Korean time:
The Bureau of Internal Revenue and the Veterans Administration issued yesterday a reminder concerning tax exemptions for former service men and women. They included the following items:
Breakdown of tariff protection under the "trade-not-aid" policy was described yesterday as the only immediate threat to an otherwise stable paper and pulp industry in the United States.
A slight increase in earnings from operating activities in 1952 enabled E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. to surpass the per-share earnings reported in 1951, it was announced yesterday.

The acquisition of two important accounts was announced yesterday by Young Rubicam, Inc. Both appointments are effective March 1. The agency has been named by Max Factor Co. to handle the advertising of its two principal products -- Max Factor Pan-Cake Make-up and Max Factor Creme Puff, the new blend of cream make-up base and powder.

The Prison Association of New York warns in its annual report and recommendations to the Legislature against any smug attitude based on the happy fact that New York has thus far been exempt from the nation-wide wave of prison disturbances. "It can happen here," in spite of the generally good management of our institutions.
New York's five chapters of the American Red Cross opened a campaign yesterday for $7,000,000 with emphasis on projects to prevent infantile paralysis and to aid the military forces.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Feb. 16 -- Former Premier Paul Reynaud of France, expressing ideas more and more widespread among the French in Indo-China, said today the present situation in Vietnam could be resolved only by the Vietnamese and that only a considerable development of the Vietnamese Army would allow renewal of a military offensive against the Communist-led Vietminh.
DETROIT, Feb. 16 (UP) -- The Detroit Red Wings increased their National Hockey League lead to 6 points tonight with a 3-1 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks before 11,975 fans at the Olympia.

The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company last year attained the highest sales and earnings in its fifty-four-year history, according to the annual report issued yesterday by P. W. Litchfield, board chairman.

Antonio F. Vigorito, a former plainclothes man who was found guilty of perjury in the first degree, was sentenced yesterday by Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz in Kings County Court to two and a half to five years in prison.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- The Federal Civil Defense Administration said today Russia could send 400 planes against any spot in the United States and drop numbers of atomic bombs capable of inflicting 110,000 casualties with each blast.
Police and fire sirens -- gladly missed by the populace while officially banned -- have returned on a sixty-day trial basis, now nearing its end.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The drive to give the states title to oil-rich submerged coast lands gained strong impetus today from a ruling by Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. that the Executive Order of Jan. 16, one of President Truman's last official acts, did not make them a naval petroleum reserve.
INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Feb. 16 (AP) -- Harry S. Truman got a new automobile today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 16 -- A blight on automobile sales was forecast today as an eventual result of overcrowded thoroughfares, increasing highway perils and the widespread lack of parking facilities. People are not going to buy cars to maintain them in idleness, delegates were told at the thirty-sixth annual convention of the National Automobile Dealers Association here.

LONDON, Tuesday, Feb. 17 -- Title Conservative Government's bill to return most of the nationalized trucking industry to private enterprise was approved in its third reading and final vote in the House of Commons tonight by a vote of 296 to 257.
PARIS, Feb. 16 -- The French believe they are making progress toward committing Britain to both military and political links with the proposed European Defense Community with a single army.

Joe Lapchick, coach of the New York Knickerbockers, was singing the praises of Al McGuire yesterday, as he talked about tonight's meeting at Madison Square Garden between the Knicks and the Milwaukee Hawks. Red Auerbach, tutor of the Boston Celtics who face the Syracuse Nationals in the first game of the National Basketball Association double-header, agreed that the younger McGuire is "the most improved player in the league."

MOBILE, Ala., Feb. 16 (AP) -- The Coast Guard cutter Blackthorn headed toward Mobile today with the bodies of seventeen victims of the National Airlines' plane crash of Sunday while the air-sea search for twenty-nine other occupants of the DC-6 went forward.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Counsel for Prof. Owen Lattimore asked the United States District Court here today to dismiss the seven-count indictment charging him with perjury in testimony given last year before a Senate Internal Security subcommittee.

As casually as though he were making a routine deposit or withdrawal, a young desperado yesterday robbed the Borough Park branch of the National City Bank at 5420 Thirteenth Avenue, Brooklyn, of $4,200 in currency.

Blood contributions in the city last week amounted to 3,326 pints, bringing the month's total to 7,946, against a quota of 20,000 for February, it was announced yesterday by the Red Cross. A campaign to assure this objective was marked by increasing activity.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Top sports leaders have demanded a full-scale Congressional investigation of gambling and bribery in amateur and professional athletics and new laws to cope with the situation. The demands are by a nine-member committee created by the United States Attorney General more than a year ago.

The genesis of "Maggie," which is arriving at 8 o'clock this evening at the National, is Sir James M. Barrie's celebrated forty-five-year-old play, "What Every Woman Knows." Jointly starred in the musical variation are Betty Paul, British performer in her American stage bow; Keith Andes and Odette Myrtil, who replaced Irene Bordoni.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- President Eisenhower reaffirmed today his determination to unshackle the economy and give greater scope to free enterprise and market conditions both in farm produce and consumer goods.

ONCE upon a time Fordham had a clear-cut objective in football. It became something of a campus slogan as the rallying cry swept from the South Gate up the elm-lined path to the university itself atop Rose Hill. It was a ringing challenge: From Rose Hill to Rose Bowl. The Rams came close a couple of times but never quite made it.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 17 -- The barring of the press and public from the Jelke vice trial recalled today a somewhat parallel case in a United States District Court in which a Mann Act conviction was reversed.

BERLIN, Feb. 17 -- In East Germany and probably throughout the Communist world the coming execution of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg is being used on an unusually large scale to incite hatred of the United States and western democracy.

BRUSSELS, Feb. 17 (Reuters) -- Premier Jean Van Houtte's statement to Parliament here today that King Baudouin is "seriously ill" was contradicted tonight by the King's physician. [Dr. Georges Luigi, the doctor attending the King, on vacation at Antibes, French Riviera, said at Antibes Tuesday that the King was not seriously ill and would be able to resume normal activities in a few weeks.
KATMANDU, Nepal, Feb. 17 -- In this tiny mountain kingdom the curtain has risen on a preview in miniature of the battle for Asia between communism and democracy.

The Children's Court of New York is not and never has been able to meet fully its responsibilities to youngsters in trouble, Dr. Justine Wise Polier, justice of the Domestic Relations Court, said last night at the Cooper Union Forum, Fourth Avenue at Eighth Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (UP) -- The State Department's "great concern" over getting competent maid service for its overseas employes prompted it to add an extra room to apartments built in Germany, officials testified today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 17 -- Ninth Federal Circuit Court of Appeals was petitioned today by the National Union of Marine Cooks and Stewards, unaffiliated, to throw out a proposal for a 5 per cent wage increase to stewards' department employes of ships of the Pacific Maritime Association.

Further evidence that Advertising Research Foundation is gaining importance came to light yesterday with the disclosure that six more companies have joined the organization. At the same time, it was reported by Edgar Kobak, president, that the subscription renewal rate for the foundation's services is running at more than 95 per cent and "pushing 98 per cent."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The long -established stand of school groups that the United States Office of Education should be an independent agency and not included, as now planned, in a new Federal department, was put before President Eisenhower today by leading educators.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Feb. 17 -- Underworld mobs headed by Joe Adonis, the late Willie Moretti and Albert Anastasia "were able to operate in Bergen County because they were assured of the aid and comfort of certain political officials," Nelson F. Stamler, dismissed deputy attorney general, said in an address read for him today before the Exchange Club.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The modern-style White House press conference was conceived March 8, 1933, when President Roosevelt faced a roomful of reporters and said:

Charges that the Department of Investigation and the Municipal Civil Service Commission were trying to "whitewash" allegations that fifteen men of questionable loyalty had been certified for appointment to the Police Department were denied yesterday by James H. Sheils, Commissioner of Investigation.

James P. Warburg, author and financier, announced yesterday that he had submitted to President Eisenhower and Secretary of State John Foster Dulles proposals for an "all-German settlement," suggesting that they be put forward by the Western powers. The proposals would:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Continuation today of Senate subcommittee investigation into the Voice of America program for penetrating the Iron Curtain with broadcasts about democracy brought new charges. They included mismanagement, a lessening of efficiency through incompetence or design, and large waste of public money.

ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- Most of Governor Dewey's state budget for the new fiscal year starting April 1 was approved by both the Senate and Assembly today after Democratic amendments to provide a 10 per cent pay increase for state employes and continued full state support of four technical institutes had been rejected by party votes.

COPENHAGEN. Denmark. Feb. 17 -- The wave of disobedience that broke out yesterday in Danish army barracks in protest against the extension of the draft period from twelve to eighteen months, as recommended by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, spread today to Bornholm, strategically situated Danish isle in the Baltic, where the garrison of 250 staged a sitdown strike.

Paul Franke, who has given an excellent account of himself in many small roles at the Metropolitan, had a chance last night to show what he could do in a larger part, that of David in "Die Meistersinger."

Three Department of Sanitation employes, who raced through an apartment house shouting warnings, were credited yesterday with saving the lives of the residents of a six-story building in which an early-morning fire broke out.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Feb. 17 -- Ten thousand armed Chinese civilians were reported today to have revolted against Chinese Communists early this month in the southwestern province of Yunnan. The revolters were reported to have occupied strategic points in eight counties near the Burma-Indo-China border.
The United States' hopes of regaining the International Racquets Cup from Great Britain were all but snuffed out yesterday as the visiting team won both doubles matches.

The report in the press of the survey just completed by the Regents Advisory Council on the Readjustment of High School Education merits close and sober consideration, particularly as it applies to New York City. The council's report points out that close to half of all students drop out of school before graduation.

In a decision of widespread significance, State Supreme Court Justice Bernard Botein yesterday annulled the action of the State Athletic Commission that reversed the official decision in the bout between Billy Graham and Joey Giardello in Madison Square Garden last Dec. 19.

BALTIMORE, Md., Feb. 17 -- One of the most spectacular and destructive Baltimore fires since that of 1904 leveled the business district swept part of the waterfront today, raging through three industries, five piers and several smaller installations, Damage was estimated unofficially at $2,000,000.

The song recital given by Gerard Souzay last night in Town Hall proved to be one of the artistic highlights of the season. Here is a most accomplished vocalist who is also a musician and a born interpreter of poetry. Few indeed are those singers today who have their vocal mechanism under such control and who can make the tone so illuminative of the word, and the phrase such an arabesque of beauty.

LONDON, Feb. 17 -- Yesterday's buoyant trend continued on the stock market here today. Australia's decision to relax import restrictions and some good profit and dividend statements brought consistent demand for domestic industrials, with widespread gains. British Government securities were modestly better, while South African gold issues improved under the lead of the uranium producers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The Dallas Power and Light Company today applied to the Securities and Exchange Commission for permission to market $9,000,000 of first mortgage bonds due on March 1, 1983, to be offered for public sale at competitive bidding.

A committee on research and publications has been appointed to manage scholarly and academic matters in connection with the celebration in 1954 of the 300th anniversary of Jewish settlement in America, Ralph E. Samuel, chairman of the American Jewish Tercentenary Committee, announced yesterday.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 17 -- Israel's Citrus Marketing Board has sent a message to Moscow offering, in spite of the severance of diplomatic relations between the two countries, to fulfill a contract for 400,000 cases of oranges, grapefruit and lemons this season.

MIAMI, Feb. 17 -- Everett Clay, a good man and true, is the press agent at Hialeah Race Course. He delights in the setting of records at his pet horse park. Today he had a stop-the-press announcement. The turnstile count, 21,184, was the largest for a Tuesday in Hialeah's twenty-six racing campaigns.

The Commercial Solvents Corporation and its subsidiaries suffered a sharp setback in earnings and sales last year, it was reported yesterday with the election of Harold W. Comfort to the board of directors.
DUBLIN, Feb. 17 -- The State Department has been called upon to invoke the McCarran Act to revoke the United States citizenship of the Vatican's diplomatic representative in Ireland.

President Eisenhower received 294 correspondents yesterday at the first official White House press conference of his Administration. The subjects touched on included most prominently the farm problem, price controls and taxes. However, the White House press conference, which is a uniquely American institution and is of unique importance to the people of the country, has never followed exactly the same pattern under any two Presidents.

John David Provoo, former Army staff sergeant who became the eighth United States citizen convicted of treason after World War II, was sentenced to life imprisonment yesterday by Federal Judge Gregory F. Noonan.

Swimming and sun-bathing at the Rockaways in Queens will be on a strictly pay-as-you-go basis from now on, Mayor Impellitteri decided yesterday. The Mayor, after a public hearing, signed a local law prohibiting unauthorized parking in vacant lots by vehicles that jump the curb.

Volume was generally light yesterday on the New York commodity exchange, with coffee easing from previous high levels. Potatoes were fairly active and sugar trading far exceeded the volume of any day this year. Prices closed irregular. Cocoa, cottonseed oil. soybean oil, lead and hides were higher.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Feb. 17 -- Troubles continue to multiply for Joe Adonis, the onetime racket boss who is now serving a two-to-three-year term in the New Jersey State Penitentiary at Trenton for running dice games.
The section of Justice Schreiber's decision dealing with freedom of the press, freedom of speech and due process follows:

HONG KONG, Feb. 17 -- The Peiping Government announced tonight that Communist China's national budget for 1953, initial year of its first five year industrialization plan, had been fixed at the equivalent of $9,864,700,000.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today refused to order reductions in railroad rates for carrying newspapers in passenger and baggage cars in the western part of the country.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 17 -- A warning that the Congressional committees investigating schools and colleges threaten not only education but the democratic way of life was voiced here today by Mrs. Agnes E. Meyer of Washington, a member of the board of directors of the National Citizens Commission for Public Schools.

BOSTON, Feb. 17 -- Gov. Christian A. Herter of Massachusetts halted a strike of 1,000 public utility employes today by invoking legislation that enables the Commonwealth to seize industries when a work stoppage would endanger public health or safety.

One of the most sobering reports ever prepared by a United States Government agency has been submitted to the President and Congress by the Federal Civil Defense Administration. This document estimates that the Soviet Union is now or soon will be capable of making an all-out atomic attack on our largest cities, utilizing 400 planes which could drop bombs capable of killing or injuring as many as 11,000,000 of our people.

Charles Edward Wilson, national campaign chairman of the Crusade for Freedom, said yesterday that its Radio Free Europe was keeping citizens of Central and Eastern Europe hostile to Russia and was making her hesitate to use their countries as a springboard for invasion of Western Europe.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 17 -- Dr. Ludwig Erhard, Minister of Economics, sought to placate the Allied High Commission today with assurances that the loss of revenue resulting from the West German Government's proposal to reduce income taxes by 15 per cent and corporation taxes from 60 to 40 per cent would not be employed as an argument to obtain a reduction in West Germany's eventual contribution to the European Defense Community.

CHAPPAQUA, N. Y., Feb. 17 -- After having been lost twenty hours in the wooded, rolling countryside east of here, Edwin Le Fevre 3d, 3 years old, was found just before noon today sprawled face downward between a boulder and the base of a high rock ledge a half mile from his parents' home on Haights Crossroad in the town of New Castle.

A bright future faces the automatic vending machine industry as a result of the increasing "conditioning" of the American people to wait on themselves, it was said yesterday by Robert Z. Greene, president of the Rowe Corporation, producer of such devices.

At the annual meeting of the Fifth Avenue Association, Inc., at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday, W. E. S. Griswold Jr. was elected president to succeed Ralph E. Ladue, who was chosen chairman of the board. Walter Hoving, chairman of the board for the last seven years, will continue to be active in the affairs of the association as a director.

The problem drinker in industry -- a hitherto neglected figure -- can be helped and, in the process, converted from an economic liability to a steady, efficient and reliable worker, a group of experts reported yesterday.

A Brooklyn civic organization yesterday presented a plaque to Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan citing the "meritorious police work" of the uniformed force and detectives in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of the borough.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Cigarettes are expected to be freed from price controls tomorrow under an edict from the Office of Price Stabilization.
Selection of Municipal Court Justice Edward G. Baker as Richmond Borough President was reported agreed upon yesterday and was scheduled for final confirmation Friday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Harold E. Stassen, Director for Mutual Security, declared tonight that United States leadership in the partnership of free nations "will be neither unilateral bullying nor multilateral Milquetoast."

ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- Business taxes that Mayor Impellitteri wants, to raise money needed by New York City for meeting the transit operating deficit without a fare increase, consist chiefly of city surtaxes on existing state levies.

CAMDEN, N. J., Feb. 17 -- The Government early today seized the Monitor, a war surplus tanker, when she docked at near-by Paulsboro. Forfeiture was sought on the ground that the vessel had been bought illegally by the North American Shipping and Trading Company, Inc., of New York.

A Brazilian official said here yesterday he was shocked to learn of legal action taken on Monday by a New York export concern to attach Banco do Brasil funds for payment of dollar drafts owed by Brazilian importers to a group of United States exporters.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, is expected to serve on a new tripartite advisory committee to be set up in a day or two by the Secretary of Labor, Martin P. Durkin. About two years ago he serevd on a labor adivsory committee to Charles E. Wilson, former General Electric president, when he was Director of Defense Mobilization.

The State of Connecticut sold yesterday $25,000,000 of rental housing notes, due March 5, 1954, at interest costs ranging from 1.2 per cent to 1.31 per cent. The Chase National Bank and associates bought $10,000,000 at 1.29 per cent, $10,000,000 at 1.3 per cent and $1,500,000 at 1.31 per cent.

ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- As the result of the death last April of the son of a member of the United Nations Secretariat, Senator Paul Graves, Republican of Gouverneur, introduced a bill today to outlaw the use of sodium pentothal as an anethetic on persons under sixteen years of age.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- President Eisenhower reaffirmed with emphasis today his opposition to tax reduction until a balanced budget was in sight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Four instead of about forty workers of the United States Office of Education are attending the convention of the American Association of School Administrators at Atlantic City this week.

Not all the culinary short cuts come out of our own factories. Among our imports are five dehydrated soups prepared in Schaffhausen, Switzerland, west of the Lake of Constance and north of Zurich, by the Societe Anonyme des Produits Alimentaires Knorr.

ORLANDO, Fla., Feb. 17 (AP) -- The defending co-champion Mrs. Babe Zaharias, and her partner, George Bolesta, shared a three-way tie for the medals today in qualifying for the international mixed two-ball tournament with a 3 under par 68.

Despite the warnings given by both the Japanese and the American Governments more than a month ago, two Soviet fighter planes recently invaded the air space over Japan and after opening fire on American interceptor planes were driven back to their own base.

BREMEN, Germany, Feb. 17 (AP) -- The West German police said today that they had foiled the attempt of a crew to make away under darkness with the 7,800-ton Turkish tanker Raman. The ship has been impounded here under court order for repair bills since last July.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Feb. 17 -- The Lower House of Parliament voted today, 75 to 11, to bar Communists from a special commission that will work with the Government on flood reconstruction and measure to avert a future disaster.

Organized labor is proposing to abolish the eighty-day injunction period provided by the Taft-Hartley Act in national emergency cases. Under this provision threatened or actual strikes affecting an entire industry or a substantial part of an industry which may imperil the national health or safety are estopped pending the utilization of other means aimed to settle the dispute.

WASHINGTON. Feb. 17 -- Democrats in Congress today challenged the finding of Herbert Brownell Jr., Attorney General, that the order issued by outgoing President Harry S. Truman on Jan. 16 failed to make a Naval petroleum reserve of rich offshore oil deposits.
New York's tercentenary is being celebrated at the Downtown Gallery by a newly opened loan exhibition of paintings of the city by twentieth-century artists.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Congressional leaders were notified late today that such substantial cuts could be made in defense establishment manpower, uniformed and civilian, that reductions of billions of dollars would be possible in future military budgets.
The need of cooperation between public and private agencies in dealing with social problems was emphasized yesterday at a conference conducted by the Greater New York Fund.

HARTFORD, Feb. 17 -- Gov. John Davis Lodge recommended to the General Assembly today that it approve a biennial general fund budget totaling $256,600,000, which would require the imposition of $42,000,000 in new state taxes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Diplomatic representatives of seven Arab states cautioned the United States today that it would be giving "weapons" to the Communists if it responded to Israel 's new appeal for "moral and material" aid.

Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, condemned to death for atomic espionage on behalf of Russia, won a new delay of execution extending at least until March 30 when the United States Court of Appeals granted time yesterday for the filing of a new petition to the United States Supreme Court for a review of the spy case.

PARIS, Feb. 17 -- A police hunt for two little boys in the south of France has stirred up the ever-present religious animosities in this country where the Roman Catholic Church and its influence have long been the subject of impassioned controversy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Top-level planning of overseas air bases won a nod of approval today from Senator Leverett Saltonstall, Republican of Massachusetts and chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Adlai E. Stevenson received a White House send-off today and the promise of full Administration cooperation on his five-month world fact-finding tour, but politics was not entirely adjourned between the victor and vanquished of the November election.

Men's wear retailers should increase profits through expanding volume and cutting expenses rather than increasing mark-ups, speakers said yesterday at the convention of the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers at the New Yorker Hotel.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 17 -- An intensive Mexican press campaign against American shrimp boats fishing in Mexican waters has led to a demand for negotiation of a United States-Mexican treaty on fishing and navigation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (UP) -- Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce said today she supported "the American tradition of separation of church and state" and would have no relations, "formal or informal, open or secret," with the Vatican in her role as Ambassador to Italy.

LONDON, Feb. 17 -- In the face of a full-scale Parliamentary attack launched today by the Labor Opposition, Selwyn Lloyd, Minister of State for Foreign Affairs, defended Britain's policy of selling jet fighter planes to the Arab nations.

ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- The Assembly completed legislative action today on a proposed constitutional amendment that would permit the temporary assignment of judges in New York City to speed up trial calendars. The vote was unanimous.
On account of indisposition I have only now seen your issue of Feb. 9 quoting reactions in the British press to President Eisenhower's new orders to the Seventh Fleet.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (UP) -- The White House press secretary, James C. Hagerty, promised women reporters today a "fair deal" in obtaining White House news but drew the line at describing Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower's gowns.

OTTAWA, Feb. 17 -- Following his week-end visit to Secretary of State John Foster Dulles in Washington, External Affairs Minister Lester B. Pearson told the Canadian Parliament last night that he felt reasonably assured that there was no intention on the part of the Administration in Washington to do anything that was "rash, provocative or adventurous" and no desire to extend the war to the continent of Asia.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 17 -- The Soviet Union has given strong indications that, as a last resort, it would agree to the election of Lester B. Pearson, Canadian Secretary of State for External Affairs, to succeed Trygve Lie as Secretary General of the United Nations.

Supreme Court Justice Benjamin F. Schreiber refused yesterday to direct General Sessions Judge Francis L. Valente to lift the ban he had imposed on the press and the public at the vice trial of Minot F. (Mickey) Jelke.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- No President of the United States, since the beginning of White House press conferences in Woodrow Wilson's time, has given a stronger impression of sincerity, mental integrity, devotion to the basic constitutional system and amiability than Dwight D. Eisenhower conveyed today to a news conference that packed the floor and balcony of the room in the old State Department Building where it was held.

James A. Taylor, 40-year-old longshoreman, was convicted yesterday in Federal Court of lying to the Federal rackets grand jury investigating waterfront crimes in denying that he had ever received checks from a stevedoring company.

PARIS, Feb. 17 -- In a statement before the National Assembly Premier Rent Mayer appealed to the Province of Alsace in the interests of French national unity to cease protests and await the Assembly's decision on an amnesty proposed today for 130,000 Alsatian youths forcibly inducted into the German fighting units during World War II.

Berlin, the standard thermometer that registers the degrees of tension in East-West relations, is again a source of grave concern to the Allied Powers. Paris, London and Washington are beset by so many pressing problems that they are not saying much about this one. Except in Bonn, Berlin was hardly mentioned in Mr. Dulles' recent round of the Western capitals.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Feb. 18 -- Premier Stalin received the Indian Ambassador, K. P. S. Menon, last night in his Kremlin suite for the second conference the Soviet leader has held with a foreign diplomat in the past eight days and the third he has had with the Indian diplomat in recent years.

ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- Assemblyman Joseph F. Carlino, Republican of Nassau County and chairman of the Joint Legislative Committee on Comic Books, introduced a series of bills today designed to curb the sale of obscene and otherwise objectionable comics.

Station WOR-TV plans to move its antenna to the top of the Empire State Building, thus affording a central transmitting site for all seven television stations in the metropolitan area. The move is subject to approval by the Federal Communications Commission.

A complete investigation into the death of two Bronx babies in the municipal Fordham Hospital on Saturday, the day after examining physicians ruled that they did not need immediate hospitalization, was ordered yesterday by Dr. Marcus D. Kogel, Commissioner of Hospitals.

ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- The State Banking Department's branch bank bill, which would authorize savings banks to open additional branches in suburban areas, received a sharp setback today when it was disclosed that the Federal Controller of the Currency has ruled, informally, that passage of the bill would give all National Banks similar branch privileges.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Feb. 17 -- The Netherlands has sent a note to the five other governments in the Schuman plan for coal and steel -- France, Belgium, Luxembourg, West Germany and Italy -- calling for a tariff union as a step toward a common market for all goods.

Television sets, radios and major appliances have proved unprofitable in most department stores because of low mark-ups and cut-price competition, according to a survey by the National Retail Dry Goods Association.
Two men were booked at the East Twenty-second Street station at 8:30 o'clock last night on charges of extortion and conspiracy, in connection with the "shakedown" of an embroidery shop proprietor.

MIDDLETOWN Ohio, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Sales of the Armco Steel Corporation in 1952 topped $500,000,000 and production crossed the four-million-ton mark for the second successive year, Charles R. Hook, chairman, announced today.

Western Kentucky, with a 21-and-4 record for the season, yesterday accepted a bid to play in the National Invitation Tournament. The Hilltoppers are the second quintet named for the sixteenth annual competition, which starts at Madison Square Garden on March 7.

Problem children of pre-school age are often a reflection of parents' problems, Dr. Frank J. Curran, Professor of Neurology and Psychiatry at the University of Virginia Medical School, declared Monday night in a lecture at Town Hall, 125 West Forty-third Street. Psychiatrists at child-guidance clinics often discover that the parent, as well as the child, needs help, he asserted.

What is possibly the most monumental display ever dedicated to the drinking habits of man opens today at the Brooklyn Museum. Arranged by Helen McKearin and called "Here's How," the show includes samples of drinking vessels used over a period of 4,500 years, a series of recipes indicating some of the beverages these might have held, and a collection of paintings, tapestries and prints depicting the vessels in use.

Anticipating a shortage of qualified college graduates because of inroads by the military services, some branches of industry are conducting a "mad scramble" for seniors this year and even picking them off the campus in the manner of baseball scouts.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 17 -- Yale defeated Cornell, 56 -- 47, tonight to tie for third place with the Ithacans in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The Federal Communications Commission took under adivsement today the claim of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and the International Monetary Fund for reduced rates on its telegraphic messages to member governments abroad.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 17 -- The Government of Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion won an overwhelming vote of confidence in the Knesset (Parliament) today after a two-day debate on the Soviet Union's rupture of diplomatic relations with Israel.

The country's paper industry has made more than ample provision for future pulpwood requirements, it was declared yesterday at the seventy-sixth annual convention of the American Paper and Pulp Association and affiliated paper trade groups.
NEW HAVEN, Feb. 17 -- Four men and a woman will be presented with Yale Medals for their "outstanding service to Yale" at Alumni Day on Monday. They were selected by the Yale Alumni Board.

Fantastic costumes and carnival divertissements were features of the second annual Mardi Gras Ball of the New York Junior League, held last night in the ballroom of the Astor for the benefit of the league's welfare fund.

Fifteen music students from public and private high schools in the Metropolitan New York area have been selected to appear on the third annual "Musical Talent in Our Schools," a series of six broadcasts to be heard over Station WQXR beginning Sunday, March 15.

MINEOLA, L. I., Feb. 17 -- Charles Starkins, 24 years old, and his 19-year-old wife, Eileen, sat calmly through a preliminary examination in First District Court here today and heard Judge Samuel Greason order them held for action of the grand jury on a first degree murder charge.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- A first-term member of Congress with an obvious knowledge of the intricacies of the Taft-Hartley Law submitted a series of amendments to the House Labor Committee today.

SEOUL, Korea, Feb. 17 -- There was some stirring of life in the frozen economy of Korea today. The people still were without a currency to buy goods but they resorted to barter for their urgent needs.

Jimmy Herring, 159, Ozone Park, L. I., scored a technical knockout over Jimmy Flood, 165, Yorkville, at the end of the third round of the feature clash listed for ten rounds at the Ridgewood Grove, Brooklyn, last night. It marked the first time in twenty-six years that a boxing card has been staged at Ridgewood Grove on a night other than Saturday.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17 -- Selling on a big scale followed substantial early gains in the grain markets today, prices easing after President Eisenhower at his press conference made known that he contemplated no temporary moves to check price declines in farm products. There had been buying previously on rumors that he would offer definite plans.

The United States Lawn Tennis Association yesterday reported it had expelled the Edgewood Country Club of Charleston, W. Va., from its membership. Harold Lebair, chairman of the amateur rule committee, issued the following statement last night:

Much of the jargon of the investment banking business held by the Government to evidence conspiracy in restraint of trade is only a "patter" peculiar to the business. Judge Harold R. Medina remarked at the anti-trust trial in Federal Court here yesterday.

T. Vincent Quinn, Queens County District Attorney, pleaded not guilty before Federal Judge Leo F. Rayfiel in Brooklyn yesterday to a second indictment charging him with taking lawyer fee illegally while serving as a member of the House of Representatives.

The Museum of Modern Art, which is under fire by art organizations for its handling of the American section of the international sculpture competition, "The Unknown Political Prisoner," and particularly for not having shown a representative selection of the entries, said yesterday through a spokesman that the museum had been overruled by the jury on the showing of any but the eleven prize winners.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 17 -- Soldiers, policemen and detectives patrolled about seventeen miles of the road to the Aztec pyramids near Mexico City in an effort to trap a bandit team that has held up three groups of United States tourists in the last month.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- A thick, juicy T-bone steak costing 39 cents a pound was dangled before Congressional noses today. The meat, said a couple of Ohio cattle men, came from New Zealand and is ruining their business. They asked Congress to stop the low-price sales.

ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- A special committee headed by Controller J. Raymond McGovern studying the advisability of bringing certain public employes under the Federal Social Security Law urged today that coverage be made available to an estimated 40,000 persons.

Oscar Sokolinsky, a 30-year-old disabled veteran, was arrested early yesterday as the hit-and-run motorist who killed a teen-age couple returning from a St. Valentine dance Sunday morning in Brooklyn.

WILMINGTON, Del., Feb. 17 -- Stockholders of Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., voted today to dissolve the company in line with a Federal Court judgment and adopted an amended plan of reorganization, giving stockholders shares in two new incorporated concerns.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 17 -- A Government official acknowledged today that Yugoslavia had about 70,000 unemployed. In this country of planning, where so much depends on the Socialist precept of "the right to work," which is guaranteed by the Constitution, an unemployment figure that high is regarded with exceptional concern. The Yugoslav population is 16,500,000.

After drifting downward for most of the session, prices on the New York Stock Exchange turned selectively firmer in late trading yesterday, but final levels were irregularly lower. Declines were confined generally to fractions, although some shares dropped a point or more.

FORT MEADE, Md., Feb. 17 -- The Army was in the process today of getting rid of Pvt. Harry Clifford Maynard for the second time. At 16 he is still too young. The Phelps, Ky., paratrooper promised he would be back next December, after he had turned 17.
LONDON, Feb. 17 -- A sharp disagreement between Egypt and Britain over the implications of their agreement on the Sudan was exhibited in the House of Commons today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- House of Representatives policy shapers acted today to take some of the sting out of the old jest that, come spring, it's always possible to get a quorum of Congress in Paris.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 17 -- The dramatic story of the double life led by United States Air Force jet pilots based in Japan will be brought to the screen in "Sabre Jet."

ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- A series of bills to limit the liability of radio and television stations in suits for slander and libel based on the programs they broadcast was submitted to the Legislature today by Senator William S. Hults Jr. of Port Washington, L. I., and Assemblyman Joseph F. Carlino of Long Beach, L. I., both Republicans.

ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- A series of bills amending the election law to overcome some objections to present election procedures were introduced today by Republican legislators with the backing of the State Republican Committee.

CAIRO, Feb. 17 -- Fouad Galal, Minister of National Guidance, said at a press conference here tonight that withdrawal of British troops from the Suez Canal zone would be a much easier problem to solve than that of the Sudan.

Leather is used in many unusual ways in a show devoted to the subject on the first floor of W. J. Sloane. It appears as a floor inlay, as a wall covering, a frame for a mirror and a special window drapery, as well as in a cornice arrangement.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17 -- How Pierre S. du Pont made financial arrangements nearly thirty years ago for his death were explained today when the 83-year-old industrialist and financier returned to the witness stand at the du Pont anti-trust trial before Judge Walter J. La Buy in Federal District Court.

Although they suffered through a 12-minute stretch with only one field goal, the New York Knickerbockers had enough to down the Milwaukee Hawks, 86 -- 67, at Madison Square Garden last night. Since the runner-up Syracuse Nationals conquered the Boston Celtics, 84 -- 65, in the opener, the Knicks' fifth straight victory protected the three-and-a-half-length lead of Joe Lapchick's quintet over the Nats in the Eastern Division of the National Basketball Association.

Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan angrily denied yesterday that there ever had been a deal with the Department of Justice whereby New York policemen were exempt from routine questioning by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents in civil rights cases involving charges of police brutality.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- When the steering wheel came off, that was just the beginning. The Voice of America owns a truck, and Donald R. Creed told investigating Senators about it today in bitter tones. He is assistant chief of domestic transmitters for the Voice.

The steady flow of Puerto Rican children into the undermanned public school system has reached the point where the brighter bilingual youngsters soon find themselves cast as teachers. They are the so-called "children helpers" who act as interpreters, relay instructions from the English-speaking teachers and generally assist and comfort their fellow Spanish-speaking Puerto Ricans.

A 37-year-old private school teacher, George Ball of New York, scored the chief surprise of the tourney when he defeated the former Swedish champion, Nils Rohlsson of Stockholm in a second-round match of the national indoor tennis championship last night at the Seventh Regiment Armory.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Feb. 17 -- A legislative investigation to determine whether there had been "collusion" in preparation of a report of the Pennsylvania Water Resources Committee urging rejection of a plan that recommended cooperation of Pennsylvania, New York, New Jersey and Delaware in solving mutual water supply problems was demanded today by Senator Joseph J. Yosko, Democrat of Northampton.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Feb. 17 (AP) -- Harvie Ward, the British amateur champion, fired a five-under-par 67 today to lead a record field of eighty players in the first qualifying round of the Tournament of Golf Club Champions.

Among other melancholy things, February is the month for painting. By this is not meant the painting of pictures suitable for framing and hanging, but just the routine, run-of-the-mill covering of ceilings and walls.

KANSAS CITY, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Former President and Mrs. Harry S. Truman were riding in a motor car that collided with a small truck at an intersection today, but no one was hurt and damage was negligible, the police said.
TOKYO, Wetdnesday, Feb. 18 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,529, for the twenty - four hours ended at 6 A. M. Wednesday, Korean time:
Business will be profitable only for "well-managed companies," it was asserted last night by George A. Renard, secretary-treasurer of the National Association of Purchasing Agents.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -President Eisenhower made it plain today that he was not considering putting on an embargo or blockade of Communist China and that he never would take any grave step in foreign policy without first consulting Congress.

The Rev. John Corridan, known as the "waterfront priest," warned last night that to improve conditions along the New York and New Jersey docks the American Federation of Labor would have to "kick the International Longshoremen's Association out of the union" and reorganize the waterfront in some other way.

WILMINGTON. Del., Feb. 17 (AP) -- The court judgment ordering dissolution was handed down Jan. 5, 1951. It required the two new companies to be operated independently of each other by April 4, with no common officers, directors, agents or other employes.

Of the 654 common stocks traded on the American Stock Exchange, 334 have paid dividends for ten or more consecutive years and two companies -- the Providence Gas Company and the Pepperell Manufacturing Company -- have paid annual dividends on their common shares for more than a century.

A new machine to aid the blind and the deaf-blind was demonstrated yesterday at the New York Institute for the Education of the Blind, 999 Pelham Parkway, the Bronx. It is a miniature typewriter that will enable the deaf blind to receive messages from the sighted who do not know Braille
The futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active and closing prices for active months were 4 to 12 points net higher than on Monday.

Dr. Mary T. Martin Sloop, who was honored in 1951 as the American Mother of the Year, has written an account of her medical crusading in North Carolina entitled "Miracle in the Hills." In her forty years in Crossnore. Avery County, N. C., Dr, Sloop fought not only to enlighten the people to the benefits of surgery and medicine, but also for better education and roads and against moonshining and child marriages.

George Raft, the spare, close-lipped gentleman who has played gangsters for many years, has switched over to the side of the law in a new television series at 8 P. M. Mondays over Channel 5. The change may have been just what Mr. Raft needed, because his show is not bad at all, at least not by the TV standard for detective stories.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Following is an unofficial transcript of President Eisenhower's first news conference, held today. The questions are verbatim, but the opening remarks and replies are paraphrased in accordance with conference rules permitting direct quotation of the Presidente only when specifically authorized by him:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -The Defense Materials Procurement Agency (D. M. P. A.) today announced "restoration of virtually free domestic trading in tungsten and molybdenum concentrates."

Consolidated net income of the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation for 1952 was $23,132,000, compared with $20,721,000 in the preceding year, according to the utility's annual report issued yesterday by Earle J. Machold, president.

TRENTON, Feb. 17 -- The struggle now taking place in New Jersey for the Republican nomination for Governor appeared tonight, despite the presence of ten contenders, to be narrowing itself into a race among four men. Only two of these men are considered favorable to the administration of Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll and can hope, therefore, for his endorsement.
Consolidated Edison Company borrowed $40,000,000 in the public market yesterday through the sale of thirty-year first-mortgage bonds at an interest cost of about 3.42 per cent.

Business and industrial failures rose to 200, the highest level since May, 1950, in the week ended on last Thursday, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. The figure compares with 159 in the preceding week and 125 in the comparable week of last year.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Feb. 18 -For the fourth straight day yesterday deadly Sabre jets of the United States Fifth Air Force tangled over North Korea with Russian-designed MIG's, downing one Communist jet fighter and damaging another.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Motor carrier freight rates went up 10 per cent today in the New York short-haul area, and 7 per cent in the remainder of the Middle Atlantic states.

The political tide in Australia has swung so definitely and for such a long period toward the Labor party from the conservative Liberal-County coalition that outsiders must give heed. There are Senatorial elections on May 9 and if he trend continues the Menzies-Fadden Government is going to lose control of the Senate.

Albert W. Gatov, chairman of the Federal Maritime Board, has denied a request for a formal investigation of the international shipping arrangement under which American Export Lines, a subsidized United States-flag operator, acts as general agent for its chief competitor, the Italian Line.

ROME, Feb. 17 (Reuters) -- The 300th anniversary of the birth of Arcangelo Corelli, who founded the modern technique of violin composition and playing, was celebrated today with a commemorative concert at the City Hall.
A comment in your editorial on the Gettysburg photograph dramatizes for the public the urgent need for the recognition of the importance of documentary photographs.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17 -- Congress should pass a law "encouraging the most rapid possible elimination of all tariffs" and thereby "lead the free world toward freer trade," Henry Ford 2d asserted today. The president of the Ford Motor Company spoke at a luncheon meeting of the Inland Daily Press Association.

NAPLES, Italy, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Firemen pumped thousands of gallons of water into the holds of the French passenger-cargo vessel Ferdinand de Lesseps today and put out a fire that forced the 11,150-ton vessel to make an emergency run into Naples Harbor.

The Episcopal Actors Guild will be the beneficiary of the performance of Stephen Vincent Bnet's "John Brown's Body" tomorrow night at the Century Theatre. Mrs. Charles Manton Richter heads the benefit committee. Already a large subscription to the event has been reported.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- President Eisenhower insisted anew today that there could be no doubt the Soviet Union had a "supply of atomic weapons" and already had tested three atomic bombs.

NEWARK, Feb. 17 -- The water supply committee of the New Jersey Section of the American Water Works Association has recommended to Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll that New Jersey establish a reservoir revolving fund for the acquisition of needed reservoir sites.
BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 17 (AP) -- The Ministry of Finance has opened the way for Argentina to barter wool against needed imports from soft currency countries.

With hopes of a Stanley Cup play-off spot fading fast, the New York Rangers disclosed yesterday that they were bringing up two youngsters and another skater who had a previous trial in a move to bolster the Broadway Blues.

Football will be continued at Fordham. The Rev. Lawrence A. Walsh, S. J., chairman of the University Council on Athletics, made this disclosure yesterday at a luncheon at Leone's in answer to repeated rumors that the sport might be dropped because of financial difficulties.

Amid the confusion, contradictions and silences surrounding the charge that policemen severely beat two arrested men in a West Side Manhattan precinct station several issues of principle are above dispute. The public will not stand for police brutality. There cannot be one code of treatment for Negroes and another code for other people.

THE school tuna, which have been a real source of recreation and food to countless thousands of coastal anglers who are unable to afford the expense of other forms of off-shore angling, may be seriously threatened by the commercial netting methods that are definitely in the offing.

PARIS, Feb. 17 -- The French will be called on to modify their proposed protocols to the European army treaty when the interim committee representing the signatory governments meets here Friday and there is reason to believe the French will do so.
A special group of fashions selected for three sizes of tall girls was previewed yesterday at Tall Wear, 13 East Forty-seventh Street. Line and color followed the proportioned sizes.
A new East Side restaurant lists nightly on its menu an hors d'oeuvre that is served perhaps in only one other eating establishment in the world.

The Children's Aid Society of 105 East Twenty-second Street announced yesterday at its 100th annual meeting that two of its seven centers would soon be moved to keep pace with the city's shifting residential areas. An eighth center will be built to serve the Puerto Rican section of Harlem.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Feb. 18 (AP) -- The Boston Celtics, excelling at the foul line, snapped the New York Knickerbockers' five-game winning streak tonight, defeating the Eastern division leaders of the National Basketball Association, 69 -- 66, on the auditorium's neutral court.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The passenger train that crashed into Union Station here on Jan. 15 ran away because an angle cock valve in the airbrake system was not located according to specifications and the movement of another part closed it, the Interstate Commerce Commission found today.

An intensive campaign for shipment to Israel of about 2,000,000 technical and scientific books published since 1940 was started yesterday by the newly organized Books for Israel, a coordinating body of forty major Jewish organizations in the United States.

Paddy Young, Greenwich Village middleweight, signed yesterday to meet Ernie Durando of Bayonne at Madison Square Garden on March 27. The bout will be part of the tournament designed to provide a successor to the championship vacated by Ray Robinson.

The theft of furs valued at $6,000 and jewels said to be worth $17,900 was reported yesterday by Mrs. John McQuillan of 290 Park Avenue, according to detectives of the East Fifty-first Street station.
Midtown police were shuffled in checkerboard fashion yesterday to meet a rash of telephoned bomb threats. In each of the three cases, the police said after investigation, the reports were unfounded.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Congressional Republicans in charge of framing tax legislation clashed openly and sharply with President Eisenhower today over the precedence of tax and budget reductions.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- President Eisenhower refused today to increase the duties on briar pipes, an issue regarded as a key to the new Administration's attitude on foreign trade, but this was an interim decision pending the development of broad international trade policies.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 18 (UP) -- Gen. Robert Neyland today asked to be relieved as football coach at Tennessee University for the 1953 season.

LONDON, Feb. 18 -- Two general practitioners here say that rheumatoid arthritis and certain allergic conditions such as bronchial asthma and dermatitis can be arrested, permanently in most cases, by injections of a special form of iodine that can be carried in the blood stream.
A brave woman teller took advantage of the greediness of a would-be robber to foil a hold-up yesterday in the Corn Exchange Bank branch at 50 Church Street, near Fulton Street.
CHICAGO, Feb. 18 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

ORLANDO, Fla., Feb. 18 (AP) -- Marilyn Smith, Wichita, Kan., and Lou Barbaro, Deal, N. J., eliminated Mary Lena Faulk, Thomasville, Ga., and Don Bisplinghoff. Orlando, 2 and 1, in first-round matches of the International mixed two-ball golf tournament today.

PARIS, Thursday, Feb. 19 -- By a vote of 348 to 217, the French National Assembly early today adopted a law providing amnesty for the Alsatian youths whom Hitler drafted into the Nazi forces in World War II.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- President Eisenhower added three more veteran Foreign Service officers today to his growing roster of career diplomats assigned to key posts here and abroad. He sent to the Senate for its confirmation the following nominations:
Soundly conceived and nurtured, the branch store can prove a decisive factor in aiding department and specialty stores in the fight to retain their relative share of retail sales.
Seton Hall, the nation's only major undefeated college basketball team, will participate in the sixteenth annual National Invitation Tournament, which starts at Madison Square Garden March 7.

TOKYO, Thursday, Feb. 19 -- Waves of United Nations jet fighter-bombers yesterday demolished a Communist tank-infantry training center at Kangso, about fifteen miles west-southwest of the North Korean capital of Pyongyang. In morning and afternoon strikes 380 Air Force and Marine Corps planes made the war's second largest all-jet attack on a single target.

In your front page story of Feb. 14 the Ambassador of Israel, Mr. Eban, is reported as pleading for the backing of the free world to prevent threatened persecution of religious minorities in the Iron Curtain countries. I hope the appeal is successful and that we Americans have the grace, this time, to open our doors to religious refugees instead of giving them the land and homes of other people, as we did in Palestine.

Eugene Garrett turned back Brendan Macken, Canada's top-ranking player, at the Seventh Regiment Armory last night in the first clash between seeded players of the United States Lawn Tennis Association's national indoor championships.

CHICAGO, Feb. 18 -- Weather news continued unfavorable in the Southwest, with dust storms predicted in Oklahoma. Nebraska, Kansas and eastern Colorado. With the growing season close at hand traders are becoming more weather conscious, and considerable reinstatement of sold-out lines was indicated.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 18 -- Pacific Gas and Electric Company, which has doubled its electrical output since the end of World War II, announced plans today for a $44,000,000 steam-electric generating plant at Morro Bay, San Luis Obispo County, in central California.

CHICAGO, Feb. 18--ControllingI interest in Reliance Manufactur-/ ing Company, Chicago, has been/ purchased for an undisclosed sum/ by M. M. Clairmont and StevenI Credit and Commerce Corporation, both of New York City, and by interests they represent, A. T. Bard, Reliance president, announced.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The resignation of Dr. Wilson M. Compton, International Information Administrator, was accepted today by John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State. Dr. Compton's agency runs the Voice of America, which is under Senate investigation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Secretary of Labor Martin P. Durkin, holding his first news conference since he took office, announced today the personnel of a fifteen-member advisory committee to scan the Taft-Hartley law as its first assignment.

During the 1952 "Friends' Fund" campaign of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society, 3,318 individuals and organizations contributed $110,000 to meet the orchestra's yearly deficit, David M. Keiser, chairman of the campaign, reported yesterday.

Net income of the Florida Power Corporation last year increased to 4,251,264 from $2,520,800 the year before, according to the utility's annual report to stockholders issued yesterday by W. J. Clapp, president. The company, in order to meet the growing demands for service throughout its territory, will spend approximately $28,000,000 for new construction and expansion this year.

Thanks to the City Center, Shaw's "Misalliance" may now be graded upwards. Most of us have been foolishly assuming that it is one of those facetious conversations that get to be unbearably tedious before a long evening is over.

FORT DIX, N. J., Feb. 18 -- A death on the infantry assault grounds here was solved today, according to Army authorities, with the signed confession of a 21-year-old enlisted man who assertedly admitted he had killed his platoon leader last week while on training maneuvers.
Stock prices moved irregularly lower yesterday in the dullest and narrowest trading on the New York Stock Exchange in nearly four months. Rails and motors were the firmest spots.

Marshal Juin of France, commander of the NATO forces in central Europe, left Saigon yesterday for Tokyo, where he will discuss with General Clark a coordinated Far Eastern strategy, with special emphasis, perhaps, on measures to be taken in the event of a Chinese Communist assault on Vietnam.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 18 -- The basic responsibility for operation and control of the public schools belongs to the local school systems and not the Government, the American Association of School Administrators declared today. Local school boards, said the association, a division of the National Education Association, can protect schools from subversive activities and at the same time preserve the right of free Americans to differ on controversial issues.

Resolutions requesting manufacturers to restore historic discounts to retailers and to offer stores a more realistic profit margin were adopted yesterday by the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers at the concluding session of its convention at the New Yorker Hotel.

Breast-feeding, "rooming-in" and so-called "natural childbirth" are valuable in many ways to both mothers and babies, but doctors should make no special efforts to "sell" the ideas to prospective parents, in the opinion of Dr. Morris A. Wessel.

ALBANY, Feb. 18 -- The Assembly Ways and Means Committee approved today a bill designed to clarify the powers of the State Athletic Commission by vesting it with "sole direction, management, control and jurisdiction" over all professional and amateur boxing and wrestling matches in New York State.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Feb. 18 -- Harry Oppenheimer, head of the South African group controlling what probably are the largest gold and diamond interests in the world, indicated today that penicillin and the sulfa drugs would make possible the operation of mines that were expected to increase world uranium production greatly and to raise South Africa's present gold production by about 50 per cent.

There was a little story in the papers the other day about an Army sergeant stationed in Munich who, having received a thirty-day furlough, decided to surprise his wife in the United States by crossing the Atlantic to pay her a visit.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- Following is the text of news conference remarks by Secretary of State John Foster Dulles concerning a possible naval blockade of the China Coast and President Eisenhower's plan to ask Congressional action denouncing secret understandings that "enslave" peoples:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The Citizens Advisory Commission on Utilization of Manpower in the Armed Services recommended today an over-all reduction of at least 10 per cent in the size of ...

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- Two backers of a bill to abolish the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, the Government's big lending agency, said today the Eisenhower Administration would support their bill.

IF Bill Klem didn't say it first, he was the most articulate spokesman for the principle that the umpire is always right. When the self-styled Old Arbitrator roared in his colorful, picturesque fashion, "I never missed one in my life," he didn't necessarily mean that he was infallible. But he did mean that he called every play as he saw it.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 18 -- The United States Information Services here are arranging for Hebrew book publishers, who want to import paper for translations of American books, to get around Israel's acute foreign exchange shortage by the same system that has permitted book distributors to flood Israel with American books during the past few months.

CHICAGO, Feb. 18 -- Woodrow Wilson was quoted in the defense of the du Ponts today at their anti-trust trial before Judge Walter J. LaBuy in Federal District Court. Attorney John M. Harlan of the defense read from a 1919 message to Congress in which the World War I President urged the development of an American dyestuffs and chemicals industry to make the United States independent of German sources.

Mayor Impellitteri's plan for substituting a New York City Transportation Authority for the Board of Transportation, as submitted to the Legislature, is essentially a tax bill rather than a transit authority bill. Its purpose is to find a device to preserve the 10-cent fare.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Goods and services representing an annual volume estimated by Government economists at $50,000,000,000 were freed from price controls today.

The McCarran-Walter Immigration and Nationality Act as it applies to alien seamen was denounced yesterday by Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, C. I. O., as an "ill-conceived and vicious law, which has no place in a democracy and which parallels in many ways the Nazi concept of superiority."

President Eisenhower in his speech before Congress advocated extending the coverage of the Social Security Law. There is one aspect of social security coverage which, unfortunately, has not been given consideration.

The Burlington Mills Corporation will consolidate its manufacturing and selling activities in the patent organization and drop the name "Burlington Mills Corporation of New York," J. Spencer Love, chairman, announced yesterday.

TOKYO, Thursday, Feb. 19 -- The Japanese Cabinet was called into emergency session today to consider the refusal of opposition groups to discuss the Government's 1953-54 national budget in the Diet (Parliament) committee yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 18 -- The United Nations will have to trim down its worldwide program of technical aid to underdeveloped countries because the voluntary contributions from governments are falling short of the $25,000,000 target set for 1953.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 18 -- President Eisenhower told the memoirs of the National Automobile Dealers Association today that they had performed a widespread patriotic service in getting voters to the polls.

HONOLULU, Feb. 18 -- Hawaii's twenty-seventh, and possibly its last, biennial territorial legislative session got under way here today in historic Iolani Palace with the traditional setting of tropical flowers, hulas and Hawaiian music.

Pianists who elect to begin a recital before an immense audience in a huge auditorium with the Cesar Franck "Prelude, Chorale and Fugue," as Artur Rubinstein did last night in Carnegie Hall, are few. Few, also, are the pianists capable of doing the justice to this grand work that Mr. Rubinstein achieved.

ALBANY, Feb. 18 -- A measure that would prohibit the blocking of traffic on open highways by "creepers" who drive at unreasonably slow speeds was introduced in the Legislature today by Senator Seymour Halpern, Queens Republican, chairman of the Joint Legislative Committee on Motor Vehicle Problems.
