The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday and closing prices on active months were 1 point higher to 6 points lower than on Tuesday.

GUATEMALA, Feb. 18 -- A provincial agrarian reform committee has approved the "denunciation" of all but one-seventh of the United Fruit Company's 300,000 acre holdings on the Guatemalan Pacific Coast, centered on the town of Tiquisate.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 18 -- Warner Brothers is arranging to film the coronation of Queen Elizabeth in its own color process, the studio announced today. Jack L. Warner, vice president in charge of production, will fly to London to supervise the unusual film operation.
LONDON, Feb. 18 -- The British newspaper industry published tonight its draft proposals for the formation and constitution of a voluntary and independent Press Council to govern its conduct.

James Reston, diplomatic correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, talking yesterday on the personality of President Eisenhower, said the new President's personal diplomacy and quality of confidence were important factors in changing foreign and domestic policies at Washington.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 18 -- Approval of proposed contract terms of settling the twelve-week-old strike by the Screen Actors Guild against producers of television filmed commercials was announced today by the union's board of directors.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 18 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru condemned today talk in the United States of a blockade of China as "obviously not talk that can lead to peace" and a development viewed by the Indian Government and people "with the gravest concern."

The sale of both domestic and imported gloves this year will show an increase in units, if not in dollar volume, Samuel Shapiro, president of the Smart Set Gloves Company, Inc., predicted yesterday. He said also that selling for fall would get under way earlier this year than in 1952, with some chain stores already beginning to make their commitments.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 18 -- We need more space, and, until we get it, most families are doomed to discomfort, according to Frederick Gutheim, a writer who participated in a panel discussion on "Space for Living" held here last night at the Baltimore Museum of Arts.

MADRID, Feb. 18 -- An estimated total of 600 Spanish workers engaged in the construction and maintenance of military installations on Gibraltar were on strike today following a breakdown in negotiations with the British contractors for a wage increase.

With long-term stabilization substantially achieved, the paper and pulp industry is now turning greater attention to community relations, increased public knowledge of its conservation programs and development of new products.

The debate on the European Army is nearing a showdown. Yesterday the NATO Council met in Paris to receive the French protocols and tomorrow they will be examined by the interim committee of the six signatory nations. As the time approaches for the decisive vote on the treaty it becomes evident that the big question -- to arm separately or together -- is not just a French-German dispute.
PARIS. Feb. 18 -- Italian Ambassador Pietro Quaroni, in a speech today before the Anglo-American Press Association of Paris, stressed the need for financial coordination among the Western Allies.

THE individuals and large sports groups that are interested in the trends and influences affecting fish and game in this country will have an opportunity to obtain detailed information on such matters at the North American Wildlife Conference, which will be held in Washington March 9 to 11 inclusive.

The United Automobile Workers, A. F. L., announced yesterday that it had ousted all the officers of a New York local whose president was arrested Tuesday night on charges of extortion. Lester Washburn, president of the parent union, said in Milwaukee that the international had taken over Local 198 here and had appointed John Romano, an attorney, to administer its affairs.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- A Senate Judiciary subcommittee opened hearings today on proposals to amend the Constitution to limit Federal treaty-making powers amid indications of strong Administration support.

The Commercial Credit Company had a consolidated net income from 1952 operations of its finance, insurance and manufacturing companies of $19,814,307, a slight gain over the previous year's $19,713,887, according to the forty-first annual report issued yesterday by A. E. Duncan, founder and board chairman, and E. C. Wareheim, president.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, today disclosed a goal of achieving a balance with the Soviet Union in the Far East by disengaging United States and French ground forces and stepping up military aid to native troops fighting the land wars in Korea and Indo-China.

The six-foot, two-inch general who, almost single-handed, quelled one of several incipient mutinies in the Danish Army this week epitomizes the military problem of Denmark, and inferentially, of several of the smaller powers of Europe.

Continuity in color, texture and furniture style lends a feeling of decorative unity to a new model house, built on four levels, to be opened Saturday in the Wantagh Oaks development on Long Island. Built by Sidney Berg and Robert Bernhard, assisted by Leslie L. Lowey, a consulting engineer and designer, the moderately priced house ($15,290) is the first of fifty additions planned for the development.
TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 18 -- London's and Washington's protracted silence on the question of settling Iran's oil dispute with Britain has begun to cause political uneasiness and anxiety in Teheran.

The final step toward ratification of last week's contract settlement in the tugboat industry was taken yesterday as Local 333, United Marine Division of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., sent out ballots for a referendum vote by its 3,500 members.

LONDON, Feb. 18 -- The recent advance in the stock markets slackened at the outset of business today. In later dealings buyers showed signs of returning. The rally lifted British Government securities and industrial shares almost back to the opening levels.

KATMANDU, Nepal, Feb. 17 -- King Tribhubana and his five councilors are considering proposals for a five-year plan on far-reaching improvements and reforms in this tiny Himalayan kingdom. They hope for aid from the United States under increased Point Four allotments from the Technical Cooperation Administration.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (UP) -- Senator Wayne Morse, Independent of Oregon, said today that military planners intended to send thousands more United States troops overseas to maintain bases that could be defended by soldiers of allied nations.

One of the outstanding desires of men and nations in the free world is for peace. We have had two world wars in one generation, we are involved in a tragic war in Korea, and we are living in constant fear of a third world war in which atomic weapons might be used.

ALBANY, Feb. 18 -- The possibility of a bipartisan agreement on nominations for judges who will be elected in Brooklyn in November was seen in the introduction here yesterday of three bills adding eight judges to the Supreme, County and City Courts in the borough.

More than 2,100 guests are expected to attend the induction of Dr. Buell Gordon Gallagher today as the seventh president of City College in the Great Hall, 139th Street and Convent Avenue. Dr. Gallagher will be sworn into office shortly after 4 P. M. by Dr. Ordway Tead, chairman of the Board of Higher Education.

Use of red-green traffic signal lights as caution lights will become standard here, a year's tests having demonstrated that the radical experiment has cut accidents by 14 per cent, Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley announced yesterday.

PARIS, Feb. 18 -- The French Government hopes for two achievements toward ratification of the European army treaty before Premier Rene Mayer and Foreign Minister Georges Bidault visit Washington late in March.

TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 18 -- An Iranian employe of the United States Point Four administration who returned today from an inspection trip to the Iranian earthquake area explained the mystery of how such a large proportion of the population of the primitive village of Turud had been killed by the tremor.
American Airlines, Inc., lifted revenues and earnings last year to the highest levels in the history of the company, according to the annual report issued yesterday.

Lights at the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, were out for one hour and forty minutes last night because of a power failure -- the first one -- at the airfield. There was no delay, however, for the twelve incoming and eight outgoing flights because auxiliary electric generators supplied dim lights for essential services.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Feb. 18 -- Marshal Juin will spend several weeks in Indo-China on his way to France from Korea. His visit en route was a brief halt of only three days.

The Bach Aria Group, William H. Scheide, director, presented last night its third subscription concert of the season in Town Hall. Frank Brieff conducted the all-Bach program, and soloists were Robert Bloom, oboe; Norman Farrow, bass-baritone; Bernard Green house, 'cello; Erich Itor Kahn, piano; Jan Peerce. tenor; Carol Smith, alto, and Maurice Wilk, violin.

ROME, Feb. 18 -- Apostolic nuncios represent "not the Vatican State but the Supreme Pontiff, the Holy See and the church" and they occupy themselves exclusively with religious and ecclesiastical affairs, the Vatican Press Service said today.

Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh accused the city administration yesterday of shamefully wasting taxpayers' funds in a "meaningless" process of arresting and convicting narcotic addicts and prostitutes rather than trying to rehabilitate them.

Rudolph Halley, City Council President, called yesterday for a public inquiry to learn whether Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan did or did not enter into a secret agreement with the Department of Justice regarding investigations of alleged police brutality in this city by the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Mayor Impellitteri promptly said he felt no city inquiry was necessary at this time.

Walter D. Binger, chairman of the temporary organizing committee of the Citizens Non-Partisan Committee, announced yesterday that the committee intended to nominate candidates for Mayor and other city offices and to have a line on the voting machines at next November's election.

Prices of commodities closedI lenerally higher yesterday on theI I New York exehanges, with con-t, tinued light volume. Coffee andI !potatoes were fairly active. Coffee,[ cottonseed and soybean orts, lead,I izi.nc, tin and rubber ended higher. Sugar and hides were mixed, and wool, potatoes and cocoa closed lowOr.

CHICAGO, Feb. 18 (AP) -- A reduction in tariffs was favored today by a group of business men attending the Chicago World Trade Conference. They displayed their sentiments in a show of hands supporting an informal resolution.

Assets of the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York reached a new high of $2,267,497,000 at the end of 1952 and the death rate among the concern's policyholders last year was the lowest in its ll0-year history. Assets at the end of 1951 were $2,196,424,200.

Designers of brotherhood posters received prizes yesterday from Richard Bach of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The first and second awards went respectively to Albert Amatulli, 17 years old, and Estelle Krasnow, 18, both of the Abraham Lincoln High School, Brooklyn.
BOSTON, Feb. 18 (UP) -- The man of tomorrow will sleep soundly on a "chillow" in summer heat, drink clear water from brackish streams -- and his shoes won't squeak, they'll moo.

An increase of 1,976,000 barrels last week in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, supplies were 154,469,000 barrels, compared with 152,493,000 a week earlier and 150,087,000 a year ago.

The home and farm freezer was the only one of four important large electrical appliances last year to show a gain in factory shipments as compared with 1951, the National Electrical Manufacturers Association disclosed yesterday.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Feb. 18 (AP) -- Harvie Ward, British amateur champion from Atlanta, Ga., and David (Spec) Goldman, Dallas, Tex., tied today at 136 -- eight under par -- for medalist honors in the national tournament of golf club champions.

Before me is Section 10, a twenty-page illustrated tabloid titled "Industry Succeeds in South Carolina," which is labeled advertisement, published in THE TIMES of Sunday, Feb. 8. My only authority for writing you is that I am a purchaser of that particular issue of THE TIMES.

A new going yield level for major new issues of top credit public utility bonds was established in the bond market yesterday as a result of the sale of $25,000,000 of new mortgage bonds by the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Feb. 18 -- The contention of the Algonquin Gas Transmission Company that it had engaged in interstate commerce by transmitting natural gas across the New York-New Jersey boundary and consequently should no longer be under the jurisdiction of state courts was rejected today by Supreme Court Justice Elbert T. Gallagher.

Bennett Junior College alumnae in New York, headed by Mrs. William L. Matheson and including Mrs. Alfred M. Ehrenclou, are advancing plans for the showing of Cinerama on April 3 at the Broadway Theatre, which has been taken over for the benefit of the college's building fund.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 18 -- Four writers in the field of education, three newspapers and a television station were cited here today for outstanding contributions to the progress of writing about education. Awards were made by the Education Writers Association at its annual luncheon attended by more than 100 newspaper men and educators.

Issues of $6,675,000 of road district bonds of Jefferson Parish, La., a part of Greater New Orleans, will be offered to investors today by Allen Co. and associates at yields ranging from 1.75 to 3.75 per cent. The issues consist of obligations of $3,725,000 of Road District No. 1 bonds and $2,950,000 of Consolidated Road District A.

Twenty-nine traffic summonses collected over the last four years by Lewis Bullock of Kalamazoo, Mich., 42-year-old conductor of the American Male Chorus, cost him $1,450 in fines yesterday in Traffic Court. Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh imposed the levies and told the offender:

An organizational conference to plan the fifteenth annual international lifeboat race was held yesterday at the Whitehall Club by steamship company representatives and officers of the American Seamen's Friend Society. The race, it was announced by John Friend Noble, executive director of the society, will be on Sept. 12, probably in the Hudson River above Grant's Tomb.
Great Britain retained the International Racquets Cup yesterday with the first sweep that has been scored in the 25-year-old competition with the United States.
BOSTON, Feb. 18 -- The United Shoe Machinery Corporation has monopolized manufacture and distribution of some shoe machinery, Federal Judge Charles E. Wyzanski Jr. ruled today.

ROME, Feb. 18 -- The editors of Latinitas, quarterly magazine published in the Vatican and written entirely in the nearest possible modern version of the language of Cicero, reported today that they had caused between 600 and 700 Americans to brush up on their Latin.
TOKYO, Thursday, Feb. 19 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,530, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Thursday, Korea time:

GENEVA, Feb. 18 -- The United States is facing increasing pressure from its Allies and particularly from its best and economically strongest customer, Canada, to participate soon in another general round of tariff cutting negotiations.
Ten members -- five writers, four artists and one composer -- have been added to the roster of distinguished Americans of the National Institute of Arts and Letters.

The creation of a new agency to assist higher education is another important step in the current campaign to keep privately endowed colleges and universities solvent. This is the purpose of the newly organized Council for Financial Aid to Education. Incorporated in this state, the Council will advise those concerned with higher education how to secure financial help from the nation's corporations and business concerns.

The Lenten season opened yesterday among Protestants and Roman Catholics with Ash Wednesday services. Ashes were imposed at all masses for Roman Catholics. It was reported at St. Patrick's Cathedral that at times the lines of those who were coming for ashes stretched down the main aisle as far as the Fifth Avenue doors.
The life of Detective Walter C. Bentley of the West 152d Street police station would provide any writer of whodunits with enough material to last through an entire literary career.

BERLIN, Feb. 18 -- Dr. James Bryant Conant, United States High Commissioner for Germany, said tonight that the United States would insist on the right of all residents of Berlin to move freely throughout the city. His statement, in effect, served notice that the United States would not accept the effective division of Berlin by the Communists, which is expected about March 1.

The five-story building at 40-48 Leonard Street has been purchased for cash by Marvin S. Winter in association with S. Jules Lakin and M. L. Bennett from J. P. Stevens Co., textile manufacturers now at 1460 Broadway. The Durand Taylor Company was the broker, with the Charles F. Noyes Company representing the seller.

A chemist's eye-view of the homemaker's long day would seem to be a kindly one, judging from the number of "wonder" products from the laboratory that are designed to combat any housekeeping mishaps or annoyances. The products are on view in the Chemical Carnival, which opened yesterday at Wanamaker's.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Feb. 11

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Feb. 18 (AP) -- Robert L. Knetzer was sentenced to five years in prison and fined $5,000 today for hiding assets from creditors who poured huge sums into his fabulous auto sales business in an alfalfa field before it collapsed.

The sponsor of television's "I Love Lucy" program signed an $8,000,000 contract yesterday guaranteeing the show's run for another two and a half years. About half of this amount will be paid to Desilu Productions, which produces the program, and the other half will cover air-time charges.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 18 (UP) -- A Federal grand jury today began questioning crew members of a freighter in an attempt to solve the murder at sea of the ship's chief steward.
MAPLEWOOD, N. J., Feb. 18 -- Mrs. Marge Moretti of 92 Tiffany Place enjoyed a Cinderella-life holiday in Washington today with Uncle Sam as her Fair Prince.

A hundred or more ice skaters competed last night on the floodlighted Wollman Memorial Rink in southern Central Park in a carnival under the auspices of the Tavern-on-the-Green. Two to three hundred shivering spectators stamped their feet in the bleachers.

SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 18 -- Leroy Robertson's "Oratorio on the Book of Mormon" received its premiere performance here tonight in a style and setting rarely accorded a work by a contemporary American composer. Braving a snowstorm, an audience of 6,000 jammed the lofty tabernacle here as Maurice Abravanel, conductor, led the eighty-six-piece Utah Symphony Orchestra and a 300-voice combined University of Utah choir in a magnificent new setting of the Biblical story.

The thirtieth anniversary of the League of Composers was observed last night in the Museum of Modern Art, where the Juilliard String Quartet presented a program devoted to the chamber music of five American composers.

Smart young fashions for junior figures were presented by Bonwit Teller at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday. Sleek, uncluttered spring ensembles designed by Junior Sophisticates showed the importance of beige, butterscotch and black for spring.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Feb. 18 (AP) -- Picket lines were withdrawn and some of the 27,000 striking workers at the Atomic Energy Commission's Savannah River plant started back to work late today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 18 -- Despite the continued discussion in Washington of a blockade of Communist China, reliable sources predicted today that the United States would not ask the United Nations General Assembly to authorize a blockade. The Assembly will resume its 1952 session here Tuesday with Korea the first item on its agenda.

Dr. Leona Baumgartner, an Assistant City Commissioner of Health, called yesterday for "a new and vigorous campaign" to save the lives of mothers and infants by providing adequate prenatal care from the earliest months of pregnancy.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Feb. 18 -- Dartmouth built up an early lead and then outlasted Army in the stretch to hand the cadets their fourth straight basketball defeat, 61 to 58, in the Field House today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Representative George M. Rhodes, Democrat of Pennsylvania, a printer by trade and a union leader, urged the Labor Committee of the House of Representatives today to knock out the Taft-Hartley ban on the closed shop.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 18 -- What price peace?, San Francisco art lovers asked today. Notices appeared on bulletin boards indicating it was for sale at almost any price.

Despite general adherence to the Federal Trade Commission's Fur Name Guide, some retail furriers continue to confuse fur-buying customers by using many varied descriptions of their garments, Mrs. Karen R. Gillespie, associate professor of retailing at New York University, asserted yesterday.

In your issue of Feb. 9 you ran a very interesting editorial on the federal prison of Alcatraz, quoting the annual report of the Federal Bureau of Prisons to the effect that The Rock has outlived its usefulness, if it ever really had any, and suggesting that its inmate population be absorbed by mainland prisons of the more open type.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The House of Representatives Armed Services Committee reported today a bill intended to prevent forced demotions of junior officers, and to fix limits until next June 30, on the number of officers on active duty in each grade in the Army, Navy, Air Force and Marine Corps.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Adlai E. Stevenson, the unsuccessful Democratic nominee for President, left Washington by plane for Chicago today with the statement that President Eisenhower "deserves the players and good wishes of us all." He said he did not envy the President his burdens and responsibilities.

The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad !reported yesterday that its net profit last year was $34.355,288 after taxes and fixed charges. MIAMI, Feb. 18 -- There was a South American touch to the proceedings at Hialeah Race Course today. W. Arnold Hanger's 5-year-old horse Iceberg II, who was imported from Chile last year, won the $20,750 Bougainvillea Handicap on the grass course and set up $19.10-for-$2 returns.

The current investigation of the Voice of America by the Senate Permanent Investigating Committee deserves, I believe, some public comment by those deeply concerned with the success of the United States information program.

The opening by the National Audubon Society of its handsome new headquarters in the former Harrison Williams mansion at Ninety-fourth Street and Fifth Avenue is a milestone in the history of this useful organization. Starting out nearly a half-century ago in a room on lower Broadway, the Audubon Society has been a vital force in the growth of the conservation movement in the United States.

LITTLETON, Colo., Feb. 18 (AP) -- Harnessing of static electricity for automobile ignition was announced today by Heckethorn Manufactucing and Supply Company. D. E. Buchanan, president of the Littleton concern, described it as a sensational and revolutionary development in the industry

MOSCOW, Feb. 18 -- Diplomats in Moscow believed tonight that the possibility of new diplomatic efforts to bring the Korean war to an end was not precluded as a result of the Kremlin conversations last night between Premier Stalin and two representatives of India.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The Un-American Activities Committee of the House of Representatives, ignoring protests by educators, began today an investigation of alleged Communist activities in the nation's colleges.

The Brooklyn Museum will present "Tillie's Punctured Romance" with Charlie Chaplin, Marie Dressler, Mable Norman and the Keystone Cops with two typical Chaplin short features, "The Vagabond" and "The Adventurer" tonight and tomorrow evening at 8 o'clock in the third floor auditorium.

When Chinese Communist Premier Chou En-lai arrived in Moscow last August he was accompanied by a sizable delegation of economic experts. The natural presumption was that Chou hoped to conclude an agreement providing for additional Soviet economic assistant to augment the comparatively small $300,000,000 loan received under the treaty of February, 1950.

The ruling of the Controller of the Currency that national banks must be granted the same branch office powers now proposed for New York savings banks is "unprecedented" and constitutes an "intrusion in a state's legislative sphere," New York's Superintendent of Banks asserted yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (UP) -- United States battle casualties in Korea increased by 274 last week to a total of 130,093, the Defense Department reported today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 18 -- The Nautilus, this country's first atomic-powered submarine, will be ready for sea tests by the spring or summer of next year and the Sea Wolf, the second atomic submarine, using a different process of harnessing atomic power, will be ready in 1955, members of the Propeller Club of San Francisco heard today.

The Manhattan and Brooklyn blood-donor centers will be open as usual on Monday, Feb. 23, Washington's Birthday, the Red Cross announced yesterday. The Manhattan center, 70 West Fortieth Street, will be open from 10 A. M. to 8 P. M., and the Brooklyn center, 57 Willoughby Street, from noon until 6 P. M.

No other basketball player in Columbia history ever accomplished what Jack Molinas did last night at University Hall, where the Lions routed Princeton, 81 -- 58, in an Eastern League encounter. The dynamic senior, who only twenty-four hours earlier had been battling the flu, netted 41 points against the overmatched Tigers.

PARIS, Feb. 18 -- Although it is still expected that a new Balkan alliance will be signed by Turkey, Greece and Yugoslavia before the next month has elapsed, it is increasingly evident that negotiations among those three countries are not going according to everyone's satisfaction.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- The Bureau of the Census reported today that cotton consumption for the period of Dec. 28-Jan. 31 averaged 36,482 bales for each working day. This compared with an average of 37,682 bales for the corresponding period a year ago and with 36,736 for the December, 1952, period.

In "Maggie," which opened at the National last evening, Hugh Thomas and William Roy have tried to improve upon Barrie's "What Every Woman Knows." Taking the Barrie comedy as sourcebook, Mr. Thomas has written a libretto on the same plot, and Mr. Roy has written the songs and lyrics.

Wholesale food prices, as reflected in the Dun and Bradstreet index, moved slightly higher during the week ended on Tuesday. At $6.20, the index compared with $6.19 last week and with $6.60 in the like week of last year. Two years ago the index stood at $7.31, the highest point reached since the outbreak of the Korean war.

Two large group exhibitions of paintings have opened in club galleries, one of work by non-members at the National Arts Club, the other of work by members at the Salmagundi. The former will run through March 1, the latter through Feb. 27. Both exhibitions are largely conservative in tenor.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization of parents and teachers, recommends as suitable for children between 8 and 14 years old the following programs to be shown Friday through Sunday, unless otherwise noted:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, Senate Majority Leader assailed Democrats today for having the "nerve" to criticize Republicans for a deteriorating farm situation when, he declared, farm prices had been declining steadily during the last two years of the Democratic Administration.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The Senate Appropriations Committee made it clear today to President Eisenhower's top foreign policy aides that it expected to provide less than the $7,600,000,000 asked by President Truman for military and economic aid abroad in the 1954 fiscal year.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 18 -- One United States employe of the United Nations -- a woman doing clerical work -- has refused to fill out the forms that will provide the basis for the loyalty investigations of United States nationals on the organization's staff.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 18 -- West German industrialists and officials of the Economics Ministry will begin tomorrow a round of conferences concerning extensive engineering contracts offered by the Egyptian Government last week to the West German mission in Cairo. The contracts, an integrated plan to modernize Egypt, could be described as the basis of a ten-year plan.

Just when it appears that they are doomed to elimination, the New York Rangers come through with one of their best games of the season. Opposing the Boston Bruins in the National Hockey League clash at Madison Square Garden last night, the Broadway Blues revealed a spirited, well-rounded attack that carried them to a 4-to-2 triumph.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 18 -- The fact that private foreign capital invested in Indonesia would be "subject to certain regulations, as in all countries," should not be interpreted as meaning that country is discouraging foreign investments, Ali Sastroamidjojo, the Indonesian Ambassador, said here today.

VERO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 18 -- Training doesn't begin officially for the Dodgers until tomorrow morning at 10 o'clock, when Manager Chuck Dressen will start pitchers, catchers and several other Brooks in their conditioning exercises.

The one-story taxpayer building containing seven stores at 118-23 Metropolitan Avenue in Kew Gardens, Queens, has been sold by Laurence M. Lyons, real estate operator, to investors represented by Netter Netter, attorneys. Richard R. Romeo was the broker and the Metropolitan Title Guaranty Company insured title.

Africa's wildlife and the perils of tracking and killing it, about which a great many books have been written, are the subjects of "Killers in Africa," a volume that "debunks many popular myths about jungle animals." The author is Alexander Lake, who was reared in Africa and spent twelve years scouting the jungles as a professional meat hunter.

Fire in a New York Central Railroad control tower halted all traffic on the line's Harlem Division and also stopped all New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad trains for more than an hour last night. The fire, discovered at 7:10 P. M., did extensive damage to Tower 1, which controls all movement within the Mott Haven yards in the Bronx.

The Netherlands has proposed that the conference of Foreign Ministers, which is to meet next week in Rome, discuss plans for a Continental customs union as a basis for further economic and political integration. The proposal is promising because, as demonstrated by the development of the German Zollverein of the previous century, a customs union is the best foundation for political unification.
Lloyd K. Neidlinger has been made executive director of the United States Council of the International Chamber of Commerce.

The American-Korean Foundation will undertake in mid-March a rehabilitation mission to Korea to help that nation's handicapped become productive again, Dr. Milton Eisenhower, chairman of the new foundation, said yesterday.
William Inge's play, "Picnic," will open tonight at 8 o'clock at the Music Box under the sponsorship of the Theatre Guild and Joshua Logan.

A collection of American nineteenth century paintings, one of the largest ever assembled for exhibition, is now on the high seas bound for West Germany. Aboard the American Traveller, cargo ship of the United States Lines, are seventy-six oil paintings and fourteen water-colors that have been lent by museums throughout the country as well as by private collectors.

A record production of men's dress and sports shirts was established last year, the National Association of Shirt, Pajama and Sportwear Manufacturers reported yesterday. The 18,282,500 dozen produced in the year compares with 16,564,300 in 1951 and 18,099,300 in 1950, the previous record.

Lehman Brothers and associates yesterday made an offering of 37,800 shares of outstanding Lehman. Corporation capital .stock at $72.375 a share for the account of the estate of Allan S. Lehman, deceased. The offeringwas oversubscribed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- President Eisenhower put this country's military position in the world before twenty-five leading members of Congress today in a hard, plain-spoken briefing that did not suggest any imminent crisis and did not involve high foreign policy.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 19 -- In contrast with the great expectations in Argentina over the impending visit to Chile of President Juan D. Peron, the Chilean man in the street shows no particular interest in the event, even if it is heralded as the first step in the formation of a Latin-American economic bloc.

Outside shooting strength brought the Billikens of St. Louis a 98-78 victory over New York University before 7,526 basketball fans at Madison Square Garden last night. Ed Hickey's long-range snipers inflicted the heaviest damage with eye-opening one-handers, after St. John's had kept its tournament hopes alive with a 60-56 triumph over Niagara in the first game.

The pleasures and problems of identical twins -- long a fascination for romantic novelists and daydreaming 10-year-olds -- are of special interest also to psychologists, psychiatrists and other students of child development. The findings of an intensive study of a small number of British twins during infancy and early childhood, carried on at the Hampstead Nurseries, a wartime home for children outside London, were made public yesterday.

Workers in Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company food stores in Brooklyn and Queens voted yesterday in favor of representation by Local 1500 of the Retail Clerks International Association, A, F. L., the regional office of the National Labor Relations Board announced last night.

A single film will open today at a Broadway theatre. At the Embassy Newsreel Theatre is "Blood Brothers," a compilation of newsreel films tracing and analyzing the growth of various totalitarian systems with emphasis on Russia from Czar Nicholas to the regime of Stalin.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The Republican economy drive got off to an uncertain start today as the House of Representatives voted down its Appropriations Committee on one proposed reduction in Federal spending and sustained it on another.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19 -- The will of Mrs. Lolita Sheldon Armour, filed in Probate Court today, disposes of an estate estimated at $7,100,000. Mrs. Armour, widow of J. Ogden Armour, died at the age of 83 years in her Lake Forest, Ill., home Feb. 7.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. announced today that the Department of Justice would no longer withhold prosecution in tax fraud cases where ill health is advanced by the defendant as a reason for avoiding trial.
CLEVELAND, Feb. 19 (AP) --' Thompson Products, Inc., reported today its biggest net income and net sales volume in history. $9,252,579 profit in 1952 on sales of $274,080,027.

LONDON, Feb. 19 -- Britain and Egypt have reached an understanding on the tricky question of the Sudan's future right to join the British Commonwealth, officials indicated here today. The understanding apparently included tacit agreement that neither side would press for precise commitments that might create domestic political embarrassment for the other.
A photograph showing Mrs. Golda Myerson, first Israeli Ambassador to the Soviet Union, being warmly greeted by Soviet Jews in Moscow in 1948 was received here from Israel yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- During the week ended Feb, 18, member bank reserves decreased $58,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 19 -- A fullfledged Red scandal has broken out over Mexico's education system with charges that the new Under Secretary of Education, Jose Gomez Robleda, is a Communist, set on converting the country's public schools into Marxist seminaries.

For promoting goodwill and understanding among Protestants, Roman Catholics and Jews, seven leaders in the communications and amusement fields were honored last night at a Brotherhood Week Dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel under the sponsorship of the National Conference of Christians and Jews.

Despite warnings that the city could not afford the projects, the Board of Estimate yesterday by divided votes approved the $10,000,000 Fort Greene slum clearance plan for Brooklyn and the $5,000,000 reconstruction of the street entrance to the Manhattan plaza of the Brooklyn Bridge.

Tuscaloosa, Ala., sold yesterday two issues of bonds totaling $4,500,000 to a syndicate headed by Shields Co. Of the total, $2,000,000 are waterworks bonds maturing from 1956 to 1983, for which the bankers paid 100.046 for interest rates of 4 per cent, 3 per cent and 3 1/2 per cent, an interest cost of 3.3815 per cent.

Communist forces in the Dressmakers Union, Local 22, of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A. F. L., suffered the worst defeat in their history in balloting yesterday that elected the local's officers and executive board members for the next three years.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) -- The Norwegian Embassy said today that two ships that had been stripped of their Panamanian registry for trading with Communist China had been identified incorrectly as Norwegian ships.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, tonight appointed a seven-man committee to produce within nine weeks a thorough plan for "streamlining" the defense establishment. He named the committee after conferring with President Eisenhower.

Mrs. Thomas E. Murray gave a tea yesterday afternoon in her home at 686 Park Avenue for her daughter, Mrs. Basil Harris Jr., and a group of women serving with Mrs. Harris in behalf of a special sale to be held on May 13 at the Fordham School of Social Service for the benefit of the school.

The American Tariff League questioned yesterday whether this country could easily absorb an additional $5,000,000,000 to $6,000,000,000 in imports. Belief that the country could absorb this quantity of foreign goods was expressed by Henry Ford 2d, president of the Ford Motor Company, in a speech delivered in Chicago on Tuesday.

Financial and commodity exchanges throughout the United States will be closed next Monday, Feb. 23, in observance of Washington's Birthday. Various livestock reports, however, will be issued by the Department of Agriculture. Canadian and European markets will be open for business as usual.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Harry S. Truman, with pen in hand and tongue in cheek, said today he was not sure whether he had been paid for a full day last Jan. 20 -- when he turned over the Presidential office at noon to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower.

Details of the initial $22,000,000 expansion program for Simpson-Sears, Ltd., in Canada were announced yesterday in Toronto by E. G. Burton, president. The company has purchased twenty acres in Hamilton, Ont., and will build a department store there carrying a full range of merchandise.

JERSEY CITY, Feb. 19 -- Hudson County's special grand jury investigating waterfront crime and racketeering today handed up indictments against two longshoremen's union labor leaders on charges of accepting bribes from a stevedoring concern.

Spring practice for football teams in the Ivy League will not be revived this year, it was disclosed yesterday. This group ruled out the spring preparation last year but there was hope among some coaches that it would be restored to permit the change over from the two-platoon system.

Domestic Relations Court Justice Justine Wise Polier decided yesterday that a father who had refused to send his daughter to an antiquated public school was not guilty of violating the compulsory education law.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19 (UP) -- Wally Hergesheimer's two goals with less than five minutes to play tonight gave the New oYrk Rangers their second straight victory over the Chicago Black Hawks, 4 to 2, before 6,881 Chicago Stadium fans in a National Hockey League game.

A "standing-room-only" crowd was present in Traffic Court yesterday when former Magistrate J. Roland Sala appeared to answer to twelve summonses for illegal parking, but the expected display of pyrotechnics never came off because Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh disqualified himself and put the hearing over till Tuesday.

Bruno Walter, appearing as guest conductor with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall, prefaced his performance of Mahler's "Lied von der Erde" with Haydn's B-flat symphony numbered as 102 of his 104 accredited works in that form.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) -The brass mill industry has appealed for immediate removal of price ceilings from its raw material, copper, and from brass mill products.

The National Shipping Authority reported yesterday that it had a total of 110 Government-owned and privately-operated cargo vessels under assignment to the Navy's Military Sea Transportation Service as of Feb. 1. This was one more than on Jan. 1.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 19 -- Glenn Ford has pulled out of a pending two-picture deal with Universal-International to sign with Columbia to play the lead in "The Big Heat." Fritz Lang will begin directing next week. The melodrama concerns graft and corruption involving the police department of a big city.

Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., the United States new chief delegate to the United Nations, assured the Senate Internal Security subcommittee yesterday that he would cooperate fully with its investigation of subversive activities among American employes of the United Nations.

One hundred fifty detectives and policemen were searching last night for a 30-year-old shipping clerk who is wanted by the Brooklyn police in connection with the violent deaths of his wife, mother-in-law and father-in-law. A nation-wide alarm was issued for the suspect.

The stock market yesterday staged a mild but mixed advance, with rails again in the front. Soft drink and food issues, which stand to do better as a result of recent commodity declines, also reflected demand. Only one of the ten most active issues closed lower.

BOSTON, Feb. 19 -- Three members of the Eisenhower Administration were honored tonight by the Northeast Division of the National Conference of Christians and Jews for their contributions to human brotherhood.

The American Heritage Foundation, which conducted a "register and vote" campaign last year, estimated in a report made public yesterday that 13,166,000 adults in the United States had been disfranchised in the 1952 Presidential election, mostly by laws and regulations in the states.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- National political interest was attracted today to a report in well-informed quarters that Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. was under consideration by "independent" party and labor leaders as a coalition Democratic-Liberal nominee for Mayor of New York.
CAIRO, Feb. 19 -- Egyptian Foreign Minister Mahmoud Fawzi talked with the British Ambassador, Sir Ralph Stevenson, half an hour at the Foreign Ministry this evening.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Resumption of exports of sulfa drugs and antibiotics to Europe have been approved on a limited scale by the Office of International Trade of the United States Department of Commerce. The department, after having put an embargo on such shipments early last month, has eased the restrictions for the benefit of flood sufferers and victims of the influenza epidemic in parts of Europe.

Fifty-one church and civic leaders appealed yesterday to President Eisenhower to condemn publicly Soviet persecution of minority national and religions groups, and to initiate a United Nations investigation of such persecutions.
Skiers headed for their favorite skilands in the north today in the hope that good sports would be available for the extended Washington Birthday week-end.
The controversy over the respective merits of private and public schools came to the fore again yesterday with proponents of each side finally agreeing that a healthy democracy needed both.

Representatives of ten struck cemeteries accepted last night the recommendations of a state fact-finding panel for settling their dispute with 200 striking gravediggers, but union leaders put off any back-to-work move until the proposals had been considered by the full membership at a meeting tomorrow night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -Mutual Security Director Harold E. Stassen told the House Foreign Affairs Committee today that the United States should expand its purchases of military equipment in Western Europe.

The American briar pipe industry is not one of the big ones -- last year it employed about sixteen hundred persons. Nor are briar pipes a large factor in international trade -- last year we imported about $400,000 worth. But relatively small items, as was once the case with tea brought into Boston harbor, may stand for sizable issues.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 19 -- The United States and thirteen of its Allies talked about Korea today, and the delegates left the conference with the impression that the trend was against calling for anything "spectacular" in the way of new action by the United Nations General Assembly against the Communists.

ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- William E. Frame, president of the State Automobile Dealers Association, asserted today in a statement distributed to members of the Legislature that compulsory automobile inspection was more effective when done through licensed private stations than through state-operated stations.

The Appellate Division reserved decision yesterday on an application by five New York newspapers and two press associations for an order rescinding the ban on the press and the public at the vice trial of Minot F. (Mickey) Jelke.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 19 -- West German authorities have filed the first criminal action of national importance in the brief history of the Bonn Republic, moving against a major industry on charges of practices in restraint of trade.

Speaking in Berlin, which he characterized as an "unshaken outpost of the Western World," Dr. Conant, the new American High Commissioner in Germany has made two statements which should go far to reassure the population of West Berlin and the Germans in general.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The Small Defense Plants Administration today put a ceiling of $300,000 on its individual loans to small businesses for plant expansions or conversions.

MOSCOW, Friday, Feb. 20 -- The Indian Embassy asserted yesterday that reports that a "Korean armistice" had been discussed in the conversation between Premier Stalin and the Indian Ambassador, K. P. S. Menon, were "entirely incorrect.''
WASHINGTON,, Feb. 19 (AP) -- A second Finnish tanker, loaded with jet fuel for Communist warplanes, has been spotted in the Mediterranean by Western security agents.

Operations of the Western Auto Supply Company (Missouri) resulted last year in net income of $4,737,972, equal to $6.31 a common share, according to the report issued yesterday by P. E. Connor, chairman. This compares with $5,579,388, or $7.43 a share in 1951.

PARIS, Feb. 19 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Supreme Commander, Allied Powers in Europe, won his battle today for the funds for the 1953 military construction program he had laid out for European defense.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (UP) -- Representative Edna F. Kelly, Democrat of New York, urged the Administration today to lower the support price for butter so that "consumers will eat it instead of having to accumulate in Government warehouses."

United States Attorney Frank J. Parker began suit yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court to liquidate the financial holdings of Joseph Profaci, olive oil distributor, so the Government could recover a total of $2,080,563 in back taxes, penalties and interest.

BIELEFELD, Germany, Feb. 19 -- Sir Ivone Kirkpatrick, British High Commissioner in Germany, was accused of exercising dictatorial powers and violating the fundamental objectives of the Allied occupation today at a habeas corpus hearing for two Nazi plotters.

We here at the United Hatters, Cap and Millinery Workers International Union were very much interested in the Feb. 11 editorial in THE NEW YORK TIMES. We were particularly concerned by your comment that "the hostility of the labor unions to the injunction stems historically from the days of an era that is today as dead as the dodo."

Nearly all of the program of piano music that Barbara Steinbach played last night in Town Hall was slanted toward the bravura end of the repertoire. It ranged from Schumann's G minor Sonata through the twelve Etudes of Chopin's Op. 10 and the percussive velocity of Prokofieff's Third Sonata.

The executive board of the State Congress of Industrial Organizations, at its monthly meeting at the Governor Clinton Hotel, called upon the Legislature yesterday to continue existing state rent controls for at least two years.

ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- A compromise bill under which the State Department of Education would be authorized to establish three television stations as a pilot project has been introduced in the Legislature by Senator Earl W. Brydges, Republican of Niagara, chairman of the Education Committee.

Defense Secretary Wilson has welcomed the report of the Citizens Advisory Commission on Utilization of Manpower in the Armed Services, in which it is stated that a reduction of at least 10 per cent in military expenditure and personnel is feasible. The commission, headed by General Sarnoff, is not a sharp-shooting or "flyspecking" body.

The Columbia Broadcasting System very possibly is the most pleasantly surprised network of them all this week. As practically a desperation measure to compete on television with the Milton Berle program over N. B. C., the network picked up on Tuesday night the climactic parade of the Mardi Gras in New Orleans.

The spring's leading trends in coats and suits are represented in wide variety in the season's new collection at Ohrbach's. Yesterday morning the press had a quick preview of the styles now available in the store.
RANGOON, Burma, Feb. 19 -- A frontier outpost on the China-Burmese border has fallen to Chinese Nationalist guerrillas, Burma Army headquarters sources reported today.

FARMINGDALE, L. I., Feb. 19 -- The 22,000 employes at the Republic Aviation Corporation who became the highest paid airframe builders in the nation when the end of Federal wage controls released $4,500,000 to them in retroactive pay early this week, will receive additional pay increase through a wage agreement signed here today.

Resuming their seasonal decline after turning upward in the previous week, loans to business by New York banks dropped $38,000,000 last week. The reduction marked the fourth in five weeks and brought the total decline since the start of this year to $192,000,000, against an increase of $9,000,000 a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended Feb. 14 totaled 681,750 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 8,994 cars, or 1.3 per cent, fewer than in the preceding week; 56,026 cars, or 7.6 per cent, fewer than in the corresponding week last year, and 58,807 cars, or 7.9 per cent, fewer than in the corresponding week two years ago.

Communist propaganda long ago passed the bounds of truth and credibility. Now, apparently, the fearsome oracle has nowhere to go but into the realm of the ridiculous. How explain otherwise the latest invention -- a story in the Neues Deutschland, party organ in East Germany, explaining American and West German aid during the recent flood disaster as a "dress rehearsal" for a new occupation of the Netherlands ?
Demands for the removal of Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan gained force yesterday in this city and in Washington.

AT THE KOREAN FRONT, Feb. 5 -- The razorback ridges, the bald and rock-ribbed mountains, the inferior road net make Korea a nightmarish place for the tank warriors of the United States Army. But on the theory that "if you've got a weapon you might as well use it," tanks are being employed against the enemy here and being employed to very good advantage.

HOUSTON, Tex., Feb. 19 -- A 427-foot long steel dock barge, described as the largest and heaviest structure of its type ever built, was launched at the plant of the Todd Shipyards Corporation here today.

Victims of malaria who have had no attack of the disease for more than a year, and those who have not received malaria-suppressing drugs for the same length of time, may now give blood, the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program announced yesterday.

Freedom of communication is an indispensable ingredient of American liberty, the Very Rev. Laurence J. McGinley, president of Fordham University, said last night in an address prepared for the opening of the annual Patterson Lecture series.
TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 19 -- Today in Teheran there was an air of expectation surrounding the subject of negotiations for a settlement of Iran's oil dispute with Britain.

Admiral Corporation, one of the country's largest television receiver manufacturers, revealed yesterday that it has increased dealer mark-ups on its products "6 per cent and more." A spokesman for the company declined to say what the maximum mark-up on any set in the line would be, but retailers reported that it comes to 36 per cent.
NEWPORT, R. I., Feb. 19 -- The will of Frederick H. Prince was filed in probate court here today, disposing of an estate of $11,000,000, most of it in a charitable trust established in 1932.

THE big game hunters who have resisted conversion to the bolt-action rifle, and refuse to abandon the slide action, will soon be able to get the increasingly popular .270 in their favorite action, for Remington has added this caliber to the three "big bores" for which their "Gamemaster" is chambered.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Feb. 19 -- All foreign merchant ships attempting to enter Communist Chinese ports are risking the danger of being intercepted or attacked by the Chinese Nationalist Navy and Air Force, it was indicated tonight by the Nationalist Government spokesman, Dr. Shen Chang-huan.

Daily newspapers reporting to the American Newspaper Publishers Association had a total newsprint consumption in January of 351,775 tons, an increase of 1.9 per cent over that month last year, the organization announced yesterday.

BERLIN, Feb. 19 -- Fears that a church-state crisis might be impending in East Germany were stirred here today by the disappearance of two prominent Lutheran clergymen in or near Halle and the abrupt halting of an Evangelical Church anniversary celebration there by Soviet Zone authorities.

FARMINGDALE, L. I., Feb. 19 -- Long Island's perennial harbinger of spring, the annual country life open house program of the Agricultural and Technical Institute of the State University of New York, opened today with the blessings of a warm sun and balmy breezes.

PARIS, Feb. 19 -- Paul van Zeeland, Foreign Minister of Belgium, journeyed to Paris today to make a plea that the United States and Europe put their bickerings aside and make a new and mutually confident approach to problems of the North Atlantic Community.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- President Eisenhower today appointed former Gov. Val Peterson of Nebraska as acting Federal Civil Defense Administrator and said he would soon send his nomination to the Senate as administrator.
PARIS, Feb. 19 -- Two Jewish war orphans, Robert and Gerald Finaly, who have been vainly claimed by surviving relatives in Israel, tonight were reported in Spain.
Among this week's numerous art exhibitions there are several that an amateur of wide taste and occasional tolerance should not miss.

TOKYO, Friday, Feb. 20 -- Eleven Allied B-29 bombers from Japan flew far into Northwest Korea early today and loosed 500-pound bombs on the Communist military headquarters and supply complex of Unhyang, five miles from the Yalu River mouth across from Manchuria.

PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 19 -- The establishment of a new Council of the Humanities to stimulate teaching and research in those fields of scholarship at Princeton University will be recommended at the next meeting of the university board of trustees by Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president, and members of the faculty.

Spring millinery, interpreted in fresh, flattering colors and combined subtly with delicate, romantic flowers, was presented yesterday by Milgrim's Custom Salon at the Hotel Plaza. Flattering softness took precedence over severe lines.
A training program that will produce 207 co-pilots and ninety-nine flight engineers by Oct. 15 has been started at La Guardia Airport by American Airlines.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The Senate subcommittee investigating the Voice of America was told today that the State Department had ordered yesterday that no material from books or other works of Communists or other controversial authors be used, under any conditions, in the American drive to pierce the Iron Curtain with the truth about democracy.

THE three of them came thundering into the finish line abreast, the closest thing to a triple dead heat since Bossuet, Brownie and Wait A Bit achieved that virtual impossibility at Aqueduct in 1943. It happened at the National A. A. U. championships in the Garden last Saturday as Mal Whitfield, Ollie Sax and Reggie Pearman hit the tape apparently simultaneously at the end of the 600.
ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- The setting up of a program designed to reduce public dependency and conserve public welfare funds was reported today by Robert T. Lansdale, State Commissioner of Social Welfare.

LONDON, Feb. 19 -- Reis Leming, 22-year-old United States airman who saved twenty-seven persons from drowning in the floods that hit the east coast of England at the beginning of this month, will get the George Medal, it was announced today.

Twenty-five pieces of uninsured jewelry, once covered by $129,650 of policies, were stolen Wednesday evening from the apartment of Mr. and Mrs. John Baruche at 1060 Park Avenue, at Eighty-seventh Street, while the two were at a neighborhood motion - picture theatre.

TRENTON, Feb. 19 -- Political developments in this state today included an announcement from Washington by Senator H. Alexander Smith that he favored the nomination of Representative Clifford Case as the Republican candidate for Governor and a formal declaration by former Representative Elmer H. Wene that he would seek the same designation on the Democratic ticket.

High tribute to American retailers and their methods was voiced yesterday by Scandinavian merchants who are winding up a six-weeks tour here. At a conference in the offices of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, the Norwegian, Danish and Swedish retailers said they were greatly impressed by store lay-out, fixtures, personnel training and the use of highly trained specialists by American stores.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Al Brosch of Garden City, L. I. and Johnny Palmer of Charlotte, N. C., led a field of 162 with eight-under-par 64's today to tie for the lead in the opening round of the ninth $9,450 Mexican open golf tournament.

Senator Charles W. Tobey, Republican of New Hampshire, chairman of the Senate Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee, disclosed yesterday that televised public hearings on waterfront crime, scheduled to open here next week, would be delayed two weeks because of "a lot of new evidence."

Predictions of trends in summer accessories were given at a meeting of the Fashion Group yesterday noon in the Astor Hotel. The showing was planned and presented by the accessories division of the group.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 19 -- The John Scott Award for 1952 was presented tonight to Dr. Glenn T. Seaborg, Nobel Prize winner in physics, and nuclear scientist of the University of California's radiation laboratory.

In its first change of ownership in more than fifty years, the five-story building at 47 Broadway through to Trinity Place was sold by the Bank of New York, trustee of Newbold Morris, and A. New-bold Morris, Stephanus V. C. Morris and George L. K. Morris to the Brunswick Realty Company, Maurice L. Zobel, vice president.

A program to strengthen the role of retail distribution in the nation's economy, covering nine specific areas of activity, has been proposed by the post-defense planning committee of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, it was announced yesterday.

OTTAWA, Feb. 19 -- Widespread tax reductions, including an 11 per cent cut in personal income levies effective July 1, were announced in Parliament tonight by Finance Minister Douglas C. Abbott. He said the moves were based on confidence that Canadian output this year would be about 4 per cent higher than the record totals for 1952.

A strike and increased costs reduced sales and earnings of the West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company in its first quarter ended on Jan. 31, David L. Luke Jr., president, informed shareholders at the annual meeting here yesterday at which Eli Whitney Debevoise was elected a director. He is a New York attorney and former assistant United States High Commissioner of Germany.
Paddy De Marco, wild-swinging warrior from the Navy Yard section of Brooklyn, will tackle George Araujo of Providence in the star bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight.

A television tour of United Nations Headquarters will be offered over Channel 2 on Sunday afternoon from 4 to 4:30 o'clock during the regular presentation of the "State of the Nation" program conducted by Eric Sevareid. Six cameras will be located in and around the U. N. buildings and one in the near-by Chrysler Tower.

Although John Golden was advised by his doctor to slow down after a recent eye operation, the doyen of Broadway producers is being urged by friends to take the Shaw comedy, "Misalliance," under his wing and move it with the same cast to a Broadway house, perhaps the Barrymore, at the conclusion of the fortnight's stand at the City Center on March 1.
CHICAGO, Feb. 19 (UP) -- A destructive blizzard spread over the Great Plains today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Plans for an economic conference on the expansion of United States private investment and trade with Israel were discussed by officials of the Zionist Organization of America today with Sinclair Weeks, Secretary of Commerce.

Amid the considerable ceremony warranted by the importance of the event, on the campus, to the City of New York and to educational circles as well. Buell Gordon Gallagher was installed in office yesterday as president of City College. The college, unique in various ways, is now 106 years old and Dr. Gallagher is its seventh president.

A statement made by the Office of Price Stabilization that decontrol of cosmetics will mean a general consumer price rise of 10 per cent on these products was condemned yesterday by the Toilet Goods Association as "completely unwarranted and false." Cosmetics were among numerous products decontrolled on Wednesday.

Arthur Larsen of San Leandro, Calif., and Kurt Nielsen of Copenhagen were among the five players to reach the quarter finals of the national indoor tennis championships at the Seventh Regiment Armory last night, completing the brackets in this round.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 19 -- A five-year program to stabilize Korea's public health and medical services has been recommended to the United Nations by a three-man team of experts from the World Health Organization, it was revealed today.

BOSTON, Feb. 19 -- The Pilot, official weekly newspaper of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston, says in its issue of this week that the Rev. Leonard Feeney, who has been involved in a controversy over the salvation of non-Catholics, has been excommunicated by the Catholic Church.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 19 -- Action taken in New York to freeze Brazilian gold deposits as security for overdue commercial debts has raised a storm of angry protest here in which for once all shades of Brazilian opinion seem to join, though not all on the same grounds.
While New Orleans was enjoying its famed Mardi Gras festival earlier this week, the manufacturer of a molasses made in that city held a party for the press here at the Pierre Hotel.

LONDON, Feb. 19 -- The stock market here closed on a firmer note today after being subdued and uncertain most of the day. Gold shares, in particular, rallied and ended, with widespread net gains. Other categories showed narrow and irregular price movements, though some individual features developed among industrials.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Feb. 19 -- Deputy Attorney General Albert Ash made public today a year-old statement by Joe Adonis, giving the imprisoned gambler's own version of a meeting he and Willie Moretti, slain racketeer, had with Republican State Chairman John J. Dickerson at the latter's home on Nov. 5, 1950.
Opera Futures, a workshop directed by Lee Shaynen, presented its third session of student performances last evening at the Carl Fischer Concert Hall.

The mother and two sisters of Julius Rosenberg, convicted atom spy, have asked a member of the jury that found him and his wife, Ethel, guilty, to sign a petition for clemency, it was learned yesterday. The request was rejected.

MIAMI, Feb. 19 -- With T. F. Atkinson, Esq., in the saddle, a 4-year-old colt named Great Captain did some brisk running in the stretch to win the $5,000 purse that headed Hialeah's program today. Great Captain is owned by Ogden Phipps, the vice chairman of The Jockey Club, and is trained by Sunny Jim Fitzsimmons, the grand old man of the horse parks.

The Illinois Central Railroad borrowed $4,500,000 in the public market yesterday on an issue of equipment trust certificates maturing semi-annually over the next fifteen years. The certificates were sold to a banking syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., at a bid of 99.1459 for a dividend of 3 per cent, a cost to the railroad of about 3.125 per cent.
ROCHESTER, N. Y., Feb. 19 (AP) -- The Eastman Kodak Company today announced a new method for figuring its employes' share of profits in excess of the current rate.

James Michener, author of three books about the Pacific, has delivered to Random House the manuscript of a new novel. Titled "Sayonara: A Japanese Romance," it is the love story of a modern Madame Butterfly and an American airman.

The death rate from tuberculosis in upstate New York last yearl dropped to the 'lowest level ever recorded Dr. Herman E. Hilleboe, State Health Commissioner, reported here yesterday at a rrreeting of the New York State Chapter of the American College of Chest Physicians at the New Yorker Hotel.
BOSTON, Feb. 19 -- Roman Catholic brides in the Boston Archdiocese no longer will march down the aisle to the tune of "Here Comes the Bride." Nor will soloists sing "Oh, Promise Me."

One of the questions that many Americans will wish to put to General Van Fleet concerns the disturbing reports of malnutrition in the South Korean Army. Dispatches to this newspaper indicate that hunger is a major cause of hospitalization and it is established that some combat units are staying at the front with a ration of three handfuls of rice a day.

The New York Chapter of La Confrerie des Chevaliers du Tastevin marked the society's 250th anniversary with a dinner this week at the Pierre Hotel. Men who know and love the wines of Burgundy compose this group, the name of which, literally translated, means the Fraternity of the Knights of Wine-tasting.

The lot of the old-time copyI writer was a simple one comparedI with that of his modern counter-I part, it was pointed out last night by Walter O'Meara, senior viceI president of Lennen NeweR, Inc. Nevertheless, he said, the basic ingredients of effective copy --promise and repetltion---are as important now as in the first days of "salesmanship in print."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Opponents of a constitutional amendment to limit this country's treaty-making powers contended today it would prevent the United States from adopting its own plan for United Nations control of the atomic bomb.

LONDON, Friday, Feb. 20 (Reuters) -- A British raiding party in Antarctica pounced on an Argentine base on Deception Island in the Antarctic Sunday, arresting two occupants and dismantling buildings, the British Foreign Office said today.
TOKYO, Friday, Feb. 20 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,531, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Friday, Korea time:
Dr. Buell Gordon Gallagher, 49-year-old Congregational minister and educator, was formally installed yesterday as the seventh president of the 106-year-old City College.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Syracuse held Penn's high-scoring center, Ernie Beck, to 11 points, but his team-mate, Dick Heylmun, came through with a brilliant second-half shooting display to give Penn its fifteenth victory in eighteen starts, 71 -- 67, at the Palestra tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Military aircraft capable of eluding the radar screens of enemy watchers are now feasible for the United States, William E. Braham, aircraft expert and chief engineer of the Zenith Plastic Company, said here today.

Defense counsel in the investment banking anti-trust trial said yesterday that unsupported charges in the complaint were a contrivance by which the Government insinuated a theory of conspiracy which it could not prove.

FORT MEADE, Md., Feb. 19 (UP) -- A motion to call former Secretary of Defense Louis Johnson and General of the Army Douglas MacArthur to testify at the court-martial of Lieut. Col. Melvin B. Voorhees was denied today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The Senate Preparedness subcommittee recommended today that all Federal agencies "having appropriate jurisdiction and authority" take immediate action to see that materiel for the Armed Forces overseas flows through the Port of New York "at a fair cost to the Government and without undue interference by any group."

Trading continued light yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges. But potatoes remained active, making the best showing for the week and the volume in coffee was the highest in two weeks. Prices were irregularly higher with wool, rubber, cotton-seed oil, lead and zinc showing gains. Cocoa and hides closed lower and potatoes, sugar, coffee and soybean oil ended mixed.

The annual Colonial ball arranged under the auspices of junior members of the Daughters of the American Revolution and the Sons of the American Revolution will be held tonight at the Pierre. Proceeds will be donated to the D. A. R. Helen Pouch Memorial Fund, which provides scholarships for several Southern schools and colleges.

Avery C. Adams, president of the Pittsburgh Steel Company, told the New York Society of Security Analysts yesterday that for ten years he has been predicting capacity operations in the steel industry and added: "I predict them for this year, too."
Housewives rushed to snap up bargain New Zealand beef in scattered parts of the nation yesterday as complaints from domestic livestock interests mounted.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Feb. 19 -- United States military authorities and the French Government have virtually completed negotiations that may eliminate a long-standing sore point between the two countries -- the shortage of suitable homes for the families of United States servicemen stationed in France.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19 -- A brisk rally in corn futures followed the announcement by the Commodity Credit Corporation that the Government agency would buy some new corn to offset sales of off-grade corn which would have to be sold in the next ten weeks. The rally failed to hold to the full extent as the agency announcement was vague in regard to the amount of corn it would buy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- In the days when the military budget was about $14 billions James Forrestal, the first Secretary of Defense, used to say on the subject of eliminating waste from Pentagon expenditures:

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Feb. 19 -- Governor Dewey appealed tonight for public support of his highway safety program which the Legislature is balking at approving despite large Republican majorities in both Senate and Assembly.

The British did not invent the sausage. Perhaps nobody did. The sausage, like hash and stew, has appeared spontaneously in many parts of the world. It is no doubt a result of natural causes. The British, let us repeat, did not invent the sausage. They ate it to a considerable extent. They presented it in their literature.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that department store sales in the week ended Feb. 14 were 3 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1952:

New York State has from the earliest days of its history been a leader, indeed a pioneer, in education. Therefore it is discouraging to see in various circles, governmental and otherwise, an inclination to defer or even oppose the acceptance of the great new educational instrument of television.

VERO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 19 -- Russell Charles Meyer, the right-hander who came to the Dodgers from Philadelphia via Boston, reported at noon today and an hour and a half later was starring in his own "Meet the Press" program, sponsored by the Brooks' vice president, Buzzie Bavasi, and Manager Chuck Dressen.
The futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday and final prices were 4 points lower to 3 points higher than on Wednesday.

Intimation of changes in the policy of the Federal Trade Commission under the new Republican Administration was heard in addresses yesterday at the fifth annual meeting of the Anti-Trust Section of the New York State Bar Association.

HONG KONG, Feb. 19 -- A national bond issue is scheduled to be floated in China this year to help the Peiping Government cover a projected gap in its record 9,864,700,000-United States dollar state budget for 1953. The American dollar equivalent is calculated on the basis of the official exchange rate of 23,670 people's dollars for one American dollar.

BERLIN, Feb. 19 -- Railway section gangs, carpenters, electricians and scores of other workmen are laboring day and night to convert Friedrichstrasse Station, the hub of Berlin's rapid transit system, into a "port of entry" for the Communist world.
LONDON, Feb. 19 -- Britain's defense budget for the financial year beginning April 1 will be 1,636,000,000 ($4,580,800,000) -- the largest in the peacetime history of this country.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- A memorandum from Department of Justice files was placed in the record today at a House Judiciary subcommittee hearing. It was identified as the only existing document bearing on the purported "agreement" under which Federal agents were to abstain from questioning members of the New York police force about brutalities arising from civil rights cases:

Something about the approach of spring seems to encourage, in certain quarters, the production of operettas. About this time of the year music teachers in the schools, and church choir directors whose duties also include supervision of youngsters' choral groups, take deep breaths, offer up prayers for patience and begin to work on operettas that may not get on the boards until May.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Feb., 19 -- French circles declared today there was absolutely no question of releasing the Chinese Nationalist soldiers interned in Indo-China. Yesterday a Rangoon report said Taipei was putting pressure on the Vietnam Government to release the internees so they could rejoin the Nationalist forces of General Li Mi on the China-Burma border.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Chief Judge Bolitha Laws of the United States District Court of the District of Columbia, sustained a motion by the Department of Justice today to dismiss the suit of I. G. Chemie, a Swiss banking corporation, to recover the stock of the General Aniline and Film Corporation, which was seized by the Government as alien property when the United states entered World War II.

On Feb. 10 you report that the air pollution department moved against waterfront smoke by issuing a summons against the liner Queen of Bermuda, with a warning to the Queen Mary and the Gripsholm. This is a little like telling a newly arrived immigrant who dropped a piece of paper on the sidewalk that he is fouling our immaculate streets.

ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- Lieut. Gov. Frank C. Moore made it clear to utility company representatives today that he intended to use every effort to obtain passage of legislation which would give to local units of government the right now performed by the state to fix special franchise valuations for railroads and utilities.

Many dinner parties will be given in the Rendez-Vous of the Plaza before the performance of "The Love of Four Colonels," with Lilli Palmer and Rex Harrison in the leading roles, next Thursday night at the Shubert Theatre, which has been taken over for the benefit of the Grosvenor Neighborhood House.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Feb. 19 -- A bill agreed to by all parties naming Queen Elizabeth II Queen of the South African Union was published today. At the same time, the leading Government newspaper, Die Burger, of which Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan was formerly editor, stated that it hoped the day would come when South Africa would be a republic.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 19 -- Unless more adequate financial support is given at once, the nation's public schools will face a crisis, educators warned here today. They called this need the chief problem in American education in this decade.

Manhattan College (17 -- 2) yesterday accepted a bid to play in the coming National Invitation basketball tournament, joining La Salle, Western Kentucky and Seton Hall in the sixteenth annual competition, which gets under way with a triple-header at Madison Square Garden on March 7.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Feb. 19 -Nine men's college teams are here tonight for the two-day Eastern Intercollegiate Ski Association championships that start tomorrow on the snow-covered slopes of Bread Loaf Mountain.
A three-month "gripe" by radio officers operating out of East Coast ports was settled yesterday as steamship companies granted pay increases equaling those given engineer officers last November.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19 -- Words of the late John J. Raskob, long associated with the automobile industry, were read and argued over today as the du Ponts got into the hottest subject of their anti-trust trial -- the purchase by E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., of stock in General Motors Corporation.
