Fish are costlier this first weekend of the Lenten season. Light receipts coupled with increased demand have pushed prices up a nickel a pound since last Friday on many of the most popular species.

For those who would like the styling and detailing of a better hat without going skyhigh in price, Bonwit Teller has introduced a new group of millinery, called "Bonchapeau," which will sell at a uniform price of $25. Shown to the press yesterday at the store, the new hats will be created by regular higher priced manufacturers who will make up this group exclusively for Bonwit Teller.

For all the manager of a bank branch in Brooklyn knew yesterday noon, thirty lives and a couple of buildings might have been lost if he made a wrong decision. The question before him was whether a sad-faced, thin little man was really wired with enough explosives to blow up the bank, as he said he was.

New and old band music was performed yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall by the United States Army Band, under the direction of Major Hugh Curry. The concert was one of the events of the fourteenth annual American Music Festival, which is being presented by radio station WNYC.

As the last of the city's 116 agencies submitted departmental 1953-54 budget estimates yesterday to Budget Director Abraham D. Beame, a final tally issued by Mr. Beame showed that the total requested was $1,605,154,727. This would be an increase of $131,592,223 above the current $1,473,562,504 budget.

MIAMI, Feb. 20 -- The richest handicap in the history of Florida horse racing is to be run at Hialeah tomorrow. It's the $100,000-added Widener, and if all of the nine entrants stay in the line-up, the gross will be $131,400 and the net to the winner will be $94.200 -- for a little more than two minutes of brisk exercise.

Several employes in the New York office of the Voice of America yesterday denied charges that had been made against them earlier in the day by witnesses before a Senate Investigations subcommittee in Washington. Some telegraphed to Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, subcommittee chairman, asking permission to testify to clear their names.
I was very much interested in your editorial of Feb. 13 about the camera man at Gettysburg.

HEADQUARTERS, Eighth Army, in Korea, Feb. 20 -- Sometime this weekend Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, new commander of the Eighth Army, will receive three reports on malnutrition among soldiers of the Republic of Korea Army.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Feb. 20 (AP) -- President Eisenhower extended his sympathy today to the parents of an Air Force man missing in Korea and another lost in the National Air Lines crash in the Gulf of Mexico.

Some sound, clear piano playing was offered last night in Town Hall by Jakob Gimpel. The owner of a first-class technique, Mr. Gimpel is an artist who achieves his points through strength rather than color, nuance or any great subtlety. His musical ideas are quite forthright, he plans everything well, and he is an altogether capable, experienced workman.

The Museum of Modern Art, the target of artists both of the "right" and "left" for its management of the American section of international sculpture competition, "The Unknown Political Prisoner," declared yesterday that a retraction of a charge by one of its severest critics "is in order."
CHICAGO, Feb. 20 (AP) -- The thunder of tumbling tenpins will start tomorrow when the American Bowling Congress opens its golden jubilee tourney.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) -- An altogether new cost-of-living index, computed after an exhaustive three-year price and spending survey across the nation, makes its first appearance next week.
CINCINNATI, Feb. 20 (UP) -- The United States Court of Appeals today reaffirmed that baseball was a sport and not a business, in dismissing two anti-trust suits that asked $450,000 damages.

TRENTON, Feb. 20 -- The case of the "Trenton Six," which gained national prominence three years ago when the Civil Rights Congress, branded as subversive by the United States Attorney General's office, stepped into it, came to an end today. Ralph Cooper, the last of the defendants facing trial, entered a plea of no defense and was sentenced to six to ten years in New Jersey State Prison.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (UP) -- Ninety-eight newspaper publishers asked the Supreme Court today to dismiss the Government's anti-trust suit against The New Orleans Times-Picayune, which lost in the New Orleans Federal Court. Arguments on its appeal are scheduled for the week of March 9.
A copy of the fame Gutenberg Bible that was acquired by Charles Scribner's Sons of New York two years ago is in Chicago, on option to the Chicago Bible Society.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The possibility that the Swiss Government might seek to have arbitrated under international law the question of whether the General Aniline and Film Corporation is Swiss or German property was brought forward today by John J. Wilson, a Washington attorney.

The Fifty-two Association of New York, whose slogan is "the wounded shall never be forgotten," celebrates its eighth anniversary today. Toward the end of the last war this organization of business and professional men and women moved into the areas of service not covered by the Veterans Administration -- job placement for the physically handicapped and a program of entertainment and service for soldiers and sailors in hospitals or at loose ends in this town.
BONN, Germany, Feb. 20 -- The Social Democratic party was accused today of contributing to Communist preparations to resist ratification of the Allied-German treaties with a general strike and riots.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- A musical headrest was patented this week by an Atlanta dentist. Designed to soothe the patient's nerves and take his mind off the operations going on inside his mouth, the device carries to his ear music that is "substantially inaudible" to others in the office.

Cattle and calf slaughter this year will top that of 1952 by about 3,500,000 head, according to estimates released yesterday by the Tanners Council of America. Cattle slaughter will be about 21,200,000 head, compared with 19,300,000 and calf slaughter is estimated at 11,500,000 head, a gain of 1,600,000.

Two books about Germany are scheduled for publication in the next two months. Henry Schuman will issue on March 5 T. H. Tetens' "Germany Plots With the Kremlin," an expose based on documents that will be published in his book for the first time.

Don't toy with the idea of buying subtle shades in playthings, advises the plastics division of the Monsanto Chemical Company. Children prefer the sharp primary colors to tints and their vision is not sophisticated enough to appreciate the subtle hues.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 20 -- Prime Minister Jawaharial Nehru said in Parliament today he was opposed to the idea of establishing an international authority to control distribution of the waters of the Indus River system between India and Pakistan.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The State Department announced today it would cooperate with the Senate subcommittee investigating the Voice of America and the departmental security filing system. To do this, it made ineffective a severe two-day-old directive to all employes that the investigators had charged would make their inquiries ten times more difficult and costly.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- White House reporters who have been getting at least a smile from the silent Cabinet will not get even that any more.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (UP) -- Senate investigators said today they would question next Tuesday a teacher accused of developing an underground organization of some 500 New York teachers.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 20 -- The staff of the Soviet Legation, headed by Minister Pavel I. Yershov, sailed from Haifa at 11:05 tonight for Istanbul, Turkey, en route to Moscow aboard the Turkish passenger ship Kadesh.

HELEN MACINNES' new novel, "I and My True Love,"* is an Anna Karenina story told suavely as a thriller. The scene is Washington. The time is a year or two ago when there were, apparently, just as many business men on the diplomatic landscape as there are now, figures in what you might call the Knudsen Migration.
Four realist painters -- in the widest acceptance of that term -- and a total nonobjectivist are among the many artists exhibiting work in metropolitan galleries this week.

Daniel Kornblum, director of the city's Division of Labor Relations, announced yesterday the establishment of a formula to settle a dispute between public school custodial helpers and their employers, custodial engineers.

LONDON, Feb. 20 -- After four years of the National Health Service, most residents in a small community near Liverpool are overwhelmingly in favor of it, according to a recent survey. The study, made by Daniel Reid Ross, former research director of a housing survey in Chicago, was published this week in Medical World, journal of British general practitioners.

BERLIN, Feb. 20 -- Taegliche Rundschau, official Soviet newspaper, said today that Western reports that East Berlin planned to split the city's elevated and subway systems were "slander." By inference it charged that such action actually was planned by West Berlin.

Mrs. Charles Ingalls Morton is chairman and Mrs. Richard S. Meredith, vice chairman, of the executive committee for the annual spring festival of St. James Protestant Episcopal Church to be held on April 23 and 24 in the Parish House of the church at Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street. Proceeds will be donated to the Youth Consultation Service and St. Luke's Hospital.
LONDON, Feb. 20 -- The British Furniture Exhibition opened here this week with emphasis on comfort and space-saving rather than new design.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20 -- Grain prices again moved up sharply today, marking the eighth day in a row in which prices advanced. New highs were set by wheat and corn. Soybeans as well as oats and rye snowed marked improvement, buying getting under way following the upsurge in wheat and corn.

PARIS, Feb. 20 -- In face of a vigorous collective attack on the proposed French protocols to the European army treaty, made today by representatives of the other signatory nations, the French spokesman, Ambassador Herve Alphand, took an extremely conciliatory position.
BIELEFELD, Germany, Feb. 20 -- A decision on the habeas corpus petition of Dr. Werner Naumann, accused as the leader of a band of Nazi plotters, was postponed for weeks, perhaps longer, today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (UP) -- Senate investigators asserted today that one Government agency handed over more money to another than it had a right to. They said Congress might have to pay out $100,000,000 or more to the "generous" agency.

Women headed by Mrs. Reginald Fincke, including Mrs. Ralph J. Hines, co-chairman, and Mrs. John McLain, are assisting in the sale of tickets for the performance of "The Love of Four Colonels," with Lilli Palmer and Rex Harrison in the leading roles, Wednesday night at the Shubert Theatre for the benefit of the Schola Cantorum. An encouraging subscription already has been reported.

THE National Sportsmen's Show, that annual outdoors extravaganza, will begin its nine-day run at Grand Central Palace at 11 A. M. today, offering the urban hunter and fisherman an interesting interlude to break the mid-winter monotony.
One of these days before spring gets any closer the prudent countryman, while he is in the cellar on some errand, will take time to inspect the sump pump to see that it is in working order.
A steady demand for low-cost student travel to Europe this summer is building up, but indications are that ships set aside for exclusive use by students will be fewer than they were a year ago.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 20 -- The Interstate Commission on the Delaware River basin, known as Incodel, denounced tonight the Pennsylvania Water Resources Committee's plan for development of the water resources of the Delaware River.

William J. Schultheis Jr. is an energetic 17-year-old youth who has taken literally the dictum that there is no easy road to learning. His own route, just now, is along marshy paths of Staten Island, and he treads it in hipboots, trapping muskrats and earning money for college tuition.

With Al McGuire as well as Max Zaslofsky now believed lost for the season as a result of injuries, the crippled Knickerbockers will attempt to maintain their first place margin in the Eastern division of the National Basketball Association when they meet the Philadelphia Warriors tonight.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 20 -- Amy expectation that the Chinese Nationalist Navy would begin an immediate blockade of Shanghai and other Communist Chinese ports, now that the United States Seventh Fleet has been withdrawn by President Eisenhower from its neutralizing patrol of the Formosan Strait, was quashed today by a son of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek.

A tie-breaking vote cast yesterday at City Hall by Mayor Impellitteri resulted in the election of Municipal Court Justice Edward G. Baker as Richmond Borough President to succeed Cornelius A. Hall, whose retirement as of Feb. 12 was approved by the Board of Estimate last Thursday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Following are the texts of the letter President Eisenhower sent to Vice President Richard M. Nixon and House Speaker Joseph W. Martin Jr. today and the draft of a proposed resolution on World War II agreements:
The three-story dwelling also containing a store at 7719 Eighteenth Avenue in Brooklyn has been sold by Anna Conti to Lillian Rosenblatt. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

PARIS, Feb. 20 -- As could have been expected, the Soviet Union is doing its utmost to counter Allied diplomatic efforts to strengthen the defenses of the free world in Southeastern Europe and the Middle East.
MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Feb. 20 -- A fraction of a point separated the leading Middlebury team from Dartmouth at the completion today of the first phase of the Eastern intercollegiate ski championships.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 20 (UP) -- Eddie Stanky, manager of the Cardinals, expressed regret today over the sale of the team by Saigh, "who gave me my first chance to manage a major league club."

United States concerns which have invested millions of dollars in Chile, need have no fear that the Chilean Government intends to nationalize copper and nitrate interests, according to Horace R. Graham, chairman of the United States Inter-American Council. Mr. Graham said yesterday that President Carlos Ibanez of Chile stressed that point in an interview with him there recently.

Commodity prices closed irregularly higher yesterday on the New York exchanges. Coffee and potato volume continued high and sugar was fairly active. Coffee, potatoes, wool, lead and zinc closed higher. Cocoa, sugar, cottonseed oil and hides were mixed and soybean oil and rubber ended lower.

William Talbert of New York and Grant Golden of Wilmette, Ill., reached the semi-final round of the national indoor tennis championships last night at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.

A 22-year-old Ethiopian soldier, who lost a leg in Korea while fighting with his unit at the side of the American Seventh Infantry Division, arrived from his native country at Idlewild Airport yesterday to be fitted for an artificial limb.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The Eisenhower Administration is considering a major contribution in money and munitions to help the French stop imperialist communism in Indo-China, and is seeking to prepare Congressional and public opinion for the enterprise.

The stock market yesterday was much a repetition of the previous two sessions, with early gains of a point or better by rails and selected industrials pared at the close. Indifference to profit-taking late in the afternoon was attributed to the pending three-day holiday.

Despite individual progress, made last year by Central American countries, more rapid development appears now to depend on economic integration of the region, it was stated in a bulletin issued yesterday by the National Foreign Trade Council.
ALBANY, Feb. 20 (AP) -- The State Department of Commerce today listed the following winter sports conditions at New York resorts:

WINNSBORO, La., Feb. 20 (UP) -- Three editorial employes of a national farm magazine, who came here to teach farm women how to look beautiful, were free on $300 bond each today after bringing down the wrath of Louisiana barbers and beauty operators.

Holiday travelers unofficially opened yesterday the city's three-day celebration of the 221st anniversary of the birth of George Washington by departing for nearby areas to which General Washington had gone many years before under more historic and less comfortable circumstances. New Yorkers who remained behind made plans for parades, military reviews and visits to museums displaying Washington mementos.
Vincent Pugh, the 39-year-old war veteran accused of shooting his wife and step-daughter to death last summer, was acquitted last night by an all-male jury of two first-degree murder charges.

Your last two editorials on Latin America -- "On Being Good Neighbors" and the "Centenary of Jose Marti" -- bring up a point of great importance in this country. Despite the efforts of scholars, universities, journalists, etc., Latin America is still unknown in the United States.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Feb. 20 (AP) -- Harvie Ward, co-medalist and two time winner of the national tournament of golf club champions, reached the semi-finals today in a determined bid to retire the trophy with his third victory.

The North Atlantic Continental Freight Conference announced yesterday that it would continue the 10 per cent freight rate discount effected last October for all shippers whether they use member lines exclusively or not. This extension will continue until March 31.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- President Eisenhower asked Congress today to adopt a resolution accusing the Russians of having "perverted" secret wartime agreements as means to subjugate free peoples and declaring that the people of the United States "are never acquiescent in such enslavement."
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 20 (UP) -- Carlos Marcello, a mobster who made his mark in the underworld and became an "evil genius" of crime, was ordered deported today, if another country would take him.

The United States kept the Rolland Cup in a ten-match doubles racquets tournament with Canada at the Racquet and Tennis Club yesterday. Each side won five matches, the issue being decided on games. The defenders took most, 19 -- 17.

A runaway team triumph by Manhattan but a wide-open scramble for nearly all of the eleven individual and two relay titles -- that's the outlook for the thirty-second annual indoor track and field championships of the Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America at Madison Square Garden tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- A House Agriculture livestock subcommittee recommended today a four-point emergency program to bolster declining cattle prices, one of the proposals being stepped-up Federal buying of meat for the school lunch program.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Feb. 20 -- Die Burger, the leading paper of Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan's Nationalist party, joined Opposition members of Parliament today in expressing fear that the so-called whipping post bill now before Parliament was a threat to freedom of the press. The bill would forbid, under heavy penalties, the expression of opinion that resulted in deliberate disobedience of law.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20 -- Startling developments to come in food growing and processing will make impossible the world-wide famines predicted by some forecasters, Nathan Cummings, chairman of Consolidated Grocers Corporation, said today.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 20 (AP) -- Bright skies, a fast track and an excellent field of eleven 3-year-olds are in prospect for the six-teenth running of the $131,600 Santa Anita Derby tomorrow.

Anyone with facilities to "make little ones out of big ones" -- in butter, that is -- may be interested in bidding at the Purchase Department in the Municipal Building next Wednesday on a contract offered by the city to cut 172,800 pounds of butter into patties.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned stronger yesterday and closed with gains of 16 to 42 points net, with the old March contract showing the most strength.
VERO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 20 -- Manager Chuck Dressen went out on a limb twice today, the first time on his own volition, the second time because he was pushed by Buzzie Bavasi, Dodger was president.

MOSCOW, Feb. 20 -- Pravda, the Communist party newspaper, revealed today that Dr. Lydia Timashuk, who received the Order of Lenin for her assistance in exposing the alleged plot of nine doctors against Soviet leaders, was a veteran medical worker who lost a son in the Soviet Air Force during World War II.

A United Press dispatch, less than three inches in length, managed to squeeze itself into the lower left-hand corner of the front page of the late editions of this newspaper yesterday, in the process rudely shouldering off page one a paragraph or two of a big story on a strategy conference at the United Nations.

Allen M. Myers of 451 East Fourteenth Street, who has refused to send his 9-year-old daughter, Shelley, to near-by Public School 19 on the ground that it constituted a "physical and mental hazard," was not permitted yesterday to register the child in Public School 40, a newer school at 320 Twentieth Street.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Argentina demanded tonight that Britain rebuild the Argentine installations she destroyed on Deception Island in the Antarctic. She also demanded that the two Argentines deported from her Deception base be returned to their post.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 20 -- August A. Busch Jr., scion of the Anheuser-Busch brewery fortune, bought the Cardinals baseball club from prison-bound Fred M. Saigh today for $3,750,000 and a pledge not to move the National League franchise out of St. Louis.
TOKYO, Saturday, Feb. 21 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,532, for the twenty-four hours ended 6 A. M. Saturday, Korea time:

The seventeenth annual show of the Press Photographers of New York, like its predecessors, captured to an amazing degree the look and atmosphere of another year in the life of the city. Most of the winning pictures stood, as to be expected, on the newsworthiness of their subjects -- Sir Gladwyn Jebb working in solitary concentration at the U. N., Frank Costello peeling off bills for a panhandler, a scowling shot of President Eisenhower.

Leisurely matinee-goers today might like to spend a few moments in a shop dedicated to the theatre. Called the Show Shop and operated under the auspices of the Show of the Month Club, it is at 136 West Forty-fourth Street.

The article "Television in Review" in THE TIMES of Feb. 16, in which two Sunday morning programs, directed to youth, are criticized for their violence, should be read by every member of the programming staff of WNBT and ABC, by the parents of every young child, by every member of the Federal Communications Commission and every member of Congress.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The State Department advised Rumania today to look for the cause of post-war oil shortages in her own communist policies and the seizure of equipment and exports by the Soviet Union.

Paddy De Marco never stopped rushing, bull-like, in his ten-round bout last night against George Araujo, Providence, R. I., contender for the lightweight title at Madison Square Garden. Araujo never stopped pumping left jabs and swishing left hooks and right crosses in the face of the Brooklynite's fiery charges.

A gunman held up Otto Hiltl, superintendent of construction for the St. Pancras Parochial School at Myrtle Avenue and Sixty-eighth Place, Glendale, Queens, at 9:30 A. M. yesterday and escaped with a $4,000 payroll meant for thirty-seven construction employes.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Two Senators favoring the abandonment of Alcatraz Prison said today that it would be cheaper to board its prisoners at hotels in New York and Washington.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20 -- Pierre S. du Pont today brushed aside with a laugh and a denial a Government charge that the du Ponts sought to influence the late Fred J. Fisher to buy products of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. by giving the automobile body manufacturer a committee post.

ALBANY, Feb. 20 -- A bill to set up an eleven-member grievance board to act as the final arbiter in labor disputes involving New York City employes has been proposed by Senator John R. Marro, Democrat of Manhattan.

The first recipe appearing in this column today is one just developed by a commercial test kitchen as a way of using canned pineapple. It consists of a layer cake with a filling of the fruit, the layers of which have a baked-on meringue.

Events today: "Babar," Hunter College Auditorium, 11 A. M. "La Boheme," Metropolitan Opera, 2 P. M.; WNYC American Music Festival Concert, Cooper Union, 4; Concert Artists Guild, Steinway Hall, 4; National Association for American Composers and Conductors, WNYC American Music Festival Concert, Town Hall, 5:30; Philharmonic - Symphony, Franco Autori conducting, Paul Badura-Skoda, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 8:45.

HOUSTON, Tex., Feb. 20 (AP) -- Tennessee Gas Transmission Company has filed a petition with the Federal Power Commission seeking authority to build $91,718,000. worth of facilities to transport natural gas for Buffalo, N. Y., and Toronto, Canada, companies.

TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 20 -- United States Ambassador Loy Henderson met with Premier Mohammed Mossadegh today in the first of a series of meetings that may be decisive in determining the outcome of their negotiations for settlement of Iran's oil dispute with Britain.

BETHLEHEM, Jordan, Feb. 20 -- Biblical scholars are perturbed over the mushrooming here of a thriving "black market in Apocrypha'' accompanying the greatest antiquarian boom in this area since the Eighteen Eighties.
The United Automobile Workers, A. F. L., announced yesterday that it was in the process of revoking the charter of Local 198 in New York because "the thing doesn't look good."

WATERBURY, Conn., Feb. 20 -- William J. Donahue, 41-year-old Waterbury newspaper man who carried a fight for public access to municipal board sessions to the State Supreme Court, was killed early today in an auto crash near Perrysville, Md.

BOSTON, Feb. 20 -- The New England Governors met today in Boston and agreed to establish a "pool of experts" to give them advice from time to time on matters of public utilities rates. The immediate problem is a request by the New England Telephone and Telegraph Company for a $10,200,000 increase in Massachusetts.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- When the Cabinet holds its weekly meeting in the White House, as it did this morning, President Eisenhower calls on the members to stand for a minute of silent prayer before proceeding with public business.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The Department of Justice issued a warrant today for the deportation of Joe Adonis, the reputed czar of a former multi-million-dollar gambling operation in Bergen County, N. J.

BUFFALO, Feb. 20 (AP) -- A Federal mediator announced tonight that company and union officials had reached an agreement in the six-month-old wage dispute affecting nearly 10,000 American Locomotive Company employes.

Enforcement operations of the Food and Drug Administration last year removed thousands of tons of decomposed and contaminated food from the market, according to Charles W. Crawford, Commissioner of Foods and Drugs, Federal Security Agency.

LONDON, Feb. 20 -- High on the agenda for Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden's forthcoming talks with Secretary of State John Foster Dulles in Washington is the problem of obtaining an agreement with Egypt for the retention of the British base in the Suez Canal Zone and obtaining Egyptian participation in a Middle Eastern defense arrangement.

New York appliance distributors re seeking to eliminate competition by campaigning for enactment of a bill that would prove unfair to surplus merchandise dealers, it was charged yesterday by Gerard I. Nierenberg, counsel for a group of surplus buyers.

Thursday was the best day since last November for blood donations to the American Red Cross in this area, officials, reported yesterday. Led by donors at Fort Monmouth, N. J., with 344 pints of blood, a total of 1,298 pints was collected.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Feb. 20 -- Farmers from the Midwest's rich Corn Belt tonight were told they could expect lower prices and less favorable profit ratios, but they also were assured that such a slump would not mean another great depression like that of the early Nineteen Thirties.

A recorded address by Adlai E. Stevenson will be presented by the National Broadcasting Company and Mutual Broadcasting System radio networks on Thursday from 12 midnight to 12:30 A. M. That evening the former Governor of Illinois will be addressing a Jefferson-Jackson Day dinner in Los Angeles on the subject of "Far Eastern Policy."
BOSTON, Feb. 20 (AP) -- The Rev. Leonard J. Feeney said today that he would appeal an order of ex-communication "to the Pope himself."

Directors of the Crown Zellerbach Corporation declared a 100 per cent stock dividend and a quarterly cash dividend of 75 cents a share, it was announced yesterday. The cash dividend will be distributed on April 1, while the stock dividend will be distributed on April 24.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Feb. 20 (Reuters) -- Eight more Danish soldiers were arrested tonight following last Monday's demonstration by about 700 troops in protest against the extension of the conscription period from one year to eighteen months.

" It is always difficult to make statistics come alive." That is the statement or Percival S. Howe Jr., president of the Lighthouse, and it refers to the figures contained in that agency's annual report, made public recently. "But," Mr. Howe went on to say, "to the 111 blind persons who were helped to find employment [in 1952] or the 284 who received instructions in Braille reading these figures are quite alive."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- A recommendation that the Federal Power Commission license the State of Ne wYork to construct the $316,000,000 power installations on the American side of the St. Lawrence River power project was submitted to the commission today by Willard W. Gatchell, assistant general counsel to the Federal agency.

Al (Jim) Robertson, Eastern League all-star catcher with Binghamton in 1952, signed with the Yankees yesterday. However, the Bombers will leave today for their St. Petersburg, Fla., training camp with twelve players, including most of their key regulars, still outside the contract fold.

No nation can be truly democratic so long as political or economic discrimination based on race, creed, or color exist within its borders, former Vice President Alben W. Barkley said yesterday. He addressed the twenty-fifth annual Brotherhood Week luncheon sponsored by the Manhattan-Westchester Region of the National Conference of Christians and Jews at the Roosevelt Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (UP) -- The Senate Republican Leader, Robert A. Taft of Ohio, today cleared the way for early Senate action, possibly next Friday, on legislation giving the states title to oil-bearing offshore lands.

LONDON, Feb. 20 -- News of tax reductions in the Canadian budget, received with envy in this country, stimulated Canadian shares and indeed industrial shares generally on the Stock Exchange here today. Although buying remained moderate little stock was available and prices rose over the fairly wide front.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 20 -- Once the novelty effect of three-dimensional movies wears off, the extent to which such film techniques will be used in the future will be determined by the public, not the motion-picture industry, Dore Schary, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer production chief, asserted today in a speech that reviewed the present state of the movie business.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Feb. 20 (AP) -- The Hashim Mardin Shipping Company asserted tonight that reports that its tanker, the Raman, had tried to sneak out of the German port of Bremen without paying a repair bill were "exaggerated."

The first of a series of talks on the "Seven Last Words of Christ on the Cross" under auspices of the Protestant Council of the City of New York and other groups was given last night at Town Hall, 113 West Forty-third Street, by the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman of Christ Church (Methodist) Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street, who is president of the council.

TOKYO, Saturday, Feb. 21 -- Communist China's propaganda machine renewed today its campaign of attack on the United Nations for alleged use of germ warfare in Korea. The Communists had been silent on the charge since early in January.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 20 -- Preceded by hundreds of Argentines, including Cabinet Ministers, athletes and Secret Service agents. President Juan D. Peron arrived today on a visit -- the first to be made by an Argentine President to Chile in forty years.

A subcommittee on a national program for the newly created Division of Social Education and Community Action of the Department of Christian Social Relations of the National Council of the Protestant Episcopal Church has drawn up recommendations and will present them to a general committee studying the project, it was learned yesterday.

United States Government bonds maturing in from nineteen to twenty years sold under 95 yesterday for the first time since their issuance; as eight issues of the Treasury's longer-term obligations declined to new low records.

If our High Commissioner's Office in Germany, in order to learn how the German people are feeling about nazism, needs a "Reactions Analysis Staff" -- which I doubt -- the findings of that staff ought not to need checking by what we otherwise know about the German people.

Two stench bombs were dropped last night in the Capitol Theatre, Broadway and Fifty-first Street, during the showing of "Moulin Rouge." Seven hundred of the 1,200 persons in the audience filed out in an orderly manner and received cash refunds or tickets for another showing.

There is a chance for some clearing of the political atmosphere in Manila with the decision of the Philippine Supreme Court that invalidates the President's use of "emergency" powers. What is involved is a long-standing contest between the executive and legislative branches of the Government.

There seems to be good reason to believe that Georgi M. Malenkov, secretary of the Communist party, is the key figure behind the wave of anti-Semitic and anti-Zionist agitation that has swept the Soviet Union since mid-January. Mr. Malenkov emerged last October at the nineteenth Communist Party Congress in Moscow as the most publicized figure in the party hierarchy after Premier Stalin.
PAUL SMITH'S, N. Y., Feb. 20 -- With Bobby Axtell of Old Forge, N.Y.; showing the way, Paul Smith's College today got off to a commanding start in the defense of its own carnival laurels.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The Federal Reserve Board today reduced margin requirements on stock market transactions from 75 per cent to 50 per cent effective when the stock exchanges resume on Tuesday after the Washington's Birthday holiday.

Suggestions for combating vandalism, with emphasis on the responsibility of parents, were made by junior and senior high school students of Queens at a panel discussion on the subject Thursday. The occasion was the monthly meeting of the Parents' Association of Public School 11 at the school, 54-25 Skillman Avenue, Woodside.

That pale, green look on some New Yorkers' faces yesterday was envy, and it resulted from reading P. J. Philip's dispatch to this newspaper from Ottawa telling about cuts in Canadian taxes. Eleven per cent comes off the income tax and other percentages from corporation taxes, sales taxes, license fees and even cigarettes.
A howling blizzard, comparable to the storm that lashed the Rocky Mountain area in 1949 and caused seventeen deaths, moved out of Colorado and Wyoming yesterday and into the surrounding states.

FORT MEADE, Md., Feb. 20 (AP) -- Army lawyers engaged in argument behind closed doors today at the court-martial of Lieut. Col. Melvin B. Voorhees, the Army censor accused of evading censorship. At issue were seven "pinpoint motions" by the defense to dismiss charges that Colonel Voorhees submitted manuscripts for publication without Army clearance and that he disobeyed a command to withdraw a book manuscript from a publisher.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (UP) -- Representative Harold H. Velde, Republican of Illinois, said today that the House committee on un-American Activities of which he is chairman, had suspended one of its investigators for giving him "inaccurate" information on Mrs. Agnes E. Meyer, wife of the chairman of the board of The Washington Post.

A $600,000 alteration for the building at 600 Fifth Avenue in Rockefeller Center was among the plans filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings. The building, used for offices, shops and storage, is owned by the Rockefeller Center, Inc., of 50 Rockefeller Plaza, and the Ministers, Elders and Deacons of the Reformed Protestant Dutch Church, of 45 John Street.

Seventy-five contract bridge teams began play last night in the first of two qualifying sessions in the twenty-sixth annual Vanderbilt Cup Tournament, blue ribbon event in the American Contract Bridge League's national championship tournament schedule.

" Misalliance," the Shaw comedy now having a successful revival at the New York City Center, will move to the Barrymore Theatre for an unlimited run after it concludes its engagement at the civic playhouse on March 1.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Judge Henry S. Schweinhaut in United States District Court signed a temporary injunction today relieving eighty textile concerns of requirement to pay a minimum wage of $1 an hour for work on goods bought by the Government.

Mayor Impellitteri and George P. Monaghan, his Police Commissioner, offered full cooperation yesterday to a House Judiciary subcommittee in its investigation to determine whether the Police Department and the Department of Justice had, by mutual agreement, interfered with Federal guarantees on civil rights here.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 20 -- President Getulio Vargas signed regulations today for operation of the law on the free market in foreign exchange to become effective tomorrow.

A bill to legalize the maritime hiring halls through amendment of the Taft-Hartley Act has again been introduced in Congress, where similar measures have failed twice before to get beyond the committee stage.

HOUSTON, Feb. 20 -- Southern Pacific Lines will spend about $6,000,000 here to build what the railroad's officials have termed one of the biggest and most modern pushbutton gravity switching yards in the nation.

National Defense Week, under the sponsorship of the Reserve Officers Association of the United States, was marked yesterday in a ceremony at City Hall. Mayor Impellitteri and representatives of the armed forces paid tribute to the contributions of reservists in war and in peace.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20 -- The Chicago Transit Authority Board entered into a contract today with John Nuveen Co., Chicago investment firm, for the sale of $7,950,000 in equipment trust certificates to help finance the C. T.A. modernization program for 1953. The authority, a public agency, owns and operates the city's elevated, street car and bus lines.

LONDON, Feb. 20 (UP) -- Winthrop W. Aldrich, new United States Ambassador to Britain, rode to Buckingham Palace today in a horse-drawn carriage to present his credentials to Queen Elizabeth II. His aides rode in two other carriages. All wore top hats.

LONDON, Feb. 20 (UP) -- Winthrop W. Aldrich, new United States Ambassador to Britain, rode to Buckingham Palace today in a horse-drawn carriage to present his credentials to Queen Elizabeth II. His aides rode in two other carriages. All wore top hats.

Long Island Railroad commuter trains were delayed thirty to fifty minutes yesterday morning after mechanical defects halted a New York bound express from Babylon at the Manhattan end of Tunnel 4 under the East River. The line was snarled for an hour and a half in the rush period.

Keith Funston, president of the New York Stock Exchange, announced yesterday that the board of governors had approved an amendment to the constitution which, if adopted by the membership, would make the corporate form of doing business available to present and future members.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Repeal of the Taft-Hartley Labor Law's controversial injunction provisions was urged by Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican of New York, today and promptly opposed by Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, co-author of the law.
For thirty years the Community Councils of the City of New York, Inc., have been opening playgrounds. They have been termed by Commissioner Moses the pioneers of the playground movement.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Al Brosch, who often starts fast and sometimes slows down in the stretch, today continued his blazing opening-day pace and gained sole possession of the lead in the ninth Mexican open golf tournament.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20 -- Armour Co. stockholders were told at their annual meeting today that net income in the thirteen weeks ended Jan. 31, the first quarter of the company's fiscal year, will approximate the $1,609,261, or 21 cents a common share, earned in the same quarter last year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Arizona's suit to force Government approval of its plan for payment of Social Security benefits to permanent and totally disabled citizens, except reservation Indians, was dismissed in Federal District Court today.

Delegates from seventy-six Eastern and Midwestern secondary schools at the fifth annual Forum on Democracy at Columbia College were urged yesterday to disregard the "twentieth - century Know-Nothingism" of United Nations opponents and to participate in the programs of the world organization's Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO).
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of use to the homemaker.

Having successfully tackled Eugene O'Neill's "Ah, Wilderness!" a fortnight ago, the Equity Community Theatre now is engaged in a similarly happy bout with Bernard Shaw's "Man and Superman," which was unveiled last night at the DeWitt Clinton High School auditorium in the Bronx.

Bankers must avoid the mistake of concentrating their advertising and promotional services among customers "in the top ten per cent bracket -- those with large balances," L. L. Matthews, president of the American Trust Company, South Bend, Ind., warned yesterday.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of use to the homemaker.

Having successfully tackled Eugene O'Neill's "Ah, Wilderness!" a fortnight ago, the Equity Community Theatre now is engaged in a similarly happy bout with Bernard Shaw's "Man and Superman," which was unveiled last night at the DeWitt Clinton High School auditorium in the Bronx.

Bankers must avoid the mistake of concentrating their advertising and promotional services among customers "in the top ten per cent bracket -- those with large balances," L. L. Matthews, president of the American Trust Company, South Bend, Ind., warned yesterday.

The Total Realty Company, Herbert Bachrach, president, owner of 1282-84 Third Avenue, southwest corner of Seventy-fourth Street, has purchased the adjoining six-story apartment house at 1280 Third Avenue from Joseph L. Ennis Co. in a deal negotiated by L. V. Hoffman Co., brokers. This gives the buyer a plot of 100 by 105, on which the Excelsior Savings Bank made a mortgage loan of $125,000.

President Eisenhower sent to Congress yesterday a resolution denouncing the Soviet Union for its violations of the wartime Allied agreements. He does not mention Yalta or Potsdam, but Secretary of States Dulles, in his first press conference, indicated that the target of the resolution is the "secret understandings" reached at those conferences.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 20 -- The campaign to complete the government-endorsed program in Yugoslavia for the establishment of priests' associations -- condemned by the Vatican and leaders of the Roman Catholic hierarchy -- was reinvigorated today with a move into overwhelmingly Catholic Croatia.

The House of Representatives of the State of Georgia was warmly gratulated by English grammarians here yesterday for passing legislation to keep language pure by making illegal the ugly and clumsy conjunction "and/or."
L. C. Perkinson and G. C. Walker have been elected vice president and treasurer, respectively, of American Cyanamid Company, it was announced yesterday.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 19 (AP) -- India is putting in operation this week-end the first units of her $140,000,000 multi-purpose power system, modeled after the Tennessee Valley Authority.
More than $600,000 worth of automobiles were shown yesterday at a preview of the Worlds Motor Sports Show at Madison Square Garden. The exhibits included cars from Spain, Italy, Germany and France.

NEWARK, Feb. 20 -- The imminent retirement from politics of David T. Wilentz, 58-year-old Democratic leader of Middlesex County and former Attorney General of New Jersey, was confirmed by Democratic leaders today. The self-imposed removal from the political scene of the former Democratic State Chairman is expected to leave a wide gap in the party structure.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The House Ways and Means Committee ordered a lengthy study of the nation's entire Social Security system today -- a task expected to prevent any major expansion of coverage at this session of Congress. This important Congressional committee, already at odds with President Eisenhower over the question of an immediate reduction of personal income taxes, appeared to move once more against Presidential wishes.

February is the sub-basement of winter. Its cold seems deeper, its snow piles higher when it comes, and the dead, brown grasses and leaves look even deader than they did in January. This is the season when time pauses maddeningly and the bleakness of the landscape and the weather seem magnified out of proportion until they almost press through the body like a curling blight to attack a man's inner core.

STAMFORD, Conn., Feb. 20 -- Three small explosions in a plant of the Connecticut Power Company here this morning cut off electrical power for 20 per cent of Stamford's 80,000 residents and affected Greenwich, Darien and outlying communities for brief periods.

A "strong movement to repeal the three-year-old timber severance law in New Hampshire was reported yesterday by R. E. Broderick, executive secretary of the Northeastern Lumber Manufacturers Association. He said if the movement is successful forest conservation will receive a serious blow and "proponents of Federal regulation of privately-owned forest lands will have a tremendous argument in favor of Federal control."

Unless signs deceive, the relative complacency with which Western Europe has been viewing the danger of further Soviet aggression is coming to an end. After the recent letdown in rearmament, accompanied by suggestions that the United States was becoming overly excited about the Soviet menace, the Western European nations appear ready to move forward again.

GENEVA, Feb. 20 -- The United States Government and the United Nations World Health Organization have reached an agreement on the principles to govern health projects in underdeveloped areas of the world that both feel will go a long way to improve the efficiency of this basic component of the Point Four program.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- A report recommending that the entire Missouri River basin, encompassing 529,000 square miles, be developed as a whole and for all of its land and water resources, was formally presented to President Eisenhower today by the Missouri Basin Survey Commission.

A number of ad campaigns planned by varied interests were announced yesterday. Advertisers involved included a home freezer manufacturer, an organization representing a foreign country, a marine motor manufacturer and a seed and fertilizer producer.
ORLANDO, Fla., Feb. 20 (AP) -- Babe Zaharias and George Bolesta, only survivor of three medalist teams, advanced today to the semifinals of the international mixed two-ball golf tournament.
LONDON, Feb. 20 (Reuters) -- American investors who put money into British projects may take home their capital profits starting tomorrow.
The concert scheduled for tomorrow afternoon in Town Hall by the New Friends of Music has been canceled, it was learned yesterday. This is the second successive cancellation of a New Friends concert.

THE Zambezi is not a cocktail; it is a river, the fourth largest in Africa, exceeded in length only by the Nile, the Congo and the Niger. It arises in a peat bog on the high plateau where the boundaries of Portuguese Angola, the Belgian Congo and Northern Rhodesia come together.

MILWAUKEE, Wisc., Feb. 21 (UP) -- Martin P. Durkin, Democratic Secretary of Labor in a Republican Administration, said today that he would not take any public stand on the controversial Taft-Hartley Act.
Shows may come and shows may go but to Johnny Rounds, 6 years old, of Wilton, Conn., the World Motor Sports Show will be the most attractive for many a long day.

The recent lifting of Government controls over petroleum and petroleum products, except light fuel oil, has resulted in only minor price changes, except on the West Coast, where crude oil was increased 10 to 50 cents a barrel and gasoline about 1.5 to 1.9 cents a gallon.

THREE sets of judgments of amateur photographs will be handed down Wednesday evening at Master Institute, 310 Riverside Drive, when two print competitions will be judged by separate juries and there will also be voting by the audience.
The discussion of academic freedom in your issue of Feb. 1 by the distinguished historian Peter Gay is so eloquent and vigorous that it is easy to forget his specific propositions.
MEXICO CITY, Feb. 21 -- Al Brosch increased his lead in the Mexican open golf tournament to four strokes today with a four-under-par 68 which brought his three-day total to 199.

ITHACA, N. Y., Feb. 21 -- Cornell upset Columbia in the 100th basketball game between the two universities, winning, 76 -- 74, on Capt. Ray Handlan's field goal four seconds before the end of the second overtime period of an Eastern League game in Barton Hall tonight.

THREE gardening technicalities sure to stir up heated debate involve the differences between pumpkins and squash, cantaloupes and muskmelons, and rutabagas and turnips. The pumpkin-squash controversy is particularly confusing.

Remember the summer of 1952 ? Remember how the heat came early and emphatically ? And how the sun's first hot breath promptly melted dealers' inventories of air-conditioning equipment, particularly of room coolers?

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Feb. 21 -- Despite an outlook that held about a zero prospect today for sailing dinghy racing, a session was started that proved most successful for Arthur Knapp in his boat Agony at the Larchmont Yacht Club.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 21 (Reuters) -- The Soviet Union's shipping industry, plagued by delayed launchings, poor maintenance, time-consuming repairs and poor turn-arounds, is in the midst of a slump. Orders have gone out to shipping organizations to "liquidate shortcomings."
VIENNA, Feb. 21 -- Thirty leading Jewish Communists in Hungary were reported tonight to have either committed suicide or otherwise fallen victim to a purge dictated by a visiting Soviet group.

COPENHAGEN -- A record number of nearly 30,000 Americans visited Denmark last summer, and Danish travel authorities are confidently predicting that the coming summer will see that record broken easily.

NAPLES -- The newest excavations at Pompeii are yielding some astounding results, but Dr. Amedeo Maiuri, director of the work, has for a long time been dissatisfied with the type of information available to tourists, who have had to rely on uninformed garbled statements of cruising guides.

A new print gallery at Altman's has auspiciously opened with a selection of work (made by Walter Pach) by the great graphic masters from Duerer to Picasso, etchings and engravings that shine out like beacons on the progress of printmaking.

OSLO -- Regardless of whether Lief Ericsson discovered America, as some dictionaries over here state, it is probably incontestable that the Norwegians were the first in this corner of the globe to discover the value of the tourist's dollar and to cater to his tastes.

Prof. Leon L. Miller (University of Rochester, N. Y.) has succeeded in keeping liver alive six to eight hours outside of an animal's body. He uses a pump to circulate the blood mechanically. This new technique is important because disorders of the liver account for many diseases. Now experimenters can determine just what happens both when the liver is functioning properly and when improperly.

William Davies, the world's first official seagoing wireless operator, according to the records of the Marconi International Marine Communications Company, was honored in absentia last night at the twenty-eighth annual "dinner-cruise" of the Veteran Wireless Operators Association of America at the Astor Hotel.
The Soviet Union's mining industries have undergone "tremendous expansion" in the past twenty-five years, although losses in World War II caused serious setbacks.

The successful marketing of two major issues of public utility bonds -- $40,000,000 of Consolidated Edison Company and $25,000,000 of Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation -- has cleared away much of the uncertainty surrounding the yield structure of prime corporate investments.

The National Association for American Composers and Conductors celebrated its twentieth anniversary yesterday with a late afternoon program at Town Hall which was broadcast as part of WNYC's annual music festival.

Among the developments causing some concern to nervous observers is the tendency of the manufacturers of East and West Germany to compete with each other for foreign trade. News reports from Egypt note the presence in Cairo of two delegations from partitioned Germany, the East German group concluding a barter deal, the other negotiating contracts for engineering help and material from West Germany.

The Republican party is committed against what its platform called "all-powerful federal, socialistic valley authorities." Whether this was a fair description of the Tennessee Valley Authority can certainly be questioned, but it is not a description of the agency proposed in the report of the Missouri Basin Survey Commission, which was released in Washington on Friday.

CHICAGO, Feb. 21 -- Industry in the Chicago area has maintained high level production since October, but a portion of the gains made during the three months has been at the expense of order backlogs, the January report of the Purchasing Agents Association of Chicago showed.

The American Heritage Foundation announced yesterday the winners of the National Nonpartisan Register and Vote Campaign that it arranged last year and which helped to bring out a record total of 62,042,777 voters in the Presidential election on Nov. 4.

BUFFALO, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Harry B. Conlon Jr., defending national singles champion, defeated Dick Stewart of Hartford, Conn., today in the second round of the forty-fifth annual United States Squash Racquets Association tournament.

ANOTHER big transcontinental line has joined the growing list of railroads which are adding dome cars to their passenger equipment. The Union Pacific has placed an order for fifteen cars of this type -- five of them coaches, five diners and five observation cars.

ONE lazy summer day at the Stadium some three or four years ago Johnny Lindell, the outfielder, was warming up in front of the Yankee dugout, playing catch with Yogi Berra. Yogi reached out his glove casually for one toss only to have the ball unexpectedly dance away and hit him on the shin. The Yogi man yowled.
STOCKHOLM -- The capital of Sweden is 700 years old this year, and the celebrations planned for the anniversary easily top the Swedish tourist calendar for the summer.
A few lines about music may give variety to letters on most every other subject. This is about the works, in large forms, of Edward MacDowell.

MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 21 -- Farmers in this rich livestock and dairying area are still chewing over the Republican Administration's new agricultural policy delivered to them in person by the Secretary of Agriculture.

FRANKLINVILLE, N. Y., Feb. 21 (AP) -- Four Niagara University students who set out from Buffalo on a skylark eight days ago were found dead today in the wreckage of their rented airplane eight miles from this western New York village.
BOWLING GREEN, Va., Feb. 21 (AP) -- A New York woman was killed and her husband and two other persons were injured in a collision ten miles north of here on Route 301 yesterday.

GARLAND ROARK'S latest salt-caked thriller. "The Wreck of the Running Gale," revolves about the theft of an American sailing vessel from Valparaiso in 1877. This serves to launch a sailing race in pursuit across the Pacific, with the skipper of the purloined craft on the deck of one pursuing schooner, and his rival and junior member of the firm of New York owners on the deck of another.

I read with interest Mr. Downes' recent article, "Violinists' Goal." He says that conductors have told him repeatedly that often a violinist comes in with a Paganini concerto ready to play to prove his prowess and then fails to read quickly and intelligently a new piece of music put before him to interpret at sight and fails to secure a position through this haphazard mode of auditioning.

ST. LOUIS. TWO years ago, because of the decline of theatre business on the road, a group of managers in cities outside of New York formed a pool through which they could make random investments in touring attractions. Their hope was to stimulate production.
ALBANY, Feb. 21 (AP) -- An intercollegiate basketball record for overtimes was believed to have been established tonight when Niagara defeated Siena, 88 -- 81, after six extra periods.

GARDEN CLUB exhibits will come in for a good share of the limelight when the Thirty-Seventh International Flower Show opens at Grand Central Palace, Lexington Avenue at Forty-sixth Street, on Sunday, March 8.

THE music season in Israel has been marked by a comparatively small group of visiting soloists but by a great variety of interesting and original offerings. The most talked-of events were of a folkloristic nature and of an amateur character.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 21 -- Dr. Werner Naumann, leader of the band of Nazis accused of plotting the overthrow of German democracy, is back in Werl prison tonight and the three-day legal fight to win his release under a habeas corpus petition is over.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- A politician who wants to preserve his electoral potential must not stay too long out of the limelight. That particularly applies to a defeated candidate. And it was with full recognition of this simple truth that Adlai E. Stevenson reentered the limelight a week ago today, after his return from a long holiday in the tropics.

CINEMA 16, that flourishing art and documentary film society, has announced the inclusion of several new and "classic" offerings for the forthcoming spring season program. G. W. Pabst's German-made study of social realism, "Kameradschaft," is an addition to a list that already numbers Carl Dreyer's "Vampyr" in its complete version and Pabst's "Secrets of a Soul," an early psychoanalysis treatise based on one of Freud's own case histories.

MIAMI, Feb. 21 -- In as exciting a race as any horse-park aficionado could ask for, the gray 6-year-old Oil Capitol, superbly ridden by Conn McCreary, today took first money of $93,200 in the $130,400 Widener Handicap at Hialeah.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 21 (UP) -Smoke Screen, an also-ran in last year's Kentucky Derby, turned in the best race of his career today as he splashed to victory in the $10,000 added LeCompte Handicap at the Fair Grounds.
Two hundred Boy Scouts marched through the rain on Wall Street yesterday morning to pay their accustomed tribute in word and deed to George Washington.

In his first major speech since succeeding President Eisenhower as head of Columbia University, Dr. Grayson Kirk enunciated a vigorous defense of freedom of thought and speech yesterday and held that if we shy away from controversial subjects we demonstrate a basic weakness.
CHICAGO, Feb. 21 -- A flood-control project, nearing completion at Fort Riley, Kan., was revealed this week by headquarters of the Fifth Army here as an outstanding example of twin accomplishments.

One of the fondest fallacies held by savings bankers is being shattered by the findings in a national survey by the American Bankers Association. Preliminary results of the study, just disclosed, indicate that a substantial majority of the nation's savers realize that savings and loan associations are not banks, and understand the distinction between the two types of institutions.

LONDON, Feb. 21 -- Britain will reject Argentina's demand for release of two Argentines who are being deported from Deception Island, in the Antarctic, and for reconstruction of a dismantled Argentine establishment there, a Foreign Office spokesman said tonight.

Representatives of professional organizations, schools and other groups concerned with medicine, dentistry and veterinary medicine met recently with Department of Defense officials to discuss a problem as intricate and complex as the Pentagon Building itself; namely, what is to happen when Public Law 779, "the doctor draft," expires on June 30?

PARIS, Feb. 21-- showdown on the pending European army treaty -- which may speed up or slow down the progress toward European union -- approached this week with the beginning of negotiations over protocols representing the French Government's second thoughts on the subject.
FORT MEADE, Md., Feb. 21 -- Lieut. Col. Melvin B. Voorhees, former Army censor, was convicted today of evading Army censorship.

An eminently sound and substantial contribution to thinking on the "post-defense" role of retailing was made last week by Malcolm P. McNair, Lincoln Filene Professor of Retailing at the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration.

LISBON -- Portugal is looking forward to receiving many foreign visitors this year, a good deal of them Americans. The official estimates show a continuing gain in American tourists. From 11,385 in 1951 the total jumped to 15,803 in 1952.
SPORTSMEN'S SHOW highlights.
CHICAGO, Feb. 21 -- Seton Hall overcame Loyola's stalling tactics tonight to win its twenty-sixth straight basketball game, 52 to 49, and remain undefeated for the season.
Italy is slated to become a principal supplier of silk for both the men's and women's apparel trades in the next few months.

Section 242, Title 18 of the Federal Code makes it a crime for a law enforcement officer to deprive a person "of any rights * * * protected by the Constitution" under the cover of law enforcement. Normally a complaint that a local, state or Federal officer has, under cover of the law, deprived a person of his civil rights must be investigated by the F. B. I.

HOLLYWOOD. When director-producer Otto Preminger heard the pleasant news that any motion picture spoken in German would gross up to 90 per cent more in Germany and Austria than a movie dubbed or subtitled, he decided to try an experiment.
LA JOLLA, Calif., Feb. 21 (AP) -- Scientists today reported that the Pacific Ocean apparently was winning a battle with a volcano over the existence of a phantom of the South Sea -- Falcon Island.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- The State Department said today that United States aid to anti- Communist forces in Indo-China has had a priority second only to arms for the Korean fighting and as been "massive and effective."

Many prominent women are actively interested in the fashion show and luncheon to be held on Tuesday in the main ballroom of the Plaza for the benefit of the Trifles and Treasures Thrift Shop of the Social Service Committee of the Society of Memorial Cancer Center.

ROCQUENFORT, France, Feb. 21 -- Gradual reorganization of the Netherlands Army is being cited at Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway's Supreme Allied Headquarters here as a typical example of the strengthening process going on throughout the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in Europe.

THE annual tournament for the Harold S. Vanderbilt Cup is now under way at the Plaza Hotel. This was the first of the contract bridge tournaments, and though others have exceeded it in size and master-point rating, none has ever overtaken it in prestige.
LONDON, Feb. 21 (Reuters) -- Arsenal's Gunners suffered a blow in their bid for the English League soccer championship today when they were turned back in the game at Blackpool, 3 -- 2.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- A new department of Cabinet status was proposed today to press the nation's global propaganda efforts.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 21 -After some hesitation, Israeli Government officials now are construing a remark by John Foster Dulles, United States Secretary of State, that Washington would welcome Israel to membership in a Middle East defense organization as a hint to the Arab states not to overplay their hand and a caution to them that the Eisenhower Administration had no intention of abandoning Israel.

I want to express my deep respect for Arthur Krock's excellent article, "As Eisenhower Takes Up the Burden," ( Jan. 18 ) on the problems confronting the Eisenhower Administration. I felt it was so remarkable because inspired with so dispassionate a historical perspective and so balanced an appreciation of the problems we are facing.

ONE of the objectives in planting our garden was to place some fragrant material in each area, rather than concentrate on a single bed of scented flowers. In addition to the high points of fragrance in the herb and rose garden, we used certain flowering trees, shrubs, perennials, annuals and bulbs to achieve a succession of fragrance all season long.

William Christian Brossman, an 80-year-old retired clothing cutter, and his physician, Dr. David B. Blumenfeld, attracted the attention of the press last week for good reasons. Brossman had been declared clinically dead by Dr. Blumenfeld after two examinations. The body was taken to an undertaker's establishment.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Feb. 21 -Army's basketball team overcame a 16-point deficit to snap a four-game losing streak and defeated Harvard, 79 to 76, in the feature event of a busy athletic week-end at the Military Academy today.

The problem, common to many states, of wide disparities in the financial resources of schools in different districts, is posed before the 1953 Arizona Legislature, with wholesale reform of the state's tax system advanced as the only solution.

FORTY years ago, an era of zany nonsense, epitomized by Keystone Cops and pie-in-the-face, burst upon the world of the film. Movies were cradled in a little place called then, as now, Hollywood, though otherwise unrecognizable today. The man responsible for that profound contribution to international culture, cinema slapstick, was Mack Sennett, a $35-a-week Biograph actor and director who had had the inspiration to launch his own concern just before World War I.

IT is a good and likable quality that enables man to feel the hurts, the indignations, and the sorrows of others. The quality is called sympathy and it is happily common in America, more common than in other parts of the world that I know.

THE most significant single development in air travel this year probably will be the wide and general expansion of tourist-class service by most of the scheduled airlines of the world. This year -- the golden anniversary of the first flight by the Wright brothers - may mark the beginning of a period in which low cost tourist-class service will dominate the commercial air transport field.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 21 -- Chanlea, a gallant young son of Kentucky and money rider Eddie Arcaro combined talents today to capture the $131,600 Santa Anita Derby for the second straight year for the Calumet Farm of the blue grass country.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica -- Central America, once upon at time quickly dismissed as a bunch of banana republics, has started to capture travelers' attention. For along the connecting strip of land between Mexico and South America stretch six countries with individual personalities and distinctive tourist attractions.
THE HAGUE -- In spite of serious flood damage, the Netherlands, which played host to a record 500,000 tourists last year, expects to do even better this year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Despite rumblings of dissatisfaction in some Republican quarters, an expected movement for major revisions in President Eisenhower's draft of a resolution on secret World War II agreements failed to materialize today.

Before the turn of the century Columbia University made an "investment" of $1,200 in the future of a promising young architect named William Kinne Fellows by giving him a traveling fellowship in Europe. Yesterday, five years after his death, the university received $560,000 for a memorial fund to be established in his name for other aspiring architects.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 21 (UP) -- The Presidents of Argentina and Chile agreed today to establish an economic union between their nations within four months.

NOTHING could be more preposterous than to say that this book, consisting of 556 words and forty-eight drawings, has the impact of a novel. But this reviewer would like to say that such is the effect it has created on him.

THE Italian States, the Lombardy-Venetia, Ceylon and Victoria (Australia) stamp collections assembled by the late Rear Admiral Frederic R. Harris brought $200,000 at four public sales here and one in London.

BELGRADE -- Tourists in search of first-class accommodations and the entertaining amenities that can be found in the busy resorts of most of Western Europe would be well advised to stay away from Yugoslavia, although the Government has been engaged in a visible effort to improve the country's tourist facilities.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 21 -- Harvard College has established a new scholarship program for undergraduate students in engineering, W. J. Bender, dean of admissions and financial aids, announced today. Ten awards will be made this spring to secondary school seniors entering college in the fall.

THERE is a considerable segment of the reading public -- including this reviewer -- whose enthusiasm for books about life in a boys' school is limited to the point of being almost nonexistent. That includes "Tom Brown," "Stalky" and those English novels in which the faculty and students are equally neurotic and passion-ridden.

ONE of the famous nonsense rhymes of Edward Lear tells about an Old Man of Corfu who never knew what he should do. So he rushed up and down, till the sun turned him brown -- that bewildered Old Man of Corfu.

GUIDED by the criterion, "Could I look at this picture on my wall for a year," a panel of five judges last week awarded $3,000 in cash prizes in the Osborne Color Transparency Contest, sponsored by the Osborne Company, of Clifton, N. J., makers of commercial art calendars and color plates.

EVER since double-sided records were introduced -- how many years ago? -- record collectors, a notably critical lot, intermittently have made long complaints about couplings. Why a violin concerto followed by a stupid encore piece?
I should like to express my satisfaction in and complete agreement with your editorial of Feb. 15 on Olympic National Park. Your analysis of Congressman Mack's letter is admirable.

HOUSTON, Tex., Feb. 21 -- Reactions of Texas farmers to the farm policy views of Mr. Benson appear to depend on the individual farmer's present straits, though there is evidence that his policy statements have not been fully assimilated.

MR. LOWREY and the hero of his first novel were both born in Mississippi early enough to become soldiers in World War II, acquire experience abroad and return at about the same age to profit by learning at an Eastern university.

SOME historical events need time to leave an impression. The first hard-cover Dashiell Hammett, for instance, was received as just another detective story, and so, thirteen years earlier, was a novel by E. C. Bentley called "The Woman in Black." (A reviewer wonders what milestone in detective fiction he passed over lightly last year.)

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Feb. 21 -- The Government asked twelve of the Netherlands' leading water defense experts today to choose between higher dikes and the damming off of the North Sea approaches as the way to make the southwestern islands floodproof.

BAD GODESBERG, Germany -- Americans are as welcome in Western Germany today as were their cigarettes back in 1945. Little now remains to remind the tourist of the poverty-stricken country of seven years ago whose population was being kept alive largely by American effort, although the scars of war are still manifest in the big cities.

THANKS to the genius of one man and to electricity, thousands of American tourists will enjoy again this summer the unique thrill of viewing the world from its otherwise inaccessible roof, and although they will be surrounded by precipitous cliffs and treacherous glaciers they themselves will be comfortable and absolutely safe.

The life insurance policyholder has become inflation concious. The average American breadwinner -- "the one who pays the freight" -- is purchasing, on the average, twice as much life protection as he did at the outbreak of World War II.

The drifting pattern of the securities markets was not altered very much by political developments in Washington last week. Neither the Administration's stand against a tax cut this year, nor the slash by Congress of the first "money" bill, caused any change in the cautious attitude of traders in the stock market.
PAUL SMITH'S, N. Y., Feb. 21 -- A formidable Paul Smith's ski team compiled a perfect score in retaining its carnival honors against seven rivals today as the week-end competition ended.
LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Feb. 21 (AP) -- Muriel Reich of New York City, 14 years old, skated off today with the girls' junior title of the eastern sectional figure skating championships.

NOW that its merger with United Paramount Theatres has been approved, the American Broadcasting Company last week made the first moves to bolster its competitive position in television. Frank Marx, vice president in charge of engineering and general services, announced that more than $2,000,000 would be spent to provide increased power to the chain's five owned TV stations.

JUST less than twenty-three years and considerably more than several hundred thousand dollars ago, Rosalind Russell -- sure that a stage-manager's fish-eye during a rehearsal of the revised edition of the "Garrick Gaieties" meant she would be fired before opening -- fled down Broad-day from Fifty-second to Forty-second Street seeking a haven.

JERSEY CITY, Feb. 21 -- Warehousing facilities at the Lehigh Valley Railroad Claremont Terminal here, abandoned last October by the Army's Corps of Engineers as a shipping point for airport construction materiel destined for North African air bases, have been leased by the Goodyear. Tire and Rubber Company of Akron, it was announced today.

Thanks to the efforts of Mrs. Eileen J. Garrett, president of the Parapsychology Foundation, New York, the prospect of holding an international conference of parapsychologists this year in the Netherlands is bright. Parapsychology deals with such matters as extrasensory perception and other phenomena from which psychologists once shied, but which more and more of them are studying.

There is a possibility that General Shtemenko left or was removed from his post some time last year. On Jan. 1 of this year the Soviet Army newspaper Red Star published an obituary of a Soviet general that included the names of twenty-eight high Soviet military figures who had signed the obituary.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (UP) -- Robert N. Denham, former counsel of the National Labor Relations Board, proposed today that Congress discharge every board official to let President Eisenhower have a free hand in selecting "unbiased" men.

EVERY year a raft of new insecticides and fungicides appears on the market to inspire new hope in gardeners for a better season than last. How good are these compounds? Are they safe? What advantages do they have over older forms?

AT THE KOREAN FRONT, Feb. 12 -- When some hoary historian comes to write his journal of this war he may find it significant that it was in Korea that the soldier learned to love his mess sergeant -- or if not to love him, to find him at least bearable.
