It was "Help Week" and not " "Hell Week" for three Columbia College fraternities that have abandoned the mayhem and pranks traditional in the seven days preceding initiations. They hope to set a pattern for thirteen other chapters at the college.

THE American composer may have his complaints, just or fancied, but one thing he receives in abundance -- talk. He is discussed in print and by word of mouth. He gets advice and criticism, approval and abuse, and quite often he does some of the talking and writing himself.
The Yankees, last of the three major league baseball clubs to make the move, yesterday transferred their base of operations to Florida's sunny clime.

Because the cost of labor is a major factor in the price of finished products, manufacturers are paying a lot of attention to determining how to set wage scales in order to bring maximum benefit to management and employe alike.
HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 21 -- Despite a brilliant 20-point performance by Ernie Beck, Penn's powerful basketball team was upset, 65 -- 55, by Dartmouth tonight before 2,200 fans in Alumni gymnasium.

MONTREAL, Feb. 21 -- A four-goal splurge in the third period, set off by Maurice (Rocket) Richard, gave the Montreal Canadiens a 4-1 victory over the New York Rangers tonight before 14,403 National Hockey League fans in the Forum.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 21 -- Receiving any sort of breaks, or at least no bad ones such as they met last year, those Giants are going to be right up there in the thick of the National League flag race with an excellent chance of grabbing it, Chuck Dressen's recently aired optimism notwithstanding.

MOSCOW, Feb. 21 -- Marshal Vassily D. Sokolovsky, who led the forces that captured Berlin in World War II, has replaced Gen. Sergei M. Shtemenko as Chief of Staff of the Soviet Army, it became known today.
MUNICH, Germany, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Communists battled police for two hours here tonight in Munich's worst riot since the war.

WE have seen their arrogant faces -- gold-leafed cap at jaunty angle, Iron Cross at throat. They were the men who were out stalking for one more kill while Berlin was in flames. They were the U-boat skippers of World War II, direct descendants of the U-boat skippers of World War I.

MAY I say that Joselito is referred to either as Joelito "El Gallo" or "Gallito." The name "El Gallo" alone would mean Brother Rafael. Regarding faena, the usually bullwise Sylvester is wrong, having confused the word with tanda.

Guido Cantelli and the N. B. C. Symphony Orchestra yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall presented a performance of Tchaikovsky's "Pathetique" symphony that has rarely been equaled as immense, ear-splitting apocalyptic sound.

Squadron A defeated the Ramapo Polo Club, 12 -- 10, in a keenly waged battle at the Squadron A armory last night. In the second game of the double-header, the Ellistan Polo Club topped New York, 9 -- 7.
" A Reader" writes (Feb. 8) re Harry Gilroy's article, "Shave, Haircut and No Lecture'' (Jan. 25), "If my dentist spent less time talking my work would have been completed long ago."

MEDICAL men are not ordinarily adventurers, except in the field of their science; but the author of this fascinating book had adventures to spare, in science, in geography and in politics. In "Captive Surgeon" he tells the story of his stay in "liberated" China, with a wry knack for observation that makes it one of the most interesting, and at the same time tragic, stories to come from behind the Yalu.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- The press in Washington is in a sense a window through which the country and in fact the whole world may look in on the President of the United States. This week the world looked in as President Eisenhower held his first news conference and was assured that the window would be kept uncurtained.

PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 21 -- George F. Kennan, former American Ambassador to Russia, said here today that current loyalty investigations had jeopardized the position of the profes sional civil servant by making him vulnerable to "some of the most severe strains and tensions our society knows."

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Feb. 21 -- Dr. Harold Taylor, president of Sarah Lawrence College, today denounced proponents of the scheduled Congressional inquiries into private schools and colleges as "political opportunists" whose help was not needed by educators or boards of trustees.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Feb. 21 -- Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson appealed today to the nation's farmers for advice and assistance in his efforts to check falling agriculture prices and promised to build a new farm program that would not bring "serious regrets and disappointments."

BEVERLY NICHOLS is responsible for a string of books as long as the feathery spike of a casuarina. Among them is "Down the Garden Path," which scattered seed in the form of hints to gardeners. Now comes "Merry Hall," a thicket of fact, fiction and garden lore.

ALBANY, Feb. 21 -- Miss Mary Donlon, chairman of the State Workmen's Compensation Board, recommended today an increase in the benefit payments to workers disabled on the job and to dependents of those fatally injured.

EDINBURGH -- From the verdant Scottish Borders of Sir Walter Scott to the purple-tinted Highlands where the castles of the clan chiefs stand guard, Europe's most ancient kingdom is ready with a royal welcome for travelers this summer.

TEL AVIV -- Israel is getting all dressed up for the tourist trade in 1953 and is hoping, very hard, that large numbers of people are looking to Israel as a place to go. The number of first-class rooms available for tourists is being increased from 1,500 to 2,500 by the construction of fourteen new hotels and the expansion of two -- a formidable jump for so small a country.

MEXICO CITY -- Negotiations are now under way between Mexico and the United States to simplify even further the travel documents required for Americans coming to Mexico, and an agreement is expected soon.

CONTEMPORARY composers have shown that they are not at all averse to publishing their thoughts on various phases of music, but only a very few have bothered to write a personal account of their own musical lives.

GUATEMALA, Feb. 21 -- At 5 o'clock on the afternoon of Feb. 17, 112 Indians from the region of Chimaltenango received eight and three-quarter acres of land each from the first private estate to be divided under Guatemala's agrarian reform law.

FARMINGDALE, L. I., Feb. 21 -- A new jet engine to power pilotless aircraft used as targets in training fighter pilots and ground defense teams was announced here today by the Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation.
MOSCOW, Feb. 21 -- Led by Premier Stalin, millions of Soviet voters will go to the polls tomorrow to elect members of local city and district councils.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- A total of 201 United Nations fliers, brought down or forced to parachute behind enemy lines in Korea, have been rescued from the start of the Korean war in June, 1950, through last Jan. 31, the United States Air Force announced today.

IN the Catskill Mountains people often say that it takes all kinds to make a world. The point m well made, for here comes Elizabeth Nicholds, who rates keeping a goat farm high among life's pleasures. In her first book, "Thunder Hill," she explains carefully that goats are much maligned animals, and are as a matter of fact, far more lovable creatures than some people.

Kurt Nielsen of Copenhagen, Denmark, and Arthur Larsen of San Leandro, Calif., gained the two remaining semi-final round brackets in the national indoor tennis championships yesterday at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.

THIS is a fresh approach to the history of the sea, the sailors and their ships. It will catch the attention of young readers from the start when it takes them aboard a large liner for a tour of inspection.

VIENNA -- Austria earned about $31,000,000 from foreign tourist traffic last year as compared with $800,000 in 1948 when the first post-war travelers began to dribble back to the newly liberated land. This year's tourist trade is expected to break all post-war records.

ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 21 -- Many Southeastern farmers are openly critical of what Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson has had to say against Government action on the farm-price decline, and increasing concern is apparent over the direction the Administration farm policy will take.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (UP) -- Charles E. Bohlen, who accompanied President Roosevelt to the conferences with Premier Stalin at Yalta and Teheran, was cleared today by Moscow for appointment as United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union.

A water main break at the intersection of St. James Place and New Chambers Street at 3:30 P. M. yesterday buckled part of the roadway and sidewalk, dislodged sewer covers and sent geysers of water into the air at several points.

RECORDING ENGINEERS, being only human, will seldom concede that the element of trial and error enters into their professional doings. It is taken for granted that progress is constant, that a record made yesterday is twice as good as one made last year and five times as good as the output of a decade ago.

BERLIN, Feb. 21 -- Step by step since last May the Communists have increased the isolation of West Berlin. It now appears likely that their measures will virtually cut the city in two and may curtail exports from the Western sectors.

It was Washington who demonstrated for us that the strength of a legendary figure can, in the gravest crisis, make or break a nation.

MR. MASTERS' private opinions on my "probable liberalism" and colonialism are quite interesting, but I fail to see their relevancy to my review. MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Feb. 21 -- Although rain caused a postponement of the final phase of the Eastern Intercollegiate Association ski championship until tomorrow, Middlebury's athletes clung to a lead over their chief rival from Dartmouth today.

Racing away from the opposition in the last eight minutes of the game, Johnny Bach's Fordham backetball team whipped New York University, 78 -- 62, in the Maroon gymnasium last night in the thirty-fourth battle between the Bronx rivals.

THE collective eyes of eleven distinguished museum men and women selected as "Landmarks of American Art, 1670-1950" the sixty-two paintings which will go on New Wednesday at the Wildenstein Galleries for the benefit of the American Federation of Arts. A sampling of their choices, gathered from collections throughout the country, appear on these pages.

MICHAEL KEON'S novel of the Chinese Communists during the transition period, when they were on the point of coming out of the mountains and assuming national power, gives to the general reader the most pertinent and unbiased commentary he can hope to find on China's internal situation today.

The formation of twenty-one committees to carry out the widespread activities of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers in 1953 was announced yesterday by W. E. Blewett Jr., society president.

TUXEDO PARK, N. Y., Feb. 21 -- Robert Grant 3d, national racquets champion, and Geoffrey W. T. Atkins, British titleholder, both won their matches in the opening round of the annual Tuxedo Gold Racquets championship today.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Feb. 21 -- Former President Harry S. Truman announced here today that he had sold the rights to his memoirs to Life magazine.

PABLO CASALS has finally made up his mind. The 76year old 'cellist will direct a fourth festival this summer in the Pyrenees Orientales, France. Like the first and third, it will be in Prades, the town where he lives, but whether it will be in the town church, its theatre or the near-by monastery of San Michel de Cuxas is not yet decided.

A liberal arts graduate program in English and comparative literature leading to a Master of Arts degree will be started at Hunter College in September, Dr. George N. Shuster, president of the college, announced yesterday.

CAPT. JACQUES - COUSTEAU clearly is a man of two worlds. One lies a couple of hundred feet beneath the surface of the sea, and to it he repairs for communion with the local color, flora, structure and fishes.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., Feb. 21 (AP) -- Pollard and Harkness' Ever Bright, leading from the start, won the $3,000 Inaugural purse as Oaklawn Park opened its 31-day spring race meeting today before a crowd of 11,567.

GENEVA -- The Swiss tourist industry is enjoying a veritable boom in Americans. Last year the number of "tourist-nights" (the unit of measurement used by the industry to take account of the fact that some people stay longer than others) attributable to Americans rose from 621,683 in 1951 to 956,434, an increase of 53 per cent.
STAMFORD, Conn., Feb. 21 -- There was more trouble today for harried emergency crews of the Connecticut Power Company as well as additional inconvenience for several thousand consumers in the area.

SINGAPORE, Feb. 21 -- The Privy Council's refusal in London to grant Lee Meng, a 25-yea-old Chinese girl, permission to appeal against the death sentence has aroused intense interest throughout Malaya.
TOKYO, Sunday, Feb. 22 -- Thunderjets of the United States Fifth Air Force flew to the Yalu River yesterday to strike at a rail-yard supply center at Manpojin, just south of the Manchurian border.

To survey plants and animals in the Papua area of eastern New Guinea, the fourth Archbold Expedition to New Guinea will spend nine months there this year. The members expect to reach New Guinea early in March.
OMAHA, Neb., Feb. 21 -- There appears to be more hysteria in Washington than at the Midwest farm and stockyard level over declining farm prices.

THE accountants -- that generic term loosely and contemptuously applied by the creative to the fact-and-figure men in films here -- are apt to come up with some depressing findings when they ferret into the commerce of the cinema.
TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 21 -- Iran has received from the United States a conditional offer to purchase a large quantity of oil from the nationalized Iranian oil industry.

EMERSON thought that "the Quakers in their best representatives appear to have come nearer to the sublime history and genius of Christ than any other of the sects." Certainly the consistent and courageous dedication of the Society of Friends to works of philanthropy, reform, education and peace have won the respect of all men of goodwill.

The United Nations buildings in this city look down on the East River. Sometimes it seems to casual observers that the water in the East River, flowing down with one tide and up with the other, never changes but grows murkier year by year. Whether this phenomenon has any symbolic relationship with the work of the United Nations we shall not know until ten or twenty or fifty years from now -- with good luck.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Feb. 21 -- The Nordic Council, consisting of members appointed by the Parliaments of Denmark, Sweden, Norway and Iceland, ended its first session tonight.
Sermons emphasizing the promotion of goodwill were preached by rabbis here yesterday morning in commemoration of Washington's Birthday.

ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands, Feb. 21 -- The Holland America Line reported today that gross revenues last year were more than 50 per cent higher than in 1951. Gross income was 54,000,000 guilders (about $14,250,000), as compared with 35,000,000 in 1951.
A Roman Catholic campaign to rid Newsstands of obscene literature has gained the support of the Brooklyn division of the Protestant Council of the City of New York.
Both Washington and Paris studied the problem of Indo-China last week.

NOW and then somebody refers to our time as an age of prose. Nothing, I think, could be further from the truth. There has never been an age, not even the eighteenth century, when poetry faded from men's minds, and I doubt that there ever will be.

THE chances are good that William Lyon Mackenzie King, Prime Minister of Canada for more than twenty-one years (between 1921 and 1948), will some day rank among the great nation-builders of the world. The Canada that he left to one of his ablest lieutenants -- Louis St. Laurent -- to govern, is moving ahead by leaps and bounds.

Meet-record performances by Fred Dwyer and Ollie Sax, Manhattan's machine-like precision in moving toward its third straight team title and one of the biggest judging mixups in a sport that specializes in confusion distinguished the thirty-second annual Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America indoor track and field championships last night.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 21 -- Under an agreement scheduled for signature next week Alfred Krupp, present head of the great arms making family of the Ruhr, will sell all his holdings in the coal, iron and steel industries.

Nine vessels beamed powerful searchlights on the Upper Bay off the western shore of Governors Island last night in an attempt to find a young woman, known only as "Nora," who reportedly had leaped from a ferryboat bound for Staten Island.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 21 -The people of northeastern Brazil have reached the point of real famine and serious disorders are feared by the authorities, according to fresh reports from various points in the region.

I was very much interested in reading in your paper recently a piece about the inauguration of children's concerts by the New Orleans Philharmonic. Surely, it is a rich opportunity for thousands of students in the entire state, and it would be a valuable educational benefit if the plan could be adopted in many states.

It is no accident that newspaper throughout the country, big and small, daily and weekly, are able to print more and better pictures than they did years ago. The man to whom much of the credit is due for this advance in mass communication is John H. Clough, whose chief interest is studying costly and difficult mechanical processes and making them simple.

LONDON -- At less feverish moments when there is no Coronation boiling up in our midst, there are 8,346,137 people in London, spread out as God, and to some extent the authorities, intended, over 461,827 acres. If all London, therefore, flocked to see the spectacle in the few square miles of its official center, few but ticket-holders and giraffe-necked ladies of Borneo would get so much as a glimpse of Her Majesty.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 21 -- Democracy and individual freedom were stressed by Yugoslav leaders here tonight on the eve of the opening of the Congress of the People's Front, whose name is to be changed to the Socialist Union of Working People of Yugoslavia.

A free ocean cruise of 15,000 miles or more and twenty-four other round-trip voyages to virtually all areas of the world await American high school students who write the best essays on the theme, "What the American Merchant Marine Means to My Community."

IN the pink-gray garden of a Venetian pensione, a middle-aged American tourist defends the mimeographed itinerary of his first European trip: "And every day, we have two hours of independent activity!"

John Steinbeck's "Autobiography: Making of a New Yorker" in "New York 1653-1953" (Feb. 1) was delightful reading. As one of those New Yorkers who, he feels, "will not know anything about this and I don't know whether they are lucky or unlucky" -- he's all wrong.

LAST Sunday this column went on at some length about the theatre's indifference to stage literature. "John Brown's Body," now installed at the Century, was not stage literature until Judith Anderson, Raymond Massey and Tyrone Power took hold of it.

Setback by Aggressive Victor Is Likely to Cost Oakland Boxer Fight With Carter BOSTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Free-swinging Henry Davis of Los Angeles, discounted Johnny Gonsalves' lightweight championship hopes sharply by taking a divided decision from the lanky Oakland, Calif., fighter in their ten-round nationally televised bout tonight at the Arena. Davis weighed 135 1/2 pounds and Gonsalves 136 for their rubber engagement.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 21 -- The Ninth Federal Court of Appeals denied "without prejudice" this week a motion by the Pacific Maritime Association for court approval of a proposed 5 per cent wage increase for some 4,000 West Coast stewards. The "without prejudice" ruling permits the association to resubmit its motion if it wishes.

MINIATURE geraniums are crowding the larger standard varieties in popularity as house plants. Their small leaves, compact habit and slow growth make the miniatures ideal for the window sill in an apartment or house. Even mature plants are rarely more than a few inches high.

In Ruth Painter Randall's "The Lincolns Were Good Neighbors" (Feb. 8) the picture "Mr. Lincoln, Residence and Horse" is captioned thus; "This print (1865) depicts the President's Illinois days with more artistic license than accuracy; for example, he wore no beard in Springfield."

ATHENS -- Greece and her ancient glories may have been sung by all the great poets, but in modern times she has reaped little benefit from such stylish publicity, at least so far as tourism is concerned. The explanation is not hard to find.

CARDIFF, Wales -- Visitors in increasing numbers are taking in Wales on their tour of the British Isles, for apart from the genuinely warm welcome that Wales offers to all visitors, it is a country that has much to show in the way of scenery, local customs and unusual food.
TOKYO, Sunday, Feb. 22 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,533, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Sunday, Korea time:

BOSTON, Feb. 21 -- The New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad is planning the construction of a $250,000 station stop near suburban Canton, Mass., to link up with Route 128, a Greater Boston cimcumferential express highway, it was disclosed this week.

New York University's class of '53 has one public-administration major who won't have to take the civil service examinations to get the Government job he desires. Alphonsus U. Ezeoke returns in June to his native Nigeria to assume his duties as chief of state and hereditary ruler of a half-million African people.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- A stubborn long-term shortage of artillery shells was acknowledged today by Army officers as they disclosed that reserve stocks in Korea had dropped below the point of safety for two months last autumn.

WHEN the epicure says cognac, what does he mean? The answer is a chestnut brown brandy that is fiery but smooth, smelling as penetrating as it tastes, with little or no after-taste; a distillate from white grapes that, at its best, is to be sniffed deeply and sipped gingerly, enjoyed as a period to dinner, connoting good food, good friends, good feeling.
TOURISTS taking their own cars abroad or renting automobiles for travel in the British Isles and Europe this year will set a record, judging by early figures.

ORLANDO, Fla., Feb. 21 (UP) -- Sam Snead had his putter working today as he teamed with Betty Mackinnon to enter the final round of the $7,500 international mixed two-ball golf tournament with a 3-and-2 victory over Betty Dodd and Bill Kaiser.

THE land of once-upon-a-time has changed but little. The road over which the good kings and bad kings, the great and the near-great of medieval Europe rode their free horses is today a highway for automobiles and buses, but the countryside is still filled with castles and woodlands, the towns are mellowed with age and history.

A PORTLY humanist whose literary and spiritual growth over the years may be said to be almost ostentatious in its brillance, A. J. Liebling is possessed, as a Dixieland side man (clarinet) once said of a certain recording supervisor, of "an ear like a bull elephant."
NO astrologer need work overtime to divine that the coronation of Queen Elizabeth II, in Westminster Abbey next June, will break world television and broadcasting records.

THIS three-generation story of a small colony of Bretons settled in a slum quarter of Le Havre has the appeal of all honest panoramic novels: it gives you insight, through the particular doings of the members of one family, into a world not essentially your own.

" Babar, the Elephant," an in ventive and delicately charming forty-minute opera for children was performed for the first time yesterday morning at Hunter College Assembly Hall as the final program in the Little Orchestra Society's fifth season of concerts for young people.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Feb. 21 (UP) -- Penn State's quintet ran off five points in the last minute of play to squelch a gallant Syracuse rally tonight and gained a 78-74 victory.

VERO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 21 -- The best third baseman in the National League, perhaps in the major leagues, will become a utility infielder if Manager Charley Dressen follows through on plans he announced today.

BRUSSELS -- Spring is the best time to visit Belgium. It is less fatiguing than in the summer and it is cheaper. Hotelkeepers in Belgian seaside resorts and near-by cities, including Bruges, grant discounts to visitors from abroad in May and June.

Halfway through a $6,000,000,000 plant expansion program to be completed in 1955, the lusty young chemical industry reported last week only a 3 per cent increase in its average prices since before the Korean war.

THIS biography of Hitler by Alan Bullock is a remarkable achievement. It is comprehensive, clear and well-written. The labor behind it is immense, but he has taken -- as a good historian should, but how few, alas! do -- great trouble to harmonize his raw material and conceal the labor of construction.
PARIS, Feb. 21 -- The Communist afternoon newspaper Ce Soir will cease publication March 1, its publisher, Communist poet Louis Aragon, announced today.

SOMETHING new in the way of traveling ballet units has been devised in the form of the First Ballet Quintet, which is shortly to take to the road. Its personnel consists of Maria Tallchief, Melissa Hayden, Patricia Wilde, Andre Eglevsky and probably Michael Maule, all stars of the New York City Ballet Company.

Last Tuesday President Eisenhower held his first White House news press conference. It was also his first news conference anywhere since early in September. It was eagerly awaited, and the eagerness was partly due to the change that came over his relations with the press during the campaign.

NOVELS are written to be read and from the standpoint of gaining or losing readers the opening pages must be the most important. So it is unfortunate that the opening pages of this first novel, by a Negro author about Negro waiters, give the impression that it is to be one long jeremiad against restaurant owners and kitchen conditions.

BERLIN, Feb. 21 -- High on the wall of the lobby in East Berlin's Friedrichstrasse railway station, displayed in a manner normally reserved for Stalin or President Wilhelm Pieck, hangs a portrait of the Rosenbergs. As travelers hurry by a voice on the loudspeaker system says, "Write protest telegrams to the Supreme Court of the United States.
DETROIT, Feb. 21 (AP) -- The auto industry has a substantial part of its capacity devoted to arms production but appears little worried about what sudden cutbacks might do to its over-all operations.

OF all the fruits that can be grown in this area, blueberries, strawberries, raspberries and grapes are the most rewarding. Blueberries, in fact, are both ornamental and edible. (The bushes are attractive at all seasons of the year.)

THINGS were quiet in Hollywood last week. For a change, nobody announced a new three-dimensional film process. And, unless our polarized vision was blurred or something, there were no significant developments in regard to various wide-screen experiments other than the decision by Twentieth Century-Fox to employ an uppercase "S" in the spelling of CinemaScope.

GENEVA -- The last thing any well-trained tourist promotion man wants to do is to worry travelers about the currents of world economy, delicate questions of international relations or anything else except having a good time.

TORONTO, Feb. 21 (UP) -- Milt Schmidt scored with 2 minutes and 15 seconds left to earn the Boston Bruins a 2-2 tie with the Toronto Maple Leafs in a National Hockey League game before 13,307 fans tonight.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 21 -- The Israeli delegation said today that a large cross-section of the members of the United Nations would take the floor of the United Nations General Assembly to denounce signs of Soviet anti-Semitism.

ISHPEMING, Mich., Feb. 21 (AP) -- Braving near-blizzard conditions, Norman Oakbig of Bush Lake, Minn., fought off the challenges of some of the country's best skiers and won the North American cross-country championship this afternoon.

APPARENTLY a foundation planting is as inevitable a home fixture as a mortgage. We acquired both when we bought our house in the suburbs three years ago. Since then we've managed to keep up with the mortgage, but getting rid of the foundation planting has been a real problem.

IT is not unusual for writers of adult books to try their hands at children's stories. The tradition goes back to Hawthorne and Dickens, and in our own day E. B. White, James Thurber, Rumer Godden, have produced notable books in this field.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 21 -- The state organization of the German party in North Rhine-Westphalia was dissolved today by the party leadership in an effort to keep the organization in line behind Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's program of German integration in Europe.

ROME -- Anyone daydreaming of an Italian holiday this year should plot his itinerary at once and make the necessary reservations. For 1953 is promising to develop into this country's biggest tourist year. From late spring to early autumn Italy will be a crowded place indeed. No leisurely roaming the peninsula and stopping where and when one likes it!

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 21 -- Educators are concerned over the forthcoming investigation of the nation's schools and colleges by Congressional committees. They are vigorously opposed to Communist teachers and have on various occasions in the past taken a strong stand against anyone of "subversive" tendencies in the classroom.

The family of Julius Rosenberg, condemned atom spy, sent letters to all twelve members of the jury that convicted him and his wife Ethel, asking them to appeal to the President to commute the death sentences, it was learned yesterday.

BACK in the early Twenties, the late Ring Lardner wrote a mordant little masterpiece called "Some Like Them Cold," in which he handled the popular music business with much the same tenderness that he had previously accorded baseball and prizefighting.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 21 -- Strong indications that the United Nations would reaffirm its standing peace offers to the Communists in Korea came today from Lester B. Pearson, president of the General Assembly.

ROME, Feb. 21 -- The Communist campaign for the Rosenbergs has found the ground particularly favorable in Italy and succeeded in arousing a great part of public opinion in their favor. How widespread the feeling is may be gauged from the fact that even the Right-Wing press says the Rosenbergs should be pardoned even if guilty, because their ordeal of being kept suspended between life and death has lasted too long.
MEXICO CITY, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Judge Fernandez Vera ruled that evidence in the case failed to prove that General showed had taken the money, but showed him to be a victim of "political persecution."

CHICAGO, Feb. 21 -- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, sounded a warning today that "we could destroy our liberty by a military and foreign expenditure in time of peace so great that a free economic system cannot survive."
NEWARK, Feb. 21 -- Two chemists perished here today in an explosion in a small factory building at 442 Frelinghuysen Avenue that was used as an experimental laboratory.

President Eisenhower went to Korea for the purpose of studying the problem at first hand, and since his return, after weighing all of the pros and cons, he and his staff have undoubtedly worked out a plan of procedure. The first step has been taken, which was to rescind Truman's order restraining the Chinese Nationalist troops from attempting to recapture the mainland of China.

PARIS -- The 350,000 dollar-laden citizens of the United States who in 1952 helped maintain the French tourist industry as one of the world's leaders are cordially welcomed back in 1953, with their friends and relations if possible.

Many buyers were in the wholesale markets here last week requesting summer merchandise and replenishing spring stocks, according to McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buying office. Activity was particularly good on dresses and low-end coats and suits.

PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 21 -- Involved in a tie seven times during the first two quarters, Princeton's basketball squad got down to business after the intermission and swept to a 66-to-59 triumph over Yale tonight. The relatively easy victory for the Orange and Black was its third Ivy League success in seven starts.

THREE Governments, Denmark, Iceland and the Netherlands, promptly issued semi-postal stamps to raise money to aid sufferers in the flood disaster in Holland. In Denmark, "NL" (for Netherlands) and "+10" were overprinted on the 30-ore red in the Frederik IX portrait design.

SPURRED by a mounting accident toll that is bringing financial hardship as well as death and injury to more and more motorists, a joint committee of the State Legislature last week reported-in favor of two bills dealing with the problem of the uninsured motorist.

Wesleyan University, Middletown, Conn., will have a graduate summer school this July and August leading to the new degree of Master of Arts in liberal studies. Intended primarily for elementary and secondary schoolteachers the program will offer courses in five major areas of the liberal arts.

THE shipping industry is getting set to handle a record flow of Europe-bound passengers this year, confident that their numbers will exceed the previous post-war high set last year, when some 620,000 travelers crossed the North Atlantic by ship.

" An unconscious creeping snobbery, mingled with a desire for novelty," is one of the big causes of imprecision in spoken and written English. So declared Jacques Barzun, Professor of History at Columbia University, in a talk to the School and College Conference on English at Barnard College yesterday.

VARIOUS members of the cissus group (grape family) are among the most attractive and easily grown house plants. Two of the best known are grape ivy (C. rhombifolia) and kangaroo vine (C. antarctica). Because of their ability to thrive on little care and withstand heat and dryness, they are especially useful in city apartments.

Dividends are usually pleasurably received, but they can cause difficulty for stockholders who have not kept a record of them for income tax purposes. With less than a month remaining for filing Federal income tax returns, the task of compiling dividend income becomes more of a problem each day for shareholders.

NOT all of the current recorded curtain calls are out of the past. Victor has pulled two of the better numbers out of its New Faces of 1952 album -- Monotonous and Boston Beguine -- and issued them as a single record. Eartha Kitt's delightful precision-cum-madness delivery of Monotonous presages a happy recording career for her.

Some erstwhile irresponsibles on the opposite side of the aisle must now become the responsibles. But it is my hope that former responsibles on our side will not now become new irresponsibles in Congress.

NO one has more cause or, in fact, is better fitted than David E. Lilienthal to write this book. In one way, it is an apologia pro vita sua priore, in another, it is an extension into the area of business policy of the author's thoughtful earlier political work, "TVA: Democracy on the March"; in still another, it is an expression of faith -- an inspirational statement that calls Americans to an act of dedication.

JOHN FORSYTHE, a man who has never been on a horse, is destined to make movie history soon as one of Hollywood's first three-dimensional cowboys. He will be heading them off at the junction of Eagle and Stereoscope Pass in an M.-G.-M. class Western called "Rope's End," scheduled for the cameras in midMarch and early release thereafter.

LILLEHAMMER, Norway, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Russian women speed skaters dominated the first two events of the 1953 world speed skating championships which opened today with the favored Mrs. Rimma Zhukova topping the list.

THIS capital, like any other, is full of rumors. More than that, it is a funnel for rumors from all over the country -- some of the oldest, most heavily bearded and venerable rumors in human experience.

LONDON -- There are only fourteen weeks to go before Coronation Day, and it is hard to imagine how bleak and wintry London will transform itself into a city of color and light in time for the crowning of Queen Elizabeth II. But it will, of course, and to prove it the first snowdrops appeared only a few days ago in the green turf about the statue of Peter Pan in Kensington Gardens.

TOKYO, Feb. 21 -- Mamoru Shigemitsu, president of the Progressive party, which is Japan's second largest political party, has announced his intention to introduce a motion of nonconfidence in the government of Premier Shigeru Yoshida at this session of the Diet (Parliament) as result of the latter's alleged plan to revive the "police" state.

INTERVIEWING George Jessel on the subject of television -- or any other subject -- can be almost as narrowing as trying to hold a tea party in Grand Central Station. The telephone in his hotel suite rings every few minutes.

HENRY G. RUSSELL'S "A Handbook of Miniature Photography" (London: Nicholas Kaye; Philadelphia: Rayelle Publications, $5.75) makes its appeal to the average beginner, suggesting ways and means of extending the opportunities of his chosen hobby.

Plans are being advanced at meetings at the Plaza and at teas in private homes for the annual luncheon and fashion show to be held March 25 in the Plaza for the benefit of various charitable organizations that are aided by the Nearly New Shop at 938 Eighth Avenue.

VALLEY FORGE, Pa., Feb. 21 -- Freedoms Foundation named tonight more than 800 American individuals, schools and organizations to receive its fourth annual freedom awards, consisting of gold medals, prizes and $100,000 in cash.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Feb. 21 (AP) -- Harvie Ward, British amateur champion, today gained the final of the national tournament of golf club champions with a 7-and-6 victory over Sam Maniaci, former Columbia University football star.

PARIS, Feb. 21 -- The Communist party here has seized eagerly upon the Rosenberg case as a weapon in its propaganda war against the United States. Few issues in recent years have afforded the Communists such an opportunity for turning public opinion against the United States and they have used every technique and every argument in the book to exploit it.

In the second episode, he throws stones at his friends -- the elephant, the monkey and the rabbit -- just in fun, of course.

THE Eisenhower Administration, deep in the process of forming foreign policy, faces an especially exacting task -- to estimate as correctly as possible the power and policies of the Soviet Union. It is dangerous in any kind of contest either to underestimate or overestimate one's opponent, and it is doubly so in the great struggle with Russia.

COMMERCE surges unseen through steel arteries that lay underground, humping over hills and spanning rivers; oil from Oklahoma and Texas flows through the welded pipelines to St. Louis, Chicago and up the industrial Atlantic Coast.

Men's wear retailers expressed considerable concern about declining profits during the convention of the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers last week. Almost every speaker commented on the rising costs of operating an outlet, which contrast with the constant mark-up.

Scientific experiments carried on with homing pigeons and other birds show that the adults are the first to find their way home over completely strange territory, says Dr. Gustav Kramer, German zoologist, who has been lecturing on the subject in American universities under the auspices of the Society of Sigma Xi.
French cabinetwork and decorations suitable as accessories for it will be auctioned on Friday and Saturday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

NEW Dance Group Productions' "Festival" at the Ziegfeld Theatre pretty well encloses the week's affairs, with one performance tonight and two next Sunday. With Charles Weidman's always popular "Fables for Our Time," new works to the number of ten, the debut of a permanent company together with several guest soloists, its programs are fairly bristling with items to attract the long-starved modern dance public.

TWO books being published this week are causing some commotion. One is called "The Wonderful World of Books" and the other "The Wonderful World of Insects." Please do not confuse them. Curiously enough it is the former that has been edited by the Editor of the Department of Agriculture Year Book. Alfred Stefferud.

Two of Ohio's symphony orchestras have arranged to play new works to celebrate the state's 150th anniversary. The Toledo Symphony's contribution will be a performance under Wolfgang Stresemann of "Johnny Appleseed Overture," by Albert Sendrey, which won the $500 first prize in the contest sponsored by the orchestra's women's auxiliary to obtain a work for the state's sesquicentennial.

MOUNT HOPE, N. Y., Feb. 21 -- In a weird atmosphere of heavy fog produced by the warm outside air on the cold indoor arena, Christian (Buddy) Arndt and the St. Andrew's No. 2 rink, winners of the district championship the past two years, reached the semi-finals of the Grand National Curling Club District No. 2 bonspiel at the St. Andrew's Golf Club today.

The multiplication of "inhuman acts" occurring in Soviet-dominated countries was condemned yesterday by the National Conference of Christians and Jews in a statement calling upon all Americans to strengthen their own protests by supporting a "program for action."

Washington's Birthday finds the country divided between Hamiltonians and Jeffersonians as it was in Washington's Administration. We may take this on the authority of Mr. Stevenson, present-day spokesman of the Jeffersonians, who said as much in his Jefferson-Jackson Day speech.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- The Secret Service announced the arrest today of two employes of the Department of Agriculture on charges of counterfeiting $10 bills.

MOSCOW, Feb. 21 (AP) -- The official accusation of the nine Moscow doctors said they had tried to weaken Soviet defenses by treating three marshals, an admiral and General Shtemenko so that they eventually would die. The Government said most of the doctors were tied up with an American Jewish relief organization and all were linked with United States and British spying.

DALLAS -- Leo F. Corrigan, an alert, fast-rising Texan who owns great chunks of valuable Dallas real estate and dreams of erecting the city's tallest skyscraper, recently announced that he would build, at the corner of Akard and Main Streets, a forty-story copy of New York's green glass Lever House (twenty-four stories).
Manhattan College's basketball team overpowered a smaller Brooklyn College five, 74 -- 51, at the losers' gymnasium last night. The victory was the eighteenth for the Jaspers against two setbacks.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- A factual study of religion is the best approach to the problem of religion in the public schools, a report by the Committee on Religion and Education of the American Council on Education said today.

As a reader of THE NEW YORK TIMES for more than twenty years, and knowing the impartiality of your great paper, I feel obliged to say that your general information about the policy of European union or "integration" and the various trends of opinion in Europe concerning this policy in its present form is perhaps not as complete as you might wish it to be.

SINCE Lawrence Langner, co-director of the Theatre Guild, already has proved that he will not say "uncle" as far as his pet project is concerned -- the establishment of an American Shakespeare Festival Theatre in Connecticut -- it is possible this morning to report that he now is at work on another phase of his plan -- namely, the means whereby actors in this country will be able to receive special training in classical acting.

EACH year the National Institute of Arts and Letters awards a half dozen gravel of $1.000 each to artists in pursuance of its policy of encouraging and stimulating the progress of art in America. Members nominate candidates for the grants and the arts committee of the institute eventually decide on six.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- The Eisenhower Administration, after one month and one day in office, is now faced with the necessity of making an accommodation with Senator Joseph R. McCarthy or colliding heavily with the most feared and powerful investigator in Congress.

Navy won all four team trophies and two of the three individual titles in the ninth annual Hypan fencing tournament at the New York A. C. yesterday. Also competing were Harvard, Yale, Princeton and Army.

By now it must be obvious to all that the New York Knickerbockers just about "own" the Philadelphia Warriors. For, last night at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory, Joe Lapchick's lads made it nine out of nine in this season's dealings with the Philadelphians.

ISTANBUL -- This year marks the 500th anniversary of a world-shaking event -- the fall of this ancient city (Constantinople) to the Turks. The great center of Christian civilization, straddling two continents, Europe and Asia, the inheritor of Athens and Rome, was shortly afterward to become the capital of the Ottoman Empire and focal point of the Moslem world.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- The average pay of the nation's 16,500,000 factory workers went up 18 cents an hour during two years of wage controls, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 21 -Navy scored its fourteenth straight home basketball victory of the season today, turning back the M. aryland quintet by 51---47. The lVIiddies were in front at half time by 30--13 as they held the Terrapins without a field goal in the second period.

VIENNA, Feb. 21 (UP) -- Austrian political leaders urged the 4,500,000 voters of this occupied nation tonight to vote for freedom and against communism in tomorrow's general elections for a new Parliament and Government.

In the draft resolution that President Eisenhower has forwarded to Congress the word "repudiate" is definitely omitted in respect to the wartime secret agreements. The emphasis is thrown, rather, on the Soviet Union's total disregard of the agreements in so far as they touched on human rights and human freedoms.

THE long-awaited American premiere of Igor Stravinsky's latest opera, "The Rake's Progress," took place in the Metropolitan Opera House eight days ago. This premiere had all the flavor of a grand gala event, which it was.

" ONE wonders if women still exist, if they will always exist, whether or not it is desirable that they should, what place they occupy in this world, what their place should be." The questions are radical enough, comprehensive enough, searching enough.

HELSINKI -- Finland expects a lot of tourists this summer as a result of the extremely favorable publicity this country earned with its very successful hosting of the Olympics last year. And judging from advance reservations now pouring in for hotel accommodations and tours, the Finns will not be disappointed.

ONE of the surest signs that spring is on the way are the announcements of -- and preparations for -- maple-sugar festivals around the country The dates of these events vary with the climates of given localities. Ohio's sugartime is usually in late March, Michigan's in early April. In the East, Vermont is the champion sugar producer and, with its late spring, the local "sugaring-off" season comes in late April.

The ruling of the United States Court of Appeals at Cincinnati, that organized baseball is a sport and not a business subject to anti-trust laws will be reversed by the Supreme Court, Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat, of Brooklyn predicted yesterday.

LIEUT. GEN. MAXWELL DAVENPORT TAYLOR, a lean and handsomely erect figure of a military man who is a scholar, a perfectionist and a paratrooper, has been entrusted with the Army's most difficult and important field command. His Army career has followed a strange pattern.

SO much excitement and confusion are loose in the motion-picture world over this matter of three-dimensional movies and the incipient promotion of the "wide screen" that the time has come to take a deep breath and cast a square look at realities.

Briar pipes and motor cars figured last week in the weighty problems of greater economic cooperation by nations of the free world. These two items -- symbols of well-being and progress -- were given an odd prominence in top-level statements concerned with the question of whether this country should reduce or eventually eliminate tariffs.

COMEDY programming is very probably the major paradox of television today. In one form or another it still is the basic meal ticket of video, yet its standard is steadily deteriorating. Real wit and humor are being supplanted by assembly-line corn and child-like charades to such a degree that a new national norm in comedy would seem in the making.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 21 -- The Mexican authorities have captured two United States shrimp boats registered in Brownsville, Tex., and jailed their crews as the first earnest of their declared intention to "chase the pirates from our shores."

An encouraging subscription has been reported for the annual card party for the benefit of the Girls Branch of the public Schools Athletic League to be held on March 14 in the Colonnades of Essex House. Mrs. Byrnes MacDonald and Mrs. F. Phillip Lindh are co chairmen of the patroness comittee.

Neither Mrs. Gray's letter (Jan. 25) nor Kenneth S. Davis' reply (Feb. 8), with reference to his article, "A Bigger Role for Farm Co-ops," made clear exactly what a co-op patronage refund is, nor why it is tax-exempt.
Three upsets marked last night's first knockout round of the 1953 Vanderbilt Cup Tournament, national team of four contract bridge championship, at the Plaza Hotel.

PARIS, Feb. 21 -- It would be both rash and incorrect to say that Soviet foreign policy has been placed upon the defensive by recent American efforts to seize the initiative in the "cold war." Nevertheless, judging by some of Moscow's recent actions, it appears that the Kremlin is being prompted to new measures designed to frustrate any design for global solidarity against aggression.

The pricing of inventories of materials and supplies plays a very important part in determining taxable income of various business enterprises. The predominant method of valuing inventories has been on the basis of cost or market price, whichever is the lower.

The Eisenhower Administration's broad strategy for the Far East began to emerge in clearer outline last week. The picture could be pieced together from hints and information gleaned at the President's press conference; a press conference by Secretary of State John Foster Dulles; a strategy meeting in preparation for the U. N. General Assembly; and from Congressmen and others who were briefed by high Administration officials.

SPRING, which comes early in the Midsouth, is already stirring preparations for the sixth annual Azalea Festival in Wilmington, N. C. It will be held from March 26 to 29 but between now and then special programs of golf and riding, the winter specialties of North Carolina, will afford a heavy schedule of tourist activity throughout the state.

THE very small, highly selective exhibition of the art of the T'ang Dynasty (618-906 A. D.), sponsored by the Chinese Art Society and presented at the China Institute, 125 East Sixty-fifth Street, makes a twentieth-century New Yorker wish he might have visited the court at Ch'ang An during the first 150 years of the dynasty -- some time before the rebellion of the Tartar general An Lu-shin.
