MUNICH, Feb. 22 -- The Bank Deutscher Laender, West Germany's central bank, has lifted the last of the credit restrictions that were imposed in 1951 to ward off the threat of inflation after the opening of hostilities in Korea.
TOKYO, Monday, Feb. 23 (AP) -United Nations Command communique 1,534, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Monday, Korea time:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) -The Very Rev. Francis B. Sayre Jr., dean of the Washington (Episcopal) Cathedral, said today that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin; Representative Harold H. Velde, Republican of Illinois, and a great many others "are demonstrating that they believe God and the nation are best served by the frightened and credulous collaborators of a servile brand of patriotism."

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Feb. 22--Flashing superlative style on both of his flights, Jon Riisnaes, University of New Hampshire Norwegian freshman, today carried off the honors in the thirty-second annual Lake Placid Club Sno Birds' ski jump. The sensational athlete, whose airflight is almost flawless and landings near perfection, thus continued unbeaten in his first year of American competition.

CHICAGO, Feb. 22--Trade in grain futures was active, but purchases failed to reach the big volume of the previous week, when the market was in the throes of heavy long liquidation. Average daily purchases last week were 50,000,000 bushels, compared with 72,000,000 in the previous week and 32,000,000 a year ago.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 22 -- Manager Casey Stengel greeted the Yankee contingent when it arrived from New York tonight and admitted he faced a troublesome hold-out situation. This had to do with Allie Reynolds, twenty-game winner of last season and a tower of strength in the World Series against the Dodgers.
FROGMORE, S. C., Feb. 22 (AP) -- Historic Penn School for Negroes will abandon its educational program and turn entirely to community service soon, its directors announced today.
VALLEY FORGE, Pa., Feb. 22 -- Twenty top winners of the fourth annual Freedoms Foundation, Inc., awards received their prizes this afternoon from Vice President Richard M. Nixon.

NEWBURGH, N. Y., Feb. 22 -The Right Rev. Henry O'Carroll, the oldest priest in the New York Archdiocese of the Roman Catholic Church, today marked the sixtieth anniversary of his ordination to the priesthood. He is 84 years old.

WASHINGTON, Monday, Feb. 23 -- An Air Force spokesman here confirmed this morning the report that three jet planes had crashed at Goose Bay, Laborador. He said only partial information about the incident had reached Air Force headquarters.

London opening dates for the reproduction of two distinguished Broadway musicals -- "Guys and Dolls" and "The King and I" -have been designated. "Guys and Dolls," cited by the Critics Circle, will come first on May 28. The Frank Loesser-Jo Swerling-Abe Burrows show will be put on by Feuer Martin at the Coliseum, where "Call Me Madam" has been entertaining Londoners since March 15, 1952.
Isoniazid, first revealed just a year ago as a dramatically successful new weapon in the war on tuberculosis, is quite literally a drug on the market today.

Now and again a book comes along that racks up the mental tenpins in your private bowling alley. An idea here -- perhaps only a phrase -- puts the things you knew into a form you can recognize and understand. Such a book is Kenneth E. Boulding's "The Organizational Revolution,"* which is the second volume of the series on ethics and economic life being produced by the study committee of the Federal Council of Churches.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 22 -- The number of persons killed when two antiquated trolley cars loaded to overflowing crashed headon in a Mexico City suburb last night reached sixty to seventy today. About ninety persons were hurt. Sixty-three bodies, many of them burned or crushed beyond recognition, had been recovered from the wreckage this afternoon.

PARIS, Feb. 22 -- Release of the thirteen Alsatian youths condemned for the part they played as drafted members of the Hitler S. S. guards in the wartime massacre of the French population of the village of Oradour-sur-Glane gave rise today to conflicting demonstrations in various parts of France.

George Washington's spirit of freedom was invoked in behalf of various causes yesterday as ceremonies commemorating his birthday were held throughout the city. Even more Washington admirers expressed their gratitude to him by enjoying the tangible freedom of the three-day holiday.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 22 -Chancellor Konrad Adenauer, before leaving tonight for the Foreign Ministers' meeting in Rome, described the French protocols to the European army treaty as a "serious threat" to the treaty's final ratification.
The first transport-type aircraft designed in this country especially for gas turbine entwines was announced here yesterday by the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation.
Before it is too late I trust some serious consideration will be given by the authorities to a proposal for converting the Third Avenue Elevated into a parking facility.

The people of Austria yesterday elected the 165 members of the National Assembly, the lower house of their parliament. As the voters went to the polls they knew they had to choose between different candidates and parties, between different political programs and philosophies. No one knew in advance who the victor would be.

It is much easier for a people to be caught up in a sudden burst of patriotism than to support their nation unwaveringly during a long period of tension. The invasion of the South Korean Republic rallied American citizens to common cause, but as the months faded into years civilian concern for the men in the battle lines grew less keen.
PARIS, Feb. 22 -- The Foreign Ministers' meeting in Rome is considered of great importance in the crucial situation caused by reconsideration of the European army treaty.

Persons who permit an ambition or an interest, however worthy, to usurp "the supreme place God holds in the heart" are "walking the road of Judas Iscariot," the Rev. William R. Bonniwell of St. Vincent Ferrer Mission and Retreat House warned yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral in the first of a series of Lenten sermons.

CAMP DRUM, N. Y., Feb. 22 -With six weeks of intensive cold weather training behind them, members of the 325th Regimental Combat Team will counterattack an aggressor force Tuesday in the first of three tactical maneuvers scheduled in Exercise Snowstorm.

Mussorgsky's "Boris Godunov" will be returned to the repertoire of the Metropolitan Opera during the seventeenth week of the season, which begins Monday evening, March 2. The opera, which is scheduled for Friday evening, will be given in a version that has been revised by Karol Rathaus after the original Mussorgsky score. An English text has been supplied by John Gutman, and George London will sing the title role. Fritz Stiedry will conduct.

Today's meeting of the Franco-Vietnamese High Military Committee in Indo-China was called to authorize the doubling of the Vietnamese forces in the field. The method that has been agreed upon by the French and the Vietnamese is somewhat different from that hitherto employed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (UP) -Representative Francis E. Walter, Democrat of Pennsylvania, defended the controversial McCarranWalter Immigration Act today as one that gave a "fair hearing" even to such a person as Joe Adonis, New Jersey gambler.
CHICAGO, Feb. 22 -- Last week witnessed steady price appreciation in all grains and soybeans, with substantial upturns in wheat and corn the feature.
The condition of Italy practically on the eve of another decisive political election holds a lesson for all of us.

TOKYO, Monday, Feb. 23 -- A Chinese Communist propaganda broadcast today quoted two captured Marine Corps air officers as saying the United States Joint Chiefs of Staff had directed the United States forces in the Far East to carry out planned germ warfare.

DEMOREST, Ga., Feb. 22 (UP) -- The issue of white supremacy arose again today at Piedmont College here as a result of the dismissal of two more faculty members opposed to policies of the school president, James Walter.

TOKYO, Feb. 22 (AP) -- United Nations Command Headquarters said today that the accidental bombing of United States troops Feb. 2 was carried out by a carrierbased Navy plane preparing for a crash landing with a fire in its cockpit.

The WNYC Music Festival, which began Feb. 12 on Lincoln's Birthday, ended last night on Washington's Birthday with a program of contemporary music, sponsored by the American Composers Alliance and Broadcast Music, Inc., and conducted by Leopold Stokowski in the Museum of Modern Art.

The first units of India's great Damodar Valley Project are being brought into operation. This is a combination of dams, flood control, irrigation provision, hydroelectric and thermal generating plants modeled in some respects on our own T. V. A. Some of the capital for the project has come from the World Bank, and the United States has played a considerable technical role thus far.
MEXICO CITY, Feb. 22 (AP) -Roberto De Vicenzo of Argentina today broke his own 1951 course record to win the Mexican open golf tournament with a 21-underpar 267.

SALISBURY, Conn., Feb. 22 -Harold Jones, a 14-year-old high school freshman from here, combined leaps of 81 and 94 feet today to accumulate 135.3 points and win the 1953 Eastern junior ski-jumping championship.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22--The Eisenhower Administration's "psychological offensive" against the Communists is running into criticism here on the ground that the President, Secretary of State John Foster Dulles, and the Republican leaders in Congress are talking too much about it.

TUXEDO PARK, N. Y., Feb. 22 -- Robert Grant 3d, national racquets champion, and Geoffrey W. T. Atkins, British titleholder, won their second-round and semifinal matches today in the annual Tuxedo Gold Racquet tourney and will meet tomorrow in the final.

The impressive feat of playing the first movements of the Mendelssohn Violin Concerto, both solo and orchestra parts, was managed skilfully by Jack Kudeviz accordionist, who made his recital debut Saturday evening at Carnegie Recital Hall.

A one-family home on plot 100 by 100 feet on Amherst Place, Hartsdale, N. Y., was sold by Emile Cormier to Mr. and Mrs. Peter V. Norden through Mrs. Alice Cohn and Walter Rostenberg, broker. It was bought for $28,600, subject to a first mortgage of $18,500.

A drastic new regulation to bar tractor-trailers, regardless of length, from congested midtown and lower Manhattan during business hours is being drafted by Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley and Hugo E. Rogers, special counsel to the Traffic Department.

Marshal Georgi K. Zhukov, the outstanding Soviet military leader of World War II. apparently has been demoted or otherwise reduced in military importance, the latest data on the higher officers of the Soviet armed forces indicate. His loss of status may be connected with the recent replacement of Gen Sergei M. Shtemenko as Soviet Chief of Staff by Marshal Vassily D. Sokolovsky.

Puccini's sentimental masterpiece, "La Boheme," was presented yesterday by the Metropolitan on the TV program known as "Omnibus," the second opera expressly prepared for television by the opera company. It was done in first-rate fashion. Both the Metropolitan and television had cause for pride, and the millions in the unseen audience had occasion for gratitude.

There were fifty-two advertising agencies that billed $10,000,000 or more each in 1952, according to Advertising Age magazine. These agencies billed $1,720,400,000. The fifty in the similar classification in 1951 billed $1,567,200,000.

A radio series of hour-long documentaries on prison conditions in the United States was started at 9 P. M. Friday by the National Broadcasting Company. The first installment, dealing with last spring's prison riot at Trenton, was dramatically effective but journalistically very uneven.
Three new orders placed in January make a total of thirty-two tankers now building in French shipyards or waiting to be laid down, the French Shipbuilders Association reported here yesterday.
LILLEHAMMER, Norway, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Khalida Chtchegoleeva of Russia won the 1953 women's world speed skating championship today with 207.640 points for the four events.
LONDON, Feb. 22 -- Britain is discovering that there are almost as many difficulties in laying down the white man's burden as there were in assuming it.
Newbold Morris, former President of the City Council and twice a candidate for Mayor, said yesterday that he would run again for Mayor if called upon to serve his city.

The movement toward universal brotherhood has been aided by scientific discoveries proving that all men share the same blood and "no man can live anywhere with complete independence of others elsewhere," the Rev. Laurence I. Neale, minister of the Unitarian Church of All Souls, Lexington Avenue and Eightieth Street, declared yesterday.

IN the quiet and unostentatious fashion he would prefer, the twelfth anniversary of the signing of Frank Leahy as Notre Dame football coach slid gently past last week. It certainly doesn't seem that long and it almost comes as a shock to realize that The Master is beginning to crowd ever closer to the thirteen-year tenure of the immortal Knute Rockne, the patron saint of football beneath the Golden Dome.
Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan, whose department is the subject of Federal investigation, went on television yesterday to defend the New York police record on civil rights.

" It's all right to talk to yourself if you don't listen!" That's the philosophy of Jimmy Curran, 73year-old track coach at Mercersburg Academy. But, the chances are, he doesn't follow his own advice.

In a Washington's Birthday observance yesterday at St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Chapel, Broadway and Fulton Street, the Rev. Robert C. Hunsicker decried "the forces at work among us in present days" that, in his opinion, sought to destroy the basic liberty of thought and expression.

LA JOLLA, Calif., Feb. 22 -- Two great ocean mysteries confront scientists as a result of findings by an expedition of the Scripps Institution of Oceanography in the South Pacific, Dr. Roger Revelle, director of the institution, reported yesterday on return of the research ships Horizon and Spencer F. Baird to San Diego Harbor.

MOSCOW, Monday, Feb. 23 -The Soviet land and sea forces were ordered today to maintain the highest battle preparedness and ceaselessly stand guard over the national interests of the Soviet Union against a threat from any quarter.

Going into the lead in the second period, the Detroit Red Wings maintained the edge over the New York Rangers in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night and subdued the Broadway Blues, 2 to 1.

MANILA, Feb. 22 -- A trade promotion conference of thirty-seven members of the United Nations Economic Commission for Asia and the Far East, including the Soviet Union and some Sovietbloc countries, opened a ten-day session today to seek expansion of East-West trade.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 22 -- Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., head of the United States delegation to the United Nations, said today that indications, "at least at present," were that the Russians preferred to see the war in Korea continue.
GOOSE BAY, Labrador, Feb. 22--Three United States Air Force jet fighter planes crashed near here yesterday. A fourth is missing in Greenland. All were part of a sixteen-plane flight to Europe.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- Senator Bourke B. Hickenlooper, Republican of Iowa, called today for much stronger language in President Eisenhower's proposed resolution on World War II secret agreements. Meanwhile, three Democratic Senators, attacking Republican criticism voiced over the week-end, said they would support the President.

BOSTON, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Boston star Bob Cousy's foul shot provided the winning margin today as the Celtics scored an 87-83 overtime victory over New York in a National Basketball Association clash at the Arena.

MADRID, Feb. 22 -- The terms of the proposed United StatesSpanish bilateral military and economic agreements have been under review by the Eisenhower Administration for a month, and active negotiating will be resumed when the newly appointed United States Ambassador, James C. Dunn, takes over the Madrid post during the latter half of March, well informed United States circles said today.
Four new films will arrive at first-run theatres this week, including importations from Britain, France and Russia. The programs follow:

One of the characteristic features of contemporary society is the rapidity with which metals that were virtually laboratory curiosities in comparatively recent times have emerged as vital components of modern technology. A news item gives added evidence of this phenomenon with the report that United States production of magnesium last year increased more than 100 per cent and attained almost 106,000 tons.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -President and Mrs. Eisenhower observed the 221st anniversary of the birth of George Washington today by attending the 11 A. M. service in the small Christ Protestant Episcopal Church, of which the first President was a founder and a vestryman.

CHICAGO, Feb. 22 -- The Thor Corporation of Chicago has announced the addition of electric ranges to its appliance line through the acquisition of Leeson Steel Products Company, New Albany, Ind. Leeson, which will be operated as a wholly owned subsidiary of Thor, has been producing electric ranges under the trade name, Presteline.

Looking up from the supper table a junior member of the family observed that the sky was quite light, whereas not long ago at the same hour it had been pitch black. True, one observed sagely; spring was coming, heralded not only by the day's lengthening but also by a large flock of cedar waxwings that the other day had paused on its journey.

" Sigrid Undset," a study of the Scandinavian writer by A. H. Winsnes, a philosophy professor in Oslo, Norway, will be published on April 15 by Sheed Ward. The work, finished a few months before Sigrid Undset's death in 1949 studies her development from agnosticism to her conversion to Roman Catholicism as this is reflected in her novels.

MOSCOW, Feb. 22 -- Soviet citizens went to the polls today to name most of the country's 83,000 city and county councils, to many of which was elected the nation's first citizen, Premier Stalin. Mr. Stalin voted in the Lenin election district of Moscow, but his name headed the list of candidates for many a local council.
ORLANDO, Fla., Feb. 22 (AP)--Betty Mackinnon and Sam Snead defeated Babe Zaharias and George Bolesta, 3 and 2, today for the international mixed two-ball golf title.

Prayers for the repentance of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, the convicted atom spies who have been condemned to death, were urged upon "true Christians" by the Rev. Dr. Ralph Walker in his sermon yesterday morning in the Madison Avenue Baptist Church, at Thirty-first Street.
BOSTON, Feb. 22 -- A Californiabred Irish setter from Ohio was one of those that attracted most attention today when the fortieth show of the Eastern Dog Club began in creaky old Mechanics Building.

The mention of Marshal Vassily Sokolovsky, whose appointment as Chief of Staff of the Soviet Army is just announced, awakes rather sad memories of the early postwar period in ravaged Berlin. After General Zhukov left, Sokolovsky was the Russian member of a Four-Power Control Council that operated, more or less as a whole, in one building -- the hastily repaired People's Court -- and there was still a semblance of quadrilateral rule.

ROME, Feb. 22 -- A long step toward creation of a single unified anti-Communist labor movement was taken today when the two outstanding democratic Italian labor groups signed an agreement to collaborate against communism. This action is believed to foreshadow their complete merger soon.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Feb. 22 (AP) -Calvin MacCracken of Englewood, N. J., and Ernie Howard of Toronto eliminated the top two seeded singles entries in the forty-fifth annual United States Squash Racquets Association title tournament today. They will meet for the title tomorrow.

Stench bombs were exploded last night in two motion picture theatres in the Bronx -- the R. K. O. Fordham at Fordham Road and Valentine Avenue and the Loew's Paradise on the Grand Concourse near 188th Street. There were 2,000 customers in each house when the incidents occurred, the police reported.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 22 (UP) -- President Juan D. Peron said today that he was in Chile at the request of his "old friend," Argentine President Carlos Ibanez del Campo to try to solve the economic problems of the two nations.

The Vanderbilt Cup Tournament reached the quarter-final round last night at the Plaza Hotel, with eight surviving contract bridge teams out of a starting field of seventy-five battling for the 1953 national knockout team-of-four championship.

VIENNA, Monday, Feb. 23 -- One of the closest races in Austria's electoral history ended at 2 this morning with the Roman Catholic and conservative People's party one seat ahead of the Socialists, although it received 36,000 fewer votes.

Allan S. Haywood, executive vice president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, who died of a heart attack while addressing a union rally in Wilkes-Barre Saturday night, learned his unionism in a rugged school. When he started organizing for the United...
VERO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 22 -Edwin (Duke) Snider, who swung the most potent Dodger bat against the Yankees last fall, donned his uniform for the first time today and went through a mild workout.

The Moore-McGovern memorandum rejecting Mayor Impellitteri's $218,700,000 fiscal program for 1953-54 was viewed yesterday by the Mayor's closest financial advisers as a key move in a campaign to put pressure on the city to adopt a payroll tax or a higher fare on the municipal transit lines, or both.
For the homemaker interested in interior decoration, antiques, or making useful objects, several courses are starting soon.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 22 -- Leading foreign Socialists, with varying degrees of optimism and skepticism, told President Marshal Tito and the people of Yugoslavia today that their bid for acceptance in the democratic world through the Socialist movement was up to them and the way they chose to prove they were democratic.
MOSCOW, Sunday, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Pravda demanded today that Russians multiply their membership in the Soviet civilian defense society "Dosaaf."

Are you 5 feet 4 inches or under? If so, you will appreciate the patterns we offer you today. They are especially designed for the "smaller" woman. Actually, according to Government statistics, 72 per cent of the women in the United States are 5 feet 4 or under.

STOCKHOLM, Feb. 22 -- The anti-Zionist policy "suddenly and surprisingly" adopted by Moscow might well develop into all-out anti-Semitic persecution, in the opinion of Dr. Schmuel Elyashiv, late Israeli Minister to the Soviet Union, now in Stockholm on his way to Tel Aviv following the break in diplomatic relations.
PARIS, Feb. 20 -- Not to be overlooked in the recent Paris showings are such designers as Jacques Heim, Madeleine de Rauch and Maggy Rouff.

The New York City Youth Board, an agency established in 1948 as a part of the city's campaign against deliquency, reported yesterday a decrease of 9.5 per cent in juvenile delinquency throughout New York in the last five years.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- The Commission on the Health Needs of the Nation, established in December, 1951, by President Truman, continued today to take the middle of the road approach to the health insurance problem. The commission called for greatly increased voluntary insurance.
TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 22 -- Because of an unexpected outbreak of political controversy and intrigue Dr. Mohammed Mossadegh apparently threatened today to resign as Premier of Iran.

PARIS, Feb. 22 -- During the Franco-Italian conference at Rome, which will follow immediately upon the meeting of the six European foreign ministers, it is expected that the Italian Government will ask for a reduction of the restrictions on trade applied by France.

TOKYO, Monday, Feb. 23--A brief patrol clash on the western front in Korea early yesterday flared into a savage hand-to-hand battle against Chinese Communist forces. Allied troops in the patrol pulled back to their own lines under cover of smoke more than seven hours later.

A citizen's complaint that he had seen a man beaten in a police radio car Saturday night was referred yesterday to Inspector Stephen Kennedy, in charge of the Eighteenth Inspection Division, Brooklyn, for investigation.
The Temporary State Housing Rent Commission no longer will issue an order raising the rent ceiling on a vacant apartment on the basis of increased services or equipment.

The spirit of brotherhood was singled out last night by a panel of sex high school students as one of the fundamental tenets of the democratic way of life. At the same time, they agreed that hatred, bigotry and prejudice stemmed for the most part from unhealthy minds.

The influence of the hollow fiber-glass fly rod on the "fly fishing market" is clearly accented at Grand Central Palace this year. After searching all three floors of the exposition we found only one custom rod maker represented. In view of the overwhelming emphasis that seems to be placed on spinning, this is not very surprising.

Progressive weakness in the Canadian dollar and a strong undertone for the British pound sterling dominated the foreign exchange market during the past week. Amount of business transacted was only moderate and lacked the general activity that usually prevails.

Arthur Larsen of San Leandro, Calif., and Kurt Nielsen of Denmark will meet today in the final of the national indoor tennis championship at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.

Few men are in a better position to talk about the problems and qualifications of the career diplomat than George F. Kennan, former American Ambassador to Russia. Speaking at Princeton on Saturday, Mr. Kennan mentioned the "severe strains and tensions" to which such men are subjected.

LONDON, Feb. 22 -- The minor boom that has characterized stockmarket conditions in the past few weeks showed signs of petering out toward the close of last week. Ruling out intervening fluctuations, there has been quite a remarkable recovery in the security markets since the low points of last June.

Paced by George Athineos, center forward from the Eintracht S. C., the New York All-Star topped the Rapid F. C. of Vienna, seventeen-time winner of the Austrian title, 4 to 3, before 10,000 fans at Dexter Park, Woodhaven, yesterday.

NYASALAND, which has been in the news recently because of proposals to federate it with Northern and Southern Rhodesia, is a narrow strip of mountainous country which runs along the western shore of Lake Nyasa and for a short distance to the south of the lake. It has comparatively few white residents and has been little described by writers of travel books.

Perhaps we may be permitted, in view of the date, to set aside current considerations of the quick dinner and low-calorie salad and recall what the table arts were like in the days of George Washington.

Starting their sixty-seventh year of service, workers in the settlement movement, spread around the United States in seven hundred settlement houses, are aware of their opportunities to create a climate of understanding for removing group fears and alleviating racial tensions.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (UP) -Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democrat of New York, urged the Federal Power Commission today not to permit the New York State Power Authority to build a power project on the St. Lawrence River without including specific safeguards for consumer interests.

CHICAGO, Feb. 22 (AP) -- The Big Ten today put Michigan State College on athletic probation for a year in a move bitterly protested by officials of the conference newcomer, which last year turned out the nation's top football team.
WINTER PARK, Fla., Feb. 22 -General of the Army Omar N. Bradley declared today that the American people must restrain their impatience to solve "tormenting problems" through catchphrase terminology.

AMSTERDAM, Feb. 22 -- Holland's foreign trade displayed a remarkably good trend in January. Imports totaled 746,000,000 guilders, against 683,000,000 in December, and exports 709,000,000 guilders, against 599,000,000, so that the import cover was 95 per cent, compared with 88 per cent the month before.

Gov. Luis Munoz Marin of Puerto Rico has invited a group of officials of this city to confer with him and members of his Cabinet in Puerto Rico next week to clarify misunderstandings arising from migration and labor problems.

The Communist assumption that a changed economic order will of itself issue in a new day is "pathetically naive," the Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken, minister of the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street, said yesterday in his sermon.

BERLIN, Feb. 22 -- A truck whose driver had been shot in the heart careened over the border of the Soviet sector of Berlin last night and crashed into a liquor store in West Berlin. The driver was apparently dead before crossing the line.

The following is the text of the memorandum prepared by the staffs of Lieut. Gov. Frank C. Moore and State Controller J. Raymond McGovern on the $218,000,000 fiscal program submitted to the 1953 Legislature by Mayor Impellitteri and the Board of Estimates:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- The Defense Department today disclosed plans for 20,300 officers and enlisted men to participate in the tests March 17 of "new and improved nuclear devices" at the Atomic Energy Commission's proving ground near Las Vegas, Nev.

CHICAGO, Feb. 22 -- Evidence that government-subsidized legal services in Britain are contributing to dissolution of family life there was cited today by Robert G. Storey, president of the American Bar Association, at conferences here.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 22 -- Nine items are on the agenda of the second part of the sevenths session of the United Nations General Assembly, which convenes Tuesday. They comprise what remained of the agenda when the first part of the session recessed last Dec. 22.

JOLIET, Ill., Feb. 22 -- Over the desk of Brig. Gen. W. E. Laidlaw, who commands the vast Army Ammunition Center twenty minutes from this city, pass many of the crucial problems encountered in pushing ammunition output from slightly more than 1,000,000 rounds in the first six months of the Korean war to 30,000,000 in the last half of 1952.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 22 -Brazil's foreign exchange crisis has been eased by the $300,000,000 loan just granted by the ExportImport Bank, but the relief is temporary and the country faces a recurrent crisis unless rigid economy in imports is practiced.

ROME, Feb. 22 -- An effort to get the movement toward European unity rolling again will be made Tuesday and Wednesday when the Foreign Ministers of Italy, France, Germany, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg meet in Rome as the Council of Ministers of the European Coal and Steel Community.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 22 -- Using the controversial agrarian reform law as a lever. Guatemala's Communists are trying to turn the powerful influence they wield in the governing of that country into outright control.

" Maybe we did make a mistake," admitted Chief Judge Dan Ferris yesterday of the peculiar "process of elimination" decision whereby Seton Hall's Bob Keegan, unpicked for any place, was named the winner of the Intercollegiate 60-yard dash over Manhattan's Joe Schatzle and John O'Connell in the meet record-equaling time of 6.2 seconds at Madison Square Garden last Saturday night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- Representative John Taber, chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, announced today that seventy-five of the country's "foremost business and management experts" had been enlisted to seek avenues for economy to avert the $9,900,000,000 deficit estimated for the coming fiscal year.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., Feb. 22 -Twenty-two sailing dinghies were out today off the Larchmont Yacht Club in the second of three weekend sessions.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (UP) -- Senator John J. Williams, Republican of Delaware, declared today that the Treasury had "completely ignored" Civil Service regulations in choosing some regional tax chiefs in a reorganization of the Internal Revenue Bureau.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Feb. 22 -Middlebury retained the eastern intercollegiate skiing championship today as its athletes excelled in the final phase of the competition that moved into its third day when unfavorable conditions forced a postponement of the jumping yesterday.
Celeste Wickliffe Cheatham, interior decorator, store in 837 Madison Ave -- Albert B. Ashforth, Inc, broker.
The body of a well-to-do Mineola, L. I., business man who had been missing for six weeks was found yesterday to have been buried in a New York City pauper's grave.

ESKILSTUNA, Sweden, Feb. 22 (UP) -- The Swedish-Russian speed skating meet was declared unofficial today because of soft ice. The decision came after a conference between the oficials of both countries.

With a fine show of party unanimity and stubbornness the Republicans in the Legislature have turned back a Democratic effort to bring Permanent Personal Registration out of committee to a vote on the floor. The Assembly vote was 96 to 51 against discharge from committee, the Senate vote 34 to 18, and both on strictly party lines.
The five-story building with twenty apartments at 1759 Montgomery Avenue, the Bronx, has been purchased by Geisinger Rau, operators, from Jonathan Holoeen. The property is assessed at $62,000.
MORRISTOWN, N. J., Feb. 22 -- Two 6-year-old youngsters who had apparently been hearing tales of George Washington's youth set out with a hatchet here today in search of a tree to fell.

MANCHESTER, Vt., Feb. 22 -Forty-two members of the Mamaroneck High School Ski Club, most of whom are trying the winter sport for their first season, drove up from Westchester County to take over a couple of dormitory lodges here for a Washington's Birthday ski week-end.

The death of Allan S. Haywood, executive vice president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, created a new leadership problem for the union group yesterday, less than three months after the bitter fight over a president to succeed the late Philip Murray.

The United States Government wants to swap its old Assay Building at 30 Wall Street for office space somewhere in the city, and is advertising for bids that will be opened March 25. The trade must involve no cash from the Government, which will, however, accept cash to boot from the swapper.

An appeal that tolerance and fair play be accorded members of the bar who are engaged in the defense of unpopular causes was made here last night by Justice Jesse W. Carter of the California Supreme Court. He said it was becoming increasingly difficult for lawyers to properly defend persons accused of subversive activities.

After holding to a narrow trading range most of last week, cotton prices in the domestic market became firm on Friday and closed the week with net gains of 18 to 38 points, or 90 cents to $1.90 a bale. The near-by March and May deliveries on the New York Cotton Exchange made the best showing.

For the last three years the Bureau of Labor Statistics has been engaged in a comprehensive revision of the Consumer Price Index. This revised series will become effective between now and the end of this week. It will make its appearance in the form of the Consumer Price Index for January.

New Dance Group Presentations last night gave the first of three "festival" performances at the Ziegfield Theatre, before a large and obviously entertained audience. With a newly organized company designed to operate on a permanent basis and several guest soloists, it presented a highly miscellaneous program of the sort that usually makes up festivals.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (UP) -Senators Russell B. Long, Democrat of Louisiana, and Wayne Morse, Independent of Oregon, said today that during their investigation of overseas military bases last year they never had been able to find out why the Navy kept 3,000 men in Naples.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 22 -- Leo Durocher, outlining plans for the Giants' spring training campaign which swings into action tomorrow, opened fire today with a series of observations that could reveal a lot on what to expect of the Polo Grounds mound staff this year.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (UP) -The first Japanese national to receive an immigration visa to enter the United States as a potential citizen promised today to try to be "worthy of this great honor."

MIAMI, Feb. 22 -- Israel will not be "sold down the river" by the United States and "permitted to become another Czechoslovakia," Gov. Theodore R. McKeldin of Maryland told more than 350 Jewish leaders today at an emergency luncheon of the State of Israel Bond Organization at Miami Beach.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Feb. 22 -- A meeting of the French-Vietnamese High Military Committee, of vital import for the future of the war in Indo-China, will take place tomorrow at Dalat. At this session a decision will be taken to double the projected size of the Vietnamese Army of sixty battalions by the addition of sixty more of a lighter type.

ALBANY, Feb. 22 -- Mayor Impellitteri's $218,700,000 long-range plan for solving New York's recurrent fiscal crises was rejected as unsound today by Lieut. Gov. Frank C. Moore and State Controller J. Raymond McGovern.

New designs in mosaics, as well as an improved type of setting, have been devised for the Casavan Sarim mosaics. Made up into table tops or fireplace fenders and facings they may be ordered, through decorators, at the Scharff Trading Corporation.

Two important shows, both opening Thursday, are on this week's calendar of art attractions. For the benefit of the American Federation of Arts, Wildenstein's will hold a loan exhibition of paintings entitled "Landmarks in American Art," opening with a private view Wednesday evening.

MIAMI, Feb. 23 -- Racetrackers who had spent the red-hot morning on beaches or at swimming pools were surprised to find Hialeah's main track wet and slow when they arrived for the afternoon of winner-hunting.

DOVER, N. J., Feb. 23 -- Several pedestrians narrowly missed being struck by a runaway gondola car loaded with sixty tons of sand as it raced out of control for seven miles, passing twenty road crossings on the way, before it was derailed near here.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Feb. 23 -- A fight for freedom of press and opinion occupied the front pages of newspapers throughout the Union of South Africa today as a last-minute effort was made in Parliament to add a guarantee of such freedom to the Government's bill to amend the criminal law.

PARIS, Feb. 23 -- Ten persons, including four Roman Catholic priests and a nun, are in custody on charges of having aided in the "kidnapping" of two Jewish war orphans, Robert and Gerald Finaly, whom the police were still searching for today in northern Spain.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations said today that the United States was a "have-not nation" in oil and registered opposition to the proposal to give the states title to petroleum-rich submerged coastal lands.

A campaign against crime and corruption, to be waged as it is assumed George Washington would have carried it out, was urged yesterday upon patriotic societies of New York. They were called on to "band together against this internal aggressor which threatens our civilization."

ALBANY, Feb. 23 -- A report to the Motor Vehicle Commissioner, James R. MacDuff, disclosed today that 77,363 automobile owners' or drivers' licenses were suspended last year for failure to meet the requirements of the safety responsibility law.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Feb. 23 -- The United States Government has approved in principle a proposal by Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Supreme Allied Commander, to shift its European Command headquarters. headed by Gen. Thomas T. Handy, from Frankfurt, Germany, to the Paris area. Financial studies in connection with the move of the tri-service headquarters are being worked out.

The world's largest corporate enterprise, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, owned by more than 1,220,000 shareholders, reported yesterday a record consolidated net income of $406,661,306 for 1952. This was equal to $11.45 a share on A. T. T.'s outstanding capital stock, and compared with a net of $364,874,176, or $11.76 a share on fewer shares outstanding, in 1951.

LONDON, Feb. 23 -- Britain granted amnesty today to 14,260 wartime deserters from the armed forces Prime Minister Churchill announced in the House of Commons the Government's decision that there would be no further prosecutions of those who deserted between Sept. 3, 1939 and Aug. 15, 1945.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Feb. 23 -- Forecasts in the recent annual message of Herbert C. Gerlach, County Executive of Westchester, that the state would have a record $100,000,000 worth of highway construction under contract in the county this year are rapidly approaching fulfillment.

PERTH AMBOY, N. J., Feb. 23 -- A method of fashioning metal in a steady flow of forms and shapes, ready for fabrication, was opened for inspection today at the plant here of the American Smelting and Refining Company It is to be shown to metal trade representatives in the next few weeks.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Feb. 23 -- World tin ore production last year reached a post-war peak of 172,500 tons while metal output held steady at 167,400 tons. Consumption was lower than in the previous year at 128,000 tons, according to the International Tin Study Group.

On Feb. 24 Estonians all over the world, except in their home country, will commemorate the thirty-fifth anniversary of their republic. Independence was pronounced-during the Russian Revolution after communism came to power and was successfully defended in the War of Liberation in 1918-20 against communism.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Robert L. Johnson of Philadelphia, president of Temple University, today was asked by John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, to head the International Information Administration.
The young actor who started out to be a villain in the theatre sixty years ago will celebrate his seventy-sixth birthday today as the gentle star of "On Borrowed Time." His name is Victor Moore.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 23 -- Francis Bosworth, executive director of the Friends Neighborhood Guild, a settlement house at Fourth and Green Streets here, was presented with the annual $10,000 Philadelphia Award tonight.
The two-year draft term and the short rotation period in Korea have reduced seriously the combat effectiveness of the Army.

Arthur Larsen saved the men's national indoor tennis championship from going abroad yesterday after Mrs. Thelma Long of Australia had won the women's title, the first player from overseas to do so since the triumph of Mme. Sylvia Henrotin of France in 1937.

A 73-year-old retired shirt factory foreman was booked for homicide last night on charges that he had killed his 68-year-old wife with an ice pick in their Bronx apartment at 274 East 166th Street. The husband, Abraham Sperber, was taken to the prison ward of Bellevue Hospital, where he was treated for shock.
ALBANY, Feb. 23 -- A bill designed to require some cities outside New York, notably Yonkers, to raise the salaries paid to teachers, firemen and policemen has been introduced in the Legislature.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 23 -- The United Nations General Assembly will start the second part of its 1952 session tomorrow afternoon amid indications that another discussion of Korea, the most important item on its agenda, will not bring any sensational proposals by the United States.

A record $151,000,000 was spent last year by the Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation for new construction, bringing gross plant investment for the first time to more than a billion dollars, the company disclosed yesterday in its annual report to stockholders.

In a move to consolidate its present four separate general and executive offices in this city, the National Association of Manufacturers has leased four floors in the twin office structures scheduled for completion by the end of this year at 579 and 599 Fifth Avenue.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democrat of New York, today denounced the McCarran Immigration Act as a despotic law that could "corrode the fibre of all our rights and liberties."

An ex-secretary, who thought she had worked out a flawless scheme to see the best shows in town at her former employer's expense, spent last night in an uncomfortable police station cell instead of in her plush orchestra reservations for a hit Broadway musical.

BERLIN, Feb. 23 -- The East Berlin press conceded today that the People's Police on the border between East and West Berlin fired directly into the cab of a truck attempting to flee across the line Saturday night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- President Eisenhower will send to the Senate shortly the nominations of Charles E. Bohlen to be Ambassador to the Soviet Union and Francis White to be Ambassador to Mexico, the White House announced today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Ohio was warned today not to try to elbow its way into the union ahead of Hawaii and Alaska.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Feb. 23 -- The Cabinet of the Chinese Nationalist Government decided tonight to repudiate the Chinese-Soviet Treaty of Friendship and Alliance of 1945. Under this treaty Nationalist China acquiesced in concessions made to the Soviet Union in the Yalta agreement between the United States, Britain and Russia.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture is considering an emergency beef purchase plan for the school lunch program and is trying to develop more foreign outlets for United States farm commodities, it was disclosed today.

When the financial markets of the country reopen for business this morning following the long holiday week-end it will be with minimum margins on stock transactions back once more at the pre-Korean level. This means that the purchaser or short-seller of stock need put up only 50 per cent of the price in cash, as against the minimum of 75 per cent that has been the prevailing rate since Jan. 17, 1951.

The results of Sunday's parliamentary election in Austria are now in, and highly satisfactory results they are, so far as the free world is concerned. The neo-Nazis on the Right and the Communists on the Left both lost seats instead of gaining, as they had expected.

Ten policemen, including a deputy inspector, who shot it out with armed thugs, were cited yesterday for honorable mention in general orders issued by Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan. They were among 306 members of the force to receive recognition for meritorious service in all cases acted upon by the department's honor committee since last Oct. 20.
HONG KONG, Feb. 23 -- With the United Nations General Assembly about to meet again, the Peiping radio focused its propaganda spotlight today on Communist China's alliance with the Soviet Union.

Twenty-one bills that would amend the city building code to permit construction of new legitimate playhouses within office buildings or apartment houses may be adopted within the next five weeks, Councilman Hugh Quinn of Queens announced yesterday.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 23 -- The market women of Guatemala City, poor but spunky vendors of fruits, vegetables and oddments from dawn to dusk, form the most courageous and determined opposition to Guatemala's Communists.

The head of two of the city's biggest privately owned bus companies promised his support yesterday Mayor Impellitteri's plan for setting up tax-exempt, limited dividend corporations to operate buses under private auspices without a higher fare.

Grant Johannesen demonstrated his versatility last night at Carnegie Hall. As soloist at the National Orchestral Association's third concert of the season, he gave excellent performances in two radically different piano concertos.

ROME, Feb. 23 -- The problems of the Saar and of the protocols that France wishes to add to the European Defense Community treaty moved to the center of the stage today as the foreign ministers of six European nations prepared to meet here tomorrow. The nations represented belong to the European Coal and Steel Community and to the proposed European Defense Community.

ALBANY, Feb. 23 (AP) -- The Senate tonight unanimously and without debate approved transfer to the State Harness Racing Commission of control over the sport now held by the United States Trotting Association.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP) -- A new drive to win Senate approval of legislative measures to authorize the St. Lawrence Seaway and power project was set in motion, today by Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican of Wisconsin.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Douglas McKay, Secretary of the Interior, told a House of Representatives subcommittee today that the Territory of Hawaii was fully prepared for statehood, and should be granted that status immediately.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Diplomatic officials in Washington regarded Chiang Kai-shek's repudiation today of the 1945 Nationalist Chinese-Soviet treaty as an act largely for the purposes of the record.

RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 23 (AP) -- A 35-year-old factory worker had an excellent chance to live a normal life today following a rare operation in which a main artery was mended with a part of a dead man's heart.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 23 -- Yugoslavia offered today to join the system of collective security against the aggressive aims of the Soviet Union, on condition that by joining she would not commit herself to any political goals.

Asserting that it was imperative for the state to take a more vigorous interest in the city's slum clearance and housing problems, Robert F. Wagner Jr., Borough President of Manhattan, called yesterday for the enactment of three measures designed to help relieve "the continuing housing crises" here.

Joseph Friedman has been elected first vice president of the United States I-Ioffman l[achinery Corporation, and John D. Schapiro was elected a 'director, George Bowdoin, president, announced yesterday. Mr. Schapiro is vice president and treasurer of the Boston Metals Corporation of Baltimore land president of the Maryland State Fair, Inc., which owns the Laurel Race Course. 1Vir. Friedman has beel% with the company since 1939.

There is nothing startling in Nationalist China's denunciation of the Sino-Soviet treaty of 1945. The action could have been taken long ago with complete propriety. A resolution adopted by the General Assembly of the United Nations declared long since that the Soviet Union had not lived up to the terms of the treaty.

TOYKO, Tuesday, Feb. 24 -- Out-numbered United Nations troops defending an outpost on the western front in Korea beat off a determined assault by an estimated total of seventy-five to 100 Chinese last night and early this morning.

SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, Feb. 24 -- It will be announced this week that the United States has agreed to pay the Korean Government between eighty and ninety million dollars to clear up a debt incurred through advances of Korean currency to the United States forces here.

MOSCOW, Feb. 23 -- Pravda warned today that the existence of United States bases in Britain and France threatened the national security of those countries and that their Prime Ministers might awaken some morning and find that their lands had been drawn into war.

The American Broadcasting ComJ pany will use a new emblem for purposes Of identification on television, starting March 1. Instead of the map of the United States, I which it nov; employs, the netvvorki will project on the screen an American eagle.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (UP) -- The Government announced today it would abandon controls on civilian use of steel, copper and aluminum after June 30.

WINTER PARK, Fla., Feb. 23 -- Lester B. Pearson, President of the United Nations General Assembly, warned today that "irresponsible action or talk which might divide the free countries in these days of crises would be folly."
LARCHMONT, N. Y., Feb. 23 -- Taking his third straight dinghy regatta today at the Larchmont Yacht Club, Arthur Knapp, with his craft, Agony, won the top prize for the holiday racing.

The Olding Realty Company has purchased for investment the nine-story and penthouse apartment building on plot 75 by 100 feet at 122 East Eighty-second Street in a deal negotiated by Rossbach Associates Inc., brokers. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

" A minor commodity in the vegetable market" is how our outpost in the local office of the Department of Agriculture describes corn-salad, also known as field salad, land cress, upland cress, lamb's-lettuce and fetticus. Receipts in a recent year amounted to only three carloads, he said, whereas those of iceberg lettuce totaled 9.881.

Eleven Boy Scouts who rescued a whimpering raccoon from a heavy-spring trap at Alpine, N. Y., yesterday morning and applied first aid to its badly wounded paw apparently performed such a splendid nursing job that their patient regained enough strength later in the day to resist hospitalization in Manhattan.
GENEVA, Feb. 23 -- The recent initiative of the Netherlands for reducing trade barriers among the countries of Western Europe is assured strong, though so far tacit.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Dr. Alfonso Cardoso de Alencastro, Brazilian Ambassador to Mexico, announced a new shipping line soon will connect Tampico and Veracruz with Rio de Janeiro to increase commerce between the two nations.

Nicolas Rivera has come from the green isle of Puerto Rico to the stone piles of Harlem and the Bronx. He came ten days ago by four-motored aircoach, the modern Mayflower that will be used by most of the 50,000 migrants coming here this year, an expected decline from last year's record 59,103.
Half the field for the sixteenth annual national invitation college basketball tournament, which starts at Madison Square Garden on March 7, was completed yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 23 -- The Navy will be invited by Twentieth Century-Fox to participate in the filming of a big-scale action picture to be shot in the studio's new wide-screen process known as CinemaScope.

How exotic forms and native techniques can effectively be adapted for use in the American home is demonstrated in a small but interesting exhibition now on view at Georg Jensen. The collection of wood, rattan and basketry objects made in the far-off Philippines was specifically geared to satisfy tastes and needs in this country while retaining an Island flavor.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Senators Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, and Harry F. Byrd, Democrat of Virginia, were honored tonight by the American Good Government Society for their "independence of mind, courage of conviction and fidelity to public duty."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 23 -- James J. Wadsworth, new Deputy United States Representative in the United Nations, was sworn in this afternoon at the headquarters of the United States delegation at 2 Park Avenue, in the presence of Mrs. Wadsworth and Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., chief of the United States delegation.

ALBANY, Feb. 23 -- Legislation to implement the Jones Beach State Parkway Authority plan to finance reconstruction and extension of the Southern State Parkway by a 10-cent toll may be opposed by the Federal Government, it became known today.

CHICAGO Feb 23 (AP) -- Livestock supplies were reduced to fit the semi-holiday nature of the market today and all divisions were steady to 50 cents higher Department of Agriculture reports of livestock trading
United States Attorney Myles J. Lane denied last night allegations that members of his staff possibly had links with underworld characters and defended the record of his office.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The resumption in New York tomorrow of the United Nations General Assembly's session will give Secretary of State John Foster Dulles an opportunity to meet his old antagonist, Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky of the Soviet Union, on terms somewhat different from those in the past.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas, Democratic leader, warned Republicans tonight that they would risk a major foreign policy fight if they tried to harden a resolution on the war-time Yalta and Potsdam agreements recommended to Congress by President Eisenhower.

A new series of four-year scholarships providing annual grants ranging from $200 to $2,000 will be awarded for the next scholastic year to students in the fields of engineering and science, the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation announced yesterday.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 23 -- Amid the usual Leo Durocher fanfare and under a cloudless desert sky, the Giants today got their 1953 training campaign off with a grand splurge and at least one spectacular performance that augurs well for the Polo Grounders' pennant prospects.

It is clear from the dispatches which our correspondent Sydney Gruson has sent about Guatemala that the country is going through a critical period. The agrarian reform, which is now being put into effect, is giving the Communists a better opportunity to win friends and influence the masses than any previous development.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Harold E. Talbott, Secretary of the Air Force, informed Congress today that Arthur Godfrey's recent inspection tour of Air Force bases in Europe did not cost the taxpayers a cent.
One thing about this country of ours -- and not to be chauvinistic about it, one thing about a lot of other countries -- is that the people like many different things. Take dogs, for example.

LONDON, Feb. 23 -- A hint that negotiations with Egypt over the future of British troops in the Suez Canal zone may begin soon was seen today in the sudden and unexpected cancellation of Field Marshal Sir William Slim's plans to depart immediately to assume his duties as Governor General of Australia.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 23 (UP) -- The Brazilian cruzeiro, unpegged today for the first time since before the war, promptly plunged from its official worth of 5.44 United States cents to values around 2.6 cents.

WHEN an old man dies an empty space is made in the lives of those who knew and loved him that memories cannot fill. But the urge to remember is almost compulsive and the past is never nearer or more poignant than when emotions are stirred by death. It is out of such memories that Ovid Williams Pierce has woven his sad, tender and occasionally elusive first novel, "The Plantation."*

The proposed Customs simplification bill should provide for continued determination by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York of foreign currency values for computing import-duty valuations in dollars, it was recommended over the week-end by the International Trade Section of the New York Board of Trade.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Feb. 23 (AP) -- Michigan State College today revealed the names of ten football players who received aid from the Spartan Foundation -- the basis of a year's probation imposed on M. S. C. by the Big Ten conference yesterday.
" Tristan und Isolde," absent one season, returned to the Metropolitan Opera House last night and brought with it a new Isolde.
SPORTSMEN'S SHOW highlights:

VIENNA, Feb. 23 -- Following yesterday's elections, which resulted in victory for the People's party by a margin of one seat in Parliament, its leaders and those of the Socialist party, which it just nosed out, began discussions intended to lead toward the building of a new coalition government.

Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan has held three conferences in the last three months with local Department of Justice officials regarding a Federal investigation of the reported beating of two Negroes recently in the West Fifty-fourth Street police station.

Washington's Birthday was a happy one for New Yorkers in their warm and sunny city, and equally delightful for the country cousins in the suburbs. One and all wished for many more returns of the same.

PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 23 -- Taking the lead half way through the second quarter, Harvard's basketball team led the rest of the way to defeat Princeton, 71 -- 49, tonight in an Eastern Intercollegiate League contest.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The White House asked the Senate Appropriations Committee today to reinstate funds, knocked out with Administration approval in the House of Representatives last week, that would permit the President's Council of Economic Advisers to operate until July 1.

A house containing five apartments and store and occupying a lot 20 by 100 feet at 515 Christopher Avenue, Brooklyn, was sold by John Di Maria to the A. C. R. Realty Corporation, which insured title with the Security Title and Guaranty Company.

Anthony DiBiase, a Stuyvesant High School student fighting unattached, knocked out Howard Speller of the Salem Crescent A. C. in one of the top bouts on the twenty-seventh annual Golden Gloves program at Madison Square Garden last night.

New York City has been the port for many a shipload of immigrants, each of which has contributed its part to the richness and variety of the community. Immigrants used to come by sea and pass through Ellis Island. Now, as Peter Kihss explains in our columns today in the second of a series of articles, the most numerous of them come by air and technically they are not immigrants.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 23 -- Even the skies frowned today as the Yankee training campaign got under way in an atmosphere of discontent and without benefit of Casey Stengel's guiding hand.

Packaging experts are urging manufacturers to cater to the preference of children in designing the cover surrounding their product. The argument goes this way: Supermarket or self-servicing plays a big part in the sales of merchandise.

" Phenomenal" holiday business was reported in movie theatres in the Broadway area yesterday, with the pace being set at the Roxy, where thousands of persons stood in line to get into the 6,000-seat theatre to see Walt Disney's "Peter Pan."

VERO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 23 -- With Russ Meyer a Dodger and two of last year's "lame ducks" -- Ralph Branca and Clem Labine -- apparently flying high, pitching has ceased to be a No. 1 problem for Manager Chuck Dressen.

TUXEDO PARK, N. Y., Feb. 23 -- Geoffrey W. T. Atkins, 24-year-old British racquets champion, defeated Robert Grant 3d of New York, the United States champion, in the final of the annual Tuxedo Gold Racquet Tourney today. Before the largest gallery ever assembled in the Tuxedo Racquet and Tennis Club, the Briton won, 15 -- 3, 15 -- 12, 11 -- 15, 15 -- 8.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP) -- The nation's capital celebrated George Washington's birthday today with sales of everything from 99-cent automobiles to five-cent shoes. It's an annual fling here and almost every store in town feature sales on the birthday of Washington, himself a canny bargain hunter.
LONDON, Feb. 23 -- British industrials and South African gold mining issues led a fairly general although modest advance on the stock markets here today.

With more than 600 bodies awaiting burial, the State Mediation Board will make a new effort this morning to settle the seven-week-old strike of 200 gravediggers at ten cemeteries in the metropolitan area.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23 -- Adlai E. Stevenson told the Decalogue Society of Lawyers at their eighteenth annual patriotic dinner here tonight that the Soviet Union's persecution of Jews did not arise from feelings of insecurity but rather from its interests in the oil-rich lands of the predominantly Arab Middle East.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Feb. 23 (AP) -- Arthur Tyler and Ed Seymour of Rochester, N. Y., set a course record, then broke it minutes later, as they flashed down the Mount Van Hoevenburg run today to win the North American two-man bobsled championship.

TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 23 -- After a day of strenuous peacemaking in Teheran, it appeared tonight that good relations might be restored between Premier Mohammed Mossadegh and the imperial court and a Government crisis averted.

All but four of the 1,253-man crew of the Cunard liner Queen Mary were cleared for shore leave yesterday in a few hours as emigration officers conducted the first in-port examination of the vessel's personnel since the McCarran-Walter Immigration Act became effective Dec. 24.

In an editorial on Feb. 11 THE TIMES comments on the serious problems of finance for institutions of higher learning and in particular of recent increases in tuition. All those interested in the democratization of higher education are indeed vexed by the continued rise in tuition, although the rise to date is probably less than the average rise of capacity to pay since 1939.
CHICAGO, Feb. 23 -- The Jewel Tea Company reported today its retail sales rose to a new high in the fiscal year ended Jan. 3 for the ninth consecutive year, but that net income declined.

An American woman archaeologist's story of life on an expedition in the Kurdish hills of Iraq will be published on March 16 by Henry Schuman, entitled "Digging Beyond the Tigris." The author is Linda Braidwood, who describes the adventure from its planning stage in the University of Chicago's Oriental Institute to the field work north of Baghdad.

PLATTSBURG, N. Y., Feb. 23 (UP) -- The Secretary of the Air Force, Harold Talbott, inspected the site of a proposed large bomber base here today and left little hope that the project might be transferred to Camp Drum.

MANILA, Feb. 23 -- The international conference on trade promotion settled today into soberly optimistic consideration of means to increase Asia's trade with the rest of the world after halting the Russian delegation's move to include Communist China in its deliberations.
The contest for the 1953 contract bridge knockout team-of-four national championship, symbolized by the Vanderbilt Cup, was reduced to two teams late last night.

CAIRO, Feb. 23 -- Lieut. Col. Gamal Abdel Nasser, second-ranking member of the Army Council of Revolution, after Premier Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib, declared today that if the British forces did not evacuate the Suez Canel zone immediately and unconditionally they would have to "fight for their lives."

TOKYO, Tuesday, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Gen. Mark W. Clark, in a blistering and extraordinary statement, attacked today Communist China's renewed radio accusations of Allied germ warfare and expressed deepest sympathy for two captive Marine airmen the Reds said had confessed to dropping germ bombs on North Korea.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23 -- Shopping and retailing are undergoing a revolution, Emanuel Katz, New York City paper manufacturer, said today at a management seminar for executives in paper distribution at the University of Chicago.
The name of Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Democrat of Manhattan, was added yesterday to the growing list of persons willing to seek the office of Mayor.

BRATTLEBORO, Vt., Feb. 23 -- Jon Riisnaes, Norway's latest contribution to American ski jumping, today came within a foot of the Brattleboro Outing Club hill record on his first flight of 238 feet in capturing the thirty first annual Winged Foot Trophy event.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Feb. 24 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,535 for the twenty-four hours ended at 6 A. M. Tuesday, Korean time:

LONDON, Feb. 23 -- Estimates for Britain's civilian expenditures for the fiscal year 1953-54 issued today show a reduction from the present budget that will outweigh the increase in defense expenditures for 1953-54.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 23 (AP) -- Reighs Bull won the $25,000 Washington's Birthday Handicap at Santa Anita today, traveling the seven furlongs in 1:22 4/5 after the track had been drenched by rains.

New York City's tax, transit and state aid package is rejected by the state administration on the grounds that it "violates principles of sound public finance" and that the state has a responsibility based partly on self-interest to see that the greatest city in the world does not "tax itself into economic paralysis."

Leaders of the major United States airlines have predicted that passenger traffic volume this year will top the record highs of 1952 on both domestic and international routes. A parallel exists in the shipping industry, in which advance bookings indicate that a record number of tourists, business men and students will travel by surface vessel to and from points overseas.

Three hundred Boy Scouts who had received scouting religious awards last year were guests yesterday at a luncheon arranged by the Grand Street Boys Association at its clubhouse, 106 West Fifty-fifth Street.

The experience of arriving in a strange country without the company of close relatives proved so overwhelming to little Karin L. Webster yesterday that all the blond, German-born girl could do was to hang on silently to her rag doll and giant toy balloon.

THE professional football folks discovered it first and the baseball people are finally beginning to agree with them. The day has passed when cities could have two teams competing for the same patronage and the trend calls for the moving of one club elsewhere. The major leagues have become so aware of the inevitability of this step that they've already relaxed the restrictions on franchise transfers with the chain reactions such shifts entail.

Patent leather is appearing in many shapes this spring. Nothing is blacker than black patent leather. There is no tinge of gray or blue in its luster, which brings out depth and interest in other colors when shown in contrast with them.

BOSTON, Feb. 23 -- The stature of Bernice Ashdown's Samoyed, Ch. Silver Spray of Wychwood, already high, grew considerably tonight when the 2 1/2-year-old dog from North Hills, L. I., became best in show in the fortieth event of the Eastern Dog Club.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 23 -- The tremendous job facing modern educators is to convince parents that it is necessary to keep schools for their children as up to date as their kitchens and automobiles, Morris Krugman, an assistant superintendent of New York schools, told delegates to the American Orthopsychiatric Association today.

Women headed by Mrs. Newbold L. Herrick, and including Mrs. Thomas W. Dewart and Mrs. Langdon S. Simons Jr., are active in furthering the sale of tickets for the performance of Stephen Vincent Benet's "John Brown's Body" tonight at the Century Theatre for the benefit of the seventy-fifth anniversary fund campaign of the Masters School in Dobbs Ferry, N. Y.

CAIRO, Feb. 23 (Reuters) -- Egypt and the United States have signed an agreement providing for a joint survey of Egypt's industrial potentialities to be carried out under the United States Point Four program of aid to underdeveloped nations, it was announced tonight.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Feb. 23 (AP) -- Capt. Michael P. Mandarino, 30 years old, of Philadelphia, stationed with the Air Force Medical Corps at Sampson Base, today sought his release from military service through a writ of habeus corpus filed in Federal court.

DELAWARE, Ohio, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, the Majority Leader of the Senate, declared today that the Eisenhower Administration was on its way toward "cleaning up the mess in Washington."

The leader in each division of the National Basketball Association will oppose each other in the feature game of a double-header at Madison Square Garden tonight. The New York Knickerbockers will tangle with the champion Minneapolis Lakers, following a 7:30 meeting between the Syracuse Nationals and the Philadelphia Warriors.

A collection of couture designs from France, Spain and Italy, adapted in patterns by McCalls and executed in the latest Cohama fabrics, was previewed by the press yesterday at B. Altman. Fashion shows for the public will be tomorrow and Friday at 3 P. M. on the fifth floor of the store.

ALBANY, Feb. 23 -- Governor Dewey's political advisers were reported agreed tonight on the inclusion in the new residential rent control law of a provision making all tenants subject to a 15 per cent increase unless their rents had been raised by that amount since 1947.

ZURICH, Feb. 23 -- Published almost simultaneously last week, balance sheets for the 1952 annual reports of three leading Swiss credit institutes, Swiss Bank Corporation, Credit Suisse and Union Bank of Switzerland, show that net profits reached levels unknown since before the great depression as following figures indicate:

Who is going to be given the responsibility for the security of the Department of State and how will he be selected? Congress has repeatedly indicated that they consider this matter of primary importance. The American voter has indicated that he feels that every effort should be made to insure the loyalty and security of employes of the Foreign Service and the State Department.

ATLANTA, Feb. 23 -- Patients worry needlessly when they become concerned about "telling secrets" while under the influence of an anesthetic, Dr. Henry K. Beecher, anesthetist in chief of the Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston, said here today.

The Equitable Life Assurance Society increased its assets by $476,800,000 during 1952 to $6,571,700,000 at the end of the year and attained record highs of $8,812,800,000 for ordinary life insurance in force and $10,224,300,000 for group life.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- A large number of Democrats, including Mr. Truman, Adlai E. Stevenson, Dean G. Acheson and Averell Harriman, should not be begrudged any amount of merriment they may feel over the bewildered irritation of a number of Republicans in Congress after reading the text of the Administration's proposed resolution on "secret" foreign policy agreements.

ALBANY, Feb. 23 -- Republican members of the Senate were told tonight at a secret party conference that a 2-cent increase in the gasoline tax was under consideration with the understanding that the entire proceeds, estimated at $50,000,000 a year, would be used for highway and parkway construction.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 23 -- President Carlos Ibanez del Campo declared today that the purpose of President Juan D. Peron's visit to Chile was to accomplish "without delay an open and objective integration of the Chilean and Argentine economies."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The Labor Department's new fifteen-member advisory committee signaled its independence today by organizing on a different basis from the one suggested by Martin P. Durkin, Secretary of Labor.

When the General Assembly of the United Nations reconvenes today for the second part of its present session it will provide a world-wide stage for an inevitable first diplomatic skirmish between the Eisenhower Administration and the Soviet bloc. It is inevitable also that this first skirmish should take place over an issue comprising the most pressing business now before both the United Nations and the United States -- namely, the Korean war.

Johnny Bratton, 152 1/2. Chicago came back from a near knockout to flatten Tuzo Portuguez, 161, Costa Rica, in 2:46 of the fifth of their listed ten-rounder at the Eastern Parkway Arena in Brooklyn before 1,800 fans last night.

Chinese Nationalist forces, "ashamed" of the debacle that forced them to retire to Formosa, will give a good account of themselves in future fighting for the recovery of the mainland from the Communists, Maj. Gen. Chiang Wei-kuo, 36-year-old son of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, said here yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 23 -- Yale University has received $14,500,000 in gifts and grants since last July 1, Dr. A. Whitney Griswold, president of the university, announced today before 1,200 persons at an Alumni Day celebration. The largest grant was $6,000,000 to establish a national fund for research in psychiatry.

RANGOON, Burma, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Reliable informants said today Chinese Nationalist guerrillas were attacking the Burmese frontier town of Namhkam, where Dr. Gordon Seagrave, "Burma Surgeon," operates his jungle hospital.

Robert Backus of the New York A. C. tossed the 35-pound weight 60 feet 11 1/4 inches for an unofficial world record at the senior Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union field event program conducted on Columbia's South Field yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (UP) -- A jury of eight men and four women was selected today to weigh perjury charges against Dr. Joseph W. Weinberg, the "Scientist X" accused of giving atomic bomb secrets to Communist agents.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Paul M. Herzog, chairman of the National Labor Relations Board told the House of Representatives Education and Labor Committee today that after five and one-half years experience, the board had concluded that the non-Communist affidavit provision of the Taft-Hartley law had outlived its usefulness.

Pan American World Airways announced yesterday that "we are planning to go ahead on our own" in reducing by 45 per cent the rates for bulk air cargo on the North Atlantic route if other trans-Atlantic operators are unable to reach agreement on a program for lower rates.

Rosalind Russell, who appeared in two Broadway shows and then went on to earn Hollywood fame, is returning to the New York stage twenty-two years later as the star of "Wonderful Town," which opens at 8 o'clock this evening at the Winter Garden.

CHICAGO, Feb. 24 -- How Pierre S. du Pont, as president of General Motors Corporation thirty years ago, sought an exclusive purchasing arrangement with E. I. du Pont de Memours Co. for a new-type paint and was turned down by his brother Irenee was told today as the defense pressed its case at the du Pont anti-trust trial.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 24 -- An announcement today by Lester B. Pearson of Canada, President of the General Assembly, that the Convention on the Political Rights of Women would be opened for signature at the end of the current session focused attention of the uncertainties that, as a result of the change in administrations in Washington, have developed in the United States delegation's attitude toward the matter.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- D. Mallory Stephens, chairman of the Temporary State Commission on Rents and Rental Conditions, declared today that the group had reached "no decision" on a new control law and was still "assessing and reevaluating" the information before it.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- Following is the text of the majority report filed today by the Temporary State Commission on the Use of Television for Educational Purposes, and a statement issued by two of the five dissenters -- Senator Francis J. Mahoney, Minority Leader of the Senate, and Assemblyman. Eugene F. Bannigan, Minority Leader of the lower house. A complete minority report will be filed in a few days.

RALEIGH, N. C., Feb. 24 (AP) -- North Carolina State's Wolfpack defeated highly ranked Fordham, 73 -- 70, tonight in an overtime basketball thriller that saw the lead change hands twelve times, including nine in the last period. The regulation game ended with the count 61-all.

TRENTON, Feb. 24 -- The New Jersey Supreme Court today denied a writ of habeas corpus sought by a couple to regain custody of their child, whom they had legally placed for adoption two and one-half years ago. In a split decision, the state's highest tribunal reversed a decision of the Superior Court and awarded the child, who will be 4 years old next month, to her foster parents.
