UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 24 -- President Eisenhower, in a message extending greetings to the delegates to the seventh, or 1952, session of the United Nations General Assembly, declared today that "the world will watch your deliberations with deep interest and high hopes."

TOKYO, Wednesday, Feb. 25 -- The Peiping radio broadcast new charges today that the United Nations used germ warfare in Korea. The broadcast ignored a statement by the United Nations commander, Gen. Mark W. Clark, yesterday branding the accusations "fantastic and utterly false."

BRISTOL, Tenn., Feb. 24 -- Gordon Clapp and G. O. Wessenauer -- top Tennessee Valley Authority officials -- were seriously injured tonight when a twin-engined T. V. A. plane crashed two miles short of the Tri-Cities Airport near here.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Feb. 25 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,536, for the twenty-four hours ended at 6 A. M., Wednesday, Korean time:

Joseph D. Nunan, former Commissioner of Internal Revenue, was indicted yesterday by a Brooklyn Federal grand jury on a perjury charge. It was the same jury that on Dec. 2 had named Mr. Nunan in an indictment charging income tax evasion.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- A threat to take over tthe sites of three race tracks in New York City for housing developments that would be more profitable to the city was made in the Legislature today as both houses beat down Democratic motions to pry from committees bills restoring the city's 5 per cent tax on pari-mutuel betting pools.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- The Temporary State Commission on the Use of Television for Educational Purposes decided today by a 10-to-5 vote that there was no justification at this time for spending state funds to build and operate a chain of ten educational ultra-high-frequency television stations.

TRENTON, Feb. 24 -- State Senator J. Richard Kafes of Mercer County was indicted here today by a Federal grand jury for income tax evasion. The jury charged the legislator with failure to pay $80,163 due over a five-year period and with failure to file tax reports during two of those years.

Representative Jacob K. Javits, who has expressed a willingness to run for Mayor, said last night that "very considerable" assistance in the solution of municipal problems could be obtained by close cooperation with the Federal Government.

WEST HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 24 -- Lord Taylor, reaching out 110 miles beyond the New York metropolitan area, held a preview here today of its newest and largest branch store. The unit, located at North Main and Albany Streets, will open for business tomorrow morning.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Administration spokesmen, reporting to Congress at two closed committee meetings, raised serious doubt today over the prospect of balancing the Federal budget for the new fiscal year starting next July 1.

" James I," the first American edition of a biographical study by Charles Williams, will be published March 16 by Roy. Originally published in England in 1934, the work presents a life of the son of Mary, Queen of Scots, who became King of England at the death of Elizabeth I.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Feb. 24 -- Policemen aided by bloodhounds were trying today to discover who damaged Thunderjet pursuit planes stationed at Karup, the big North Atlantic Treaty Organization airbase on Jutland, last night.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Feb. 24 -- Five high-ranking generals of the Chinese Nationalist Army visited the United States Military Academy today on the first leg of a twenty-three day tour of United States military installation and training centers.
An advance toward the fully automatic processing plant of the future was demonstrated yesterday by the Perkin-Elmer Corporation, manufacturer of analytical infra-red equipment.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 24 -- The board of directors of Robin Hood Dell today eliminated the box office at this summer's twenty-one concerts in the Dell's picturesque National Amphitheatre in Fairmount Park.

The electric range, section of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association and the Edison Electric Institute will join forces during April and May to promote the sale of electric ranges, Manufacturers, electric light and power companies, distributors and dealers may participate.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Feb. 24 -- Nationalist China's Legislative Yuan (Congress) unanimously decided today to scrap the Chinese-Soviet Treaty of Friendship and Alliance of 1945, reserving the right to demand indemnities from the Soviet Union.
ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- The State Tax Commission today authorized employers to refund the newly reenacted 10 per cent reduction in state income tax to nonresident employes whose state taxes were withheld.

Orlon fiber, one of the new chemical textile products of E. I. duPont de Nemours Co., Inc., will enjoy its first fullfledged season in the fall of 1953. Forty of the country's leading textile mills are weaving fabrics containing Orlon filament and staple yarn and 120 clothing manufacturers will soon begin nation-wide distribution of men's and boys' fall suits and slacks containing the fiber.

The so-called voluntary surrender of two top underground leaders in Communist Poland last December was "unquestionably animated by America's announced intention of following a policy of liberation of the East European countries," an exiled member of the pre-Communist Polish parliament and chief of the nation's resistance movement during the Hitler occupation, asserted here yesterday.

You are to be complimented for your timely editorial of Feb. 20 entitled "TV for Education." Your very cogent remarks with reference to the need for educational television are indeed appreciated by the many colleges, universities and civic groups who have expressed concern and vital interest at the public hearing held by the Temporary Commission on the Use of Television for Educational Purposes.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 24 -- Allie Reynolds, Mickey Mantle, Hank Bauer and Joe Collins accepted Yankee contracts today, removing four names from the list of the dozen players who had not yet signed when training opened yesterday.
CHICAGO, Feb. 24 -- Ilmari Tapiovaara of Finland, one of Europe's leading furniture designers, believes that furniture terrorizes our lives and that chairs are part of that conspiracy.

An effort should be made within the schools to educate teen-agers about legal requirements governing baby sitters, an advisory committee on child employment set up within the Board of Education's bureau of attendance will recommend to the superintendent of schools.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The White House announced today that President Eisenhower would leave Washington Thursday afternoon on his plane, the Columbine, for a golf-playing holiday at Augusta, Ga. He will return to Washington on Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) -- An Agriculture Department official who incurred the displeasure of :dairy area Congressmen wqtha speech last fall is out as director of the Office of'Foreign Agriculitural .relations. He is James J; Haggerty who vas appointed to the post last May by the then Secretary of Agriculture, Charles F. Brannan.

The Lux Video Theatre, one of the better half-hour programs devoted to original dramas, presented at 8 o'clock on Monday night over C. B. S. an unusual play, a romance between two patients in a tuberculosis sanatorium. The work had a sensitive and poignant point of view, but failed of a very satisfactory resolution.

Puerto Ricans who come here want to work. The charge most commonly bandied against them -- that they flock to the city's relief rolls and stay there -- is vigorously rejected by the city's welfare leaders.

George Mikan was "off" and the 6-foot 10-inch ace of the champion Minneapolis Lakers was of no help to his mates, who dropped a 79-63 decision to the New York Knickerbockers before 10,219 fans at Madison Square Garden last night.

The International Business Machines Corporation and its subsidiaries last year increased their net income to $29,874,541 from $27,892,089 earned in 1951, according to the forty-first annual report issued yesterday.

Since early last December, the average price for a pound of butter has remained steady at 79 cents. In some chain stores, the cost is lower -- from 73 to 75 cents a pound. These rates may not seem outstandingly economical, but they are considerably below those charged a year ago at this time, when the general price of butter was 97 cents a pound.

Toward the end of last year THE TIMES published an editorial relative to the efforts of the Broadway Association to rid Times Square and its environs of the deplorable "carnival" atmosphere which so many find objectionable and depressing and which is endangering the future of the area as an amusement and theatrical center.

A 55-year-old raincoat manufacturer committed suicide at 1:30 P. M. yesterday by jumping from the window of his twelfth-floor office at 237 West Thirty-seventh Street. His body struck and critically injured a passer-by.
SPORTSMEN'S SHOW highlights:

ORMOND BEACH, Fla., Feb. 24 (AP) -- Barbara Romack, the defender in the women's South Atlantic golf championship, took medal honors in the amateur tournament today with a 34, 38 -- 72 -- five under women's par and one over men's par.

The late Mrs. Eleanor Morgan Satterlee, granddaughter of J. Pierpont Morgan, financier, was mentally "far below normal," and was "under the dominance" of her lawyer and her physician, the Appellate Division ruled yesterday in ordering a new trial to determine whether her will should be admitted to probate.

Several dinner parties will be given in advance of tonight's preview of the exhibition, "Landmarks in American Art," at the Wildenstein Gallery for the benefit of the American Federation of Arts. Mrs. Arthur A. Houghton Jr. heads the committee of sponsors for the benefit. Among her aides is Mrs. Donald F. Hyde.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- A plan by which the 10,000,000 Chinese in the Southeast Asia area, outside the Communist-controlled mainland, would support with both funds and military manpower the Nationalist regime on Formosa will soon be placed before Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense.

A statement that "we are entering a competitive period when value and prices will again play their part after twelve years of a seller's market" is made by Roy A. Foulke, vice president of Dun Bradstreet, Inc., in a new edition of his book, "Behind the Scenes of Business." The volume, a discussion of management problems and financial ratios first issued in 1935, was released for publication today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (UP) -- Representative Laurie C. Battle was filled with indignation today by a Danish charge that he had spent most of his time in Copenhagen inspecting the local brewery.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Secretary of the Interior Douglas V[cKay today recommended the appointment of B. Frank Heintzelman as Governor of Alaska and Waino Edward Hendrickson as Secretary of the Territory of Alaska.

MOSCOW, Feb. 24 -- India's Dr. Saiffudin Kitchlu was en route home via Soviet central Asia tonight after having gained a series of impressions from a personal discussion with Premier Stalin and from travel through the Soviet Union.

TRENTON, Feb. 24 -- The New Jersey Supreme Court, with Chief Justice Arthur T. Vanderbilt dissenting, reversed today a decision of the Hudson County Court and ordered a new trial for two men convicted of murder in the first degree.

TORONTO, Feb. 24 -- Rabbi Abraham Bick of New York has been refused entry to Canada. The rabbi, at present without a synagogue, had been scheduled to share the platform with the Very Rev. Hewlett Johnson, the "Red Dean" of Canterbury, at a Soviet Friendship rally tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- A suggestion that the Federal Government give the states responsibility for most of the aid programs in which Washington now participates was made here today by the Council of State Chambers of Commerce.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam of the Methodist Church struck out today against methods he said were being used by Congressional committees searching for communism in education.

Five of the Rangers' thirteen National Hockey League victories this season have been scored against Boston and tonight the Blues will have a chance to improve on this mark when they oppose the Bruins at Madison Square Garden.

The gravediggers' strike was settled yesterday after almost seven weeks and one false peace. Today 200 cemetery workers will go back to their jobs in ten Jewish and nonsectarian burial grounds in the metropolitan area.

It seems to be generally assumed that Congress may dispose of the vast offshore oil reserves belonging to the United States in any way that it sees fit. But, in spite of the broad wording of Article III, Section 2, of the Constitution, by which Congress is given power "to dispose of the territory or other property belonging to the United States," it is believed that this is not necessarily true.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission today ordered the Chain Institute of Chicago and its eighteen members to halt what the F. T. C. said were price-fixing practices.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 24 (AP) -- The secretary of the Yugoslav Parliament's Foreign Affairs Committee called on world Socialist movements today to avoid supporting either of the "two major powers" in what he called their struggle for supremacy.

Songs and choral works by Mary Howe, composer from Washington, were presented last evening in Town Hall by Katharine Hansel, soprano, and the Howard University Choir, under the direction of Warner Lawson.

PARIS, Feb. 24--Premier Rene Mayer indicated in an interview today that France could not fulfill any additional heavy commitments on European defense unless her North Atlantic Treaty allies assumed a larger share of the costs of financing the civil war in Indo-China.

ANDY LOTSHAW retired at the end of the 1952 season as trainer for both the Chicago Cubs and the Chicago Bears. But he never had a chance to enjoy his retirement. The fabled Doc Lotshaw died suddenly the other day at the age of 73 and deep will be the grief in the entire world of sports. He was a colorful, engaging sort with an immense popularity.

City Councilman Earl Brown charged yesterday that the police and Magistrates Courts had "seemingly entered into what amounts to a conspiracy" to deter citizens from pressing police brutality complaints in criminal courts. He said that a clerk in Uptown Magistrates Court had said he had been instructed not to issue summonses against policemen when requested by complainants.

LONDON, Feb. 24 -- Britain's Defense Ministry and the War Office asked Parliament for substantially larger appropriations for defense today. Army estimates jumped 50,000,000 ($140,000,000) and the Ministry of Defense estimated it would need more than 2,000,000 ($5,600,000) more this year than last to meet obligations arising under the North Atlantic Treaty.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 24 (AP) -- A defense lawyer predicted today that a Government victory in the anti-trust suit against the National Football League would mean the "death knell of pro football" or at least a nation-wide blackout of radio and telecasts of pro games.

Prices of long-term United States Government bonds continued their decline to new low levels yesterday with resumption of trading after the extended holiday week-end. As a consequence, seven issues of Treasury 2 1/2 per cent obligations due from 1969 to 1972, were selling at the close at yields ranging from 2.85 per cent to 2.87 per cent.

Saying he was "shocked" over the state's rejection of his administration's $218,700,000 long-range plan for solving this city's recurring financial crises, Mayor Impellitteri summoned the Board of Estimate yesterday to meet in executive session at 3 P. M. today at City Hall to consider the situation.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 24 -- Going on the theory that new faces are as important to the movie business as new technical developments, Universal-International has appropriated $1,000,000 to carry out an accelerated program for the development of fresh screen personalities during the year.

CHICAGO, Feb. 24 -- After a recovery from recent lows in wheat, and substantial recoveries in other grains and soybeans, the demand was less active in grains today, with wheat and corn selling off sharply on reports of light to fair rains in the Southwest. On setbacks there was good buying of the major grains, while soybeans maintained a relatively strong tone.

New York's first City Hall opened 300 years ago yesterday. The occasion was recalled by the Downtown Manhattan Association and the Holland Society of New York, which cooperated with the Mayor's committee for the city's tercentenary celebration in a ceremony at noon near the original site at Pearl Street and Coenties Slip.

While the foreign steamship lines are bearing the brunt of the alien-screening provisions of the McCarran-Walter Immigration and Nationality Act, American-flag companies also have been having difficulties since the measure went into effect Dec. 24.

TRENTON, Feb. 24 -- The case of the "Trenton Six," which was believed to have come to an end last week when Ralph Cooper, sole remaining defendant, entered a no defense plea and was sentenced to six to ten years in New Jersey State Prison, was revived suddenly today.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- In denying today the need for establishment of educational television stations, the Temporary State Commission on the Use of Television for Educational Purposes, reported that "all of the time desired by educational institutions in the state has been made available" by commercial television stations and that in some instances the full time offered was not used.

The Vanderbilt Cup, symbol of the knockout team-of-four national contract bridge championships, was won early today by the all-New York team of Peter Leventritt, Miss Ruth Sherman, Dr. William Lipton, Edgard Kaplan and Richard Kahn.
DALLAS, Feb. 24 (AP) -- United Airlines wants the Civil Aeronautics Board to let it link the Dallas-Fort Worth area with the company's network, which extends from Boston to Hawaii.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Feb. 24 -- Two top-ranking Presbyterian theologians -- one representing the so-called Northern Church and the other speaking for the Southern Presbyterians -- agreed here today that social and economic differences were a greater impediment to church unity than creedal or doctrinal divisions.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Informed United States officials said today the United States was willing to furnish $42,000,000 to help the build up of loyal Indo-Chinese troops but wanted the right to have military observers with such troops.

LONDON, Feb. 24 -- The stock markets developed renewed strength today. British government securities were particularly firm. Industrials also tended to improve although profit-taking caused some irregularity in price movements.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Eight New Jersey Girl Scouts Spent a busy sight-seeing day in the capital, beginning with a picture-taking visit to Mrs. Eisenhower in the White House, as a reward for an unusual record of two years of good deeds.

ROME, Feb. 24 -- The conference of the Foreign Ministers of the nations making up the European Coal and Steel Community and the European Defense Community unanimously approved in principle today a proposal by the Netherlands to create a six-nation single European market by the progressive elimination of customs barriers between those countries.

The development of a variety of decorating styles has accompanied the revival of tile design, with the result that collections of such objects resemble an art gallery. As with other ceramic objects, tiles (which are glazed ceramic squares) have a useful as well as a decorative life. They appear as table tops or trays, as well as the usual base for hot dishes.

After two months' uneasy recess the General Assembly of the United Nations resumed yesterday the interrupted session of 1952. Last fall the Assembly met for the first time in its permanent headquarters. But the delegates were still en route, so to speak; under the brightly lighted dome of that insulated amphitheatre they seemed a little like passengers riding out a storm in the lounge of a very modern ship.

The average man has a deep - rooted instinct to postpone a number of things. There is going to the dentist, of course. This delay is due to the knowledge, learned early in childhood, that while teeth have active nerves, the dentist's drill has none whatever.

Carmen Fiore, 146 3/4 pounds, Brooklyn, knocked out Marcel (Rocky) Brisebois, 146 1/2, Montreal, in 1 minute 41 seconds of the first round of a scheduled ten-round bout at Ridgewood Grove, Brooklyn, last night.
The dispute leading to January's twenty-nine-day bus strike will go into arbitration tomorrow, Walter A. Lynch, chairman of the arbitration panel, announced yesterday.

MIAMI, Feb. 24 -- Harrison B. Wilson, the Darby Dan Farm's jockey, had a highly enjoyable 83- 3/5 seconds of race-riding at Hialeah today. He was astride the 5-year-old mare Atalanta in the $6,000 purse that headed the program, and she led all the way, with no pressure on her at any stage in the seven-furlong proceedings.

With a new and revolutionary device to train students in "behind the wheel" driving, the Board of Education started yesterday an experimental program to augment its regular driver education courses that were initiated two years ago to help reduce highway accidents.
Action by the Export-Import Bank to help Brazil clear up its heavy backlog of dollar trade debts built up over the last year brought relief as well as satisfaction to export traders involved.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) -- The Defense Department recommended today that Congress make Hawaii the forty-ninth state.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Wilfrido Omano, Venezuelan Air Force captain, sought by authorities since last September on charges of leading an abortive uprising at the Boca del Rio air base, was shot to death tonight in a gun battle with national security agents, it was officially announced.
Warning to business men: Even though price controls are being removed, records of transactions must be kept.

Several officials of city or city-connected agencies were sworn in yesterday by Mayor Impellitteri at City Hall. Among them was Sidney Waugh of 104 East Thirty-eighth Street who became sculptor member of the Art Commission. Mr. Waugh will serve until next Dec. 31, filling out the unexpired term of Cornelia Van A. Chapin, who resigned.

Aluminum metal sheets valued at $30,000 and a $10,000 green trailer truck on which they were loaded were stolen early yesterday from the Gowanus Warehouse Corporation at 310-12 Third Avenue, Brooklyn.
CAMP DRUM, N. Y., Feb. 24 -- Paratroopers of the Eighty-second Airborne Division dropped by "proxy" today on entrenched aggressor forces to open the first tactical phase of Exercise Snowstorm.
A Chinese puzzle that has been engaging some of the keenest minds at Williams College for the last week appears somewhat closer to a solution today.

Dr. Israel Goldstein, president of the American Jewish Congress, asserted yesterday that only prompt action by the United Nations could save Jews imperiled by the anti-Semitic campaign being waged by the Soviet Union and its satellites.

MAYS LANDING, N. J., Feb 24 -- Charles Hogan, termed by the Atlantic City police one of the resort's top gambling figures, was sentenced today to two to three years in State Prison, fined $1,500 and placed on probation for five years on four indictments covering perjury and lottery charges.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 24 (AP) -- One of the Senate's top Republicans, Styles Bridges, tonight called for a full-fledged naval blockade of the China coast and an end to "political restrictions" on pursuit of enemy aircraft into Manchuria.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Feb. 24 (AP) -- The Carrier Corporation reported today new orders booked in the first three months of its fiscal year beginning Nov. 1 were 34 per cent above the first quarter of the previous fiscal year.

Operations at the nation's steel mills are scheduled at an estimated 99.5 per cent of rated capacity this week, indicating production of 2,244,000 tons of ingots and steel for castings, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The figures are up slightly from last week's actual output of 2,235,000 tons on a 99.1 per cent operating rate.

Mahler's Symphony No. 2, in C minor, known as the "Resurrection" Symphony, requires about an hour and twenty minutes to perform, and it occupied the entire program of the Philadelphia Orchestra at Carnegie Hall last night.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The State Department today suspended Alfred H. Morton, chief of the Voice of America's international broadcasting service.

The 60-foot-11 1/4-inch weight toss by Robert Backus of the New York A. C. in the senior Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union field event program at Columbia's South Field on Monday will not be certified as a world mark, the Metropolitan A. A. U. said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The Eisenhower Administration officially advised Congress today that it felt the national interest would be best served by affirming state claims to oil-rich submerged lands within historic offshore boundaries. However, it would preserve for 'the nation as a whole" revenue derived in the area from the state-claimed area out to the edge of the Continental Shelf.

The largest peacetime production, an increase of $3,879,456 in earnings and a rise of 132 per cent in sales were achieved by the Douglas Aircraft Company in its thirty-third year of operations ended last November. This was reported yesterday by Donald W. Douglas, president since its establishment and now also chairman of the board of directors.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- As the public storm against Congressional investigation into alleged Communistic infiltration into the educational processes of the country arose to a new intensity here -- on the ground that the methods of inquiry served to stifle academic freedom -- public hearings were resumed today.

Milwaukee, Wis., sold yesterday $7,000,000 of sewer and school bonds due from 1954 to 1963 to a syndicate headed by Northern Trust Company at a bid of 100.3365 for interest of 1.7 per cent. Three other bids for the same interest rate ranged from 100.23 to 100.1599.

The Eisenhower Administration has met its first important test in the field of Latin-American relations and it has done so with courage and common sense. Over a certain amount of inter-governmental opposition the Export-Import Bank has approved a loan of $300,000,000 to Brazil, to be applied to the liquidation of the large commercial arrears which that country imprudently allowed to accumulate.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Feb. 25 -- United Nations raiders, backed by heavy artillery and tank fire, attacked a Communist position southeast of Panmunjom at dawn today and blew up or burned out enemy fortifications with explosives and flamethrowers.

CHICAGO, Feb. 24 -- Frank E. Holman of Seattle, former president of the America Bar Association and a leading advocate of a Constitutional restriction on treaty-making power, said today that he had an appointment with President Eisenhower tomorrow to "discuss not the need for an amendment but its text."
MEXICO CITY, Feb. 24 -- The United States has adopted a hands off attitude toward the situation in Guatemala and its threat that a Communist stronghold will be established near its backdoor.
The futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed irregular yesterday, 9 points higher to 10 lower than on Friday.
A narcotics peddler and his two messengers, one an 18-year-old girl, were arrested last night by the police of the narcotics squad after a month of investigation.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 24 -- Atmospheric disturbance in the north which is the usual way they account for these things around here, raised a bit of havoc with the Giants as they moved into their second day of spring training today.

VERO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 24 -- Billy Cox arrived at the Dodger training camp unexpectedly late today and expressed his willingness to go along with Manager Chuck Dressen's plan to make a utility infielder out of him.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Wednesday, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Melbourne may apply to have the equestrian events of the 1956 Olympic Games held in another country, Chairman Arthur Coles of the Olympic Committee said today.

CARACAS, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Venezuelan industrialists were told today that establishment of a steel industry here never will be "a source of great wealth to your nation in a strictly monetary sense -- at least, not as long as the economics of steel remain what they are today."

FORT DIX, N. J., Feb. 24 -- A charge of premeditated murder today was lodged against Pvt. Edgar Owens, 21 years old, of Brooklyn, who, the Army says, has confessed slaying Lieut. Richard M. Davenport, 22, of New London, Conn.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Former Senator Robert M. La Follette Jr. of Wisconsin died today of a self-inflicted bullet wound.

The professional painter who fears the "do-it-yourself" trend may harm his business was given some advice by a panel of three experts at yesterday's meeting of the first annual convention of the city Council of Painting and Decorating Contractors of America at the Biltmore Hotel.

Commodity prices closed irregularly higher yesterday on the New York exchanges. Cocoa volume was the highest for the year and cottonseed oil trading was more active than during the last two weeks. Sugar and wool had very light volume. Coffee, wool, soybean and cottonseed oils, hides and lead closed higher. Cocoa, sugar, rubber and zinc were lower and potatoes ended mixed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The nation's output of goods and services (gross national product) rose by $17,000,000,000 last year to a new high level of $346,000,000,000, the United States Department of Commerce reported today.
The undefeated Seton Hall Pirates were No. 1 in The Associated Press basketball poll for the sixth straight week yesterday.

AT AN ADVANCE FIGHTER BASE, Korea, Feb. 24 -- If Maj. David Cleeland of Santa Ana, Calif., had agreed with the United States Marines that 100 missions are enough for any pilot he would not have had to make a forced landing seventy miles behind the enemy lines on a frozen reservoir today.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Feb. 24 -- A Cabinet crisis is looming in Denmark following the Labor party's move today in the Folketing (lower house of Parliament) to lodge an interpellation addressed to Defense Minister Harald Petersen regarding the near mutinies in the army over the lengthening of the service term as recommended by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 24 -- Conceding defeat, Yugoslavia's Communist leaders have abandoned all further collectivization of land and have decided to set up the Western type cooperative as the basic organizational instrument for agricultural production.

Much to the relief of organizations conducting big conventions in the city, the Federal Government has decided to drop its plan to lease the first four floors of Grand Central Palace as offices for the Bureau of Internal Revenue.

Anxiety in many cases causes the human heart to beat slower, not faster, as generally believed, Columbia University psychologists reported yesterday on the basis of a year's experimentation with 250 men.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 24 -- Anti-Semitic developments behind the Iron Curtain probably will be brought up by Israel in connection with Poland's "world peace" item on the agenda of the United Nations General Assembly, a Foreign Ministry official said today. He added that the Israeli Government had decided against bringing up anti-Semitism as a separate item.

Mrs. Harold Ruckman Mixsell will give a tea this afternoon in her home, 161 East Sixty-fourth Street, for members of the committee aiding in plans for the benefit performance of "Hazel Flagg" on the night of April 20 at the Mark Hellinger Theatre in behalf of Woman's Hospital.

Attendance of retailers at the New York Gift Show in the New Yorker and Statler Hotels is breaking all records, the George F. Little Management declared yesterday. The Little organization, which directs the show, reported that most of the 600 exhibitors, showing about 1,000 lines, were writing more business than in many years.

MINEOLA, L. I., Feb. 24 -- Mrs. Lillian B. Robinson, former executive of a Roslyn home improvement company who was accused of a $478,000 loan swindle by the Central National Bank of Mineola, pleaded guilty in Nassau County Court today to fifty counts of second-degree forgery and one count of conspiracy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The House Armed Services Committee voted today to recommend extension of the Dependents Assistance Act for the armed forces to July 1, 1955. The existing law will expire April 30 unless Congress renews it.

QUEBEC, Feb. 24 -- Canadian publishers who entertained any hopes of a newsprint price cut following removal of the $10 sales tax in the recent Ottawa budget were doomed to disappointment today, for newsprint manufacturers have announced that a $10 a ton increase will be levied on all sales to Canadian publishers effective on April 1.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The entire Senate Democratic hierarchy arrayed itself in fighting position today against any hardening of President Eisenhower's proposed declaration against Russian "perversion" of the wartime Yalta and Potsdam agreements.

Myles J. Lane, United States Attorney here, urged yesterday that his successor -- "and I think there will be one appointed in the not too distant future" -- get salary increases for his staff of assistants since the office handled 30 per cent of the Federal civil and criminal cases in the country.
HILDEN, Germany, Feb. 24 -- The Allies' Northern Army Group in West Germany is capable of fulfilling its tasks and meeting a Soviet attack, its commander, Gen. Sir Richard Gale, asserted today.

MANILA, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Western and Communist nations at the United Nations Trade Promotion Conference joined today in pledging to stimulate economic development of Asian nations through increased trade.

If there was any doubt, statistics issued yesterday by the world's largest life insurance institution, the $11,592,529,045 Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, conclusively proved the advantages of living.

Federal Judge John F. X. McGohey reserved decision yesterday in a "rare and unusual" dual application by the Government to have a receiver appointed and to enjoin Frank Costello and his wife from disposing of their property until a Government income tax lien totaling $486,722 is satisfied.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- Indications developed today that any Republican attempt to increase the state gasoline tax by 2 cents to finance an expanded highway program might be delayed until the 1954 Legislative session.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Westinghouse Electric Corporation reported today its 1952 net income rose 6 per cent to $68,581,000, equal to $4.25 a share, from the 1951 earnings of $64,578,000, or $4.03 a share.

A revised estimate of $4.23 a hundredweight as the uniform price for February milk deliveries was issued yesterday by Dr. C. J. Blanford, Market Administrator of the New York Metropolitan milk marketing area. In an earlier forecast Dr. Blanford had estimated the price at $4.32, 9 cents higher, but he said the downward adjustment was necessitated by unforeseen declines in basic quotations used to determine prices.

Brooklyn College graduates received 219 scholarships, fellowships, assistantships, and other academic honors from seventy-eight institutions in this country and abroad in 1952, according to a report made yesterday by the Faculty Committee on Scholarships and Awards.
HARTFORD, Feb. 24 -- A caucus of Republican Senators and Assemblymen voted today to support the $135,000,000 Fairfield County Thruway.
Members of the Women's Committee of the American Museum of Natural History held their second Portrait Room luncheon of the year yesterday at the museum.

The largest mass dismissal of policemen in the recent history of the department took place yesterday when Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan discharged twenty-three of them for taking graft from Harry Gross, the former bookmaker.

Michael Potter, chairman of the City Fusion party, announced yesterday that his organization would hold a conference of civic groups at the Biltmore Hotel at 8 o'clock this evening to develop "united and non-partisan action for good, efficient and far-sighted government."

BONN, Germany, Feb. 24 -- West Germany's preparations to transform the Duetsche mark from a controlled into a fully convertible currency in 1953 have been slowed down as a result of the struggle with France over ratification of the European Defense Community treaty and the Bonn peace contract with the Western Allies.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 24 -- A newcomer to the United Nations, Generalissimo Rafael Trujillo, strong man of the Dominican Republic, eclipsed Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky in attracting attention at today's reopening of the general assembly's seventh session.
LONDON, Feb. 24 (AP) -- London had a preview of a sausage today, and it was a gala social and artistic affair.

The freshman science class of Harrison High School, Harrison, Ohio, is awaiting with keen anticipation the outcome of an experiment it is conducting with the assistance of Capt. John W. Anderson, master of the United States Lines' flagship United States. The experiment is the tracing of the currents of the North Atlantic.

The defense in the vice trial of Minot Frazier (Mickey) Jelke 3d opened yesterday in an atmosphere of ill-tempered respectability before General Sessions Judge Francis L. Valente. The press and public, excluded for the last two weeks on the judge's order because of the nature of the testimony, were admitted.

Stocks advanced vigorously yesterday on the first day of trading after margin requirements reduced by 75 per cent to 85 per cent. But the rally was short-lived. After registering gains up to about three points in early dealings with the tape running as much as three minutes behind transactions on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange, the list turned easier all around and resumed last week's drift.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (UP) -- A House Agriculture subcommittee said today that the spread of the hog disease vesicular exanthema was a "serious threat" to the livestock industry and to consumer supplies of all meats.

CHICAGO, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Robert J. Kane, Cornell University athletic director, today was named permanent chairman and Asa A. Bushnell, Eastern College Athletic Conference Commissioner, was retained as TV program director by the 1953 N. C. A. A. television committee.
Copper scrap prices, decontrolled less than two weeks ago, continued to work higher yesterday. Prices of brass and bronze ingots made from scrap material rose 1/2 to 3 1/4 cents a pound.

The President's aides have announced that he will soon send to the Senate for confirmation the names of Charles E. Bohlen to be Ambassador to the Soviet Union and Francis White to be Ambassador to Mexico. Both men have had extensive diplomatic experience which should serve them well in their new posts.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 24 -- President Juan Peron today promised Chilean workers in the industrial city of Concepcion that the Argentine Government would resume work on the transcontinental railroad linking that city with the Atlantic seaport of Bahia Blanca.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 24 -- Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., United States representative to the United Nations, denied today reports that friction had developed between him and Secretary of State John Foster Dulles.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 24 (Reuters) -- Master Tara Singh, dynamic leader of the Indian Sikhs, and nine other members of his party were arrested in the Punjab today, adding new fuel to India's smouldering crisis over Jammu, in Kashmir state.

A $2,900 fine, described as the highest amount levied in the current drive against traffic violators, was imposed yesterday by Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh on a 24-year-old daughter of a Pittsburgh idustrialist. The young woman, Miss Nancy Schuchman of 39-A Gramercy Park North, had pleaded guilty to fifty-eight parking violations.

When Secretary of the Interior Douglas McKay said this week that he saw no reason for further study of the question of Hawaiian statehood he wasn't trying to ride roughshod over the opposition. He was merely lending emphasis to the fact that in the last twenty years there have been at least a half-dozen Congressional investigations of the subject and just about everything has been said about it that can be said.

The National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis will spend $11,000,000 for gamma globulin, or G. G., the fraction of adult human blood found in large-scale field tests last year to provide temporary protection against paralytic polio.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Donald C. Cook today submitted his resignation as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, but President Eisenhower accepted his suggestion that he serve until a replacement is appointed.

The selection of Eddie Albert to star in a one-man television show five afternoons a week was among several new program developments yesterday at the Columbia Broadcasting System headquarters. Included also were the discontinuance of the "Mike and Buff" show and the signing of Joan Caulfield for a projected series.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (UP) -- A Christian Science official today urged prompt Congressional approval of a constitutional amendment to prevent the United Nations from over-riding basic "individual and religious rights."

A break sooner or later between President Eisenhower and Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, is likely over foreign affairs, William S. White of the Washington Bureau of THE NEW YORK TIMES said yesterday.

Philco and York Corporations soon will market the first window-type air-conditioners that provide heating as well as cooling in one unit. Spokesmen for both companies said the new products are in production and should be in stores in the next thirty days.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 25 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie has authorized non-American employes of the United Nations to give the Federal Bureau of Investigation information about the 375 Americans who hold professional, or policy-making, positions in the upper level of the Secretariat.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 25 -- Gen. James A. Van Fleet, welcomed as a hero today after nearly two years as Commander of United Nations forces in Korea, called the Eighth Army there the greatest bunch of fighting men in world history.

William A. White Sons, agents for Grand Central Palace, said yesterday that they were amazed at the last-minute action of the Federal Government in dropping plans to lease most of the exhibition building. The agents reported they had notified the General Services Administration that they considered there was a "completed deal," and expected the Government to live up to it.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The heads of the two-part National Labor Relations Board divided today on the question whether they should stay divided.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Feb. 25 (UP) -- Avery Brundage, president of the International Olympics Committee, said today that final word was expected from Australia this week on whether Melbourne would stage the 1956 Olympics.

The Seaboard Air Line Railway reported yesterday for 1952 a net income of $19,217,813 after charges, taxes and sinking fund requirements, or $19.69 each on the 973,790 capital shares outstanding. This compares with $12,356,692 in 1951, or $13.65 each on the 850,000 common shares after dividend requirements on the preferred shares which were retired during 1952.

Warm thanks to you for your good and conspicuous report of Agnes E. Meyer's gallant speech defending freedom of thought and teaching against the erratic and unjust attacks of our Congressional committees. I am grateful to Mrs. Meyer for saying so well things I feel deeply, and to you for helping give them publicity.
The Chinatown Mission of the Rescue Society at 5 Doyers Street marked its sixtieth anniversary yesterday, still in the business of feeding and sheltering homeless and penniless men of the Bowery.

Prices on the New York commodity exchanges closed irregular yesterday. Cottonseed oil trading was more active than at any time this year and coffee continued to show sizable volume. Sugar was inactive. Cottonseed and soybean oils, rubber, hides, lead and tin were higher.

HONG KONG, Feb. 25 -- The reorganization of a first group of about 40,000 Communist party rural branches is officially reported as being brought to a close now in Communist China under a three-year "overhauling of ranks" movement that is scheduled to continue until the spring of 1954.

The Bronx Zoo would like to inform all children in the city that it has a pair of pandas now, and that the boys and girls may see these popular and playful animals beginning today in a cage outside the Small Mammal House.

VERO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 25 -- Donald Albert Hoak arrived at the Dodger camp today and immediately increased the interest in the answer to the $64 question posed by Manager Chuck Dressen: "Who's on third?"
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 25 -- The United States declared today that Soviet attacks against religious groups had pushed the day of peace further away.

The United States Rubber Company attained a new sales record for the third successive year, but earnings, second highest in the company's history, fell 7 per cent from 1951, reflecting higher operating costs and stiffer competition, the sixty-first annual report to stockholders disclosed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- A Government witness swore today that he had attended about twenty Communist party meetings with Dr. Joseph W. Weinberg in 1939 and 1940.

This is the season when manufacturers of washing machines, both of the automatic and conventional types, step up their advertising and selling activities in an effort to capture what they believe to be their proper shares of the consumer's dollar.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Feb. 28 -Vietnam approached today its goal of a freer hand in the establishment of a national army.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25 -- Key members of the du Pont family, whose company has been credited with saving the Allies with huge supplies of gunpowder early in World War I, were willing to deal with the Germans if they placed big enough orders, a letter introduced by the Government at the du Pont anti-trust trial disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee unanimously approved today a resolution condemning the persecution of Jews in the Soviet Union, after broadening it to include other minority groups.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The Army today exhibited its rapid-firing, completely radar - controlled and deadly accurate Skysweeper anti-aircraft gun. The electronically guided artillery weapon is designed to search out hostile aircraft in all weather and destroy them at altitudes up to four miles.

LONG BEACH, L. I., Feb. 25 -- Long Beach's entrance into the convention field gained impetus today with the announcement by Harold J. Garne, secretary of the New York State C. I. O. Council, that 1,100 delegates representing all local Congress of Industrial Organizations unions would convene in the seaside city on Sept. 24, 25 and 26.

A number of changes, in Federal tax laws were urged yesterday by the Machinery and Allied Products Institute to assure a continued high level of employment and productivity. A special committee of the group has ben conferring with the staff of the Joint Congressional Committee on Internal Revenue taxation.

SPORTSMEN'S Show highlights: It would be a hopeless task to attempt a count of the lures and baits displayed at this exposition, but certainly there is no item of the fish's diet that is not represented in the real or imitated form. There are imitation worms that you expect to move in your hand, eels with all the appearance of life and plastic lizards that should tempt the wariest largemouth.

The testimony of Paul M. Herzog, Chairman of the National Labor Relations Board, before the House Committee on Education and Labor was a well-balanced presentation of the Board's administration of the Taft-Hartley Act. It merits the careful consideration of Congress.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 25 -- Father Divine, Negro cult leader, today ordered his followers to stop using the New Jersey Turnpike until further notice.

Society will create serious problems for the future unless it develops more wholesome attitudes toward the older persons who are becoming an increasing part of the population, authorities attending the thirty-second annual meeting of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies declared yesterday.

Net earnings of the United Fruit Company and its subsidiaries last year declined to $37,937,126, or $4.32 a share, from $50,893,898, or $5.79 a share, earned in 1951, Kenneth H. Redmond, president, reported yesterday in the fifty-bird annual report to stockholders.

RALEIGH, N. C., Feb. 25 -- The North Carolina Supreme Court unanimously reversed the "assault by leer" conviction of a Negro sharecropper today, ruling he could not be convicted "for what may have been in his mind" when he looked at a teen-aged white girl in a cornfield.

Instead of the "repudiation" of the so-called secret pacts, the best way to find a peaceful solution to liberate the enslaved nations behind the Iron Curtain would be to accuse and brand Soviet Russia of ignoring those pacts and to compel her to put the Yalta and Potsdam agreements into effect in the spirit and understanding of Western minds and parliamentary democracy.

The lifting of price controls on copper, aluminium and cigarettes along with a host of other commodities, sparked interest in the stock market yesterday. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange reached 2,860,000 shares, the largest single session since Oct. 22, 1951.

A collection of fabrics from man-made fibers was shown yesterday at the Fashion Institute of Technology, 225 West Twenty-fourth Street. The exhibit, Modern Living Fabrics, was arranged for the Institute's students by E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. and will be open to the public on Wednesdays only from 2 until 4 P. M. in March.

The final regular-season double-header at Madison Square Garden tonight will send St. John's, which, along with Tulsa, yesterday accepted a bid to play in the National Invitation Tournament, against New York University. Manhattan College opposes Iona in the 7:45 opener.

ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- The Assembly approved today a resolution to create a joint legislative committee to represent the state in connection with the celebration in 1954 of the bicentennial of Columbia University.
A "gallery" of trays, their bold, brightly colored designs derived from various sources, will go on view today at Tray House, 821 Avenue of the Americas.

Judge Harold R. Medina said at the investment banking anti-trust trial yesterday that he was impressed by the line of argument developed by a woman lawyer who has appeared at recent trial sessions at the Federal court here to further the anti-trust department's charges of monopoly and conspiracy against seventeen-major investment houses.

The Ford Foundation has appropriated $15,000,000 for the newly organized Fund for the Republic, which announced the grant yesterday and said one of its first activities would be a study of civil liberties.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- President Eisenhower said today he would go to any reasonable place to meet Premier Stalin if he thought it would do any good for world peace.

LONDON, Feb. 25 -- Most industrial prices moved irregularly today influenced by profit-taking sales. Changes, however, were generally limited to a few pence. Demand for British Government securities continued and most of them were marked up.

Opinion varies considerably between British and American teenagers when they stop to consider seriously their biggest problems. Results of a poll put recently to young people on both sides of the Atlantic have just been released by the National Midcentury Committee on Children and Youth.

VINCENT SHEEAN was surprised when he saw Ernest Hemingway's passport one day in the Nineteen Thirties and noticed that they had both been born in 1899. "For a good many years," he said in "Not Peace but a Sword," recalling the incident, "I had assumed that Hemingway (or anybody else who had been in the Great War) belonged to a different generation.
A plea for greater understanding of minority groups and their problems was made yesterday at a conference on bigotry and the New York press at Freedom House, 20 West Fortieth Street.

BERN, Switzerland, Feb. 25 -- After long consideration the Swiss Federal Government has decided to permit a few countries, including the United States, to raise the status of their Bern missions or legations to embassies.

TOKYO, Feb. 25 -- Japan's Foreign Minister Katsuo Okazaki has announced the Japanese Government may ask United Nations intervention in the fisheries dispute that is severely straining the relations of this country with the Republic of Korea.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) Following is an unofficial transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today, his second since the Inauguration, with the President's replies and his other comments put in indirect discourse as required by White House rules:
TORONTO, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Abitibi Power and Paper Company, Ltd., today notified its Canadian customers of an increase of $10 a ton in the price of newsprint, effective on April 1.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 25 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Foreign Minister, today dismissed President Eisenhower's statement about a meeting with Premier Stalin with one word -- but there was some doubt as to what the word meant.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Feb. 25 -- The Christian church has lagged far behind government, education, social work, industry and the medical and legal professions in according equality of status and opportunity to women, it was reported here today to the annual meeting of the western section of the World Presbyterian Alliance.

" At Home With Harry Hershfield," a weekly television program, will make its debut over Channel 7 Tuesday night from 11 t0 11:30 o'clock. The columnist, cartoonist and raconteur will hold auditions for various young performers in the presence of prospective talent buyers, in addition to telling stories and recalling events from the past.

The wheels of municipal legislation move slowly and ever so cautiously. On Tuesday the City Council's Building Committee decided it was necessary for the League of New York Theatres to file a brief, specifying the necessity, purpose and application of the twenty-one bills, introduced back in April, 1950, by Councilman Hugh Quinn, to amend an archaic theatre-building code.

Mrs. Ralph W. Teal of Saw Mill Road, Danbury, Conn., mother of Minor Frazier (Mickey) Jelke, testified for nearly three hours yesterday at his trial in General Sessions Court on charges of procuring and of living off the earnings of prostitutes.

Immigration officers went late yesterday afternoon to the home of Mrs. Raissa Irene Berkman Browder, wife of Earl Browder, former head of the Communist party in the United States, to arrest her for deportation.

The majority decision of the Temporary State Commission on the Use of Television for Educational Purposes is a disappointing document. It adopts a wait-and-see philosophy. It commands the sun of technological progress in education to stand still, relying on the magic lantern when a great new instrument of teaching is at hand.
The straight line vied with the full-skirted silhouette at the spring fashion show presented yesterday on the fifth floor of Martin's in Brooklyn.

Substantially greater sales are indicated for Bendix Aviation Corporation for the fiscal year which will end on Sept. 30, Malcolm P. Ferguson, president, told stockholders yesterday at the annual meeting in South Bend, Ind. He said sales for the first quarter, ended last Dec. 31, were approximately $145,000,000, compared with $111,522,000 in the like period of the previous fiscal year.

Events today: Searle Wright, organist, St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University, at noon; "Rigoletto," Metropolitan Opera, 8:30; Philharmonic-Symphony, Igor Stravinsky conducting, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Joseph Bloch, pianist, with chamber orchestra conducted by Frederick Prausnitz, Town Hall, 8:30.

Blocks of corporate securities valued at more than $50,000,000 will be offered to investors today. The marketings represent new common stock of a casualty insurance company, outstanding common stock of an industrial company, mortgage bonds of an Eastern railroad, and debentures of a manufacturer of pharmaceuticals.

Dr. Marcus D. Kogel, Commissioner of Hospitals, gave the Fordham Hospital a clean bill of health yesterday after an investigation into allegations of improper denial of admission to infants who died there the next day.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Permission of the Federal Power Commission for New York State to proceed with its program in developing hydroelectrical power in the St. Lawrence was advocated today by Douglas McKay, Secretary of the Interior.

To help state income taxpayers make out their returns for 1952, the State Income Tax Bureau will set up temporary headquarters in the Bronx, Westchester, Richmond, Queens, Orange, Nassau and Suffolk Counties before April 15, when state income taxes are due.

Another chapter in the sordid story of police protection of the Harry Gross multi - million - dollar gambling operations in New York City ends with dismissal of twenty-three policemen and the restoration to duty of six others. The six months' departmental trial before James A. Delehanty, retired Surrogate of New York County, serving temporarily as a deputy police commissioner, appears to have been a fair one.

Yale's zone defense may have worried Columbia, but it did not stop the Lions, who finished strongly and gained a 71-64 victory over the Elis last night before 2,000 fans at University Hall. The triumph enabled Lu Rossini's quintet to gain undivided possession of first place in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League, breaking the tie with idle Pennsylvania.
The 1953 fund appeal of the New York Catholic Charities for $2,477,138 was opened yesterday at a meeting of Cardinal Spellman's Committee of the Laity in the Empire State Building.

John Clark Knox, senior judge of the United States District Court, asserted yesterday that despite current apprehension over juvenile delinquency only a small portion of the nation's youth was guilty of criminal conduct.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 --President Eisenhower, in the midst of widespread protest against current Capitol Hill inquiries into communism in education and into operations of the Voice of America, said today that it would be extremely dangerous to try to limit the power of Congress to investigate.

" Martin Luther," the biographical feature produced by Louis de Rochemont Associates with the cooperation of Lutheran Church Productions, Inc., has been completed and will be released for public showing this spring.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today nominated Albert M. Cole, former member of Congress from Kansas, to be Administrator of the Housing and Home Finance Agency, succeeding Raymond M. Foley, who has resigned but who has agreed to serve until the Senate acts on his successor.
Hattie Carnegie is the first among New York's couture group to open the spring season. Yesterday afternoon her spring and summer fashions were shown in her East Forty-ninth Street establishment.

ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- Governor Dewey signed into law today a bill reorganizing the State Civil Service Commission and declared that it marked the most significant advance in state personnel policies of the last twenty-five years.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (UP) -- Republicans and Southern Democrats of the House of Representatives combined today to reject the first civil rights legislation of the near Congress -- an attempt to ban Government-insured loans unless property owners bar racial or other discrimination.

ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- The State Social Welfare Board endorsed today a bill to ease some of the restrictions on inspection of state relief rolls as it received a report that the opening of welfare rolls in Alabama, Illinois and Indiana had had no appreciable effect on the cost of aid programs in those states.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 25 -- After paying tribute to Chile's democratic form of government, which he said had a half-century start on Argentina, President Juan D. Peron of Argentina gave a Chilean audience today an unusual and long story on how he removed chaos from the Argentine political scene.

The Bennington College Scholarship Fund will be the beneficiary of the March 10 performance of "John Brown's Body" at the Century Theatre. Mrs. Stanley G. Mortimer Jr. is chairman of the benefit committee and serving as vice chairmen are Miss Jill Warburg and Mrs. Richard S. Emmett. Mrs. George S. Franklin is honorary chairman.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- President Eisenhower declared today that it would be terrifically difficult to balance the budget, the more so because there were so many new projects the Admin istration would like to carry out if it had surplus money.

ROME, Feb. 25 -- In its final session today the conference of the foreign ministers of the European Defense Community nations unblocked the road to European military collaboration and to the creation of a European army by having decided unanimously that the six governments concerned would press for speedy ratification of the European Defense Community Treaty by their parliaments.

Parents of young children will be able to attend afternoon classes without having to hire baby sitters this spring. The Extension Division of the City College School of General Studies is offering a program in which the parents take their courses at the same time that the youngsters attend arts and crafts classes in adjoining rooms.

PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 25 -- Eleven career Federal Government employes, nine men and two women, were named today as the first recipients of the Rockefeller Public Service Awards for outstanding public service. The announcement was made by Dr. Harold W. Dodds president of Princeton University.

NEWARK, Feb. 25 -- Two suspended members of the Newark Board of Adjustment received maximum sentences of two to three years in state's prison and were fined $1,000 each today as a result of convictions for extortion. They are U. Harry Perlmutter, 46 years old, and Joseph C. Caprio, 62, both convicted in County Court of extorting money from applicants for permits to allow variations in construction or zoning regulations.

ORMOND BEACH, Fla., Feb. 25 (AP) -- Polly Martin, former Ohio State University student, upset Edean Anderson, Helena, Mont., 2 and 1, today in the first-round match play of the women's South Atlantic golf tournament.

MANILA, Thursday, Feb. 26 -The dangerously muddled political situation in the Philippines was clarified to a degree today with President Elpidio Quirino openly bidding for renomination as the ruling party's candidate for President next November.

An increase last week of 1,388,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, total supplies were 155,857,000 barrels, compared with 154,469,000 a week earlier and 150,900,000 a year ago.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 25 -- The problem of West Germany's annual financial contribution to the European Defense Community when and if that body is constituted will be discussed tomorrow when Ambassador William H. Draper Jr., President Eisenhower's special representative in Europe, arrives for consultation with Dr. James B. Conant, United States High Commissioner.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (UP) -- An Interstate Commerce Commission examiner disapproved today a proposal by Transcontinental Bus System to acquire control of American Buslines, Inc.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 25 -- The Dunningcolor Company has entered the three - dimensional movie sweepstakes with a single-camera process. Exclusive licensing rights have been granted to Nat Levine, veteran producer and former president of Republic Pictures.

JERSEY CITY, Feb. 25 -- Projects under construction for the New Jersey Highway Department and the State Highway Authority at a cost of $300,000,000 will eliminate seriously traffic bottlenecks and facilitate trans-Jersey travel by the summer of 1954.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Feb. 25 -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek of Nationalist China, formally abrogated the Yalta-based Chinese-Soviet treaty of friendship and alliance of 1945 in a proclamation issued tonight.

Competition between American-grown wool and the new man-made fibers will be of a very limited nature, according to Carl A. Setterstrom, sales manager of the textile fibers department, Carbide and Carbon Chemicals Company.

The Inland Steel Company is embarking on a $50,000,000 iron ore project at Steep Rock Lake, northwestern Ontario, that is expected to put the company in a strong position for many years without recourse to remote sources of ore.

ATHENS, Feb. 25 -- A treaty of friendship and collaboration, binding the three Balkan countries outside the Iron Curtain -- Greece, Turkey and Yugoslavia -- was initialed this evening at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs here.
ROME, Feb. 25 (UP) -- The text of the official statement on the conclusion of the conference of six European foreign ministers today follows:
PUSAN, Korea, Feb. 25 -- The United States agreed this afternoon to pay the South Korean Government $85,800,000 to settle its account for Korean currency and services advanced to its troops.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- President Eisenhower declined today to indicate whether he might be a candidate for re-election in 1956. At his news conference a reporter noted that there had been stories recently that the President had confided to friends that he was not interested in running again in 1956.

Three wounded veterans of Korea who are patients in St. Albans Hospital were among several hundred volunteer workers for the Red Cross fund campaign who saw blood processing yesterday at the Regional Blood Center, 214 East Twenty-first Street.
CHICAGO, Feb. 25 (AP) -- A motorized wheel chair for incapacitated persons, operated by pressing buttons, was demonstrated yesterday by a paraplegic veteran of the Korean war.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 25 -- Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., the United States representative, warned the Soviet Union today that the Eisenhower Administration would continue the policy of no compromise with Communist aggression in Korea. Mr. Lodge told correspondents later that the United States was not planning to submit any resolution on Korea at this session of the United Nations General Assembly.
City College's basketball team gave favored St. Francis College some anxious moments last night before going down to a 69-66 defeat at the Beavers' gymnasium.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Edmund Grassl, 31-year-old Appleton, Wis., molder, rolled 1,888 to take second place today in the all-events division of the American Bowling Congress' golden jubilee tournament.

John Bess, head of Freshmaster, Inc., and F. O. A. Marketers, Inc., appliance maker and distributor of food for his Freezer Owners Association, yesterday made public the results of a survey among the 25,000 members of the plan in thirty major cities.

As one citizen, perhaps one of many, who is aware of the personal and official integrity, the ability and the distinguished record of public service of Police Commissioner Monaghan, I am acutely disturbed by the current clamor for his removal.

BERLIN, Feb. 25 -- In a single year the East German Government meted out punishments normally reserved for murderers and thieves to 10,000 political opponents, according to a report on a United States survey made public today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The House of Representatives passed and sent to the Senate today a bill to set temporary limits on the number of officers in the higher ranks of the armed forces, to be reached by June 30. The vote was 370 to 0.
MONTREAL, Feb. 25 (AP) -- The International League, baseball's oldest minor league, announced today a 154-game schedule for its seventieth season.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 25 -- Following is the text of a statement on Korea made today in the Political and Security Committee of the General Assembly by Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., United States representative:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (UP) -- The Defense Department announced today that United States battle casualties in Korea now totaled 130,321, an increase of 228 over last week's report.
LONDON, Feb. 25 -- Britain's Air Force will spend 80,360,000 ($225,008,000) more this year than last because of the expansion of armament.

In view of a recent stay preventing the Board of Education from trying three teachers and a teacher-clerk charged with insubordination, Arthur Levitt, board member and trial examiner, ruled yesterday that no trial date would be set for these four and three others under similar charges until the stay had been lifted.

High in fashion and low in price was the theme of Bonwit Teller's showing yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel of youthful spring fashions from their eighth floor. The box jacket silhouette again proved its popularity by appearing repeatedly, first in suits and later in costume ensembles.

Thirty-five aspiring young commercial artists -- freshmen at the School of Industrial Arts Annex -who put aside textbooks and dry recitations last September for learning by participation in the community, yesterday presented seventy-five posters to American Relief for Korea.

The opening move in the first diplomatic encounter between the Eisenhower Administration and the Soviet bloc was made yesterday in the General Assembly of the United Nations when Ambassador Lodge in effect ranged Soviet Russia among the aggressor nations by accusing it of instigating, expanding and continuing the Korean war.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Beard announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Feb. 18:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Philip B. Perlman, former Solicitor General, voiced the fear today that President Eisenhower had "no adequate knowledge either of the facts or the law" in advocating that Congress give the states title to oil-rich submerged lands within historic offshore boundaries.

News that Marshal Tito's regime in Yugoslavia has conceded defeat in its efforts to collectivize Yugoslavia's peasantry marks a milestone in the post-war history of that country. Instead of pushing forward in an effort to duplicate in Yugoslavia the agricultural organization of the Soviet Union, the emphasis is now to be put on voluntary farm cooperatives.

The two arresting policemen in the West Side case that touched off the current controversy over police brutality and civil rights investigations testified yesterday for almost two hours before a Federal grand jury here.

Control of F. R. Tripler Co., men's wear retailer of this city, has been acquired from the estate of the late Albert F. Free by Frederic C. Stecker, president; George A. Baraldi, first vice president, and Thomas H. Hanley, second vice president and secretary-treasurer, it was announced yesterday following a meeting of the board at the company's offices, 366 Madison Avenue.

GENEVA, Feb. 25 -- Dr. G. J. van Heuven Goedhart, United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees has proposed immediate action along three lines to meet the emergency caused by the flow of refugees from East Germany into West Berlin.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- General Service Administration officials acknowledged to Senate investigators today that a mistake had been made in storing 831,680 pounds of palm oil in unheated tanks, where it congealed.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N. J., Feb. 25 -- Paced by Toby Maxwell, Princeton today won the fifteenth annual Polar Bear track meet. In registering their fourth straight triumph in this fixture, held again in the comfortable surroundings of Lawrenceville School's Lavino Field House instead of the wintry outdoors as of yore, the Tigers tallied 56 1/3 points to Pennsylvania's 53 1/3 and Columbia's 29 1/3.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The Eisenhower Administration is deeply concerned over its current inability to select its own key personnel for policy-making jobs in nearly every department and agency of the Government.

CAMP DRUM, N. Y., Feb. 25 -- A tank-led assault by "Aggressor" forces "wiped out" one company of the 325th Regimental Combat team this morning, but failed to halt a steady advance of "Defender" forces in Exercise Snowstorm.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- While the capital awaited an executive order from President Eisenhower setting up a new internal security program for Government employes, the State Department today named an official to take charge of just such a program.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Feb. 25 -- Socialist members of Parliament will meet tomorrow morning to decide whether to introduce in the Chamber of Deputies a motion of no confidence in the Government.
Maybe the Rangers can't do much against the other teams in the National Hockey League, but they just can't get enough of the Boston Bruins.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- President Eisenhower, proclaiming March as Red Cross month, today urged "every American to respond as generously as possible to the appeal for funds for this humanitarian cause."

Twelve candidates for Mayor were suggested last night at a conference of civic organizations at the Biltmore Hotel, called by the City Fusion party. Michael Potter, chairman of the City Fusion party, presided. About two hundred persons were present.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Rocky Marciano, heavyweight champion, and Jersey Joe Walcott, today signed officially for their April 10 return match with a cautious word about their likely strategy when they square off again.
PHOENIX, Feb. 25 -- As the Giants swung smoothly into their training routine today with the reappearance of a bright desert sun, one important item became clear.

RANGOON, Burma, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Burma has turned down an offer by the Chinese Communists to help throw back Chinese Nationalist troops raiding the northeast frontier region and started the job herself, a Burmese staff officer reported tonight.

The eighty-sixth annual exhibition of the American Water-Color Society had a members' preview last evening in the galleries of the National Academy. A score of awards, honorable mentions and citations was announced. The exhibition will open today and will run through March 15.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Feb. 25 -- Within the next two weeks a fresh effort will be made to persuade President Eisenhower and top ranking United States political and military leaders to set up in Washington a central agency to coordinate Allied strategic-political planning in the three vital areas of the world, Europe, the Middle East and the Far East.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The Coast Guard, with the cooperation of Customs enforcement officers, has stopped and searched more than 1,500 ships in the last two years about thirty miles off the Port of New York in a search for atom weapons and other explosives, it was disclosed today by Rear Admiral A. C. Richmond, assistant commandant of the Coast Guard.

An outstanding convention year for the city was forecast yesterday in the annual report of the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau. The report expressed satisfaction with the $175,000,000 that was spent here last year by 2,448,369 convention-goers, an influx of delegates and visitors topped only by the World's Fair year of 1939 and an increase of 341,989 over the 1951 figure.

TOKYO, Thursday, Feb. 26 -- Sabre jet pilots of the United States Fifth Air Force broke a three-day lull in Korean air battles yesterday. The Americans reported downing two of the enemy's Soviet-designed MIG fighters over northwest Korea, just south of the Yalu River with two others damaged and another damage claim awaiting check-up.

Mayor Impellitteri and the Board of Estimate agreed unanimously yesterday to accept an invitation from Lieut. Gov. Frank C. Moore and State Controller J. Raymond McGovern to hold further conferences with the state officials on the city's fiscal program for 1953-1954.

The new 25,000-deadweight-ton tanker P. C. Spencer, flagship of the Sinclair Refining Company's fleet, arrived here yesterday afternoon on her maiden voyage. The Spencer will dock this morning at Sinclair's terminal at Tremley Point, N. J., with 170,000 barrels of heating oil.

Twelve persons participating in the seventh and final panel of the American Round Table series under the sponsorship of the Advertising Council, Inc., were generally agreed yesterday that the United States offered a climate hospitable to artistic excellence.

A second book about the American Great Plains and the artists who painted them will be published on March 23 by Scribners under the title "Artists and Illustrators of the Old West, 1850-1900." The author is Robert Taft, Professor of Chemistry at the University of Kansas, who has written three other books of Americana.

Liberalization of the State Department's directive restricting the Voice of America in its use of material from Communist and fellow traveler sources is expected soon, informed sources reported yesterday. The directive, they said, has seriously interfered with the psychological warfare activities of the Voice and weakened its effectiveness.

The caution of both United States exporters and Brazilian exchange authorities toward further extension of draft credit, together with the lack of progress in reducing the outstanding backlog, are reflected in the Latin American export credit data issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Robert Moses, president of the Jones Beach State Parkway Authority, challenged yesterday any right of the Federal Government to oppose a 10-cent toll proposed for the Southern State Parkway as a means of financing a $40,000,000 improvement program. The issue is pending Before the State Legislature.
In theory, the "Evening of Mozart" presented at Town Hall last night by Sydney Baron and the Classic Chamber Orchestra ought to have been an event of unusual interest.

The United Parent Teachers Association of New York City yesterday expresed diappointment over Tueday's majority report of the Temporary State Commision on the Use of Television for Educational Purposes in which state acquisition of television channels was opposed.

BOSTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Bobby Wanzer clicked with seven consecutive foul shots in an overtime period and Cal Christensen connected for two field goals to provide the Rochester Royals with a 79-71 victory tonight over the New York Knickerbockers, Eastern Division leaders of the National Basketball Association.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- The Missouri Pacific Railroad Company today gave notice that it may pull out of the railway express business as that service is presently constituted.

Not everyone was helped by the reduction in margins from 75 per cent to 50 per cent. Among those who were not are brokerage customers whose accounts are "frozen," i. e., whose equity with their broker is below requirements.
