Such investors if they desired to sell securities out of their accounts last Friday, were able to withdraw 75 per cent of the proceeds.

It is true that Robert M. La Follette Jr. got his political start in life because he was the son of his father, but he was much more than that. With none of "Fighting Bob's" flamboyance but with all of his intensity, the younger La Follette made an honored name in his own right and became one of the most esteemed and useful members of the Senate of the United States.

This year, under the federal income tax laws, a person who can qualify as a "head of a household" is entitled to special consideration when he files his tax return. This regulation is of particular benefit to widows and widowers with unmarried children at home, and to others who maintain a home and share it with certain individuals.
ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- The Senate approved unanimously and sent to the Assembly for concurrence today an Administration proposal to increase the personnel of the State Police by one-third.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The State Department reinstated Alfred H. Morton tonight as director of international broadcasting for the Voice of America, but reprimanded him for administrative laxity and poor judgment.

Charles B. Hitchcock, executive secretary of the American Geographical Society and a jungle explorer, returned to New York yesterday to report that his trip to an unknown mountain area of South America had failed.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The Department of Justice announced today the setlemen for $100,000 of a claim of the Department of Agriculture against Adolph Gobel, Inc., of North Bergen, N. J.

According to the Constitution, Rosalind Russell cannot run for President until 1956. But it would be wise to start preparing for her campaign at once. For she can dance and sing better than any President we have had. She is also better looking and has a more infectious sense of humor.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- A cousin of former Senator Millard F. Tydings, Democrat of Maryland, was depicted at a Congressional hearing today as apparently immune from disciplinary action as an official of the Internal Revenue Bureau.

HONG KONG, Feb. 25 -- Ho Chi Minh's Lao Dong (Labor party) in Indo-China, leader of the Vietminh rebellion there against the French, has adopted a five-point program that highlights "agitation among the masses" as its prime task for 1953, the Peiping radio reported tonight.

Dumpling recipes appearing in a recent Sunday magazine of this newspaper have prompted an interesting communication from a New Yorker. The reader, who asked that his name be withheld, said he was of German background, and that he was sending us directions for Bavarian dessert dumplings that were seldom prepared in this country.

The Pennsylvania Highway and Bridge Authority announced yesterday that it will receive bids on March 2 on $20,000,000 of serial bonds. The offering was first scheduled to be made on Feb. 5 but was postponed.

The National Music League, in conjunction with the Instrucao Artistica do Brasil, will begin in August an exchange - of - artists project to sponsor concerts by American artists in Brazil and by Brazilians in this country.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The large majority of Senators who support the fundamental objective of the constitutional amendment proposed by Senator Bricker of Ohio base their case on the argument that, as the Constitution is now written, treaties can impose on Congress a national obligation to legislate in fields not delegated to it, and in areas reserved to the states, by the Constitution itself.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 --President Eisenhower disclosed in his news conference today that the armed forces planned to request the draft of 1,200 physicians in the last quarter of the fiscal year 1953, which is April, May and June.

While there have been substantial gains in political, cultural and military areas among nations, there has been no similar understanding of the economic basis of mutual security, according to Milton D. Thalberg, president of the American Association of Machinery Importers.

John Paul (Frankie) Carbo was tried yesterday in Special Sessions on an eleven-count criminal information charging him with contempt in his refusal to answer questions before the State Crime Commission last Dec. 19.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Feb. 25 -- Despite a decision yesterday by the New Jersey Supreme Court that their 4-year-old daughter, Diane, should remain with a couple that adopted her in 1950, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph B. Lavigne, through their attorney, Donald G. Davis, today announced they would continue their fight for the child's custody.
GUATEMALA, Feb. 25 -- The United Fruit Company was informed today by the Agrarian Department that 225,000 acres of its Pacific holdings would be expropriated.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Cigarettes, most dry groceries and copper and aluminum were cut loose from price controls by the Office of Price Stabilization today.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 25 -- Gil McDougald arrived in camp today and launched the first Yankee experiment. The infielder from Nutley, N. J., has decided to change his unorthodox batting stance.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 25 (UP) -- Bert Bell, Commissioner of the National Football League, testified today that professional football could not survive with unlimited radio and television broadcasts of games.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25 -- More active buying support came into the grain market after prices had been depressed by free selling early. As a result, there was good recovery from the low spots of the day. Weakness in corn was an unsettling influence in the early trade, with bear traders inclined to capitalize on prospects for heavier marketings of Government grain.

MADISON, Wis., Feb. 25 -- The death of former Senator Robert M. La Follette Jr., who killed himself at his home in Washington yesterday, is not expected to have any considerable impact on the Wisconsin political situation, even though many of his followers in the old Progressive movement never abandoned hope that he would someday attempt a political comeback.
PEEKSKILL, N. Y., Feb. 25 -- Seven boys, 13 to 15 years old, were accused today of helping themselves to some of the 100 Army jeeps and trucks in the State Armory on Washington Street.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb 25 (AP) -- A dockworkers stoppage that employers had said might shut down the Port of Philadelphia ended today at the urging of a priest who is the final arbiter of waterfront disputes. It was the second time since he was named arbiter several months ago that Father Dennis J. Comey had succeeded in persuading waterfront groups to call off a strike.
The full story of why Harry Gross wrecked a criminal trial one and a half years ago of eighteen policemen charged with taking his bookmaking graft moved closer yesterday to unfolding.
TOKYO, Thursday, Feb. 26 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,537, for the twenty-four hours to 6 P. M., Thursday, Korean time:
Prices of cotton futures closed barely steady yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange, with active months 4 to 15 points off on the day.

The remarkable program that Vladimir Horowitz offered at his recital last night in Carnegie Hall revealed the full gamut of extraordinary interpretive gifts. We do not speak of his powers as a virtuoso. They are taken for granted, and represent but one facet of his art, one weapon of his tonal armory.

MIAMI, Feb. 25 -- A couple of hours before the running of the first division of the Hialeah Juvenile Stakes today, the favorite, the Florida-bred filly, Wolf Gal, was bought by Dr. S. Dewey Gottlieb of Washington, who started her under the silks of the Kay-Gee Stable, in which he holds the majority interest.

PARIS, Feb. 25 -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle advised against the creation of a European army today partly because in his opinion such an army would place France in the position of subordination to United States military strategy.
Mary Drayton's comedy, "Debut," is scheduled to arrive April 20 under the sponsorship of William Dozier and the direction of Guthrie McClintic, with Sally Forrest and Tom Helmore heading the cast.
The text of a memorandum issued at City Hall yesterday on the "State's analysis of Feb. 23, 1953, of the city's financial program," follows:
MASSAPEQUA, L. I., Feb. 26 -- A disguised message over a two- way radio system to a taxicab driver brought about the arrest today of a man suspected of having fled in the cab from a hold-up.

The machine tool industry, which makes the machinery that makes mass production possible and therefore is able to indicate the trend of industry as a whole, is marking up advances although most companies had been expecting a decline during the first quarter of 1953.
SEOUL, Friday, Feb. 27 (AP) -- The food crisis in the Army of the Republic of Korea has grown so grave that its Chief of Staff said Thursday he would ask the United Nations for help.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 26 -- Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., United States delegate to the United Nations, gave assurance today that the Eisenhower Administration would carry out past United States promises to contribute $14,708,750 to United Nations technical assistance programs for 1953.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 26 -Deck officers voted at a stop-work meeting this afternoon to refuse to sign aboard ships of the Pacific Maritime Association.

Loans to business by New York banks, which have been declining seasonally during most of the last six weeks, turned upward during the week ended on Wednesday. The $8,000,000 advance marked the second increase to be registered in the six-week period and brought the total reduction since the start of this year to $184,000,000, against an increase of $34,000,000 a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -Following is the text of a statement by John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, before the Foreign Affairs Committee of the House of Representatives today on the Administration's proposed resolution on treaties:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today it will support grower prices of 1953 crop cotton at a national average of at least 30.80 cents a pound, gross weight, for the base grade of middling seven-eighths-inch cotton.
TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 25 -- Unless a compromise with Britain can somehow be arranged Iran may go the way of Mexico on oil nationalization.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26 -- Serious and sometimes fatal reaction to the use of "miracle drugs" demands that these antibiotics should be used with the utmost caution, Dr. Harold A. Shoemaker, Professor of Pharmacology of the University of Oklahoma School of Medicine, today told a conference of the Academy of Forensic Sciences here.
PARIS, Feb. 26 -- Premier Rene Mayer will leave by air tomorrow for North Africa to make a speech from Setif, Algeria, Sunday, that will be broadcast to the nation.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Abba S. Eban, Ambassador of Israel, voiced his confidence today that "American-Israel relations are on a firm foundation."
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were quiet but steady yesterday and active months closed 4 to 13 points higher than on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Granville Hicks, author, scholar and former Communist turned active foe of communism, testified today that Congressional investigating committees were encouraging "an irrational apprehension" among people over infiltration by Reds into the educational system.

BOSTON, Feb. 26 -- Frederic C. Doumaine, president of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, said tonight that a "satisfactory settlement" has been reached in a struggle for control of the road. This was reached, he added, as a result of a series of conferences here, in New York and in Hamilton, Ont., Canada.

ALBANY, Feb. 26 -- The Assembly Judiciary Committee reported out today a Republican bill that would put a major obstacle in the path of political leaders in New York City desiring to nominate a member of another party for a city-wide office.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Feb. 26 (AP) -- The House of Representatives gave the Social Christian Government of Premier Jean Van Houtte a vote of confidence, 107 to 95, today.

About 237,500 Americans will visit the British Isles this year and more than 30,000 will be there at the time of the coronation. This was forecast yesterday by Sir Alexander H. Maxwell, chairman of the British Travel Association, who is visiting the United States on a speaking tour.

A suspended Brooklyn policeman testified yesterday in Kings County Court that he shot Arthur Battle, the father of three children, to protect a fellow policeman who was being threatened with a knife by Mr. Battle.

PARIS, Feb. 26 -- Announcing completion of the draft proposal for a six-nation European constitution, Heinrich von Brentano, chairman of the committee that prepared the plan, said today that it would facilitate ratification of the European Defense Community treaty.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Robert N. Denham, former General Counsel of the National Labor Relations Board, proposed today that Congress abolish the entire agency and set up a new one with different personnel. He will testify tomorrow before the House Education and Labor Committee.

Milenko Filipovic, Yugoslav Minister Plenipotentiary to the United States, accepted yesterday a gift of 5,000 bushels of seed grains from Church World Service, representing twelve interdenominational agencies, as "a substantial and deep contribution to the development of friendly cooperation between peaceful and freedom-loving nations."

PERRYOPOLIS, Pa., Feb. 26 -After three bitterly contested court suits and other difficulties, this poor-little-rich village of 1,700 residents hurdled today the last major obstacle blocking use of the $1,500,000 it inherited in August, 1948.

GROTON, Conn., Feb. 26 -The submarine Haddock rolled gently in the river Thames here today, tied up to a barge, half a world away form the sweep of blue Pacific waters where she seriously wounded the Japanese Imperial Navy ten years ago.

Considerably more price decreases than increases probably will result over the year as a result of the lifting of controls, it was predicted yesterday by advertising spokesmen. There will be rises when controls are lifted, but many factors within the year are expected to force prices down again, it was held.

Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., warned an arbitration panel yesterday not to "tie" the wages of private bus employes to those of city transit workers or "all hell will break loose on the subways."
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 26 -- Pennsylvania's basketball team jumped back into a first-place tie with Columbia in the Eastern Intercollegiate League tonight by beating Princeton, 82 -- 74, at the Palestra.
The bowl-of-soup-and-crust-of-bread children's meal immortalized by Charles Dickens in "Oliver Twist" is revived this week by the Children's Aid Society -- but only for display purposes.

Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, received an unusual vote of confidence from members of the Board of Education yesterday when they voted unanimously to re-elect him to a second sixyear term of office six months before the present term expires.

ALBANY, Feb. 26 -- Of all the school districts in the state, only New York City has reported having any teachers or other educational employes suspected of subversive leanings, the Board of Regents informed the Legislature today in its first report on enforcement of the Feinberg Law.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 26 -Having complied with the traditions of Latin courtesy by refraining from attacking President Juan D. Peron or the Argentine political system during the course of his six-day visit here, the Chilean press opened fire this morning as the general began his homeward journey.

Food shoppers will find excellent buys this week-end in beef, poultry and fresh produce. Such Lenten favorites, however, as eggs and fish remain high with eggs up another couple of cents a dozen and several species of fish marked up a nickel a pound.

The point of significance in the results of the meetings simultaneously held this week in Rome and Athens is that they mark a sharp turn in a tide that appeared to be receding in recent months. It is somehow fitting that these ancient capitals should be the scene of a dramatic revival of the temporarily stalled movement for the unity and defense of the West.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- A good many Republicans had barely begun to try to swallow their disappointment over the failure of the Administration's "secret treaty" resolution to denounce Presidents Roosevelt and Truman for making these compacts, when President Eisenhower did something else to demonstrate that a lot of Republican campaign rhetoric, including contributions of his own, is to be disregarded as ashes of the dead past.

Igor Stravinsky appeared as guest conductor of a program of his own works with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall. He is now a familiar figure with the baton, as well as the composer whose orchestral output is well known to us.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Feb. 26 -- President Eisenhower, on his first journey out of Washington since he became President, flew into Augusta for a three-day stay late today with a single determination: to break 90 on the tough par 72 Augusta National Golf Club course, scene of the famed Masters' Tournament.

The guessing game of what happens next, when and by whom, with regard to the expressed desire of the Internal Revenue Bureau to drop negotiations for the leasing of Grand Central Palace continued apace yesterday while Federal negotiators here prepared to put the matter up to officials in Washingington.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Douglas McKay, Secretary of the Interior, today questioned whether states would have any power to tax oil production seaward of their historic boundaries in the event full Federal dominion on the outer continental shelf is affirmed by Congress.

The skiing prospects for the week-end remain limited. Most of the areas in the far north report fair to good running on terrain surfaced with frozen granular, corn and powder snows, but close to metropolitan New York, the outlook is discouraging.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 26 -The Joint Judiciary Committee of the Connecticut General Assembly voted late today to report favorably a bill that changes the boundary lines of all the thirty-six State Senate districts, a move that Democrats charged would be "gerrymandering."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 26 -James Stewart and UniversalInternational will continue their profit-sharing association through a fifth picture, under terms of a contract signed today. The new project will be "Alder Gulch," based on a magazine story by Ernest Haycox and dealing with the gold rush in the Northwest in 1863. Borden Chase will write the screen play, for filming on location in Oregon and Montana starting in August.

YONKERS, Feb. 26 -- Government immigration officials placed the ailing Mrs. Earl Browder under arrest here today, but not before her Kansas-born husband, the former Communist leader, had scrimmaged with Federal agents to keep them from crossing the threshold of his apartment.

Critics of television got an antagonist yesterday in Cardinal Spellman, Roman Catholic Archbishop of New York. Speaking at a television workshop before 100 Catholic clergymen and educators interested in the medium. Cardinal Spellman declared, "It is true that television has been criticized, but everything is criticized."

Two Connecticut teams, the Farmington and the New Haven polo clubs, gained the final of the annual George C. Sherman Memorial indoor polo tournament last night at the Squadron A Armory. Farmington halted Manhattan, 11 -- 5, while New Haven eliminated Long Island, 12 -- 11.

Fleet leasing as opposed to automobile ownership by large concerns has "more than doubled in the last six months," John W. Rollins, president of Rollins Fleet Leasing Company, Rehoboth Beach, Del., told members of the Exchange Club at their meeting at the McAlpin Hotel today.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 26 (AP) -Commissioner Bert Bell of the National Football League today asked for a chance to live with television, to compete with the TV set people who advertise 50-yard line seats in the living room.

ALBANY, Feb. 26 -- The Court of Appeals ruled today that the Board of Regents had the right to suspend the licenses of two New York City physicians convicted of contempt of Congress for refusing to produce records of the Joint Anti-Fascist Refugee Committee subpoenaed by the House UnAmerican Activities Committee.

Lauro Salas, former lightweight champion of the world, will make the first appearance of his career in a New York ring tonight. The 25-year-old campaigner from Monterey, Mexico, will oppose Pat Marcune of Coney Island in the ten-round feature at Madison Square Garden.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 26 -- It is becoming increasingly clear that Dr. Ludwig Erhard, Minister of Economics, and his associates of the free trade school of economics are determined to employ the growing economic power of West Germany in a crusade to establish economic unity in Western Europe to a degree far surpassing the objectives of the European Coal and Steel Community or any of the proposed organizations for international cooperation.
ORMOND BEACH, Fla., Feb. 26 (AP) -- Mary Riley, 22-year-old newcomer to the Florida winter golf circuit from Bloomington, Ill., upset the upsetter today in the South Atlantic amateur tournament.

In a message delivered yesterday to Lieut. Gov. Frank C. Moore and State Controller J. Raymond McGovern, a united Board of Estimate accused the state of rejecting the city's $218,700,000 fiscal program for 1953-54 because the program failed to include a transit fare rise and a city income or payroll tax.

Expansion through new branch stores continues a marked feature of the retail field. On the heels of a $35,000,000 modernization program for its present stores, Gimbel Brothers plans a series of suburban branch units. Integrated with the stores in New York, Philadelphia, Pittsburgh and Milwaukee will be a suburban branch.

In a continuation of Wednesday's "decontrol market," stock prices opened strong yesterday. However, they lost momentum about noon and ended virtually unchanged on the day. Volume was above 2,000,000 shares on the New York Stock Exchange for the third successive day -- 2,290,000, against 2,360,000 Wednesday.
SPORTSMEN'S SHOW highlights:

MONTREAL, Feb. 26 (UP) -- The Montreal Canadiens silted idle Detroit's lead in the National Hockey League to 4 points tonight as the runners-up smothered the Toronto Maple Leafs, 4 -- 1, before 14,430 fans in the Forum.

The case of Minot Frazier (Mickey) Jelke, 23-year-old oleo-margarine heir charged with procuring and living off the earnings of prostitutes, will go to a blue ribbon all-male jury today in General Sessions Court. Jelke, who has been out on $50,000 ball, spent last night in the city prison by order of the trial judge.

Jersey City, N J., sold $6,278,000 of school and general improvement bonds yesterday due from 1954 to 1988 to a banking syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., at a bid of 100.417 for interest of 3 1/2 per cent. The bonds were reoffered at yields ranging from 1.5 per cent to 3.55 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -The Pasadena lawyer who served as trustee of the controversial Nixon Senatorial expense fund has filed a report showing he handled $25,056.63 in political contributions during Richard M. Nixon's campaign for the Vice Presidency last year.
ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 26 - Turkey and Yugoslavia signed today a trade and payments agreement providing for an exportimport program of $70,000,000.
The trucking committee of the New York Board of Trade protested yesterday against proposed regulations to bar tractor-trailers from midtown and lower Manhattan during business hours.

The world figure skating champion, Hayes Alan Jenkins of Colorado Springs, Colo., in from Europe by air departed almost immediately yesterday for Cleveland to begin training for the North American championships on March 6-7.

MELBOURNE, Feb. 26 (UP) -Trade union opposition to the Olympic Games intensified tonight when the Victorian secretary of the Australian Labor Party, Daniel Lovegrove, told the Trades Hall Council he hoped Melbourne did not stage the 1956 games.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 26 -- The mysterious conviction carried in the soothing arguments of Roy Hamey, assistant to General Manager George M. Weiss, today caused Lefty Ed Lopat to sign one of the few provisional contracts in the Yankees' history.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., Feb. 26 -- The police were investigating tonight the mysterious beating of a 34-year-old woman by an intruder who had broken into her home at 20 Fifth Street here.
PARIS, Feb. 26 -- The French Government took a hand today in a controversy raging over the disappearance of two Jewish war orphans, Robert and Gerald Finaly, whom the police are seeking in Spain.

Francis W. Hirst, a distinguished economist of the old school, who died Feb. 22 at his home in Sussex, may well be called the last of the Liberals. He knew the United States well and had many American friends, among them President Hoover, President Butler of Columbia and President Lowell of Harvard.

ALBANY, Feb. 26 -- A former school custodian who let the air out of the tires on a car belonging to the school board president was cleared today because the District Attorney's office prosecuted under the wrong section of the Penal Law.

A thoroughly unwise and poorly written state law, passed last year at the behest of Governor Dewey and the Republican-controlled Legislature, has arisen to plague television and radio broadcasters and conceivably cut them off from a primary source of news.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- President Eisenhower and a delegation of Congressional leaders, Governors and Federal officials proposed today a sweeping study of Federal-state programs with the aim of decentralizing Federal power and reducing and eliminating costly programs and duplicating taxation.

Distributors of rayon, acetate and silk textiles will press for longer credit terms from mills that are still adhering to terms of thirty days net. The Textile Distributors Institute, an association of textile converters, announced yesterday that mills that have not lengthened their terms would be approached by a committee, which the institute will name, to discuss the subject.
TRENTON, Feb. 26 -- The inquiry by the New Jersey Legislature into the ouster of Nelson F. Stamler as deputy Attorney General will get under way here tomorrow.

A plan to engineer, develop and build complete pulp and paper mill projects -- in Point Four style -- in various area of the world was announced yesterday by Parsons Whittemore, Inc., of this city, supplier of pulp, paper and machinery for the industry.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 26 -Pakistan is eager to explore at once with United States representatives the question of possible inclusion of this large strategic country in the proposed Middle East defense organization. Officials and other leaders interviewed here and in provincial capitals during a week's tour of Western Pakistan, were unanimous in favoring a Middle East bloc, including Pakistan, to contain Communist aggression in this part of the world.

There was no rice market in New York yesterday. Mills withdrew all price lists until they could find out where removal of controls left them, between the uncontrolled prices they have hitherto paid the grower and the O. P. S. ceilings at which they have had to sell.

Norman Palmer's excellent letter from New Delhi contains support for Chester Bowles' administration of United States policy in India. Certainly no one recently in India, as I have been, could possibly quarrel with Dr. Palmer's evaluation of Mr. Bowles' contribution to Indian-American relations.

Cheers and a likely bid to the forthcoming National Invitation Tournament went to little Iona College as Jimmy McDermott's soundly coached Gaels from New Rochelle upset Manhattan, 66 -- 59, last night at Madison Square Garden. This notable triumph before 6,149 fans was followed by a 66-61 victory by St. John's over N. Y. U.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The Bureau of Land Management in the Department of the Interior conducted a land rush by mail order this afternoon, and 134 World War II veterans acquired lots in Alabama, Florida and Wisconsin. There were 8,000 other veterans who had tried and failed.

BELVIDERE, N. J., Feb. 26 -The 3,363 farmers, merchants and housewives of this small Warren County community who signed a petition to keep one of the town's two doctors from going back into the Navy are going to have Dr. John J. McDonald around a little while longer.

NORFOLK, Va., Feb. 26 -- Norfolk's twenty-six-day-old tugboat strike ended tonight, with the union and company officials agreeing on a new contract. The contract calls for wages granted by the Wage Stabilization Board on the 1952 contract, plus double time pay for the six holidays on the old contract, and a grievance clause.

BERLIN, Feb. 26 -- The current purges of non-Communist political parties in East Germany are designed to eliminate passive resistance to the Communist program and are succeeding in that objective, according to a prominent Christian Democratic official who recently fled to West Berlin.

A public relations concern hired by eastern railroads to put out publicity unfavorable to trucking interests made payments to a New Jersey newspaper man for research work and to officials of a New Jersey automobile group, it was testified in Federal Court here yesterday.
